title: Geneva Auto Show: Rolls-Royce 102EX

description: Milan

title: Scorecard | Marni Wins!
description: Envelope, please. Scorecard and all the critics who watched that other catwalk  OK, red carpet  extravanganza in the wee hours of the morning from their hotels in Milan know Dolce & Gabbanas social network-themed show didnt fare too much better in the final tally than Aaron Sorkins. Marnis Consuelo Castiglioni, meanwhile, was roundly praised by fashions academy for her new vision of glamour as something that has nothing to do with flashbulb-friendly sparkle.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,470 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: With Its Eye on China, Japan Builds Up Military
description: NAHA AIR BASE, Japan  This sun-baked airfield was built atop Okinawas rocky coral by Americans during the cold war, but these days its roaring jets proudly display the red sun of Japan.

title: Valentine Familiar With Mets Sale Talk
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The former Mets manager Bobby Valentine, now an announcer for Sunday Night Baseball on ESPN, has many friends and colleagues in high finance. Some of them, he says, have expressed an interest in buying the Mets. He would not divulge which ones or if he might be part of their venture.

title: Keeping Women Safe Through Social Networking
description: EVERY female business traveler I know concedes that she has experienced at least some kind of sexual harassment on the road. Usually its verbal, though sometimes its physical.

title: Bloggingheads: Fox News Republicans
description: Amy Sullivan, left, of Time and Ramesh Ponnuru of National Review debate Fox News and the GOP presidential field.

title: Wave2Wave I.P.O. Faces S.E.C. Scrutiny
description: A little-known Internet service providers quest to raise money in the financial markets has stalled  yet again.

title: Panel Seeking Answers in Fatal Pipeline Blast
description: WASHINGTON  Amid a rash of pipeline accidents, the National Transportation Safety Board will open two and a half days of hearings here Tuesday on a natural gas pipeline explosion Sept. 9 that killed eight people in San Bruno, Calif. The hearings will explore issues that may have far-reaching implications.

title: Jane Russell, Sultry Star of 1940s and 50s, Dies at 89
description: Jane Russell, the voluptuous actress at the center of one of the most highly publicized censorship episodes in movie history, the long-delayed release of the 1940s western The Outlaw, died on Monday at her home in Santa Maria, Calif. She was 89.

title: Mets Owners Hope Courts Will Limit Liability
description: Ever since Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme collapsed, the owners of the Mets have insisted they were unwitting victims who, like thousands of other investors, lost millions of dollars at the hands of a devious swindler.

title: Commercials at the Oscars Play It Safe and Play It Again
description: THE Oscar show on Sunday was predictable, dull, formulaic and repetitive.

title: Dontrelle Willis Tries Again
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  Dusty Baker got a scouting report on Dontrelle Willis from Ray Burris, the former pitcher who coaches in the Detroit Tigers organization. Willis pitched poorly  and expensively  for the Tigers for much of the last three seasons, but Burris saw no reason he should be finished as an effective pitcher.

title: Who Are the Four Candidates to Succeed Warren Buffett?
description: Warren E. Buffett.

title: Redskins Cut Clinton Portis
description: The Jets notified four players  offensive lineman Damien Woody, linebackers Vernon Gholston and Jason Taylor and defensive tackle Kris Jenkins  of their impending release. The moves were first reported by The Daily News, which estimated the Jets will clear more than $10 million from their salary cap in 2011  assuming there is both a salary cap and a 2011 season.

title: Private Spies Aid F.B.I. in Afghan Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  Not long after the Pentagon severed its relationship with a private spy network operating in Afghanistan and Pakistan, the F.B.I. quietly began tapping the same group to help investigate the killing of 10 medical aid workers in northern Afghanistan, according to American officials and private contractors.

title: WeatherBill Raises $42 Million
description: Google Ventures and Khosla Ventures have led a $42 million financing round in WeatherBill, a San Francisco start-up that insures farmers against extreme weather conditions that can cripple crop production.

title: Confession Is Reported in Case of 18-Year Captive
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The lawyer for Nancy Garrido, who is accused of helping her husband kidnap Jaycee Dugard in 1991 and hold her for 18 years, says his client has confessed to her role in the crime, and met with Ms. Dugard privately.

title: With Their Stars in Place, Knicks Adjust to the Rest
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Mike DAntoni does not know whether Anthony Carter and Chauncey Billups blend well in a backcourt. He is not sure if Carter, a veteran point guard, can defend bigger shooting guards. And he is not certain that Carter stayed in shape while planted at the end of Denvers bench most of this season.

title: Weak Ticket Sales Contribute to Large Loss for Live Nation
description: Live Nation Entertainment, the music and ticketing giant created last year by the merger of Ticketmaster and Live Nation, on Monday reported a loss of $228.4 million for 2010 as a result of a weak touring season.

title: For Schools, Free Art Supplies, and Much More
description: Talim Johnson inched along toward the check-out counter, looking over her schools shopping list to make sure she had not missed anything. Construction paper. Colored paper of various thicknesses and textures. File holders. Three-ring binders. Posters to brighten up the hallways.

title: Watson Still Cant Think
description: Many who responded to last weeks column about the relationship (if any) of Watson the computers performance on Jeopardy! to actual human thinking cited recent developments in artificial intelligence research, and wondered what Hubert Dreyfus, professor of philosophy in the graduate school at U.C. Berkeley and author of What Computers Cant Do, would say about this new work. The editors and I have invited him and Sean Dorrance Kelly, professor and chair of the department of philosophy at Harvard University and co-author, with Professor Dreyfus, of All Things Shining: Reading the Western Classics to Find Meaning in a Secular Age, to reply.  Stanley Fish

title: Sheens Lawyer Seeks Payment for the Actor
description: The war of words initiated by Charlie Sheen against his employers at CBS and the Warner Brother television studio turned into a legal confrontation Monday, when a lawyer hired by Mr. Sheen demanded that the actor be paid for lost episodes of his show, Two and a Half Men.

title: Where Freedom of Expression Runs Headlong Into the Impulse to Censor
description: New York, never at a loss for self-congratulatory words, regards itself as the most tolerant of cities, a place where one may express any thought freely. It is true. In New York, one may articulate any idea whatsoever  as long as that idea parallels popular opinion.

title: Seeking Better Team Through a Better Culture
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Kevin Towers joined the Arizona Diamondbacks as their dreary 2010 season lurched to a close. Towers, the new general manager, had spent the season as a superscout for the Yankees, learning the inner workings of a wealthy team and perennial contender. The Diamondbacks are neither.

title: Red Bulls Drop Two Longtime Assistant Coaches
description: The Red Bulls on Monday fired the assistant coaches Richie Williams and Des McAleenan, a surprising move in that it came less than three weeks before the teams season opener.

title: Beyond the Politics of Breast-Feeding
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx-Lebanon Obstetricians Face Malpractice Insurance Cutoff
description: A malpractice insurance group has warned obstetricians at a South Bronx hospital that it is considering cutting off their insurance, which could force surrounding hospitals to absorb hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of baby deliveries a year.

description: Facing a mounting housing shortage, squatters have transformed an abandoned skyscraper in downtown Caracas into a makeshift home for more than 2,500 people.

title: Arkansas Quake Is Its Most Powerful in 35 Years
description: A 4.7-magnitude earthquake that researchers described as the largest in Arkansas in 35 years was recorded late Sunday night near Greenbrier. It was the latest in a swarm of quakes that has bedeviled the region since early last fall.

description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Architects still call the 45-story skyscraper the Tower of David, after David Brillembourg, the brash financier who built it in the 1990s. The helicopter landing pad on its roof remains intact, a reminder of the airborne limousines that were once supposed to drop bankers off for work.

title: When Players Like Duke Snider Were Also Neighbors
description: Florence Cozzolino remembers the man who used to live down the street from her at 178 Marine Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. She and other children from the neighborhood would gather outside his house, waiting for him to return home so they could ask for his autograph.

description: The go shop on Wall Street is quickly becoming a no shop.

description: Sometimes, when the boxer Yuri Foreman looks back at the past nine months, it feels like nine lifetimes.

title: Well-Oiled Security Apparatus in China Stifles Calls for Change
description: BEIJING  The call to action shot across mobile phones and Internet chat sites, urging people to converge on 13 Chinese cities to demand an end to corruption, inflation and the strictures of authoritarian rule. The Chinese people do not have the patience to wait any longer, said one message.

title: The Lone Star State Turns South
description: Texas officially joined the Confederacy on March 1, 1861, and within days it was organizing representatives, resources and troops for the new Southern nation. So far out west, Texas would never be a central theater of the Civil War. Yet from the very beginning it played an unusually outsized role in the conflict.

title: Unintended, but Sound Advice
description: In Lewis Powells now-famous memo to Americas business community, which felt beleaguered in the political environment of 1971, the future Supreme Court justice stressed the importance of organizing.

description: Chris Sacca is known in Silicon Valley for his Western-style button-down shirts and his early investments in start-up companies like Twitter.

title: Citys Lengthy Push for Hybrid-Engine Taxicabs Hits a Legal Dead End
description: The Bloomberg administration has banned cars from parts of Broadway, prohibited smoking in public parks and cracked down on fats and salts in restaurants. But City Halls march toward better living, whether its citizens want it or not, may have finally met a yellow-hued Waterloo.

title: Mystery Deepens on Status of Iran Opposition Leaders
description: CAIRO  The mystery over the whereabouts of the two main Iranian opposition leaders, Mir Hussein Moussavi and Mehdi Karroubi, deepened on Monday with contradictory reports over whether they had been jailed on the eve of a nationwide protest or remained under extreme house arrest, completely cut off from the outside world.

title: Taped Statement Admissible at Police Officers Rape Trial
description: A 27-year-old woman was several minutes into her conversation with a veteran police officer outside his Manhattan station house when the officer made the crucial statement.

title: Behind the Scenes at the Dakota
description: In the past few weeks, a racial discrimination lawsuit filed against the Dakota by one of its former board presidents has opened the gates of privacy at one of the citys most renowned and tight-lipped apartment buildings. Phrases residents may or may not have uttered in board meetings, and decisions they have made about approving residents, have been pored over by lawyers and blogged about by experts in real estate and finance.

title: Mexico: Drug Gang Figure Is Captured
description: Marines have captured a regional commander for the Zetas drug gang, the navy said Monday, in the latest high profile arrest since the Feb. 15 attack that killed an American agent and wounded another. Jos Luis Vergara, a navy spokesman, said the suspect, Sergio Antonio Mora, controlled the Zeta organization in the state of San Luis Potos, where the attack on agents of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement took place. He said that Mr. Mora oversaw Julian Zapata Espinoza, also thought to be a Zeta member who was arrested last week and who, according to the authorities, confessed that he took part in the Feb. 15 ambush.

title: Afghanistan: 6 NATO Members Killed
description: Six NATO service members were killed Monday across Afghanistan in one of the bloodiest days in February for coalition forces, according to a NATO statement. However, casualties this February were lower than last: 37 troops died this February and 53 died in February 2010, according to icasualties.org, which tracks military deaths.

title: Japanese Company in Deal to Improve Its Cancer Drug Pipeline
description: The Daiichi Sankyo Company, the No. 3 drug maker in Japan, agreed to buy Plexxikon Inc. for as much as $935 million, gaining experimental drugs for cancer and arthritis.

title: In Shadow of 1995, G.O.P. Freshmen Stand Firm
description: WASHINGTON  The specter of the 1995 government shutdown hangs over Capitol Hill, a memory many hoped to leave behind, along with beepers and episodes of Baywatch Nights.

title: Tuesday: Heated Exchanges
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  I had the pleasure of meeting C. W. (Carolyn) Stewart at a Women in Crosswords breakfast a couple of years ago at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. The breakfast, which was organized by Amy Reynaldo of Diary of a Crossword Fiend and myself, is fast becoming a tradition at the tournament, and is a way for constructors who possess two X chromosomes to meet and get to know each other.

title: The New Normal
description: Were going to be doing a lot of deficit cutting over the next several years. The countrys future greatness will be shaped by whether we cut wisely or stupidly. So we should probably come up with a few sensible principles to guide us as we cut.

description: STORRS, Conn.

Bloomberg quietly reached out to a handful of the countrys top journalists with an intriguing job offer: Divine and distill his unique brand of political philosophy and disseminate it around the globe for an annual salary of close to $500,000.

title: Necmettin Erbakan, a Turkish Prime Minister, Dies at 84
description: Necmettin Erbakan, the first Islamist prime minister of Turkey, whose attempt to turn his country away from the West led the military to depose him in 1997, died on Sunday in Ankara. He was 84.

description: NEWARK  If he was looking for a big, bold welcome, Deron Williams got it Monday night, from a familiar image gracing a downtown facade, in a city he hardly knew.

title: A Right Without a Remedy
description: In a landmark case three years ago, the Supreme Court ruled that detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, who are not American citizens have the constitutional privilege of habeas corpus. It gives them the right to have a federal judge decide promptly whether their detention is illegal and, if so, order their release because the United States controls the place they are held. The 5-to-4 decision in what is known as the Boumediene case was a repudiation of the Bush strategy of imprisoning the detainees outside American territory so the Constitution would not apply. Or so many thought.

title: Qaddafis Crimes and Fantasies
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya is deep into a fantasy world. In an interview with ABC News, he insisted that his people love me, blamed the courageous uprising against his rule on terrorists and refused to take responsibility for his many crimes.

description: One can scarcely imagine the pain borne into St. Marys Pro-Cathedral in Dublin last month at a prayer service  A Liturgy of Lament and Repentance  offered for the victims of sexually abusive priests.

description: Democracy is particularly messy for the workers responsible for cleaning the Wisconsin statehouse each day.

description: We love watching our fellow New Yorkers, and we are particularly devoted to watching the many creative ways they hail taxis. The taxi-seeker edges out into the street. And as the arm goes up, he or she is not merely signaling a taxi but also betraying a need in public  something New Yorkers dislike doing.

description: In Benghazi, speaking out against Qaddafi comes at a cost.

title: Dr. Richard F. Daines, Former State Health Chief, Dies at 60
description: Dr. Richard F. Daines, a former New York state health commissioner who espoused politically risky public health initiatives like closing hospitals and banning the use of food stamps to buy soda, died on Saturday at his family farm in Stanfordville, N.Y., in Dutchess County. He was 60.

title: Natalie Portman Condemns Galliano
description: The actress Natalie Portman, who has an endorsement contract with Dior for its Miss Dior Cherie fragrance, has strongly condemned its chief designer, John Galliano, for anti-Semitic remarks after a video surfaced of Mr. Galliano appearing to deliver a tirade in a Paris bar. In a separate incident, he was accused of verbally abusing a French couple last week in the bar. He was suspended Friday from Dior.

title: In a Marine Worms Eyes, the Theory of Evolution
description: Charles Darwin considered the evolution of the human eye one of the toughest problems his theory had to explain. In On the Origin of Species, he wrote that the idea that natural selection could produce such an intricate organ seems, I freely confess, absurd in the highest possible degree.

title: In U.S.-Libya Nuclear Deal, a Qaddafi Threat Faded Away
description: WASHINGTON  In late 2009, the Obama administration was leaning on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his son Seif to allow the removal from Libya of the remnants of the countrys nuclear weapons program: casks of highly enriched uranium.

title: Suze Rotolo, a Face, With Bob Dylan, of 60s Music, Is Dead at 67
description: Suze Rotolo, who became widely known for her romance with Bob Dylan in the early 1960s, strongly influenced his early songwriting and, in one of the decades signature images, walked with him arm-in-arm for the cover photo of his breakthrough album, The Freewheelin Bob Dylan, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 67.

title: Gary Winick, Director of Small and Studio Films, Dies at 49
description: Gary Winick, a producer and director of independent films who later graduated to big-budget studio work, including directing an adaptation of E.B. Whites childrens classic, Charlottes Web, died on Sunday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 49.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Rev. Peter J. Gomes Is Dead at 68; A Leading Voice Against Intolerance
description: The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, a Harvard minister, theologian and author who announced that he was gay a generation ago and became one of Americas most prominent spiritual voices against intolerance, died on Monday in Boston. He was 68.

title: Libyan Rebels Said to Debate Seeking U.N. Airstrikes
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  In a sign of mounting frustration among rebel leaders over Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis diminished but unyielding grip on power, rebel leaders here are debating whether to ask for Western airstrikes under the United Nations banner, according to four people with knowledge of the deliberations.

title: Tumult Around the Region
description: LIBYA Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces struck back against the rebels on three fronts with special forces, regular army troops and, rebels said, airstrikes, escalating the conflict with attacks on an oil refinery and cities on either side of the country. Almost 100,000 people have fled to Egypt and Tunisia, the United Nations refugee agency said.

Though, as the article points out, she is depressingly impressive, everyone has talents he or she hasnt yet had the ability or drive to bring out. What do you think yours might be? Why? How do you think you could develop them?

title: Finding a Place in Bahraini Society
description: For her Measure of a Woman project, Hazel Thompson spent six months in 2007 and 2008 in Bahrain and Qatar, documenting womens roles in modern Arab culture. James Estrin interviewed her in New York last week about her experiences in Bahrain. Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

title: India Sentences 11 to Die for Fatal Train Fire
description: NEW DELHI  An Indian court sentenced 11 people to death on Tuesday for the burning of a passenger train in 2002 that killed 59 Hindu pilgrims and set off bloody communal riots that swept across the state of Gujarat. Twenty other defendants received life sentences.

Mauer, 27, sees those same developmental questions facing the Yankees top catching prospect, Jesus Montero, who is 6-4, 225 pounds.

title: Americans Dont Hate Unions
description: The new poll reported in this mornings Times will, I suspect, come as a shock to many political commentators. Quite a few news analyses of the assault on public-sector workers have simply assumed that the move was a political winner, with little if any thought given to the possibility that the general public wasnt actually ready to go along. But whaddya know: while people dont necessarily love unions  hey, I personally dont necessarily love unions  most people apparently see them as having a legitimate role.

title: Tuesday Reading: The 5-Second, Dropped-Food Rule
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: March 1: Updates on Libyas Revolt and Mideast Protests
description: On Tuesday, The Lede is supplementing coverage of the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East by our colleagues in the region. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. Readers can also follow some of the discussion of the region on Twitter in this blogs right column.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Red Shoes
description: In light of Natalie Portmans Oscar win this week for her role as an obsessive ballerina in Black Swan, A. O. Scott looks back at The Red Shoes, one of the definitive dance films about an artist who sacrifices herself for her art. The 1948 film, directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, is a wonderful depiction of an artist at work and a fascinating examination of the obsessive drive to create art, Mr. Scott says. But what makes it great is how completely it surrenders itself to that obsession.

title: Goldmans Legal Bill Could Hit $3.4 Billion
description: Goldman Sachs estimates its legal wrangles could reasonably cost the firm $3.4 billion, according to a regulatory filing released Tuesday.

title: On Quiet Deadline Day, Capitals and Kings Make Boldest Moves
description: The N.H.L. trade deadline is certainly not what it used to be. Many general managers have begun to see the wisdom of making deals when theyre not under the gun of filing paperwork by 3:00 pm. After 31 trades were made at the deadline a year ago, only 16 were finalized on Monday.

title: Concern Over Energy Sends Indexes Lower
description: The major indexes slid on Tuesday, sending the Standard & Poors 500-stock index to its first decline in three days, as concern that rising energy costs will hurt the economic recovery overshadowed the fastest manufacturing growth since 2004.

title: Blackstone Pays Up for Top Lawyer
description: We all know that the top deal makers at the Blackstone Group  led by its chief executive, Stephen A. Schwarzman  are among the most well-paid executives on Wall Street. But what about its top lawyer?

title: For Michelin Customers, the Company Picks Up the Tow Bill
description: 2:13 p.m. | Updated

title: The Paranoid Style
description: Wow. Via Jon Chait, a vision of how the good people at National Review think:

title: Maya Axes, and Moles Under the Pyramid
description: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal.

title: Morgan Stanley Completes Spinoff of FrontPoint
description: 8:24 p.m. | Updated

title: New Dancing With the Stars Competitors Are Revealed
description: ABC took a break on Monday night from providing a 24-hour platform for Charlie Sheen so it could briefly address the more pressing business of unveiling the next cast of contenders for Dancing With the Stars. The roster of semi- and never-were-celebs for the 12th season of that popular reality competition may not include anyone as instantly fascinating as, say, Bristol Palin, who danced her way to a third-place finish on the show last fall, and producers were apparently unsuccessful in casting their spell over Christine ODonnell, the Republican senatorial candidate from Delaware, to take part in the new cycle.

title: A Home for Captured Carbon Dioxide
description: FutureGen, the Energy Departments on-again, off-again pilot project for capturing and sequestering carbon dioxide from coal-fired power plants, has chosen a place to put this greenhouse gas: in Morgan County, Ill., about 32 miles from a power plant in Meredosia, Ill., that was chosen for the project.

title: Chinese Move to Stop Reporting on Protests
description: BEIJING  In the days since plainclothes security agents harassed and assaulted several foreign journalists on Sunday, the Chinese police have moved to prevent reporters and photographers from covering any potential public protests by establishing no reporting zones in Shanghai and Beijing.

title: Treasury to Cut Its Stake in Ally Financial
description: The Treasury Department announced plans on Tuesday to begin unwinding its stake in Ally Financial, the former lending arm of General Motors, which received a substantial taxpayer bailout during the financial crisis.

title: Optimism and Caution In Bernanke Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  Oil prices are rising. Housing prices are falling. But the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, told Congress on Tuesday that neither issue was likely to derail renewed growth.

title: Breaking Down the Capitals Moves
description: The N.H.L. trade deadline day was relatively quiet. But one team was hard at work: the Washington Capitals. Striving to turn around a rocky season and strengthen their hand for the playoffs, the Caps made the biggest moves of the day, acquiring Jason Arnott from the Devils and Dennis Wideman from the Florida Panthers.

title: J. Crew Shareholders Approve $3 Billion Buyout
description: 7:25 p.m. | Updated

title: Risking Jail Time, Trainer Again Vows He Wont Testify Against Bonds
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Greg Anderson, the personal trainer who has long stuck by his childhood friend Barry Bonds, indicated to a federal judge yet again Tuesday that he would not testify in Bondss perjury trial.

title: Wheels on the Floor at the Geneva Auto Show
description: Automakers have already put a considerable dent in the 170 product debuts expected at the Geneva auto show, which opened Tuesday to the press. A Wheels correspondent, Jerry Garrett, is on the convention floor and will file news and photos throughout the day. You can check back regularly for the latest.

title: John Galliano Fired From Dior
description: In news that will surprise absolutely no one, Christian Dior has begun proceedings to terminate John Gallianos employment in the wake of two race-tinged scandals that have emerged in the past week.

title: Republicans Hit Kaine Ahead of Senate Decision
description: 12:43 p.m. | Updated Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is no stranger to tough ads. His Republican opponent for governor of Virginia in 2005 once alleged Mr. Kaine would defend Hitler from murder charges (see below).

title: Lancia Thema: The Chrysler 300 Studies Abroad
description: GENEVA  Why is the Chrysler 300 wearing a Lancia Thema badge? Because in Europe, Chrysler products are the new Lancias, irrespective of any heritage disconnect.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Crossroads Sets $120 Million Goal to Defeat Obama
description: Karl Rove, the former senior adviser to President George Bush, has a new goal for 2012: raise $120 million to help defeat President Obama and the Democrats.

title: Albany, 9:38 A.M.
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch arrived at the Capitol, documentary film crew in tow, to press his campaign to reshape the redistricting process.

title: Dior Dismisses Galliano
description: Christian Dior said today it has dismissed the designer John Galliano, citing anti-Semitic remarks made by Mr. Galliano in a Paris bar that were recorded on a video.

title: Ohio Lawmakers Battle Over Union Bargaining Rights
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Republican state senators unveiled a new version of a bill governing public employee unions on Tuesday, saying it would preserve their right to collective bargaining, but Democratic lawmakers said the revisions failed to alter the essence of the bill, and in some cases made it even worse.

title: Saab PhoeniX Showcases Rescued Brands Hybrid Ambitions
description: GENEVA  The PhoeniX is what Saab calls an aeromotional design, and one that can potentially inspire futureSaab models. We did it to show we could, to show that we are here to stay, said Victor Muller, Saabs chief executive, in an interview. The concepts name is meant to show that Saab is, at last, rising from the ashes of its star-crossed relationship with General Motors, which ended early last year when Spyker bought the orphaned Swedish automaker.

title: Brashear on Hockey, Fighting and His Lost Rangers Season
description: That clip above is of Donald Brashear going nuts in Trois-Rivires, Quebec, last Friday night. He attacked two opponents  three, if you count the one gloved punch he threw at a forward who just happened to be standing there  in the semipro Ligue Nord-Amricaine de Hockey. (Full Times article on the Slap Shot-like league at this link.) It was only the second fight Brashear has had this season in the mayhem-filled L.N.A.H.  he had 278 in 16 seasons in the N.H.L.  but it was a doozy. The account of the game from Steve Turcotte of Le Nouvelliste describes the fight and the postgame reaction of Brashear and both coaches; if you cant read it in French, run it through Googles translator tool.

title: Car Sales Jumped in February, but Here Come Gas Prices Again
description: DETROIT  Sales of new vehicles in the United States increased 27 percent in February, automakers said Tuesday, even as violence in the Middle East and a surge in gasoline prices threatened to slow the industrys postrecession recovery.

title: After Recount, Sad Ending for Gnomeo & Juliet
description: In the end, the garden gnomes lost by a blade of grass. Final ticket grosses for the weekend box office showed that Gnomeo & Juliet, an animated release from Walt Disney Studios, actually sold $13.4 million in tickets and not the $14.2 million estimated on Sunday. That smaller total dropped the picture to second place in the weekend derby, behind the comedy Hall Pass, which had a final tally of $13.5 million.

title: Motherlode 101
description: Last week, during the discussion of parenting blogs, a reader, Kari (from Boulder), asked some questions about THIS blog.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: As Longhorns Swoon, Coach Faces More Questions
description: AUSTIN, Tex. Texas Coach Rick Barnes likes to perform magic tricks in home visits with recruits, pulling handkerchiefs from his sleeve to put family members at ease and showcase his homespun charm.

title: Did P.S. 22 Singers Ruin Oscars?
description: Whats not to love about a chorus of adorable Staten Island schoolchildren rounding out the Oscars with a rousing rendition of Over the Rainbow?

title: Trends | The Pleated Skirt
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#197", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Thinking the Unthinkable Again in a Nuclear Age
description: In his previous books the journalist Ron Rosenbaum has tackled big topics  Hitlers evil, Shakespeares genius  with acuity and irreverence, believing, correctly, that some things are too important to leave to the experts. Hes proud of his gonzo amateur status, so much so that you half suspect he has a scarlet A tattooed across his chest, where Superman wore his S.

title: Profile in Style: Jenn Lombardo
description: The fashion impresaria Jenn Lombardo muses on the essence of personal style.

title: Harry Connick Jr. to Star in Broadways Reincarnated On a Clear Day
description: Heres a stage revival we didnt expect to see in this or any other lifetime: Harry Connick Jr. will star in Michael Mayers Broadway-bound reinvention of On a Clear Day You Can See Forever, one that puts a gender-bending twist on that classic musical by Burton Lane and Alan Jay Lerner.

title: Frank Rich to Leave The Times for New York Magazine
description: Frank Rich, who over the course of a three-decade career at The New York Times was a theater critic, magazine essayist and Sunday Op-Ed columnist, is leaving the paper to join New York magazine.

title: Trade Deadline: Winners, Losers and Wade Redden
description: Trade deadline day has come and gone, with a busy month of deals capped off by a relatively slow day Monday. With more than 40 trades in February, only time will tell which teams made wise moves.

title: An N.H.L. Deadline Without a Headline
description: That ennui you might feel in the air today has wafted down from Canada. Monday, you see, was supposed to create fireworks in their favorite game. The N.H.L. trade deadline is all but declared a national holiday, celebrated with live blogs and breathless live updates on Canadian television. Teams are supposed to swap superstars like crazy, shifting the leagues landscape like tectonic plates. Hey, the N.B.A. went a little nuts at its deadline. Why cant Canada join the fun?

title: Leon Black: Market Is Hot, Not Overheated
description: BERLIN  Private equity has reason to be optimistic. Deal-making continues to be strong, and the market for initial public offerings is experiencing a modest revival.

title: A Roundup of F1 Business Deals
description: As we approach the first race of the season, there has been a string of announcements of new sponsorships, shifts in ownership and partnerships. I suspect much of the news was supposed to break just before the Bahrain Grand Prix, which was to have run on March 13, with testing to have started on Wednesday.

title: A Roundup of F1 Business Deals
description: As we approach the first race of the season, there has been a string of announcements of new sponsorships, shifts in ownership and partnerships. I suspect much of the news was supposed to break just before the Bahrain Grand Prix, which was to have run on March 13, with testing to have started on Wednesday.

title: How to Lose a Country Gracefully
description: As a reporter, I covered two of the greatest losers of the last century. The superlative greatest applies both to the scale of the loss  Mikhail Gorbachev lost Russia and all of its colonies, F. W. de Klerk lost the richest country in Africa  and to the manner in which they lost it.

title: Dagny Taggart Wept
description: Oh, boy  this George Will column (via Grist) is truly bizarre:

title: A London University Wrestles With a Qaddafi Gift
description: LONDON  The London School of Economics will divert a donation of $488,000 it received from the Gaddafi International Charity and Development Foundation to establish a scholarship fund for North African students, the university announced Tuesday.

title: 2010 Pogie Awards
description: David Pogue's favorite innovations for 2010.

title: ReTweet | Changes at Louis Vuitton Mens Wear
description: According to the press release issued this morning, Helbers takes back his freedom in order to realize new projects. Excuse me, while I go use the euphemism.

title: A Look Back at Jane Russell
description: Images from Jane Russells films and career.

title: Sheep Flock to Times Square
description: Joining the art carnival that descends on New York City during the annual Armory Show, the huge contemporary art fair that opens on Thursday, Times Square is transforming itself into a whimsical sculpture garden.

title: Ex-Goldman Director Accused of Passing Illegal Tips
description: Rajat Gupta

title: The Broccoli Argument
description: A thin end of the wedge theory that a government which could require the purchase of health insurance could also demand everyone buy broccoli.

title: Video Extra | Jenn Lombardo
description: Jenn Lombardo, the subject of our recent Profile in Style, is the branding genius behind Terminal Presents, which oversees Fashion Weeks M.A.C. & Milk events hub. In this exclusive video, she explains her fierce personal style, which mixes cutting-edge designers with semi-destroyed garage-sale and flea-market finds.

title: Documents: Politics, Recycling and Tracking of Natural Gas Waste
description: Review documents obtained by The Times through open records requests and by visiting various regional offices that oversee drilling in Pennsylvania.

title: Mets Closer Scratched After Trip to New York
description: 11:21 p.m. | Updated PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez was scratched from a scheduled appearance against the Washington Nationals on Tuesday after a brief trip to New York.

title: A Lesson in Tolerance in 2 Minutes 44 Seconds
description: Updated, March 4 | When two Chinese students were attacked with baseball bats outside Flushing International High School in November by a group of Latino students and nonstudents, the episode shattered the fragile idyll of a school community already grappling with the twin challenges of teenage and immigrant angst.

title: A (Very) Pregnant Bride
description: Yes, the world is changing, and families are being redefined, and its been a long time since most of us have used the term out of wedlock with any real sense of outrage. Still, Laurie Dents first thought when learning she was pregnant seven months before her wedding was What will people think?

title: Where and Know  Two Poems
description: These are two poems by Amalie Flynn, from her blog Wife and War. On the site she writes: Amalie Flynn is a wife. Her husband went to war. This is her writing. That much is true. These are her words. Some are fiction. Others are nonfiction.

title: Notes From a Young American in Congo: Sex Workers
description: I find it interesting that in possibly the most prominent place of sexual violence in the world, Ive overlooked sex workers. Maybe at first, I thought it was actually a profession; a choice. However, after speaking with a group of sex workers, Ive realized its not a job, its a desperate last resort.

title: 2011 Geneva Auto Show
description: The 2011 International Motor Show in Geneva is packed with flashy new vehicles.

title: Life After Dancing: A Book From Bristol Palin
description: The rumors were true: Bristol Palin is writing a book. Not Afraid of Life will be released this summer by HarperCollins, the publisher of Sarah Palins books, Going Rogue and America By Heart. Bristol Palins book will be an inside look at her life, her world, and the things that matter most, including her family and the faith that keeps her centered, the publisher said in a statement on Tuesday.

title: Jeter Tries to Fix Timing in New Hitting Approach
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With rain gently falling on Steinbrenner Field on Tuesday morning, Derek Jeter and the Yankees hitting coach, Kevin Long, stepped into the indoor batting cage about 20 minutes before the scheduled 10 a.m. workout for players not making the trip to Bradenton.

title: Q&A: An Easy Side Trip from Warsaw?
description: I am a Canadian, and my Polish fianc and I have decided to get married in Warsaw, where a majority of his family lives. After Warsaw, we would like to go to at least one other city by train, either in Poland or a neighboring country. Do you have any suggestions for a (not too ambitious) itinerary?

title: Greylock Expands Fund to $1 Billion
description: The venture capital firm Greylock Partners announced Tuesday that it had expanded its main fund, Greylock XIII, to $1 billion, from $575 million.

title: Phone Calls via the Internet
description: The Times's technology columnist sorts through the various options for using the Internet to make phone calls.

title: The East Anglia Climate Snatch  Not (Yet) a Crime
description: David Roberts at Grist has posted a deconstruct of the machinations of professional climate deniers, the failures of the press and the staining of climate scientists reputations in the wake of Climategate. Theres plenty worth exploring in his analysis, but one specific point needs to be rebutted right off the bat  his contention that the media, including yours truly, were wrong not to call a crime a crime.

title: Fill-In | Marriage at McDonalds
Home Grown | Ryan Roche
description: Ryan Roche lives in stone farmhouse in upstate New York. She is married with three children. She has chickens, goats and a vegetable patch. For the past nine years she has designed a childrens line called Mor Mor Rita, whose biggest fan may be her friend Maggie Gyllenhaal. (When she and her husband, Peter Sarsgaard, got married, their daughter Ramona wore a dress by Roche.) She has so much style and her finger on a particular elegance you dont see anywhere else, Gyllenhaal says. I kept thinking to myself, I wish she could do this for adults.

title: Issa Fires Staff Member Who Shared E-mails With Times Reporter
description: Representative Darrell Issa, Republican of California, has dismissed his chief spokesman, Kurt Bardella, after concluding that Mr. Bardella had secretly and regularly shared his e-mail conversations with a New York Times reporter who is writing a book about Washingtons political culture.

title: Protecting the Lion From U.S. Predators
description: Lions are an African species  perhaps the most venerated African species of all. But such is the nature of the global economy and the interconnectedness of the planet that to save the King of the Beasts in its natural home, advocates say it must be listed as endangered in the United States.

title: Even a Weakened Qaddafi May Be Hard to Dislodge
description: PARIS  The regime of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has been badly undermined, but he retains enough support among critical tribes and institutions, including parts of the army and the air force, that he might be able to retain power in the capital, Tripoli, for some time to come, say experts on Libya and its military.

title: Jeb Bush to Appear with Obama on Education Trip
description: 1:58 p.m. | Updated Well, that didnt last. The White House just issued a correction regarding Jeb Bush and President Obama:

title: Savory Cornbread Muffins With Jalapeos and Corn
description: Cornbread bakes nicely in a muffin tin. Ive added corn, chilies and cheese to this cornbread. With soup and a salad, it makes a great lunchtime muffin.

title: Hello Again, Norma Jeane
description: So bottomless and vast is our presumed hunger for every iota of information pertaining to Marilyn Monroe that MM  Personal (Abrams), a volume of ephemera edited by Lois Banner, with photographs by Mark Anderson, opens with a full-page color picture of the two file cabinets  one tan, one gray  in which the books contents were housed for more than 40 years. The gray ones third drawer has been replaced with a combination safe  the tantalizing repository of a sex goddesss most closely guarded secrets.

title: Doing Good in a Bad Economy
description: He was the valedictorian of his class and an aspiring graphic designer. But like many recent graduates, John Hanawalt needed to adjust to searching for work during the financial crisis.

title: More College Graduates Take Public Service Jobs
description: If Alison Sadock had finished college before the financial crisis, she probably would have done something corporate. Maybe a job in retail, or finance, or brand management at a big company  the kind of work her oldest sister, who graduated in the economically effervescent year of 2005, does at PepsiCo.

title: Life Beyond TARP: Barofsky to Teach at N.Y.U.
description: Neil M. Barofsky, the chief watchdog of the governments $700 billion Troubled Asset Relief Program, will soon be joining New York University School of Law as a senior fellow.

title: Detroit Symphony Musicians Offer Binding Arbitration
description: Backing away from an earlier assertion by their spokesman, the musicians of the striking Detroit Symphony Orchestra said on Tuesday that they in fact would not be going back to work and were only offering to undergo binding arbitration.

title: Picking Winners and Losers in the S.B.A. Budget
description: Small Business Administration officials often describe their mission as providing access to the three Cs  credit, counseling and contracts with the federal government. In The Agendas first report on the Obama administrations proposed 2012 budget for the S.B.A., which seeks $818 million for small-business efforts, we noted that the agency planned to either limit its ability to make loans or to make fewer loans, depending on the program. Today, we turn to counseling.

title: Ford Ranger Wildtrak: Built Ford Tough, but Not Tough Enough for U.S.
description: GENEVA  The Ford Ranger Wildtrak is just the type of smaller pickup that truck-loving Americans would go crazy for. Why, then, would it be introduced here rather than somewhere perhaps more market-appropriate, like during the Detroit auto show in January or the Chicago auto show last month?

title: What to Buy New vs. Used
description: In a recent Bucks post, The Craigslist Gym, Matthew Thibeault of Urbana, Ill., created a home gym by buying used gym equipment with the help of Craigslist. Mr. Thibeault, however, recommended against buying certain home gym items used  floor pads and exercise balls among them  because of hygiene issues.

title: Report Says Assange Cited Jewish Conspiracy
description: LONDON  A report published by a British magazine on Tuesday said the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, suggested that British journalists, including the editor of The Guardian, were engaged in a Jewish-led conspiracy to smear his organization.

title: Wastewater Recycling No Cure-All in Gas Process
description: As drilling for natural gas started to climb sharply about 10 years ago, energy companies faced mounting criticism over an extraction process that involves pumping millions of gallons of water into the ground for each well and can leave significant amounts of hazardous contaminants in the water that comes back to the surface.

title: Nelly Furtado Says Shell Give Qaddafi Money Away
description: The Canadian pop singer Nelly Furtado has decided to donate the $1 million she was paid for a concert she performed for members of the family of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, four years ago. On Monday she announced via Twitter: In 2007, I received 1 million$ from the Qaddafi clan to perform a 45 min. show for guests at a hotel in Italy. I am going to donate the $. She offered no details on her plans to donate the money.

title: Underground Figures and Overachievers
description: Februarys designation as Black History Month remains controversial (Why confined to a single month? Why the shortest month?), but the release of books highlighting African American history and themes is now a predictable part of the publishing and school curriculum calendars. And while they differ wildly in tone, consider two books: Giant Steps to Change the World, confident and inspirational; Underground, mournful and stark. Both seek to convey a sense of much trammeled, Obama-style hope.

title: The Top Places to Study Video Game Design  For Credit
description: Are you a high school student who dreams of inventing the next Wii or Kinect sensation, or the next Call of Duty?

title: Orlando Still a Big Factor Despite Shift in the East
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The joke since last weeks blockbuster trade is that the Knicks did well to land Carmelo Anthony in the Chauncey Billups trade. There is some truth to it. Billups is living up to his nickname of Mr. Big Shot and dispelling the notion that the Knicks gained only one redeemable player in the deal.

title: Motion Picture Industry Group Names Ex-Senator Dodd as Its New Chief
description: LOS ANGELES  Christopher J. Dodd, the former Democratic senator of Connecticut, was named as Hollywoods top lobbyist on Tuesday, a move that might initially prove tricky because of lobbying restrictions for former members of Congress.

title: Manager Accused of Putting $12 Million in Side Pockets
description: 8:30 p.m. | Updated

title: Christian Dior Fires John Galliano
description: Suzy Menkes reports from Paris on the firing of Christian Dior designer John Galliano following reports that he made anti-Semitic remarks at a bar.

title: Carlyle Names Co-Head of Its U.S. Buyout Team
description: The Carlyle Group announced two senior executive promotions on Tuesday within its huge private equity operations, including naming Peter J. Clare as co-head of its United States buyout group.

title: Ferrari FF, Aston Martin Virage and McLaren MP4-12C Rekindle Horsepower Wars at Geneva
description: GENEVA  Electric vehicles and fuel-sipping city cars may be the politically correct transportation solutions of the future, but the old-fashioned, fuel-guzzling, about 200 miles an hour supercar still lives.

title: A New Breed of Markets
description: A proposed merger of stock markets illustrates how electronic exchanges and demand for international services are pushing market operators to gain scale.

title: Scenes From the Governors Ball
description: Academy Award winners, nominees and other Hollywood celebrities mingled at the Governors Ball after the award ceremony Sunday night.

title: A New Breed of Markets
description: When the operators of the New York and Frankfurt stock exchanges announced a merger last month, it was the latest example of consolidation among the worlds financial markets. If the NYSE Euronext-Deutsche Brse deal goes through, it will create a trans-Atlantic powerhouse that offers trading in stocks, options and derivatives.

title: Islanders Goalie Makes Most of Fresh Start
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders look as if they will not make the playoffs this season, and Al Montoya does not know if they would be interested in signing him to a contract after the season. But he is their goaltender for now, and that seems to be the only thing that matters.

title: Remembering Triangle Fires Jewish Victims
description: The inferno that killed 146 workers at the Triangle shirtwaist company 100 years ago occurred on March 25, but because 102 of the victims were Jewish, a date that is as significant is the 25th of Adar in the Hebrew calendar. That anniversary  their yahrzeit  occurred Tuesday.

title: Behind the Cover | Salma Hayek
description: A number of people have commented on the cover image of Salma Hayek on our spring womens fashion issue. The cover story was a piece that, as the reporter Gaby Wood mentions in her opening paragraph, took as its starting point some iconic 60s and 70s images from the history of fashion. The cover portrait of Hayek was inspired by an image taken by the fashion photographer Melvin Sokolsky. It has been brought to our attention that the contemporary artist Josephine Meckseper produced a similar image in 2003. The photographer and Ts editors were unaware of that work.

title: At Geneva, an Upbeat but Uncertain Mood
description: GENEVA  The mood among carmakers at the Geneva auto show this year might be described as nervously confident. Yes, sales around the world are up, emerging markets are booming, and the car companies are introducing fleets of new models. Heck, even General Motors is profitable again.

title: Utility Expert Blames Faulty Weld in California Pipeline Explosion That Killed 8
description: WASHINGTON  A Pacific Gas and Electric pipeline expert said Tuesday that the rupture of a gas pipeline last Sept. 9 in San Bruno, Calif., was caused by a welding error in a pipeline factory, possibly made as long ago as 1948.

title: An Oscars for the People
description: LOS ANGELES  Now that the full ratings are out, its hard to find a glimmer of good news in the Oscars telecast. Despite a direct demographic appeal, the show lost viewers aged 18-49, as Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply report.

title: What Will the iPad 2 Look Like?
description: Were just hours away from the start of Apples presentation on Wednesdayat the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco, at which the company is expected to announce the iPad 2.

title: Huckabee Questions Obama Birth Certificate
description: 6:31 p.m. | Updated

title: T Exclusive Interview | Walter Pfeiffer
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#799", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: White House Issues Report on Women in America
description: Women have higher graduation rates than men at all academic levels and by 2019 they are projected to account for 60 percent of all American undergraduates. In 2009, they accounted for more than half of all people employed in management and professional occupations.

title: Photo Replay: March 1
description: A view of the day in sports, which included some up-close shots and a steep walk downhill.

title: Skype Opens a Conference Call Service
description: Skype is hoping to play a more important role in business meetings.

title: PDT
description: Public Display of Technology.

title: Bono Swings In To Help Decide Whether Spider-Man Is Ready To Fly
description: Bono has returned to New York City to attend Tuesday nights performance of Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark and then share with his fellow creators and producers whether he thinks the Broadway musical is ready to open on March 15, or they should spend more time on the script, music, and other elements of the production, according to several people who work on the $65-million-and-counting show.

title: Using The New York Times for Teaching and Learning About Women
description: March brings the annual celebration of Womens History Month, as well as the 100th anniversary of International Womens Day on March 8.

title: Rallies in Oman Steer Clear of Criticism of Its Leader
description: MUSCAT, Oman  Thousands of demonstrators spent Tuesday marching down the manicured streets of this modern seaside capital by day and speeding around in caravans of honking cars by night.

title: TimesCast | March 1, 2011
description: Libyan rebels appear to have control of Zawiyah; Christian Dior fires its chief designer; and Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin presents his budget.

title: Utah Activist Goes on Trial for Disrupting Oil Auction
description: In the waning days of the Bush administration, Tim DeChristopher, a University of Utah economics major and former wilderness guide, bid on and won nearly $1.8 million worth of federal oil and gas leases before confessing to federal agents that he had no intention of or ability to pay for them.

title: Marcus Thornton and a Possible Clash of Kings
description: The Sacramento Kings are one of the N.B.A.s worst offensive teams, but on Monday night they received a much-needed scoring boost from their newest addition. Marcus Thornton might have had trouble securing regular playing time as a member of the New Orleans Hornets, but so far the minutes and shot attempts have been there for him in Sacramento.

title: Facebook Acquires Beluga, a Group Messaging Service
description: Facebook on Tuesday acquired Beluga, a group messaging start-up for mobile phones.

title: Fishtag
description: WHAT a strange and frustrating if occasionally marvelous restaurant is Fishtag, Michael Psilakiss new venture on West 79th Street, across the street from the Dublin House.

title: Reviewing Fishtag
Hot Plates | Sustain in Miami
description: I arrived at Sustain, a two-month-old Miami restaurant, clutching my favorite dinner date: low expectations.After all, Sustains chef, Alejandro Pinero, works almost exclusively with ingredients produced within a 50-mile radius.A 50-mile radius of Miami?Sounds like a punch line, even to someone who has written about South Florida agriculture. But the low expectations didnt last long. Pinero trained under Michelle Bernstein (of Michys) and worked at Casa Tua, the haute Italian pit stop in Miami Beach, and he hasnt let his ideals cloud his judgment about what it takes to make a restaurant soar.

title: Similar Tradition, but Translation Required
description: In its Manifest Legacy festival the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is hoping to show that Brahms inherited Beethovens artistic spirit. The society never quite defines that nebulous concept, but it was apparently no picnic, judging from comments in a program note by David Finckel and Wu Han, the organizations artistic directors. They tell us, with the reductionism of hindsight, that this inheritance was a burdensome responsibility imposed on Brahms by the musical intelligentsia of his day.

title: Why Comparisons of Walker and Christie Dont Hold Up
description: My profile of Chris Christie, New Jerseys combative Republican governor, on the cover of the Times Magazine this past Sunday generated a lot of discussion. In particular, a lot of commentators seem to be pairing Mr. Christie with Wisconsins Republican governor, Scott Walker, who has become a national figure in his drive to curb collective bargaining for state employees.

title: Expert Finds Defendants Assisted-Suicide Account Plausible
description: He is as much of a celebrity as one can be in a field in which cadavers are the main attraction.

title: Roth and Oates to Receive National Humanities Medals
description: Philip Roth and Joyce Carol Oates are among the 2010 winners of the National Humanities Medal, and Harper Lee, Meryl Streep, James Taylor and Quincy Jones are among the winners of the National Medal of Arts, the White House announced on Tuesday.

title: Pictures of the Day: From Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Yemen, Turkey and Mexico.

title: Of Irish Soil and Ugandan Politics
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The patient crowd huddled around the shed  young and old, a mosaic of the Katwe slum  to hear the politician speak. They had seen his picture around town  how could anyone forget his face?  and now they had a chance to see him in action.

title: Death Comes Calling Once Again, Just as in 1977
description: Paul Taylor has created so many dances that no one could really know them all. But wedged somewhere between the elegant raunchiness of Cloven Kingdom and the radiance of Airs sits Mr. Taylors Dust. In many ways just as worthy, this dance, from 1977, isnt a feel-good work: the subject is a plague. It serves as a reminder that Mr. Taylor is not messing around. Some artists pretend to be eccentric; he really is.

title: A Bravo Pan for Those Singing Schoolkids
description: LOS ANGELES  Not that there arent plenty of Oscar scapegoats to go around  James Franco, the writers, the Internet  but so far only one man has blamed the schoolchildren. As our sister blog City Room points out, on Morning Joe today, Andy Cohen, the Bravo network vice president, said the P.S. 22 fifth-grade choir was the worst thing about the show.

title: Uncertainty Drives Up Oil Prices
description: HOUSTON  Just when oil markets appeared to be calming, crude oil prices surged again on Tuesday as the potential for more oil shipment disruptions spread across the Middle East and North Africa.

title: Lamborghini Aventador, Pagani Huayra and Gumpert Tornante Are Among Genevas Unobtanium
description: In which Jerry Garrett continues his list of the highest-horsepower hypercars from the Geneva auto show. Here are the top five.

title: Christopher Sieber Rushes to the Rescue of La Cage on Broadway
description: 5:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Born of 9/11, an Effort to Rebuild Shattered Haiti
description: Just four days after 9/11, James P. Stuckey, then a vice president of Forest City Ratner Companies, met with executives of Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield at Forest Citys headquarters in Brooklyn. Empire had been the fourth-largest tenant at the World Trade Center, and the shell-shocked executives were already thinking about new offices.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Bigger Than Madoff? John Carney is asking that provocative question: Rajat Gupta may be the most important businessman ever charged with a serious violation of securities laws. . The only people who even comes close to the stature of Gupta are Michael Milken and Bernard Madoff. But despite the vast wealth people had given to Madoff to manage, he was never a member of the inner circle of corporate power in America the way Gupta is.  Net Net

title: The Upper East Side Goes Grungy in David Hammonss Gallery Show
description: The New York artist David Hammons, who has a raved-about show at L&M Arts on the Upper East Side, once said in an interview with the art historian Kellie Jones: I cant stand art actually. Ive never, ever liked art, ever.

title: House Advances Budget and Cuts $4 Billion
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Tuesday approved a two-week budget measure that cuts $4 billion in federal spending. Senate Democrats said they would quickly pass the bill and send it to President Obama, averting any immediate threat of a government shutdown when current financing runs out Friday.

title: A Conversation with Tim DeChristopher
description: Environmental activist Tim DeChristopher speaks with The Times about what he calls his act of civil disobedience for falsely bidding on a controversial set of Utah oil and gas leases.

title: First Payments Are Made to Victims of Marcos Rule
description: MANILA  The last time Nilo Olegario heard his sons voice was in a telephone call 25 years ago, shortly before the strongman Ferdinand E. Marcos fled the Philippines in the face of a people power uprising.

title: The Demubarakization of Egypt
description: CAIRO  The former president of Egypt was not the statue-building kind, or else wed have already seen a few Baghdad-like imagesof marble icons being brought down by jubilant masses after his abdication on February 11. (Come to think of it, I wish we had a few statues to bring down.) But after three decades of rule, and with a particularly auspicious name Mubarak means blessed  the number of buildings, roads and projects named after him is impressive; and as Egyptian society is endeavoring to repair the damage of his corrupt regime, its a different task altogether cleaning up the expressions of the blessed ones megalomania.

title: Patient Voices: Sickle Cell Anemia
description: With extreme pain, frequent hospitalizations and major complications, sickle cell anemia can affect all aspects of life. Six men and women speak about living with this condition.

title: Fewer Patients in I.C.U. Getting Blood Infections
description: Bloodstream infections caused by tubes inserted into major blood vessels of intensive care patients showed a big drop from 2001 to 2009, government researchers said on Tuesday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Turkey and Mexico.

title: Sheen Brings Piers Morgan Best Ratings Yet
description: Charlie Sheens surprise appearance Monday night on Piers Morgan Tonight delivered the six-week-old talk show its highest rating so far in the 25- to 54-year-old demographic that advertisers and cable news executives covet.

title: Bus Stop | Lodekka Dress Shop
description: Your average vintage clothing shop does not come with the warning Mind Your Head When Leaving Seat. Its sound advice at Lodekka, a recently opened boutique in the North Williams neighborhood of Portland, Ore., housed inside in an eggshell white two-story Bristol Lodekka bus. The bus itself  built in 1965 for the citizens of Liverpool  has been exhaustively remodeled in shades of almond, coral pink and warm red. The exterior cant help but catch eyes (and foot traffic from the nearby brunch spots), but its the selection inside that tugs at the bargain hunters heartstrings: midcentury Oleg Cassini dresses for $12, a pair of purple Halston pumps for $7 and mens western wear culled from the high deserts of eastern Oregon. Comfortable, not cluttered, Lodekka is also home to trunks full of yellowing National Park maps, McCalls pattern books from the early 80s, Brownie Twin 20 Kodak cameras and a curators closet of Pendleton skirts and button-ups  this is Portland, after all.

title: Revisiting an Annual Rite of Beethoven and Sibelius
description: The exacting and exuberant Finnish conductor Osmo Vanska arrived as the music director of the Minnesota Orchestra in 2003, determined to lift this respected ensemble to world-class status. However such things are measured, there is no denying that Mr. Vanska has had enormous success. The orchestra sounded terrific on Monday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: The New York Times Magazine - Masthead
description: A listing of staff members and contributors to The New York Times Magazine.

title: The Battle for Zawiyah
description: David D. Kirkpatrick reports from Tripoli, where after a night of fighting, Libyan rebels appear to have control of the city.

title: A Cuomo Aide Criticizes a Former Cuomo Aide
description: A spokesman for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo attacked a former Cuomo aide and a government watchdog advocate on Tuesday, calling him a mouthpiece for the trial lawyers after he criticized a proposal backed by Mr. Cuomo to cap awards in medical malpractice lawsuits.

title: Egypt Antiquities Chief Says He May Quit
description: In a marked shift from his previous statements, Egypts minister of antiquities, Zahi Hawass, said on Tuesday that his department was unable to protect Egypts historic sites and artifacts and that he was considering resigning.

title: At the Bar in the Galliano Case, Silence
description: PARIS

title: From Tired Buildings to Slick New Offices
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Six years ago, when a corporate restructuring abruptly put Robert H. Silver out of his job as the president and chief operating officer at UBS Financial Services, he also lost his handsome New York office, of course. So Mr. Silver went home.

title: 'John Zorns Music Interpreted'
description: The choreographers Donald Byrd and Pam Tanowitz created dances to the music of John Zorn for the latest Works & Process evening at the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Take Unusual Music, Mix Contrasting Movements, Stir Well
description: How may music be answered by dance? On Sunday the mysteries of this topic were the main subject of a Works & Process evening, John Zorns Music Interpreted, at the Guggenheim Museum.

title: 328 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn, 1:11 P.M.
description: Hour 3 of a three-alarm fire in a laundromat in Crown Heights that left two firefighters with minor injuries. Its cause is under investigation.

title: The Travel Industry Shares Money-Saving Tips (and Freebies)
description: This weekend, I attended the New York Times Travel Show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York, where my Travel section colleagues and I spoke on a panel called How to Get the Most Out of Your Travels in 2011. That was the boring part. (I mean for me  not for the audience, lets hope.)

title: Exclusive Clip: 'Uncle Boonmee'
description: A scene from "Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives," the winner of the Grand Jury prize at the 2010 Cannes Film Festival.

title: Mining Blogs for Sources: A Dangerous Occupation
description: Kate Zernike, in her report on Michelle Obamas effort to promote breast-feeding, went to the blogs to canvas political comment. There, she found a surprising number of people crossing political boundaries to express support or opposition.

title: Music Director Cancels in Boston
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra said on Tuesday that it had lost James Levine, its music director, for the rest of his scheduled performances this season, the latest blow to his tenure there.

title: Gingrich Poised to Put Toe in 2012 Waters
description: Presidential announcements come in baby steps. And Newt Gingrich is poised to take the first ones of the 2012 campaign cycle on Thursday.

title: A Farewell to This Life, and All Its Ghosts
description: Last May, when a Cannes Film Festival jury headed by Tim Burton awarded the Palme dOr to Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives, there was widespread surprise and a few eruptions of outrage. The film  from the Thai director Apichatpong Weerasethakul, who has become a familiar presence on the festival circuit over the past decade  is unquestionably strange, at times mystifyingly oblique. Those who insist on a linear narrative or an easily identifiable set of themes may find themselves puzzled, perhaps to the point of frustration. But it is hard to see how this movie, with its contemplative mood and genial, curious spirit, could make anybody angry. On the contrary: encountered in an appropriately exploratory frame of mind, it can produce something close to bliss.

title: Alice on Her Toes, at a Rare Tea Party
description: LONDON  How do you make a full-length story ballet in 2011? Christopher Wheeldon must have asked himself that as he prepared Alices Adventures in Wonderland, his much hyped new full-length work for the Royal Ballet, set to a commissioned score by Joby Talbot and given a splashy gala opening at the Royal Opera House on Monday night.

title: Oscars Red Carpet (Parallel Universe)
description: WAS it good for you  the Academy Awards that is, which last Sunday continued its long tradition of getting it wrong? It was for me, even if the Academys habit of rewarding mediocrity, especially if it comes with a British accent, remains intact. Then again I was closer to the action than usual, having finally admitted, if only to myself, that I wanted to walk that tawdry red carpet. I wanted to see Christian Bale, Natalie Portman and most of all David Fincher win in person or on the screen inside the Kodak Theater. I wanted to watch The Kings Speech go down in flames. Oh, well. Forget it, Jake  its Hollywood.

title: Chemicals and Toxic Materials That Come With Hydrofracking
description: Interactive graphic of the chemicals and toxins that come with hydrofracking. Hazards in extracting gas and in waste disposal.

title: Scenes From Libya
description: Images from Libya, going back to the beginning of the unrest.

title: Politico Requested E-Mails of Other Reporters in 2009
description: 8:59 a.m. | Updated Politico, the news Web site that on Monday revealed that a Congressional aide had been secretly sharing e-mails with a New York Times reporter, itself sought correspondence between government officials in numerous federal agencies and other news organizations.

title: David Hammons at L&M Arts
description: Images of paintings from Mr. Hammonss latest show, which closes Friday.

title: Alexander Wangs Store Opens in SoHo
description: AFTER lying on a fur hammock for about 40 seconds, a paradigm shift takes place. I once thought that fur hammocks were absurd bourgeois luxuries, but actually, they are what Ive unknowingly spent my entire life searching for.

title: The Chelsea Room
description: WHEN the Hotel Chelsea was put up for sale last year, some wondered if the iconic haven for artists would finally crumble into the surrounding sea of Duane Reades and Radio Shacks. It remains unsold and bohemian, but for a harrowing vision of the future, look no further than the Chelsea Room, the basement nightclub that opened under the hotel in October.

title: Clinton Calls for 'Orderly Transition'
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton appeared on several Sunday talk shows to discuss Egypt's future. (Video: MSNBC & Reuters)

title: With Deal, Clear Channel Eyes Pandora-like Service
description: Clear Channel Communications, the largest radio broadcaster in the country, has acquired most of the assets of Thumbplay, a small digital music company, and will soon begin to incorporate some of Thumbplays technology in its own online radio services, the company announced on Tuesday.

title: Debt Market Rebounds From the Crisis, and So Does Risk
description: Harry Campbell

description: A Dot Earth commenter, SAS from New York, posted a constructively provocative retort after my latest piece on eating alien invasive species where possible:

title: Trains and Freedom
description: A bit more on this subject  not serious, just a personal observation after a long hard day of reading student applications. (My suggestion that we reject all applicants claiming to be passionate about their plans was rejected, but with obvious reluctance.)

title: The (Partial) Vindication of the Tea Party
description: There were a lot of surprising developments during the weeks I just took off from writing (who knew Charlie Sheen had so much to offer the world?), but the what entitlement problem? evasiveness of President Obamas 2011 budget wasnt one of them. What was a surprise, though, and a pleasant one, was the House G.O.P.s response: A politically-gutsy pledge that their forthcoming budget would tackle entitlements head-on. And while how all this plays out remains to be seen, it seems fair for the Tea Party movement to claim a measure of vindication from the way Congressional Republicans have conducted themselves to date.

title: At Algarve Cup, the Power of Confidence
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Womens Professional Soccer and as the United States womens national team prepares to play in the Algarve Cup and the FIFA Womens World Cup in Germany later this year.

title: White House Talks With Labor and Business
description: The White House chief of staff, William M. Daley, as usual took the business audience while the chief strategist David Plouffe spoke to a big-labor conference as the Obama team covered both bases on Monday in its ongoing outreach to press the administrations agenda.

title: Japan Phone Makers See Opportunity in Android
description: TOKYO  Japanese mobile phones are a gadget lovers dream. They double as credit cards. They can display digital TV broadcasts. Some are even fitted with solar cells.

title: In Politics, Demographics Are Not Destiny
description: A lot of political analysis focuses in near-obsessive detail on demographic groups. The strategy, for example, that Mark Penn outlined for Hillary Clinton before the 2008 Democratic primaries identified 25 distinct swing demographic categories, including such relatively narrow ones as women aged 35 to 49 and single men.

title: Beautiful Burnout
description: Images from the show at St. Anns Warehouse.

title: A Chefs Life, With Scars and All
description: I LOVE my scar, Gabrielle Hamilton said the other day. I am covered in scars.

title: Stop This Grill  I Want to Get Off! (Or Do I?)
description: On a snowy afternoon in January, I caught the F train downtown to meet Gabrielle Hamilton at Prune, her restaurant in the East Village. She and I sat in the G-spot.

title: Scorecard | Giorgio Armani Wins!
description: On the sixth and final day of Milan fashion week, Scorecard knows critics for once grudgingly acknowledged the Caten brother duos display of true grit for sticking like a burr to a theme. On that note, Giorgio Armanis post-feminist boardroom-inspired boudoir collection was resoundingly declared in the pink.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Piedmont Food and Wine

title: Greenhouse Projects Nurture Produce and Workers
description: HACKETTSTOWN, N.J.
