description: Opening

title: Wasan
description: 108 East Fourth Street (Second Avenue), (212) 777-1978, wasan-ny.com

title: Bankers Line Up to Meet Elizabeth Warren
description: Elizabeth Warren is highly sought after in Washington  especially among bankers.

title: A Hefty Guide to Eating Italian
description: The subtitle of Monica Sartoni Cesaris Italy Dish by Dish (A Comprehensive Guide to Eating in Italy) only tells part of the story. The chunky new book, with the dimensions of a nice portion of lasagna, is really a guide to Italian food no matter where you eat it. Region by region, plate by plate and glass by glass, it provides definitions and background for thousands of items. So if you see porceddu on a menu, you can discover that its Sardinian suckling pig. Theres a basic recipe for each region, like the bucatini allamatriciana for Lazio. Among other minor gaps, Ligurians may quibble that their focaccia gets short shrift, but thats not to take away from the usefulness of this volume.

title: Bushwick Looks More Sicilian With Arancini
description: When David Campaniello and his partner, Will Levatino, came up with the idea of selling the breaded, golden, fried rice balls known as arancini three years ago, they headed to Sicily for research. The arancini there are ubiquitous and sometimes as large as grapefruits, as Mr. Campaniello put it. At Arancini Bros., the partners new storefront in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the globes of rice are the size of tennis balls or, actually, oranges, from which they get their name.

title: Ginger Beer: Some Like It Hot or Cool
description: When it comes to ginger beer, some decidedly like it hot. Others prefer it cool. Luscombe, made in Devon, England, offers a version for each palate. Both are sparkling and are made from ginger root, sugar and lemons, all organic, with no additives or preservatives. The refreshment quotient is top notch when chilled and poured over ice, either straight up as a nonalcoholic aperitif or with a splash of white rum. And consider using either version as a marinade for fish or in place of Champagne for an Asian sabayon.

title: Edi & the Wolf
description: 102 Avenue C (East Seventh Street), (212) 598-1040, ediandthewolf.com.

title: Sauted Shrimp With Coconut Oil, Ginger and Coriander
description: Time: 10 minutes

title: Once a Villain, Coconut Oil Charms the Health Food World
description: A FEW years ago I noticed something odd at the health food store. There, rubbing elbows with the extra-virgin olive oil and cold-pressed canola oil was virtually the last fat I expected to see in such esteemed company: coconut oil.

title: The Art of Winfield House
description: The United States ambassador to London and his wife use their residence as a setting for American art.

title: After Brewers Debut, a Relaxed Greinke Meets the Media
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Zack Greinke made his first exhibition appearance for the Milwaukee Brewers on Tuesday, walking three of his eight hitters but not feeling too bad about it. He missed with a few high fastballs, and is learning a different curveball grip. His side muscle bothers him a little, but he said it was improving. The ball felt good leaving his hand.

title: The High Cost of Efficiency
description: Wall Streets titans arent paid to sweat the details. That has become painfully obvious from the foreclosure and mortgage mess that may cost big banks like JPMorgan and Bank of America billions of dollars. The last two decades of bank merger mania brought big cost savings and temporarily higher stock prices, but left a huge muddle.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,473 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: A.I.G. to Speed Up Sale of MetLife Shares
description: The American International Group said on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement with MetLife to sell shares it owns in its rival, gained as part of a deal between the two insurers, earlier than expected.

title: A Tax Cut May Carve Into the Budgets of 19 States
description: Struggling states could lose as much as $5.3 billion in tax collections during the next few years in an unintended consequence of one of the lower-profile federal tax cuts that President Obama signed in December, according to a report released Tuesday.

title: An Ode to February (and Lets Keep It Short)
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Union Contracts, Not Pay, Are States Problem
description: When Ed Rendell became the mayor of Philadelphia in 1992, he started a fight with the citys labor unions that will sound familiar to anyone who has been following the recent news from Wisconsin. In his inaugural address, Mr. Rendell, a Democrat, announced, Philadelphia stands on the brink of total disaster.

title: Shunting a Key Figure to the Sideline
description: Orlando, Fla.

title: CBS Chief Leaves Open Possibility of Sheens Return
description: The chief executive of CBS, Leslie Moonves, may be leaving the door ajar for a settlement with Charlie Sheen, the troubled star of Two and Half Men.

title: Trial in Sweat Lodge Deaths Begins
description: The trial of James A. Ray, a motivational speaker charged with manslaughter in the deaths of three of his followers during a sweat lodge ceremony, opened Tuesday in the central Arizona town of Camp Verde.

title: Fending Off Paparazzi May Earn Glory, but Not Necessarily a Visa
description: PHOENIX  Nobody disputes that Nikolaos Skokos is adept at what he does, which is keeping unruly crowds away from Celine Dion, the singer, and helping to whisk her away safely to her next engagement.

title: New Routine for Posada, and a Bit of the Old One
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  For the past two days, Jorge Posada displayed three new two-tone catchers gloves on a shelf in his locker, each holding a baseball autographed by multiple teammates. On Tuesday morning, when a Yankees clubhouse attendant rounded up gear for the trip here, he grabbed Posadas bag of catching equipment, one that contained a fourth new glove, one Posada is breaking in.

title: Why Your Boss Is Wrong About You
description: Los Angeles

title: Governors Seek Help on Medicaid Costs
description: WASHINGTON  Governors told Congress on Tuesday that President Obama had not gone far enough in proposing to let states opt out of major provisions of the new health care law in 2014, and they said they needed more immediate relief from the growing financial burden of Medicaid.

title: The Dim Light of Hope
description: The only thing foggier than war itself may be the path to its frightening, if too often exhilarating, outbreak. Indeed, the secession crisis and road to civil war took an enormous emotional toll on Americans of every persuasion and in every corner of the land. Few, however, expressed themselves as publicly or eloquently as Frederick Douglass. I have never spent days so restless and anxious, he said in an early April 1861, lecture at Rochesters Spring Street A.M.E. Zion Church. Our mornings and evenings have continually oscillated between the dim light of hope and the gloomy shadow of despair.

title: Galliano Case Tests Dior Brands Future
description: PARIS  The career of Christian Diors star designer, John Galliano, may well be over after he was dismissed Tuesday for a video that surfaced of him making anti-Semitic remarks. But Dior  and its parent company, LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton  acted quickly and decisively in an attempt to limit any long-term damage to the Dior name.

title: Feeling Budget Pinch, States Cut Insurance
description: EASTON, Pa.  Ken Kewley woke up Tuesday without health insurance for the first time in nearly nine years.

title: Gates Plays Down Idea of U.S. Force in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Tuesday played down the possibility of American military intervention in Libya, saying that there was no agreement within NATO about the use of force and that now was not the time for the United States to be entering into another war in the Middle East.

title: The Hidden Victims of Wartime Rape
description: Los Angeles

title: Supreme Court Rules on AT&T Case
description: WASHINGTON  In a lively decision that relied as much on dictionaries, grammar and usage as it did on legal analysis, the Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled unanimously that corporations have no personal privacy rights for purposes of the Freedom of Information Act.

title: How Not to Rid New York City Schools of Bad Apples
description: For five years, the principal of P.S. 114 in Brooklyn ran the school into the ground. She blew out the budgets, eventually costing the school its guidance counselors, special reading and math projects, and gifted program.

title: Dont End Agricultural Subsidies, Fix Them
description: Agricultural subsidies have helped bring us high-fructose corn syrup, factory farming, fast food, a two-soda-a-day habit and its accompanying obesity, the near-demise of family farms, monoculture and a host of other ills.

title: Vizquels Path to Shortstop at 40 Could Stand as a Test for Jeter
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.

title: Unanimously, Supreme Court Backs Veterans in 2 Cases
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court issued two unanimous decisions on Tuesday reflecting solicitude for members of the military.

title: Kenyas Rudisha Refocuses After Record Year
description: ITEN, Kenya  His workout over, David Rudisha sat quietly on the couch in the small lounge outside his small shared bedroom here, thumbing through the February issue of Track & Field News, a chronicle of his achievements set against far less spartan backdrops.

title: Political Crisis in Ivory Coast Cripples a City
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  At the Marcory market, iron shutters are pulled down tight over storefronts for block after block. In the Koumassi neighborhood, idle men drift up to a rare open vendor, cadging a lone cigarette. Fish and grain stalls on the road into another area, Abobo, are deserted, save the rats scurrying in a facing gutter. Lines of women, fleeing the violence in a single-file exodus, balance possessions on their heads and then scatter at the sound of nearby gunfire.

title: In Labor Clash, N.F.L.s Union Calls Old Play
description: WASHINGTON  With the National Football Leagues players unions agreement with owners set to expire at midnight Friday, and little progress reported in eight days of negotiations that have included a federal mediator, the union is planning to effectively dissolve itself.

title: Plan Would Erase All-Business Town
description: VERNON, Calif.  Vernon is a bleak, 5.2-square-mile sprawl of warehouses, factories, toxic chemical plants and meat processors that looks like the backdrop for Eraserhead, the David Lynch movie set in an industrial wasteland. It has a population of 95  and 1,800 businesses, drawn by low taxes, lax regulations and cheap municipal power.

title: Vernon Residents Fight For Town
description: The residents of this small California town are fighting disincorporation by the state.

title: Yahoo in Talks to Shed Stake in Japan Joint Venture
description: Yahoo is in talks to shed its 35 percent stake in its Yahoo Japan joint venture, possibly handing over control to its partner, Softbank, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

title: Judge Says N.F.L. Acted Against Players When It Renegotiated Television Deals
description: A federal judge ruled Tuesday that the N.F.L. acted against players interests when it failed to maximize revenue from networks when it renegotiated its television deals.

title: Arab Unrest Puts Their Lobbyists in Uneasy Spot
description: WASHINGTON  For years, they have been one of the most formidable lobbying forces in town: the elite band of former members of Congress, former diplomats and power brokers who have helped Middle Eastern nations navigate diplomatic waters here on delicate issues like arms deals, terrorism, oil and trade restrictions.

title: Credit Card Data Tells Mixed Story
description: American shoppers did not shed their reliance on credit cards over the year-end holidays.

title: On Metro-Norths New Haven Line, New Cars Arrive
description: Much has changed in the 40 years since Corydon B. Dunham began commuting to his home in Riverside, Conn., from New York City. Most of the trains he rides on, however, have not.

title: Ex-UBS Banker Is Said to Have Been Informant in Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors who arrested a senior private banker at Credit Suisse in the United States in January in connection with a federal investigation into offshore accounts learned his identity from an indicted UBS banker, according to court papers unsealed on Tuesday.

title: Wisconsin Standoff
description: Monica Davey reports from Madison, Wisconsin where governor Scott Walker presents his budget, as the collective bargaining standoff continues.

title: Assembly Will Push to Keep Tax Increase on High Earners, Defying Cuomos Wishes
description: ALBANY  The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said on Tuesday that Democrats in the chamber would seek passage of a budget bill that includes the renewal of a temporary income tax surcharge on high-earning New Yorkers, a proposal staunchly opposed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Rebels Continue to Move Against Qaddafi
description: Frustrated with Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafis unyielding grip on power, the revolutionary council in the city is debating whether to ask for Western airstrikes, under a United Nations banner.

title: This Is Just the Start
description: Future historians will long puzzle over how the self-immolation of a Tunisian street vendor, Mohamed Bouazizi, in protest over the confiscation of his fruit stand, managed to trigger popular uprisings across the Arab/Muslim world. We know the big causes  tyranny, rising food prices, youth unemployment and social media. But since being in Egypt, Ive been putting together my own back-of-the-envelope guess list of what Id call the not-so-obvious forces that fed this mass revolt. Here it is:

title: Filmmakers in Tow, Irate Koch Presses Albany on Redistricting
description: ALBANY  Nobody seemed quite sure what to make of the electric car inching through the halls of the State Legislature at two miles per hour on Tuesday. It looks like a June bug, one man said. A space vessel, another said.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 1, 2011

title: Wisconsin Budget Would Slash School and Municipal Aid
description: MADISON, Wis.  Gov. Scott Walker, whose push to limit collective bargaining rights and increase health and pension costs for public workers has set off a national debate, proposed a new budget for Wisconsin on Tuesday that called for deep cuts to state aid to schools and local governments, provoking a new wave of fury.

title: Mr. Obamas Health Care Challenge
description: President Obama had a splendid idea this week. He challenged governors who oppose his health care reforms, most of whom are Republicans, to come up with a better alternative. He has agreed to move up the date at which states can offer their own solutions and thus opt out of requirements that they oppose, like the mandate that everyone buy health insurance and that most employers provide it.

title: Ireland, Under New Management
description: Irish voters had every right to be angry at the catastrophic mismanagement of their economy. But the drubbing they administered to Fianna Fail, the longtime ruling party, by itself wont undo the damage that came from years of lax government oversight and disastrous policy choices.

title: PPL to Buy E.ONs British Power Grid for $5.6 Billion
description: PPL agreed late Tuesday to buy the British electrical grid business of Germanys E.ON for about $5.6 billion in cash, significantly expanding its operations in that country.

title: Truth in Pregnancy Counseling
description: The New York City Council is about to vote on, and should pass, an important measure that addresses the problem of crisis pregnancy centers that masquerade as licensed medical facilities but are, in fact, fronts for anti-abortion groups that interfere with the ability of women to make timely, well-informed decisions about their reproductive health.

title: Baseball Said to End Big Loans to Mets
description: The Mets, in need of cash to pay off loans and meet other financial obligations, can no longer look to Major League Baseball for substantial monetary assistance, according to two people briefed on the teams finances.

title: Spokesman Loses Job for Sharing His E-Mail
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Darrell Issa, Republican of California, dismissed his chief spokesman, Kurt Bardella, on Tuesday after concluding that Mr. Bardella had secretly and regularly shared e-mail exchanges he had with journalists with a reporter for The New York Times writing a book about Washingtons political culture.

title: Government Bans Five Chemicals Used in Marijuana Stand-Ins
description: Using its emergency authority, the Drug Enforcement Administration on Tuesday announced a temporary ban of five chemicals used to make synthetic marijuana products, which have grown increasingly popular over the past few years. The ban, which the drug agency said it would pursue in 2010, will remain in effect for at least a year until it is determined whether the chemicals should be permanently controlled. Fake marijuana products produce a high similar to marijuana when smoked. The products  typically sold at smoke shops  have caused numerous health problems including seizures and hallucinations, the drug agency has said.

title: Hundreds Arrested in Gang Crackdown
description: An anti-gang dragnet has led to the arrest of 678 gang members and their associates, most of them immigrants, in 168 cities, federal officials announced Tuesday. The three-month-long operation focused on groups with ties to international drug trafficking, said officials from Immigration and Customs Enforcement, an arm of the Department of Homeland Security. Some 447 of the defendants were charged with crimes while the rest were arrested for administrative immigration violations, officials said. The offensive was part of a five-year campaign by immigration officials to combat violent street gangs by prosecuting and deporting their members.

title: Judith Coplon, Haunted by Espionage Case, Dies at 89
description: Judith Socolov, who as a diminutive Barnard graduate named Judith Coplon was convicted of espionage more than 60 years ago after embracing a utopian vision of communism and falling in love with a Soviet agent, died Saturday in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: Spain: Budget Deficit Goal Met
description: Spain met its 2010 budget deficit target, Finance Minister Elena Salgado said Tuesday, as spending cuts by the central government in Madrid helped offset the missed targets of about half of the countrys regional governments. The budget deficit for last year was about $135.6 billion, amounting to 9.24 percent of gross domestic product, Ms. Salgado said.

title: Jets Tinker With Roster, Making Offers to 9 Players
description: The Jets continued their roster renovation Tuesday, extending qualifying offers to nine players and releasing three others.

title: Wednesday: Je Ne Sais Quoi
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Man, I bounced all over the place on this one, but it was totally worth it. Normally, Ill solve within a sector until its filled, but I kept getting stuck and seeking out familiar territory until I could get a firm toehold somewhere, anywhere. A person could work up a real hunger on a puzzle like this, but thankfully, David Poole has provided us with a snack at 31 Across. Not only that, but theres enough wonderful wordplay here to make this a satisfying solve.

title: Pro Bono Campaign Aims to Keep the Kings in Sacramento
description: BILLBOARDS that went up in Sacramento recently say Game Over, with a deflated basketball representing the O, and, below that: If the Kings leave, we all lose.

title: A Dinner of Water and Stones for Those Friends Who Dont Come Through
description: The barking is voluminous, but the bite doesnt draw much blood in the Public Theaters new production of Timon of Athens, the inaugural Shakespeare Lab presentation from the company, starring Richard Thomas as the Greek nobleman transformed from lavish philanthropist to confirmed misanthrope in the twinkling of an eye, or rather the emptying of a once-fat purse.

title: Hoping to Punch a Path to Glory
description: An argument over style and substance erupts at a climactic point in Beautiful Burnout, a new play from Scotland about amateur boxers aiming for glory that opened on Tuesday night at St. Anns Warehouse. A hotshot young fighter thinks his unique style will carry him to the top. His domineering coach is having none of it. Hard work, proper training and strict obedience are the keys, he gruffly insists.

title: Rajat Gupta Charged With Insider Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed charges against Rajat Gupta, a prominent business executive, accusing him of passing illegal tips to Raj Rajaratnam, the indicted hedge fund manager.

title: A $20 Loan, a Facebook Quarrel and a Fatal Stabbing
description: The dispute between the two friends began over $20, money that had been given to buy baby formula and diapers, but that went for some other purpose. Days later, it became a heated public matter, splayed on the two young womens Facebook pages.

title: Zimbabwe: Seeking Release of 45
description: The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Navi Pillay, on Tuesday called on Zimbabwean authorities to release 45 activists charged with treason. A statement from her office said they were being held for discussing events in Egypt and Tunisia. She said the arrests violated the detainees rights to freedom of expression and assembly. The United Nations torture investigator, Juan E. Mndez, said Monday that he had written to the government about allegations that the detainees had been beaten in custody.

title: Deal Is Reached for Line Under Hudson Giving the City a New Source of Electricity
description: After being pressed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and other elected officials, New York City has struck a deal that would end months of wrangling over a plan to send electricity to Manhattan from New Jersey, people involved in the negotiations said Tuesday.

title: Slashing Community Service
description: PRESIDENTS F.Y. 2010-11 REQUEST: $1.4 BILLION

title: Cuomo Seeks Speedy Change in Teacher Evaluations
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Tuesday that he would introduce legislation to speed the implementation of a statewide system to evaluate teachers performance.

title: Mexico: Ex-Mayor Tied to Killings
description: A man who confessed to executing 60 people while working for the drug gang La Familia has told the police that he was originally recruited for the job by the mayor of the small town where he lives, the authorities said. The police in Mexico State, near Mexico City, arrested the former mayor of Tlalmanalco, Ral Snchez Reyes, who left office in 2009, at his house on Monday. Rodolfo Aboytes, the man who confessed to the killings and who was arrested Saturday, told the police that his cell paid off the local and state police to avoid arrest, and described six sites where he had buried bodies.

title: Police Departments Turn to Volunteers
description: FRESNO, Calif.  Roman Sarkisian easily passes for your average Fresno police officer: crew cut, tight-set jaw and just-the-facts demeanor.

title: City Council Earmarks Flow to Brain Scan Group
description: Every year, the Brain Tumor Foundation bombards the City Council with stories of loved ones lost, frightening statistics about the prevalence of cancer and pledges to literally save the lives of your constituents.

title: Behind Miller, Recharged Sabres Draw Closer to Rangers
description: Five weeks remain in the regular season, but there is little margin of error for Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist or Buffalo Sabres goalie Ryan Miller as they try to carry their middling teams as far into springtime as they can.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Annie Girardot, Versatile French Actress, Dies at 79
description: Annie Girardot, a versatile French actress who played the doomed Milanese streetwalker in Luchino Viscontis Rocco and His Brothers and, moving easily from drama to comedy, became Frances most popular actress of the 1970s, died on Monday in Paris. She was 79.

title: Niese Solid in Spring Debut
description: Other than a pair of two-out walks, Jon Niese had a solid outing in his spring debut. Aside from the walks, he allowed just two hits while striking out two in a 5-3 loss to the Nationals. Niese needed only 22 pitches to get through three innings.

title: God of Love
description: A scene from the Oscar-winning film, "God of Love," starring Luke Matheny.

title: Word of the Day | gentility
description: gentility  \jen-ti-l-te\ noun

title: Can Exercise Keep You Young?
description: We all know that physical activity is beneficial in countless ways, but even so, Dr. Mark Tarnopolsky, a professor of pediatrics at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario, was startled to discover that exercise kept a strain of mice from becoming gray prematurely.

title: French Films Turn Back the Clock
description: What would French film culture look like without its queen, Catherine Deneuve, steering the ship of state? This magnificent enigma, now an ageless 67, recently received her 11th Csar (the French Oscar) nomination, for best actress in Potiche, Franois Ozons freewheeling screen adaptation of a boulevard comedy by Pierre Barillet and Jean-Pierre Grdy.

title: News Quiz | March 2, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Inside the Kitchen at Prune
description: Behind the scenes at the East Village restaurant owned by Gabrielle Hamilton, author of the new memoir "Blood, Bones & Butter."

title: Photos of the Moment | Josephus Thimister
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#711", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Doris From Rego Park Lives On in Song
description: You know its spring training when even Doris from Rego Park can make a comeback.

title: Doing Good in a Bad Economy
description: WHO are taking jobs in public service rather than private industry, according to this article?

title: Migrant Workers Pile Up at Libyas Borders
description: RAS AJDIR BORDER CROSSING, Tunisia  Tens of thousands of migrant workers fleeing Libya found themselves in a desperate crush of refugees trying to cross the border into Tunisia on Wednesday.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 2, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article In New California Gold Rush, Old Mines Reopen.

title: Are You Hard or Easy on Yourself?
description: According to new research, going easy on yourself  or having self-compassion  may be healthier for you. Are you hard or easy on yourself? Are you judgmental about your own flaws and inadequacies, berating yourself for not exercising more or getting better grades? Do you treat yourself as well as you treat your loved ones? Why or why not?

title: Stairways as Mountains
description: Police Officer Pierre Lucien, 27, dreams he will one day have his Rocky moment. It just wont be at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. I will walk up the steps of the Brooklyn Museum, all the way to the top, he declared. With my arms up.

title: Extremists Are Suspected in Killing of Pakistani Minister
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  The only Christian cabinet minister in the Pakistani government was shot dead Wednesday two months after the assassination of another liberal politician, raising questions about how firmly Pakistans government is tackling Islamist extremism.

title: Daily Lexeme: Bepurfurate
description: Todays word, in association with the awesome Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Celebrating New French Film
description: A look at some of the films appearing in the Rendezvous With French Cinema series.

title: Gates Warns of Risks of a No-Flight Zone
description: WASHINGTON  With rebels in Libya calling for Western airstrikes on forces supporting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates warned Congress on Wednesday that even a more modest effort to establish a no-flight zone over Libya would have to begin with an attack on the countrys air defenses and would require a big operation in a big country.

title: American Idol': The Top 12 Guys
description: There is Jacob Lusk, and then there is American Idol. That they overlap, at least for now, is something of a miracle.

title: How Not to Get Sick From a Flight
description: WHEN Peter J. Sheldon boards a plane to any destination, his safety routine extends well beyond buckling his seat belt and noting the nearest exit. Once at his seat, he meticulously wipes down the cushions, armrests and tray table with disinfectant wipes. He refuses to touch the in-flight magazines and avoids using the restroom if at all possible. Since he began his in-flight cleansing routine he says he has weathered countless stares from other passengers but has never gotten ill from a flight.

title: An Old Paris Venue Is Reborn and Goes Digital
description: We marvel at the potential of digital technology for facilitating access to information, quickening the pace of modern life and changing our means of communication. Less cited? The fact that it provides seemingly inexhaustible possibilities for creative endeavors. The newly renovated La Gait Lyrique (3bis rue Papin; www.gaite-lyrique.net) will highlight the artistic facets of digitalization through exhibitions of innovative projects, in every medium from music to cinema, graphic arts to video games.

title: The Minimal Impact of the Stimulus
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: The Early Word: Bills, Bills, Bills
description: From Todays Times

title: Rebels in Libya Win Battle but Fail to Loosen Qaddafis Grip
description: BREGA, Libya  From the feeble cover of sand dunes, under assault from a warplane overhead and heavy artillery from a hill, rebels in this strategic oil city repelled an attack by hundreds of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis fighters on Wednesday. The daylong battle was the first major incursion by the colonels forces in the rebel-held east of the country since the Libyan uprising began.

title: Judges Ruling on N.F.L. TV Money Gives Union Leverage to Make Deal
description: The N.F.L. players union won a significant legal battle Tuesday. In a reversal of a prior ruling, a federal judge in Minneapolis said that the N.F.L. violated an agreement with the players when it negotiated its latest TV contracts. The judge said the league settled for less money in exchange for the continued flow of cash in the event of a work stoppage. The N.F.L. had a duty to maximize revenue for the players, the judge said.

title: Q&A: Transplanting Your iPhoto Library
description: Q.

title: Citizens on Patrol
description: Faced with budget cuts and layoffs, Fresno, Calif., is giving police volunteers more responsibility.

title: The Yeti Pro Mic: Not Abominable at All
description: The Blue Microphones Yeti Pro is, like its Arctic namesake, heavy, cold, and visually impressive. With a stand seemingly cast out of iron and a body like a soda can, this six-inch tall microphone has three internal microphone capsules for stereo surround-sound recording that allows for podcasters, interviewers and musicians to switch sound recording positions on the fly.

title: Microcredit Pioneer Ousted, Head of Bangladeshi Bank Says
description: NEW DELHI  Muhammad Yunus, the Bangladeshi economist and Nobel Peace Prize winner who pioneered tiny loans for village entrepreneurs as a way to fight poverty, has been forced out of the bank he founded, the government-appointed chairman of the bank said Wednesday.

title: Oscars Online: No to James Franco, Yes to Bob Hope
description: In search of a younger audience, the producers of Sunday evenings broadcast of the 83rd Academy Awards pulled out all the stops to engage viewers on social media, even having one of their own co-hosts live-tweet during the ceremony.

title: Vizquel Is a Reminder of What Might Have Been
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  One of the great disappointments of the 1990s, I think, is that the Seattle Mariners never reached the World Series. I am partial to Seattle, having worked there at the end of that decade, knowing the passion of the fans and the wonders of that region of the country. And the construction of Safeco Field, one of the very best ballparks in the majors, is a lasting legacy of that era in Mariners history.

title: Why Arent This Sites Visitors Buying?
description: Greencare Interior Plants is a store in Houston that sells plants to residences and businesses. The company has long served the Houston area through its brick-and-mortar store but has only recently decided to try the world of e-commerce. Working with a minimal budget, Patrice Watine, the owner, built a Web site, houstoninteriorplants.com, with the hope that if he built it, they would come.

title: Safety Agency Pulls Back on Power Window Rule
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration announced on Monday that it would not go forward with a proposed rule that would have required some power windows to automatically reverse if a hand, head or other obstruction were placed in their path.

title: Rochas Casting
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#436", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Showdown With Congress Could Stall Obama Travel, Again
description: On March 19, President Obama will take off on his first foreign trip of 2011, a five-day Latin American excursion to Brazil, El Salvador and Chile.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: The Voices of Sickle Cell Disease
description: In todays Patient Voices audio feature, six people talk about living with sickle cell disease.

title: Leon Washington, Rod Tidwell and Risking It All in the N.F.L.
description: Jets fans will always have an admiration and an appreciation for Leon Washington. In four seasons with the team from 2006-9, he earned a reputation as one of its most exciting and hardest-working players, and he developed into one of the best kickoff return men in the N.F.L.

title: On Our Radar: Attempted Homicide Charge for Driver Who Hit Brazilian Cyclists
description: A car deliberately plows into a large group of cyclists in the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre, injuring at least 40 people, some of them seriously. The ride was organized by the group Critical Mass, which advocates cycling as an environmentally friendly form of transportation. The driver, held by police on a charge of attempted homicide, says the cyclists threatened him. The lead investigator on the case calls his claims fanciful. [The Telegraph]

title: March 2: Updates on Libyas Revolt and Mideast Protests
description: On Wednesday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. Readers can also follow some of the discussion of the region on Twitter in this blogs right column.

title: Morning Buzz | Cuomo Offers Teacher-Merit Proposal
description: Gusty Wednesday, but creeping ever so slowly toward spring with highs of 52 and mostly sunny. During the night, the weather will plunge back into winter, with overnight temperatures below freezing.

title: Galliano to Face Trial Over Anti-Semitic Remarks
description: PARIS  John Galliano, the talented and troubled designer who was fired by the fashion house Christian Dior for making anti-Semitic remarks in a drunken rant at a bar, will be put on trial for the offenses, the Paris prosecutors office said Wednesday.

title: Vatican Condemns Killing of Christian Official in Pakistan
description: ROME  The Vatican swiftly condemned the killing of Pakistans only Christian government minister on Wednesday.

title: The Next Test for the Madoff Trustee
description: The efforts of Irving H. Picard, the trustee tasked with recovering assets for victims of Bernard L. Madoffs enormous Ponzi scheme, faces an important test on Thursday.

title: Race Complicates Living Decisions
description: She thought her father, who was 70 and a retired teacher, could use some help. He handled all his personal care, but shopping and cooking and laundry were beginning to tax him. Hed fallen several times.

title: Private Equitys Get Out of Jail Free Cards
description: BERLIN  What was private equitys key to survival during the financial crisis?

title: Craft Brings Back Old-Timers to Celebrate Its Birthday
description: Tom Colicchio will celebrate the 10th anniversary of his restaurant Craft on Monday with culinary fireworks. He has called on five alumni of the restaurant to help with the cooking.

title: They Eat What They Want
description: In Wednesdays Dining section, the writer Henry Alford offers an appreciation of the elderly who, in the face of all advice to the contrary, continue to eat the foods they love.

title: Wednesday Reading: Why Performance Reviews Are Unfair
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Cooking With Coconut Oil
description: Whether coconut oil is good or bad for you remains a topic of debate in the nutrition community. But as Melissa Clark reports on Wednesday in the Dining section, coconut oil is winning some fans.

title: Fte Accompli | Salute to a Baldwin
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#866", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: LaCies Thunderbolt-Enabled Hard Drive
description: To paraphrase Cracker, what the world needs now is another computer peripheral connection standard like I need a hole in the head. However, Apple has just put their might behind something theyre calling Thunderbolt, a new type of data port that can transfer data at speeds up to 10 gigabits per second. Considering that the fastest USB 2.0 drives can transfer data at about 480 megabits per second (thats 0.46 Gbps or, in laymans terms, really slow), Thunderbolt may be a welcome change.

title: Gay Group Joins Fight Against Wal-Mart
description: As Wal-Mart strives to open its first store in New York City, it has attracted a long list of opponents, from elected officials to labor leaders to small business people.

title: Ovechkins Solo Effort Leads to Overtime Goal
description: Alex Ovechkin scored an overtime goal on Monday by combining all of the skills that make him one of the most dynamic athletes in sports.

title: 3 Are Dead After Bronx Man Sets Apartment Afire, Police Say
description: 11:09 p.m. | Updated  A Bronx man fatally stabbed his wife Wednesday morning, then set fire to their fifth-floor apartment, killing their 1-year-old daughter and himself, the authorities said.

title: ReTweet | Galliano Headed to Rehab
description: Suzy Menkes

title: Theater World Remembers a Critic
description: A celebration of the life of Michael Kuchwara, a widely read theater critic and writer for The Associated Press for 25 years, raised $30,000 on Monday night to support research and advocacy for a cure for pulmonary fibrosis, the disease that took his life last May.

title: Pakistani Minister Was Ready to Die
description: As my colleagues Salman Massod and Jane Perlez report, Shahbaz Bhatti, Pakistans minorities minister, was shot dead on Wednesday morning as he left his home.

title: Eugene Fodor, Violin Virtuoso, Dies at 60
description: Eugene Fodor, an American violinist who made international headlines in the 1970s after earning a top prize in the Tchaikovsky Competition and in the 1980s after being arrested on drug charges, died on Saturday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 60.

title: Further Reading on Agricultural Subsidies
description: Start by taking the Environmental Working Groups farm subsidy database out for a spin: itll show you how much money the government doles out, and who is on the other end. Note that President Obamas proposed budget would cap direct payments to farmers. The House of Representatives isnt on board. No surprises there.

title: Timely | Frankie Rose
description: Frankie Rose may be a little commitment-challenged  she played drums for Vivian Girls, Dum Dum Girls and Crystal Stilts but never hung around long enough to be considered part of any of those bands  but there is no questioning her status as a crusader of Brooklyns indie-pop scene. Lately, Rose has been fronting her own retro-pop group, Frankie and the Outs. While it was a scary transition, it was a natural progression for me, too, she says of her move from behind the drum kit to guitar and vocals. I really did just get tired of playing the drums. And after touring her joyful, self-titled debut album, she is back in Brooklyn, which she calls the best place in the world, in search of inspiration for her next album.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Model of N.B.A. Success Has Fallen Into Disarray
description: DETROIT  The Detroit Pistons appear to be in chaos, a startling state for a franchise that has clicked so well on so many levels over the past decade.

title: Now Just a Muggle, With Song and Dance
description: THE most famous 21-year-old on the planet came barreling into a West Village diner one wintry February morning, desperately craving Belgian waffles. He was bleary eyed, scruffy and stubbly but energetic despite the early hour, and slightly winded after rushing from the previous restaurant chosen for him, which was closed because of a gas leak.

title: Teixeira Drops Boras as His Agent
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Mark Teixeira used to be the editor of his high school newspaper, which gives him an appreciation of news cycles and how reporters do their jobs. So when Teixeira decided to drop Scott Boras as his agent, he asked Jason Zillo, the Yankees media relations director, to send beat reporters to his locker early Wednesday morning to answer all of their questions at once, rather than wait for the news to leak out.

title: Alfa Romeo 4C Concept: America Bound?
description: GENEVA  Could the 4C be the vehicle that finally brings Alfa Romeo back into the United States market? Alfa says, Yes.

title: Doug Morris to Take Reins at Sony Music
description: 8:16 p.m. | Updated Doug Morris, a longtime power broker of the record business as the head of the Universal Music Group, is taking over the reins of Sony Music Entertainment, Universals biggest rival, Sony announced on Wednesday.

title: Warren Buffett Hints at Next Deal
description: Warren Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, explains why Berkshire will have more luck buying private businesses than public companies, in this video interview with CNBCs Becky Quick.

title: Lianghui
description: Chinese term meaning two meetings  recently appropriated by protesters to evade Chinas censors. (The term usually refers to meetings of the National Peoples Congress and the Chinese Peoples Political Consultative Conference.)

title: Christie Says He Could Win Presidency, but Still Wont Run
description: The ample self-confidence that Chris Christie displays in governing New Jersey apparently extends to the long, punishing, unpredictable pursuit of the presidency.

title: Justices Rule for Protesters at Military Funerals
description: WASHINGTON  The First Amendment protects hateful protests at military funerals, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday in an 8-to-1 decision.

title: Unexpected Costs of Kids
description: Children are expensive. As a financial reporter, blogger and author of the Dollars and Sense column over at sfgate.com, Lisa Schmeiser knew that. Really. And she thought she was prepared.

title: Popcorn With a Little Extra
description: In my article about coconut oil on Wednesday, I mentioned in passing a recipe for popcorn cooked in coconut oil. In my view, I think it is a perfect way to make popcorn. But if you want to get slightly fancier, try this double coconut version. The coconut flakes get brown and toasty and the mustard seeds add zing. If you dont have mustard seeds, leave them (and that step) out and add a pinch of cayenne to the coconut flakes instead.

title: Nine Afghan Boys Collecting Firewood Killed by NATO Helicopters
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Nine boys collecting firewood to heat their homes in the eastern Afghanistan mountains were killed by NATO helicopter gunners who mistook them for insurgents, according to a statement on Wednesday by NATO, which apologized for the mistake.

title: My Congressman *Is* A Rocket Scientist
description: Thats what Rush Holt bumper stickers say. And its true! He beat Watson the computer on Jeopardy.

title: Art Collective Announces Cross-Country Road Trip to Inspire Art Students
description: It might not be the Merry Pranksters  hallucinogenic drugs and sex will almost certainly be absent  but the New York art collective known as the Bruce High Quality Foundation has decided to embark on a cross-country road trip, in a limousine painted to look like a school bus. (The Pranksters traveled in an actual school bus, a beaten-up 1939 International Harvester.)

title: Subtropical Wisconsin
description: Via Digby, Fox News shows us film of violent protests in Wisconsin. Except notice the people in shirtsleeves and the palm trees in the background.

title: Growing Up Potter
description: Daniel Radcliffe, who stars in the revival of Equus, is best known as Harry Potter on film.

title: Stable Boy
description: Photos of Daniel Radcliffe in the revival of Equus.

title: F.D.A. Orders Prescription Cold Drugs Pulled From Market
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday ordered that about 500 prescription drugs used to treat colds, coughs and allergies be removed from the market, saying that the medicines had never gone through a federal review of their safety and effectiveness.

title: Oaklands Plan to Cash in on Marijuana Farms Hits Federal Roadblock
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  For a brief, smoky moment last fall, this economically challenged city seemed poised to become the nations most aggressive when it comes to growing and taxing medical marijuana.

title: Color Commentary
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#471", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: With Pixel, Tata Gives the Continent Another Try
description: GENEVA  Tata Motors introduced its Pixel concept here Tuesday in an effort to show what a Europeanized Nano would look like.

title: Shooting at Germany Airport Kills 2 U.S. Airmen
description: FRANKFURT  Two United States airmen on their way to Afghanistan were killed and two others were wounded Wednesday when a gunman opened fire on an American military bus at the Frankfurt airport, according to American military officials in Europe and the German police.

title: Obama Signs Two-Week Budget Extension
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama called on Wednesday for high-level negotiations to bridge major budgetary differences between Congressional Republicans and Democrats after the Senate passed a measure to buy at least two more weeks for talks.

title: How to Wink for an Uprising
description: Facebook and Twitter are now well-known aids to the revolutionaries in Northern Africa and the Middle East. And so the opponents of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, with their social-media accounts being watched by the Libyan government, needed to find a new way to send messages over the Internet that would escape the notice of the police. One solution: Omar Shibliy Mahmoudi, a leader among the Libyan antigovernment protesters, set up a fake profile on Mawada, the most popular dating site in Libya.

title: Scientologys Message Machine
description: Doesnt it seem as if the Church of Scientology has been all over prime-time TV lately? The ads werent made in response to Lawrence Wrights Scientology expos/Paul Haggis profile in The New Yorker (they were first shown last August), but it does seem as if the numerous and prominent recent ad buys (30 Rock, the Today show) are an attempt at damage control.

title: Bank of America Hires a Citi Banker
description: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has plucked a top Citigroup banker, Paul Simpson, to lead its global treasury solutions unit.

title: Fox News Suspends Gingrich and Santorum
description: 12:50 p.m. | Updated | The Fox News Channel said Wednesday that it had suspended the contracts of two employees, Newt Gingrich and Rick Santorum, who are considering running for president.

title: Score One for the Players
description: Although we are hunkered down for a long season of N.F.L. labor discontent  equipment includes airport-style earmuffs and a device that can change a TV channel to a gardening show at the first mention of the word lockout  a little ray of common sense emanated from a federal judge on Tuesday. He essentially called out the owners for rigging their television deals so they could afford a lockout.

title: AMC to Give Autism Film National Exposure
description: A little documentary about autism  playing in a multiplex? AMC, one of the largest movie theater chains in North America, plans to announce on Thursday that it will give a film about two men with autism, Wretches & Jabberers, a national theatrical run. The feature documentary, directed by Gerardine Wurzburg (who won an Oscar in 1992 for the short Educating Peter, about a boy with Down syndrome), will have a one-week run starting April 1 at the AMC Empire 25 in Manhattan.

title: Live Blogging the iPad 2 Announcement
description: Plenty of tech pundits are calling 2011 the year of the tablet. Apple is hoping to make it the year of the iPad. The company summoned reporters to an event in San Francisco on Wednesday, where it unveiled a new version of its popular tablet computer. Follow the live blog here.

title: Pushback on Ruin Porn of Detroit
description: If you have any friends from Detroit on Facebook or Twitter, you probably heard from them even as the Imported From  Detroit ad for Chrysler was winding down during the Super Bowl. Despite some debate over the meaning of the ad, which featured Eminem, it was a rare, two-minute bit of pushback from ruin porn: online pictures, mostly generated by visitors, of the thousands of abandoned houses, businesses and civic buildings in Detroit.

title: The Way We Blog Now
description: Hello? Hello!

title: Alex Steffen, a Designing Optimist
description: Anyone following this blog is aware that there are smart, informed people in this world with completely divergent views of the sources of human progress and problems and the best route forward as populations and appetites crest in coming decades.

title: The Liberation of Lori Berenson
description: Lori Berenson has always loved to walk. When she was a high-school student in Manhattan in the mid-1980s, she walked home at night from her job at Pasta & Cheese, on the Upper East Side, to the apartment where she grew up, on East 25th Street. When she began her prison sentence in Peru, in 1996, for collaborating with a terrorist group, convicted terrorists had to spend 23 hours a day inside their cells. Even then, Berenson walked in the 6-by-9-foot space she and another woman shared  two steps forward, two steps backward  for hours. People ask, what did you miss most? she said in August, two and a half months after she was released on parole, having served nearly 15 years of a 20-year sentence. This was definitely it.

title: Would You Consider Buying Down?
description: In an audio podcast and article, The Chronicle of Higher Education explores whether more of this years college applicants are buying down  which the publication defines as settling for second best or second choice, if the price is more appealing.

title: B.Y.U. Dismisses Starting Forward
description: Brigham Young Universitys storybook basketball season has added an unexpected page, thanks to the surprise suspension of the starting sophomore forward Brandon Davies  on Tuesday.

title: Whats Next for J. Crew
description: The J. Crew buyout saga reached its culmination on Tuesday. Shareholders approved the transaction by a substantial margin, with about 64 percent of investors voting for the takeover.

title: A Chat With the Mother Who Knows Best
description: It was the aphorism heard round the world. The moral of the story is, listen to your mother, Tom Hooper said, accepting his Oscar for best director Sunday night, after recounting how his Australian-born mum led him to the material that became The Kings Speech. The phrase instantly lit up Twitter and became fodder for guilt-inducing (or -induced) messages between parents and children. In a night notable mostly for its flubs, it was one of the few memorable lines.

title: Through the Looking Glass With Ambac
description: If the claims by the Internal Revenue Service are true, Ambac has managed to pull off something that Lehman Brothers could not: force the government to provide a bailout. Ambac got its bailout by receiving more than $700 million in tax refunds that the I.R.S. now argues were unwarranted.

title: The Full Text of John Gallianos Statement
description: Here is the full text of a statement issued on Wednesday by the recently dismissed Dior designer John Galliano through his London law firm, Harbottle & Lewis:

title: There but for the Grace of Lehman
Are You Optimistic About the Future?
description: David Brooks: Gail, Im looking at the Queen Mary. Im at a hotel in Long Beach, Calif., for the TED conference, which is a gathering of really smart people who have job titles like chief disruption officer at various tech firms.

title: Gridiron and Steel Toughened Judge In Clemens Case
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Book on Obamas Mother
description: One of the most fascinating figures to emerge from the story of President Obama  his mother, Stanley Ann Dunham  is the subject of a wide-ranging biography to be released in May, the books publisher said on Wednesday. A Singular Woman, by Janny Scott, will be published by Riverhead Books, an imprint of Penguin Group USA.

title: Photos of the Moment | Damir Doma
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#584", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Martial Vivot, Barber to the Famous and Not-Quite
description: MARK RONSON, the ubiquitous D.J., has sat in his chair and surrendered his bouffant to whim. So has the chef Daniel Boulud, the Miami financier Josh Gilinski and a menagerie of moguls who think nothing about flying him across the country for a shave and a haircut.

title: Eddie Borgo: Its All About Him
description: Paris

title: Product of the Pros: Coupons
description: Nancy Cook, vice president of new media business development for the coupon provider Valpak, says she doesnt tend to base her shopping decisions on what she has coupons for. Instead, she looks for coupons for things she plans to buy anyway.

title: A Small Business Made to Seem Bigger
description: People who run a business alone often want it to appear bigger than it really is  as if it has teams of employees and unlimited resources. This is now more possible than ever thanks to some tools that so-called solopreneurs and other small businesses have at their disposal, giving them the reach and capabilities of far bigger companies.

title: ABC Draws Viewers as Sheen Talks Again
description: The story of Charlie Sheen continued to generate hit television ratings Tuesday night, as a special edition of the ABC news program 20/20 attracted more than double the number of viewers that the network typically draws on that night.

title: In This Family, Turning Heads Is Not Enough
description: WHO are those girls?

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Hotels should start offering packages for fugitive lawmakers, called Club Fled. 2. One of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis only friends on the international scene is Silvio Berlusconi. A Night at the Roxbury, Mediterranean edition.

title: Tech Tools That Can Help a Small Business Seem Big
description: I got a sneak peak at Eilene Zimmermans guide to tools that can help a small business seem big, and I have to say it got me thinking. While it doesnt try to be a comprehensive look at the various software and service options available to small businesses  that would be a never-ending project  it offers some nice, quick illustrations of the fact that no matter what your company oryour problem, somebody probably has a high-tech tool to help you deal with it. Sometimes you dont even know you have a problem until you stumble on the tool that solves it.

title: For P.S. 22 Chorus, Theres No Place Like Home
description: When the wheels were up on the two Continental Airlines flights from Los Angeles carrying the 64 Staten Island public school students home from their star turn singing the finale at the Academy Awards, the chorus squirmed in their seats with triumphant joy. But on Tuesday evening, they landed with a thump.

title: The Enduring Call of the Wild, at Any Age
description: ANIMAL hats are the winter trend that refuses to die.

title: Qaddafi Vows to Fight to the Last Man
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Amid new reports of fighting between his security forces and rebels seeking his ouster, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi took time out today to deliver a meandering, disjointed three-hour speech mixing a combination of giveaways to the public, promises of reform, and vows of retaliation in an apparent bid to quell the growing unrest here.

title: On Patrol Under 'Karzai's Twelve'
description: An American patrol left before dusk to hand out letters to Afghan villagers, but its work was interrupted by night and the rules that govern it.

title: Jazz and Black History on Embassy Row
description: If the rhythm of jazz pulsing through the halls of the Turkish ambassadors residence in Washington sounded a bit unusual last night, all the more so in the days of the Great Depression when the teenaged sons of the ambassador welcomed jazz musicians to perform in the mansion.

title: John Galliano to Face Trial in France
description: John Galliano may face up to six months in prison for his alleged racist outbursts in a Paris cafe, according to French prosecutors, who decided to put the British designer on trial after a police inquiry.

title: Risks to Obama in Oil Price Instability
description: The price of oil is on the rise  above $100 a barrel in overnight markets  while President Obamas approval ratings may be on the decline.

title: Vantage Point: Restraint After Dark
description: Imagine that you were a soldier sent to fight the insurgency in Afghanistan, and assigned to an area where the Taliban were strong. Now imagine that you were told, by both your officers and by the Afghan government that your country was underwriting, that you were forbidden from searching inside buildings after the sun went down. What might you think of this prohibition, knowing that Taliban gunmen and bomb-makers were unimpeded by any such rules?

title: Gingrich Advisers Explain Mixed Signals
description: Presidential announcements are typically carefully scripted affairs, with significant thought given to timing, location and all other details in order to create a good first impression of a candidate and his campaign.

title: How Big Is the Pension Funding Gap?
description: As I mentioned in my column this week, the accounting assumptions behind the valuing of government pensions go a long way toward determining whether government workers appear to be overpaid  and also toward determining how much long-term fiscal trouble state and local governments face.

title: A Russian-Language Daily Hits the Streets
description: Walking around Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, its hard to grasp that problems are roiling the newspaper business.

title: Honor Code Separates B.Y.U. From Other Teams
description: When the sophomore center Brandon Davies was dismissed from Brigham Youngs third-ranked basketball team Tuesday for violating the universitys honor code, it dealt a hard blow to the championship aspirations of the Cougars. But it also highlighted one of the big differences between B.Y.U. and other universities involved in major college sports.

title: New Site for Consumers on the Health Care Law
description: A coalition of health care and advocacy groups started a new Web site this week that seeks to help Americans understand what can seem like confusing changes that are beginning to occur under the new health care law.

title: Off the Menu: From Bagatelle to Beaumarchais
description: Beaumarchais Menu

title: Scene City: Emergency Party
description: The Emergency Party at Santos Party House was a back-to-the-80s night, when the art world and clubbing were synonymous.

title: Now Screening | Dries Van Noten
description: The fall 2011 collection of Dries Van Noten at Paris Fashion Week.

title: A Feverish Warm-Up to the Art Fair
description: WITH the Armory Show starting today, the city is awash in highbrow soirees and their requisite Champagne and canaps. But for those who dont need a big art fair as an excuse to dance the night away, there are still places where art feels like an extension of a rave in a colorful bomb shelter.

title: Now Screening | Dries Van Noten
description: The fall 2011 collection from Dries Van Noten at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Populism and the Partisan Mind
description: Speaking of the Tea Party, I enjoyed this Will Wilkinson post analogizing the ongoing public-sector union rallies in Wisconsin to the right-wing protests of the last two years. And I especially enjoyed his follow-up defending the analogy:

title: Wheelies: The Enthusiasts Lament Edition
description: In which we bring you automotive news from around the Web:

title: China to Unveil Its Strategy to Rebalance Robust Economy
description: BEIJING  The agendas for Chinas two quasi legislatures this week include proposals to raise taxes on gas-guzzling cars, crack down on drunken driving and improve food safety, most of them predigested by the Communist Partys leadership and destined for rote approval. About the only uncertainty involves the one topic that will get the most attention: the future of Chinas roaring economy.

title: Radiohead Succeeds, Despite Itself
description: Once again, the counterintuitive Radiohead model for success somehow seems to be working. The key appears to be this: Do the opposite of whatever youre supposed to do.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Crackdown on Wall Street Bonuses
description: 8:28 p.m. | Updated

title: Apps to Keep Your Dog Healthy, Active and, Maybe, Quiet
description: Im part owner of a nervous little dog with a bark like an ice pick through my brain and a tendency to use that weapon at random, several times a day.

title: Levine Replacements for Carnegie Concerts Are Named
description: The Carnegie Hall concerts this month that the conductor James Levine will miss because of health problems will be led by a colleague at the Boston Symphony Orchestra, a conductor also familiar to the orchestra, and a newcomer, according to a statement from the Boston Symphony press office.

title: Jobs Returns to Introduce a New iPad
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, interrupted his medical leave on Wednesday to introduce the companys much-anticipated new iPad, a thinner, faster and lighter version of its popular tablet computer that will sell at the same prices as the original models.

title: Elton John Documentary, Directed by Cameron Crowe, Will Open Tribeca Film Festival
description: If Cameron Crowe could make a memorable scene with just a couple of verses of Elton John  as he did when the Almost Famous cast sang Tiny Dancer in the back of that tour bus  imagine what he could do with an entire movie about him? Audiences at the Tribeca Film Festival will be among the first to find out: the festivals organizers said on Wednesday that their 2011 program will open on the night of April 20 with a free outdoor screening of The Union, Mr. Crowes documentary about Mr. John, followed by a performance from that best-selling pop performer.

title: Lori Berenson Speaks
description: In 2010, Simon Romero interviewed Lori Berenson who spent more than a decade in a Peruvian prison for collaborating with a Marxist terrorist group.

title: Graphic Content | Andrew Byrom
description: Typography is now a bona fide art form. Some artists and graphic designers are turning typefaces into paintings and even sculpture. Andrew Byrom, a British-born type designer and professor at California State University at Long Beach, is a typographic conceptualist  a sculptor by any other name  who creates experimental typefaces out of Band-Aids, drinking straws, steel railings and neon lights. He has also turned them into objects like furniture, bathroom fixtures and kites.

title: In Jordan, Some Regret a Missed Opportunity
description: AMMAN  Two weeks ago, Manal, 27, dressed in a black robe, walked slowly in a crowd of several hundred demonstrators  mostly men  carrying children, waving Jordanian flags or holding up homemade protest signs near the prime ministers office.

title: Writers No One Reads?
description: I always thought I was a reader of obscure writers until I found this Tumblr blog, courtesy of GalleyCat. Of 30 Writers No One Reads, Id heard of5 and read 3. (Of these, I own a book by one, which Ive barely cracked. In my defense, a cursory glance at an E. M. Cioran text gives you a feelfor what lies within: Its not worth the bother of killing yourself, since youalways kill yourself too late.) You can nominate your own unread favorite, andif you dont have one, the cover art alone is worth a scroll  theres even aphoto of the ever-glamorous Clarice Lispector.

title: A Test Where the Banks Had the Questions and the Answers
description: Later this month, the Federal Reserve is going to let banks know how they did on its most recent round of stress tests.

title: Fed Notes Modest to Moderate Growth of Economy
description: Economic activity in the United States expanded at a modest to moderate pace in the early part of the year, as retail sales and manufacturing grew in all but a few regions of the country, according to a survey of the Federal Reserves 12 districts released on Wednesday.

title: Fighting Disease: Researching the History and Biology of Vaccines
description: Overview  | What is a vaccine, and why do we need them? How do vaccines work, and how were they developed? In this lesson, students gauge their previous knowledge about vaccines. They then explore the history and biology of vaccines and create educational posters on the nature of vaccines and public opinions about them.

title: Ohio Senate Approves Union Bill
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Ohio took its first step Wednesday toward passing sweeping legislation that would curtail collective bargaining rights for public sector workers by banning strikes and putting the power of breaking labor impasses in the hands of local elected officials.

title: Is Apple Losing Its Core?
description: The veil of secrecy that shrouds Apple Computer Inc. is both impenetrable and legendary, and a continuing source of frustration for those on the outside looking in.

title: James Levine to Resign as Music Director of Boston Symphony Orchestra
description: James Levine, dogged by a relentless series of health problems, said on Wednesday that he would resign as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, concluding that he could no longer handle the job along with his duties in the same post at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: What If? In Next Novel, Stephen King Imagines a Chance To Alter the JFK Presidency
description: In early 2002, Stephen King said he was written out and was thinking of retiring. Some retirement. He has since published at least four novels, a couple of story collections and has collaborated on a monthly comic book. On Wednesday, Scribner, his publisher, announced that in the fall it will bring out yet another King novel, called 11/23/63.

title: Steppenwolf Theater Company to Tackle Doctorows Civil War Novel
description: Frank Galati, a Tony Award winner in 1990 for best play and best director for his adaptation of John Steinbecks Grapes of Wrath, is undertaking a similarly enormous new work at his artistic home, the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago: a 27-actor production next year of E. L. Doctorows Civil War novel, The March.

title: The Samurai Shopper | Pencil This In
description: Imagine the technology that creates real objects like medical implants, lampshades, car parts and mobile phones by hitting Print and sending digital files to inkjet printers. Its already happening. The ink is actually material that gets deposited in successive layers; after one layer is complete, the next follows, until solid objects emerge. One American company is now trying to print an entire car this way.

title: Israelis Float an Interim Peace Plan
description: JERUSALEM  There were signs on Wednesday of a new effort to restart the Israeli-Palestinian peace process after months of stagnation, but chances of a resumption of talks looked slim, and Israel appeared to be stepping back from the stated goal of reaching a framework agreement resolving the core issues of the conflict by September.

title: Keith Richardss Daughter Charged With Graffiti Tagging
description: It is not one of their big hits, but the Rolling Stones song Little T & A from Tattoo You, sung by Keith Richards, seems to have worked its way into one fans consciousness.

title: Automakers Big Green Party Is Also a Masquerade Ball
description: GENEVA

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia, Yemen and Egypt.

title: If You Get Confused, Listen to the Music Play
description: We lost a lot of brain cells out on the road with the Grateful Dead, but maybe we gained some, too. Witness The Music Never Stopped, a film adaptation of Oliver Sackss account of a man who is unable to store new memories after a brain tumor ravages his frontal lobe. It is discovered that music  particularly the Deads  is able to penetrate the barrier ever so slightly and help the man to reconnect with himself and his family. Some facts (some big ones) from Sackss essay, The Last Hippie, seem to have been altered and molded into a workable movie narrative, naturally, and I worry that Sackss poignantly honest account will have received a Hollywood face-lift. But maybe the film will surprise us, as did the melancholy but still-hopeful ending to Awakenings.

title: Friends on Facebook, Before Death Interrupted
description: The online profiles of two young women at the center of a Brooklyn homicide case  an 18-year-old murder suspect and the 22-year-old friend whom she is accused of killing  offer reflections of their broken lives.

title: The Amr Moussa Futures Fund
description: Want an easy way to predict the downfall of Arab governments? Follow Amr Moussa. When the former Egyptian foreign minister and longtime general secretary of the Arab League showed up in Tahrir Square on Friday, Feb. 4, I turned to a colleague  I really did!  and said words to this effect: Amr Moussa never sticks his neck out. Mubarak is finished. Soon history fell in neatly behind.

title: An Autobiography in Pictures
description: For three years, Christian Hansen was a freelancer for The Times and other publications. Now 26, he is studying journalism at Western Kentucky University. His work captures life as it happens. This conversation with Kerri MacDonald, in the Turning Point series, has been edited.

title: Jury Doesnt Indict Man in Police Shooting
description: A special grand jury in Manhattan has declined to indict a man at the center of a chaotic police-shooting case in Harlem last summer in which police officers who were breaking up a block party ended up firing 46 bullets, several of them striking the man.

title: TimesCast | March 2, 2011
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces try to take back eastern Libya, but rebels stand firm; a photographic essay on the lives of Bahrani women.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia, Yemen and Egypt.
