description: In a splendid posting on the OUP Blog, concerning theunswerving authority accorded to the dictionary, Elizabeth Knowles observed:

title: Beauty Spots
description: A SILVER ANNIVERSARY

title: Vampire Face-Lifts: Smooth at First Bite
description: IN this anti-aging age, perhaps its unsurprising that vampires  ancient, but with forever-young skin  are a cultural obsession. Now a cosmetic treatment to fill in wrinkles or to plump up hollow cheeks is being marketed as a vampire filler or a vampire face-lift.

title: 'The Orchid Show: On Broadway'
description: Marc Hachadourian, the orchid curator at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, narrates a look at preparations for this year's Broadway-themed orchid show.

title: Council Speaker Criticizes Article on Cancer Group
description: The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, sharply challenged a report in The New York Times on Wednesday that raised questions about the Councils generous support of a program that offers free brain scans to city residents.

title: On Location | A Home on the Yucatn
description: The home was created from a former one-room nursery school, which included a bathroom set up in an out building in the backyard.

title: Judge Unexpectedly Imprisons Ex-Goldman Programmer
description: A federal judge has unexpectedly locked up the former Goldman Sachs programmer found guilty of stealing the investment banks computer code.

title: Former Louisiana Governor to Explore Presidential Bid, Report Says
description: Politics abhors a vacuum, and so without any announced presidential candidates, candidates are beginning to jump into the Republican primary.

title: Rich in History and Colorful Designs
description: VALLADOLID, MEXICO  A shared love of Mexican history and craft are what led Nicolas Malleville, an Argentine model, and his wife, Francesca Bonato, an Italian fashion designer, to buy a 16th-century home here in this small city on the Yucatn peninsula.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: McKinsey, the Root of All Evil? Barry Ritholtz seems to think so: Where ever there has been a financial disaster in the world, if you look around, somewhere in the background, McKinsey & Company is nearby. The Big Picture

title: The Lowdown | Sophie Morner
description: Sophie Morner has been a central figure in what has come to be a new photography movement in and around Brooklyn. As the founder and owner of the widely respected Capricious Magazine and the soon-to-close Capricious Gallery, she has provided exposure for young, up-and-coming photographers, as well as the often marginalized work of people deeply embedded in queer culture. Morner is an avid equestrian as well as an artist, and her simultaneous passions for gender ambiguity and horses weave a curious pair of threads through much of her work and curatorial choices.

title: Katori Hall Wins Blackburn Prize for Outstanding Women Playwrights
description: Katori Hall, a 29-year-old playwright from Memphis whose work examines the historical and social forces affecting African-American characters, has been named the 33rd winner of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize. The award is given annually to outstanding women playwrights. Ms. Hall received $20,000 and a signed and numbered print by the artist Willem de Kooning for her play Hurt Village, about the problems of families in a decaying Memphis housing project.

title: Whats Behind Banks New Legal Disclosure
description: Whats in a number, anyway?

title: In Montreal, a Loft in a Former Office Building
description: A loft apartment in a 1920s building in Old Montreal is on the market for $1.07 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Montreal
description: A LOFT APARTMENT IN A FORMER OFFICE BUILDING IN OLD MONTREAL

title: News Corp. Offers to Spin Off Sky News
description: 9:01 p.m. | Updated

title: Driver Accused of Injuring Brazil Cyclists
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The monthly bicycle ride known as Critical Mass began in the southern city of Porto Alegre as such rides do in cities around the world: with activist cyclists riding through downtown streets, blocking traffic, ringing bells and shouting slogans about the environment and the superiority of bicycling for transportation over driving.

title: Taymor Feeling the Heat Over Spider-Man
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  Julie Taymor, the director of the new Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, said on Wednesday that she was currently in the crucible and the fire of transformation as she and her collaborators continue to work on improving the show.

title: Homes for $300,000
description: An adobe in Tucson, an antebellum house in rural North Carolina and a contemporary town house in Tulsa, Okla.

title: What You Get for ... $300,000
description: TUCSON

title: Washington Ads Hit Wisconsin Airwaves
description: 7:07 p.m. | Updated As the Wisconsin public workers protests against Gov. Scott Walkers plan to strip their collective bargaining rights stretches into its 17th day, national groups on both sides are launching air strikes. But neither sides advertisements seem geared to help end the stalemate.

title: Investigating Droughts and Maya Collapse
description: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal.

title: With Sharp Declarer Play, England Wins the Junior Camrose
description: The Junior Camrose for players under 25 was contested on Feb. 19 and 20 in Ayr, Scotland, among England, Northern Ireland, the Republic of Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

title: Black Watch Will Return For a Third Run at St. Anns Warehouse
description: A newly cast production of Black Watch, the hit play from Edinburgh about a harrowing tour of duty in Iraq by a legendary Scottish Army regiment, will be performed at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn for a limited run, April 16-May 8, the theater announced on Wednesday.

title: Wisconsin! as a Battle Cry in Albany
description: ALBANY  We are not Wisconsin, State Senator Suzi Oppenheimer, a Democrat from Westchester County, told a packed hearing room on Tuesday.

title: A Citrus Gelatin Dessert Shakes the Mold
description: I recently had a citrus fruit-based trifle and it brought to mind a citrus terrine I had eaten years ago at Astier, a restaurant in Paris. I am not sure if it is still on the menu, but it basically was made up of grapefruit and orange segments held together in a mold by their own gelled juice. Was there a thin layer of cake? I dont think so; just fruit, juice and gelatin, and a little Grand Marnier.

title: John Galliano: An Ability to Shock
description: A sensible designer would have pleaded insanity and zipped off to rehab, but Mr. Galliano is not a sensible man, any more than fashion chiefs are missionaries.

title: Paper in Egypt Says Mubarak Is at Saudi Site Receiving Care
description: Speculation that former President Hosni Mubarak had departed Egypt for Saudi Arabia heightened Wednesday with a government-owned newspaper saying that he had gone late last week to a special Saudi military complex at Tabuk for chemotherapy treatment by his usual German doctors. He is suffering from pancreatic and colon cancer, it said.

title: Hardcover Business Best Sellers
John Galliano Exits the Way That He Entered
description: Paris

title: Paperback Business Best Sellers
Behind the Persian Veil: Theater Illuminating the Iranian Experience
description: Iran has a sophisticated millennial culture, but it is sometimes hard for Americans to discern that through the haze generated by a theocracys tirades and the global controversy over the countrys nuclear program. That is one of the main reasons that the Brick Theater is sponsoring an Iranian Theater Festival, to undo stereotypes and misconceptions.

title: Words and Music: A Jazz Trumpeter Plays, Sings and Blogs
description: Whats going on with Nicholas Payton? If youre in any way part of the jazz citizenry, you probably understand the question. Mr. Payton, a ferociously gifted trumpeter originally from New Orleans, has spent much of his career sidestepping expectations. Over the last few years especially, he has made contrarianism a usable facet of his art, pushing back against the script in deftly inscrutable ways.

title: Adele Is No. 1
description: Adele, the British singer who won the Grammy Award for best new artist two years ago, is the big winner on the Billboard chart this week, with a No. 1 opening for her new album and a rebound for her last one. Adeles new album, 21 (XL/Columbia), opened with 352,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Thanks to a blitz of television appearances to promote the album, that was the best opening-week sales of any album in three months. (In the interim, there have been some painfully low numbers.) And her debut album, 19, bolted 34 spots to No. 16, with 18,000 sales. But almost everything else on the chart is a loser. Last weeks No. 1, Justin Biebers Never Say Never: The Remixes (Island), fell to No. 2 with 102,000, a 38 percent decline, and Mr. Biebers My World 2.0, at No. 5, lost 22 percent. Mumford & Sons Sigh No More (Glassnote), at No. 3, dropped 46 percent; Now Thats What I Call Music! Vol. 37 is No. 4 with a 38 percent loss; Bruno Marss Doo-Wops & Hooligans (Elektra), at No. 6, lost 40 percent, and so on. Last weeks numbers were higher than usual because of the traditional retail boost the week after the Grammys. But that only underlines the scale of Adeles success. On the digital singles chart, Lady Gagas Born This Way, which was enormously popular out of the gate, lost 44 percent of its sales in its third week, with 286,000, although that was enough for it to hold at No. 1.

title: Edith Whartons World, Recast for Gossip Girl
description: MRS. WILLIAM ASTOR did not network. Cornelius Vanderbilt II never friended anyone on Facebook. Stuyvesant Fish never tweeted. Times, apparently, have changed.

title: Wife on the Rebound, Husband on the Edge
description: Carol Edgarians Three Stages of Amazement shares a surprising amount of common ground with last years most argued-about novel, Jonathan Franzens Freedom. Whatever the overarching themes of either book may be, its the sharply observed detail and intensity that matter: the spectacle of high-strung, hot-blooded, restless people conflating their own private crises with the political and economic turmoil of their times. What Halliburton and the Bush era were to Mr. Franzen, Silicon Valley and the Obama presidency are to Ms. Edgarians turbulent, furiously compelling book.

title: One Way to Encourage Checking-Out at the Library
description: OUTSIDE of college campuses and romantic comedies, the library is not usually a place to pick up a date. But that didnt stop several dozen singles, mostly in their 20s and 30s, from showing up on a recent Tuesday night at the main branch of the San Francisco Public Library for its first speed-dating session.

title: Scorecard Update | Hakaan
description: The fashion critics weigh in on Hakaans fall 2011 collection at Paris Fashion Week.

title: A New Slice of Italian Pie
description: Pizza, a new magazine in Milan, is temptingly named. It caught my eye when a friend brought it to the dinner table. Wait, what is this? I said, pushing back my pasta to crack the thick issue. Dedicated to contemporary art, fashion, music, design and photography, Pizza takes an enlivening look at emerging talent, without many formal art-direction constraints.

title: With PhoeniX Concept, Jason Castriota Hopes to Set Saabs Future in Motion
description: Perhaps the surprise of the Geneva auto shows press previews, which concluded today, was the Saab PhoeniX, a concept that could presage the shape of a new 9-3. But Jason Castriota, the executive design director for Saab, has set off something of a controversy among Saab fans with his vision for the Swedish brands future form.

title: A Grand Stage for a Diva Plant
description: STEP aside, Rose. Its Orchids turn.

title: Trains, Planes, and Automobiles
description: Some of the comments on my various pro-train posts have been along the lines of Oh yeah, try taking the train to Los Angeles. But that, of course, misses the point.

title: Its Back to the Studio, as Oscar Season Ends
description: LOS ANGELES  It was the aphorism heard round the world. The moral of the story is, listen to your mother, Tom Hooper said, accepting his best director Oscar on Sunday night, after recounting how his Australian-born mum had led him to the material that became The Kings Speech. The phrase instantly lit up Twitter and became fodder for guilt-inducing (or induced) messages between parents and children. In a night notable mostly for its flubs, it was one of the few memorable lines.

title: Stravinskys Tales, Dunked in the Spin Cycle
description: The training regimens for aspiring opera singers typically include acting classes, movement workshops, dance lessons, sometimes even tips on fencing. But I wonder if the committed young singers who took part in the director Robert Lepages enchanting production of Stravinskys one-act opera The Nightingale on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music ever anticipated that one day they would be asked to perform demanding vocal parts, in Russian, while sloshing around in 12,000 gallons of water as they deftly manipulated puppet versions of the characters they were portraying.

title: Whos on First? Finds a Home in Chinese Clubs
description: BEIJING  Guo Degang, wearing sunglasses at night, strutted into the club followed by an entourage of sharply dressed men and was shown to an elegant private dining room in the back. He sat down and held court as friends from out of town presented him with gifts of liquor, rare mushrooms and artwork.

title: Violinist Adds Intimate Stage to a Concert Hall Week
description: Between her last two performances of the Britten Violin Concerto with the New York Philharmonic, Janine Jansen played a Monday evening recital at Le Poisson Rouge with the pianist Inon Barnatan. Mr. Barnatan is nearly as busy as Ms. Jansen. Having played a recital of his own on Sunday, he still had to perform music by James MacMillan as part of a Making Music program at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: Levine, Citing Health, Says Hell Leave Boston Symphony
description: James Levine, dogged by a relentless series of health problems, said on Wednesday that he would resign as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, concluding that he could no longer handle the job along with his duties in the same post at the Metropolitan Opera in New York.

title: Storing Your Files Inside the Cloud
description: WHEN the hard drive on Melissa Groves computer failed, she faced the possibility of losing 7,000 Word documents, 600 spreadsheets, hundreds of PowerPoint presentations and 12 years of federal grant applications.

title: How to Make a Quick Response Code
Photos of the Moment | Rochas
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#336", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Dickey Doesnt Take Security for Granted
description: JUPITER, Fla.  For the first time in his career, R.A. Dickey went into his spring training debut knowing that he had not only a spot in the rotation, but a guaranteed contract over two years as well.

title: Dance This Way
description: An outtake from the epic dance video set to Girl Talk's new release.

title: American Ballet Theater Will Return to City Center
description: 12:39 p.m. | Updated When New York City Center announced this week that it was the first performing arts complex in the city to sell tickets directly to iPhone users via a new app, a whiff of dtente was buried in the details. The performances for which one could buy tickets included those by American Ballet Theater. Yet less than a year ago it was unclear when or if American Ballet Theater would return to City Center, its regular fall home.

title: Cable TV in Pursuit of Mobility
description: FOR INTERNAL COMCAST USE ONLY. DO NOT LEAK.

title: The Unknowable Man
description: The wizards over at Politico know that a Marginally Famous Author plus a Specious Comparison of Obama to an Unloved Ex-President equals Web Traffic Gold, and so today they have a predictable essay (picked up by The Drudge Report, of course) by Steve Forbes about how Obama is messing up the environment, just as Jimmy Carter did. I dont want to get into the specifics of Forbess argument here  its pretty boilerplate stuff  but I do want to call your attention to a recent Rolling Stone article about Carter. Its not an apologia, far from it. But it complicates our understanding of our 39th president in necessary ways. By the end of the article  and if you have the patience, the end of the essay Carters old speechwriter Hendrik Hertzberg wrote about him way back when  Carter will feel to you much more like a real man, not just a punching bag who is trotted out every now and again to boost Web stats.

title: Staying in Touch With Technology
description: HERE is the problem with typical elder tech products: theres not enough tech in a phone that uses an oversize keypad but offers limited features, for one example. Advancing age can rob people of their abilities, and products that help mitigate that are good things indeed. But what if the need for that kind of assistance is still decades away? Todays baby boomers are just now crossing the retirement line, but that does not render them incapacitated. Far from it. It may, however, render them out of touch.

title: Resist the Pull of Smartphones, Nintendo Chief Urges Developers
description: The president of Nintendo told video game developers Wednesday that smartphones were driving a trend toward lower quality, and economically unsustainable, video games.

title: Shopping for Chaise Longues With Dufner Heighes
description: The architects Daniel Heighes Wismer and Gregory Dufner, of the firm Dufner Heighes, shopped for classic, luxurious chairs.

title: Chaise Longues
description: A CHAISE LONGUE is an inherently luxurious piece of furniture, at least in a city like New York. Thats what Daniel Heighes Wismer believes, because its about being by yourself, which in itself is a luxurious concept.

title: Youve Got a Fan Club? Network and Mobilize It
description: A few social media early birds found a new kind of recorded message on their smartphones on Monday: Good morning, said a woman in a soft, deep voice. Its February 28th, 2011 A.D. Were on planet Earth; some of us, anyway.

title: Thing Three: Dr. Seuss, Rap and Racism?
description: There is nothing more ridiculous than the cultural insights you derive as a parent, at least the kind that come to you when you are reading The Foot Book or The Sleep Book for the 107th time. I am not the first to notice that Dr. Seusss rhymes sound good declaimed in hip-hop-style. Try it with the opening lines of The Sleep Book. Try it and you will see.

title: Making the Most Out of Less
description: JEFF NELSON, a manager in the Utah Health Department, says he constantly scolds himself for not setting aside more for retirement. Its always there, like that squeaky screen door in back that you want to fix , but you never get to, said Mr. Nelson, 40, the father of a 10-year-old and 7 -year-old. I feel I have more pressing needs. I have to make the house payment. I have to make the car payment.

title: One Secret to Clocking Out May Be a Moving Van
description: IT seems like bait and switch. People who spent their working lives believing that they could retire at 65 or so are looking at their financial statements and thinking that it cant be done. The recession  and maybe their own spending  took too big a bite out of their balances.

title: Nightshade Is Growing Like Weeds
description: NEWS bulletin from the spirit world: The specter of Edward Gorey, who died in 2000 at the age of 75, is haunting our collective unconscious.

title: Gothic Romance
description: More than 10 years after Edward Goreys death, his cult continues to grow.

title: Mugler Gets a Remake, With Help From Lady Gaga
description: In the late 1980s, I bought a Thierry Mugler dress from Linda Dresner and wore it to meet Queen Elizabeth II. You think Im kidding? I met her, with about 1,000 other people, at the Library of Congress. Dont ask me what I was doing there; I couldnt tell you. All I remember is that I loved that dress: black pique, belted, with a wavy Mugler neckline. I still have it, though the shoulders are little bit funny.

title: Boots That Work, So Neatly
description: THERE is no end to the predictions about the toll that global warming will take on our naughty little planet. The jury seems to be out, though, as to its effect on style, the high-waters at Thom Browne notwithstanding.

title: Trading Up: Boot Up
description: Boots for the man who wants something that can pass muster in a place of business.

title: At Moss, an Exhibit Erases the Lines Between Art and Design
description: Arthur, an exhibition challenging the traditional categories of art and design, opens Thursday at Moss, coinciding with the start of Armory Arts Week.

title: Home Tech: More Sound, Fewer Wires
description: Five wireless audio systems that promise better sound with much less electronic interference.

title: Hooked on a Seaside Theme
description: The latest collection from Hable Construction is a dramatic departure from its typical charmingly imperfect, hand-drawn geometries.

title: Sales at Sur la Table, Cappellini and Others
description: During Sur la Tables clearance sale, many items are up to 75 percent off while supplies last (Wsthof Silverpoint II shears and paring knife sets, originally about $20, are about $15; a Cuisinart SmartStick Immersion Blender in buttercup, regularly about $30, is about $22). For information and locations: (800) 243-0852 or surlatable.com.

title: Henrybuilt Moves Beyond the Kitchen
description: Henrybuilt, a company in Seattle known for its meticulously crafted minimalist kitchens, is expanding its line of free-standing furniture. The company previously sold a handful of tables and chairs to complement its kitchens, but were now separating out the furniture business, said the chief executive, Scott Hudson, and producing additional pieces.

title: At Blue Hill at Stone Barns, Plates to Match the Cuisine
description: Diners at Blue Hill at Stone Barns may have noticed a recent addition to the table: porcelain pieces by the ceramicist Dana Brandwein Oates. Ms. Oates, whose company is dbO Home, created a bread-and-butter plate, a platter, a votive candleholder and a vase that are used in service and sold in the gift shop. While the candleholder and vase are relatively free of decoration, the platter has a honeycomb pattern and the bread-and-butter plate, left, bears the imprint of an heirloom grain. They sent me an enormous box of grains  spelt, winter wheat, spring wheat, something called Timothy grass and oats  all tagged. I had no idea there was such a huge variety of wheat, Ms. Oates said. I was looking for what would look best when rolled in the clay.

title: He Keeps Ancient Apples Fresh and Crisp
description: PITTSBORO, N.C.

title: A Colorado Blogger on Losing Her Home to a Fire
description: When Andi OConors house in the foothills west of Boulder, Colo., burned down last September, she began to blog. The Fourmile Canyon wildfire had started one very dry, windy day, sparked by an improperly extinguished fire pit, investigators believe. Flames ravaged the foothills and meadows for 11 days, blackening more than 6,000 acres and destroying 169 homes. Ms. OConor, who is 53 and works as a public speaking coach and writer, drove back from vacation with her little dog, Nellie, a laptop, the clothes packed for traveling and a kayak, only to find that she had nothing else left. Her home, and everything in it, was incinerated, including those few heirlooms salvaged from the fire that destroyed her parents house in Glenview, Ill., when she was a child.

title: Untangling Wireless Audio Systems
description: A FEW years ago I bought a high-end home theater system that promised to surround me in sound when watching Hollywood blockbusters  or, more likely, reruns of Law & Order. But when I unpacked the system, I saw that for the best audio, Id have to surround myself in speaker wires, too.

title: Hardware Store Style
description: A Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, row house is filled with light fixtures made from plumbing parts, tables made from ductwork and other offbeat creations.

title: In Brooklyn, Making It Up as They Go
description: STEPHEN ANTONSON, an artist with a wily and mischievous point of view, is fond of saying that when he makes something, hed like that thing to do more than just lie there. He might throw in a sight gag: a plaster bust of Pan wears a cream pie in his face; a ghostly plaster side table erupts into a fruit bowl.

title: Cubs Return to Fighting Ways
description: PHOENIX  The Chicago Cubs have played so poorly this spring training that when two players fought in their dugout Wednesday, it was not even the main reason to schedule a team meeting. The Cubs lost to the Milwaukee Brewers, 12-5, committing five more errors to push their total to 14 in four exhibition games.

title: Rebel Forces Drive Government Forces Back in Brega
description: Rebel forces in Brega, a strategic oil town, successfully repelled an attack on Wednesday by Libyan government loyalists backed by artillery and war planes, witnesses in the town said.

title: For Frist, a Portrait and a President
description: Bill Frist, the former Senate majority leader, returned to the Capitol Wednesday for the unveiling of his official portrait with a supporting appearance by a man who helped Mr. Frist reach that leadership position  former President George W. Bush.

title: Remodeling Now to Avoid Accessibility Problems Later
description: ON a visit to her friends home in France last fall, Nancy Carlin of Naples, Fla., admired the elegant shower room.

title: Owl Assassin Fined and Suspended in Colombia
description: In the world of Harry Potter, owls are a bridge between the magical and muggle (thats normal folk to me and you) world.

title: A Conspiracy With a Silver Lining
description: As Americans know all too well by this point, commodity prices  for corn, wheat, soybeans, crude oil, gold and even farmland  have been going through the roof for what seems like forever. There are many causes, primarily supply and demand pressures driven by fears about the unrest in the Middle East, the rise of consumerism in China and India, and the Feds $600 billion campaign to increase the money supply.

title: City Drops Plan for 34th St. Pedestrian Plaza
description: In an abrupt concession to community complaints, the Bloomberg administration said Wednesday that it would scrap a plan for a pedestrian plaza on 34th Street in Manhattan that would have banned automobile traffic on the block between Herald Square and the Empire State Building.

title: When Abuse of Older Patients Is Financial
description: DOCTORS with older patients hear clues all the time. Elderly people mention, in passing, that they are missing money or that they signed forms they did not understand. Or maybe they cant find a treasured possession like a watch or a wedding ring.

title: Choosing the Right Executor for Your Estate
description: BEING an executor has always been a time-consuming job. And if the task of sorting through the remnants of someones life and carrying out final wishes was not hard enough, it recently got even more complicated.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,476 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Gaza: Agricultural Exports Resume
description: Israel on Wednesday allowed the export of cherry tomatoes from Gaza for the first time since Hamas took control in 2007, Palestinian officials said. The two and half tons of tomatoes were bound for the Netherlands, which finances agricultural projects in Gaza. The Dutch have received permission to ship more than 450 truckloads of carnations, strawberries and sweet peppers to European markets.

title: Germany: Defense Minister Named
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel appointed Thomas de Maizire, who has been interior minister since 2009, as Germanys defense minister. He replaces Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, who resigned Tuesday over a plagiarism scandal. Mr. Maizire, 57, left, takes over the Defense Ministry at a time of upheaval: conscription is set to end in June, the army is cutting its troop levels to under 190,000 from over 250,000, and German forces will begin withdrawing this year from Afghanistan.

title: A Trainer Who Acts Your Age
description: A good personal trainer should be someone who has a college degree or certification in exercise physiology, and can communicate and motivate.

title: Toned, Strong and a Little Gray, Too
description: WHEN Ellen Guest decided to seek out the services of a personal trainer, she had a mental picture of what that person would look like:

title: South Africa: Spokesman Called Racist
description: Trevor Manuel, leader of the National Planning Commission, said in an open letter on Wednesday that the behavior of the new government spokesman, Jimmy Manyi, was racist in the worst order. In videotaped comments that surfaced recently, Mr. Manyi said there were too many mixed-race South Africans in Western Cape Province. They should spread in the rest of the country, he said. He has apologized.

title: Refined Algorithms and Legal Defense
description: Googles plans to tweak its search algorithms to reduce low-quality links, announced last week, will make the sites users happier. That should help maximize the companys long-term value. But the technology update may also bring an added, less obvious, benefit. It should shore up Googles legal defenses against antitrust regulators.

title: Adding to Income by Caring for Pets That Arent Yours
description: JOHN DARIANO had not planned to be a professional pet sitter when he first started thinking a decade ago about his retirement from the Palm Beach County, Fla., school districts police department.

title: A Planning Aid, but Not a Road Map
description: ONLINE retirement calculators are the equivalent of a financial GPS system. Although they will give you a general idea of how to reach your destination, they wont necessarily show you the best route or steer you away from the worst roads. The calculators are no substitute for a qualified retirement planner.

title: Proposed Malpractice Limits Face a Fight in Albany
description: ALBANY  Last week, hospital leaders stood alongside Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo at the Capitol, pledging their support for billions in cuts proposed by his Medicaid redesign team. This week, they paid for full-page advertisements in newspapers around the state, putting their approval in writing.

title: Laying Claim to a Treat, And Hearing, Not So Fast
description: The whoopie pie consists of two round pieces of chocolate cake, icing and, of late, controversy.

title: Senator Akaka Wont Seek Re-election
description: Senator Daniel Akaka says it is time for him to go home to Hawaii to stay.

title: Justices Appear to Back U.S. on Material Witness Law
description: WASHINGTON  The current Supreme Court is considered a hot bench, meaning one from which advocates may expect a barrage of challenging questions. But the bench was cool on Wednesday at the argument of a case testing how far the government may go in using the federal material witness law to detain and interrogate people it suspects have ties to terrorism.

title: Go Play Golf, but Monitor Your Portfolio Too
description: WITH stock prices advancing smartly  both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poors 500-stock index have gained more than 22 percent in the last six months  retirees who fled to the safety of money market funds and savings accounts when the market plunged in 2008 and 2009 may well want to move some assets back into stocks.

title: Shifting Strategies for Target-Date Funds
description: TARGET-DATE fund managers are not saying so outright, but they have apparently learned a lesson from the 2008 market collapse and the furious reaction of many 401(k) investors. Now, the fund managers are de-emphasizing stocks and adding investments that are more diversified, less likely to make sharp moves and more likely to provide a steady income.

title: Libyas Patient Revolutionaries
description: Benghazi, Libya

title: Agencies Fine and Sue Companies That Purported to Aid Jobless
description: WASHINGTON  A yearlong investigation into allegations that bogus employment and business opportunities had bilked consumers out of millions of dollars has yielded dozens of civil and criminal actions, federal and state officials announced Wednesday.

title: Money Manager to the Stars Going to Jail for Fraud
description: A money manager whose client roster once included Hollywood luminaries like Martin Scorsese and Uma Thurman was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison on Wednesday for siphoning more than $30 million from his clients.

title: Sudoku
description: Every day on NYTimes.com you can solve a new sudoku puzzle that matches your level of expertise. Select easy, medium or difficult. For information on how to play, please see below.

title: Shopping Picks for March 3
description: Improvd now has an e-commerce site; Loeffler Randall, known for updating classic looks with a dash of edge, is coming out with a new line next week; and other items.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: Pressure Grows for Answers on Fracking
description: Congressional Democrats are demanding answers from the Environmental Protection Agency about the safety of hydraulic fracturing, a form of natural gas drilling also known as fracking, after revelations that wastewater from such drilling, which contains radioactive material, is regularly dumped into rivers and streams without proper treatment.

title: The Other Emancipation Proclamation
description: St. Petersburg, Russia, March 3, 1861

title: Wifes Charity Offers Corporate Tie to a Governor
description: WASHINGTON  Louisianas biggest corporate players, many with long agendas before the state government, are restricted in making campaign contributions to Gov. Bobby Jindal. But they can give whatever they like to the foundation set up by his wife months after he took office.

title: A Contest to Find Ads Worth Passing On
description: THE nonprofit organization TED, whose tagline is ideas worth spreading, has decided to spread something else: advertising.

title: The Hollow Cry of Broke
description: Were broke! Were broke! Speaker John Boehner said on Sunday. Were broke in this state, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin said a few days ago. New Jerseys broke, Gov. Chris Christie has said repeatedly. The United States faces a looming bankruptcy, Charles Koch, the billionaire industrialist, wrote in The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday.

title: Good Step for Burnett as He Tries New Stride
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The tight little rectangle of scuffed dirt on the front slope of the pitching mound Wednesday offered tangible evidence. So did some key statistical columns for A. J. Burnett in his first spring start: no wild pitches, no hit batsmen, no walks.

title: Suburbs Veneer Cracks: Mother Is Held in Deaths
description: TAMPA  The Tampa Palms neighborhood here is the kind of place people move to get away from crime.

title: Even Hurtful Speech
description: In a narrow ruling in the sense of applying law to one set of facts, the Supreme Court has provided an admirable reminder of how broad the protection of free speech is under the Constitutions First Amendment, including hurtful and hateful speech.

title: Officials Disagree on Penalties for Mortgage Mess
description: Even as state attorneys general and regulators in Washington approach the end of their investigation into abuses by the nations biggest mortgage companies, deep disputes are emerging over how much to punish the banks as well as exactly who should benefit from a settlement.

title: Regulator to Cite Hudson City as Carrying an Excessive Risk
description: Shares of Hudson City Bancorp dropped after it said that regulators may require it to reduce a concentration in financing.

title: When Not to Tough It Out
description: If there is a lesson from this weeks resignations of two scandal-tainted European ministers its this: Once a leader loses trust, its best to exit quickly. Frances now departed foreign minister, Michle Alliot-Marie, and Germanys departed defense minister, Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, both tried to tough it out, further damaging their governments and reputations.

title: Soldier Faces 22 New WikiLeaks Charges
description: WASHINGTON  The Army announced 22 additional charges on Wednesday against Pfc. Bradley Manning, the military intelligence analyst who is accused of leaking a trove of government files to WikiLeaks a year ago.

title: Closer to the Truth About Big Branch
description: Federal investigators have finally delivered a get-tough message to the coal industry with the indictment of Hughie Stover, the security chief at the Upper Big Branch Mine where 29 men perished last April. Mr. Stover is accused of lying to investigators and ordering the destruction of records as federal agents sought to get to the root causes of the deadliest mine disaster in 40 years.

title: A.I.G. Fetches $9.6 Billion for MetLife Holdings
description: The American International Group sold its holdings in MetLife late Wednesday, fetching about $9.6 billion from the stock offerings to help pay back its government bailout.

title: Williams Was Treated for Blood Clot in Lungs
description: Serena Williams, out of action since winning Wimbledon in July, has experienced another significant health problem that could further delay her return to the game she once dominated. Williamss representatives confirmed Wednesday that she was hospitalized last month in Los Angeles because of a pulmonary embolism and that she then required emergency treatment Monday for a hematoma, a pocket of blood that swells under the skin.

title: Perez Gets Another Chance
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Oliver Perez is scheduled to start Thursday against the Cardinals in Port St. Lucie. Perez, who is fighting for a spot on the roster despite being guaranteed $12 million this year, has already pitched once, and it did not go well. He allowed four runs in two innings and walked three batters in a row at one point.

title: The Fighter: Bob Probert
description: Bob Probert was notorious for his brutal style of hockey, but his many fights led to an eventual diagnosis of a serious brain disease.

title: Hockey Brawler Paid Price, With Brain Trauma
description: TECUMSEH, Ontario  For 16 seasons, Bob Proberts fists were two of hockeys most notorious weapons, winning most of his 246 fights and feeding the N.H.L.s fondness for bare-knuckle brawling.

title: Afghan Tells of Ordeal at the Center of Al Qaeda
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Abdul Khaliq Farahis kidnappers attacked fast, smashing into his car to stall it, seizing him and executing his driver as he tried to make a phone call. Within seconds, they were driving away to a hide-out just 20 minutes away.

title: In Social Media Postings, a Trove for Investigators
description: First, Facebook helped get Rodney Bradford out of jail; later, it threatened to send him back.

title: Budget Battles and American Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking for Answers From a Wanderer at Rest
description: Ossining, N.Y.

title: Anti-Semitism, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Searching Laptops
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers Wonder, Why the Scorn?
description: The jabs Erin Parker has heard about her job have stunned her. Oh you pathetic teachers, read the online comments and placards of counterdemonstrators. You are glorified baby sitters who leave work at 3 p.m. You deserve minimum wage.

title: Girls and Boys Together
description: In honor of Womens History Month, President Obama ordered up the first report on the status of American women since the one Eleanor Roosevelt prepared for John F. Kennedy. Its chock full of interesting bits of information.

title: Many in N.H.L. View Fighting as Necessary
description: Efforts to outlaw fighting in hockey go back decades. But though the number of fights in the N.H.L. has dropped significantly in recent years, fighting persists, preserved by the idea that it is a deterrent against cheap shots, a safety valve against more serious mayhem and something that fans like to watch.

title: Bloggingheads: Israel and Obama
description: Meir Javedanfar, left, of The Guardian and Matt Duss of the Center for American Progress discuss President Obama's relationship with Israel.

title: Fox News Takes Two Potential Candidates Off Air
description: Fox News is helping jump-start the Republican primary.

title: Heres What We Can Do to Tackle Libya
description: In 1986, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi gave an interview to a group of female foreign journalists. Then he invited them, one by one, into a room furnished with just a bed and television and propositioned them.

title: Drinking Off the Job
description: A little more than a year before I was laid off from my job as an editor of Harpers Magazine, one of my colleagues quit and I was given his office. It was easily twice the size of my previous windowless workbox, with ego-boosting views of lower Manhattan, and ample space for decoration and a few personal comforts. Before moving in I decided to contribute a few dollars to Ikeas global revenue. In short order, I had outfitted myself with a pair of down-market reading lamps, a few modernist picture frames for my family photos, a colorful little area rug and even a ridiculous lumbar cushion pillow for my reading chair, all of which, in my humble opinion, suggested a certain sense of permanence and ease.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 2, 2011

title: Protester Says He Didnt Plan Lease Bids
description: SALT LAKE CITY  An environmental protester charged with fraudulently buying federal oil and gas leases at an auction here in 2008 took the witness stand at his criminal trial on Wednesday and told the jury he had acted spontaneously, with no clear plan or intent to harm.

title: Study Finds Criminal Pasts of Nursing Home Workers
description: WASHINGTON  More than 90 percent of nursing homes employ one or more people who have been convicted of at least one crime, federal investigators said Wednesday in a new report. In addition, they said, 5 percent of all nursing home employees have at least one criminal conviction.

title: N.F.L. and Union Prepare for Worst
description: CHANTILLY, Va.  The N.F.L. and its players union are prepared for a labor showdown, with the players poised to decertify the union Thursday afternoon and seek to block a lockout that the owners are expected to impose, said several people with knowledge of the plans of owners and players.

title: How Should the U.S. Respond to the Libyan Turmoil?
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Universities Seek More Autonomy as Financing From States Shrinks
description: With states providing a dwindling share of money for higher education, many states and public universities are rethinking their ties.

title: You've Got Readers
description: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss AOL's acquisition of The Huffington Post.

title: City Council Favors Pregnancy Center Disclosures
description: The City Council passed a bill on Wednesday seeking more transparency from crisis pregnancy centers that present themselves as medical clinics but that critics say offer little more than pregnancy tests and counseling intended to steer women away from abortions.

title: This Year, Mets Bring Real Dirt to Spring Training
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  They have been slinging dirt in Mets camp for the past month, and the infielders just love it.

title: Group With Link to Rays Is Said to Show Interest in Mets
description: A group that includes an owner of the Tampa Bay Rays has shown interest in buying a share of the Mets, becoming one of about a dozen serious investors to emerge in the auction for at least a quarter of the club.

title: In Plea Deal, Ex-Paterson Aide Admits Shoving Former Companion
description: A former aide to ex-Gov. David A. Paterson pleaded guilty on Wednesday to harassing a former girlfriend, capping a series of events that enveloped Mr. Paterson in scandal and derailed his bid for election last year.

title: 2 Teenagers Are Sentenced for Killing Man Asleep in His Car
description: Two teenagers convicted of killing a Queens man whom they overpowered as he slept in his Lexus were sentenced on Wednesday to prison terms of at least 20 years each.

title: Thursday: High-Spirited
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Weve got a special one today. There have been a few puzzles like this in the past, most notably this 1996 one by Jeremiah Farrell (Across Lite, Solution), and I am always amazed at the creativity and care that it takes to construct with a gimmick like this tucked neatly inside.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: And Paul Would Make Three
description: Chauncey Billups ceded the Madison Square Garden spotlight to Chris Paul on Wednesday, providing a tidy point-guard analogy for the Knicks future and a free agency-obsessed public.

title: Battle Erupts Over City Contract Costs
description: In a scathing critique of the Bloomberg administrations oversight practices, New York Citys top fiscal watchdog has accused the citys main agency for economic development of allowing a contract with a construction company to balloon by tenfold in three years to nearly $74 million, and authorizing over $3 million in dubious payments.

title: California: Sirhan Sirhan Denied Parole
description: Sirhan Sirhan, convicted of killing Robert F. Kennedy more than four decades ago, will remain in prison, after a parole board again denied him parole on Wednesday. Mr. Sirhan, who assassinated Mr. Kennedy at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles in 1968, had originally been sentenced to death, but his sentence was commuted when the State Supreme Court ruled the death penalty unconstitutional. He has since been denied parole 14 times. In the lead-up to the hearing, Mr. Sirhans lawyer indicated that Mr. Sirhan did not remember shooting Mr. Kennedy, who had just won the California Democratic presidential primary.

title: James McClure, Powerful Western Senator, Dies at 86
description: James A. McClure, a three-term Republican senator from Idaho who epitomized the rugged, independent thinking of Western politicians who used new leadership positions in the 1980s to transform their sagebrush rebellion into conservative legislation, died on Saturday in Garden City, Idaho. He was 86.

title: Contractor With a Past Is Facing Tax Charges
description: Philip B. Schwab, an 82-year-old demolition contractor whose work helped reshape several American cities even as rogue business practices led to indictments and federal prison, is expected to surrender on Thursday to face state tax charges.

title: 2 Qaddafis Fought Over Business, Cables Show
description: WASHINGTON  Soon after Coca-Cola decided to move into Libya in 2005, it received a harsh lesson in how the personal jealousies and brutality of the feuding family of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi shape the nations economy.

description: The star and the understudy talked, as they have nearly every day for the last week. The conversation was basic and to the point. The Knicks needed a new Three in their Big Three, and Toney Douglas, with his humble rsum, was the sole candidate.

title: Eastern Cougar Is Declared Extinct, With an Asterisk
description: Seven decades after the last reported sighting of the Eastern cougar, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service declared it extinct Wednesday and recommended that it be removed from the nations endangered species list.

title: Cuomos Teacher Plan Criticized as Falling Short on Seniority Rule
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has portrayed a plan to change the way New York teachers are evaluated as a significant break with the past that would end a longstanding practice of laying off less senior teachers first.

title: Yemen President Apologizes to the White House
description: SANA, Yemen  President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen called the White House on Wednesday to express regret for misunderstandings over remarks he had made accusing the United States and Israel of fomenting unrest in the Middle East, the administration announced in a statement.

title: Bill Wurtzel, Jazz Guitarist, Strums in the Key of Life
description: For decades, Bill Wurtzel worked in advertising by day and moonlighted as a guitarist in big bands. In 1989, he retired from advertising and turned to music full time. Now 73, he plays with the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band, performing at Henrys on the Upper West Side and the American Folk Art Museum, among other places. Mr. Wurtzel is a founding director of the Jazz Foundation of America, which helps jazz and blues musicians in need. He and his wife of 49 years, Claire, live on the Upper West Side.

title: In First Game Back After Suspension, Gillies Throws Another Dangerous Hit
description: In his first game back from a nine-game suspension for hitting Eric Tangredi on Feb. 11 with an elbow to the back of the head, Islanders forward Trevor Gillies checked Minnesotas Cal Clutterbuck at the side of the head and into the glass at Nassau Coliseum on Wednesday. Although he took a while to get up, Clutterback was not injured on the play. Gillies received a five-minute major penalty for checking from behind and a game misconduct.

title: More on the Vegetable Soup Matrix
description: My first New York Times Magazine column is a clever little matrix (Im allowed to call it clever because I didnt come up with the idea; the art department did) showing you how to make and vary four categories of vegetable soup. You could argue that the four categories  creamy, brothy, earthy and hearty  arent that distinct, but they were useful for the sake of organization and will give you a simplified way of thinking about vegetable soups, especially if youre a newcomer.

title: Creamy, Brothy, Earthy, Hearty
description: Im not anti-recipe (obviously), but some things just dont need them  and most vegetable soups fall into that category. Here are easy-to-follow instructions for making vegetable (vegetarian and, for the most part, vegan) soups with common ingredients, a variety of choices and terrific flavor. Print the following page, stick it on your refrigerator and work your way through it. By the time youre done  12 days or 12 weeks later  youll never again need a recipe for vegetable soup. Promise.

title: Libyan Refugee Crisis Called a Logistical Nightmare
description: RAS AJDIR BORDER CROSSING, Tunisia  Thousands of stranded immigrant workers fleeing Libyas violence stood huddled together at this desolate outpost on Thursday evening, braced silently against a whipping, sandy wind, hoping they would not spend the night outside. Then the doors of a bus opened, shouts went up and the crowd swarmed  men and women surging frantically, their overstuffed suitcases balanced precariously on their heads as they ran.

title: Fantasy Focus: Rebuilding Problems
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates last had a winning record and made the playoffs in 1992. The Kansas City Royals had a winning season in 2003, but the last time they made the playoffs was in 1985, when they beat the St. Louis Cardinals in the World Series. Chances are the situation isnt that dire for the worst team in your keeper league, but the experiences of the Pirates and the Royals illustrate how difficult it can be for us fantasy leaguers to rebuild a franchise, and we can learn from the mistakes of those franchises. Well talk about some of the common rebuilding problems here, then discuss a few possible solutions to get out of the rebuilding rut in your keeper leagues.

title: (More) On Charlie Sheen
description: If youve been following the Charlie Sheen Self-Immolation World Tour 2011  during which he has appeared, or is scheduled to appear, on every talk show, radio program and podcast that will have him (which, as of now, seems to be all of them)  youve noticed that we are now in Defcon Three of Celebrity Scandal: The Whither Society portion of the meltdown. Defcon Five is the scandal itself. Defcon Four is the all-of-us-watching-with-mouths-agape phase. With Defcon Three comes the clothes-rending: Are we enablers? Should we be egging him on? Is this actually news? And most worrying of all: why do we care?

title: Inky Becks
description: Some day theres going to be a tattoo bake-off between European soccer players and their N.B.A. brethren, right? We can hope. In the meantime, just in time for the start of the Major League Soccer season two weeks from now, when the Seattle Sounders host the L.A. Galaxy, one likely contestant has beefed up his qualifications. David Beckham recently revealed on his Facebook page the latest addition to his body-art collection. Its a Piet-like image of Christ being tended to by cherubim. Not sure about this, but its hard to avoid spinning out some exegesis about that whole Beckham-as-savior-of-soccer-in-America business that kicked off four years ago when Beckham took his talents from Spain to the Galaxy  especially now that his final season under contract here is about to begin. At the moment, those cherub wings may also remind many of the poor broken-winged owl that died after being kicked by a Colombian soccer player when it landed on the field in the middle of a match earlier this week. The visiting player who struck the bird, a mascot for the home team, could use some absolution himself: he faces a fine and possible jail time.

Taking a page from programs in the U.S. and Canada, a real school in Staffordshire, England,is using real dogs, specially trained greyhounds, to listen patiently while small children read aloud to them. The best part is you can tell your kid that when the dog is sleepinghes dreaming about their story.

title: The Memory Champion
description: Joshua Foer is right. In ancient times, memorization was a key skill vital to preserving knowledge. And it wasnt only the ancient Greeks who used their memories in such a fashion. There are still vestiges of the vast bodies of knowledge that must have been common place in preliterate cultures. There are still a handful of Pacific Islanders who can navigate based on the precise position and distance of the stars above the horizon and on their knowledge of tides and currents. In many Muslim countries, it is commonplace for children no older than 10 or 12 to have memorized the entire Koran. Such feats of memorization are also common among Orthodox religious students and among Hindus who memorize chanted prayers and scriptures. Religion was once the major institution for passing on vital cultural knowledge. We are no longer lonely bands of hunter-gather warriors, so this vast amount of informationis no longer necessary. But the capacity is there, in all of us.RUANNEArkansas, Feb. 19, 2011, 9:56 a.m., nytimes.com

title: Broke Town, U.S.A.
description: Vallejo, a city about 25 miles north of San Francisco, offers a sneak preview of what could be the latest version of economic disaster. When the foreclosure wave hit, local tax revenue evaporated. The city managers couldnt make their budget and eliminated financing for the local museum, the symphony and the senior center. The city begged the public-employee unions for pay cuts  all to no avail. In May 2008, Vallejo filed for bankruptcy. The filing drew little national attention; most people were too busy watching banks fail to worry about cities. But while the banks have largely recovered, Vallejo is still in bankruptcy. The police force has shrunk from 153 officers to 92. Calls for any but the most serious crimes go unanswered. Residents who complain about prostitutes or vandals are told to fill out a form. Three of the citys firehouses were closed. Last summer, a fire ravaged a house in one of the citys better neighborhoods; one of the firetrucks came from another town, 15 miles away. Is this Americas future?

title: N.F.L. and Union Agree to Extend Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON  The N.F.L. and the players union agreed Thursday to extend by one day the deadline for expiration of its collective bargaining agreement. The agreement gave them time to see if they can further extend the deadline to continue negotiating in hopes of averting the first work stoppage in the league since players struck in 1987.

title: Even Superman Had a Mom, and Diane Lane Will Play Her
description: Its a bird, its a plane, its a former cast member of The Outsiders who we never expected would one day grow up to be the mother of a quintessentially all-American superhero: its Diane Lane, who is only the second member of the cast to be announced for a new Superman movie that the director Zack Snyder is preparing for next year. On Wednesday night, Warner Brothers Pictures said Ms. Lane, whose more recent movies include The Perfect Storm, Unfaithful and Secretariat, would play the mother of the films title character  not the Kryptonian mother of Kal-El, who arrives on earth from a dying alien planet, but Martha Kent, an adoptive parent who raises him in his guise as Clark Kent.

title: China Tightens Controls on Foreign Press

title: Paris Report | Runway as Nightclub at Mugler and Pugh
description: Believe it or not, Lady Gaga once had trouble getting any designers to lend her clothes. So much trouble in fact that she had her own knockoff-ish pieces made for the stage. That changed around the time Nicola Formichetti styled her for the September 2009 cover of V Magazine. She quickly owned the must-dress list. And now  as the muse for Formichettis new vision for Thierry Mugler  shes come full circle. Let it be said, Gaga makes for a pretty sick model. Sometimes even the most captivating show can drag on, and rarely does the audience of editors walk out laughing about the good time they just had. Even the models appeared to be having a blast. The clothes  shiny and sexy, with sculptural shoulders sharp enough to be used as weapons  were fun too, and theres nothing wrong with that.
