description: INTRODUCTION

title: Application Adventure: A Dads College Essay
description: Asked to come up with a mock title for a surefire best seller, the legendary publisher Bennett Cerf (1898-1971) is said to have replied, sticking a finger into the prevailing winds, Lincolns Doctors Dog.

title: Keeping Score: Billupss Quiet Effectiveness
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Waiting in The Twilight Zone for College Decision Letters
description: Cue the suspenseful music and the surreal black-and-white title sequence, because ever since I became a second-semester senior, I have felt like I have been cast in an episode of The Twilight Zone that has yet to be broadcast.

title: Comedian, Rebranded
description: WHEN it comes to Chris Rock, its the gait above all. Sure, theres the voice too, a purring rasp that never sounds at peace, and the eyes, which are emphatic and precise. But anyone whos seen Mr. Rock walk the stage during one of his comedy shows knows his stride cold: the long, slightly jagged steps that seem to eat up the floor beneath him; the mild bop in his strut; the liquidity of his movement, as if hes engaged in one very long motion, not hundreds of small ones.

title: When Psychology Trumps Logic
description: For the past day or so, Ive been taking a break from our offices to listen in on a climate, mind and behavior conference at the Garrison Institute, named for a beautiful little town up the Hudson, north of New York City.

title: Poisoned Trees Bring Truce to a Civil War in Alabama Football
description: The attempted killing of two trees that are occasionally draped with toilet paper might have been considered a blip on the police blotter.

title: Gingrich Tests 2012 Presidential Support
description: ATLANTA  Newt Gingrich on Thursday became the first major Republican to begin raising money for the 2012 presidential race, but he stopped short of declaring his candidacy until he finishes delivering paid speeches this month and distances himself from a web of business ventures that would interfere with a campaign.

title: When a Fisher Goes Missing
description: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

title: Neoconservatism and the Arab Revolutions
description: James Kirchick has a good piece exploring the divide thats opened between American neoconservatives and many Israelis over the revolutions and protests currently roiling the Middle East  with neocons welcoming the fall of Hosni Mubarak and the promise of democratic change throughout the region, even as the Israeli leadership classes wax more pessimistic about the likely consequences of replacing despots with more popular regimes. Could there be a starker illustration of just how mistaken the neocon-Israeli conflation always was? Kirchick asks, and hes right: The last few weeks should bury, once and for all, the foolish idea that neoconservatisms rhetorical commitment to democracy promotion is just a smokescreen for Likudnik dual loyalties or U.S. imperialism.

title: Asked & Answered | Luke Matheny
description: This past Sunday, Luke Matheny took home the Oscar for Best Live Action Short with God of Love, a charming twist on the classic Cupid story. In the wake of his win, the former New York University film student took a few moments to speak with The Moment about the excitement of the Oscar experience, what made his crew different from that of, say, The Kings Speech and whats up next for this rising talent.

title: The Die-Later Diet
description: David Murdock, 87, holds a strong conviction that plants, eaten in copious amounts and the right variety, hold the promise of optimal health and maximal life span.

title: Terror Suspects in New Jersey Plead Guilty
description: NEWARK  Two New Jersey men who were thwarted in a plan to join an armed Islamic group in Somalia pleaded guilty on Thursday to a felony conspiracy charge in federal court.

title: Invasive Amphibian Species Upend a Darwin Idea
description: Charles Darwin has had a remarkable record over the past century, not only in the affirmation of evolution by natural selection, but in the number of his more specific ideas that have been proved correct.

title: First 3-D Star Wars Film Not So Far, Far Away: Phantom Menace Coming Feb. 10
description: What will Darth Mauls double-bladed light saber, Anakin Skywalkers pod racer and Jar Jar Binkss unyielding floppy ears look like to audiences as they appear to leap off the screen? And more important, when can they buy tickets for the first Star Wars movie to be released in 3-D? Lucasfilm and 20th Century Fox answered one of those questions on Thursday, announcing that Star Wars: Episode I  The Phantom Menace, the first of the six space-adventure films that George Lucas and Industrial Light & Magic are converting for 3-D presentation, will be released in theaters next year on Feb. 10. In a statement, the studios said the 3-D conversion is being done with utmost respect for the source material, and with a keen eye for both technological considerations and artistic intentions. (We assume that means artists wont overemphasize the adorable chipmunk cheeks of a young Natalie Portman.) For science-fiction fans expecting to learn release dates for 3-D versions of the franchises other films (including the original trilogy of Star Wars, The Empire Strikes Back and Return of the Jedi), this isnt the blog post youre looking for.

title: A Sneak Peek at the February Jobs Report
description: Tomorrow, the much-anticipated jobs report for February comes out, and policy makers are crossing their fingers for some good news.

title: In Search of the Confidence Fairy
description: In the debate over the budget, Republicans seem to be leaning on the claim that austerity will actually increase employment, because it will raise business confidence; at least thats what John Taylor seems to be saying.

title: The New Yankee Stadium
description: Three panoramic views of Yankee Stadium in the Bronx, the teams new ballpark.

title: Yankees Win World Series
description: With a 7-3 victory over the Phillies in Game 6, the Yankees won their 27th World Series championship.

title: Final Game at Yankee Stadium
description: Yankees legends and tens of thousands of fans joined in the celebration of Yankees Stadium as the last game was played at the stadium.

title: Athletes to Bring Life to Venice Biennale
description: Putting together an exhibition in the Giardini di Castello, the lush garden that is home to the international pavilions for the Venice Biennale, is always a contest of sorts. Too little time, too many complex details, seemingly impossible logistics and the hope of getting recognized by the Biennale committee. Now it appears that the artists representing the United States  the team of Jennifer Allora and Guillermo Calzadilla  will be taking the notion of a competition both literally and metaphorically this summer.

title: Playing the Silver Ball: Flipping and Tilting as Team Sport
description: KRISTOPHER MEDINA hunched over. His eyes were bright and focused, his body taut. He pulled a lever; it slapped back. A gleaming silver ball ricocheted up and out, spurring a dizzying cavalcade of lights and whoops. Mr. Medina  the mastermind behind Pinball NYC, a new competitive league  was leading his team, the Cartel, to a spectacular victory.

title: The Padres Quarterback Challenge
description: PEORIA, Ariz.  Early this spring training, in a team meeting, San Diego Padres Manager Bud Black asked his players if any of them had been quarterbacks in high school. Black kept track of the names and announced that the team would soon hold a quarterback challenge.

title: How to Enter the Hyundai Curb, and Other Lessons from the Geneva Auto Show
description: Without door handles, Hyundais crossover concept makes getting into and out of it a challenge even for trained technicians.

title: An Angry Man Is Met by a Smart, Experienced Police Team
description: The story could be told through the bullet holes: what the bullets hit and did not hit.

title: New York Aviators Set for Playoff Run
description: The New York Aviators, a Brooklyn-based team in the fledgling Federal Hockey League, open the playoffs at home on Friday as the unlikely favorite to win the championship. A 21-game winning streak catapulted them to the top of the standings at 32-13-2.

title: A Rock-Solid Magazine
description: After dinner last night, I ducked into that giant magazine store off Union Square, among the last of its kind. The lighting in there is as flattering as the full-body-cavity-search room at J.F.K. (not that Ive been there), but it had the new April issue of Mojo on March 2, the sign of a newsstand that still cares. I rushed home and devoured the 17-page cover package on the Smiths, marking the 25th anniversary of The Queen Is Dead (which, interestingly, Mojo ranks as only their second-best album). Though its largely about the rock music of years gone by, Mojo steers clear of sentimentality and cheap nostalgia by sheer, unabashed devotion to its subject. Also: strong, well-defined sections, loads of vintage rock pictures, graphic design that draws inspiration from classic album covers and wonderful paper stock that feels so good in your hands.

title: Chernow Wins History Prize for Washington Biography
description: The historian Ron Chernow has won the annual American History Book Prize for his biography Washington, the New-York Historical Society announced on Thursday. Roger Hertog, chairman of the societys board, said the book, published by Penguin Press, would undoubtedly become the definitive life of our first president. Mr. Chernow is also the author of biographies of John D. Rockefeller and Alexander Hamilton, among other works. The prize, which comes with an engraved medal, the title of American Historian Laureate and an award of $50,000, will be presented on April 8 in Manhattan.

title: A Hybrid Path to Feeding 9 Billion on a Still-Green Planet
At SuperReturn, Private Equity Looks in the Mirror
description: BERLIN  Does private equity add value to the companies it owns?

title: Videophiles | Patterns & Repetitions II
description: This week, The Moment features the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown.

title: Depression After Miscarriage
description: Periodically when I write about miscarriage on Motherlode, a debate breaks out in the comments between those who see losing a pregnancy as a lasting tragedy in their lives and those who wonder why those women cant see the loss as natures way and move on.

title: Behold the Sky: Full of Such Mischief, British U.F.O. Files Say
description: LONDON  The year was 1977. Above the tiny island nation of Grenada, big things were happening in the sky. Sir Eric Gairy, the countrys prime minister, was convinced that the objects he thought he was seeing were hostile alien aircraft from outer space.

title: Videophiles | Doug Aitkens Patterns & Repetitions: Mike Kelley
description: There are certain things that all creative people share in common  and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitkens 2006 book Broken Screen, which featured interviews with everyone from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas, challenged the convention of the linear narrative. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetitions [http://www.patternsandrepetition.com], the artist sits down with a whole new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. Theres Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; LCD Soundsystems James Murphy on the sound of snow; and Jack White weighing in on Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. This week, The Moment features the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown. But dont be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesnt do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

title: The Mandate Thing
description: A quick note on polling and voting: as more and more polls come out showing that the public does not, in fact, hate public workers and their unions, theres been a stock answer  namely, that the real poll took place in November, so who cares what a thousand or so people say now.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Its time for our weekly guessing game. This week, were offering one hint about the location of this photograph: Cold water temperature and unusually warm air temperature have created a cotton-like effect mist over this urban islands south side.

title: Egyptian Antiquities Chief Says He Will Resign
description: 12:09 p.m. | Updated Zahi Hawass, Egypts antiquities minister, said in a telephone interview on Friday that while he is planning to resign he had not yet and still holds the post. He clarified his status after an ArtsBeat report on Thursday said he had already stepped down.

title: What Makes a Good Apology?
description: Thats what Ive been wondering since catching up with Steve Fishmans remarkable jailhouse interview with Bernie Madoff in New York Magazine. Im not sure what I expected from the mastermind of a $65 billion Ponzi scheme, but it wasnt whiny rationalizing like this: Everyone was greedy. I just went along. Its not an excuse. Some crimes are so big that they demand full-throated, active voice, nonhedging remorse. (Not with we participated language a la Lloyd Blankfein, either.) If only Madoff were more like Richard Nixon. True, it took hours of pushing and pressing by David Frost to get Nixon to apologize for Watergate  I let the American people down, and I have to carry that burden with me for the rest of my life  and he could have apologized for so much more. But watch Nixons face. Something is there. Could it be contrition?

title: Answers to Retirement Questions
description: In Thursdays special section on Retirement, Steven Greenhouse reported that as the first baby boomers reach 65 this year, many will find themselves financially unprepared for retirement. Mr. Greenhouse is taking questions from readers about what these workers, as well as younger ones, can do to get themselves ready.

title: An Artist Gets His Wish, and Wants Your Help
description: The Parisian street artist known as JR  a peripatetic figure who has made a name for himself by plastering urban areas around the world with huge photographs of the downtrodden residents who live there  became the unlikely winner several months ago of the 2011 TED Prize. The philanthropic honor gives the winner (past recipients have included Bono and Bill Clinton) the chance to make a grand wish.

title: Obama Tells Qaddafi to Quit and Authorizes Refugee Airlifts
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama demanded Thursday that the embattled Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, step down from power and leave immediately, and said he would consider a full range of options to stem the bloodshed there, though he did not commit the United States to any direct military action.

title: International Criminal Court Begins Libya Inquiry
description: THE HAGUE  The International Criminal Court has started a formal investigation into possible crimes against humanity in Libya that will focus on the role of the countrys leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, several of his sons and members of his inner circle, the chief prosecutor said Thursday.

title: Skating on Thick Ice
description: Pond hockey for 1,700 players.

title: In Rejecting Peltz, Family Dollar Shows Desire to Stay Independent
description: In rejecting the Trian Groups takeover bid  worth at least $7 billion  Family Dollar Stores had one clear message for investors and potential suitors on Thursday.

title: City Invites Groups to Help Immigrants Start Businesses
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a competition Thursday aimed at helping immigrant entrepreneurs finance their businesses and overcome language barriers and other obstacles hindering their growth.

title: Solar Roadways Offer a Possible, if Distant, Remedy for E.V. Range Anxiety
description: The highway of the future measures 12 feet by 12 feet and fits in Scott Brusaws garage workshop in Sagle, Idaho. But Mr. Brusaw, who founded Solar Roadways with his wife, Julie, has expansion plans, and people are listening.

title: A Big Surprise Beneath the Ice
description: Only rarely do researchers discover an entirely new physical mechanism that forces them to rethink a branch of science. But some new results from Antarctica promise to do exactly that in the field of glaciology.

title: The Problem With College Costs
description: Donald Heller, the director of Penn States Center for the Study of Higher Education, wrote to me to take issue with part of my post on college costs. He makes a good point:

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia and Pakistan.

title: B.Y.U. Loses Badly to New Mexico
description: Brigham Young Universitys mens basketball team revealed the toll of playing without the suspended sophomore forward Brandon Davies Wednesday, looking confused in a 82-64 loss to New Mexico in Provo.

title: Snail Mail
description: Receiving mail is a huge morale booster for deployed troops.

title: World Cinema for Kids
description: Images of some of the offerings in the 2011 New York International Childrens Film Festival.

title: Snail Mail Hasnt Lost Its Power to Boost Troop Morale
description: A Year at War

title: Oliver Perez Throws Two Scoreless Innings
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Oliver Perez had a reasonably good start on Thursday, or at least a far better outing than in his spring training debut, in which he gave up four runs and three walks in just two innings.

title: Seeing Things | Rodartes States of Matter
description: Kate and Laura Mulleavy, the two Los Angeles-based designing sisters behind the fashion house Rodarte, have never had a solo exhibition on their home turf. Until now. Rodarte: States of Matter, which opens this weekend at the Museum of Contemporary Arts Pacific Design Center gallery, treats visitors to an up-close look at 20 Rodarte creations, including six ballet tutus that the sisters designed for the film Black Swan. Were really happy to have the opportunity to show our work in an art museum, Laura said. Were used to seeing our garments on tables in our studio as flat pieces that are kind of lifeless. For the exhibition, we wanted to abstract the clothes, removing them from the human figure, and show them as sculptural objects in the round.

title: Creepy People With a Plan, and a Couple on the Run
description: Who is George Nolfi? a colleague whispered when the final credits began to roll for The Adjustment Bureau, a fast, sure film about finding and keeping love across time and space. Good question. If the fates allow  or perhaps, as in this very enjoyable movie, the men in gray suits and fedoras permit and things go according to plan  you should be hearing more from Mr. Nolfi, a screenwriter turned director who has brightened the season with a witty mix of science-fiction metaphysics and old-fashioned fluttery romance.

title: Women Said to Be Killed at Ivory Coast Protest
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  At least six women were shot dead here on Thursday as they protested against the continued rule of Laurent Gbagbo, according to witnesses and the United Nations.

title: What Does Libyas Opposition Want From the Outside World?
description: A colleague bounced up from her chair earlier this morning to ask: What does this Libyan National Council want? And what IS it?

title: Aging: Hearing Loss Is Common but Often Ignored
description: Nearly two-thirds of Americans 70 and older suffer from hearing loss that ranges from mild to severe, according to what may be the first study to gauge the prevalence of hearing impairment in a nationally representative sample of older adults.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Hazards: Misuse of Drugs Crowds Emergency Rooms
description: Some 700,000 Americans are taken to the hospital each year after ingesting drugs, both legal and illegal, a new study reports. And the care costs nearly $1.4 billion in emergency room charges alone.

title: Qaddafi Said to Accept Venezuelan Offer for Help
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis government has accepted a proposal by President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela to negotiate a solution to the turmoil in Libya, a top aide to Mr. Chvez said on Thursday. But confusion emerged after Colonel Qaddafis son reportedly rejected the plan.

title: Costco Pulls Threatened Fish from Stores
description: Under pressure from environmentalists, the retail giant Costco has said it would immediately halt the sale of a dozen fish species widely considered to be threatened by overharvesting.

title: Fighting Continues Along Contested Sudan Border
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  More than 100 people have died in clashes over the last week in a hotly contested region of Sudan, authorities said Thursday.

title: In Price of Farmland, Echoes of Another Boom
description: The 80 acres of rich farmland that Jeff Freking and his brother Randy bought near Le Mars, Iowa, on Monday for $10,000 an acre would seem to have nothing in common with a condo in Miami or a house in Las Vegas.

title: Regimens: Drugs Benefits Go Beyond Blood Pressure
description: A new analysis suggests that blood pressure drugs may benefit heart disease patients even if they dont have high blood pressure.

title: Unplugging the Hendrix Experience
description: In 1969 David Balakrishnan, then a teenage violin student, attended a Jimi Hendrix concert in Los Angeles that led him to reconsider his approach to his instrument, and to music more broadly. He began learning some of Hendrixs guitar solos on the violin, and he decided that his repertory should embrace both classical music and pop. As a composer he extended that philosophy to his own music.

title: Judge Stays Own Ruling Against Health Care Law
description: A federal judge in Florida stayed his own ruling against the Obama health care law on Thursday, allowing the act to be carried out as the case progresses through the Courts of Appeal and on to the Supreme Court.

title: More Great Read-Alouds From The New York Times
description: On Wednesday, the National Education Association celebrated its annual Read Across America Day. Next Wednesday, well celebrate World Read-Aloud Day. Readers may remember that last year, to honor those days, we offered a selection of engaging, short, student-friendly Times essays, articles, Op-Eds and humor pieces on a range of topics for teachers, parents or students to read aloud.

title: Photos of the Moment | Balmain
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#580", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Libyas Hidden Wealth May Be Next Battle
description: LONDON  As the battle for Libya rages on, the struggle over control of the countrys sovereign wealth fund and its $70 billion in assets has just begun.

title: Albany Budget Cuts Imperil Senior Centers, City Warns
description: The Bloomberg administration may need to close 105 senior centers  40 percent of the entire system  if Albany makes good on a budget cut of approximately $25 million, city officials said on Thursday.

title: A Once-Upon-a-Time Romance
description: IF harried shoppers eating Swedish meatballs at the Ikea in South Philadelphia ever look out the windows of the cafeteria toward the water, the first thing they will see is a gorgeous and desolate ship, the length of three football fields. My ex-boyfriend, Steven, got a book deal to write a social history of that ship. His working title: The Ideal Ship.

title: U.S. Tried to Protect Pakistani Official
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Obama administration, concerned for the safety of the Pakistani official who was assassinated on Wednesday, tried in the weeks before his killing to secure an armored car and beef up protection for him, an American official said Thursday.

title: Theater Listings: March 4  10
description: Theater

title: Streetscapes | Mansard Roofs
description: New York City was peppered with mansard roofs between 1868 and 1873. A few spectacular examples survive.

title: Family Bonding? Keep It Outside the Locker Room
description: I went swimming at the Y.M.C.A. Later, in the mens locker room, a father walked in with his daughter. Occasionally, this happens with babies or toddlers, but the girl was 7 or 8. He put her in a shower stall while he showered, and left her there while he shaved and flossed. Then he brought her to the lockers, where they changed. I was appalled. What do you make of this?

title: TimesCast | March 3, 2011
description: State budget battles; the N.F.L. and its players face off; and a Libyan newspaper finds freedom.

title: The Fading Sounds of Analog Technology
description: Ive always loved the musical Company, a Broadway show by Stephen Sondheim that opened in 1970. It was about a 35-year-old Manhattan guy, still unmarried even though all of his best friends are married couples. The set, the tone and the score were all ultrachic, ultramodern, ultraurban. So urban and modern, in fact, that the first thing you hear as the show begins is a busy signal  in its day, the ultimate technological symbol of a fast-paced, full-up lifestyle.

title: For Boards, S.E.C. Keeps the Bar Low
description: When a vast accounting fraud is disclosed, or when a chief executive is caught looting a company, it is to be expected that the Securities and Exchange Commission will bring civil charges against the responsible executives. In egregious cases, criminal prosecution may follow.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elswhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia and Pakistan

title: Comcast's Internet Television Strategy
description: Comcast turns to the Internet as it attempts to maintain its role as the nation's largest cable provider.

title: Obama Tells N.F.L. Owners and Players to Settle Dispute Without Him
description: President Obama took a shot at warring  and wealthy  football players and team owners on Thursday, telling them that for an industry thats making $9 billion a year, they ought to be able to figure out how to divvy up the money and avoid a lockout.

title: Not About Charlie Sheen
description: I dont want to write about Charlie Sheen. He seems to be a victim of mental illness, and needs medical, not public, attention.

title: Paris Report | Ready to Wear  Right Now
description: With only a day and a half under our belts, we are already finding a lot of clothes not just to shoot for the magazine but also to wear. At Hakaan, short, tight minidresses in black, navy, red and cream were shown with pointy flat oxfords and little socks. A sparkly, derriere-grazing one in particular provided a sexy, belle-of-the-ball moment.

title: Lawmaker Withdraws Bike-License Bill
description: A state Assemblyman has quickly withdrawn a bill that would require paid registration and license plates for all bicycles in the state, whether ridden by adult or child.

title: Government Report Finds Elder Abuse on the Rise
description: A rising number of elder abuse cases threatens to overwhelm inadequately staffed adult protective service agencies in many states, according to a report released on Wednesday by the federal Government Accountability Office.

title: Love, Adjusted
description: Images from The Adjustment Bureau, starring Matt Damon and Emily Blunt.

title: From Lebanon, With Pessimism and Hope
Reborn This Way
description: Lady Gagas latest monster hit, Born This Way, has sold more than 1.2 million copies already, and there have been almost as many comparisons to Madonnas 1989 hit Express Yourself. But the song had another progenitor, from another diva who did interesting things with hair and makeup: Dusty Springfield, the bouffanted and eye-linered British wonder who in the 60s made half a dozen seminal singles, one critical lodestone of an album (Dusty in Memphis) and later lots of other great records that few who were not critics ever heard.

title: 36 Hours in Orlando
description: You cant go far without stumbling upon a picturesque lake, and the area abounds with small regional museums.

title: 36 Hours in Orlando, Fla.
description: PEOPLE who live in the Orlando area will tell you that there is life here beyond the theme parks, gator farms and citrus groves. You cant go far without stumbling upon a picturesque lake, and the area abounds with small regional museums like the Zora Neale Hurston National Museum of Fine Arts in nearby Eatonville. Downtown, the new Amway Center, home of the Orlando Magic, has given a boost to the night-life district on Church Street, and Orlandos many neighborhoods are home to lounge acts, bars, vintage fast-food joints and brick-paved streets.

title: All Around Town, Stories Well Told
description: THE bar at Soho House was hopping as those in the members-only crowd clinked glasses and regaled one another at a midlevel roar. But the real drama was playing out one floor down, in the clubs library, where a small cross-section of New York City was held rapt by tales seldom overheard in polite company: love disintegrating amid differences in dental hygiene, teenage fumbling in a graveyard, death by plate glass.

title: Aldous Huxleys Brave New Storybook
description: Teenagers may know Aldous Huxley as the author of Brave New World (assigned in tandem with 1984 in a unit on political horrors) and as the guy who likely took more LSD than any other writer of his generation.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Fish Tales Gourmet Seafood Market
description: In Cobble Hill, a fresh smelling shop has been a pescatarians paradise since 1996.

title: A Plan to Phase Out Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
description: A PROPOSAL to phase out Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-controlled enterprises that for decades have underpinned the American housing industry, is in draft form right now. But industry experts say the plan will most likely affect borrowers even before it is finalized.

title: Harvard Basketball Seeks First Ivy Title
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  There is an unmistakable air of expectation surrounding the Harvard mens basketball team as it heads into the final weekend of the season. Something special, something never before accomplished, is within reach.

title: Early Maya Building Rituals
description: Daniela Triadan, an associate professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where she and Takeshi Inomata are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal.

title: Passionate, Muscular Searches for Interpersonal Connections
description: Elisa Monte is firmly planted on the emotional side of the modern-dance world. There is yearning in her dancers taut muscularity that reaches to the back row. Such emotion can get excessive, but shes been at it for years. Known for her time as a member of the Martha Graham Dance Company and for her acclaimed 1979 piece, Treading, Ms. Monte is celebrating her groups 30th anniversary with three programs and three New York premieres at the Joyce Theater.

title: Pivoting From Patter to Poetry
description: What the singer Kurt Elling says between songs, and what he writes in some of his lyrics, feels jokey and genial and on the edge of corny. Theyre the secondhand niceties of an older jazz culture. (Mr. Elling was born in 1967. Some of his lingo and patter was born around 1929.) But then he whomps you with something quite deep and practiced, quite serious and elevating.

title: Fish People With Heart. Noses Agree.
description: ONE of the first things you notice when walking into Fish Tales Gourmet Seafood Market is the smell. There is none. But the fish motif is definitely in the air, including walls strung with nets and traps and a whole fish mounted above the stained wainscot. The shotgun layout feels like the well-lighted hull of a boat.

title: Coming Full Circle With a Grand Gesture
description: Big institutions like the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic anchor New Yorks cultural life. But what makes the city a city  a scene, a place where music lives  is what groups like Eve Quelers Opera Orchestra of New York provide: texture, variety, depth. Ms. Quelers is the kind of company that makes the difference between a place youd want to visit and a place youd want to live.

title: A New Scottish Concerto, Dressed Up and Dreamy
description: During the 1990s the Scottish composer James MacMillan was promoted widely as the brightest hope of his generation: a creator who replaced modernist aridity with communicative directness. His initial promise has been borne out since in a diverse body of substantial works  including multiple symphonies, concertos and operas  through which he has grappled fruitfully with the contrasting tugs of modernity and history, Celtic folk traditions and Roman Catholic convictions.

title: Rango Characters: Full Scale
description: A look at some of the characters appearing in Rango.

title: 7 More Journalists Detained in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Seven journalists were detained Thursday in connection with a long-running investigation into a murky network that prosecutors maintain has been plotting to overthrow the government, a case that critics have characterized as a pretext to neutralize dissidents.

title: The Insider | Felipe Oliveira Baptista
description: As the creative force behind Lacoste and his namesake label, Felipe Oliveira Baptista is one of the most interesting young names on the fashion radar. Here, the Portuguese native who now calls the City of Light home shares his favorite spots in his adopted stamping ground.

title: When the Dead Arise and Head to Times Square
description: There is a lot of traffic these days in well-preserved bodies, human and otherwise. They are sliced and pickled for artistic effect or uncannily dissected and plasticized, with every blood vessel visible. They have toured the world, wrapped and mummified in the manner of ancient Egypt, or have been displayed, more modestly preserved by the dry desert sands of the Silk Road. And there are many, many more mummies yet to come.

title: Moonlight and More From a Victorian Artist
description: Lockwood de Forest, a Victorian furniture designer, produced entire paneled rooms out of imported Indian teak for elite clients like Andrew Carnegie and the painter Frederic Edwin Church. His esoteric wares had a brief heyday around 1890, and then he developed a new obsession: painting the moon reflected on bodies of water.

title: Exclusive Clip: 'Time of Eve'
description: A scene from Yasuhiro Yoshiura's animated science fiction film "Time of Eve."

title: Weekend Miser
description: Its almost time to do the Mardi Gras mambo down in New Orleans, and the good times are rolling northward this week. Bands from the Big Easy will be playing all over New York, accompanied by hefty helpings of Creole food and, of course, abundant libations.

title: Naked Girls Reading
description: Photos from a literary reading at Madame X in the West Village.

title: Happy to Bend Over Backward
description: IT might seem strange that when Adam Woolley turned 26 in November, a group of his colleagues sang Happy Birthday as they, and he, were doing handstands.

title: Video Crew On Huntsman? Its Documentary, Not Politics
description: Word that Jon Huntsman, the American ambassador in China and a possible 2012 Republican presidential candidate, has a television crew following him around in Beijing has gotten the political world all, well, a-Twitter.

title: Fish People With Heart. Noses Agree.
description: ONE of the first things you notice when walking into Fish Tales Gourmet Seafood Market is the smell. There is none. But the fish motif is definitely in the air, including walls strung with nets and traps and a whole fish mounted above the stained wainscot. The shotgun layout feels like the well-lighted hull of boat.

title: Timescast: N.F.L. Labor Dispute
description: The N.F.L. and the players union are still at odds over how to divide $9 billion in annual revenue. This fall's season is at stake.

title: A 3-Week World Tour for (but Not Only) Kids
description: Does your wish list for the weekend include seeing a new foreign movie in a real theater? And are you finding your choices limited  that youre a victim of what A.O. Scott of The New York Times recently called the peculiar and growing irrelevance of world cinema in American movie culture?

title: Inhofe and Upton: Just Say No to the E.P.A.
description: Senator James Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, and Representative Fred Upton, Republican of Michigan, on Thursday formally introduced their bill to thwart the Obama administrations intent to regulate greenhouse gases from power plants, factories and refineries.

title: Simpson Thacher Hires Senior Bank of America Lawyer
description: The law firm Simpson Thacher & Bartlett said on Thursday that it had hired a senior Bank of America lawyer as a partner specializing in financial services regulation.

title: Moby-Duck
description: At the outset, I felt no need to acquaint myself with the six degrees of freedom. Id never heard of the Great North Pacific Garbage Patch. I liked my job and loved my wife and was inclined to agree with Emerson that travel is a fools paradise. I just wanted to learn what had really happened, where the toys had drifted and why. I loved the part about containers falling off a ship, the part about the oceanographers tracking the castaways with the help of far-flung beachcombers. I especially loved the part about the rubber duckies crossing the Arctic, going cheerfully where explorers had gone boldly and disastrously before.

title: Winters Ache May Soon Be a Memory
description: And now, the weather for March, April and May. Watchword: normal.

title: Theres a New Sheriff in Town, and Hes a Rootin-Tootin Reptile
description: Feature animation currently finds itself in a golden age of mediocrity, with sensationally inventive technical means tethered, more often than not, to drab and cynical imaginative ends. The perennial Pixar exception tends to prove a dreary rule: as animated movies claim an ever bigger share of money and attention  drawing cross-generational, demographically diverse audiences more readily than most other films  they rely more and more on manic, synthetic formulas.

title: Second-Year Fair Hopes to Stay an Upstart
description: Independent, last years much-lauded upstart of an art fair, is back in the former Dia Center building on West 22nd Street in Chelsea. But its hard to be an upstart the second time around, as evinced by a preview in Vogue and the launch of an unaffiliated mini-fair called the Dependent at the Sheraton Hotel on West 25th Street.

title: Ristretto | Brains and Baristas
description: The TED conferences taking place this week in California are famous for their brainy presentations (held by futurists, technologists, the odd paper-cutter artist) and a rapt audience (a Comic-Con of early adopters and outliers), where a biomedical engineer might cede the stage to an artist who reshapes urban airspace while Bill Gates takes notes. Soon, TED could be known for its coffee, too.

title: As Chaos Continues, Refugees Gather at the Borders
description: Rebels reinforced a key oil port Thursday while facing new regime airstrikes in eastern Libya, and thousands of mourners buried victims of a counteroffensive by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces, shooting guns in the air, shouting Down with Qaddafi! and swearing to take vengeance.

title: SALON ZRCHER
description: Zrcher Studio

title: LAURIE SIMMONS: The Love Doll: Days 1-30
description: Salon 94

title: Federal Jury in Utah Convicts Environmentalist
description: SALT LAKE CITY  A Utah man who infiltrated a sale of federal energy leases in December 2008 to protest United States policies about climate change was found guilty by a jury on Thursday of disrupting a government auction and faces up to 10 years in prison.

title: Corcoran Adds Curbed Articles to iPhone App
description: Real estate shopping has clearly changed for the better in the age of the smartphone. In the past, when planning a weekend of apartmenthunting, you would need to sift through hundreds of listings before hitting the pavement.

title: Federal Officials Say Theyll Examine Fracking Practices
description: Testifying before Congress on Thursday, Obama administration officials said they planned to scrutinize the waste disposal practices of natural gas producers after reports that drilling wastewater containing radioactive material was being dumped in public waters without proper monitoring or treatment.

title: Free-for-All Spirit Breezes Into a Vast Art Fair
description: Art fairs are for art lovers. Theres really no way around it. You can say that they demean art, that theyre all about commerce. You can complain about the crowds, the bad food, the poor ventilation. I hear you.

title: Republicans Have High Hopes for Iowa
description: Matt Strawn, the chairman of the Iowa Republican Party, on Thursday offered an upbeat assessment of the partys position in his state, where the nation will hold its first 2012 presidential caucus in less than a year.

title: KAI ALTHOFF: Punkt, Absatz, Blmli
description: Gladstone Gallery

title: The Uncluttered Look Has Its Day
description: The Art Show is the Benjamin Button of art fairs. The annual production of the Art Dealers Association of America, it is still the most conservative of the three major and several smaller fairs happening this weekend, but it has gotten younger in spirit over the past decade. If it keeps aging in reverse, it may one day replace the Armory Fair and the Independent as the go-to place for connoisseurs of the hip.

title: In Thrall to the 1980s: Put 16 Candles on That Hunk of Frosted Yearning
description: Heres to honesty. Were nostalgic for something we never actually experienced, a member of Summer Camp said in an interview last year.

title: Paris Report | Down a Dark Path
description: Highlights from Thursday included two darkly beautiful runway shows from Ann Demeulemeester and Rick Owens. Demeulemeesters large black feather headpieces and dramatic black hair extensions made the models look almost birdlike. She used intricate leather lacing on crushed velvet jackets, wedged booties and long black gloves. A fantastic dark orange and crimson fur coat provided a shot in the dark.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Discounting Dollars Defense Yes, Family Dollar has a poison pill, but it doesnt have a staggered board. M&A Law Prof Blog

title: A Fixer-Upper
description: It took two years to make a Hudson Valley getaway livable for a couple that was used to weekends in the Hamptons.

title: House Tour: Clinton Corners, N.Y.
description: WHAT Six-bedroom house on 25 acres.

title: Artifacts | The Women of !W.A.R.
description: Cindy Sherman, Marina Abramovic and Tracey Emin are among the most successful women in art today. Their work regularly appears in international museum shows, is prized by top collectors and has no trouble getting attention in the press. If their market share still does not approach that of male peers like Richard Prince, Damien Hirst and Jeff Koons, at least they didnt have to wait for fame as long as Louise Bourgeois, who emerged as a force when she was over 60.

title: From Hottie to Homely, Transformed by a Witch
description: With its gossip-girl-and-guy milieu and adolescent anguish, Beastly, a surprisingly painless if ragged redo of Beauty and the Beast, looks as if it should be on the CW network. Its the same old story, a fight for love and glory, though really one for that coveted youth demographic. This update of the durable fairy tale is so strategically aimed at the jailbait set (and their older sisters) that it should come with a complimentary tub of Justin Biebers favorite zit zapper. (It was produced by CBS Films, a division of the CBS Corporation. But its a small-ville after all: the CW is the offspring of big CBS and Warner Brothers Entertainment.)

title: A Maestros Unfinished Legacy
description: Sitting in his crammed but cozy office at the Metropolitan Opera in the spring of 2004, James Levine could barely contain his excitement about the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He was just six months away from conducting his first official program as that eminent orchestras music director, a performance of Mahlers sprawling Symphony of a Thousand.

title: A Maestro and His Maladies
description: A look at the recent health problems and canceled performances that forced James Levine, 67, to resign as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and cancel performances at the Met.

title: Bonderman Sees a Return of Big Private Equity Deals
description: BERLIN  David Bonderman, the founding partner of TPG Capital, sees a return of the heady days of private equity deal-making, with bigger acquisitions financed by easier credit and growing opportunities in emerging markets.

title: Idol Retains Its Rule
description: Fox trounced the competition in the ratings on Wednesday night as the dozen women remaining on American Idol took to the stage for a chance to advance to the reality shows top 10. According to Nielsens estimates, 22.6 million viewers tuned in to Fox for the 90-minute episode, considerably more than any other show on the night. CBS ranked second with its back-to-back procedurals Criminal Minds at 9 p.m. (14.3 million) and Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior at 10 (10.3 million). ABC placed third, earning solid ratings for Modern Family at 9 (10.1 million) but trailing at 9:30 with its new series Mr. Sunshine (7 million) behind Foxs comedy Traffic Light (7.4 million). ABCs 10 p.m. offering, Off the Map, struggled further with 5 million viewers. NBC was a distant fourth on the night, broadcasting a lineup of mostly reruns with the exception of a new episode of Minute to Win It at 9 (3.6 million).

title: The Heyday of Mansard Roofs
description: IT was a craze, a fad, just like Art Deco, Permastone and swoopy titanium-skin buildings. The mansard mania of 1868 to 1873 swept over New York with a peculiar incandescence, but then went out like a guttering candle. Traces of the mansard bubble somehow survived, and that on the 1868 Grand Hotel, at Broadway and 31st Street, is getting a particularly loving restoration.

title: Spare Times for Mar. 4  10
description: Around Town

title: Galleon Lawyer Says S.E.C. Suit May Taint Jury
description: 8:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Dance Listings
description: Dance

title: Co-Housing Group Plans for Shared Future
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Spare Times For Children
description: For Children

title: Classical Music Listings
description: Classical

title: Betting on a Spring Housing Market Rebound
description: THE spring selling season is usually under way by Super Bowl Sunday, but it got a late start this year. The reasons for the delay included the snowy winter, the uncertain economy and the extinction of the first-time buyer tax credit that ignited the market last year.

title: Pop Listings
description: Pop

title: Jazz Listings
description: Jazz

title: In Some Places, Multicar Garages Are Standard
description: A CHATEAU-STYLE house on the market for $18 million in Cedar Grove seems over the top in every respect: 7 fireplaces, 8 enormous bedrooms, 9 opulent bathrooms, a 16-seat theater, and a 4-car garage  oversized to fit a personal limousine.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Art

title: Singles, City and Child
description: It is no wonder that the insufferable romantic comedy Happythankyoumoreplease, set in New York, looks and sounds like a flop pilot for a television sitcom. Its writer, director and star, Josh Radnor, who plays Ted in How I Met Your Mother, has obviously absorbed the first rule of the game: no matter what, keep things perky and gabby, even if nothing of substance is expressed, and the wisecracks fizzle. If you have to throw in a few requisite tears, make sure they dry quickly.

title: Film Series and Movie Listings
description: Movies

title: Carl Galioto
description: Mr. Galioto, 57, is the managing principal of the New York office of HOK, one of the worlds largest architecture firms. HOK New Yorks current projects include LG Electronics headquarters in Englewood, N.J., and Harlem Hospital.

title: Liriano Trade Rumors Cool Down, for Now
description: The Yankees need for starting pitching is no secret, but until recently, their pursuit of the Twins ace Francisco Liriano was unknown to the general public.

title: Q & A
description: Backing Out of a Lease

title: Play and Progress
description: .I cant believe I only just learned of this playful behavioral experiment (corporate sponsorship alert), via Matt Lewis at Climateworks.org, speaking at the Garrison Institute meeting on Climate, Mind and Behavior.

title: Android Pulls Ahead in Smartphone Race, Report Says
description: The smartphone race is still raging, but who is winning might look different depending which question you ask.

title: Few Winning Scenarios for Gingrich
description: About a year ago, back at the old FiveThirtyEight, I had a very skeptical take on Newt Gingrichs potential candidacy for president. The issue I highlighted is that Mr. Gingrich is neither especially well-liked by Republicans  his numbers among Republicans are fine, but not as good as those for some other candidates  nor among the general population, with whom he is almost as unpopular as Sarah Palin:

title: Tween College and What Comes Next
description: Duran Duran, cocaine, big hair: the period signifiers in Take Me Home Tonight all scream 1980s. But the premise of this reasonably watchable immersion in nostalgia is timeless, as Hollywood hype would have it. What that means is that you could attach any set of sounds and images from a specific decade of American pop culture, starting in the 1950s, to the same basic concept established by The Graduate and American Graffiti and made formulaic by John Hughes comedies and the American Pie franchise. You dont need a hot tub time machine to go back 25 years or so.

title: A Move Dictated by Miscellany
description: ONCE their son was born, Erin Gleason Alvarez and Greg Alvarez found themselves buried under stuff. Their spacious ground-floor two-bedroom in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, for $2,600 a month, came with the use of the basement, and we took up the entire basement, Mr. Alvarez said.

title: Datapoint Me
description: I just heard Henry Farrell give a talk on networks, diffusion, intellectual influence, and the rise and fall of Keynesianism in the crisis. And I have to say, Im feeling awfully objectified. I am not a datapoint! I am a free man! Hahahaha! (end The Prisoner.)

title: Handicapping the Backup Catchers
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  The Yankees left Charlotte Sports Park after a 10-inning, 1-1 tie with the Tampa Bay Rays on Thursday without updating the condition of the backup catcher Francisco Cervelli, who fouled a ball off his left foot Wednesday. Manager Joe Girardi said team doctors in New York were reviewing a magnetic resonance imaging test for a possible stress fracture.

title: Recording Academy Responds to a Critic
description: Two weeks ago Steve Stoute, a marketing executive and music industry veteran, caused a stir by attacking the Grammy Awards in a full-page ad in the Sunday Styles section of The New York Times.

title: Scorecard | Mugler Wins!
description: Paris fashion week started on quite a somber note, butScorecard knows critics were cognizant of the old saying about show business  and ready for a little performative distraction. In the final time slot Wednesday, uberstylist Nicola Formichetti showed his first womenswear collection for the former Haus of Thierry Mugler and  with a little help from his star client  had them putting their paws up in the air.

title: Quickly, New Lloyds Chief Sets a Path to Exert Control
description: LONDON  Antnio Horta-Osrio spent the last four years turning a Spanish bank into one of the biggest retail lenders in Britain. Now, he will have to prove he can do the opposite at the Lloyds Banking Group: shrink a financial firm to make it more profitable.

title: An Obit Writers Chance to Think Inside the Box
description: I think about death more than most people  I write obituaries for a living, after all  but stepping into a coffin, I didnt know what to expect. A corpses-eye view of death, I figured, might be informative, but I had my trepidations; being killed and disposed of, even as a volunteer in front of an audience, was unnerving.

title: My Fathers Fortune
description: Homburg

title: Michael Frayns Memoir of His Father
description: Contemporary British letters do not lack for memoirs, autobiographies and other works in which the main event is the father-son relationship. John Mortimers wonderful play A Voyage Round My Father, about his dad, a celebrated, blind barrister; Max Hastingss funny and touching Did You Really Shoot the Television?, about his feckless but irresistible father; Auberon Waughs sublimely titled Will This Do?, about life with Evelyn, who comes off (to my mind, anyway) as the Dad From Hell; then there is Auberons own son Alexanders superb multigenerational layer-cake memoir, featuring Auberon-Evelyn-Arthur; Martin Amiss nuanced but adoring portrait of his dad, Kingsley; and most recently Christopher Hitchenss brilliant Hitch-22, featuring his complex, fraught relationship with his father, Commander Hitchens of the Royal Navy. Rich terrain  and Ive probably omitted a dozen or so others.

title: The Caucus Podcast: From Atlanta to Libya
description: Click to Listen

title: The Back of Beyond
description: A man separated from his family strives to reunite someone elses in The Human Resources Manager, a disappointingly shallow story in which only the dead are named, and the living are reduced to stereotypes.

title: House Action Likely on Marriage Act
description: House Republicans are expected to move Friday to assert themselves as defenders of the Defense of Marriage Act, the 1996 law that bars federal recognition of same-sex marriages. Last month, the Obama administration said it had decided the law was unconstitutional, and had directed the Justice Department to stop defending it in court.

title: The Armory Show
description: Photos from the exhibition of contemporary and modern art.

title: The Ashtray
description: Errol Morris's incident at Princeton.

title: Turning the Gaze Back to the Clothes
description: PARIS

title: The Billionaire Who Is Planning His 125th Birthday
description: One morning in early January, David Murdock awoke to an unsettling sensation. At first he didnt recognize it and then he couldnt believe it, because for years  decades, really  he maintained what was, in his immodest estimation, perfect health. But now there was this undeniable imperfection, a scratchiness and swollenness familiar only from the distant past. Incredibly, infuriatingly, he had a sore throat.

title: Heads Will Roll
description: Heads roll in I Saw the Devil, though not very far. The first, belonging to a lovely young woman (Oh San-ha), exits a police evidence box and stops at the feet of her dumbstruck fianc, Soo-hyun (Lee Byung-hun). The second head is not nearly so pretty, but, by the time it tumbles from its torso, rather more eagerly anticipated.

title: U.S. Says Lost Former Agent May Be Imprisoned in Southwest Asia
description: The United States has evidence that a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who disappeared in Iran four years ago is alive and being held in the region, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said in a statement on Thursday.

title: Colombia's Gold Rush
description: As the Colombian government works to eradicate the coca trade, guerrillas have turned to local gold mining for cash. Now the government is cracking down on illegal mines.

title: The Libyan School of Economics?
description: Qaddafis ties to the British elite have been well reported in The Times and other papers this week, and today the British press is reporting that those connections have taken down Howard Davies, the director of the London School of Economics.

title: A Band That Fights and Plays
description: The Belgian director Koen Mortiers punk fantasia Ex-Drummer plays like a more extreme Trainspotting, in which the brittle, candy-colored surrealism has been replaced by an occasionally potent but irritatingly intellectualized new-European Sturm und Drang. As the not-so-comic violence and the violent, misogynistic sex pile up, it becomes the kind of black humor in which the joke is largely on the audience.

title: An Illegal Gold Rush in Colombia
description: High gold prices and the success of coca eradication projects have attracted criminals once focused on the illegal drug trade.

title: For Yanks Abroad, More Midfield Madness
description: Saturdays German Bundesliga match between third-place Hannover and fourth-place Bayern Munich should have huge implications as the teams battle for a Champions League slot.

title: In Colombia, New Gold Rush Fuels Old Conflict
description: CAUCASIA, Colombia  Officers pored over intelligence reports describing the movements of two warlords with private armies. Then the helicopters lifted off at dawn, carrying an elite squad armed with assault rifles to the newest front in this countrys long war: gold mines.

title: Reputed Arms Trafficker Complains About Jail Diet
description: Apparently, a diet is a diet, even if you are Viktor Bout, accused of being an international arms trafficker.

title: Viewing Libya Through the Prism of Lockerbie
description: All eyes are on the remarkable events unfolding in Libya, but all eyes are not equal.

title: Dog Lovers Want to Loosen Proposed Leash Laws
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Colorado Boy, 12, Held in Killing of Parents
description: DENVER  A rural Colorado community, not far from the Kansas border, was left shaken this week after a 12-year-old boy was taken into custody on suspicion of killing his parents and wounding his younger brother and sister on Tuesday night.

title: In Indiana, Top Official Is Accused of Vote Fraud
description: Indianas top elections official, Secretary of State Charles P. White, was indicted Thursday on felony charges that he committed voter fraud.

title: Extracurricular Sex Toy Lesson Draws Rebuke at Northwestern
description: The president of Northwestern University said Thursday that he was troubled and disappointed by a psychology professors decision to present his students last week with a demonstration outside class that featured a couple engaging in a live sex act using a prop.

title: After Building a Power at Marist, Coach Sees No Reason to Leave
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  After the buzzer echoed through the McCann Center, ending the regular season, 3,000 cheering fans of the Marist womens basketball team stopped and turned their focus to midcourt, where Coach Brian Giorgis held a microphone.

title: Carl B. Hess, Pioneer of Private Equity, Dies at 98
description: Carl B. Hess, the founding chairman and longtime leader of AEA Investors, a pioneer private equity company and a precursor to the leveraged-buyout giants of the 1980s, died on Feb. 15 at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: Chief of Beazer Homes Settles a Fraud Claim for $6.5 Million
description: The chief executive of Beazer Homes, Ian J. McCarthy, agreed to return $6.5 million in compensation that he had received while the company was accused of accounting fraud, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday.

title: Linked to Imperfection, but Perfect Face of Young Indians
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  Chris Antonetti was not with the Cleveland Indians in Detroit last June 2, when Jason Donald went to the plate as the 27th batter to face Tigers pitcher Armando Galarraga. When Donald bounced a slider to the right side, Antonetti, watching on television, assumed Galarraga would get his perfect game.

title: Immigrants Health Crisis Leaves Her Family on Sideline
description: MILLERSVILLE, Md.  When Jerome Ndayishimiye entered the overheated room at the nursing home where his 58-year-old mother lay under a tightly tucked blanket, he quickly closed the curtains around her bed and turned on her boom box so that a melodic Rwandan song enveloped them. He stroked her forehead and her eyes fluttered open and closed again.

title: As Economic Pinch Eases, Concerns Remain for Dining Chains
description: FOR months, restaurant chains have felt better about business as customers who cut back to save money began eating out again. Now, as the spring marketing season approaches, they are concerned about what rising gasoline prices may do to their nascent recovery.

title: In Libya, We Won. Then a Rebel Becomes a Martyr.
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Late for the funeral of his friend the martyr, Muhieddin Gebril raced his car through the soldiers checkpoints, toward the cemetery next to the cement factory where the rebels buried their dead in a long and growing line.

title: The Fictions of Mike Huckabee
description: Mike Huckabee is supposed to be the Republican with a heart. Hes the guy who said Mexicans are people too during the 2008 race for the White House. Hes the weight-loss humanist who refused to join that anti-common-sense fringe of his party bashing Michelle Obama for suggesting that children eat more vegetables.

title: Madoff Victims Have Their Day in Appeals Court
description: If former Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York wanted to see what he faces as the designated mediator in the legal battle between the owners of the New York Mets and the trustee who is liquidating Bernard L. Madoffs enormous Ponzi scheme, he was in the right place.

title: House Votes to Help Small Businesses Comply With Health Bill, but Relief Is Held Up
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to repeal burdensome tax-reporting requirements that were imposed on small businesses to help pay for the expansion of health insurance coverage under the new health care law.

title: Calls Mount to Tap U.S. Oil Reserves
description: WASHINGTON  As oil prices have risen in recent weeks, calls have been growing in Congress for the Obama administration to consider tapping into the nations strategic petroleum reserve, which is now at its full capacity of 727 million barrels.

title: Pharmacists Fight the Rise of Mail Order
description: A fierce battle is being waged between retail pharmacists and mail-order companies over where people should be able to fill their long-term prescriptions.

title: Police Chiefs Wary of Immigration Role
description: As many state legislatures consider laws to expand the role of local police departments in immigration control, police chiefs across the country say they are reluctant to take on these tasks and want clear lines drawn between local crime-fighting and federal immigration enforcement, according to a new report by a police research group.

title: New App Provides a 360-Degree View
description: Bubbli, a stealth Silicon Valley start-up that is inventing a new type of photographic experience it calls bubbles, gave an early demonstration of the technology at the TED conference in Long Beach, Calif.

title: 22 Years Later, the Exxon Valdez Case Is Back in Court
description: Disasters eventually end. Their aftermaths can seem infinite.

title: James Franco Straddles Two Roles at Yale
description: On Sunday night he was in Hollywood, as co-host of the Oscar telecast in black tie. At 9 the next morning, he was in a Starbucks in New Haven, hunched over a book and barely recognizable in a gray sweatshirt, but still wearing his tuxedo pants.

title: Soldier in Leaks Case Was Jailed Naked, Lawyer Says
description: WASHINGTON  A lawyer for Pfc. Bradley Manning, the Army intelligence analyst accused of leaking secret government files to WikiLeaks, has complained that his client was stripped and left naked in his cell for seven hours on Wednesday.

title: Ex-Enforcer Says Fights Arent Real Problem
description: Marty McSorley is no stranger to hockey violence. He fought 273 times in a 17-year N.H.L. career. In 2000, he was convicted of assault after swinging his stick at the head of Donald Brashear, another feared enforcer, and was suspended for a year, effectively ending his career. He had numerous concussions as a player and today, at 47, has memory loss and other symptoms often associated with brain injury.

title: Motivational Speakers Killer Convicted of Murder
description: A Manhattan jury convicted a man Thursday in a bizarre, fatal stabbing of a despondent motivational speaker, determining that his death was not assisted suicide, as the defense had insisted, but murder.

title: Arizona: Phoenix Public Safety Chief Is Suspended
description: Jack Harris, the public safety manager in Phoenix, has been stripped of day-to-day control of the Police Department while an audit is being conducted to determine whether he inflated kidnapping statistics to win federal grant money, officials said on Thursday. The police reported more than 350 kidnappings in 2008 and said that almost all of them were linked to border violence, prompting some to label Phoenix the kidnapping capital of the United States. The actual number might have been closer to 250, officials said. Joe Yahner, the executive assistant chief, will take over during the 60-day review, City Manager David Cavazos said.

title: Massachusetts: Two Charged in Overdose Deaths
description: A former doctor and nurse practitioner who worked in Needham were charged Thursday with the overdose deaths of six patients and overprescribing powerful prescription painkillers for financial gain. The doctor, Joseph Zolot, and the nurse, Lisa Pliner, were accused of conspiring to distribute the painkillers fentanyl, methadone and oxycodone and distributing the drugs that led to the overdoses, which occurred from 2004 to 2006. Mr. Zolot surrendered his medical license two years ago, said his lawyer, David Meier. Dr. Zolots intent at all times was to do good as a doctor, he said. It was never his intent to cause harm or death to his patients.

title: Education Secretary Cautions Districts About Layoffs
description: Arne Duncan, the federal secretary of education, urged state and local authorities to avoid short-sighted decisions as they cut school budgets, and said laying off teachers based solely on seniority was a wrong way to cut spending. Fourteen states, including New York, ban districts from considering any factor but seniority in layoffs. This often results in layoffs of young teachers. Teachers unions say, however, that laying off by seniority prevents struggling districts from removing more experienced and higher-paid teachers.

title: A Tasty Fungus, Stirring Dreams and Lawsuits
description: HILLSBOROUGH, N.C.  The two contenders in the great North Carolina truffle wars could not be more different.

title: Serena Williams Faces Tough Battle
description: Comebacks have been as emblematic of Serena Williamss tennis career as ferocious grunts and wardrobe changes. Major injuries, Hollywood distractions and the murder of her half-sister Yetunde in 2003: she has overcome them all to continue winning Grand Slam titles and to establish herself as one of the greatest players in the history of her sport.

title: Harvard Says It Will Allow the R.O.T.C. to Return
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Nearly 40 years after Harvard expelled the Reserve Officers Training Corps program from its campus, university officials announced Thursday that they would officially recognize the Naval R.O.T.C.

title: Navy Officers Face Censure Over Videos on Carrier
description: WASHINGTON  A senior commander in the United States Navy found fault with 40 officers and sailors on Thursday for their roles in crude, sexually explicit videos that were shown as onboard entertainment from 2005 to 2007 to the crew of the Enterprise, the worlds first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier.

title: Without Loan Giants, 30-Year Mortgage May Fade Away
description: WASHINGTON  How might home buying change if the federal government shuts down the housing finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac?

title: Slapped in the Face With a Money Pie
description: WASHINGTON

title: Experts Fear Looted Libyan Arms May Find Way to Terrorists
description: Security analysts say the armed uprising in Libya poses a long-term security threat  that weapons looted from government stockpiles could circulate widely, including heat-seeking antiaircraft missiles that could be used against civilian airliners.

title: Democrats Open Talks by Offering $6.5 Billion More in Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  As they opened negotiations with Republicans over budget cuts, the White House and Congressional Democrats on Thursday offered to trim an additional $6.5 billion from current spending, a figure far short of the Republican goal of cutting agency budgets by $61 billion.

title: Lincoln Addresses the Nation
description: Abraham Lincoln delivered his first Inaugural Address on the East Portico of the Capitol 150 years ago today. Tens of thousands turned out, not only to see the new chief executive but to hear him speak about the nations roiling secession crisis. Would he offer compromise to the Confederate states? Or would he take a hardline stance on the besieged Fort Sumter and other hotspots? The Disunion editors asked four Lincoln scholars for their thoughts on the speech.

title: Can McKinsey Keep a Secret?
description: Can clients still trust the mighty McKinsey & Company? Thats something they should be asking after the Securities and Exchange Commission, as part of its insider trading crackdown, accused Rajat K. Gupta, the elite consulting firms former chief, of betraying Goldman Sachss secrets.

title: Prosecutors Fight Release of Reports in Shootings
description: PHOENIX  Federal prosecutors had hoped to prevent the public release of the autopsy reports for the six people killed in the Jan. 8 Tucson shooting rampage, but a medical examiner said Thursday that he intended to release them next week unless ordered not to do so by a judge.

title: New Yankee Tries Other Corner Spot
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  The front half of the play sparkled. Brandon Laird, a minor league third baseman for the Yankees, dived to his left for Evan Longorias grounder, scrambled up and fired across the diamond. His throw bounced four feet in front of Eric Chavez, the neophyte first baseman. Chavez waited, then smoothly swept his glove forward and snagged the ball for the out.

title: Egypts Chief of Antiquities Says Hes Not Staying On
description: Zahi Hawass, Egypts chief antiquities official for almost a decade and a cabinet minister since January, said Thursday that he would not stay on in a newly formed government.

title: For a Day and a Game, Rodriguez and Perez Look Like a Pair of Aces
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  They are both outcasts of sorts with the Mets, two pitchers who, for different reasons, became pariahs to their club and its fans last year.

title: Cuomo Has Held Talks With Both Sides in Mets Case
description: Former New York Governor Mario M. Cuomo, the mediator trying to broker a settlement between the owners of the Mets and the trustee representing the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme, said Thursday that he had been working with both sides on an almost daily basis.

title: The Disposable Woman

Before that, Mr. Morgan and Mr. Sheen had mostly traded chuckles and anecdotes about multiday benders, inflated network salaries and meet-ups in Aspen, Colo. But then, after three commercial breaks, Mr. Morgan inquired, Have you ever hit a woman?

description: Another courageous Pakistani official has been assassinated because he stood for tolerance. We increasingly despair over the hatred and extremism that has Pakistan in a death grip.

For the female-to-male transgender 16-year-old, the nerve-racking minutes he spends trying to find his friends at school each morning is when bullies are most likely to strike.

title: Canada: 5 Cuban Dancers Stay on After Performances
description: Five members of the Cuban National Ballet remained in Canada after performances in Montreal last month. Catherine Chang, a spokeswoman for the National Ballet of Canada, said on Thursday that some of the Cubans are now taking classes with that company in Toronto. She declined to give any information about the dancers plans. The Montreal Gazette reported that only one of the dancers remained in Montreal. The federal government, citing privacy rules regarding immigration matters, declined to comment. The Cuban government, however, has confirmed that five members of the company have not returned to Cuba. In 2007, three dancers from the Cuban National Ballet defected to the United States after performing in Ontario.

title: Bangladesh: Microfinance Pioneer Fights to Keep Bank
description: The embattled Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus filed a petition in the Bangladesh High Court on Thursday to fight the governments efforts to remove him from the microfinance bank he founded three decades ago. Mr. Yunus has been locked in a battle with the Bangladeshi government over Grameen Bank, the institution that pioneered giving small loans to rural women as a way to fight poverty. The government claims that it is simply seeking to bring the bank under its oversight, but Mr. Yunuss allies, many of them powerful international figures, say that he is a target for political reasons. Mr. Yunus is a decade older than the banks mandatory retirement age of 60. The court is set to rule on his request on Sunday.

title: Greg Goossen, Baseball Player Who Broke Mold, Dies at 65
description: Yogi Berra called him overweight. Casey Stengel uttered a famous line about him. And Jim Bouton, the pitcher-turned-author, said he was the only teammate released in early spring training by the short-lived Seattle Pilots who interested him, because he could laugh at himself.

title: China: 10 Million More Migrants
description: The so-called floating population of China increased by 10 million last year, adding to the enormous number of people who are moving from Chinas countryside to its cities to look for work, according to the National Population and Family Planning Commission. The total number of people who live in an area different from the one where they have a hukou, or permanent residence permit, is now 221 million, the commission said at a recent conference in Guangzhou, according to a report in China Daily on Thursday. Nearly 43 percent of that population was born after 1980 and nearly 75 percent are migrant workers. In the next three decades, another 300 million people from the countryside are expected to go to the cities looking for work. In recent years, senior Chinese officials have discussed reforming the hukou system so that migrants can get social welfare benefits available now only to those who have permits for the areas in which they live.

title: What Role Should Community Colleges Play?
description: About three-quarters of the freshmen at the City University of New Yorks six community colleges this year have needed remedial instruction in reading, writing or math. This rising tide of students needing to get academically up to speed before they can take college classes is changing what and how these colleges teach. What is the role of community colleges in your community? To what extent do you think these colleges should be expected to offer remediation for students not prepared for college work? Why?

title: In Cyberattack, Virus Infects 40 Web Sites in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Forty Web sites in South Korea were attacked by a computer virus on Friday, including the official sites of the presidential Blue House, the Foreign Ministry, the countrys biggest bank, the countrys two largest search engines, a major online auction house and some American and Korean military sites.

title: Qaddafi Brutalizes Foes, Armed or Defenseless

title: Court Hearing in Exxon Valdez Case
description: A federal court hearing is scheduled today in Alaska on whether a reopener clause can be invoked to force Exxon Mobil to pay out over $100 million more for the damage caused by the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Prince William Sound, William Yardley reports.

title: New Premier Speaks in Cairo Square
description: CAIRO  Carried on the shoulders of protesters who claimed him as their own, Egypts new prime minister waded into a crowd of tens of thousands in Tahrir Square on Friday, delivering a speech bereft of regal bombast that illustrated the reach of Egypts nascent revolution and the breadth of demonstrators demands that remain unanswered.

title: Last Month on the Internet
description: THE MONTH IN ROMANCE1. Facebook stalking briefly got easier (phew!) with Breakup Notifier, an application that lets you monitor whether a friend is in a relationship on the site. According to their slogan: You like someone. Theyre in a relationship. Be the first to know the instant theyre out of it. (Or, presumably, the third.) But the app died a silent death just days after it began (Facebook shut it down), leaving its reported 3.6 million users to rely on olden methods of stalking that no one had forgotten or even stopped doing.

title: From the E.P.A., a Hint on New York Schools and PCBs
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency has not said much publicly so far about New York Citys plan to deal with the problem of toxic PCBs in school buildings.
