description: The economic waiting game may soon be over, as businesses signal that they are finally willing to resume widespread hiring.

title: Colbert vs. Fallon: They Scream for Ice Cream
description: Stephen Colbert is hardly the only late-night television host with an 11:30 show, but there was one quality that distinguished him from the pack: his own flavor of Ben & Jerrys ice cream, called Stephen Colberts AmeriCone Dream. Now even that isnt enough to distinguish him. On Wednesday those disloyal confectioners at Ben & Jerrys observed Jimmy Fallons second anniversary as a late-night host by giving him his own flavor, Jimmy Fallons Late Night Snack. (Dont groan at us, were not the ones who come up with these names.)

title: As Obamas Top Aide, Daley Is Everywhere
description: He may not be the high-profile, high-volume, hard-charging White House chief of staff that Rahm Emanuel was, but suddenly, William M. Daley is everywhere.

title: The Comet: Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina
description: Why on earth did your parents  wealthy Sikh immigrants from Punjab, one with a law degree, the other with a Ph.D.  settle in Bamberg, S.C., a town with one traffic light and 2,500 people, none of whom were Indians?  They came to the U.S. to tour for a year. Right before they went back, someone said, You cant leave; this is the best country, and they said, We dont have jobs. And by chance, my mom was offered a job to teach sixth-grade social studies, and my dad was offered one to become a professor. It happened to be in Bamberg, so thats where they stayed.

title: What I Really Want Is Someone Rolling Around in the Text
description: One day in college I was trawling the library for a good book to read when I found a book called How to Read a Book. I tried to read it, but must have been doing something wrong, because it struck me as old-fashioned and dull, and I could get through only a tiny chunk of it. That chunk, however, contained a statement that changed my reading life forever. The author argued that you didnt truly own a book (spiritually, intellectually) until you had marked it up.

title: A Faith-Biased Decision
description: I work at a wholesale distributor. One of our good customers from India asked if the holy man from his temple could stop by to bless our place of business. We accepted his offer. He then added this caveat: The holy man would prefer that no woman enter that area of the building during the ceremony. Some women on our staff were insulted by our willingness to abide by this restriction. The holy man ended up canceling, but we are still left with some bitterness. Should I have been more considerate? NAME WITHHELD, CONNECTICUT

title: House of Coups
description: THE KIDS CALLED it the house of revolution. It was a huge place on Tahrir Square, more like a decaying antique shop than an apartment, with rooms full of dusty furniture and gilt-framed paintings, decaying encyclopedias, dead plants, chipped tables covered with ashtrays and plates of half-eaten food. The owner, a 50-year-old bohemian named Pierre Sioufi, threw it open after the demonstrations began, giving refuge to protesters not out of any political conviction but because he was afraid there would be a massacre and he wanted to protect the kids.

title: B-Girl Bouillabaisse
description: It started randomly, as collaborations often do for young people with high-speed connections, limited budgets and big ideas. Back in the summer of 2009, Jacob Krupnick, an aspiring art photographer in his mid-20s, persuaded a fashion P.R. company to hire him to make a promotional video for a footwear show. He went on Craigslist to recruit 50 dancers (all skills, all ages, all bodies) to come to a makeshift studio in the Meatpacking District one hot night in July. Payment was in pizza slices.

title: The Tire Iron and the Tamale
description: During this past year Ive had three instances of car trouble: a blowout on a freeway, a bunch of blown fuses and an out-of-gas situation. They all happened while I was driving other peoples cars, which for some reason makes it worse on an emotional level. And on a practical level as well, what with the fact that I carry things like a jack and extra fuses in my own car, and know enough not to park on a steep incline with less than a gallon of fuel.

A serious, loyal readership may be our most precious asset. Wed be fools to trifle with it by making change for changes sake. But theres also the puzzling question, in this moment of technological upheaval, of how to intensify the experience of reading a print magazine.

title: All Signs Pointing Up on Jobs
description: A month ago, the two jobs reports together made no sense at all. We were told the unemployment rate fell but few people got jobs. That was possible because the figures come from two different surveys, one of employers and one of households. To make it even more confusing, the government changed its estimates of the population, to make it hard to compare the household numbers from one month to the next.

Harris frames his piece around the immense box office success of Christopher Nolans Inception, which for a time seemed like it might actually send Hollywood studios on a hunt for (gasp!) original material. title: No I.P.O. for ABN Amro Before 2014
description: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank that was nationalized and then merged with a branch of Fortis, reported a net loss on Friday of 414 million euros because of costs tied to integration after ABNs separation from the Royal Bank of Scotland.

title: Do Motives Matter? The DeChristopher Verdict
description: The American legal system tends to pay obsessive attention to a persons motives and mental state. A hate crime, for example, only becomes a hate crime at all with motive. Premeditated offenses often get harsher treatment than impulsive acts of rage or passion. The capacity to understand right and wrong is a fundamental threshold of competency in a courtroom.

title: In Hall or Lobby, Toronto Symphonys Festival Offers Intriguing Sounds
description: TORONTO  The north lobby of Roy Thomson Hall seemed the hot place to be in this city on Wednesday night. And how often can you say that of a nondescript passageway in a symphony hall, anywhere? As a passage it was pretty useless because it was crammed with immobile people before the concert, during intermission and again at the end. But as an adjunct auditorium it served beautifully.

title: Comparing Recoveries: Job Changes
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: In Philadelphia, New Cases Loom in Priest Scandal
description: PHILADELPHIA  Three weeks after a scathing grand jury report said the Archdiocese of Philadelphia had provided safe haven to as many as 37 priests who were credibly accused of sexual abuse or inappropriate behavior toward minors, most of those priests remain active in the ministry.

title: Much Ado About Dust Mites
description: Before you wage war on dust mites by buying new pillows, mattresses and protective covers, read the latest Patient Money column. As Lesley Alderman reports, dust mites may seem disgusting, but unless youre allergic, you dont need to worry about them.

title: YSL and the Spirit of the 60s
description: Pierre Berg, the old devil, has just a released a new book, La Revolution de la Mode, about the beginnings of Yves Saint Laurents Rive Gauche, in 1966, and its impact. Not only are we having a 1960s revival, but the industry also seems to be waking up with a crushing hangover or a severe case of doubts, and, well, people dont like the feeling. The book is actually a catalog of images  and splendid they are  from the archives of Fondation Pierre Berg and Yves Saint Laurent, where an exhibition about Rive Gauche and its first boutique will open on Saturday at the foundations headquarters. (It runs through July 17.)

title: For Dior, the Show Goes On
description: An emotional week, sometimes as overwrought as couture itself, ended this afternoon on a surprisingly calm and graceful note as members of the Dior ateliers, all in their white lab coats, took to the catwalk for the final bow of the fall 2011 Dior show.

title: Doubt Cast on Renault Spying Charges
description: PARIS  Has the French carmaker Renault been the victim of an elaborate hoax, internal score-settling, fraud or industrial espionage? The questions went unanswered Friday, but the spying complaint filed by Renault in January, which coincided with the dismissal of three employees, has been undermined.

title: Look of the Moment | Elisa Sednaoui
description: The Look: Black and blue  paired together, a total knockout.

title: Roundup: Remedial Classes at CUNY, James Franco at Yale, Presidents on Tuition
description: As the school week draws to a close, Choice readers, my eye has been drawn to a handful of articles this morning that you might as well consider your homework.

title: Drugs by Mail or by Store
description: Retail pharmacists have been pushing back against mandatory mail-order programs, in which health plans require people taking medications for chronic diseases to fill their prescriptions through the mail rather than at their local drugstores. A related article in The Times on Friday outlines the issues and proposed legislation.

title: With West Coast Choppers Closed, Jesse James Plots Next Move
description: In 2009, when American Honda introduced its first mass-produced chopper-styled motorcycle, the Honda Fury, Jesse James saw it not as a beginning, but an end.

title: China Reportedly Plans Strict Goals to Save Energy
description: HONG KONG  With oil prices at their highest level in more than two years because of unrest in North Africa and the Middle East, the Chinese government plans to announce strict five-year goals for energy conservation in the next two weeks, China energy specialists said Friday.

title: The Madness of Jean-Claude Trichet
description: The European Central Bank is strongly hinting that it will raise interest rates at its next meeting, in response to rising headline inflation  even though this rise is the result of rising food and oil prices, which are not the results of ECB policy.

title: Women Lead Rebirth in College Ski Jumping
description: On Saturday, for the first time in 31 years, there will be a United States collegiate ski jumping championship. And for the first time, it will include women.

title: Friday Prayers Lead to Mideast Protests
description: In what has become something of a weekly appointment for displaying disaffection with unresponsive governments, thousands of people poured into the streets across the Arab world to protest after noon prayers on Friday. There were only scattered reports of violence outside of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis harsh crackdown on demonstrators in Libya, with the worst of it in Yemen.

title: The Insider | Colin Peter Field
description: The Bar Hemingway is a Parisian institution  any night can play host to writers, models and designers. The gatekeeper ensuring patrons have a wonderful evening is Colin Peter Field. His anointment as the best barman in the world, by Forbes and Travel + Leisure magazines, is hardly surprising given his coterie includes Kate Moss, who wrote the preface for his book, Le Ritz Paris  Une Histoire de Cocktails (Editions de la Martinire), which was published in October. The model and muse favors the French 76 (a seductive concoction of vodka, lemon juice and sugar mixed with Champagne) whenever she is in town. With Paris fashion week in full swing, Field revealed where to unwind after the shows and where to get the best takeout. And for those not across the pond, he shared one of his favorite recipes for at-home imbibing. Sant!

title: Jobs in Perspective
description: My basic reaction to todays jobs report was, been down so long it looks like up to me. Clearly, this was better than the kind of report weve grown accustomed to seeing. But for perspective, here are annual averages of monthly job gains going back to Clinton:

title: Hearty, Healthful Muffins
description: Most muffins sold in bakeries are just cupcakes in disguise. But in this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman shows how to make homemade muffins into a tasty, healthful source of whole grains.

title: Turnaround Puts 76ers on Knicks Heels
description: While everyone seems to be talking about the Knicks and their newest acquisition, Carmelo Anthony, not much attention has been paid to the Philadelphia 76ers, who arequietly only 1.5 games behind New York for the sixth seed in the East.

title: Pelphrey Under Fire at Arkansas
description: A public campaign is under way to unseat Arkansas mens basketball Coach John Pelphrey, evidenced by a quarter-page ad running in Thursdays statewide editions of the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette.

title: Farewell to All The Hoopla
description: So the season is officially over. (Was it good for you?) Amid the near-radio silence of the last few days, the Bagger has taken some time to ponder the ups-and-downs of the awards circuit. Complaints that the Oscars lacked drama left us stumped; dont follow along if you dont want to know what will happen. Anyway, there was some mystery, and not just surrounding Banksy and the Academys preference when it comes to directors. Is anyone still wondering why The Kings Speech took the top prize? Perhaps because, as one awards-watcher put it, it made you feel smart for getting the jokes, just like Shakespeare in Love did, while The Social Network made you feel comparatively lazy and unambitious.

title: Taking the Mini to the Max
description: ITS an immutable law of the car business: the more focused a companys lineup, the greater the outrage when that company decides to expand its product range.

title: It Buildings of the Other Boroughs
description: THE very mention of certain apartment buildings in New York evokes a genteel world of wealth, power and discretion. At the Dakota, 740 Park Avenue or 15 Central Park West a gantlet of daunting prices, white-gloved doormen, and in some cases Kremlinesque co-op boards, keep mere mortals from a nirvana of sun-drenched penthouses, richly paneled salons, and squads of porters and concierges who smooth out lifes rough patches.

title: An Olivier Award for Sondheim
description: Stephen Sondheim will be honored with the Olivier Special Award 2011 by the Society of London Theater, the society announced on Friday. The society said Mr. Sondheim would accept the award in person at the Olivier Awards on March 13 and that the ceremony  Londons equivalent of the Tony Awards ceremony  would conclude with a tribute to him.

title: EADS Wont Protest Loss of Tanker Contract to Boeing
description: The European contractor that lost a bid to build Air Force refueling tankers said on Friday that it would not protest the decision, ending years of struggle that had highlighted flaws in the Pentagons contracting procedures.

title: The Perils of Libyas Loose Arms
description: Fridays New York Times covered fears that looted Libyan arms could find their way into terrorists hands. The articles emphasis is on heat-seeking, shoulder-fired, anti-aircraft missiles and the threats they pose to civilian aircraft.

title: Divided Over $9 Billion
description: By holding the countrys most popular sport in limbo Thursday  with the music and dancing extending into Friday now  the N.F.L. owners reminded us that the robber baron era consuming the business world has officially swallowed sports too. Not that any of us lived under any illusion that professional sports cared about the people that fuel its popularity, or that college sports are much more than professional sports trying to disguise themselves with a few pompoms, but Thursday still felt like being on the wrong end of a boxing match, in which you get no headgear or gloves and are outweighed by 100 pounds.

title: The Specter of Wage Declines
description: Todays jobs report is not as encouraging on wages as it is on jobs. Thats something of a reversal: for most of the past three years, the wage trends have been better than the employment trends. The economy could now be headed into a period in which unemployment is falling but wages are not keeping with inflation.

title: An Escape Device Inspired by 9/11 Victims
description: A personal escape harness inspired by the victims who jumped from the World Trade Center will be available in time for the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11 attacks, its inventor announced Tuesday at the TED conference in Long Beach, Calif.

title: Counting Species in Peru
description: Douglas Stotz of the Field Museum and Nigel Pitman of Duke University took a biological inventory of a vast roadless area in Perus northern Amazon.

title: Scorecard Update | Balenciaga
description: The fashion critics weigh in on Balenciagas fall 2011 runway show at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Wisconsin Protesters Leave Capitol After Judges Ruling
description: CHICAGO  Even as Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin began issuing layoff warnings on Friday to unions representing state employees, discussions were under way between Mr. Walkers office and State Senate Democrats who oppose his bill to cut workers bargaining power.

title: Q. and A. on Perus Northern Amazon
description: Douglas Stotz, near left, of the Field Museum in Chicago and Nigel Pitman of Duke University took a biological inventory of a vast roadless area in Perus northern Amazon.

title: On Capitol Hill, Budget Battle Continues
description: They held their tongues overnight, but Republican Congressional leaders on Friday ripped the initial Democratic offer in new budget negotiations, with Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky calling the bid of another $6.5 billion in cuts unserious.

title: On the Street | A Diverse Palette
description: The recent New York shows had an international and diverse array of guests, many bringing a fresh spirit in dressing.

title: Early Music Is Enjoying Its Moment
description: ARTISTIC revolutions rarely happen overnight, and if they do happen quickly, they do not necessarily spread uniformly. In recent decades the early-music movement has provoked a radical shift in performance styles throughout much of the music world. As an eccentric, irrelevant outsider in cultural life, the movement has managed to transform attitudes toward tradition and has wrought major changes in orchestral practice. A movement that started in powerful opposition to modern conventions has become increasingly integrated with mainstream performance.

title: A 60s Mash-Up That Didnt Happen
description: WHATEVER else it may accomplish, 1969, the latest thematic project of the contemporary-music ensemble Alarm Will Sound, proves that you can build something substantial  a historically astute program that makes solid, provocative points  around a notion thoroughly lacking in substance.

title: The Next Thing for Mr. I-Can-Do-Everything
description: IS there any kind of stage or dance work that Larry Keigwin hasnt yet turned his hand to? And are there possibly two of him? (Actually there are, sort of. Keep reading.)

title: The Week Ahead: Mar. 6  14
description: Dance

title: Weekend Competition: Define Manners
description: This weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting definitions of manners.

title: Lawyers on Ice
description: Richard Perry/The New York Times J. Gregory Milmoe of Skadden, left, and Jason Crelinsten of Proskauer walk off the ice.

title: Holding to Tradition, and Independence
description: TUCKAHOE was put on the map in the early 19th century by the discovery that it was sitting on a rich vein of brilliant white marble. Sought after by architects and builders for use in Greek Revival structures like the Capitol, the Washington Monument, the New York Public Library and St. Patricks Cathedral, the stone generated an industry that drew succeeding waves of German, Irish and Italian immigrant workers.

title: In Pro Athletes Finances, a Defensive Line Pays
description: PROFESSIONAL athletes have a horrible reputation for managing their money. It may be apocryphal, but one commonly cited statistic is that three-quarters of players in the National Football League have serious financial problems within two years of leaving the game.

title: Have It Your Way? Purist Chefs Wont Have It
description: At a pea-size Lower East Side bistro known for its fries, the admonition is spelled out on a chalkboard: No ketchup. At a popular gastropub in the West Village, customers cannot have the burger with any cheese other than Roquefort.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Face of True Evil
description: One of the great maxims of comic books is that behind every good hero is a really nasty villain. Nemesis, a mini-series published by Marvel, whose collected edition arrives at No. 8 on our hardcover list, is about the ultimate, unstoppable villain. The concept of the book has been described as what if Batman were the Joker? In other words, what if - instead of fighting for good - the smartest, toughest, richest man were a champion of evil? Nemesis was written by Mark Millar, who was also behind Kick Ass, and illustrated by Steve McNiven. Mr. Millar and Mr. McNiven were also the creative team behind Civil War, a pivotal event story line that was published in 2006 and had a lasting series of repercussions for Marvels heroes.

title: I.R.S. Tips on Changing Your Name
description: Just recently, I crossed off another task from my changing my name checklist.

title: Fla. Supreme Court Says Governor Can Reject Rail Funds
description: The Florida Supreme Court on Friday upheld Gov. Rick Scotts decision to reject more than $2 billion in federal funds to build a high-speed rail link between Tampa and Orlando, which had been a major part of the Obama administrations plan for a nationwide network.

title: Wedding Etiquette
Oh, the Dinners She Has Known
description: MANY gifted cooks have a vivid memory of their first experience in the kitchen. For Marisa Robertson-Textor, a 36-year-old freelance writer who grew up in the Bay Area of California, that memory involves making dinner for her family when she was 6. It was some riff on tacos, my favorite meal, she recalled. Preformed packaged tacos, as best I remember. Not to mention, as her mother reminded her, Minute Maid pink lemonade.

title: Habitats | Fort Greene, Brooklyn
description: Marisa Robertson-Textors apartment is filled with posters, maps, artworks and memorabilia reflecting her years in Russia and extensive travels.

title: Postscript: F.W. de Klerk Responds
description: Hows this for columnist karma: no sooner had we posted my tribute to historys graceful losers than F.W. de Klerk popped up in New York at the end of an American speaking tour to raise money for a foundation he heads. I spent an hour with him Wednesday at his hotel, discussing the negotiated surrender of white rule in South Africa and the echoes he hears in todays Middle Eastern tremors.

title: Love and Money in San Francisco
description: The economy may still be sluggish, but its been a veritable boom time for novels concerning the problems of people of privilege, those particularly American tragedies where folks with money, education and nice teeth invent elaborate ways to mess up their lives. In the last year or so, we had The Financial Lives of the Poets, by Jess Walter; Model Home, by Eric Puchner; The Privileges, by Jonathan Dee; Union Atlantic, by Adam Haslett; and Dear Money, by Martha McPhee. Joining the pack is Carol Edgarians Three Stages of Amazement, an expansive novel (with a lamentably fussy title) about the intricate economies of the American marriage.

title: News Corporation Is Carbon-Neutral, Murdoch Declares
description: The News Corporation, the media conglomerate and parent company of Fox News Channel, has gone carbon-neutral, fulfilling a goal set four years ago, Rupert Murdoch, the companys chairman, announced this week in a companywide memo.

title: Norman Foster to Design Huge Hong Kong Cultural District
description: The British architect Norman Foster has been selected to design the master plan for the 100-acre West Kowloon Cultural District in Hong Kong, his firm, Foster & Partners, announced on Friday.

title: Huckabee Slams Natalie Portman For Out-of-Wedlock Pregnancy
description: 2:42 p.m. | Updated Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas and a potential 2012 presidential candidate, has been getting lots of press recently for his comments on radio shows. The latest? This week, he went after the Hollywood star Natalie Portman.

title: Malikis Broadened Powers Seen as a Threat in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  As protesters throughout the Arab world challenge their authoritarian leaders, Iraqis, government officials and regional experts see increasing signs that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is expanding his power, undermining the fragile democracy struggling to take hold here.

title: The Week in Pictures, March 4
description: A look back at the past weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Explaining a Consequence of Closing Freddie and Fannie
description: Among the interesting consequences that could follow from shutting down the mortgage lending giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is the possibility that borrowers who now pay the same interest rates would be charged different rates in the absence of a federal guarantee.

title: Right Next to the Cake Topper? Why, Thats a Jar of Rainwater
description: A JAR of rainwater is not the sort of sentimental keepsake newlyweds usually take home from their ceremonies. The brides bouquet, absolutely. The cake topper, likely. A few monogrammed napkins, sure. But some couples do buck tradition and save unusual mementos.

title: One Size Fits All? Reflecting on the Role of Government
description: This week, Congress and President Obama acted to avert the impending government shutdown by approving a temporary budget extension.

title: Counting Down to Nuclear War
description: Every thousand years a doomsday threatens. Early Christians believed the day of judgment was nigh. Medieval millenarians expected the world to end in 1000 A.D. These fatal termini would have required supernatural intervention; in the old days humans lacked sufficient means to destroy themselves. The discovery, in 1938, of how to release nuclear energy changed all that. Humankind acquired the means of its own destruction. Even were we to succeed in eliminating our weapons of doomsday  one subject of How the End Begins  we would still know how to build them. From our contemporary double millennium forward, the essential challenge confronting our species will remain how to avoid destroying the human world.

title: Power of Apparel: A Look That Conveys a Message
description: To tour an assembly plant in Canada, Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Chrysler, wore a black sweater and a checked oxford shirt.

title: Big Deal | Luxury Market Shows Signs of Improvement
description: For months, New York City brokers have been saying that sales in luxury real estate, the last segment of the market to back away from the edge of a cliff, were rebounding. But one week sales were up, one week they were down. One month they were down, one quarter they were up.

title: Uniformed Business Leaders
description: A look at famous figures who frequently appear in the same attire.

title: Oy, Canada?
description: My take on the US economic crisis has increasingly been that banks were less central than many people think, while the housing bubble and household debt are the key players  which is why financial stabilization by itself wasnt enough to produce a V-shaped recovery.

title: 2011 Mini Cooper Countryman
description: The Countrymans length offers the Mini Cooper a new dimension of practicality.

title: City of the Future: An Airport?
description: To find yourself at La Guardia Airport, that repository of bad food, dim lighting, unsettlingly indistinct odors and too-short runways, is to be inclined toward embracing John D. Kasarda and Greg Lindsay and all they have to say about the future of travel and modern life.

title: Terra Incognita | Gregory Euclide
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#517", 592, 480, true, chameleonData);

title: A Cold War Spy Trial, Before McCarthy and the Rosenbergs
description: On Wednesday The New York Timess obituaries included one of Judith Coplon, who in 1949 was tried and convicted of giving secrets to the Soviet Union. The two counts  one for spying, the other for conspiracy  were overturned, because of improper investigative conduct by federal agents, though, as Sam Roberts reported, the evidence against her was solid and reinforced by the release, long afterward, of Soviet documents.

title: Davies to Stay on Morgan Stanley Board
description: Morgan Stanley is standing behind Sir Howard Davies.

title: Judi Dench Remembers
description: I do not consider this an autobiography, Judi Dench writes in the first line of And Furthermore, which might have come as news to her publishers. Marketed as a memoir in which, for the first time ever, Dench writes about her very private life, it is in fact a set of theatrical anecdotes, as light and intimate as an air kiss. Memwhah, if you like.

title: Wheelies: The Contingency-Plan Edition
description: In which we bring you automotive news from around the Web:

title: The First Chinese Exchange Students
description: To outsiders, China may seem purposefully dynamic. To its own people, the same ceaseless change can seem frighteningly chaotic. During my own recent three years of living there, I was often startled by the dramatic stories told by my Chinese friends  both the terrible parts (famine, split and scattered families, trust betrayed, fortunes lost) and the astonishing rebounds (an against-all-odds admission to a university, a fearless gamble that paid off, a random kindness from a generous stranger).

title: Karen Cahill and James Nicholes
description: When Karen Cahill and James Edward Nicholes went to the Manhattan Marriage Bureau on Feb. 22, they arrived in a white stretch Hummer, not to be ostentatious but because they needed a big vehicle: Five of the six children from their previous marriages were taking part in their wedding.

title: An Unfamiliar Role for Goldmans Blankfein
description: The upcoming insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam could cast Lloyd Blankfein in an unfamiliar role: cooperating witness.

title: A Philosophy of Genocides Roots
description: Consider, as Americans are so wont to do these days, the zombie. Once, he was a person, just like you or me, but then he changed. Now, despite his outward resemblance to a human being, he is a different thing altogether. He cannot disguise himself. He cannot change back. Another minus: He yearns to sink his zombie-plague-spreading teeth into your brain.

title: The Man Who Molested Me
description: Who might know a pedophile better than the child on whom he (its usually a he) has lavished his attention, sometimes for years? Who has studied him as intimately, allowing him his humanity as most of us refuse to do?

title: Up Front: Elizabeth Royte
description: Donovan Hohns Moby-Duck tracks a fleet of some 29,000 bath toys that fell off a container ship in 1992 and then drifted into unexpected geographical and metaphysical territory.

title: 28,800 Toys at Sea
description: Hast seen the white whale? a Melville-loving officer aboard a research vessel asks Donovan Hohn, in his dazzling Moby-Duck, whenever they pass in the ships corridor.

title: For Citys Transportation Chief, Kudos and Criticism
description: ON a balmy night last June, the citys Congressional delegation gathered for dinner at Gracie Mansion. Representative Anthony D. Weiner, who aspires to live in the mansion someday, knew he would have only a few minutes with the host, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. So he brought up the hottest topic he could think of: bicycle lanes, and the transportation commissioner who had nearly doubled the number of them, Janette Sadik-Khan.

title: Block Quote: The Case for the Novella
description: The only hope for a Golden Age, anymore, is being ignored. Bluntly, the novella is in its Golden Age as a form right now because no one is beating it with a stick until nickels fall out. So my plan for the novella is  drum roll: Do nothing. Or do whatever little is required to steward the status quo. Lets agree, shall we, to keep throwing around the inane term Great American Novel, and to never, ever utter the phrase Great American Novella. Lets agree not to remind California what it used to take for granted, that novellas, because of their length, can often be more handily adapted than novels into movies. Let us not remind New York what all the avid and demanding among us take for granted, that a volume of three novellas is more intriguing than one flabby novel. Let us downplay the novella in casual conversation. Writers, if you have a cant-miss commercially viable yarn a-brewing, be good enough to stretch it into a short novel or compress it into a long story. And look, lets keep the novella for ourselves, the adults. We deserve something, dont we? Lets free the novella of prizes and awards and citations and all manner of gold star. Lets fail to educate our students about the novella, fail to convince them of its charms. That way, we need never be nostalgic for the Golden Age of the novella. Weve got something they dont want, a noncommodity, and we need to look out for it.

title: House of Mirth, Updated
description: To take on a reinterpretation of one of the greatest novels of the 20th century in ones debut is, to put it mildly, a gutsy move. Victoria Pattersons first novel, This Vacant Paradise, set in Newport Beach, Calif., in the expansive, bullish 1990s, is a modern take on Edith Whartons House of Mirth. Pattersons first book, a story collection, Drift, was also set in Newport Beach, but it concerned itself mainly with drifters, lowlifes and working stiffs rather than the upper crust.

title: CSI: Georgian England
description: Four years ago, Imogen Robertson submitted the first thousand words of a historical thriller to The Daily Telegraphs Novel in a Year competition. Her opening, one of five winners, was appealing but not sensational. It moved swiftly from a couple of children lying in bed, listening as their father welcomes some visiting musicians downstairs, to a reclusive anatomist receiving news that a body has been found nearby, and back again to the children, eavesdropping on a conversation between their parents. A date and various details  a violoncello, a maid, the anatomists isolation from county society  established the setting as late-18th-century England.

title: Looking for Poe in Antarctica
description: If we can identify how the pathology of Whiteness was constructed, the narrator, Chris Jaynes, proposes early in Pym, Mat Johnsons relentlessly entertaining new novel, then we can learn how to dismantle it. For Jaynes, the only black male professor at an intimate, good but not great college, the project of making whiteness visible has led to an obsession with The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym of Nantucket, the only novel by Edgar Allan Poe.

title: Grief and Faith in Tibet
description: Trekking among the temples and monasteries of Nepal and southwestern Tibet, Colin Thubron hears variations of the same message whenever he consults a Buddhist priest: The soul has no memory. The dead do not feel their past. Its not much consolation for an agnostic Englishman, aging and childless and now, after the death of his mother, the last surviving member of his family. But consolation  emotional if not intellectual or even spiritual  is what Thubron is after as he sets off on a grueling pilgrimage to the most sacred of the worlds mountains, an insurmountable eerie white cone that rises out of a barren plain in Tibet, shielded from easy access by the natural fortress of the Himalayas and the imported vigilance of the Chinese Army. Mount Kailas, the mystic Mount Meru of the Hindu scriptures, is venerated not only by Hindus but by Buddhists, Jains and practitioners of Bon, Tibets primeval faith. Together they constitute a fifth of mankind. Yet Thubron, approaching its inscrutable fastness, feels ever more solitary.

title: A Fathers Suicide
description: There are many ways for a parent to leave a childs life. A restraining order is one of them. Divorce is another. And then theres the situation facing the novelist Michele Scott and her sons, who lost their father suddenly, unexpectedly, and by his own hand, late last year.

title: I Was a Dancer
description: Balanchines Burial

title: Balanchines Golden Boy Looks Back
description: Since Jacques dAmboise was among the most distinguished American male dancers of his day  his prime was probably 1952-74  it is startling to read, in his memoirs, of his part in a stabbing. He had been a student at the School of American Ballet for several years when in the summer of 1949, heading home through Washington Heights in Manhattan, he found himself in a clash with a local bully, who produced a switchblade. Without even thinking, I did a grand battement  a big kick  knocking his hand and sending the knife flying, dAmboise writes in I Was a Dancer. The force of my kick spun me around on the ball of my foot 360 degrees. I arrived with both feet under me in pli, leaped in the air, and jumped so high my feet kicked down on top of his shoulders, smashing him to the ground. Then dAmboise, infected by the virus of the bully, pinned down his opponent, stabbed him in the buttocks, tearing through his jeans, piercing the skin and drawing blood.

title: The Jaguar E-Type Is Still an Object of Desire
description: SINCE it was unveiled at the Geneva auto show in March 1961, the Jaguar E-Type has regularly topped lists compiled by designers and enthusiasts of the most beautiful cars ever made.

title: Why Do Writers Abandon Novels?
description: A book itself threatens to kill its author repeatedly during its composition, Michael Chabon writes in the margins of his unfinished novel Fountain City  a novel, he adds, that he could feel erasing me, breaking me down, burying me alive, drowning me, kicking me down the stairs. And so Chabon fought back: he killed Fountain City in 1992. What was to be the follow-up to his first novel, The Mysteries of Pittsburgh, instead was a black mark on his hard drive, five and a half years of work wasted.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE WRONG WAR: Grit, Strategy, and the Way Out of Afghanistan,  by Bing West (Random House, $28.) West goes a long way toward explaining why Americas embrace of counterinsurgency strategy has not delivered its promised success.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE INFINITIES,  by John Banville (Vintage International, $15.) Inspired by the myth of Amphitryon, Banvilles novel takes place over the course of a single summers day in the confines of a big, shabby house in the middle of Ireland. With a clan of mischievous Greek gods presiding, the Godley family gathers at the deathbed of Adam, their patriarch and a theoretical mathematician whose work has somehow unlocked the key to infinity.

title: When Your Life Becomes a Verb
description: LAST Monday night Matt Stone and Trey Parker, the creators of South Park, regaled the audience of Late Show with David Letterman with a vivid description of their appearance at the Academy Awards ceremony in 2000. They told the audience how they decided to dress in drag that night  their hairy chests scantily covered in silk and taffeta  which they fretted was a mistake even before they left home.

title: Picks of the Jaguar Litter
description: THE Jaguar E-Type can tick all the boxes for almost any car collector. Beautiful, fast and descended from a line of Le Mans-winning racecars, only their lack of rarity  more than 72,000 were built from 1961-74  keeps them off the A-list of collectible European sports cars. But accessibility has always been part of the Jaguar equation: even new, the cars offered performance and looks on par with European exotics that cost much more.

title: Tweeters Ask Mayor About Magnets, Etc. Mayor Answers.
description: If you could ask Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg a question, anything at all, what would it be? Would it be about traffic or budget cuts? Crime? Layoffs? Maybe youd go for an old standby: Whats it like to be so rich?

title: Food Photography: Mastering the Pour Shot
description: Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce.

title: Take Back the Trash
description: THE fight goes something like this: My wife and I are rummaging through the refrigerator after dinner, looking for space for the leftovers, when suddenly she goes on a jag against all the food that has overstayed its welcome. She starts madly purging, like one of those old Soviet dictators cleansing the politburo after a coup. Shell pick up a container of cheese, hummus, chutney or vinaigrette, glance at the date stamped on the package, and if the date is coming up in, say, the next few days, shell summarily toss it into the trash.

title: No Longer Tangled Up, Dylan Concerts Are Planned in China
description: Its not exactly Richard M. Nixon going to China, but it is someone who also made some memorable recordings in the 1970s: Bob Dylan is likely to play his first concerts in mainland China this spring, one year after a previously scheduled set of shows there fell through, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Average Length of Unemployment Reaches High
description: 3:14 p.m. | Updated See note on break in the data series below.

title: Loughner Faces 49 Counts in Tucson Shootings
description: PHOENIX  Prosecutors filed 49 federal charges Friday against Jared L. Loughner, the suspect in the Tucson shooting rampage, accusing him of murdering and attempting to murder five federal officials; killing four constituents of Representative Gabrielle Giffords who were attending a public event she sponsored; and injuring 10 others waiting in line to talk to her.

title: Inside the List
description: STARTER WIFE: In The Paris Wife, new at No. 9 on the hardcover fiction list, Paula McLain gives a sympathetic portrait of Hadley Richardson, the self-effacing homebody that Ernest Hemingway divorced in 1927 in favor of her best friend, Pauline Pfeiffer.

title: No Charges for Officers in Harlem Shooting
description: A special grand jury in Manhattan has declined to bring charges against four police officers who were involved in a fatal shooting and fired a total of 46 rounds while trying to break up a fight at a block party, according to a union that represents police officers.

title: Transformations | Situ Studios reOrder
description: We all have our favorite one, Wes Rozen muses, referring to the field of columns in the Brooklyn Museums Great Hall, which he and his colleagues in the design firm Situ Studio have turned into fabric-covered, warped and twisted versions of their Beaux-Arts originals, complete with integrated seating. The installation, reOrder: An Architectural Environment by Situ Studio, opens to the public on Saturday and is part enchanted forest and part architectural debutantes ball, in which the structural elements appear to start dancing through the otherwise static space. (The designers also credit the museums 19th-century costume collection as inspiration for their crinoline-like structures.)

title: Mary Oey and Prem Kumar
description: Mary F. Oey and Prem Ganesh Kumar were married Friday at the Superior Court of the District of Columbia. Geneva Murphy, the chief of the domestic relations branch of the family court, officiated.

title: Lauren Smythe, Daniel Wasser
description: Lauren Courtney Smythe, the daughter of Jody Smythe and Thomas Smythe of Plantation, Fla., was married Saturday evening in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Daniel Craig Wasser, a son of Deborah Wasser and Dr. Kenneth Wasser of Little Silver, N.J. Rabbi Loring Frank officiated at the Hilton Fort Lauderdale Marina.

title: Sarah Katt, Luke Meixner
description: Sarah Jeanette Katt and Luke Robert Meixner were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Joshua Boettiger at the Beekman Arms, a hotel in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: Emily Popp, Charles Finch III
description: Emily Linda Popp and Charles Baker Finch III were married Tuesday at the Monroe County Courthouse in Key West, Fla. Lisa Pierce, a deputy clerk of the court, officiated.

title: Adrienne Saunders, Richard Guberman
description: Adrienne Faye Saunders married Richard Mark Guberman Saturday evening at the Harold Pratt House and Peterson Hall, an event space in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated, and Cantor George Lindenblatt participated.

title: Lucy Baker and Alexander Brandes
description: Lucy Allison Baker and Alexander James Brandes were married Saturday evening at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Edward Schecter officiated.

title: Dabee Kaye, Andrew Bernstein
description: Dabee Rene Kaye and Andrew Michael Bernstein were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton, Battery Park in New York. Cantor Endre Stamler officiated.

title: Susan Cahan, Jrgen Bank
description: Susan Elizabeth Cahan and Jrgen Bank were married Saturday evening in New Haven. Xinia Robles Stein, a Connecticut justice of the peace and a maternal cousin of the bride, officiated in the couples apartment on the campus of Yale University.

title: Vivian Liu and Donald Lin
description: Vivian Yuan Liu, a daughter of Yie Lee and Mei Sheng Liu of Closter, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Donald Kuang Lin, the son of Christine C. Lin and Ming C. Lin of Parsippany, N.J. Michael Stuempfle, a minister of Open Door Ministries, officiated at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios in Brooklyn.

title: Felicia Morris and Christopher Principe
description: Felicia Ann Morris and Christopher Joseph Principe were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Jeffrey von Arx, a Roman Catholic priest and the president of Fairfield University who is also the bridegrooms uncle, performed the ceremony.

title: Miriam Udel and Adam Newton
description: Miriam Jenny Udel and Adam Zachary Newton are to be married Sunday at the Metropolitan Building, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Stephen S. Friedman is to officiate, and Wendy A. Amsellem, a teacher of the Talmud and Jewish law, is to give a blessing.

title: Ruskin Cooper and William Carpenter
description: Ruskin King Cooper and William Scott Carpenter were married Tuesday by Jon Hunt, a Connecticut justice of the peace, at Town Hall in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Gari Gold and Peter Richardson
description: Gari Gold and Peter Gould Richardson were married Saturday at the Little Church of the West, a wedding chapel in Las Vegas. Timothy Rowland, pastor of the Sunrise Community Church in Las Vegas, officiated.

title: Morissa Falk, Michael Freedman
description: Morissa Robin Falk and Michael Cohen Freedman were married Saturday evening at Waters Edge, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Daniel Alder officiated, with Rabbi Rebecca P. Rosenthal assisting.

title: Rachel Goodman, Jonathan Wilf
description: Rachel Glenna Goodman, a daughter of Cheryl and Michael H. Goodman of Villanova, Pa., is to be married Sunday to Jonathan Zachary Wilf, a son of Audrey and Zygmunt Wilf of Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Ethan Franzel is to officiate at the Westin Philadelphia Hotel.

title: Iceland Court Hands Bobby Fischer Estate to Japanese Claimant
description: PARIS  A long fight over the estate of the chess champion Bobby Fischer appears to have reached its endgame, with a court ruling that a Japanese woman is indeed his widow and heir.

title: Finding Bliss in Bahia Bustamante
description: A huge, almost untouched swath of Argentine Patagonia, Bahia Bustamante combines Atlantic coastline, pastures, fields, desert and canyons.

title: Where the Jobs Are, and Arent
description: Two categories stand out in the jobs numbers, a one good and a one bad.

title: When the Boy Next Door Was Evil
description: NO one likes to argue that the world needs more wickedness. What with despots, Charlie Sheen and rail riders who feel that quiet-car restrictions apply to everyone but them, it seems we already have plenty to go around. And yet advocating for more wickedness is exactly what I am forced to do after watching Season 1 of Dennis the Menace, which is being released this month on DVD by Shout! Factory.

title: Indie-Label Folkie to Rock Patriarch
description: JAC HOLZMAN, the 79-year-old founder and former chairman of Elektra Records, might be expected to rest on his laurels. Yet Mr. Holzman, who will be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame on March 14, was in his office at Rockefeller Center, as usual, one recent Saturday morning at Warner Music Group, where he is a senior adviser to its chairman, Edgar Bronfman Jr.

title: Sad Out West, Rocking Out in Brooklyn
description: Lykke Li

title: Santurce Section of San Juan Aspires to Be an Arts Mecca
description: ON a recent Friday night, the streets of Santurce in San Juan, P.R., were filled with a parade of 20-somethings wearing thick-rimmed reading glasses, retro high-tops and limited-edition T-shirts. This style-conscious young crowd  drawn by a cultural festival  has become an increasingly common sight in this sleepy, mostly working-class neighborhood that in recent decades fell into disrepair.

title: Hotel Review: W Retreat and Spa  Vieques Island
description: THE BASICS

title: In Vienna, a Bespoke Tradition Thrives
description: AT the threshold of Rudolf Scheer & Shne in Vienna, a company that has made shoes since 1816 and was the Austro-Hungarian imperial courts cobbler starting in 1878, I hesitated. Not a soul was inside the chapel-like storefront. I entered, stepped across a creaky wood floor, past a vitrine displaying antique wooden lasts, then ascended a narrow staircase along the back wall. Upstairs, in a kind of anteroom, there they were: exquisite shoes and boots, made by a family that has custom-shod royalty, celebrities and the very tasteful for nearly two centuries. A man emerged from the back workshop. Do you make ladies shoes, too? I asked timidly.

title: Skiing Igloo-to-Igloo Across the Grand Tetons
description: THE view from my airplane window at Jackson Hole airport was one that most skiers would envy: snow cyclones purling down the runway, baggage attendants in ski goggles, drifts the size of camper vans framing the arrival gate. The Grand Tetons, which jut from the high prairie of western Wyoming like a serrated knife, were not even visible as the plane came to a stop. There was only white. And, as I descended the planes stairs, cold. Which would have been sublime had I been headed to a slope-side condominium to schuss the Jackson Hole Mountain Resort for the week.

title: In Cambodia, Koh Kong Emerges as an Eco-Tourism Destination
description: INSIDE a breezy bamboo structure in Chi Phat, a village in the remote province of Koh Kong, near the Thai border in southwestern Cambodia, a dozen or so foreigners sat down to a communal dinner of chicken curry and Angkor Beer. Cinnamon-hued cattle and elderly women wearing ikat sarongs and checkered scarves ambled along the dusty road outside.

title: Bahia Bustamante: Argentinas Secret (and Private) Answer to the Galapagos
description: THE first thing you notice is the scale of everything. The unending distance between towns, the unfathomable stretch of land between you and the horizon, the vast expanses of sky.

title: Old Mexico City Mixes in the New
description: In the Santa Mara la Ribera neighborhood, northwest of the citys historic center, vestiges of former grandeur remain, even as a new generation of artists, art spaces, boutiques and bars has moved in.

title: The Call of the Wilds in Cambodia
description: In Koh Kong province, new eco-friendly resorts are drawing both backpackers and more luxury-oriented travelers.

title: Vienna, a Paradise for Modern-Day Dandies
description: Shoppers can find holdovers from the late 19th century, when every European city had its local milliners, master tailors and star shoemakers.

title: Finding Bliss in Bahia Bustamante
description: A huge, almost untouched swath of Argentine Patagonia, Bahia Bustamante combines Atlantic coastline, pastures, fields, desert and canyons.

title: A Real Ballerina Hits the Big Screen: A Conversation With Natalia Osipova
description: Dancing as Kitri in Don Quixote at the Metropolitan Opera House last year, Natalia Osipova proved herself the most sensational ballerina now before the public, Alastair Macaulay wrote. On Sunday balletomanes will get another chance to see the 24-year-old Ms. Osipova in the role, this time from the comfort of a soft movie theater seat, popcorn optional. At 11 a.m., Eastern time, Emerging Pictures will screen in high-definition a live performance from Moscow of a Bolshoi Theater production of Don Quixote starring Ms. Ospipova and Ivan Vasiliev.

title: National Day of Unplugging
description: Sundown Friday marks the start of the National Day of Unplugging. Scheduled to coincide with the Jewish Sabbath, the day is meant to encourage us to disconnect our devices and reconnect with one another.

title: On Our Radar: The Most Typical Person in the World
Morgan Stanley Vice Chairman to Leave
description: 3:57 p.m. | Updated

title: Another Hike on the Moors for Jane Eyre
description: CARY FUKUNAGA, the director of the new movie version of Jane Eyre, which opens Friday, joked recently that there was an unwritten law requiring that Jane Eyre be remade every five years. It sometimes feels that way. Of all the classic 19th-century novels, Charlotte Bronts Jane Eyre has been by far the most filmed, outstripping even the ever-durable Pride and Prejudice.

title: The Chasm Between Consumers and the Fed
description: INFLATION in the United States is low, and seems to be going down if it is moving at all. The Federal Reserve thinks it will be years before there is any significant inflation.

title: The Work of Stefano Pilati
description: Ready-to-wear clothes from Yves Saint Laurent, designed by Stefano Pilati.

title: Balanced on Fashions Wobbly Pedestal
description: Paris

title: Haute Tables | Paris Japonaise
description: While Japans fashion designers (Miyake, Yamomoto, et al) are well know for their time as expats in Paris, the new wave of Japanese transplants in France are more likely to be cooking than sketching. In recent years, in fact, the French capital has become home to an unusual number of classic French restaurants run by Japanese chefs, along with a slew of new Franco-Japanese hybrids. And while the food at Michelin-starred, Japanese-run veterans like Hiramatsu (52, rue de Longchamp; 011-33-1-56-81-08-80) and Stella Maris (4, rue Arsene Houssaye; 011-33-1-42-89-16-22) is very classically French, many of the newer arrivals are letting their Japanese heritage come through clearly.

title: Star-Studded Early Music in Toronto
description: TORONTO  Sometimes you get lucky. I came here to see how the Toronto Symphony was faring a decade after its troubled times, and that, it turns out, would have been satisfying enough.

title: Cervelli to Miss 6-8 Weeks With Broken Foot
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The backup catching competition was blown open Friday when the Yankees announced that Francisco Cervelli will miss six to eight weeks because of a broken left foot. His injury increases the likelihood that Jesus Montero, the touted 21-year-old prospect, will make the opening day roster, although Joe Girardi said that Austin Romine and the veteran Gustavo Molina also remain in the mix. The Yankees still plan to use Jorge Posada at designated hitter.

title: Greenspan on Corporate Profits and the State of the Economy
description: Addressing robust corporate profits, Alan Greenspan, a former Federal Reserve chairman, says this does not mean a business is willing to invest in illiquid assets. He says, however, that there is a positive effect from paper profits. Greenspan also shares thoughts on whether the economy is picking up significant speed and the outlook for inflation in this CNBC video.

title: Where William Tell Is an Amateur
description: NEWARK  You can buy all sorts of stuff from the concessionaires at the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, but the things you may want the most after seeing this years show arent for sale.

title: The Circus Returns
description: The Ringling Brothers extravaganza returns to New Jersey and Long Island.

title: TimesCast | March 04, 2011
description: Qaddafi forces fire on protesters following Friday prayers; the rebels' spokeswoman in  Benghazi; and budget protest spin on the cable news networks.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Sam Talbot has opened his elegant restaurant Imperial No. Nine in the Mondrian SoHo hotel, with crystal chandeliers and sustainable seafood. And Edi & the Wolf, the casual Austrian spot at 102 Avenue C (East Seventh Street) in the East Village, introduces brunch this weekend from 11:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. with dishes like schnitzel burger and kaiserschmarrn (caramelized pancake bits with seasonal fruit). Each table also receives a complimentary bread basket with croissants, mini pain au chocolat and two other kinds of breads.

title: More on Mens Wages
description: One more thought on the Hamilton Project chart showing a big decline in mens wages since 1969: it is not depicting the wage history of a typical male worker. The typical 50-year full-time male worker, for instance, is not making 28 percent less than the equivalent man was in 1969.

title: No Glory (Satellite) in Space
description: .The loss of the Glory satellite early this morning is another setback for efforts to fill substantial gaps in the understanding of some important aspects of the climate system. Just over two years ago, another important satellite, the Orbiting Carbon Observatory, was destroyed in a failed launch. Components that contributed to that failure (couplings for a clamshell-like shield over the satellite) had been redesigned and three successful launches took place last year, mission officials said at a news conference (video is below).

title: Survey Finds Widespread Mis-Selling by Brokers
description: Mom-and-pop investors beware.

title: Book Review Podcast: Michael Frayn
description: The novelist and playwright Michael Frayn on his memoir, My Fathers Fortune; Donovan Hohn on his book, Moby-Duck; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Jane, Rochester and That Zombie
description: In the dozens of versions for the big and small screens, artists have tried to make Jane Eyre their own.

title: The Footprints of Web Feet
description: SHARING and communicating are essential components of being human. But as celebrities like Britney Spears and Charlie Sheen have shown us lately, there is such a thing as over-sharing.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Egypt, Pakistan and Paris.

title: Chic in Review | The Trouble With John (Galliano)
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: George C. Wolfe To Help Out on The Normal Heart
description: One star can only do so much at once on Broadway, even if hes Tony and Academy Award winner Joel Grey.

title: Conductor Makes Philharmonic Debut With Sufi Poetry and Celestial Yearnings
description: Few conductors the age of Daniel Harding have had his extensive international experience. Currently this 35-year-old British artist is the music director of the Swedish Radio Symphony Orchestra, the principal conductor of the Mahler Chamber Orchestra, the principal guest conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra and a presence on opera podiums including La Scala and Covent Garden. He proved himself to New Yorkers last fall when he opened Lincoln Centers Great Performers season, conducting two impressive programs with the Dresden Staatskapelle.

title: Skipping Through Russia, Lingering in a Biblical Age
description: The composer Judd Greensteins music, beautifully wrought and consistently appealing, has not always seemed as audacious as his barnstorming initiatives with NOW Ensemble, the New Amsterdam record label and the Ecstatic Music Festival, all of which he helped to found. But Shlomo (Solomon), introduced during a festival program at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night, felt like an epiphany. Played by Mr. Greensteins new ensemble, the Yehudim, this work in progress fuses his disparate musical inspirations with his abiding interest in Jewish history and literature to explosive effect.

title: Adding It Up: Amazon Ship vs. Costco Shop
description: For millions of Costco customers, this is an eagerly awaited time of year. Right about now is when their big annual rebate checks arrive from American Express.

title: More Anne Marsen
description: For this weekends issue of the magazine, I wrote about Girl Walk//All Day, an epic, 71-minute-long dance-music video being created by Jacob Krupnick, Anne Marsen and a few collaborators. Online, you can see the eight-minute trailer that Krupnick cut from their guerrilla-style test shoot on and around the Staten Island Ferry in January, as well as a frantic and funny music video involving buses, cats, text messages and brownie mix that Marsen made (and starred in) a year ago.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Egypt, Pakistan and Paris.

title: Lets Play 2,471!
description: Opening day is still a month away, but you have only this weekend to finish your application for MLB.coms Dream Job, which seeks one lucky fan to eat, sleep and live baseball for an entire season. The job apparently entails being confined to some kind of baseball-themed dungeon and watching every inning of every game, all the while blogging and chatting and tweeting and texting about the experience.

title: CBS Buys Clicker and Names New Digital Media Chief
description: The CBS Corporation said on Friday that it had acquired Clicker, a guide to online television, and installed its chief executive, Jim Lanzone, as the head of its digital media division.

title: Obama and Jeb Bush Visit a Miami School
description: President Obama and Jeb Bush, the Republican former governor of Florida, joined in an awkward partnership on Friday, when Mr. Obama visited a high school here to push his plans to boost education funding and revamp No Child Left Behind, the school policy bill signed into law by Mr. Bushs brother, the former president.

title: Environmental Impact: Costco vs. Amazon
description: I probably could have written an entire column on the question of whether Costco or Amazon.coms Subscribe & Save program is the more environmentally friendly choice. Instead, I gave it a brief mention in my column this weekend.

title: Kicking the Costco Habit
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I ran a little experiment. Id always wondered how much money I was really saving by shopping at Costco and whether it was worth the two hours it generally takes round trip.

title: Motus Motorcycles: Sport-Touring, American Style
description: So you want to start a motorcycle company? Better do your homework first, because the list of those who have succeeded in recent years is short indeed.

title: Goodbye, DVD. Hello, Future.
description: THAT distant rumble you hear is the sound of yet another approaching cultural shift, accompanied by all the shouts of joy and gnashing of teeth that come with such upheaval.

title: And the Prize Goes to
description: For just over a year now, Ive been conducting a literary experiment on Twitter: tweeting the best sentence I read every day. (Well, not every single day, but almost. And its not always the No. 1 very best sentence Ive read  its the best sentence, or the best verbal chunk, that will fit into Twitters 140-character straitjacket.)

title: Unrest in Libya and the Middle East Is Costing the Russian Arms Industry
description: MOSCOW  In its statements and actions, Russia has joined the international community in condemning the violence by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya against his citizens. But that has not stopped Russia from counting up its business losses from canceled arms sales to Libya.

title: Fighting Continues as Libyas Rebellion Enters Third Week
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis government struck hard at protesters in Tripoli and at a rebel-controlled town.

description: Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigned in the towns and villages of New Hampshire, from Derry to Nashua.

title: Obama Launches 2012 Fundraising Effort in Miami
description: President Obama officially launches the 2012 money chase in Miami Friday night, offering fundraising assistance to Democratic senators even as his own staff begins the run for $1 billion.

title: Gunman in Germany Wanted Revenge for Afghanistan
description: FRANKFURT  Arid Uka, the 21-year-old man suspected of killing two American airmen this week, has told investigators that he was seeking revenge for the deployment of Americans in Afghanistan after watching radical Islamist videos on the Internet, German authorities said Friday.

title: Sake-Steamed Chicken? Who Needs Crispy!
description: STEAMED chicken is not the kind of dish that makes my mouth water. It sounds like bland diet food, better spoon-fed to someone feeling under the weather.

title: Prosecutors Link Former Goldman Director to Galleon
description: 7:04 p.m. | Updated

title: Idol Gives a Boost To Fox and Thursday
description: On a night of mostly repeats in prime time a two-hour edition of American Idol helped Fox earn the highest ratings of any network on a Thursday in four years. According to Nielsens estimates an average of 25 million viewers watched the reality competition from 8 to 10 p.m. as the top 13 finalists were revealed. CBS ranked second over all with a new episode of Rules of Engagement at 8:30 (8.3 million) following a rerun of The Big Bang Theory at 8 (9.2 million). The rest of CBSs lineup, CSI (8.7 million) and The Mentalist (10.4 million), remained largely solid in repeats. ABC was third and NBC in fourth.

title: Espada Is Upbeat as Judge Sets Trial Date
description: Pedro Espada Jr., the former State Senate majority leader who is facing federal corruption charges, strode into federal court in Brooklyn on Friday with a far different demeanor than he did four months ago.

title: Excerpt: 'Dennis the Menace'
description: The sitcom, which debuted in 1959, receives a DVD release.

title: TVs Problem Children
description: Sitcoms have featured plenty of scamps but none so mischievous as Dennis the Menace.

title: Golden Girl
description: LAST Wednesday evening, Blake Lively, the star of Gossip Girl, arrived at La Grenouille in Midtown, where Chanel had organized a dinner to introduce her as the new face of the French fashion houses Mademoiselle handbag ad campaign. Wearing a white Chanel minidress that contained  at least, to a degree  her famously curvaceous torso while still showing off her long, perpetually tanned legs, the 23-year-old Ms. Lively seemed, at times, to have trouble believing that she was the focal point of the room.

title: The Perils of Libyas Loose Arms, Part II
description: While it has already been well established that Libyas stocks of portable antiaircraft missiles have been broken into by rebels in the countrys east, what is less known is how well the now loose missiles might work. The one bit of evidence so far, a photograph by Tyler Hicks, suggests that at least some of the looted stock was manufactured in 1977. Manpads, as these weapons are commonly called, are perishable items, and can become less reliable with the passage of time, the exposure to elements, and, like many munitions, to heat cycling, or the exposure to swings in ambient temperature over time.

title: A Harvard Sweep? Dont Remind Me
description: In Fridays Times, Peter May wrote about the expectation surrounding the Harvard mens basketball team as it headed into Friday nights game with Penn and Saturdays against Princeton:

title: A Feisty Singing Gypsy, Right There on Your Lap
description: If you want to see Carmen in 3-D, get thee to an opera house!

title: A Last-Minute Juliette Stands Tall in Verona
description: There are singers who hold an opera company together, and theyre not the ones you might think. These singers dont star in new productions; their photos arent on the posters. They sing the supporting parts, the Zerlinas and Micalas, and when they do get leading roles, its often late in runs after the critics have gone home.

title: Money Lessons From Athletes
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan discusses how professional athletes handle their money.

title: Courtney Love Settles Twitter Defamation Case

description: TEMPE, Ariz. - The last time Jake Peavy had pitched in a game, his latissimus dorsi muscle detached from his back. Think about that.

description: ROME  In response to the murderous tactics of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis militias against unarmed protesters, the United States and the European Union have announced steps to freeze the governments assets, and the International Criminal Court has opened an investigation into possible crimes against humanity.

title: Surprise! Daddys Home, From War
description: Surprise reunions are amazingly popular  YouTube is crammed with home videos of soldiers returning from Iraq and Afghanistan  unannounced  to their spouses offices or their childrens classrooms. One clip, in which a bubbly fourth-grade girl, Hannah, falls to pieces when her father, Master Sgt. Joseph Myers of the Air Force, walks in, has been watched more than 3.7 million times.

title: Crisis at Princeton
description: Dont worry, the school is doing fine. Were talking about the wider world.

title: Slicing Up Brains to Advance in High School
description: The Web was abuzz this week with news that Natalie Portman had a secret past as a science geek and was once a semifinalist at the Intel Science Talent Search, one of the oldest high school science competitions in the country.

title: Soldier in Leaks Case Will Be Made to Sleep Naked Nightly
description: WASHINGTON  Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, the Army intelligence analyst accused of leaking government files to WikiLeaks, will be stripped of his clothing every night as a precautionary measure to prevent him from injuring himself, an official at the Marine brig at Quantico, Va., said on Friday.

title: A Free Man Still Looks Over His Shoulder in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY

title: Aligning His Planets for Another Star Turn
description: Clive Barnes once wrote, I challenge anyone with any feeling for the dance in his bones not to love Orbs. Its certainly a line that can be repeated on the occasion of its revival by the Paul Taylor Dance Company. First performed in 1966, Orbs is ambitious, but its more than that  its magnificent.

title: Scorecard | Balenciaga Wins!
description: Scorecard knows day three of Paris fashion week always brings the Bal-same competition between two resurgent giants of the couture era  and results. Yet at the house that Pierre Balmain founded, where it was almost a party as usual though the current designer Christophe Decarnin appeared to be missing, critics werent sure where to assign blame. Meanwhile the heir to fashions Picasso Cristbal Balenciaga, Nicolas Ghesquire, scaled new, illustrious heights.

title: Filming Couples in Motion While Being One Themselves
description: Welcome to Ver-Bronx, the actor Jon Hamm said, inviting a group of visitors into the seemingly paradoxical setting of a Vermont-style log cabin on a waterfront strip nestled between the Throgs Neck and Bronx-Whitestone bridges.

title: Thousands Protest Detentions of Turkish Journalists
description: ISTANBUL  Thousands of people protested in two Turkish cities on Friday in response to the detention this week of seven journalists, a development that has prompted new expressions of concern from Europe and the United States about the state of press freedom in Turkey.

title: Gingrich Files Campaign Form With I.R.S.
description: 9:08 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, took the first official step toward running for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination on Friday by filing paperwork with the Internal Revenue Service to explore a potential candidacy. The new organization, Newt Exploratory 2012, will report its contributors and expenses to the I.R.S.; it is not required to report to the Federal Election Commission unless Mr. Gingrich becomes an official candidate. Mr. Gingrich is listed as the committees only officer, and his chief election lawyer, Stefan C. Passantino, as the committees treasurer.
