title: Better Place Reveals E.V. Charging Plan and Customer Center in Denmark
description: After years of planning, Better Place, the California-based electric-vehicle infrastructure company, opened its first showroom in Europe on Thursday. The Better Place Center, near Copenhagen, will display the Renault Fluence Z.E.  an electric car with swappable lithium-ion batteries  and will function as a gateway for Danish consumers to learn how the car fits into the companys approach.

title: First Amendment Rulings
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable Channels Choosing Sides in Union Protests
House Republicans Move to Uphold Marriage Act
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans quietly moved Friday to uphold the Defense of Marriage Act, the 1996 law that bans federal recognition of same-sex marriages, saying they would step in to argue for the measures constitutionality after the Obama administrations decision to stop defending it.

title: Taping Inmate Phone Calls
description: To the Editor:

title: Spider-Man Cited for Federal Safety Violations
description: Federal regulators on Friday cited Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark for three serious workplace safety violations, though the proposed fine of $12,600 is unlikely to faze a production that has already run through $65 million.

title: At the Slava Cup in Moscow, Leading Issues Swing Points
description: The ninth Slava Cup was contested at the Moscow City Golf Club from Feb. 18 to 20. Sixteen top pairs were invited to compete for the $10,000 first prize.

title: What Price a Pound of Flesh?
description: If youve scanned the headlines recently, you have no doubt been freshly reminded that the toxin of anti-Semitism has hardly been eradicated from contemporary culture. In the last couple of weeks it has surfaced spectacularly in the worlds of show business and fashion, blighting, if not ending, two major careers.

title: Eavesdropping on the Weekend
description: What are you reading, watching or listening to this weekend? Hugo Lindgren, our editor in chief, asked all of us at the magazine. I compiled some answers:

title: Reviewing the Mini Cooper Countryman
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer takes the measure of the Mini Cooper Countryman. The BMW subsidiarys largest model to date brings two significant additions to the range  all-wheel drive and a considerable amount of storage space  without diluting the brands DNA. He writes:

title: Goldmans Own Ferries Will Ply the Hudson
description: Tis the season for investment bankers to tool around in Italian sports cars purchased with this years bonus checks. But only the employees of Goldman Sachs will be riding on their own ferryboats.

title: Islander Lasts 3 Shifts Before Earning Another Suspension
description: The Islanders Trevor Gillies, who had just returned from a nine-game suspension, was suspended 10 games Friday by the N.H.L. for delivering a blow to the head of Minnesota forward Cal Clutterbuck in a game Wednesday at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Cutting the Budget, and Then What?
description: To the Editor:

title: As Health Costs Soar, G.O.P. and Insurers Differ on Cause
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Workers at a circuit-board factory here just saw their health insurance premiums rise 20 percent. At Buddy Zarembas print shop nearby, the increase was 37 percent. And for engineers at the Woodland Design Group, they rose 43 percent.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 4
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a union rally in New Jersey, a church in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, and a dispute at the Dakota.

title: Inside Mars Needs Moms
description: A look at the production process for the film.

title: Captured Across the Cosmos
description: IN the past seven years 3-D performance-capture technology has taken moviegoers to far-reaching places like the North Pole, sixth-century Denmark and the moon Pandora. So Mars would seem a reasonable next stop on the journey of a process that is continually transforming the way we watch.

title: Hairnets, Yes; Fried Foods, No
description: Steak, lobster, McDonalds: Ask students in New York Citys public schools what their cafeterias should be serving, and those are the top three answers. Their parents have a lot of suggestions, too, which are rarely any more realistic. Eric Goldstein, the Department of Education executive who oversees school food, fields those suggestions. Frequently, he says, they start like this: I just ate in this really great restaurant for $100 a person and this cafeteria food doesnt compare with that.

title: Bodies of Evidence
description: Dr. Ramin Asgary, of New Yorks Mount Sinai School of Medicine, traces the scars of torture victims seeking asylum.

title: Convivio Shuts Its Door and Alto May Do So Also
description: Eater breaks the news that Chris Cannon has closed his restaurant Convivio  and possibly Alto.

title: Proving Torture, to Help Win Asylum
description: A MAN from Mauritania sat stone-faced, cradling his head, which bore a scar that marked the spot where his master had gouged him with a piece of firewood, he told the doctor. A Congolese businessman showed a deformed knee that, to the doctors trained eye, indicated a forced fracture. And a man from Southeast Asia was sure that a mark on his lower torso was evidence of a beating with a bat, though a medical examination showed that it was a sign of a fungal infection.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Photographs from features and news articles in business.

title: App Smart Extra: The (New) Best Android Photo App
description: When I published my list of Top 10 Android Apps late last year, FXCamera was the only entry from the photography category.

title: In Paris, Ovations Where Merited
description: Paris

title: St. Joe Names Ex-Chairman as Interim Chief
description: The St. Joe Company has named Hugh Durden, its former chairman, as interim chief executive after settling a dispute with its largest shareholder, Fairholme Capital, the company said in regulatory filing on Friday.

title: Pastor Stirs Wrath With His Views on Old Questions
description: A new book by one of the countrys most influential evangelical pastors, challenging traditional Christian views of heaven, hell and eternal damnation, has created an uproar among evangelical leaders, with the most ancient of questions being argued in a biblical hailstorm of Twitter messages and blog posts.

title: C. S. Lewiss Legacy Lives on, and Not Just Through the Wardrobe
description: Who, since the time of Jesus and his apostles, has brought more people to Christianity than anybody else?

title: Sunday Routine I Rev. Al Sharpton
description: An early riser, the Rev. Al Sharpton recites poetry for inspiration, hops on the treadmill, does two radio shows and preaches at church services around town.

title: Gates Ratchets Up His Campaign of Candor
description: WASHINGTON  This is the season when defense secretaries typically sit for hours, hat in hand, before Congressional committees to plead for more money and then journey to the military academies to give perfunctory speeches about patriotism before young cadets.

title: Financial Fraud Case Pits Arbitration vs. Class Actions
description: Ewald Groetsch was lonely after his wife died in 2003. Mr. Groetsch, a retired grocery wholesaler who had dementia, struck up a relationship with a broker from Securities America and eventually agreed to put the bulk of his portfolio into a risky security usually reserved for experienced investors.

title: The Wake-Up Is a Victory
description: Unmistakable and formidable, if a physically reduced version of the man he once was, the Rev. Al Sharpton, 56, uses Sundays as his half-down day. Its a workday, for sure  including two hourlong radio broadcasts  but it also offers chances for decompression, companionship, exercise, sending texts and posting on Twitter. A Brooklyn native, Mr. Sharpton lives in a two-bedroom apartment in the West 70s in Manhattan. DAVID M. HALBFINGER

title: Italy: Priest Is Sentenced to Prison
description: A Rome court has sentenced a Catholic priest to 15 years and four months in prison for sexually abusing minors, in one of the rare cases in Italy in which a bishop was called to testify in civil court. The Rev. Ruggero Conti, from a parish in Rome, was found guilty on Thursday of abusing seven minors between 1998 and 2008, a lawyer for the priest said. The court also ordered Father Conti to pay 50,000 euros ($70,000) in damages to each victim. Father Conti was suspended from his duties as a parish priest in the outskirts of Rome soon after his arrest in 2008, but not from his clerical duties, said his lawyer, Patrizio Spinelli. He said his client would appeal the ruling.

title: Far From the Mets, Takahashi Makes Angels Debut
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Hisanori Takahashi was a bright spot in a bleak season for the 2010 Mets. A 10-year veteran of the Yomiuri Giants, Takahashi was 10-6 with a 3.61 earned run average, making 12 starts and 41 relief appearances. Yet the Mets allowed him to leave as a free agent, and he signed with the Angels for two years and $8 million.

title: Florida: Rejection of Rail Money Stands
description: The State Supreme Court on Friday upheld Gov. Rick Scotts decision to reject $2.4 billion in federal money to build a high-speed rail link between Tampa and Orlando, part of the Obama administrations plan for a nationwide network. Mr. Scott, a Republican, has said he wants no part of the project, calling it a boondoggle. The ruling was in response to a suit filed by two state senators, who said Mr. Scott had exceeded his authority. The Transportation Department will evaluate options for making the funds available to other states.

title: Texas: Capital Trial Is Suggested in Rampage at Fort Hood
description: An Army colonel recommended Friday that Maj. Nidal M. Hasan be tried by a general court-martial and face the death penalty in the shooting deaths of 13 people at Fort Hood in 2009. The recommendation by Col. Morgan Lamb now goes to Lt. Gen. Robert W. Cone, the Fort Hood commander, who will decide whether to convene a court-martial at the base or pass the case to another general elsewhere. John P. Galligan, a retired colonel and a lawyer for Major Hasan, said he did not believe that his client could receive a fair trial at the base.

title: Swimming While the Tide Turns in Tunisia
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Maybe Ous Mellouli is swimming so well because his shoulder no longer feels as if its being stabbed every time he races, as was the case last summer when he competed for his native Tunisia despite a torn rotator cuff.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Repeat Offender Gillies 10 Games
description: The N.H.L. has suspended Islanders forwardTrevorGillies for 10 games a blow to the head of Minnesota Wild wing Cal Clutterbuck, the league said the league Friday afternoon.

title: Britain: A Royal Visit to Ireland
description: Queen Elizabeth is to make a state visit to the Irish Republic this year, the first by a British monarch in 100 years and the only one since Ireland broke from Britain to become an independent country. The visit, which will likely take place in early summer, is of huge symbolic importance and illustrates how far relations between Britain and Ireland have come since the struggles over independence and the worst days of the Troubles between the nationalists and unionists in Northern Ireland. Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, criticized the trip as premature but said that he respected the Irish presidents right to invite the queen to come.

title: Last In, Most Worried
description: Novice teachers at a new school, among the likeliest targets of potential layoffs, talk about their work and what they may miss about it.

title: A Straight-Arrow Judge Takes On the Galleon Trial
description: One of Manhattans most outspoken jurists, known for his sometimes incendiary opinions, is overseeing a forthcoming battle between the government and the former hedge fund magnate Raj Rajaratnam.

title: As the Tournament Approaches, the Envelope Please
description: As the regular season comes to a close and March Madness creeps closer, teams across the country are searching for answers and just itching to hit the dance floor. We can look to our idols in the West  Hollywood  for guidance.

title: Child Molester Is Castrated in Plea Deal
description: NEW ORLEANS  A 78-year-old Louisiana state prisoner was surgically castrated this week at a hospital in Baton Rouge as part of a plea deal in a child molestation case.

title: Mixed Reviews for N.B.A. Debut in London
description: LONDON  On the court, Brook Lopez and Deron Williams combined to push the Nets to a 116-103 victory over the Toronto Raptors. Off the court, the N.B.A. and its ambitious team owners, with an eye toward the global expansion of the sport, watched anxiously to gauge the reaction to the leagues first regular-season game in Europe.

title: Bahrainis Fear the U.S. Isnt Behind Their Fight for Democracy
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  As more than 100,000 protesters descended into the streets on Friday, women uniformly dressed in black flowing robes carried signs saying, Revolution: The only solution.

title: Can You Hear Libya Now?
description: Washington

title: Shooting in Yemen May Widen Tensions
description: SANA, Yemen  A rebel group that signed a cease-fire with the government last year said the Yemeni military fired artillery at some of its members who were staging a peaceful antigovernment protest in a northern city, killing two. The government confirmed that there was violence, but said that forces fired at the rebels only after they tried to storm a military post and that no one died.

title: Behind the Scenes: 'Mars Needs Moms'
description: A look inside the performance-capture shoot for the 3-D animated film "Mars Needs Moms."

title: Teacher Layoff Plans in Los Angeles Pose Broad Implications
description: LOS ANGELES  Last year, when the school district here handed out thousands of layoff notices, Samuel Gompers Middle School in South Central stood to lose half of its roughly 150 teachers. Now, with the district planning to lay off as many as 4,500 teachers under what school leaders call a doomsday budget, the school could have been even worse off.

title: Obama, With an Unlikely Co-Star, Pushes Bipartisanship on a Miami Visit
description: MIAMI  President Obama, road-testing his new message of bipartisan cooperation here on Friday, promoted his education agenda with Jeb Bush, the former Republican governor, and then used his first stump speech of the 2012 season to call on Democrats to find common ground.

title: Podcast: Jobs, the Deficit and the Muni Market
description: There is clearly some good news in the monthly report on jobs and unemployment. After all, the unemployment rate dropped below 9 percent, and 192,000 jobs were created in February, up from 63,000 the previous month.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Poison Pen Politics
description: We may be embarking on a new era in politics, in which candidates and officials are just as likely to be brought down by bad writing as adultery.

title: Rebuilding Lives in Former Soviet Lands
description: In 1994, on the last day of a month long stay at the only hotel in Nagorno-Karabakh, a disputed region between Armenia and Azerbaijan, the photographer Bruce Haley took a picture of a woman he had come to know as Mama. Over the course of his visit, Mama brought him breakfast every day. The two became friends, but she refused to be photographed. When Mr. Haley visited her to say goodbye, though, she let him take her picture under one condition: that he permit her to hold an image of her dead son.

title: Flood of Fleeing Migrants Eases at Tunisian Border Crossing
description: RAS AJDIR BORDER CROSSING, Tunisia  The flow of migrant workers fleeing Libya into Tunisia slowed drastically on Thursday and Friday, but aid workers said they worried the decline could mean that Libyan officials were harassing or blocking workers who wanted to leave the country.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Obama Upbeat About Israels Future
description: President Obama told Democratic donors in Miami here that while we cant be nave about what is happening in the Middle East, he believed Israel would ultimately benefit from the recent upheaval in Egypt.

title: For Level Global, F.B.I. Raid Is a Final Blow
description: David Ganek faced two stark choices: try to keep running his hedge fund after a raid by the F.B.I., or shut it down.

title: Trainer Faces Ban After Latest Violations
description: Richard Dutrow Jr. was once a drug-addled horseman who was barred from New York racetracks for five years. He has attracted a rogues reputation for a long and varied list of transgressions, including multiple medication violations.

title: Mortgage Modification Overhaul Sought by States
description: State attorneys general have presented the nations five biggest banks with a list of demands that could drastically alter the foreclosure process and give the government sweeping authority over how mortgage servicers deal with millions of Americans in danger of losing their homes.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: College the Easy Way
description: The cost of college has skyrocketed and a four-year degree has become an ever more essential cornerstone to a middle-class standard of living. But what are Americas kids actually learning in college?

title: Spider-Man Is Cited Again for Violations
description: Federal regulators on Friday cited Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark for three serious workplace safety violations, though the proposed fine of $12,600 is unlikely to faze a production that has already run through $65 million.

title: Kittens With Jet Packs? Not Yet, but These Inventors Are on It
description: Finally, they were ready to push the button.

title: A Place to Enjoy the Night Before a Big Day
description: A strong sense of place runs through this cozy wine bar nestled amid a developing cluster of restaurants on Dyckman Street in Inwood. The proprietors, Benlly Polanco and his sister Dariana, have lived in the neighborhood since emigrating from the Dominican Republic in 1996 (or 1997, depending on who tells the story). The roughly 45 wines available were selected for their expression of terroir, said Vladimir Garcia, who used to work at the Chelsea Wine Vault and curated the list. The entertainment at Corcho Wine Room reflects the location, an evolving but strongly Hispanic neighborhood, with regular Latin jazz and conga nights, as well as wine classes and a harpist who plays pop and show tunes. The crowd, too, is decidedly local, and on Wednesday it included three friends catching up. DIANE CARDWELL

title: The Anti-Arizonans
description: Washingtons inaction on immigration reform has left the states feeling abandoned and wondering what to do. When the frustration boils over, as it has most scarily in Arizona, Republicans have been pushing what amounts to vigilantism  states taking on federal enforcement, shouldering aside civil rights and the Constitution and spending whatever it takes to get rid of illegal immigrants. Its a seductively simple vision, and lawmakers across the country are grasping at it, pushing Arizona-style copycat laws.

title: Februarys Jobs Report
description: Over all, the job market did not get any worse in February, and by some measures, showed signs of new life. It would be wrong, however, to regard the latest data with anything other than extreme caution.

title: Waste Wells to Be Closed in Arkansas
description: Two oil and gas companies agreed to temporarily shut down wastewater disposal wells in Arkansas that some experts believe are connected to a recent swarm of earthquakes.

title: Should Politics Be Nice?
description: Heres a task for Bill Clinton, George H.W. Bush and their well-mannered minions at the University of Arizonas new National Institute for Civil Discourse: Is it uncivil when someone implicitly compares someone else to Hitler, Stalin and Hosni Mubarak, but then says he is, of course, not comparing anybody to Hitler, Stalin or Hosni Mubarak?

title: No Rest for a Blues Legend, 79, or His Guitar
description: TOTOWA, N.J.

title: End of the Tanker Saga
description: The Air Forces decision to award Boeing the multibillion-dollar contract to replace its fleet of Eisenhower-era KC-135 refueling jets appears to have been based on a fair assessment of costs and capabilities rather than favoritism for the home team over its European rival EADS, the maker of Airbus.

title: Asbury Park Celebrates Its Musical Legacy
description: ASBURY PARK, the first stop in New Jersey for the Smithsonian traveling exhibition New Harmonies: Celebrating American Roots Music, is putting together six weeks of concerts, workshops, lectures and films to commemorate the occasion. The exhibition, which runs from next Saturday to April 17 at the Asbury Park Public Library, will also be seen in West Deptford, Eastampton, Trenton, Newton and Millville; its tour in the state is sponsored by the New Jersey Council for the Humanities.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 4, 2011

title: A Source of Food, and of Artistic Fuel
description: WHEN Europeans arrived in the Americas, they found the natives growing more than 150 varieties of the plant that we call corn and science calls Zea mays. Dried, pounded, roasted, ground, boiled and baked, its kernels became bread, mush, soup, stew and even a kind of coffee. Occasionally, as a special treat, it was eaten fresh, on the cob.

title: Loud Whistles From Bellmen Draw Cabs, and Anger
description: The whistles from bellmen at the Muse Hotel echo down West 46th Street, bouncing off sidewalks and buildings and penetrating apartments, music studios and a theater at all hours of the day and night.

title: In Coney Island, Landmark Status for Fire-Eaters Showplace
description: Picture a landmark New York City building. Do you imagine intricate wrought-iron work or turrets of heavy stone? Stately columns or the kind of gabled roof that seems sprung from an Edith Wharton novel?

title: Cervelli Fractures Foot, Altering Yankees Plan for Younger Catchers
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Russell Martin settled behind the plate Friday night for the first time in Yankee pinstripes, the first time this spring, the first time since last August. Every move he made reflected the state of his health. Would his surgically repaired hip affect how quickly he popped up from his crouch? Would his surgically repaired knee slow his ability to slide over and block errant pitches?

title: Nina Ricci's Peter Copping
description: Suzy Menkes talks with the Nina Ricci designer Peter Copping about being true to the romantic French spirit of the famed fashion house.

title: Cancer Research Before Activism, Billionaire Conservative Donor Says
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  More than a thousand miles from the labor tumult in Wisconsin  where his name shows up on the signs of protesters and a liberal blogger impersonating him got through to the governor on the phone and said gotta crush that union!  the real David H. Koch was greeted rather more warmly here Friday when he officially opened a new cancer research institute bearing his name.

title: Defining an Illness Is Fodder for Debate
description: When reports emerged 30 years ago that young gay men were suffering from rare forms of pneumonia and cancer, public health investigators scrambled to understand what appeared to be a deadly immune disorder: What were the symptoms? Who was most susceptible? What kinds of infections were markers of the disease?

title: Radical Cleric Still Speaks on YouTube
description: WASHINGTON  From the shootings at Fort Hood, Tex., to the stabbing of a British member of Parliament, investigators have identified Anwar al-Awlakis stirring online calls to jihad as an important instigator of terrorism.

title: The Minds of the South
description: Early 1861 found the 23-year-old Henry Adams in Washington, working as the private secretary to his father, Charles Francis Adams, a representative from Massachusetts. Adams was a keen observer even at that early age, and he focused much of his attention on the Southern political delegations going through the throes of secession. To Adams, the Southerners were little more than madmen. In a Jan. 8 letter to one of his brothers, he wrote, I do not want to fight them  They are mad, mere maniacs, and I want to lock them up till they become sane; not kill them. I want to educate, humanize, and refine them, not send fire and sword among them.

title: Self-Portraits of Society
description: FIVE smiling faces greet visitors entering Cindy Sherman: Works From Friends of the Bruce Museum. They nearly fill the frames of five black-and-white photographs hanging side by side on a wall  four different young women and a man with a double chin, all looking directly at the camera. Each is a unique and evocative character shot by Ms. Sherman in 1975, and, as with all of Ms. Shermans photographic portraits, each is really Ms. Sherman herself.

title: Peavy Encouraged After First Appearance Since His Injury
description: The last time Jake Peavy had pitched in a game, his latissimus dorsi muscle detached from his back. Think about that.

title: On Climate, Who Needs the Facts?
description: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change

title: Devotees of Irish Music Make a Joyful Noise
description: Bay Shore, N.Y.

title: Bloggingheads: Is Newt Ready?
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Kristen Soltis of The Winston Group debate Newt Gingrich's presidential chances.

title: A Basketball Friendship Sprinkled With Music and Golf
description: NASHVILLE  Belmonts Rick Byrd and Vanderbilts Kevin Stallings hold the same job, in the same city, their offices separated by a five-minute drive. Both coach basketball. Both run motion offenses. Both consider the country singer Vince Gill a close friend.

title: For a Met, a Pain-Free Start Is a Great Feeling
description: JUPITER, Fla.  One of the few positive aspects of the Mets 2010 season was their surprisingly effective starting pitching. So far, in the early days of training camp, that trend is holding.

title: Bean Casserole Adapted From Jorge Collazo
description: 4 12-ounce cans kidney, black, pinto or great Northern beans, or a combination, drained (reserve the liquid) and rinsed

title: Johnson & Johnson Implant Unit Executive Resigns
description: Johnson & Johnson said Friday that the worldwide president of its DePuy Orthopaedics division, a maker of artificial hips and knees that has struggled with product recalls and lawsuits over faulty implants, is leaving the company. The executive, David Floyd, submitted his resignation last week and will leave at the end of March, a spokeswoman said. He had been president of the unit since 2007. He is leaving to pursue interests outside the company, the spokesman, Lorie Gawreluk, said, declining to be more specific. DePuy recalled the ASR XL Acetabular hip system last August, after researchers found 13 percent of patients needed a repeat operation to fix problems with the implant. The company took a $280 million charge in the fourth quarter to pay for the recall. The company faces more than 500 lawsuits by patients who had the hip implants.

title: Circuit Maker Marvell Forecasts Disappointing Sales
description: The Marvell Technology Group, a maker of electronic circuits for the communications industry, predicted sales for its current quarter would fell short of analysts estimates, setting off an 11 percent decline in its share price. Revenue for the quarter will be $800 million to $850 million, said Clyde R. Hosein, the companys chief financial officer, in a conference call Thursday. Analysts had estimated $882.5 million. The company made the forecast after reporting a slight increase in net income and sales in the quarter that ended Jan. 29. Marvell, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., reported its results after the close of market trading Thursday. Its stock fell $2.09, to $16.13 a share.

title: The Health Coach You Know
description: On Tuesday, I wrote about how a health worker named Reynaldo Rodriguez worked with a patient, Joe McManus, to help him stick to his treatment plan to control his AIDS and Hepatitis C. Most of us dont have the multiple serious illnesses and problems that McManus does, but a lot of us still share his basic challenge: how do we get ourselves to live more healthfully? We might need to eat better, quit smoking or drinking or exercise more. Instead of thinking of it as treatment adherence, we might call it keeping our New Years resolutions.

title: Saturday: Term of Endearment
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  When youve done enough crossword puzzles, you not only start to recognize bylines but you also recognize styles. Solve even more and its not uncommon to begin to feel like youre on a certain constructors wavelength. By wavelength, I mean that you get the constructors jokes, you understand his or her wording of clues, and its easy to get into the Solving Zone, where the puzzle falls without too much struggle.

title: Armies of Expensive Lawyers, Replaced by Cheaper Software
description: When five television studios became entangled in a Justice Department antitrust lawsuit against CBS, the cost was immense. As part of the obscure task of discovery  providing documents relevant to a lawsuit  the studios examined six million documents at a cost of more than $2.2 million, much of it to pay for a platoon of lawyers and paralegals who worked for months at high hourly rates.

title: Tea Party Tailspin
description: The Tea Party is synonymous with anger. Anger defined it. Anger fueled it. Anger marred it. Anger became its face and its heart. But anger is too exhausting an emotion to sustain.

title: Concerns Raised Over Young Police Chief in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Marisol Valles Garca, the young mother who took the job of police chief in her violence-ravaged town when nobody else would, has not been to work in three days. On Friday, it appeared she might not be planning to come back soon.

title: Policing in Public Housing Leads City to Pay Some Plaintiffs
description: New York City has quietly reached settlements with several plaintiffs in a federal class-action lawsuit alleging that the citys trespassing-enforcement policies in public housing complexes are discriminatory and unlawful, lawyers and others said this week.

title: Alto Has Closed
description: Chris Cannon has closed both Alto and Convivio, the restaurants he was left with after breaking up with his former partners, Michael White and Ahmass Fakahany.

title: Wally Yonamine Dies at 85; Changed Japanese Baseball
description: Wally Yonamine, who was the first American to play professional baseball in Japan after World War II, has often been compared to Jackie Robinson for integrating the Japanese game.

title: Turning a Passion Into Big Business
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.

title: Bloomberg and Cuomo, Co-Stars, Vie for Top Billing
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg the other day with an unexpected gesture: a peace offering.

title: Irish Soda Bread, Family Style
description: As a fifth-generation Irish baker, Colm Shanahan, the owner of Shanahans Bakery and Cafe in Milltown, knows his soda bread. In March, when St. Patricks Day brings a surge of interest in all things Irish, he estimates making up to 7,000 loaves. Along with the bread ($5.95) and desserts like Baileys cream pie ($15), Shanahans turns out artisanal wood-fired pizza.

title: Asian-Inflected, With Hefty Portions
description: WHEN Scott Howlett, a veteran chef for hire, finally opened his own first restaurant in June 2009, he didnt want to feel locked in to a particular kind of cuisine. So the name he chose  Sublime deliberately offered few culinary clues, though it did set expectations high.

title: A Week of Prix-Fixes Aplenty
description: ALONG with stiff winds and snowdrops, March brings the annual Hudson Valley Restaurant Week, running this year from March 14 through 27. The event, organized by Janet Crawshaw, a publisher of The Valley Table magazine, has snowballed since it began in 2006 into a foodie fantasia, with 160 restaurants participating.

title: A Warm Welcome and a Spirited Chef
description: THESE days, when waiters bring out a cake with candles and sing Happy Birthday to a customer, most other diners barely lift their heads. Its hard to get anyone to sing along, even those at the birthday persons own table.

title: Cavaliers Continue to Haunt Knicks
description: The long-discussed trade that finally brought Carmelo Anthony to the Knicks was celebrated as both a homecoming for the player and a turning point for the franchise. Last weeks win over Miami seemed to validate the feel-good story, which would be further buoyed by situations like the one the Knicks faced in the final seconds Friday against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Beyond the Java Rush
description: Caffeines Cafe is not easy to categorize. Housed within a large shopping plaza in Unionville, it has a curbside appeal that is predictably minimal, but a comfortable interior that encourages lingering. And though the establishment sells a large selection of coffee drinks, it also offers full breakfast, lunch and dinner menus.

title: Its Menu Changes Daily; Its Romance Endures
description: WHEN Paci opened in 1996, it caused something of a design sensation. Located on the eastbound side of the Southport railway station, the restaurant had a dramatic setting, with the projection of a gigantic clock dominating one large end wall, high ceilings, exposed heating and cooling ducts and an open kitchen. The Italian food at the time was highly creative with many unusual dishes, the inspiration of Robert Patchen, the chef and owner.

title: Protests After Friday Prayers
description: David D. Kirkpatrick reports from Tripoli, where Col. Qaddafi's forces fired on protesters after Friday prayers.

title: Photo Replay: March 4
description: A look at the day in sports, from chilly baseball players in Nebraska to hot line drives in Florida.

title: Hofstras Jenkins Stayed Home and Stayed Focused
description: Charles Jenkins will leave Hofstra as the Prides career scoring leader, its most unforgettable basketball star since Speedy Claxton, with his jersey retired to the rafters.

title: John Haines, a Poet of the Wild, Dies at 86
description: John Haines, whose experience hunting, trapping and surviving as a homesteader in the Alaskan wilderness fueled his outpouring of haunting poetry of endless cold nights, howling wolves and deep, primitive dreams, died on Wednesday in Fairbanks. He was 86.

title: Arnost Lustig, Who Wrote Tales of Holocaust, Dies at 84
description: Arnost Lustig, an acclaimed Czech author who drew on his own harrowing experiences as a teenager in World War II to produce novels and short stories laced with tales of young people who survive the Holocaust, died on Feb. 26 in Prague. He was 84.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: In Libya, Both Sides Gird for Long War as Civilian Toll Mounts
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Each side of the conflict in Libya pushed forward on Saturday as militia forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi launched a second day of attacks on the rebel-held city of Zawiyah, just 30 miles west of the capital, and a ragtag rebel army moving from the east won its first ground battle to take the oil port of Ras Lanuf, about midway down the Mediterranean coast.

title: Frank Chirkinian, the Father of Televised Golf, Dies at 84
description: Frank Chirkinian, who defined televised golf as the innovative executive producer and director for CBSs coverage of the Masters tournament for 38 consecutive years, died Friday at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84.

title: Jim McMahon Talks About B.Y.U.s Honor Code
description: The banishment of Brandon Davies from the Brigham Young basketball team has left a lot of people befuddled.

title: The Early Word: Stuck in the Middle
description: Todays Times

title: Turmoil in Libya Poses Threat to Italys Economy
description: ROME  In response to the murderous tactics of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis militias against unarmed protesters, the United States and the European Union have announced steps to freeze the governments assets, and the International Criminal Court has opened an investigation into possible crimes against humanity.

title: Eggs, Over Easy, Scrambled or Smiling
Does Rossi Have a Point About Italian Soccer?
description: Complaints about the quality of play in Italys Serie A, compared with that in the top leagues in England and Spain and  as of last week  Germany, are not uncommon. Complaints about it from members of Italys national team are much rarer.

title: 1099 Repeal: Now What?
description: So the House has joined the Senate in voting to repeal the expanded 1099 reporting requirements in the health care overhaul law  but as The Timess Robert Pear unsurprisingly reports, the two chambers remain far apart on the particulars. For one thing, the Republican-crafted House bill also dismantles a second expanded 1099 reporting requirement directed at landlords that was part of the small-business jobs act. But the crucial difference, as Robert reports, is over how to pay for the repeal. House Republicans used the bill as an opportunity to take a swipe at the health care law, forcing Democrats to choose between protecting small business and defending their signal legislative achievement of recent memory.

title: U.S. Women Back in Algarve Final
description: The United States Womens national team is set to return to the final of the Algarve Cup after its 2-0 victory over Norway on Friday.

title: The Eastern Cougar: Dead or Alive?
description: When I looked over the news release that was the basis for my article on Thursday about the extinction of the eastern cougar, I thought it would be a straightforward reporting task. Cougar was here, now it isnt, what happened, when and a few colorful details.

title: Cairo's Facebook Flat
description: A new generation of revolutionaries, ensconced in a communal apartment, are trying to bring down President Hosni Mubarak's government by broadcasting the revolt on Facebook.

title: Behind Chinas Shift on Energy and Growth
description: Interpreting shifts in Chinas growth and resource use has long been a challenge, to say the least. A decade ago, some energy analysts and environmental groups were quick to conclude that an apparent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions from coal burning proved China was capable of avoiding the western pattern of rising emissions in a growing economy.

title: 30 Seconds  With Notre Dame Coach Brian Kelly
description: After winning four consecutive games to close the football season, including victories over Southern California and Miami, Notre Dame appears to have some momentum. Coach Brian Kelly and his staff also recruited an impressive class, which was a question mark when he was hired last year. He will host an event to raise money for the Kelly Cares Foundation, the inaugural Irish Eyes Dinner to Remember, on March 16 at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York. The benefit will honor the former Notre Dame coaches Ara Parseghian and Lou Holtz.

title: Grown-Ups on Balenciagas Runway
description: Look back over the season just winding down in fashion and youll find one admirable trend that has more to do with clotheshorses than clothes. After years of casting jail-bait models that often were so young looking (or just plain underage) they sometimes looked as if theyd been kidnapped from a babysitting gig, industry tastes are undergoing some welcome change.

title: In Montana, an Economic Boon Faces Repeal Effort
description: BOZEMAN, Mont.  With his electricians tool belt and company logo cap, Rick Schmidt looks every bit the small-business owner he in fact is. That he often reeks of marijuana these days ... well, it is just part of the job, he said.

title: Hundreds of Weeks
description: A sampling of other titles that spent hundreds of weeks on individual New York Times best-seller lists and the date they last appeared.

title: Now Screening | Lanvin
description: The fall 2011 collection from Lanvin at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Model-Morphosis | Nimue Smit for Lanvin
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Nimue Smit before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Painting Viktor & Rolf Red
description: It was a telling sign that just after Haider Ackermanns show Saturday morning in Paris, television reporters were thrusting microphones in editors faces asking whether they thought Mr. Ackermann would be a good fit for the house of Dior. Mr. Ackermann is just one of several designers who in media reports have been speculated as potential replacements for John Galliano there, but you start to get the feeling that its all a guessing game, and editors are quickly taking sides. At every show, they ask one another who might end up where, should the Dior shakeup lead to a musical-chair round of designer moves.

title: In M.L.S., Another Day, Another Stadium Project
description: For the San Jose Earthquakes, last Thursday was Demolition Day, as the Northern California club began what could be a long process toward the completion of a new stadium.

title: Obamas Choice: To Intervene or Not in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  For President Obama, who told Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi last week that it was time to quit, the bloodshed and terror in Libya have posed a dilemma that sooner or later confronts every modern American president: whether, and how, to intervene with military force in a distant conflict.

title: Photos of the Moment | Haider Ackermann
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#40", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Hey, S.E.C., That Escape Hatch Is Still Open
description: ITS hard to say whats more exasperating: the woeful performance of the credit ratings agencies during the recent mortgage securities boom or the failure to hold them accountable in the bust that followed.

title: Libyas Late, Great Rights Record
description: Until Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis violent suppression of unrest in recent weeks, the United Nations Human Rights Council was kind in its judgment of Libya. In January, it produced a draft report on the country that reads like an international roll call of fulsome praise, when not delicately suggesting improvements. Evidently, within the 47-nation council, some pots are loath to call kettles black, at least not until events force their hand. Last week Libya was suspended from the body, and the report was shelved. Here are excerpts.  TOM KUNTZ

title: MERS? It May Have Swallowed Your Loan
description: FOR more than a decade, the American real estate market resembled an overstuffed novel, which is to say, it was an engrossing piece of fiction.

title: Photos of the Moment | Lanvin
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#85", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Its Time to Face the Fiscal Illusion
description: FISCAL policy debates often focus on technocratic questions about how much money the government should spend and when, yet the actual course of events depends not on the experts but on politics. The more that our government runs up unfunded obligations and debt, the more we are setting a trap for ourselves.

title: Cheap, Ultrafast Broadband? Hong Kong Has It
description: HONG KONG residents can enjoy astoundingly fast broadband at an astoundingly low price. It became available last year, when a scrappy company called  Hong Kong Broadband Network introduced a new option for its fiber-to-the-home service: a speed of 1,000 megabits a second  known as a gig  for less than $26 a month.

title: Fighting Words
description: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. was the lone dissenter in a Supreme Court case last week that ruled the First Amendment protects hateful protests at military funerals. The case was brought by the family of a Marine killed in Iraq whose funeral was the target of protestors carrying signs with messages like America is Doomed and God Hates Fags.

title: Variety: Forgotten Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Im sorry, who are you all again?

title: Prime Number
description: 0: The number of eastern cougars left, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service says. The agency wants to remove the eastern cougar from its list of endangered species after concluding the big cat is extinct. The last records of wild cougars in the East date back to the 1930s. There have been persistent reports of big cat sightings in the East, but scientists say these were other subspecies that had been held in captivity and had escaped or had been released to the wild.

title: Charlie Sheen, Deconstructed
description: Its not just the analysis of the troubled actor. Its the analysis of the analysis. Excerpts from last weeks meta-conversation.

title: Chaos and Order: How to Strike the Best Balance
description: This interview with Marjorie Kaplan, president of the Animal Planet and Science networks, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: A Chemist, an Artist and a Lot of Fizz
description: BY day, Antonio Ramos is a medicinal chemist at the drug maker Sanofi-Aventis in Bridgewater, N.J., where he helps develop molecules for prescription drugs.

title: Opportunity in a Muni Maelstrom
description: PSST. Interested in some hot munis?

title: Twitter Patter | @TheRevAl
description: Tweeting Since May 2009Followers 38,870Twitter Bio Baptist Minister & Political, Civil Rights, and Social Justice Activist

title: For the Brewers Axford, Its Closing Time
description: PHOENIX  There is urgency around the Milwaukee Brewers, a sense of opportunity that has rarely existed for a team that has never won the World Series. They have position players in their prime, including the potential free agent Prince Fielder. They have three pitchers who started on opening day last season. The National League Central seems wide open.

title: Ex-Security Chief Hauled to Court as Egyptians Storm His Compound
description: CAIRO  Egypts once-powerful and feared interior minister, Habib el-Adly, pleaded not guilty Saturday to corruption charges in the first of an expected series of speedy, high-profile cases against ministers ousted with former President Hosni Mubarak.

title: No Fights. No Checking. Can This Be Hockey?
description: Is hockey simply too dangerous to play?

title: Hannover 96 86s Bayern Munich
description: Hannover 96, a club that was within a whisker of being relegated last season, has turned the pecking order in the German Bundesliga on its ear after Saturdays 3-1 victory against visiting Bayern Munich.

title: Born to Be an Engineer
description: I can recollect my grandfather explaining the spelling of our family name, Yarossi, to me when I was young. Were Italian, but theres no y in the Italian alphabet. My grandfather arrived in the United States through Ellis Island. He said that when he stated his name, Iarossi, at the arrivals desk, the inspector wrote Yarossi and asked him if that was how to spell it. My grandfather said, If I say yes, can I enter the country? The inspector answered that he could. Then thats how you spell it, my grandfather said.

title: The Transition to My Real Self
description: THE past couple of years were momentous for me  I was finally able to reveal my true self at work.

title: Tenacious Summitt Sticks to Principles and Drives Tennessee Hard
description: NASHVILLE  It was the low point of Pat Summitts coaching career, a stunning early exit by Tennessee from the 2009 N.C.A.A. tournament, shocking because the Lady Vols were the two-time defending champions and had never lost in the second round, much less the first.

title: Pashtun Boys Video Exalts Suicide Raids
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Boys almost always look up to their elder brothers and their friends, but what if your brother is a suicide bomber or one in training  do you want to train, too?

title: Underdogs Feat Is Inspiration for Crickets Dreamers
description: Ireland beat England. This delicious upset last Wednesday has been the highlight of the Cricket World Cup, at least so far  particularly after some of the established cricket nations acted so huffily toward the inclusion of lesser teams.

title: On BART Trains, the Seats Are Taken (by Bacteria)
description: Carrie Nee prefers to stand during her half-hour commute on BART from San Leandro to downtown San Francisco. Although the trains blue fabric seats are plush and comfortable, Ms. Nee refuses to sit on them.

title: Google Schools Its Algorithm
description: To humans, computer intelligence is a puzzle, as if the machines have split personalities. They can be so remarkably smart at times, yet so bafflingly dumb at others.

title: Discovered: The Happiest Man in America
description: For the last three years, Gallup has called 1,000 randomly selected American adults each day and asked them about their emotional status, work satisfaction, eating habits, illnesses, stress levels and other indicators of their quality of life.

title: Mapping the Nations Well-Being
description: Americans health, well-being and happiness.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Duke Snider, the center fielder in the Brooklyn Dodgers glory years, died last Sunday at 84. His career spanned three decades and both coasts. Fans recalled Snider on the Bats blog last week.

title: Forever a Boy of Summer, in Brooklyn and Beyond
description: Ill never forget the winter of 1947. Because of the Dodgers plan to sign Jackie Robinson as the first African-American in the majors, we avoided Florida and spent training camp in Havana. This was the great postwar Brooklyn team of Pee Wee Reese, Dixie Walker, Pete Reiser and Hugh Casey. Our manager was the indomitable Leo Durocher.

title: High School Football Recruitings New Face
description: HALLANDALE, Fla.  Sony Michel is still a high school freshman, yet he has shown flashes of Hall of Fame potential. A tailback for American Heritage in Plantation, Fla., Michel has rushed for 39 touchdowns and nearly 3,500 yards in two varsity seasons.

title: State Workers and N.Y.s Fiscal Crisis
description: At a time when public school students are being forced into ever more crowded classrooms, and poor families will lose state medical benefits, New York State is paying 10 times more for state employees pensions than it did just a decade ago.

title: Energy Geeks Converge on M.I.T.
description: Put on a blindfold, throw a dart at a calendar, and youll probably pierce a date on which an energy conference is being held somewhere around the world.

title: Organized Labor Hopes Attacks by Some States Help Nurture Comeback
description: WASHINGTON  When Wisconsins governor, Scott Walker, began his crusade against collective bargaining by public employees, his states unions seemed woefully outmatched. But Wisconsins beleaguered labor movement woke up and mobilized, through e-mail blasts, phone trees and Facebook, getting tens of thousands of supporters to rally in Madison against the legislation and surprising itself that it could muster such a show of force so quickly.

title: Thurgood Marshall
description: Life and art stood side by side when the University of Virginia released the transcript of a July 1965 phone call between Lyndon Johnson and Thurgood Marshall. The same day, HBO first broadcast the play Thurgood starring Laurence Fishburne. Both featured a conversation in which President Johnson called Judge Marshall of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and asked him to become solicitor general of the United States.

title: Colombia Leader Seeks Wide-Ranging Changes, and Looks Beyond the U.S.
description: NEIVA, Colombia  President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia glows when speaking of a plan by Chinese and European investors to build a city for 250,000 people near the Caribbean coast. His foreign minister has circled the globe in the seven months that Mr. Santos has been president, visiting places like Cambodia, but not Washington.

title: Fan Helps Game Designers Open Doors in Virtual World
description: Hans Smith has spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy and a love of baseball. A 24-year-old student at Boise State, he uses a wheelchair and cannot dress or feed himself but appreciates the nuances of sacrifice bunts and cutoff men.

title: Natural Gas Drilling, in the Spotlight
description: To the Editor:

title: Buses at 9/11 Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Junya Watanabe Takes Leather for a Ride
description: Motorcycle jackets, couture shapes, tomboys  Junya Watanabe has explored all of these elements in the past. Today in Paris, though, they were in perfect balance in one of his most inspiring collections in a while. Mr. Watanabe didnt overemphasize the 1950s hourglass shapes of his black leather jackets; he eased off the shape just enough to keep them contemporary. There were also capes and loose-back jackets, all in matte black leather that didnt look rigid and wasnt embellished. Another way he kept things contemporary was to put the molded jackets with A-line or softly gathered wool skirts that didnt enhance your rear in a regrettable way. On the feet were updated jodhpur boots with moderately pointed toes.

title: The Exerciser in Chief
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Touch Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: At 19th Hole, Recalling an Innovator
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Frank Chirkinian lifted his game for one final performance.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Paradoxes of Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: Wisconsins Legacy of Labor Battles
description: The protesters who camped out in the Wisconsin Capitol building in Madison for nearly three weeks hung a handwritten placard over the marble bust of Robert La Follette, the states titan of progressivism.

title: Arabs Rise, Tehran Trembles
description: IN Garden of the Brave in War, his classic memoir of life on a pomegranate farm in 1960s Iran, the American writer Terence ODonnell recounts how his illiterate house servant, Mamdali, would wake him every morning with a loud knock on the door and a simple question: Are you an Arab or an Iranian?

title: Radiation Overdoses Despite F.D.A. Warnings
description: Problems with radiation overdoses during CT brain perfusion scans became apparent in 2009, leading to an investigation by the Food and Drug Administration. Despite repeated warnings by the F.D.A., patients at Cabell Huntington Hospital in West Virginia continued to received elevated levels of radiation.

title: Mets Igarashi Stays Mum as Opportunity Slips Away
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  He has been stripped of his roster status, his compatriot from last year is gone, he throws some bullpen sessions far from the analytical eyes of top staff members and he has pitched in only one exhibition game, last Monday.

title: For Commes des Garons, Kawabuko Chooses Art Over Front Row
description: It is an axiom of fashion that no one ever looks at the row behind him. Front-row seating is the pinnacle of an almost Darwinian hierarchy. The disposition of front-row placement makes designers and their publicists insane, inspires editors to extreme acts of diva temperament (tantrums are par for the course) and gives everyone else a bit of insight into the drives that insure survival of a particular species of the status-obsessed.

title: Is Islam the Problem?
description: CAIRO

title: The Midwests Legacy for and Against Labor
description: The American Midwest has long swung left and right between two conflicting traditions: protecting workers, and opposing unions and expansive government as impediments to prosperity.

title: Fighting in Ras Lanuf, Libya
description: Rebels took control of the Libyan oil port, Ras Lanuf.

title: Governor Brown Redux: The Iceman Melteth
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: Women Fight to Maintain Their Role in the Building of a New Egypt
description: CAIRO  When the prime minister of Egypt stepped down on Thursday, Shereen Diaa, 32, was cooking lunch for her two young sons in a suburb on Cairos outskirts. A veiled woman who molds her life around her children, Ms. Diaa had promised herself she would stop attending political protests and focus on her boys, ages 6 and 8. But when she saw on Facebook that the new prime minister himself would address the protesters the next day, in an unprecedented act, she could not resist.

title: The Young and the Perceptive
description: Chicago

title: Too Much Money for One Man
description: NEW YORKS $140 billion pension plan is one of the largest pools of money in the world. But there is something else that makes it exceptional: it is run by just one person. The state comptroller, who is elected, is the sole trustee.

title: West Virginia Hospital Overradiated Brain Scan Patients, Records Show
description: A large West Virginia hospital seriously overradiated patients suspected of having strokes with CT scans for more than a year after similar episodes prompted federal officials to alert hospitals nationwide to be especially careful when using those types of scans, interviews and documents show.

title: Man Is Arrested in String of Rapes on the East Coast
description: A suspect wanted in at least a dozen sexual attacks across four states over the last decade was captured on Friday in Connecticut by law enforcement agents who had received a tip about his whereabouts, officials said.

title: Photos of the Moment | Christian Dior
