description: [March 6, 8:36 p.m. | Updated below]

title: Scorecard | Lanvin Wins!
description: The fourth day of Paris fashion week was a day of swan songs planned  at Issey Miyake  and otherwise. So as Scorecard can tell you, the question of how well the white lab coated can carry on in the absence of their team leader was foremost on critics minds. Accolades went to Lanvins Alber Elbaz for creating from a new pruned down silhouette a powerful vision of fashion as tree of life.

title: Libyas Ras Lanuf in Opposition Hands
description: Libyan rebels pushed their front lines westward, taking the central oil port of Ras Lanuf.

title: Why is the Middle East Backward?
description: Thats the topic of my column for Sunday. (Frankly, its hard to write about rapidly changing events, like Libya, in my Sunday column because the deadline is Friday evening and then I cant make changes on Saturday even if there is stunning news  but the Middle East is likely to remain backward on Sunday.)

title: Business News You Didnt Read Here
description: THE universe covered by The New York Times is vast, spiraling to the ends of the known worlds of politics, business, culture, sports, science, entertainment and more.

title: Piazza Sees Team Ownership in His Future
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  With all the money the Mets paid Mike Piazza over the years, he might one day decide to buy a chunk of the team back from them. Piazza said Saturday that he would like to get involved in owning a team eventually, but said he wasnt currently pursuing that option with the Mets.

title: Giving Life After Death Row
description: Salem, Ore.

title: How Not to Assign Kidneys
description: MORE than 87,000 Americans suffering from end-stage renal disease are on dialysis and awaiting a kidney transplant. Fewer than 17,000 of them are likely to have new kidneys by the end of the year.

title: For Hedge Fund Baron, Trial Poses a Steep Risk
description: When Raj Rajaratnam was a hedge fund baron managing billions of dollars and being lionized as one of Wall Streets savviest investors, he was asked what made him so successful.

title: Falling Demand for Brains?
description: And now for something completely different.

title: Bangladesh Faces Atrocities of Its Independence Era
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  In the last days of the bloody war that created this nation out of the eastern half of Pakistan in 1971, a gang of men abducted Dr. Alim Chowdhury, an eye surgeon and independence activist, from his home. Three days later, his battered body was found in a mass grave, his eyes gouged from his head.

title: U.S. Updates the Brand It Promotes in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  On the third floor of a shopping mall here, around the corner from a Gap Kids and a Wedgwood china outlet, a new tenant is busily promoting what is perhaps the worlds biggest brand: America.

title: Life After Anthony Is Turning Out O.K. for Nuggets So Far
description: In a seemingly impossible situation, with a star player demanding a trade amid a playoff push, the Denver Nuggets won raves for the players they received for forward Carmelo Anthony at the leagues trading deadline. While many saw Denver as the long-term winner in the trade, it appears as if the team may not be all that far off in the short term, either.

title: Soup Without Fins? Some Californians Simmer
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As the proprietor of Chung Chou City, a packed-to-the-gills dried seafood emporium in Chinatown here, Anna Li presides over barrels full of coveted ingredients like dried shrimp eggs and scallops and fried fish stomachs.

title: Love Had High Hopes for Timberwolves
description: The problem with the Internet is that once something is posted, it rarely goes away. In the case of Kevin Love, the Timberwolves breakout star at power forward, it means that he cannot escape the bold prediction he made in his debut as a blogger for GQ.com.

title: States Prosecute Fewer Teenagers in Adult Courts
description: A generation after record levels of youth crime spurred a nationwide movement to prosecute more teenagers as adults, a consensus is emerging that many young delinquents have been mishandled by the adult court system.

title: Sunday: For Your Edification
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  I have a confession to make: sometimes it takes me a while to get some themes.

title: Pelfrey Loses to Braves, But On Track for Opening Day
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  Mike Pelfrey allowed two runs (one earned) and four hits and didnt walk anyone in three innings in a 6-4 loss to the Braves on Saturday. Manager Terry Collins said afterward Pelfrey was right on track to pitch opening day on April 1.

title: Talk Doesnt Pay, So Psychiatry Turns Instead to Drug Therapy
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa.  Alone with his psychiatrist, the patient confided that his newborn had serious health problems, his distraught wife was screaming at him and he had started drinking again. With his life and second marriage falling apart, the man said he needed help.

title: Off the Catwalk, the Battle for Herms
description: PARIS

title: City Critic: School Lunches
description: The City Critic finds a startling discovery in New York City school lunches: real food.

title: Needing Snack, Red Sox Pedroia Hits Concession Stand
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  After his teams 11-2 loss to the Florida Marlins on Saturday, Red Sox Manager Terry Francona heard an unusual question by a reporter: Did he have a rule against players leaving the clubhouse during a game to buy hot dogs? Always a good sport, Francona played along.

title: The Hands That Steer Are Building the Bikes
description: Like thousands of other New Yorkers, Jason Henkle throws a leg over a bicycle every day and pedals to work. Unlike most of his fellow riders, Mr. Henkle built his understated single-speed bike by hand.

title: With Drive (and Without a Law Degree), a Texan Fights for Immigrants
description: DALLAS  The calls from Malaysia come in daily to Ralph Isenberg, a Texas businessman who has become an unorthodox advocate for immigrants in extreme distress.

title: A Mixed Reception for the Mayor at Queens Parade
description: Spectators clearly relished the green regalia and the incessant wail of bagpipes at the 36th annual Queens County St. Patricks Day Parade in Belle Harbor, the Rockaways, on Saturday. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared intent on not reacting to the mixed reception he received from people along the mile and a half parade route.

title: Unforeseen Business Circumstances Blamed for Closing of Alto and Convivio
description: Heres a statement from Chris Cannons law firm that raises as many questions as it answers about the sudden closing of his two well-regarded restaurants, Alto and Convivio:

title: In New Food Culture, a Young Generation of Farmers Emerges
description: CORVALLIS, Ore.  For years, Tyler Jones, a livestock farmer here, avoided telling his grandfather how disillusioned he had become with industrial farming.

title: Paris: Sing Out
description: Saturday is my day off (no newspaper deadline at least) and so I did what I normally do on Saturday in Paris. I went to the Cafe de Flore. I climbed into a taxi in the Place Vendme and we puttered across the Seine and down the Boulevard Saint-Germain. It was nearly 8 a.m., the streets were quiet, and as the taxi approached the cafe, I noticed that the metal grilles of the buildings next to Brasserie Lipp shimmered pale pink; and when I looked further down the boulevard, there was a chalky haze. I wondered where the sun was. Then, suddenly, it was there, enormous, rising above the church next to the Cafe Deux Magots.

title: To Quiet Critics, Romney Puts 2012 Focus on Jobs
description: BARTLETT, N.H.  As Mitt Romney travels the country lining up contributors and influential Republicans for a second presidential bid, he is presenting himself as a ready-to-lead executive, gambling that a fluency in economic matters distinguishes him from other candidates and can help overcome concerns about authenticity that dogged his first race.

title: The Knicks Are Racing to Blend Talent Into a Team
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Mike DAntoni looked straight ahead for a moment Saturday as he flipped through a mental calendar for the next date that his team could have a full practice. He finally settled on next Saturday. Yes, he said, the Knicks could have a good practice then.

title: Sabathia Hit Hard, Just on Schedule
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joe Girardi opened his postgame news conference Saturday with a declarative understatement. C.C. was off today, he said as a cluster of reporters laughed along with him. With no control of his fastball, changeup or, as he acknowledged, anything else, Sabathia allowed five runs and six hits, including a homer by Jeff Frazier, in the Yankees 10-8 loss to the Washington Nationals.

title: Piazza Supports Mets but Isnt Looking to Buy
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  With all the money the Mets paid Mike Piazza over the years, he might one day decide to buy a chunk of the team back from them. Piazza said Saturday that he would like to get involved in owning a team eventually, but said he was not currently pursuing that option with the Mets.

title: Yankees Brackman Learns to Bide His Time
description: TAMPA, Fla.  All around him, corks flew and beer flowed, but Andrew Brackman was in little mood to party. He stood alone in a far corner of the visiting clubhouse at Rogers Centre, watching his quasi teammates celebrate a return trip to the playoffs. During his 11 days with the Yankees last fall, Brackman did not throw a pitch. He observed, tried not to stand out  not so simple for someone nearly 7 feet tall  and committed to memory how it felt that September night in Toronto when he dodged a Champagne bath he thought he did not deserve.

title: Both Sides Begin Efforts for Recalls in Wisconsin
description: CHICAGO  The fight over collective bargaining rights for public sector workers in Wisconsin remained at an impasse this weekend, even as its political fallout  in recall efforts of state legislators and dueling television commercials  grew larger.

title: How to Stop Trading Away the Future
description: THE worlds leading economies are facing crises related to their vulnerability to booms and busts, rising income inequality, unsustainable government obligations, climate change and a widespread erosion of public trust, according to Diane Coyle, an economist and consultant.

title: Inflation Signals and Fed Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Government and Electronic Health Data
description: To the Editor:

title: A Calmer Sabbatini Takes Command
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Rory Sabbatini again shot the lowest score in the field at the Honda Classic on Saturday, deftly working his way through the snares, hazards and Bear Trap holes at the Champion Course at PGA National Resort & Spa for the second straight day. He opened up a five-stroke lead on Y. E. Yang and Jerry Kelly.

title: Corrections
description: OBITUARIES

title: Moacyr Scliar, Brazilian Novelist, Dies at 73
description: Moacyr Scliar, one of Brazils most celebrated novelists and short-story writers, whose existential allegories explored the complexities of Jewish identity in the Diaspora, died on Feb. 27 in Porto Alegre. He was 73.

title: The Texas Shuffle
description: Eight local acts that could make an impact at South by Southwest.

title: Stay Thirsty Wins Gotham, and Owner Dreams Big
description: Mike Repole and Todd Pletcher were a long way from the sunny skies of Florida, the glamour of Gulfstream Park and their big horse Uncle Mo, whom they are counting on come Triple Crown season. Instead, the owner, Repole, and the trainer, Pletcher, were hunched against a cold wind here at Aqueduct as a colt named Stay Thirsty shrugged his shoulders as his saddle went on.

title: Lawmakers Consider Plan to Make Counties Pay for Jail Inspections
description: Texas counties could soon have to pay for state inspectors to assess their jails. The proposal is getting mixed reviews from local officials already struggling with budget problems, but it may be the only way to maintain the small agency responsible for overseeing the states 245 county jails.

title: An Early Tussle Over Abortion
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Organ Donations Lag in South Texas, and Culture Is a Factor
description: A posse of police officers, sheriffs deputies and family members scoured the streets of McAllen one morning in 2004 after Gloria Garzas family reported her missing. When the authorities found her, she had been driving aimlessly around South Texas, unaware of her whereabouts.

title: Dolphin Club
description: Hardy, near-naked swimmers of the Dolphin Club are seen paddling in the bone-chilling waters of Aquatic Park on even the coldest days. The 134-year-old club in Fishermans Wharf maintains its adventurous tradition with numerous open-water races. HANK PELLISSIER

title: Fraud Case Against Lawyer Remains Stalled
description: In November, the San Francisco city attorney, Dennis Herrera, filed a lawsuit against a disbarred immigration lawyer, calling him one of San Franciscos most notorious predators who had defrauded tens of thousands of vulnerable individuals out of millions of dollars over 35 years.

title: Ensemble Cast Gives Flyers Room to Breathe
description: It seems hard to believe that one year ago the Philadelphia Flyers were clawing for a playoff berth, part of a season-long struggle in which they had fallen as low as 14th place.

title: The Digital-Music Business Blooms Where It Was Planted, Right Here
description: The recording industry is dead. Long live digital music.

title: 3 Environmental Groups to Sue Water District
description: The dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico is an area the size of New Jersey where little marine life survives because algae suck virtually all oxygen from the water. Two years ago, the federal government found that Chicago is the largest single source of the phosphorus and nitrogen that feed those life-killing algae.

title: Daleys Legacy of Libraries, Culture and Literacy
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: After Amputation, Wrestler Tries to Ease Rivals Pain
description: BELVIDERE, Ill.  When Heriberto Avila lost his leg as a result of an accident during a high school wrestling match in January, he and his family could have started calling lawyers. They could have turned bitter or angry.

title: Among Blacks, Mayoral Election Forces a Push for New Ideas and Leaders
description: Nostalgia does not bother Maze Jackson. Like most people he knows, he cherishes the memory of Mayor Harold Washington.

title: Harvard Has Piece of Title but Wants the Rest of It
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The Ivy League champion has yet to be determined, but in a packed and raucous Lavietes Pavilion on Saturday, there was still cause for celebration for Harvard and its long-suffering followers.

title: College Basketball Replay: March 5
description: A look around the hardcourts from a stunning win for Iowa to an N.C.A.A. bid for U.N.C.-Asheville.

title: Egyptian Armys Business Side Blurs Lines of U.S. Military Aid
description: In the late 1990s, the Pentagon announced that it would contribute tens of millions of dollars to a 650-bed International Medical Center that the Egyptian military was building in the desert outside Cairo. The money, for medical equipment, training and logistical support, would help improve health care for Egyptian soldiers.

title: A New Generation of Farmers
description: With a new food culture whetting interest in agriculture among people under 40, the average age in a Corvallis Grange goes to 35 from 65.

title: Cuban Trial of American Reaches End
description: WASHINGTON  Cuban state television announced Saturday that the argument phase of the trial of an American government contractor, Alan Gross, charged with crimes against the state, had ended. A verdict is expected in the coming days. If convicted, Mr. Gross faces up to 20 years in prison.

title: Vows: Felicia and Chris
description: When Felicia and Chris met, they bonded over a mutual love of trashy TV shows and sports . Although they are fans of rival football teams, their passion conquers all their differences.

title: Still No. 1 in the World, by the Thinnest of Margins
description: In the World Chess Federations rankings that were published last week, Viswanathan Anand was again No. 1. But the top players ratings are so exceptionally close, he is just the first among true equals.

title: Sheens Saturday Night Live
description: After a week of interviews, Charlie Sheen offered up an unmediated version of his rollicking, intermittently coherent message on Saturday evening, with a live 44-minute video show on the Web. Shot at his home with a cadre of sidekicks, Charlies Korner featured a constant flow of winning and other Sheen-isms punctuated by flatulent sound effects. While some had speculated the broadcast could surpass the UStream record of 400,000 simultaneous viewers, the audience peaked at just over a quarter of that number.

title: Rebel Advance in Libya Set Back by Heavy Assault
description: AL UQAYLAH, Libya  With tanks, helicopters and fighter planes, troops loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi attacked rebel troops in the coastal town of Bin Jawwad on Sunday and pushed them east, stalling, for the moment, hopes by the antigovernment fighters of a steady march toward Tripoli.

title: Taschen Store Pops Up in Hong Kong
description: The book publisher Taschen, best known for coffee-table books that are big enough to serve as actual coffee tables, has opened a pop-up store in Hong Kongs heavily trafficked Tsim Sha Tsui shopping district.

title: Way Back Machine | Rough Boy Statue May Get More Respect in Brooklyn
description: Editors Note: An earlier version of this post included descriptions of the historical background very similar to material the same author published in The Daily News in 2000. Had editors known of the earlier article, those passages would not have been used; this post has been revised to eliminate that material. Two other posts by this author also included descriptions similar to material he had previously written for The Daily News.

title: Tallon Cleans House in Florida
description: Last Mondays trade deadline provided the final opportunity for teams to make changes in advance of the playoffs. But for those teams out of the hunt, like the Florida Panthers, it was also a chance to rebuild and prepare for next season.

title: New Trademark for Bart Scott: Pro Wrestling
description: Maybe Jets linebacker Bart Scott should participate in the discussions between the N.F.L. and the players. He can talk with the best of them, and he can put someone in a headlock if need be.

title: Photos of the Moment | Jean Paul Gaultier
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#226", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Autor! Autor!
description: A further note on brains and jobs: the story I told in my whimsical magazine piece bears a clear family resemblance to the influential analysis of Autor, Levy, and Murnane a few years later, which argued that the crucial difference in terms of possible replacement of humans by machines was one of routine versus non-routine, rather than white-collar versus blue-collar, and that computerization was if anything likely to increase demand for some low-skill occupations and reduce demand for some traditionally well-paying white-collar jobs:

title: Bahrains Promised Spending Fails to Quell Dissent
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  The leaders of Bahrains opposition movement said Sunday that they would not be mollified by offers of money and jobs, raising the prospect of a protracted standoff between protesters and the embattled government of this strategically important Persian Gulf island nation.

title: Japanese Foreign Minister Resigns Over Donations
description: TOKYO  Japans foreign minister resigned Monday over illegal campaign donations, dealing another blow to the struggling government of Prime Minister Naoto Kan.

title: In Portugal, With the Team, but Not on the Team
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Womens Professional Soccer and as the United States womens national team participates in the Algarve Cup and the FIFA Womens World Cup in Germany later this year.

title: Herms: Are We Ready for Pant Boots?
description: Oh, I want the Herms bows and arrows, Joe Zee, the creative director of Elle, said Sunday, as a model wearing a quiver slung over her shoulder and carrying a weapon walked past.

title: U.S. Senators Call for No-Flight Zone Over Libya
description: Despite skepticism from Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates, three influential United States senators from both political parties on Sunday called for the United States to consider carving out a no-flight zone in Libya to prevent Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from massacring the rebels trying to overthrow him.

title: Somali Forces Take Border Town From Rebels
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  After several days of fighting, Somali and African Union troops have captured the border town of Bulo Hawo, military officials said.

title: Television in Review
description: AMERICAS NEXT

title: A Bittersweet Note for Galliano
description: John Gallianos signature collection, despite the troubles of its designer, was shown this afternoon in a building on the Avenue Foch, the same one where Miu Miu, up until this season, has presented. The atmosphere was somewhat surreal, with arriving editors expecting an informal presentation, only to discover that seats had been scattered around for a slightly more formal showing on models.

title: On the Left Hand, There Are No Easy Answers
description: Humans are asymmetric animals. Early in our embryonic development, the heart turns to the left. The liver develops on the right. The left and right lungs have distinct structure.

title: More Rumblings of Designer Shake-Ups
description: More turmoil may yet be in store for the Paris collections, which have been beset by rumors of designer discontent and an anticipated wave of big job changes.

title: Obama Considers Tapping Oil Reserve
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is considering tapping the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in response to rapidly rising gasoline prices brought on by turmoil in the Middle East, the White House chief of staff, William M. Daley, said on Sunday.

title: Paris Report | A Bisou from Lanvin
description: Alber Elbazs fall collection for Lanvin was a perfect mix of the designers signature dresses (a strapless midnight blue mini, a long sleeve off the shoulder red cocktail) and some new surprises like dark coats, flat pointy shoes and wide brimmed hats. There were skinny heeled ankle boots and metal chokers. The models hair was tied into a long messy braid  very of the season. It was, by and large, a darker show than we have seen from Lanvin of late save for the bright colors splashed in the last 10 looks.

title: A Long-Absent Comedy Leaps Out for a Farewell
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which Ive been following for more than 30 years, has just revived a work here that neither I nor many devotees have ever seen: Antic Meet (1958). Not seen onstage since 1969, this deadpan comedy, with costumes and dcor by Robert Rauschenberg and music by John Cage, will be repeated this month at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan. It was performed on Thursday and Friday at Zellerbach Hall at the University of California here (as part of the companys farewell tour before it disbands at the end of this year).

title: Afghan Leader Calls Apology in Boys Deaths Insufficient
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American commander in Afghanistan apologized in person to the leadership of the Afghan government on Sunday for the mistaken killing of nine Afghan children in Kunar Province on Tuesday, but the Afghan president rejected the apology, according to a statement from the presidents spokesman.

title: Fear Not: Your Chosen Heroes Are Fighting for You
description: By the time fighting games reached their zenith in the 1990s, I wasnt spending much time in arcades anymore. I had dabbled with the likes of Street Fighter, but by then most of my play time was happening at home and online.

title: Opposition Fighters Turned Back By Tank and Artillery Assault
description: The Libyan military drove rebel forces back along the main coastal road on Sunday, ambushing the advancing militias as they entered the town of Bin Jawwad.

title: Even With Protests Averted, China Turns to Intimidation of Foreign Journalists
description: BEIJING  Western journalists have lately been tolerated in China, if grudgingly, but the spread of revolution in the Middle East has prompted the authorities here to adopt a more familiar tack: suddenly, foreign reporters are being tracked and detained in the same manner  though hardly as roughly  as political dissidents.

title: New Interior Minister Revives a Debate: Can Muslims Be True Germans?
description: BERLIN  Germanys new interior minister, appointed just last week, has already managed to upset politicians, church leaders and representatives of the Muslim community by saying that Islam is not a part of the German way of life.

title: So Far Rivals Cant Beat iPads Price
description: The iPad 2, unveiled on Wednesday, offers several sleek improvements over its predecessor. But its most attractive feature is perhaps the same one its predecessor had: the price tag.

title: Revisiting Bone Drugs and Femur Fractures
description: Nearly six years ago in this column, I discussed what was then a little-known problem associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, the valuable drugs that protect against fractures caused by bone loss. The drugs, among them Fosamax, Actonel and Boniva, can slow bone loss, increase bone density and cut fracture rates in half in women with established osteoporosis.

title: Now Screening | Celine
description: The fall 2011 collection of Celine at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Now Screening | Celine
description: The fall 2011 collection from Celine at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Model-Morphosis | Karlie Kloss for Viktor & Rolf
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Karlie Kloss from Next Model Management before (top) and after (above) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar down to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Too Early to Wear White? Not for Rangers, Who Score Fast and Frequently
description: Ryan Callahan sat happily in the Rangers dressing room Sunday afternoon, fresh off the ice after scoring four goals in a nationally televised 7-0 shellacking of the Philadelphia Flyers. Someone asked him why the Rangers wore white sweaters at home instead of their customary blues for this game.

title: Moacyr Scliar, Brazilian Novelist, Dies at 73
description: Moacyr Scliar, one of Brazils most celebrated novelists and short-story writers, whose existential allegories explored the complexities of Jewish identity in the Diaspora, died on Feb. 27 in Porto Alegre. He was 73.

title: Hearings on Muslim Extremism Prompt Times Square Protest
description: A crowd of 500 gathered at the bottom of Times Square on Sunday to protest upcoming Congressional hearings on radicalization within the Muslim community, arguing that the hearings threaten to single out one religious group unfairly.

title: Scorecard | Haider Ackermann Wins!
description: Questions of imminent designer reshufflings hung in the air on the fifth day of Paris fashion week, but Scorecard knows one thing is certain: the general emotive level of praise for a certain avant-garde arriviste who has a way with draping went Haider still. (Sorry, Cathy!) Also, Viktor & Rolfs fashion offensive got everyone a bit red in the face.

title: Rhythmic Riffs of Explosive, Manic Instrumental Energy
description: The Psychic Paramount doesnt use words. Its a rock trio without a singer, just guitar-bass-drums, and it lives entirely in the brawny lead-up, the big gestures of riff, rhythm and echo that generally point toward the real composed beginning of a song, the part that we end up whistling.

title: Surrounded by Percussion (Noise, That Is)
description: Iannis Xenakis was a master of many things, musical and otherwise, and as a composer one of his specialties was getting musicians to make a whole lot of noise. It is deeply organized noise, naturally, and in terms of timbres, textures and dynamics you could hardly hope for more variety than he provides. And if you have quibbles about the term noise, used nonpejoratively, plan to be on hand the next time Xenakiss Persephassa (1969) is performed in the relatively close quarters of Alice Tully Hall.

title: Good Guy Up Against the Aliens and Sheen
description: When The Event arrived on NBC in the fall, the network placed great faith in it as a prospective hit despite scheduling it to compete on Monday nights with CBSs Two and a Half Men, the most successful comedy on television. The ambition hardly seemed grandiose, as the audience for the two shows was bound to be dissimilar: The Event is a science-fiction-tinged political thriller, while Two and a Half Men, with its crashing star Charlie Sheen receiving a reported $2 million an episode, can now be described only as a science experiment.

title: Music in Review: Annie Gosfield
description: The Kitchen

title: Music in Review: Tokyo String Quartet
description: 92nd Street Y

title: Rango Is Strong At Weak Box Office
description: The weekend box office was sturdy, at least at first glance. Rango (Paramount Pictures), left, an animated entry featuring the voice of Johnny Depp, was No. 1 in North America with about $38 million in ticket sales. The Adjustment Bureau (Universal Pictures) was second with an estimated $20.9 million, a good result for a difficult-to-market science-fiction thriller cum romance. Even the struggling CBS Films, exhibiting greatly improved marketing, had a decent weekend with its inexpensive Beastly, which sold about $10.1 million for third place. So was Hollywood in a glum mood? Moviegoers spent a total of $135 million on tickets over the weekend, a 31 percent decline from the same period a year ago, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. So far this year ticket revenue is down 20 percent on a 22 percent decline in attendance. The problem is that while films have been doing fine, there has been no blockbuster of the kind that can lift interest in moviegoing across the board. (Last year it was Alice in Wonderland.) Rounding out the top five were two holdovers; Hall Pass (Warner Brothers) sold about $9 million in tickets for a two-week total of $27 million, and Gnomeo & Juliet (Walt Disney) sold about $6.9 million for a four-week total of $83.7 million.

title: Grants for Opera Writers
description: American Lyric Theater, an organization formed in 2005 to help develop new operatic works, has been chosen by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to receive a $90,000 grant. The money will be distributed to American Lyric over a three-year period to support its Composer Librettist Development Program, the groups initiative to provide full-time mentorship to emerging opera writers through classes, workshops with professionals and residencies with New York City Opera. No one else is doing this, Mark Adamo, the director of professional development for American Lyric, said in a statement. Aspiring librettists can study music-theater writing on the graduate level, but their work will draw overwhelmingly from the commercial and nonprofit theater, leaving unexamined the substantial differences that remain between the theater and the opera house. The Poe Project, a series of three one-act operas inspired by the short stories of Edgar Allan Poe and written by six composers and librettists in American Lyrics development program, had its first concert reading at Symphony Space in New York in November. The company is aiming for an official premiere in 2012.

title: Tyler Perry Wins Big
description: Tyler Perry, below, took top prizes in the film and television categories at the N.A.A.C.P.s 42nd Image Awards on Friday at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Tyler Perrys House of Payne won for best television comedy, and his film For Colored Girls, based on a play by Ntozake Shange, won Mr. Perry trophies for best movie and best director. The actress Kimberly Elise won for her supporting role in the film. There is nothing like having nine strong black women holding you up, Mr. Perry said of the cast during the ceremony. Notable winners for literature included Terry McMillan for her novel Getting to Happy and Isabel Wilkerson for her debut book, The Warmth of Other Suns. The award for new music artist went to Willow Smith, the daughter of Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith, and the prize for gospel album went to Mavis Staples for You Are Not Alone, which also won Ms. Staples her first Grammy last month.

title: The 10 Best Poets
description: In February Dean Rader, an English professor at the University of San Francisco, set out to discover historys 10 best poets (much like Anthony Tommasini of The New York Times recently did for composers). After spending two weeks compiling a list of nominees and fielding readers comments about them on the Web site of The San Francisco Chronicle, Mr. Rader has released his final list, with the Latin American poet Pablo Neruda at No. 1. No poet has more passionately and thoroughly spoken for his people than Neruda, Mr. Rader wrote, citing Canto General, a 15-part book comprising over 200 poems and 15,000 lines tracing the history of Latin America. It is an insanely ambitious project that seemed to unify a country. In second place was Shakespeare, whose name, according to Mr. Raders shockingly unscientific measurements, appeared most frequently in reader e-mails, followed by Dante, who Mr. Rader said was the most controversial pick, because hes only well known for one poem (The Divine Comedy). Western literary greats like Walt Whitman, John Donne, Emily Dickinson, William Butler Yeats and Wallace Stevens also appear on the list with the Eastern favorites Rumi and Li Po, whom Mr. Rader called the great poet of drunkenness.

title: Quad Q.& A.: MAAC Commissioner Rich Ensor
description: Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference Commissioner Rich Ensor sat down for an interview Friday night at the leagues tournament in Bridgeport, Conn. An abridged version follows. Along with the topics discussed below, Ensor also mentioned that the MAAC is in the preliminary stages of setting up a mens basketball challenge series with the Mid-American Conference, or as he called it, the other MAC. However, he said that if the series happens, it would not begin next season.

title: Hello
description: Tom Wolfe was once asked, What is the most important change of your lifetime? He is purported to have answered, Oh, thats easy. Co-ed dorms.

title: Gaining an Edge With a Deschapelles Coup
description: The American Contract Bridge Leagues Spring North American Championships officially begin in Louisville, Ky., on Thursday. But the Baldwin Flight A North American Open Pairs Championship is contested there on Wednesday and Thursday.

title: Drumbeat to E-Mail: The Medium and the Message
description: The Information offers this point-blank characterization of its author: James Gleick is our leading chronicler of science and modern technology. This new book goes far beyond the earlier Gleick milestones, Chaos and Genius, to validate that claim.

title: A Quick Study of Status (Fine Watches Set to Rap)
description: There goes Rick Ross, growing up before your very eyes. In hip-hops long tradition of wealth and taste acquisition, perhaps no one has had a quicker rise than this Miami rapper; certainly no one has been more voluble and enthused about it.

title: Conceptually Challenging in Familiar Repertory
description: The American pianist Nicholas Angelich performed works by Bach, Chopin and Schumann on Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that consistently challenged my thinking about this repertory. But his playing was so deliberate in its intentions, alternately refined and feisty, and so intriguing that I was affected and impressed, especially with his engrossing account of Kreisleriana, a teeming, craggy Schumann masterpiece.

title: Mixing Electric Funk With Joyful Malian Wails
description: Regal in a blue-and-gold robe, with a golden tiara headdress, one of Africas greatest singers performed on Saturday night at the Bell House in Brooklyn. The Malian singer Khaira Arby, from Timbuktu, has long been recognized at home, where Ali Farka Tour was a mentor; she was named a Chevalier de lOrdre National du Mali in 2006. Her 2010 album, Timbuktu Tarab (Clermont Music), was one of the decades best African albums, and onstage her music was even more electrifying.

title: Dance in Review: Royal Ballet School and ABTII
description: Ailey Citigroup Theater

title: Dance in Review: Mariangela Lopez and Arturo Vidich
description: Danspace Project,

title: In the Mysteries of Everyday Movement, Multilevel Stories
description: During a chat with students once, a young Paul Taylor related a conversation that hed had at a festival in Vienna. Youre a modern dancer, why dont you use modern music? someone asked him. Mr. Taylor replied: Well, Beethoven is modern to me. So its all in the frame of reference.

title: Danity Kanes Fallen Frontwoman Tries for a Return to Relevance
description: Reality television gave us Aubrey ODay, the glamorous, difficult frontwoman of the as-made-on-TV girl group Danity Kane, selected by Diddy on MTVs Making the Band in 2005. And it gave Ms. ODay a high platform, from which she could gracelessly stumble back to earth.

title: Monday: Outside of a Watermelon
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Decisions, decisions. Life is a constant stream of decision-making, but poor Mike Torch seems to have a problem with it.

title: The First Trick
description: March 29, 1861

title: Stell-aaa! Where Are You? And Wheres Your Sister?
description: The Method Gun can seem like a revue made up of experimental theater acts. Theres a short, silly one-man dance; some audience participation; multimedia inside jokes hinting at classic plays; and, of course, nudity. For laughs.

title: Your Brand on TV, for a Fee, in Britain
description: PARIS  As Phil Vickery, a British television chef, prepared cottage pie last week, viewers got a taste of the future of television in Britain  a future that arrived long ago in the United States and many other countries.

title: Free of Qaddafi, a City Tries to Build a New Order
description: BAYDA, Libya  The signs in Bayda still read the Great Socialist Peoples Libyan Arab State of the Masses. It was never much of a state, nor did the people have much say. Now two weeks after its liberation, residents of this highland town have the task of making it so, a challenge that may prove pivotal to the course of Libyas revolt.

title: Bradens Perfect Moment Still Resonates
description: PHOENIX  There are no advertisements on the outfield wall at Phoenix Municipal Stadium, which is really striking considering how common such ads have become. Of course, there are several billboard just above the fence, including one for the Oakland Athletics Web site, with a picture of Dallas Braden raising his arms and the tag line, Ever seen a perfect game?

title: Loss of Speech Evokes the Voice of a Writer
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review Good People
description: Readers had mostly good things to say about the Manhattan Theater Clubs production of Good People, David Lindsay-Abaires new play starring Frances McDormand and Tate Donovan as childhood friends from South Boston who reunite after taking different paths in life. Following are excerpts from readers reviews on the Theater section of NYTimes.com and from Facebook.

title: LVMH to Take Control of Italys Bulgari
description: 1:40 a.m. | Updated LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury conglomerate, said Monday that it would take control of Italys Bulgari in an all-share deal, adding another high-end brand to its formidable stable in a deal worth 3.7 billion euros.

title: Introspective Silence Befalls Bali, but Only for a Day
description: KUTA, Indonesia  The resort island of Bali fell quiet over the weekend as the authorities shut down its airport and seaports, and switched off all radio and television transmissions. Its streets, normally jammed with tourists, were deserted as security guards patrolled the island, ensuring that locals and foreigners alike stayed indoors, and even exhorting them to turn off their lights.

title: Baghdad Neighborhood Celebrates as a Wall Is Taken Away
description: BAGHDAD  It is just one wall in a city of thousands  a line of anonymous gray blocks running, like a scar, through one of Baghdads most violent neighborhoods.

title: After Cuts, Voters Back Ruling Bloc in Estonia
description: MOSCOW  Early results in Estonias parliamentary election on Sunday showed the ruling coalition headed for a victory, in a remarkable show of support for a government that has imposed harsh austerity measures to lift the country out of recession.

title: Metropolitan Diary: City Observations From Readers
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Tweets From Tahrir Collects Egypt Posts in a Book
description: Some of the earliest and most raw reports of the revolution in Egypt were published on Twitter. Now an enterprising publisher, OR Books, has gathered many of those Twitter messages for a book, Tweets From Tahrir, a narrative of the revolution told in snippets of 140 characters or less.

title: A Place Where Emotions Became Poetry Is for Sale
description: A man who runs a gallery and salon in the East Village that has managed to survive even as the neighborhoods bohemian past fades recently got some startling news from a visitor.

title: Turkish Court Jails 2 Journalists
description: ISTANBUL  A Turkish court ordered two journalists jailed on Sunday, pending the outcome of an investigation into accusations that the military plotted to overthrow Turkeys pro-Islamic government in 2003.

title: Padres Coach Gains Energy From Baseball in Cancer Fight
description: PEORIA, Ariz.  Gleaming green fields spread before Darrel Akerfelds. He sits at a picnic bench under a canopy behind the spring training clubhouse of the San Diego Padres, where he has been the bullpen coach for a decade. He gazes at the reassuring sights  mounds and batting cages, grass and dirt  and it seems as if he might cry.

title: Beltran Gives Knee a Run and His Manager a Scare
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The sun was barely up when the first fans pulled into Digital Domain Park, six hours before the first pitch. The Sunday matinee between the Mets and the visiting Boston Red Sox sold out in two hours, and judging from the number of spectators whose backs bore the numbers of Jonathan Papelbon, David Ortiz and Kevin Youkilis, the 2011 Grapefruit League debut of Carlos Beltran was not the main attraction.

title: Less Talk, More Medicine
description: Psychiatrists are talking less and prescribing more. Many of the nations 48,000 psychiatrists no longer provide talk therapy, the form of psychiatry popularized by Freud that has been a mainstay of psychiatry for decades, writes Gardiner Harris in Sundays New York Times. Instead, they typically prescribe medication, usually after a brief consultation with each patient.

title: A Pitcher-Catcher Dynamic Framed by Hockey
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  The morning after watching his beloved Tampa Bay Lightning lose to the Montreal Canadiens, Phil Hughes was forced to relive the anguish in the Yankees clubhouse. Russell Martin, who grew up outside Montreal, sidled over to gently remind him of the final score. Not once. A few times. You know, just in case Hughes forgot.

title: Ivory Coast Rebels Claim to Expand Their Advance
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Rebels opposed to the strongman Laurent Gbagbo seized a town near the Liberian border on Sunday, a rebel spokesman said, in a further sign of Ivory Coasts possible slide toward civil war.

title: Glamours iPad Series to Let Viewers Buy Clothes From Gap
description: The ability to buy products strategically placed on television programs  a handbag clutched by the actressBlake Lively on Gossip Girl or a suit worn by the actorJon Hamm on Mad Men  with the click of a button has for years been talked about as something that marketing would offer in the future. But like flying cars or robot companions, it has never materialized.

title: Degrees and Dollars
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that education is the key to economic success. Everyone knows that the jobs of the future will require ever higher levels of skill. Thats why, in an appearance Friday with former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, President Obama declared that If we want more good news on the jobs front then weve got to make more investments in education.

title: ABC Family Spins Gold in Dramas
description: BURBANK, Calif.  If Michael G. Riley, the new president of ABC Family, comes across as a bit nervous these days, cut him some slack. Only seven months ago he was working in radio. Now hes about to lead a major expansion of one of televisions hottest brands.

title: Napping on Game Day Is Prevalent Among N.B.A. Players
description: The All-Star point guard Steve Nash is 37 and knows that decline may come fast at his age. But his solution is not to increase his conditioning or to lift more weights. Instead, he plans to increase his naptime, seizing on an element of N.B.A. life as common as a 3-point shot.

title: Devils Keep Drive Going in Shootout Win Over Isles

description: The N.F.L.s labor negotiations resume Monday with optimism that Commissioner Roger Goodell and the union leader, DeMaurice Smith, whose stature among wary owners has grown in recent days, are committed to making a deal and avoiding a legal fight that could imperil the regular season.

When they tuned into state television broadcasts, they heard stunning news: the Libyan military had routed the rebels seeking to oust Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The gunfire, they were told, was in celebration.

title: White House Seeks to Allay Muslims Fears on Terror Hearings
description: STERLING, Va.  As a Republican congressman prepares to open hearings on the threat of homegrown Islamic terrorism, President Obamas deputy national security adviser visited a mosque here on Sunday to reassure Muslims that we will not stigmatize or demonize entire communities because of the actions of a few.

description: ATLANTA  His vision impaired, his head pounding and his jumper dampened, Carmelo Anthony took a seat on the Knicks bench and watched the critical minutes unfold Sunday night. Even through the blurs and the distortions, he could see the clear signs of a minor revival.

description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  When it counted most on Sunday at the Honda Classic, and Rory Sabbatinis five-stroke margin had been whittled to one by Y. E. Yang, Sabbatini delivered the way winners do.

It was founded by gay activists over 26 years ago, most of its City Council members are gay, and the community is famous for its concentration of gay residents and nightlife.

Senate leaders still seem shell-shocked by that breathtaking ruthlessness, and have pleaded with the administration for help in pushing back. The White House needs to do so, and firmly.

In New York City, only about 12,000 of 80,000 teachers have been evaluated, based on their students grades on standardized tests.

title: Eye on Women Directors at London Festival

In an effort to change this, they decided to buy out Londons Curzon Soho Cinema on a November night in 2002 to debut one of their films. That same night, they asked for submissions of other short films made by emerging women filmmakers. They took five of the submitted films, created a program, and the annual Birds Eye View Film Festival was born.

title: Japans Splatter Auteur
description: Theres prolific, and then theres Takashi Miike. Since 1991, the Japanese director has made more than 80 feature films, plus some television, music videos and a kabuki drama. With that kind of work schedule, not all Miike films are going to be masterpieces. Not-so-good Miike films have zombies, sadomasochistic yakuza love stories, decapitated body parts turned into blood fire hoses, lengthy scenes of torture and musical numbers. Good Miike movies have those things, too, so it can be hard to tell which is which. For many fans, the difference is a matter of polish, but disagreements about whether more polish is desirable are frequent.

title: Are We the Greek Vase Painters?
description: I didnt know enough about Ancient Greece. I picked up a book published by Penguin that promised me, the reader who is not a student or expert in classical literature, the chance to be swept along from the days of Mycenae to the splendors of Athens. I would finally understand how Sophocles revolutionized dramatic history by introducing a third speaking actor. Never again would I mix up the laughing philosopher Democritus with democracy. Like any history book, the Penguin might help me comprehend our own history, in a vague way  they had slavery and freedom at the same time, too! But then I came to the plight of the vase painters, and I realized that I might as well be reading the Penguin Foretelling of the Fate of Newspapers in the Internet Age. Novelists, musicians, politicians and many others should also recognize themselves.
