title: Time to Tap the Piggy Bank?
description: With gasoline averaging $3.50 a gallon, as I wrote in  Monday mornings paper, Washington is slipping back into one of its intermittent debates about whether it is time to raid the national piggy bank, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The debate is following the usual pattern: members of Congress, especially those who are also looking at the price of home heating oil, say yes. But the administration looks at the oil as not just as a rainy-day fund but as something that should be preserved for real emergencies.

title: For Electric Car Owners, a Way to Share Juice
description: From our colleagues at Green:

title: Monday Reading: How to Avoid Airplane Germs
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Corporate Solidarity
description: Matt Yglesias has a post about the remarkable solidarity of corporate executives, who seem to support their class interests even when their individual firms would benefit from the policies they oppose.

title: Beltran Scratched From Mondays Game
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The original plan for Carlos Beltran was to make his spring training debut by playing two consecutive games as the Mets designated hitter. But after one game, the plan was scratched.

title: Libya: A Fighter Departs
description: A construction worker is among the civilian volunteers at Benghazi preparing to join rebel forces.

title: Middle-Wage Workers and the Recession
description: David Autor, an M.I.T. economist who has done excellent research on the labor market, has been the focus of blogosphere discussion lately. Tyler Cowen says he deserves much more attention than he gets. Paul Krugman discussed his work in a blog post and column. Michael Luo featured Mr. Autors work in a Times article last summer.

title: Turning a Blind Eye to the Obvious
description: Brad DeLong is mad at Tyler Cowen, with reason  for Cowen writes about US fiscal irresponsibility, fairly sensibly, without mentioning the elephant, and I do mean elephant, in the room: the role of the post-Reagan GOP.

title: Scorecard Update | John Galliano
description: John GallianoDesigner: John GallianoDate and Location: Sunday, Mar. 6, 34 Avenue FochPhotos: slide show

title: Charting Jamie xx
description: Jamie xx is a DJ, producer and a member of the acclaimed British indie pop band The xx. On the just-out Were New Here (XL) he remixes songs from Gil Scott-Herons 2010 release Im New Here. He played some of these songs at a recent DJ gig at Le Poisson Rouge in New York. The artist Andrew Kuo charts the highs and lows of the set.

title: Who Needs New York? For His Next Film, Woody Allen Takes a Roman Holiday
description: Any happy New York couples waiting in line to see The Sorrow and the Pity at their favorite Manhattan movie theater or getting romantic in view of the Queensboro Bridge will continue to go undocumented by Woody Allen for at least a few more months: that quintessential New York director is once again taking a pass on his hometown and making his next movie in Rome this summer, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Numberplay: Devils Wager
description: Our puzzle this week was written by the prolific and ingenious Terry Stickels, inventor of FRAME GAMES (found in USA WEEKEND magazine) and STICKELERS (by KING FEATURES) puzzles and author of over two dozen puzzle books including Classic Mind Benders.

title: Chrysler Recalls 20,500 Jeep Wranglers for Axle Problem
description: Chrysler is recalling about 20,500 of its off-road icon, the Jeep Wrangler, because fasteners holding the axles to the vehicle could loosen and lead to loss of directional control.

title: S.E.C. Is Severely Understaffed, Review Finds
description: A Securities and Exchange Commission internal review has concluded that the agency needs 400 new employees, Bloomberg News reports. The preliminary review, done by an outside consultant, said the S.E.C. was unable to complete its duties under the Dodd-Frank law. Read more

title: Praise From Afar for the Park Slope Food Co-op
description: After The Times ran an article about Park Slope Food Co-op members sending their nannies to work their shifts, many members and alumni rose up in the co-ops defense. One former member, Michael Crewdson, an author transplanted to the other side of the world, was livid enough on Facebook that we asked him to set down his thoughts.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of The Timess Dining section.

title: Eurofile | Le Dauphin
description: With a sticker for Kanterbrau beer (middle-brow Gallic suds) over the door and an anonymous plate-glass-and-steel-framed facade, Le Dauphin doesnt look like much when you get there, but in the three months since it opened, it has become a major hub of gastro cool. Why? The Pritzker Prize-winning Dutch architect Rem Koolhaus and Clment Blanchet designed the white Cararra marble and mirrored interior, and the small-plates menu is by Inaki Aizpitarte, the chef at Le Chateaubriand next door and probably the hippest cook in Paris.

title: Vegan Recipes for Lent
description: This week marks the beginning of Lent, when many of us choose to abstain from meat or dairy products until Easter. Hearty vegan dishes are perfect for the season. The ones offered here last year were Greek in origin. This years Lenten recipes are Mediterranean, too, but with Middle Eastern and North African flavors.

title: Orbiting Eyes Capture Sudan Village Destruction
description: A Twitter note from Nicholas Kristof alerted me yesterday to fresh satellite images documenting the destruction of a Sudanese village:

title: Atheros Delays Vote on Takeover by Qualcomm
description: Qualcomm will have to wait a little bit longer before its acquisition of Atheros is official.

title: Scene City: An Art Party at the Wooly
description: Invisible-Exports, a tiny subversive gallery on the Lower East Side, unveiled two new works at the semi-secret lounge in the basement of Woolworth Building.

title: Subversive Artists Host a Party at the Wooly
description: The Wooly, the semi-secret lounge in the basement of Woolworth Building, has hosted a smattering of private parties since opening in 2009. Fashion designers have presented after-parties there. Socialites-in-training have celebrated their birthdays (one Sweet 16 was even serenaded by Nicki Minaj). And various artists have left their mark on its faux-decaying walls and cluttered five-and-dime nooks.

title: Pass the Heat a Tissue
description: You know you have reached some sort of weird nadir in a season when the biggest question of the weekend is whether the Miami Heat players were crying in their locker room after Sundays loss.

title: Gheorgiu Withdraws From Another Met Production
description: Another run of Angela Gheorghiu performances at the Metropolitan Opera has bitten the dust. The Met said on Monday that Ms. Gheorghiu was withdrawing from the fall performances of Gounods Faust, and that her place in the role of Marguerite would be taken by Marina Poplavskaya. The Met cited artistic reasons. Ms. Poplavskaya was already scheduled to sing a later series of Faust performances next winter.

title: The Happiest Man in America, Annotated
description: Sundays Week in Review featured a package on a subject that is much beloved by Economix: happiness.

title: The Happiest Man in America, Annotated
description: Sundays Week in Review featured a package on a subject that is much beloved by Economix: happiness.

title: Compassion Writ Small
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously supplied definitions of manners.

title: Photos of the Moment | Stella McCartney
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#881", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Note: The answers to two reader questions last week about subjects that included the first pairing of copywriters and art directors discussed the famed Doyle Dane Bernbach agency. That led many other readers to offer comments about DDB, some of which follow.

title: The Promise of Silk
description: Researchers at Tufts University are working wonders with silkworm silk, manipulating it in ways that have potential applications in medicine and other fields.

title: Who Will Take the Stand in Galleon Trial?
description: Jury selection in the prosecution of Raj Rajaratnam begins on Tuesday in the most significant insider trading trial in years.

title: More Tips From Social Media Pros
description: We small-business owners sometimes just dont know what we dont know about new topics we need to master, like social media. Last week, I wrote about a company, Expert Laser, that found a creative approach to engaging with potential customers. I also recently had the opportunity to talk to two people who have earned much street cred in social media  one who expanded his familys small business exponentially through his use of social media and the other a savvy journalist and observer of this space.

title: Comparative Destructiveness
description: Jonathan Chait gets angry at the way Republicans, who claim to care about the deficit, propose saving money by cutting back on expenditures that are needed to control health costs. Indeed. But theres a larger dynamic at work here than mere stupidity.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Armani Exchange, part of Giorgio Armani, is introducing a logo to mark its 20th anniversary. The new logo will re-present the Armani Exchange brand, known as A/X, as A/XX; the words twenty years will appear below the letters. The logo, to appear throughout the year in venues like ads, shopping bags and tags, was designed by Sagi Haviv, principal partner at Chermayeff & Geismar, New York, which redesigned the brands original logo in 2008.

title: Keller Named Chevalier of French Legion of Honor
description: Thomas Keller will join Julia Child and Alice Waters as the only Americans in the food field to be named Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor. He is being granted the distinction for his work in promoting French cuisine in America.

title: The Reinvention of Silk
description: As some silk researchers see it, if spiders were gregarious vegetarians, the world might be a different place.

title: Justices Allow Inmates to Sue for DNA Testing
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday made it easier for inmates to sue for access to DNA evidence that could prove their innocence.

title: Cromer and Hecht to Reunite for Streetcar at Williamstown
description: The director David Cromer (Off Broadways acclaimed Our Town) will reunite with the Tony Award nominee Jessica Hecht as Blanche DuBois for a scaled-down version of A Streetcar Named Desire as part of this summers lineup on the Nikos Stage at the Williamstown Theater Festival, the festivals artistic director, Jenny Gersten, announced on Monday. The season includes several prominent New York actors and directors, in part a reflection of Ms. Gerstens years working at the Public Theater and the Naked Angels theater troupe before taking over the festival last fall.

title: Obama Bolsters Relief Effort at Libyan Border
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Monday that the United States was conferring with its NATO allies about potential military options to stem the bloodshed in Libya. He also said he had authorized an additional $15 million for emergency relief operations in the border regions of Libya, where tens of thousands of refugees have massed as they flee the violence.

title: Does IMF Stand for Impressive Macroeconomic Flexibility?
description: So the IMF is holding a meeting on rethinking macroeconomic policy (I was invited but couldnt make the timing work.) And the Funds chief economist has already made it clear that hes open to some serious revision of the prevailing paradigm.

title: Bipartisan Group Backs Common School Curriculum
description: A bipartisan group of educators and business and labor leaders announced on Monday their support for a common curriculum that states could adopt for public schools across the nation.

title: Harry Wilsons Latest Fix-It Job
description: Remember Harry Wilson  a key architect of the Obama administrations overhaul of General Motors and last years losing candidate for New York state comptroller?

title: Womens N.C.A.A. Field Starts Taking Shape
description: The womens N.C.A.A. basketball field is gradually filling up, thanks to the growing number of conference tournament champions claiming their spots.

title: Space Explorer
description: Whether theyre nebulae, star formations, supernovae or planetary landscapes, images from space fascinate the designer Christopher Kane. Theyre breathtaking to look at, he says, plus they translate well on fabric using digital printing. These havent been tweaked. The space-print shirt Kane wears here is part of his new mens line. The basic pieces  T-shirts, tank tops, knits and hoodies  are adapted from the themes and fabrics of his main collection, though with an easier, sportier feel. Pretty much anyone can be a customer. The oldest I know of is Ronnie Wood, he says. And the youngest is probably my 7-year-old nephew.

title: Best Financial Blogs
description: According to Time magazine; number 1 is at the bottom. Im glad to see most of my favorites there. But wheres Mark Thoma? (They could have dispensed with some of the others; you can guess which.)

title: Diverging Recoveries Highlight Danger of Concussions
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Eight months after sustaining a season-ending concussion while breaking up a double play, the Minnesota Twins Justin Morneau has yet to play in another baseball game. He is participating in spring training, but still has lingering symptoms, like occasional fogginess, and does not yet have medical clearance to return to the lineup.

title: Remember How Important It Is Not to Forget
description: An epidemic of amnesia, as potent as one of the surreal plagues in Gabriel Garca Mrquezs novels, seems to have hit our culture. Its not just aging baby boomers who are complaining about their lousy memories. Their kids, too, have forgotten how to remember phone numbers, driving directions and the basic data of daily life. After all, why bother to memorize anything when there are cellphones and Google to do it for you?

title: Musical Couples of All Kinds on the Bill at Tribeca Festival
description: Documentaries on Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova, the Academy Award-winning musicians from the hit indie feature Once and the band the Swell Season, and Genesis P-Orridge, the gender-bending performance artist of the groups Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV, are among the 44 feature-length films announced for the Tribeca Film Festival on Monday.

title: Shrovetide Football: 1 Ball, 2 Days, 3,000 Players
description: The accepted wisdom is that Tuesdays Champions League match at the Camp Nou between Barcelona and Arsenal is the biggest game in the world, but it is not in fact the biggest, at least in terms of players on the field.

title: The Single Womans Shopping List
description: Carrie Bradshaw may have spent approximately 97.3 percent of her income on Manolos, but the typical single woman budgets a little differently.

title: The Big Public Spending Debate
description: Roger Altman, chairman of Evercore Partners, discusses the battle set to begin this week in Washington over how to cut the budget deficit. In this CNBC video, he talks about how  despite some politicians reluctance to consider the revenue side of the budget equation  the deficit problem cannot be adequately addressed by focusing only on spending.

title: France 24 Interview With Colonel Qaddafi
description: In an exclusive interview, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi tells France 24 television that western journalists are presenting a distorted picture of the crisis in his country.

title: Time to Eat Tuna? Wonder No More
description: A talking tuna, a mermaid and a bee walk into a supermarket and ... Sounds like the set-up for a joke, yes? It is, however, for real, as three long-time competitors whose brands are represented by those characters join forces to stimulate demand for the pantry staple they all sell.

title: Andy Warhol as Gearhead: Museum Considers Artists Fascination With Cars
description: Long before BMW commissioned him to paint an art car, Andy Warhol had translated an abiding fascination with automobiles into work. A new show at the Montclair Art Museum in New Jersey includes some 40 works and other items on the exhibition theme, Warhol and Cars.

title: Come and Get It | Phillips de Pury Shop
description: Today, the auction house Phillips de Pury & Company is opening a shop at its 450 Park Avenue galleries. Designed by Markus Bergstrm and Joe Nunn of the London studio Glass Hill, the 600-square-foot space will feature a flexible, modular shelving system of black lacquered dowels and shelves. The shop builds on the success of two pop-up retail installations  Connectors and the Projectory  that Phillips opened last year in its (now closed) temporary quarters at the Saatchi Gallery in London. (Those installations were also designed by Glass Hill.)

title: Q&A: Deleting Gmail Messages on an iPod Touch
description: Q.

title: Big Love Watch: A Night of Horrors
description: Of the many horrors that unfolded on Sunday nights excellent episode of Big Love, I count the loss of Barbs delicious-looking fresh layer cake right up there. Despite her meticulous frosting efforts, she threw it against the window when she learned that Heathers unloading to the bishop was what led to all the legal heat now roasting the Henricksons to such an unsavory crisp.

title: Oh, Mickey, Youre So Fine
description: You may have noticed that this blog was not the only major consumer product that was unveiled during the past several days.

title: Jim Parsons and Lee Pace Join Cast of Normal Heart on Broadway
description: Proving that it is possible for the star of a CBS comedy to take a break from his series without mortifying the network or his co-stars or burning all of his bridges in the entertainment industry, Jim Parsons, the Big Bang Theory star, will join the cast of the coming Broadway production of The Normal Heart, the plays press representatives said Monday. Mr. Parsons, who in recent months has won an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe for his portrayal of the physicist Sheldon Cooper, will make his Broadway debut in The Normal Heart, playing Tommy Boatwright, a Southerner in a nascent group of HIV/AIDS activists in the early 1980s. Also joining the cast is Lee Pace, a star of the late, lamented ABC series Pushing Daisies, who will be making his Broadway debut in the role of Bruce Niles, a closeted fellow activist.

title: Romney Says Obama Is Vulnerable on Economy
description: Mitt Romney was pretty clear over the weekend that he believes the best way for Republicans to defeat President Obama in 2012 is to focus on the economy. Thats not how he saw things in the fall before the midterm elections.

title: A Battle for Chinese Hearts and Minds in Flushing
description: On the bustling thoroughfare of Chinese immigrants that is Main Street in Flushing, Queens, countless people hand out fliers for massage parlors, calling cards, English classes, money-wiring stores and other services.

title: Q. and A.: Christophe Lemaire of Herms
description: Something I learned while revisiting Christophe Lemaires debut collection for Herms in the companys showroom on Monday was that an important piece was cut from the lineup at the last minute. Well, it was not important, really, so much as it was something that would not have gone unnoticed.

title: Waxman Angrily Assails G.O.P. Science Deniers
description: There are few more powerful forces in nature than Henry Waxman in righteous fury. The California Democrat, scourge of the tobacco industry, the pharmaceutical business, the oil lobby and other malefactors of great wealth, is trying to adjust to his new role in the minority in the House. It is not going well.

title: Go800 Lets You Dial Friends Via Their Twitter Names
description: Smartphones are supposed to make calling easier, but between free calling apps like Google Voice, Skype, Fring, as well as services like Line2,there are a baffling collection of names and numbers remember.

title: Lenticular Vernacular
description: For those of us with a lazy eye, a 3-D movie is not the mind-blowing experience that it seems to be for James Cameron. But a new digital take on lenticular images requires no binocular dexterity to transfix you.

title: When Your Child Is a Lefty
description: Roughly 90 percent of people are right-handed, while just 10 percent are left-handed. But why humans develop handedness, or differences in fine motor skills between right and left hands, isnt fully understood, explains Dr. Perri Klass in the latest 18 and Under column.

title: Women Keep House (and Maybe Senate?) Better Than Men
description: Also in honor of International Womens Day (which is Tuesday): A new study finds that Congressional representatives who are women outperform their male counterparts, perhaps because the bar is higher for them to get elected in the first place.

title: Burberry Rises as Luxury M.&A. Again Comes to the Fore
description: Could Burberrys signature tartan plaid be snatched up in a sale?

title: Leisurely Meals Dont Curb Snacking, Study Finds
description: A leisurely four-course dinner at a fine restaurant can take two hours to eat, while meals eaten at home are usually over in 30 minutes. Does one leave you more satisfied  and less likely to snack afterward  than the other?

title: Familiar Bylines Grace Tina Browns Newsweek
description: Harvey Weinstein. Leslie H. Gelb. Kathleen Parker.

title: Democrats Press Cuomo on Schools and Taxes
description: ALBANY  Dozens of Assembly Democrats have sent a letter to Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, criticizing Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos proposed cuts to state education aid and calling on Mr. Silver to push for the extension of a temporary income tax surcharge on high-earning New Yorkers.

title: Flip-Flopping
description: The Teva, that multistrapped mid-80s fashion disaster beloved by Deadheads in dreads, is having a moment. Created to keep rubber flip-flops on board while white-water river rafting, the sandal, formerly just functional, has achieved some fashion notoriety. The designer Richard Chai says its carefree attitude and eclectic fans have inspired his quirky urban version, which pairs patent leather with canvas in unusual colors like ultramarine and moss green. Lanvins take looks like Transformers, with straps crisscrossing every which way. And Tomas Maier at Bottega Veneta took his jewel-toned leather Tevas on a trip, sporting gray dress socks for a high-luxe touristy look. I wouldnt recommend giving those a dunk in the deep end.

title: Home Schooling, Done Reasonably
description: The LearnMeProject is for anyone who has ever contemplated the idea of educating his kids at home, or wondered about the relationship between rigor and learning, say, or laziness and creativity. Its about a lot of other things, too, sports and faith and music and marriage, written by a Brooklyn-based author and teacher and his terrifically smart and funny and frustrated-by-traditional-schooling son.

title: When Your Money Is the Dumb Money
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: A Landmark Insider Trading Trial
description: One of Wall Street's most successful investors will appear in federal court to face charges that he made more than $45 million dollars trading on illegal stock tips.

title: Visiting Artists | Henry Taylor
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#852", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: A Look at the Landmark Insider Trading Case
description: The trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the co-founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund, begins in Manhattan on Tuesday. As the unprecedented prosecution unfolds, DealBook takes a look at some of the potential legal strategies and what the case could mean for Wall Street.

title: Pain, Persistence, Family: Sickle Cell Disease
description: HOW do you live with a disease that can cause sudden episodes of extreme pain? What do you do when the only thing that helps relieve the pain are powerful, addictive painkillers? How does a family manage the needs of a child with a chronic, untreatable illness? These are among the questions that people facing a diagnosis of sickle cell anemia have to answer.

title: Optic Sonic Yin Yang
description: Perhaps on the assumption that everyone enjoys a mildly psychedelic experience from time to time, the Web editors at Rhizome  a nonprofit with ties to the New Museum that maintains an online archive of more than 2,500 new media art projects  posted a video by the artist Brenna Murphy last week called yingyyangyhuman. Murphy calls it a cosmic disc resonancy exercise. And maybe, aside from admitting that from time to time I really do enjoy this kind of mildly psychedelic experience, nothing else needs to be said.

title: Ensign Will Retire From Senate
description: Senator John Ensign, the two-term Nevada Republican caught up in a sex scandal, is to announce Monday afternoon that he will not seek re-election next year, according to Republicans familiar with the decision.

title: The Claim: Back Pain Runs in Families
description: THE FACTS

title: Back Pain Runs in Families
description: To find out if youre at risk for back pain, check the family tree, reports Anahad OConnor in todays Really? column.

title: Optical Tracking Offers Glimpse of the Future
description: The M.I.T. Sloan Sports Analytics Conference is a collection of big-name basketball executives, owners, former coaches, news media members, hardcore sports fans and, of course, the established and budding minds of the analytical community. There is a lot of smart discussion and analysis going on, and one would be greatly entertained and learn plenty by soaking up all that the conference has to offer.

title: A Deep Dive to Retrieve and Fortify Memories
description: For years scientists have dreamed of developing a genuine memory booster, a drug that could tune the brains biological search engine so that its better at retrieving not only recently learned facts, like last nights dinner menu, but details that seem all but lost in the fog of time, like childhood classmates names and antics.

title: Control Yourself!
description: Q. Is there evidence that Kegel exercises really strengthen bladder control?

title: Briefly Noted: Practicing Useful Annotation Strategies
description: Overview | How does annotating books help to develop stronger reading skills? What can we learn from the marginalia of others? In this lesson, students review strategies of annotation and consider the benefits. They brainstorm ways to annotate, explore various methods in depth and test the value of annotating while reading.

title: The Return of Incentive Travel
description: Incentive trips  all-expenses-paid excursions offered as a reward for outstanding performance  almost disappeared after the American International Group was widely criticized for the lavish spending on one such trip in September 2008, less than a week after it got $85 billion in government bailout money.

title: More Formula One Thrills? Just Add Water, Says Race Boss
description: With a number of off-track dramas to manage  racecars catching fire, drivers in horrifying crashes, political unrest  Bernie Ecclestone badly needed a diversion. So, he created one.

title: When Lady Gaga Knows Your Name
description: Legislators often see their e-mail addresses publicized by various groups asking New Yorkers to write them in support of their causes. Dealing with the correspondence that ensues is simply part of the job.

title: A New App Shows How National Geographic Got Those Shots
description: Any photo buff who wants to know what it takes to shoot award winning images can find out with the new iPad app, 50 Greatest Photographs of National Geographic.

title: Saving Face
description: The Brooklyn-based jeweler A. Jason Ross is part Indiana Jones, part dandy. His latest venture, the Watch Transformation Project (starting at $5,500), is a service for men who want to give some edge to underused timepieces. Clients supply their own watches  a Cartier, say  and Ross swaps the band for rugged straps and then bundles it in a stylish leather case that would look nice on a nightstand next to a fedora.

title: I Want to Walk Like You, Talk Like You
description: BASRA, Iraq  It seems clear that Iraqi society, especially in the south, has witnessed the arrival of new customs and traditions since 2003. Iraqis have adopted many behavioral patterns from the Americans. Some are strange to us. From my observations in Basra, I have noted the following phenomena:

title: Back Story With Monica Davey
description: Negotiations in Wisconsin over between Democratic legislators and Gov. Scott Walker, a Republican, over bargaining rights seem to have stalled.

title: Vermont Shuts Down With Snow Over the Top
description: BOSTON  Vermonters pride themselves on being undeterred by the heavy blankets of snow that fall each winter. But this year, many are ready to wave the snow-coated white flag.

title: Software Progress Beats Moores Law
description: One of the old jokes in computing is that what the hardware giveth, the software taketh away.

title: A Lawyer Under Investigation Shuts Down His Foreclosure Practice
description: David J. Stern, one of the countrys best-known beneficiaries of the foreclosure boom, who pocketed millions from evictions processed by his Florida law firm, told regulators on Monday that he was shutting down his foreclosure practice.

title: Redo-berty
description: The final push into adulthood that takes place between the ages of 26 and 32.[Redo-puberty]

title: Britains Excellent Libyan Adventure
description: Senators John McCain and Mitch McConnell were out on the Sunday shows to push for more forceful American involvement in Libya. They were joined (with caveats) by an increasingly assertive Senator John Kerry, who insisted that a no-fly zone did not necessitate a military attack per se, contradicting Defense Secretary Gatess statement on March 2. The question of American policy on intervention in Libya has been murky; Hillary Clinton seemed a bit more hawkish than the president for a while, as did Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain. Obama has been getting real results on Libya at the United Nations  in the Security Council, at the General Assembly and even in Geneva at the Human Rights Council. But in American politics, successes at the U.N. are not to be spoken of. Americans may have lost their taste for unilateral actions, but they havent gained one for multilateral actions either.Then how about some Special Forces sneaking about, as a sop to pride or at least an outlet for the national sense of adventure? Britains experience last week suggests caution is in order. A report in The Guardian this morning says a fellow named only Tom, whom the paper believes to be a British intelligence agent, had been working at the Al-Khadra Farm Company  which raises wheat southwest of Benghazi, Libya  for five months, until last Thursday, when he drove off into the desert at 3 a.m. with another foreign national, later returning with large bags and six armed Special Air Service men. Guards at the farm arrested them. That must have had a wilting effect on the S.A.S. mens spirits. But farm personnel gave them a good hot breakfast and packed them off, and by Sunday the little band was safely away to Malta.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Yemen and Afghanistan.

title: Talk of Libya Overheard in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As some members of Congress and rebels fighting the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi press the White House to intervene militarily in Libya, President Obamas top general and defense secretary joked Monday about the unlikelihood of American airstrikes on the country.

title: India: Despite Growth, Struggle Continues With Malnutrition Among Children
description: Theres no evidence that Indias growing prosperity has led to less malnutrition among Indian children, according to a new study by scientists from Harvard and the University of Michigan.

title: From End of History Author, a Look at the Beginning and Middle
description: Human social behavior has an evolutionary basis. This was the thesis in Edward O. Wilsons book Sociobiology that caused such a stir, even though most evolutionary biologists accept that at least some social behaviors, like altruism, could be favored by natural selection.

title: After the Revolution
description: My column today makes what I hope is a non-utopian argument for why social conservatives are right to welcome the recent evidence that American teens and twenty-somethings are waiting somewhat longer to have sex. And it pivots, in part, off this post from Dana Goldstein, in which she argues 1) that premarital sex has always been with us, 2) that even if people are sleeping together more casually than they did generations ago, its just because theyre marrying later, and 3) that anyway, theres no need for anyone to feel anxious about 50-year macro social trends that have brought about unprecedented gender equality and personal fulfillment.

title: A Rare Bipartisan Call to Share Budget Pain
description: RICHMOND, Va.  While the Obama administration and Congressional Republicans fight in Washington over cutting a small slice of the federal budget, deficit hawks from both parties have taken to the road to persuade the public that the only way to really fix the nations finances is to shrink the growth of popular entitlement programs and to raise revenues.

title: Fear the Tears
description: Yesterday there were tears in the locker room again. The setting wasnt a championship, however, but a regular-season game in the N.B.A., a loss by the home-team Miami Heat to the Chicago Bulls. We know this because the Heats coach, Erik Spoelstra, said so in his postgame comments: This is painful for every single one of us to go through this, there are a couple of guys crying in the locker room right now, it is not a matter of want. As youd imagine, the general reaction hasnt been one of extending gestures of comfort (for example). And you have to wonder what Spoelstra was thinking when he went all confessional, even if he didnt name names  didnt he learn anything from all that grief John Boehner recently had to put up with over his weepiness? As Spoelstra and the Heat are finding out, crying just doesnt make for good optics most of the time. (You might find some exceptions  or confirmations in todays gallery from Sports Illustrated, Athletes in Tears.)

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Yemen and Afghanistan.

title: A Tool Gives a New View, Virus-Level, of the World
description: Researchers report this week that they have constructed the worlds most powerful optical microscope, allowing scientists to see objects the size of a virus. The findings appear in the current issue of the journal Nature Communications.

title: TimesCast | March 07, 2011
description: In Libya, questions surround Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's claims, small towns struggle in transitioning to democracy and a Benghazi construction worker joins the rebels.

title: Hawaiian Volcano Erupts, Producing Fiery Images but No Damage
description: New cracks in Hawaiis surface continued to spew lava on Monday in the latest punctuation of Kilauea Volcano, the mythical home of the Hawaiian fire goddess Pele.

title: Charlie Sheen Fired From Two and a Half Men
description: 8:51 p.m. | Updated Throughout his recent rants about CBS, Warner Brothers and his own drug use, Charlie Sheen insisted that he was ready to return to work on the hit sitcom Two and a Half Men.

title: American Composers Orchestra
description: Zankel Hall

title: With Billie Joe Gone, American Idiot Ticket Sales Plunge
description: As the Green Day song in Broadways American Idiot goes, give me novacaine  please. In its first week of performances without the bands frontman, Billie Joe Armstrong, as the special guest star in the cast, American Idiot saw a painful drop in its box office grosses, falling from $1.3 million to $395,275 for its standard eight performances through Sunday.

title: Georgia Poses Hurdle for U.S.-Russia Ties
description: MOSCOW  When Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. sits down with Russias leaders later this week, a central topic will be the payoffs of the reset between Russia and the United States, among them Russias long-awaited accession to the World Trade Organization, which American officials have vigorously supported.

title: Gupta Resigns From AMR Board
description: Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble director accused of leaking confidential information about those companies, has stepped down from another corporate board.

title: Leapfrogging Feds, Wal-Mart Bans Controversial Flame Retardant
description: A wide body of scientific evidence suggests that a popular class of flame retardant  P.B.D.E.s, or polybrominated diphenyl ethers, found in products like fabrics, car interiors and electronics  pose a significant risk to human health.

title: London Gives Explanation of Botched Libyan Venture
description: LONDON  The British government on Monday revealed embarrassing details about a British mission that was apparently meant to reinforce relations with opposition leaders in eastern Libya, but that ended with eight Britons being handcuffed and detained on a military base for two days.

title: YouTube Acquires a Producer of Videos
description: SAN FRANCISCO  YouTube, the video site owned by Google, formally announced on Monday that it had acquired Next New Networks, a Web video production company, in its biggest effort yet to move beyond short, quirky home videos to professionally produced content.

title: St. Louis Symphony
description: Carnegie Hall

title: Militias Help Somali Force Regain Towns Near Borders
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somali government troops and allied militias have repelled Islamist militants from two towns near the Kenyan and Ethiopian borders in a string of recent victories, Somali officials said Monday.

title: Signs of Razing in Contested Part of Sudan
description: GOMA, Democratic Republic of the Congo  As violence increases before southern Sudans expected independence this summer, a satellite image emerged of a razed village in the contested region of Abyei, offering a rare glimpse of fighting there.

title: A Pilot Happy to Be Paid in Cookies
description: I DONT mind flying for business. Im almost always by myself and the solitude is a nice break.

title: A Monk in Confinement, Waiting to Reclaim a Title
description: JERUSALEM  Like a figure in a medieval drama, the monk Irenaeus I has been cloistered for the last three years in a third-floor apartment in the compound of the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate high above a narrow, bustling alleyway of Jerusalems Old City, unwilling or unable to leave.

title: Face Time | Ivanka Trump
description: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

title: Mariinsky Ballet to Perform at Lincoln Center Festival
description: Lincoln Center on Monday announced the third pillar of what is shaping up to be an especially high-profile festival this summer: the Mariinsky Ballet. The company will give eight performances at the Metropolitan Opera House in July, joining the Cleveland Orchestra and the Royal Shakespeare Company as major presences at the Lincoln Center Festival. The Mariinsky will present two works receiving their first United States performances, Anna Karenina and The Little Humpbacked Horse, full-length ballets choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky and set to the music of the contemporary Russian composer Rodion Shchedrin. A third program includes Alberto Alonsos Carmen Suite, choreographed to Bizets music as arranged by Mr. Shchedrin, and Symphony in C, the George Balanchine work. Valery Gergiev, Mariinskys artistic director, will conduct.

title: Automatic for the CD Bin
description: When I was younger, I wondered who bought new Rolling Stones albums. I now know, because I am the descendant of that man: I cant help buying  in physical, compact-disc form, no less  every new R.E.M. album. Tomorrow we get another one: Collapse Into Now. NPR is streaming it free until then.

title: Inspector Faults Energy Department Over Loan Program
description: WASHINGTON  Poor record-keeping by the Energy Department has made it difficult for managers to document how decisions were reached in its $71 billion loan guarantee program, the departments inspector general said in an audit released on Monday.

title: When Energy Efficiency Sullies the Environment
description: For the sake of a cleaner planet, should Americans wear dirtier clothes?

title: The Food of Love, Coaxed From Ancient Instruments
description: Constantinople is nominally a French-Canadian early-music trio, based in Montreal. But it is not quite that simple. It was founded in 1998 by Kiya Tabassian, an Iranian-born performer on the setar: a Persian lute with a long, rounded neck. The ensemble, which Mr. Tabassian directs, includes his brother, Ziya Tabassian, a percussionist who is particularly adept on the Persian tombak, a goblet-shaped drum, and Pierre-Yves Martel, a viola da gamba player who splits his time between Montreal and Paris. But the group seems rarely to work in this stripped-down form: its Web site lists a long roster of regular collaborators who play Middle Eastern stringed instruments and sing, as well as a flamenco guitarist, a clarinetist and a D.J.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Volcker May Get Last Laugh Roy Smith says that a study by the Financial Stability Oversight Council suggests the regulators really do get it and are prepared to regulate proprietary trading effectively. Financial News

title: He May Be Bound, but This Prometheus Still Manages to Rock
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  In Aeschylus Prometheus Bound the title character is punished for stealing fire and giving it to humans. For the playwright Steven Sater the idea of having ones life altered by flames is intensely personal.

title: Drug-Fueled Fantasies (Without the Drugs)
description: PARIS

title: Connecting the Dots, From the 18th Century to the Hip-Hop Now
description: You have to admire Lynn Parkerson, the director of the Brooklyn Ballet, for not exactly pandering to popular taste through most of the companys current program at the Performance Space at the Schermerhorn.

title: East Side, West Side, Bias Claims Abound
description: Francesco and Evelyn Bruni enjoy living in their one-bedroom at the Trafalgar House condominium in Carnegie Hill, so much that they would like to trade up to a larger apartment in the building to make room for their growing family. But they are also embroiled in a messy discrimination lawsuit against their condo board, which Ms. Bruni once served on.

title: Lifestyles of the Natives Off Southern California
description: Inhabitants of Californias Channel Islands 12,000 years ago had a diverse sea-based economy that included shellfish, seals, geese and fish, archaeologists say in the current issue of the journal Science.

title: Quote Unquote | Gaga Love
description: Anna Dello Russo tells WWD about her conversation with Lady Gaga at Thierry Mugler. Can we expect a duet in the near future?

title: Developing the Next John McEnroe
description: At a tennis academy on Randalls Island, John McEnroe envisions top young players leading normal lives while learning to embrace their individuality and creativity.

title: Decadent Russian Art, Still Under the Boots Shadow
description: MOSCOW  Later this week moviegoers in New York will learn the strange story of Igor V. Savitsky, an obsessive collector credited with saving tens of thousands of avant-garde artworks from Soviet authorities who forced artists toward Socialist Realism in the 1930s.

title: Americas Love of Sherry Smolders
description: FOR years, wine writers and other enthusiasts have lamented the publics indifference to the manifest charms and complexities of sherry. Why doesnt everyone love sherry, they asked, celebrating it as the most undervalued, underappreciated wine in the world, as it languished in the back pages of wine lists and on the dustiest of retail shelves.

title: A New Firebird for Ballet Theater
description: American Ballet Theater is no stranger to The Firebird: the troupe already has in its repertory several versions of the ballet set to Stravinskys 1910 score. But none of those were by its artist in residence, Alexei Ratmansky. That oversight is about to be rectified: Ballet Theater announced Monday that Mr. Ratmansky would be creating a new version, with scenery by Simon Pastukh and costumes by Galina Solovyeva, to have its premiere next March during the companys Costa Mesa, Calif., engagement. New Yorkers will get to see the production during the spring 2012 season at the Metropolitan Opera House. For those keeping score at home, this will be Ballet Theaters fourth production of The Firebird and the choreographers second  he created a version for the Royal Swedish Ballet in 2002.

title: Obama Clears Way for Guantnamo Trials
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday reversed his two-year-old order halting new military charges against detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, permitting military trials to resume with revamped procedures but implicitly admitting the failure of his pledge to close the prison camp.

title: Want a Cheaper iPad? You Have Options, Actually
description: So theres a new iPad2. And thats great. But for those willing to put up with last years model, theres a cheapskate strategy that can help you save big  if you know where to look.

title: Google Maps on Android Now Features Traffic Data
description: Read this Google press release to learn about a new feature for Android users of Google Maps Navigation: real-time traffic data. The feature will work automatically in the app, accounting for real-time and historical traffic data when it plots your route.

title: Critics' Picks: 'The Warriors'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Walter Hill's 1979 film about a New York City gang fighting their way home.

title: Prometheus Bound
description: Photos from the new rock musical at American Repertory Theater.

title: Men With Nets Meet Scientists With Clipboards
description: Lekelia D. Jenkins, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington, writes from Ecuador, where she is studying factors in the cross-cultural adoption of marine conservation technologies like turtle excluder devices and circle hooks. She co-leads this project with Patrick Christie, who is an environmental sociologist and associate professor at the University of Washington.

title: Its Hard to Be Sexy
description: PARIS

title: Nerve and Verve on a Grand Scale
description: SAN FRANCISCO  San Francisco Ballet, often Americas most distinguished ballet company outside New York, regularly sets standards that match New Yorks. No other American company covers an equal range of international ballet styles; none surpass it for overall elegance and finesse of execution; no other has a greater number of ballerinas worthy of the leading roles of its repertory. Its levels of orchestral playing are generally better than those of its New York peers.

title: Orchestras New Hall, Finely Tuned
description: Church mice have nothing on classical musicians in New York when it comes to haunting church basements. Behind all those polished musical performances in glamorous halls lie hours of rehearsal, often in dank rooms that have little to recommend them but adequate space and relatively low cost, acoustics be damned. And that is where church basements come in, or used to.

title: Web Site Reveals Hotel Rooms Before You Check In
description: Ever check into a hotel only to be disappointed that your pricey deluxe suite sits on the second floor and has a view of a parking garage? A new Web site and free iPhone app called Room 77 seeks to help you avoid this fate.

title: Stevensons Tale: Yo-Ho-Ho and a Parrot, Too
description: When you are witness to a really good stage production, your immediate thought is, Wow, everybody ought to see this. But thats rarely true, and its probably not true of the rousing, spiffily acted Treasure Island now at the Irondale Center in Brooklyn.

title: Used iPads Selling Quickly Online
description: Steve Jobs was still on stage introducing the new iPad 2 last week when my inbox and Twitter stream started filling up with the same question : I want the iPad 2, but what can I do with my old iPad?

title: Gheorghiu Withdraws From Faust at Met
description: The Romanian-born soprano Angela Gheorghiu, whose diva-size reputation is beginning to loom larger than her exciting voice and stage presence, has yet again caused arms to fly in exasperation at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Quad Q.& A.: Texas Coach Mack Brown
description: Feeling re-energized after a brutal season on the field and an off-season full of change, Texas Coach Mack Brown sat down for an interview in his office last week. He touched on topics as varied as his love of the Boise State offense to his new young coordinators to why he wont be taking his shirt off around Texas new strength coach. He also talked about how YouTube aided his hiring process, how Texas new ESPN channel will impact the programs future and how he re-evaluated the programs recruiting philosophy last year.

title: Foreclose Deal Near, State Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  A broad agreement could be struck within two months to overhaul how millions of foreclosures are handled by the nations biggest banks and to expand the use of home loan modifications, according to Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Warriors
description: This weeks Critics Pick video looks at the Walter Hills drama The Warriors. The film takes place in a dystopian version of New York City run by gangs jockeying for control.

title: End of the Beginning for the Soda Tax?
description: Last year, the soda tax was proposed and set back in New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco and elsewhere. It was dead in the water.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,480 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Digging Up Energy Savings Right in Your Backyard
description: Five years ago, my husband and I walked out of what was left of our historic house after a propane explosion. As the house caught fire, the cat jumped out to safety, too. When we rebuilt, we wanted to avoid burning fossil fuels in our new home, and I remembered reading an article about an architect who drilled geothermal wells to heat and cool his Lower Manhattan town house.

title: JPMorgan Names New Senior Lawyer for Home Lending
description: JPMorgan Chase has hired Matthew L. Biben, a former senior lawyer at Bank of New York Mellon, as the general counsel of its home lending unit, as the bank revamps its mortgage operations, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

title: 12-Year-Old Girl May Embody McEnroes Vision
description: For John McEnroe, a man of impassioned and instantly expressed emotions, hitting with Ingrid Neel was almost a case of love at first tennis stroke.

title: Putting Teachers in the Firing Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Improver of Street Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: What Verizon Offers
description: To the Editor:

title: 14 Pit Bulls Rescued From Fiery Bronx Apartment
description: Updated, March 9 | Firefighters responding to an apartment fire in the Bronx on Monday afternoon broke into the apartment to find 14 pit bulls that had been injured by the smoke and fire.

title: The Human Touch (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicine Is Still an Art, as Well as a Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Video: 'It Happened Today' by R.E.M.
description: The band's new video was directed by Tom Gilroy.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: AVRIL LAVIGNE

title: Anesthesias Mysteries (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Eat That! (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hanging On for Dear Life, Outside a Police Station House
description: It was perhaps one of the more unlikely locales for such a scene of chaos.

title: Scorecard | Cline Wins!
description: It was raining not Rottweilers, but panthers on the Givenchy runway on the sixth day of Paris fashion week. And while Scorecard knows theres no question Riccardo Tisci put forth a vision of fierce feline fashion, when it comes to looks for more practical cats, critics felt Phoebe Philos Jaguars really had bite.

title: Senate Nears Final Vote on Patents
description: Inventors, get your sneakers on. The race to the patent office could soon be winner-take-all.

title: The Waiting Game Doesnt Have to be Stressful
description: I have read multiple accounts of the waiting game, described as the dreadful months from January to April in which every senior sits impatiently waiting for the arrival of anticipated college decisions. However, for me the last two months have been relaxing and lovely, though still filled with ample work.

title: Restaurateur Is Said to Win Pier A Lease
description: A prince of the restaurant scene in Manhattans financial district could soon expand his realm to a 125-year-old Victorian pier that juts out from Lower Manhattan toward the Statue of Liberty.

title: Kors Gets a Place to Hang His Hat, in Paris
description: PARIS  A couple of nights ago, Charles H. Rivkin, the United States ambassador to France, was standing in the park-sized gardens behind his residence on the Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honor, watching a crew erect a clear plastic tent decorated with a mirrored backdrop and eight glistening Moooi chandeliers, each encased in a clear, circular frame.

title: Rachel Alexandra in Foal to Curlin
description: In a mating of classy pedigrees, Rachel Alexandra, the 2009 Horse of the Year, is in foal to Curlin, who was the Horse of the Year in 2007 and 2008. Whether they will produce a horse will be determined, but the bride and grooms owner, Jess Jackson, certainly had that in mind.

title: Russia Faces 3-Year Race to Secure Site of Olympics
description: SOCHI, Russia  Less than 250 miles separate the skating arenas being built here for the 2014 Winter Olympics and the home of a suicide bomber who killed 37 people at a Moscow airport in January. A little farther on is Chechnya, site of two civil wars and a still seething Muslim insurgency. In a neighboring region, three tourists on a ski trip were shot to death recently, and local resorts were closed as soldiers searched in vain for the assailants.

title: The New Humanism
description: Over the course of my career, Ive covered a number of policy failures. When the Soviet Union fell, we sent in teams of economists, oblivious to the lack of social trust that marred that society. While invading Iraq, the nations leaders were unprepared for the cultural complexities of the place and the psychological aftershocks of Saddams terror.

title: A New Job in Beijing for Secretary of Commerce
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama plans to nominate Gary F. Locke, the commerce secretary and one of the highest-ranking Chinese-Americans in the administration, as the next American ambassador to China, administration officials said Monday. Mr. Locke, 61, would succeed Jon M. Huntsman Jr., who is stepping down next month to explore a bid for the Republican nomination for president.

title: Peace-Building That Pays Off
description: Williamsburg, Va.

title: Vonn Sees Slim Shot to Catch Top Rival
description: In three days over the weekend, Lindsey Vonn successfully defended three of her four World Cup ski championships, clinching titles in the downhill, the super-G and the super combined. But on Monday, Vonn acknowledged that her retaining the World Cup overall title, which she has won the last three years, was unlikely.

title: Sticks and Stones
description: In his new book, Philosopher Kings? The Adjudication of Conflicting Human Rights and Social Values, law professor George C. Christie notes that with respect to the conflict between privacy rights and free expression rights, the United States and Europe seem to be going in different directions. European jurists will try, as one court put it, to strike a fair balance . . . between the competing interests of the individual and of the community as a whole; American courts are likely to come down strongly in favor of the individuals right to free expression even when an expressive activity arguably pollutes the communitys conversational space or is intentionally hurtful to other individuals.

title: Shrovetide Game Is One a Whole Town Can, and Does, Play
description: The accepted wisdom is that Tuesdays Champions League match between Barcelona and Arsenal is the biggest game in the world, but it is not literally the biggest, at least in terms of players on the field.

title: Michigan Town Split on Child Pornography Charges
description: MUSKEGON, Mich.  People in this economically pressed town near Lake Michigan are divided into two camps: Those who think Evan Emory should pay hard for what he did, and those who think he should be let off easy.

title: Peter Kings Obsession
description: Not much spreads fear and bigotry faster than a public official intent on playing the politics of division. On Thursday, Representative Peter King, the chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, is scheduled to open a series of hearings that seem designed to stoke fear against American Muslims. His refusal to tone down the provocation despite widespread opposition suggests that he is far more interested in exploiting ethnic misunderstanding than in trying to heal it.

title: Journalists in Yemen Say They Are Being Attacked
description: SANA, Yemen  Journalists covering the antigovernment movement in Yemen are reporting being attacked by supporters of President Ali Abdullah Saleh and in some cases by state security officers.

title: Tucson Autopsy Reports Are Released
description: TUCSON  Witnesses to the Tucson shooting rampage describe it in emotional language, and court documents lay it out in legalese. Now, newly released autopsy reports give a glimpse of the chilling attack from the clinical viewpoint of the forensic pathologist who examined the bodies of the six people who were killed.

title: E.P.A. Steps Up Scrutiny of Pollution in Pennsylvania Rivers
description: Radioactivity levels are at or below safe levels in Pennsylvania rivers, state regulators said on Monday, based on water samples taken last November and December from seven rivers.

title: Rising Calls to Replace Top Man at Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress, including Democrats, have urged the Obama administration to search for another Medicare chief after concluding that the Senate is unlikely to confirm President Obamas temporary appointee, Dr. Donald M. Berwick.

title: The Ashtray: Shifting Paradigms (Part 2)
description: This is part two of a five-part series.

title: CARE, in Return to Roots, Will Offer Virtual Packages
description: Marta Edie has no trouble remembering the first package stamped with the letters CARE that arrived at her familys home in Limburg an der Lahn, Germany, shortly after World War II.

title: In the Shadow of Blackstone
description: Stephen A. Schwarzman still has a step on Henry Kravis. Efforts by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity firm Mr. Kravis co-founded, to diversify are off to a good start. But Kohlberg Kravis, due next Tuesday to host its first investor day as a public company, has much to prove while the Blackstone Group, run by Mr. Schwarzman, has found its stride in public markets.

title: Too Long to Wait
description: Seven months have passed since Proposition 8, Californias voter-approved ban on same-sex marriages, was ruled unconstitutional by a federal judge in San Francisco following a much-publicized trial that turned up no evidence to justify the measures denial of equal protection and due process.

title: Patents, Reform and the Little Guy
description: In the last decade, Congress has missed several chances to reform a patent system that is slow, costly and puts the United States at odds with the rest of the industrial world. On Wednesday, the Senate has another opportunity to reform the nations patent law.

title: The Grand Canyon Uranium Rush
description: In July 2009, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar imposed a two-year halt to uranium exploration and mining on one million acres around the Grand Canyon. The moratorium was a much-needed timeout to a rush of prospecting claims near the canyon, most of them by Canadian and British companies. The rush was fueled by two things: an increase in uranium prices and the wide-open exploitation allowed on public lands by the harmful, antiquated 1872 mining law.

title: Walter Zacharius, Romance Publisher, Dies at 87
description: Walter Zacharius, who rode the passion-swollen wave of romance fiction in the early 1980s to build the Kensington Publishing Corporation into a leading purveyor of bodice-rippers and other romance genres, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Absent Police Chief Is Fired in Mexico, Ending an Experiment
description: MEXICO CITY  An experiment in law enforcement in a drug-ravaged border town ended Monday when the 20-year-old police chief was fired after failing to turn up for work.

title: As the Pretzels Go, So Goes Flying Quality
description: THE cost saving is peanuts, really. Actually, make that pretzels, since Continental Airlines has eliminated those tiny bags of free pretzels for coach customers on domestic flights. The airline says it will save $2.5 million a year.

title: With Stars Aplenty, Heat Looks for Leader
description: To fix the Miami Heat, somebody is going to have to figure out what exactly is wrong with it.

title: Debit Card Fees Prompt a Push Near Deadline
description: WASHINGTON  It seemed a good idea last year, when the financial crisis had turned banks into Public Enemy No. 1 and lawmakers were looking for ways to reward consumers still bitter about billion-dollar bailouts and executive bonuses.

title: From Oman, With Love
description: Muscat, Oman

title: Exchanges Duel for Customers
description: Last fall, when Continental and United Airlines were merging and deciding where to list the new companys shares, the New York Stock Exchange offered to sponsor ceremonies for airline executives at the open and close of trading in Paris and New York. It also agreed to buy advertisements in the airlines magazine to herald the listing.

title: Drawing U.S. Crowds With Anti-Islam Message
description: FORT WORTH  Brigitte Gabriel bounced to the stage at a Tea Party convention last fall. She greeted the crowd with a loud Texas Yee-HAW, then launched into the same gripping personal story she has told in hundreds of churches, synagogues and conference rooms across the United States:

title: Judge Allows Players Testimony in Bonds Perjury Trial
description: Despite repeated efforts by Barry Bondss lawyers to bar the testimony of several current and former major league players in Bondss perjury trial this month, those athletes will be allowed to take the stand, a federal judge ruled on Monday in San Francisco.

title: Battle in Ras Lanuf
description: As rebels took cover from government warplanes, the worlds attention was drawn further toward the possibility of military intervention in Libya.

title: Discord Fills Washington on Possible Libya Intervention
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly three weeks after Libya erupted in what may now turn into a protracted civil war, the politics of military intervention to speed the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi grow more complicated by the day  for both the White House and Republicans.

title: A Cuomo Schedule Conflict Draws Scrutiny
description: For Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, it is a lesson that not even his Catholic-school upbringing could have taught: When you are the states top elected official, even the most innocent scheduling conflict can assume a life of its own.

title: A Film About Capitalism, and (Surprise) Its a Love Story
description: LOS ANGELES  At the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., next weekend, moviegoers can see what might be the rarest bird in the documentary world: a genuine love story about capitalism.

title: Managers Inspire Villanova Teams, and Also a Film
description: VILLANOVA, Pa.  The chant started in the student section and spread through the Pavilion before Villanova hosted Pittsburgh in basketball here last month. An ESPN feature had played on the video boards, and as the building shook with a singsong Nick and Frank-ie! Wildcats Coach Jay Wright wiped away tears.

title: St. Peters Tops Iona for First N.C.A.A. Bid Since 1995
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  St. Peters was a founding member of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference in 1981, but history never equated with tradition. The program had only two conference championships despite six appearances in the tournaments title game.

title: Spider-Man Director May Face Her Own Exit
description: The producers of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark were negotiating on Monday with their director, Julie Taymor, for her to work with a newly expanded creative team to fix the critically derided $65 million musical or possibly leave the show, according to people who work on Spider-Man or have been briefed on the negotiations.

title: Mog, the Digital Music Service, Takes Aim at the TV and the Car
description: The next frontier for digital music is not a tablet or a smartphone, but two items that have been part of everyday life for decades: the car and the television set.

title: Flailing After Muslims
description: It has often been the case in America that specific religions, races and ethnic groups have been singled out for discrimination, demonization, incarceration and worse. But there have always been people willing to stand up boldly and courageously against such injustice. Their efforts are needed again now.

title: Openness of Owners on Finances Could Be Key in Talks
description: With negotiations toward a new collective bargaining agreement reopening on Monday, progress could hinge on the willingness of N.F.L. owners to share more financial information with players this week.

title: Diverse Character in City Qaddafi Calls Islamist
description: DARNAH, Libya  This fiercely independent port city on the Mediterranean coast, once the center of a simmering Islamist insurgency in the 1990s, is now branded by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi as an Islamic emirate infiltrating his embattled country.

title: Taking Photos of Breakfast and Giving Meals to Children
description: BREAKFAST eaters around the country are photographing their bowls of cereal, plates of eggs and assorted pastries, not out of a personal obsession with food but for a more wholesome reason: giving breakfast to children in need.

title: For Bulgari, LVMH Deal Paves Way to Growth
description: The Bulgari familys long quest to figure out the future of its 127-year-old jewelry and watch business ended last Thursday at a dinner overlooking the Roman skyline.

title: The Rabbi and the Rebellion
description: New York, March 1861

title: Florida Republicans Are at Odds With Their Leader
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Rick Scott, the conservative Republican billionaire who plucked the governors job from the party establishment in November with $73 million of his own money and the backing of the Tea Party, vowed during his campaign to run the troubled state like a corporate chief executive (which he was) and not a politician (which he proudly says he is not).

title: A Sponsor of the Mets Mulls a Bid
description: The Mets are looking for buyers of at least 25 percent of the club, and at least one potential bidder may come bearing flowers.

title: Senator, After Scandal, Wont Run Again
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John Ensign, the two-term Nevada Republican caught up in a sex and ethics inquiry, announced Monday that he would not seek re-election in 2012 to avoid what he predicted would be an exceptionally ugly campaign.

title: Lawsuit Seeks to Erase Bike Lane in New York City
description: Well-connected New Yorkers have taken the unusual step of suing the city to remove a controversial bicycle lane in a wealthy neighborhood of Brooklyn, the most potent sign yet of opposition to the Bloomberg administrations marquee campaign to remake the citys streets.

title: From Minors to Majors, a Connection Endures
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Terry Collins and Jim Leyland, two baseball lifers, renewed their managerial acquaintance Monday, chatting at the cage during batting practice and exchanging lineup cards at home plate as competing skippers for the first time in 15 years.

title: Curious Accusations in S.E.C.s Insider Case
description: The fact pattern looks bad, very bad.

title: G.O.P. Voters Are Ready for the 2012 Race. Now Somebody Tell the Candidates.
description: WAUKEE, Iowa  The 2012 presidential campaign is beginning, whether the candidates are ready or not.

title: Bus Trips Are Treat for Yanks Fans, if Not Veterans
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Every spring training, gray pants are issued to Mariano Rivera. And every spring training, they go unworn, hanging in his locker like a painting in a museum. Rivera, perhaps the greatest closer in history, does not do trips.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 7, 2011

title: Drunken Driving Conviction Voided for Crime Lab Errors
description: Continuing questions about the reliability of tests done in Nassau Countys now-shuttered crime laboratory led a judge to overturn a drunken driving conviction on Monday.

title: Libyan War Traps Poor Immigrants at Tripolis Edge
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  As wealthier nations send boats and planes to rescue their citizens from the violence in Libya, a new refugee crisis is taking shape on the outskirts of Tripoli, where thousands of migrant workers from sub-Saharan Africa have been trapped with scant food and water, no international aid and little hope of escape.

title: Tapes Show Beatings by Youths in Prisons
description: ALBANY  A former official suing a state agency for discrimination revealed on Monday videos of youths at four state prisons ganging up on and beating guards and other youths in custody.

title: Diet Plan With Hormone Has Fans and Skeptics
description: Every morning, Kay Brown engages in a ritual similar to a heroin addicts, or a diabetics: she sticks herself with a syringe. Only hers contains hCG, a pregnancy hormone.

title: Tuesday: Racer on a Strip
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  One of the formative moments of my childhood was being taken to the movies to see the theatrical release of The Ten Commandments starring Charlton Heston and watching him stretch his staff over the roiling waters of the RED SEA, parting them like it was nothing. It was a scenery-chewing moment that wasnt helped by the cheesy visual effects of 1960s cinema, but to a young mind it was pretty heavy. I remember hoping that the Egyptian soldiers who were being swallowed by the closing of the sea might be able to TREAD WATER.

title: Rape Trial for 2 Police Officers Is Delayed as Prosecutor Seeks Another Grand Jury
description: The trial of two New York City police officers indicted on charges of raping a drunken woman in the East Village was delayed for two weeks after a prosecutor said Monday that his office wanted to present evidence to a second grand jury.

title: Laura DAndrea Tyson
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. She served as dean of London Business School from 2002 to 2006, and as dean of the Haas School from 1998 to 2001.

title: Coming Together to Give Schools a Boost
description: We only have to consider some of the nations greatest achievements to appreciate whats possible when we coordinate efforts rationally. At its peak, for example, the Apollo program, which put a man on the moon, involved 400,000 people and 20,000 companies and academic organizations. The Manhattan Project, which produced the first atomic bomb, coordinated the work of 130,000 scientists, engineers and others. The Los Angeles Olympic Games were successful because of unprecedented cooperation among civic groups, government agencies and businesses.

title: Roger Ebert Tests His Vocal Cords, and Comedic Delivery
description: First there was the Turing Test, a benchmark for computer intelligence via conversation.

title: For Knicks, Stars Align and Points Come Easy
description: There is no perfect template for the superstar partnership, no set formula to divine victories from star power and really no way of telling when and how these arranged marriages will produce wedded bliss.

title: Restrictions on Logging Are Restored
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal district judge has reinstated a Clinton-era regulation that prevented logging on old stands of hemlock, cedar and spruce trees in large stretches of the Tongass National Forest in Alaska.

title: Bloggingheads: Is Sudan Next?
description: Mark Leon Goldberg, left, of UN Dispatch and Rebecca Hamilton, author of "Fighting for Darfur," discuss whether protests will spread to Sudan.

title: Hearing Is Sought on Helmet Safety
description: Representatives Henry A. Waxman and G. K. Butterfield formally requested that the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade hold a hearing on football helmet safety.

title: Justice Delayed and Delayed for One Felon
description: Let us consider the case of a man who is the leading figure in a multimillion-dollar criminal operation, an admitted felon. He confessed his misdeeds to a judge (complete with a by-the-numbers statement of regret, which always seems to come only after the miscreant has his back against the wall).

title: Jewish Texts Lost in War Are Surfacing in New York
description: In 1932, as the Nazis rose to power in Germany, a Jewish librarian in Frankfurt published a catalog of 15,000 books he had painstakingly collected for decades.

title: City Agrees to Take Less of School Principals Budget Savings
description: The New York City Education Department said Monday that it would allow principals to roll more money than anticipated from this years budget into next years, but that they would still have to return some unspent money to the school system headquarters.

title: France: Chirac Trial Suspended on Statute Challenge
description: The criminal trial of former President Jacques Chirac began Monday, but it was quickly suspended. Mr. Chirac, 78, the first head of state to be tried since the Vichy leader Philippe Ptain was convicted of treason in 1945, is accused of padding the Paris payroll with ghost workers who were political cronies while he was mayor from 1977 to 1995.

title: Ensigns Retirement May Actually Help the G.O.P.
description: Some retirement announcements are devastating news for a political party. When Byron Dorgan, the Democratic Senator from North Dakota, stated early last year that he would not seek re-election, Democrats went from having a seat that they were favored to retain to one that they would almost certainly lose  which they did by 51 points last November.

title: West Bank: Clash Over Olive Trees Leaves 8 Wounded
description: At least seven Palestinians were wounded by gunfire and rubber bullets in clashes with Israeli settlers and soldiers in the northern West Bank on Monday, according to a Palestinian official and the Israeli military. One settler was reported wounded after being hit by a rock. Palestinians accused the settlers of having uprooted olive trees in the area. A military spokeswoman said that settlers and soldiers opened fire after being attacked by Palestinian stone throwers. Three of the Palestinians were shot by settlers, and four by soldiers, the spokeswoman said, adding that of the four, two were wounded by rubber bullets and two by live fire.

title: Zimbabwe: 39 of 45 Activists Released, but Not Leader
description: A magistrate ordered the release on Monday of 39 of the 45 activists who were charged with treason and accused of plotting Egyptian-style protests to topple President Robert Mugabe, according to Zimbabwe Lawyers for Human Rights. Six of the detainees, including the organizer of the Feb. 19 meeting on the North African uprisings, Munyaradzi Gwisai, remain jailed.

title: Somalia: Government Takes Back Two Towns
description: Somali government troops and loosely allied militias have repelled Islamist militants from two towns near the Kenyan and Ethiopian borders in a string of recent victories, Somali officials said. President Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed was quick to take credit, although African Union peacekeepers were involved in the fighting.

title: Game That Has Everything Could Hinge on Whats Missing
description: There has been much written in the last few weeks about Cesc Fbregass return to his roots Tuesday, when he will lead Arsenal against Barcelona in the second leg of the teams Champions League Round of 16 matchup.

description: After decades of floating through Times Square, the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade will bypass it in 2012, going down Avenue of the Americas instead, City Hall officials said on Monday.

description: Mike DeStefano, a burly, tattooed comedian who turned his recovery from heroin addiction into brutally honest, profanity-laced routines, died on Sunday in the Bronx.

description: Test your vocabulary skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article Another Stop on a Long, Improbable Journey.

title: Does Class Size Matter?
description: How large are your classes? How do you think the number of students in a class affects how well teachers can teach and students can learn? According to this article, class sizes are rising across the nation because of budget cuts  in Detroit, high school classes may go up to 60 students. How many kids in a class is too many? What experiences have you had with the ways class size affects learning?
