title: Chinese Impose Travel Ban on Tibet
description: A senior Chinese official, Zhang Qingli, has said foreigners are barred from entering Tibet this month. Mr. Zhang said the travel ban was because of cold weather, a shortage of capacity for tourists and safety concerns, according to Xinhua, the state news agency.

title: Tuesday Reading: An Odd New Diet Fad
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Housing Authority Official Resigns After Letter Surfaces
description: A top city public housing official resigned Monday after using his official letterhead to write a letter to a judge on behalf of the son of a family friend who was facing child pornography charges.

title: Cracking Down on Croparazzi
description: Photographers  perhaps including some ghosts from Farm Security Administration days are astir at news of a bill introduced by State Senator Jim Norman of Florida that would make it a felony to take a picture of a farm without the owners permission:

title: What I Read
description: A number of people have asked for my own list of top finance/economics/whatever blogs. I dont know that I can be systematic. What I can do, however, is tell you what I read most mornings.

title: The Elusive Dream of American Energy Plans
description: Why does same as it ever was keep coming to mind when examining the responses of Americas elected leaders to durable challenges  whether confronting deficits and the debt, the glaring lack of alternatives to oil and the risks posed by unabated emissions of greenhouse gases.

title: New Strategy Weighed for Failing Schools
description: The Bloomberg administrations signature strategy for low-performing schools has been to shut them down, a drastic move that often incites anger and protests from teachers, parents and neighborhood officials. Since the beginning of the mayors first term, more than 110 schools have been shuttered or are in the process of closing.

title: Sole Mate
description: Try to phone the British-born bootmaker Julian Imrie and youll probably get his voice mail, which begins: Im in the jungle right now. Actually, on a recent weekday, Imrie, 39, was aboard a sailboat anchored somewhere in the French West Indies, when he was prompted, via e-mail, to recount his life thus far  a life that has been so peripatetic, romantic and unlikely that its almost obnoxious. Imrie quit college to assist Bruce Weber, went on to work on a horse farm in Montauk, N.Y., then movedto Amish country, where he salvaged crumbling barns. He spent a year studying the New Testament (in Greek). Then he biked from Los Angeles, his current home base, to Brazil. At one point, he decided to start Julian Boots, his stylish take on 19th-century footwear (from about $700, at Barneys New York), but first he learned how to make molds in the English Midlands and to tan leather in a 250-year-old Swiss factory. Now hes an amateur boot historian, able to slip easily into a disquisition on what a 19th-century Cornish miner might wear. What his boots share with their fuss-free forebears, Imrie says, is that you can use them in your garden and then rub them off and go to a wedding.

title: Republicans Seek to Slow Agencys Work on Derivatives Regulation
description: Federal regulators are running out of time to write hundreds of new rules for Wall Street. Yet Republican lawmakers  and even some regulators  want to slow the pace.

title: A Big East Goal: Avoid the N.I.T. Watch
description: If you could design your own conference tournament, you probably could not create one better than the Big Easts. Sixteen teams, fifteen games, five days and one historical location all come together to form an event in which winning the whole thing can be more difficult than winning the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: No Escape This Time: British Court to Rule in Star Wars Costume Dispute
description: The Galactic Empire of the Star Wars movies may have given us the planet-annihilating Death Star, and George Lucas may have given us the Star Wars movies but there is still a force in the universe that may prove more powerful than either of them: a British court that will soon rule on whether a designer can continue to sell replicas of the storm trooper costumes from the Star Wars movies without permission from Mr. Lucas or his studio.

title: Trial for Former French President Is Delayed
description: PARIS  Former President Jacques Chirac won at least a temporary reprieve on Tuesday from his trial on corruption charges, which was delayed after a judge ruled that the case presented serious constitutional issues.

title: On the Waterfront, Business Is Bouncing Back
description: The cars, clothing and coffee came pouring in last year, along with beer, flat-screen televisions and patio furniture. Wheres the party?

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of The Timess Dining section.

title: Kevin McHale Talks Knicks
description: Kevin McHale is an expert on All-Star unions, having played for the 1980s Boston Celtics teams alongside Larry Bird and Robert Parish. He later became an executive and coach for the Minnesota Timberwolves. McHale, who will serve as a TNT analyst when the Knicks play the Dallas Mavericks on Thursday, recently offered his thoughts on the reconfigured Knicks.

title: Floral Fix | Chris Benz
description: Getting extra height is something women want, right? the designer Chris Benz asks slyly about his spring platforms. And, after positive reactions from his and Alejandro Ingelmos spring collaboration, he gave sky-high stature and prints another go-round in his fall 2011 collection. I love the heaviness of the toe and the lightness of the slingback, Benz elaborates. It turned out so nicely that we decided, thats our shoe. Its a fresh spin on the standard wedge and what we expect cool girls to be wearing.

title: From the Bronx to St. Johns, With a Few Stops
description: As St. Johns has returned to national prominence, the senior guard Dwight Hardy has been the star, a dazzling scorer who chose to play for his hometown Red Storm at a time when that was not fashionable.

title: Get Your Free Map of the Revolution!
description: Libyas opposition seems to have surfaced online. NTCLibya.org was registered as a domain on March 6 for the Libyan Interim Transitional National Council. Among the tabs across the top of the sites English-language home page are some you rarely see: Allegiances, Map of Revolution. A WhoIs search turned up Identity Protect as the administrator. This is a British company that manages domains while concealing the identity of the actual owner.

title: NPR Executive Caught Calling Tea Partiers Racist
description: 12:57 p.m. | Updated |  NPR was jolted Tuesday by the release of a videotape that showed one of the organizations fund-raising executives repeatedly criticizing Republicans and Tea Party supporters.

title: On Eve of Retirement, Space Shuttles Capture Museums Hearts
description: Condition: 27 years old, 150 million miles traveled, somewhat dinged but well maintained.

title: Behind the Scenes at Ceibal
description: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal.

title: Visualize It
description: Two things to check out:

title: Taking Dysfunction on a Road Trip, by Van, to California
description: SAN DIEGO  Life brings no calamity that cannot be succored or at least sweetened by song in the new musical Little Miss Sunshine, adapted from the popular indie movie of 2006 written by Michael Arndt. Marital dissatisfaction, attempted suicide, teenage malaise and the trials of being young and plump are among the road bumps faced by a fractious family in this premiere production, at the La Jolla Playhouse through March 27. But the indomitable Hoover clan, portrayed by a cast of Broadway veterans, including Hunter Foster, Dick Latessa and Malcolm Gets, sings down even the specter of sudden death in this chipper and polished but oppressively cute musical.

title: Is It Tim Pawlentys to Lose?
description: Two great pieces of horse-race analysis this morning from my two favorite smart-aleck liberals. The first comes from Jonathan Chait, who convincingly makes the case that Tim Pawlenty  despite the low name recognition, despite the far-from-overflowing coffers, despite the mullet of yore   is the Republican front runner. I would block-quote a section of it, but its worth reading in full.

title: Managing Director of Long Wharf Theater Resigns
description: The Long Wharf Theater of New Haven has lost its fourth managing director in less than a decade with the departure of Ray Cullom, whose resignation was accepted by its board, the theater said on Tuesday. Mr. Cullom came to the Long Wharf Theater, whose recent critically acclaimed productions include a revival of The Glass Menagerie starring Judith Ivey (which transferred Off Broadway to the Laura Pels Theater) and the American premiere of Simon Grays Old Masters, in May 2009 under what was supposed to be a five-year contract. But in a news release the theater said that Mr. Cullom was leaving to pursue a professional opportunity in the producing and presenting theatrical world, and that the board would soon announce a transitional management plan. Mary Pepe, chairwoman of the board, said in a statement that the theater was very grateful to Ray for his leadership of Long Wharf during a period of unprecedented economic challenge. Mr. Collum said in a statement that the theater is an incredible place.

title: A Tiny New Culture Section With No Name
description: In our ongoing effort to pack every inch of the magazine with delicious goodness, we have created a new section-within-a-section that doesnt have a name. (Yet?) Its the few inches of space that come at the bottom of the Riff essay, which, in-house at least, weve taken to calling Subculture. (Because it is sub- the culture pages.)

title: A Stockton Leads Gonzaga, Again
description: It appears there is a new rising point guard on the Gonzaga horizon, with a very familiar last name. Redshirt freshman David Stockton, the son of N.B.A. Hall of Famer John Stockton, is beginning to write his own history as a player.

title: Balenciaga for Dogs
description: Over at the bright Balenciaga showroom today, retailers and editors were examining the merch up close, including the show-opening chunky knit black jacket and vests that are made of silk and wool cord wrapped in faux leather. The vests are expected to cost about $10,000, but the jacket may not be produced. It weighs about seven pounds.

title: Q&A: Counting Monthly Text Messages
description: Q.

title: Wheelies: The Fiat-Effect Edition
description: In which we bring you automotive news from around the Web:

title: If You Feel Like Skipping Lunch Today
description: From A.A. Gills justly admired skewering of LAmi Louis in Paris in the April issue of Vanity Fair, this dish will stay with me:

title: Kennedy Center Announces 2011-12 Season
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Tuesday morning announced its 2011-12 season, which will include a festival celebrating the music of Budapest, Prague and Vienna; a production of the Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart musical Pal Joey, with a new book by Terrence McNally; and the Sydney Theater Companys production of Uncle Vanya, starring Cate Blanchett. There will also be a series of free performances throughout Washington called Look Both Ways: Street Arts Across America.

title: Plan for Test Votes on Budget Erodes
description: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, accused Senate Republicans of reneging on an agreement that would allow dueling budget votes without a procedural fight as plans for Senate test votes on spending cuts broke down Tuesday.

title: Florence Welch at Valentino
description: Walking out of the Valentino show on Tuesday with my colleague Alix Browne from T, we heard someone behind us singing Missing, the 90s song by Everything but the Girl, which had just been played on the runway soundtrack. You know, the one that goes, and I miss you  and sticks in your head for weeks. Maybe it was because it was crowded, hot and late in a long fashion season, but this seemed like kind of a lame thing to be doing. We turned around. It was Florence Welch. Oops. She can sing anything she wants.

title: A Dark Warning on Global Oil Demand
description: Many top corporate and political figures gathered in Houston on Tuesday for the annual CeraWeek conference on the outlook for energy, and they got an earful from John B. Hess, chairman and chief executive of the Hess Corporation.

title: Small Fish, Big Pond  or Vice Versa?
description: Last week, James Harkin, the author of Lost in Cyburbia and a reporter for The Financial Times and The Guardian, released Niche (Little, Brown), a business book about how focusing on a smaller audience and gathering a greater percentage of its attention can be a stronger long-term business plan for a start-up than casting a wider net.

title: Tendinitis in Left Knee Sidelines Beltran
description: The Mets are playing a split-squad doubleheader on Tuesday afternoon, Games 10 and 11 of the exhibition season. Carlos Beltran will not be playing in either game, and it is not clear when he may play next.

title: David Lynch Introduces Web Store
description: Hold onto your avant-garde hats: David Lynch is back on the Web.

title: A Flight to Here, There and Everywhere (but New York)
description: Even by the seemingly ever-higher standards of air travel horror stories, this one, involving a flight from Barbados to New York that entailed three reroutings, two aborted landings and a whirlwind tour of East Coast airports Sunday and Monday, is pretty impressive.

title: Driving the Fiat 500: A Spicy Mini-Meatball
description: I recently spent several days darting around in a piccolini-size portion of Italian automotive cuisine: the Fiat 500 that will soon be served from new American showrooms. And, like the bite of Nonnas gnocchi that it resembles, the minicar came drenched in red sauce  in this case, a paint job the color of Sunday-dinner marinara.

title: Memolane Transforms Social Data Into Visual Timelines
description: Over the last few days, Ive checked-in at several favorite haunts on Foursquare, favorited a few Lady Gaga and cat videos on YouTube, uploaded half a dozen photos of a cookie party to Instagram, and posted several status updates on Twitter and Facebook.

title: Twitter: A New Edge in Commodities and Stock Trading?
description: Twitter is changing the commodities market, reports Kate Kelly of CNBC in the first video clip below. Traders, investors and farmers are using the social media site to get real-time updates on pricing and planting  in 140 characters or less.

title: Bookshelf
description: In 2007, the Alinea chef Grant Achatz was stricken with Stage 4 tongue cancer and, in a Beethovenian twist, lost his sense of taste. Life, On the Line (Gotham Books, $28) is the story of how he bounced back.

title: The Happiest Man in America Goes Viral
description: We recently noted that Alvin Wong of Honolulu just might be the happiest man in America, since he has all the demographic characteristics that match up with higher levels of happiness according to the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index. His family has informed me that hes now become an overnight celebrity, and has been asked to do interviews in publications everywhere from Israel to Australia. Im told hes gone viral in Bangkok.

title: Albany, 11:57 A.M.
description: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, left, paid a visit to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo at the Executive Mansion on his lobbying swing through the capital. The meeting of prelate and not-quite-by-the-book-Catholic governor had taken a bit of arranging, prompting a bit of speculation.

title: Q&A: Spanish Study Abroad
description: Q.

title: The Devil Wears Pinstripes: A Woman on Wall Street
description: Working as a junior analyst at a large investment bank can be tough for even the hardiest twenty-somethings, and Nina Godiwalla was no exception. From 1997 to 1999, she worked in the corporate finance group at Morgan Stanley, where she says she saw lots of outrageous behavior: lavish spending, nervous breakdowns, off-color humor and an incident when one of Ms. Godiwallas fellow analysts was discovered to have posed nude for a gay magazine.

title: A Closer by Any Other Name, if You Please
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.

title: Guest Post: Robert Lane Greene on Language Sticklers
description: In my new book, You Are What You Speak, I devote an early chapter to the notion that our language is in decline. Perhaps most famously in recent years, Lynne Truss wrote a little book about punctuation, Eats, Shoots & Leaves, which sold in the millions (to Ms. Trusss own surprise) and made her a household name (at least in language-nerd circles). What sold so many books, I imagine, was Trusss tone, never less than urgent and sometimes downright furious: nobody knows how to punctuate anymore, and if we dont stop the rot were doomed!

title: Is Phil Collins Calling It a Day?
description: He began as a child actor and later went on to enjoy enormous commercial success, both as a member of the progressive rock group Genesis and as a solo artist. But after nearly 50 years as a performer, the drummer and singer Phil Collins has announced his retirement. Or maybe he hasnt: it all depends how you interpret a statement Mr. Collins, one of the most popular performers of the 1980s and 90s, has posted on his Web site explaining why he is stopping his creative activities.

title: The Case of the Missing Pepcid Tablets
description: Where has all the Pepcid Complete gone?

title: Laissez les Bons Temps Rouler
description: If you ever lived in New Orleans, you know that today is Mardi Gras. (Or rather, as they say in New Orleans, Mardi Gras Day.)

title: What Should Teachers Be Paid?
description: Whats most surprising about the worldwide charts on teachers pay posted onJonathan Cohns New Republic blog? (Via Andrew Sullivans  Daily Dish.) Its not that the United States fares poorly butthat we do better than nanny states like Sweden and France (or Sweden andNorway,depending on whether youre looking at teachers starting salaries or salaries after 15years).

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia, Afghanistan and Ivory Coast.

title: Reactor Design Edges Toward Approval, but Not Without Complaints
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is moving toward approval of the Westinghouse AP1000 reactor and its strikingly different containment design, which has far fewer pumps and valves plus a safety system that relies mostly on foolproof forces, like water flowing downhill or heat rising. But complaints over the design persist.

title: Netanyahu Vows to Keep Jordan River Posts
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared definitively on Tuesday that he would maintain an Israeli military presence along the Jordan River under any future arrangement involving the Palestinians, buttressing a known policy with a demonstrative visit to that area of the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: Everythings Coming Up Romney
description: Last August, I wrote the following about Mitt Romneys odds of winning the Republican nomination:

title: Paris Financial Center Wins Respite From Creditors
description: PARIS  Frances highest court ruled Tuesday that the owners of Coeur Dfense, the largest office complex in Europe, could remain under court-appointed creditor protection while they restructure their debts.

title: Consumer Watchdog Takes Aim at Abusive Lending
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has put mortgage companies and other lenders on notice: be on your best behavior.

title: Even a Wealthy Suburb Faces Pressure to Curb School Taxes
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y.  This wealthy New York suburb prides itself on its public schools. Class sizes are small. Students can choose from an array of subjects not offered everywhere. Teacher pay ranks among the nations highest. And voters long approved high real estate taxes to pay for it all.

title: Do Women Leaders Matter?
description: A nagging thought on the 100th anniversary of International Womens Day:

title: Prosecutors Want Tucson Suspect to Undergo Psychiatric Testing
description: PHOENIX  Prosecutors asked a federal judge on Monday night to order Jared L. Loughner, the suspect in the Tucson shooting spree, to undergo psychiatric testing to determine if he is competent to stand trial.

title: Foreign Parts, a Tale From the Scrap Heap, Plays MoMA
description: Willets Point, Queens, a swath of automobile repair shops and parts-scavenging operations in the shadow of Citi Field  where the Mets play  is the subject of Foreign Parts, a documentary that examines this self-contained world.

title: The Baker and Her Baby
description: Anyone who has ever passed through an airport or mall has experienced the overpowering aroma of industrial-strength gusts of cinnamon; those who have not themselves indulged have surely seen many a would-be dieter fall victim to the wallop of cinnamon bun calories. But according to Cinnamon Baby, the first picture book by Nicola Winstanley, the scent of cinnamon also has the ability to cure colic. Well, why not?

title: Airbus Gets $9.5 Billion Order for 100 Jets
description: PARIS  International Lease Finance Corporation, the worlds largest aircraft leasing company, reached a preliminary agreement on Tuesday to buy 100 Airbus single-aisle jets in a deal valued at $9.5 billion.

title: Insuring Fine Art
description: As demand for art starts to rebound, the Insurance Information Institute recently put out some helpful insurance tips for those who have recently bought a valuable piece of art or have a whole collection.

title: Video Shows Man Suspected in Brooklyn Attacks
description: The police released a video this afternoon of a man suspected of attacking two women within a few minutes in Brooklyn last month and sexually assaulting one of them.

title: Galleon Trial Begins With a Quiet Day of Jury Selection
description: 8:03 p.m. | Updated

title: UConn Ends Its Big East Tournament Blues
description: The last time the Connecticut mens basketball team won a game in the Big East tournament, Rudy Gay and Charlie Villanueva led the way and the conference had 12 teams. That was in the tournaments quarterfinals in 2005.

title: Allen and the Plight of the Undervalued Defender
description: As much as N.B.A. fans and analysts have made an effort to appreciate individual and team defense, nothing on that side of the ball quite measures up to the sex appeal of scoring. The game itself is structured around made field goals, and basketball observers largely fall into the trap of glamorizing that straightforward act of goal attainment while diminishing the appeal of lock-down defense.

title: Body and Spirit
description: Nancey Murphy of Fuller Theological Seminary has an interesting and challenging essay in a recent book called Neuroethics. She argues that the dominant conception of a soul, a spiritual essence separable from the body, is the result of a mistranslation. The Hebrew word nephesh, which was translated into soul, was actually just a way of referring to the whole living person, body and mind together. Thats closer, I guess, to what we would call the self.

title: Elise Overlands India
description: Elise Overland is one of New York Citys favorite around town designers. But what most dont know is that her social circle is even bigger and busier in India. On her latest trip to Rajasthan for trunk shows, weddings and a little vacation time, Overland shared some under-the-radar haunts and what it is that keeps bringing her back.

title: AARP Sues U.S. Over Effects of Reverse Mortgages
description: Reverse mortgages, which pay older homeowners a regular sum against the equity in their house, are supposed to shield borrowers from economic upheaval. But the popular loans have become tangled up in the real estate collapse.

title: 'Jim Nutt: Coming Into Character'
description: A trailer for the retrospective of Jim Nutt's work at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago. (Video courtesy of the museum.)

title: Egypt, the Panda and Us
description: I knew something was up in Egypt last fall, long before the first protesters entered Tahrir Square. That was when I first saw a series of Egyptian TV commercials for the Panda brand of food products. The first one felt like pure allegory: Dad and son in Egyptian supermarket. Dad tells son to put a package of Panda-brand cheese back on the shelf. Cut to the panda, now in the same aisle, who is very, very angry. Panda tips over shopping cart. Was the panda Mubarak? Or did the panda represent the aspirations of the Egyptian people for a normal, consumer society?

title: Back to Testing and Some FIA Decisions
description: The last winter test session for the Formula One teams began Tuesday in Barcelona and Mark Webber set the fastest time in his Red Bull. Jenson Button was second fastest in the McLaren Mercedes, but he said that the Red Bulls and the Ferraris are faster than his car.

title: Back to Testing and Some FIA Decisions
description: The last winter test session for the Formula One teams began Tuesday in Barcelona and Mark Webber set the fastest time in his Red Bull. Jenson Button was second fastest in the McLaren Mercedes, but he said that the Red Bulls and the Ferraris are faster than his car.

title: After Sour Note From Gheorghiu, Director Responds
description: The withdrawal of Angela Gheorghiu from next seasons Metropolitan Opera production of Faust by Gounod continued to cause ripples on Tuesday. The Met announced the cancellation on Monday, with Ms. Gheorghius management blaming her dislike of the productions updated 20th-century setting. But the director, Des McAnuff, said on Tuesday that when he met with Ms. Gheorghiu in November to discuss the production she voiced no objections. We had a meeting where ideas were shared with enthusiasm, he said in a statement.

title: Eruption and Destruction: Curating an Exhibition on Pompeii
description: Overview | What can we learn about life and culture in the ancient city of Pompeii by examining preserved artifacts and structures? What new strategies are being employed by museum curators to help people not just find information about the past, but virtually experience it too? In this lesson, students research and develop their own 21st-century exhibits on the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D. and the resulting destruction of the city of Pompeii, in what is now Italy. They then compare their installation with a new exhibition on Pompeii by reading an article about it.

title: Steve Schirripa on the Real-Life Button Men in His New Series
description: It has been nearly four years since Steve Schirripas bullet-riddled body plunged through an elaborate model train set on The Sopranos, his character the victim of a hit put out by a rival crime boss. This week he begins delving into actual contract killings in a new true-crime series on the Investigation Discovery cable channel.

title: BP Chief Says Industry Must Change to Guard Against Spills
description: HOUSTON  In his first public address to oil industry executives since becoming chief of BP, Robert Dudley said the entire industry needed to change to prevent another devastating deepwater oil spill like the one BP suffered last year.

title: Bank of America Looks to Expand Prime Brokerage
description: Thomas K. Montag, who oversees Bank of America Merrill Lynchs investment banking and brokerage business, told an investor day conference on Tuesday that the bank wants to expand its prime brokerage business, providing services to hedge funds.

title: 21 Priests Suspended in Philadelphia
description: The Archdiocese of Philadelphia announced Tuesday that it had suspended 21 priests from active ministry in connection with accusations that involved sexual abuse or otherwise inappropriate behavior with minors.

title: Photo Replay: March 8
description: A view of the day in sports, from frosty biathlon contenders to cycling collisions to a perfect shot through the five hole.

title: Photos of the Moment | Emanuel Ungaro
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#392", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: TimesCast | March 08, 2011
description: Libyan rebels try to set up an alternative government; journalists wait for Colonel Qaddafi; and Democrats and Republicans differ on what to do about the budget.

title: Celebrating the Birth of Natural Forests
description: More than 43 million people visit national forests east of the Mississippi each year, according to the United States Forest Service, but few know that their origins lie in the Weeks Act, signed into law 100 years ago, on March 1, 1911.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia, Afghanistan and Ivory Coast.

title: Beavis, Meet Snooki!
description: On this date in 1993, Beavis and Butt-Head made its debut on MTV, beginning a 200-episode run that would last until the end of 1997. It was a crude, new beast of animated television in its discourse and its social commentary. Shows like South Park have since raised/lowered the bar considerably, but Beavis and Butt-Head was the Elviss pelvis of its day.

title: 3 Law Officers Are Shot in St. Louis; One Dies
description: ST. LOUIS  A deputy federal marshal was killed and two other law officers were wounded in a shootout early Tuesday while trying to serve an arrest warrant at a house in South St. Louis. The man named in the warrant was pronounced dead at the scene.

title: Red Rooster Harlem
description: THERE were four elderly black women in hats at Red Rooster Harlem the other night, across the aisle from a group of white men who had come north to 125th Street by subway. Also present were a mixed-race family sharing apple pie, a stroller beside them; an Asian same-sex couple, drinking wine; and mixed-gender black couples eating Swedish meatballs. Above them all was a Philip Maysles painting depicting the artist Norman Rockwell staring into a mirror and painting a portrait of himself  as Ruby Bridges, the African-American girl who integrated an all-white elementary school in New Orleans in 1960.

title: Reviewing Red Rooster Harlem
Night Life and Beaches in Brazil, for Less Than the Cost of Rio
description: Carnival ends today in Brazil, which means that over the last week or so, international travelers have flocked to Rio de Janeiro and Salvador, cities known for transforming themselves into international redoubts of hedonism for five days before Lent and hiking their prices way up in the process.

title: Bucknell? The Team That Beat Kansas, Right?
description: Patrick Behan played on the Bucknell basketball team, graduating last year.

title: A Glossary of Sherries
description: My column on Wednesday is about how sherry, after years of maddening unpopularity, seems to be catching on among younger wine enthusiasts. Given the usual problem of wanting to include too much information in not enough space, I opted to forgo the array of sherry definitions that seemingly must accompany every such article.

title: Astringent Modernist Meets Instrument of Old
description: In the second of seven poems set by Gyorgy Kurtag for voice and cimbalom in 1981, Amy Karolyi writes, Excess and restraint: these two will in the end tear me in two. Its the kind of despairing text that has always appealed to Mr. Kurtag, but its not true of him. His defining characteristic is to bring together excess and restraint to revel in their simultaneous presence  not to tear his work in two, but to give it unremitting tension.

title: Proving That Early Music Can Contain Startling Shifts
description: The Akademie fr Alte Musik Berlin is a magnificent chameleon of an ensemble. Where most period-instrument bands are shaped by a director with (ideally) a distinct interpretive vision, the academy is led by rotating concertmasters. And though it can, and often does, produce the highly charged, earthy sound currently in vogue in early-music circles, the group has clearly reserved the right to shift gears radically at will.

title: Traveling to the Stars, No Joy or Romance Needed
description: You dont need to pore over the lyrics of Fran Landesman, the little-known New York-born songwriter and poet who has lived in London since the mid-1960s and is now 84, to get their drift. The song titles alone evoke the lives of bohemian sophisticates, as the rugged swingers of an earlier era were quaintly labeled.

title: Bound for Glory
description: Im a big ugly son of a bitch, says the Chicago artist Tony Fitzpatrick, whos not actually ugly, just a bit imposing  tattooed, tall, gruff and given to profanity. An art legend in the Windy City, Fitzpatrick has a multidisciplinary bent, although hed probably never use the word multidisciplinary.

title: Police Kill Protesters in Major Ivory Coast City
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  At least four demonstrators, including a 19-year-old woman, were shot dead by riot police officers on Tuesday as they protested the shooting deaths of women who marched last week, witnesses said.

title: Bits of Humor From a Life of Torment
description: The Australian poet Les Murray  he is among the greatest living English-language poets, annually said to be a Nobel Prize contender  is a very wide, very bald man who resembles a less doleful version of Colonel Kurtz in the film Apocalypse Now. It is possible to imagine him having a small meal of minor critics for breakfast, as if they were kippers, and then polishing off a pile of verse novelists with his 11 a.m. tea.

title: Europe Sets Higher Goal for Cutting Emissions
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission is aiming to minimize the effects of sharply rising fuel prices and to beat its current goal for reducing emissions, under measures proposed on Tuesday, in part by requiring member governments to upgrade the energy efficiency of public buildings.

title: Photos of the Moment | Chanel
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#779", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: A.I.G. Repays $6.9 Billion of Government Bailout
description: In a widely expected move, the American International Group repaid $6.9 billion of its huge government bailout on Tuesday, according to the Treasury Department.

title: A Trill Ride, From Rossini to Harold Arlen
description: Shes the hostess every American woman wants to be, my friend said admiringly as the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato charmed the audience at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon with a stream of engaging commentary. Indeed, Ms. DiDonato seemed the perfect 21st-century diva  an effortless combination of glamour, charisma, intelligence, grace and remarkable talent.

title: European Union Salaries a Haven for Eastern Europeans
description: BRUSSELS  As prime minister of Latvia, Valdis Dombrovskis has one of the worst jobs in politics: cutting jobs and slashing salaries in an effort to strengthen his nations depleted finances.

title: Some Clues to Hasty Exit at the Public Theater
description: The Public Theater parted ways with its executive director, Andrew D. Hamingson, last month because in the theaters transfer of shows to Broadway and Londons West End he had exposed it to financial risks without fully informing the board, people involved with the productions say.

title: Scenes From the Libyan Exodus
description: A humanitarian crisis has many faces.

title: As Skins Nears the Finish Line, Madison Avenue Still Shies Away
description: The provocative drama series Skins has two episodes left in its scheduled run after MTV presented Episode 8 on Monday night. And mainstream sponsors are continuing to avoid the show, which has been the target of conservative advocates who have urged advertisers not to buy commercial time.

title: Cuomo, in Gay Marriage Push, Will Meet With Leading Supporters
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will hold a confidential strategy session with leading gay activists on Wednesday to discuss how to legalize same-sex marriage in New York, the latest sign that he is preparing to put the weight of his administration behind legislation that has divided lawmakers and voters across the country.

title: Restaurant Plan Approved for Lower Manhattan Pier
description: The directors of the Battery Park City Authority voted on Tuesday to approve a 25-year lease of Pier A in Lower Manhattan to the Poulakakos family and a partner who plan to turn it into a 40,000-square-foot restaurant complex in New York Harbor.

title: Model-Morphosis | Josephine Skriver for Alexander McQueen
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Josephine Skriver from Marilyn before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Peter Philips for Chanel Beaute and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Capturing Modernist Cuisine
description: The photography in the encyclopedic new book is an arresting mix of stunning images and clear-eyed illustration.

title: Bombastic, Boisterous and Triumphant
description: Lupe Fiascos third album, Lasers, came out on Tuesday, but on Monday night it wasnt certain that hed be in the mood to celebrate at his album-release concert at Webster Hall.

title: Qaddafis Arms Bazaar, Slowly Exposed
description: Of the heads of state closely associated with the underground arms trade, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has long been a veritable case study. His deep pockets of oil revenue, combined with his ambitions to be a regional power broker, spiced with his on-and-off role as supporter of nationalist movements elsewhere, has made him a prominent and persistent figure in an often shadowy game.

title: For Two Choreographers, Adventures in the Realms of Dreams and War
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Almost every choreographer begins as a dancer, usually serving another choreographer; and so theatrical dance acquires a complex sense of successive generations. At Z Space here, Hope Mohr Dance presented a new work by its namesake choreographer. But Ms. Mohr also presented, as a guest, the Liz Gerring Dance Company in an excerpt from a new work by Ms. Gerring that will be seen later this year in New York at the Baryshnikov Arts Center.

title: Albatross Is a Mother at 60
description: Wisdom, the oldest known wild bird in the United States, is a new mother, the United States Geological Survey and Fish and Wildlife Service announced on Tuesday.

title: Man, 77, Killed in Barbershop Dispute by Off-Duty Jail Officer, Police Say
description: A 77-year-old man with a gun was shot and killed by an off-duty city correction officer after an argument and a scuffle in a barber shop in Brooklyn on Tuesday afternoon, law enforcement officials said.

title: Corporate Boards Should Add Diversity to the Mix
description: Harry Campbell

title: Photos of the Moment | Alexander McQueen
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#250", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Now Showing | Yohji Yamamoto
description: In pursuit of imperfection, Yohji Yamamoto changed the course of fashion. Now, 30 years after his first show in Paris, which was greeted by astonishment, pro and con, the avant-garde designer is having his 30th museum exhibition, his first in London. The catalog that accompanies the show opening Saturday at the Victoria and Albert Museum (on view through July 10) reflects not just the heart-stopping beauty of the clothes, as photographed by Yamomotos longtime collaborators Nick Knight, Max Vadukul and Paolo Roversi, but also, in his own words, the designers enigmatic stance. So we learn, almost poignantly, that from the beginning: I wanted to protect the clothing itself from fashion, and at the same time the womans body from something, maybe from mens eyes or a cold wind.

title: When to Report Another Parent
description: No, I did not have surgery today. The surgeons verdict is that the ankle is still far too swollen, so I get to spend another week with it elevated and icing. Which means I have plenty of time (between drug- induced naps, I guess) to blog.

title: The Galleon Network
description: Prosecutors have called it the biggest insider-trading case in United States history. On Wednesday, a jury in federal district court in Manhattan found Raj Rajaratnam guilty of 14 counts of securities fraud and conspiracy. He had been accused of making $63 million trading on illegal information scoured from a network of sources that spanned Wall Street and corporate America. The trial highlighted an array of aggressive tactics the Justice Department used in its long-running investigation into insider trading, including confidential informants, wiretapped phone conversations and top executives as witnesses.

title: Cuomos Right to Holy Communion Is a Private Matter, Bishop Says
description: ALBANY  One of New York States leading Roman Catholic bishops said on Tuesday that it was not appropriate for church officials to comment on whether specific elected officials should be allowed to receive holy communion.

title: Spotify Cracks the Million-User Ceiling
description: Spotify, a streaming music service in Europe that is trying to enter the American market, has reached something of a milestone for digital music: a million paid subscribers.

title: St. Patricks Day Parade Getting in Line With Others
description: When the New York Police Department announced early last year that all parades would have to be shortened to reduce police overtime costs, several parade organizers cried foul. The 2010 St. Patricks Day Parade, for which the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, happened to be serving as grand marshal, ended up being given an exemption from the new rules (the Police Department said the parade had not been given enough advance notice).

title: Pittsburgh Pursues Plan to Demolish the Igloo
description: PITTSBURGH  The fate of Civic Arena, a gleaming symbol of this citys postwar renaissance when it opened in 1961, has been debated ever since the Pittsburgh Penguins hockey team decamped last August to the nearby $321 million Consol Energy Center.

title: New York Office Renovations in Downturn Pay Off
description: It was the looming threat of a lease expiration that would open up 200,000 square feet of space occupied by UBS and other tenants that persuaded the owners of 535 Madison Avenue to invest in the buildings first major upgrades in more than two decades. That the wager, at a cost of more than $5 million, was made in 2009 at the depths of the market only made it riskier.

title: G.O.P. Freshmen Forming Leadership PACs
description: On Monday, Representative Kristi Noem, Republican of South Dakota, became the latest freshman member of Congress to form a leadership political action committee, commonly used to bolster the political aspirations of its founder.

title: Colonial Teams Reversing Underdog Role
description: RICHMOND The Colonial Athletic Association has become something of a feeder system for Cinderella.

title: It All Comes Through in the Mix, Even the Kazoos
description: The Wordless Music Orchestra had a kazoo section for its concert on Monday at Alice Tully Hall, along with six electric guitars. There was whistling, too. As part of the TullyScope series, the orchestra was performing pieces from Tyondai Braxtons 2009 album, Central Market (Warp). The music is a manic and meticulous commingling of ideas from overlapping musical domains, among them classical Minimalism, progressive rock, soundtracks, early-20th-century avant-garde and early-21st-century electronica, not to mention sprinklings of comedy and darkness.

title: Tiki Barber Coming Out of Retirement
description: Tiki Barber has filed for reinstatement to the N.F.L.  four years after he retired  the league confirmed on Tuesday.

title: A Monday Win for Fox
description: For the first time this season Fox attracted the most viewers on Monday as CBSs mostly repeat lineup cleared the way for Foxs House to draw the nights largest audience. According to Nielsens estimates, that medical drama delivered 11.1 million viewers at 8 p.m. while Foxs new series The Chicago Code remained relatively solid at 9 with 7.5 million. In second place, ABC garnered an average of 9.9 million viewers for The Bachelor from 8 to 10. CBS had a rare third-place finish with reruns, as well as a new episode of Mad Love at 8:30 (7.3 million). NBC ranked fourth, averaging 5.2 million viewers for two hours of The Event followed by Harrys Law at 10 (9.4 million).

title: Oil and Copper
description: Via FT Alphaville, an interesting indicator of whats going on in the world: the oil-copper spread. Copper is basically about the prospects for world economic growth: strong growth means lots of copper demand. Oil is partly about growth, but also about chaos in the Middle East.

title: Sizing Up the Big East
description: Pete Thamel and Connor Ennis break down this year's field at the men's Big East Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: On Our Radar: $2 Billion Carbon Bill for European Airlines
description: European airlines will spend nearly $2 billion on carbon dioxide emissions permits next year as European Union rules on emissions take effect, financial analysts estimate. Under the rules, the number of free carbon permits allocated to airlines will shrink considerably beginning in 2012. By 2020, the cost of permits to the industry could climb to almost $10 billion annually. [Guardian]

title: Warner Tests Renting Film on Facebook for Web Cash
description: Warner Brothers became the first major media company to offer a movie for rent on Facebook, a move that could position the social network to become a force in the digital distribution of movies, rivaling services like Netflix and iTunes.

title: Scorecard | Yves Saint Laurent Wins!
description: How to avoid the dreaded boo hiss diss? If the collections shown on the seventh day of Paris fashion week demonstrate anything for Scorecard, keep your use of pelts, hides and skins to a minimum  particularly of those ophidian. As Stefano Pilati proved again, the winning look might just have been there in La Revolution de la Mode all along.

title: Other Stuff I Read
description: A followup on the post about mostly economics reading; on politics, culture, etc. there are other blogs I read fairly often. On politics, Greg Sargent, Josh Marshall, Digby, and I still get a kick out of Atrios, who gets to use all the words I cant. And Im a big fan of the folks at Crooked Timber.

title: Opposition in Libya Struggles to Form a United Front
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  In less than three weeks, an inchoate opposition in Libya, one of the worlds most isolated countries, has cobbled together the semblance of a transitional government, fielded a ragtag rebel army and portrayed itself to the West and Libyans as an alternative to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis four decades of freakish rule.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Change Patent System and Pricing
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate easily passed a bill on Tuesday that would overhaul the nations patent system, giving the Patent and Trademark Office more flexibility to control its own financing and changing the system to one that rewards the first inventor to file a valid application.

title: Ground Truthing Satellite Images of Violence in Sudan
description: 11:21 p.m. | Updated Whether using satellites to track deforestation, sea ice thickness or civil strife, it is vital to do whats called ground truthing  direct assessment of conditions on the surface  to be sure whats estimated from orbit is accurate. I wrote yesterday about the latest satellite images appearing to show the ashen remains of villages in the Abyei region of Sudan.

title: At House E.P.A. Hearing, Both Sides Claim Science
description: WASHINGTON  Science and politics rarely play nicely together, and a House hearing Tuesday on a bill to strip the Environmental Protection Agency of its power to regulate greenhouse gas emissions proved no exception.

title: Beckoning Visitors Back to Tijuana
description: With the restaurant Mision 19, a local chef hopes to help revive a city that has gone from being one of Mexicos most visited to one of its most feared.

title: Master of a New Tijuana
description: TIJUANA, Mexico

title: A Sudden End for Alto and Convivio
description: LAST Friday, the career of the restaurateur Chris Cannon seemed to thud to a halt when, without explanation, he abruptly closed Alto and Convivio, the highly regarded Italian restaurants where he had been the managing partner.

title: F.T.C. to Take Another Look at Alcohol Ads
description: For the fourth time in 12 years, the Federal Trade Commission plans to study the effectiveness of the voluntary guidelines followed by most marketers of alcoholic beverages. The guidelines are intended primarily to reduce the exposure of advertising to those under the legal drinking age.

title: Debate in an Eggshell: Yolks vs. Whites
description: PHILOSOPHERS may ponder the chicken-egg question. But for cooks, a far more pressing concern is the yolk-white question. Which comes first depends on whom you ask.

title: Goldman Names New M.& A. Heads for the Americas
description: More staffing changes are under way at Goldman Sachs.

title: After the Pressure, the Smoke
description: PARIS

title: New York Senate Confirms Environmental Chief
description: The New York State Senate unanimously confirmed Joseph Martens on Tuesday as commissioner of the states Department of Environmental Conservation. He will face challenges like deep budget cuts and a brewing controversy over hydraulic fracturing, a form of natural gas drilling. As Leslie Kaufman noted in a blog post in January, Governor Cuomo won plaudits for his choice.

title: Not Pretty, but Rutgers Outlasts Seton Hall
description: In the same way some people can see art in a thrift store watercolor, Mike Rice saw grace and elegance in Rutgerss Big East tournament victory over Seton Hall on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Spider-Man Overhaul Forces a 3-Month Delay
description: The producers of Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark are planning a significant overhaul of the $65 million Broadway musical that would involve shutting down performances for two to three weeks, as well as delaying its scheduled opening on March 15 for about three months, according to people who work on Spider-Man or were briefed on the producers plans.

title: Morneau Strokes Double in Return From Concussion
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Eight months and a day after he last appeared in a game for the Minnesota Twins, first baseman Justin Morneau took a major step in his recovery from a concussion by playing three and a half innings in a B exhibition game on Tuesday.

title: Take This Baby Out for a Drive
description: My first experience trying a recipe from Modernist Cuisine for my review of the book gives you a good sense of what the book is like. (More photos from the book can be seen in this slide show.)

title: Fair to Muslims?
description: Washington

title: Keeping the Paper Plates Spinning
description: MOST garlic knots let you down. After one or two salty, satisfying bites, youre left to chew on the increasingly impenetrable thing like a masticating cow. Its a snack food for suckers and optimists, anybody with a Charlie Brown-like faith that maybe Lucy Van Pelt wont pull away the football, that this time it might be great.

title: Library of Congress Buys Audio Archive
description: Bob Murphys account of Nolan Ryans first strikeout in his debut with the Mets in 1966 is among more than 6,000 radio and television broadcast recordings of memorable games and colorful calls that the Library of Congress has acquired and plans to make public.

title: The Hague: 6 Top Kenyan Politicians Are Summoned
description: Six top politicians from Kenya have been summoned to appear at the International Criminal Court in April to answer charges of crimes against humanity in connection with Kenyas election violence in 2007 and 2008. The men, whose names were first cited by the prosecutor in December, include Uhuru Kenyatta, finance minister and son of Kenyas founding leader; Mohammed Hussein Ali, the former police chief; and several other ministers. Coinciding with the courts announcement, Kenyan government envoys have arrived at the United Nations in New York, seeking to block the move.

title: Pressure-Cooked Chicken Stock
description: Adapted from Modernist Cuisine

title: Cook From It? First, Try Lifting It
description: DESCENDING this week on the culinary scene like a meteor, Modernist Cuisine: The Art and Science of Cooking is the self-published six-volume masterwork from a team led by Nathan Myhrvold, the multimillionaire tech visionary who, as a friend of mine said, decided to play Renaissance doge with food.

title: Woods and Mickelson to Renew Acquaintances
description: MIAMI  Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson have fallen in the official World Golf Ranking, but when it comes to moving the needle with a head-to-head matchup, nobody can top them.

title: A Visual Overview of the Galleon Network
description: Prosecutors have called it the biggest insider-trading case in United States history. On Tuesday, Raj Rajaratnam went on trial in the federal district court in Manhattan, accused of making $45 million trading on illegal information scoured from a network of sources that spanned Wall Street and corporate America.

title: Judge Criticizes Independence Party on Monitoring Money
description: A State Supreme Court justice on Tuesday criticized the New York State Independence Party for failing to monitor money given to the party by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that prosecutors say was stolen by a political operative for his own use.

title: Eric Claptons Magic, for Sale
description: Some of the legendary British music icons guitars and amps, including some replicas, are being auctioned for charity.

title: Sustainable Farming Can Feed the World?
description: The oldest and most common dig against organic agriculture is that it cannot feed the worlds citizens; this, however, is a supposition, not a fact. And industrial agriculture isnt working perfectly, either: the global food price index is at a record high, and our agricultural system is wreaking havoc with the health not only of humans but of the earth. There are around a billion undernourished people; we can also thank the current system for the billion who are overweight or obese.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Dining Calendar
description: Irish and Downtown

title: Play With Your Vegetables While You Scrub
description: Dont worry, vegetarians. Its O.K. to scrub your potatoes, carrots, celeriac and mushrooms with a squirrels tail or an elephants trunk. These finely finished wooden brushes from Italy have natural bristles and come in assorted animal shapes. They are easy to hold and more pleasing than plastic.

title: Otis Stout Bread Makes Its Debut
description: Cayuga Pure Organics near Ithaca, N.Y., has been one of the leaders of the local grain movement. It is also selling breads made with their grains that are baked by Orwashers bakery on the Upper East Side. A round whole-grain bread was the first, and Cayuga has added a longer loaf, with a braided pattern on top, called Otis Stout Bread.

title: Social Eatz Opens in Midtown
description: Angelo Sosa had brief success at the modern Chinese restaurant Yumcha in Greenwich Village and the sandwich shop Xie Xie in Hells Kitchen.

title: Urge to Own That Clapton Guitar Is Contagious, Scientists Find
description: Why would someone pay $959,500 for a used guitar?

title: Ohio State Suspends Tressel for 2 Games
description: Ohio State University suspended Coach Jim Tressel for the first two games of the 2011 season and fined him $250,000 after he acknowledged that he did not inform the university of potential violations of N.C.A.A. rules.

title: The Changing Face of Psychiatry
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Budget Battles
description: Democrats and Republicans differ on what to do about the budget.

title: Doing the Brukup
description: Dozens of dance groups scattered in Brooklyn are reviving an Afro-Caribbean freestyle dance called the brukup.

title: Brukup Follows an Afro-Caribbean Beat
description: IT was Friday night in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, and 30 young men were crammed inside a tiny storefront on Marcus Garvey Boulevard. The wiry ringleader, Albert Esquilin, a 27-year-old graphic designer, cleared out a small oval and started to flail like a zombie.

title: Hollywood Feels Ripples From Libya
description: LOS ANGELES  Things have gotten chilly here for Natural Selection, the film production company backed by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis son Saadi.

title: Petraeus Sees Military Progress in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Besides well-reported advances in southern provinces, American and NATO forces have also been able to halt or reverse Taliban gains around the capital, Kabul, and even in the north and west of the country, Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Afghanistan, said Tuesday.

title: A Slap on Calhouns Wrist, and Life Goes On
description: Kemba Walker was a child of the Bronx, a hip-hop dancer, a natural point guard and not so much a Knicks fan. Truth is, he probably was not unlike many a young New Yorker growing up indifferent to the hometown team during a deplorable decade of professional basketball.

title: Natural Gas Drilling: Calls for Stricter Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Turtle in Hanoi Escapes Would-Be Rescuers
description: BANGKOK  Rescuers in Vietnam began an urgent effort on Tuesday to capture and treat an old and ailing turtle that lives in a landmark lake in Hanoi and is revered as the citys spiritual symbol.

title: Greece Makes Progress, but Debt Woes Persist
description: Its hard not to sympathize with Greece after Moodys latest downgrade of the country. Like Sisyphus, the government has been pushing a heavy rock uphill. It has gotten somewhere, as Athens asserts. The fiscal deficit is six percentage points of gross domestic product lower than it was. But the debt burden will probably prove too heavy and roll Greece back into crisis. The market views a restructuring as highly likely. But while that would fix Greeces debt problem, it would not in itself solve the countrys competitiveness and growth challenges.

title: S.E.C. Chairwoman Under Fire Over Ethics Issues
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission took a beating two years ago for failing to detect Bernard L. Madoffs multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme during the decades that he ran it.

title: Mexico: Former Police Chief Seeks Asylum in the U.S.
description: A woman who took the job of police chief in a border town riddled with drug gang violence has asked for asylum in the United States, officials said Tuesday. The woman, Marisol Valles Garca, who was 20 when she was named police chief of Prxedis G. Guerrero in October, left with her whole family, including her baby son, last week, said Gustavo de la Rosa Hickerson, a Chihuahua State human rights investigator. A spokeswoman for United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement confirmed that Ms. Valles Garca was in the United States.

title: How Can He Do the Job?
description: Germanys new interior minister, Hans-Peter Friedrich, has gotten off to a disturbing, loathsome start. Just three days after Chancellor Angela Merkel named him to the position, Mr. Friedrich told reporters that Islam, the religion of four million Germans, did not really belong in Germany because it was not rooted in the countrys long Christian history and way of life.

title: For Hoboken, a Day of Revelry Is Overwhelmed by Lawlessness
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  With its mile-long stretch of boutiques, restaurants and bars, this waterfront city long ago left its roots as a shipping and industrial center, finding new life as young professionals set up homes here, and hordes of younger folks arrive each weekend to drink.

title: Qaddafi Forces Renew Assault Against Rebels
description: Libyas government forces seemed to be gathering momentum on Tuesday.

title: Facing Lawmakers Fire, NPR Sees New Setback
description: Already under fire from Republicans who want to strip its federal financing, NPR was forced into damage-control mode on Tuesday after the release of a video that showed one of its fund-raising executives repeatedly criticizing Republicans and Tea Party supporters.

title: Union Rejects N.F.L.s Offer to Share More Financial Data
description: N.F.L. players union officials on Tuesday rejected an offer from the owners to turn over audited profitability data from all 32 teams for the past several years. The offer, made Monday night, was the first time the owners indicated a willingness to share financial information with the players beyond what is required by the collective bargaining agreement.

title: Slashing Civil Legal Aid
description: PRESIDENTS F.Y. 2010-11 REQUEST: $407 MILLION

title: Flirting With a Repeat of a Stunted Recovery
description: WASHINGTON

title: Frankfurt Attack Mystifies Suspects Family
description: FRANKFURT  In the eyes of his family and friends, Arid Uka was a model youth: never in trouble with the police, unlike many other young men in his predominantly immigrant neighborhood in Frankfurt.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 8, 2011

title: With 3 Perfect Innings, Garcia Gives Yanks Something to Think About
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  Joe Girardi enjoys answering hypothetical questions about as much as he does watching a player make the first out at third base. So it was a little surprising when Girardi  perhaps weary from a long Monday, when the keys to his rental truck somehow disappeared from the clubhouse in Sarasota  agreed to play along Tuesday morning when asked whether Freddy Garcias experience would give him less reason to worry if Garcia were to pitch poorly later in the day against Atlanta. In short, the answer was yes.

title: Odd Spot for a Coach Who Wins: Off the Field
description: Hold on a minute; Steve Mandl cant talk right now. He is getting yelled at on the other line.

title: Washingtons Options on Libya
description: The Obama administration is throwing out so many conflicting messages on Libya that they are blunting any potential pressure on the Libyan regime and weakening American credibility. Its dangerous to make threats if youre not prepared to follow through. All of the public hand-wringing has made it even worse.

title: The Rise of the West
description: Missouri was always different. Admitted to the Union under the Missouri Compromise, it was the eponymous exception to the agreement, which banned slavery north of the 3630 parallel  the line that defined the states southern border. And when, in November 1860, the northern free states voted for Abraham Lincoln, most slave states voted for John Breckinridge and three Upper South states voted for John Bell, Missouri was the only state to vote for the Northern Democrat, Stephen Douglas. The results in St. Louis were even more unusual: Lincoln edged out Douglas in a four-way race that  unlike any other that day  mirrored the returns of the country as a whole. St. Louis became the only large city in a slave state won by the president-elect, defying regional stereotypes. And Missouri stayed true to form on March 9, 1861, when its secession convention became the first such meeting to vote for staying in the Union.

title: Sexy Ruses to Stop Forgetting to Remember
description: WASHINGTON

title: City Housing Official Quits After Using Official Letterhead on Behalf of Friends Son
description: A top city public-housing official has resigned after using his official letterhead to write a letter to a judge on behalf of a man facing child pornography charges in Florida.

title: For California, a Slower-Growing Population
description: LOS ANGELES  Perhaps the legendary beaches here are losing their pull. California, once the very symbol of sun-drenched American growth, had a population increase of only 10 percent in the last decade, the slowest rise in the states history. And for the first time since California became a state in 1850, it will not gain a Congressional seat.

title: Is It Dunk and Done for Perry Jones?
description: Update: After this story was published, Perry Jones, a freshman on Baylor Universitys mens basketball team, was suspended by the N.C.A.A. on Wednesday, keeping him out of that evenings Big 12 tournament game against Oklahoma. The writer reacts here.

title: Making Every Oil Calorie Count
description: Nashville

title: Court Upholds Cyclists Ban Based on Biological Passport
description: The international governing body of cycling won on Tuesday what some are calling landmark cases for the sports antidoping program, adding credibility to the sports trailblazing method of catching athletes who dope.

title: Putting Afghan Plan Into Action Proves Difficult
description: ALAM KHEL, Afghanistan  If the American-led fight against the Taliban was once a contest for influence in well-known and conventionally defined areas  the capital and large cities, main roads, the border with Pakistan, and a handful of prominent valleys and towns  today it has become something else.

title: Former Mets Officer Weighs a Bid
description: The Mets continue to attract investors who are willing to consider buying a stake in the team.

title: For Lawmaker Examining Terror, a Pro-I.R.A. Past
description: WASHINGTON  For Representative Peter T. King, as he seizes the national spotlight this week with a hearing on the radicalization of American Muslims, it is the most awkward of rsum entries. Long before he became an outspoken voice in Congress about the threat from terrorism, he was a fervent supporter of a terrorist group, the Irish Republican Army.

title: Britain: Police Arrest Man Tied to Stockholm Bombing
description: The Scottish police said Tuesday that they had arrested a man in Glasgow on terrorism charges related to a suicide bomber who killed himself and wounded two others in Sweden in December. The arrest came as part of an investigation across Sweden and Britain into the bomber, Taimour Abdulwahab al-Abdaly, 28, who had lived in both countries and who detonated bombs in Stockholm on Dec. 11, 2010. The arrested man was described only as a foreign national.

title: How the World Was Supposed to Look in 2000
description: The particular challenges of feeding 9 billion people without destroying the planet seem both overwhelming and endlessly complex. Trying to peek into the future, however thrilling and terrifying it might be, is usually a failure. But its not, of course, unprecedented. (In fact, weve been here before, and in my adult-ish lifetime, too.) To that end Ive been reading New York Times articles from the 1960s (I was a teenager then) about food crises, and the challenge of feeding 6 or 7 billion people in the year (gulp) 2000. (Im only permitted to link to the abstracts of these archived articles, but Ill give you some highlights.)

title: The Ashtray: Hippasus of Metapontum (Part 3)
description: This is part three of a five-part series.

title: Wednesday: It Breaks in the Morning
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Ahem. After completing todays grid, it is apparent to me that Peter A. Collins has never meta puzzle he doesnt like.

title: Now Both of Beltrans Knees Are a Concern
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Because of recurring problems in his right knee, Carlos Beltran has played in less than half of the Mets games over the past two years. Not coincidentally, the Mets finished below .500 in each of those seasons.

title: Pakistan: Charges Delayed for American in Shooting
description: A court on Tuesday further delayed charging Raymond A. Davis, a C.I.A. operative who shot two people to death in Lahore. The next hearing will be held March 16, according to a prosecutor. On Jan. 27, in what Mr. Davis claims was self-defense, he shot and killed two motorcyclists at a busy intersection. The United States described the episode as an attempted robbery.

title: In Florida, Push to Link Teacher Pay to Student Performance
description: MIAMI  The Florida Legislature, convening its 60-day session on Tuesday, quickly set its sights on measures that would link the pay of new teachers to student performance and allow school boards to fire teachers more easily for mediocre results.

title: Criticism and Questions Over Plan to Move Macys Thanksgiving Parade Out of Times Sq.
description: Thanksgiving is a time of tradition: turkey, family and, for the past 84 years, the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade. In that regard, this year will be no different.

title: Devils Playoff Push Is Slowed Against Lowly Senators
description: NEWARK  The Ottawa Senators came to town Tuesday with the worst record in the N.H.L. and with a lot less motivation to beat the Devils than the Devils had to beat them.

title: Research on Brain Scans
description: To the Editor:

title: Villanovas Late Slide Continues in Early Exit
description: Villanova arrived at the Big East tournament hoping a new environment would right a season that became unglued. The Wildcats opened the regular season ranked No. 6, but they lost their last four games, causing them to fall out of the polls.

title: In Brooklyn, Divided Opinion About a Bike Lane by a Park
description: Bicyclists in boots and backpacks glided effortlessly on Tuesday along a milky green path of controversy, although few stopped to discuss it.

title: Vicious Assault Shakes Texas Town
description: CLEVELAND, Tex.  The police investigation began shortly after Thanksgiving, when an elementary school student alerted a teacher to a lurid cellphone video that included one of her classmates.

title: An iPhone Holster That Doubles Talk Time
description: The AmigoCase combining an iPhone case and backup battery is a clever take on the problem for all phone battery packs.

title: The House Hearings on American Muslims
description: To the Editor:

title: In Egypt, Preparations for a Rarity: A Real Vote
description: CAIRO  Amr Moussa kicked off his attempt to become Egypts first president in a real election with a raucous town-hall-style meeting on Tuesday, taking a few potshots at the previous government while promising to be the caretaker leader needed to fix the countrys political and other ills.

title: Neither of Rival Budgets Is Expected to Move in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  A House Republican proposal to cut $61 billion in current federal spending was headed toward defeat in the Senate on Wednesday even as Democrats appeared unable to rally support for their own fiscal plan, keeping a stubborn budget stalemate alive.

title: U.S. Economy Is Better Prepared for Rising Gas Costs
description: The increase in energy prices is beginning to resemble the rise in 2008. But this time, the American economy may be better prepared for higher fuel costs.

title: Hard Stance Seems Softer in E-Mail of Wisconsin Governor
description: CHICAGO  For weeks, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has publicly held firm to his plan to sharply curtail collective bargaining rights for most public workers, despite the protests of union supporters. But e-mail messages released Tuesday between representatives of Mr. Walker and some Senate Democrats who oppose the measure suggest that Mr. Walker has privately considered tempering at least some limited elements of those bargaining changes.

title: Expounding on a Theme, Obama Visits Boston School
description: BOSTON  President Obama visited a high-tech public school here on Tuesday to pound away at his themes of innovation and education, sticking to a schedule that has taken him out of Washington nearly every week, despite budget battles and upheaval in the Arab world.

title: Bank Chief Rejects Idea of Reducing Home Loans
description: Showing resistance for the first time against government pressure to write off tens of billions worth of mortgage debt, Bank of America executives said on Tuesday that the idea was unworkable and warned that it would be unfair to borrowers who had managed to stay current on their loans.

title: Fateh Singh Rathore, the Tiger Guru, Dies at 73
description: Yes, there was that day in June 1976 when, after years of roaming the hills, valleys, lakes and gorges of Ranthambhore National Park in northwest India, Fateh Singh Rathore stopped in his tracks as the orange blur of a tigress glided through the forest, trailed by four prancing cubs.

title: S. Hazard Gillespie, Former U.S. Attorney, Dies at 100
description: S. Hazard Gillespie, who aggressively pursued securities fraud as the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York in the last years of the Eisenhower administration and who was a top litigator for the Manhattan firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell for nearly 50 years, died on Monday at his home in Nyack, N.Y. He was 100.

title: The Prison That Wont Go Away
description: The prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, has long been the embodiment of Bush-era arrogance and lawlessness, and Barack Obama raised the hopes of millions around the world in 2008 when he campaigned on the promise of closing it. On Monday, that promise crumbled, the victim of Congressional spinelessness and President Obamas inability to create political support for a way out of the moral quagmire created by his predecessor.

title: Alaska: Ruling in Spill Favors Exxon
description: A federal district judge late Monday rejected a request to immediately order Exxon Mobil to pay more than $100 million to help Prince William Sound recover from the oil spill caused by the 1989 wreck of the Exxon Valdez. A marine biologist said the government, which first demanded the money in 2006, had failed to follow up its claim. The government said it was still studying how to proceed. The judge, H. Russel Holland, asked for a status report by Sept. 15.

title: Waiting for Colonel Qaddafi
description: Foreign journalists wait for Colonel Qaddafi's announced press conference in Tripoli as fighting continues in Zawiyah and Ras Lanuf.

title: U.S. Appeals Florida Health Care Ruling
description: The Justice Department filed notice on Tuesday that it was appealing a decision by a federal judge in Florida who struck down the new health care law, saying it was unconstitutional for the federal government to require Americans to obtain health insurance. The judge, Roger Vinson of Federal District Court in Pensacola, voided the entire law after finding that the insurance requirement was inextricably bound to other provisions of the statute. The Justice Department said it was asking the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, to provide an expedited review of the decision.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Rebel-Led Government
description: Libyan rebels try to create an alternative government that could replace Colonel Qaddafi regimeNorth.

title: Man Is Shot Dead in Dispute at Barber Shop in Brooklyn
description: A 77-year-old man with a gun was shot and killed by an off-duty city correction officer after an argument and a scuffle in a barber shop in Brooklyn on Tuesday afternoon, law enforcement officials said.

title: Memphis Votes for County to Run Schools
description: Memphis residents voted Tuesday to transfer the administration of the citys schools to the county, supporting earlier moves by city officials and effectively putting an end to the city school system.

title: Talking Point: Van Persies Red Card
description: Quick quiz: The red card shown to Robin van Persie early in the second half of Arsenals 3-1 loss at Barcelona in the Champions League on Tuesday either (a) cost Arsenal the chance at wresting control of the game; (b) gave the Gunners a convenient excuse for losing a game in which they were thoroughly dominated; or (c) was concrete proof of a celestial conspiracy to deny Arsne Wenger another trophy as long as he lives.

title: Hoping to Be the Netflix for the Sundance Crowd
description: A new Web site focused on independent films is hoping to become Netflix for the Sundance Film Festival crowd.

title: When Exercise Is Too Much of a Good Thing
description: Recently, researchers in Britain set out to study the heart health of a group of dauntingly fit older athletes. Uninterested in sluggards, the scientists recruited only men who had been part of a British national or Olympic team in distance running or rowing, as well as members of the extremely selective 100 Marathon club, which admits runners who, as you might have guessed, have completed at least a hundred marathons.

title: Word of the Day | unaccountable
description: unaccountable \n--kaun-t-bl\ adjective

title: Gold Cup Coming to New York, but U.S. Probably Isnt
description: The United States was placed with Canada, Panama and Guadeloupe on Tuesday in what appeared to be the easiest of the three groups for the first round of this summers Concacaf Gold Cup.

title: Big East Replay, March 8
description: A look at the first round of the Big East tournament, with Rutgers advancing with an ugly victory and Villanova making an early exit.

title: News Quiz | March 9, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: African Art Museum Receives $3 Million Gift
description: The Museum for African Art in New York has received a $3 million gift from the Ford Foundation toward the completion of its new home on Fifth Avenue, at 110th Street, which is scheduled to open in the fall, the museum said on Tuesday. In recognition of the gift the museums lobby will be known as the Ford Foundation Lobby. The museum has raised $76 million toward the $90 million cost of construction. It originally planned to open its new home, which will occupy the lower floors of a 19-story condominium designed by Robert A. M. Stern Architects, next month, but postponed the opening, citing construction delays.

title: Loyalists Batter Libyan Rebels Near Strategic Oil Town
description: RAS LANUF, Libya  Forces loyal to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, attacked rebel fighters Wednesday on the outskirts of this strategic refinery town, provoking a response that included the firing of missile fusillades and rocket-propelled grenades. It was perhaps the fiercest engagement yet between the budding opposition army and the government during the three-week-old conflict.

title: Recovery in Airbus Jet Sales Helps EADS Return to Profit
description: PARIS  A strong recovery in new jet sales at its Airbus unit lifted European Aeronautic Defense and Space to a profit last year. A steady flow of deliveries of commercial planes and military hardware also helped the company bolster its war chest for potential acquisitions to more than $16.5 billion, the company said Wednesday.

title: Carnivals Louder Commercial Beat Adds Dissonance

The economist won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2006 and spawned a microfinance boomlet, with everyone from the Gates Foundation to smaller N.G.O.s like Kiva piling on. But is he beloved in Bangladesh?
