The pile of white stuff in back of my apartment in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, must have topped 10 feet, perhaps 15. When I read The Snowy Day to my twin toddlers, I thought to myself, this is the kind of human-made hill that Ezra Jack Keats imagined Peter climbing up and sliding down.

title: One Dead After Yemen Security Forces Fire on Protesters in Capital

Protests in Sana, the capital, have been relatively peaceful since President Ali Abdullah Saleh said that Yemeni security forces would protect the demonstrators. The episode was the first time that uniformed officers used live ammunition since the protests began here nearly a month ago. Two protesters were killed in Sana several weeks ago by men in civilian clothes.

title: Health at Every Size?
description: The start of Lent today will offer many of us yet another opportunity to renew that resolution we made at the start of the year (and abandoned by the time February rolled in), to lose the extra poundage. But before you vow to give up your glasses of Cabernet and your plates of pasta primavera, you might want to consider H.A.E.S., or Health at Every Size, a new peace movement that one of its proponents, Linda Bacon, a nutritionist in the Department of Nutrition at the University of California, Davis, says was designed to halt the collateral damage  food and body preoccupation, self-hatred and eating disorders  that has resulted from the failed war on obesity. H.A.E.S. is based on the idea that the best way to improve health is to honor your body, and it supports the adoption of good health habits simply for the sake of health and well-being rather than weight control.Bacon and Lucy Aphramor, a National Health Service specialist dietitian and an honorary research fellow at the Applied Research Center in Health and Lifestyle Interventions at Coventry University in England, published a paper in Nutrition Journal earlier this year. It argues that a weight-focused approach geared toward losing weight is  surprise!  not especially effective in either reducing the weight or creating healthier bodies. In fact, they say, such an approach can unintentionally lead to weight gain and worse health.

title: Thinly Veiled Restraint

title: David Broder, Political Journalist and Pundit, Dies at 81
description: David S. Broder, who skillfully straddled the line between commentary and reportage for more than four decades as a political correspondent and columnist for The Washington Post and who spread his influence on television as a Sunday morning pundit, died on Wednesday in Arlington, Va. He was 81. The cause was complications of diabetes, The Post reported.

title: Airline Fees Worth the Cost
description: These days, it seems airlines are coming up with all sorts of new fees.

title: For a Change, They Came to Praise Her
description: There is no question that the policies of the citys transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, can be polarizing.

title: UConn Gains Some Momentum
description: The Georgetown senior Austin Freeman, the Big East preseason player of the year, chewed his mouth guard at halftime. It curled up his left cheek as he took a few shots with his teammates before he took a seat on the bench alone, still chewing.

title: A Parent on the Couch
description: You will probably not be surprised to hear that I am hardly the first parent to have to step out of her life (theres another foot pun; so many of them, Im learning) because of an illness or injury. Among the many supportive notes I have received in the past few days are a number from other moms who have broken their ankles and spent the same six to eight weeks being reminded of how much they actually do in a day that requires two feet.

title: Two New Museums to Explore Vegas Mob Past
description: For decades, the connection between Las Vegas and the world of organized crime was a well-known secret. Now, two Sin City museums aim to embrace that history.

title: Dont Judge Us, Well Judge You
description: A FEW weeks ago, Sarah Sophie Flicker, the striking brunet founder of the Citizens Band, walked into a gift suite at Sundance with her husband, the director Jesse Peretz, and the actress Zooey Deschanel, and was invited to undergo an appearance assessment being performed by an oddly dressed couple sitting in the corner, calling themselves Gill and Jill Bumby.

title: King Vows He Wont Back Down Over Hysteria on Hearings
description: On the eve of his controversial hearing on homegrown Islamic terrorism, Representative Peter King, Republican of New York and chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, has vowed in an e-mail to supporters that he will not back down to the hysteria created by my opponents.

title: Reader Idea | The DNA Dance
description: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

title: In Ecuador, With Mountain Views
description: A five-bedroom concrete house is on the market in for $550,000 in an upscale suburb of Quito.

title: House Hunting in ... Ecuador
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM THREE-AND-A-HALF-BATH HOUSE IN GREATER QUITO

title: An iPhone App Helps the Blind Identify Currency
description: For the millions of blind people living in the United States, paying for something in cash can pose major challenges because there is no difference between the size and shape of a $1 or $100 bill. To tackle this problem, many blind people set up systems to identify a bills value by folding the notes into different sizes and shapes, which then make them easily identifiable later.

title: The Insider | Lauren Remington Platt
description: From first glance, Lauren Remington Platt appears to have it all. Statuesque, poised and intelligent, the 26-year-old looks more Westport, Conn., than West Village. Graduating from Columbia University in 2006, Platt became a research analyst at a hedge fund. Swapping out her Chanel jackets for chaos theory, long hours at the office left Platt only minutes and a mascara wand before hitting the benefit circuit post-work. This prompted the platinum-haired beauty to start Vnsette.com, a members-only Web site that allows its users to select from pre-styled hair and makeup options, starting at $250 for in-home visits by professional hair and makeup artists. Makeup options range from a natural, sun-kissed look to red-lipped Grace Kelly regalness, while hair styles run the gamut from a slicked-back ponytail (The Tribeca) to a classic, iron-straight middle part  la Gwyneth Paltrow at the Oscars. With an international gaggle of good-looking clients that include the model Anouk Lepere and Monaco royal Charlotte Casiraghi, who better than Platt to tell you how to put your best face forward.

title: Cutting Through the Bother of City Parking
description: Longtime city dwellers generally dont need an app to tell them where they parked, where they should park or where they cant park.

title: Gems From 2008 Paris Theft Found in Drainpipe
description: PARIS  More than two years after men dressed in wigs and scarves struck the Harry Winston jewelry store in Pariss golden triangle of upscale shops, the police this week discovered a cache of sparkling diamonds from the theft in a far less glamorous place: a drainpipe in the northern suburbs of the city.

title: As Charlie Sheen Tweets, Twitters Valuation Grows
description: The actor Charlie Sheen has posted the word winning more than a dozen times since starting his Twitter account on March 1.

title: Like NPR, PBS Met With Fictional Donors
description: NPR was not the only media organization duped by the Republican provocateur James OKeefe.

title: Adele and Lady Gaga Top the Pop Charts
description: Women rule the pop charts this week, with the British singer Adele holding at No. 1 on Billboards album chart for a second week, and Lady Gagas Born This Way the top digital download for a fourth week in a row.

title: Cabbies Say No as the Camera Is Rolling
description: The first cabdriver tells his prospective fare that, lacking GPS and a map, he does not know how to get to Union Street and Third Avenue in Brooklyn, an intersection of two relatively major streets about 1.5 miles, and two turns, from the base of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia and Pakistan.

title: Art Deco Restored
description: An apartments owner had already spent years studying the Art Deco style when he embarked on renovating his 1,420-square-foot apartment in Shanghai..

title: Lipman Agency Gets New Top Executive Lineup
description: Lipman, the New York advertising agency known for its work for luxury and fashion brands, is getting a new executive suite that includes Michael Mendenhall, who was until recently the senior vice president and chief marketing officer at Hewlett-Packard.

title: JPMorgan Chases Jimmy Lee on Deal Trends
description: James B. Lee, JPMorgan Chases vice chairman, discusses what chief executives are planning to do with corporations big cash hoards in this CNBC video. The investment banker also talks about the trends influencing deals, as seen in the General Motors I.P.O., which he handled.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia and Pakistan.

title: Notes From the Underground | Caveman
description: The New York-based band Caveman recently took the home front by storm with a rolling set, thick with animalistic drums and swooning guitar riffs, at the Bowery Ballroom. The instrument-laden group of boys looked as though they had walked in off the street, picked up their instruments and casually strummed out nearly an hour of seamless musical beauty. Opening for Arms and the White Rabbits, the unsigned Caveman kicked off a night of soul-calming psychedelia and danceable rock n roll.

title: Republican Expresses Support for Tax on Wealthy
description: ALBANY  A Republican state senator said on Wednesday that he would introduce legislation to extend a temporary state income tax surcharge on wealthy New Yorkers, a move that could shift the political calculus around a measure strongly supported by Democratic lawmakers but opposed by most Republicans and by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: TimesCast | March 09, 2011
description: Thirteen people are killed in a clash between Muslims and Christians in Egypt; the Tucson suspect Jared L. Loughner returns to court; and NPRs chief executive resigns.

title: A Shanghai Apartments Art Deco Splendor Restored
description: SHANGHAI  To say that Spencer Dodington, an entrepreneur, is passionate about Art Deco design is an understatement. He has devoted years to studying the style, amassed a vast collection of period furniture and started a business renovating prewar apartments for expatriates.

title: Sit. Stay. Take a Picture.
description: For years, jokesters have made fun of modern art by inviting babies or chimpanzees to paint pictures and then promoting the results as masterpieces in galleries. An advertising agency trying to gain some attention for a pro bono client has come up with a clever variation on that.

title: Scenes From the Film 'Monogamy'
description: The relationship of a Brooklyn couple.

title: Frankies 457 Spuntino to Accept Credit Cards
description: Frank Falcinelli, one of the voluble Franks behind the Frankies mini-empire in Brooklyn and Manhattan, just reached out to Diners Journal to say that the flagship Frankies Spuntino in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was now taking credit cards. Famously it had never done so.

title: The Other British Singer-Songwriter
description: Dont wait for a VW commercial (like the one featuring Nick Drake and Pink Moon) to discover or rediscover Michael Chapman, the English singer and guitarist.

title: Fire Truck Collides With a Van, Killing One Passenger
description: Updated 4:47 p.m. | A van carrying a group of disabled adults was struck by a city fire truck in Staten Island on Wednesday afternoon, killing one of the vans passengers and leaving two others seriously injured, police and fire officials said.

title: At Ease, Sailor
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#649", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: U.S. Women Win Eighth Algarve Title
description: The United States womens national team survived a scare from upstart Iceland to claim its eighth Algarve Cup title on Wednesday. The teams inspired second-half performance helped the American women avoid a potentially humiliating loss.

title: In City of Loss the Dead Shall Dance
description: Elisabeth Kbler-Ross never mentioned arranging date nights for the dead (with dancing) among the five stages of grief, but this is one of the more poetic rituals of The Argument, a multimedia walk-through theatrical experience inspired by the disaster of Hurricane Katrina.

title: Natural Causes Drove Russian Heat Wave, Study Finds
description: The deadly heat wave that seared Russia last summer was driven primarily by a natural weather phenomenon, not man-made causes, government researchers said in a study Wednesday.

title: Reconstructing the Day Reagan Fell: Chaos After a Presidents Shooting
description: The patient was 70, fit and very polite. He made it a point of pride to walk into the emergency room under his own steam. The medical staff went to work on him immediately, cutting off clothes, inserting IV lines, starting fluids and hooking up monitors. The process moved so fast that one worker never bothered to look at his face. Another asked for an address and was surprised by the answer: 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Ex-Aide Calls for Ensign to Resign From the Senate Right Now
description: Senator John Ensigns announcement this week that he is retiring has brought little solace to his chief accuser, Doug Hampton, the husband of Mr. Ensigns former mistress.

title: The 10-Night Intergalactic Funk Odyssey
description: There is a certain species of New York music fan that is ready to skimp on sleep. This person probably has a day job, a career even. But thats not going to stop him (and it is usually, though hardly always, a him) from getting down to live music until 1 in the morning on a Wednesday, if theres a good show to be had.

title: Bowlive at Brooklyn Bowl
description: The jazz funk band Soulive just completed its second annual 10-night residency at Brooklyn Bowl.

title: Investigating Un-American Activities, Now and Then
description: The coming hearings on Islamic radicalization, to be presided over by Representative Peter T. King, theRepublican fromLong Island who is chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, have already prompted much protest. One critic, Rabbi Marc Schneier, president of the Foundation for Ethnic Understanding, said the hearings are by definition unjust since they single out Muslim-Americans as the source of homegrown terrorism. The committee shouldinstead examine all forms of violence motivated by extremist belief.

title: HCA Prices Its I.P.O. at $30 a Share
description: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

title: ING Puts Its U.S. Online Banking Unit Up for Sale
description: The ING Group has put its ING Direct USA online banking unit up for sale to help comply with terms of the financial firms bailout by the Dutch government, an ING spokesman confirmed to DealBook on Wednesday.

title: The Disruptor
description: THE DISRUPTERMatt Bai and the union leaders he interviewed for his profile of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey gave the impression that Christie is nearly entirely responsible for the sacrifices being demanded of the states public employees. But he is just the governor of New Jersey, not its dictator. He cant unilaterally force his will on the state. Neither Bai nor the union leaders quoted in this otherwise excellent piece focused on the role of New Jerseys Legislature, which last July approved the proposals that have so infuriated state employees.JOHN C. KATZFalls Church, Va., e-mail

title: The Last Refuge
description: Or, for some people, the first. Newt Gingrich explains why he dumped wife #1 while she was in the hospital after cancer surgery, and wife #2 soon after she was diagnosed with MS. It was because of his love of country:

title: With an Assist From Officials, St. Johns Escapes
description: While Rutgers Coach Mike Rice was on the dais warning that blood might spill from his mouth from biting his tongue, Justin Brownlees relieved smile was on full display in the St. Johns locker room Wednesday afternoon.

title: Rival Bills to Keep the Government Running Fail in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday dismissed competing plans to impose new spending cuts and finance the government through Sept. 30, forcing top lawmakers and the Obama administration back to their search for a way out of the budget stalemate.

title: Soul-Baring Offered Amid Glitter
description: The stage of Radio City Music Hall looked like a garish disco on Tuesday night, with a wide-screen video backdrop, eight tall towers for rotating lights, illuminated fabric canopies like minibandshells and frequent blasts of strobes and spotlights to keep the audience blinking and flinching. It was an unlikely, even bizarre, setting for songs about self-doubt, vulnerability, artistic ambition and a search for love and meaning: the songs Conor Oberst writes and sings in Bright Eyes, which was opening a sold-out two-night stand.

title: NetApp to Buy Engenio From LSI
description: NetApp announced on Wednesday afternoon that it has agreed to buy Engenio, an external storage business owned by the LSI Corporation, for $480 million in cash. The acquisition, which is expected to close in 60 days, should add to NetApps earnings by the end of the second quarter in 2012.

title: A Unified Home for Arts Education, With a Split Right Down the Middle
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  Its hard to know whether Brown Universitys latest experiment in interdisciplinary studies, the new Perry and Marty Granoff Center for the Creative Arts, will ever bear worthwhile artistic fruit. Cross-disciplinary programs have been around for decades, with dubious results. But at least the center has given rise to a handsome piece of architecture.

title: A Power Strip You Wont Want to Hide
description: Most power strips are ugly: utilitarian, jacketed in black, cream, or white plastic with an easthetic that deserves to be kept out of sight.

title: Suspect Charged in Attempted MLK Day Bombing
description: SEATTLE  A man suspected of planting a sophisticated bomb along the route of a march honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Spokane, Wash., was arrested early Wednesday, law enforcement officials said.

title: 19-Year-Old Is Charged in Hamsters Death
description: The trouble began, Theresa Smith said, shortly after she bought a hamster for her 9-year-old son. A few months later, the hamster, Princess Stephanie, was playing in its exercise ball on the floor of their apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, when an older son, who is 25, flew into a rage.

title: One Fresh Score in Place of Another
description: The centerpiece of the St. Lawrence String Quartets program at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening was to have been a new work by Osvaldo Golijov, whose music this ensemble has championed since its (and his) early days. But the piece was not ready, so the St. Lawrence players revived another recent acquisition, John Adamss String Quartet (2008).

title: Prodigious Talent Discovers Balance
description: Sierra Hull opened her Tuesday-night show at the Living Room with Easy Come, Easy Go, her genteel and wistful new single, a burst of adult-contemporary bluegrass. Ms. Hull tiptoed lightly with her vocals, never pushing the lost-love feeling too hard, and she took it easy on her mandolin, too, not wanting to overpower the moment with virtuosity.

title: Company Jabs Mets Fans on the Subway
description: Win or lose, the death of all sports teams is when fans stop paying attention. After two fourth-place finishes and dim prospects for this season, the Mets may have a hard time generating headlines with their play this year. The lingering questions about the teams owners, who are being sued for $1 billion and are trying to sell a quarter of the club, have not helped either.

title: Off the Grid in the West Texas Desert
description: You wont find directions to the Field Lab, a homestead two and a half miles off Highway 118, deep in the West Texas desert and 30 miles or so from the Mexican border, on Mapquest.

title: Spirals in and Out of Dark Obsession
description: Exit, a new work by Larry Keigwin, begins in near darkness with six dancers posing rather fiercely along the edge of the stage. As bleeps of industrial sound gain momentum, the dancers inch backward and forward, eventually staggering into Dane Laffreys free-standing, somewhat shiny black wall at the rear.

title: Showering the Songwriter With Love and His Words
description: Rectangular is the wooden box/Where lies my love neath the golden phlox/They say he died of the chicken pox, goes one of the sillier rhymes in Sheldon Harnicks amusingly nonsensical Ballad of the Shape of Things. Then comes the comic kicker: In part I must agree; one chick too many had he.

title: Rethinking Normal Blood Pressure
description: Millions of people who have been told they are on the path to hypertension may never develop life-threatening problems, according to new research that suggests its time to redefine normal blood pressure.

title: Marcelo Does Milan
description: Styled to a T | Marcelo Burlon

title: House Warmed, the Orchestra of St. Lukes Settles In
description: By the end of its opening day on Tuesday the DiMenna Center for Classical Music already seemed, in the best sense of the term, old news. The new home of the Orchestra of St. Lukes, on West 37th Street in Manhattan, replete with rehearsal spaces for the ensembles own use and for rental to other groups, the center appeared to be a settled issue, a proven success.

title: Off the Grid in the West Texas Desert
description: The Field Lab, a homestead in a part of the desert known as the Moonscape, is where a former New Yorker lives without electricity or running water.

title: Young Hands Tackling Chopins Intimidating tudes
description: At 22 the American pianist Charlie Albright already boasts a daunting rsum. An economics and pre-med undergraduate at Harvard and a masters student at the New England Conservatory of Music, he recently won two prestigious prizes: the Young Concert Artists auditions and the Gilmore Young Artist award.

title: Church of Saint Mary the Virgin, Times Square, 3:29 P.M.
A Glow in the Desert
description: TERLINGUA, Tex.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Spreading Ads
description: The Web is awash in marketing videos, but who wants to watch those outside of the marketing department? The creators of the nonprofit TED Conference held an Ads Worth Spreading contest earlier this month to help inspire advertisers to make videos that actually interest and engage the audience. Bettina Edelstein chats with Tanzina Vega, the Times media reporter who covered the TED contest.

title: Tough Situations Demand Tough Bidding
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams is the premier event at the Spring North American Championships, which have just started in Louisville, Ky. The winners last year were Pierre Zimmerman from Switzerland, Franck Multon and Michel and Thomas Bessis (father and son) from France, and Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness from Norway. They won by 104 international match points to 94 over Martin Fleisher of New York; Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.; Bobby Levin of Lake Ariel, Pa.; Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y.; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; and Lew Stansby of Dublin, Calif.

title: Climate Change and Coffee
description: In Colombia, coffee yields have plummeted as a result of rising temperatures and more intense and unpredictable rains.

title: At the Show, Robot Floor Sweepers Dance
description: At the International Home and Housewares Show in Chicago this week, a floor-cleaning device from Mint was programmed to show off some moves.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Pimcos Treasury Dump The Pimco flagship fund, its Total Return Fund, has taken its government related holdings to zero. Zero Hedge

title: Climate Change in Your Coffee Cup
description: Coffee growers are losing out to climate change.

title: Heat Damages Colombia Coffee, Raising Prices
description: TIMBO, Colombia  Like most of the small landowners in Colombias lush mountainous Cauca region, Luis Garzn, 80, and his family have thrived for decades by supplying shade-grown, rainforest-friendly Arabica coffee for top foreign brands like Nespresso and Green Mountain. A sign in the center of a nearby town proclaims, The coffee of Cauca is No. 1!

title: Rutgers Runs Out of Time
description: The final 4.9 seconds of St. Johns victory over Rutgers in the mens Big East tournament:

title: Photo Editing Online, Easy as Pie
description: When Alexey Ivanov and his future wife, Marina Kiseleva, were dating, she gave him a memorable gift: a photograph of himself that looked as if it were hanging in the Tate Modern in London.

title: Reruns vs. Glee
description: Reruns on CBS attracted the most viewers in prime time on Tuesday, but Glee on Fox led among those aged 18 to 49. According to Nielsens estimates Foxs musical comedy drew 12 million viewers at 8 p.m. In total viewers Fox ranked second, with modest ratings for its comedies at 9 and 9:30, Raising Hope (6.8 million) and Traffic Light (3.8 million). CBS earned the largest audiences in every time slot of the night with repeats of NCIS at 8 (13.4 million), NCIS: Los Angeles at 9 (13.4 million) and The Good Wife at 10 (8.3 million). NBC was third, and ABC was fourth.

title: Microsoft Sells 10 Million Kinects, Breaking Record
description: Microsoft was pushed aside asking of technology last year when Apple became the worlds most valuable technology company. But Microsoft just got some payback, breaking consumer electronics records with the sale of its Kinect game controller for the Xbox 360.

title: Counting Monthly Text Messages
F.D.A. Approves Benlysta, a New Lupus Drug
description: 7:51 p.m. | Updated The first new drug to treat lupus in more than half a century won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, offering a new option for people with the often debilitating immune system disease.

title: Comic With Short Fuse and Some Long Feuds
description: During an appearance on Fox News last weekend Sarah Palin called the comedian Kathy Griffin a 50-year-old adult bully and a has-been whose New Years resolution was to destroy Ms. Palins teenage daughter Willow.

title: Kathy Griffin On Broadway
description: The comedian narrates a tour of the Belasco Theater, the home of her new Broadway show.

title: A Grab for Wall Streets Rising Stars Before Theyve Risen
description: Some of the worlds largest private equity firms are in a tug of war over top talent. But the competition isnt over brand-name executives commanding eight-figure salaries. Instead, firms are fighting for the affections of bankers barely old enough to rent cars.

title: The Americanization of the Rue St.-Honor
description: PARIS

title: Brooklyn Senator and Assemblyman Face Corruption Charges
description: State Senator Carl Kruger, a powerful and at times controversial Brooklyn Democrat; a state assemblyman; and an influential lobbyist are expected to turn themselves in on Thursday to federal authorities in Manhattan on corruption charges, according to several people briefed on the matter.

title: Live on Times Talks
description: March 10, 2011, 12:54 p.m. | Updated The archived video of the Times Talks event is available here 8:06 p.m. | Updated This live event has ended.

title: Burlesque Performer, New York City, 2010
description: You never see anything until the very end when I drop the boa.

title: Actor, Writer, Director, Nobody
description: ON a recent Saturday morning, Xavier Dolan sat on a bench outside the Mercer Hotel in SoHo, sipping his second latte with whiskey. The glass awning shielded him from the cold rain, as passers-by tromped through black puddles of icy water. The 21-year-old filmmakers second film, Heartbeats, is opening across the country and on Video on Demand this month.

title: Total Recall
description: The Hershey High School Memory Team has won the memory championship three years straight, and three students hold overall national records.

title: A Patch of Rusty Paradise That Might Be Paved
description: Its a safe bet that the Willets Point section of Queens, setting and subject of the new documentary Foreign Parts, does not figure in many New York tourist itineraries, though it has starred in a movie before, Ramin Bahranis Chop Shop. This battered stretch of junkyards and auto repair shops may thrive (or fester, depending on your point of view) in the shadow of Citi Field, but it seems a universe away from that gleaming corporate food court where the Mets occasionally win a baseball game.

title: Beauty Spots
description: NO PASSPORT REQUIRED

title: Fewer Eyebrows Raised at Brow Grooming for Men
description: TAKING Propecia and using Rogaine for more than a decade have helped to slow hair loss for Michael Sultana. Meanwhile, a few inches below his receding hairline, hair grows like kudzu with no pharmaceutical assistance whatsoever.

title: Bold Colors and Ideas: New Products From the Housewares Show
description: Standouts from the International Home and Housewares Show in Chicago, where thousands of goods were on display this week.

title: Scorecard | Alexander McQueen Wins!
description: In the forests of fashion months dark, volcanic ash-strewn second to last night, the task at hand for two of of Pariss most talented couture-level designers was whose collection would burn most bright. The critics conclusion? AsScorecard can tell you, its not quite black and white.

title: From Jaime Hayon, New Bathroom Accessories for Bisazza
description: Bathrooms are very boring, said Jaime Hayon, the Spanish artist and designer. They are square and white and geometric, and only care about being hygienic. Instead, he suggested, A bathroom should be treated as a living room, full of glamour, a place you want to show to others.

title: Pillows and More From Christian Lacroix
description: The House of Christian Lacroix has introduced its first line of textiles for the home. Designed by the creative director Sacha Walckhoff for the British company Designers Guild, the collection includes various patterns inspired by the south of France: Tempera has painterly stripes; Vuelta, piles of flowers; and Arles, left, monuments from the city. As it was the first collection, I really thought it was important to make it happen in the south of France, because Mr. Lacroix was born in Arles, Mr. Walckhoff said. We will go to visit other cities and countries in future collections.

title: Reinterpreting Rudolph Schindlers Home
description: Schindler Lab, Round One, which opened last week at the MAK Center for Art and Architecture in West Hollywood, Calif., is the first in an annual series of installations at the late architect Rudolph Schindlers home. Initiated by Sara Daleiden, a guest curator, the series will pair a different emerging artist and architect every year.

title: Sales at Apartment 48, Fishs Eddy and Others
description: Apartment 48s merchandise is as much as 60 percent off, through March 31, when the store is closing (a Burlap hurricane lamp, originally $36, is $21.60; Roman Glass napkins, originally $12 each, are $4.80); 12 West 17th Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 807-1391 or apartment48.com.

title: In Eastern Europe, a Trove of Vintage Objects
description: When Stacy Borocz and her husband, Joe, left Atlanta to move to Budapest for his career, she was a merchandise manager for a chain of gift shops and bookstores. But she soon realized that her new home offered greater opportunity.

title: Mario Buatta on 50 Years of Design
description: Mario Buatta, the prankish interior designer long known as the Prince of Chintz, is celebrating his 50th year in business. All sorts of honors are accruing to him, including the renaming of the materials library at the New York School of Interior Design as the Mario Buatta Atelier. Were a New York institution and hes a New York institution, said Christopher J. Cyphers, president of the school, open since 1916.

title: At the Home and Housewares Show, All Things Bright and Clever
description: CHICAGO

title: Send in the Fronds
description: THE Archbishop John Ireland used to pray in my kitchen  or so the neighbors say. Long before it was my attic apartment, this space was reportedly his home chapel in St. Paul, Minn.

title: Carriage Houses Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Pets as Bedmates
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter and the Starcatcher
description: Photos from the show at the New York Theater Workshop.

title: Mexican Billionaire Widens Lead as Worlds Richest Man
description: When it comes to the race for money, Carlos Slim Hel, the worlds richest man, has surged even further into the lead. The Mexican billionaire accumulated an additional $20.5 billion over the last year, bringing his total fortune to $74 billion, according to the Forbes annual ranking of the worlds billionaires.

title: A Chef Is Cooking
description: SAM TALBOT, wearing a black Valentino coat over a Rogan flannel, moved easily through the fashion ranks at an art opening that Vladimir Restoin Roitfeld held last month in SoHo. Come by the friends-and-family tasting, Mr. Talbot called out in his North Carolina drawl to a surfer-looking guy he knew from Montauk. Ill put you on the list.

title: Los Angeles Agency to Start an Ad School
description: Madison Avenue is starting to do something about its need for employees who are trained to meet the challenges posed by new methods of advertising and marketing.

title: Shopping for Decanters With Jim Meehan
description: The author of The PDT Cocktail Book, and co-owner of the speakeasy for which the manual is named, shopped for handsome decanters.

title: Decanters
description: JIM MEEHANS decanter collection was accumulated in record time: as the self-described booze guy in his family, Mr. Meehan, a managing partner of the East Village speakeasy PDT, was the recipient of 16 decanters from his grandmother upon her death several years ago. They now reside alongside dozens of liquor bottles in his one-bedroom apartment in the East Village.

title: Half the Game Is Mental; So Is the Other Half
description: HERSHEY, Pa.  There is a narrow little room inside the sprawling brick tangle of Hershey High School, not far from the dual smokestacks of the famous chocolate company. The door is not numbered and the walls have no windows. A teacher named Colette Silvestri spends Thursday afternoons inside, leading her team in practice.

title: Hanson Dry
description: Fulton Street in Clinton Hill, a few blocks from the neighborhoods rows of stately brownstones, is undergoing a slow makeover, with markets serving farm-raised meats, French cafes and fresh new faces. Opened in December, Hanson Dry is a midcentury-modern-themed cocktail lounge that caters to the young professionals who now call the neighborhood home.

title: Got a Pinkie Ring? Youre All Set for This Party
description: THE RAVENITE, a Gambino social club in Little Italy frequented by John Gotti, is now a boutique selling handcrafted shoes. But its ghost was raised a few blocks north on Monday night, when Kill the Irishman, a film based on Danny Greene, a Cleveland gangster, had a New York screening and after-party.

title: Most Public Schools May Miss Targets, Education Secretary Says
description: More than 80,000 of the nations 100,000 public schools could be labeled as failing under No Child Left Behind, the main federal law on public education, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan told Congress on Wednesday.

title: Yankees Try to Sort Out Pitching
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees game Wednesday night is not being broadcast on television or radio, and that is a shame for fans curious about their pitching.

title: New Jersey Nearly Sold Secret Data
description: Files on abused children. Employee evaluations. Tax returns. A list of computer passwords. Names, addresses, birth dates and other information on hundreds of foster children and abused children. And, of course, Social Security numbers.

title: Perry Jones in Suspension
description: My article on Perry Jones, to be published in the magazine this Sunday, but already online here, places Baylors freshman basketball phenom in a complicated world  19 years old, vastly talented, projected as a top-five draft pick in this years N.B.A. draft and therefore a probable one-and-done player at the college level. As I checked in on him throughout this past season, agents hoping to represent him were already filling up the cellphone message box of his summer-league coach and mentor, anticipating his jump to the pros.

title: British Link Iran to Rockets Found in Afghan Province
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The British Foreign Ministry announced Wednesday that rockets found several weeks ago in Nimruz Province in the far southwest of Afghanistan were Iranian weapons en route to the Taliban.

title: Shopping Picks for March 10
description: Sip Champagne and linger in a luxurious setting at the new Etro store; Anna Sui is selling an exclusive line of dresses on Outnet (outnet.com); and other items.

title: Resignation Comes at Sensitive Time for NPR
description: In the midst of a brutal battle with Republican critics in Congress over federal subsidies, NPR has lost its chief executive after yet another politically charged embarrassment.

title: Baylor Star, a Top N.B.A. Prospect, Is Suspended
description: The N.C.A.A. has suspended Baylor forward Perry Jones III, one of the nations top freshmen, for accepting impermissible benefits from his Amateur Athletic Union coach.

title: Dozens of Cases to Be Dropped in San Francisco Police Scandal
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With a group of undercover police officers under suspicion of perjury and conducting illegal searches, the San Francisco district attorney said Wednesday that his office would drop dozens of drug and robbery cases and continue to investigate scores more for possible dismissal.

title: 10 Face Charges in Mexico Killings
description: MEXICO CITY  Ten members of a Mexican drug gang working on both sides of the border have been charged in the murders last year of a pregnant American Consulate employee, her husband and the husband of another consulate employee in Ciudad Jurez, Mexico.

title: Scrutinizing a Governors Statements
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has built a national reputation as a straight talker who will answer tough questions. But a close look at his public statements over the past year shows that some do not stand up to scrutiny. Here are a selection of statements, and an examination of their truthfulness. RICHARD PREZ-PEA

title: New Director for Spider-Man
description: The producers of Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark have announced that Julie Taymor would step aside as director after nine years of work and that a new creative team  along with the musicals composers, Bono and the Edge of the band U2  would be making significant changes to the script and the $65 million production over the next three months.

title: Canadian Banks Object to Toronto Exchange Merger
description: OTTAWA  The proposed merger between the London Stock Exchange and the holding company that owns the Toronto Stock Exchange has encountered opposition from a perhaps unexpected front, Canadas financial community.

title: In Tucson, Loughner Enters Plea: Not Guilty
description: TUCSON  Some of those hit by bullets in the Tucson shooting spree got their first glimpse since that day of the man accused of pulling the trigger as Jared L. Loughner, shackled and wearing a tan prison jumpsuit, pleaded not guilty in federal court here on Wednesday to 49 counts stemming from the shooting.

title: Marketers Celebrate Glimmers of Recovery
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: Standing Guard, and Protecting the Premises
description: Jose Caceres, 25, has been a security guard since last March with the Protection Plus Security Corporation in Manhattan. Since October, Mr. Caceres has been assigned to guard the Department of Motor Vehicles office in Peekskill. He recently completed a 47-hour armed guard training course at the Blackhawk Security School in the Bronx, and expects to get his license to carry a firearm  along with a transfer and a raise  this spring. Mr. Caceres lives with his mother (his parents are divorced) and his two sisters in the Marble Hill Houses in the Bronx.

title: Connecticut City Settles Suit in Arrests of Day Laborers
description: The City of Danbury, Conn., has agreed to pay $400,000 to settle a federal lawsuit brought by eight day laborers who complained that their 2006 arrest in a local police sting operation was illegal and amounted to racial profiling, lawyers for the laborers announced on Wednesday.

title: Canada: Conservatives in Contempt
description: The speaker of the House of Commons found the Conservative government in contempt of Parliament on Wednesday for refusing to provide cost estimates for a new anticrime program and because of potentially misleading remarks from a cabinet minister. It was the third such finding against the government in about a year. After a review by a parliamentary committee, there is a remote possibility that the decision might ultimately jeopardize the ruling Conservative governments hold on power.

title: NPR Chief Executive Resigns
description: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss the latest NPR controversy, one that led to Vivian Schiller's resignation.

title: Ireland: New Prime Minister Is Sworn In
description: The Irish Republic on Wednesday swore in its new prime minister, Enda Kenny, after an election that wiped out the longtime ruling party, Fianna Fail. Mr. Kennys center-right Fine Gael party will now govern in a coalition with the center-left Labour Party. Ireland has been traumatized by the collapse of its economy and recently accepted a $93 billion loan from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund. Mr. Kenny pledged to enter into a covenant with the Irish people in which honesty is not just the best policy; its our only policy.

title: Burkina Faso: Protests Over Deaths
description: Students in Burkina Faso demonstrated in several cities to protest the deaths of a student in police custody last month and of other marchers killed in later protests, according to a local human rights group. Demonstrations took place in Koudougou, Fada NGourma, Tougan and Sabou, Chrizogone Zougmore, president of the Burkinabe Movement for Human Rights, said by phone.

title: In the Shadow of the Big East, a Spotlight for the Ivy League
description: Philadelphia

title: Russia: Biden Says U.S. Will Push For Russia to Be in Trade Organization
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., left, in meetings with Russias president on Wednesday, called the countrys accession to the World Trade Organization the most important item on our agenda, and promised that the White House would push for the repeal of cold-war-era trade restrictions. But he warned that international investors were watching closely to see whether Russia made progress on corruption and rule of law.

title: Police in Los Angeles Step Up Efforts to Gain Muslims Trust
description: LOS ANGELES  Sgt. Mike Abdeen, on duty in the county Sheriffs Department, got a call last year from a Muslim father who was worried about his son. The young man had grown a full beard and was spending a lot of time alone in his room, on the computer. The father was worried that perhaps his son had fallen in with Islamic extremists, and wanted Sergeant Abdeen to look into it.

title: An Anniversary to Bear in Mind
Telmex to Place Rural Phone Lines in Separate Company
description: MEXICO CITY  Telfonos de Mxico, the countrys dominant fixed-line phone carrier, plans to carve out its rural lines into a separate company, adding a new layer to a dispute between the company and its competitors.

title: Wright and Villanova Are  Looking for the Way Up
description: For the second straight year, Villanova is enduring a late-season skid, and this one appears to be even more crippling.

title: The Ashtray: The Author of the Quixote (Part 4)
description: This is part four of a five-part series.

title: A Glimmer in the Darkness
description: Charleston Harbor, March 1861

title: Wisconsin Senate Limits Bargaining by Public Workers
description: CHICAGO  The bitter political standoff in Wisconsin over Gov. Scott Walkers bid to sharply curtail collective bargaining for public-sector workers ended abruptly Wednesday night as Republican colleagues in the State Senate successfully maneuvered to adopt a bill doing just that.

title: Basketball Night at White House
description: President Obama combined two of his passions  basketball and politics by playing host to a dozen members of Congress at the White House on Wednesday night to watch the televised contest between the Chicago Bulls and the Charlotte Bobcats.

title: Liverpool Declines Role in Government Overhaul by Britain
description: LIVERPOOL, England  When he became prime minister last year, David Cameron announced that the days of big government were over. In its place he proposed to build something called the Big Society, a new model in which public-private partnerships, charities and community groups would take over as the state pulled back.

title: Mets Had Money Trouble Before Lawsuit Was Filed
description: When the owners of the Mets said in late January that they would seek buyers for up to 25 percent of the club, they cited the air of uncertainty created by the $1 billion lawsuit brought by Irving H. Picard, the trustee representing the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme.

title: A Heros Burial for Long-Dead President Marcos? Its Being Considered
description: BATAC, Philippines  More than two decades after former President Ferdinand E. Marcos died in disgrace in Hawaii, the Philippine government says it is formally considering his familys longstanding demand for a burial with honors in a cemetery reserved for presidents and other prominent figures.

title: In Pinedale, Wyo., Residents Adjust to Air Pollution
description: PINEDALE, Wyo.  Strong sun, not too much wind, a good thick snow pack: sounds like a perfect late winters day in a remote rural Western valley rimmed by snaggle-topped mountains.

title: Justice Scalia Objects
description: One rough measure of how any Supreme Court term is going is to track the decibel level of Justice Antonin Scalias dissenting opinions. In a case last week, the question was whether statements made to the police by a shooting victim as he lay bleeding to death in the parking lot of a Detroit gas station were properly used at trial to obtain a murder conviction of the man he named as the gunman.

title: Qaddafi Forces Attack Rebels Near Ras Lanuf
description: Forces loyal to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, attacked rebel fighters on the outskirts of Ras Lanuf, a strategic refinery town, on Wednesday.

title: Rio Tinto Raises Offer for Riversdale Mining
description: In the hopes of breaking a shareholder standoff, Rio Tinto on Wednesday increased its offer for the coal producer Riversdale Mining by 3 percent, to 16.50 Australian dollars a share.

title: Peter Kings Hearings on Muslims
description: To the Editor:

title: Woods Sees Some Progress, but Others Are Looking for Victories
description: MIAMI  When he dropped the idea of fixing his own swing and decided to take on a new teacher, his third since turning professional in 1996, Tiger Woods warned everyone who would listen: there is no quick fix. That was last August, and he was telling the truth.

title: F.D.A. Approves Drug for Lupus, an Innovation After 50 Years
description: The first new drug to treat lupus in more than half a century won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, offering a new option for people with lupus, an often-debilitating immune system disease.

title: Finally, Perez Is Out of the Rotation
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Terry Collins announced on Wednesday what has been widely believed since the end of last season when the Mets refused to use a healthy Oliver Perez even in blowout losses. Perez, Collins said, will not be part of the rotation.

title: Christies Talk Is Blunt, but Not Always Straight
description: New Jerseys public-sector unions routinely pressure the State Legislature to give them what they fail to win in contract talks. Most government workers pay nothing for health insurance. Concessions by school employees would have prevented any cuts in school programs last year.

title: F.D.A. to Study Whether Anesthesia Poses Cognitive Risks in Young Children
description: A federal panel will meet on Thursday to evaluate growing concerns about whether anesthesia in young children, used in millions of surgical procedures, can in some cases lead to cognitive problems or learning disabilities.

title: The Promise and Costs of Charters
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N.J.

title: Blekko Blocks 1.1 Million Sites From Its Search Engine
description: Last month, Google caused a stir when it changed its algorithm to push down low-quality sites in search results. Now Blekko, a new search engine, is going much further by banning 1.1 million Web sites from its search engine.

title: Appeal of iPad 2 Is a Matter of Emotions
description: An utter disappointment and abysmal failure (Orange County Web Design Blog). Consumers seem genuinely baffled by why they might need it (Businessweek). Insanely great it is not (MarketWatch). My god, am I underwhelmed (Gizmodo).

title: Owen Laster, Literary Agent at William Morris, Dies at 72
description: Owen Laster, one of the most powerful literary agents of his generation, who ran William Morriss worldwide literary operations and had a long list of best-selling writers that included James A. Michener and Gore Vidal, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Revolts Raise Fear of Migration in Europe
description: LAMPEDUSA, Italy  Until a few weeks ago, the immigrant transfer center on this tiny Mediterranean island  a kind of Italian Ellis Island  was empty. An extensive European campaign against migration from Africa was considered so effective that the authorities basically shut it down.

title: Rhode Island Town Fights the Release of a Child Killer
description: The impending early release of a convicted child killer has stirred outrage in Rhode Island and sent state officials scrambling for alternatives to freeing him.

title: Libya Calling
description: London

title: Cuomo Vows Personal Push to Legalize Gay Marriage
description: In a closed-door meeting with gay advocates, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo pledged on Wednesday to deploy his own political popularity and prestige to push for the legalization of same-sex marriage in New York, saying he was prepared to devote his full attention to the cause this spring.

title: Tressel Is a Reminder of Why Rules Blur
description: The richest detail about the latest scandal to puncture the piata that the 2010-11 college sports year has become was buried deep in an Associated Press article Tuesday.

title: The Case for a No-Fly Zone
description: This is a pretty easy problem, for crying out loud.

title: Tucson Suspect Arraigned
description: Suspected Tucson killer Jared Loughner appeared in court Wednesday.

title: Hoard of Cash Lets Qaddafi Extend Fight Against Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  The Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has tens of billions in cash secretly hidden away in Tripoli, allowing him to prolong his fight against rebel forces despite an international freeze on many of the Libyan governments assets, according to American and other intelligence officials.

title: Its Greed vs. a Picture of Solid Research in Galleon Trial
description: Greed and corruption  thats what this case is all about, a federal prosecutor said on Wednesday at the trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire hedge fund manager accused of being at the center of a huge insider trading ring.

title: Amid Battle to Cut Spending, Republicans Turn Spotlight to Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  Under fire for focusing heavily on cutting spending rather than stimulating job creation, House Republicans are taking new steps to emphasize their efforts to spur hiring, including a jobs forum with business leaders to be held in the Capitol next week.

title: School of Glock
description: Its been nearly nine weeks since that tragic shooting in Tucson, and you may be wondering whether theres been any gun legislation proposed in the aftermath.

title: The Lakers Could Tell the Heat a Few Things
description: MIAMI  The line between empathy and sympathy is subtle but significant, and for about a half hour on Wednesday the Los Angeles Lakers lived in the hazy space between the two.

title: Connecticuts Better Budget
description: In comparison to New Yorks $88 billion budget or New Jerseys of $29 billion, Gov. Dannel Malloys budget in Connecticut is a mere $19.7 billion. Yet Governor Malloy has managed to create a better, fairer budget than both of his colleagues. And he is doing it without bombast, without YouTube, without making hard enemies or playing favorites.

title: California: 2 Incumbents Re-elected
description: After a bitter campaign in which West Hollywoods future as a capital of gay culture and nightlife became the subject of debate, voters re-elected the longtime incumbents John Heilman and Abbe Land to the City Council on Tuesday. Challengers alleged that during Mr. Heilman and Ms. Lands time in city government, development had priced young gay men and lesbians out of the city in favor of middle-class families. But on the whole, voters supported Mr. Heilman and Ms. Land, who characterized changes in the city as results of a larger cultural shift. John DAmico, one of the challengers, also won a seat on the Council, while Lindsey Horvath, who was appointed to the Council in 2009 after a members death, was defeated.

title: Many Refugees From Libya Dont Want to Go Home
description: CHOUCHA TRANSIT CAMP, Tunisia  Europe fears Abdou Dirisu Minimu Aliu.

title: 2 Driver Announcements; Further Confirmation of Red Bull Strength in Spain
description: Just when it was beginning to look as if the Hispania Racing Team would settle for only one driver this year, it announced Wednesday that Vitantonio Liuzzi would be the second driver for the team. HRT is the last team to announce its drivers.

title: 2 Driver Announcements; Further Confirmation of Red Bull Strength in Spain
description: Just when it was beginning to look as if the Hispania Racing Team would settle for only one driver this year, it announced Wednesday that Vitantonio Liuzzi would be the second driver for the team. HRT is the last team to announce its drivers.

title: Appeals Court Cuts Forfeiture From Ex-Officer at Monster
description: An appeals court upheld the conviction of James J. Treacy, the former chief operating officer of Monster Worldwide, for improperly accounting for backdated stock options, but it also ruled that the amount he had to forfeit was not correctly calculated.

title: Blogginheads: Was Bush Right?
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Mickey Kaus of kausfiles debate the Iraq War's influence on the Arab uprisings.

title: A Million Fish Can Die in a Night; Cleanup Takes Days
description: LOS ANGELES  How do you remove a million dead fish from the water?

title: Marquette Extends Year by a Day, or Maybe More
description: In the early rounds of the Big East tournament, Marquette was one of the more intriguing teams, seeming to need at least one victory to sew up an at-large bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: With Castillo in Front, the Mets Ponder a Big What-If
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  After two weeks of exhibition games, it appears that the 35-year-old Luis Castillo, in the final season of his often-belittled four-year, $24 million contract, has the early lead for the Mets second-base job. He is in front somewhat by default, having nosed ahead of a modest group of players who have not stood out in any particular way this spring training.

title: Researchers Show How a Cars Electronics Can Be Taken Over Remotely
description: With a modest amount of expertise, computer hackers could gain remote access to someones car  just as they do to peoples personal computers  and take over the vehicles basic functions, including control of its engine, according to a report by computer scientists from the University of California, San Diego and the University of Washington.

title: New York Transportation Chief Defends Bike Lanes
description: WASHINGTON  Janette Sadik-Khan, New York Citys transportation commissioner, looked out at several hundred bicyclists gathered here on Wednesday morning and allowed herself a smile.

title: Give Peaceful Resistance a Chance
description: Middletown, Conn.

title: New Jersey Neighborhood Under Water Braces for More Rain
description: WAYNE, N.J.  The residents of the Hoffman Grove neighborhood here are so used to their homes being flooded by the Pompton River that few keep anything of value in their basements, and most own boats for times when the river swells, as it did after drenching rain on Sunday and Monday.

title: Another Win for Artificial Intelligence: the Turing Award
description: Its been a banner year or so for artificial intelligence, from the recent triumph of I.B.M.s Jeopardy-winning supercomputer to a wave of news coverage of the field, like the Smarter Than You Think series in The Times, but also coverage elsewhere, including The Atlantics March cover story.

title: Thursday: Lady of the Knight?
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  I might have said this before, but its worth saying again. Matt Ginsberg is a very nice person. Hes just a trifle bossy.

title: Kim Hill, Inspiration for Ronald McDonald House, Dies at 44
description: Kim Hill, whose childhood battle with leukemia inspired the first Ronald McDonald House, the model for an international network of temporary housing for families of sick children, died on Saturday in Orange, Calif. She was 44.

title: Price Tag and Age Are Roadblocks in Barbers Comeback
description: Unretirements are hardly surprising in professional sports. Athletes like Michael Jordan, George Foreman and Brett Favre practically made an art form of them. Long ago, the Hockey Hall of Famer Gordie Howe made a case of playing as long as possible  into his 50s. But Tiki Barbers decision to return to the N.F.L. at age 35 comes with a caveat: he is a running back.

title: Peter Pan (the Early Years), With Bounding Main and All
description: All sinking sensations should feel this sensational. When the H.M.S. Neverland goes down in Peter and the Starcatcher, the blissful exercise in make-believe that opened on Wednesday night at the New York Theater Workshop, its the most enthralling shipwreck since James Cameron sent the Titanic to her watery grave in the late 1990s (and picked up a crate of Oscars).

title: New York City Fared Better in Recession Than Thought
description: The recession that ended in 2009 caused less damage in New York City than economists previously thought, according to revised jobs data released on Wednesday by the State Labor Department.

title: In the Thick of Libyas Brutal Fighting
description: When Tyler Hicks says that he has just witnessed what may have been the thickest fighting in a single day that he has ever experienced, with the most firepower  coming and going, he is describing extraordinary hostilities.

title: Meanwhile in Washington
description: The Senate on Wednesday voted down the House budget bill, with its string of $61 billion in mostly political cuts through Sept. 30. That formally puts an end to the Houses grandstand play. But the Senate also rejected its Democratic leaders own plan to cut $6.5 billion. The governments financing is due to run out in eight days. To prevent a shutdown, the two chambers will probably have to agree to yet another short-term financing bill.

title: Egyptians Get View of Extent of Spying
description: CAIRO  The files have started flowing out of Egypts dreaded state security headquarters, part of the post-uprising rush to excavate some of the states darkest corners.

title: Justice Advances in Illinois
description: Gov. Patrick Quinn of Illinois has done the right thing in signing legislation that abolishes the death penalty in his state. Since 1977, Illinoiss criminal justice system has wrongly condemned at least 20 people to death. Governor Quinn courageously put aside his own longtime support for the death penalty to ensure that the state does not commit any more such horrors.

title: On Second Thought
description: A federal district judge in Florida backed down, as he should have, from his effort to bully the Obama administration into halting implementation of the new health care reforms even before the issue of the laws constitutionality is resolved by higher courts.

title: Battle Line Hardens Over N.F.L. Financial Data
description: WASHINGTON  The N.F.L. and the players union hardened their stands Wednesday over financial disclosure while the union leader DeMaurice Smith cast doubt whether the players would continue to negotiate an 18-game regular season, a critical element in reaching a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: 3 BBC Journalists Report Being Tortured in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Security forces working for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi physically abused and psychologically terrorized three British Broadcasting Corporation correspondents for 21 hours after they were detained trying to reach the scene of a bloody battle in a city just 30 miles from the capital, the journalists reported Wednesday night.

title: Photo Replay, March 9

description: FRONT PAGE

title: At a Libyan Hospital, Pride and a Wars True Cost Are Seen
description: AJDABIYA, Libya  A short walk from the morgue, men gathered at noon Wednesday before a billboard that read Free Libya and listed the dead and wounded in the fighting that had raged for days a couple of hours away along the Mediterranean. No. 15 was Mahmoud Abdel-Hamid, from Benghazi. No. 43 was Ibrahim el-Sharif, from Ajdabiya.

title: Russian Charity Event Drew Putin, but Perhaps No Money
description: MOSCOW  Turn on Russian television and one is bound to see images of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin skiing, riding a horse or flying a plane. He has also been shown shooting a tiger with a tranquilizer dart and chasing whales in a dinghy while wielding a crossbow. It is all part of a well-honed tough-guy image.

title: Anthonys Last-Second Shot at Redemption Saves Knicks
description: MEMPHIS  Carmelo Anthony was acquired, in part, to be a closer, and the results so far have been mixed.

title: The Fighter: Jillian Michaels
description: You do a lot of yelling on The Biggest Loser, and Ive often thought you must have some sort of regimen for your voice that involves honey and lemon and tea.  No, in fact, I actually have polyps on my vocal cords that occasionally prevent me from elevating my tone. On particularly rough weeks of The Biggest Loser, you will hear me lose my voice.

title: Word of the Day | disparity
description: disparity \di-sper--te, -spa-r-\ noun

title: Russian Heat Extraordinary But Not Unnatural
description: A peer-reviewed paper bolsters the argument that the extraordinary Russian heat wave last summer (see the area of dense red dots below) was almost assuredly the result of unusual, but normal, variations in the atmosphere, with any contribution from accumulating greenhouse gases essentially hidden in the statistical weeds. There are other views, and attempts to clarify the causes of rare extreme weather patterns are among the toughest tasks in climate science.

title: Mel Gibson to Plead Guilty in Abuse of Former Girlfriend
description: LOS ANGELES  Mel Gibson has agreed to plead guilty to a charge of misdemeanor battery against his ex-girlfriend Oksana Grigorieva in a deal that could let him avoid jail and clear some of his legal problems before the release of his next film, in May.

title: Big East Replay, March 9
description: A look at the second round of the Big East tournament, which included some surprises and some controversy.

title: Domestic Terrorism Hearing Opens With Contrasting Views on Dangers
description: WASHINGTON  A Congressional hearing on Thursday addressing homegrown Islamic terrorism offered divergent portraits of Muslims in America: one as law-abiding people who are unfairly made targets, the other as a community ignoring radicalization among its own and failing to confront what one witness called this cancer thats within.

title: Colombia's Coffee Crisis
description: Abnormal rains and high temperatures are having a huge impact on coffee growers in Colombia.

title: 2 Bodies Found in Trunk of Car in Brooklyn
description: Updated, 10:20 a.m. | The bodies of a man and a woman were found in the trunk of a car in Brooklyn late Wednesday night, the police said.

description: Republican senators in Wisconsin successfully maneuvered on Wednesday night to adopt a bill that sharply curtails collective bargaining for public-sector workers.

description: In the past two weeks, Manager Felix Magath has led Schalke to the final of the German Cup and to the quarterfinals of the Champions League.

title: U.S. Removes Diplomat Over Comments Angering Japan
description: TOKYO  A top American diplomat, Kevin K. Maher, has been removed from his post after stirring outrage in Japan for reportedly belittling Okinawans, a State Department official said Thursday.

title: News Quiz | March 10, 2011

description: ANAHEIMThe nights dwindle down, and for the Rangers there is no margin of error. Not with Buffalo and Carolina so close behind, wielding several games in hand in the race for the last two playoff spots.

title: Dalai Lama Gives Up Political Role
description: NEW DELHI  The Dalai Lama announced Thursday that he would formally relinquish his political leadership role in the Tibetan exile government, a decision intended to strengthen the democratic structure of the Tibetan movement on the eve of elections to choose a new generation of political leaders.

title: Opera or Musical Theater: A Debate
description: Is it opera or musical theater? A panel of composers and playwrights will debate this question on Sunday, April 10 on the stage of the Gershwin Theater (home to Wicked) in a discussion moderated by George Steel, the general manager and artistic director of New York City Opera.The panel was prompted by the upcoming New York premiere of Stephen Schwartzs first opera Sance on a Wet Afternoon, which opens at New York City Opera on Tuesday, April 19.

title: Do You Eat Cafeteria Food?
description: Some school cafeterias are striving to offer students better lunch options in terms of both nutrition and taste. What is served in your school lunchroom? Are the options attractive to you? Do you usually eat cafeteria food or bring lunch from home? Why? If you could advise your school cafeteria on what changes should be made to its offerings, what would you suggest?

title: Yemens Leader Proposes Shifting Powers
description: SANA, Yemen  President Ali Abdullah Saleh on Thursday proposed giving more power to Parliament in an attempt to quell growing challenges to his 32-year rule, but a leader of the antigovernment protesters staging a sit-in here quickly rejected the offer.

title: France Becomes First Country to Recognize Libyan Rebels
description: PARIS  Moving ahead of its allies, France on Thursday became the first country to recognize Libyas rebel leadership in the eastern city of Benghazi and said it would soon exchange ambassadors with the insurgents.

title: Test Drive Unlimited 2 Hits Its Stride Online
description: Test Drive Unlimited 2, the Atari racing simulation series for the Microsoft Xbox 360, Sony PlayStation 3 and Windows operating system, hit the streets in early February. Over the next month, Sam Schembari  our resident racing game aficionado  will unravel the layers of the game.

title: At London Show, All About the Home
description: March is the traditional time for spring cleaning and perhaps giving the house a freshening-up. For new ideas, and to catch up with the latest trends and technologies, the Ideal Home Show, at the London Earls Court exhibition space from March 11 to 27, is the place to go.

title: Fantasy Focus: Finding Bargains

title: When Doctors Advice Is Ignored at Home
description: One evening during my residency, I found a friend, another doctor in training, standing at the foot of his patients bed in the intensive care unit, shaking his head. The middle-aged patient was well known to many doctors and nurses in the hospital. Unemployed and living in one of the citys rougher neighborhoods, he appeared regularly in the emergency room with his blood sugars way out of control.

title: How to Buy the Right iPad

title: In Memory of Smoking
description: In memory of tobacco (conquered by President Obama, banned from many open-air spaces, soon to be grown only in the backyards of the defiant) you may enjoy watching what was probably the first cigarette commercial ever made. Created in 1897 on behalf of Admiral cigarettes by the Edison Manufacturing Company, this is only one of 341 Edison films available online at the Library of Congress. (In case the governments slow speeds get to you, the Library has also uploaded it to YouTube.)

title: Qaddafi Forces Bear Down on Strategic Town as Rebels Flee
description: RAS LANUF, Libya  The momentum shifted decisively Thursday in an uprising that has shaken Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis four decades of rule, as rebels fled from this strategic refinery town under a sustained land, air and sea assault by government forces.

title: Why Checking References Isnt a Waste of Time
description: My last post  The Hidden Costs of Hiring  got an unusual response: all of the commenters agreed with me! Clearly, the costs of a bad hire more than justify taking the extra time to try to hire the right person.

title: Need Advice on What to Read? Ask the Internet
description: Netflix uses a software algorithm to recommend movies and Zappos uses one to recommend shoes. Now Goodreads, the social network for book lovers, is introducing an algorithm to recommend books.

description: LONDON  The Bank of England kept its main interest rate and bond purchasing program unchanged on Thursday, signaling that concerns about a weakening economy outweighed worries about rising inflation.

title: March 10: Updates on Libyas Revolt and Middle East Protests
description: On Thursday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. Readers can also follow some of the discussion of the region on Twitter in this blogs right column.

title: British Grocer Buys Stake in FreshDirect
description: The British grocery chain Morrisons has acquired a 10 percent stake in FreshDirect for 32 million as part of a broader effort to expand online.

title: Luminous Fables in a Land of Loss
description: Ta Obrehts stunning debut novel, The Tigers Wife, is a hugely ambitious, audaciously written work that provides an indelible picture of life in an unnamed Balkan country still reeling from the fallout of civil war. At the same time it explores the very essence of storytelling and the role it plays in peoples lives, especially when they are confounded by the extremes of war and social upheaval and need to somehow stitch together unconnected events in order to understand what is happening around them.

title: Credit Card Debt That Outlives Mom
description: Following a recent post on the rising levels of credit card debt among the elderly, several readers raised an important question: What happens when borrowers die? Do they take their credit card balances to the grave, or are those left behind responsible for the debt?

title: Lust in the Classroom
description: Weve heard quite a bit in the past week about Michael Bailey, a professor of human sexuality at Northwestern University, who allowed a male and female guest to demonstrate female ejaculation usinga vibratorlike device after a class where Bailey lectured on the controversy surrounding the existence of the G-spot. Much outrage was expressed and Northwestern, which initially defended Baileys right to teach any way he wanted, later said they would investigate.

title: Danger at the Factory
description: There is a long history of celebrating American manufacturing. And often for good reason. Manufacturing made up a big share of the American economy during its great 20th century rise. Some people also find factory work to be more satisfying than office work: youre making something tangible.
