title: U.S. Escalates Pressure on Libya Amid Mixed Signals
description: WASHINGTON  The White House announced a five-point program on Thursday of steps to isolate Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and ultimately drive him from power, all stopping well short of military action, but distanced itself from the assessment of the nations top intelligence chief, who said Thursday that over the longer term Colonel Qaddafis superior firepower will prevail over the opposition.

title: Arab Voices, Heard at Last
description: To the Editor:

title: Montaignes Moment
description: Anyone who sets out to write an essay  for a school or college class, a magazine or even the book review section of a newspaper  owes something to Michel de Montaigne, though perhaps not much. Montaigne was a magistrate and landowner near Bordeaux who retired temporarily from public life in 1570 to spend more time with his library and to make a modest memento of his mind. He called his literary project Essais, meaning attempts or trials, and the term caught on in English after Francis Bacon, the British philosopher and statesman, used it for his own collection of short pieces in 1597.

title: A.I.G. Offers to Buy Back Securities for $15.7 Billion
description: 9:12 a.m. | Updated with New York Fed statement

title: City of Angels Resists Becoming City of Aliens (the Outer-Space Type)
description: Lets figure out how were gonna get out of this mess, Aaron Eckhart says with about 40 minutes to go in Battle: Los Angeles. An excellent idea, and the solution that presents itself is a simple one: stop talking.

title: Videophiles | Doug Aitkens Patterns & Repetitions: James Murphy
description: There are certain things that all creative people share in common  and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitkens 2006 book Broken Screen, which featured interviews with everyone from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas, challenged the convention of the linear narrative. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetitions, the artist sits down with a whole new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. Theres Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown; and Jack White weighing in on Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. This week, The Moment features LCD Soundsystems James Murphy on the sound of snow. But dont be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesnt do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

title: Plaza Hotel Fountain to Be Home for Ai Weiwei Sculpture
description: A place for dancing, maybe, but for art?

title: Hotel Campaigns Promote Savings and Memories
description: WHEN Conrad N. Hilton  the real one, not the character on Mad Men  published his autobiography in 1958, he titled it Be My Guest. Years later, lodging chains bearing his and other names are still striving to figure out the best ways to reach potential customers.

title: N.H.L. Faces New Scrutiny for Hockey Violence
description: Air Canada, a major sponsor of the N.H.L., has urged the league to crack down on violence, and a criminal investigation has begun in Montreal as the result of a hit on Tuesday night that left a Canadiens player with a concussion and a fractured vertebra.

title: More Baby News: Zenyatta Is in Foal
description: The 2010 horse of the year, Zenyatta, is with child, and she announced it herself, sort of, on Zenyatta.com. The Web site is run by Zenyattas racing manager, Dottie Ingordo Shirreffs.

title: St. Vincents Deal Would Provide Emergency Care
description: A new emergency care center would replace the shuttered St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan in Greenwich Village under a deal announced on Thursday involving the hospital, its creditors, a developer and a hospital chain that would run the center.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Sale of Blockbuster
description: A federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday approved the sale of the ailing movie rental chain Blockbuster after a marathon day of negotiations among its many creditors, allowing the business to avoid liquidation.

title: On the Road, Packing Querulous Erudition
description: The Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostamis delicious brain tickler, Certified Copy, is an endless hall of mirrors whose reflections multiply as its story of a middle-aged couple driving through Tuscany carries them into a metaphysical labyrinth.

title: Citi Signs Deal as U.S. Olympic Team Sponsor
description: Citi said Thursday that it had signed a deal to sponsor the United States Olympic Committee.

title: In Canada, Opposition Grows to Purchase of 65 Fighter Jets
description: OTTAWA  Political opposition to Canadas plan to buy 65 F-35 fighter jets from Lockheed Martin increased on Thursday after the release of a report suggesting that the government had understated their cost by about $12 billion.

title: Obamas Focus on Antibullying Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama poked fun at his own big ears and funny name on Thursday, but all in the service of a serious subject as he and Michelle Obama opened a White House conference to spur antibullying efforts in schools and communities nationwide.

title: House Panel Votes to Strip E.P.A. of Power to Regulate Greenhouse Gases
description: WASHINGTON  A House subcommittee voted on Thursday to strip the Environmental Protection Agency of its power to regulate greenhouse gases, chipping away at a central pillar of the Obama administrations evolving climate and energy strategy.

title: How to Butcher a Chicken
description: Mark Bittman gives step-by-step instructions for deconstructing a raw chicken.

title: Obama to Discuss Energy Prices
description: President Obama plans a news conference Friday morning to discuss rising energy prices.

title: Visit From Goon Squad Wins Critics Award
description: Jennifer Egan won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction at the Tishman Auditorium of the New School on Thursday night for A Visit From the Goon Squad (Knopf), a wildly inventive novel of interlocking stories.

title: Subject Is Sex (Sort Of), Milieu Is Zany (Sort Of)
description: Late in Sebastian Gutierrezs flat, quasi-Almodvarian comedy Elektra Luxx, Julianne Moore makes an uncredited cameo appearance as the Virgin Mary to offer comfort and advice to the title character, a retired porn film star who is pregnant.

title: The Ashtray: This Contest of Interpretation (Part 5)
description: This is part five of a five-part series.

title: Israel Holds Gaza Engineer, Relatives Say
description: GAZA  Relatives of an engineer from Gaza who disappeared last month in Ukraine said Thursday that he had been kidnapped by Mossad agents and transferred to an Israeli prison.

title: Braised and Roasted Chicken With Vegetables
description: Time: About 2 hours, largely unattended

title: Chicken-Skin Croutons
description: Time: About 30 minutes

title: Quick Chicken Stock
description: Time: 40 to 60 minutes

title: Winner, Winner, Chicken Dinner
description: Roast chicken is a classic and wonderful go-to main dish, whether on a weeknight when theres a bit of time or as the centerpiece of a dinner for friends. Its appeal to the cook is easy to grasp: most people like it; it requires virtually no preparation; its nearly foolproof (given minimal technique); and good if not great results are pretty much guaranteed.

title: Terror Hearing Puts Lawmakers in Harsh Light
description: One member of Congress broke down and cried. Another was so incensed that she waved a pocket-size copy of the Constitution and declared, This breathing document is in pain. And there were so many angry charges of McCarthyism and countercharges of political correctness that it sometimes seemed that the topic at hand on Thursday in Washington was the radicalization of the House Homeland Security Committee, not American Muslims.

title: T.C.U. Sharpshooters, All Women, Try to Keep Title
description: FORT WORTH  Last year, Texas Christian became the first all-womens rifle team to win the N.C.A.A. championship, defeating seven other teams that were either coed or all men. Among their opponents were teams from Army and Navy, whose best shooters were excellent, but not as good as T.C.Us.

title: Natural Gas, Scrutinized, Pushes for Growth
description: KENEDY  At a packed meeting here one evening last week, natural gas industry boosters told long tables of ranchers and townspeople about anticipated jobs and economic opportunities. Outside, along lonely country roads near town, lights from drilling equipment glittered in the dark night.

title: Plain Speaking From Biden in Moscow Speech
description: MOSCOW  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who two years ago introduced the idea of a thaw between the United States and Russia, used a speech at Moscow State University to criticize Russias legal and political systems, a move likely to irritate the countrys leaders.

title: Uneasy Lies the Fedora in a Cap World
description: Will the slights and the innuendo never end?

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Cheating on His Fiance With a Camera
description: Venturing into the same waters tested by countless novelists, self-help gurus, filmmakers and TV show runners before him, the director Dana Adam Shapiro has taken on men, women, fear and fidelity for his first feature-length fiction movie. Its a seemingly domesticating turn for someone whose 2005 feature debut, the documentary Murderball (made with Henry-Alex Rubin), about quadriplegic rugby players on and off the court, had a desperate edge. Having lost so much already, the athletes seemed possessed by the need not to lose anything else.

title: Texas May Consider a Bill Forcing Losers in a Suit to Pay Opponents Legal Fees
description: Loser pays; everyone wins.

title: U.S. Regulators and J.&J. Unit Reach a Deal on Plant Oversight
description: Federal regulators reached an agreement on Thursday with a unit of Johnson & Johnson that would impose greater federal oversight at three manufacturing plants responsible for recalls of childrens Tylenol and many other popular over-the-counter medicines.

title: No Lawmaker Immunity as Some Benefits Are Cut
description: As they talk of cutting pension contributions and raising premiums for state employee health care, having state employees pay to park in state garages, and mandating layoffs and furloughs at state agencies, what are lawmakers doing to their own compensation and benefits?

title: Struggles Continue, but B.Y.U. Prevails
description: LAS VEGAS  Brigham Young did little to squelch doubt over its national tournament prospects, needing four free throws in the final 12 seconds Thursday to dispose of Texas Christian, 64-58, in the quarterfinals of the Mountain West Conference tournament.

title: Whats Really Beneath Those Manicured Lawns (and Suburban Smiles)
description: In Eric Mendelsohns 3 Backyards, the sunlight spearing through thick green foliage on a summer afternoon in a Long Island hamlet evokes a magical fairy-tale jungle. Here secrets are buried, and wild creatures roam. The air seethes with the sounds of insects, birds and the neighborhood. On the ground, tiny creatures wiggle and squirm; the earth is alive.

title: A History-Making Week to Consider the 2 Sides of George Ryan
description: On the morning the death penalty was formally abolished in Illinois, former Gov. George Ryan awoke at the Federal Correctional Complex in Terre Haute, Ind., three miles from the Illinois border.

title: Uncertainty at Juvenile Jail in Wake of Latest Lawsuit
description: For much of the past two decades, the Cook County Juvenile Temporary Detention Center has been considered a prime example of what is wrong with the nations juvenile justice system. Three times in the last 10 years, federal court actions have taken aim at patronage, overcrowding and unhealthy and unsafe conditions.

title: Rise of the Ethnoburbs
description: SAN GABRIEL, Calif.  Just east of the still-seething volcano that is Charlie Sheen a visitor finds The Great Mall of China, so-dubbed, 12 acres of new-century America in the midst of an ethnic makeover far more compelling than the Twitter bursts of a raging celebrity.

title: Clean-Coal Debate Focuses on Gasification Plant
description: A bill now on Gov. Pat Quinns desk to build a plant on the far Southeast Side that would supply Chicago customers with substitute natural gas made from Illinois coal has turned up the heat on the clean coal debate.

title: Group to Phase Out Old Football Helmets
description: Football helmets more than 10 years old are worn by about 100,000 young players every fall, presenting what manufacturers and experts in the field have long considered an inappropriate safety risk, particularly in the current age of growing concerns about concussions.

title: Angola: Arrests and Threats Said to Derail Protest
description: The government carried out a campaign of intimidation to deter a demonstration inspired by the uprisings in Egypt and Tunisia, Human Rights Watch reported Thursday. The protest, planned for March 7, did not occur. The group said the police arrested journalists and activists, as well as 17 young rap musicians who were reading poems and distributing pamphlets. Leaders of three opposition parties received anonymous death threats by phone and text messages, Human Rights Watch reported.

title: Let There Be More Efficient Light
description: Boulder, Colo.

title: Sabathia Looks Sharp in Battle With Phillies Halladay
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Just before Roy Halladay struck out Jorge Posada with runners on second and third to cap an afternoon of six scoreless innings, the fans at Bright House Field stood and clapped and hollered. It was as if the next pitch would determine their mood for the rest of the day, and in the Yankees dugout Curtis Granderson started to wonder.

title: Galleon Case Strains Old Grad School Friendship
description: Raj Rajaratnam and Anil Kumar met 30 years ago at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, ambitious graduate students who had come to the United States for an elite business education.

title: Dumbing Deficits Down
description: Like anyone who writes regularly about what passes for economic and fiscal debate in American politics, Ive developed a strong tolerance for nonsense. After all, if I got upset every time powerful people were illogical and/or dishonest, Id spend every waking hour in a state of raging despair.

title: Cuts to Head Start Show Challenge of Fiscal Restraint
description: WASHINGTON  The difficulty Senate Republicans faced voting this week for a bill full of spending cuts is best illustrated on the home page for the Alaska Head Start programs Web site.

title: New Temporary Spending Bill in Works
description: WASHINGTON  With little hope of a budget deal being reached before the end of next week, House Republicans are preparing another short-term spending measure to give the House and Senate a chance to come to agreement over a broader plan to keep the government operating through Sept. 30.

title: The Modesty Manifesto
description: Were an overconfident species. Ninety-four percent of college professors believe they have above-average teaching skills. A survey of high school students found that 70 percent of them have above-average leadership skills and only 2 percent are below average.

title: A Swirling Musical Mash-Up, via Lithuania
description: If Kestutis Stanciauskas has done his job right, there should be at least some degree of discomfort Saturday night at the Chopin Theater in Wicker Park  both on stage and in the audience.

title: Showdown on Vermont Nuclear Plants Fate
description: WASHINGTON  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Thursday rejected all challenges to extending the operating license of the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant, setting up a confrontation between the reactors owner and the Vermont Legislature, which has blocked a state certificate needed to keep the plant running.

title: Start-Ups Are in a Rush to Bring the Chat Room to the Smartphone
description: For all the clever things smartphones can do these days  like stream movies and play 3-D games  the latest mobile craze centers on revamping one of the earliest phone applications, the text message.

title: New Tape Increases Pressure for NPR
description: NPR was forced to do damage control for a third day in a row after the release of undercover audio in which a top fund-raiser is heard telling a person she thought was a potential donor that NPR could possibly shield the donation from government tax authorities.

title: Qaddafi Reaches Into Schools but Some Youths Elude His Grasp
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The crackdown by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi against the rebels trying to unseat him has extended even into Tripolis schools, where students talk about visits from military officers warning them to watch only state television, payments of 200 Libyan dinars a day to attend pro-Qaddafi rallies and their fears that confiding in the wrong friend may mean interrogation by the secret police.

title: Hispanics Are Surging in Arizona
description: PHOENIX  In Arizona, fervor against illegal immigration is so intense that politicians have pushed some of the nations toughest laws and citizen activists have patrolled the border themselves. But census data released Thursday show another side of the population story: Arizonans are increasingly becoming Hispanic.

title: In Bonds Case, Lengthy Wait Has Raised Costs for Plaintiff and Prosecutors
description: When Barry Bonds walked into San Franciscos federal courthouse on Dec. 4, 2003, Buster Posey, the hero of the Giants 2010 world championship, was 16.

title: Does Anybody Really Know What Time It Is?
description: Hancock, N.H.

title: New View of How Humans Moved Away From Apes
description: Anthropologists studying living hunter-gatherers have radically revised their view of how early human societies were structured, a shift that yields new insights into how humans evolved away from apes.

title: N.F.L. Talks Spill Into Frustration as Hopes for Deal Fade
description: WASHINGTON  On the eve of the labor bargaining deadline, the N.F.L. appeared to be teetering on the brink of its first work stoppage since 1987. The negotiations on the financial issues that divide owners and players are at a virtual standstill and representatives of both sides are trading barbs in public. By late in the evening, the meltdown in relations seemed nearly complete, playing out on television and on Twitter.

title: Developer Among Cast of Characters in Kruger Case
description: A corruption case unsealed on Thursday included a large cast of characters beyond State Senator Carl Kruger, Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr. and six others who were charged.

title: Indefensible Detention
description: Should a former attorney general be held personally liable for brazenly misusing the material witness statute when he was in office to hold an American man in brutal conditions on the pretext that he was a witness in a case in which he was never called to testify?

title: Black Death and Dark Ages Drama
description: Scene: The year 1348, somewhere in Europe. Enter the bubonic plague, represented by lolling corpses and scurrying rats. Osmund (Eddie Redmayne), a conflicted young monk, has been recruited by a fanatically devout knight (Sean Bean) and his small band of church-hired mercenaries to lead them to a remote, pestilence-free village. Disturbed by rumors that the villagers are using sorcery to ward off the sickness, the bishop would like his heavily-armed goons to ask them very nicely to stop.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 11, 2011

title: Pentagon Places Its Bet on a General in Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  The chief of staff of the Egyptian armed forces, Lt. Gen. Sami Hafez Enan, had just finished breakfast at the Ritz-Carlton in Pentagon City with two old American friends  one a former head of Central Command, the other a top defense official  when he got a call that the Egyptian Army was going into the streets of Cairo to manage the revolution.

title: Perez Sees 29 Options Outside the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Oliver Perez knows he is down to his last chance with the Mets, perhaps just a bad outing or two away from being passed through waivers and released. But if that happens, Perez said he still hoped to catch on with another team and continue his major league career despite his struggles over the last two years.

title: City Board Grapples With a New Law on Campaign Finance Rules
description: Tackling a highly charged topic that is likely to affect the 2013 race for mayor, the New York City Campaign Finance Board wrestled on Thursday with the contours of a new law requiring more disclosure of campaign spending by independent groups like unions and corporations.

title: Its Not Over in Wisconsin
description: Republican lawmakers in Wisconsin have reversed half-a-centurys middle-class progress in the state by erasing collective-bargaining rights for public employees. Union members, caught off guard and infuriated by the Senate vote on Wednesday and the Assembly vote on Thursday, immediately talked of legal challenges and general strikes, but the outcome was probably inevitable given the Republican success in the 2010 elections. Now union members have to make sure they do not stay away from the polls again when their rights are at stake.

title: Who Has the Toughest Banking Rules, U.S. or Europe?
description: Regulatory arbitrage is the latest buzz-phrase. Wall Streets new parlor game is guessing whether Swiss, British or United States banks will end up with the toughest rules on capital and liquidity. But as reforms play out around the world theres also the possibility that entire business lines will migrate, raising a whole new set of systemic risks.

title: Bank Customers Win One (Soon)
description: Barring a last-minute assault from the banks, a federal rule to protect vulnerable Americans from overly grabby creditors will take effect on May 1.

title: Friday: Egyptian Expanse
description: Note for Those Who Cannot Access the Friday Puzzle: Here is a link to the Across Lite version of the puzzle. Please dont hurt me. Thank you.

title: The Power of Partnerships
description: Some problems are simply too complex to solve with any single approach. Consider the fact that in the United States, a million students drop out of high school each year. To begin to turn back that trend, we need to work on several fronts  assist vulnerable families when children are infants, improve classrooms from preschool through high school, provide after-school supports and college access assistance, tackle the issue of summer-learning loss and get much smarter about addressing students social and emotional needs at every stage. In the words of Clay Shirky: Nothing will work, but everything might.

title: As Web Flourishes, Gay Groups Watch Enrollments Dwindle
description: The lobby of San Franciscos stylish Parc 55 Hotel was packed with bears. Not beasts from the forest, but large, hirsute gay men in jeans and hoodies.

title: Hearing Sees Financial Success and Education Failures of For-Profit College
description: For investors, it was an impressive story: Bridgepoint Education used seed money from Warburg Pincus in 2005 to buy a struggling religious college with 300 students in Clinton, Iowa, and turned it into an online behemoth with 78,000 students and $216 million in profits last year.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,482 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Cynical Non-Enforcers
description: Gridlock is the name of the game at the Federal Election Commission, where all three Republican members routinely block any punishment of even the most blatant violators.

title: Honey, Im Married, and Heres My Wife
description: Summer theater has come early to New York. Its still a bit brisk for outdoor Shakespeare, and the various festivals (Fringe and otherwise) have yet to infiltrate downtown en masse. But summer stock  that durable constellation of musty titles and formerly marginally famous performers  makes a rare appearance in Manhattan with the witless revival of Cactus Flower that opened on Thursday night at the Westside Theater Upstairs.

title: The Medicare Chief
description: To the Editor:

title: Healthy School Lunches
description: To the Editor:

title: Side by Side, a Bold Opening for Frey Norris
description: Raman Frey and Wendi Norris, co-owners of the Frey Norris gallery  which just moved into a spectacular South of Market storefront space are not fans of predictability.

title: With More Than Yawns, Pupils Rate Teachers Book
description: Besides finishing their assignments and playing nicely with others, the third graders in Joe Imwalles classroom have another important job: They are front-line editors of their teachers book.

title: Given Rest, Irish Show No Signs of Rust
description: When Pittsburgh abruptly departed from the Big East tournament Thursday afternoon, it created a ripple that was felt from Seventh Avenue to South Bend, Ind. The big-city stage had been formally set for Notre Dame.

title: Obama and Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: City Says State Is Forcing Cuts to Program for the Homeless
description: Saying that state budget cuts have forced New York City to stop accepting new people into a successful program intended to reduce homelessness, the city mailed a letter on Thursday to hundreds of real estate brokers involved in the program informing them that no new participants will be taken after next Monday.

title: Immigrants and the Secure Communities Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Corruption Case Ensnares a Self-Styled Fighter for the Underdog
description: He was omnipresent in the press rooms at City Hall and the State Capitol in Albany, a wiry man with a gray mustache, bags under his eyes and a Bluetooth headset that seemed to have been permanently lodged inside his ear  endlessly pushing, prodding and pitching stories.

title: Brotherhood: Pledge Night Gone Wrong
description: Any college presidents who didnt ban fraternities after Animal House came out in 1978 might consider doing so if they happen to see Brotherhood, a fast-moving thriller about a pledge night at a fictional frat house that goes horribly wrong.

title: Rebuilt Iraq Mosque Buoys Spirits, but New Sectarian Splits Loom
description: SAMARRA, Iraq  The mosque at the heart of this ancient city, once a bombed-out epitaph for Iraqs spiral into civil war, is now heralded as a symbol of its painstaking recovery.

title: City Comptroller Rejects Contract to Recruit New Teachers
description: The New York City comptroller on Thursday rejected a $21 million contract to train and recruit teachers over the next five years, a move the city said jeopardized a popular program that attracted teachers from nontraditional backgrounds to the citys schools.

title: California Budget Deadline Passes, but Deal May Be Near
description: LOS ANGELES  When Gov. Jerry Brown first proposed his plan of tax extensions and deep cuts to close the $26 billion shortfall California is facing, he said it needed to pass the Legislature by March 10, so the taxes could be put before voters in a referendum in June, a key part of his plan.

title: Heat Ends Its Anguish by Edging the Lakers
description: MIAMI  The arena was shaking, with excitement and anxiety and perhaps every other volatile emotion on the spectrum. The Miami Heat had been this close before  within points, within seconds of victory  only to send everyone away in various states of distress.

title: The Battle Over Union Rights, State by State
description: WISCONSIN

title: Chechnya: Women Forced to Wear Head Scarves, Report Says
description: Chechnyas strongman Ramzan Kadyrov is forcing women to observe an Islamic dress code, while the Kremlin remains silent, Human Rights Watch said Thursday. The New York-based organization said that womens rights in the southern Russian republic had deteriorated to the point that they were not allowed to enter, much less work, in government offices without head scarves, long sleeves and skirts below the knee, and that girls and young women could not attend school or university if their heads were uncovered. Women are not allowed to enter movie theaters or concert halls or often even to be outdoors without head scarves, the Human Rights Watch report said. Tanya Lokshina, a Russia researcher at Human Rights Watch and the reports author, said at a news conference in Moscow that the Chechen women shot with paintballs last summer for failing to follow the dress code were too frightened to file formal complaints. Some of the unidentified assailants were in uniform and thought to be law enforcement officials. Mr. Kadyrov has said that he was not behind the attacks, but that the assailants should receive awards for their deed.

title: China: Chongqing Will Add 200,000 Surveillance Cameras
description: Chinas largest metropolitan region, Chongqing, will spend $781.6 million by 2014 to install 200,000 new video surveillance cameras, raising the total to 510,000. A report on the municipal governments Web site stated that 310,000 digital eyes are still not enough to monitor crime and other social ills, adding that Beijing and Shanghai together operate more than three million surveillance cameras. The Web site report states that 30 percent of the 8,217 criminal cases solved by local police officers in the last three months were helped by leads from surveillance cameras.

title: Honduras: Cocaine Lab Said to Be Sign of Mexican Gangs
description: The police have discovered what they said was the largest cocaine processing lab ever found in Honduras, calling it a troubling sign of Mexican drug trafficking organizations spreading into their territory. The lab was found Wednesday on a remote coffee farm in mountains 100 miles north of Tegucigalpa after a six-month investigation with the assistance of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency, said Oscar lvarez, the security minister. It was capable of producing about a ton of cocaine a month. Honduras is a growing transshipment point for cocaine from Colombia to the United States but Mr. lvarez said the laboratory suggested the drug, usually processed in large clandestine laboratories in Colombia, was being refined in Honduras as well. Mr. lvarez estimated the lab had been operating for the past two or three years. No arrests were made.

title: Consumer Agency to Post a Database of Unsafe Products
description: Despite threats of a budget cut, the Consumer Product Safety Commission will unveil on Friday a database that will allow the public to search for complaints about the safety of everyday products.

title: Art, Saved
description: True stories of individuals who risked everything to save people or artworks or historical records from tyrants are always stirring, but at this point there have been enough of them to constitute a genre. So how to keep yours from seeming formulaic? Amanda Pope and Tchavdar Georgiev, who wrote and directed the gorgeous documentary The Desert of Forbidden Art, knew that for their subject, a man named Igor Savitsky, the answer was to make the art he saved, in effect, the films co-star.

title: Greece: Tax Official Fired for Failing to Increase Revenues
description: The finance minister has fired the countrys top tax official for failing to increase revenue collections, efforts seen as critical if Greece is to meet its debt obligations, ministry officials said. The tax official, Dimitris Georgakopoulos, who was in charge of dozens of tax collection offices, submitted his resignation on Wednesday after a performance evaluation, the officials said. Despite efforts to overhaul the tax collection systems, revenues have declined over the last year. In January, tax revenues were down 9 percent compared to the year before. Greece had budgeted for a 5.5 percent increase. In its latest progress report on Greek fiscal and structural reforms, the European Union had noted persistent deficiencies in tax collection.

title: China: Democratic Reforms Risk Plunge Into Abyss, Leader Says
description: The leader of Chinas quasi-legislature said Thursday that China would never embrace Western political tenets like multiparty democracy or the separation of governmental powers because loosening the Communist Partys hold on power risked plunging the nation into the abyss of internal disorder. The statement by the chairman of the National Peoples Congress, Wu Bangguo, echoed his statements at the legislatures last annual meeting in March 2010, when he said that a China without absolute Communist Party control would be paralyzed by internal divisions. Mr, Wu, the partys second-ranking official, made the remarks during a speech in which he said the government last year had completed a socialist system of laws with Chinese characteristics based on the situation and realities in China.

title: Iraq: Gunmen Kill 6 in Failed Robbery Attempt
description: Gunmen trying to rob a jewelry store in northeastern Baghdad on Thursday killed four police officers and two others, according to a law enforcement official. The gunmen fired on the officers while they were responding to an alarm from the store, the official said. The stores owner and a pedestrian were fatally wounded. Two policemen and one other person were injured. The gunmen fled in several cars and investigators later discovered that no jewelry had been stolen. Over the past year, insurgents have robbed jewelry stores as they have searched for new sources of money.

title: Response of W.H.O. to Swine Flu Is Criticized
description: A panel of independent experts has harshly reviewed the World Health Organizations handling of the 2009 epidemic of H1N1 swine flu, though it found no evidence supporting the most outlandish accusation made against the agency: that it exaggerated the alarm to help vaccine companies get rich.

title: Mafia Madness
description: Theres a bit of good in every Irishman, says a nosy crone (Fionnula Flanagan) midway through Kill the Irishman, an extravagantly corny ode to the collapse of the Cleveland mafia in the 1970s.

title: Mars, Moms and More
description: It seems that its time to admit that dressing actors in LED-studded catsuits, asking them to give performances on sterile white sets and handing the results to a team of computer animators is not a way to make a good movie. It didnt work for The Polar Express, Beowulf or A Christmas Carol, and it doesnt work for Mars Needs Moms, the latest product of Robert Zemeckiss obsession with motion-capture animation.

title: Punishment Recommended for Handling of Horse in Breeders Cup Race
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The Kentucky Horse Racing Commission on Thursday recommended sanctions for jockey John Velazquez and one of its stewards, John Veitch, for not scratching Life at Ten before the Breeders Cup Ladies Classic on Nov. 5.

title: Syracuse and UConn Prepare to Battle
description: The Big East men's basketball tournament is set up for another classic matchup as Syracuse and Connecticut advance at Madison Square Garden.

title: Arkansas Coach Faces Questions About Photograph
description: ATLANTA  Arkansass postseason got off to a bad start Thursday with a report by CBS Sportsline that Razorbacks Coach John Pelphrey committed a recruiting violation. Things got worse with a 74-68 loss to Tennessee in the Southeastern Conference tournament.

title: Residents Face Off Over Brooklyn Bike Lane
description: For all the legal challenges, political hubbub and neighbor-against-neighbor conflict, the bicycle lane on Prospect Park West seems to have united Brooklynites on one thing: it is nice to be the center of attention.

title: James Elliot Is Dead at 67; Discovered Rings of Uranus
description: James Elliot, an astronomer who used light from distant stars to study planetary objects throughout the solar system, leading to his discovery of the rings of Uranus, died on March 3 at his home in Wellesley, Mass. He was 67.

title: 'The Boys' Through the Years
description: A look at the journey of Mart Crowleys play, The Boys in the Band, as well as its creative team.

title: A Recent History and a Personal Story
description: Sometimes you dont have to go very far into the past to be amazed at how drastically things have changed. That is driven home by Making the Boys, Crayton Robeys captivating documentary about the creation of, and reaction to, the breakthrough play The Boys in the Band.

title: Photo Replay: March 10
description: A look at the day in sports, including treacherous weather at the United States Open Snowboarding Championships and the PGA event at Doral.

title: Idol Wins Again
description: With 24.2 million viewers, Foxs American Idol topped the ratings in prime time on Wednesday, according to Nielsens estimates, as the 13 singers remaining in the competition vied for the next round. No other program came close to matching the ratings for the two-hour installment of Idol. CBSs Survivor: Redemption Island was runner-up with 10.9 million viewers at 8 p.m. CBS ranked second for the night over all, broadcasting a rerun of Criminal Minds at 9 (8.2 million) and a new episode of Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior at 10 (9.1 million). ABC was third with reruns early in the night until 9:30, when Mr. Sunshine attracted 4.8 million viewers followed by Off the Map at 10 (4.3 million). NBC ranked fourth, drawing just 3.5 million at 8 for Minute to Win It followed by back-to-back repeats of Law & Order: SVU at 9 (3.2 million) and 10 (5.3 million).

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Trailer | 'Certified Copy'
description: The official trailer for "Certified Copy," a film by Abbas Kiarostami, starring Juliette Binoche.

title: Word of the Day | visceral
description: visceral \vi-s-rl, vis-rl\ adjective

title: In N.C.A.A. Tournament, Overachievers Often Disappoint
description: Notre Dames basketball team has been a great story this season. Unranked to start the year  in fact, Notre Dame didnt receive a single vote in the Associated Press preseason poll  theyve compiled a 14-4 record in the deep Big East conference and a 25-5 record overall. Now ranked fourth in the country in the A.P. poll, they could secure a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament with a strong performance during the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Big East Replay: March 10
description: A look at the Big East tournament quarterfinals at Madison Square Garden includes a buzzer beater and a dunk that didnt quite work.

title: Now Playing: The Usual Chaos
description: A. O. SCOTT The movie world now finds itself in limbo between the Academy Awards and the summer movie season, which starts on the first Friday in May. These are the months of an annual mood swing from euphoria (or at least mild satisfaction) to despair (or at least mild dyspepsia). The Oscar broadcast may have been dreary and barren of surprise, but it did provide one last reminder that 2010 was, all in all, a good year for American movies. In the rearview mirror we have Black Swan, The Social Network, True Grit, The Fighter and The Kings Speech: all embraced by critics and popular with audiences. Up ahead we have more sequels than ever  The Hangover ad Nauseam, Pirates of the Caribbean: Back for More of Your Money, X-Men Tiny Toons Adventure  and thus a fresh set of reasons for critics and their readers to grouse about the horrible state of movies.

title: Right Man to Handle an Irreverent Alien
description: SITTING down for a drink in a SoHo gastropub one frosty January night, Greg Mottola looked tired. For the last two years he had directed Paul, a quirky science-fiction comedy opening nationwide on March 18. The film involves two fanboys (Simon Pegg and Nick Frost, who double as screenwriters) encountering a foul-mouthed alien (voiced by Seth Rogen) in the New Mexico desert. Paul marked a step up in scale for Mr. Mottola, best known for the 2007 teenage comedy (and sleeper hit) Superbad, which rejuvenated his previously stagnant career.

title: Stoudemires Technical Adds to Knicks Woes
description: DALLAS  The Knicks three-game winning streak came to a crashing halt Thursday night as the Dallas Mavericks scored in brilliant bursts, turning the game into a 48-minute rout.

title: A Directors Toughest Competition
description: IN the sausage factory of moviemaking the remake is an age-old temptation. For love or money (but usually money) studios have tapped old stories for different times, fresh stars and ambitious directors, streamlining conceits and translating inconvenient foreign languages. Fans of the originals usually cry desecration, and even talented remakers have trouble living up to the aura surrounding their predecessors versions, much less the appeal.

title: The Rules of the Game in a Feudal World
description: RAROVIDEO, a leading Italian DVD company, inaugurates its new American division this week with two releases that reflect the two faces of 1970s Italian cinema.

title: Inflation Pressures Grow in China As Consumer Prices Increase 4.9%
description: SHANGHAI  China said on Friday that consumer prices rose sharply in February, suggesting that the government might have a difficult time curbing inflation this year.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: News Quiz | March 11, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Powerful Quake and Tsunami Devastate Northern Japan
description: TOKYO  Rescuers struggled to reach survivors on Saturday morning as Japan reeled after an earthquake and a tsunami struck in deadly tandem. The 8.9-magnitude earthquake set off a devastating tsunami that sent walls of water washing over coastal cities in the north. Concerns mounted over possible radiation leaks from two nuclear plants near the earthquake zone.

title: Test Yourself | History, March 11, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about a World War II general.

title: Off the Grid and Back to the Land
description: WHERE does John Wells live?

title: Lil B | Back to Cali
description: Lil B first hit in 2006, at 16, when his group the Pack and its song Vans lionized the eponymous skate shoe that had, until then, most definitely not been associated with hip-hop style. (The song was unsponsored, akin to what Run D.M.C. did in the 80s with their song My Adidas.) As a solo artist, the Bay Area rapper has continued against the grain. Last years album Rain in England melded ambient with rap, perhaps for the first time. A collaborative track with the goth-y Chicago/Michigan trio Salem in late 2010 demonstrated refreshing cross-genre (or subgenre) knowledge. Without being politically correct, Lil B is adept at playing clever word games to undermine some of the negative tropes inherent to hip-hop; his trademark boast  the constantly recycled lyric Im a pretty bitch  uses egotism to unravel misogyny. In three years he has posted enough clips to his YouTube page  more than 240 songs, videos, remixes, video remakes and rambling commentaries  to create something of a canon. Those who explore it tend to grow obsessed.

title: What Are the Best Live Theatrical Performances Youve Ever Seen?
description: The latest bad news for the trouble-plagued Broadway show, Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, inspires us to ask what live theater youve seen and enjoyed. What were your favorite shows, whether you saw them on Broadway, in a local theater or in your high school auditorium? Why were they so memorable?

title: Updates on the Earthquake and Tsunami in Japan
After a Year Away, a Homecoming for the Allmans
description: Welcome home, the guitarist Warren Haynes said on Thursday night, not far into the first show of the Allman Brothers Bands 13-night stand at the Beacon. And that was the only direct reference to recent derailments: the fact that the band had to move elsewhere last year on its visit to New York, breaking a 20-year ritual for its annual string of gigs that have become the bands most important live shows, or that Gregg Allman, the keyboardist and principal singer, now 63, had undergone a liver transplant nine months ago. (The bands 2010 concerts took place instead at the United Palace Theater in Washington Heights, after Cirque du Soleil had booked the Beacon through the spring.)

title: Antarctica in Black and Very White
description: Bernard Kalbs rsum is almost unrivaled. New York Times correspondent. CBS News correspondent and Washington anchorman. Diplomatic correspondent for NBC News. Assistant secretary of state for public affairs. CNN media critic. Author of books on foreign policy and foreign affairs.

title: Barclays and Deutsche Units in Spain Have Capital Gaps
description: Among the lenders that Spains central bank said were in need of of extra capital were two international names: Barclays and Deutsche Bank.

title: Gates Faults U.S. Allies on Afghan War
description: BRUSSELS  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates sharply rebuked the United States allies on Friday for preparing to effectively abandon Afghanistan, threatening what he described as tenuous progress in the nearly decade-old war.

title: Fantasy Focus: An N.L. Auction Reviewed
description: This past weekend, I went to Arizona with my colleague Chris Liss, who wrote a post about his American League team in the annual League of Alternative Baseball Reality auction. L.A.B.R. is the oldest industry league, and I was responsible for the N.L. side. The format is 5X5, 13-team National League only with 2 C, 1 1B, 1 2B, 1 3B, 1 SS, 1 CI, 1 MI, 5 OF, 1 Util, 10P, 6 reserves and a $260 budget. Some observations about the results:

title: History of a New Chicken Dish
description: This weeks magazine column is a contemporary chicken dinner that doesnt waste a single part of the bird, at least the way most birds are packed. (Its best to make if you start with a whole chicken, one you take apart yourself: video here.) I make good stock in which I braise thighs and vegetables; on those I roast the breasts; and, for a snack, or salad, I make crispy chicken-skin croutons. I had two inspirations for the piece, both recipes from Minimalist columns I wrote years ago.

title: The Early Word: A Plan of Action
description: From Todays Times:

title: Celestial Sales for Boys Tale of Heaven
description: Just two months shy of his fourth birthday, Colton Burpo, the son of an evangelical pastor in Imperial, Neb., was rushed into emergency surgery with a burst appendix.

title: Chrysler C.E.O. Presents United Front With 200, 300 and Town & Country
description: This was not the Motor City.

title: Education and Women in the Labor Market
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is an economics professor at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

title: Tis the Season: White Asparagus in Berlin
description: Every April, without exception, white asparagus arrives in markets around Germany with much fanfare. Over the next eight weeks, all sorts of eating spots, from Michelin-starred establishments to office cafeterias, will serve the white stalks, usually boiled and drenched in hollandaise sauce, accompanied by Black Forest ham, schnitzel, scrambled eggs or plain potatoes. And Berlin, surrounded by Germanys largest single asparagus-growing region, is not immune to the cult-like excitement.

title: Libyan Rebels Defiant but in Disarray, as Qaddafis Forces Gain Momentum
description: RAS LANUF, Libya  Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi trumpeted their retaking of the rebellious city of Zawiyah near the capital and pressed toward the countrys largest refinery here Friday, as rebel lines began to crumble before an onslaught of airstrikes, tank and artillery fire, and relentless siege.

title: Retirement Play
description: You know that $9 billion in annual N.F.L. revenue we keep hearing about, that the owners and players are bickering over? Tiki Barber wants some of that. The former New York Giants running back, who quit after the 2006 season, has turned in his unretirement papers. The widespread assumption is that the soon-to-be-36-year-old, whose broadcasting career and marriage have both foundered badly, needs the money. And thats a mercenary motive that makes some people mad, apparently, and some people sad. (If youre John Riggins, age 63, it makes you want to throw on the old leather helmet again.) It also prompts one Mike to ask the other Mike on Mike and Mike in the Morning, on ESPN Radio, if its even possible for a football player like Barber to succeed in coming back if his primary motivation is money and not a raging love for the game. Mike (the former football-playing one) expresses doubt, says it would be hard. A coach in the N.F.L., Raheem Morris, who happens to coach Tikis twin brother, Ronde, says you have to have the heart and the desire and the fire.

title: In Quakes Aftermath, Japanese Companies Try to Take Stock
description: Companies with operations in Japan were assessing the damage to operations on Friday after an earthquake and tsunami struck the northeastern part of the country.

title: Aftermath of the Earthquake and Tsunami in Japan
description: A devastating tsunami hit the coast of northeast Japan on Friday in the aftermath of an 8.9 magnitude earthquake about 80 miles offshore.

title: My Business Problems This Week
description: Here are my business problems this week:

title: DeMaurice Smiths Rebuttal in the Rain
description: It seems the pessimists might have been right all along about a War of the Roses between the N.F.L. and the players union. March may not be enough of a deadline. September would be different.

title: Arriving in Panama to a Series of Games
description: Bryson Voirin, a doctoral student at the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology in Germany and fellow at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, writes from Panama, where he is studying sleep in wild frigate birds.

title: Who Made This Typeface?
description: The text youre reading right now is set in Georgia, one of the most common typefaces used online. Youll see it on countless other sites. It was released by Microsoft 15 years ago and was designed specifically for the screen by Matthew Carter, a legendary typographer and AIGA medalist. Five years ago, Alice Rawsthorn wrote a comprehensive article in The International Herald Tribune about the development of this face and its popularity. Despite vast developments in display technology and typefaces produced for use on screens since then, Georgia still proves to be so reliable and legible that, chances are, you havent noticed it.

title: Complaint Box | Old and Dear
description: The other morning, I went for a grocery run. I parked my car and made a mental note of the aisle number, remembered to take in my reusable shopping bags, and although there was a slight hitch in my git-a-long, as the old saying goes, I was feeling pretty, pretty good.

title: Alexander Wang | A Rare Bond
description: Alexander Wang is still flying high from the excitement of his newly opened SoHo flagship store. To keep the momentum going, Wang has introduced an exclusive all-leather collection of some of his favorite styles from the past. We wanted to create special product for the store that felt very classic and representative of our DNA, he says of the reinvented six best-selling silhouettes  the fishtail parka, tank bra, aviator jacket, trench vest, overall dress and tailored shorts. The skillful deployment of leather, the placement of smooth patched pockets and asymmetrical buckles, and the contour seaming reaffirms the young designers uncanny eye for subtlety.

title: The iPad 2, 5.1 Seconds and Smart Covers
description: It takes me, on average, 5.1 seconds to start and begin using my first-generation Apple iPad. This is how I spent those 5.1 seconds: opening the cover protector, pressing the power button in the top right corner of the device and then swiping my finger across the screen to unlock the iPad.

title: Where Googles Algorithm Overhaul Is Good News
description: When Google declared it had re-engineered its search formula two weeks ago, the spotlight was understandably on the likely losers.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Walker Hands a Victory to  Obama?
description: The votes late this week by the Wisconsin Legislature to curtail collective bargaining rights appears to hand political victories to two very different men: Scott Walker, the Republican governor of Wisconsin, and President Obama.

title: Shares Move Ahead, Lifted by U.S. Signals Despite Quake in Japan
description: Stocks advanced on Friday, trimming the weekly loss in the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, as gains in fuel, metal and industrial companies helped the market overcome a global slump after the worst earthquake on record in Japan.

title: Video: Syracuse and UConn Prepare to Battle
Morning Buzz | A Spotlight on Krugers Lifestyle
description: Weather on gradual improvement program: warmish (55) and rainy Friday with danger of flooding, similarly warmish but unrainy Saturday, slightly cooler but crisply sunny Sunday. No tsunamis expected. And now the news.

title: Transportation Etiquette
description: Slugging, if you dont know  and I certainly didnt before reading this great Emily Badger article in Miller-McClune, thanks to commentary on it by Felix Salmon  is a type of commuting practiced by suburbanites in Virginia traveling into Washington. Those without a car wait in an orderly line and are picked up by those with a car who need extra passengers to take the speedy H.O.V. lanes. This has been going on for decades  an unplanned, unpaid, grassroots form of quasi public transportation that seems to benefit everyone. What particularly struck me was that, over time and without (apparently) any meetings or votes, everyone involved adopted a unique slugging etiquette.

title: Friday Reading: Some Rules for Responsible Tourism
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: In New Case, iPad Starts in an Instant
description: In technology, fast is never fast enough.

title: This Weekends Top European Matchups
description: Saturday

title: Austerity Chic in the U.K.
description: In the ocean of multinational praise still swelling around last years Big British Movie, The Kings Speech, a lone curmudgeons dinghy managed to bob its way onto the waters of consent. The review, not surprisingly, came from France. Here is but the latest manifestation of British narcissism, grumbled Thomas Sotinel, a reviewer for Le Monde. It can be summarized thusly: We are ugly and boring, but, by Jove! We are right!

title: The Road to the White House Is Paved With Pizza
description: Were less than a year from presidential primary season, which means that three million Iowans are in for some ritual abuse. They will stand accused of being an unrepresentative sample, which they are, and holding disproportionate influence, which they do. But Iowans is still an abstraction far too broad. Actual Republican caucusgoers will not merely be Iowans but a small group of highly informed, older, mostly evangelical Iowans with the time and inclination to coax other highly informed, older, mostly evangelical Iowans toward a preferred candidate. They will be the kind of Iowans who have shown up at the Pizza Ranch in Sigourney on this bitterly cold day to hear Bob Vander Plaats talk about marriage.

title: Letter of the Law
description: I asked a former professor to write me a recommendation for law school. It was particularly important to me that this professor write the letter, as my top-choice law school specifically asks for a letter from a former professor, and she is the teacher who knew me best. She said she was too busy, but if I would write it, she would gladly edit as needed and submit it under her own name. I felt uncomfortable writing my own letter, but I did not wish to jeopardize my chances of being accepted into my top-choice school by being overly conscientious. May I do so? I.N., NEW YORK

title: The Enthusiast
description: This weeks enthusiast: Andrea Seigel, novelist (Like the Red Panda) and blogger (andreaseigel.typepad.com).

title: Gangsta Folk
description: Keren Ann rst made her way to a big English-speaking audience in 2004 with Not Going Anywhere, an album of wistful, willowy, slow-acting alt-folk-cabaret songs, partly in the shadow of Norah Jones but also quirkier, messier and with more international accents. As she worked her way through a couple of more albums, she found herself upstaged by Feist, who is less chanteusey but also poppier and perkier. Now Keren Ann gets solidly back in the mix with her new album, 101, and she does it by shedding some blood.

title: A Brutally Candid Oral History of Breaking Up
description: On Thanksgiving 2008, Dana Adam Shapiro, a few years removed from his Oscar nomination for directing the documentary Murderball, visited his childhood home in Boston to find that a good friend of his was divorcing. The friend had been married for three years and, like Shapiro, was in his mid-30s. (Shapiro is now 37.) This was the fourth divorce that Shapiro heard about just that month. In fact, after absorbing the news, he sat down to make a list of all the couples he knew, under the age of 40, whose marriages had already broken up. He came up with 14 names. That struck Shapiro as too many. It was unbelievable, he says now. I wanted to ask them all what went wrong, but you cant ask those kind of personal questions of people. Unless youre writing a book.

title: The Mellegards of Mellerud
description: My grandfather, Birger Mellegard, always dreamed of bringing his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren together for a reunion on the family farm in Mellerud, Sweden. But he died before it could happen. Determined to honor his wish, last July my mother and her two surviving sisters gathered all 35 of Birgers descendants there at the farm. His progeny came from all over: Idaho, California, Holland, Denmark and various parts of Sweden. My cousin Anna had the shortest commute: she and her husband live in Birgers old house.

title: A Documentary Reveals the Dark Side of Conan OBrien
description: The early months of 2010 were an unsettled time for Conan OBrien. He left his job as host of The Tonight Show, committed himself to a 32-city live tour and wrestled with what the next phase of his career would be. So, naturally, Mr. OBrien did what anyone else would do during a frightening, life-altering and already highly public moment of truth: he invited a director to make a movie about him.

title: Student Crossword | Women in STEM Fields
description: Learn about women in whats come to be known as STEM  the fields of science, technology, engineering and math  by playing our new Student Crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Design for Good | Joy of Living
description: Before she died of breast cancer in 1995 at the age of 53, the garden designer and connoisseur Maggie Keswick Jencks helped lay the groundwork for a network of cancer care centers, now called Maggies Cancer Caring Centers, that put the patient first. Designed by architects like Zaha Hadid, Frank Gehry and Richard Rogers, the centers (which are mostly in Britain) offer free medical and psychological support in settings that are the antithesis of most hospitals cold and confusing institutional interiors.

title: Polar Ice Loss Is Accelerating, Scientists Say
description: One of the largest challenges in climate science is determining how the great ice sheets over Greenland and Antarctica will respond to the increase in temperatures expected from rising concentrations of heat-trapping emissions in the atmosphere.

title: Economic Blind Spots, Left and Right
description: Tyler Cowen had two posts at Marginal Revolution this week listing what he believed were the common sins of left-wing economists and right-wing economists. Kevin Drum then offered a point-by-point response to the lefts list, which in turn inspired this post.

title: Union Bill Is Law, but Debate Is Far From Over
description: MADISON, Wis.  Gov. Scott Walker on Friday signed into law a bill that limits bargaining rights for most government workers, ending a rancorous legislative battle but doing little to stem a loud and continuing debate  here and around the country  over the future of unions.

title: Zumthor Rising
description: Some of the works that have left the Swiss architects mark on Europe.

title: The Ascension of Peter Zumthor
description: Over lunch in Los Angeles some months ago, with the actor Tobey Maguire and his wife, Jennifer Meyer, Peter Zumthor was imperious, charming and a little reserved, as usual. The Swiss architect was in town to discuss a new design for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, and Maguire and Meyer had invited him out to persuade him to build a house for them. Having long avoided commissions for houses for the rich and famous, Zumthor, now 67, lately concluded that it might be nice to put aside a little nest egg. Besides, he could imagine leaving a mark on a city where plenty of other great architects had worked. So when coffee arrived, he promised to take a look at the property but asked that Maguire and Meyer make a tour of his work in Europe and afterward visit him at his studio in Haldenstein to talk about what they saw. Then he would decide if he could design their house  whether, in effect, they could be his clients.

title: California and Hawaii Escape Major Damage
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A tsunami emanating from the massive earthquake that hit Japan on Friday sent seven-foot waves into the Hawaiian islands, but appeared to have caused no major damage in Hawaii or along the West Coast.

title: How Shifting Plates Caused the Earthquake and Tsunami in Japan
description: Diagram and maps showing what caused the Japan earthquake and tsunami.

title: Top Notes That Shatter The Glass Ceiling
description: AFTER performing in a high school music competition, Lawrence Brownlee was approached by an audience member who suggested he sing opera. Mr. Brownlee, who had had no exposure to classical music growing up, responded: Me, opera? Are you crazy?

title: Sympathy for Japan, and Admiration
description: Our hearts are all with the Japanese today, after the terrible earthquake there  the worst ever recorded in Japan. But, having covered the 1995 Kobe earthquake (which killed more than 6,000 people and left 300,000 homeless) when I lived in Japan as Tokyo bureau chief for The New York Times, I have to add: Watch Japan in the coming days and weeks, and I bet we can also learn some lessons.

description: ATLANTA

title: Cocktails at M. Wells
description: M. Wells, the diner in Long Island City, Queens, serving Qubcois culinary inventions, will begin pouring cocktails with dinner on March 15, with a separate brunch cocktail menu to follow.

title: Hyundai Equus: Impersonating a Lexus at the Luxury-Car Ball
description: FOR top luxury cars, theres an old saw about prices: if you have to ask, you cant afford it. Hyundai clearly feels theres no harm in asking, especially in a shaky economy. How else to explain the Equus, its new priced-to-sell luxury sedan?

title: Searching for New Tech at South by Southwest
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Were here on the ground in Austin South by Southwest Interactive, the annual gathering of tech enthusiasts, entrepreneurs, investors and leaders in the industry.

title: Geneva Park in Limbo as Citys Loyalties Conflict
description: GENEVA  As this compact Swiss city pushes to enhance its reputation as a host for international organizations, there are likely to be some local casualties. In fact, there may already be one.

title: Kia Optimas Are Recalled to Prevent Rolling-Away Problem
description: About four years after learning that an automatic-transmission gear selector in Park position may not prevent a roll-away crash, Kia is recalling about 70,000 Optima sedans from 2006-8.

title: Blockbuster and the Pushback by Unsecured Creditors
description: Blockbusters fight to stay in Chapter 11 may represent another round in the pushback against aggressive secured lenders and the increasing use of quick 363 sale in place of traditional Chapter 11 plans.

title: Dear FloFab: Can My Boyfriend Learn to Like Vegetables?
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Wives and Money
description: Eilene Zimmerman was a financial expert  except when it came to her own finances.

title: Chinese Government Gives Approval for Dylan Performance
description: The Chinese government has given Bob Dylan official approval to perform in Beijing, The Associated Press reported. Gehua Live Nation, the concert organizers, said last week that Mr. Dylan would perform at the Workers Gymnasium in Beijing on April 6 and the Shanghai Grand Stage on April 8, while he is on an Asian and Australian tour. The Ministry of Culture, according to The Associated Press, on Thursday gave a nod for the Beijing concert, but there was no word yet on Shanghai. Neither concert was listed as of Friday morning on Mr. Dylans Web site. A previously planned visit to China, scheduled for last spring, fell through.

title: Gangs of New York
description: Fashion warriors come out to play. See interactive slide show >>

title: Japans Strict Building Codes Saved Lives
description: Hidden inside the skeletons of high-rise towers, extra steel bracing, giant rubber pads and embedded hydraulic shock absorbers make modern Japanese buildings among the sturdiest in the world during a major earthquake. And all along the Japanese coast, tsunami warning signs, towering seawalls and well-marked escape routes offer some protection from walls of water.

title: Obama Rejects Republican Criticism on Energy
description: 1:37 p.m. | Updated President Obama on Friday rejected criticism from Republicans that his administration was blocking domestic oil production and said his government was prepared to encourage new drilling in the face of rising gas prices.

title: Teaching Ideas: The Earthquake and Tsunami in Japan
description: 10:25 a.m. March 21| Updated

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of The Timess Dining section.

title: Congressional Hearing Puts Muslim Civil Rights Group in the Hot Seat Again
description: WASHINGTON  At Thursdays contentious Congressional hearing on radicalization in the American Islamic community, one Muslim advocacy group became a repeated target for damning accusations from Republicans: the Council on American-Islamic Relations, or CAIR.

title: Muslims on Capitol Hill Find Hearings Dispiriting
description: One otherwise innocuous day of his childhood, Suhail A. Khan clicked the family television onto an episode of Schoolhouse Rock. The screen filled with a drawing of the Capitol in Washington, the American flag flapping above the portico. On the steps hunched a rolled-up piece of paper that, in cartoon style, had limbs, a face and a voice.

title: The Ascent of the Little Guys
description: THE A in A.C. Lawrence & Company stands for Anthony, as in Anthony DeGrotta, who co-founded this upstart real estate firm in 2006. The C doesnt stand for anything  Mr. DeGrotta and his partner, Larry Friedman, just thought it sounded good. Lawrence is for Mr. Friedman, even though his name isnt Lawrence; it really is just Larry. The overall effect that the now-35-year-old co-founders were striving for is a name that suggests experience, longevity and venerability.

title: Volvo Drives Campaign on YouTube
description: For a car that is sold on being safe, Volvo rarely plays it safe when it comes to advertising, as demonstrated by a campaign to get under way on Saturday.

title: Ricardian Confusions, Continued (Seriously Wonkish)
description: I wrote yesterday about the sad persistence of misunderstanding, on the part of Ricardian equivalence types, of how their own models work. Nick Rowe has a critique of my critique, in which he makes a good point about measuring output. But I think hes answering the wrong question, or at any rate not the question both the Ricardian misunderstanders and I am trying to answer.

title: Clips of the Earthquake and Tsunami
description: Footage of the devastation from an 8.9. magnitude earthquake and tsunami which struck Japan Friday. The quake was centered off the Pacific coast of Japan, near the city of Sendai.

title: State Dept. Releases Travel Alert for Japan
description: The United States State Department has released a travel alert for Japan, warning American citizens to avoid travel to that country for the next few weeks, after an 8.9-magnitude earthquake struck off the Japanese coast on Friday, followed by a devastating tsunami. The alert expires on April 1. It reads, in part:

title: 2011 Hyundai Equus
description: Big spenders can feel like big savers if they choose the Hyundai Equus.

title: Despite Foreshock, No Way to Anticipate Japans Great Quake
description: .[1:50 p.m. | Updated below  with an excerpt from a post I did about 24 hours before the quake struck, musing on how humans dont do well with several kinds of risk, including the risk attending rare, but potent earthquakes. Japan is a best case because it has three vital things: wealth, technological skill and sufficiently frequent seismic activity to boost political will to invest against the worst case. The Pacific Northwest has two out of three, which isnt evidently good enough.]

title: The Rationing Switcheroo
description: One thing that should be obvious about death panel arguments a la Huckabee  but which I havent seen pointed out  is the game of three-card monte that goes on over what it means to ration health care.

title: Japan Orders Evacuation Near 2nd Nuclear Plant
description: WASHINGTON  Japanese officials issued broad evacuation orders on Saturday for people living near two nuclear power plants whose cooling systems broke down as a result of the earthquake. The officials warned that small amounts of radioactive material were likely to leak from the plants.

title: Montreal Symphony Orchestra Announces Inaugural Concerts at New Hall
description: Celebrate the local, and then the universal. That is how the Montreal Symphony Orchestra plans to mark the opening of its new concert hall in September. The orchestra late Thursday announced its inaugural concerts at the hall, which is due for completion this spring and has yet to be named. The opening program, to be performed Sept. 7, 9 and 10, will begin with works by three Qubcois composers, Claude Vivier, Gilles Tremblay and Julien Bilodeau, and finish with Beethovens Symphony No. 9. The orchestras music director, Kent Nagano, will conduct. He will also lead a childrens concert as part of the opening festivities. The Borodin Quartet, the New York Philharmonic and the Mariinsky Orchestra are also scheduled to visit in the opening months.

title: Bronx River Parkway, 9:45 A.M.
description: The floods that inundated the citys northern and western suburbs also shut down the Bronx River Parkway on Friday morning. It remained closed near East Gun Hill Road at 11:50 a.m. The Henry Hudson Parkway and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan were closed for a while, too, but have reopened. The Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers  see below  wasnt looking so hot, either.

title: Habitats | Ditmas Park West, Brooklyn
description: Bennett and Gretchen Fischer were drawn to the Ditmas Park West neighborhood of Brooklyn, where they live with their three daughters today.

title: Happenstance House
description: BACK in 1979, when Bennett Fischer moved to New York for a college internship in theater, he educated himself about the city in an energetic way.

title: As N.F.L. Talks Fail, 11 Season Seems in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON  The National Football League, which last year had revenues of more than $9 billion as Americas most popular sport, was plunged into deep uncertainty Friday when negotiations between owners and players for a new contract broke off. At 12:01 a.m. Saturday, the owners locked out the players to create the games first work stoppage since 1987 and imperil the 2011 regular season.

title: Daisys Green Light Fades to Black
description: If you have a soft spot for real places that may have inspired literary masterpieces, and if you happen to have $30 million or so burning a hole in your pocket, maybe its not too late to save a relic from the Gilded Age. Lands End, the turn-of-the-century mansion thought by some to be the model for Tom and Daisys house in The Great Gatsby, is slated to be razed, and the 13-acre estate in Sands Point, N.Y., is going to be divvied up and turned into a development of five $10 million homes.

title: Expatriate Games
description: For seven years, Josh Winters partied with the Mideast elite and lived to tell about it.

title: The N.H.L. Shrugs
description: In the race for biggest kerfuffle in sports these days, its hard to pick a winner. Theres the N.F.L. labor scuffle, of course, which gives us the daily opportunity to watch league and union lawyers howl at the moon. The N.B.A. has the Miami Heat, who even in victory just seem to be setting up their next ridiculous melodrama. Even amid all the charm of college basketballs conference tournaments, you have Big East referees pulling themselves from the tournament for botching a game, which feels suspiciously like foreshadowing (cue ominous music) for the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: A Thaw in the Condo Market
description: LAST month a few strong blips indicated a quickening pulse on the New Jersey condominium market. Or maybe just a pulse.

title: Gergiev Cancels Another Performance
description: The conductor Valery Gergiev continues to suffer from exhaustion and has canceled yet another performance at the Metropolitan Opera, the company quoted his manager as saying. Mr. Gergiev missed Wednesdays performance of Boris Godunov and was to return for Saturdays matinee. But according to his manager on Friday, the conductor was unable to travel to New York due to exhaustion. His manager added:  He has been resting in St. Petersburg and will remain at home to recuperate. He has been advised by his doctors not to fly. Pavel Smelkov, who took over for Mr. Gergiev on Wednesday, was assigned to conduct on Saturday, the Met said.

title: Going Vegan for Lent
description: This week marks the beginning of Lent, when many of us choose to abstain from meat or dairy products  making this the perfect time to try new vegan dishes, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: At Amelia Island Concours, a Show With Fewer Formalities
description: HIGH-END car shows, known to the cognoscenti as concours dlgance, can be as formulaic as romantic comedies. But instead of predictable happy endings, concours all seem to have a lush golf course, obsessively shiny old cars and officious judges in blazers and funny hats. The level of seriousness at most concours makes the staid Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show look like a Judd Apatow film by comparison.

title: The Big Easts Momentum Men
description: Winning  especially in the post season  is all about gaining and sustaining momentum.

title: The S.E.C. Under Fire
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is being scrutinized over both its handling of a former general counsel with a financial interest in a Bernard L. Madoff fund and its filing against a potential witness in the insider trading prosecution of Raj Rajaratnam.

title: Aftermath of the Earthquake in Japan
description: Tokyo bureau chief Martin Fackler reports on the huge earthquake and tsunami that hit Japan.

title: Picking Winners in the Fall Horse Race
description: It helps to see a lot of clothes over the years to know the ones you like in a new season. Thats what I say when people ask how editors and writers can remember what they have seen over nearly a month of shows. I essentially keep two mental lists, one for the clothes I personally love and the other for looks I think will be relevant. Inevitably, there is some overlap.

title: Lowes Seat Grows Hotter at North Carolina State
description: North Carolina State Coach Sidney Lowe tried everything Thursday to bring good luck to his team in the A.C.C. tournament. He wore his bright red sports jacket, complimented by a black and white striped tie, to invoke the schools colors.

title: Buicks Gas-Saving Strategy
description: THE Energy Department calculates that 17.2 percent of a vehicles fuel is consumed when its engine idles in traffic, adding up to billions of gallons burned at stop signs and traffic lights and in urban congestion. Put another way, 69 cents worth of a $4 gallon is wasted by idling.

title: Go v. Glo: Dentist Wins Round in Whitening War
description: A man whom some might call a dentist to the stars can  er  smile easy after a judge ruled this week that he can essentially go forward with his business for now.

title: One Posture at a Time
description: Jeanne Heaton recalls her journey from addiction to her new life as a yoga instructor.

title: Teacher: Experience Needed
description: ITS 10:30 a.m. on a Monday, the seventh week of a nine-week Bikram yoga teacher training course. I am lying face down on my smelly mat and I feel my will escaping. The tent is hot: 120 degrees. I cant breathe. My head hurts. My legs hurt. I feel old and broken. Bikram Choudhury is yelling from his giant podium, one merciless correction after another. Miss Black and Blue! You lazy! I hate lazy people. Im all the way in the back, Row 10, among 376 trainees. Surely he cant be talking to me. Is he talking to me?

title: Alfred Brittain, Who Reshaped Bankers Trust, Dies at 88
description: Alfred Brittain 3d, who reshaped the giant Bankers Trust New York Corporation as its chairman and chief executive in the 1970s and 80s, died last Saturday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 88.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Life on the Reservation
description: Volume 7 of Scalped, about South Dakotas fictional Prairie Rose Indian Reservation, arrives at No. 3 on our softcover list this week. The series is about Dashiell Bad Horse, who left the reservation as a teenager and returns as an undercover agent for the F.B.I. The mission is to bring down Lincoln Red Crow, a corrupt casino owner. Twisted family dynamics and assorted conflicting loyalties make it all the harder to accomplish. Volume 6 of the series landed at No. 5 on the softcover list in June.

title: Angry Birds and Its New Nest Egg
description: AUSTIN, Texas  Angry Birds, the wildly popular game for mobile devices that challenges players to sling grumpy birds at complex formations of smirking pigs, has close to 100 million downloads and a flourishing line of merchandise like cute plush toys.

title: Correcting Premium Crossword Issues
