description: 6:10 p.m. | Updated  The home-delivery/online problems have been corrected, but if youre still having problems accessing your premium puzzles, try this: (1) Log out of nytimes.com, on the top right next to your username (2) Log in  again, adding your password. You should have access to the puzzles. If that doesnt work, then try e-mailing crosswords@nyt.com.

title: In Tokyo, the Search for Solid Ground
description: TOKYO  I looked at my co-workers and then dove for cover. I thought thats what one did during an earthquake. But no matter how I contorted my 63 frame, my legs jutted out from under my child-sized desk. The shaking lasted a long time. I prayed it would end, hoped it wouldnt get worse. To calm myself, I thought about my niece and nephew back in Maryland.

title: Picture Books for Little Princesses
description: Little girls attraction to all things pink seems encoded in their DNA, as inevitable to their development as, say, learning to sit up or typing with their thumbs. Few parents realize it has not always been thus. A century or so ago, when colors first entered the nursery, pink  which was considered a pastel version of red  was seen as a masculine hue, while blue, with its intimation of the Virgin Mary was designated feminine. As late as the 1930s, 25 percent of customers in a survey conducted by Lord & Taylor still held to this pink-blue divide.

title: A Closer Look at the Damage From the Earthquake and Tsunami in Japan
description: Zoom in on images and examine scenes of the destruction in Japan.

title: The Teenage Sherlock Holmes
description: By the time were 14, most of us have few accomplishments to our name: passing algebra, playing goalie on a soccer team, stealing a first kiss, if were lucky. That about covers it. Meanwhile, in Death Cloud, by Andrew Lane, Sherlock Holmes has managed, at the age of 14, to quell a possible outbreak of bubonic plague, duel a French baron and win the affections of a rambunctious American girl.

title: Volvo Drives Augmented-Reality Ad Campaign on YouTube
description: From our colleagues at Media Decoder:

title: Doctors Detail Giffordss Progress
description: HOUSTON  Representative Gabrielle Giffords is making leaps and bounds in her neurological recovery after being shot in the head on Jan. 8 in Tucson, her doctors said Friday at a news conference.

title: Misadventures of a Teen Showgirl
description: Part of what makes the teenage years so fascinating, and so full of trepidation, for both teenagers and the adults involved in their lives, is that ethical codes are still in in their larval form and, very much in flux. As she did in her National Book Award-winning What I Saw and How I Lied (2008), in Strings Attached Judy Blundell offers another noirish thriller in which teenagers uncover the questionable actions of their elders and learn to form their own judgments.

title: Living In | Bay Ridge, Brooklyn
description: The omnipresent Verrazano-Narrows Bridge is a hallmark of Bay Ridge. Though co-ops are available, the housing landscape in this waterside neighborhood consists largely of single-family homes, among them colorful arrays of row houses.

title: App Smart Extra: New Apps for Guitarists
description: In a recent App Smart column, I highlighted apps for guitarists who want an alternative to a crate full of effects pedals. Since then, one of the leading developers of guitar-related software, IK Multimedia, has introduced a new app, AmpliTube Fender ($15 for iPhone and iPad), which should make the short list of any guitar player.

title: Youll Notice Theres a Bridge
description: THE Verrazano-Narrows Bridge is inescapable in Bay Ridge, its lofty silhouette a constant presence on block after block.

title: Hospitals With Robots Do More Prostate Cancer Surgery
description: Hospitals that buy surgical robots end up performing more prostate cancer operations, suggesting that technology has become a driving force behind decisions about mens cancer care, new research shows.

title: Ivy Champions to Settle Score at Yale
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  After a practice this week, Harvard guard Christian Webster pondered his teams assignment in Saturdays one-game playoff against Princeton to decide which team will receive the Ivy Leagues automatic berth to the N.C.A.A. tournament. In the spirit of impartiality, the game has been moved to a neutral site: Yale.

title: Little Big Man
description: Tim Lincecum, the diminutive power pitcher known variously as Seabiscuit, Tiny Tim and, most memorably, the Freak, slid behind the wheel of his silver Mercedes-Benz on a recent afternoon, sipping a Red Bull. His hair, which he hadnt cut since leading the San Francisco Giants to their first World Series in more than 50 years  and didnt intend to cut anytime soon unless his manager, Bruce Bochy, ordered otherwise  was pulled back into a ponytail. A mustache, if the underseeded patch of grass beneath his nose could be called that, had sprouted up during the off-season, giving him the aspect of a teenager trying to avoid getting carded.

title: Mr. Chartwell
description: Chapter 1

title: The Social Animal
description: Chapter 1

title: Inside the List
description: GNOMES AND UNKNOWNS: Thirty-five years ago, America was invaded by an army of tiny, ostensibly friendly eco-warriors in conical red hats. Their folkways were recounted in Gnomes, written by the Dutch doctor and childrens author Wil Huygen and illustrated with loving, Norman Rockwell-meets-J. R. R. Tolkien watercolors by Rien Poortvliet. The book sold more than a million copies and spent 56 weeks on the hardcover list before the little creatures crawled back under our collective Pet Rock. Now, an anniversary edition, published on April 1, aims to enlighten a new generation with its accounts of gnome biology (they weigh 300 grams and live an average of 400 years), gnome customs (they greet each other by rubbing noses and maintain friendly relations with rabbits) and gnome sex (which always results in twins, who live at home until age 100).

title: Is the Imperial Presidency Inevitable?
description: In The Executive Unbound, Eric A. Posner and Adrian Vermeule, law professors at Chicago and Harvard, respectively, offer with somewhat alarming confidence the Weimar and Nazi jurist Carl Schmitt as their candidate to succeed James Madison for the honor of theorist of the Constitution.

title: Maxine Hong Kingstons Life in Verse
description: Why would anyone want to be a poet? If that question seems too broad (or too harsh), lets try a more modest one: Why would someone whos already mastered an art form that is vastly more influential and lucrative than poetry  fiction or songwriting, for example  want to be a poet? The most famous poets arent famous, the richest poets arent rich, and not even the best-loved poets will ever enjoy the devotion inspired by Barbara Kingsolver, let alone Lady Gaga. So when a superstar from another arena turns his or her attention to poetry, the result can be like watching the Super Bowl M.V.P. forgo an entire season to devote himself to foosball. Why, one wonders, is this person bothering?

title: A Mythic Novel of the Balkan Wars
description: Think back to the wars of the 1990s in the former Yugoslavia, with their profusion of names that are difficult to pronounce and acts that are painful to recall: the massacres at Brcko and Srebrenica, the bombing of bread lines in Sarajevo, the destruction of Mostars 400-year-old bridge.

title: Gabrielle Hamilton, Cooking With Words
description: Its hard to think of another American chef who has outdone Gabrielle Hamilton in converting the humblest of stages into the heftiest of reputations. The restaurant she opened in downtown Manhattan in 1999, Prune, has barely enough room for the 30 diners it squeezes in at brunch, lunch and dinner, and despite the reliable presence of dozens of additional customers waiting on the sidewalk, she has either escaped or resisted the itch for expansion that so many of her contemporaries scratch and scratch. Prune has no annex or uptown sibling; there is no Prune Dubai. Just this one cramped, irresistible nook with its scuffed floors, nicked tables and servers in pink.

title: How to Memorize Everything
description: When we meet Joshua Foer, his memory is nothing special. A year later, he is able to memorize the order of a shuffled deck of cards in less than two minutes and the names of 99 people hes just met. He has also etched in his brain images of his friend urinating on Pope Benedicts skullcap, of Rhea Perlman involved in indelicate acts with Manute Bol, and of other things most of us would try hard to forget. Let it never be claimed that there is no cost to self-improvement.

title: Childrens Bookshelf
description: I MUST HAVE BOBO! By Eileen Rosenthal Illustrated by Marc Rosenthal Unpaged. Atheneum. $14.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

title: David Brookss Theory of Human Nature
description: Readers of his Op-Ed column in The New York Times know that David Brooks is an aficionado of research in the social sciences, especially psychology, and that he believes it has great practical importance. Now he has written a book, The Social Animal, in order to assemble the evidence for a certain conception of the human mind, the wellsprings of action and the causes of success and failure in life, and to draw implications for social policy. The book is really a moral and social tract, but Brooks has hung it on the life stories of two imaginary people, Harold and Erica, who are used to illustrate his theory in detail and to provide the occasion for countless references to the psychological literature and frequent disquisitions on human nature and society.

title: Churchill, Depression and a Talking Dog
description: Every few years, there appear in most countries books that reveal the dirty truth about the national readership. France has recently given us The Kindly Ones and The Elegance of the Hedgehog  the first distasteful, the other pretentious, and both eagerly embraced by a readership keen to be chastened for its middle-class pieties. Americans, meanwhile, have rhapsodized about and then violently rejected a series of fake memoirs, suggesting we find greater cultural currency in creative misbehavior than in literary skill, or at best seriously conflate the two.

title: Editors Choice
description: MY FATHERS FORTUNE: A Life,  by Michael Frayn (Metropolitan/Holt, $25.) Forty years after his fathers death, the British novelist and playwright recalls the dignified restraint that embodied their complicated relationship.

title: A Trophy Wifes Tale
description: The archetypal American private eye is a good man who atones for his bad deeds by performing selfless acts of courage on behalf of others. Walter Mosley started Leonid McGill on that existential journey in The Long Fall by providing his New York P.I. with a murky history as a mob fixer. WHEN THE THRILL IS GONE (Riverhead, $26.95) finds McGill three books into the series but unable to shake his underworld connections  as a personal favor hes undertaking a search for the lost friend of a powerful crime boss. But there are other pressing matters to be taken care of: a man who has been like a father to him lies dying in McGills apartment, McGills wife is sleeping with a man half her age and if McGill doesnt get a paying job he wont be able to pay the rent on his office. (And those were just the devils I knew.)

title: Paperback Row
description: MAKING TOAST: A Family Story,  by Roger Rosenblatt (Ecco/HarperCollins, $12.99.) When Rosenblatts daughter, a pediatrician and mother of three, died suddenly in 2007 of a rare undetected heart disorder, the author and his wife picked up their life on Long Island and moved to Maryland to become co-parents with their son-in-law. This lovely memoir is written as a series of vignettes, some contemplative, others in the form of simple notes (Whats Jessies favorite winter jacket? The blue not the pink, though pink is her favorite color).

title: What Harlem Is and Was
description: About midway through Sharifa Rhodes-Pittss slim, enchanting volume we are introduced to rather an odd figure, L. S. Alexander Gumby, proprietor of the Gumby Book Studio and motive force behind a 1920s Harlem-based literary salon. The studio and salon both evolved, Rhodes-Pitts explains, out of Gumbys singular passion for scrapbooking  his impulse to compile, collect and curate the detritus of his reality. Gumbys efforts ultimately produced an apartments worth of materials about the so-called black experience, culminating, we are told, in a brilliant and strange production. These words well describe Rhodes-Pitts own achievement in Harlem Is Nowhere. Her happily disparate text blends the historical and the personal, the exceptional and the ordinary, adroitly communicating the multiplicity of Harlem itself.

title: A Dystopian Tale of Russias Future
description: Russias future is medieval.

title: Taking a Plan and Making It a Park
description: Our colleagues at the Brooklyn Local featured this video from the Department of Parks and Recreation on Friday morning in which Emanuel Thingu, a senior landscape architect for the parks department, walks through the very cheery playground at South Oxford Park in Fort Greene and explains how it came to be (a story he also shared with Times columnist Jim Dwyer in 2007). Mr. Thingu was one of six city employees honored with Sloan Public Service Awards on Thursday.

title: Wheelies: Japan Earthquake Disrupts Vehicle Production
description: The 8.9-magnitude earthquake that struck Japan on Friday caused significant disruption to the countrys automotive sector. Wheels will update this list as we learn more.

title: Fashion Week Favorites
description: Cathy Horyns picks from the fall 2011 New York, Milan and Paris collections.

title: When Mister Rogers Went to Washington
description: Love or hate public television and radio, this footage of Fred Rogers, a k a Mister Rogers, testifying at a Senate hearing in 1969 to defend the $20 million budget for the newly formed Corporation for Public Broadcasting is utterly stirring.

title: Valero to Buy Chevron British Refinery and Assets
description: Valero Energy agreed on Friday to buy Chevrons refinery in Pembroke, Wales, for $730 million and other related assets for about $1 billion.

title: Verizon Clarifies iPad Activation Fees
description: When I was writing my review of the iPad 2, I was trying to get straight the pricing plans for the WiFi/3G iPad version. As I noted in the column, the beauty of these plans is that theres no two-year contract needed. You can start and stop the cellular service (and pay for it) on a month-by-month basis, as you need it. I just wanted to find out the prices.

title: Layoffs at All-Time Low, but Still 5 Unemployed for Every Job Opening
description: 3:16 p.m. | Updated  to add comment from JPMorgan analyst.

title: Small Realtors Hold Their Own
description: AGAINST a backdrop of mergers, acquisitions and reshuffling among corporate real estate brokerages, independent agencies have maintained a strong presence in Westchester, the poor housing market notwithstanding.

title: Gates Visits Bahrain Amid Huge Protests
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  As security forces and pro-government vigilantes beat back protesters here, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived Friday on an unannounced visit to offer American support to the royal family and prod the king and the crown prince toward talks with protesters demanding more democracy.

title: Artspace Opens New Rental Building in Patchogue
description: Patchogue

title: Up Front: Childrens Books
description: Readers of the Web version of the Book Review may have noticed a new feature, an online-only review of a new picture book each week, supplementing  but not replacing  our print coverage, to quote Pamela Paul, the Book Reviews new childrens books editor. Paul, who had the idea, will be writing the reviews herself.

title: Book Review Podcast: Joshua Foer
description: This week, Joshua Foer discusses his book, Moonwalking With Einstein; Frank Bruni talks about the chef Gabrielle Hamiltons memoir, Blood, Bones and Butter; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: A Lamp Too Good to Be True
description: I HATE you, Violette V.

title: Away From Japan, Tsunamis Effect Is Diffuse
description: The powerful earthquake that struck off the coast of Japan on Friday set off tsunami warnings around the Pacific Rim, including in Hawaii and California, but the vast majority of destructive flooding occurred in Japan itself, in the area nearest the quakes epicenter.

title: 99 Cents Joins Low-Cost Retailers on Sales Rack
description: Apparently there is a blue-light special on low-cost retailers, as 99 Cents Only Stores disclosed on Friday that it had received a $1.3 billion takeover offer from Leonard Green & Partners and the companys founding family.

title: Big Deal | Woolworth Opulence for $90 Million
description: The market for multimillion-dollar residences has picked up lately, but you dont see this very often: a mansion built in the early 1900s for a daughter of the dime store magnate Frank Winfield Woolworth is being put up for sale for $90 million. It can also be rented, for $210,000 per month.

title: Gang Rape Story Lacked Balance
description: The story quickly climbed The Timess most emailed list but not just because of the sensational facts of the crime involved. Vicious Assault Shakes Texas Town, published on Tuesday, reported the gang rape by 18 boys and men of an 11-year-old girl in the East Texas town of Cleveland.

title: U.S.O.C. Officials Make Headway Internationally
description: Both the chairman and chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee were named to two influential commissions of the International Olympic Committee on Friday, a development that indicates their efforts to rebuild relationships with the international body are paying off.

title: When to Buy or Sell? Dont Trust Your Instincts
description: ANYONE watching television commercials could easily conclude that trading stocks is something a baby can do from a crib. But new research into 17 years of call records at a boutique investment adviser shows that the baby in all of us is likely to buy or sell at the worst possible time.

title: Decisions, Decisions
description: AMANDA HEARST, 27, is an associate market editor and a blogger at Marie Claire magazine, one of the publications of the Hearst Corporation, which was founded by Amandas great-grandfather, William Randolph Hearst. She lives in the West Village and is active on the boards of several charities. CHLOE MALLE

title: The Last Boho Standing
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#95", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Miami Won, but Nothing Has Changed
description: Five straight Heat losses were read as a sign of the apocalypse in Miami, but just when things seemed their most dire, the central characters banded together to reverse their collective fate. They pulled themselves up by their bootstraps, offered a few inspiring words and one-liners, and set off to save themselves and the world around them in most epic fashion.

title: Carolyn Wonderland and Whitney Brown
description: WE said 4:44, and we meant 4:44, Michael Nesmith, the wedding officiant, said with mock insistence before about 125 guests on March 4 in Butler Park, which looks out at the Austin, Tex., skyline.

title: Cultural Connoisseurs
description: To the Editor:

title: Misunderstood Firebrand
description: To the Editor:

title: A Year to Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wrong War
description: To the Editor:

title: Defining Blackness
description: To the Editor:

title: Schumacher Fastest in Barcelona, and a Season Preview
description: Well, there we go. Just what we love about winter testing: After weeks of doomsaying  even from the Mercedes team itself  Michael Schumacher set the fastest time during testing in Barcelona on Friday, and his teammate, Nico Rosberg, set the third-fastest time. Fernando Alonso set the second-fastest time, .3 seconds from Schumacher, and Nick Heidfeld had the fourth fastest time in the Lotus Renault.

title: Schumacher Fastest in Barcelona, and a Season Preview
description: Well, there we go. Just what we love about winter testing: After weeks of doomsaying  even from the Mercedes team itself  Michael Schumacher set the fastest time during testing in Barcelona on Friday, and his teammate, Nico Rosberg, set the third-fastest time. Fernando Alonso set the second-fastest time, .3 seconds from Schumacher, and Nick Heidfeld had the fourth fastest time in the Lotus Renault.

title: Its Just Fine to Make Mistakes
description: WE all know that old saw that nothing in life is certain except death and taxes. We should probably add mistakes to that category. More than three years ago, I wrote a column about mistakes and my regret about making an error in an article. I asked why we are taught when young that everyone makes mistakes, but as we grow older, were more often punished for making mistakes.

title: Smithsonians Controversial Show May Come to Brooklyn Museum and Tacoma Art Museum
description: The controversial National Portrait Gallery exhibition Hide/Seek may come to the Brooklyn Museum, the museums spokeswoman, Sally Williams, said on Friday. The show, which examined gay and lesbian themes in American portraiture, won critical praise when it opened in October but later drew attacks from Republicans and religious conservatives over a video that included an image of ants crawling on a plastic crucifix. In response, the Smithsonian Institution removed the video from the show, prompting accusations of censorship and moving dozens of museums across the country to display the video and other works by the artist, David Wojnarowicz, in protest. Hide/Seek closed last month, but now the Brooklyn Museum and the Tacoma Art Museum in Washington State are collaborating to reconstitute it, Rock Hushka, the director of curatorial administration at the Tacoma museum, said. Mr. Hushka said that the planning was on a fast track, with an eye to the exhibition possibly opening in Brooklyn before the end of the year, and eventually going to Tacoma.

title: Borrowing Again, but Less on Credit Cards
description: AMERICAN consumers are borrowing again, but many are still reluctant to run up credit card debts.

title: Igawa Leaves Yankees After Earthquake Strikes Japan
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The effects of the devastation in Japan were felt in Yankees camp Friday morning, when the minor league left-hander Kei Igawa left the complex so he could try to locate his family. Igawa is from Oarai, Ibaraki prefecture, which was ravaged by a tsunami caused by the 8.9-magnitude earthquake, the strongest to strike Japan. According to photographs, Oarai is partly submerged. If Igawa wants to fly home, General Manager Brian Cashman said he could, no doubt about it.

title: In Milan, Boutiques Display Goods and Creativity
description: The Isola section of Milan is attracting its share of artists, designers and young, newly married couples. Along with this shift, a homegrown boutique scene is emerging.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: IN THE FRENCH ALPS

title: Restaurant Review: At Klub Gastronomada, Regional Croatian Food
description: The three owners of Klub Gastronomada wear two hats. The first has them as consulting food purveyors and growers in and around Croatia. But they also experiment with dishes in a sort of culinary laboratory; membership to the Klub gives regulars access to dinners with specially designed menus. But the restaurant proper, which opened in 2009, is open to all  though it helps to have an interest in the bounty of regional items that, through their consulting work, Gastronomada obtains from around southeastern Europe. Its 30 or so rotating menu items come from a stockpile of more than 250, which have been concocted in the laboratory.

title: Getting Your Own Slice of Prince Williams Wedding
description: THEY have already bought their sapphire-and-diamond engagement rings from the Home Shopping Network, found wedding gowns at local thrift shops and planned their rehearsal dinner and wedding day events. Never mind that Gigi Baay and Marianne Swanson of New Orleans are married with children. The two friends have been planning a celebration of Kate Middleton and Prince Williams nuptials for months. Though neither has an invitation to Westminster Abbey, what they do have are plane tickets to London, where they plan to spend the royal wedding weekend celebrating in regal fashion.

title: Lisbons Culinary Golden Age?
description: TRAVELERS to Lisbon invariably learn at least two Portuguese words. The first is obrigado (thank you). The second is bacalhau. It means cod.

title: Near Salvador, Brazil, a Paradisiacal Place to Disconnect
description: WITH the phone to his ear and a look of exasperation on his face, it was safe to assume that Charles Levitan was chasing yet another would-be guest from his fuss-free collection of whitewashed cottages on Boipeba, a lushly untrammeled island off the coast of Brazil. No, we dont have televisions in the room, he said. No, we only have fans. The impish grin on his face suggested the prospective guest had been satisfactorily dissuaded.

title: Tennessee Williamss 100th Birthday, Marked in Columbus, Miss.
description: DO you know what Spring Pilgrimage is? asked Brenda Caradine, the chairwoman of the Tennessee Williams Birthday Celebration in Columbus, Miss. Its when you Yankees come down South to see our antebellum homes and we take back your money.

title: 14 Easy Weekend Getaways
description: FORGOT to plan for a spring break? Havent gone skiing yet this year? Its March, people!

title: Hotel Review: New Orleans, at the Hotel Le Marais
description: THE BASICS

title: 14 Easy Weekend Getaways
description: From New York to Portland, Ore., (and cities in between), quick trips that can have you poolside  or cliff-diving  in half a day.

title: An Island Paradise Off Brazils Coast
description: Boipeba, a remote island near Salvador, boasts empty palm-shrouded beaches and perfect weather.

title: What Oil Prices Mean for Airfares
description: As the price of crude oil goes up, so goes the airfare.

title: Hangs Ten
description: Kelly Slater leaves every other surfer in his wake.

title: Knicks and Rangers Fans to See Higher Ticket Prices
description: The fruits of Madison Square Gardens three-year renovation will be apparent to Knicks and Rangers fans next season  and so will the prices they will pay for tickets.

title: Italian Flair and American Muscle
description: Palm Beach, Fla.

title: N.B.A. Rescinds Stoudemires Latest Technical Foul
description: For a third time this season, the Knicks Amare Stoudemire received a reprieve from the N.B.A. when it reviewed and expunged his latest technical foul. The decision Friday will allow him to play Sunday against the Indiana Pacers.

title: My Diamond in the Rough
description: MY first old car was a 1940 Ford  picture the convertible that Lumpy Rutherford drove on Leave It to Beaver  found behind Charlies Welding Shop in Rocky Point, Long Island, when I was 14. I paid $25 for the derelict; my father dragged it home.

title: Controlling the Means of Reincarnation
description: Im trying once again to wrap my mind around the idea that an avowedly atheist group (the Chinese Communist Party government) insists on its power to certify reincarnations.

title: Celebrities Bottle Water for Unicef Sweepstakes
description: The fifth year of a campaign from a water charity with roots in Madison Avenue is taking a turn toward the stars.

title: Galleon Wiretap of the Day: Buddy Reviews the Portfolio
description: So just how do those hedge fund titans make so much money? What is their secret sauce? How do they talk? Wouldnt it be great to be able to listen in on their conversations?

title: Royal Exes: Royal Excess or the New Social Norm?
description: IN my opinion, certain things definitely do not belong at a wedding: ivy and spider plants, because both seem so clingy, and clinginess is anathema to romance; white stretch Hummers, because they make one think of war; and ex-paramours of either the bride or bridegroom, because they also make one think of war. An ex at a wedding is like a baby on an airplane: a tearful disturbance of one kind or another seems inevitable.

title: Europeans Reach New Deal to Fight Debt Crisis
description: BRUSSELS  European leaders agreed early Saturday to new measures intended to end the euro zone debt crisis, offering the debt-laden Greece a cut in its interest rate and injecting more flexibility into the way a bolstered bailout fund for the euro can be used.

title: Find a Father and Discover a Rock Star
description: Its one thing to learn, at age 42, who your biological father is. It is another thing altogether to learn that that person is Ted Nugent, the guitar-, gun- and far-right-rhetoric-slinging Motor City Madman. A Brooklyn restaurateur and bar owner, Ted Mann, had that experience recently, and the blog Brooklyn Based has now told his remarkable story. I got to his ranch and he was grilling elk he had shot for me, said Mr. Mann, who owns Cubana Social in Williamsburg and No Name Bar in Greenpoint, among other places. Read it and weep.

title: College Grads, High School Dropouts and Long-Term Unemployment
description: In most things job-related, education matters. Except when it comes to leaving unemployment.

title: Collector Sues Gagosian Gallery for Selling Him a Painting Partially Owned by Met
description: Mark Tanseys 1981 painting The Innocent Eye Test, a crisply realistic rendering of a bunch of experts showing a live cow a crisply realistic portrait of a couple of other cows, has long been seen as a hilarious send-up of the art world.

title: A Media Swarm Awaits Mel Gibson at Court
description: LOS ANGELESAnyone who doubts Mel Gibsons enduring star power had only to check out the crackling tension around the Airport Courthouse of the Los Angeles County Superior Court on Friday.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 11
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Earthquake and Tsunami in Japan: Readers Photos
description: NYTimes.com asked readers to send photographs from areas affected by the earthquake and tsunami. Here is a selection of images.

title: Same As It Ever Was
description: Source.

title: War Dogs
description: At outposts away from the main base, American soldiers and Afghan dogs are drawn to each other. But the human-canine relationships do not always end well.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Tom Stoppard, the Strokes, Bradley Cooper and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section.

title: The Video Q | Juliette Binoche on Certified Copy
description: Though she has never taken the plunge herself, Juliette Binoche hasnt given up on the idea of finding the perfect match, much like the lonely, mercurial gallery owner she plays in Certified Copy, which opens today in New York. The need of marriage is in all of us, the 47-year-old French beauty says in this video interview, below.

title: Charges Dropped in Hamsters Death
description: Updated, 4:57 p.m. | The criminal case has been dropped against a 19-year-old Brooklyn woman who had faced up to two years in prison on charges of killing her little brothers hamster, after family members who witnessed the animals death recanted their accounts, the authorities said.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Bill Falls Short in Maryland
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Lawmakers in Maryland on Friday failed to gather enough votes to pass a bill that would have allowed same-sex couples to marry, withdrawing it from consideration after hours of emotional debate and effectively killing the bills chances for passage this year.

title: Japanese Nuclear Plant in Jeopardy
description: Matthew L. Wald reports on a nuclear plant in the Fukushima region of Japan that faces a state of emergency.

title: Mascot Dogs of American Combat Outposts
description: They leave droppings, are dirty and carry diseases. They are beloved playthings that help break the drudgery of frontline life. They are forbidden. They are commonplace. They are the mascot dogs of American combat outposts in Afghanistan.

title: Tip of the Week: How To Get Your PC To Listen to You
description: If you find typing on a computer keyboard difficult or painful, the built-in speech recognition functions of Windows 7 or Mac OS X may make things easier by allowing you to speak simple commands to control and navigate the system by voice. You do need a working microphone (included with most machines these days) and a bit of patience to learn and say the specific commands the computer expects to hear.

title: Bands Electro Aesthetic Is Reflected by Discoball Smart Car
description: Apparatjik, a pan-European art band based loosely in Berlin, performs avante-garde electro music in giant transparent cubes. Its members dress in costumes made of mirrors. The groups Web site describes the players style as combat-disco  but judging from Apparatjiks new tour vehicle, the battles are waged onstage, not on the road.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Libya, Egypt and Indonesia.

title: To Run or Not to Run?
description: Mitt Romney sure seems to be running; Newt Gingrich and Tim Pawlenty are probably running, too. Palin may run as well, and Obama will run no matter what. Should I?

title: Putin Throws Curveball to Biden With Suggestion on Visas
description: MOSCOW  When Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. sat down for his meeting with Vladimir V. Putin this week, the Russian prime minister opened with a curveball.

title: Boots on the Ground
description: Leon Wieseltier, today:

title: Help for a Disturbed Child
description: You are driving me insane.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Libya, Egypt and Indonesia.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Young chefs have garnered attention lately. Now the 15-year-old chef Greg Grossman joins in on the pop-up restaurant frenzy with a temporary dining room at the Sanctuary Hotel, 132 West 47th Street (between Sixth and Seventh Avenues), Friday and Saturday at 8:30 p.m. The teenage chef plans a four-course menu, $95 (before tax and tip), with a molecular gastronomy theme inspired by artists like Jeff Koons and Roy Lichtenstein.

title: Citrus Salad Variations
description: Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates how to make a simple salad with oranges, grapefruit and a number of other citrus fruits.

title: Mini Mart
description: Fashion mavens arent born, theyre made. Little Edit, the latest shopping destination for the under-7 set, is inside Edit, a designer boutique on the Upper East Side. Stocked with labels like Baby Dior, Marie Chantal, Girl and a Mouse and Maloles, its an ideal place for fledgling fashionistas to cut their sartorial teeth. The space (which opens March 16) also has an exclusive line of handmade baby bijoux by Jamie Wolf, a ballerina turned jeweler who does custom pieces for celebrities like Natalie Portman and Julia Roberts.

title: A Red Flag on Reverse Mortgages
description: It is the saddest of paradoxes: a government-backed financial maneuver intended to free up extra money for struggling older people turns out to have left some widows and widowers on the brink of foreclosure.

title: Friday Prayers in Benghazi
description: After the capture of Ras Lanuf by Qaddafi's forces, the rebels in Benghazi reflect on their loss at Friday prayers.

title: Twilio Powering Mobile Start-Ups at SXSW
description: AUSTIN  If the number of unread text messages on my phone is any indication  60 and counting  group mobile messaging applications like GroupMe, Beluga, Yobongo and FastSociety are quickly gathering steam as one of the breakout technologies to hit the South by Southwest conference.

title: Report Your Reverse Mortgage Experience
description: The problem with writing about reverse mortgages, as I do in this weekends Your Money column, is by the time youre done explaining them in plain English, theres no more room to go through all of the various scenarios in which they do, or do not, make sense.

title: Reviewing the Hyundai Equus
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Equus, Hyundais new luxury sedan. The car seems to be a copy of the Lexus LS 460, but an imperfect one, Mr. Ulrich writes:

title: The Art Worlds Ruling Couple
description: Individually, each is a force to be reckoned with. Together, John Currin and Rachel Feinstein have become the ruling power couple in todays art world.

title: Rachel Feinstein and John Currin, Their Own Best Creations
description: OUTSIDE, there were snowdrifts and icy sidewalks that made getting into Lever House a tricky navigational challenge for the fashionably dressed crowd on this freezing January evening. But once inside the lobby of Lever House, the modernist Park Avenue landmark, the grim reality of a seemingly never-ending New York winter was replaced by a fairy tale world of giant toy soldiers, a garden of red roses and a gaslit golden coach  and a hothouse gathering of some of the citys more notable figures from art, fashion and publishing.

title: Payments to 9/11 Workers Are Off to Slow Start
description: Payments to the 9/11 rescue and cleanup workers who settled their lawsuits with New York City last year are going out on schedule, lawyers for the two sides said, even if thousands of the plaintiffs have yet to see any money.

title: Cesare Siepi Celebration Announced
description: The family of the Metropolitan Opera bass Cesare Siepi is holding a celebration of his life at the Bruno Walter Auditorium on Saturday at 6 p.m. The bass, who sang at the Met from 1950 to 1973, died in July at 87. Speakers are scheduled to include the former Met singer Roberta Peters, Walfredo Toscanini (the conductors grandson) and Siepi family members.

title: Slings and Arrows? Nothing New to Him
description: BEN SHERWOOD, the recently appointed president of ABC News, sat in his New York office one afternoon in February, pitched forward in a mustard-colored armchair that barely contained his 6-foot-4-inch frame, discussing a 1988 profile of him in Spy magazine that still rankles.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 11
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Wisconsin's Public Union Bill
description: The proposal to curtail public workers bargaining rights caused multi-week turmoil in Wisconsins normally polite capitol.

title: Letters
description: A Former Dior Customer

title: Jennifer Egan for the Win
description: This seems bloggable, came an e-mail from an editor at the magazine this morning. The news: Jennifer Egan won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction last night.

title: Look of the Moment | Rihanna
description: The Look: Hot Crop  in season when worn with high-waisted, tailored trousers and heels.

title: The Internet Kept Me Company
description: TOKYO  The first thing I was worried about was where to put my tea. Id been sitting on the heated carpet in my apartment, working on a blog post about Japanese chewing gum. I stood up few seconds after the room started to sway. The TV was jumping. Buildings outside were swaying. A six-foot tall cabinet full of books was rocking. Things were falling in the kitchen and water was sloshing over the edge of the balcony, spilling from something above. I moved out from under the light fixtures and held onto a small table. I wanted to put down my tea cup, but there were no stable surfaces. Things were sliding around the floor.

title: N.F.L. Lockout Q. & A.
description: WASHINGTON  With the union dissolving itself Friday and owners in position to lock players out, the N.F.L. has embarked on its first work stoppage since the players strike in 1987. Prepare for an off-season with no activity on the field, but plenty of news from courtrooms.

title: Market Trading on Impulse
description: Paul Sullivan writes this week about investor behavior. Specifically, he discusses new research, based on 17 years of call records at a boutique investment firm, that found that investors tended to wait until a period of greatest volatility in the markets had passed and then sell at the bottom or buy at the top.

title: The Best Sentence of the Week, Part Deux
description: It is now time for Round 2 in our ongoing weekly social-media blog-fusion smackdown: @Shamblandersons Sentence of the Week. Im not sure how (probably some kind of mathematical paradox), but this week I managed to come up with eight sentences. Lets take them one by one.

title: Big Deal | Susie Essman Puts Her Condo On the Market, Again
description: The tale of Susie Essman and the red couch in her Upper West Side apartment sounds uncannily like an episode of Seinfeld.

title: Protesters March in Yemen
description: On Friday, about 100,000 protesters participated in a sit-in to demand that President Ali Abdullah Saleh step down.

title: Meet the New Ethicist
description: Since my first column as The Ethicist appeared last week, numerous readers have written in to ask who I am, or more specifically, what my ethical qualifications are, what school of thought I adhere to, how I will arrive at my answers and what makes me think Im an ethical person myself.

title: Slavery and Heritage in Charleston
description: Exhibitions in and around the South Carolina city examine slaverys history and legacy.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 11
description: More Photographs

title: Long Gone, but Fighting Hard Not to Be Forgotten
description: Between legend and fact, the world lusts after legend. So says the British intelligence double agent known as Kim Philby in Spy Garbo, nailing the central conceit of this multidisciplinary mashup.

title: Leapin Labels
description: This seasons double-breasted jackets are crazy good. Just ask these laid-back dudes: Chris Del Moro, Erik Ellington, Neal Schofield and Zach Schuringa. See interactive slide show >>

title: No. 7 Train Service Hampered by the Rain
description: Rain-related problems on the No. 7 train line that knocked service for a loop Friday morning will persist throughout the weekend as repair crews work to fix damaged signal equipment, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority says. There will be no service between Times Square and Queensboro Plaza until 10 p.m. tonight, at which point service will be restored on only one track, effectively turning the No. 7 into a very long shuttle train with correspondingly long delays. Customers are encouraged to use the E, F, N or R lines as a substitute.

title: N.F.L., Union Statements on Failure of Negotiations
description: The statements released by the N.F.L. and by the players union after negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement failed Friday. The union has moved to decertify.

title: Ocean-Spanning Power of Japans Great Quake on Display
Networks Rush to Bolster Coverage in Japan
description: Western television networks are playing catch-up in the wake of the massive earthquake and tsunami in northern Japan.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Photographs of business news events and features over the week.

title: The Cunningham C-3 Family Album
description: A glimpse at 14 of the 25 Cunningham C-3 built in the 1950s.

title: Finding the Then in a Suite of Songs From Now
description: The difference in tone between the title of the beloved standard All the Things You Are and that of a 2009 Kelly Clarkson hit says a lot about the gap between then and now in American popular music. That comparison was made on Thursday evening by the gifted young cabaret singer Jennifer Sheehan at the Metropolitan Room, where she presented a smart, far-reaching show, You Made Me Love You: Celebrating 100 Years of the Great American Songbook.

title: Binky and Sheba, Meet Rei
description: I happened to see these new Life in Hell T-shirtsa collaboration between Rei Kawakubo and Matt Groening, the creator of the comic strip and, of course, The Simpsonswhen I was visiting the Comme des Garons showroom in Paris early this week. I thought they were quite sweet and demented, even if you dont love rabbits. The shirts, in four styles, will be available in Comme de Garcons stores after March 15.

title: Courtesans on the Make and Actors on the Move
description: Something strange is happening at the World Financial Center. Its shiny marble floors and shop-studded passageways are being transformed into a series of stages for the New York Classical Theaters production of Aphra Behns 17th-century Restoration comedy The Rover.

title: In Church, Tapping Out Memorials
description: Tap and Danspace Project have never really hooked up, but David Parker, the artist-programmer behind the latest Platform series, Rhythm & Humor, would like to change that. On Thursday he presented the first performance of a shared evening showcasing Michelle Dorrance and Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards. It was, he said, the culmination of a long-held dream.

title: Leeks That Stayed in Bed All Winter Come Out to Play
description: HERES something that I know about leeks: The ones planted in the fall and left in the cold ground until the first thaw in early spring taste sweeter, earthier and deeper than new-crop leeks in summer.

title: Chic in Review | Who Invited Kanye?
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Idol Lifts Fox to No. 1
description: American Idol made its first elimination from its top 13 finalists on Thursday  Ashthon Jones  as Fox led the night with 21.7 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The 8 p.m. episode lifted Fox to No. 1 on the night over all by a wide margin. CBS ranked second, winning the 9 p.m. hour with CSI (13.6 million), ahead of Foxs Bones (10.9 million). At 8 and 8:30, CBSs sitcoms The Big Bang Theory (12.1 million) and Rules of Engagement (9.5 million) remained solid, while at 10, CBSs procedural The Mentalist dominated the time slot with 14.4 million viewers. ABC was third with a two-hour rerun of Wipeout from 8 to 10 (5.5 million), followed by a repeat of Greys Anatomy at 10 (3.5 million). NBC ranked a distant fourth with repeats of its comedy lineup.

title: A String of Good Results Helps Offset a Shaky Start
description: At the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., on Thursday evening, the Baldwin North American Open Pairs Flight A was won by Joe Grue and Shane Blanchard of New York. They finished one-and-a-half boards ahead of Kevin Bathurst and Joel Wooldridge of New York. Third were Lloyd Arvedon of Natick, Mass., and Pat McDevitt of Brookline, Mass.

title: Podcast: Oil, Stocks and Starbucks
description: After the earthquake and tsunami in Japan, oil prices fell sharply, although they had been trending upward for weeks as events in the Middle East rattled the markets.

title: Masters of Deception
description: Things really were simpler back then, before every act was a public act, when the fiercest threat to the privacy of the average Americans unguarded speech was this guy:

title: Pelosi Questions Legal Cost on Marriage Law
description: Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, has written a letter to the speaker, John A. Boehner, requesting an estimate of the cost of defending cases concerning the Defense of Marriage Act, and suggested that to do so will be too costly to taxpayers.

title: Liszt Suites of Travel, United as a Journey
description: Franz Liszt had no special intentions for the musical sketches he made during his years in Switzerland in the 1830s. But many years and many revisions later, his little travel pieces had alchemized into a grand expression of his art: three suites for solo piano that he called Annes de Plerinage (Years of Pilgrimage), the first based on Switzerland, the second on Italian art and poetry, and the third on introspective, spiritual concerns.

title: Salonen and the Big Sounds of a Small European Nation
description: In the mid-1990s, as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, Esa-Pekka Salonen presented a series of programs that paired works by Haydn and Ligeti, two of his favorite composers. In doing so, he was not making excessive claims for the connections between the Classical master Haydn and the contemporary path-breaker Ligeti, with whom Mr. Salonen had worked closely. He was simply inviting audiences to hear resonances across time between two audaciously inventive composers.

title: Roomy!
description: And speaking of shapes, Jil Sander and Stella McCartney offered a cocoon-shaped sack.

title: Rhythms Rise Up From the Pampas
description: Early in his career, Alberto Ginastera incorporated elements from the music of his native Argentina into his scores with traditional tonal means. Later, in his neo-expressionist period, he used serialism and avant-garde techniques to reflect indigenous South American traditions, as in his rarely heard Cantata Para Amrica Mgica, for soprano and percussion orchestra.

title: Moodys Warns About a Return of Lavish Bank Pay
description: Bank bonuses are not what they used to be, although they could make a comeback once the dust settles from the financial crisis, according to a new report from Moodys Investors Service.

title: Most Teachers in Disciplinary Limbo Have Returned to Class
description: Whatever happened to all those teachers who were cooling their heels in the citys infamous rubber rooms, doing nothing while waiting to hear if they would be fired on charges of incompetence or worse?

title: Harlem: A Century in Images
description: Selected photographs from this chronicle of Harlem as a crossroads of art, culture and politics.

title: Transcendence and Mystery in Tiny Gestures
description: WASHINGTON  For the first 20 days of March, India is to be found in many parts of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here. Cuisine, fabric, visual art, music, film, literature and theater, as well as dance, are all part of its Maximum India festival. The foyers of the building have been unusually full. Audiences have included American women in saris and Indian men wearing sports jackets.

title: A Soundtrack to a Collaboration That Never Was
description: In the work of Alarm Will Sound, a vibrant, technically dazzling new-music ensemble, listeners have grown accustomed to encountering the amazing, the amusing and, occasionally, the near-impossible. A musical event called 1969, which the group presented for a capacity audience at Zankel Hall on Thursday night, had all those qualities and more. So what if it was based on what is probably a misremembered bit of history?

title: Emancipating History
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Here, in this lovely town, once one of the most prosperous in the American colonies, there is no escape.

title: Japan Earthquake and Tsunami: How to Help
description: Updated March 17 |  For readers interested in contributing to help victims of the earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan and the Pacific region, here is a list of contact information and links for some agencies that plan to provide relief. (The New York Times does not certify the charities fund allocations or administrative costs. More information about giving, for this and other causes, is available online from the GuideStar database on nonprofit agencies and the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.)

title: New Opening Date Announced for Spider-Man
description: Mark your calendars and place your bets: The producers of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark have picked a new date, June 14, for their opening night, which has now been delayed six times. The $65-million-and-counting musical will end up having more than 180 preview performances  the most in history  assuming it opens as scheduled.

title: Ballad of a Thin Man
description: Godfathers of glam who can still rock a skinny suit. See interactive feature >>

title: Mens Spring 2011 Issue
description: Spring? Yes, please. After a punishing winter, were more than ready to shed some layers and embrace the new season. In our new mens fashion issue, Jonathan Mahler profiles the giddy San Francisco Giants pitching phenom Tim Lincecum, while a portfolio of rock stars gives a lesson on enduring cool. Elsewhere in the magazine, we drop in on models who box (seriously), a Soviet cosmonaut who was equal parts boozer and charmer, and a Californian who spent seven years on the shadowy margins in Yemen and the Horn of Africa. And of course theres plenty of straight-up style, too, from head to toe (easy espadrilles). See all stories from the issue >>

title: The Bridge, My Muse
description: ON a recent cold afternoon, I crossed the Williamsburg Bridge, taking the advice of a spray-painted slogan to look sharp. Not only did I look out and see the usual sights  the sun slicing off the Domino Sugar building behind me, Manhattan a glassy wall of light in front  I also looked down at countless words and images, as if the bridge itself were a living diary, the commuters public notebook.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 11
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include flooding in New Jersey, a bike lane in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and a St. Patricks Day parade in Queens.

title: Representing District 28
description: Ruben W. Wills, New Yorks newest City Council member, endured a bruising seven-person race last fall to win his first election.

title: Newest City Council Member Is Learning on the Run
description: ON an icy February morning, Ruben W. Wills, New Yorks newest City Council member, looked over a to-do list of 12 tasks, each one written in capital letters: Do Dishes. Call District Attorney. Pray to God.

title: Rebels Flee From Ras Lanuf
description: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi retook Ras Lanuf and pressed toward the countrys largest refinery Friday.

title: Winning Hearts While Flattening Vineyards Is Rather Tricky
description: PANJWAI, Afghanistan  No one disputes that the campaign by NATO and Afghan forces that wrested this southern district from Taliban control last fall caused tremendous damage. The evidence is all around. In one place a whole village was destroyed.

title: Obama Defends Detention Conditions for Soldier Accused in WikiLeaks Case
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has defended conditions in a Marine Corps jail for Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, who is accused of leaking classified government documents to WikiLeaks. The president said Friday that he had been assured that such measures as forcing Private Manning to sleep without clothing were justified and for his own safety.

title: For Displaced Gamers, a Light on the Horizon
description: For decades, Chinatown Fair welcomed everyone  misfits, cool kids, world champions, novices, dancers, fighters, strategists, tourists carrying leftover dumplings from their dinner across the street. Then, two weeks ago, it disappeared. Even among the devoted gamers and urban nostalgists who had been whispering about its demise for weeks, the end came as a surprise. About midnight, a simmering rent dispute forced Chinatown Fair, a video-game arcade at 8 Mott Street for several decades, to shut its doors; by the next evening it was stripped bare, an empty shell of a retail space with an old battered sign.

title: Cabby Is Sentenced for Overcharging
description: A taxi driver who pleaded guilty in January to overcharging on more than 4,000 trips to earn thousands of dollars extra was sentenced on Friday to 100 days of community service and five years probation. The driver, Norman Feiner, 65, was also prohibited from reapplying for his taxi license during his probation.

title: The Netherlands: Taylor Trial Ends
description: Arguments in the more than three-year-long war crimes trial of Charles Taylor, the former Liberian president, ended Friday at a United Nations-backed court in The Hague. The case against the first African president to face an international tribunal has been the scene of much courtroom drama and multiple delays as the defense dragged out proceedings, ignoring deadlines and staging several boycotts. Mr. Taylor, 62, was indicted while in office in 2003 and charged with large-scale atrocities committed by rebels under his command. Mr. Taylor has denied the charges and dismissed his trial as a political event. If he is found guilty, he will serve his sentence in a British jail. The three international judges are expected to take months before delivering their verdict.

title: Not Just Another Title Run for Rebounding Tar Heels
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  When fans rushed onto the court after North Carolina beat arch rival Duke to capture the Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season title, it was a telling moment for a program that was once accustomed to big victories and championship banners.

title: Looking to Lead Canada, and for a Little Name Recognition
description: OTTAWA

title: Immigrants Replenish Irish Ambience of N.Y. Enclave
description: The Butchers Fancy is getting more customers for its Irish sausages and steak-and-kidney pie. The Irish Coffee Shop notices more orders for its slow-cooked Irish oatmeal, brown bread and rashers.

title: A Legal Privilege That Some Lawmakers See Broadly
description: PHOENIX  The majority leader of the Arizona State Senate scuffled with his girlfriend during an argument on the side of the road late one night recently. He hit her and she hit him, according to the police, but the two suffered dramatically different fates.

title: M.L.S. Commissioner: Looking Back, Looking Ahead
description: M.L.S. Commissioner Don Garber held a one-hour conference call with the news media on Friday a few days before the start of the leagues 16th season, which opens Tuesday night when the Los Angeles Galaxy plays at the Seattle Sounders.

title: Human Rights Advocates Vanish as China Intensifies Crackdown
description: BEIJING  Teng Biao is no stranger to the wrath of the Chinese authorities.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Mel Gibson in Plea Deal in Battering Case
description: LOS ANGELES  Mel Gibson pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor charge of battering his former girlfriend on Friday, under a deal that will let him avoid jail and deny liability for the incident in any civil litigation.

title: E.P.A. Rejects City Timeline on PCBs
description: New York Citys 10-year plan to identify and replace school-building light fixtures that are leaking toxic chemicals should be handled in a speedier and more comprehensive fashion, the Environmental Protection Agency said Friday.

title: Japans Industrial Heart Escapes Heaviest Blows
description: As bad as the toll might eventually be in lives and property from Japans earthquake and tsunami, the fact that the disaster hit far from Japans industrial heartland will at least soften the economic blow, both at home and abroad.

title: Spider-Man Will Open on June 14 (So They Say)
description: Mark your calendars and place your bets: The producers of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark have picked a new date, June 14, for their opening night, which has now been delayed six times.

title: In Libya Revolt, Youth Will Serve, or at Least Try
description: RAS LANUF, Libya  The bullet the boy held was bigger than his hand. He said he was 15, but then admitted he was 14, and frankly, he looked a year or two younger than that. When an enemy warplane approached, sending the gunmen around him scrambling for cover, the boy, with placid poise, stood and watched.

title: My Life As a Juvenile Delinquent
description: It was one of those delicious summer nights in Nebraska when youre blissfully wallowing in vacation. You gulp dinner in order to slip out through the screen door into the dark, into an atmosphere of rustling elm leaves and June bugs, and join up with some friends to play kick the can or ditch or to raise, if not hell, heck.

title: Energy Policy Defended as Gasoline Prices Rise
description: WASHINGTON  With rising gasoline prices fueling public pain, President Obama defended his energy policies on Friday against critics who claim he has pushed prices up by clamping down on domestic oil production.

title: Losing Their Ace, Rangers Go to Plan B
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.

title: Former Fannie Mae Chief May Face S.E.C. Charges
description: Brendan Hoffman/Bloomberg NewsDaniel H. Mudd is facing more scrutiny over his tenure at Fannie Mae.

title: 4 Decades Spent Romancing Dietrich
description: The way Puma tells it, the movie star Marlene Dietrich and the author Erich Maria Remarque met in Venice in 1930, when Ms. Dietrich was having lunch with Josef von Sternberg, her director, mentor and lover. After Mr. Remarque came over and introduced himself, Mr. Sternberg made a hasty exit because, as Mr. Remarque says, he knew a great two-shot when he saw one.

title: U.S. to Name a Liaison to Libyan Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Friday that he would appoint a special representative to Libyas rebel leaders and that the Treasury Department had placed sanctions on nine more family members and friends of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in an effort to force the Libyan leader to resign.

title: Mountain West and WAC Cross Paths in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  Their headquarters are separated by about 60 miles of Interstate 25 in Colorado, but the Mountain West Conference and the Western Athletic Conference have always been much more connected than that. And never as tightly wound as now.

title: Peapod Challenges Fresh Direct in Grocery War
description: Fresh Direct started selling groceries online in New York City nine years ago, and in that time, one of its biggest national competitors, Peapod, has circled ever closer to Manhattan. But it has not crossed the river  until now. Starting on Sunday, armed with a hefty budget for parking tickets, Peapod plans to roll its delivery trucks through big sections of Manhattan, and a new kind of food-delivery war will be on.

title: Midcentury Collectivism
description: One of the good things about art history is that it is always being rewritten. In the case of the New York School, that self-described Greatest Generation of midcentury artists, newer histories have moved past the singular, heroic-figure narrative to emphasize the eras inherent collectivism and internationalism, and the presence of women  and not just as wives or lovers.

title: McCann Returns, Feeling Relieved
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It was a therapeutic return to the lineup Friday for Braves catcher Brian McCann. He went 0 for 3 against the Yankees, playing for the first time since Wednesday, when he hooked a liner into the Atlanta dugout that struck Luis Salazar, a minor-league manager, in the left eye. The impact caused Salazar, standing on the top step, to fall forward onto his face, and he was unconscious for at least 20 minutes. McCann, shaken, took himself out of the game.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: STADIUM SOUVENIRS, like other memorabilia spots near Yankee Stadium, began coming to life last week after a long, snowy off-season. Workers opened the doors and hustled to get merchandise ready for March 31, opening day at the stadium.

title: How Flaws Undid Obamas Hope for High-Speed Rail in Florida
description: The rest of the world calls them bullet trains because they go so fast. But in the United States, the nickname is apt for a different reason: They keep getting shot down.

title: Sidewalk Is His Prison Yard
description: STAYING fit in New York City, with all the high-tech gyms and holistic yoga classes, can be complicated.

title: Flooding Rivers Soak Parts of Northern New Jersey
description: Rivers gushed over their banks in portions of northern New Jersey and elsewhere in the region on Friday after heavy rain doused the area for the second time in a week, resulting in roads knee-deep in water, sopping homes, and miffed residents yet again being displaced, possibly for days.

title: U.S. Inquiry on Military Family Foreclosures
description: The Justice Department is investigating allegations that a mortgage subsidiary of Morgan Stanley foreclosed on almost two dozen military families from 2006 to 2008 in violation of a longstanding law aimed at preventing such action.

title: Shedding Light on Influence of Hospitals on Albany
description: Running a hospital in a poor neighborhood of New York City means hoping your competitor fails before you do, getting squeezed by insurers, treating a growing uninsured population, angling for alliances to survive and always, always, asking for favors from Albany.

title: Fredettes 52 Points Help Revive B.Y.U.
description: LAS VEGAS  Jimmer Fredette scored a career-high and a team-record 52 points Friday to lead Brigham Young past New Mexico, 87-76, in the Mountain West Conference semifinals.

title: New 34th St. Traffic Plan Gives Cars Just 2 Lanes
description: Cars and trucks on 34th Street in Manhattan would be squeezed into two lanes  one moving east, the other west  with a bus-only lane on either side, under a revised plan for the thoroughfare to be unveiled by the Bloomberg administration on Monday.

title: The Basic No-Knead Bread Recipe Adapted From Sullivan Street Bakery
description: 3 cups flour

title: Hot Cakes Adapted From Kathleen Claibornes Recipe
description: cup cornmeal

title: Reads and Reactions II
description: In this edition of Reads and Reactions: a Gingrich run, the Oscars, more unions, more 2012 analyses and hoops. (We are now taking suggestions for this feature via Twitter, just reply to @micahcohen).

title: European Leaders Dont Rule Out Armed Intervention in Libyan Conflict
description: BRUSSELS  European leaders on Friday agreed to examine all necessary options  including armed intervention  to protect civilians should the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, escalate attacks on rebel-held territories.

title: A Time for Books and Baking
description: Even on his day off, Paul LeClerc, president of the New York Public Library since 1993, is happily focused on books and the simple pleasure of uninterrupted reading, though bread making is also a significant pastime. He is the designated chef in his household. Mr. LeClerc, 69, intends to retire this summer and write a book inspired by French history. He lives on the Upper East Side with his wife, Judith Ginsburg, 64, executive director of the Nash Family Foundation, and their son, Adam, 23. ROBIN FINN

title: Can This Union Maintain a Lasting Unity?
description: Washington

title: Democrats See Wisconsin Loss as Galvanizing
description: Even as the Republican governor of Wisconsin was signing a bill Friday that all but ended collective bargaining for state employees, Democrats nationally had put out advertisements and letters to use his own success against him.

title: You Cooked What? Ill Trade You Granola!
description: THE kombucha guy was doing it wrong, and so was I.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Facebook Users Who Are Under Age Raise Concerns
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The fake ID has gone digital, and spread to elementary school.

title: Give Up Familiar Light Bulb? Not Without Fight, Some Say
description: WASHINGTON  American protests against the encroachment of government have been spurred by many causes  tea, of course, and guns, frequently. The latest catalyst: light bulbs.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: John Gilmers Last Stand
description: Writing from Greensboro, N.C., in March 1861, the week after Abraham Lincoln took power, Representative John A. Gilmer sent a rapid-fire sequence of letters to William Henry Seward, the new secretary of state. I am here in the very midst of the South, Gilmer implored Seward, and I beg you to weigh well the suggestions which I make to you. He described the nervous impetuousness among secessionists, who were beginning to believe that fighting and bloodshed were necessary to sustain their flagging revolution. Their only hope was to instigate a collision between federal and state forces in the Deep South.

title: Defendant in 3 Killings Seeks to Give Guilty Plea
description: One of the two men charged in a 2007 home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., in which a woman and her two daughters were killed, has asked a judge to allow him to plead guilty on the condition that he receive a sentence of life without parole rather than the death penalty.

title: Simon van der Meer, Nobel Laureate, Dies at 85
description: Simon van der Meer, who shared the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1984 for a technological advance that was crucial to the discovery of fundamental building blocks of the universe, died March 4 in Geneva. He was 85.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: I Do, Hungarian Style
description: THE two shows on March 19 in New Brunswick by the local Hungarian musical ensemble Eletfa Folk Band and its companion dance troupe, the Csurdongolo Folk Ensemble, are called There Is a Wedding on Our Street.

title: Lockout Becomes Part of Playbook
description: As the realization set in that labor strife had sent the N.F.L. into a legal limbo, the leagues players and executives tried to get a handle on what the breakdown in negotiations and the union decertification would mean for them, even if nearly all of them had been bracing for what happened on Friday.

title: Subtleties Worth Detecting
description: After James Silver became general manager of the Peconic Bay Winery in 2009, he tasted barrel samples from the outstanding 2007 vintage and thought a terrific blend was possible. Greg Gove, the winemaker, agreed. They were right.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 11, 2011

title: Virginia: Judge Orders Nutrition for Immigrant in Nursing Home
description: A judge ordered Friday that a Rwandan immigrant whose feeding tube was removed three weeks ago against her familys wishes be given nutrition and hydration immediately. Rachel Nyirahabiyambere, 59, who has been in a vegetative state since suffering a major stroke, lay close to death in a Maryland nursing home early Friday, said her son, Jerome Ndayishimiye. Her family had felt powerless to save her after a court-appointed guardian ordered her feeding tube removed; the guardian, Andrea J. Sloan, believed that Ms. Nyirahabiyambere should be receiving only palliative care because she was profoundly vegetative and had no chance of recovery. After The New York Times published an article about her case, the Alliance Defense Fund, a Christian legal alliance, petitioned Judge Nolan B. Dawkins of Alexandria Circuit Court on behalf of her children. He ordered her feeding tube reinstated while the legal issues were weighed.

title: A Menu Beyond Italian, Asian and Even Fusion
description: TRATTACHINO, a stylish new restaurant that opened in Wantagh in late January, sends mixed signals. The name sounds Italian, but Joseph Balbo, the executive chef and one of the three owners, said it was not; in a conversation after my visits, he said the name was made up to express the restaurants new dining concept.

title: M.L.S. Would Welcome Wilpons as Owners
description: In a conference call with reporters on Friday, Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber, who has a long relationship with the Wilpon family, said the Mets owners would be great owners in M.L.S., and expressed hope that the family would get their financial difficulties sorted out in time to be part of the league, which hopes to add a second team in New York. More coverage at the Goal blog.

title: Do We Get Tsunamis Yet?
description: The question above is not meant literally; on Friday morning, the energy of even relatively low tsunami surges created by the Japanese earthquake did plenty of damage to the boats parked cheek by jowl (bow by bow?) in a small lagoon off Santa Cruz harbor. Onlookers recorded the scene; local television news was full of it.

title: After Tsunami, Igawa Leaves Yankees Camp
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The effects of the devastation in Japan were felt in Yankees camp Friday morning, when the minor league left-hander Kei Igawa left the teams complex so he could try to locate his family.

title: Stopgap Bill Cuts Budget by $6 Billion
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Friday proposed a plan to finance the government through April 8 as President Obama warned that it would be irresponsible to go much beyond that date with another short-term budget.

title: When Raj Rajaratnam Talks, People Listen
description: Prosecutors have released audio files of three wiretapped telephone calls that Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Groups founder, had with four other people. The government contends that Mr. Rajaratnam received illegal tips on these calls.

title: Maker of Thomas the Tank Engine Toys to Be Acquired
description: The Tomy Company, the Japanese maker of Transformers and Pokmon toys, agreed to buy the RC2 Corporation for $640 million to add Thomas the Tank Engine products in North America. The offer is valued at $27.90 a share in cash, 27 percent more than Wednesdays closing price, the companies said. Tomy, based in Tokyo, is seeking overseas acquisitions to revive growth as falling birth rates in Japan, which contributed to two consecutive annual declines in revenue, crimps demand for new toys. In addition to Thomas, RC2 makes products under the Learning Curve, Johnny Lightning and Ertl brands. This merger further enables Tomy to move towards our goal of increasing our global profile adding significant additional business in North America and Europe, Tomys president, Kantaro Tomiyama, said in a statement. Shares of RC2, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., rose $2.80, or 11 percent, to $28.31. Tomys stock rose 1 percent in Tokyo trading.

title: Founding Family Bids for 99 Cents Only Stores
description: The discount chain 99 Cents Only Stores said Friday it had received a $1.3 billion takeover offer from Leonard Green & Partners and the companys founding family. The company said Leonard Green and the Schiffer/Gold family bid of $19.09 a share for 99 Cents Only, a 14 percent premium over Thursdays closing price for 99 Cents. The Schiffer/Gold family owns 33 percent of the company. Its partner, Leonard Green, is a longtime investor in retail companies that has struck deals for Jo-Ann Stores and J. Crew. Shares of 99 Cents, which is based in City of Commerce, Calif., rose $2.90, or 17 percent, to $19.58.

title: Valero Agrees to Buy an Oil Refinery in Wales
description: Valero Energy agreed on Friday to buy Chevrons refinery in Pembroke, Wales, for $730 million and other related assets for about $1 billion. The transaction is the latest move by a big oil company to refocus on exploration instead of less lucrative refining operations. Chevron has already agreed to sell refining assets in more than 20 countries, and it is looking to sell more operations in the Caribbean and Central America. The deal also gives Valero, a major American oil refiner, its first significant foothold in Europe. The Pembroke refinery has a capacity of 270,000 barrels of oil a day, the vast majority of which is crude. Valero said it expected the purchase to immediately add to its earnings per share.

title: Charges Against Health Care Executive Raise Broader Issues
description: We learned this week from a federal bribery case, of all places, that the going rate in 2008 to park a dying person in a hospital bed in Brooklyn was $772.80. That fee was enough to cover hospice care and, if the charges are true, a payoff to a state senator from Brooklyn.

title: AnnTaylors Profit Tops Forecasts on Higher Sales
description: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation, the womens apparel retailer, said on Friday that it earned $8 million in its fourth quarter, propelled by a 10 percent increase in sales, topping analysts estimates. The company said the profit amounted to 14 cents a share and came on sales of $515 million. The company earned $41,000, or break-even per share, on sales of $469 million a year earlier. Shares of Ann Taylor, which is based in New York, rose $3.08, or 13 percent, to $27.29. The company also said it would change its name to ANN.

title: Grandmas Recipes, Made With Her Tools
description: MORRIS PLAINS, N.J.

title: Saturday: Words From Un Innamorato
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Yes, there are Saturday puzzles, and then there are Saturday puzzles by Joon Pahk. With a puzzle like this, its not so much a matter of choosing something to like and highlight. Its more a matter of trying to find something I didnt like. It was still a bear, though. I crashed and burned in the south and the southeast, just barely making it out alive. The northeast wasnt much easier.

title: At Doral, Japanese Golfers Play On Despite Concern for Homeland
description: DORAL, Fla.  Half a world away from the 8.9 magnitude earthquake that devastated northeastern Japan early Friday, players at the $8.5 million W.G.C.-Cadillac Championship gradually became more and more aware of the earthquakes impact as the day wore on.

title: Partisans Adopt Deceit as a Tactic for Reports
description: The reporter in disguise has largely faded from mainstream American journalism. But the tactic is alive and well in the hands of passionate partisans.

title: In a Series of Phone Calls, an Ear Into a Federal Corruption Case
description: Just before 10 a.m. on Monday, as federal investigators searched the Upper West Side apartment of Richard J. Lipsky, a lobbyist suspected of corruption, other F.B.I. agents  who were monitoring wiretaps of Mr. Lipskys phones  detected a strange call.

title: Art, Often Writ Large, Moves From the Garage to the Gallery
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  Norman Gorbaty, a retired advertising executive, stood in a corner of the Walsh Art Gallery at Fairfield University here, rag in one hand, can of tung oil in the other, patiently polishing his 7-foot-by-5-foot walnut bas relief, called Struma.

title: Corrections
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Mets Young Sees a Need for College Sports Reform
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Last autumn Princeton University asked pitcher Chris Young, one of its former student-athletes, to join an athletics advisory committee.
