Young promptly accepted, and he does not expect it to be an honorary post, so Princeton will soon be hearing his strong and clear opinions about the state of major college athletics.

title: A Lifetime of Art
description: A former ad executive exhibits his artwork after years.

title: Gas Prices and a Sane Energy Policy
description: Hard-pressed Americans are understandably concerned about rising gasoline prices. Republicans predictably are trying to use that anxiety to promote their drill-anywhere-and-everywhere agenda. At his press conference on Friday, President Obama wisely chose not to pander to the appetite for quick or destructive fixes.

title: Eye of the Newt
description: The presidential race is barely under way, but already we have had our first Big Thought. I am speaking, of course, of Newt Gingrichs suggestion that he was driven into serial adultery by hard work and patriotism.

title: The Master Key
description: The United States is not racked with the turmoil that is shaking the Arab world, or the tragic devastation that has hit Japan. We are not in a state of emergency. Were in a moment when it is possible to look thoughtfully at the American landscape and take rational steps to ensure a better, more sustainable future.

title: Accountability Would Seem to Begin and End With Referees
description: It is a wonderful concept, the way three basketball officials called a technical foul and whistled themselves out of the Big East tournament.

title: The Limits of Safeguards and Human Foresight
description: Heres the truly scary thing about the 8.9-magnitude earthquake off the coast of Honshu Island and its resulting tsunami: Japan is a country that is lauded for doing preparedness right.

title: Everything Falls in Line for Walker and UConn
description: Officiating blunders aside, the week at Madison Square Garden  the spotlight, the highlights, the buzz  has belonged to Connecticuts Kemba Walker.

title: For Duke, Bad Toes and Bad Timing
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  If Duke fails to defend its national championship this spring, the Blue Devils can blame bad toes and bad timing.

title: Homeward Bond
description: HERES a statistic you may not be aware of: about 50 percent of the worlds uncultivated, arable land is in Africa. This abundance of potential farmland offers Africa the opportunity to feed itself and to help feed the rest of the globe. But consider another statistic: because of poor roads and a lack of storage, African farmers can lose up to 50 percent of their crop just trying to get it to market.

title: Gentler View of Bruin Under Fire
description: When the Islanders chose Zdeno Chara, a 6-foot-9 defenseman from Slovakia, in the third round of the 1996 N.H.L. draft, their goal was to turn him into a tough, durable veteran.

title: In Tournament, Theres No Place Like (Close to) Home
description: Most of the focus when the N.C.A.A. tournament bracket is revealed on Sunday will be on how teams are seeded and what sort of opponents theyre due to face  and which teams make the field of 68 at all. But there is another factor that can make just as much difference: where the games are played.

title: Bloggingheads: Islam and Democracy
description: Daniel Drezner, left, of Tufts University and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate democracy and the appeal of political Islam.

title: As the Season Winds Down, the Rangers Are in a Familiar Spot
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  The Rangers have been in playoff position since Oct. 30, their 10th game of the season, but on the eve of their 70th, they are in danger of letting it slip away.

title: An Unpredictable Test of Japans Resilience
description: TOKYO  As I type this at my home here, every television channel here is devoting almost all of its coverage to reports of the staggering damage caused by the earthquake that occurred Friday off the Pacific Coast of northeastern Japan. The shaking itself, and the tsunami and fires caused by the quake, have combined to cause staggering damage. Based on past experience, it will be several days before the scale of the disaster fully emerges, as communication with the most damaged areas is still cut off.

title: A Hint of the 30s
description: The fall shows offered many different shapes in dresses. Ive already mentioned the Junya Watanabe dress with its 1930s lines, but here are two others, from Balenciaga and Miu Miu, that reminded me of that silhouette.

title: Rare Sellout Sets Stage as Nets Win in OT
description: NEWARK  In another woebegone season for the Nets, there have been few attractions to entice sellout crowds to Prudential Center, even when stars as big as Kobe Bryant and LeBron James have come to town.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Kings Sound and Fury
description: Representative Peter King demeaned the crucial issue of homeland security  and himself  building a Congressional hearing around his foolish, provocative and hurtful claims of widespread radicalization of Muslim Americans.

title: No Way to Run a Democracy
description: Turkey has long provided a heartening model of democracy for the Muslim world. Now, with so many people in the region demanding freedom, Turkeys government is betraying its values and its citizens, pressuring journalists to mute critical reporting about Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his administration.

title: The War in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Naftas Unfinished Business
description: We are happy to hear that President Obama has decided to restart a pilot program that will allow Mexican trucks to carry goods across the United States. We hope the announcement, which was made last week during a Washington visit by President Felipe Caldern of Mexico, puts an end to Washingtons breach of its obligations under the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Photo Replay: March 11
description: A look at the day in sports, from street hockey at the White House to cricket in Bangladesh.

title: Blackhawks Get the White House Treatment
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama welcomed the Chicago Blackhawks to the White House on Friday in a ceremony that celebrated their Stanley Cup championship last season and hockeys rough-and-tumble ways.

title: Argentina Names Roster for U.S. Trip
description: Argentinas national team on Friday announced its roster for two exhibition games later this month. Argentina will play the United States on March 26 at New Meadowlands Stadium, then travel to play at Costa Rica on March 29.

title: Danny Stiles, Radio Host Who Kept the Oldies New, Is Dead at 87
description: Danny Stiles, who brought back the music of yesteryear, spinning records for more than six decades on New York-area radio, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Jean Dinning, Songwriter of Pop Tragedy Teen Angel, Dies at 86
description: That fateful night the car was stalled

title: Louisville Erases Deficit and Heads to the Final
description: Louisville Coach Rick Pitino doesnt have any players who make N.B.A. scouts drool. His roster, on the basis of pure talent, may be one of the worst he has had in his 10 seasons at Louisville.

title: Big East Replay: March 11
description: Images from the semifinals of the Big East basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden, featuring UConn vs. Syracuse and Louisville against Notre Dame.

title: Japanese Scramble to Avert Meltdowns as Nuclear Crisis Deepens After Quake
description: TOKYO  Japanese officials struggled on Sunday to contain a widening nuclear crisis in the aftermath of a devastating earthquake and tsunami, saying they presumed that partial meltdowns had occurred at two crippled reactors and that they were facing serious cooling problems at three more.

title: Rescuers Search for Survivors
description: Rescuers struggled to reach survivors on Saturday morning as Japan reeled after an earthquake and a tsunami struck in deadly tandem.

title: The Aftermath in Japan
description: Japan reeled after an earthquake and a tsunami struck in deadly tandem.

title: Japan Pushes to Rescue Survivors as Quake Toll Rises
description: NAKAMINATO, Japan  While nuclear experts were grappling with possible meltdowns at two reactors after the devastating earthquake and ensuing tsunami in northern Japan, the country was mobilizing a nationwide rescue effort to pluck survivors from collapsed buildings and rush food and water to hundreds of thousands of people without water, electricity, heat or telephone service.

title: In Yemeni Capital, Security Forces Attack Protest Encampment
description: SANA, Yemen  Fighting escalated between antigovernment protesters and security forces on Saturday, and four people were reported killed, even as President Ali Abdullah Saleh promised the White House that he would not use violence against the demonstrators.

title: Weekend Competition: (Mis)Fortune Cookies
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise fortune cookie wisdom fit for our times  and share cookie quotes they have actually unwrapped.

title: March 12 Updates on Earthquake Aftermath in Japan
description: On Saturday, in addition to The Timess coverage of the devastation following the deadly earthquake and tsunami, which damaged local nuclear power plants, The Lede tracked news out of Japan a day later. Updates below mix news alerts with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground.

title: The Weekend Word: Keeping Money, and Oil, Flowing
description: Todays Times

title: Suspecting Palestinians, Israeli Military Hunts for Killers of 5 West Bank Settlers
description: ITAMAR, West Bank  It was close to midnight on Saturday when the bodies of five members of the Fogel family were removed from their home in this Jewish settlement in the hills of the northern West Bank, more than 24 hours after intruders, suspected to be Palestinians, stabbed them to death in their sleep.

title: Doug Aitken With James Murphy
description: This week, The Moment features LCD Soundsystems James Murphy on the sound of snow, as interviewed by Doug Aitken.

title: Marcelo Does Milan
description: A look at the life of Marcelo Burlon, the founder of the famed Pink Is Punk parties in Milan.

title: 14 Dead as Bus Overturns on Bronx Highway
description: A more recent version of this story that appeared in the newspaper can be read here.

title: Lawson Software Receives $1.8 Billion Takeover Bid
description: Lawson Software disclosed on Friday that it had received a $1.8 billion takeover proposal from Infor Global Solutions and the buyout firm Golden Gate Capital.

title: A Note On Household Balance Sheets
description: Calculated Risk has gone through the latest Flow of Funds report, which shows that households have made up about half of the loss in net worth they suffered in the crisis. Were almost home!

description: Little or no posting for the rest of today.

title: N.F.L. Breakdown: Money, Power and Mistrust
description: You may have heard Fridays talking points from the N.F.L. and the union about protecting the fans. If you missed them, dont worry, youll get more chances in the next few months.

title: On Earthquakes, Warming and Risk (Mis)Perception
description: I was invited to join David Roberts of Grist last night for a Bloggingheads.tv chat on living resiliently on a turbulent, crowding planet. We focused initially on the enormous seabed earthquake off Japan and the resulting tsunami and then on the challenges facing journalists and activists trying to communicate about human-driven climate change in ways that hew to the science but also gain traction (a very tough challenge; we have very different views).

title: Hearing Is Set in Climate Fraud Case
description: A nearly yearlong effort by Attorney General Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II of Virginia to force the University of Virginia to turn over the documents of a prominent climatologist is headed to the states Supreme Court.

title: Nobu Plans a Hotel With Caesars Palace in Las Vegas
description: Nobu restaurant has long been known for upscale Japanese cuisine that draws jet-setters to its 25 locations around the world. Now Nobu is bringing its cachet to a different sort of setting: a hotel.

title: Opinion: Earthquakes in Japan
description: Andrew Revkin of Dot Earth on what earthquake-prone countries can learn from Japan's resilience, motivation and planning.

title: The Scene in Sana
description: Fighting between anti-government protesters and security forces escalated on Saturday.

title: Retiring Senators Make a Wish List of Bills
description: WASHINGTON  Call it the Bucket List Caucus  the growing number of departing senators who just might want to get a few big things done before they pass on to new lives outside of Congress.

title: The Destructive Power of Water
description: Water, usually thought of as soothing and caressing, is surprisingly heavy  and surprisingly destructive.

title: Southern Sudanese Forces Repulse Rebel Attack Linked to a Renegade Politician
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Hundreds of rebels invaded one of southern Sudans largest cities on Saturday, leaving more than 20 people dead and adding to a litany of security concerns across the region as it prepares for independence.

title: Gingrich Stance on Libya Examined
description: Newt Gingrich, the former Republican speaker of the House, has been highly critical of President Obamas handling of Libya, accusing Mr. Obama of coddling a man who has been an enemy of the United States for decades.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JIMMY FALLON

title: Fighting Words
description: Was a Congressional hearing last week on Muslims in America a revival of McCarthyism? Or a look at a community ignoring radicalization among its own, as suggested by Peter T. King, the Republican chairman of the Homeland Security Committee who convened the session.

title: Spilled Milk Regulations a Myth, E.P.A. Says
description: To Representative Morgan Griffith, a freshman Republican from Virginia, nothing illustrates the Environmental Protection Agencys overreach more clearly than a new rule applying the same regulations that govern spilled oil to milk spilled on dairy farms.

title: Variety:  Noisy Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Todays Acrostic was a pleasure to solve because  I SAID, TODAYS ACROSTIC WAS A PLEASURE TO SOLVE BECAUSE

title: Robert Spano Named New Aspen Music Festival Music Director
description: The Aspen Music Festival and School, a rite of passage for many of the nations leading musicians but an institution fraught with dissension in the recent past, has hired the conductor Robert Spano as its new music director.

title: Prime Number
description: 1.5: The number, in millions, of layoffs and firings in January, the lowest number since the Labor Department began tracking those numbers in 2000. Still, there were five unemployed workers for every available job in January, a ratio that has been virtually unchanged for several months, according to the government. The ratio is lower than it was during the worst of the recession two years ago  when it was nearly seven workers per job opening  but it is still much higher than it was before the recession.

title: 1906: The San Francisco Earthquake
description: A magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck San Francisco shortly after 5 a.m. on April 18. An estimated 3,000 people died. Heres how The Times reported events in a dispatch filed at 12:15 a.m. the next day:

title: Soul-Riding the Slopes
description: Do spirituality and snowboarding intersect? A priest from St. Andrews Anglican Church in Trail, British Columbia, thinks so, and explored the question in a thesis that recently earned him a doctorate in snowboarding from Kingston University in London, the CBC reports. The Rev. Neil Elliot said he became interested when reading about the term soul-riding in a Web discussion group. Soul-riding starts with powder, it starts with some kind of almost transcendent experience in riding powder and in the whole of your life, so soul-riding is about being completely focused, completely in the moment, he said.

title: Green Development? Not in My (Liberal) Backyard
description: Park Slope, Brooklyn. Cape Cod, Mass. Berkeley, Calif. Three famously progressive places, right? The yin to the Tea Party yang. But just try putting a bike lane or some wind turbines in their lines of sight. And the karma can get very different.

title: Elizabeth LiCalzi and Mark Van Deusen
description: Dr. Elizabeth Marie LiCalzi and Dr. Mark Barringer Van Deusen were married Saturday at Corpus Christi Church in Celebration, Fla. The Very Rev. Gregory L. Parkes, chancellor and vicar general of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlando, Fla., performed the ceremony.

title: Lizzie Fischbein and Andrew Brown
description: Elizabeth Anne Fischbein and Dr. Andrew Bennett Brown were married Saturday night at the Yale Club in New York. Rabbi Daniel Gropper performed the ceremony.

title: Court in Minnesota Has Been a Home Field for a Leagues Labor Disputes
description: For N.F.L. players, federal court in Minneapolis is a legal nirvana.

title: Holly Stingley, Carl Navarre III
description: Holly Marie Stingley, a daughter of Roxane L. Rosati of Atlanta and John D. Stingley of New Canaan, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Carl Albert Navarre III, a son of Pamela M. Navarre and Mr. Navarre Jr. of New York. The Rev. Henry King Oehmig, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Morada Bay Beach Cafe, a restaurant in Islamorada, Fla. The Rev. Mary Navarre Moore, also an Episcopal priest and an aunt of the bridegroom, took part in the ceremony.

title: Courtenay White, Timothy McAlea
description: Courtenay Carolan White and Timothy Patrick McAlea were married Saturday at St. William Catholic Church in Naples, Fla. The Rev. George Ratzmann, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Esmihan Almontaser and Omar Shah
description: Esmihan Mosad Almontaser, a daughter of Lowza Almontaser and Mosad Muthana Almontaser of Brooklyn, was married Friday to Dr. Omar Shah, the son of Zahida T. Shah and Syed Jaffar Shah of Aliso Viejo, Calif. Imam Yassir Fazaga officiated at the Orange County Islamic Foundation in Mission Viejo, Calif.

title: Rebecca Browngoehl, Daniel Feinberg
description: Rebecca Browngoehl and Daniel Feinberg were married by Rabbi Peter Rigler Saturday evening at the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Carrie Feibel, Eric Kayne
description: Carolyn Jane Feibel and Eric Lyle Kayne are to be married Sunday afternoon at Temple Emanuel in St. Louis. Rabbi Justin Kerber is to officiate.

title: Aryn Jordan, Jeremy Hellinger
description: Aryn Courtney Jordan and Jeremy Cecil Hellinger were married Saturday evening in Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Mark L. Winer, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Resort Palm Beach.

title: Personal Finance for Dictators: Where to Stash the Cash
description: As his country burns around him, the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has stashed away tens of billions of dollars in cash in United States dollars, Libyan dinars and possibly other currencies in banks and in Bab Al Azizia, his Tripoli compound, intelligence officials and a person with ties to the Libyan government disclosed last week.

title: Arab League Endorses No-Flight Zone Over Libya
description: CAIRO  The Arab League asked the United Nations Security Council on Saturday to impose a no-flight zone over Libya in hopes of halting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis attacks on his own people, providing the rebels a tincture of hope even as they were driven back from a long stretch of road and towns they had captured in the three-week war.

title: Mary-Katherine Brooks, Alexander Fleming
description: Mary-Katherine Brooks and Alexander Carlson Fleming were married Friday evening in Telluride, Colo. Stephen F. Brooks, a Baptist minister and the brides uncle, performed the ceremony at the Alpine Chapel.

title: Taylor Porter, Norman Pentelovitch
description: Taylor Rogers Porter, the daughter of Brian Porter of Westport, Conn., and the late Aleta Taylor Porter, was married Saturday evening to Norman Henry Pentelovitch, a son of William Z. Pentelovitch of Minneapolis and the late Barbara Pentelovitch. John R. Tunheim, a United States district judge for Minnesota, officiated at the home of the bridegrooms parents.

title: Rebecca Wyman, Lee Gold
description: Rebecca Burke Wyman and Dr. Lee Adam Gold were married Saturday evening in Los Angeles. Rabbi Michael D. Mayersohn officiated at the Smog Shoppe, an event space.

title: Lauren Bregman, Daniel Barrie
description: Lauren Rachel Bregman and Daniel Bennett Barrie were married Saturday evening in North Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Greg Harris officiated at the Mansion at Strathmore, an event space.

title: Rachel Cohn, Jeffrey Braverman
description: Rachel Elyse Cohn, the daughter of Rose Schwarzberg Cohn and Dr. William J. Cohn of Old Field, N.Y., was married in Lawrence, N.Y., Saturday evening to Jeffrey Elliot Braverman, the son of Aimee S. Braverman and Kenneth Braverman of Edison, N.J. Rabbi Moshe Edelman performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence.

title: On Edge of Disaster, Town Reels From Tsunami
description: NAKAMINATO, Japan  Takako Koguchi turned 78 on Thursday. On Friday, hours before a planned birthday celebration, she saw a wave of black water coursing through the streets of this small fishing town, heading toward her.

title: Afghan Leader Questions U.S. Military Operations
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai on Saturday appeared to call for NATO and the United States to cease military operations in Afghanistan, but then issued a clarification saying that he was referring only to specific operations that had caused civilian casualties.

title: Jeter, After an Overhaul and Then a Tweak of His Swing, Feels Ready
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Through 24 spring training at-bats, Derek Jeter is hitting .333. Results are nice, but Jeters average is not what excites Kevin Long, the Yankees hitting coach. This does: On Friday, when Jeter was 1 for 3 with an infield single against Atlanta, he swung at the first pitch every time up. That he fouled them all off was irrelevant, at least to Long.

title: The Bedrock of a Franchise
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Dave Snow coached the Long Beach State baseball team for 13 years, long enough to recognize the subtleties of practice. By 2005, he was scouting for the Colorado Rockies, four years removed from the dugout, and he watched the teams infield drills on a day when its junior shortstop, Troy Tulowitzki, was out with an injury.

title: A Better Way to Watch Sports
description: One of the more odd aspects of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, which starts this week, is how excited people will get about games they do not intend to watch for more than several minutes at a time.

title: Gates Tells Bahrains King That Baby Steps to Reform Arent Enough
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  In the wake of a violent clash between protesters and Bahrains security forces and pro-government vigilantes, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates warned this tiny kingdoms ruling family on Saturday that baby steps toward reform would not be enough to meet the political and economic grievances sweeping the region.

title: Moon and Stars Collide at Opening Night of SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The South by Southwest film festival turned up the star wattage on Friday night for its premiere of Source Code, the mind-bending thriller that is Duncan Joness follow-up to his minimalist sci-fi feature Moon.

title: Carnage on I-95 After Crash Rips Bus Apart
description: A tour bus barreling south for Manhattan overturned at high speed on a highway in the Bronx early Saturday and was sliced open by a sign stanchion in a shriek of rending metal that hurled riders about like rag dolls. Fourteen people were killed and 19 were injured, 5 of them critically, the authorities said.

title: Police in Azerbaijan Arrest Antigovernment Protesters
description: MOSCOW  The police in Azerbaijan arrested 50 protesters on Saturday, the second day of demonstrations in Baku, the capital, calling for the resignation of President Ilham Aliyev, whose family has been ruling the oil-rich state since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

title: Kept Off Court, but Welcomed by B.Y.U. Fans and Teammates
description: LAS VEGAS  Brandon Davies is the most important player who will not play a game in the N.C.A.A. tournament. But he will probably be there, on the Brigham Young bench, for all to see and few to understand. His sins are private. His face is public.

title: A Shooting in Pakistan Reveals Fraying Alliance
description: WASHINGTON  Inside a dark jail cell on the outskirts of Lahore, Pakistan, a brawny 36-year-old American from the mountains of southwest Virginia has sat for weeks as Pakistan began proceedings against him on murder charges and his own government made frantic attempts to secure his release.

title: Brown Begins Overhaul of Texas Program
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Mack Brown does not like late-night phone calls because they usually mean that something bad has happened to one of his Texas football players. So when his phone woke him well after midnight on Jan. 2, 2007, Brown dreaded answering.

title: A Golf Course Shooting Shakes the Notion of Refuge
description: DEERFIELD BEACH, Fla.  Sitting in a cart just to the side of Deerfield Country Clubs 17th tee, the two golfers were still savoring their pars on the previous hole when they were confronted by two men wearing ski masks and flashing .38-caliber revolvers.

title: With a Bigger Field, Bigger Bracket Issues
description: When the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament added a play-in game between No. 16 seeds in 2001 as the field expanded to 65 teams from 64, it was rarely included in pool brackets. The game was played on a Tuesday and the teams were considered irrelevant.

description: The death toll continues to rise as the Japanese military tries to find survivors in towns that have completely vanished.

title: Pearl Presses on While Awaiting N.C.A.A. Reckoning
description: ATLANTA  The coachs caravan of shame rolled over the Ohio State football coach Jim Tressel and the Connecticut mens basketball coach Jim Calhoun and left minimal damage. Tressel received a two-game suspension and $250,000 fine from the university for not reporting an N.C.A.A. violation. Calhoun received a three-game suspension from the N.C.A.A., as well as a scholarship reduction and recruiting restrictions for his role in violations.

description: Mountain View, Calif.

title: For Runner, Motherhood Humbles and Inspires
description: Kara Goucher, who made her marathon debut in New York with a third-place finish in 2008, is returning for the NYC Half-Marathon next Sunday, less than six months after giving birth to a son, Colt. Goucher, 32, also plans to run in the Boston Marathon on April 18; she finished third in 2009. She and her husband, Adam, train together in Portland, Ore. Last week, between fighting a bad cold and feeding Colt, she agreed to a telephone interview. LIZ ROBBINS

title: From Reckless Mets Rookie to Clubhouse Sage
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Every day that he drives to camp and parks in the premier reserved spot closest to the Mets clubhouse, Jason Isringhausen asks himself the same fundamental questions.

description: Masai Ujiri moved easily around the city last week. Having breakfast in Times Square, standing in line in a drizzle to pick up a ticket for the Big East mens basketball tournament, walking through Madison Square Garden, Ujiri rubbed elbows with New Yorkers who had no idea that he had either given the Knicks new life or snatched a piece of their future, depending on your perspective.

description: FOR many American investors, European stocks were an afterthought last year, as a growing debt crisis threatened to upend economic recovery on the Continent. But in recent months, European shares have rebounded.

description: AS promised, more Better Business Bureau bummers:

title: Confessions of a Recovering Op-Ed Columnist
description: THE first political columnist I ever encountered, after a fashion, was Walter Lippmann. It happened on a snowy afternoon when I was a kid of 11 or 12 growing up in Washington during the J.F.K. years. My wallet had somehow slipped out of my pocket as I trudged past the National Cathedral on my way home from school. Hours later, my mother barged into my bedroom, interrupting my full-scale sulk to announce a miracle. I just got a call from Walter Lippmanns maid, she said, sounding more excited than the circumstances warranted. They found your wallet on Woodley Road in front of Walter Lippmanns house!

title: Debate Over Baseballs Origins Spills Into Another Century
description: Moving beyond the binary and false options of Abner Doubleday and Alexander Cartwright Jr. as the father of baseball, three better candidates emerge: Daniel Lucius Adams, William Rufus Wheaton and Louis Fenn Wadsworth. Cartwrights plaque in the Baseball Hall of Fame declares he set the bases 90 feet apart and established nine innings as a game and nine players as a team. He did none of these things, and every other word of substance on his plaque is false.

title: The Problem With Pointing Fingers
description: Q.  You work as part of a team that has made a serious mistake and lost business as a result. You know who dropped the ball and think that this person should be held accountable. How can you place the blame in an acceptable, professional way?

title: Are Statistics Practical? Count the Ways, Online
description: A HOST of Web sites and smartphone apps, designed in collaborative efforts, are aiming to turn an outpouring of government data into practical information.

title: Keeping Tabs on the Infrastructure, Wirelessly
description: ENGINEERS routinely inspect bridges and other structures for cracks and corrosion. But because they cant always be there in person, one highly intelligent bridge knows what to do when trouble arises: send them an e-mail.

title: His Music Never Stops
description: I GREW up in the San Fernando Valley of Southern California in the 1970s. My friends and I were into bicycle motocross, and into skateboarding in empty swimming pools. Those activities shaped my generation.

title: Overnight Casino Trips Mean Low Fares for Riders, and Grueling Days for Drivers
description: The discount buses travel all night, back and forth from the city, so players can try their luck at the grand gambling houses all across the New York region.

description: WASHINGTON

description: This article is by Norimitsu Onishi, Henry Fountain and Tom Zeller Jr.

title: Danger Posed by Radioactivity in Japan Hard to Assess
description: The different radioactive materials being reported at the nuclear accidents in Japan range from relatively benign to extremely worrisome.

title: Cuba Gives 15-Year Prison Term to American
description: MEXICO CITY  An American contractor who United States officials said went to Cuba to deliver communication equipment to religious groups was sentenced Saturday to 15 years in prison by a Cuban court, the latest turn in a case that could trip up thawing relations between the countries.

title: Medicaid and the N.Y. Budget: Sensible Cuts, and Little Political Flak
description: New Yorks Gov. Andrew Cuomo has achieved a significant political and budgetary victory getting the states powerful health care providers and its major health care workers union to agree to live within a strict Medicaid spending limit for the next fiscal year and accept a slow rate of growth after that.

title: N.F.L. Hires Attorneys for Suit Against Players
description: The National Football League geared up for its antitrust battle against players Saturday by hiring two prominent attorneys for its legal team.

title: Earthquake and Tsunami in Japan: Readers Photos
description: NYTimes.com asked readers to send photographs from areas affected by the earthquake and tsunami. Here is a selection of images.

title: Medicaid and the N.Y. Budget: A Bad Deal on Malpractice
description: When Governor Cuomo and his aides started looking for ways to reduce Medicaid costs, capping malpractice payments was not on their radar. Hospital leaders on the Medicaid Redesign Team pushed the idea hard, justifying it with data supplied by the hospital industry.

title: How to Become a College Basketball Legend
description: If I asked you to name the last 10 national players of the year, my guess it that you wouldnt be able to. But if I asked you about all-time great players from the last 10 years, youd be able to rattle off a more comprehensive list.

title: For Wisconsin Lawmakers, a Heros Homecoming
description: MADISON, Wis.  They are the unlikeliest of folk heroes.

title: Marvel and Persistence
description: Again and again, Im struck by the persistence of objects. I go out to do the chores wearing a blue plaid wool coat. I have no idea how old it is, because its a hand-me-down, and yet every day its waiting on the hook. I feed the horses and reflect that Remedy, the retired cutting horse, is at least 31 years old, still sultanic in his majesty. The sun comes up, and here we all are every day animate and inanimate  persisting together.

title: Reforming Mexico's Police
description: The idealistic mayor of Jalapa, a small town in southern Mexico, is hoping to turn around an outgunned, notoriously corrupt police force by hiring foreign experts.

title: Wanted: Officers to Retake Mexico
description: JALAPA, Mexico  They were out looking for cattle thieves in the rolling pastures of this small town, bumping along in their police truck on a remote road, talking about nothing, when bright lights snapped them to attention.

title: A Cocktail Party With Readers
description: EARLY adopters at The Times boldly went there four years ago. I made the move only in the last few weeks  to Twitter, that is, that curiously named domain where Middle Eastern revolutions erupt and Charlie Sheen, too.

title: A Prison Life Gets a Second Act
description: Robert Salzman, 51, has spent most of his life incarcerated, but a chance meeting with a film director last year has him concentrating on a new life as a film actor.

title: Mets Still Searching for Second Baseman
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Daniel Murphy had two hits Saturday and raised his batting average in spring training to .303. But he had a difficult day at second base, committing two errors: one on a bad throw, the other on a ball that took a strange hop.

title: General Managers Likely to Address Hits to Head
description: N.H.L. general managers will be under intense public scrutiny when they convene for their annual meeting in Boca Raton, Fla., beginning Monday. Under pressure from medical researchers, owners and even players, the general managers are expected to strengthen Rule 48, the leagues bylaw governing checks to the head, which was instituted this season.

title: Schools Feeling New Immigration Pressure
description: In Salinas, California, schools are reeling from the added pressures students and their families are feeling from the intensified debate on immigration.

title: Quad Q&A: Bill Raftery
description: The college basketball analyst Bill Raftery took time Thursday night between games at the Big East tournament to discuss March Madness.

title: The Happynomics of Life
description: London

title: 7 Iraqi Soldiers Fatally Shot
description: BAGHDAD  Seven Iraqi soldiers were fatally shot in an ambush on Saturday morning as they left their base near Mosul to head home on vacation. It was the deadliest single attack on security forces in weeks.

title: Itinerant Life Weighs on Farmworkers Children
description: SALINAS, Calif.  A girl in Oscar Ramoss third-grade class has trouble doing homework because six relatives have moved into her familys rusted trailer and she has no private space.

title: Pay Teachers More
description: From the debates in Wisconsin and elsewhere about public sector unions, you might get the impression that were going bust because teachers are overpaid.

title: The Digital Pileup
description: SOME facts of life are just plain counterintuitive. It can be too cold to snow. Heavy things float. Martinis have calories.

title: How the Internet Tried to Kill Me
description: Boston

title: A Journey From Field to Classroom
description: Oscar Ramos spent his childhood adrift, picking lettuce, chilies and walnuts: Portersville to Visalia, Visalia to Delano, Delano to Bakersfield, Bakersfield to Gilroy. In the classroom, his story unfolds as his students complete their All About Me biographical posters.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,483 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Sunday: Reverend Spooner, U.S.P.S.
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Some people look at crossword puzzles as a glum reminder of the things they dont know, but (cue 1950s commercial music) how many times has this happened to you? Youre solving away happily, and out of the blue (O.K., out of the black and white) you run into a clue that makes you stop and think, How is anyone supposed to know that?

title: Abraham Lincoln, Rookie Executive
description: That Abraham Lincoln brought to the presidency a modest record in public office  eight years as a state legislator, one term in the House, an unsuccessful Senate candidacy  is well known. What is less often acknowledged is that Lincoln became the nations chief executive with almost no executive experience  even his two-man law firm had been managed largely by his partner. And that lack of experience showed.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 13
description: With thousands missing and rescue efforts underway in Japan, many of the Sunday talk shows will cover the aftermath of Fridays devastating earthquake and tsunami. ABC will broadcast This Week with host Christiane Amanpour reporting live from Japan.

title: Reader Comments on My Teacher Column
description: My Sunday column argues that the political battle in Wisconsin and elsewhere about public sector unions rests on a fallacy: teachers arent overpaid, but underpaid.

title: In a Miniature Space, High-Impact Sushi
description: IT is a widely held notion that the best sushi in a Japanese restaurant is served at the counter. While that may sometimes be true  especially when the sushi chef directs you to whats new or seasonal  at Fujinoya, the restaurant is so small and informal that the sushi counter and the dining tables are as good as merged. Of course, customers sitting at the counter and ordering a piece or two at a time can watch their choices being custom-made, as it were. But from anywhere in the restaurant, if you show interest in the fish displayed in the refrigerated case, the helpful waitress will point out whats particularly special that day.

title: Colossal Crispy Crusts
description: Tucked into a shopping strip next to an A&P, the family-owned Portofino Pizzeria in Goldens Bridge has been firing pizzas for 22 years, and both the Roman and the Neapolitan styles have enthusiastic supporters.

title: E. B. Leisenring Jr., Coal Executive, Dies at 85
description: E. B. Leisenring Jr., the scion of a powerful Pennsylvania coal family who led industry negotiators during a long and bitter mine workers strike in 1978, ignoring pleas by President Jimmy Carter and helping to win a settlement that largely favored mine owners, died on March 2 at his winter home in Aiken, S.C. He was 85.

title: Jack Hardy, Folk Singer and Keeper of the Tradition, Dies at 63
description: Jack Hardy, a folk singer and folk music promoter whose Greenwich Village recordings and songwriting workshops kept alive the neighborhood tradition of counterculture troubadours, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: For a Warm End to Winter
description: To celebrate the approaching end of this long, snowy winter, you might consider a visit to Sun Splash Jamaican Restaurant, where authentic island cuisine shines bright enough to warm the windiest of March days.

title: Indonesian Cuisine Makes the Scene
description: INDONESIAN food doesnt get much play on the American restaurant scene, which is surprising, given the popularity of other Asian cuisines. With the exception of satay, a Malaysian dish that has thoroughly penetrated the American market, Indonesian specialties remain a little exotic, even to our 21st-century global palates. But those coconut curries, tantalizing spice blends and unfamiliar menu names are well worth searching out. And New Havens Bentara restaurant, serving cuisine from the province of Kelantan in a quietly sophisticated setting, is a good place to start.

title: Taking on the Role of Gender in Media
description: NEAR the entrance to The Deconstructive Impulse, at the Neuberger Museum of Art, is Lynn Hershmans 1988 black-and-white photograph Seduction. In it, a woman vamps for the camera as she sprawls on a bed. She wears a short black dress and high heels, but instead of her head, a television set frames her oversize, mascara-heavy, closed eyes. The photograph is one of 68 works by 22 American artists supporting the shows premise, boldly stated in its subtitle: Women Artists Reconfigure the Signs of Power, 1973-1991.

title: Breeders Chasing the Superhorse
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  In the seemingly incomprehensible symbolism of alchemy, the copulation of kings and queens is viewed as a marriage of lower-value base elements like copper and iron to produce natures most precious metal, gold.

title: Two Artistic Giants, and the Man Who Manipulated Them
description: Thats Renaissance Florence on Hartford Stages proscenium, and those men in gold and purple robes and smart belted tunics are Michelangelo, Leonardo, Machiavelli and Soderini. With Michael Kramers Divine Rivalry, Michael Wilson, the companys departing artistic director, is going out in grand style.

title: Hartford Symphony Seeks to Stay Vital
description: LIKE many orchestras, the Hartford Symphony Orchestra is refashioning itself for the 21st century  a task for which its new music director, chosen after a search that began two years ago, seems particularly well suited.

title: When Punk Roots and Soul Collide
description: THE British singer Billy Bragg is known for his punk roots and for steering them in a folksy direction in recent years. He is not known for his contributions to gospel or soul music  which is not to say he would disavow a deep appreciation for those genres.

title: Photo Replay, March 12
description: A view of the day in sports, from Nagpur, India, to New Haven.

title: Higher Property Taxes, Teacher Cuts and Blame
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Playoffs Are in Sight as Devils Edge Isles
description: NEWARK  Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur has made more than 25,000 saves in his magnificent N.H.L. career, and a few hundred of them have probably been more memorable than the one he made on a third-period shot Saturday night. This save only extended his teams frantic playoff chase.

title: Mexican Police Upgrade Training
description: Local police forces in Mexico have lagged in training and professionalism. Both on the state and local level, the authorities are trying to improve their readiness for law enforcement and for local emergencies.

title: Policymakers Express Anxiety Over Hiring of Special Adviser at University of Texas
description: Late last month, three weeks after becoming chairman of the University of Texas System Board of Regents, Gene Powell selected Rick ODonnell, a former director of Colorados higher education department, to fill a newly created position, that of special adviser to the board.

title: Proposals Could Make It Harder to Leave Prison
description: Danny Bell sat on a brick ledge outside the plain, beige Greyhound station a block from the prison complex in Huntsville and, from behind dark shades, soaked in the sights and sounds of a world he had not seen in more than two decades.

title: Jonathan Toews, a Team Captain to Inspire His Elders
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Its Breakfast Time, and Education Will Pay
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Records Reveal Holes in Campaign-Finance Law
description: The highly acclaimed state campaign-finance law that took effect seven weeks before the Feb. 22 mayoral election declares that no individual can give more than $5,000 to a candidate, and no company can donate more than $10,000.

title: All in the Family
description: Under a new state law, candidates can receive no more than $5,000 from an individual donor or $10,000 from a corporation. Yet, Gery Chicos mayoral bid got $30,000 on Feb. 3 through contributions from six companies owned by the Puig family.

title: The Pulse: As the Price of Gasoline Rises, the City Fleet Is Saving Money
description: As gasoline prices race toward $4 a gallon, jumping 37 cents in the last two weeks, Chicagos Department of Fleet Management is benefiting from forward contracts that locked in some of the citys unleaded and diesel purchases before prices spiked.

title: The Pulse: Solis Changes a Position and Adds Crucial Support
description: As he faces off against a challenger in the April 5 runoff election, Alderman Daniel Solis (25th Ward) has abruptly changed his position and now supports an ordinance to curb pollution from a coal-fired power plant in the ward  a switch that has won him key union support in a tough race.

title: For Errant Lawmakers, a Heros Homecoming
description: The 14 Democratic state senators who fled Wisconsin nearly a month ago returned on Saturday to the cheers of tens of thousands who once again packed the streets in protest.

title: With Driver Malfunction Solved, Johnson Looks for a Victory at Doral
description: DORAL, Fla.  Dustin Johnson got off to an inauspicious start at the W.G.C.-Cadillac Championship, but after finishing with a flourish Saturday, he put himself in a good position to win it all.

title: An Uphill Climb to Compete for the Womens Title
description: In the sixth Womens Grand Prix in Doha, Qatar, which ended last weekend, Humpy Koneru of India and Nana Dzagnidze of Georgia had more to play for than the other participants. Depending on how they finished, one of them would earn the right to play Hou Yifan of China for the Womens World Championship this year.

title: Princeton Pauses but Still Beats Buzzer on Way to N.C.A.A. Bid
description: NEW HAVEN  Douglas Davis, the hottest player on the floor, caught the ball in the left corner, 25 feet from the basket with 2.8 seconds remaining in the game. Daviss Princeton Tigers trailed the Harvard Crimson, a team seeking its first N.C.A.A. tournament berth in 65 years, by a point.

title: Amid Shock and Hysteria Along I-95, a Tangle of Bodies and Survivors
description: Nothing about it sounded right. Nothing about it sounded good.

title: Shoe Marketer Who Enriched N.C.A.A. Takes on His Creation
description: Sonny Vaccaro signed Michael Jordan to his first shoe contract.

title: Asians Flock to South Bay, Census Shows
description: Jin Hu Jiang is part of the biggest demographic change in Silicon Valley over the past decade.

title: In Gettys Exclusive Preschool, Its Tough to Fly from Gilded Cage
description: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: An Unorthodox Life Yields a Novelist of Promise
description: Unlike a lot of other headline-grabbing debut novelists, Taylor Stevens did not graduate from a prestigious creative-writing program. In fact, she attended school only sporadically until sixth grade, when she stopped going entirely.

title: Corrections
description: POSTSCRIPT: MAGAZINE

title: The Shutdown Pushes the Fight for Field Position Into the Courtroom
description: On the day after the N.F.L. shut down with its first work stoppage in more than 20 years, the parallel tracks of its future crystallized.

title: Vows: Rebecca and Lee
description: When Rebecca moved to New York, she needed a dentist. Lee's surgery was conveniently across the road from her work. After multiple treatments, they fell in love and he is still her dentist.

title: Nuclear Emergency Is Worst in Decades
description: The earthquake and tsunami that battered northern Japan on Friday set in motion one of the worst nuclear accidents in over two decades.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 12, 2011

title: N.F.L. Players' Antitrust Filing
description: The 52-page lawsuit names 10 defendants, including Tom Brady, Peyton Manning and Drew Brees.

title: Questions About the Bracket and Beyond
description: The N.C.A.A. mens tournament bracket will be revealed at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, and questions remain.

title: Veering From Peaceful Models, Libyas Youth Revolt Turns Toward Chaos
description: RAS LANUF, Libya  It is a bromide of dictators like Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that they stand as the only bulwark against forces of chaos and religious militancy. The tragedy of Libyas uprising, its genesis in peaceful protests over a governments disdain for its people, is that Colonel Qaddafis own brutal repression from Tripoli east to Ras Lanuf and beyond may make the platitudes reality.

title: Rebels Withdraw to Ajdabiya
description: The Arab League endorsed a no-flight zone over Libya, but it was far from clear if such an action would be enough to stall the march of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis troops eastward to the rebel capital of Benghazi.

title: Workers Keep Their Jobs, Even After Repeat Offenses
description: An investigation by The Times found that state employees who sexually abused, beat or taunted residents of group homes were rarely fired, and in many cases, were simply transferred elsewhere.

title: A Case History: Roger Macomber
description: An edited selection of documents in the case of a developmental aid worker in western New York.

title: At State-Run Homes, Abuse and Impunity
description: Nearly 40 years after New York emptied its scandal-ridden warehouses for the developmentally disabled, the far-flung network of small group homes that replaced them operates with scant oversight and few consequences for employees who abuse the vulnerable population.

title: Uncle Mo Protects Reputation in Return
description: HALLANDALE, Fla.  The expectations for Uncle Mos return to the racetrack were huge. The colt is the undefeated 2-year-old champion, and the Timely Writer Stakes  a nontaxing one-turn mile  was written for him by Gulfstream Parks racing secretary so Uncle Mo would make his first start of the year here. But what about Uncle Mos opponents?

title: Hazards of Storing Spent Fuel
description: Dangerous conditions can occur if water drains from pools storing radioactive fuel rods.

title: Passing First, but Still Shooting
description: One of the top passing guards in the N.B.A., Jose Calderon of the Toronto Raptors, may want to consider whether he would be willing to pass the ball to himself.

title: Steal Age Wanes
description: It is a near certainty that this will be the 20th consecutive season that no player has averaged more than three steals a game.

title: Players Have Plenty to Say, in Short Bursts
description: The first sports work stoppage of the social networking era has left N.F.L. players concerned, confused and a little distracted. But they were chatty and  at least temporarily  united.

title: Knicks Expect Billups in Lineup on Sunday
description: Chauncey Billups practiced for the first time in two weeks and is expected to be in the starting lineup Sunday night when the Knicks host the Indiana Pacers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Iraqi Women Feel Shunted Despite Election Quota
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi women hoped that last years election would cement a larger role for them in the government. But they have less political influence today than at any time since the American invasion.

title: For a Fifth and Final Day, Walker Carries UConn
description: Late in the second half of Connecticuts victory in the Big East tournament final against Louisville, Kemba Walker came to the sideline and told his coach, Jim Calhoun, that he couldnt feel his legs.

title: Redesigned BMW 650i Coupe Unveiled
description: Following its convertible sibling, which was first shown at the Detroit auto show in January, the BMW 650i coupe broke cover on the Web on Saturday. A concept version of the coupe was shown at the Paris and LA auto shows last fall.

title: Satellite Photos of Japan, Before and After the Quake and Tsunami
description: Compare satellite images of areas of Japan before and after the disaster.

title: Miscues Cost Louisville the Chance to Play Spoiler
description: A few blocks from Broadway, Louisville has been cast in the role of spoiler recently at the Big East tournament. And with Connecticut becoming the toast of the town over the past week, the Cardinals found themselves a part of a familiar story line.

title: Big East Final Replay: March 12
description: Connecticuts Kemba Walker led the team to victory over Louisville in the Big East Conference final.

title: Rescue Effort in Japan Continues
description: Japan mobilized a nationwide rescue effort on Sunday to pluck survivors from collapsed buildings and rush food and water to thousands.

title: Lundqvist Sparkles, and Rangers Move Up a Spot in the East
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  A nervy shootout win, losses by their closest rivals for a playoff spot  all in all, a perfect Saturday night for the Rangers, turning what had been a dire sojourn in California into a happy one.

title: Second Explosion at Reactor as Technicians Try to Contain Damage
description: TOKYO  A second explosion rocked a troubled nuclear power plant Monday, blowing the roof off a containment building but not harming the reactor, Japanese nuclear officials announced on public television.

title: The Pentagons Biggest Boondoggles
description: AS our government teeters on the brink of a shutdown, and Congress and the president haggle over spending cuts, the Pentagon budget should be scoured for places where significant reductions may be made. Not the handful of trims alluded to by Defense Secretary Robert Gates  $78 billion over the next five years, with these savings simply used to shore up spending on other acquisitions  but major cuts to systems that dont work very well or that are not really going to be needed for decades to come.

title: Rooms Without a View
description: The view from my window is my jungle.

title: Death Toll Estimate in Japan Soars as Relief Efforts Intensify
description: SENDAI, Japan  Japan reeled from a rapidly unfolding disaster of epic scale on Sunday, pummeled by the death toll, destruction and homelessness caused by the earthquake and tsunami and new hazards from damaged nuclear reactors that were leaking radiation. The prime minister called it Japans worst crisis since World War II.

title: At Paris Salon, Nostalgia Is King
description: Top dealers in vintage clothing and knickknacks, from France and elsewhere in Europe, show up annually in Paris to sell their unusual, often one-of-a-kind items at the trendy Salon du Vintage. Running from March 18 to 20, this years show will feature 60 exhibitors offering everything from street clothes and sportswear to evening finery  plus the shoes, scarves, jewelry and hats to go with them. And although nostalgia is the theme, eras from the 1930s to the 90s will be represented.

title: For Arsenal, a Bitter Treble
description: Three weeks ago, Arsenal, coming off a thrilling first-leg win over Barcelona in the Champions League, was dreaming of winning as many as four trophies this season. A succession of painful defeats has reduced that number to one, and the teams reservoir of confidence to almost zero.

title: Urban Forager | Maple-Sugaring on Staten Island
description: Some may think maple-syrup-making can only happen in Vermont or Canada. But if last years little experiment sugaring in Brooklyn proved anything, it was that fine maple syrup could be made in New York City as well. I recently located a healthy sugar maple in the Stapleton section of Staten Island, and although it was already a little late in the season, I set up shop, hoping for a good run. Temperatures have to be just right for quality sap flow: more than 40 degrees in the daytime, dipping to freezing at night.

title: Remembering Tom Boisture, Who Helped Build Champions
description: With the draft the only sure thing remaining on the N.F.L. calendar, a few remarks about one of its better practitioners: Tom Boisture, the Giants longtime personnel director, who died Friday at age 79. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down.

title: March 13 Updates on Earthquake Aftermath in Japan
description: On Sunday, The Lede continues to supplement reporting from our colleagues in Japan on the aftermath of the devastating earthquake that struck the country on Friday, including the ongoing crisis at nuclear power plants. Updates below feature reports from other news sites and firsthand accounts, photographs and video posted on social media networks.

title: In Brooklyn Scuffle With Suspect, Officer Falls Over a Railing and Dies
description: It was a relatively routine call, the kind that the New York City police usually handle without too much trouble. A frightened woman in Brooklyn telephoned 911 early Sunday morning and reported that her ex-boyfriend was threatening her.

title: Israel to Step Up Pace of Construction in West Bank Areas
description: JERUSALEM  Israel said Sunday that it would build hundreds of new housing units within the populous West Bank settlement blocs, ending a slowdown in government-supported construction that had lasted several months.

title: Japan
description: Obviously not up my alley; Im just watching the images in horror like everyone else. If you havent done so already, check out the Timess awesome and disturbing before-and-after satellite photo multimedia.

title: Interview: Danny DeVito
description: The actor Danny DeVito discusses his new film "Girl Walks Into a Bar," which screened at SXSW and is also now on YouTube.

title: The Wisconsin Effect
description: The big question about Wisconsin has been whether the controversy would just fade away, or whether it would serve as a rallying cry for an extended period. If yesterdays crowds were any indication, this is a long way from over:

title: Postscript: Aggregation Aggro
description: Nothing sucks the joy out of a column like explaining it. And judging from the reaction to my little poke at the self-obsession of the media tribe, most readers needed no explanation. They got it. But for those who may have been misled by some of the more clueless commentary:

title: Stocks in Japan Plunge as Investors Worry
description: HONG KONG  The Japanese stock market plunged Monday morning as investors struggled to assess the impact of the huge earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan on Friday.

title: Coming Into Character
description: A look at the work of the artist Jim Nutt.

title: Cockroach Ideas
description: Way back, when I spent a year in the government, an old hand told me that fighting bad ideas is like flushing cockroaches down the toilet; they just come right back. Im having that feeling a lot lately, on at least two fronts.

title: For Neighbor of Stricken Nuclear Plant, Second Thoughts About a Centerpiece
description: KORIYAMA, Japan  When the earthquake and tsunami struck Friday, Kumiko Fukaya ignored the evacuation order that afternoon and instead gathered up her teenage son and daughter, her mother and her older sister. Afraid to sleep in the house, they spent the night in her blue 2010 Toyota hatchback.

title: Santana Denies Report That He Will Be Shut Down
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Johan Santana never figured to have a prominent role on the Mets this season, but he still hopes to recover from shoulder surgery and pitch in some games in 2011.

title: State Department Spokesman Out, After Comments on Prisoner
description: P.J. Crowley, the state department spokesman, stepped down Sunday after saying publicly that treatment of Wikileaks suspect Pfc. Bradley Manning in military detention has been ridiculous and counterproductive and stupid.

title: Antigovernment Protesters Seal Off Bahrains Financial Center
description: CAIRO  Thousands of antigovernment protesters in Bahrain blocked access to the financial district in Manama, the capital, on Sunday, preventing workers from getting to their offices and pushing back police officers who tried to disperse them.

title: Seawalls Offered Little Protection Against Tsunamis Crushing Waves
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  At least 40 percent of Japans 22,000-mile coastline is lined with concrete seawalls, breakwaters or other structures meant to protect the country against high waves, typhoons or even tsunamis. They are as much a part of Japans coastal scenery as beaches or fishing boats, especially in areas where the government estimates the possibility of a major earthquake occurring in the next three decades at more than 90 percent, like the northern stretch that was devastated by Fridays earthquake and tsunami.

title: At Sendai City Hall, a Relief Center, Thousands Wait and Wonder Whats Next
description: SENDAI, Japan  The central portion of the city of Sendai, the namesake of the quake-tsunami-nuclear disaster now afflicting Japan, was remarkably spared from the worst of the damage and by Sunday had been transformed into a large makeshift emergency relief center, with Japans military authorities commandeering the eight-floor City Hall to treat evacuees.

title: Digital Collaboration at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Two films screening together at this years South by Southwest festival look at the way that art is shifting in a digital age.

title: Roast, as Usual, on the Gridiron Menu
description: Whether it was worth the wait is beside the point: In the third year of his term, President Obama on Saturday finally attended the annual dinner-and-spoofs gala of the 126-year-old Gridiron Club, made up of Washingtons journalistic elite, and won the night with his roast of Republicans, Democrats, the media and  what was most appreciated  himself.

title: Ruling Party Is Accused of Fraud in Russian Vote
description: MOSCOW  Voters in Russia went to the polls on Sunday in regional elections amid complaints by the opposition of ballot-stuffing and other violations by the governing party, United Russia.

title: Welsh Remains in the Game
description: Tim Welsh was back at the Big East tournament this past week for the first time since he was fired as Providences coach in 2008.

title: Day 3: Japans Nuclear Woes
description: The Japanese government is now attempting to keep two nuclear reactors cool to prevent fuel from cracking or melting which would result in the release of highly radioactive fission products.

title: Frontier Womans Desperate Proposition
description: In what it calls its season of stereotypes, Metropolitan Playhouse, a company that specializes in raidings of the lost archives, has already staged The Drunkard and Uncle Toms Cabin from the 19th century. Now it offers The Great Divide, a more obscure 1906 melodrama that provides a new set of clichd characters who, at their best, are intriguing reflections of a changing nation.

title: Monday: What M&Ms Do
description: Administrivial Update: Earlier, I touched on dropping in to visit the goings-on at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, taking place this Friday, March 18 through Sunday, March 20. Id like to elaborate on that: Drop-ins are welcomed Sunday morning starting at 11:00 AM. There is a crossword contestants talent show from 11:00-Noon. Then the playoffs are held (division C, B and A) and the awards are handed out. The whole event is over by about 1:30. The cost for this is $30, which includes copies of all the tournament puzzles over the weekend. People should register ahead of time, if possible. The registration form is here: http://www.crosswordtournament.com/info/onlinereg.htmIt is also still possible for people to register for the tournament. Registration is accepted at the door on Friday up to 8 P.M. as well as on Saturday morning between 9:30-11:00 A.M. Full information about the tournament, including bios and photos of this years constructors, appears at www.crosswordtournament.com.

title: Aboard the Intrepid, Gobs of Nautical Terms
description: Dont worry, well keep it clean, Mark Roberts said, sounding reassuring right from the beginning.

title: Milestone Referendum in Egypt Just Days Away
description: CAIRO  With the referendum over the constitutional amendments that will shape Egypts immediate political future just days away, the countrys nascent political forces were squaring off on Sunday, scrambling to influence a choice that leaves many confused.

title: Selection Sunday: What a Player Thinks
description: Selection Sunday is here  the day that we have all been waiting for. Joe Lunardi, the apparent bracketology guru, has generously provided us all a foundation of expectations. Everyone has been blogging and dropping Twitter bombs from the sky with their own opinions and predictions. The analysts are matching tournament resumes and trying to determine who deserves to be in and who deserves to be out, calculating R.P.I.s and often using simply the transitive property  If we beat North Carolina, and North Carolina beat Duke, then clearly we are a No. 1 seed. That would be nice.

title: Selection Sunday Analysis
description: Zach Hillesland, a former forward for Notre Dame who contributes to the Quad, provided analysis as the field was selected for the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Auto Plants in Japan Remain Closed as Companies Take Stock
description: Most Japanese auto assembly plants will remain closed on Monday, even though the factories are outside the hardest-hit regions and did not experience significant damage from the devastating earthquake and tsunami that struck on Friday.

title: A Teddy Bear on the Hot Seat, With Hysteria Swirling All Around
description: Osama bin Laden. Carlos the Jackal. The Unabomber. Charles Manson. O. J. Simpson. Intoned with studied gravitas by a cable news reporter, that villainous lineup acquires a polarizing new entry in a sentient teddy bear named Winkie.

title: From Twilights Mysteries Right Up to the 25th Hour
description: Serious though they may be, the members of the Emerson String Quartet are clearly not above having a bit of fun, as parts of the concert the group presented at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening made clear. Likewise the flutist James Galway, for all his popular appeal and crossover success, is eminently capable of turning in a high-minded, strait-laced performance. What might have been a bipolar collaboration instead showed disparate parts blended into a complementary whole.

title: Looking for the Gal That Got Away?
description: A recreation of one of the greatest nights in show business history promised the press release for The Great Judy Garland, the New York Pops concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening. The epochal event to be resurrected was Garlands famous comeback in the same hall 50 years ago, on April 23, 1961.

title: Rameaus Blend, the Toast of France
description: Quick, name the composer whose theater works are the hardest to pull off without staging. Wagner? You might think so, but certain near-static productions have shown how thoroughly his musical dramaturgy survives a lack of motion and scenery. Verdi? His greatest operas provide enough character depth and narrative impetus to go bare, as Riccardo Muti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra will try to show with a concert version of Otello at Carnegie Hall in April.

title: Joe Morello, Drummer with Dave Brubeck Quartet, Dies at 82
description: Joe Morello, a jazz drummer whose elegant, economical playing in the Dave Brubeck Quartet sounded natural and effortless even in unusual time signatures, died on Saturday at his home in Irvington, N.J. He was 82.

title: When We All Pulled Together, Like Those Boys in Uniform
description: The moment on Saturday evening that distilled the cheerful gung-ho spirit of the new Lyrics & Lyricists show, Stage Door Canteen: Broadway Responds to World War II, belonged to the song-and-dance man Jeffry Denman. As he strolled, cane in hand, onto the stage of the Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92nd Street Y, Mr. Denman was every inch the spiffy, confident vaudevillian eager to entertain.

title: A Letter from the Postmaster
A Bid Can Be Brave or Foolhardy, or Sometimes a Bit of Both
description: At the American Contract Bridge Leagues Spring North American Championships in Louisville, Ky., the Lebhar IMP Pairs, which ended Saturday, showed how international these tournaments have become. The event was won by Runar Lillevik and Oyvind Ludvigsen from Norway. They finished 5 international match points ahead of Jon Baldursson and Thorlakur Jonsson from Iceland. Third were Hector Camberos of Charlotte, N.C. (who has played many times for Argentina), and Carlos Pellegrini from Argentina.

title: Look Out, Celebrities: Her Aim Is True
description: As just about any well-known actress who has made the mistake of going to Starbucks without makeup can attest, fame can be a cruel mistress. Her most tenaciously censorious handmaiden is surely Kathy Griffin, the flame-haired, torch-tongued stand-up comedian who has claimed the hypocrisies, peculiarities, misjudged plastic surgeries and occasional court appearances of semi-, quasi- and actual celebrities as her particular turf.

title: Betting on Not-So-Sure Things: Love and a Trick to Win at Cards
description: Among other things, Tchaikovskys mysterious, psychologically complex opera The Queen of Spades is a tough, and quite revealing, conducting assignment. But this is not the only reason there was heightened anticipation over the appearance of the Latvian conductor Andris Nelsons, 32, when Elijah Moshinskys production of this great 1890 work returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night.

title: Basking in a Rappers Glow, Feeling Burned
description: It is the age of the plus-one in hip-hop. More than 30 years of rap stars have created untold classes of hangers-on who crave a piece of the action: managers, label mates, even wives and children. Now more than ever, rap success can be measured more by what your fame does for those around you than by the fame itself.

title: U.S. Nuclear Industry Faces New Uncertainty
description: WASHINGTON  The fragile bipartisan consensus that nuclear power offers a big piece of the answer to Americas energy and global warming challenges may have evaporated as quickly as confidence in Japans crippled nuclear reactors.

title: A Girl, a Bar and Danny DeVito
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Danny DeVitos career has taken him a tremendous number of places, with varied roles on stage, screen and television. He can add another to his rsum: YouTube. That is where his latest film, Girl Walks into a Bar, now resides. The film, directed by Sebastian Gutierrez, had its premiere on Friday at SXSW and on YouTube. It features Carla Gugino as the titular girl and connects several stories that take place in 10 bars around Los Angeles. Mr. DeVito plays a character in one of those bars, and he took a moment to talk about working on a film made for the Internet and his attempt, generally, to avoid Italian-American gangster roles.

title: 520 Miles of Waterfront to Get Long-Range Plan
description: Less than five years ago, preservationists criticized the Bloomberg administration for allowing Ikea to pave over a dock for repairing ships in Red Hook, Brooklyn. They said city officials had forsaken New Yorks working waterfront by catering to developers of hangar-size stores and luxury condominiums.

title: Where Human and Animal Worlds Come Together
description: The dark, strange imagination of Jill Sigman is a theatrical phenomenon unto itself. In Fowl Play: Some Dances About Civilization, performed at the 92nd Street Y on Friday night, Ms. Sigman offered three pieces that clearly belonged to the same oddly coherent universe. Its one in which human and animal behaviors are simultaneously visible, in which hallucinatory landscapes are conjured and dispelled with dreamlike elisions, and in which movement surges in uneasy fits and starts through the dancers bodies.

title: A Festival of Japans Culture Proceeds
description: When Carnegie Hall announced Japan as the focus of this seasons big festival, it did not seem a particularly pathbreaking subject. Now it seems prescient.

title: In Deadly Earthquake, Echoes of 1923
description: The earthquake hit in the early afternoon off the coast of Honshu, Japans most populous island, triggering unprecedented destruction. Ninety percent of the houses in a score of seaside towns collapsed in seconds. Passenger trains fell off railway bridges and plunged into the sea. A few minutes later, a 35-foot-high tsunami rolled in, sweeping away cars, houses and thousands of people, and burying entire towns in mud. Then came fires, fanned by winds and fueled by flimsy wooden houses, reducing much of what remained to ashes.

title: Very, Very Bad Things, Very, Very Tiny Packages
description: Paul McEuens techno-thriller, Spiral, sounds like something written by Michael Crichton in his prime. Its actually better than a lot of what Mr. Crichton wrote once his prime was over.

title: State Legislatures Slow on Immigration Measures
description: Under newly fortified Republican control, many state governments started the year pledging forceful action to crack down on illegal immigration, saying they would fill a void left by the stalemate in Washington over the issue.

title: Several Plant Workers Are Ill, but Radiation Risk in Japan Is Seen as Low for Now
description: Although several plant workers are ill from radioactive exposure in Japan, the radiation risk to the public appears low so far, experts said.

title: How to Win a Pool That Rewards Upsets
description: In 1996, Princeton, seeded 13th, defeated U.C.L.A. in the first round of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, busting just about everyones bracket.

title: Trip to California Gives Rangers a Surprising Lift
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  The Rangers shootout victory over the San Jose Sharks on Saturday, coupled with losses by the Rangers two closest rivals for a playoff berth, turned what had been a dire weeklong sojourn in California into a happy one.

title: A Broadway Superlative for All the Wrong Reasons
description: After a year of false starts the producers of Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark proclaimed in January that their Broadway musical would absolutely open on a newly set date, March 15. Most of the cast and crew members werent buying it.

title: Poker Bots Invade Online Gambling
description: Bryan Taylor, 36, could not shake the feeling that something funny was going on. Three of his most frequent opponents on an online poker site were acting oddly, playing in ways that were so similar it was suspicious.

title: Clashes Erupt as Protests Continue in Yemens Capital
description: SANA, Yemen  In a sign of increasing tensions here in the Yemeni capital, clashes broke out on Sunday for the second consecutive day at an antigovernment demonstration, a continuous sit-in that has lasted for about three weeks.

title: Olivier Awards Bypass Andrew Lloyd Webber
description: At Sunday nights Olivier Awards, Britains equivalent to the Tony Awards, the Society of London Theater gave three prizes to the West End production of Legally Blonde, the Musical, but none to Andrew Lloyd Webber. Legally Blonde won best new musical, and two of its stars also took prizes, Sheridan Smith for best actress in a musical and Jill Halfpenny for best supporting actress in a musical. The award for best new play went to the Royal Courts production of Clybourne Park, Bruce Norriss political comedy about race relations in suburban America. (The play had a critically acclaimed run Off Broadway at Playwrights Horizons in 2010.) Other winners included Roger Allam for best actor, in Henry IV, Parts 1 and 2 at Shakespeares Globe, and the actress Nancy Carroll for her turn in the World War II drama After the Dance, which won for best revival. The award for direction went to Howard Davies for The White Guard, which also took best lighting and set design. Love Never Dies, Mr. Lloyd Webbers anticipated but poorly received sequel to The Phantom of the Opera, won nothing after receiving seven nominations in major categories. Stephen Sondheim was honored with a special award for his contributions to London theater.

title: Amazon Pressured on Sales Tax
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Across the country, state officials struggling with big budget shortfalls are trying to get Amazon.com to take on a role it does not want: tax collector.

title: At Crossroads, Libya Rebels Vow to Stand or Die
description: AJDABIYA, Libya  Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi advanced Sunday on this anxious town, a strategic linchpin on the doorstep of the opposition capital Benghazi and within grasp of a highway crucial to recapturing the eastern border and encircling the rebellion with heavy armor and artillery.

title: Mars Needs Moms ... and Paying Customers
description: The box office bomb Hall of Fame  Ishtar, The Alamo, Cutthroat Island, Gigli, Speed Racer  has a new member. Mars Needs Moms cost $150 million to make (excluding marketing) and managed to bring in only $6.8 million in North American ticket sales over the weekend. What happened? Unappealing alien characters, a tepid marketing campaign, family film gridlock at theaters and the movies antifeminist undertones contributed. But Hollywood will read this Walt Disney Studios flop as a rejection of Robert Zemeckiss style of performance-capture animated filmmaking. (Mr. Zemeckis produced Mars Needs Moms.) Meanwhile a well-executed marketing push by Sony Pictures Entertainment catapulted Battle: Los Angeles to a stronger-than-expected No. 1 position over the weekend. This alien invasion movie had about $36 million in sales, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data. The animated Rango (Paramount Pictures) held up in its second weekend, taking in about $23 million for a new total of $68.7 million and second place. Red Riding Hood (Warner Brothers) failed to tap into the Twilight fantasy fan base, selling a soft $14 million in third place. The Adjustment Bureau, a drama from Universal Pictures, was fourth in its second weekend, selling about $11.5 million for a new total of $38.5 million. Mars Needs Moms (a scene from the film, right) was fifth.

title: Muti Leads Encore in Rome
description: Riccardo Muti, below, conducted the audience in a rare encore of Va pensiero during a production of Verdis Nabucco at Teatro dellOpera in Rome on Saturday night, The Associated Press reported. At the beginning of the show, Mr. Muti criticized the government for cutting Italys arts budget. When the crowd cheered for more after the choruss rendition of Va pensiero, Mr. Muti said he would allow an encore if the audience sang along in support of culture and patriotism. Less than five weeks after having heart surgery, and against the advice of his doctors, Mr. Muti was back at the podium on Saturday for the first of several performances of Nabucco planned for this month as part of Italys celebration of 150 years of national unity.
