I dont want, today, in 2011, that Nabucco becomes a funeral hymn to culture and music, Mr. Muti said before starting. He appeared energetic during the performance, according to The A.P., despite having had a pacemaker installed recently. In February, Mr. Muti fell from the podium during a rehearsal with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, of which he is the music director. He had what his doctor called a common heart rhythm disturbance. He is scheduled to conduct a concert performance of Otello in April at Carnegie Hall.

title: Technical Issues Delay Foxs Terra Nova
description: Fox is forgoing its planned preview this spring of Terra Nova, an ambitious drama involving time travel. The network said Friday that Terra Nova would have its premiere in the fall rather than in May, as it had been planned. The May premiere was intended to be a preview of the show, but the special effects will not be ready in time, Foxs president of entertainment, Kevin Reilly, said in a statement. The visual effects are essential, he said, so we are pushing back the special early preview date to give the visual effects team the time needed for their groundbreaking work. The Terra Nova story starts in 2149, when Earth is dying and scientists must find a way to send a family back to a prehistoric, dinosaur-era version of the planet. In the place of Terra Nova on May 23 and 24, Fox will show the season finales of The Chicago Code and Glee.

title: Novel of Wartime Berlin to Get a Fresh Life
description: Every Man Dies Alone, a German novel about a husband and wife who oppose the Nazis in early 1940s Berlin, is about to be published there for second time, but with much more attention, the BBC News reported. The novel, by Hans Fallada, is based on the true story of Otto and Elise Hampel, who wrote anti-Hitler slogans on postcards and dropped them in public buildings. They were eventually arrested and executed. Fallada wrote the book soon after the war ended, when he was given the Hampels Gestapo file. The book was written quickly and had a quiet release in Germany in 1947, just after Falladas death. But it was not widely read until 2009, after its release in the United States and Britain. Aufbau publishing house in Berlin recently uncovered the unabridged manuscript and will publish a new edition, which is to include a deleted chapter depicting the Quangels, as the couple is called in the novel, as fans of Hitler until they learn of their sons death on the German front. Penguin has said it is considering a release of the unabridged version in Britain.

title: G.M.s Will Consider Changes for Player Safety
description: As N.H.L. general managers gather Monday in Boca Raton, Fla., for their annual meeting, the focus will be on whether to recommend a broadening of Rule 48, the regulation outlawing blindside hits to the head.

title: Cashing In Coins and Skipping the Surcharge
description: AT Coinstar, which operates about 19,000 coin-counting machines in supermarkets and other spots, marketers analyze consumer data closely  but sometimes they just like to watch.

title: Mexico Puts Its Children on a Diet
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexico put its schoolchildren on a diet at the beginning of the year. But as often happens with New Years resolutions, there are many ways to cheat. Here is some of what is allowed for sale in schools under new guidelines that are intended to combat childhood obesity: lollipops, potato and corn chips (in multiple guises), and cookies (complemented by marshmallow or chocolate filling).

title: Watney Wins at Doral; Woods Bounces Back
description: MIAMI  For most of the final round at the World Golf Championship event on Sunday, it was a battle of big bombers, Nick Watney and Dustin Johnson, two of the longest hitters in the game trading punches like heavyweight boxers.

title: In Turkey, Thousands Protest a Crackdown on Press Freedom
description: ISTANBUL  Thousands of people marched in central Istanbul on Sunday to protest a crackdown on the press in Turkey after the arrest of more than a dozen journalists this month.

title: In Tight Times, PBS Leans on Pledge Drives
description: If it feels as though Suze Orman and the cast of Les Misrables have taken over your local public television station, youre not dreaming.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Advice on How to Fix Spider-Man
description: It was a rough week for the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark. The producers announced on Wednesday that the director Julie Taymor was stepping aside from the now $70 million production. On Friday, they announced that about three weeks of performances, from April 19 through May 11, would be canceled to provide time for their newly hired creative team to rehearse significant and exciting revisions to the show. They also picked a new date, June 14, for their opening night, which has now been delayed six times.

title: Mets Santana Plays Down Doubts About Return This Year
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Johan Santana never figured to have a prominent role on the Mets this season, but he still hopes to recover from shoulder surgery and pitch in some games in 2011.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of March 14
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include import prices for February (Tuesday); the producer price index for February, housing starts for February, and the current account deficit for the fourth quarter (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Consumer Price Index for February, industrial production and capacity utilization for February, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for March, and leading economic indicators for February (Thursday).

title: Some Circle the Date for a Day of Accustomed Sadness
description: Perhaps it is not a coincidence that the field for the N.C.A.A. mens tournament is announced on a Sunday each March. After all, Selection Sunday is a holy day for some. For others, it means spending a full day in prayer hoping their team receives an invitation.

title: Charlie Sheen Helps Make a Name for Ustream
description: His last job was on a network sitcom that drew 15 million viewers a week. Now Charlie Sheen, fallen television star, delivers nonsensical, expletive-laced rants before an audience of roughly three million on a live video-streaming Web site called Ustream, whose most prominent claim to fame was showing the early lives of six Japanese hunting dogs.

title: D.L. Cox, a Leader of Radicals During 1960s, Dies at 74
description: Donald L. Cox, who was at the center of black radical politics as a member of the Black Panther Party high command and who earned a moment of celebrity in 1970 when he spoke at the Leonard Bernstein fund-raising party in Manhattan made notorious by the writer Tom Wolfe, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Camps-sur-lAgly, France. He was 74.

title: Riveras Art, as Always, Is Strictly Minimalist
description: TAMPA, Fla.  In the sixth inning Sunday, Jason Kubel of the Minnesota Twins struck out looking at a 92-mile-per-hour two-seam fastball that started along the inside corner before curling over the plate. It is practically unhittable, the type of pitch that often needs seven weeks of refining before it is ready to unveil in the regular season. It was also the fourth pitch thrown in a game this spring training by the Yankees Mariano Rivera.

title: Mobile Start-Up Aims to Upstage Text-Messaging
description: When people were seeking to contribute money after the earthquake in Haiti last year, the Red Cross offered a simple solution: text-message the word Haiti to 90999. Thats when it became clear to many that text-messaging could work for commerce.

title: Adieu, Sweet Life of 20s Luxury
description: In its heyday, it was the epitome of an era that haunts us still as a fleeting moment of America on the cusp of something it never quite duplicated or achieved  money with style, sin that seemed innocent, human-scale pleasures, a jazz-inflected version of the American dream minus todays cynicism and rust.

title: A Possible Lesson From the Luddites
description: The British weavers known as the Luddites, who destroyed looms 200 years ago, thought rising unemployment within their ranks was because of machinery. But theres a case that inflation, money supply expansion, budget deficits and trade barriers were equally to blame. Maybe we havent learned much in two centuries.

title: Whole Foods to Sponsor Environmental Film Festival
description: LOS ANGELES  Rutabagas. Rice cakes. Roll em?

title: For Cuomo, Slower Pace on Addressing Mandates
description: Four days after taking office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo established committees to tackle what he called two of the biggest problems facing New York: rising Medicaid costs and state spending requirements that drive up local property taxes.

title: By Asking for Less, Obama May Reap More
description: The biggest difference in this new phase of Barack Obamas presidency: hes not so needy.

title: Fiddling While Libya Burns
description: PRESIDENT Obama says the noose is tightening around Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. In fact, it is tightening around the Libyan rebels, as Colonel Qaddafi makes the most of the worlds dithering and steadily retakes rebel-held towns. The United States and Europe are temporizing on a no-flight zone while the Organization of the Islamic Conference, the Gulf Cooperation Council and now the Arab League have all called on the United Nations Security Council to authorize one. Opponents of a no-flight zone have put forth five main arguments, none of which, on close examination, hold up.

title: A Postcard to the Pacific Northwest: Prepare
description: Most Dot Earth postcards come from places. Heres one being sent out to a place  specifically the Pacific Northwest and particularly Oregon.

title: In Lockout, Loopholes Replace Regulations
description: As long as the N.F.L. lockout continues, no signings, trades, practices or games will take place. But the ripple effects from this work stoppage are potentially more unsettling as layers of regulation are peeled away.

title: Chinas Gradual Revolution
description: ABOUT a week after Egyptian protesters forced out President Hosni Mubarak, anonymous calls demanding a similar revolution in China appeared on Web sites hosted outside of China. The unnamed activists asked people to gather every Sunday at designated spots in 13 Chinese cities.

title: Military Crew Said to Be Exposed to Radiation, but Officials Call Risk in U.S. Slight
description: The Pentagon was expected to announce that the aircraft carrier Ronald Reagan, which is sailing in the Pacific, passed through a radioactive cloud from stricken nuclear reactors in Japan, causing crew members on deck to receive a months worth of radiation in about an hour, government officials said Sunday.

title: Campaigning as All Things to All Republicans
description: CONCORD, N.H.  Many aspiring Republican presidential candidates are going to great lengths to avoid the spotlight, but not Tim Pawlenty. He is doing whatever he can to step into it.

title: Founder of a Provocative Web Site Forms a New Outlet
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  For most entrepreneurs, running a Web site that is rife with pornography and frequently criticized as a menace to society would not be considered a rsum booster. Many venture capitalists would head in the opposite direction.

title: Bus Swerved Repeatedly Before Crash, Riders Say
description: In interviews with investigators, witnesses to the gruesome bus crash that killed 14 people in the Bronx over the weekend said the bus had repeatedly veered off Interstate 95 and onto the shoulder of the highway before the accident, a law enforcement official said on Sunday.

title: Disruptions of Power and Water Threaten Japans Economy
description: As the humanitarian and nuclear crises in Japan escalated after the devastating earthquake and tsunami, the impact on the countrys economy appeared to be spreading as well.

title: Chinese Community Devastated After Bus Crash
description: The arc of some of their lives followed a common, defining narrative of the immigrant experience. Two of the men had worked in restaurants, one as a cook and the other as a waiter in Manhattans Chinatown. Their wives had worked in garment factories. A fifth victim had worked for a grocery store, and lived in a Chinese enclave in Brooklyn.

title: For Detroit Schools, Mixed Picture on Reforms
description: DETROIT  In 2009, Detroit public schools had the lowest scores ever recorded in the 21-year history of the national math proficiency test.

title: Radioactive Releases in Japan Could Last Months, Experts Say
description: WASHINGTON  As the scale of Japans nuclear crisis begins to come to light, experts in Japan and the United States say the country is now facing a cascade of accumulating problems that suggest that radioactive releases of steam from the crippled plants could go on for weeks or even months.

title: Lottery Numbers
Mr. Malikis Power Grab
description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq is drawing the wrong lessons from the upheavals in the Arab world. Inspired by uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt, thousands of Iraqis have taken to the streets to criticize their governments failure to combat corruption, create more jobs or improve electricity and other services. Nearly 20 Iraqis have been killed in clashes with security forces.

title: When Unrest Stirs, Bloggers Are Already in Place
description: As the protests spread across Tunisia for weeks, many international news organizations scrambled to cover the unrest just before President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali fled on Jan. 14, ending 23 years of authoritarian rule. But Amira al-Hussaini was all over the story.

title: Gulf Oil Spill Damages, Phase Two
description: There must be days when Kenneth Feinberg, who administered the 9/11 victims fund nearly a decade ago, asks himself why he ever volunteered to run the $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. He has heard little but criticism  some justified and helpful, some unfair and unhelpful  from the start.

title: With 11 Teams in Expanded Bracket, Big East Is a Region All Its Own
description: As the N.C.A.A. unveiled the new 68-team format for its mens basketball tournament Sunday, the defining quality of this years field was not the brackets redesign, but the record 11 teams from the Big East to earn an invitation.

title: Clear Your Calendar; It Will Be a Busy Month
description: Leo Tolstoy once wrote, Happy N.C.A.A. tournament experiences are all alike. He later switched the line to happy families are all alike when he changed Anna Karenina from a Purdue point guard to a Russian aristocrat. But Tolstoy was on to something.

title: The Cheaters and Their Banks
description: The Obama administration is rightly keeping the pressure on tax cheats and the bank executives who help them by stashing their money in secret accounts overseas. Now we would like to see the Internal Revenue Service and the Justice Department take the battle to the banks themselves. Thats the only way of getting them to drop this lucrative and illegal business.

title: Listen to Judge Lippman
description: Acknowledging New Yorks deep fiscal crisis, Judge Jonathan Lippman, the states chief judge, has reluctantly agreed to make cuts in his $2.7 billion budget request, including a reduction in the number of people working for the court system. But he is refusing to back down on his call for a $25 million increase, to $40 million, in support for civil legal service programs that help low-income New Yorkers faced with foreclosures, evictions, domestic violence and other serious legal problems.

title: Boys and Girls High and Murry Bergtraum Repeat as City Champions
description: The boys and girls city basketball crowns remained untarnished Sunday in the Public Schools Athletic League AA championship games at Madison Square Garden.

title: Quake Moves Japan Closer to U.S. and Alters Earths Spin
description: The magnitude-8.9 earthquake that struck northern Japan on Friday not only violently shook the ground and generated a devastating tsunami, it also moved the coastline and changed the balance of the planet.

title: Undaunted, New Batch of Gamblers Takes a Trip
description: Darkness had fallen by the time the machinist from Brooklyn slipped into the plush back seat of the bus that would ferry him on Saturday night from Chinatown to the Mohegan Sun casino, three hours away. Fiftyish, with a lined face and doleful brown eyes made huge by thick glasses, the machinist was not especially proud of his gambling habit, which preyed on his desires while thinning his wallet.

title: Billups Returns, but Rhythm Goes Absent
description: After two weeks of involuntary separation, the three pillars of the Knicks lineup stood together again Sunday night, shoulder to shoulder to slightly lower shoulder. Chauncey Billups was back, restoring the so-called Big Three with Amare Stoudemire and Carmelo Anthony.

title: Metropolitan Diary: Readers Tales From the City
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Look at the Mechanics of a Partial Meltdown
description: The difference between a partial meltdown and a full meltdown at a nuclear plant is enormous, both in the degree of damage and in the potential release of radiation, experts in nuclear power said.

title: After Quake and Tsunami, Japanese Citizens Flock to Social Networks for Information
description: With the explosions at the Fukushima Daini nuclear power plant causing widespread concern after the earthquake and tsunami on Friday, many Japanese citizens used Twitter over the weekend to express their fears and to debate the need for nuclear energy.

title: On Long Island, Fatal Shooting Is a Case of Mistaken Identity
description: A police officer responding in plain clothes with a rifle to a confrontation with a knife-wielding deranged man was fatally shot by an officer from another department on Long Island Saturday night shortly after the suspect had been shot to death, the police said.

title: Another Retirement Option
description: To the Editor:

title: Using a Formula to Rate Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Kidney Transplants
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Nuclear Plants Have Same Risks, and Backups, as Japan Counterparts
description: With the Japanese authorities working to avert a catastrophic meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant and one other Japanese plant showing problems, the safety of Americas nuclear plants  and the wisdom of any expansion  is beginning to come under a new round of scrutiny.

title: Figure in Insider Case Sought to Quit Goldman
description: Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs director accused by the government of passing insider information about the Wall Street firm, had tried to resign from the Goldman board in the middle of the 2008 financial crisis, only weeks before he is said to have provided the tips to the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam.

title: Radiation and Pregnancy
description: Douglas Almond, a Columbia University economist who has studied the effects of the Chernobyl disaster, is concerned that the Japanese government may not be doing enough to warn pregnant women to leave any areas at risk of radiation exposure. Those areas can be much farther from the nuclear plants than many people realize.

title: Another Inside Job
description: Count me among those who were glad to see the documentary Inside Job win an Oscar. The film reminded us that the financial crisis of 2008, whose aftereffects are still blighting the lives of millions of Americans, didnt just happen  it was made possible by bad behavior on the part of bankers, regulators and, yes, economists.

title: Residents Who Escaped Return to See What, if Anything, Is Left of Their Lives
description: NATORI, Japan  One couple rode out the tsunami on top of an irrigation tower, crammed in with three other people. A man had to abandon his car in a field and run for it. Another couple simply got lucky, riding out the torrents in their house, one of the few in a swath of destruction that inexplicably held together.

title: Iraq Then, Libya Now
description: Five years ago, in the darkest days of insurgent violence and Sunni-Shia strife, it seemed as if the Iraq war would shadow American foreign policy for decades, frightening a generations worth of statesmen away from using military force. Where there had once been a Vietnam syndrome, now there would be an Iraq syndrome, inspiring harrowing flashbacks to Baghdad and Falluja in any American politician contemplating an intervention overseas.

title: Parity May Have Its Day, but Elite Seeds Will Prevail
description: The odds of picking a perfect N.C.A.A. tournament bracket, even before the field expanded to 68 this year, were somewhere in the neighborhood of one in nine quintillion. We will forgo showing the math for the 68-team field and assure you that there was a better chance that Connecticut guard Kemba Walker spent Sunday doing hours of voluntary wind sprints than you have of acing your office pool.

title: The Interpretation of Trends in Teenage Sexuality
description: To the Editor:

title: College for Everyone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Official Exits State Dept. After Jabs at Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department spokesman, Philip J. Crowley, resigned on Sunday, three days after publicly criticizing the Pentagon as ridiculous and counterproductive and stupid in its treatment of Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, the soldier imprisoned on charges of leaking classified government documents to the antisecrecy group WikiLeaks.

title: Discouraging Home Buyers
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Virginia Officers and Suspect Killed
description: A shootout in southwestern Virginia on Sunday left two deputy sheriffs dead and two injured, one critically. The suspected gunman was also killed.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: The News, in Bright Bits
description: Somewhere along the line, utility became a bad word at news magazines. And thats where The Week saw an opening.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Day of Preparation
description: The fate of Ajdabiya, Libya, may prove decisive in the most violent and chaotic of the uprisings that have upended the Arab world.

title: Shares Fall Amid Concerns About Japan
description: Stock markets plunged in Japan and across the rest of the Asia-Pacific region on Tuesday amid fears of the impact of the nuclear disaster and resulting concerns about radiation exposure.

title: Police Say a Man Confesses to a Former Models Stabbing
description: A man has been arrested in the stabbing death of a 42-year-old former model on the Lower East Side more than a month ago, the police said on Sunday.

title: Word of the Day | corrosive
description: corrosive \k-ro-siv, -ziv\ adjective/noun

title: BPs Dispute Over a Joint Venture in Russia Intensifies
description: BPs directors who serve on the board of a Russian joint venture voted against a proposal to swap shares and join an exploration venture with Rosneft, escalating a long-running dispute.

title: Familiar Voices in Ads During Oscars
description: Six times as many ads featured celebrities during this years Oscar show as last year, according to GreenLight, a broker for celebrity endorsements. Many of those stars were heard but not seen, so that the ads would not compete with the awards themselves, said David Reeder, a vice president at GreenLight. For example, Jason Bateman was the voice for ads for Hyundai, filling in for Jeff Bridges, who was barred by academy rules from appearing in ads because he was nominated for best actor.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Gains for NPR Are Clouded
description: The Pew Project for Excellence in Journalism will issue its annual State of the Media report on Monday, and you will be unsurprised to learn that journalism remains in broad retreat.

title: 17 in U.S. Navy Treated for Contamination
description: WASHINGTON  American Navy officials in Japan said early Monday that 17 military personnel who had been aboard three helicopters assisting in the earthquake relief effort had been exposed to low levels of contamination.

title: EAST: Buckeyes Big Numbers Meet Big Expectations
description: Thamels Predictions: East | West | Southwest | Southeast

title: WEST: A Lot of Hard Work, and Its Finally Paying Off
description: Thamels Predictions: East | West | Southwest | Southeast

title: SOUTHWEST: Steady Force Helps Kansas Navigate a Rough Patch
description: Thamels Predictions: East | West | Southwest | Southeast

title: SOUTHEAST: Game Face Hardened by Toil in Prison Yard
description: Thamels Predictions: East | West | Southwest | Southeast

title: News Quiz | March 14, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Sports Replay: March 13
description: A day in the world of sports, Swiss skiers, rugby injuries and more.

title: Pro-Qaddafi Forces Press Rebels East and West of Tripoli
description: AJDABIYA, Libya  Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi cranked up military and psychological pressure on the rebels on Monday, offering amnesty to those who surrendered their weapons but bombing a strategic linchpin in the east and invading a rebel-held town in the west.

title: Paralysis Across Japan
description: Japan reeled from a rapidly unfolding disaster of epic scale on Sunday, pummeled by the death toll, destruction and homelessness caused by the earthquake and tsunami and new hazards from damaged nuclear reactors that were leaking radiation.

title: Need Overwhelms Japan After Quake and Tsunami
description: NATORI, Japan  What the sea so violently ripped away, it has now begun to return. Hundreds of bodies are washing up along some shores in northeastern Japan, making clearer the extraordinary toll of the earthquake and tsunami that struck last week and adding to the burdens of relief workers as they ferry aid and search for survivors.

title: The Devastation in Japan
description: WHAT mounting humanitarian, nuclear and economic emergencies is Japan facing now, in the wake of Fridays earthquake and tsunami?

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 14, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article By a Point, Caltech Ends 26-Year Conference Skid.

title: Japan Faces Potential Nuclear Disaster as Radiation Levels Rise
description: TOKYO  Japans nuclear crisis verged toward catastrophe on Tuesday after an explosion damaged the vessel containing the nuclear core at one reactor and a fire at another spewed large amounts of radioactive material into the air, according to the statements of Japanese government and industry officials.

title: What News Stories Are You Following?
description: Though most days we choose a Times article and create a question around it for you, occasionally we just like to hear what news stories youve gravitated to on your own. (In fact, last summer we asked the question What Interested You Most in The Times This Week? every Monday, and published our favorite student answers each Friday.) So: Whats caught your attention lately, and why?

title: Tension and Theater at Chinas Congress
description: In a formal political environment, Shiho Fukada found a remarkably theatrical atmosphere.

title: U.S. Roster Preview: Bradleys Best Bets
description: United States national team coach Bob Bradley will announce his roster this week for upcoming friendly matches against Argentina and Paraguay. But not all of his choices are clear cut.

title: Fantasy Focus: Auction and Draft Strategy
description: Weve talked a good deal about league parameters, owner tendencies and how to find bargain players, but a big part of doing well in fantasy leagues is mastering the player acquisition process itself. A vast majority of leagues apportion players to owners via auction or draft. Lets tackle some of the key considerations for each.

title: The Early Word: Reactions
description: Todays Times

title: Pakistan Defers Ruling on C.I.A. Operative
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  The Pakistani government on Monday further postponed the resolution of the question of whether a C.I.A. operative being investigated for a double murder is entitled to diplomatic immunity.

title: Bank of America Unit Tried to Hide Foreclosure Information, Hackers Say
description: A hacker organization known as Anonymous released a series of e-mails on Monday provided by a former Bank of America employee who claims they show how a division of the bank sought to hide information on foreclosures.

title: Berkshire Hathaway to Buy Lubrizol for $9 Billion
description: 9:25 p.m. | Updated

title: Defying the Economics of Baseball
description: Jonah Keri is a former stock-market columnist for Investors Business Daily and now a writer for The Wall Street Journal and FanGraphs. Hes the author of a new book, The Extra 2%: How Wall Street Strategies Took a Major League Baseball Team From Worst to First, about the Tampa Bay Rays.

title: Indias First Female Photojournalist Showcased in Mumbai
description: An exhibition featuring the work of Indias first female photojournalist is showing at the National Gallery of Modern Art through April 11. The collection of about 150 photographs by Homai Vyarawalla includes images of the last days of the British Empire, the Indian Independence movement and the birth and subsequent struggles of a new nation.

title: This Week in Small Business: Start-Ups Surge
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: 11 Are Killed as Car Bomb Is Detonated at Iraq Base
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber detonated a car packed with explosives outside a military headquarters on Monday in the city of Kanan, about 40 miles northeast of Baghdad, killing 11 Iraqi soldiers, according to local security officials.

title: E-books vs. Real Books
description: Will Funny or Dies enhanced e-books take off?Not inBrooklyn, where twentysomethings opt, aggressively, for hardcovers.There, if you believe The Awl,Kindles and iPads are verboten, and even presumably low-tech book jackets  andtheir promotional blurbs  are out; readers prefer their books naked. I have to wait at least two years before I can be seen on the subwaywith a book that was made into a major motion picture, says one retrograde reader. I dont want everyone tothink thats why I bought it.

title: Back to the Budget, in Fits and Starts
description: The House and Senate are preparing to give themselves another three weeks to resolve their so-far intractable spending fight before heading out on recess for one of those weeks.

title: The Forager Handbook
description: When Copenhagens Noma was named the worlds best restaurant by Restaurant magazine last year, the gastronomes who think nothing of settling into a four-hour, three-star dinner suddenly developed an interest wild plants. For years, foraged ingredients played an important if subtle role in the multicourse meals that unfurl at restaurants like Michel Bras, the Fat Duck and Coi. But it was Nomas exuberant celebration of what grows wild in the Nordic countryside that turned cloudberries and wood sorrel into culinary stars.

title: Renault Apologizes to Employees Fired in Spy Case
description: PARIS  Renault apologized on Monday to three executives that it had accused of industrial espionage as the focus of the inquiry turned to an internal security agent who had been investigating the case.

title: March 14 Updates on Japans Nuclear Crisis and Earthquake Aftermath
description: On Monday, The Lede continues to supplement reporting from our colleagues in Japan on the aftermath of the devastating earthquake that struck the country on Friday, including the ongoing crisis at damaged nuclear power plants. Updates below feature reports from other news sites and firsthand accounts, photographs and video posted on social media networks.

title: Hockey Joins Football in Soul-Searching on Head Injuries
description: Hockey, especially in Canada, is going through the same kind of questioning  and soul-searching  that the N.F.L. experienced this past season.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Best Political Quotes of the Weekend
description: With all the news around the world these days, its easy to miss the good political commentary over the weekend. Heres a roundup of some of the best quotes.

title: Morning Buzz | Riders Give Accounts of Bus Crash
description: In its continued vacillation between resembling a lion and a lamb, March will lean toward the latter Monday, with a high of 49 degrees, partly cloudy skies and mild winds.

title: The Creature Connection
description: Bashert is a gentle, scone-colored, 60-pound poodle, a kind of Ginger Rogers Chia Pet, and shes clearly convinced there is no human problem so big she cant lick it. Lost your job, or bedridden for days? Lick. Feeling depressed, incompetent, in an existential malaise? Lick.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Braised Endives With Blood Oranges, Pistachios and Ricotta Salata
description: Jordan Frosolone, the 34-year-old chef de cuisine at Hearth in Manhattan, thinks endive is an underused vegetable.

title: Emergency Rooms Built With the Elderly in Mind
description: When Harold Richards, 81, arrived at the hospital emergency room in Ann Arbor, Mich., he expected a long wait. After all, hed been through the emergency room drill before. The patient in the worst condition would be seen first, he knew, and the waiting time could be indeterminable. The rush, the harsh lights, the white walls and bright floors  everything about the place seemed designed to confuse and frighten elderly patients like him.

title: Monday Morning Skate: Bettmans Deal, Norris Race, Remembering Martin
description: Seven things to know from the weekend action in the N.H.L. and one man to remember

title: Libyan Rebels Retreat
description: Libyan rebel fighters were pushed east by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Roots of Macroeconomic Ignorance
description: Brad DeLong discusses the remarkable profusion of wrong-headed macroeconomic ideas, and blames Milton Friedman  not because Friedman himself was that wrong-headed, but because he led many economists down a path that eventually left them ignorant of basic principles.

title: Penn Extends Likely Letters (and Videos)
description: Significantly more than 200 applicants for the University of Pennsylvanias next freshman class have received likely letters, which let them know early that they will soon be offered formal admission, according to The Daily Pennsylvanian.

title: Republicans for Environmental Protection  Endangered Species?
description: After watching Republican leaders in Congress last week stick with same old approaches to rising energy prices (extract, baby, extract ) and climate science (what, me worry? ), I began to wonder whether the groupRepublicans for Environmental Protection should be put forward as a candidate for theEndangered Species Act.

title: Monday Reading: How High Oil Prices Affect Airfares
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Saudi Troops Enter Bahrain to Help Put Down Unrest
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Saudi Arabias military rolled into Bahrain on Monday, threatening to escalate a local political conflict into a regional showdown with Iran.

title: Big Love Watch: Lots of Action and Many Questions
description: Things are happening so quickly now that Big Love is winding down  there is only one more episode to go  that it felt as if we got two hours worth of plot points in 60 minutes on Sunday night. This was an exciting episode by and large, but so many cylinders were clicking that words and actions didnt always feel organic to the characters delivering them.

title: Priests and Judge in Abuse Case Spar Over Legal Fees
description: PHILADELPHIA  Four Roman Catholic priests and a Catholic school teacher appeared in court here Monday in the first of whatwill most likely be several legal skirmishes over whether they will face trial on charges of sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of minors.

title: Wall Street Shares End Lower
description: Shares on Wall Street closed lower on Monday, following Japanese markets lower, as investors tried to assess the economic impact of the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear accident in Japan.

title: Easing the Way in Therapy With the Aid of an Animal
description: Weve all seen guide dogs that can direct blind people around obstacles and tell them when it is safe to cross the street. Perhaps you also know of guide dogs for the deaf, which can alert people to a ringing phone, a doorbell or a smoke alarm, or dogs that can warn people with epilepsy of an incipient seizure, giving them time to get to a safe place before they lose consciousness.

title: Hereafter Is Pulled From Japanese Theaters
description: A division of Warner Brothers said that it would pull the Clint Eastwood movie Hereafter from theaters in Japan following the earthquake and tsunami that have devastated the country, The Associated Press reported. Hereafter, which was released in Japanese theaters in February and was scheduled to be shown there through late March, follows several characters who are affected by death and near-death experiences, including a journalist played by Ccile de France who is caught in Thailand during the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami. On Monday, Satoru Otani, an official at Warner Entertainment Japan Inc., told The A.P. that the tsunami sequences in the film were not appropriate at the present time and that the film would no longer be shown.

title: Does Your Pet Keep You Healthy? Send Us Your Videos
description: This weeks special issue of Science Times explores why we love animals and the rich relationships between pets and people. Numerous studies show that pets are good for your health. They may lower your risk for heart problems or may simply be a better walking partner than a human.

title: Carlyle Forms $5 Billion Shipping Joint Venture
description: 8:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Stimulating Happiness
description: Roger Cohen writes about David Camerons new campaign calling for a focus on emotional prosperity rather than just financial prosperity. As he notes, its easy to be cynical about Camerons motives  and I am.

title: Bomber Kills 36 Outside Afghan Recruiting Center
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A Taliban suicide bomber posing as an army recruit blew himself up in the midst of a crowd outside an Afghan military recruiting center on Monday in the northern city of Kunduz, killing 36 people, including five children, the authorities there said.

title: Knowledge Corrupts
description: This blog isnt really about politics, but sometimes Ill veer into the psychology of politics. For example, when people hold high office they change a zillion different ways. They have power, with all the attendant corruptions. They become the center of every room they enter, with all the attendant narcissism. They also have inside information, and often leap to the conclusion that people who dont have this information are simply not worth listening to.

title: Now Booking | Caribbean Face-Lifts
description: Development in the Caribbean tends to move on, well, island time. But this season, snowbirds were buzzing about a handful of dazzling upgrades. The biggest news is the re-launch of the Four Seasons Resort Nevis, which had been closed for two years following the destruction wrought by Hurricane Omar, which struck the twin island of Nevis and St. Kitts in October 2008. (The faltering economy played a role as well.) Now the resort on a prime stretch of Pinneys Beach is back with a new design, a new spa director (who has come up with a new range of island-y treatments using rum, sugar cane and papaya) and a new chef, Andreas Donnerbauer, who will scuba dive with certified guests to pluck their supper right from the sea. The hotel has also added super-luxe day cabanas on the beach along with a sailing school. But guest favorites like the endangered sea turtle program and the Robert Trent Jones-designed golf course remain  as does Sunshines, the famous ramshackle bar just down the beach.

title: Daily Lexeme: Quizzify
description: Todays word, in association with the fantastic Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Ford Pinto, an Automotive Punchline, Celebrates 40 With Road Rally
description: The Ford Motor Company spent 2008 celebrating the centenary of its Model T, while in 2009 the automaker sponsored a four-day celebration of its vaunted Mustang. Though 2011 marks the 40th birthday of the Ford Pinto compact car, Dearborn has not issued so much as a Tweet of recognition.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of The Timess dining section.

title: Video Interview: Josh Lucas
description: The actor Josh Lucas discusses his role in the SXSW competition film "A Year in Mooring."

title: Quake Survivors Face a Landscape of Loss
description: HIGASHI-MATSUSHIMA, Japan  Outside the public gymnasium here, on a hillock about a mile from the Pacific Ocean, survivors of the tsunami came and went all day on Monday, searching for the dead.

title: Appreciation Flows to an Injured Food Runner
description: In the service industry, the job of food runner, the colloquial term for those who take plates of food from the kitchen to dining tables, is as anonymous as they come. Most customers do not notice food runners and many food runners do not stick at one restaurant for very long.

title: Nuclear Plants in Europe Are Delayed
description: BERLIN  With the crisis in Japan raising fears about nuclear power, Germany and Switzerland said on Monday that they would reassess the safety of their own reactors and possibly reduce their reliance on them.

title: The Least Happy Person in America
description: Last week we wrote about Alvin Wong, the American who fits all the demographic characteristics associated with happiness, based on results from Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index data. That is, he is a tall, Asian-American, observant Jew who is at least 65 and married, has children, lives in Hawaii, runs his own business and has a household income of more than $120,000 a year.

title: Provincial Governor Stabbed During Clash in Yemen
description: A Yemeni provincial governor was stabbed in a melee with antigovernment protesters on Monday, the official news agency Saba reported. Local reports said the stabbing occurred after the governors bodyguards opened fire on the protesters, injuring dozens.

title: Not Your Grandmas Jewels | Jordan Alexander
description: So you think youre too young to wear your mothers jewelry? Its all a matter of how you wear it, says Theresa Bruno, the designer of Jordan Alexander. Her fine jewelry collection is a mlange of lustrous Tahitian pearls, twisted strands of quartz and diamond-encrusted gold ornaments, with unexpected touches of macram, sandalwood and 300-year-old Yemen prayer beads  all strung together with boho leather and silk knots.

title: Its All About the Bracket
description: Let us officially welcome you to the madness of March, the collective sports experience we share around the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. The madness, of course, has only a little to do with the mayhem of the games  the buzzer beaters, finding yourself in a crowd of people howling for a school none of you had heard of before Sunday, finding yourself hating Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski for no reason you can put a finger on.

title: Fast Food for Harried Days
description: My son, Liam, 13, never eats lunch at school. I harp about how it isnt healthy; I tell him that he needs some energy in the afternoon. But he wants to play basketball or football during recess, and no matter how much I nag, lunch goes uneaten. So eventually I stopped packing sandwiches for him.

title: The New Issue of Meatpaper Is Out!
description: Perhaps you are familiar with Meatpaper: Your Journal of Meat Culture. I was not, but how can anyone resist browsing such an attractive periodical? Especially when its called Meatpaper? Yet after flipping through the Spring 2011 issue for a a solid three or four minutes, I was still unsure: Is Meatpaper pro-meat? Is it an ironic dispatch from militant vegans? A pull quote under a movie still of Catherine Deneuve didnt clarify matters: The carcass comes to symbolize the psychosexual malaise by which Catherine Deneuves character is afflicted. Well, sure  obviously. Which made me wonder whether Meatpaper wasnt an anagram of Meta Paper. But regardless of its editorial mission, Meatpaper has surely published the definitive interview with Franc Fernandez, better known as the tailor of Lady Gagas meat dress:

title: Hello, Ozzy: Tribeca Lineup Adds Ozzy Osbourne and Carol Channing Documentaries
description: Carol Channing, Ozzy Osbourne and A Tribe Called Quest may not show up together on any iPod playlist ever created in human history, but theyll all have a presence in movies being shown at this years Tribeca Film Festival. Among the features that Tribeca organizers announced on Monday to round out the festivals 2011 program are Carol Channing: Larger Than Life, a documentary directed by Dori Berinstein about that Hello, Dolly! star; God Bless Ozzy Osbourne, directed by Mike Fleiss and Mike Piscitelli, about the 40-year career of that long-lived heavy-metal singer; and Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest, directed by Michael Rapaport, about that vintage-1990s hip-hop group.

title: Hugh Martin, Composer of Judy Garland Hits, Dies at 96
description: Hugh Martin, the composer, lyricist, arranger and pianist best known for creating the Judy Garland standards Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas, The Boy Next Door and The Trolley Song, died on Friday at his home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 96.

title: Britain Awarded Spot in 2012 Olympic Basketball Field
description: The wait is over for Great Britains mens and womens national basketball teams. Basketballs international ruling body, F.I.B.A. voted, 17-3, to include Team Great Britain in the 2012 Olympic tournaments during its Sunday meeting in Lyon, France.

title: Obama Calls for Remaking of No Child Left Behind
description: 2:22 p.m. | Updated President Obama called on Congress to revamp the No Child Left Behind education law by the time students start a new school year in September, urging lawmakers to seize this education moment.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: Expect the talk in Washington about the federal health care law to intensify as we approach the one-year anniversary of the passage of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act next week.

title: Death Toll in Bus Crash Reaches 15
description: The death toll in the weekend bus crash climbed to 15 people on Monday, as a 70-year-old male passenger succumbed to injuries he sustained in the accident, according to a spokesman for St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx, where the man was being treated.

title: Peltz Presses Family Dollar on Takeover Offer
description: 1:11 p.m. | Updated Nelson W. Peltzs investment firm,Trian Fund Management, called on Family Dollar on Monday to reconsider its rejection of Trians $7 billion-plus takeover bid.

title: How We Made Our N.C.A.A. Picks
description: I participated in my first N.C.A.A. tournament pool in 1992 when, as a 14-year-old, I correctly predicted sixth-seeded Michigan to reach the Final Four.

title: Towers Built for the Poor Hear Call of the Condo
description: For generations of space-starved New Yorkers, Cobble Hill Towers has been an affordable oasis. More than 130 years ago, its architect, Alfred Tredway White, designed its nine low-rise, red-brick buildings to demonstrate that housing for the poor could be both humane and economically feasible.

title: TimesCast | Japan's Elderly Victims
description: March 14, 2011 - Martin Fackler, The Times's Tokyo bureau chief, reports from the fishing town of Natori, Japan, where rescue efforts are affected by its significant elderly population.

title: Strobe Lights and Blown Speakers
description: Andi Watsons profession doesnt come with a sexy title  hes a lighting and stage director  so its probably best to think of his work this way: Hes the guy responsible for Radioheads mise-en-scne.

title: In Germany, Uproar Over a Doctoral Thesis
description: BERLIN  While Americans have been obsessing lately about Charlie Sheen and his live-in porn film stars, Germany has been consumed by improprieties over a doctoral thesis.

title: Buy an Apartment or Rent It? Explain Your Answer
description: Its the kind of discussion renters often obsess over: If I could buy my apartment, would I?

title: Hanging Art
description: Thats the beauty of the game. Its a useful phrase in sports talk. It allows you to sum up  without actually having to say much about  things like comebacks and buzzer-beaters and the unexpected twists and turns of unscripted athletic contests. But Im going to use it as a way to characterize my reaction to two art installations I came upon the other day online. The first is a sculpture of Muhammad Ali  made up of speed bags  strung from wires. Its very cool. (Its probably also some sort of commentary on shifting perspectives and focus and, for all I know, maybe even various Greatest of All Time debates.) Even cooler is this installation connected to another G.O.A.T. candidate, the F1 racer Michael Schumacher. The pictures of his car, taken apart, each piece suspended from an art-gallery ceiling, are rather amazing. And now Im going to call time on this post, before I start talking about things going down to the wire.

title: Ex-Client Says Kaupthing Inflated Its Shares
description: 6:54 p.m. | Updated

title: Why the New 1099 Rules Arent That Bad for Small Businesses
description: There may be nobody in Washington who has anything good to say  publicly, at least  about the expanded 1099 reporting requirements that became law with the health care overhaul. Republicans and Democrats all want to repeal it. President Obama, in his State of the Union speech, described the provision as an unnecessary bookkeeping burden. But now that Congress must reconcile two very different approaches to striking the provision, it may be a good time to risk pillory and wonder if perhaps the new laws supposed crippling effects on small business are exaggerated.

title: A Year With Josh Lucas
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Throughout his film career, the actor Josh Lucas has been more of a supporting player. But in the SXSW competition film A Year in Mooring, his role couldnt be more central. Directed by Chris Eyre (Smoke Signals), the film follows a year in the life of a man whos trying to rebound from a tragedy by buying and spending time on a sailboat. It was a challenging role for the actor, which features Mr. Lucas alone on screen for a good portion of its running time. At the festival he spoke about the film and how he got involved. He also shared some thoughts on the competitive nature of landing roles in Hollywood.

title: Documentary Rekindles Fab Five Memories
description: It served as a flashback to a time when baggy basketball shorts, hip-hop music and black shoes were considered controversial and an affront to hoops purists. ESPNs Sunday evening airing of a documentary on the Fab Five, a.k.a. former University of Michigan basketball players Jalen Rose, Jimmy King, Juwan Howard, Chris Webber and Ray Jackson, is rekindling conversations and controversy.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Ames Scullin OHaire, Atlanta, was named by the Coca-Cola Company, Atlanta, to create a campaign for Seagrams ginger ale as Coca-Cola significantly expands distribution for the full line of Seagrams beverages. Spending was not disclosed. The line also includes products like seltzer and tonic water.

title: Supremacy of a Social Network
description: Every time some human attribute is said to be unique, whether tool-making or language or warfare, biologists soon find some plausible precursor in animals that makes the ability less distinctive.

title: More News From the Tiny New Culture Section With No Name
description: As was reported exclusively on this blog last week, one new element in the redesigned Times Magazine is a Tiny New Culture Section With No Name. The first week featured Block Quote, a microexcerpt from a compelling argument found elsewhere.

title: From Campus Grounds to Coffee Grounds
description: The road to the Final Four begins this week, as the National Collegiate Athletic Associations annual mens basketball tournament gets under way. For hoops fans in one state, there is another contest with an alliterative title they are also watching: the Battle for Bean Street.

title: An Hour from Now, You Will Be Hungry Again
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously proposed fortunes fit for cookies.

title: Special Sunday Deal at Mohonk Mountain House
description: The historic Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, N.Y., is continuing its Super Sunday promotion with a one-night deal on March 20.

title: Testing Your Environmental Principles
description: In my European reporting for several installments of the newspapers Beyond Fossil Fuels series last year, I became accustomed to seeing wind turbines, bike lanes and all sorts of green infrastructure. In many European countries, a big chunk of heat and electricity is now generated from renewable fuels.

title: Remembering the Triangle Fire, 100 Years Later
description: In the arts and academia, on television and on a Greenwich Village street, the 146 victims of the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire will be remembered over the next few weeks in an outpouring of events marking the centennial of the workplace tragedy.

title: Jury Hears Dozen Taped Calls at Galleon Trial
description: Anil Kumar testified in the insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam.

title: Investing at the Bottom of the Venture Capital Cycle
description: Mike Kwatinetz and Cameron Lester are general partners at Azure Capital Partners.

title: A Real Wake-Up Call at St. Peter's
description: To receive national television exposure for their mens basketball programs, St. Peters and Monmouth agreed to play at 6 a.m. so they could participate in ESPNs College Hoops Tip-Off Marathon.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, India, Tunisia and Libya.

title: March Madness, in Like a Lamb
description: Routinely, the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament is the greatest sporting event of the year, and in particular, the tournaments first weekend serves up the most entertaining four days in sports. Yet this year, the N.C.A.A. has unwisely decided to step on that Thursday-to-Sunday tradition by beginning the tournament on Tuesday and Wednesday, with a set of First Four games. In doing so, the N.C.A.A. has somehow conspired to create a situation in which the first round of a second-tier playoff, the N.I.T.  particularly the Harvard-Oklahoma State game that will be broadcast on ESPN on Tuesday  is more interesting than the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament (broadcast on truTV).

title: Despite Fix, Some Subaru Outback and Legacy Owners Still Experience Highway Vibration
description: Minimizing vibration over a variety of surfaces and speeds is a fundamental challenge of automotive engineering. According to many owners, Subaru did not devote adequate attention to this task on the automakers 2010-11 Outback wagons and Legacy sedans.

title: BP Joint Venture in Russia Mulls Rosneft Deal
description: The separate shareholder management teams for TNK and BP still cannot agree on what part, if any, their joint venture TNK-BP should play in Rosnefts Arctic venture, reports Reuters.

title: Carnegie Hall Lists Japan Relief Groups
description: Carnegie Hall, which is sponsoring a festival of Japanese culture, has followed through on its stated desire to steer patrons toward places to help the victims of Japans earthquake and tsunami. It has posted a list of seven organizations accepting relief money on the festivals Web page. Hall officials said over the weekend that only one event so far had been canceled and that they saw the festival as an opportunity to pay tribute to a country in a time of suffering.

title: Former Presidential Candidate, Claiming Abuse, Flees Belarus
description: MOSCOW  For two months Ales Mikhalevich, an opposition presidential candidate in Belarus, sat in prison after protesting the results of the December election as blatantly rigged. He said he had been tortured and then released only on the condition that he collaborate with the security service.

title: Effects Coordinator Cleared in Death of Dark Knight Cameraman
description: A British jury said on Monday that an Academy Award-winning special effects coordinator was not responsible for the death of a cameraman who was killed in a stunt mishap during the filming of The Dark Knight, Reuters reported. After less than two hours of deliberation, jurors at Crown Court in Guildford, southwest of London, ruled unanimously that the effects coordinator, Christopher Corbould, was not guilty of failing to ensure the safety of the cameraman, Conway Wickliffe. Mr. Wickliffe was killed in 2007 on the set of The Dark Knight, Christopher Nolans sequel to his superhero film Batman Begins, as he rode in a pickup truck driving parallel to a stunt car; the pickup missed a 90-degree turn and crashed into a tree. Last week, prosecutors argued that Mr. Corbould, who won an Oscar for his work on Inception and whose filmography includes several James Bond movies, did not follow proper safety guidelines in planning the stunt and that the accident was foreseeable. Mr. Wickliffe was honored in the closing credits of The Dark Knight, along with the actor Heath Ledger, who died before the films release.

title: Interview: Greg Mottola
description: The director Greg Mottola discusses his new alien comedy "Paul," which played at SXSW and is in theaters March 18.

title: Madvocates
description: Consumers who trumpet bad consumer experiences to their friends and family.

title: Whos No. 1? Investigating the Mathematics of Rankings
description: Overview | Rankings and ratings can have considerable, and serious, implications. How do we determine that a student, team, school, teacher or policy is better than another? And what does better mean? In this lesson, students explore the use of quantitative ratings by examining how Division I college basketball teams are ranked, and how specific mathematical decisions can have significant consequences.

title: Alex Stupak: From Pastry Chef to Taco Maker
description: I guess you could say I have no business opening a Mexican restaurant, said Alex Stupak, who, as he approached 30 years of age, decided it was time to open his own place, Empelln.

title: Premier Says China Will Let Currency Appreciate Gradually
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, answering prescreened questions at an annual news conference, said Monday that China faced daunting challenges of taming inflation and developing a more consumer-based economy, and that the government would allow the nations currency to appreciate but at a cautious pace in order to protect Chinese jobs and businesses.

title: Its Lowered Productivity Week
description: By experience, most of us are intimately familiar with how the N.C.A.A. tournament disrupts work. Of course it does, considering the fact that the first-round game are played during the day on Thursday and Friday, coupled with the almost universal concept of the office bracket pool.

title: Will Buffett Deal Create a Chemical Reaction?
description: The specialty chemicals business might not seem to be a great candidate for a wave of consolidation right now. The jittery rise in prices for its main ingredient, crude oil, is but one reason.

title: Barbour Slams Obama on Economy and Energy
description: CHICAGO  Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi may not yet be a Republican presidential candidate, but his travel itinerary suggests that may be simply a formality, as he visited President Obamas hometown on Monday before flying to Iowa to begin testing themes of a probable campaign.

title: Nontraditional Route for James Frey Book
description: James Frey has avoided traditional publishers with his next novel, The Final Testament of the Holy Bible, the story of a modern-day Jesus that his publisher, the Gagosian Gallery, predicted would be the most compelling and provocative work of his career. The book is set in the Bronx, and Mr. Freys version of the Messiah is a heavy drinker. It is set for release on Good Friday. The Gagosian Gallery, which has never published a novel before, will print only 11,000 copies. The book will include original artwork by Ed Ruscha, Terry Richardson and Dan Colen, among others. Mr. Frey will make an e-book edition available to traditional retailers.

title: G.O.P. Cuts Could Hit Tsunami Warning System, Foes Say
description: A spending bill passed by House Republicans last month could affect the nations tsunami monitoring system, which issued warnings in response to last weeks devastating earthquake and tsunami in Japan, opponents warn. The plan cuts $126 million from the 2011 budget of the National Weather Service, which runs the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center in Hawaii.

title: Get a Tax Receipt From Uncle Sam
description: Curious how much of your tax bill last year went to pay for the retirement fund at the Central Intelligence Agency? Want to know what your contribution to foreign aid was in 2010? How about the Postal Service?

title: Revealing the Soul of the MetroCard
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: The Streak Is Over, but Love Is Rolling
description: Minnesota Timberwolves forward Kevin Loves ridiculous streak of 53 consecutive double-doubles came to an end Sunday night against the most unlikely of opponents. Golden State  which was on the receiving end of a 37-point, 23-rebound game from Love just three weeks ago  held him to 6 points Sunday (and 12 rebounds) in a 100-77 Warriors victory despite an up-tempo game and a defensively inferior frontline. Somehow David Lee was able to do what the leagues best defensive bigs could not, and Loves double-double ways hit their first hiccup in 54 contests.

title: Prosecutors Ask for Up to 10 Years for Former Goldman Programmer
description: Prosecutors are asking a federal judge to give a prison sentence of up to 10 years to a former Goldman Sachs computer programmer convicted of stealing proprietary code, according to a filing.

title: The Caucus: What's Ahead for Obama
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times and Jackie Calmes of The New York Times discuss the four issues that President Obama is facing this week.

title: What Is Missing in Deal on Europes Debt Crisis
description: LONDON  Another missed opportunity for Europe?

title: For Voice of March, Authenticity Comes With Sizzle
description: Sometimes, Gus Johnson feels like a human jukebox, a sports broadcaster beholden to his greatest hits, to Pure! and What a game! and Ha-HA! and the rest. That man, the one who shouts and screams and channels his inner fan in the waning seconds of sporting events from basketball to boxing, is part Gus Johnson, but only part.

title: Threats to Traveling Data
description: With small and fast laptops, powerful smartphones, tablets and readily available Wi-Fi, working on the road  on planes, in airports and hotel rooms  has never been easier. But security experts say these conveniences also make the offices away from home more vulnerable to serious security threats.

title: Video: Whats Ahead for President Obama
description: Reporters with The New York Times look at gun control, the federal budget and other issues on President Obamas policy agenda this week.

title: Greg Mottolas Alien Adventure
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The director Greg Mottola takes comedy seriously. While the filmmaker has been interested in making funny movies (Superbad, Adventureland), hes also concerned about the craft involved in making those films work within specific genres. Mr. Mottola was profiled in this weeks Arts & Leisure and was in Austin to discuss Paul, his film starring Seth Rogen as the voice of an alien who gets himself mixed up with two British fanboys (Simon Pegg and Nick Frost, who also wrote the screenplay). Mr. Mottola spoke about the challenges and rewards of making a film with a CGI alien character at its center.

title: Al Morgan, Novelist, Playwright and Television Producer, Is Dead at 91
description: Al Morgan, a novelist, screenwriter, playwright and television producer who was probably best known for writing The Great Man, a 1955 novel that became the basis of a movie of the same name, died on March 3 at his home in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 91.

title: No Face, but Plants Like Life Too
description: Several years ago, after having to drive for too long behind a truck full of stinking, squealing pigs being delivered for slaughter, I gave up eating meat. Id been harboring a growing distaste for the ugliness that can be industrial agriculture, but the real issue was a long-suppressed sympathy for its  or really, my  victims. Even screaming, reeking pigs, or maybe especially screaming, reeking pigs, can evoke stark pity as they tumble along in a truck to their deaths.

title: Photo Replay: March 14
description: A view of the day in sports included rival fans, wet fans and even some compassionate ones.

title: Kurosawa on Earthquakes
description: When the Great Kanto earthquake of 1923 and the fires that erupted along its trail destroyed Yokohama and three-fifths of Tokyo, killing nearly 150,000 people, Akira Kurosawa was in middle school. Kurosawa, the director of Rashomon and The Seven Samurai, never tried to put the wasteland that suddenly overtook the landscape of his childhood on film, but in interviews and an autobiography, he returned to the devastation again and again. Trying to take in the scale of the destruction in the aftermath of the earthquake last week in Japan, particularly the way active coastal towns were suddenly vaporized by the tsunami, I was reminded of what Kurosawa never forgot.

title: Emotional Power Broker of the Modern Family
description: First, he tore up his dog toys. Then shredded the furniture, clothes, schoolbooks  and, finally, any semblance of family unity. James, a chocolate-brown pointer mix, turned from adorable pet to problem child in a matter of weeks.

title: For Elderly, Echoes of World War II Horrors
description: NATORI, Japan  Hirosato Wako stared at the ruins of his small fishing hamlet: skeletons of shattered buildings, twisted lengths of corrugated steel, corpses with their hands twisted into claws. Only once before had he seen anything like it: World War II.

title: Looking at Schubert and Finding Hamlet
description: The excellent English baritone Simon Keenlyside has memorably portrayed Hamlet at the Metropolitan Opera and elsewhere. And on Sunday in the TullyScope festival at Alice Tully Hall, Mr. Keenlyside  restless, eyes downcast, a little standoffish and unpredictably emotive  brought some of the same character to songs of Schubert.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, India, Tunisia and Libya.

title: New Elementary School Planned for Lower Manhattan
description: The Department of Education announced on Monday that it would open an elementary school inside its headquarters at the Tweed Courthouse behind City Hall, a move that could chip away at the longstanding problem of school overcrowding in Lower Manhattan.

title: East Meets Farther East When the Aural Mirrors the Visual
description: The Rubin Museum of Art encourages performers in its concert series to find connections between their music and the museums exhibitions, but given its focus on Asia (particularly the Himalayas) that can be a challenge for classical players. But it is precisely the kind of challenge that appeals to the cellist Maya Beiser, whose solo performances in recent seasons have been multimedia mlanges of classical, electronic and world music.

title: TimesCast | Crisis at Japanese Reactor
description: March 14, 2011 - Matthew L. Wald reports on the deepening Japanese nuclear reactor crisis.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Hacker Slacker FT Alphaville, under the headline of the day, Rocky Balboa, is disappointed with the e-mails of the Bank of America unit that were released: Unless weve missed something, the documents released last night added little to our understanding of a complicated and sad story that continues to blight ordinary Americans and the U.S. economy. FT Alphaville

title: Riverbank State Park, Harlem, 2 P.M.
description: Just as we were giving up hope that there was a single molecule of snow remaining in the city of New York, a reader sent us this, which she promises was taken today. Kind of reminds us of the O. Henry story The Last Leaf. Hang in there, little snowflakes, though you may not live to read these words.

title: Battle-Zone Absurdity and Adrenaline-Fueled Folly
description: A funny book about Afghanistan and Pakistan? It sounds like an oxymoron. Where is the comedy in a terrible war that continues to claim American and Afghan lives? What is comic about suicide bombers and I.E.D.s, or a nuclear-armed Pakistan, reeling from corruption, violence and chronic dysfunction?

title: Numberplay: Pi in the Sky
description: Todays date is March 14, numerically written as 3/14, and therefore celebrated around the world as Pi day. Today is also the birthday of the great Albert Einstein. A day that celebrates both a transcendental genius and a transcendental number Nerd heaven! So heres our tribute to this amazing number, 3.14159 26535 89793 23846 26433 83279 50

title: Celebrating an Irishman Who Preceded Chopin
description: The words Chopin and nocturne are invariably linked, but the Irish composer John Field, 28 years Chopins senior, was the one who originated the form. Field began composing nocturnes for piano while living in St. Petersburg, Russia, in the early 19th century, where he enjoyed a lavish, Lisztian life as a darling of the nobility.

title: Abbas Condemns Killing of Jewish Family
description: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, expressed abhorrence on Monday over the killing of five members of a family in a Jewish settlement in the West Bank. The emphatic condemnation, delivered over Israels public radio, came after Israel criticized the Palestinian leadership for what it considered to be an initially mealy-mouthed response.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Citizen Kane'
description: A. O. Scott examines the themes of power and isolation in Orson Welles's 1941 film about a newspaper baron.

title: Russias Ruling Party Stumbles in Some Regional Elections
description: MOSCOW  Russias ruling party, United Russia, won less than half of the popular vote in the weekends regional elections, the last electoral test before momentous coming races for Parliament and president, according to results released Monday.

title: Japans Long Nuclear Disaster Film
description: OXFORD, England  Peering at the post-tsunami devastation in Japan on miniature YouTube windows or video-streaming displays from Japanese news outlets provokes not only great empathy and concern, but an unmistakable feeling of dj vu. As a scholar focusing on the place of nuclear energy in Japanese culture, Ive seen more than my share of nuclear-themed monster movies from the 50s onward, and the scenes of burning refineries, flattened cities, mobilized rescue teams and fleeing civilians recall some surreal highlights of the Japanese disaster film genre.

title: Call of the Whales Leads to a Retreats Discovery
description: By studying whale calls, scientists have discovered that thousands of humpbacks may be wintering and breeding in the remote northwestern Hawaiian islands.

title: An Uncommon View of Amelia Island Concours
description: The 16th annual Amelia Island Concours d lgance was held Sunday with the customary clear skies and mid-70s temperatures that Bill Warner, the events affable founder, seems to be able to conjure at will (in preceding years, Friday and Saturday weather has been downright hostile at times).

title: Humans First Use of Fire May Not Be So Long Ago
description: Fire, scientists agree, helped give rise to a successful, thriving human population by providing heat for cooking and protection from the cold.

title: Forget the Treadmill. Get a Dog.
description: If youre looking for the latest in home exercise equipment, you may want to consider something with four legs and a wagging tail.

title: Republicans Assail Regulator on Costs of New Rules
description: Republican lawmakers are stepping up their criticism on federal regulators charged with writing new rules for Wall Street, saying the agencies are ignoring the costs of the rules.

title: Critics Picks Video: Citizen Kane
description: This weeks Critics Pick video looks at Orson Welless first feature film, Citizen Kane. Welles, just 26 at the time, directed, produced, co-wrote and played the lead role in the 1941 film, which was loosely based on the life of the newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst.

title: TimesCast | U.S. Nuclear Policy
description: March 14, 2011 - David Sanger reports on nuclear policy in the United States.

title: Until the Final Four, There Will Be Ads Galore
description: 11:43 a.m. | Updated As the National Collegiate Athletic Association gets ready for its annual mens basketball tournament, Madison Avenue is gearing up for one of its most intensive periods of pitching and peddling outside of the Christmas shopping season.

title: Author Earns Her Stripes on First Try
description: Ta Obreht is just 25, and The Tigers Wife is her first book. It is also the first book ever sold by her agent, Seth Fishman, who is 30, and the second book bought by her editor, Noah Eaker, who was 26 when he acquired it and, strictly speaking, still an editorial assistant.

title: From Single Cells, a Vast Kingdom Arose
description: Lurking in the blood of tropical snails is a single-celled creature called Capsaspora owczarzaki. This tentacled, amoebalike species is so obscure that no one even noticed it until 2002. And yet, in just a few years it has moved from anonymity to the scientific spotlight. It turns out to be one of the closest relatives to animals. As improbable as it might seem, our ancestors a billion years ago probably were a lot like Capsaspora.

title: Developers Matter the Most for iPad 2s Success
description: A few people who found themselves wandering past the Fifth Avenue Apple Store in Manhattan on Friday were perplexed by the hundreds of people patiently waiting in line and the dozens oftelevisionscamera crews filming them.

title: Answering the Call for New Talent
description: During any competition, whether its the Olympics figure-skating championship or the Miss America pageant, when it comes time for the winners to be chosen, whoever is hosting the event always speaks of the unenviable task facing the judges. So it was on Sunday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House when the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato graciously presided over the Grand Finals Concert of the Mets 58th annual National Council Auditions.

title: The Rails Derby 10
description: A look at the contenders for the Kentucky Derby, listed in order of preference. You can follow Joe Drape on Twitter.

title: Glenn Becks Web Site Questions Attack on NPR
description: 6:21 p.m. | Updated Has the Fox News host Glenn Beck helped to undercut the recent conservative attack on National Public Radio?

title: CBS Carries Sunday
description: CBSs procedural CSI: Miami and the reality show Undercover Boss delivered the most viewers in prime time on Sunday. According to Nielsens estimates, 11.8 million viewers tuned in to CSI: Miami, leading its 10 p.m. time slot and edging past Undercover Boss at 9 (11.7 million) to rank as the nights most-watched show. CBS won the night easily, starting with 60 Minutes in the 7 p.m. hour (10.3 million) and trailing only at 8 with The Amazing Race (9.4 million), which lagged behind ABCs Secret Millionaire (11.3 million). ABC finished second even as it drew low ratings for repeats of Desperate Housewives at 9 (4.9 million) and Brothers & Sisters at 10 (3.2 million). NBC was third with 5.6 million at 7 for Dateline, 4.2 million at 8 at for Americas Next Great Restaurant and 8 million from 9 to 11 for The Celebrity Apprentice. Fox ranked fourth with its animated comedy lineup.

title: Fte Accompli | A Mondrian Opens in SoHo
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#951", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Budget Stalemate Leaves Chaos at Many Agencies
description: WASHINGTON  Unsure from week to week how much money Congress will provide them as the two parties battle over the budget for the rest of this year, federal officials say many agencies have been operating in chaos, confusion and uncertainty.

title: Footnotes
description: The comedian Kathy Griffin, below, scored a hit at the Broadway box office last week. Her limited-engagement solo show, Kathy Griffin Wants a Tony, took in $345,677 for its first three performances at the Belasco Theater, according to the Broadway League. ... Carnegie Hall, which is sponsoring a festival of Japanese culture, has followed through on its stated desire to steer patrons toward places to help victims of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan. It has posted a list on the festivals Web page of seven organizations accepting relief money. Hall officials said over the weekend that only one event had been canceled so far and that they considered the festival an opportunity to pay tribute to a country in a time of suffering.

title: Tintinnabulation of the Acela
description: There comes a day in the life of any transportation reporter  ever the disinterested, impartial observer  when a personal travel experience seems too amusing to resist a mention. Reader, bear with us: today is that day.

title: Aflac Searches for New Duck
description: Aflac fired the voice of its spokesduck, Gilbert Gottfried, after the comedian made insensitive remarks about the disaster in Japan.

title: Well, So Much For Lufthansa
description: In the Times:

title: Joe Uva to Step Down as Univision Chief
description: In a move that surprised some television industry executives, Univision, the growing powerhouse of Spanish-language programming in the United States, announced Monday that its chief executive, Joe Uva, would not renew his contract and would leave the company April 2.

title: On a Visit to Saudi Arabia, Doing What the Saudis Do
description: When in Rome, do as the Romans do is a maxim derived from advice that St. Ambrose is said to have offered to St. Augustine in the late 4th century.

title: Pregnant? You, Too, Can Help Balance a Small Plane
