description: I NEVER wanted a 9-to-5 job. I graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a law degree, and started working in corporate law. I eventually went out on my own to secure talent and handle contract negotiations for various events. Although I travel quite a bit, its great because when Im not flying someplace, I get to work from home and spend time with my three kids.

title: The Bronx Bus Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Plains Indian Culture, as Seen Through the Ingenuity of the Tepee
description: You know theres trouble when the first object you encounter in a museum exhibition looks as if it had been misplaced from the gift shop. That problem runs deep in Tipi: Heritage of the Great Plains, at the Brooklyn Museum. The exhibition mixes kitschy pieces by contemporary American Indian artists into an otherwise outstanding selection of mostly 19th-century works of art and craft by members of Blackfoot, Crow, Arapaho, Lakota and other tribes that once nomadically roamed the prairies from the Mississippi River to the Rocky Mountains. Most of the historic material is from the museums collection of about 700 Plains objects.

title: Farewell, Frank Rich
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Different Trips From Georgia to New York
description: Consider this: the most popular great Georgia rock band, the Allman Brothers, opened a 13-night stand on Thursday at the Beacon Theater on the Upper West Side. Three days later the least popular great Georgia rock band, Harvey Milk, opened its own three-night run at Union Pool in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Both sang plenty of songs about suffering and dying; both were long-haired, guitar-heroic, deeply impressive. Both attracted sentimental audiences, somewhere in the 25-year span of middle age. The main difference between them was the size of those audiences. The Beacon theater seats 2,800; the Union Pools capacity is 74.

title: U.S.-Saudi Tensions Intensify With Mideast Turmoil
description: WASHINGTON  Even before Saudi Arabia sent troops into Bahrain on Monday to quell an uprising it fears might spill across its own borders, American officials were increasingly concerned that the kingdoms stability could ultimately be threatened by regional unrest, succession politics and its resistance to reform.

title: A Scanner Suitable for Rats and Other Squirmers
description: Researchers from the Brookhaven National Laboratory and Stony Brook University have built the first positron emission tomography (PET) scanner that is suitable for rats and other small rodents.

title: Q&A: Finding Free and Cheap Photo Editors for Windows 7
description: Q.

title: G.O.P. Wants Deal on Commerce Secretary
description: Trying to ramp up pressure on the White House to move forward on a trio of trade pacts, Senate Republicans said Monday that they would block confirmation of a new Commerce secretary or any other trade nominee until President Obama submitted trade deals with South Korea, Colombia and Panama for ratification.

title: For Whom the Cell Mutates: The Origins of Genetic Quirks
description: There was very little that was safe or conventional in Ernest Hemingways life. The great writer hurled himself into danger in three wars, managed to survive two plane crashes on the same big-game safari in remote Africa, and precipitated many domestic dramas with a variety of love affairs in the course of his four marriages. Moderation appears to have been one word lacking from his otherwise superb vocabulary, even when it came to cats.

title: Leo Steinberg, Art Historian, Dies at 90
description: Leo Steinberg, one of the most brilliant, influential and controversial art historians of the last half of the 20th century, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

description: A Question of Savings

description: To the Editor:

title: Chvez Tries to Rally Venezuela Against a New Enemy: Breast Lifts
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez is known to have expressed little patience for imported leisure pursuits like golf or Scotch whisky tippling. Now he has reserved some ire for another practice that is beloved in Venezuela: breast augmentation surgery.

title: The Aftershocks in U.S. Treasuries
description: The United States Treasury market could feel financial aftershocks from Japans earthquake. Offloading some of the Asian giants $1 trillion of foreign reserves would raise cash to help rebuild after Fridays disaster. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve is set to end its Treasury bond-buying program in June. If Japan, the second-biggest foreign holder, starts selling, thats another support gone  with the potential to make borrowing more expensive for the federal government.

title: Pairings: Chicken Tagine With Eggplant and Olives
description: Priorat, near the Mediterranean coast of Spain and a stones throw from Barcelona, produces wines with dark fruit flavors, spice, bold complexity and ample alcohol. To compete with reds like these, the food alongside must take no prisoners.

title: Spaniards of Distinction From Priorat
description: SPAIN is awash in ancient wine regions rejuvenating themselves for the modern age, but none of these historic lands has demonstrated its innate potential as well as Priorat. Twenty-five years ago, this isolated territory high in the hills of Catalonia was virtually unknown to most of the wine-drinking world. Today, Priorats command some of the highest prices of any Spanish wines.

title: You Can Say That Again (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gus Johnson's Signature Calls
description: Gus Johnsons signature calls have turned memorable games epic.

title: Insects as Food? Trying to Change Ick to Yum
description: S HERTOGENBOSCH, the Netherlands  Johan Van Dongen sells insects.

title: Mormon Politicians From Utah Feel Tea Party Heat
description: COALVILLE, Utah  Jacqueline Smith fits no ones stereotype of a political kingmaker. A home-schooling Mormon mother of five, Ms. Smith lives in a modest ranch-style house here in the mountains outside Salt Lake City with her husband, Cleve, a plumbing contractor.

title: Chinas Energy Industry Pushes Into Developed Markets
description: PetroChina agreed last month to buy a 50 percent stake in a Canadian gas venture for $5.4 billion. If the deal goes through, it will be the largest overseas acquisition on record for the Chinese oil company.

description: To the Editor:

title: Unrest? Nonsense, Say Libyans at the Border
description: RAS AJDIR BORDER CROSSING, Tunisia  There is no civil war in Libya, they say, no bombs, no fighting, no fear.

description: PEORIA, Ariz.

description: To the Editor:

title: As Nasdaq Weighs NYSE Bid, Big Hurdles Remain
description: 8:42 p.m. | Updated

title: Physicists Jailing Is Veiled in Mystery
description: When Adlne Hicheur, a French-Algerian physicist working on antimatter at CERNs enormous particle collider outside Geneva, was arrested on Oct. 8, 2009, on suspicion of conspiring with an Algerian branch of Al Qaeda, fears of doomsday plots rippled through the tabloid press.

title: Stirring Win for Horse Without the Hype
description: HALLANDALE, Fla.

title: For Japanese, Learning to Receive
description: On a normal Monday, Motoatsu Sakurai would have focused on a board of directors meeting scheduled for the next day at the Japan Society, on East 47th Street. He might have reviewed cultural programs, like a series of films now running about Japanese mobsters, known as yakuza.

title: For Honolulus Homeless, an Eviction Notice
description: HONOLULU  From his home on Ilalo Street, Banery Afituk can feel the breeze off Mamala Bay, two blocks away. Walking out his front door, to his right, he can make out the tops of the luxury ocean liners, and to his left, some of this citys finer high rises. I like it here, he said, as his three children played around him.

title: Briefing on Protest for Palestinian Unity Becomes a Rally Itself
description: GAZA  Hundreds of demonstrators calling for Palestinian unity took to the streets here on Monday, a day earlier than scheduled, in an effort to prevent what they said were attempts by political factions to hijack their movement for their own agendas.

title: Knicks Have the Stars, but Not the Answers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Mike DAntoni called it a horror film, but he could have just as easily classified the latest Knicks defeat as a horrendous sequel, filled with predictable premises and tired clichs.

title: The Abuse of Private Manning
description: Pfc. Bradley Manning, who has been imprisoned for nine months on charges of handing government files to WikiLeaks, has not even been tried let alone convicted. Yet the military has been treating him abusively, in a way that conjures creepy memories of how the Bush administration used to treat terror suspects. Inexplicably, it appears to have President Obamas support to do so.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,487 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: The Sport Needs to Change
description: Dave Duerson was once a world-class athlete, a perfect physical specimen whose pro football career included Super Bowl championships with the Chicago Bears and New York Giants. Friends and former teammates would tell you that he was also a bright guy  a graduate of Notre Dame with a degree in economics and, at least for awhile, a successful businessman.

title: Chile: Priest Sex Abuse Case Re-Opened
description: An appeals court voted unanimously on Monday to reopen a criminal case into charges of the sexual abuse of minors by the Rev. Fernando Karadima, a Roman Catholic priest. A Vatican investigation found Father Karadima guilty last month of abusing minors and ordered him to retire to a life of prayer and penitence. A judge in Santiago closed a criminal case late last year, ruling there was not enough evidence to charge him. The appeals court ruled that the case should be reopened because the events, time and circumstances of the punishable acts had not been sufficiently investigated.

title: With 3 Network Partners, CBS Adjusts
description: As fans of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament are discovering, March Madness is no longer a CBS-only event.

title: India: Navy Seizes Pirate Ship
description: The Indian Navy said Monday that it had arrested 61 pirates and rescued 13 crew members on Saturday some 700 miles off the western coast. The Navy said it had seized the Vega 5, a fishing boat from Mozambique that Somali pirates had captured in December and were using as a mother ship to attack other ships in the Arabian Sea. The Navy increased its patrols in December after a series of pirate attacks near the Indian coast. The raid was the third major capture of Somali pirates by Indian authorities this year. India captured 43 pirates in two raids in January and February.

title: Azerbaijan: Protesters Sentenced
description: At least 30 people who took part in rare antigovernment protests last weekend have been sentenced, Human Rights Watch reported Monday. Participants received sentences of five to eight days in prison after trials lasting from 5 to 40 minutes. Defense lawyers said that they were not informed of the trials time or place, and that judges denied access to the news media and family members.

title: Sos Your Old Man
description: In a recent column in The Miami Herald, Leonard Pitts criticized Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour for failing to denounce the proposal to honor Ku Klux Klan founder Nathan Bedford Forrest by issuing a vanity license plate bearing his name. When pressed by the NAACP, Barbour said, I dont go around denouncing people.

title: N.H.L.s New Concussion Protocol Requires a Physicians Review Off the Ice
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  N.H.L. players showing signs of a concussion will be removed from the bench area and examined by a doctor in a quiet room away from the ice, Commissioner Gary Bettman said Monday at the general managers annual meeting.

title: The Ike Phase
description: On Jan. 20, 1961, John Kennedy delivered his rousing Inaugural Address. But this speech was preceded, as William Galston of the Brookings Institution has reminded us, by an equally important speech: Dwight Eisenhowers farewell address.

title: Virginia: Gunman Kills 2 Sheriffs Deputies
description: The Virginia State Police on Monday identified the man they said shot four police officers, two of them fatally, in southwestern Virginia last weekend, but the motive for the shooting remained unclear. The man, Gilbert Newberry, 52, was shot to death by the police on Sunday after refusing to surrender, the authorities said. He had hidden on a wooded hillside and fired a high-powered rifle at officers responding to a call of possible larceny at a scrap yard in rural Buchanan County. The state police identified the dead officers as Cameron Justus, 41, and William Stiltner, 46. The wounded officers, who were both in critical condition on Monday, were Erik Rasnake, 32, and Shane Charles, 25.

title: Rhode Island: Providence Mayor Plans School Closings
description: As many as 70 teaching jobs could be eliminated under a plan to close four elementary schools in Providence, Mayor Angel Taveras said. The closings, meant to help address a city budget gap of $110 million, could save at least $12 million, city officials said. The schools were all low performing and in poor physical condition, and Mr. Taveras, a Democrat, said the closings would not significantly increase class size across the system. Last month, the Providence School Board sent termination notices to all 1,926 of the citys teachers, but Mr. Taveras said most would keep their jobs.

title: Owsley Stanley, Artisan of Acid, Is Dead at 76
description: Owsley Stanley, the prodigiously gifted applied chemist to the stars, who made LSD in quantity for the Grateful Dead, the Beatles, Jimi Hendrix, Ken Kesey and other avatars of the psychedelic 60s, died on Saturday in a car accident in Australia. He was 76 and lived in the bush near Cairns, in the Australian state of Queensland.

title: That Tsunami? Not a Joke. Seriously.
description: In this age of instant communications, beware: Off-hand remarks about the earthquake and tsunami in Japan have claimed the careers of three high-profile people in the last several days.

title: Memories, Washed Away
description: ON Aug. 9, 1945, my great-uncle was out fishing in the Pacific, far enough away from Nagasaki, Japan, that he missed the immediate impact of the atomic bomb dropped by the Americans that day. My great-aunt was in their new house outside Nagasaki; the entire family had only a few days earlier fled the city because my great-uncle feared a repeat of the bombing of Hiroshima.

title: Let Kids Rule the School
description: New Marlborough, Mass.

title: In Stricken Fuel-Cooling Pools, a Danger for the Longer Term
description: Even as workers race to prevent the radioactive cores of the damaged nuclear reactors in Japan from melting down, concerns are growing that nearby pools holding spent fuel rods could pose an even greater danger.

title: Back in Albany After U.S. Charges, State Senator Finds a Different World
description: ALBANY  When his Democratic colleagues held their daily meeting on Monday, State Senator Carl Kruger stayed holed up in his office across the street from the Capitol. When he finally emerged, a woman who spotted him down the hallway gasped. And when Mr. Kruger walked onto the Senate floor, most of his colleagues acted as if he were invisible.

title: Theyre Not Listening
description: Bahrain and Yemen are both important to American strategic interests. The former is home to the United States Navys Fifth Fleet; the latter is battling, with Washingtons frequent participation, one of Al Qaedas stronger affiliates.

title: Danbury 11
description: In September 2006, an undercover police officer in Danbury, Conn., who was driving a van and posing as a contractor, picked up 11 Latino day laborers at a park and delivered them straight to federal immigration agents. The men were arrested and placed in deportation proceedings. In another city, this would have struck officials as abusive policing and a gross violation of civil rights. Not in Danbury. Its mayor said the city had only supplied logistical support to the agents.

title: Cry of Gun! Is Claimed in Fatal Shooting of Fellow Officer
description: Nassau County police officers who witnessed the  fatal shooting of a fellow officer last weekend said that the victim was wearing his badge and that they did not hear the officer who shot him identify himself or yell anything before firing, the president of the Nassau police union said Monday.

title: Tuesday: Celebrity Guest Solver Merrill Markoe
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  We have a very funny guest today, so Im going to keep my own comments brief.

title: Money for Nothing
description: Montgomery, Ala.

title: Miami-Dade Mayor Faces Special Vote to Keep Job
description: MIAMI  Mayor Carlos Alvarez of Miami-Dade County faces a recall vote on Tuesday that has tapped into the frustration of an area still reeling from a decimated housing market and stubbornly high unemployment.

title: Radiation Exposure Could Curtail Workers Efforts
description: As radiation levels rise at the crippled reactors in northern Japan, a basic question arises: how long can workers keep struggling to ward off full meltdowns?

title: Harnessing the Power of the Mom Blogger
description: THE latest advice on child-rearing, baby products and prenatal yoga stretches is not being found in conversations over the picket fence but rather in Twitter messages, blog rolls and on Facebook walls. To that end, marketers have been increasingly harnessing the power of mothers online to reach their intended audiences for products.

title: Clinton Meets in Paris With Libyan Rebel Leader
description: PARIS  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton met late Monday with a leader of Libyas increasingly beleaguered opposition, but did so privately and without a public statement.

title: Obama Urges Education Law Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama called on Monday for an overhaul of education legislation enacted in the Bush administration, telling an audience of teachers and students that Congress should change the No Child Left Behind Act before the start of the next school year.

title: Conservatives Balk at Stopgap Spending Measure
description: WASHINGTON  Frustrated with the pace of budget negotiations, Congressional conservatives are lining up against a new stopgap spending measure in a challenge to Republican leaders who back the legislation needed to avert a government shutdown.

title: Derivatives, as Accused by Buffett
description: Warren E. Buffetts elephant gun and itchy trigger finger may be the market chatter, after Berkshire Hathaway announced a $9 billion deal to buy Lubrizol on Monday.

title: City to Revise Treatment of Children in Foster Care
description: New York City is no longer allowed to keep troubled foster-care children in psychiatric hospitals after doctors have recommended their release, and must closely adhere to laws that require such children to be placed in the least restrictive setting possible, after reaching a settlement agreement in federal court last week.

title: Head of Citys Main Labor Federation Quits Amid Criticism
description: The president of New York Citys main labor federation said Monday that he was resigning because of personal differences with other union leaders.

title: N.R.A. Declines to Meet With Obama on Gun Policy
description: WASHINGTON  More than two months after the Tucson shootings, the administration is calling together both the gun lobby and gun safety groups to find common ground. But President Obama has no plans to take the lead in proposing further gun control legislation, aides say, and the nations major gun rights group is snubbing the invitation.

title: Many Culprits in Fall of a Family Film
description: LOS ANGELES  In the movie business, sometimes a flop is just a flop. Then there are misses so disastrous that they send signals to broad swaths of Hollywood. Mars Needs Moms is shaping up as the second type.

title: Guilty Plea in Fraud Case Tied to TARP
description: Raymond E. Bowman, the former president of Taylor, Bean & Whitaker Mortgage, pleaded guilty on Monday in connection with a $1.9 billion fraud that included trying to deceive the federal bank bailout program.

title: N.F.L. Talks Start a Phase of Waiting

Hundreds of thousands homeless. Whole villages wiped out. And now there is the threat of further harm from badly damaged nuclear reactors. The worst-case accident would be enormous releases of radioactivity.

title: Parting Glance: Brian Lanker, 1947-2011

title: Lax Rules for Discount Buses Cited After I-95 Crash

title: Computer-Based G.E.D. Tests Planned
description: The American Council on Education and Pearson, a major education and testing company, are starting a partnership to design and deliver a computer-based G.E.D. test, aligned with the Common Core State Standards. The new business, which will continue to use the G.E.D. Testing Service name, will not offer the new G.E.D. until 2014, but will begin to roll out computer-based versions of the existing test this spring in California, Florida, Georgia and Texas. The new test and the computer-based version of the existing one will be available only at official testing centers. There are no plans to offer them online. About 800,000 people take the G.E.D. each year, and more than 470,000 of them earn their high school equivalency.

title: Who Made Those Album Covers?

The bands lead singer, Colin Meloy is a tale spinner, singing character studies and parables, Jon Pareles wrote in his review of the album for The Times. His lyrics have never held back a literary vocabulary that includes words like arabesques, harrowing and attrition. And the Decemberists have spent much of their decade-long career trying ever-expanding structures: songs, suites, concept albums.

title: Mr. Cohen Has a Beef

We waited a total of two hours and were finally told that they were out of nearly every entree and would we consider sampling what they had left? When they couldnt confirm how long it would take to get tastings, we left NEVER TO RETURN TO THIS HORRIBLE PLACE  And the owner came up to us to say it was a bad night He was arrogant and didnt apologize or offer us the opportunity to return comped or discounted. AVOID THIS RESTAURANT. Alex C.

This post is part of a series on some of the findings that I thought were worth sharing.

title: The Boy From Guantnamo
description: In the wake of President Obamas announcement last week that military trials will resume at Guantnamo Bay and that the prison camp will remain open indefinitely, its well worth taking the time to read Michael Paternitis article from the February issue of GQ about the current life of former detaineeMohammad Jawad. Jawad is one of two minors (the other is Omar Khadr) held for years at the prison camp. His precise age is not known, but human rights workers and family members claim he was was 12 when he was detained in December 2002. (The American military says he was at least 16.) He was released from Gitmo in August 2009 after a federal judge ruled the militarys case against him was riddled with holes and the chief prosecutor of the case resigned in protest of the military commissions. Paterniti, who recently wrote about Haiti for this magazine, also compiled a partial but fascinating oral history of the camps, which accompanies his GQ article online.

title: Now Reading | My Korean Deli
description: Imagine youre an editor at The Paris Review, the product of a WASPy New England milieu. Your life entails daily interactions with George Plimpton  editing, writing, looking for the next Philip Roth. Then, for reasons that seemed reasonable at the time, you decide to pour your life savings into a cruddy bodega in the Boerum Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn for the sake of your Korean-American wifes parents. A New York story par excellence, Ben Ryder Howes My Korean Deli is a hilarious account of clashing cultures and backbreaking, soul-squeezing vocational juggling. Here, Howe takes questions on his life post-deli and his relationship with his stubborn Korean mother-in-law (the Mike Tyson of Korean grandmothers), and even offers a few pointers on what to avoid at a convenience store.

title: New Gore Book Is Meachams First Acquisition for Random House
description: Now certainly feels like one of those moments when the world needs to be explained to us, and Random House believes it has found just the writer to do it: Al Gore, the former vice president and Nobel Peace Prize winner, will write a new book about what he calls the drivers of global change, that connects the dots among social, economic and political forces shaping our times, Random House said on Tuesday. The book, which is planned for release next year and does not yet have a title, is the first acquisition for the publishing house by Jon Meacham, the author and former Newsweek editor, who was named an executive vice president at the Random House Publishing Group in January.

The title of the post I clicked to was Avoiding Old Flames on Facebook. An important topic for a person of any faith. Ill read that!

title: Modern Times, Indeed: Dylan Plans First Concert in Vietnam
description: That guy who said The times they are a-changin  really knew what he was talking about, didnt he? Adding to the itinerary of locations where Bob Dylan has never previously played and where we never imagined hed someday appear in concert, that ragged counterculture bard is slated to give a performance in Vietnam next month, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Dylan, whose songs like Blowin in the Wind and Masters of War were sung at many a Vietnam War-era protest, is scheduled to perform a set list of his own determining on April 10 at RMIT University in Ho Chi Minh City. Rod Quinton, the general manager of Saigon Sound System, a Ho Chi Minh City company that is promoting the concert, told The A.P. that Mr. Dylan is a very important legend of music, and we think its important that Vietnamese people, particularly the younger generation, are exposed to his legacy and what hes done for music. The director of Art Performances Department of the Vietnamese government said Mr. Dylan had been granted permission to give the concert, which will come days after his first performances in China, in Beijing on April 6 and in Shanghai on April 8. The A.P. said tickets for Mr. Dylans Ho Chi Minh City performance would run from about $43  just more than Vietnams monthly minimum wage  to about $120 for V.I.P. seats.

title: High Schools Emotional Run Ends
description: There is enough sobering news in the world to have to find even more in sports, but sometimes people can create light in even the darkest stories. In little Fennville, Mich., an entire community, joined by other communities whose teams played Fennvilles grief-stricken boys basketball team over the past 10 days, strived to make that happen. Fennvilles games after the death of the 16-year-old player Wes Leonard seemed to bring out the best in everyone involved.

title: A New Comment System for Well
description: Readers of the Well blog always have a lot to say, and now were going to make it easier for you to say it.

title: Shifting Importance of Parenting
description: What is most important in your life, parenting or partnership?

title: E-Mail Lessons Learned, but . . .
description: Over the last several years, it has been amazing that people did not seem to have learned that e-mails could  and would  be searched if something ever got to court. E-mails that incriminated the writers, or at least embarrassed them, became a fixture of lawsuits and trials. A whole industry was born to efficiently search though millions of messages.

title: Japanese Tech Execs Share Save Japan Strategies at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Takahito Iguchi zipped through his presentation on Japans mobile social scene here on Monday until he got to his last slide: SAVE JAPAN.

title: The Debate Over Brokers Fees
description: The issue of how to weigh the cost of paying insurance brokers under the new federal health care law is up for debate again, even though state regulators made their final recommendations last year.

title: Accident at Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Plant
description: The worst nuclear accident since the Chernobyl explosion in 1986 is unfolding in northern Japan at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant. Three reactors have been critically damaged and one caught fire.

title: Some Airlines Serving Japan Adjust Schedules and Stops
description: PARIS  Citing concerns about potential disruptions to air traffic because of the nuclear crisis in Japan, Lufthansa said Tuesday that it had begun rerouting its Tokyo flights southwest to airports in Nagoya and Osaka.

title: Interview: Ti West
description: The director Ti West talks about merging humor and horror in his latest film The Innkeepers.

title: Deborah Eisenberg Wins PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction
description: Deborah Eisenberg was named the winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction on Tuesday for The Collected Stories of Deborah Eisenberg (Picador), a compilation of four volumes of her work. It was chosen from a selection of roughly 320 novels and short story collections, all published in the United States in 2010. Laura Furman, one of the judges, said of Ms. Eisenbergs collection, From the first to the last of her collected stories, Deborah Eisenberg demonstrates her sharp intelligence, literary inventiveness and her clear understanding of human interconnectedness as it exists in isolation. She will receive $15,000; the four finalists, Jennifer Egan, Jaimy Gordon, Eric Puchner and Brad Watson, will receive $5,000. An awards ceremony is scheduled for May 7 at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

title: Empathys Decline
description: In last Fridays column, I cited some research to suggest that young people today have a more expanded sense of self than young people a generation ago. The meaner way of saying this is that they are more narcissistic. I hesitate to use the meaner vocabulary because of my sense that people under 30 are a remarkable generation: they volunteer more, hurt each other less and hurt themselves less than previous generations.

title: Dish Network in Revised Deal for Satellite Operator
description: 3:27 p.m. | Updated

title: Experts Had Long Criticized Potential Weakness in Design of Stricken Reactor
description: The warnings were stark and issued repeatedly as far back as 1972: If the cooling systems ever failed at a Mark 1 nuclear reactor, the primary containment vessel surrounding the reactor would probably burst as the fuel rods inside overheated. Dangerous radiation would spew into the environment.

title: Oil Price Falls as Investors Dump Commodities
description: The price of oil fell below $100 a barrel on Tuesday for the first time in two weeks as investors dumped commodities for safer assets amid worries that the widening disaster in Japan could lead to a global economic slowdown.

description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The kind of thing you think about in the morning: How does all the beer get here?

description: We have a 14-hour layover at Seoul Incheon airport later this month. Well be traveling with our three children, ages 6 to 13. Can we see anything of Seoul during that time? Wed consider a resort.

title: Questions on the Nuclear Crisis in Japan
description: 3:59 p.m. | Updated New York Times reporters covering the scientific, public health, environmental and political ramifications of the nuclear crisis in Japan took questions from readers. Answers to selected questions are posted here.

title: Legends of Brunch
description: The city of Athens, Ga., has produced its share of rock legends, but not many people outside Clarke County know of a star among dishes served in downtown Athens: the fried green tomato eggs Benedict at Five Star Day Cafe.

description: The N.F.L. lockout is taking a toll on players, who cannot work out or receive treatment at their teams facilities. Now it may have an impact on incoming players, too.

description: A top banking regulator approved a plan to seize and unwind big banks  a proposal that will help address those too big to fail firms whose collapse could imperil the financial system.

description: In a recent issue of The New York Times Magazine, Sam Anderson wrote about the delights of writing and reading marginalia in books by and for grownups. But what about children, champion scribblers and their own literary possessions?

title: Gauging Disasters Toll on an Economy
description: For all the devastation wreaked by natural disasters, economists say that the long-term impact on a nations economy is generally negligible  particularly in countries with strong institutions and deep pockets.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Libya, Tunisia and the West Bank.

title: G-8 Ministers Fail to Agree on Libya No-Flight Zone
description: PARIS  The eight most powerful industrialized nations failed to agree Tuesday on a no-flight zone or any other military operation to help the Libyan opposition, instead passing the problem to the United Nations Security Council by urging an undefined increase of pressure on the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Party Seeks One Voice. Schumer Steps Forward.
description: WASHINGTON  The Sunday morning news conferences to denounce overpriced breakfast cereal are a thing of the past. So is edging colleagues out of jobs and camera shots with elbows as sharp as a sushi knife.

title: Man Charged in Stabbings Spoke of Doozy of a Day
description: In the minutes after the police arrested and charged him last month with a 28-hour rampage that left four people dead, Maksim Gelman began babbling to the police, saying things that were alternately grim, confusing and just plain bizarre.

title: Fed Staying on Current Path, With Job Creation as Top Priority
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve on Tuesday reiterated that the economy was improving but said it would continue measures to stimulate growth because it remained more concerned about persistent unemployment than the risk of increased inflation.

title: What Scares Germans About Japans Nuclear Fallout
description: In Germany, where anti-nuke fervor runs high, Chancellor Angela Merkel announced that seven nuclear plants have been shut down for testing as part of a nationwide review. Meanwhile,the German news media have their own way of dealing with the crisis. According to TheGuardian, Sddeutsche Zeitung, a Munich-based daily, noted that a novel for young people with a nuclear theme, Die Wolke (The Cloud), by Gudrun Pausewang, published a year after the Chernobyl disaster, hit No. 2 on German Amazon over the weekend. And though Japan lies nearly 6,000miles from Germany, Bild, Europes biggest-selling tabloid, ran a nuclearmeltdown Q.&A. anyway. The queries?  Is it O.K. to carry on eating sushi? (Answer: yes. German sushi restaurants do not usually use Japanese fish); and Should I buy a Geiger counter? (no).

title: A Foil for the Koch Brothers?
description: Is Thomas F. Steyer the anti-Koch?

title: In Lehmans Demise, a Dwindling Chance of Charges

Valukas, the bankruptcy examiner for Lehman Brothers, issued an extensive report outlining potential accounting fraud at the firm through the so-called Repo 105 transactions used before its collapse. Mr. Valukas asserted that these transactions created a materially misleading picture of the firms financial condition in 2007 and 2008.

Apparently Ken Cuccinelli, the states Republican attorney general, does. His folks appear to have snatched up www.timkaine.com. Clicking on it takes you to Mr. Cuccinellis Web site.

But thats what has happened.

description: ALBANY  State lawmakers expressed outrage on Tuesday over a news report detailing cases of abuse at state-run group homes for the developmentally disabled, vowing to seek criminal prosecution of workers and to introduce legislation improving oversight.

description: March 15, 2011 - Mac William Bishop reports on the aftermath of the tsunami and earthquake in the fishing village of Kesennuma, Japan.

title: War and Responsibility
description: In my column yesterday, I suggested that in debates over potential military interventions, the burden of proof should generally rest with hawks rather than with doves. That line was inspired, in part, by this post from Peter Feaver, objecting to the way the debate over Libya has proceeded, and criticizing what he terms sloppy thinking by critics of intervention. Heres one of his examples of a supposedly sloppy premise:

title: Photo Replay: March 15

Bloomberg of New York joined Representative Carolyn McCarthy on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to show support for a bill she will sponsor to try to close loopholes that permit criminals, drug abusers and the mentally ill to bypass the National Instant Criminal Background Check System and purchase guns.

title: Officers to Be Mourned in Back-to-Back Funerals
description: It is unlikely that many people knew both of the police officers killed in the line of duty over the weekend, but that was irrelevant in the planning of their funerals, scheduled for Friday  in part by accident and in part by design  to accommodate the many officers who are expected to attend both.

title: Ghost Stories and Jokes With Ti West
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The horror director Ti West returns to SXSW with The Innkeepers, his follow-up to the creepy House of the Devil. But this time, the laughs are almost as plentiful as the scares. His film, about two staffers at a vintage hotel who may have more guests on site than they thought, uses many of the conventions of old-fashioned horror, but adds in characters not usually found in those films. In an interview appropriately conducted at the historic (and sometimes spooky) Driskill Hotel, Mr. West spoke about his goals for the film, including experimenting with jump jokes, rather than jump scares.

title: 20 Ways to Teach About the Disaster in Japan Across the Curriculum
description: Since the earthquake and tsunami hit Japan, we have been updating a list of teaching and learning resources, including articles, interactive features, past lessons, photo galleries and videos.

description: Lens: Shiho Fukadas photographs from Japan.

title: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Publisher Steps Down
description: Barry OCallaghan, the chief executive of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, resigned on Tuesday after less than two years on the job, the publisher said.

title: Ink Barely Dry on Finance Ministers Deal, Trichet Calls Europes New Fiscal Rules Weak
description: BRUSSELS  European Union finance ministers agreed on Tuesday to toughen the fiscal rules for euro zone governments, only to have the proposals dismissed as insufficient by the president of the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet.

title: Bloomberg Speaks Up for Gun Bill
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spoke on Capitol Hill on Tuesday, in his role as co-chairman of Mayors Against Illegal Guns, to lobby for a bill being proposed by Representative Carolyn McCarthy that aims to close loopholes permitting convicted criminals, drug abusers and the mentally ill to buy guns without background checks. The vast majority of Americans agree about what should be done, the mayor said. Read all about it on The Caucus.

title: Three Defensive Up-and-Comers
description: Though exceptional rookies are able to rack up points, assists, or rebounds from Day 1, its a rare first-year player who begins his pro career as a competent defender. N.B.A.-level defense doesnt only require athletic tools, but also defensive awareness and familiarity with a system that young players often lack. Each player develops on his own curve; some may make significant strides by his second or third season, and others may not be fully comfortable on defense until they settle into the right system or alongside the right on-floor leader.

title: Germany Shuts 7 Plants as Europe Plans Safety Tests
description: BRUSSELS  Germany on Tuesday became the first European country to shut nuclear plants in the wake of the crisis in Japan as the European Union made plans to test all 143 nuclear power plants in its 27 countries.

title: All the News After 64 Years: The Story That Didnt Fly
description: Editors Note (slightly overdue). An article on Oct. 21, 1942, about the death of Byron Darnton, a war correspondent for The New York Times, described the death as accidental without any elaboration. Two subsequent articles said the boat he was traveling on was bombed from the air. It was many years before The Times explained further: Mr. Darnton was killed by friendly fire in an attack by an American B-25 bomber on the Australian fishing boat that was carrying the reporter and a force of American troops to Buna, in New Guinea. The circumstances of his death quickly became known to his family and were recounted correctly in Meyer Bergers 1951 history, The Story of The New York Times: 1851-1951, and in a 1975 article in The Times by Martin Arnold reporting on the discovery of Mr. Darntons last notebook, the one in which he was writing when he died.

title: Social Security Suicide
description: Via Jonathan Chait, The Hill reports that Obama administration economic officials are pressing for Social Security benefit cuts.

title: Ohio Town Sees Public Job as Only Route to Middle Class
description: GALLIPOLIS, Ohio  Jodi and Ralph Taylor are public workers whose jobs as a janitor and a sewer manager cover lifes basics. They have moved out of a trailer into a house, do not have to rely on food stamps and sometimes even splurge for the spicy wing specials at the Courtside Bar and Grill.

title: Hamas Forces Break Up Pro-Unity Protests in Gaza
description: GAZA  Mass protests in Gaza on Tuesday were violently broken up by Hamas police officers and security officers, many in plainclothes, witnesses said.

title: Heller to Run for Ensign Senate Seat in Nevada

description: WASHINGTON  The House gave grudging approval on Tuesday to a plan to finance the federal government for three more weeks, even as dozens of Republicans broke with their leadership and opposed the stopgap legislation.

title: Nigerian Finds Pop Stardom in Beijing
description: BEIJING  The silver scales of Hao Ges glam shirt glitter against his dark violet designer suit as a spotlight focuses on him. Female dancers in jumpsuits orbit him as he slowly begins to sing a sugary pop ballad and clenches his fist as if to invoke the gods of love.

title: A Note On Titles and Such
description: A semi-serious followup to my Doktor Doktor post: in the kinds of circles I mostly move in, actually using your academic titles is considered tacky. But thats not out of humility: if youre a real player, you see, people are supposed to know your credentials without your telling them.

title: Mr. Rodgers in a New Neighborhood With Red Bulls
description: HARRISON, N.J.  If a video game simulation is to be believed, the Red Bulls new English striker, Luke Rodgers, is going to lead Major League Soccer with 17 goals this season.

title: Obama Pays Respects to World War I Veteran
description: President Obama made an unannounced trip to Arlington National Cemetery on Tuesday afternoon to honor the last American World War I veteran.

title: What to Expect: X-Ray Vision, Doubled Life Spans and Lots of Robots
description: Reading a dull, charmless nonfiction book is almost always better than reading a dull, charmless novel. With a nonfiction book, you might at least learn something.

title: A Role in Kruger Scandal, and in Reality Show
description: Nothing like a link to a high-profile political scandal to goose a reality shows visibility and, perhaps, viability.

title: Ancient Roots, Fresh Sounds
description: Globalization has long had enemies along every point in the political spectrum, and colonialism, once considered a form of nationalistic virtue, is today regarded as an unalloyed evil. But in purely musical terms, there is a great deal to be said for hybrids born of different cultures coming into contact, and musicians grafting alien ideas about form, timbre, rhythm and harmony onto their own traditional styles. Yo-Yo Ma has made that point in his Silk Road Project, and Jordi Savall, the viola da gamba master and director of a handful of ensembles, has made a specialty of building programs from the fruits of musical cross-pollination and antique forms of multiculturalism.

title: Do-Over for Renovation Plans at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Building
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday asked the owner of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust building on Fifth Avenue at 43rd Street to revise its renovation plans for the buildings interior, recently designated a landmark. Preservationists had argued that the changes would amount to sacrilege. Read more on ArtsBeat.

title: Rerolling the Dice
description: For those of us who traverse I-95 North and the New Jersey Turnpike South, the sight of a casino bus weaving through traffic at high speeds is an urgent call to change lanes. So the recent crash in the Bronx, which dominated  the tabloids over the weekend, was not exactly surprising, even if it was shocking.

title: An Agreement Is Reached in Ansel Adams Lawsuit
description: It is not exactly clear just what has been resolved, beyond a cessation of name calling, but the federal lawsuit between the Ansel Adams Publishing Rights Trust and the California man who believes he owns a set of this photographers lost negatives has been settled out of court.

title: An American Jacket in Paris
description: No two species of iconic American outerwear mate quite so well as the bomber and the varsity letter. One particularly fine specimen can be found in the window of Blackrainbow, a boutique at 68 rue des Archive, in Paris. It has existed online and within the department store Citadium for four years, and this past January opened its first stand-alone shop. In addition to a well-edited selection of street-wear brands like Stssy, Wood Wood, Woolrich, Barbour and Supra, Blackrainbow produces a small in-house label that includes a yearly limited-edition leather jacket manufactured by hand in France. (See related video.)

title: New York Philharmonic Casting Change for Bluebeards Castle
description: The actress Marthe Keller has withdrawn from the New York Philharmonics performances of the opera Bluebeards Castle by Bartok because of illness, the orchestra said on Tuesday. Richard Easton will replace her in reciting the prologue. The performances are on Friday, Saturday and Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall.

description: NOAA Center for Tsunami Research

title: New to the Board of Regents, but No Stranger to City Schools

But several years back, when superintendents actively supervised, Kathleen M. Cashin led principals in some of the citys worst neighborhoods, with notable success.

description: Will I be seeing you at SXSW? No?

Living Up to Its Cellar

description: WATA POOR, Afghanistan  The labor boss stood looking down at a man and his four sons squatting in the dirt, the boys mechanically rolling and slapping mud as they made line after line of dull gray bricks.

title: Uzbekistan Expels Human Rights Watchs Staff
description: MOSCOW  Human Rights Watch announced on Tuesday that the government of Uzbekistan had decided to expel its employees from the country, a move the group said indicated a deepening human rights crisis in the authoritarian former Soviet republic.

title: U.C.L.A. Students Video Rant Against Asians Fuels Firestorm
description: LOS ANGELES  When Alexandra Wallace recorded her rant about Asian students using cellphones in the library at the University of California, Los Angeles, she was alone, speaking to her computer.

title: Modern Flavors Transform a Purim Tradition
description: TEL AVIV

title: Hamantashen: Trendy in Tel Aviv, Traditional in Paris
description: Lehamim Bakery in Tel Aviv plays with flavors when filling the traditional Purim cookie, while Florence Kahn stays close to the classic at her bakery in Paris.

title: Why Did G.M.s Keep Some Head Hits Legal?
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Despite growing concern over concussions inside and outside the game and the leagues own statistics showing that 14 percent of all concussions this season have been caused by legal checks to the head, N.H.L. general managers decided not to broaden Rule 48 to outlaw all head contact at Day 2 of their annual meeting.

title: Stars Heart Condition Keeps L.I.U. on Edge
description: Julian Boyd should not be playing basketball. Thats the standard medical advice for people who, like him, have a malformed heart. Because so little is known about his condition  known as left ventricular noncompaction  medical experts recommend against playing most competitive sports.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Chic, Along Fifth Ave., Moves Below 50th St.
description: Once an unremarkable stretch of discount stores, banks and camera and electronics shops, Fifth Avenue south of St. Patricks Cathedral has sprung to life in the last year, offering the promise of becoming a fashionable shopping destination.

title: 9 Senators Seek to Delay Debit Card Fee Changes
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group of senators introduced a bill on Tuesday that would delay a new federal regulation to lower the swipe fees that banks could charge merchants for processing debit card transactions.

title: Compose
description: 77 Worth Street (Broadway), TriBeCa; (212) 226-1444, composenyc.com

title: An Elegant Alternative to Peanut Butter (Hold the Jam)
description: The distinctively toasted flavor of Marcona almonds shines through in this chunky nut butter from Valencia, Spain, elevating it beyond a partnership with grape jelly in a school lunchbox. Fashion canaps on toast by dabbing it on slices of membrillo (Spanish quince paste), use it as a change of pace the next time you make cold Chinese noodles with peanut or sesame sauce, or spoon it on as a topping for an ice cream sundae with chocolate sauce. The consistency is loose, so keep it refrigerated.

title: Nesting Dolls at Work in the Kitchen
description: Straightforward measuring tools are efficient and businesslike in the kitchen. But not fun. Heres a change of pace: white plastic nesting babushka dolls that are measuring cups for dry ingredients, with the calibrations embossed on the bottom of each. In addition to the usual 1/4, 1/3, 1/2 and full cup, there are also 2/3 and 3/4 cup measures.

title: A Restaurant Thats Very of the Moment
description: WHAT HAPPENS WHEN is the pop-up restaurant John Fraser and company opened in the old Jardin bistro in SoHo. It will run until the end of the summer, changing its menu and concept every 30 days. Then the lease expires and with it the restaurant.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Partaking to Aid Japan

title: A Wholesale Bakery Goes Retail
description: It feels like a speakeasy. A barely marked gray door leads down a flight of stairs to another door. Ring the bell, and you will enter an industrial kitchen filled with improbably delectable aromas. There, Ernesto Bolta (below), in an almost goofy chefs hat, may be whisking a big pot of buttery stuff on the stove, pulling crumb-topped tarts from the oven or arranging rustic-looking chocolate confections on cooling racks.

title: Pondexter Apologizes, but Is That Enough?
description: What was Cappie Pondexter thinking?

title: Former City Council Leader Avoids Prison for Tax Evasion
description: Andrew J. Stein, a former president of the City Council and a fixture in New York politics for aquarter-century, was sentenced on Tuesday to three years probation for tax evasion, dodging a prison sentence after delivering an emotional plea for leniency.

title: Warren Buffetts Funny Take on the Financial Crisis
description: Last night, dont ask me why, I plowed through the full 23-page transcript of Warren Buffetts interview with the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, discovered via Felix Salmon. It was surprisingly light reading; Buffett cracked himself up so many times there couldve been a laugh track. He offered plenty of the plain-spoken discernment for which he is idolized  pricing power makes even an idiot C.E.O. look like a genius; investing in your house is a currency play (really a way to go short on the dollar); Wall Street profits by fooling its customers with complex risk underwriting (Theres just more money in contracts that people dont understand); Bank of Americas Ken Lewis is the unheralded hero of the financial crisis because he saved the world as we know it by buying Merrill Lynch when he could have had it the next day for nothing.

title: Ex-Adviser Out of Jail After 11 Years, Including 7 for Contempt
description: Martin A. Armstrong, who prosecutors accused of running a $3 billion Ponzi scheme, is finally out of jail after 11 years, including a possible record seven years for contempt of court in a dispute over gold and antiquities.

title: Two Bills Put Focus on Equipment Safety for Children
description: Already under scrutiny from two federal agencies, football helmet safety will enter both houses of Congress on Wednesday through bills that would improve standards for headgear and curb spurious advertising of all childrens sports safety equipment.

title: Capturing a Look at Me Milieu With Impish Modesty
description: A few moments into the film Bill Cunningham New York, its subject  the legendary street-fashion photographer and society chronicler for The New York Times  is seen darting into the maw of Midtown traffic, unconcerned about the threat of death by taxi. Fast, intensely focused and apparently able to tune out all but the shot hes after, Mr. Cunningham calls to mind a war photographer, which is an unlikely thing for an 82-year-old fashion photographer to call to mind.

title: Some Animals Are More Equal Than Others
description: Its time to take a look at the line between pet and animal. When the ASPCA sends an agent to the home of a Brooklyn family to arrest one of its members for allegedly killing a hamster, something is wrong.

title: Libyan Oil Buys Allies for Qaddafi
description: BAMAKO, Mali  Elhadj Maiga is a Qaddafi recruiter and a proud one at that, scrambling to assemble a pipeline of young men from Mali to go and fight for The Great Leader.

title: A Charitable Rush, With Little Direction
description: Disasters, particularly those epic enough to earn round-the-clock news coverage, are a fast way to get donors to open their wallets. So it was no surprise when nonprofit groups, starting with the American Red Cross and moving down to small charities, scrambled to raise money to help the victims of the Japanese earthquake and tsunami.

title: Anxiety Over Radiation Drives a Sales Surge for a Drug Against Thyroid Cancer
description: As Japan races to avoid a nuclear disaster, some Americans and companies in the United States are scrambling to obtain potassium iodide, a drug that can protect people from radiation-induced thyroid cancer.

title: Loan Study on Students Goes Beyond Default Rates
description: For each student who defaults on a loan, at least two more fall behind in payments on their student debt, a new study has found.

title: Pillar of Relief Coverage: Americans Reconnected With Anxious Families
description: A television correspondent, still wearing a radiation detection badge on his lapel, had important news to convey to a worried woman in the United States. This is Bill Weir with ABC News. Im actually in northern Japan right now, and I just saw your sister Elsa and shes O.K., and she wanted you to know that, and that she loves you.

title: The Haitian Lazarus
description: Port-au-Prince, Haiti

title: The White House Collection
description: The White House is also a museum full of important art and objects, a collection curated by William G. Allman.

title: When the Marketing Reach of Social Media Backfires
description: SOCIAL media like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube have been embraced by Madison Avenue as effective new ways to reach consumers. But what happens when behavior on social media is deemed antisocial?

title: As Riesch Stumbles, Vonn Climbs Back Into Title Race
description: SPINDLERUV MLYN, Czech Republic  Less than two weeks ago, before the races in Tarvisio, Italy, Maria Riesch of Germany held a seemingly insurmountable 196-point lead over Lindsey Vonn in their battle for Alpine ski racings overall womens title.

description: Harry Campbell

title: Egypt Ends Domestic Spying Agency, but Creates New One
description: CAIRO  Egypt on Tuesday disbanded the state security organization, a force of widely loathed agents whose blatant spying and use of torture helped drive the public revolt that led to the overthrow of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Fight on Islamic Center Flares Anew as Ex-Firefighter Takes His Case to Court
description: The furor over an Islamic center and mosque planned near ground zero flared up again on Tuesday, as lawyersfor a former New York City firefighter asked a judge to overturn the citys decision to withhold landmark protection for the building site.

title: Iraqi Delay Hinders U.S. Planning
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs long delay in finalizing its government has complicated the Obama administrations drive to set up a small army of diplomats and contractors here after the end of the year, when the last American troops are supposed to leave.

title: Immune to Cuts: Lofty Salaries at Hospitals
description: At Bronx-Lebanon, a hospital that exists only by the grace and taxed fortunes of the people of New York State, the chief executive was paid $4.8 million in 2007 and $3.6 million in 2008, records show. At NewYork-Presbyterian, a hospital system that receives nearly half a billion dollars annually in public money, the chief executive was paid $9.8 million in 2007 and $2.8 million in 2008.

title: Returning to a Nightmare in Japan
description: Shiho Fukada was born and raised in Tokyo. Now a freelance photographer in Beijing, she began making her way back to Japan, on assignment for The International Herald Tribune, hours after the earthquake. She is traveling with Michael Wines, a writer from the Beijing bureau of The New York Times, and Mac Bishop, a video journalist for The Times. This narrative is an edited version of her conversation with Kerri MacDonald from her hotel room in Kitakami, in northern Iwate Prefecture.

title: Japans Crisis and Nuclear Power

title: Still in the Fight: A New Reality
description: This is the first of a three-part series.

title: Wednesday: Pentathletes Weapons
description: Administrivial A.C.P.T. Study Aid Alert: If you are planning to attend the A.C.P.T. (we all know what that stands for by now, right?) and would like to get in a little extra cramming, or youd just like to increase your ability to recognize clues and their answers, Jim Horne has added a fun game to Xword Info here. Think fast, because the letters start to fill themselves in pretty quickly after you see the clue. Best of luck to all who are competing!

title: Feel Locked Out? Nothing to Tackle? Well, Try Opera
description: Lawrence Harris, an opera singer, poked the ballrooms faded carpet with the toe of his black alligator boot and said it reminded him of another arena he once performed in.

title: Pay for Bankers Creeping Back Up
description: Compensation for bank bosses is creeping back to the bad old days. Sure, nearly all of them now pocket a smaller amount each year than either they or their predecessors did before the financial crisis. But after a year or two of relative restraint, their boards are starting to favor them over shareholders again.

title: On Opinion: Documenting Veterans
description: In a three-part series on Opinionators Home Fires, a war artist documented the challenges of three wounded soldiers. The author and artist Michael D. Fay met with the marines at McGuire Veterans Administration Hospital in Richmond, Va., to record them in what most would consider the worst possible conditions. In the first post, he met Lance Cpl. Tyler Huffman, who was paralyzed from the waist down, and Cpl. Zachary Stinson, who lost both legs mid-thigh and whose right hand was virtually unusable.

title: Northrop to Spin Off Shipyards
description: Northrop Grummans board approved the spinoff of its struggling shipyards to stockholders after making changes to ease Navy concerns about the deal, Pentagon and industry officials said on Tuesday.

title: Disasters Costs to Fall on Japans Government
description: Apart from an expected $35 billion in insurance claims from last weeks earthquake, the financial losses in Japan will probably fall most heavily on the Japanese government once it tallies the damage from the tsunami and the nuclear disaster.

title: Casinos and Buses Cater to Asian Roots

description: A small crew of technicians, braving radiation and fire, became the only people remaining at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station on Tuesday  and perhaps Japans last chance of preventing a broader nuclear catastrophe.

title: In Albany, Battle Lines Are Drawn Over the Budget
description: ALBANY  Both houses of the State Legislature passed budgets on Tuesday that rejected crucial provisions of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos overhaul of Medicaid and restored hundreds of millions of dollars in proposed cuts to education, drawing sharp battle lines with the governor two weeks before the deadline to pass a spending plan.

title: At Miami Beach Hotel, Galleon Tips and Trading
description: Just a week before their arrests in 2009, Raj Rajaratnam and Anil Kumar were lounging in deck chairs on Miami Beach together, enjoying the high life  and swapping illegal stock tips.

title: What Would Jefferson Do?
description: During the secession crisis, no Americans were more trapped between secession and Union, between slavery and emancipation, than middle-of-the-road Virginians. And no Virginia family was more torn than Thomas Jeffersons clan.

title: Neighbors Blood Binds Settlers to West Bank
description: ITAMAR, West Bank  To outsiders, this Jewish settlement clinging to a hill in the northern West Bank would seem to offer a precarious existence.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 15, 2011

title: Netflix Is Said to Be Close to Acquiring a Television Show
description: Netflix may be on the verge of acquiring its first original television series, House of Cards, a drama to be directed by David Fincher.

title: Stocks End Lower as Traders Focus on Japan Crisis
description: There was no respite for weary investors Wednesday as deepening worries about the nuclear crisis in Japan prompted another sharp sell-off, leaving stocks in negative territory for the year.

title: Precautions Should Limit Health Problems From Nuclear Plants Radiation
description: Worsening conditions at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan have raised fears that people will be harmed by radiation. But experts say that in terms of public health, the Japanese have already taken precautions that should prevent the accident from becoming another Chernobyl, even if additional radiation is released.

title: Focal Point of Players Lawsuit Is Lifting the Lockout
description: The name of the class-action lawsuit is captivating: Tom Brady v. National Football League.

title: Hospital Chief Facing U.S. Charges Is Fired
description: A hospital executive who has been accused of bribery in a federal corruption investigation has been ousted by his board and replaced by his second in command, the board announced on Tuesday.

title: More on Farm Animal Protection
description: I mentioned in my column that in recent weeks politicians in Florida and Iowa have introduced bills that aim to crack down on shooting photographs and videos of agricultural operations. The Florida bill would require anyone wishing to photograph a farm to first secure written permission from the owner. And what if they dont? First-degree felony. The implicit goal here is to deter and criminalize damning undercover exposs like this one. The bill would also make it illegal for an agenda-less passerby to snap a picture of a farm from the side of the road, but my best guess is that those crimes might not be prosecuted quite so diligently.

title: Freddie Macs Former Chief May Face S.E.C. Action
description: The former chief executive of Freddie Mac may face a civil action as the government ramps up an investigation of disclosure practices at the mortgage finance giant and its sister company, Fannie Mae, people briefed on the investigation said.

title: U.S. Drones Fight Mexican Drug Trade
description: WASHINGTON  Stepping up its involvement in Mexicos drug war, the Obama administration has begun sending drones deep into Mexican territory to gather intelligence that helps locate major traffickers and follow their networks, according to American and Mexican officials.

title: Bloggingheads: Japan's Disaster
description: Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and Brink Lindsey of the Kauffman Foundation debate our reaction to the Japanese earthquake and tsunami.

title: G.M.s Reject Total Ban on Hits to the Head
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Meeting Tuesday amid concerns for player safety, N.H.L. general managers recommended stricter enforcement of boarding and charging rules, but refrained from recommending a full ban on hits to the head.

title: Gen. Petraeus Reports
description: In his first public assessment since taking over the Afghan war effort last year, Gen. David Petraeus was cautiously upbeat. He told the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday that Taliban momentum has been arrested in much of the country and reversed in a number of important areas. He acknowledged that the progress is fragile and reversible.

title: The Courts Recusal Problem
description: Supreme Court justices have life tenure to assure their independence and impartiality. The courts lack of a recusal policy leaves each justice to decide whether he or she is meeting that standard. That plainly violates the age-old legal principle: Nemo iudex in causa sua  no one should be a judge about his or her own case. It damages the justices credibility and the courts authority.

title: Taking a Radar Gun to a Crash Site, and Finding Buses on Good Behavior
description: They came sporadically at first, crowded tour buses on still-uncrowded lanes of Interstate 95 into the Bronx.

title: Forest Rules
description: There has been good news recently for Americas national forests, and some that could have been better.

title: Government by the Week
description: Parents have begun arranging alternative child care for their preschoolers, uncertain whether their Head Start program will be there when they need it. The Social Security Administration is unable to open new hearing offices to handle a backlog of appeals. The Pentagon has had to delay equipment repairs. There is chaos throughout the federal government, as Robert Pear reported in The Times on Tuesday, because a riven Congress has forced agencies to operate on a week-by-week basis.

title: Yankees Are Enthused About a Hard-Throwing Dominican Pitcher
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees gave no players on the international market a $1 million bonus last season. That underscores just how highly they think of their investment in Juan Carlos Paniagua last week.

title: Developers in New York Try to Ease Prickly Relations
description: The subway escalators that run under the brick high-rise at the corner of East 15th Street in Union Square have long been in a near-constant state of disrepair. The developer of the building, a condominium named Zeckendorf Towers, built the escalators in the 1980s as a public benefit in exchange for approvals to develop the site. As part of the deal, the condominium association was responsible for the machinerys maintenance.

title: An Affluent Suburb Wrestles With School Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Police Said to Interview Man at Scene of Officers Killing
description: Nassau County police investigators have interviewed a retired New York City police sergeant who witnesses said may have shouted Gun! when he saw a plainclothes officer carrying a rifle on Saturday, a shout that possibly prompted another police officer to fatally shoot the officer with the rifle, the president of the Nassau police union said on Tuesday.

title: On Perez and Castillo, Mets Keep Waiting and Seeing
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  With roughly two weeks left before the start of a new season under new leadership, the Mets continue to hold on to two players who have come to symbolize all the miscalculations of recent years.

title: Rick Martin, Part of Famed N.H.L. Line, Dies at 59 After Car Accident
description: BUFFALO  Rick Martin, a member of the Buffalo Sabres celebrated French Connection, one of the most prolific scoring lines in the National Hockey League in the 1970s, died after he was involved in a car accident on Sunday near his home in Akron, N.Y. He was 59.

title: Tata Chairman Says U.S. Car Will Cost $7,000 or $8,000
description: Tata Motors struck headline gold in 2008 with the 100,000-rupee, or $2,172, price for its Nano city car. But if the Indian automaker succeeds in bringing a car to the United States, the cars window sticker will sacrifice a good deal of its shock value.

title: Checking In With the Future
description: The revival of the T.W.A. Terminal at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Scoring Outburst Powers Rangers
description: The out-of-town scoreboards at Madison Square Garden are hard to miss. They hang over the seats at both ends of the arena, next to the Rangers auxiliary scoreboards, flipping from one N.H.L. score to the next at 10-second intervals to track an intensifying playoff chase.

title: Police Commissioner Calls Queens Killing a Hate Crime
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said Tuesday that the fatal beating of an 18-year-old man in Queens early Saturday falls into the category of a hate crime.

title: A New Game Accessory for the iPad
description: Despite looking a lot like a kitchen-variety vegetable slicer, Discovery Bay Games new Duo ($40) has a very different function. It sits on your iPad screen for use with specially designed, multiple-choice style apps.

title: Mike Tyson Moves to the Suburbs
description: The gold caps on his teeth are gone, as are the frenzied trappings of celebrity: the nonstop partying, the cars, the jewelry, the pet tiger, the liters of Cristal. Mike Tyson  who was once addicted, by his own account, to everything  now lives in what might be described as a controlled environment of his own making, a clean, well-lighted but very clearly demarcated place. The 44-year-old ex-heavyweight champion is in bed by 8 and often up as early as 2 in the morning, at which point he takes a solitary walk around the gated compound in the Las Vegas suburb where he lives while listening to R&B on his iPod. Tyson then occupies himself with reading (hes an avid student of history, philosophy and psychology), watching karate movies or taking care of his homing pigeons, who live in a coop in the garage, until 6, when his wife, Lakiha (known as Kiki), gets up. The two of them go to a spa nearby where they work out and often get a massage before settling into the daily routine of caring for a 2-year-old daughter, Milan, and a newborn son, Morocco; they also run Tyrannic, a production company they own. It is a willfully low-key life, one in which Tysons wilder impulses are held in check by his inner solid citizen.

title: No Final Shot for Anthony After Granger Hits Winner
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Knicks acquired Carmelo Anthony to hit big shots and guide them closer to a future championship. In the process, however, immediate aspirations are being threatened by accumulating losses.

title: The D.I.Y. Cooking Bibliography
description: A companion to Julia Moskins D.I.Y. cooking handbook  small, do-it-yourself kitchen projects that anyone can tacklefor the industrious, or merely curious, home cook.

title: Police Department Increases Fees for Road Races, but Not Until 2012
description: The New York Police Department will be charging organizers of the New York City Marathon and dozens of other races that use the city streets for traffic control costs and other services incurred for shutting down the roads. But the mayors office has said the rule will not go in effect until Jan. 1, 2012, allowing race organizers time to plan for the extra fees.

title: Pair Linked to Columbia Drug Suspects Pleads Guilty
description: A man accused of supplying Columbia University students who have been charged with dealing drugs from fraternity houses and campus residences pleaded guilty on Tuesday to drug charges, said a spokeswoman for the special narcotics prosecutor.

title: The Brickmakers of Afghanistan
description: Brickmaking in Afghanistan is dirty, back-breaking work, often done by children toiling in extreme weather.

description: Following the earthquake in Japan, officials measured radiation at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant.

title: Overcrowded Classrooms
description: To the Editor:

title: When 15th Is Better Than 8th: The Math Shows the Bracket Is Backward
description: Suppose that, lucky you, youre the coach of a team given a No. 8 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament bracket.

title: Mets Ready to Hit the Road
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For the Mets, hourslong bus rides are part of the normal rhythms of life in the Grapefruit League. But the Mets will be making a rare spring training overnight trip this week when they have games on consecutive days in Fort Myers.

title: Is Fitness All in the Genes?
description: Why do some people respond to an aerobic workout routine by becoming incredibly fit, whereas others who exercise just as hard for months end up no fitter than when they began?
