title: Security Council Uncertain About Intervening in Libya
description: The United Nations Security Council remained divided on Tuesday over a proposed draft resolution that calls for a no-flight zone over Libya and authorizes the use of force to halt the bombing of civilians by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: J-League Season Postponed Indefinitely
description: Officials of Japans soccer league on Tuesday postponed all games until mid-April as the country struggled to recover from the string of disasters sparked by last weeks earthquake. On Monday, they had wiped out the J-Leagues schedule until the end of March.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Raise Teachers Status
description: To improve its public schools, the United States should raise the status of the teaching profession by recruiting more qualified candidates, training them better and paying them more, according to a new report on comparative educational systems.

title: Gabriel Laderman, Painter of Figurative Art, Dies at 81
description: Gabriel Laderman, a painter and critic who played a leading role in the revival of figurative art in the 1960s and 1970s, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Shifra Lerer, Actress in Yiddish Theater, Dies at 95
description: Shifra Lerer, who was discovered at age 5 in Argentina by the great Yiddish actor Boris Thomashefsky and went on to become a winsome and wide-ranging trouper of the Yiddish theater for the next 90 years, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 95.

title: Libyas Rebel Fighters Routed in Ajdabiya
description: Qaddafi loyalists attacked a strategically important city and forced rebels into retreat.

title: News Quiz | March 16, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Boston Symphony Shows Verve Even Without Levine
description: No one would have blamed the Boston Symphony Orchestra for feeling demoralized when it appeared at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. This was the first of three programs at the hall that its music director, James Levine, was to have conducted.

title: Forces Rout Protesters From Bahrain Square
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Popular protests here modeled on the hopeful events in Egypt took on the darkness of those in Libya on Wednesday as hundreds of Bahraini troops, backed by helicopters and tanks, forcefully cleared the capitals central square of demonstrators clamoring for reform. Three protesters and two security officers were killed.

title: Grappling With Disaster in Japan
description: As workers struggled to avert meltdowns at a nuclear plant, about 440,000 people in northern Japan were living in makeshift shelters or evacuation centers after the earthquake and tsunami.

title: A Strange Opening Night for the Sounders
description: The Major League Soccer season opened Monday night with the Los Angeles Galaxys 1-0 win over the Seattle Sounders at Qwest Field. But fans in Seattle, and the Sounders, may remember the events that occurred in the hours before kickoff  when Seattle cryptically announced that it had cut ties with the Swiss striker Blaise Nkufo, one of the teams designated players  for much longer.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 16, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article The Dirty Little Secrets of Search.

title: Big Bomb at the Box Office
description: WHO runs the movie animation division for Disney?

title: U.S. Calls Radiation Extremely High; Sees Japan Nuclear Crisis Worsening
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave a far bleaker appraisal on Wednesday of the threat posed by Japans nuclear crisis than the Japanese government had offered. He said American officials believed that the damage to at least one crippled reactor was much more serious than Tokyo had acknowledged, and he advised Americans to stay much farther away from the plant than the perimeter established by Japanese authorities.

title: Postmedia Moves Toward Listing
description: The Postmedia Network Canada Corporation, owner of major Canadian dailies including The National Post, The Ottawa Citizen, The Montreal Gazette and The Vancouver Sun, said on Tuesday that it had taken steps to go public on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: A Sonorous, Smiling City
description: Matthew Whitaker, 9, has never seen a smile. Its sound that makes him happy: the sound of the city, the sound of music and the sound of the people around him.

title: Parting Glance: Metros Lens Series
description: Negatives filed in drawers clamor for attention and light, Sylvia Plachy wrote. I seem to hear them. As in the streets of New York I look for what once was and still is and if it speaks to me.

title: U.S. Urges Wider No-Go Area Around Nuclear Plant
description: TOKYO  The United States told its citizens and military personnel on Wednesday to stay at least 50 miles away from the stricken nuclear plant in northern Japan, a much wider radius of safety than the Japanese government has set for its people.

title: What Role Do Pets Play in Your Family?
description: This weeks Science Times was a special issue devoted to animals, and one article is about the roles pets can play in families. What pets do you have, or have you had? Have they in some way altered your familys routines or relationships? What does your pet mean to you? To your family as a whole?

title: Fantasy Focus: The Problem of Closers Value
description: I have an annual valuation problem on RotoWire. After running the projections for all our pitchers and then turning those projections into values, I find that the closer prices inevitably come up short, considerably so in some cases, when compared with what theyll cost at the auction table. In many cases, theyll even come up short compared with other relievers that arent their teams closers.

title: Real Estate Crisis? It Depends on Supply
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: The Early Word: On Message
description: Todays Times

title: Dan Snyder Wants Redskins Name All to Himself
description: Dan Snyders charm offensive has hit another iceberg.

title: Pressure on Portugal After New Credit Downgrade
description: MADRID  Portugal was forced to offer higher rates to sell 1 billion euros of debt on Wednesday, underlining concerns among investors about the countrys ability to continue financing itself without emergency European financing.

title: Hours of Service
description: The tragic bus crash last weekend that took the lives of 15 people heading home to New York after a day of gambling at the Mohegan Sun casino in Connecticut brought me back to Dec. 26, the day the blizzard of 2010 buried much of the East Coast in snow. My husband and I were flying home to New York City that day after visiting family in Cleveland for the holiday. When LaGuardia Airport was shut down just as our plane approached the city, the pilot announced that our flight was being diverted to the nearest available airport. We found ourselves in Syracuse  where it was not snowing!  wondering how, and when, we were going to get home. Eventually the airline gave the passengers who were on our flight the option of either checking into a hotel overnight or taking a bus to New York City, for those who were crazy enough to take their chances on the road.

title: Hushed Deal Frees C.I.A. Contractor in Pakistan

title: Luggage Tags
description: To help travelers avoid the pileup of indistinguishable black bags on the luggage carousel, Tumi has enlisted the graffiti artist John Matos to decorate a group of its lightweight Vapor cases. Matos, who goes by Crash, started spray-painting walls in the Bronx in 1975 and was showing in galleries and museums by the 1980s. For the Tumi project  which will be limited to 1,000 of each case in the four-piece collection  Matos explains that he didnt sit there thinking, What would be cool on a Tumi bag? If hed thought of himself as just a tagger for hire, he says, the work wouldnt have come out as good. $445 to $595; tumi.com.

title: March 16 Updates on Japans Nuclear Crisis and Earthquake Aftermath

Updates below feature reports from other news sites and firsthand accounts and video posted on social networks. A Twitter stream in the right column of this blog includes messages from journalists and officials in Japan.

title: Natural Selection Wins Grand Jury Prize at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex. The grand jury prize for the best narrative feature film at the South by Southwest festival went to Natural Selection on Tuesday night. The film, written and directed by Robbie Pickering, is a comedy about a woman who gets to know the eldest son of her husband, who has been a regular donor at a sperm bank. The grand jury prize for a documentary went to the director Tristan Pattersons Dragonslayer, about the life and love of a youth in Fullerton, a Southern California suburb. Natural Selection also received prizes for performances by Rachael Harris and Matt OLeary, and for its script, editing and score, setting it up as the big winner at a festival that focused heavily on low-budget films with small, personal stories. On Wednesday, by contrast, Jodie Foster was set to appear with The Beaver, from Summit Entertainment. That film, which she directed and in which she performs, stars Mel Gibson as a troubled toy executive who sorts out his life with the help of a beaver hand puppet. Mr. Gibson, who pleaded no contest on Friday to a misdemeanor count of battering his ex-girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva, is not expected to attend the films Wednesday-night premiere. The South by Southwest festival, which explores, film, music and digital culture in presentations and panels, continues here through Sunday.

title: Taller People Are Happier, Especially if Theyre Male

The film is part drama and part dark comedy. After playing at last years Sundance Film Festival, the movie made its way to the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., complete with a fiery after-party. The director Spencer Susser discussed his film and what he thinks the character of Hesher represents.

title: Tribeca Film Festival Selects Short Films
description: They say theres no such thing as a small role, but then what do you call a performance in a short film? The 60 short films selected for the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival include turns by actors as, well, big as Campbell Scott, Anthony LaPaglia and Colin Quinn. And some of the animated shorts feature the voices of David Duchovny, Joseph Fiennes and Ian McKellen. The films were chosen out of 2,862 submissions; they represent 20 countries and include 22 world premieres. Documentary subjects include a Haitian community that joins together to build a movie theater, a rock musician who decides to have transgender surgery, and a motivational speaker privately battling bipolar disorder. The narrative films include one in which a character tries to atone for a car accident that left a girl in a vegetative state; one about a man seeking justice after he thinks his son has been sexually assaulted; and  for those in search of lighter fare  a film titled Mr. Stache and described as the awesome adventures of a man and his mustache. The short films will compete for three awards  Best Narrative Short, Best Documentary Short and the Student Visionary Award  with combined cash and value-in-kind prizes totaling more than $15,000. The winner of Best Narrative Short will qualify for consideration in the short-film category of the Academy Awards without the standard theatrical run. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 20 to May 1.

The first-time director Anne Buford spent four years tracking the lives of her subjects for this film, and spoke at the South by Southwest festival here about the experience.

description: Breaking the fourth wall, or its literary equivalent, is so raucously appealing to young children, its a wonder childrens book authors dont try it more often. Youre Finally Here! written and illustrated by Mlanie Watt (Chester, Squaredy Squirrel) brings to mind the Pigeon series by Mo Willems in both tone and look. Substitute an impatient bunny rabbit with bug eyes, bad attitude and a tendency toward emotionalism for a pigeon with bug eyes, bad attitude and a tendency toward emotionalism, and youve pretty much got formula and execution.

title: New John Guare Play for McCarter Theaters 2011-12 Season
description: The 2011-12 season for the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., will include world premieres by John Guare, Danai Gurira (Eclipsed), and the Irish playwright Marina Carr, along with productions of Tom Stoppards Travesties and a new musical directed by John Doyle and based on the songs of Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, Playbill reported. The season will open with Mr. Doyles musical Ten Cents a Dance, a co-production with Williamstown Theater Festival, in which the cast doubles as the orchestra. It will be followed by Ms. Carrs Phaedra, an adaptation of that classical myth. Next up is The Convert, by Ms. Gurira, a playwright and actress who was one of the creators and stars of In the Continuum, about women living with AIDS in Africa and Los Angeles. The Convert is set in 1895 amid uprisings against colonialism in southern Africa. After Travesties, the season will close with Mr. Guares new play, Are You There, McPhee?

title: Eurofile | Tunisia Moderne

In the distance the large salt lake Chott El Jerid shimmered in a brick-red mist. When I arrived the night before, Id seen dromedary-crossing signs along the main access road from the airport in Tozeur. This was true North African desert culture.

As a reporter, Im not sure I would have said the same thing  maybe go for a scaled-back version of the truth, like, There was an earthquake in Japan and people got hurt? But I was not about to contradict her after the fact.

title: Riccardo Muti Awarded $1 Million Birgit Nilsson Prize
description: Riccardo Muti, the Italian maestro and the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, has been awarded the $1 million Birgit Nilsson Prize for his extraordinary contributions to the music world, The Associated Press reported. The prize was awarded by the Birgit Nilsson Foundation, established after the death of Nilsson, a renowned Wagnerian soprano, in 2005. The only previous winner, Placido Domingo, was chosen by Ms. Nilsson before her death; Mr. Muti was chosen, as subsequent winners will be, by the foundation and by a jury of at least five members. Mr. Muti, 69, who had surgery last month for facial injuries sustained in a fall from the podium during a rehearsal, was back at work last week conducting Giuseppe Verdis Nabucco at the Teatro dellOpera in Rome. Mr. Mutis fall was related to fainting because of a heart rhythm disturbance; he subsequently received a pacemaker.

title: America Corrupts

In the journal Addictive Behaviors, Mildred Maldonado-Moline, Jennifer Reingle, Wesley Jennings and Guillermo Prado looked at drunk driving arrests among new immigrants and U.S.-born young adults. The recent immigrants had low DUI arrest rates. Second generation Americans had higher arrest rates than first generation Americans and third generation had higher rates than the second generation. The same pattern applied to arrests for marijuana use.

title: A Momentary Escape From Reason

The barometer was spinning like a pinwheel, and there was a fidgety animal tension in the ozone. Heads were throbbing, and SoHo shoppers seemed dementedly giddy, like kids trying to stifle a laughing fit at a funeral.

title: Get Real and Get a Mandoline
description: A mandoline seems to be one of the last frontiers for the home cook. Maybe it seems too fussy with all those different blades, or maybe people are under the impression that you have to buy the most expensive model, which can get extremely pricey. But even the cheapest mandoline will make your life so much easier in the kitchen.For example, while I could, with much time and a little effort, thinly slice the potatoes for a gratin (such as in my column on Wednesday), running them through a mandoline takes about three minutes and gives me perfectly even, gossamer slices, which melt into the cream while baking in the oven. I also rely on my mandoline for paper-thin slices of fennel and zucchini for salads, and lovely wafers of beets that I serve carpaccio-style with a walnut-mustard dressing on top. And then theres my recipe for French apple tart, which depends on uniform slices of apple that are a breeze with a mandoline.So here are a few tips for those of you ready to take the plunge.Mandolines range in price based on the sharpness of the blade, the number of different cuts the blades will make and the sturdiness of the base. I have used the Super Benriner (about $50), but years ago, I had the most basic Benriner ($20) and it served me just fine until the blades grew dull. If you just want something basic, go for a cheaper model  they start somewhere around $15 (Norpro and Kyocera, for example, make them). And if you want something a bit more substantial (able to handle a more diverse range of fruits and vegetables), go for a sturdier, more advanced model. Oxo and Swissmar Borner (both about $40) are two reliable brands in this price range.And if you are looking to invest in something that will last you a lifetime and give you the widest variety of blades for different cuts, stainless steel professional models go for around $100, but you probably wont ever have to replace them. Mandolines from MIU sell for about $110; Bron has one for $150 and De Buyers model, $229, allows for left-handed users.Most of the mandolines are compact and collapsible, which is particularly useful if youre in a tiny kitchen and space is at a premium. And if youre worried about cuts and scrapes, consider this glove, which has saved my knuckles from many an injury.

title: LOHAS
description: Those adopting Lifestyles Of Health And Sustainability.

title: Crisis in Japan: Understanding Nuclear Energy and Reactors
description: Overview  | What is the extent of the nuclear crisis in Japan following the wake of the tsunami and earthquake? What is nuclear power, and how do nuclear power plants work? What are the benefits and risks associated with nuclear power? In this lesson, students learn about the nuclear crisis in Japan, then research nuclear energy to prepare informative news bulletins.

title: Interview: Mike Mills
description: Mike Mills, the director of "Beginners," discusses the true events that inspired his fictional film.

title: Lupe Fiasco Tops the Pop Charts
description: Another week, and yet another new occupant of the top slot of the Billboard record charts. This time its Lupe Fiascos Laser that makes its debut at No. 1, pushing aside Adeles 21 and continuing a pattern of volatility at the top of the chart, with few albums showing a lot of staying power. But initial sales were strong: 204,000 copies of Laser were sold in its first week of release, continuing a recent recovery from slow sales at the start of the year that was also evident in the performance of 21: 133,000 copies sold, down a modest 21 percent from the week before.

title: In Proposed Mortgage Fraud Settlement, a Gift to Big Banks
description: Tom Miller, attorney general of Iowa.

title: In Italy, Holding Out Hope for Bryants Return
description: With the possibility of an N.B.A. lockout next season becoming more real, Kobe Bryant has spent some time talking about his future. Would he consider playing in Italy in the event of a lockout?

title: In Europe and China, Japans Crisis Renews Fears About Nuclear Power
description: As Japans nuclear crisis intensified Wednesday, governments across Europe remained at odds over whether to scale back nuclear power programs or continue plans to expand, while China announced that it was suspending new plant approvals until it could strengthen safety standards.

title: No Blackouts With March Madness at Your Fingertips
description: Sports fans are accustomed to paying for the privilege of watching live games on their mobile devices.

title: The Magazine Wins a Digital Ellie
description: The New York Times Magazine just won a National Magazine Award for Digital Media in the category of design. The awards are more popularly known as the Digital Ellies, after the Alexander Calder elephant that is given to each winner.

title: The Snooze Moment in the Galleon Trial
description: 4:24 p.m. | Updated

title: Beauty Spots
description: FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS A new pimple zapper has been cleared by the F.D.A. The palm-size device, called No! No! Skin ($180), uses pulses of light that penetrate into the problem area to kill bacteria and soothe inflammation and redness, according to Radiancy, the manufacturer. The 10-second treatment is meant for mild to moderate acne and eliminates the need for topical medications, the company says (my-no-no.com).

title: Warmed-Over Atkins? Dont Tell the French
description: PARIS

title: European Central Bank Appears Firm on Interest Rate Increase
description: Is this really such a good time to raise interest rates?

title: Cuomo? Oh, There He Is
description: ALBANY  For state lawmakers, Tuesday was one of the busiest days so far this year. Hundreds of New Yorkers converged here to lobby them for relief from budget cuts. Both houses of the Legislature passed separate spending plans, and their leaders held their first budget negotiating session.

title: Rival Leaders Agree to Hold Gaza Meeting
description: JERUSALEM  The rival Palestinian leaderships of the West Bank and Gaza appeared to be taking practical steps on Wednesday toward ending their schism, in a rare response to public pressure for national unity after years of deep division.

title: Europeans Introduce Corporate Tax Plan
description: BRUSSELS  A new effort to coordinate corporate tax policy in the European Union introduced on Wednesday has increased tensions between some member states and Ireland, which said it was skeptical about the process.

title: The French Diet Youve Never Heard Of
description: A popular French diet is crossing the Atlantic, reports todays Styles section.

title: Will There Be a QE3?
description: With the markets worried about a global economic slowdown, CNBC debates whether the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, will be forced into another round of stimulus.

title: Mike Mills and Beginners at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The latest film from the director Mike Mills (Thumbsucker) is a personal one. Among several topics, the film looks at the life of a graphic designer (Ewan McGregor), whose father (Christopher Plummer) comes out at the age of 75 after his mother dies. Mr. Mills discussed the events that inspired the making of the film and explained how ideas and memories make their way into his fictional work.

title: The Republic of East Libya?
description: I agreed with National Reviews last editorial on Libya, which argued against a no-fly zone on the sensible grounds that 1) it probably wouldnt be militarily effective and 2) it would be better for American interests if Qaddafi was toppled without a U.S. intervention anyway. The new editorial, though, takes a much more unpersuasive line. After arguing, reasonably, that there are good reasons for America to wish Qaddafi gone from power, the editors go on to argue that those reasons justify establishing an American protectorate around Benghazi, so that the rebels can live to fight another day:

title: Democrats Face Party Unity Problem on House Votes
description: As the new minority party in the House, Democrats will need to keep their caucus together if they hope to win many votes. But in the early months of the 112th Congress, a clear pattern is emerging that could cause concern for party leaders: some House Democrats are voting against their party more often than ever. An analysis by The New York Times of the first 180 recorded votes in the House shows that 14 Democrats have agreed with a majority of their colleagues less than 70 percent of the time. Six of those are below the 60-percent level, including Dan Boren of Oklahoma, who has voted with a majority of Democrats only 44 percent of the time.

title: TimesCast | Fishing Town in Rubble
description: A Japanese fisherman, who lost his home and livelihood, shares his story.

title: Why to Know What a Home Seller Paid
description: If youre in the market for a home, you may want to consider some advice from academics before sealing the deal. Research on the topic of negotiation offers numerous tips to help potential real estate buyers navigate the process, as I recently learned when I wrote a paper for my business school negotiation class on the subject. This post is part of a series on some of the findings that I thought were worth sharing.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Bahrain and Kazakhstan.

title: For Bucknell, Another Chance to Shock the Tournament
description: Patrick Behan played on the Bucknell basketball team, graduating last year.

title: Player Called Tank Leads Tough Team
description: When Frank Hassell arrived at Old Dominion in 2006 as a lanky 6-foot-7 freshman, he tried to make a name for himself by making a name for himself. After declaring at one of the Monarchs first workouts that his teammates should call him Flight, he drove toward the rim, awkwardly tried to dunk and landed on his backside.

title: Growth Spurts: Stinky Bklyn and Caffe Falai
description: Stinky Bklyn has closed its original Cobble Hill store and will reopen about two blocks away, in triple the space, on Thursday morning (a day later than they planned earlier this week).

title: Beaches and Jazz in Fiji
description: Travelers in search of great jazz usually flock to clubs in cities like New Orleans or New York, or attend festivals in Montreal or Montreux, Switzerland.

title: Sharron Angle Is Running for House Seat
description: It would seem that Sharron Angle is running for a House seat in Nevada.

title: Guggenheim to Auction Easy Rider Replica Choppers
description: Two emblems of restless American freedom are being offered for sale to the public for the first time.

title: Hes Not an Impostor; He Plays One Onstage
description: PRETTY-BOY singer. That typecasting label has dogged many a would-be Broadway star, and it was haunting the actor Aaron Tveit in 2007 as he went on auditions after playing the heartthrob Link Larkin in the hit musical Hairspray. A dozen callbacks for a lead role, Prince Eric in The Little Mermaid, did not pan out, recalled the blue-eyed, deeply dimpled Mr. Tveit (pronounced tuh-VATE). Particularly painful was that the role he badly wanted  the lead in Catch Me if You Can, a musical being developed from the 2002 Leonardo DiCaprio movie  seemed lost.

title: The Newest Element in McMillans Laboratory
description: Its now clear that Gerald Wallace was only the most basic of the Portland Trailblazers trade deadline acquisitions. Simply, Portland added a former All-Star who plays tenacious defense, a valuable player on a decent contract who could obviously elevate the level of play from his spot in the rotation. However, dig deeper and what the Blazers netted was a ridiculous level of lineup versatility. With so many capable players able to swing between positions, Nate McMillan now has a canvas to handle all the free-form painting he can muster. McMillan has never been considered part of basketballs avant garde, but hes not afraid of going small, going big, or going with whatever works, and that makes him a worthy coach to handle such a strange roster.

title: On Long Island, Local Inspiration and Global Ambition
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.

title: Free Passes: A Museum Salute to the Military
description: LAST summer, facing two months in Parris Island, S.C., while her husband, a Marine Corps colonel, was deployed to Afghanistan, Kathryn Roth-Douquet packed her two children into the family S.U.V. and drove up the Eastern Seaboard, visiting one museum after another, free.

title: An Interactive Exhibit for About $30
description: JUST five years ago, an artist or designer who wanted to add the slightest bit of interactivity to a work for a museum or gallery had two options: buy a computer that cost about $2,000 and have it reprogrammed to fit the task at hand, or hire a computer engineer to design and fabricate a computer chip specifically for the artwork.

title: Four to Follow
description: On March 17, the subjects of this article joined other Twitter users for a lunchtime chat on the subject of social media and museums. To see or continue the conversation on Twitter, use the hashtag #nytmuseums.

title: Not Forgotten
description: FORT SUMTER, S.C.

title: Help in Getting Started
description: Step-by-step written tutorials, descriptive videos and forums will help you jump into the exciting world of the Arduino; a computer engineering degree is not required.

title: After a Flood, Running a Homeless Museum
description: To Sean OHarrow, becoming director of the University of Iowa Museum of Art seemed like an opportunity to think outside the box.

title: In a Bigger Pond, and Looking to Make Ripples
description: IN October, during his second month on the job as director of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Julian Zugazagoitia held his first of his Art Tasting with Julian.

title: Ancient Chinese Art
description: Maxwell Hearn, the new head of Asian Art at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, demonstrates the ancient art of understanding and appreciating Chinese scroll paintings.

title: A Curator With a Penchant for the Collective
description: COMPETING to be the commissioner of the United States pavilion at the Venice Biennale is like being a jockey in an artistic horse race. Each candidate chooses an artist or artists to represent the country in the festivals international competition, and there is stiff competition from curators around the country, who have picked their own top talent.

title: A Flooded Museum Innovates
description: Since a flood destroyed the University of Iowa Art Museum, new ways have been explored to show the collection.

title: From the Backdrop to Their Own Stage
description: FOR the last half-century, New York City has been home to an art collection that has grown steadily in both size and legend  with work by giants like Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Frank Stella and Bruce Nauman, to name only a few  but it has never behaved much like art collections are supposed to behave.

title: Elegant Attire of a Cereal Heiress
description: An exhibit shows off wedding dresses and other riches of the Marjorie Merriweather Post family.

title: The Spirit of Sharing
description: SHELLEY BERNSTEIN lives with her computer. Most days she hunkers down in her spartan office at the Brooklyn Museum where, as chief technology officer, she invents ways to keep people visiting the museum and its Web site, brooklynmuseum.org.

title: In a Stressful Setting, Artistic Treatment for the Traveler
description: ANYONE facing a long wait at an airport in these days of heightened security and random pat-downs may want to unwind at an art exhibit in a terminal.

title: Supplementing a Physical Collection, Online
description: MINOOKA, Ill.

title: Classroom and Playground, All Rolled Into One
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.

title: A Growing Use of Private Art in Public Spaces
description: THE exhibition that opens at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art on May 21 is certain to be a dazzler: The Steins Collect: Matisse, Picasso and the Parisian Avant-Garde will have 40 works by Picasso, 60 by Matisse and many by favorites like Bonnard and Czanne. Picassos Gertrude Stein will be there, with his Boy Leading a Horse. So will Matisses wildly colorful Woman With a Hat, which was derided by critics when revealed in 1905 but was soon purchased by the Steins for what would become their pioneering collection of modern art.

title: At Met, New Leadership (and Direction) for Asian Art
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Arts Asian art galleries are some of the most reposeful spaces in New York City. Its hard to imagine that they were banged into place, room by room, from practically nothing over the last 40 years, though they were. Or that they continue to mirror changing times, a changing museum and a changing Asia, though they do.

title: Promising Exhibitions From Coast to Coast
description: Art museums, trying to do more with less, are stretching to be creative this season. Heres a sampling of their most promising exhibitions.

title: Art Beyond the Canvas, Resonating With Youth
description: BOSTON

title: Multimedia Tour Guides on Your Smartphone
description: ON your next museum visit, you might want to skip the information kiosk and seek out a Wi-Fi hot spot instead.

title: A Grand Mansion Flaunts Its Parade of Weddings
description: FEW families have been as expert at wedding planning as Marjorie Merriweather Post and her daughters. The Post cereal heiress, who once owned a spate of mansions including Palm Beachs Mar-a-Lago and Topridge in the Adirondacks, had almost as many husbands  four  as she had homes.

title: Year-Old Nascar Museum Wants a Restart
description: THE $200 million Nascar Hall of Fame, a four-level museum filled with exhibits, displays and simulators that approximate real stock-car racing, opened last May in Charlotte, N.C., with no lack of fanfare. Richard Petty and Junior Johnson, two of the first inductees, even rumbled up to the opening ceremonies in replicas of their old cars.

title: Scent of a Museum
description: SINCE the Museum of Arts and Design opened in September 2008 on Columbus Circle in New York, it has sought to engage three senses, with shows, programs and hands-on workshops. Last December came word that the museum would soon go for a fourth by founding a department of olfactory art.

title: Smithsonian Uses Social Media to Expand Its Mission
description: THE Smithsonian Institution is shaking off its image as the nations attic brimming with arcane treasures and using Web and mobile projects to enlist the public in delving into its collections, expanding its research and, sometimes, just adding interesting postscripts to history.

title: Speaking Digitally About Exhibits
description: WHEN Bridget Oliveri, a 25-year-old medical student, was deciding where to take a visitor one recent evening, she dismissed the usual destinations for 20-somethings in Manhattan and Brooklyn in favor of the American Museum of Natural History.

title: California Insurer Retreats on Raising Rates
description: Blue Shield of California, a nonprofit health insurer, said on Wednesday that it would no longer seek a rate increase this year for individuals who buy coverage on their own rather than through an employer.

title: Fresh Life for Madoff Play in Washington
description: A play about Bernard Madoff that had been slated for production at a Jewish theater company in Washington last summer but was canceled after a legal threat from the author and Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel, who was depicted as a character, will now go on at that theater in a revised version, The Washington City Paper reported. The play, Imagining Madoff by Deborah Margolin, originally depicted a close relationship between Mr. Madoff and Mr. Wiesel, who in real life lost all his and his wifes savings and $15.2 million of his charitable foundations assets in Mr. Madoffs Ponzi scheme. Before the plays premiere at Theater J in Washington, Ms. Margolin sent Mr. Wiesel a copy of the script, hoping he would like it. Instead, he threatened to have his lawyer halt the production. Ms. Margolin agreed to revise the play, but when Theater Js artistic director, Ari Roth, volunteered to show the revised script to Mr. Wiesels foundation, she decided to back out of the production entirely. Instead, she took the rewritten version  with Mr. Wiesels character replaced by a fictional Holocaust survivor and poet named Solomon Galkin  to Stageworks/Hudson, a small theater company in upstate New York, where it was performed last summer. Mr. Roth saw the play there and subsequently renewed a discussion with Ms. Margolin about producing it at Theater J. The play will open on Aug. 31 and run through Sept. 25.

title: Afghanistan Plans Departure of Security Firms
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government is planning to phase out most private security companies and replace them with its own forces over the next 12 months, according to Afghan and international officials.

title: How the iPad 2 Lost Weight
description: The new Apple iPad 2 weighs in at about 600 grams, or about 15 percent less than the first iPad, forever more to be known as The Fat iPad.

title: New Features on Twitter Let You Secure Your Sessions
description: It might seem pointless to worry about someone snooping on your Twitter traffic. After all, wont everything you type end up on public display anyway?

title: Perp Walk or Catwalk?
description: Celebrities turn the perp walk into a runway strut.

title: Turning the Perp Walk Into a Runway Strut
description: THE movie offers may not be rolling in these days, but Lindsay Lohan is camera-ready and intent, it seems, on parlaying the traditional walk of shame en route to court into an image-boosting stroll of fame. In recent months her courtroom outfits  a succession of cleavage-baring shirts and clingy frocks  seem to have been deftly engineered to keep Ms. Lohan front and center in the minds of her fans.

title: TimesCast | Japanese Communication Style
description: Hiroko Tabuchi reports on how Japanese communication style has influenced the governments handling of the nuclear crisis.

title: To Stretch or Not to Stretch
description: AS a senior vice president of Colin Cowie Lifestyle, a SoHo-based event-planning company, Jocelyn Greenky Herz, 47, takes great care with how she dresses: No holes, no threads, no snags, and my jewelry and hair and makeup are pulled together. And yet Ms. Herz can often be found at work or out to dinner wearing any one of her more than 10 pairs of elastic-waist pants. If your entire outfit looks very chic, theres no reason not to, she said. Her collection ranges from high-end  David Lerner leggings and GoldSign jeggings (each about $150) to mass-market Hard Tail yoga pants ($65 to $95) to what she calls toss away jeggings from Forever 21 ($8 to $25), just as good, by the way, she said.

title: Fashions Approachable Ambassador
description: IT happens all the time. When Joe Zee, the inexhaustible creative director of Elle, was flying back to New York from Chicago after taping Oprah recently, he looked up from tying his shoes after passing through security at OHare. A couple dressed in fleece jackets and fanny packs were hovering above him with eager expressions.

title: Letters
description: A Salons Successor

title: Westwoods Lasting Imagery
description: VIVIENNE WESTWOOD makes a rare appearance in a current advertisement for her spring collection, a portrait that shows her striding purposefully down a dirt road, looking every inch the survivor.

title: Remembering Those Radical Chic Evenings
description: On March 13, The Times reported the death of D. L. Cox, a former member of the Black Panthers who died in France in February at the age of 74. Mr. Cox, as Bruce Weber wrote, earned a moment of celebrity in 1970 when he spoke at the Leonard Bernstein fund-raising party in Manhattan, an event best remembered today as the subject of Tom Wolfes witheringly funny satire Radical Chic: That Party at Lennys.

title: Newly Released Books
description: This months trove of new fiction considers identity,lost and found. Two young men hunt for who they are. A woman hopes to give her early self the slip. An academic tracks a man who may or may not exist. Skiers emerge from an avalanche not feeling like themselves. And an alchemistic short-story writer whips up a multitude of types.

title: The Long Half-Life of Chernobyl
description: When I look back on the explosion and fire at the Chernobyl nuclear plant, which unfolded when I was living in the Soviet Union in 1986, I reflect on how that plant differed from the Fukushima Daiichi site in Japan. Theres the reactor design, for one, and the cause of the explosions that ruptured buildings  in Chernobyls case, a botched safety experiment, and at Fukushima Daiichi, an epic earthquake and resulting tsunami.

title: Dancers Remix From Steps To Synth-Pop
description: WHAT do The Nutcracker, Pearl Jam and Bangin Sid, a new synth-pop band, have in common? A former ballerina.

title: Ache and Anger, Desire and Tenacity
description: Marsha Ambrosius

title: Mar. 20  26
description: Theater

title: Bahrain: The Widening Gulf
description: Bahrain is a very little place  fewer than a million people on one modest island. But Bosnia was small too, and it helped kick off World War I. The risk in Bahrain is that battles there could ignite a broader Shiite-Sunni conflict. As Vali Nasr (currently at the State Department, in Richard Holbrookes old shop) wrote in his indispensable 2006 book, The Shia Revival, Bahrains Shiites, who account for more than 70 percent of the population, consider themselves to be the salt of the earth ruled by a minority of Sunni settlers who invaded from Qatar in the eighteenth century. Since Bahrain gained independence from Britain in 1970, Nasr writes, Shias have been heavily involved in every coup attempt, street agitation, uprising and reform movement in the Persian Gulf emirate.

title: Twitter Users Congregate Based on Mood, Study Says
description: Youve probably heard the adage birds of a feather ock together. A new research paper with the catchy title, Happiness is assortative in online social networks, has found another example of this maxim.

title: Kickball, Tennis And App Writing
description: Summer camps have long been part of the American experience for children and teenagers, and for the last 30 years or so, computers and technology have added to the equation.

title: Horn Players Many Lights Under a Bushel No Longer
description: For a trumpeter of his experience, proficiency and adaptability, Terell Stafford has had a relatively low profile in jazz. If youve heard him, youve probably heard him as a sideman, bringing light and heat to albums by the Clayton Brothers, the saxophonist Bobby Watson or the drummer Matt Wilson. Or youve seen him some Monday night in the Vanguard Jazz Orchestra. For whatever reason, its less likely you know him as a bandleader, though he has a handful of albums to his name.

title: Bradley Picks U.S. Roster for March Friendlies
description: It was something old (make that veteran) and something new (make that young) when United States mens national team coach Bob Bradley announced the 24 players he has selected for a training camp in advance of two international friendly matches later this month. And he did not take the safe route.

title: Great New Things Watch: Ben Katchor Returns
description: Ben Katchor is one of those cultural figures who evokes a variety of reliable responses: Youve never heard of him; you are vaguely aware of him; or youre entirely and irrevocably smitten with his peculiar charms.

title: 2 Former CNBC Personalities Go to Yahoo Finance
description: Jeff Macke, the former Fast Money cast member notorious for his 2009 meltdown on CNBC, is joining another old CNBC hand, Matt Nesto, to start a daily stock-picking show called Breakout for Yahoo Finance.

title: Fight Waged With Forks Is Rejoined in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Within the war between Republicans and Democrats over the federal spending rages an affray over disposable forks.

title: All That Logging in Makes Dropping Out Much More Difficult
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  There it was again, that note of digital doubt, in the opening lines of a film, Small, Beautifully Moving Parts, at the South by Southwest festival here.

title: Styled to a T | Lily Collins
description: Related: Asked & Answered | Lily Collins

title: Weavers Threading a Tale, Chapters 1 Through 20
description: Art, on some level, is communication. But how much to say, and what to leave unspoken? Herein, often, lies the art in art.

title: Mystery Is a Thing With Paradoxes
description: In her latest book to feature the quasi-retired detective named Jackson Brodie, Kate Atkinson lets him deliver a fair working definition of how an Atkinson book is apt to unfold. A whole lot of cryptic individuals may be involved in it, he admits: Jackson didnt know what it was, but that was the point, wasnt it? That was what solving something was about, it was hunting the it down, pinning its arms above its head and making it spill the beans. It was like being in a game, a game where you didnt know the rules or the identity of the other players and where you were unsure of the goal.

title: Boehner Tries to Serve Two Masters in Budget Deal
description: WASHINGTON  After being granted three weeks to cut what has been an elusive budget deal, Speaker John A. Boehner is navigating the uncharted territory between legislative pragmatism and Tea Party zeal.

title: Jack White Still Knows How to Grab Attention
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  South by Southwest is about music, lots and lots of it: 2,000-plus bands over six days. But partly as a result of there being so much music, the festival is also about attention-getting stunts: bands playing up to a dozen gigs in unusual spaces, announcing last-minute performances on Twitter, teasing crowds with TBAs on schedules.

title: Irish Feet Aflutter, Stepping Into an Extra Dimension
description: Presumably no one who doesnt already love the clickety clickety clickety thump of Irish dancing is going to go to a concert film featuring an hour and a half of Irish dancing. And nobody who doesnt already love the self-aggrandizing style of Michael Flatley is going to go to a movie focused relentlessly on Michael Flatley. So really only two questions need to be answered about Lord of the Dance 3D, a film version of Mr. Flatleys popular stage show: Does whatever excitement this kind of spectacle holds transfer to film, and does the 3-D add anything?

title: Obama Makes His Final Four Picks
description: Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director, apparently found the limits of his influence on President Obama this week. In making his picks for the Final Four, Mr. Obama excluded Mr. Pfeiffers alma mater, Georgetown. Picks Kansas. No love for the #hoyas, Mr. Pfeiffer tweeted.

title: Lazard to Take Over Foursquare Conference
description: At the 2006 Foursquare conference, Katie Couric, left, was on a panel with Jerry Seinfeld and Howard Stringer of Sony.

title: Abu Dhabi Guggenheim Faces Protest
description: A group of more than 130 artists, including many prominent figures in the Middle Eastern art world, says it will boycott the $800 million Guggenheim museum being built in Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, unless conditions for the foreign laborers at the site are improved.

title: Fresh Off Hiatus, Pleasing Fans and Testing Stamina
description: First, a confession: Godspeed You! Black Emperor is the only band I have ever abandoned midconcert because of physical exhaustion, during a 2000 show at the Knitting Factory.

title: In Iceland, a Snowy Retreat
description: A three-bedroom town house on the sea is on the market in Reykjavik for 46.9 million kronur ($400,000.)

title: House Hunting in ... Iceland
description: A THREE-BEDROOM WATERFRONT TOWN HOUSE IN REYKJAVIK, ICELAND

title: Older Elephant Matriarchs Keep the Lions at Bay
description: With age comes wisdom, an old adage goes.

title: Homes for $280,000
description: A renovated town house in Savannah, Ga., a 1921 house in St. Louis and a co-op in Seattle.

title: What You Get for ... $280,000
description: SAVANNAH, GA.

title: Heads Bowed in Grateful Memory
description: There is a bit of Owsley in me.

title: Lauding a Great Artist With No Example of Her Greatness
description: It should go without saying that Martha Graham is one of the greatest of all American artists and one of the great choreographers of all time. Twenty years after her death, however, fewer and fewer people have much grasp of her choreography. Graham herself outlived the larger part of her talent: almost none of her post-1960 works are worth watching seriously. Though the Martha Graham Dance Company guards the flame, most dancegoers under the age of 50 will have only sketchy ideas of her most famous works.

title: Surveyor of a Desert Where the Past and Present Coexist
description: The Atacama Desert of northern Chile is the driest place in the world and surely one of the most desolate. But it has always proved fertile ground for the Chilean documentary filmmaker Patricio Guzmn, who first filmed there 40 years ago and has now returned to make Nostalgia for the Light, a meditation on astronomy, archeology, geology and human rights.

title: Dvoraks Folk Music You Can Dance To
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center enlisted the pianist Jeremy Denk to preside over two concerts this season, each built around works that draw on Eastern European folk songs and popular dance rhythms. The first, in October, inclined toward modernity, with works by Zemlinsky, Ligeti and Kurtag offsetting Dvoraks Romanticism, with the mostly Romantic Dohnanyi as a bridge.

title: First Look at Broadway Bares XXI Posters
description: Fine bodies meet fine art in the posters for this years Broadway Bares, the annual event at which performers dance, vamp and strip to help raise money for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

title: Interview: Jason and Brandon Trost
description: Jason and Brandon Trost, the co-directors of "The FP," discuss their comedy.

title: On Location | In Uruguay, Animal Hides and Ocean Waves
description: A familys vacation home in Punta del Este was built on a plateau of sand to ensure the best possible view of the ocean.

title: Beans Over Broadway?
description: If the Smithsonian is Americas Attic then Broadway is its open mike night, a place where almost anything can be put to a tune and belted out on stage: a cartoon (The Addams Family), a comic book (Spider Man: Turn Off the Dark), a childrens book (How the Grinch Stole Christmas!), a hair band (Rock of Ages), a mix tape (Movin Out), a Top-40 album (American Idiot), a comedy film (Legally Blonde), a 1980 box office flop despite a sprinkling of star dust from Olivia Newton-John (Xanadu).

title: Dream Girl of Musicals Dreams On
description: Cheerfully recounting her life and times in An Evening of Story and Song, at Feinsteins at Loews Regency on Tuesday evening, Shirley Jones didnt mince words. Speaking of clowns, she remarked after delivering a hearty rendition of Send In the Clowns, I happened to marry two.

title: At the Spring Nationals, Titles, an Upset and a Smart Defense
description: At the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., the three-day Norman Kay Platinum Pairs was won on Sunday evening by John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge of New York. They finished nearly three boards ahead of Laurie and Ken Kranyak of Bay Village, Ohio. Third were Jiang Gu of Mountain Lakes, N.J., and Xiaodong Shi of Naperville, Ill.

title: Parents Are Tempting Target in Debate on Teacher Seniority
description: The debate over whether stop protecting long-serving teachers from layoffs is getting closer and closer to the classroom.

title: Hoping to Avoid the Knife
description: In November, the prestigious Cleveland Clinic hailed a scar-less weight-loss surgery as one of the top 10 medical innovations expected this year.

title: Patterns: For Heart Risk, No Telltale Body Shape
description: A major new analysis challenges the long-held idea that obese people who carry their extra weight mainly around the middle  those with an apple shape  are at greater risk for heart disease than pears, whose fat tends to cluster on their thighs and buttocks.

title: With Ivory Coast Crippled by Sanctions, a Leader Still Holds On
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Signs of economic collapse, big and small, are obvious: a once booming port is as peaceful as a country road; lines of civil servants hoping for pay snake around downtown banks for days; factories, shops and restaurants are shuttered until further notice; eggs are impossible to find in the supermarket.

title: Stalled Plan for Donnell Library Site May Be Moving Again
description: The plan for the West 53rd Street site of the Donnell Library, shuttered since 2008, may be morphing once again, from a library-cum-hotel into a library-cum-hotel-cum-condominium.

title: Petraeus Tells Panel July Drawdown in Afghanistan May Include Some Combat Troops
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. David H. Petraeus told Congress on Wednesday that some American combat troops might be included in an initial withdrawal of United States forces from Afghanistan in July, but he said that he was still preparing options for President Obama and that no final decision had been made.

title: An Aria for Italys Unity Also Sounds Like an Elegy
description: BOLZANO, Italy  This picturesque town in the foothills of the Tyrolean Alps became Italian by a twist of history, when a pact signed after the upheaval of World War I handed the territory from Austria to Italy. With its German-speaking majority and reticent elegance, it still feels closer to Vienna than to Rome.

title: A Clever End Run Around the Movie-Streaming Gremlins
description: Fellow movie fans, we find ourselves in a time of great transition. We have one foot in the world of recorded movies  a time of fantastic selection, but also a time of tapes and discs. Our descendants will laugh their little holographic heads off when they hear about our ridiculous trips driving back and forth to the video store.

title: At a Vacation House in Uruguay, Animal Hides and Ocean Views
Who Lives There: Hudson View, Overlooking the River
description: A 1920s-era house in Croton-on-Hudson preserves the history of the large family that shared it.

title: The Family Museum
description: CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Telepsychiatry
description: Video conferencing is often used for business meetings, but the technology is increasingly used in medicine, including psychiatry. On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein discusses JSA Health, a telepsychiatry practice that uses high-definition video to provide mental health services in rural areas and prisons in Texas. She speaks with the companys founder and chief medical officer, Dr. Avrim Fishkind, a psychiatrist, and its chief executive, Dr. Robert Cuyler, a psychologist.

title: Garrison Keillor Plans to Leave the Prairie
description: Garrison Keillor, the longtime host of A Prairie Home Companion and arguably the biggest star in the world of public radio, told interviewers that he plans to retire in the spring of 2013  maybe.

title: Shopping for Glass Lamps With Omer Arbel
description: The architect, and creative director of Bocci, searched for inspiring glass lamps.

title: Glass Lamps
description: ITS really easy to get mystical when you talk about light, so I hesitate, said Omer Arbel, an architect based in Vancouver, British Columbia. But I do acknowledge that light touches peoples souls in an interesting, subconscious way  light is a medium you can manipulate to evoke emotion.

title: Overcoming a Fear of Plumbing Jobs
description: LIKE a lot of kids, I memorized the forbidden vocabulary of grown-ups by standing within earshot of my dad on Saturdays when he was on his back, wrench in hand, raging at pieces of metal that refused to do what he wanted them to do.

title: Chalkboards for Scribbling or Merely Admiring
description: Suspended from their thick linen ties and piled one on top of another, as they are at the John Derian store, these shapely pieces of zinc by Un Esprit en Plus look like simple but beautiful wall hangings. In fact, they are chalkboards that can be cleaned with a damp cloth (and come with a piece of chalk).

title: Sales on Lighting From Norman Foster, and More
description: All merchandise is 35 percent off, both in stores and online, during the spring sale at Fontana Arte, from March 18 to 27 (the Uovo outdoor table-floor lamp, originally $1,272, will be $827; the Three Sixty task lamp by Norman Foster, left, regularly $780 to $995, will be $507 to $647; the Sara table by Pierluigi Cerri, originally $348 to $455, will be $226 to $296); 45 Greene Street (Broome Street), (212) 334-3295 or fontanaartestore.com.

title: Laurie Beckermans Lucite Butterfly Chair
description: Laurie Beckerman, a furniture designer, began her career in architecture, working for Steven Holl and for Pratt Architectural Collaborative. It wasnt until later, when carving stone for a project at the Jewish Museum, that she made her first table  the simplest thing she could imagine carving out of stone  in her spare time, and she has been making furniture ever since.

title: At More Mobile-Home Parks, a Greater Sense of Security
description: NORTH ATTLEBORO, Mass.

title: A Vacuum That Attacks Bedbugs
description: The war on bedbugs has become so pervasive that only an act of Congress is needed to make it official. Meanwhile, the civilian population is stepping up its weapons. One of the newest is the CleanWave Sanitizing Bagless Vacuum by Verilux, which was introduced at the International Home and Housewares Show in Chicago last week and sells for about $400.

title: In Chicago, Rich Brilliant Willings First Solo Show
description: Pro Forma, the first solo exhibition of the work of Rich Brilliant Willing, the New York design studio, opens tomorrow at the Volume Gallery in Chicago. The show features five pieces inspired by airplane shipping containers. Each piece, made in editions of 12 to 16, is being sold with two bases, one vertical and one horizontal, to allow for dual uses of each design.

title: Marcel Wanders on Designing Upbeat Tableware
description: Marcel Wanders is like the Lady Gaga of the design world: a constant font of ideas and energy who is nearly impossible to ignore.

title: Concert for Japan at Miller Theater
description: 10:14 a.m. | Updated

title: Andreessen Horowitz Makes a Bet on Jawbone
description: Andreessen Horowitz  the venture capital firm owned by the Netscape co-founder Marc Andreessen  has invested $49 million in Jawbone, a headset maker.

title: Obama Begins Fund-Raising Phase in Earnest
description: President Obama has yet to say it out loud. But there is no clearer evidence that he is gearing up for a re-election campaign than the company he has been keeping recently.

title: Libyas Experiments With a Free Press Often Rattle the News Media Lab Rats
description: TRIPOLI  First an Italian journalist and his Libyan minder had a fistfight in the lobby. The next day at breakfast a photographer threw his juice at a writer for a French magazine. A correspondent for The Los Angeles Times threatened to punch a Turkish newscaster for holding up the bus.

title: U.S. Picks Roster for Two Friendlies
description: The United States mens national team coach Bob Bradley announced the 24 players he had selected for a training camp in advance of two international friendly matches later this month. And he did not take the safe route.

title: China: Tibetan Monk Sets Himself on Fire
description: A Tibetan monk in Sichuan Province tried committing suicide on Wednesday by setting himself on fire to protest Chinese rule in Tibetan areas, according to two Tibet advocacy groups, International Campaign for Tibet and Free Tibet, based outside China. The fate of the monk, Phuntsog, was unclear by nighttime, but there were rumors he had died. He was the second monk at Kirti Monastery to protest Chinese policies through self-immolation. In 2009, another monk did the same, but survived. This month is the third anniversary of an uprising against Chinese rule that rippled across Tibetan areas in March 2008. Kirti Monastery was a center of protests in Sichuan.

title: How To Keep Your Facebook Group Secret
description: I recently joined an amateur music group whose members set up a Facebook group. Two days into the project, one member panicked. All my friends can see everything were talking about, she wrote us via e-mail. I dont want them to even know Im doing this. We need to go back to e-mail.

title: Pressure Mounts on All Parties in Afghan War to Begin Talks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As American troops press the Taliban in their desert and mountain redoubts, Western diplomats, Taliban leaders and the Afghan government have begun to take a hard look at what it would take to start a negotiation to end the fighting.

title: Caramelized Onion Dip With Frizzled Leeks
description: Time: 2 hours

title: Pork Rillettes
description: Time: About 3 hours, largely unattended, plus time to chill

title: Pimentn Potted Shrimp
description: Time: About 30 minutes, plus time to chill

title: SATs Reality TV Essay Stumps Some
description: Every year, the SAT reduces more than a few teenage test-takers to tears.

title: No Skinny Dipping
description: Maybe it will happen at the start of next month, when the N.C.A.A. Final Four games take place. Or maybe it will be later this year, during the World Series, or next years Super Bowl, or the weekend when your ship comes in and you get to buy that 65-inch TV. But at some point, if youre like most Americans, you are likely to have some friends over to watch the Big Game  and your friends are going to show up hungry.

title: Tikkun Editor a Target of Vandals
description: Michael Lerner, a rabbi and the editor of the leftist Jewish magazine Tikkun, has been the target of vandalism because of his magazines support of Richard Goldstone, the South African judge who led a committee that published a report in 2009 concluding that Israel had taken actions amounting to war crimes, Rabbi Lerner said on Wednesday.

title: For SAT Test-Takers, Is The Situation the Right Answer?
description: Those readers of The Choice who took the SAT last Saturday  or who may have had a child who did  know that one of the essay prompts asked them to give their opinions on reality television.

title: Agreeing to Be Bought, but Keeping Autonomy
description: A fledgling agency holding company is making an acquisition in the realm of traditional and digital advertising.

title: Manager Hit by Line Drive Loses an Eye
description: Luis Salazar, a minor league manager in the Atlanta Braves system, lost an eye after he was struck in the face by a line drive while watching a spring training game.

title: Soft Spot for Rays? Look at Bullpen
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.

title: A Few Surprises in This Years Fashion Awards
description: There were a couple of surprises among the honorees and nominees for this years American fashion awards, announced Wednesday evening by the Council of Fashion Designers of America. For one, Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, who have proven their design chops (despite the naysayers) with their popular collection called the Row, were nominated for an award for new talent. For another, most of the biggest American designers, including Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan, Michael Kors and Calvin Kleins Francisco Costa, were shut out.

title: Michelle Obama Writing a Book on Healthy Food
description: Michelle Obama will write a book about the organic garden she planted on the South Lawn of the White House and the virtues of eating fresh, locally grown food, a cause that has been the centerpiece of her work as first lady. The book is not yet titled and is scheduled for publication in spring 2012. The book deal was announced by her agent, Robert Barnett, and the Crown Publishing Group, a division of Random House. Mrs. Obama did not accept an advance and will donate the proceeds to charity.

title: Forecast for Plume's Path Is a Function of Wind and Weather
description: The Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty Organization shows how weather patterns might disperse radiation from a continuous source in Fukushima Prefecture, Japan.

title: N.H.L. Moving in Right Direction on Hits to Head, Some G.M.s Say
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  N.H.L. general managers who favor a full ban on checks to the head said that although such a ban was not adopted this year, there was some optimism that the managers as a group would continue moving in that direction.

title: Struggling to Cope With the Crisis in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Degrees of Influence?
description: In the next few weeks, hundreds of thousands of high school seniors around the world will begin hearing from colleges and universities in this country about whether they have been lucky enough to be accepted for admission.

title: Reading the Stars to Guide Terrestrial Life
description: Heres what the stars ordained in 1985 for Shirley Soffer: The novel she was writing wasnt going well, so she consulted her astrological chart, dumped the novel and began reading every astrology reference book in sight. After years of reading and studying with Eileen McCabe, a certified astrologer, she became a consulting astrologer in 1992. Ms. Soffer, 76, the author of The Astrology Sourcebook, lives in SoHo.

title: 4 Times Journalists Are Missing in Libya
description: The New York Times said Wednesday that four of its journalists reporting on the conflict in Libya were missing.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Living With a Nuclear Question Mark in the Backyard
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y.

title: Harlem Is Losing a Piece of Clinton
description: When Bill Clinton officially began his post-presidency in Harlem in 2001, he was greeted with open arms  thousands of them. At a plaza near his new office, at 55 West 125th Street, a crowd of 2,000 residents and civic leaders gathered on a hot July afternoon to celebrate the arrival of a neighbor whose presence, two blocks from the landmark Apollo Theater, seemed to put a presidential stamp of approval on the neighborhoods revival.

title: In Lockout, a Close Eye Falls on the NFL Network
description: In the brief history of league-owned cable networks, none have covered a work stoppage until now.

title: Amid Shortages, a Surplus of Hope
description: Yokohama, Japan

title: Label Chief to Depart for X Factor
description: In the latest round of changes among executives at the major record labels, Antonio Reid, a top hit maker at the Universal Music Group, will leave the company to become a judge on The X Factor.

title: Dividends Will Enrich Bank Chiefs
description: Even as ordinary investors look forward to the prospect of larger dividend payouts by the big banks, another group is poised for a rich payday: bank chief executives. In the next few days, the Federal Reserve is expected to give a handful of institutions, including JPMorgan Chase and Capital One, permission to pay higher dividends, another sign of the remarkable comeback of banks since the depths of the financial crisis.

title: Prefabricated Tower May Rise at Brooklyns Atlantic Yards
description: In a bid to cut costs at his star-crossed Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, the developer Bruce C. Ratner is pursuing plans to erect the worlds tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 34-story tower that would fulfill his obligation to start building affordable housing at the site.

title: As Rose and Bulls Rise, So Do the Expectations
description: CHICAGO  Derrick Rose is surrounded by the intimidating legacy of the Chicago Bulls. His agent is B. J. Armstrong, the point guard who once shared the backcourt with Michael Jordan. So did John Paxson, who is now one of the Bulls top executives. Even Scottie Pippen is around more often after reuniting with the organization and accepting an ambassadors role.

title: Tests for a New White House Spokesman
description: WASHINGTON  Jay Carney has never been much of a partisan.

title: Bahrain Pulls a Qaddafi
description: It is heartbreaking to see a renegade country like Libya shoot pro-democracy protesters. But its even more wrenching to watch Americas ally, Bahrain, pull a Qaddafi and use American tanks, guns and tear gas as well as foreign mercenaries to crush a pro-democracy movement  as we stay mostly silent.

title: Looking Ahead to Thursdays Games
description: EastKentucky ended Cornells tournament run in the Round of 16 last season. This year, the fourth-seeded Wildcats have another date with an Ivy League champion. On Thursday, they will face No. 13 Princeton in Tampa, Fla. The Tigers could pull off an upset, but as the former Kentucky player DeMarcus Cousins said before the game against Cornell last year, Its not a spelling bee. Also in Tampa, fifth-seeded West Virginia faces a trivia answer: No. 12 Clemson, the first winner of an at-large play-in game (or, as the N.C.A.A. refers to it, the First Four) in tournament history.

title: Talking About Guns
description: More than two months after the killings in Tucson, Ariz., and some 2,400 American gun deaths later, President Obama has finally broken his silence on gun violence.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 16, 2011

title: Specter of Rebel Rout Helps Shift U.S. Policy on Libya
description: WASHINGTON  The prospect of a deadly siege of the rebel stronghold in Benghazi, Libya, has produced a striking shift in tone from the Obama administration, which is now pushing for the United Nations to authorize aerial bombing of Libyan tanks and heavy artillery to try to halt the advance of forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: For the Record
description: An editorial on Tuesday about the soldier suspected of leaking documents to WikiLeaks incorrectly reported that Pfc. Bradley Manning is shackled while exercising in the recreation room in the Marine Corps brig. He is only shackled while walking to and from that room.

title: Scientists Project Path of Radiation Plume
description: A United Nations forecast of the possible movement of the radioactive plume coming from crippled Japanese reactors shows it churning across the Pacific, and touching the Aleutian Islands on Thursday before hitting Southern California late Friday.

title: Economic Downturn Holds Fierce Grip on Border Town
description: EL CENTRO, Calif.  This is the desert, not meant for lush fields and tight cul-de-sacs. But here they are, a few miles from the Mexican border. For a time, this was a thriving place that represented the promise of a new middle-class life, full of hope and optimism.

title: Broken Trust
description: A recent Congressional hearing and the poignant testimony of an unexpected victim  Mickey Rooney  have helped focus new attention on the abuse and exploitation of old people. Congress should seize the moment to help repair their threadbare web of protection.

title: Nuclear Agency Tells a Concerned Congress That U.S. Industry Remains Safe
description: WASHINGTON  Facing questions about the implications of Japans nuclear catastrophe for power plants in the United States, the Nuclear Regulatory Commissions top official said Wednesday at two Congressional hearings that his agency would take a methodical look at Japan and incorporate lessons from the disaster.

title: Seeking Work and Swapping Stories
description: EL CENTRO, Calif.  The crowd gathers early each morning at the unemployment center, which sits amid a long strip of beige government buildings in the center of town.

title: TimesCast | Inside a Nuclear Reactor
description: A look at the workings and problems of a nuclear reactor.

title: Guns, Blood and Congress
description: Washington, D.C., March 1861

title: Punishment for NPR
description: Here is the latest example of House Republicans pursuing a longstanding ideological goal in the false name of fiscal prudence: On Thursday, they have scheduled a vote to kill federal support for National Public Radio.

title: Walker and UConn a Long Way From One-and-Done
description: WASHINGTON

title: In Syria, Demonstrations Are Few and Brief
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  For a moment, you might almost have thought you were in Cairo, or Tunis. Five brave young men stood in this citys ancient Hamidiya market and began chanting, We sacrifice our blood and souls for you, Syria! Soon, a crowd of about 150 had gathered, and the call was heard: The revolution has started!

title: Sleepy California Town, and a Tsunami Magnet
description: CRESCENT CITY, Calif.  There are images of waves throughout Crescent City: on the signs marking the city limits, on the logo of its credit union and on the facade of Tsunami Lanes, where this citys local rollers come to bowl.

title: Road Report
description: This is the time of year when the paved surfaces upstate tear themselves apart. It is the work of the very thing weve all been hoping for: a thaw. The days are warm, but the nights can still freeze, the sap flows and the roadways undulate like the imaginary sandworm, expanding and contracting.

title: What Should Be Done About Libya?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares Rally as Panic Over Japan Eases
description: Stocks staged a broad relief rally as panic about the nuclear crisis in Japan seemed to abate temporarily and markets were reassured by an intervention by the Group of 7 industrialized nations to help stabilize the yen.

title: Bloggingheads: Who's Afraid of Shariah?
description: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and Michael Brendan Dougherty of The American Conservative debate the American fear of Islamic law.

title: Long Pause for Japanese Industry Raises Concerns About Supply Chain
description: TOKYO  Japans vaunted just in time approach to business has become wait and see.

title: Insurer to Forgo Rate Rise
description: Blue Shield of California, a nonprofit insurer, on Wednesday withdrew its request to seek higher rates this year for individual policies amid stiff criticism from regulators and consumers.

title: Viral Videos Catch On That Only Hint at a Sponsors Purpose
description: Can a man with a tiny electronic device hack into the multitude of jumbo screens in Times Square and play videos from his iPhone? Maybe, if you believe a YouTube video that has been watched by more than half a million viewers in the last four days.

description: Tokyo

title: Paper Admits to Plagiarism by Reporter
description: The Washington Post published an editors note on its Web site Wednesday apologizing for two articles by a longtime Post reporter who used material from The Arizona Republic without crediting that newspaper or citing it as a source.
