description: Biddeford, Me.

title: The Evacuation Zones Around the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Plant
description: Map of the evacuations zones recommended by the American Embassy in Tokyo and Japanese officials.

title: Pelfreys Fastball Doesnt Seem So Fast
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Mike Pelfrey located his fastball well for five innings in the Mets 4-3 loss to Minnesota on Wednesday. He did not have the type of velocity on his pitches that he would like.

title: A Star Rebounder Leaves Trouble Behind
description: DENVER  About this time last spring, Morehead State forward Kenneth Faried thought about trying to reach for the N.B.A. His life was in a blender.

title: A Year After a Big Run, It Is Back to Normal
description: WASHINGTON  The public life of Butler Coach Brad Stevens took a precipitous uptick last spring when President Obama called and David Letterman encouraged him to get some chocolate milk.

title: Lawmakers Find a Path Around an Earmarks Ban
description: Representative Timothy H. Bishop of eastern Long Island reached out to a top colonel in the Army Corps of Engineers a few weeks ago seeking help on something that might have slipped under the radar: dredging Lake Montauk.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,488 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the death of the following American:

title: For Driver in Bronx Crash, Fight That Led to a Killing
description: The killing of Robert U. Martin in 1990 began with a fight over a gun lent for possible use in a murder.

title: Marty Marion, Cardinalss Slick-Fielding Shortstop, Dies at 93
description: Marty Marion, the St. Louis Cardinals celebrated slick-fielding shortstop, who was known as the Octopus for his long arms and uncanny range in gobbling up ground balls, died on Tuesday in St. Louis. He was 93 and lived in Ladue, Mo.

title: Nevada: Angle Announces She Is Running for Congress
description: It would seem that Sharron Angle is running for a House seat in Nevada. In a video on her Web site, Ms. Angle says she is running for the United States Congress but does not name the seat. Presumably it is the one in the Second District, which is being vacated by Representative Dean Heller, a Republican who narrowly defeated her in a 2006 primary run for the position. Mr. Heller is now running for the Senate seat left open by Senator John Ensign, the beleaguered senator who is not running again. Ms. Angle shook up her party and her state last year when she won the Republican primary and faced off with Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, in a race she lost by several points. A messy primary could pave a path for a moderate Democrat in the district, which has been reliably Republican for decades.

title: Florida House Approves Ending Tenure for New Teachers
description: MIAMI  A bill to end tenure for new teachers and link their job security and pay to how well students perform on assessment tests cleared the Florida House of Representatives on Wednesday and now goes to the new governor, Rick Scott, a Republican who strongly supports the measure.

title: Defense Continues to Stop the Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Charles Barkley is seldom shy to tweak the Knicks or lean on hyperbole. He combined both when he designated them as the worst defensive team ever on Late Show With David Letterman.

title: Victor Blanco, Stargazer, Dies at 92
description: Victor Blanco, a Puerto Rican astronomer who helped build a major outpost for American science, the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile, and shepherded it through 14 years of revolution, counterrevolution and economic turmoil, died on March 8. He was 92 and lived in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Castro Enemy Said to Have Recounted Role in Attacks
description: EL PASO  A journalist called as a key prosecution witness in the perjury trial of an elderly anti-Castro militant testified on Wednesday that the defendant had described in detailed interviews his role in a wave of bombings that tore through Havana in 1997.

title: A Republican Fund-Raiser Is Indicted in a Ponzi Scheme
description: LOS ANGELES  A prominent Republican fund-raiser was charged Wednesday in a federal grand jury indictment with orchestrating a Ponzi scheme that defrauded investors of hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: In Return, St. Johns Is Ready for Amends
description: DENVER  The last time St. Johns played in the N.C.A.A. tournament, in 2002, the appearance was later wiped from the record books for various infractions. It was as if it never happened at all.

title: Executions in Doubt in Fallout Over Drug
description: ATLANTA  The worldwide shortage of a drug used in executions reverberated this week in two of the most active death-penalty states as Texas announced it would replace the anesthetic in its three-drug regimen and federal agents seized Georgias supply.

title: Nova Makes His Case With Six No-Hit Innings
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Ivan Nova pitched for the Yankees late last season, his slider grip unleashed a pitch that acted like a flat curveball. After Torontos Jose Bautista bashed it for a home run, Nova scrapped the grip.

title: Measuring the Impact of N.C.A.A. Injuries
description: N.C.A.A. tournament games between the No. 1 seed and the No. 16 seed arent normally worth watching. No mens 16th seed has ever beaten a No. 1, and that doesnt figure to change this year.

title: New Armed Services Chairman Is Ready to Be Heard
description: WASHINGTON  When the House Armed Services Committee convened on Wednesday, it heard from the commander in Afghanistan, Gen. David H. Petraeus, the most recognized military officer in America. Sitting opposite him was the new Republican committee chairman, Representative Howard P. McKeon, who is all but unknown outside his California district.

title: Honoring a Spirit of Survival and Artistry
description: Not long after surviving 11 German concentration camps, 15-year-old Jack Garfein, once down to a skeletal 48 pounds, found his lifes work. The displaced-persons camp in Sweden where he was recuperating staged a play. The youth was cast to type  as a child in a concentration camp.

title: Co-Presidents to Head Up USA Channel
description: Comcasts NBCUniversal division is promoting two executives, Jeff Wachtel and Chris McCumber, to be the co-presidents of USA, the most-watched channel on cable television.

title: Internet Users Turned to Social Networks in Elections, Survey Finds
description: One in five adults who use the Internet, including a growing number of older, conservative Republicans, turned to social networks to get or share information about the midterm elections last year, according to a Pew Research Center study released on Thursday.

title: Photo Replay: March 16
description: A view of the day in sports, with bright sun at spring training games and some over-excited soccer fans.

title: Nate Dogg, Hip-Hop Collaborator, Dies at 41
description: Nate Dogg, a singer with a silky, burly voice who helped shape the sound of West Coast hip-hop, died on Tuesday in Long Beach, Calif., the city where he was born and that he helped memorialize in song. He was 41.

title: Morneau and Bay Help Each Other Deal With Concussions
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Jason Bay of the Mets and Justin Morneau of the Minnesota Twins played together for Canada in the 2006 World Baseball Classic and forged a friendship based on their shared personal and professional experiences.

title: Dozens Injured in Clashes in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemeni security forces in the central city of Taiz fired tear gas and live ammunition into the air on Thursday to break up clashes between protesters and plainclothes government supporters, witnesses said. More than 100 people were injured, most as a result of tear-gas exposure, according to local reports.

title: Purim Pastries
description: WHAT is hamantashen?WHAT unconventional flavorings are Israeli bakeries using in their hamantashen this year?WHAT spring holidays do you and your family or community celebrate?

title: Test Yourself | English, March 17, 2011
description: Test your proofreading skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the blog post Should Suns Adjust to Vince Carters Game?.

title: As Big Names Shut Down, Smaller Funds Step Up
description: We have all heard about big hedge fund managers returning outside investors money: Chris Shumway, Stanley Druckenmiller and, more lately, Carl C. Icahn. While the news may seem grim, the industry as a whole has seen capital levels rebound from the lows of a few years ago.

title: With Quest to Cool Fuel Rods Stumbling, U.S. Sees Weeks of Struggle
description: TOKYO  Amid widening alarm in the United States and elsewhere about Japans nuclear crisis, military fire trucks began spraying cooling water on spent fuel rods at the countrys stricken nuclear power station late Thursday after earlier efforts to cool the rods failed, Japanese officials said.

title: Lagardre Delays Canal Plus I.P.O.

title: Beauty, Through Pinhole or Plastic
description: Otto Kitchens has found the perfect camera for an imperfect world: a plastic Holga.

title: What Does Middle Class Mean to You?
description: Several states have experienced serious wrangling over the rights of public-sector union employees and the benefits they receive. One of the questions at issue now is whether those workers will be able to maintain middle-class status if changes are made to union workers pay. What does the term middle class mean to you?

title: American Idol': The Top 12
description: Stefano Langone > Pia Toscano > Scotty McCreery > Jacob Lusk > Haley Reinhart > Lauren Alaina > Casey Abrams > James Durbin > Thia Megia > Karen Rodriguez > Naima Adedapo > Paul McDonald

title: What Happened to the Jay-Z Jeep?
description: Before Diddy and his missing Mercedes-Benz S-Class, before Eminem and his imported-from-Detroit Chrysler 200, even before Funkmaster Flex and his special-edition Ford Expedition, there was the Jay-Z Jeep Commander. You would be forgiven, however, for not remembering the commercials.

title: Paris Museum Opens Collection, With a Twist
description: Long famed for its temporary exhibitions of contemporary masters like Edvard Munch and Jackson Pollock, the Pinacothque de Paris (28 place de la Madeleine; 33-1-42-68-02-09; www.pinacotheque.com) recently opened extensive space for its first permanent collection. Located in a space adjacent to the main building, it displays 100 paintings from foreign and French collectors, including works by Rembrandt and Picasso.

title: The Early Word: Force and Forks
description: In Todays Times:

title: What Makes a Hospital Great
description: Toward the end of my general surgery training, a senior surgeon pulled me aside to ask about my plans for further training. One of the best surgeons in the hospital, he had done his own subspecialty training at a hospital famous for vascular surgery.

title: Fantasy Focus: Keeper-League Inflation
description: Most fantasy baseball leagues are of the one-year variety, but a significant number allow you to keep players for multiple seasons. A typical structure in a league with a $260 budget allows you to keep a player at his purchased price for as long as three years, and if you want to extend him beyond that, youll have to add $5 per year.

title: 2010 Bears: What the Film Revealed
description: Offense

title: VIDEO: G.O.P. Hits Obama on Deficit
description: Republicans in Washington believe they have the upper hand when it comes to dealing honestly with the nations debt, and a new video by the National Republican Campaign Committee aims to exploit that advantage.

title: Roemer to Run as Irritant to Republicans in 2012
description: Buddy Roemer, the former Republican governor of Louisiana, is eager to be an outspoken, sharp-edged irritant to members of his own party, casting them as bought and paid for by the special interests in Washington.

title: The Giant Catfish Under Japan
description: In the last 17 years, I acquired in-laws who still live in Tokyo, and I have spent maybe a year of my life there. So the earthquake and everything else since then has a heavy immediacy.

title: China Calls for Candor From Japan on Crisis
description: BEIJING  China urged Japan on Thursday to report any developments in its nuclear crisis quickly and accurately as concern spread over whether officials in Tokyo had played down the scope of the radiation risk.

title: South by Southwest: The Din of Business Meeting Pleasure
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  By the time I arrived at this years South By Southwest music festival, on Wednesday, the din on East Sixth Street, where a strip of clubs runs block after block, was already rising. It was the din of live music and recordings, of come-ons and conversations, of pitches and pickup lines, of excited giggles and male banter, of tentative connections and of fortuitous reunions and, as the day goes on, of drunken bonhomie or befuddlement, of strategies being worked and of pure chaotic happenstance. Its the din of business meeting pleasure, which is what has now sustained SXSW into its 25th year.

title: Where the Lights Arent Neon
description: The pulse of neon, the perfume of roasted nuts, human-arachnid hybrids tumbling from the rafters of a misbegotten musical  Times Square and the theater district can be relied on for all of these.

title: Looking Toward 2012
description: Michael D. Shear interviews Former Louisiana Governor Buddy Roemer about his presidential ambitions.

title: Looking Toward 2012
description: Michael D. Shear interviews Former Louisiana Governor Buddy Roemer about his presidential ambitions.

title: Qaddafi Warns of Assault on Benghazi as U.N. Vote Nears
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi warned Benghazi residents on Thursday that an attack was imminent, as the United Nations Security Council seemed headed for a vote Thursday on a resolution authorizing not just a no-flight zone but additional steps to halt the movement of Colonel Qaddafis forces.

title: Fosters Moves Forward With Spin-Off of Wine Business
description: The Fosters Group is moving forward with its plan to spin off its wine unit, laying out the time line for the deal on Thursday.

title: How to Beat the Salad Bar
description: Statistics can be used for benevolent purposes or for evil ones. Then theres the middle ground, which is where this column resides. Once each month, Ill suggest ways in which you can exploit data to improve your lot in everyday life. I wont advocate that you do anything illegal or (in my opinion) immoral. But statistical analysis is being used, and not always to your benefit, by everyone from your cable company to your real estate broker. Consider this your chance to fight back.

title: Opposition Leaders Arrested in Bahrain as Crackdown Grows
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Bahrain arrested six opposition leaders on Thursday, kept the main hospital surrounded by troops and tanks and imposed a nighttime curfew on the center of its capital as it moved to the next stage of its crackdown on reform-seeking protesters, sending the political opposition into crisis.

title: Last Year Was a Good Year for Ad Spending, Report Finds
description: The recovery in advertising spending continued in the fourth quarter last year, according to a report that is to be released on Thursday morning, resulting in a solid full-year gain compared with the results of 2009.

title: Spains Borrowing Rates Ease in Latest Bond Sale
description: MADRID Spain managed to sell 4.1 billion euros, or $5.7 billion, of debt at slightly lower rates on Thursday, in an auction that was considered a crucial test of market confidence after last weekends agreement to bolster the euro zones rescue fund.

title: U.S. Official Affirms Nuclear Loan Guarantees
description: With many riveted on Japans reactor crisis, the head of the Department of Energys loan guarantee program has affirmed that it will continue to finance nuclear projects in the United States.

title: Uncertainty Clouds I.P.O. Market
description: After getting off to a strong start in 2011, the market for initial public offerings has started to cool as a result of global uncertainty caused by the disaster in Japan.

title: Dancing to a Different Tune With the Trost Brothers
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The FP, which screened in the SXFantastic sidebar of South by Southwest, may be the only full-length feature film in existence that combines Jerry Bruckheimer-esque action tropes with life-or-death duels played out on a game similar to Dance Dance Revolution. This comedic hybrid of styles and ideas comes from the minds of Jason Trost (who also stars in the film) and Brandon Trost, making their directing debut. The FP, shot in the brothers hometown of Frazier Park, Calif., celebrates its outlandishness while its performers play it straight. In this video interview, they discuss their collaboration.

title: March 17 Updates on Japans Nuclear Crisis and Earthquake Aftermath
description: On Thursday, The Lede continues to supplement the latest reporting from our colleagues in Japan on the aftermath of last weeks earthquake, including efforts to regain control of a damaged nuclear plant. Updates below feature reports from other news sites and firsthand accounts and video posted on social networks. A Twitter stream in the right column of this blog includes messages from journalists and officials in Japan.

title: Morning Buzz | Tour Bus Driver Under Scrutiny
description: Thursday will be the first clear spring day, with temperatures reaching the low 60s. Keep a jacket handy in the morning, though.

title: Seeing Things | Handmade for Japan
description: It has been almost one week since the devastating earthquake and tsunami struck Japan. If, like me, you love design, you probably have a favorite Japanese designer in fashion, architecture, graphic design or ceramics. Japan is a country that has always nurtured design, from handcraft to industrially produced goods; as a result, good design has become synonymous with Japanese design. Many of the countrys designers have been affected by the disaster, which continues to unfold in ways that are unfathomable to most of us. In Kasama and Mashiko, centers of ceramic production that are about halfway between Tokyo and Sendai, potters were hard hit by the quake when brick kilns collapsed and years worth of production shattered in minutes. Moved by the desire to support their fellow artists, three enterprising women in the United States have organized Handmade for Japan, an online auction of handmade work donated by Japanese artists and American artists with ties to Japan. Ayumi Horie, a Japanese-American potter who lives in Hudson, N.Y., recruited her friends Kathryn Pombriant Manzella and Ai Kanazawa Cheung to solicit donations and set up the auction, while the illustrator David Gordon designed a logo overnight. Offers of support, in-kind donations and handmade goods have poured in via Twitter, Facebook and e-mail. And artists including the illustrator Lisa Congdon, the textile designer Kaoru Oka and the ceramists Jun Kaneko, Justin Rothshank, Kathy Erteman and Diana Fayt, to name a few, have contributed paintings, shawls and, of course, pottery. The auction will go live on eBay on March 24 and will run through March 27. Through GlobalGiving, 100 percent of the auction proceeds will support relief efforts in Japan. To see more, check out Handmade for Japans Facebook page and Twitter feed.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Thursday Reading: Do-it-Yourself Plumbing
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Report Urges Even Higher Global Retirement Ages
description: PARIS  Retirement ages in advanced economies will have to rise more than currently planned if countries hope to cover the increase in costs caused by aging populations, a global economic organization warned Thursday.

title: Poetry Pairing | March 17, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Lady Gaga Gets Garbled on Malaysian Radio
description: You cant read Lady Gagas poker face, and you cant hear her single Born This Way as the provocative pop singer intended on radio stations in Malaysia, where broadcasters are playing the song but obscuring lyrics that they feel encourage acceptance of homosexuality, The Associated Press reported. Born This Way, whose chorus proclaims Im beautiful in my way / Cause God makes no mistakes, would already seem a tough fit in Malaysia, where last year the singer Adam Lambert had a concert protested by the Pan Malaysian Islamic Party, which said his shows promote gay culture. And while radio stations there are playing the song, they have been garbling a lyric that says, No matter gay, straight or bi, lesbian, transgendered life, Im on the right track, baby, for fear that it violates Malaysian indecency laws. The Malaysian broadcaster AMP Radio Networks told The A.P. that those lyrics may be considered as offensive when viewed against Malaysias social and religious observances, adding that being gay or bisexual is still considered as a taboo by general Malaysians.

title: Samurai Shopper | The Pajama Game
description: The Samurai Shopper greeted daylight saving time with some recreational shopping at the cutesy Lower East Side boutique Babel Fair (no relation) and a quick drive-by of overexposed Bleecker Street. Then I popped into Olivier Theyskenss pop-up shop for Theory, but after the long days journey, I still hadnt contributed a single sou to the local economy. As I regrouped with some Harneys tea and almond croissants at La Bergamote in Chelsea, some poetry rattled inside my parched mind, a line from The Love Song of Alfred J. Prufrock:

title: Trying to Connect With Customers? Tell a Story
description: The best part of writing for this blog is getting to talk to lots of successful business owners. Recently, I was reflecting on the companies who really capture my imagination and heart. They have in common an important ingredient for successful companies, large and small. Its not nice packaging or a good product at a good price or passion or exceptional service  although those things are all important. Its that they all have a company story, told well.

title: C.I.A. Drones Kill Civilians in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Several missiles fired from American drone aircraft on Thursday struck a meeting of local people in northwest Pakistan who had gathered with Taliban mediators to settle a dispute over a chromite mine. The attack, a Pakistani intelligence official said, killed 26 of 32 people present, some of them Taliban fighters, but the majority elders and local people not attached to the militants.

title: Art, and War and Consequences
description: This week Home Fires is publishing Still in the Fight, a three-part series by the Marine combat artist Michael D. Fay, recounting his visit to McGuire Veterans Administration Hospital in Richmond, Va., where he spent two days with wounded Marines in rehabilitation. Fay, along with his fellow combat artist Richard Johnson, is a member of the International Society of War Artists (ISWA), and in co-operation with the Smithsonians National Museum of American Historys Armed Forces History Division, set out to record a few days in the lives of wounded Marines in rehabilitation. In Still in the Fight, Fay offers both a written and visual account of time spent with three soldier and their families, on the mend.Though Still in the Fight deals with Marines wounded in Afghanistan, the series may be seen as a sequel to Drawing Fire, a five-part account published in 2010 that recounts in detail several weeks of Operation Steel Curtain in 2005 in Iraq. The conflicts in question are different, but both read in conjunction offer an inside view of the before, during and after of war.

title: The Times Announces Digital Subscription Plan
description: The New York Times introduced a plan on Thursday to begin charging the most frequent users of its Web site $15 for a four-week subscription in a bet that readers will pay for news they are accustomed to getting free.

title: Reagan and Interest Rates
description: I see that Arnold Kling is exasperated when I cite continuing low interest rates as evidence that concerns about crowding out are wrong, citing the Reagan years as a counterexample.

title: A Marked Man in America
description: The conservative Muslim cleric Yasir Qadhi speaks the language of jihadists, but denounces their violent actions.

title: A Letter to Our Readers About Digital Subscriptions
description: This week marks a significant transition for The New York Times as we introduce digital subscriptions. Its an important step that we hope you will see as an investment in The Times, one that will strengthen our ability to provide high-quality journalism to readers around the world and on any platform. The change will primarily affect those who are heavy consumers of the content on our Web site and on mobile applications.

title: UNESCO Team Will Go to Egypt
description: UNESCO is planning to send a delegation to Egypt early next week to assess the conditions at Egypts archaeological sites and monuments, Ahram Online reported. Egypts former antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, was invited to attend a UNESCO seminar in Paris this week marking the 40th anniversary of the UNESCO convention that seeks to prevent the illicit trade of cultural property, but could not attend; instead, he sent a message asking the international community for help in finding objects that have been looted from Egypts museums and archaeological sites since that countrys revolution began in January. On Wednesday, Egypts Supreme Council of Antiquities released an illustrated list of 54 objects missing from the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, which was looted on Jan. 28. The list is much longer than the list of 18 missing objects that Mr. Hawass released on Feb. 13. Mr. Hawass originally claimed that nothing was missing from the museum.

title: Further Thoughts on Dips
description: Making dips and spreads  the subject of this weeks magazine column  is mostly about intensifying flavors. Since theyre usually served in smallish dollops on relatively bland, starchy foods (like bread, chips, and crackers), dips should taste punchier than the kind of thing you eat by the forkful.

title: Want a New Life? Wait Here for a While
description: Doug Saunderss first book, Arrival City, reads like a special issue of The Economist, that estimable weekly, in ways that are mostly good but sometimes not. You can envision its subtitle stamped in 18-point type on the magazines cover: How the Largest Migration in History Is Reshaping Our World.

title: Reading and Responding: Holding Writing Workshops
description: Overview | How can a teachers artistic vulnerability inspire students to share their own work? In this lesson, students do a free-writing and sharing exercise, with the teacher providing a model. They then consider the roles of teacher as writer and student as responder, and take part in a writing workshop in which they provide the teacher with feedback and suggestions on his or her original written work.

title: An American Cleric
description: To young, conservative Muslims, Yasir Qadhi is one of the most influential clerics in America. The 36-year-old Houston native has preached before tens of thousands of Muslims, drawing a strong following on Facebook and Twitter. Law-enforcement agents have also tracked his rise among a subset of Muslims considered vulnerable to radicalization. After a former student tried to blow up a plane, Qadhi found himself caught between a suspicious government and a young following he could lose.

title: The Curtain Rises on the Class Act
description: It probably tells us something that the hearing that began in Washington this morning, before the health subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, is the very first congressional hearing on the Class Act.

title: Soccer Made in the U.S.: Where M.L.S. Stands, Soccermetrically Speaking?
description: When the Los Angeles Galaxy beat the Seattle Sounders, 1-0, when Major League Soccer opened its 2011 season on Tuesday night, each team took nine shots on goal, committed eight fouls, saw two yellow cards and was awarded four corner kicks.

title: Why Yasir Qadhi Wants to Talk About Jihad
description: On a chilly night in the dead of a New England winter, Yasir Qadhi hurried down the stairs of Yale Universitys religious-studies department, searching urgently for a place to make a private call. A Ph.D. candidate in Islamic studies, Qadhi was a fixture on the New Haven campus. He wore a trim beard and preppy polo shirts, blending in with the other graduate students as he lugged an overstuffed backpack into Blue State Coffee for his daily cappuccino. A popular teaching assistant, he exuded a sprightly intensity in class, addressing the undergraduates as dudes.

title: Fat Pig Will Not Open on Broadway This Season
description: If you were looking forward to Dane Cooks Broadway debut youll have to wait a bit longer. And if you werent, youve just been handed a reprieve: producers for the coming Broadway production of Fat Pig said on Thursday that they were postponing the shows opening until the 2011-2012 season after losing a key investment.

title: TimesCast | Struggling for a Solution
description: The Times's Hong Kong bureau chief, Keith Bradsher, on Japan's efforts to contain Reactor 3 at the stricken nuclear plant.

title: A Note to Our Readers About Digital Subscriptions
description: Updated | Aug. 2012

title: Fear of Fallout From Japan Spreads in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Fears of radioactive contamination from the crippled nuclear plant in Japan are spreading to Russias Far East. Residents there are ignoring official assurances that there is no danger, and are beginning to stockpile food, medicines and face masks.

title: Too Much Sharing of Feelings With Kids?
description: We want our children to share their feelings, right? RIGHT?

title: Lincoln Tops J.D. Power Dependability Survey
description: Lincoln knocked Porsche off its perch as the most dependable of 34 brands in the 2011 J. D. Power and Associates Vehicle Dependability Study. It was the first time Lincoln has topped the list, which has been published annuallysince1990.

title: Editors Note: DealBook and Digital Subscriptions
description: The publisher of The New York Times, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., announced earlier on Thursday that The Times was introducing digital subscriptions to Times content on computers, smartphones and tablets. Read Mr. Sulzbergers letter and a list of frequently asked questions to learn more.

title: Princeton Players Driven by Memories of Crunch
description: When No. 13 Princeton tips off against No. 4 Kentucky in the N.C.A.A. tournament Thursday afternoon, the Tigers will wear a piece of their hearts on their uniforms. Their tribute to the kid they called Crunch  11-year-old Christian Michael Regulski  can be found on their warm-up jackets and on their bench. There, a blue pillow with his name will serve as a constant reminder, not that the Tigers need one.

title: In India, Leaked Cable About Bribes Sets Off a Furor
description: NEW DELHI  Indias Parliament erupted in outrage on Thursday over a report of an American diplomatic cable that described insiders in the governing Congress Party showing off chests of money and boasting of paying bribes to wavering lawmakers to secure passage of a critical 2008 vote on a landmark civilian nuclear deal between India and the United States.

title: With Crises, Universities Worry About Students Abroad
description: In January, as protests turned chaotic in Cairo, New York University hastened to evacuate 50 students and staff members from three sites across Egypt. Less than a month later, when an earthquake hit New Zealand, Cornell University quickly relocated students whose heavily damaged campus there had suspended classes.

title: Tibetan Who Set Himself Afire Dies
description: BEIJING  A young Tibetan monk who set himself on fire to protest Chinese rule in the vast Tibetan regions of western China died early on Thursday. It was the first time that a monk protesting against China had killed himself through self-immolation, according to historians of modern Tibet.

title: A Merce Cunningham Trove for the Walker Art Center
description: Even before Merce Cunningham died, in 2009, plans were being made to ensure the choreographers legacy. They included his companys farewell tour, which comes to the Joyce next week, and a new box set of music composed for his dances. Now the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis has acquired a trove of material that major 20th-century artists like Robert Rauschenberg and Andy Warhol made for Cunningham performances. The collection covers some 150 props, costumes, backdrops and other objects. Among them are a Rauschenberg combine and his costumes for the 1958 dance Antic Meet, Frank Stella set pieces for Scramble (1967) and silver-colored pillows that Warhol contributed to RainForest (1968), as well as work by Jasper Johns. A spokesman for the museum would not comment on how much the Walker paid for the material. Some of the objects will go on display in November when the Merce Cunningham Dance Companys Legacy Tour reaches Minneapolis.

title: The Times Announces Digital Subscription Plan
description: The New York Times announced a plan on Thursday to begin charging the most frequent users of its Web site $15 a month. Under the plan, which will begin on March 28, visitors to NYTimes.com will be able to read 20 articles a month free. The most frequent users will pay $15 a month; print subscribers will have unlimited access.

title: SXSW: Questions for Greta Gerwig
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Greta Gerwig is no stranger to SXSW. Her new film, The Dish & the Spoon, marks the sixth time she has had a movie in the festival in an film career that has stretched the same number of years. This new film, directed by Alison Bagnall, about a woman and a young man (Olly Alexander) who bond during a tumultuous time in their lives. Ms. Gerwigs acting style, which A.O. Scott lauded for its apparent absence of any method, is employed in this intimate, primarily two-character study.

title: Immigrant Detentions Draw International Fire
description: Immigration enforcement in the United States is plagued by unjust treatment of detainees, including inadequate access to lawyers and insufficient medical care, and by the excessive use of prison-style detention, the human rights arm of the Organization of American States said Thursday.

title: Vain Glorious | Liv Tyler Is Very Irrsistible
description: What: Very Irrsistible Givenchy LIntense

title: Wounded British Photographer Shows Signs of Improvement
On Our Radar: No Robots Deployed In Nuclear Crisis
description: Despite Japans position as a world leader in robotics, no robots have been deployed to repair the countrys damaged reactors or help cool their overheating nuclear cores, the authorities say. French nuclear officials have offered to send their own robots to assist, but it is unclear whether the offer has been accepted. [Reuters]

title: TimesCast | A False Alarm
description: A false tsunami alarm in Kesennuma sent survivors in the town into a panic.

title: Missouri Tigers Let Loose
description: Sometimes people think they are in good shape, but they are really not. To play for Mike Anderson, you know that you are in great shape. The tag fastest 40 minutes in basketball, has been following Anderson around since his days as an assistant with Nolan Richardson at Tulsa and Arkansas.

title: At Board 18, Nary a Whisper of Kruger
description: A federal corruption investigation into State Senator Carl Kruger has upended politics in Brooklyn and dominated conversations across the borough. Everywhere, it seems, but at Community Board 18, in his home district.

title: Top Commodities Regulator Pleads for More Money
description: Gary Gensler, the top regulator of the derivatives industry, told lawmakers on Thursday that his agency needs more money to prevent another financial crisis.

title: Aftermath of the Punch That Went Viral
description: STANFORD, Calif.  A year after throwing the punch that rocked womens basketball, Brittney Griner is making headlines for her superlative play. Her all-around game has carried Baylor to a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Thursday means its time for our weekly guessing game. Your hint this week:

title: Ultimate Box of Jazz? Not Exactly
description: LOOK out: theres a new jazz canon coming toward you. A boxed set of six discs to be released on March 29, it emanates from the Smithsonian Institution; it is called Jazz: The Smithsonian Anthology. It surveys jazz chronologically, from its complicated beginnings to its just as complicated near-present.

title: Groupon Valuation Soars as Possible I.P.O. Nears
description: In contrast to the sea of deep discounts on its Web site, the valuation of Groupon keeps moving higher.

title: Greater Danger Lies in Spent Fuel Than in Reactors
description: Years of procrastination in deciding on long-term disposal of highly radioactive fuel rods from nuclear reactors are now coming back to haunt Japanese authorities as they try to control fires and explosions at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station.

title: MTV to Revive 120 Minutes
description: The dream of the 1990s is not alive only in Portland: its also flourishing on MTV, which on Thursday morning announced that it was resurrecting 120 Minutes, the musical showcase that introduced insomniacs (and viewers who recorded it on their VCRs and watched it the next day after school) to many memorable acts from the age of Nirvana.

title: Daily Lexeme: Wonning
description: Todays word, in association with the incredible Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Slip Away
description: These easy-on-easy-off flats will put you into the airport-security fast lane (and let you step out in style once youve landed).

title: A Look at Alaas Fall Collection
description: Coming out of the Miu Miu show on the last day of the Paris collections, I had the feeling I was connecting again with ordinary life. Energized by the early spring weather, or maybe the thought of going home, everybody had lightened up, retracted their claws. I thought about going for a drink or a manicure. Instead I went to Eric Kayser, bought my umpteenth caf au lait, and took it back to my hotel room and started a review. Around 8:30 p.m., I went to Azzedine Alaas place in the Marais.

title: Bob Marcucci, a Rock Music Idol Maker, Dies at 81
description: Bob Marcucci, who discovered Frankie Avalon and Fabian and helped make them two of the biggest rock n roll stars of the late 1950s and early 1960s and whose career inspired the 1980 film The Idolmaker, died on March 9 in Ontario, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: On Nuclear Power in a Post-Tsunami World
description: As some of you may be aware, Im barely online this week, working in Belize with a dozen Pace University communications students and their professor. While hundreds of thousands of college students are kicking back this week, this team has been sweating and hustling and videotaping their way through their spring break. They are making a documentary about an American womans 25-year adventure in trying to grow shrimp while reducing environmental impacts. You can follow their efforts on their Sustainable Shrimp blog or keep track via Twitter.com/got_shrimp.

title: Aristide Heads Home to Haiti as Election Nears
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Despite warnings from President Obama that his return could cause yet another tumultuous political development here, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the twice-exiled former president of Haiti, left his adopted home in South Africa on Thursday and headed back to Haiti.

title: High Radiation Hinders Emergency Work to Cool Nuclear Plant
description: Amid growing alarm about Japans nuclear crisis, the authorities reached for ever more desperate methods on Thursday.

title: Popcast: SXSW at 25
description: This week: Jon Pareles faces the hurlyburly of South by Southwest, and in Jazzcast, Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the new six-CD set Jazz: the Smithsonian Anthology, and the controversial function of canons in jazz. Ben Ratliff is the host.

title: Fantasy Football, Truly
description: Now that the N.F.L. owners have locked out the players, Cincinnati Bengals receiver Chad Ochocinco (n Johnson) has some time on his hands. And feet  hes currently trying out for Sporting Kansas City (n Wizards  n Wiz), a Major League Soccer team whose season starts this Saturday. Ill be taking my talents to futbol, his Web site declared.

title: Case Study | Eat This Drink
description: Though I came of age in the 1980s, I missed out completely on the whole Jell-O shot phenomenon. I, like most people, ticked it off as a vile ritual practiced by the orangey-tanned in beachfront bars, and shut the book. At the time I was trying to gain some semblance of what might pass for adult sophistication, not regression, in my drinking. Now that we all know high is low and sophistication may be disguised as pork belly sliders, I began a year or more ago considering the Jell-O shot as a Platonic concept pregnant with possibility.

title: Chief of St. Jude Medical Is Arrested
description: The chairman and chief executive of St. Jude Medical, a producer of medical devices, was detained by police officials Wednesday at the airport in New Delhi, after a live ammunition cartridge was found in his pocket, a representative for the company said.

title: Darren Aronofsky Withdraws from The Wolverine
description: The coming movie The Wolverine may appear to have an extraneous article in its title, but for the time being it lacks a director. On Thursday, Darren Aronofsky, the filmmaker responsible for Black Swan and Requiem for a Dream, said he was withdrawing from the Marvel comic-book project, which is set to star Hugh Jackman as the mutant superhero more commonly referred to as Wolverine.

title: Cuomo Hints at Possible Budget Compromise
description: ALBANY  Heeding the wishes of New York City lawmakers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Thursday that an extension of rent regulation laws should be included in the states budget  along with a cap on local property taxes.

title: Japan Offers Little Response to U.S. Assessment
description: TOKYO  A day after the top American nuclear official portrayed the situation at the troubled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in graver terms than the government in Japan, United States most important Asian ally, Japanese officials attributed the diverging accounts on Thursday to a delay in sharing information.

title: Citing Near Misses, Report Faults Both Nuclear Regulators and Operators
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which oversees the nuclear power industry in the United States, came under fire from critics on Thursday for recommending that Americans in Japan remain at least 50 miles away from the ailing Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant there.

title: A Faded Industrial Town Is Feeling Britains Cuts
description: MIDDLESBROUGH, England  It is by far the largest employer in town, accounting for one out of every two jobs. Its workers are teachers, doctors, museum curators and social workers whose salaries range from 21,000 to 210,000 a year.

title: Egypt Releases Brother of Al Qaedas No. 2
description: CAIRO  The governing military council in Egypt released the younger brother of Ayman al-Zawahri, Al Qaedas second in command, from prison on Thursday after detaining him for a decade on charges of conspiracy to overthrow the government, his lawyer said.

title: The Windscreen Wiper Wave
description: Style of waving used by celebrities who aspire to appear down-to-earth.

title: What Foods Are You Making Yourself?
description: When it comes to the complex science behind food preservation, recipes dont answer every question. In researching and writing this weeks D.I.Y. handbook, I was lucky  when the bacon looked too wet, or the kimchi appeared to be bubbling  that I was able to call up the authors and ask why. When my cheese didnt set because I used the wrong kind of rennet, Robin Mather  who keeps goats, chickens, and writes about self-sufficient living from her house in rural Michigan, diagnosed the problem. Are you thinking about trying out a D.I.Y. food project (from our guide, or elsewhere) this weekend? Send questions, concerns, and preliminary results by Monday, and Ill consult the experts.

title: Citys Next Engineering School May Be Foreign Outpost
description: The next engineering school in New York City could be a satellite campus of a university in Finland, Korea or Switzerland, judging by the responses city officials received to their call for ideas on how to raise New Yorks profile in the realm of technological innovation.

title: FriendFinder Braves Choppy Markets With I.P.O., Again
description: A wide swath of companies, from Glencore to Lagardre, are postponing long-awaited initial public offerings as the markets roil from developments in Japan and the Middle East.

title: Seeing Double
description: There is an almost clinical sobriety to the photos in Todd Eberles new book, Empire of Space (Rizzoli, $85). Culled from Eberles 30-year career and presented in pairs, the pictures force you to consider the visual kinship between disparate subjects: a Jeff Koons sculpture begins to look like a tomato; Grannys plaid sofa becomes a Frank Lloyd Wright ceiling; and an old I.B.M. computer morphs into the United Nations Secretariat tower. Eberle says that after making this book, he finds such parallels everywhere: Its incredible to have a new way of seeing the world.

title: F.D.I.C. Sues Ex-Chief of Big Bank That Failed
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation sued the former chief executive of Washington Mutual and two of his top lieutenants, accusing them of reckless lending before the 2008 collapse of what was the nations largest savings bank.

title: Theater Talkback: Spring Can Really Hang You Up The Most
description: I finally knuckled under and went to see Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark last weekend. And guess what? Im not going to say a word about it! The interminable saga of this interminable musicals long gestation, technical problems, serially delayed opening night and awesome badness has long since exhausted my interest in the topic, which was never exactly feverish to begin with. And Im sure Im not the only one suffering from Spidey-fatigue.

title: Fifth Avenue and 52nd Street, 11:57 A.M.
Report Finds Wide Abuses by Police in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  Justice Department officials on Thursday released the findings of a 10-month investigation into this citys Police Department, revealing a force that is profoundly and alarmingly troubled and setting in motion a process for its wholesale reform.

title: Japans Meltdown and the Global Economys
description: Four years ago, there were fears of a financial meltdown  a term borrowed from the nuclear power industry. Now there are fears of a real meltdown.

title: Palin Jets to India and Israel This Weekend
description: Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, leaves this weekend for a three-day trip to India and Israel.

title: Duncan: N.C.A.A. Should Stop Rewarding Schools With Poor Academic Record
description: With the mens basketball tournament as a backdrop, U.S. Education Secretary Arne Duncan renewed his call for the N.C.A.A. to impose stricter penalties on universities that do not graduate enough of their athletes.

title: Half the Salt Would Suffice, a Study Says
description: New Yorkers are eating twice as much salt as they should, mostly from prepackaged sources, according to a study released Thursday by the citys health department.

title: Insider Host Joins Good Morning America
description: Lara Spencer, the host of the entertainment newsmagazine The Insider, will join Good Morning America in the spring as that shows lifestyle anchor.

title: Bob Geldof Says Hyperdemocracy Is Overhyped
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Speaking at a festival awash in bands and bloggers, South by Southwests keynote speaker, Bob Geldof, poured cold water on Utopian thoughts of hyperdemocracy brought by the Internet.

title: Chimping and Other Photo-Taking Tips
description: Last week, for my birthday, a friend bought me an amazing gift: a private photo lesson, taught by a professional. I know a lot about photography, and Ive come a long way, but Im not a pro. Tom Bear, on the other hand, is the ultimate pro; his shots have graced many a magazine cover. And during my afternoon shooting with him, I learned a ton. I thought Id share with you some of his tips.

title: Smithsonian Plan to Remove Murals From Los Angeles Lobby Is Criticized
description: In 1949, the African-American painters Charles Alston and Hale Woodruff covered the lobby walls at a Los Angeles insurance company headquarters  a trapezoidal Moderne building designed by the African-American architect Paul Williams  with murals of early black Californians including explorers, cowboys and oil riggers. Now the original owner, the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, is being liquidated, and the Smithsonians National Museum of African American History and Culture is planning to buy the works for $750,000 and remove them from the lobby. (They have been appraised for up to $5 million.)

title: The Youth of the Mideast
description: The youth-led momentum for change stalled first in Libya, where Muammar el-Qaddafi unleashed troops on his people, and then in Bahrain, where the king enlisted Saudi Arabias help to crush demonstrations.

title: The Dilemmas of Entitlement Reform
description: Theres a bipartisan consensus that the only politically plausible path to entitlement reform requires maintaining the existing level of benefits for current retirees, and then easing the system in a more sustainable direction for the under-55 population. Politically plausible, but also obviously unfair, for the reasons David Frum suggests here:

title: Who Made Those Labels?
description: The Parisian brand Diptyque was founded in 1961 by a trio of artists: Yves Couselant (a stage designer), Christiane Gautrot (a designer) and Desmond Knox-Leet (a painter). The first shop they opened sold fabric designs and various decorative items, but by 1963, they had introduced scented candles.

title: Missing Friends
description: We are still worried about our colleagues missing in Libya: Stephen Farrell, Lynsey Addario, Anthony Shadid and Tyler Hicks. Anthony had  a wonderful piece on Iraq in the magazine just last month, while Lynseys and Tylers award-winning photography has distinguished these pages for a decade. All four colleagues have faced many dangers before. Our thoughts are with them now. Were looking forward to having them back.

title: Old Arab Ties May Harm New Ones
description: WASHINGTON  There once was no American institution more hostile to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis pariah government than the Central Intelligence Agency, which had lost its deputy Beirut station chief when Libyan intelligence operatives blew up Pan Am Flight 103 above Scotland in 1988.

title: West Virginia Advances Past Sleepy Clemson
description: TAMPA, Fla.  While Clemson was playing Tuesday night in Dayton, Ohio, to advance to Thursdays second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, West Virginia had a relaxing evening, watching the game from its hotel here.

title: Keeping Your Top House Price to Yourself
description: If youre in the market for a home, you may want to consider some advice from academics before sealing the deal. Research papers on the topic of negotiation offer numerous tips to help potential real estate buyers better navigate the process, as I recently learned when I wrote a paper for my business school negotiation class on the subject. This post is part of a series on some of the findings that I thought were worth sharing.

title: Crisis Prompts Exodus of Executives From Tokyo
description: TOKYO  The crisis at the nuclear power plant 140 miles north of here is leading to a steady but orderly departure of business executives from Tokyo. Foreigners in particular are among those leaving, as concerns grow about the possibility of a catastrophic release of radiation and governments urge their citizens to consider seeking safety elsewhere in Japan or overseas.

title: Excerpt: 'Arcadia'
description: David Turner, left, and Tom Riley in a scene from the Broadway revival of Tom Stoppard's play. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Required Viewing | Desert Flower
description: Theres one discovery story about African models so dominant that it has become legend, true or not: A young girl is born in the bush or desert; shes poor and barely educated; almost by accident she winds up in a big city, never having known running water or television or shoes; suddenly a famous photographer or agent spots her scrubbing floors at McDonalds and wham!  shes a model.

title: Interview: Tom McCarthy
description: The director Tom McCarthy discusses merging drama and comedy in his films, including his latest, "Win Win."

title: Senate Approves Stopgap Budget
description: The Senate on Thursday approved and sent to President Obama a measure that keeps the federal government open through early April, while Congressional leaders and the White House tried to strike a broader deal to fund federal agencies through Sept. 30.

title: Having Done It Before, Butler Does It Again
description: WASHINGTON  As the shot left Matt Howards right hand, kissed the backboard and dropped through the hoop and into N.C.A.A. tournament lore, the ethereal quality that embodied Butler on its run to the N.C.A.A. title game last year reappeared.

title: Economics as a Science: A Bad Example
description: Adam Ozimek weighs in on the debate over economics as a science, and argues in favor thusly:

title: Galleon Jury Hears of Tips About a Companys Sale
description: Yana Paskova for The New York TimesJohn Dowd, lawyer for Raj Rajaratnam, leaving court on Thursday.

title: House Votes to Cut Off Money for NPR
description: The House voted on Thursday to cut off funding for National Public Radio, with Democrats and Republicans fiercely divided over both the content of the bill and the manner in which it was brought to the floor.

title: Hawaii Braces for Dip in Japanese Tourists
description: Hawaii is bracing for a major drop in tourists from Japan  one of the states most important visitor markets  following the devastating earthquake, tsunami and resulting nuclear crisis in Japan.

title: Lacking Parts, G.M. Will Close Plant
description: DETROIT  General Motors said Thursday that it would temporarily shut a truck plant in Louisiana because it could not get enough Japanese-made parts, the first in what analysts say could be widespread disruptions at auto plants in North America because of the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis half a world away.

title: Democrats Set Ambitious Goals for Top Fund-Raisers
description: The nations top Democratic contributors were given an ambitious set of marching orders on Thursday, with a select group of 450 donors each asked to raise $350,000 before the end of the year.

title: George Mason Appears Ready for Villanova
description: CLEVELAND  Two days after they were reportedly injured in practice, George Mason guards Andre Cornelius and Luke Hancock took part in the Patriots public practice at Quicken Loans Arena on Thursday. Hancock wore a wrap on his left shoulder, which he injured earlier this season. Both appeared to run, jump and cut without any problems.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament Kicks Off in Full
description: If your online bracket doesnt let you select a winner for a game, then said game doesnt count.

title: Time to Focus on Sad Dads
description: Much is known about postpartum depression in women, but now researchers are calling attention to the plight of depressed fathers.

title: TimesCast | Fleeing the Nuclear Crisis
description: March 17, 2011 - Tokyo Bureau Chief Martin Fackler reports from Yamagata on the influx of people fleeing the nuclear crisis.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Tunisia, Bahrain and Iraq.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Tunisia, Bahrain and Iraq.

title: Calpers Drops Medco as Drug Manager
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System has decidednot torenewitscontract with Medco Health Solutions to manage the pharmacy benefits of its members, according to a statement by Medcoissued on Wednesday. The new contract would have started next January.

title: What New M.&A. Rules in China Could Mean
description: Changing regulation in the fast-growing market could leave international deal makers at a disadvantage, Reuters reports.

title: Simultaneous Shows, One Indoors, One Out
description: Still without a permanent home in Manhattan and with spring fast approaching, the Dia Art Foundation has cooked up a way to lure audiences to its museum on the Hudson River in Beacon, N.Y., while also paying homage to its past.

title: 36 Hours in Hong Kong
description: Hong Kongs coiffed professionals attract the worlds most inventive chefs to their city, while the nonstop shoppers get first shot at the latest in fashion and design.

title: 36 Hours in Hong Kong
description: IN Hong Kong, that most cosmopolitan of cities, contrasts abound. Ladies toting Gucci handbags wait two hours in dingy alleys for a coveted bowl of noodles. Incense-filled Buddhist temples fight for space with gleaming new high-rises. Cutting-edge art galleries share a block with junk shops. Always reinventing itself  a recent example being the rebirth of the former marine police headquarters as the 1881 Heritage, housing a luxury mall and boutique hotel  Hong Kong is a city of constant change. Its coiffed, work-hard-play-harder professionals attract the worlds most inventive chefs to their city, while the nonstop shoppers  soldiering on, late into the night  get first shot at the latest in fashion and design. Somehow, over seven million residents have managed to carve out a niche in this buzzing, compact, vertical city.

title: Staten Island Ice Cream Truck Sold Oxycodone Too, Officials Say
description: As Louis Scala drove through Staten Island in a Lickety Split ice cream truck, it was not just the children who eagerly awaited his arrival, officials said on Thursday. Mr. Scala also used the truck to sell oxycodone, a highly addictive prescription painkiller, to waiting addicts, they said.

title: Google Ventures Leads Financing of Biofuels Start-Up
description: Google Ventures has led a $20 million financing round in CoolPlanetBiofuels, a Southern California start-up that is developing mobile refineries to turn wood chips, agriculture waste and other biomass into biofuels.

title: Nuances Attached
description: I sent the following message, via Facebook, to three family members: I would like you to delete the photos of me and my young kids from your Facebook pages. I know you guys will understand. Thanks. In reply, I received a text message and voice mail, telling me that my message was cold and rude. But I wanted to be short and to the point. Could I have done a better job?

title: Quote Unquote | The Real Deal
description: Lara Stone confirms that her breasts are indeed her own. Phew.

title: A Vision, a Dream and a Block for Morehead State
description: DENVER  Sometimes the tears reveal the outcome as much as the score. When Morehead States Kenneth Faried blocked the last-second shot by Louisvilles Mike Marra and the buzzer sounded in time with the eruption of cheers from the small but mighty contingent of fans from the northeastern corner of Kentucky, there were tears. Coaches, players, fans.

title: Foreclosure Deal Could Be Delayed
description: A plan to force the nations biggest mortgage firms into helping millions of homeowners avoid foreclosure was supposed to take two months to hammer out. The timeline, it turns out, was overly optimistic.

title: Bolshoi Ballet Facing Turmoil
description: The Bolshoi Ballet, with a major tour to Paris planed for the spring and the opening of its theater set for the fall after a long renovation, is facing leadership turmoil. Its artistic director, Yuri Burlaka, left after his contract expired on Tuesday, according to Reuters, and no successor was named. Also on Tuesday, Gennady Yanin, the company director, abruptly resigned; on Wednesday, a 37-year-old Bolshoi soloist, Yan Godovsky, was named director in his place. News reports, referring to an article in the Russian daily Izvestia, said Mr. Yanin resigned after an e-mail with a link showing erotic pictures of someone who resembled him was sent to hundreds of people. Efforts to reach Mr. Yanin on Thursday were unsuccessful.

title: Wheelies: The Sibling-Rivalry Edition
description: In which we bring you automotive news from around the Web:

title: Asked & Answered | Lily Collins
description: Related: Styled to a T | Lily Collins

title: More Arrests Likely in Pedophile Raid
description: PARIS  When international police teams revealed this week what they described as the biggest online pedophile network uncovered so far, the numbers were staggering: 670 suspects, 230 rescued children and 184 arrests across 30 countries.

title: Apple or Pear? Maybe Body Shape Doesnt Matter
description: For years people who are thick around the middle (apples) have been told they are at higher risk for heart problems than those who collect weight on their hips and backsides (pears).

title: Pearl Struggles to Keep Focus
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Bruce Pearls hold on his job as Tennessees coach apparently is even more tenuous that he might have thought going into Fridays N.C.A.A. tournament second-round game against Michigan at Time Warner Cable Arena.

title: Asia Week Dealers Stress Provenance
description: Because forged antiques are a growth industry in Asia, collectors prize provenance. Dealers even report seeing fake labels with the names of prominent or fictitious past owners on objects for sale. To fend off such deceptions during Asia Week in New York, which starts on Friday, half a dozen galleries and auction houses are focusing on pieces that have belonged to well-researched and exhibited collections.

title: Wisconsin-Green Bay Women Inspired by History, Packers
description: If the women of Wisconsin-Green Bay have their way, another championship trophy will be coming home to their small metropolis. The Super Bowl-winning Packers have provided a degree of inspiration to the No. 5-seeded Phoenix. Green Bay starts its N.C.A.A. tournament road Sunday, taking on No. 12 Alabama-Little Rock (23-7), in Wichita, Kan.

title: A Simple Prescription for Superior Powers
description: Is there a cure for writers block? (And no, get a real job doesnt count.) A recent article in The New Yorker profiles a therapist who treats struggling screenwriters for hundreds of dollars an hour. For centuries, poorer scribes (which is to say most of us) have preferred to rely on rituals and folk remedies. Sharpen 10 pencils. Eat a sandwich. Pretend that the first chapter of your long-overdue opus is a casual letter to your grandmother. Weep quietly. Have another drink.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Because the Miser is almost as tired of hearing New Yorkers complain about these last lingering days of winter as she is of complaining about them herself, here are some events to provide a glimpse of hope, a light at the end of the wind tunnel that is 40th Street, a reminder that spring is on the way.

title: 'Cocktails With Orpheus'
description: Terrance Hayes reads his poem "Cocktails With Orpheus" at the Mattress Factory in Pittsburgh.

description: Around Town

title: Armed and Ready to Paint
description: JOE GIORDANO should have seen it coming. He should have noticed the evil glint in the young womans eyes. She was fixated on her ex-boyfriends smart tuxedo and innocent smile.

title: Neighborhood Joint | The Paint Spot
description: A street level shop in the Gerritsen Beach neighborhood of Brooklyn lays claim to being the only paintball supply shop in the borough.

title: Incorporating Roots and Tubers Into Risotto, Paella and Fried Rice
description: Ive been seeing a lot of roots and tubers at Manhattans farmers markets. (And pretzels, but they are not much help in planning our meals.) My wife and I have been incorporating them into our typical round of risottos, paella-style dishes and variations on fried rice.

title: Making Maple Syrup in New York State
description: If youre interested in how its really done, check out the annual Maple Weekend in Harpersfield.

description: HARPERSFIELD, N.Y.

title: Radiation Spread Seen; Frantic Repairs Go On
description: WASHINGTON  The first readings from American data-collection flights over the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in northeastern Japan show that the worst contamination has not spread beyond the 19-mile range of highest concern established by Japanese authorities.

title: Nearly Half a Million Japanese in Shelters, as Tolls Rise and Foreigners Flee
description: With the worlds attention riveted on the unfolding nuclear crisis in northeast Japan, the more immediate toll from the powerful earthquake and tsunami continued to mount on Thursday, as more deaths were confirmed, more foreigners prepared to leave the country and more of the disasters wide-reaching effects came into focus.

title: Avant-Garde Dancing Feet, Tickling Composers Minds
description: ESPECIALLY during the 20th century, many a modern composer had a prominent choreographer to thank for help in securing lasting fame: think of the role that Diaghilev and Balanchine played in Stravinskys rise, or the hand of Martha Graham in the careers of Copland, Barber, Menotti and numerous others. Add to that potent list Merce Cunningham, with his iconoclastic style and revolutionary notions.

title: Diet: Eating Fish Found to Ward Off Eye Disease
description: A new study reports yet another good reason to eat fish: women whose diet was rich in omega-3 fatty acids found in fish were at significantly lower risk of developing age-related macular degeneration.

title: Risks: Pain Drugs May Lead to Birth Defects
description: Women who take codeine, oxycodone and other opioid pain drugs early in pregnancy may be exposing their babies to a higher risk of birth defects, a new study suggests.

description: A four-bedroom house on a parklike two and a quarter acres has a new pool, meandering perennial gardens and the privacy to enjoy both.

description: TUCSON  Fran Dunphy had traveled much farther than 2,500 miles for this moment.

title: Armed and Colorful
description: Joe Giordano should have seen it coming. He should have noticed the evil glint in the young womans eyes. She was fixated on her ex-boyfriends smart tuxedo and innocent smile.

title: Group Buys Honolulu Symphonys Assets
description: Hope is alive for the revival of an orchestra in Honolulu. A group of local business people and prominent citizens paid $210,000 at auction on Thursday for the assets of the Honolulu Symphony, which declared bankruptcy in October and was forced to liquidate.

description: Pop

title: ISS to Postpone I.P.O.
description: The Danish global services company ISS announced late Thursday that it would postpone its initial public offering  the latest company to scuttle its stock plans amid the global uncertainty.

description: Classical

title: New York Aviators Reach Federal Hockey League Finals
description: The New York Aviators are preparing to face off against the Akwesasne Warriors in the finals of the first season of the Federal Hockey League, with Game 1 in Brooklyn on Saturday night.

title: Videophiles | Doug Aitkens Patterns & Repetitions: Jacques Herzog
description: There are certain things that all creative people share in common  and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitkens 2006 book Broken Screen, which featured interviews with everyone from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas, challenged the convention of the linear narrative. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetitions, the artist sits down with a whole new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. Theres LCD Soundsystems James Murphy on the sound of snow; the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown; and Jack White weighing in on Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. This week, The Moment features Jacques Herzog discussing instinct and architecture. But dont be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesnt do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

title: NBC Renews Two Thursday Comedies
description: NBC offered a vote of confidence to two of its marginally rated comedies Thursday, announcing that it will renew both Parks and Recreation and Community for another season.

description: Jazz

description: THE irony was not lost: during the year leading to her marriage to Matt Kay on March 5, Sascha Rothchild was writing a book titled How to Get Divorced by 30.

title: France Advances Investigation Into Crash of Airbus Jet That Killed 228 en Route to Paris
description: PARIS  The European plane maker Airbus said Thursday that a French judge had placed the company under formal investigation over accusations of involuntary manslaughter as part of an inquiry into the 2009 crash of an Air France jet that killed all 228 people aboard.

title: Chiles Past Is Present in the Desert
description: The Atacama Desert in northern Chile  the setting of Patricio Guzmns transfixing cinematic essay Nostalgia for the Light  is a place where heaven and earth converge. Or some might say heaven and hell.

title: Detroit News Auto Critic Resigns After Dealer Complaint Results in Changes to Review
description: Scott Burgess, the automotive critic for The Detroit News, resigned on Wednesday after a local Chrysler dealer complained about his review of the Chrysler 200  the centerpiece of the companys Imported from Detroit advertising campaign. Mr. Burgess was subsequently directed by editors to amend the online version of his story, which he did on March 11, the day after the article appeared in the print edition.

title: Movie Listings for March 18-24
description: Movies

title: TimesCast | Mood of Calm in Tokyo
description: Hiroko Tabuchi reports on the calm mood in Tokyo despite the nuclear crisis.

title: Butler Is on the Rebound
description: WASHINGTON  Butler center Andrew Smith sat on a stool in the locker room with a butterfly bandage covering a gash above his right eye. It was a reminder of how bruising and physical the No. 8-seeded Bulldogs 60-58 win over No. 9 Old Dominion had been, and that style of play was just fine with Butler.

title: Calm Down, People; He Comes in Peace
description: Extraterrestrials have been invading the big screen since 1902, when earthlings met acrobatic aliens in Georges Mliss Trip to the Moon, widely thought to be the first science-fiction film. Back then the space beings wore unitards with lobsterlike claws. The titular otherworldly creature in the genial comedy Paul (voiced by Seth Rogen) has the classic far-out look  the ponderous, bald bobble head, the big eyes and gaunt limbs  only he wears board shorts and a backpack: hes a little green dude.

title: Keeping Score: Why the Nuggets Are Winning
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Navigating in a Long-Distance Affair
description: THAT there were 1,200 miles and several states between us meant constant motion: planes, taxis, buses, trams. And a lot of sitting around waiting  in airports, for cabs, for one of us to pick up the other.

title: Pushed by Princeton, Kentucky Wins in Final Seconds
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Fifteen years ago as a junior guard at Princeton, Sydney Johnson helped pull off one of the biggest upsets in N.C.A.A. tournament history. On Thursday, as coach of the Tigers, he was nearly involved with another tournament stunner.

title: Oil Industry to Form Safety Group
description: American companies involved in offshore oil drilling are moving to set up a safety institute modeled on those established by foreign oil companies and the nuclear power and chemical industries, the American Petroleum Institute said on Thursday.

description: Following is the transcript for President Obamas speech on Japan's nuclear crisis and earthquake aftermath on Thursday, as released by the White House:

description: Theater

title: Lively Neighborhood Essential
description: TEDDY PHILLIPS and Paul Morejon believe in the try-before-you-buy philosophy. They moved often and, each time, learned something about what was important to them in a home.

title: Still in the Fight: Scars
description: This is the second in a three-part series.Before leaving McGuire Veterans Administration Hospital, after our first day of sketching two battle wounded Marines, Richard Johnson and I go by the Wounded Warrior Detachment office and thank Gunnery Sgt. Alain Frederique for setting everything up for us. The gunny says theres another Marine who would really love to participate, Lance Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter. Its pretty late in the day, and we ask if we can set up a time to meet and draw him tomorrow. The Gunny tells us no  Carpenter will be at Walter Reed all of the next day for medical appointments. Carpenters face was virtually blown off and his right arm shattered by a grenade blast and after no less than 30 surgeries in nine weeks, he wants to tell his story. We dont want to miss this opportunity.We find Lance Corporal Carpenter relaxing on his hospital rooms La-Z Boy lounger. His still-boyish face is a crazy quilt of scars. Kyle, as he prefers to be called, is resting his heavily bandaged right arm on a pillow across his lap. Both upper thighs are bandaged, and his right eye is a milky ghost of its former self.

title: Streaming Video Without the Wait
description: David Pogue reviews Zediva, a new service that offers streaming movies the same day they are released on DVD.

title: Swatches Illuminate a Painters Other Art
description: It is the rare museum exhibition that bets most of the house on fabric swatches  or, more politely, textile samples  and succeeds. This is the impressive achievement of Color Moves: Art and Fashion by Sonia Delaunay, a sumptuous and enlightening show at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum that may change forever the way you look at dry goods.

title: Form and Follow-Through
description: Today we rise up in defense of traditional values. For example, is it a good idea to have sex with somebody on the first date? Probably not. In the Journal of Family Psychology, Dean Busby, Jason Carroll and Brian Willoughby studied the effect of sexual timing on later marriage relationships. They found that couples who waited before engaging in sex for the first time went on to have higher relationship satisfaction, even after controlling for education, the number of sexual partners, religiosity and relationship length.

title: Big Continent, Much to See
description: Not so long ago Manhattans annual spring Asia Week was feeling diminished. The Asian Art Fair had folded. Gallery shows were scattered around town. Collective energy was low.

title: Anxiety on the Fault Line
description: Bye Bye Kitty!!! Between Heaven and Hell in Contemporary Japanese Art, a piquant exhibition of dark-minded work at Japan Society and a kickoff event for Asia Week, was conceived as a sharp counterweight to the cult of cuteness  kawaii  that has been Japans dominant aesthetic for decades.

title: Irving Will Play for Duke
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Duke played the entire regular season without dropping out of the top five in the Associated Press rankings, won the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament last Sunday and earned a No. 1 seed in the NCAA Tournament  mostly without the services of arguably its best player.

title: John Fitzpatrick
description: Mr. Fitzpatrick, 50, is the president of theFitzpatrick Hotel Group, North America, which owns and operates boutique hotels in Manhattan under that name. The company is celebrating its 20th year of doing business in the United States.

title: Crazy World
description: Images from a new exhibition on the work of Maira Kalman.

title: Dispatches From the Kvetchnyan Ambassador
description: In a cartoon painted in 2001 by Maira Kalman a motley assortment of people shuffle along a park roadway on a bleak winter day. Two hold a red banner announcing, Annual February Misery Day Parade; the motto What did you expect is appended below the main text. A man wears a yellow sash that says, Who cares. Paralyzed with Panic Brigade, reads a sign carried by a woman with a downcast mien. A glum man in the foreground wears a button that says, I feel rotten. It was, as you might have guessed, published in The New Yorker magazine.

title: Kenny G, the Riot Suppression Specialist
description: In an a commercial for Audi that made its premiere during the Super Bowl, Kenny G, the saxophonist whose popularity peaked in the 1990s, appears as a riot suppression specialist in a prison that resembles a country club. In the commercial and an online-only three-minute video, the premise is that Kenny G can suppress uprisings with his music because his playing quickly puts inmates to sleep.

title: Q & A
description: Succession Rights for Family Members

title: Obama Acts on a Key Vacancy at Justice
description: 7:47 p.m. | Updated President Obama on Thursday moved to fill a crucial vacancy in the Justice Department, nominating Lisa Monaco to be the next assistant attorney general for the national security division.

title: At Desolate Girls School, Diving Teacher Rules Roost
description: Mean girls will be mean girls. And under pressure, in the cloistered atmosphere of the gothically moody girls school drama Cracks, meanness can be lethal. The many echoes that crowd through the film  the flashy directorial debut of Jordan Scott (daughter of Ridley)  include Lord of the Flies, The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie, Heavenly Creatures and The Childrens Hour.

title: Bye Bye Kitty!!!
description: Images from the new exhibition at Japan Society.

title: iPad 2 Quickly Nurtures Chinese Resale Market
description: Late last year I wrote an article about Chinese men and women who were queued up outside of Apple stores in New York with the hopes of buying an iPhone 4 or an iPad.
