These devices would then be smuggled into China and resold through an underground electronics black market that islargelyfueledby the sale of Apples sleek products.

title: More Borrowers Are Opting for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages
description: IN the years since the financial crisis, adjustable-rate mortgages, or ARMs, with their low initial interest rates that changed over time, have been considered riskier than fixed-rate loans and shunned by most buyers. But these days more people are being persuaded to give the loans a try.

title: IPad Case Makers: Smart Cover Wont Kill Us
description: Gadget reviewers have been singing the praises of Apples new smart cover for the iPad 2 ever since Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, showcased them on stage two weeks ago. They are thin and colorful, clip on with magnets, double as a stand and, as I wrote last week, save us a few seconds each time we use them by turning an iPad on and off.

title: CNN Notches a Rare Prime-Time Win
description: Continuing interest in the breaking news out of Japan led CNN to a rare prime-time win over Fox News Wednesday night among the viewers most sought by news advertisers.

title: As U.N. Backs Military Action in Libya, U.S. Role Is Unclear
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council voted Thursday to authorize military action, including airstrikes against Libyan tanks and heavy artillery and a no-fly zone, a risky foreign intervention aimed at averting a bloody rout of rebels by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Bringing the Met Into the 1300s
description: Moroccan craftsmen are creating a new 14th-century courtyard in the Islamic art galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Historys Hands
description: WHEN the Metropolitan Museum of Art makes a big curatorial decision, it tends to do so with the kind of grave deliberation that goes into a papal bull. Gut feeling is not a prized consideration. But in the spring of 2009, in a dust-covered basement workshop in Fez, Morocco, a young curator in the museums Islamic department sat among a group of artisans  workers in traditional North African tile, plaster and wood ornament whose roots stretched back seven generations in the trade  and asked the companys chief executive yet again why the museum should enlist them for an unusual mission.

title: Operating on the Margins of Pay-to-Play Justice
description: What happened  did Matthew McConaughey roll out of bed one morning and decide that, after smiling through one too many schlocky movies, playing the pretty boy opposite Sandra-Kate-Jennifer, he wanted to do something decent? Not great, mind you, just solid and satisfying, a movie that asked more of him than rock-hard abs and bleachy-white teeth, one with a touch of grit, a story to chew over and maybe even a beautiful woman who looks real, something like his latest, The Lincoln Lawyer.

title: Radiation Fears and Distrust Push Thousands From Homes
description: YAMAGATA, Japan  Neither last weeks earthquake, nor the tsunami that followed, nor days without electricity, water or heat could drive 70-year-old Sadako Shiga from her home. What finally caused her to flee was something invisible, but to her mind far more sinister: radiation.

title: App Smart Extra: Earthquake Apps
description: Earthquake-related information is freely available from the Web site of the United States Geological Survey, but as is often the case with government data, its much better viewed through a mobile app.

title: Excerpt: 'Arcadia'
description: David Turner, left, and Tom Riley in a scene from the Broadway revival of Tom Stoppard's play. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Washington Post Suspends Reporter
description: The Washington Post has suspended Sari Horwitz, an investigative reporter who admitted to plagiarizing material from The Arizona Republic for articles about Jared Lee Loughner, the suspect in the shootings in Tucson in January. According to The Post, Ms. Horwitz has been suspended for three months. On Wednesday night, Ms. Horwitz issued this apology in a statement through a spokeswoman at The Post:

title: A Troupe Is an Extension of an Artists Lively Brain
description: Its perhaps not quite accurate to say that Yvonne Rainer has an official company. What she has are the Raindears, a troupe consisting of dance artists with their own distinct careers.

title: Bronts and Medea, Bent Into New Forms
description: In the repertory of Martha Graham, no consciousness reveals itself in anything so fluent as a stream. A soliloquy is seldom shaped as a steady progression of thought. Instead, contradictory impulses arrive in a startling sequence. The point often seems to be a special form of incoherence. The dancer seems stuck in one train of thought, then in a completely different one, then another. She  or, less likely, he  may reach a climax, but chances are it comes out of the blue.

title: What Lurks Under the Splashiness
description: Early in his show at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, Elton John played Madman Across the Water, and grew invested in it.

title: Nintendos 3-D Players Are on Schedule
description: Nintendos 3DS portable game player is expected to be available as planned on March 27, despite the destruction caused by Japans massive earthquake.

title: Riding the Wave of Lifes Indignities
description: There are actors who suffer nobly, with tragic and stoical reserve. Then there is Paul Giamatti. Squirrel cheeked and beetle browed, with rounded shoulders and a scratchy voice, he is a virtuoso of exasperation, a maestro of disappointment, an intrepid navigator through squalls of frustration and failure. Who else could have played John Adams, the most misunderestimated of the founding fathers, a great man and also a petty one, possessed of an outsize sense of grievance? Or Harvey Pekar, the Cleveland file clerk who wrung deadpan, misanthropic comic-book masterpieces from the grind of daily existence?

title: Private Gestural Language, Unfolding Poetically
description: About halfway through Trisha Browns Foray Fort, two men and a woman suddenly run from different corners of the stage toward the center and simultaneously jump and collide, legs splitting in the air. The woman is spun around, midflight, as if caught in a revolving door, while the men rush seamlessly offstage.

title: That Other Bach, C. P. E., Is Having His Moment
description: You have to feel a little sorry for Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach, Johann Sebastians second son. Renowned in his day  revered by Haydn and Mozart, and an influence on Beethoven  he has since been overshadowed by his father and his younger brother, Johann Christian, and even, for some listeners, by the fictional P. D. Q. Bach.

title: Palatial Homes for the Wielders of the Club
description: THE middle ages broke out all over Brooklyn around 1890, when George Ingram churned out medieval-style police stations like a ticket blitz; crenelations, spires and parapets made them redoubts of order in a changing city. But no fortification is perfect, and his two best designs are in peril.

title: Teenager Encounters Adulthood and Nazis
description: The spartan world of Martin Koolhovens sober, well-made World War II melodrama, Winter in Wartime, is a rustic blue-gray landscape of woods and snow-covered roads through which armed German soldiers roam in trucks. This handsome film, set in a village in the Nazi-occupied Netherlands and shot in Lithuania, is an adaptation of a semiautobiographical 1972 novel by the Dutch author Jan Terlouw, who lived under German occupation for five years.

title: Unpainted Paintings
description: Luxembourg & Dayan64 East 77th StreetManhattanThrough May 27

title: Borders Is Closing 28 Additional Stores
description: The bookstore chain Borders said on Thursday that it would close an additional 28 stores, on top of the 200 that it is liquidating.

title: AIPAD Photography Show New York
description: Park Avenue Armory643 Park Avenue, at 67th StreetThrough Sunday

title: Paintings by Jonas Wood
description: Anton Kern Gallery532 West 20th StreetChelseaThrough March 26

title: When Art Imitates an Actors Troubled Life
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  At least Jodie Foster seems to get how tough it will be for some to watch her new movie, The Beaver, which features amputation, mental illness and Mel Gibson, all in one swoop.

title: New Details Are Announced for Europes Bank Stress Tests
description: LONDON  Under pressure to re-examine the health of its banks, the top European banking regulator released details on Thursday about a second round of stress tests, outlining what it considered the worst-case situations for economic growth and sovereign debt losses that financial institutions might face.

title: The Caucus Podcast: The Libya Shift
description: Click to Listen

title: TimesCast | Expanding Evacuation Zones
description: March 17, 2011 - David E. Sanger reports on how new intelligence is influencing U.S. opinion on Japan's nuclear evacuation zone.

title: Sammlung Ludwig: Art of the Sixties and The Chocolate Master
description: Specific Object601 West 26th StreetChelseaThrough April 29

title: Silicon Valley Backs Effort to Help Foreign Entrepreneurs
description: A New Zealand entrepreneur seemed to have everything lined up for the start of his social networking venture in the United States. He had raised $430,000, hired 14 employees and leased an office just a few miles away from the famed Sand Hill Road in Silicon Valley.

title: The 250th St. Patricks Day Parade
description: Images of the 250th Annual St. Patricks Day parade in New York.

title: Richmond Outlasts Vanderbilt
description: DENVER  Richmond guard Kevin Anderson scored a game-high 25 points, including a clinching fadeaway basket with 18.9 seconds remaining, to lift the 12th-seeded Spiders to a 69-66 upset victory over No. 5 Vanderbilt.

title: In a Battle for Turf, Sears Revs Up the Riding Mower
description: A RETAILER struggling to fend off increasing competition is borrowing a page from the marketing playbook of products like soft drinks and soup by naming its rivals in aggressive advertising.

title: Higher Costs Dent Profit at Nike
description: Nike, the sporting goods company, reported third-quarter profit that missed analysts estimates on Thursday, the first time in 19 consecutive quarters, amid higher costs.

title: Richard Wirthlin, Pollster Who Advised Reagan, Dies at 80
description: Richard B. Wirthlin, the political consultant and pollster who for 20 years helped Ronald Reagan shape his political message and strategies, both in presidential campaigns and in the White House, died on Wednesday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 80.

title: Learning From the Crisis in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Praise and Criticism: Doling Them Out to a Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Palins Successors (Republicans Too) Seek to Dismantle Her Energy Legacy
description: JUNEAU, Alaska  While every online swipe from former Gov. Sarah Palin still draws national attention and stirs fresh speculation about her political ambitions, back home she is no longer quite so imposing.

title: Regulating Drilling: The View From Exxon Mobil
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: March 17
description: Action from across the country in the second round of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: Frankenfish Phobia
description: At a time when the shell of the earth has cracked and the ocean heaved a mortal wave upon a shore of vulnerable nuclear plants, a small miracle is playing out in the biggest river of the American West. Spring Chinook salmon, the alpinists of the maritime world, are following biological imperative and climbing their way up the Columbia to spawn and die.

title: The Forgotten Millions
description: More than three years after we entered the worst economic slump since the 1930s, a strange and disturbing thing has happened to our political discourse: Washington has lost interest in the unemployed.

title: Davies Resolved to Rebuild a Career
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Charlie Davies awakened in a daze with 25 staples down his abdomen and thought he was in a hostel in Honduras, where bandits were harvesting his organs.

title: After a Lot of Snow Fell, Just a Few Tickets for Not Cleaning It Up
description: Within days and even hours after snow falls on New York City, little pink tickets turn up by the hundreds, posted on doors in every borough. Eyes squint (the handwritten tickets are as easy to read as a doctors prescription) and then shoulders sag (the penalty: $100).

title: A Roguish Candidate Taps Haitians Discontent
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Almost anywhere else, the videos of the candidate circulating on the Internet would have spelled doom. He admits to to having regularly smoked marijuana and crack cocaine, he dances semi-nude onstage during a concert, he describes a sex act he would perform on a former president whose politics he disliked.

title: House Votes to End Money for NPR, and Senate Passes Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted Thursday to cut off financing for National Public Radio, with Democrats and Republican fiercely divided over both the content of the bill and how it was brought to the floor.

title: 31 Are Accused of Conspiracy to Traffic in Oxycodone
description: From an ice cream truck on Staten Island named Lickety Split, Louis Scala II offered the usual array of frozen treats. But one of the more popular items was not on the menu: He also sold oxycodone, the highly addictive prescription painkiller, prosecutors said Thursday.

title: Remembering Is Motivation for Kansas
description: TULSA, Okla.  Oklahoma in March is mayhem for Kansas. The Jayhawks should not feel comfortable here when the weather starts to turn warm.

title: Modest Senior Gives Butler Special Moment
description: WASHINGTON

title: U.S. Agency Ends Accounting Firms Afghan Contract
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American government has terminated its contract with an international accounting firm that was providing technical advice to the Afghan banking system here because of the firms failure to report signs of trouble at Kabul Bank, the nations largest financial institution.

title: $350,000 Goal Is Set For Re-election Donors
description: WASHINGTON  The top contributors to President Obamas re-election campaign were given an ambitious set of marching orders on Thursday, with an elite group of 450 donors each asked to raise $350,000 this year to help finance what is likely to be the most expensive political race in the nations history.

title: In Obama Visit, Brazils Leader Aims to Mend Fences
description: BRASLIA  Two years ago, President Obama energetically reached out in London to shake the hand of Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, who was then the president of Brazil. Heres my man, right here, Mr. Obama said. I love this guy. Hes the most popular politician on earth.

title: Group of 7 to Intervene to Stabilize Yens Value
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and other major industrial nations will join Japan in a highly unusual effort to stabilize the value of the yen by intervening in currency markets, the Group of 7 nations announced Thursday night.

title: Interests of Saudi Arabia and Iran Collide, With the U.S. in the Middle
description: WASHINGTON  The brutal crackdown in Bahrain poses the greatest Middle East democracy dilemma yet to the Obama administration, deepening a rift with its most important Arab ally, Saudi Arabia, while potentially strengthening the influence of its biggest nemesis, Iran.

title: Funds Find Opportunities in Volatility
description: For Jason Adler, it doesnt matter whether the market goes up. Or down. What matters is that it goes.

title: A Yen Position for Speculators
description: Is it time to reboot the yen carry trade? The Japanese currency is at historic highs, with most logic pointing toward depreciation. That makes the trade that involves borrowing cheaply in yen and investing elsewhere look interesting  but volatility makes it perilous.

title: Looking Ahead to Fridays Games
description: East

title: Vonn Foiled in Chance to Pad Lead
description: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland  Lindsey Vonns quest for a fourth overall World Cup title became more challenging after the cancellation of Thursdays final super-G of the season as a result of fog, rain and wet snow.

title: Bullets Stall Youthful Push for Arab Spring
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  These days, Muhammad al-Maskati is a prisoner in his apartment, his BlackBerry shut off by the government, the streets outside his apartment filled with tanks, the hospitals around town packed with the wounded.

title: The Youth of the Mideast
description: Protests sweeping the Middle East were propelled by young people free of the fear that held back their parents. The young remain out front, wielding the online tools they grew up with to mobilize protests, elude surveillance, and cross class lines.

title: Doubts on Mayors Forecast of 4,600 Teacher Layoffs
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been warning that 4,600 city teachers will receive pink slips this spring, as he pushes for legislation in Albany that would eliminate rules requiring that layoffs be based solely on seniority.

title: Morocco: The Youth Rise Up
description: An inside look at Morocco's youth-led revolt, where a group of activists, formed on Facebook, organize nationwide protests demanding democracy.

title: Social Science Palooza II
description: The nice thing about being human is that you never need to feel lonely. Human beings are engaged every second in all sorts of silent conversations  with the living and the dead, the near and the far.

title: Plastic: Too Good to Throw Away
description: San Francisco

title: Early Questions After Japan
description: As Japans nuclear crisis unfolds, nations around the world are looking at the safety of their nuclear reactors  as they should. But most are also waiting until all the facts are in before deciding whether or how to change their nuclear plans. The Obama administration has vowed to learn from the Japanese experience and incorporate new safety approaches if needed.

title: Twitter? Mayors Gaffes Come the Old-Fashioned Way
description: Even by his own standards of verbal inelegance, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has committed more gaffes of late than would seem absolutely necessary. But lets look on the bright side. At least he doesnt tweet.

title: Indonesia to Continue Plans for Nuclear Power
description: JAKARTA  While the world looks on with trepidation at the nuclear crisis touched off by the earthquake and tsunami in Japan, officials in Indonesia, one of the worlds most seismically active countries, are pushing ahead with plans to build the countrys first nuclear power plants.

title: A Threadbare Time, and a Rug to Match
description: HAVERHILL, Mass.  Budget dramas are engulfing cities everywhere, but this may be the only one in the country where the most contentious spending proposal involves a rug.

title: Ex-Racehorses Starve as Charity Fails in Mission to Care for Them
description: One of the largest private organizations in the world dedicated to caring for former racehorses has been so slow or delinquent in paying for the upkeep of the more than 1,000 horses under its care that scores have wound up starved and neglected, some fatally, according to interviews and inspection reports.

title: To Medicate, or Not to Medicate?
description: Mama tries to meditate every morning. But her cellphone is always ringing. And before you know it, her young son, Jesse, is awake  and Jesse demands a lot of attention.

title: Homer Simpson Need Not Apply
description: Hong Kong

title: With U.S. Nuclear Plants Under Scrutiny, Too, a Report Raises Safety Concerns
description: With Japans nuclear industry facing intense scrutiny after the devastating earthquake and tsunami, critics of nuclear power in the United States are increasingly shining a spotlight on American regulators and power companies.

title: Universities Will Compete to Build a Campus on City Land
description: The next engineering school in New York City could be a satellite campus of a university in Finland, South Korea or California, judging by the responses city officials received to their call for ideas on how to raise New Yorks profile in the realm of technological innovation.

title: Disaster May Deal Blow to Tourism in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU  Even before Japan was hit by an earthquake and a tsunami, Hawaii had been struggling with a budget shortfall that seemed suffocating for a state this small: close to $1 billion over two years.

title: Goodell Urges Players to Push for More Talks
description: In a letter sent directly to every N.F.L. player Thursday, Commissioner Roger Goodell asks the players to press their leaders  he still refers to their group as a union, although it decertified last week  to return to negotiations. The sides are not expected to meet until at least after a April 6 hearing in federal court in Minneapolis on the players request for an injunction to lift the lockout imposed.

title: The Foreign War Panacea
description: On the morning of March 18, 1861, a bemused crowd shuffled through the narrow streets within the walls of old Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic. Proclamations plastered throughout the city had ordered the people to assemble in the Cathedral Plaza, where rumors circulated about a Spanish takeover and the return of slavery.

title: Bloomberg Tries to Make Amends for a Joke, but a Cloud Trails Him
description: It was just before 8 a.m. on Thursday when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took the lectern at Gracie Mansion to address a capacity crowd. He wasted no time in getting to the days most pressing issue:

title: Complaints of Abuse in Army Custody
description: CAIRO, Egypt  Ragy el-Kashef was relieved when Egypts military took power last month and pledged to steer the country from dictatorship to democracy. But after he spent four days in army custody, during which he says he was arrested, tortured and hastily tried before a military judge, anxiety and dread now cloud his hope for the future.

title: For Radiation, the Alarm Bells Are Boxes
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The radiation monitor works unobtrusively here on a tiny strip of fenced-off land just behind a schoolyard on a dead-end street. The machine that regularly sniffs the air, measuring whether radioactive fallout from Japan has reached Southern California, is a gray box, about three feet high and two feet wide.

title: A Pay-for-Performance Evolution
description: Every discussion about foreign aid is a heated discussion. Readers of Tuesdays column on a new idea for foreign aid  paying for outcomes instead of providing money in advance  had plenty of suggestions about how to fix foreign aid (or why to abandon it). But before we get to them, we should make sure we know what were talking about when we say foreign aid. It would be better if the citizens understood that foreign aid is a misnomer, wrote Millie Bea of Washington (25).

title: Pitt Hopes to Leave Disappointment in the Past
description: Over the past decade, Pittsburgh has been a model of consistency in the Big East. The Panthers have made the N.C.A.A. tournament in all eight of Coach Jamie Dixons seasons, with a record of 98-38 in Big East play. But in the first seven of those tournament appearances, Pitt, despite several high seeds, has gotten as far as the Round of 8 just once.

title: Cuban Exiles Jury May See Secret Fax
description: EL PASO  A federal judge ruled Thursday that a secret fax, which a witness said was written by an anti-Castro militant and links him to a campaign of bombings in Havana in 1997, can be viewed by jurors at his perjury trial.

title: Easy Fixes at Reactors in Long Run Are Elusive
description: As operators at a Japanese nuclear power station face weeks or months of crisis management to bring several stricken reactors under control, entombing the plant in concrete and steel, as was done after the Chernobyl accident, is not an immediate option for halting further releases of radiation, experts said on Thursday.

title: Florida Attracts 2.8 Million Over Decade
description: MIAMI  Overcoming the effects of high unemployment and a crashed housing market, Florida attracted 2.8 million new residents in the last decade, according to census data released Thursday.

title: With Blues for Sale, Checketts Admits the Dodgers (Not Mets) Intrigue Him
description: Now that Dave Checketts is selling the St. Louis Blues, is he interested in buying the Mets?

title: A Volatile Week Ends Higher on Wall Street
description: Stocks closed out a bumpy week with a modest rally on Friday, jumping after the announcement of a cease-fire in Libya and a move by global leaders to intervene in the currency markets and stabilize the Japanese yen, which had soared to near record highs in recent days.

title: Chernobyl Study Says Health Risks Linger
description: Nearly 25 years after the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine, children and teenagers who drank contaminated milk or ate affected cheese in the days and weeks after the explosion still suffer from an increased risk of thyroid cancer, according to a study released Thursday by the National Cancer Institute.

title: New York Suspends Licenses of Bus Driver in Bronx Crash
description: New York State suspended the driving privileges of the driver of the casino bus that crashed in the Bronx last weekend, killing 15 passengers, after investigators learned that he had made false statements on his drivers license applications, a state official said Thursday.

title: Interfaith Initiative Formed for Colleges
description: The White House on Thursday announced a new initiative to encourage college students of different religions to collaborate on yearlong community service projects, like building homes or tutoring children. President Obama will send a letter to thousands of college presidents urging them to undertake what he calls The Presidents Interfaith and Community Service Campus Challenge during the 2011-12 academic year. He said in a video announcement that the purpose is to encourage cooperation among students of diverse religious beliefs  as well as non-believers. The initiative, which has no discrete government financing, was announced by the White House faith-based office and the Corporation for National and Community Service.

title: The U.C.L.A. Video
description: Alexandra Wallace is the student at the University of California, Los Angeles, who made the three-minute video seen by millions of people on YouTube in which she disparages Asian students for using cellphones in the library to call family members after the tsunami struck Japan.

title: Amazon v. the States
description: It never made sense to exempt online retailers from collecting sales tax. Its ridiculous now when so many states are in deep fiscal trouble. Illinois estimates that it is losing more than $150 million a year in uncollected taxes; California is losing an estimated $300 million a year. That would cover more than half the planned cuts for the University of California system.

title: Horrors in Ivory Coast
description: In Ivory Coast, an autocrats desperate bid to hang on to power has led to unspeakable atrocities and hundreds of deaths. Hundreds of thousands of people have been driven from their homes. The international community must move quickly to halt this terror.

title: With Federal Case and Modular Building Plan, New Attention for Atlantic Yards Project
description: The Atlantic Yards project began with much fanfare in December 2003, when the developer Bruce C. Ratner unveiled his plans at a pep rally at Brooklyn Borough Hall: an exotic basketball arena and a sprawling residential development that would provide affordable housing, jobs and community development.

title: Friday: Part of an Ancient Procession
description: The New York Times apologizes if you are having problems accessing the crossword puzzle. If you had a subscription through the old Times Reader system, please try logging out and then logging in again. If that does not work, please do NOT leave a comment on this blog or send e-mail to me, as I will not be able to assist you. Instead, please click on the Member Center, then Online Paid Products and click through to Contact Us/NYTimes.com to contact Customer Care. Alternatively, you may call Customer Service at (800) 591-9233 Mon.Fri. 5 a.m.midnight E.T. and Sat.Sun. 5 a.m.5 p.m. E.T. Thank you for your patience.

title: The 180-Year Itch, Metaphysically Speaking
description: A suspicion lingers in the heart of the constant theatergoer that if you are too clever, then you must be made of ice. This prejudice has misguidedly dogged, among others, that greatest of songwriters, Stephen Sondheim, like a peevish, affection-starved beagle. But it has never clung to anyone more tenaciously and erroneously than it does to the playwright Tom Stoppard.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 17, 2011

title: Man Is Person of Interest in Wifes Death
description: After the body of a missing Bronx woman was found in a wooded area of Westchester County on Wednesday evening, police officials a day later characterized her husband, a former police officer, as a person of interest in the womans death.

title: Muslim Cultural Center Appears Near Approval
description: A long battle over a proposed mosque in DuPage County is approaching a turning point, and although anti-Muslim sentiment and resistance to mosques in the Chicago area are hardly going away, Muslims appear to be winning this time.

title: Gardner Replaces Jeter in Leadoff Spot
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi moved Derek Jeter down in the batting order to the second spot while shifting the speedy Brett Gardner to the leadoff position against Tampa Bay on Thursday night.

title: SecurID Company Suffers a Breach of Data Security
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The RSA Security division of the EMC Corporation said Thursday that it had suffered a sophisticated data breach, potentially compromising computer security products widely used by corporations and governments.

title: Relying on Fredette Even More, B.Y.U. Wins
description: DENVER  Before an N.C.A.A. tournament crowd that either cheered for Jimmer Fredette or simply wanted to experience Jimmermania firsthand, Fredette, the nations leading scorer, did not dazzle or disappoint.

title: Study Undercuts View of College as a Place of Same-Sex Experimentation
description: The popular stereotype of college campuses as a hive of same-sex experimentation for young women may be all wrong.

title: Girardi Tries Gardner at Leadoff, With Jeter Second
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi moved Derek Jeter down in the batting order to the second spot while shifting the speedy Brett Gardner to the leadoff position Thursday against Tampa Bay.

title: 100-Day Spotlight Shines on Preckwinkle
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: At Rocknes School, a Different Sport Thrives
description: Notre Dame, where Knute Rockne invented college football and Ara Parseghian perfected it, has become a basketball school.

title: Defense? The Knicks Hit a Record 20 3-Pointers
description: The glaring deficiencies will not be eliminated anytime soon, nor forgotten with a single victory or a record-setting shooting display. But for one night, the only noteworthy glare at Madison Square Garden came from Toney Douglass shiny feet.

title: The Pulse: Accolades for Disclosure, but None for Chicago
description: Sunshine Reviews annual awards for transparency in government Web sites were given this week to 112 state and local governments nationwide  none of which were in Chicago.

title: The Pulse: Quinn Vetoes Plan to Build Pair of Coal-to-Gas Plants
description: Gov. Pat Quinn vetoed legislation Monday that would have allowed coal gasification plants to be built on the Southeast Side of Chicago and in Southern Illinois. Our investments in clean coal must not come at the expense of consumers, said Mr. Quinn, echoing critics who said the Chicago measure would result in an increase in gas bills by requiring that utilities buy substitute natural gas at a fixed rate for 30 years from a subsidiary of the Leucadia National Corporation, which wanted to build the Chicago plant.

title: Surging Nets Are Handed a Setback by the Bulls
description: NEWARK  The Nets use a locker room across the hall from a much bigger room that the Devils use to dress for their games at Prudential Center. But that does not mean the Nets have been inspired by  or even paid any attention to  the Devils amazing surge.

title: Washington Celebrates St Patrick's Day
description: Images from Doug Mills, a New York Times photographer in Washington.

title: S.R.O. Hotel Managers Question Their Obligations to the Police
description: When Virgilio Candari bought the Luz Hotel in the Tenderloin district of San Francisco in 2004, he replaced the dirty mattresses, painted the walls and increased the rates.

title: Out of Gas? Huskies Apparently Refueled
description: WASHINGTON  After it barnstormed the Big East Conference tournament by winning five games in five days, it seemed the only team that could slow Connecticut at the start of the N.C.A.A. tournament was Connecticut.

title: For Unconventional Music, Build a New Orchestra
description: Dont look for conventional signs of music making in the West Oakland workshop of Paul Dresher, a composer. The piano has been covered to protect it from dust. A broken drum set sits in a corner.

title: Tressel Requests Five-Game Suspension
description: The Ohio State football season, already tenuous with the suspension of five players and Coach Jim Tressel being investigated by the N.C.A.A., appeared even more dire Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: THE ARTS

title: Sunshine Ordinance, Now 17 Years Old, Still Has Baby Teeth
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Video: Green at the White House
description: Doug Mills, a photographer for The New York Times, captured the scene on Thursday as President Obama celebrated St. Patricks Day at the White House and across town at the Capitol building.

title: Bay Cities Are Courting Berkeley Lab
description: The quest by Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory to find a site for a second campus has prompted cities around the East Bay to go to great lengths to outshine one another.

title: San Antonio Takes Lead in Land Conservation
description: HONDO  From Marcy G. Rothes hillside home, she can see oaks and grasses and a creek bed spread out, looking much the same as when her grandfather first arrived here in the 1920s. In June, she sold a conservation easement on her land to the City of San Antonio to prevent development that would harm the aquifer below  and also to ensure that her nearly 2,000 acres remained undisturbed for her descendants.

title: Motherland, the Debut of Doris Yeung
description: Doris Yeungs slow and slight debut feature, Motherland, combines a downbeat immigrant-family story with the bare bones of a murder mystery. Both plot strands are so vague and attenuated, however, that the film plays like an artsy short stretched to 93 minutes.

title: Trying Not to Get Wet With the Rainy Day Fund
description: Texas legislators have to choose between mobs.

title: Plan to Merge Agencies on Jails, Police and Firefighters Concerns Safety Officials
description: A money-saving proposal to combine state agencies that oversee police and firefighter training and local jail operations has public safety officials statewide worried about their future.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Desert Flower Tells Story of Waris Dirie
description: Desert Flower, a well-made film that depicts the remarkable life of the model Waris Dirie, manages to be both a classic feel-good story and about as far from a feel-good story as you can get.

title: Eliot Spitzers TV Days
description: Youve written critically about President Obamas Libya strategy, as well as his inability to harness the anger that fueled the Tea Party. Do you fantasize about being president of the United States?  I dont talk to journalists about what I fantasize about.

title: 0s and 1s, by Eugene Kotlyarenko
description: Eugene Kotlyarenkos 0s and 1s may be the ultimate has-to-be-seen-more-than-once movie. Not because its great, particularly, but because so much is disgorged onto the screen so quickly that no one will be able to catch all the witty tricks and asides with one viewing.

title: Vanderbilt Fades Away, Falling to Underdog Specialist Richmond
description: DENVER  Richmond guard Kevin Anderson listed his height as shoes on, 6 foot, but that did not stop him from playing the biggest role in his teams upset victory over Vanderbilt on Thursday.

title: Story of a Jewish Boy
description: Immersed in the alien beauty of the Kazakh steppe, The Gift to Stalin moves slowly but engages thoroughly. Set in 1949, just before Stalins 70th-birthday jubilee, the film centers on Sasha (Dalen Shintemirov), a 9-year-old boy who escapes from a train transporting Jewish refugees from Moscow to Kazakhstan.

title: After Benching, a King of Memphis Regains His Form
description: TULSA, Okla.  The e-mails, teeming with venom, rolled into Josh Pastners in-box. Most of them started the same way.

title: Bereavement by Stevan Mena
description: Bereavement is the third feature by the independent filmmaker Stevan Mena, a writer and director whose underground oeuvre is rounded out by the titles Malevolence and Brutal Massacre.

title: Born to Be a Trail Runner
description: Last November, I was on my way to the New York City marathon when I got word that my father had two clots on his brain and needed emergency surgery. My family urged me to go ahead and run anyway.

title: Word of the Day | aviary
description: aviary \a-ve-er-e, -e-re\ noun

title: The Music Never Stopped, by Jim Kohlberg
description: The title of The Music Never Stopped might suggest an almost forgotten 70s disco musical with Bruce Jenner, but the film is actually an unabashed pitch to geriatric flower children.

title: Mets Second Basemen Play All Over the Infield
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  It wasnt exactly a St. Patricks Day parade, but Mets Manager Terry Collins did march four of his five second-base candidates into Thursdays game against the Boston Red Sox as he apparently tried to speed up a competition that has no clear front-runner.

title: The Butcher, the Chef and the Swordsman
description: The Butcher, the Chef and the Swordsman, a dizzying period pop extravaganza from China, explodes with brio. Directed by Wuershan, a veteran of commercials who is making his feature debut, the film ricochets in a breakneck delirium from ham-fisted comedy to solemn revenge drama to antic martial-arts thriller, a crazy quilt of energy and style.

title: Michael Gough, Known as Butler in Batman, Dies at 94
description: Michael Gough, the lithe, angular-faced British character actor best known for his role as Alfred Pennyworth, Bruce Waynes trusted butler, in four Batman movies, died on Thursday at his home in England. He was 94.

title: Velvet-Voiced Ferlin Husky Dies at 85
description: Ferlin Husky, the smooth-voiced singer whose 1956 hit  Gone became the first country single of the Nashville Sound era to cross over to the pop Top 10, died on Thursday at his home in Hendersonville, Tenn. He was 85.

title: I Am by the Director Tom Shadyac
description: Whats wrong with the world? What can we do about it? You might not expect these questions to haunt the mind of the director of Ace Ventura: Pet Detective and The Nutty Professor. But in the painful aftermath of a cycling accident, Tom Shadyac started to think differently about his life and success. And he started asking questions.

title: Buoyed by Memory of His Mother, Indiana State Guard Plays On
description: CLEVELAND  A few days after Indiana State won the Missouri Valley Conference tournament to earn its first N.C.A.A. bid in a decade, Jake Kelly, a senior guard, drove out to Marshall, Ill., to visit the grave of his mother, Julia. Kelly intended to lay his M.V.C. championship T-shirt at the site, but something told him to hold off.

title: St. Johns Is Back, but Its Gone This Year
description: DENVER  St. Johns came looking for more than its first N.C.A.A. tournament victory in 11 years. The once-proud basketball power was looking to slingshot into a new era, one filled with the type of memorable postseason moments that were once standard in Queens.

title: Kansas State Takes Care of Utah State
description: TUCSON  The age-old practice of feigning disrespect is an annual affair in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Seedings do not always match self-images. Rankled young men vow revenge. It is as much a part of the events tradition as pompoms and buzzer-beaters.

title: For Now, Duke Ignores Documentary
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  As Duke begins its defense of the N.C.A.A. tournament title, Coach Mike Krzyzewski has chosen not to defend the Blue Devils recruiting practices amid accusations that his program discriminates against some African-Americans.

title: News Quiz | March 18, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Japan Continues Efforts to Cool Nuclear Fuel
description: Readings indicate that the worst contamination around the Fukushima nuclear plant has not spread beyond the 19-mile range of highest concern established by Japanese authorities.

title: Japan Races to Restart Reactors Cooling System
description: This article is by  Ken Belson,  Hiroko Tabuchi and  Keith Bradsher.

title: Corrections
description: THE ARTS

title: Test Yourself | History, March 18, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about the 2008 presidential race.

title: Kids + Tech = Summer Fun
description: WHO founded the first technology summer camp, and WHEN was it founded?

title: General Mills Nears $1.1 Billion Deal to Buy Half of Yoplait
description: 6:11 p.m. | Updated

title: What Do You Think of an SAT Essay Question About Reality TV?
description: Some versions of the SAT test given last week contained an essay prompt asking students to write about reality television. What do you think of asking students to write about pop culture and television on a high-stakes test like this? Why?

title: A Muse Named Patti Smith
description: We were two girls with no one to please, Patti Smith recalled.

title: Obama Warns Libya, but Attacks Go On
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday ordered Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to carry out an immediate cease-fire, withdraw his forces from rebel-held cities and stop all attacks on Libyan civilians or face military action from the United States and its allies in Europe and the Arab world.

title: Daily Lexeme: Amapakati
description: Todays word, in association with the glorious Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Risks, Radiation and Regulation
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: The Early Word: Driving the Wedge Deeper
description: From Todays Times:

title: Solar E.V. Charging Arrives in Brooklyn and Eyes Suburbia
description: Solar entrepreneurs, corporations and municipalities are bullish on electric-vehicle charging with renewable energy, especially because many grids offer a variable  and, often, carbon-emitting  mix of power sources. The concept is gaining traction both in cities and the suburbs.

title: A Guide to Hong Kongs Wet Markets
description: When it comes to food, Hong Kongers value freshness, so it should be no surprise that many neighborhoods have an outdoor market, known as wet markets, where the produce, meat and seafood  usually from mainland China or the New Territories in Hong Kong  is often of better quality and cheaper than what is sold in the supermarkets.

title: Fantasy Focus: Catchers to Consider
description: While closers are easily the most unpredictable aspect of fantasy baseball, catchers also provide quite a bit of variance because of the grueling nature of the position, but that can be mitigated by league specifics. Ive already stated why I think catchers should be mostly ignored in deep only leagues, which may seem counterintuitive. In reality, the scarcest position actually matters most in the shallowest league. That is, the higher the replacement value, the tougher it becomes to gain an advantage per specific position.

title: 2010 Detroit Lions: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis.

title: Found Poetry on the Internet
description: Recently, while pinballing mindlessly between sites on the Internet, I happened mistakenly on a site-in-progress. The site itself seemed to be a personal Web page, not yet completed. But the following greeting was posted, along with a hint as to its future contents (reprinted here with minor spelling corrections):

title: Tip of the Week: Compressing PowerPoint Photos
description: If your picture-laden Microsoft PowerPoint presentation is getting too huge, you can whittle it down by reducing the size of the photos used in the file. If you do not want to use a photo-editing program to reduce each photos size and resolution before inserting them back into the file, recent versions of PowerPoint can compress the images right in the file.

title: Capitalizing on South by Southwests Credibility
description: I spent a strange hour Wednesday night at one of the many events piggybacking on SXSW: the Woodie Awards show presented by MTVu, the college music cable channel of MTV Networks. It was the first one presented outside of New York City, apparentlylike the many other corporate brands promoting themselves at SXSW  to capitalize on the festivals indie, do-it-yourself credibility. (Some of the festivals badge-holders got tickets.) I was there to see an early appearance by Odd Future Wolf Gang Kill Them All, the wild-eyed teenage hip-hop collective thats the talk of SXSW.

title: Giving Shakespeare His Sombrero and Kazoo
description: Propeller, the all-male British theater troupe that routinely turns Shakespeare into a donnybrook, has never hesitated to hit below the belt. Or above it, or behind it, or right in the buckle. But it has surely never landed as many blows as it does in its relentlessly punch-drunk production of The Comedy of Errors, which runs through March 27 at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Republicans Find More to Cut From the S.B.A. Budget
description: In April, House Republicans plan to lay out the broad outlines of their budget to fund the federal government for 2012, but this week the chairman of the House Small Business Committee revealed his spending priorities for the Small Business Administration. While President Obama proposed to save $28 million in his budget by cutting or eliminating a handful of programs, Representative Sam Graves, Republican of Missouri, declared that the presidents cuts did not go far enough. He recommended cutting an additional $100 million.

title: Why Do Animals Sleep?
description: Bryson Voirin, a doctoral student at the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology in Germany and a fellow at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, writes from Panama, where he is studying sleep in wild frigate birds.

title: The American Near-Fukushima
description: I had the honor of lunching on Wednesday with Gary Hart, the former Colorado senator, who is both a seriously insightful political observer and a central character in my next book. (More on that when I actually get around to writing the thing.) Senator Hart reminded me that, as chairman of a Senate subcommittee on nuclear regulation in 1979, he led an investigation into the near-disaster at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant. He told me we were much closer to a Fukushima in this country than most Americans ever realized. (I dont know about you, but I was 10 at the time, and my only real memory of that moment is of Dan Akroyd dressed up as a giant, irradiated Jimmy Carter on Saturday Night Live, peering into high-rises like King Kong.)

title: Complaint Box | Noisy Diners
description: I used to love eating out; I dont anymore. Even though the smokers have been moved outside and the food is more likely to be from some local, free-range, organic farm, and I can finally afford the better places, I would rather stay home  because I am tired of the noise.

title: Is Amazon Working on an Android Kindle?
description: Amazon has been incrediblysuccessful with its Kindle e-reader, offering a lightweight reader at an affordable price. Butthe pizazz of the iPad 2 and the dozens of Android-based tablets that are slowly making their way off of conveyor belts and onto store shelves is rekindling a number ofunansweredquestions about the next generation of Amazons e-reader.

title: Former Wal-Mart Chief to Leave Goldman Board
description: Another Goldman Sachs director is stepping down.

title: Queer Classic
description: A gay cult film re-emerges, along with its director, James Bidgood.

title: A Few Tax Tips for the Elderly
description: With the tax-filing deadline bearing down, many of us are wrestling with financial issues particular to elder care. Opportunities to lower tax bills abound, thank goodness, but the details are often complicated or confusing  and most seniors cant afford to leave money on the table. Here are a few details to keep in mind this year.

title: Food, Fuel and Medicine Run Short in Shelters
description: TOKYO  One week after a devastating earthquake and tsunami struck Japans northeastern coast, the country was still grappling Friday with the difficult logistics of attending to half a million people in evacuation shelters running low on food, fuel and medicine.

title: Dozens of Protesters Are Killed in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemens pro-democracy protests exploded into violence on Friday, as government supporters opened fire on demonstrators in this capital, killing at least 45 people and wounding more than 200. The bloodshed failed to disperse the angry throng of tens of thousands of protesters, the largest seen so far in a month of demonstrations calling for the ouster of President Ali Abdullah Saleh.

title: Athletes Come to Aid of Japan
description: They had just moved back to Britain from Japan, and for several days, the British marathon star Mara Yamauchi and her Japanese husband watched coverage of the developing catastrophe and felt moved beyond words, yet powerless.

title: NPR Vote One of Many Distractions to Come
description: The vote by House Republicans Thursday to strip National Public Radio of much of its federal funding is an early example of the ways in which narrow issues are likely to repeatedly distract lawmakers during the 2012 election season.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Breeden to Step Down as Chairman of H&R Block
description: Richard Breeden, an activist investor, announced on Thursday that he would step down as chairman of H&R Block  calling his effort at the tax preparer mission accomplished.

title: Qaddafi Son Says Libya Will Release 4 Journalists
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Four New York Times journalists missing in Libya since Tuesday were captured by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and will be released, the Libyan leaders son Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi told Christiane Amanpour in an ABC News interview early Friday.

title: Credibility and Monetary Policy in a Liquidity Trap (Wonkish)
description: Via Mark Thoma, Mankiw and Weinzierl have a paper (pdf) arguing that fiscal expansion shouldnt be the tool of choice even at the zero lower bound; that monetary policy can still work if you can credibly make commitments about future monetary policy.

title: Morning Buzz | 8 Million People, 4 Snow-Removal Tickets
description: Weather: disorientingly and almost inappropriately delightful Friday, with a high around 70. Back to normal for the weekend, which is still pretty good  sunny with highs in the low 50s.

title: March 18 Updates on Libya and Arab Uprisings
description: On Friday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from journalists and bloggers in the region.

title: Five-Ku: Short Poems on the Films of Matt Damon
description: Your Good Will Hunting'Twas a masterpiece. Its true:We liked them apples.

title: Boris Bikes Roll in London
description: Sitting astride a big, gray bicycle at the head of a long line of traffic on City Road last month, I studied the 20 or more other cyclists who were  with varying degrees of skill and impatience  crossing the intersection on a red light. Some were swerving among startled and cursing pedestrians, bells ringing; others had expertly timed a slalom between four lanes of cars. What all these cyclists shared, however, was a sense of liberating entitlement. For more than half a century, Londons historical tangle of streets has been owned by cars and vans and double-decker buses and black cabs. Not anymore.

title: Our Imperfect Search for Perfection
description: So, its the late fourth century, and youre a British monk named Pelagius. You travel to Rome and are appalled by the low moral standards of the place. Maybe youre stuffy, but you attribute the general air of laxity to Augustine, who believes man can attain perfection only through divine grace, not human effort. This just sounds to you like an excuse not to try. You believe free will means that we are free to make good choices  and that we should be severely punished if we dont. So you track down Augustine in North Africa, where he tells you to take it easy. A guy can strive for perfection but can do only so much. Besides, its the effort that counts. But, of course, the argument doesnt end there.

title: Mysterious Justice
description: Five years into his tenure, Justice Samuel Alito is the one conservative on the Supreme Court without a flashy legal signature. We know what to expect from the other justices on the courts reliable right: Antonin Scalia has his constitutional theory of originalism, often in the company of Clarence Thomas. Chief Justice John Roberts also tends to lead with big legal principles. Alito usually reaches the same results as the others, but he does it by being small-bore. Hes the offensive linesman on the team, a clerk who worked for Alito when he was a federal judge says. He puts his head down and stays focused on the case in front of him.

title: A Gay Cult Classic Re-Emerges
description: Its like I survived a train wreck and everybody else died and my name is associated with that disaster, says James Bidgood of his first and last film, Pink Narcissus, a 1971 erotic fantasia that contrasts a hustlers satin reveries with sordid reality. On March 21, it will be shown at the IFC Center in New York as part of Queer/Art/Film. Bidgood, 77, is debating whether or not to go. I cant look at it.

title: Giving Back
description: My mother died at 92, several weeks ago. Saturdays mail included a gift intended for her from an old friend whom she worked for 25 years ago. I had not notified the friend of my mothers death because I didnt have his contact information until the gift arrived bearing his return address. I have since written a short letter telling him about my mothers death. Heres the question: should I also send the gift back to him? DAVID BOMSE, SANTA FE, N.M.

title: The Last Townie
description: In a driving snowstorm in late February, the rural routes that lead into downtown Mount Morris, N.Y. (population 2,800), resembled the roads in the movie Fargo. They were windswept white landscapes, farmland on either side, lighted only by the occasional distant flickering taillight.

title: The Supersizer of Brooklyn
description: Lets begin with the mystery of the hidden bathroom.

title: Ask the Contractor
description: Is it difficult to remove a cracked bathroom-floor tile? DARDICK: You have to have a lot of patience. First you clean the grout around the tile with a sharp tool or diamond saw. Then you score the tile and break it up with a hammer. WAHAB: The hard part is when you are dealing with tiles that are installed close together, like marble. If the tiles are almost touching, it is very easy to break the adjacent tiles. It can be done, but it is riskier. SLOVAK: The critical thing is this: Do you still have that tile in that color in your house? Tile glazes change from lot to lot. Thats why when you are installing a new tile floor, you should buy extra tiles and leave them in your basement.

title: Hollywoods Leading Geek
description: In August 1970, around 300 people gathered in the basement of the U.S. Grant Hotel in San Diego for an event called the Golden State Comic-Con. As 300-person groups go, these people were not as cool as, say, the 300 Spartan warriors who took on the entire Persian Army during the Battle of Thermopylae in 480 B.C., about whom more in a minute.

title: Culture as an Economic Engine
description: Modern Germans may still be harvesting significant economic benefits from extravagant opera houses built by spendthrift Baroque princes, according to a study published this month by the Ifo Institute for Economic Research in Munich.

title: Now Reading | Cocktails With Orpheus
description: Orpheus, that muse with the tunes so beautiful that he convinced Hades to release his serpent-bit wife from the underworld, knows a thing or two about loss. As he led his wife, Eurydice, back to the surface, he was forbidden to look back, which of course he did, casting her back to the nether zone forever with, essentially, a look that killed. Orpheus says she did / not perish, reports the narrator of Terrance Hayess poem Cocktails With Orpheus. Take it from Orpheus  hes been to hell and back. They sit at a bar, in the dark, imagining worlds that could have been.

title: Crosby Skates, Could Return For Playoffs
description: If the early returns on his first workouts are an indication, Sidney Crosby maybe back in the Pittsburgh Penguins lineup for the playoffs. The teams captain, the leagues leading scorer on Jan. 5 when he was sidelined with post-concussion syndrome, skated on Monday, Tuesday and Thursday. Although the workouts were brief, Crosby reported no setbacks.

title: Talbot Group Selling Off Mining Assets
description: The Talbot Group, the mining investment firm that experienced the loss of a director, Ken Talbot, who died in a plane crash last summer, is starting to sell off its assets.

title: More Foreigners Are Seeking to Flee Japan
description: TOKYO  The exodus from Japan grew Friday as foreigners sought to flee the threat of radiation from the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant.

title: Palins Popularity Declines Among Republicans
description: On Thursday, a poll was released asking voters whether theyd rather elect Sarah Palin or  the actor Charlie Sheen.

title: The Magazines New Look
description: While there are certainly some things to applaud in your magazines new layout (the cover page is a definite improvement), the aim of making everything sharper, clearer seems to have gotten lost in the attempt to make the pages look more like they belong on the Web than in print. The contents page is laid out like a jigsaw puzzle, requiring Page 19 to be listed ahead of 18. Moreover, I believe that those who are current or prospective readers have no interest in Internet gossip, whether on Twitter or Facebook. Over all, the attempt to modernize has many successes, but you must remember that your readers are just that: people with attention spans longer than a tweet! ARTHUR D. APTOWITZ, Forest Hills, N.Y., e-mail

title: What you get for $700,000 in ...
description: Listings in New York, Memphis, Seattle and other locations.

title: Meet the Super-Parents: Kevin Costner to Play Clark Kents Dad
description: Have no fear that Superman will grow up not knowing how to hit and field a baseball, how to wield a bow and arrow or how to rid Prohibition-era Chicago of organized crime: hes now got Kevin Costner for an adoptive father. Warner Brothers Pictures announced on Thursday evening that Mr. Costner, the star of Field of Dreams, Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves and The Untouchables, will play Jonathan Kent, one of two human parents who take in the Kryptonian baby Kal-El and raise him as their son, Clark, in the new Superman movie being prepared by the director Zack Snyder (the Watchmen and Sucker Punch filmmaker). It was previously announced that Henry Cavill (of The Tudors) will play Superman and Diane Lane will play Jonathans wife, Martha.

title: Pacific Slim
description: PACIFIC SLIM  At the Blue Pearl boot-camp spa in Laguna Canyon, youre put through your paces in style.

title: With Fed Consent, Banks Raise Dividends and Buy Back Stock
description: 10:35 a.m., March 19 | Updated

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Advisory Panel Urges F.D.A. to Re-examine Menthol in Cigarettes
description: A federal advisory panel on Friday said that removing menthol cigarettes from the market would benefit public health in the United States, but stopped short of recommending that the Food and Drug Administration take any specific actions, like restricting or banning the additive.

title: The Week in Pictures, March 18
description: A look back at the weeks events in in New York City and the region.

title: Khanum Free
description: Term in Afghanistan for a loose woman or prostitute, reflecting suspicions about the concept of womens emancipation.

title: Dances in the Dark
description: The No-See-Ums, a New York dance ensemble, use sound, scent and touch to perform "Unseen Dances." Their audiences include both the blindfolded and the blind.

title: Rockwell Group to Design Blue School Interiors
description: In the five years since members of the Blue Man Group theatrical troupe founded an alternative pre-K and elementary school in Lower Manhattan, the institution has been its own gypsy, moving from one location to the next. Now the so-called Blue School is getting a permanent home in the former Seamens Church Institute building at 241 Water Street.

title: Just Days Before Election, Aristide Returns to Cheers and Uncertainty in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the former priest who rose to become Haitis first democratically elected president before being forced into exile twice, returned home on Friday to a raucous welcome from supporters and jitters that he would rattle a presidential runoff intended to settle months of political discord here.

title: The Joy of Bad Reviews
description: Ill admit, I was excited for Battle: Los Angeles to come out in theaters; the short previews to which I was treated on TV made it look pretty good. Other folks must have felt the same way, because in its opening weekend B.L.A. raked in $35 million and opened at No. 1 at the box office.

title: Outstanding Weekend Matchups in European Soccer
description: The outstanding matchups this weekend in European soccer.

title: Into Libya
description: All of my doubts about intervention stand, but obviously the die is cast and I hope this works out for the best. The good news is that just the promise of force seems to have halted Qaddafis offensive. Unless thats the bad news, since nobody in any position of authority in the United States seems to have made any effort to answer Andrew Exums list of questions about what happens next:

title: Deadly Violence Mounts at Protests in Yemen
description: Security forces and pro-government gunmen fired on protesters in Sana in the most violent crackdown yet during two months of political unrest.

title: A Dance the Audience Cannot See
description: It smelled something like waffles inside Andrew Heiskell School Braille and Talking Book Library on West 20th Street last Saturday, where a dance performance was about to begin. For some 30 people milling about a large meeting room, most blindfolded, the odor hit hard.

title: Elvis Contest Seeks Elvis Art in Return for Elvis Prizes
description: Think of all that Elvis Presley has given you over the years: hours of memorable music; a couple of half-decent movies; the inspiration to decorate the jungle room of your home with floor-to-ceiling shag carpet. What could you possibly give the King in return as a key anniversary in his career approaches? Elvis Presley Enterprises, the company that manages that rock legends licensing, publishing and merchandising, is hoping it can entice you to create some Elvis-oriented art, in return for a shot at a Presley-themed prize package. To mark the 55 years since 1956, the fateful year when Presley released his single Heartbreak Hotel, his album Elvis Presley and his movie Love Me Tender, the company said in a news release that it is seeking a a work of art that symbolizes Elvis revolution in 1956. Entries can be provided in just about any medium (which would seem to include velvet paintings) and must be submitted in .jpeg or .pdf format at Elvis.com/revolution by April 28. The finalists will be chosen by a panel of judges, and the artist whose work received the most likes on Facebook (how very 1956!) will receive a prize package that includes a trip to Memphis, Tenn., during Elvis Week 2011; tickets to Cirque du Soleils Viva Elvis show in Las Vegas; and a cabin on the 2012 Elvis Cruise (does it go to Blue Hawaii?). Any contestants who draw comparisons between Elvis Presley and Justin Bieber are disqualified in our book.

title: Try-Anything Strategy in Nuclear Crisis Draws Criticism, and Sympathy
description: TOKYO  For a country that is known for its industrial robots, advanced cellphones and hybrid vehicles, Japans efforts to cool the hobbled nuclear reactors in Fukushima Prefecture have seemed, at least to a world watching on television, to be decidedly low-tech.

title: Coast Garde
description: The seaside town of Margate, England, a thriving summer playground until its decline in the 1970s, is counting on the Turner Contemporary to revive its fortunes. Opening April 16, this striking museum  designed by David Chipperfield and named for the painter J. M. W. Turner, one of Margates famous visitors  has already spurred new galleries, pubs and cafes, as well as the restoration of Dreamland, a 1920s amusement park down the road. And it has inspired a lyrical new work by Tracey Emin, who grew up in Margate. Her pink neon sculpture I Never Stopped Loving You hangs adjacent to the museum. (Hundreds of people showed up to cheer its installation last year.) There is more of an appetite for contemporary art here than you might imagine, says Victoria Pomery, the Turners founding director. The inaugural show presents six artists whose works relate to a little-known Turner canvas depicting the Soufrire volcano on St. Vincent. We want to help audiences get a better sense of the contemporary through the historical, Pomery says. And we will always have a Turner presence. Adds Emin, The other nice thing about the Turner is that it will have a really beautiful cafe, so people like my 82-year-old mum can go and look out at the sea and have a nice cup of tea.

title: TimesCast | Libya Calls for Cease-Fire
description: March 18, 2011 - David D. Kirkpatrick reports on Libya's call for an "immediate cease-fire and the stoppage of all military operations."

title: The Skids? Hardly
description: The Bowery, no longer for the down and out, is up and coming.

title: The Skids? Not Hardly
description: BEFORE the Bowery bums and urban blight, before the restaurant-equipment dealers flooded the sidewalks, before lighting stores illuminated storefront windows and before the area became known as a haven for punk rock, one of New Yorks oldest thoroughfares fell into the cross hairs of real estate speculators. They helped transform it into one of the citys ritziest addresses.

title: The Spies Who Loved Each Other
description: In The Company We Keep, Robert and Dayna Baer tell the story of two failed marriages and one triumphant one.

title: Free Money From the Government, Going Fast
description: If you made less than $50,000 last year and have yet to file your taxes, you may be able to get up to $500 in a matching refund from a government program intended to encourage people to open bank accounts and save money.

title: Where the Young Singles Live
description: CHRIS SALIERNO, a single 31-year-old dentist, occasionally thinks about moving to Manhattan, he said, but always decides to stay where he lives now: a small one-bedroom apartment above a store on Main Street in Huntington, where he sees a friendly face on every street corner.

title: American Idol, the History
description: Its the night before the American Idol finale. Youre one of the two remaining contestants  the lesser one  and all but certain to receive a thrashing in front of nearly 30 million people. What do you do? According to Richard Rushfield, if youre Bo Bice in Season 4, up against the bionic future country superstar Carrie Underwood, you do the sensible thing: get very, very drunk. (For what its worth, Bo, even steroids wouldnt have helped.)

title: Heading Into the Tsunami
description: Yesterday, at a meeting to discuss the magazines coverage of Japan, a colleague circulated a short clip from The Financial Times about fishermen who, in the moments before the tsunami hit, headed not for higher ground but out into the open sea, calculating that the surge of water would be less severe there and they could save themselves and their precious boats. A local resident described the choice:

title: A Novel of Hemingways First Marriage
description: No one ever accused Ernest Hemingway of creating memorable women characters  except perhaps in his posthumously published Paris memoir, A Moveable Feast, where he idealizes his first wife, Hadley Richardson, as the alter ego who shared with him the good old days before fame and fortune and another woman wrecked it all.

title: After Revolt, Egyptians Try to Shape New Politics
description: PORT SAID, Egypt  When a few youthful organizers of the Tahrir Square revolution brought their democracy road show to this graceful Suez Canal port one recent evening, an animated throng rushed the tented stage as the speeches ended.

title: Whats the Collective Noun for Rubber Rat?
description: Though inflated rubber protest rats sometimes seem almost as common as (and not much larger than) their warm-blooded life models, you rarely see them in  what would the collective noun be: a band?

title: Taking On the Ubiquitous Colonial
description: MILFORD

title: Your Comments on SATs Reality Show Moment
description: More than 250 readers of The Choice (and counting) have weighed in on the decision by the College Board to include an essay question on some versions of the SAT given last weekend seeking students opinions on reality television.

title: In Raritan, New Homes Planned for Disabled Veterans
description: A NEW apartment building designed to suit the needs of disabled veterans of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan is to rise in Raritan Borough.

title: Inside the List
description: BURNING BRIGHT: Its title might sound like a publicists dream mash-up of The Paris Wife (No. 8 on the hardcover fiction list) and Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother (No. 11 on the hardcover nonfiction list), but Ta Obrehts novel, The Tigers Wife (new at No. 11 on the hardcover fiction list), is in fact an unlikely best seller: a debut literary novel, set in the Balkans, that balances a war story against a collection of contemporary folk tales. Even before the book was reviewed on our cover a couple of weeks ago, keen readers may have been familiar with Obreht as the youngest member of The New Yorkers 20 Under 40 coterie of fiction writers, announced last June when she was 24. (Other 20 Under 40 writers to make our best-seller lists include Joshua Ferris, Jonathan Safran Foer, Karen Russell and Gary Shteyngart.) Not that Obreht was unacquainted with best sellers before. In 2009, she wrote a post for The New Yorkers blog The Book Bench in which she talked about her plans to read Lolita on a holiday flight to Russia. Distracted, she picked up her seatmates Da Vinci Code instead. I doubt he cares that my copy of Lolita wound up with him, she wrote, or that I finished The Da Vinci Code three days later on a deckchair on our porch.

title: Why Last Chapters Disappoint
description: In his 1922 treatise Public Opinion, the young Walter Lippmann dealt a blow to Progressive Era dreams of a rational, well-functioning mass democracy. In the modern world, Lippmann argued, the number and intricacy of policy issues and the human tendency to cling to irrational stereotypes had rendered the public far less capable of enlightened deliberation than liberals had long supposed.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE TIGERS WIFE,  by Ta Obreht (Random House, $25.) In her first novel, Obreht uses fable and allegory to illustrate the complexities of Balkan history, unearthing the regions pervasive patterns of suspicion, superstition and everyday violence.

title: Paperback Row
description: LONG FOR THIS WORLD: The Strange Science of Immortality,  by Jonathan Weiner (Ecco/HarperCollins, $15.99.)In his Pulitzer-winning book on evolutionary biology, The Beak of the Finch, Weiner followed Peter and Rosemary Grant, who had spent years studying birds in the Galpagos Islands. Here he makes similar use of another theoretical scientist, the English gerontologist Aubrey de Grey, a tireless proselytizer for radical life extension.

title: 285,000 Hyundai Elantras Recalled for Air-Bag Inflation Issue
description: Hyundai is recalling about 285,000 Elantras for air-bag problems, while Continental Tire says about 391,000 of its truck tires are vulnerable to tread separation, according to documents filed this week with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Habitats | Mott Haven, the Bronx
description: Carol Zakaluk lives with her husband, John Knoerr, in a house in the Bertine Block, which has landmark status. The house, and most of the furnishings, have been in her family for decades.

title: Up Front: Geoffrey Nunberg
description: Geoffrey Nunberg is perhaps best known for his witty commentaries on language usage and politics, gathered in the collections Going Nucular and The Years of Talking Dangerously.

title: James Gleicks History of Information
description: The universe, the 18th-century mathematician and philosopher Jean Le Rond dAlembert said, would only be one fact and one great truth for whoever knew how to embrace it from a single point of view. James Gleick has such a perspective, and signals it in the first word of the title of his new book, The Information, using the definite article we usually reserve for totalities like the universe, the ether  and the Internet. Information, he argues, is more than just the contents of our overflowing libraries and Web servers. It is the blood and the fuel, the vital principle of the world. Human consciousness, society, life on earth, the cosmos  its bits all the way down.

title: A Journalist Investigates a Father Lost at War
description: We are all familiar with the five stages of memoir: myth, trauma, revelation, redemption, book contract. In his wonderful memoir, Almost a Family, John Darnton has taken this modern form to a new level. His story is excruciatingly personal, with painful drama and dreadful sorrow, but as a journalist who won a Pulitzer Prize when he was reporting for The New York Times, he calmly researches the narrative of his life detail by detail. His heart was broken, but his focus is on the facts.

title: The Misunderstood Death of Modigliani
description: With his milky skin and sleepy eyes, Amedeo Modigliani was one of modern arts fabled beauties. His life was box-office gold, a classic mortal tale of squalor and salvation. An artist-genius sinks under the weight of poverty, illness and addiction, dies at 35, leaving behind ruined lives  his distraught mistress kills herself and their unborn child  and a body of hugely popular art.

title: A Thriller Revisits the Cambridge Spies
description: The five spies from Trinity College, Cambridge, may have betrayed their country during the cold war, but they performed an indisputable service for British literature. A number of works have either been inspired or enlivened by the misdeeds of Kim Philby, John Cairncross, Guy Burgess, Donald Maclean and Anthony Blunt. In Anthony Powells panoramic Dance to the Music of Time, for example, Lord Widmerpool gets into political hot water for what his wife derisively calls his little under-the-counter Communist games. Then there is the Irish writer John Banvilles elegant roman  clef, The Untouchable, which explored Blunts life. And novelists of such varying stripes as Ian Fleming and John le Carr have drawn sustenance from the treachery that emanated from 1930s Cambridge, where enlistment in the workers revolution seems to have easily accompanied sipping claret, participating in debauches and collecting Poussin paintings. After Burgess and Maclean, and later Philby, fled to Moscow, the K.G.B. must have sometimes wondered whether the information they supplied was worth the sheer bother of having to put up with these spoiled brats.

title: George Sand, Novelized
description: Mention George Sand today and an image is instantly summoned: a Frenchwoman in mens clothes, a writer who smoked cigars and slept with Chopin. She is scarcely read in America, despite her resurrection by the contemporary womens movement.

title: In Search of Moonlight
description: Moonlight beguiles, enchants and deceives. Like poems and dreams and love, it can be maddeningly difficult to characterize  some might say impossible. We know what it is, but we dont know why it exerts such a powerful hold on the imagination, or how it works its magic. Theres a perfect madness in the desire to study moonlight, to wander across the world under its spell, to seek out the ways in which it alters reality, inspires art or otherwise leaves its mark on the soul. But thats just the sort of intellectual wanderlust that seized James Attlee one evening during a walk on the coast of Cornwall as he watched the rim of the harvest moon emerging from the sea, a monstrous, swollen apparition. Struck by this spectacular sight, Attlee was also struck by the realization that our lives are no longer held, as they were for countless millennia, in the sway of the night sky. Nocturne: A Journey in Search of Moonlight is his eccentric, rambling, charming report from this abandoned field, a book by turns erratic and spellbinding.

title: Grappling With Religion and Violence
description: In an era when publicity departments hotly compete with editors for space in the offices of financially challenged publishing houses, the old adage about how you shouldnt judge a book by its cover is truer than ever. But what about titles? Surely it isnt unreasonable to expect that a book with Jerusalem in its name  twice!  will be about . . . Jerusalem.
