But alas, James Carrolls Jerusalem, Jerusalem is not really about that ancient city, and despite what its subtitle suggests, it has next to nothing to say about how Jerusalem ignited our modern world.

title: Anne Roiphes Wild Oats
description: In her latest memoir, Art and Madness, the novelist Anne Roiphe, who married a playwright she mistook for a genius and sacrificed part of her youth to the god of self-deception, does not speak for all women who have married writers. Her darkly moralistic version of la vie bohme takes place in the 1950s and 60s, not on scruffy Avenue B  where downtown artists tended to pride themselves on scraping along and being rejected by the Establishment  but on the fiercely status-conscious Upper East Side, only a short walk from Elaines. It is perfectly true, however, that both uptown and downtown, writers drank, womanized and had misogynistic attitudes. (Of course, so did the rest of America, which was running on alcohol after the war and was on the uneasy verge of a sexual revolution.)

title: A Historical Romance of 20th Century India
description: In fictional love triangles, the heroine is often presented with two options: the dashing bad boy or the nice, dependable dud. Just such a triangle appears in Tiger Hills, the first novel by Sarita Mandanna, which opens in the South Indian district of Coorg (where Mandanna was born) at the turn of the 20th century.

title: From The Paris Review to a Korean Deli
description: Its hard not to fall in love with My Korean Deli. First, its the (very) rare memoir that places careful, loving attention squarely on other people rather than the author. Second, it tells a rollicking, made-for-the-movies story in a wonderfully funny deadpan style. By the end, youll feel that you know the author and his family quite well  even though you may not be eager to move in with them.

title: I Took the Turing Test
description: In his landmark 1950 paper Computing Machinery and Intelligence, the mathematician, philosopher and code breaker Alan Turing proposed a method for answering the question Can machines think?: an imitation game in which an interrogator, C, interviews two players, A and B, via teleprinter, then decides on the basis of the exchange which is human and which is a computer.

title: Mets Release Luis Castillo
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets released second baseman Luis Castillo on Friday, cutting ties with a symbol of their discouraging recent past. Another lingering symbol, Carlos Beltran, had a cortisone shot in his aching left knee.

title: Gaza Ebbs Toward Normalcy
description: As the cease-fire holds in Gaza and Israel, residents are moving slowly toward a semblance of normal life and making plans for reconstruction.

title: Taliban Snipers Bedevil Troops in Marja
description: In Marja, the Taliban has shown a side not often seen in nearly a decade of American military action in Afghanistan: the use of snipers, both working alone and integrated into guerrilla-style ambushes.

title: Gaza and Hamas Begin Recovery
description: Days after Israel completed its three-week assault on Hamas in the Gaza Strip, reconstruction is beginning.

title: Afghans Go to the Polls
description: The polls for Afghanistans presidential election opened for a race that is proving tighter than expected.

title: After Inspirational Year, Furyk Is Back Where It Began
description: PALM HARBOR, Fla.  Loud cheers and sustained applause greeted Jim Furyk when he arrived at the first tee Thursday, ready to defend his title at the Transitions Championship at Innisbrook Resort and Golf Club. But the noise was not just from the fans lining the gallery ropes.

title: Quarterfinal Draws for Champions League and Europa League
description: The draws for the Champions League and Europa League quarterfinals were announced Friday, and include some intriguing matchups for this round and the next. In the Champions League, the first leg will be April 5 and 6, with the return legs a week later. The matchups:

title: Caucus Questions
description: Jennifer Steinhauer answers reader questions about the move Thursday in the House of Representatives to defund NPR.

title: Lair and Sanctuary in the South Bronx
description: CAROL ZAKALUK lives in a ruddy brick and stone row house in the Mott Haven section of the South Bronx, one of 10 similar houses built in the 1890s. Though the strip, known as the Bertine Block, takes its name from the developer, Edward Bertine, these buildings were the work of a single gifted architect named George Keister.

title: China Frees 7 Tibetan Monks Detained After Protest
description: BEIJING  Chinese security officers in a restive Tibetan area of Sichuan Province have released seven monks who were detained after one monk, Phuntsog, died after setting himself on fire to protest Chinese rule, according to a report issued late Thursday by International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group based in Washington.

title: Europes Starter Castles
description: Handcrafted masonry. Lots of bedrooms. Priced to moved. Needs plumbing.

title: Clark Art Institute Tries to Deaccession a Renoir at Maastricht Art Fair
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  Museum directors, curators and donors generally come to art fairs to look, and occasionally to buy. But auctions are where museums most often decide to sell works of art, because public sales are widely considered the most transparent method of deaccessioning.

title: Just Like the Good Old Days in the Ring
description: DURING their childhood in New Providence, N.J., sports were not the strong suit of Tom McCarthy and his friend Joe Tiboni.

title: Production to Resume
description: Nissans production, like that of other automakers in Japan, was affected by the recent earthquake and tsunami. The plant in Oppama, where the Juke is made for markets other than Europe, was to resume operations on Sunday, though Nissan said delivery of some parts from suppliers had been delayed.

title: Nissans Cartoon Cars, Once So Hip
description: BRYAN THOMPSON has a cute little orphan that needs a home.

title: A Design So Far Out It Just Might Be In
description: I TOOK my first close look at the Juke, Nissans new funhouse-mirror crossover, a few weeks before my 40th birthday. The truth quickly settled in: man, you are way too old for this car.

title: Seeing Red (and White)
description: For six days only  March 25-30  what promises to be an extraordinary exhibition will fill the Wade Thompson Drill Hall at the Park Avenue Armory. Infinite Variety: Three Centuries of Red and White Quilts, which was organized by the American Folk Art Museum, will present 650 red and white quilts  no two of which are alike  from the collection of Joanna S. Rose (who will donate 50 of them to the museum when the exhibition ends). The largest quilt exhibition ever mounted under one roof in New York City, it will fill the 55,000- square-foot drill hall to a height of 45 feet with a series of rooms defined by quilts that will be suspended on cardboard tubes. In the center of the installation, which was designed by the New York firm Thinc Design, a group of quilts will hang in a spiral formation that the designers liken to a tornado, above a circle of chairs that alludes to the social  and female-dominated  nature of quilting. Organized by Elizabeth V. Warren, a guest curator who is also a trustee of the museum, and Stacy C. Hollander, a senior curator at the museum, the exhibition will be free to the public and will include a cafe and shop. Even if you wont be able to buy the quilts, the postcards should be terrific.

title: Burger King and Its Ad Agency Part Ways
description: Burger King and Crispin Porter & Bogusky, the advertising agency that has created risk-taking, attention-getting work for the company since early 2004, are unexpectedly parting ways.

title: L.S.U. Womens Team Seeks a New Coach, Direction
description: These are tough times for the L.S.U. womens basketball team. The Tigers, a fixture in the N.C.A.A. field for the past 12 years, missed the tournament after a 19-13 season.

title: Teachers Respond to the Crisis in Japan
description: From the moment last Friday when we posted our first list of resources and links about the crisis in Japan, weve been hearing from teachers and students all over the world.

title: Bahrain Tears Down Monument as Protesters Seethe
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Bahrain tore down the protest movements defining monument on Friday, the pearl at the center of Pearl Square. The destruction of the 300-foot sculpture, a stone pearl held by six sweeping arches, was part of a chain of events that in a matter of days turned the country from a symbol of hopeful pro-democratic protest into one of repression.

title: Canine Genetic Wrinkle Has Human Potential
description: Shar-peis are an ancient Chinese dog breed characterized by two singular traits: thick, wrinkly skin and frequent bouts of fever. Researchers now say that the same gene mutation is responsible for both the wrinkles and the fever.

title: Videophiles | Patterns & Repetitions IV
description: This week, The Moment features Jacques Herzog discussing instinct and architecture.

title: ArtScience Museum Opens in Singapore
description: Singapore has a bauble to add to its collection: the ArtScience Museum, which opened last month in a building designed by Moshe Safdie. The museum adds a brainy element to the Las Vegas-style Marina Bay Sands development, which includes a casino, 2,561-room hotel, seven restaurants from big-name chefs and a park on the roof.

title: The Lincoln Lawyer as Epitaph for the Town Car
description: As a young lawyer, Abraham Lincoln rode from courthouse to courthouse in Illinois on horseback. A latter-day lawyer in The Lincoln Lawyer, the novel by Michael Connolly whose film adaptation opens nationwide on Friday, rides from courthouse to courthouse in a Lincoln Town Car.

title: Modern Gas in Vintage Engines
description: MODERN gasoline vehicles are engineered to perform satisfactorily on fuel blends containing up to 10 percent ethanol, or E10. It can be a different story, though, when such blends are used in vintage cars (as well as boats and outdoor power equipment), suggesting that some precautions are worth considering  particularly for engines built before 1990.

title: Collectors Go Looking for Nonalcoholic Blends
description: IT was not such an extraordinary wish, really. All Sam Hokin wanted to do was fill his motorcycle with gasoline.

title: Judges Order Blocks Law on Unions in Wisconsin
description: CHICAGO  Efforts to shrink collective bargaining rights for public workers in Wisconsin were slowed on Friday when a judge issued a temporary restraining order blocking a much-debated law from taking effect.

title: Friday Reading: Tax Tips for the Elderly
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: For W.P.S. Franchise: New Home, New Name, Same Team?
description: One of the premier womens soccer teams in the United States may now exist in name only, and that is debatable.

title: A Man With a Truck Brings Costco to You
description: It almost sounds too good to be true: Getting the savings of shopping at Costco, without the hassle of getting to the store. Yet Michael Eberstadt says hes for real, and thats just what he offers to Manhattanites on his Web site, MonsterSavings.com.

title: Tai Chi Eases Depression in Elderly
description: The ancient Chinese practice of tai chi appears to relieve symptoms of depression in older people, a new study shows.

title: Netflix Gets Into the TV Business
description: 9:04 p.m. | Updated |  There is a new competitor for HBO and Showtime in the television landscape  and, for the first time, it is not a television network.

title: New Pre-existing Condition Insurance Plans
description: Pre-existing condition insurance plans, mandated by the new health care law, opened for business last July, but many consumers still have no idea they exist, reports Walecia Konrad in this weeks Patient Money column.

title: Delay in Coal Pollution Rules Took Toll in Lives
description: A tough new pollution standard for power plants proposed this week by the Environmental Protection Agency will cost utilities at least $10 billion, and several companies have already signaled that they will close aging coal plants rather than upgrade to meet the new standards. The new rules require major reductions in mercury, arsenic and other hazardous emissions.

title: How to Circumvent DVD Region Codes
description: If I ever get time to mount a crusade against the idiocies of modern copy protection, Ill have to tackle DVD region codes first. Its yet another of those elaborate movie industry schemes aimed at preventing piracy that, inevitably, punishes only the law-abiding citizens. The pirates work around it with one click.

title: TimesCast | Deadly Violence in Yemen
description: March 18, 2011 - Security forces unleashed a brutal and sustained assault on protesters in Sana, Yemen's capital, in the country's largest protest so far. Laura Kasinof reports.

title: Weekend Competition: Modern Paint Colors
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to propose paint color descriptions fit for our times.

title: Spring Shopping | Bright Jackets
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#187", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Land of the Free and the Home of the Jets
description: AMONG those of college age, Florham Park is known for Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: A Snowy March 18, Shrouded in Poetic Mystery
description: Richard Brautigan, the poet and novelist, who died in 1984, loved dates, sometimes incorporating them into poems with titles like September 3 (The Dr. William Carlos Williams Mistake) and Yeah, There Was Always Going to Be A June 5, 1968.

title: Genevieve Boland, Michael Steigman
description: Dr. Genevieve Marie Boland and Michael Richard Steigman were married Saturday afternoon at Our Lady of Victories Church in Boston. Msgr. John P. Boland, a Roman Catholic priest in Philadelphia and the brides paternal uncle, who received a one-day solemnization certificate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, performed the ceremony, with the participation of Rabbi Laurence A. Alpern.

title: Charlotte Haselden and Daniel Mndez Montes de Oca
description: Charlotte Marian Haselden, the daughter of Lori A. Breningmeyer and William M. Haselden of Tallahassee, Fla., was married Saturday to Daniel Alejandro Mndez Montes de Oca, a son of Sonia Montes de Oca de Mndez and Douglas Rafael Mndez Urdaneta of Caracas, Venezuela. The brides father, a Florida notary, officiated at Dorothy B. Oven Park in Tallahassee. Harry B. Bailey III, a friend of the brides parents, led the ceremony and read passages from the Episcopal Book of Common Prayer.

title: Live Updates: The Real Day 2 at the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Someones messing with us.

title: Video: Answering Reader Questions About NPR Funding
description: The Timess Jennifer Steinhauer, a congressional correspondent, answers reader questions submitted via Twitter about the move in the U.S. House of Representatives to defund National Public Radio.

title: Stephen Pryce, Ryan Wirtz
description: Stephen Mark Pryce, the son of Janet Pryce and Derek J. Pryce of Heighington, England, was joined in a civil union Friday in Berlin to Ryan David Wirtz, the son of Judith Anne Hennessey of Wilton Manors, Fla., and Dr. David Leonard Wirtz of Mount Vernon, Ohio. Karin Klapp, a civil registrar of Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf district in Berlin, officiated at the Schmargendorf Town Hall.

title: Washington Post Reporter to Be Biden Aide
description: WASHINGTON  For the second time in just over two years, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is raiding the Washington press corps for his communications director.

title: Nkechi Olisemeka and Kevin Mitchell
description: Nkechi Irene Olisemeka and Kevin Bernard Mitchell were married Saturday on Tybee Island in Georgia. The Rev. Thomas J. Peyton performed the ceremony at St. Michael Catholic Church, where he is the pastor.

title: Jessica Klein, Michael Healy
description: Jessica Malden Klein and Michael Edelen Healy were married Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Justice Alice Schlesinger of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Amy Rafa, Matthew DeVoe
description: Amy Meera Rafa and Matthew Scott DeVoe were married Saturday evening in Chicago. Jillian K. Wesley, the brides sister, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Fultons on the River, a restaurant and event space. Adam T. DeVoe, the bridegrooms brother who also became a Universal Life minister, participated.

title: Marissa Certilman and David Zackowitz
description: Marissa Felice Certilman and David Ari Zackowitz are to be married Sunday evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Elliot J. Cosgrove is to perform the ceremony, with Rabbi Evan Jaffe participating.

title: Connie Hsu and Matthew Pearl
description: Connie Hsu and Matthew Randall Pearl were married Friday evening in Las Vegas in a suite at the Venetian, a resort and casino. The Rev. Julie Nourish, a minister of the Center of Light Church, officiated.

title: Madhavi Reddy, Patrick Tripp
description: Dr. Madhavi Thukivakam Reddy and Dr. Patrick McKiernan Tripp were married Saturday afternoon at the Trump International Hotel and Tower in Chicago. Pandit Pattabhirama K. Jois led a Hindu ceremony.

title: Andrea Kussack, Jeremy Berman
description: Andrea Caroline Kussack and Jeremy David Berman were married Saturday evening at Location 05, a photography studio in New York. Rabbi Gloria B. Milner officiated.

title: Weekend Fare
description: With room for hundreds at communal tables, genuine Hofbra beers (including seasonal bock), several kinds of sausage and schnitzels, sauerbraten and sauerkraut, the just-opened Bierhaus, at 712 Third Avenue (45th Street), (646) 580-2437, brings a bit of old Germany next to the Blarney Stone.

title: Olufolake Oguntebi and Joseph Protheroe
description: Olufolake Adewumi Oguntebi and Joseph Thomas Protheroe were married Saturday at the University of South Florida Botanical Gardens in Tampa. The Rev. Alan Rowbotham, a minister of the Unity Church, officiated.

title: Update: Missing Friends
description: We were relieved to hear that our four colleagues in Libya will be released today, according to an ABC News interview. As we wrote yesterday, four of our Times colleagues  Stephen Farrell, Lynsey Addario, Anthony Shadid and Tyler Hicks  went missing in Libya. Seif al-Islam Qaddafi, the son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, told Christiane Amanpour in an interview that they were captured Tuesday by forces loyal to the Libyan leader.

title: A Shift in the Balance of Debt Obligations
description: FOR years, the American financial sector borrowed and borrowed. Its obligations rose even more rapidly than consumers. Both sectors were far more aggressive borrowers than the federal government.

title: Deborah Daniels, Steven Dorlen
description: Deborah Daizadeh Daniels and Steven Brett Dorlen are to be married Sunday at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Clifford Kulwin is to officiate.

title: Virginia Adair, Allan Mathis
description: Virginia Charlotte Adair and Allan Taylor Mathis were married Saturday evening in the Robinson Room at Millennium Gate in Atlanta. The Rev. Samuel G. Candler, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Nerissa Weiner, Bradley Pryba
description: Nerissa Savitt Weiner and Bradley Mitchell Pryba were married Saturday evening at Liberty House Restaurant in Jersey City. Rabbi Bruce S. Block officiated.

title: Cantor and Democrats Raised Big Contributions in February
description: Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the House majority leader, raised almost $600,000 in campaign contributions in February, a huge haul in the first month after Republicans took control of the chamber.

title: Genevieve Gonzalez-Turner, Jonathan Cohen
description: Genevieve Carre Gonzalez-Turner and Jonathan Christopher Cohen were married Friday at the St. Regis Bahia Beach Resort in Rio Grande, P.R. The Rev. Aran Santana, a minister of the Missionary Churches of Christ, led a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Emily Chang, Hal Brands
description: Emily Teresa Chang and Hal Brands were married Tuesday at the Durham County Court House in Durham, N.C. Aminah M. Thompson, a civil magistrate, officiated.

title: Only Japanese Player in M.L.S. Seeks Help for People at Home
description: It has been a week since the devastating earthquake and tsunami that has affected the people of my home country of Japan

title: Vain Glorious | Yummy Bites
description: What: Bite Beauty, a new natural cosmetics line.

title: How to Procure an iPad 2
description: So you want an iPad 2.

title: Hollywood Ignores East-West Exchange
description: AT the Oscars last month the gap between what interests Hollywood and what the rest of the world seems to be doing was sharp and clear. Of the five nominees for the best foreign-language film, all but one, among them the winner, In a Better World, from Denmark, dealt in some way with relationships between the West and Islam.

title: On the Street | Signs of Spring
description: On the street in Paris, the first signs of spring bring a welcome change of color.

title: Goldman Will Repay Buffett His $5 Billion
description: 8:17 p.m. | Updated

title: Riesch Leapfrogs Vonn and Sets Up a Showdown
description: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland  The battle for the World Cup womens overall title will come down to the wire Saturday after Lindsey Vonn, the three-time defending champion from the United States, lost her lead to Maria Riesch of Germany.

title: Should Menthol Cigarettes Be Banned?
description: A federal advisory panelsaid on Friday after a year of study that menthol cigarettes caused more harm than nonmenthol cigarettes. (See related article.)

title: In Thailand, One Mans Dream Becomes a Bangkok Sanctuary
description: BUDDHIST temples in Bangkok are about as ubiquitous as hot dog stands in Manhattan, and after a day or two of playing duck-the-camera with tour groups, even the most devout tourists can become shrine shirkers. But Bangkok has a fantastic sanctuary from the sanctuaries that stands out for both its secret grandeur and for its ancient style. You just have to find it.

title: Happenings in Asia
description: April

title: 37 Asian Odysseys
description: BALI1 Ubud Get yourself to the bustling Ubud market by 6 a.m and watch the colorful daily routine of locals buying everything from fruit to religious offerings. Enjoy a hearty sweet or savory bubur (similar to rice pudding), and from there head by foot to the end of Jalan Kajeng for a 90-minute hike through traditional rice paddies to Tjampuhan, a neighboring hamlet. Top it all off with a healing Balinese-style massage at the Ubud Bodywork Centre back in town.

title: A Rising Nanjing Thrives on Youth and Art
description: IT was a Saturday night at Tonys Bar in Nanjing, China, and as in any good university town, packs of rowdy students were making quick work of their pints. A long-haired guitarist in a black leather jacket crooned Chinese love songs from a small stage. Young men bent low over tables playing boisterous dice games while their girlfriends, hair dyed various shades of red and brown, smoked disinterestedly and texted, their faces illuminated by the glow of their phones.

title: New Hotels in Asia Embrace Their Local Settings
description: COOKIE-CUTTER chains and luxury brands are chief among the many new hotels serving travelers in the wake of rising Asian affluence. But a distinct and dramatic subset aims to underscore local culture, be it pagoda-style architecture at the new Four Seasons in Hangzhou, China, wok-manning cooks in the market-inspired Six Senses Con Dao in Vietnam or vernacular town house design at the Hotel Kanra in Kyoto, Japan.

title: Exotic Tastes in China, Vietnam, Singapore and Japan
In Seoul, a Rare Bustle-Free Neighborhood
description: Samcheong-dong is one of Seouls most rapidly evolving places to visit.

title: A Serene Oasis in Bangkok
description: The Prasart collection brings together Asian treasures in a trove of magical gardens.

title: Iraqi Shiites Protest Bahrain Crackdown
description: BAGHDAD  In the southern port city of Basra, the slums of Sadr City, the divided city of Kirkuk in the north and other areas across Iraq, followers of Moktada al-Sadr, the populist Shiite cleric, flooded the streets after Friday prayers to denounce the violence unleashed on Shiite demonstrators in Bahrain and the presence of Saudi troops there.

title: A Rising Nanjing Thrives on Youth and Art
description: In recent years, the city has moved beyond its tragic past to become a vital engine of Chinas economic growth.

title: Asia Up Close
description: A 17-country tour of Asias must-see destinations in 2011.

title: The Full-Album Set Is a Plus for Fans and Bands
description: Over the past few years SXSW has become a place where bands debut a different and, for me, welcome kind of set: playing their next album and nothing but. On Thursday, I heard two of those sets: by Antlers, playing their Burst Apart, due in May, and by Emmylou Harris, playing Hard Bargain, due in April. They had more in common than I would have expected. Today Ill be going for another: TV on the Radio.

title: As S.E.C. Watches, Secondary Market Seeks Transparency
description: As the gaze of the Securities and Exchange Commission bears down on the secondary market for private company shares, some firms involved in these stock transactions are taking steps to increase their controls.

title: Complexity + Complacency = Calamity
description: Michael Schlesinger, a climate scientist and engineer at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, sent this comment after reading my Dot Earth post rounding up reader views on next steps for nuclear power in the wake of Japans extraordinary nuclear emergency.

title: On a Day of Grieving, Duty Ties Two Slain Officers
description: Police Officers Geoffrey J. Breitkopf and Alain Schaberger died nine hours and 38 miles apart. Their funerals were closer: Four hours and 15 miles apart, on the same day, in the same county on Long Island, before some of the same mourners.

title: Honda Pledges to Boost CR-Z Power
description: The CR-Z, Hondas two-seat hybrid, has been roundly taken to task since its debut last summer for looking more sporty than it behaves. In his review for The Times, Richard S. Chang wrote that in fuel-sipping Eco mode the CR-Z barely registers a pulse, especially on the highway.

title: Note to Readers
description: There are several destinations in Japan included in this issue. None are in the areas most severely affected by either the March 11 earthquake or the subsequent tsunami, but we encourage readers to heed the current State Department travel alert for the country. It urges travelers to avoid tourism to Japan at least until April 1, when the warning expires. After that point, please check the State Department Web site at travel.state.gov/travel for further updates.

title: Big Deal | Homage to Bacchus
description: Sean Parker, a co-founder of Napster and the founding president of Facebook, has expressed sardonic irritation at his portrayal as a hard-partying playboy in the film The Social Network.

title: Senators Urge Obama to Confront Debt and Deficit
description: 4:21 p.m. | Updated More than 60 senators  evenly divided by party  sent President Obama a letter on Friday urging him to support a comprehensive effort to confront the nations growing deficit and debt.

title: The Poetry of Catastrophe
description: Even devoted followers of the news seem overwhelmed by the sheer volume of horrific events unfolding just now  in particular the continuing bloodshed in the Arab world and the ever-worsening story of the earthquake-tsunami-nuclear crisis in Japan. These headlines recall the most frightening chapters of antiquity, times of pestilence and war, a steady mood of darkening apocalypse.

title: Vols Are Gone; Pearl Is Left Waiting
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The daily Bruce Pearl watch provided more compelling drama than anything else in Tennessees sixth consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament appearance. And it created an air of finality Friday when Pearl, the Volunteers coach, who faces accusations that he violated N.C.A.A. recruiting rules and who has acknowledged that he lied to investigators, led his team onto the floor to face Michigan in its opening game in the West Region.

title: No Pepsi, Diet Coke
description: I must admit, I dont know many people who drink Pepsi, and only a dozen or so who consume Coke proper  and most of those folks are either very slender or quite obese and probably think, Hey, another 46 grams of sugar wont kill me. Today.

title: One Word: Plastics
description: To the Editor:

title: Less Than Human
description: To the Editor:

title: A Writers Afterlife
description: To the Editor:

title: Anatomy Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Homage to Orwell
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Builds a Lead, Then Holds On
description: TULSA, Okla.  A disjointed performance like Fridays explains why Texas received a No. 4 seed in the West Region of the N.C.A.A. tournament. The Longhorns looked ready to overwhelm an offensively-skilled Oakland team, building a 17-point lead, but Texas lost its competitive zeal along the way and had to hold on for an 85-81 victory over its 13th-seeded opponent.

title: Ex-Goldman Director Sues S.E.C. Over Galleon Case
description: Rajat K. Gupta

title: As Remodeling Rebounds, Caveats for the Homeowner
description: ONE part of the housing market is experiencing a rebound that will probably continue even if the rest of the market remains sluggish: remodeling.

title: House Renovation Tips From Insurers
description: The housing market remains sluggish but the demand for renovations is expected to rise as many homeowners decide to fix up where they are now instead of moving elsewhere. And as new owners take over foreclosed properties that were long neglected, they, too, are expected to make repairs.

title: Egypt in My Heart
description: As spring arrives, so too do the seeds of a new era for the Muslim world. This video by Shirin Neshat is a tribute to the young protesters.

title: Make Yourself a Quesadilla
description: If you need healthful food fast, quesadillas are always a good bet, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Gratitudes Gifts
description: Gratitude is also a nice feature of human nature. In the Journal of Happiness Studies a research team led by Jeffrey Froh studied surveys of high school students that were designed to measure levels of materialism, gratitude, envy, depression, social integration and self-absorption. They found that high gratitude scores powerfully predict higher grades, better social integration and lower envy and depression levels. Students with more materialistic attitudes earned lower grades.

title: Now Booking | Htel Americano
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#414", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Tantalizing Reporters, Bar Association Again Backs Cameras in Courts
description: The New York City Bar Association released its annual legislative agenda this week, calling for changes across a range of legal areas, from equal access to the courts, election law and court operations.

title: Mildred Pierce: A Mothers House of Love and Hurt
description: ASKED recently about his longstanding attraction to the melodramatic form known as the womans picture  the untouchable of film genres, as the critic Molly Haskell once put it  the director Todd Haynes had a ready answer.

title: Among the Dead, a Character Finds Life
description: TELEVISION dramas, at their cores, are about characters. What Dana Delany is doing, then, every day on the set of Body of Proof is character building.

title: France and Britain Lead Military Push on Libya
description: PARIS  France and Britain continued to press their hawkish position on Libya on Friday, saying they intend to take the lead in enforcing a no-flight zone.

title: 2011 Nissan Juke
description: Nissan is hoping to lure the Mini crowd with the Juke.

title: Jenn-Air in Ad Deal With Architectural Digest
description: A leading line of higher-end appliances is making changes in how it seeks to reach potential buyers of products like ranges, cooktops, refrigerators and dishwashers.

title: Book Review Podcast: John Darnton
description: This week: The author and journalist John Darnton on his memoir, Almost a Family; The Timess art critic Holland Cotter on a new biography of the painter Amedeo Modigliani; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Twitter Patter | @GRAMMARHULK
description: Tweeting Since July 2010Followers 2,500Twitter Bio HAVE NICE DAY!

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: A MOTHERS DRESS COLOR

title: Insults and War
description: If the world gets crazy with us, we will get crazy, too. We will respond. We will make their lives hell because they are making our lives hell. They will never have peace.

title: City May Face Increase in Homeless Costs, Report Says
description: Spending on homeless shelters in New York City could increase by up to 66 percent next year because of the elimination of a generous rental voucher program for poor families, according to a report by the citys Independent Budget Office released on Friday.

title: Longform Storytelling in a Short-Attention-Span World
description: It was smart and inviting, dense like a good chocolate cake, long enough that it left you feeling satiated, and when it ended it left you hungry for more. If you were at Wednesdays Pro Publica talk at The New School, this was the definition of longform journalism that you heard a panel of editors present to a house full hushed and attentive media connoisseurs.

title: Friendship Reaches Into Ambulance for Huggins and Calipari
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Bob Huggins was riding inside an ambulance en route to a Pittsburgh-area hospital, fading in and out of consciousness. Huggins heart had stopped earlier on that afternoon in 2002, but he was about to receive another jolt.

title: Owner Weighs Options for Nightly Business Report
description: The majority owner of Nightly Business Report has hired an advisory firm to weigh strategic options for the program, from selling a minority stake up to selling the entire company, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

title: Answers on Canning, Syrup, Yogurt and Tomatoes
description: After Julia wrote about do-it-yourself cooking, she asked readers for their  comments and questions on the subject. Heres her first set of replies. Shell have more next week.

title: Across and Down, and Onward to Victory
description: Mexican salamander. Seven letters. The first two letters are AX. Hmmm.

title: Onward Toward Sentence of the Month
description: Here is our third installment of Sentence of the Week. (This means that were right on the brink of having some kind of winners bracket meta-tournament for Sentence of the Month. Stay tuned.) Here are this weeks candidates:

title: A Match Made in Maje
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#705", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: The Sidekick No More
description: ALMOST as soon as the NBC anchorman Brian Williams slipped out of view, Gayle King stripped down to her slip.

title: Fisher Discusses Fab Five Film
description: TUCSON  Steve Fisher has been the harshest of film critics for decades, whether he was breaking down tape of his famed Michigan teams or those of his San Diego State squad that is preparing for its Round of 32 matchup against Temple on Saturday in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Obama Speaks About Libya
description: Obama Speaks About Libya

title: Smoking Permitted Only by the Engine
description: WHAT WAS IT? 1974-76 Bricklin SV-1

title: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: March 18
description: Action from across the country in Fridays N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: Look Whos Meditating Now
description: RUSSELL BRAND, the lanky British comedian, has made a career of his outrageous antics. While a host at MTV UK, he went to work dressed up as Osama bin Laden. At the networks annual music awards, he likened Britney Spears to a female Christ. And he was fired from the BBC after leaving raunchy messages on the voice mail of a 78-year-old actor, a comic bit that even his countrys then-prime minister felt compelled to denounce.

title: Dont Call Me, I Wont Call You
description: NOBODY calls me anymore  and thats just fine. With the exception of immediate family members, who mostly phone to discuss medical symptoms and arrange child care, and the Roundabout Theater fund-raising team, which takes a diabolical delight in phoning me every few weeks at precisely the moment I am tucking in my children, people just dont call.

title: Nissans Cute Little Orphans
description: Nissan offered four limited-edition cars in Japan in the late 1980s and early 90s.

title: Lincoln Earns Most Dependable
description: LINCOLN was the top brand in the J. D. Power & Associates 2011 Vehicle Dependability Study, the first time it has taken the No. 1 spot in the two decades the study has been conducted.

title: New Yorkers Support Bicycle Lanes, Poll Finds
description: The Bloomberg administrations new bicycle lanes, the subject of one of the more heated civic controversies in recent memory, are supported by a majority of New Yorkers, according to a poll released on Friday by Quinnipiac University.

title: On the Web, Every Day Is Casual Friday
description: LAST year found Mark Zuckerberg, the Facebook creator and 26-year-old billionaire, topping a lot of short lists. Time chose him as 2010s Person of the Year. He headed the Vanity Fair 100 list of most influential people. Then Esquire pinned him to its 2010 list of the most unfortunately dressed men. Ouch.

title: Liquidity Traps, Once Again
description: Arnold Kling complains that I talk too much about the liquidity trap, but still doesnt get the point.

title: Pre-existing Condition? Now, a Health Policy May Not Be Impossible
description: SIX years ago, Jerry Garner, 45, a real estate agent in Gowen, Mich., underwent a kidney transplant. He recovered nicely, and thanks to diligent adherence to his drug regimen and frequent checkups, he has been healthy ever since  a miracle, said his wife, Stephanie.

title: Virtual Visitation Rights
description: NEARLY a year ago, my 70-year-old father sent me a friend request on Facebook. Though I publish my every movement  from the mundane to the salacious  on the site, and there might be things about my life that I wasnt sure I wanted to share with him, I seriously considered accepting his request. If only to make up for lost time or give him basic biographical information so our interactions wouldnt always feel like an awkward first date.

title: Not the Fake Scandals I Expected
description: OK, Republicans have surprised me, at least so far. Based on the experience of the Clinton years  not to mention all that stuff about how the Obama administration is the most corrupt in modern times  I expected a proliferation of fake scandals over mowing the White House lawn, or Sharia law presidential hit squads led by the reanimated corpse of Vince Foster, or something. Maybe thats still in the pipeline.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Sana, Yemen; Tobruk, Libya; Baghdad; Manama and Sitra, Bahrain; Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Iwate Prefecture, Japan; Abidjan, Ivory Coast; Tel Aviv; and East Islip, N.Y.

title: Asked & Answered | Jos Parl
description: A true flneur, the artist Jos Parl records his observations of the streets of cities like Havana, Istanbul, New York and Tokyo, collecting posters, taking photographs and writings on the wall, turning them into a visual diary. Consisting of memories written in calligraphic script layered on fragments of reconstructed city walls, Parls paintings capture bits and pieces of his encounters. Born in Miami in 1973 to Cuban migrs, and now a resident of Brooklyn, Parls work has evolved into highly complex collages that emulate the various cityscapes he has visited. The Moment recently caught up with the artist to talk about his show Walls, Diaries and Paintings, which is at New Yorks Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery until April 16.

title: RSAs Secure IDs Hacked; What to Do
description: If you use an RSA SecurID keyfob or card for stricter security than a user name and password provides, you may have just become a last line of defense.

title: Notre Dame Fights Off Akron to Advance
description: CHICAGO  Well, Charlie Sheen is out of his N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament pool. Sheen, the troubled television star, had Akron making the championship game in Houston. But alas, the Zips shot poorly and were no match for No. 2 seed Notre Dame, losing, 69-56.

title: Clinton Says U.S. Should Elect Female Presidents
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton talks about Latin Americas record of electing female presidents. (At about the 28:30 mark.)

title: UConns Walker Contemplates His Future
description: WASHINGTON  The Connecticut junior point guard Kemba Walkers N.B.A. stock rises a bit more with each dominant performance.

title: Union Square, 3:18 P.M.
description: Supporters of sex workers rallied at Union Square to celebrate the American governments endorsement of a United Nations measure condemning human-rights abuses against sex workers.

title: Martha Graham Dance at the Rose Theater
description: The company continued its season on Thursday with a program of collaborations between Martha Graham and the artist Isamu Noguchi, renowned for his stage sets and mid-century furniture designs.

title: Confident George Mason Improvises a Comeback
description: CLEVELAND  Coach Jim Larranaga said he never considered signaling for a timeout to set up a play in the final minute of George Masons tight and rugged game with Villanova. Larranagas players had not run most of the plays he called all day, so why aggravate himself even more?

title: All Creatures Great and Lizardy, and Humans, Too
description: THERE is a special kind of appeal to stories that lead us to the far boundary of the human and allow us a glance at what is on the other side, where the wild things are. What often comes into view out there is a projection of something buried deep within. That wolf in the bed, in grandmas clothes, embodies some threatening animal emanation of the self, sexual or otherwise, lurking in disguise in our cozy domestic enclosures. Those invaders from outer space, preying on our cities, represent our own predatory, destructive urges in monstrous, alien form. And we cant forget the vampires, whose cold glamour places them at the busy intersection of love and death, where our longings chase their morbid shadows.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Iraq and Bahrain.

title: Celebrating an Enduring Partnership
description: Its fitting that in a film of Appalachian Spring, Isamu Noguchi is credited not with the set, but with the setting. He created the sparest of worlds. Even now, when the curtain rises on this 1944 dance by Martha Graham, you gasp a little at the raw simplicity of Noguchis farmyard: there is the peaked frame of a house, a section of a fence, a tree stump that doubles as a pulpit, a smooth bench and a slender rocking chair.

title: Look of the Moment | Ashley Olsen
description: The Look: Beyond the Pale  a modern way to think pink.

title: A Masters Baby Steps
description: THE Criterion Collection may have put the cart before the horse with Silent Naruse, a five-film set on its no-frills Eclipse label, but the paradoxes are many when it comes to the distribution of classic films in the current marketplace. The Naruse in question is Mikio Naruse (1905-69), a director many would place with Yasujiro Ozu and Kenji Mizoguchi at the summit of Japanese cinema.

title: Compose Doubles Down
description: The quirky little restaurant Compose, which serves a $120 10-course tasting menu at its bar for a single 7 p.m. seating a night, will now add a second seating at 10 p.m. It had served as many as 12 people per night, but now each seating will accommodate only 10. (A bar menu is available all evening at its banquettes.)

title: Restaurants Try to Help Japan
description: Several New York restaurants have arranged menus or fund raisers to help Japan recover from the recent earthquake and tsunami:

title: Moroccan Artisans at the Met
description: A look at some of the Moroccan craftsmen at work in a courtyard being created in the Islamic art galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (Video courtesy of the Met.)

title: Podcast: Risks and the Marketplace
description: The death toll in Japan is mounting, and engineers are still struggling to bring the reactors at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant under control. The specific details of the horrific events in Japan could not have been foreseen, but there were plenty of advance warnings about the dangers of building a nuclear plant in an earthquake zone.

title: Actor Shows His Burly Singer-Songwriter Side
description: Just to be clear: there is nothing frilly, coy or effeminate about Douglas Hodge. This British singer and songwriter, who won a Tony in 2010 for his portrayal of Albin, the wife in the revival of La Cage aux Folles, is a hearty bloke whose vocal punches land hard. A typical song in his New York cabaret debut, An Evening With Doug Hodge, at the Caf Carlyle, begins with some astringent crooning that is just a wind-up to a flurry of knockout blows before he returns to his corner.

title: Duke Rolls, Giving Irving Plenty of Playing Time
description: CHARLOTTE  Duke opened the N.C.A.A. tournament Friday with a rout that would have been uneventful if it had not produced a significant milestone. The West Region game against No. 16 seed Hampton marked the return of the prized point guard Kyrie Irving, who played for the first time since injuring his toe Dec. 4.

title: Crispy Calamari, Lemon and Maitake Salad Over Arugula
description: Time: 45 minutes

title: A Golden Crunch to Carry You Into Spring
description: TO me, crunchy fried food is hearty fare, the kind of thing I crave by the bucket in the frigid cold. But spring is middle ground, when the call for golden crackly fried morsels still rings loud, but so does the siren song of salad.

title: Ascendant Ballet Troupe May Trip Over Finances
description: GHENT, Belgium  A disembodied voice echoed through the theater: Warning: 3 ... 2 ... 1. Then a black-clad man leaped from the back of the stage, limbs slashing through space as rhythmic, syncopated electronic music pounded and wailed. Women on point picked their way along diagonals of light; an odd trio manipulated a ball and a plant; a pas de deux of breathtaking virtuosity and daring materialized from the darkness, then finished abruptly, the dancers strolling casually offstage.

title: Hanging Out With Bangin Sid
description: In every dance company, certain shenanigans take place because, well, creative people need outlets. While chatting about their new band, Bangin Sid, for an article in Arts & Leisure on Sunday, the New York City Ballet dancers Ask La Cour Rasmussen and Henry Seth brought up a somewhat unrelated subject: end-of-season parties. One involving the choreographer Jerome Robbins and the ballet master in chief Peter Martins was too good not to share. The anecdote begins with Christopher MacDougall and Peter Hansen, two company members and musicians who had made a tape of Robbins correcting dancers in rehearsal.

title: Libya Says It Will Release Times Journalists
description: Libyan government officials have told the United States State Department that four New York Times journalists who have been missing since Tuesday will be released, The Times has reported. They are Tyler Hicks and Lynsey Addario, both photographers; Stephen Farrell, a reporter and videographer; and Anthony Shadid, the Beirut bureau chief.

title: Life After Saw Turns Out to Still Be Scary
description: MOST of Insidious, the new film from James Wan and Leigh Whannell that opens April 1, takes place not in a dank, rust-stained industrial-size mens room, but in a perfectly respectable middle-class house. There are no visible hacksaws, manacles or face masks wired with explosives intended to blow a jaw apart. No one is dismembered or disemboweled. In fact, there is no bloodshed of any sort.

title: New Ideas Between Twists and Turns
description: Despite the title, Vicky Shicks Not Entirely Herself is entirely in keeping with her past dances: gossamer in structure, finely wrought in detail, full of luxurious space but thrumming with resonances and moods.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 18
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Atlantic Yards development, a gala at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and the St. Patricks Day Parade in Manhattan.

title: Texts (and Gyrations) on the Art of Movement
description: Im obsessed with the movement of ideas and the choreography of language, types Aynsley Vandenbroucke, her words projected on a screen. Those thoughts pervade Untitled, a piece in which no one dances, but thoughts about dance and our relationship to art are gently, poetically, presented.

title: The Information
description: Prologue

title: Reviewing the Nissan Juke
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Robert Peele reviews the Nissan Juke, a youth-oriented crossover whose quirky design all but begs for a passerbys mockery. He writes:

title: Chic in Review | Tyra Inc.
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Paris Wife
description: ONE

title: Journeying From Head to Toe, With a Layover at the Heart
description: Heart and brain keep meeting in the work of the choreographer Mark Morris, but each time with new results. Sometimes they marry in an irresistible outpouring whose meanings and structure reward further viewings. Sometimes they fuse in extraordinary dramatic poems buoyed by an underlying dance current. In either case we recognize him as one of the dazzling artists of our day. On other occasions they forge canny but tense alliances, with brain as the senior partner, drawing our attention to special feats of construction, nudging us to notice motifs and asking us to place meaning before pleasure. In a few works they simply collide, cancel each other out, or fight an unhappy duel to the death.

title: A Fresh Face Confronts a Seasoned Mahler
description: Mahlers Ninth Symphony is not an old mans music, exactly. Mahler was not yet 50 when he wrote it. But he was dispirited by illness and death in his family, and his own health was failing. The symphonys outer movements exude world-weariness, if not always resignation.

title: Filling a Political Vacuum in Egypt
description: Youthful organizers of the Tahrir Square revolution brought their democracy road show to Port Said, Egypt.

title: Extinct Species and Vibrant Poetry
description: Students in the Bard College Conservatory of Musics Graduate Vocal Arts Program are encouraged to explore the standard repertory and participate in the development of new music. They have an ideal mentor in the soprano Dawn Upshaw, artistic director of the program, who has worked closely with many prominent composers.

title: In Novels, an Ex-Spy Returns to the Fold
description: The sexy female spy has a well-worn place in popular culture. Angelina Jolie, donning heavy black eyeliner and a slim trench coat, in Salt. Halle Berry in Die Another Day, seductively climbing out of the surf in an orange bikini.

title: A Baltic Traditions Youthful Voice
description: Evidence of a lively choral music tradition flourishing among the Baltic nations has been with us for some time now: in splendid recordings the Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir has made for Harmonia Mundi and ECM, and in ravishing performances by the Latvian National Choir at Lincoln Center last year.

title: Free Throws and a Block Are Enough for Arizona
description: TULSA, Okla.  When Lamont Jones walks toward the foul line to shoot free throws, he can hear the voice of his mother, Jeneen Fuller, in his head.

title: At SXSW, Cue the Music
description: The music portion of the South By Southwest conference got under way in Austin on Wednesday.

title: Music Executive to Judge Contestants on The X Factor
description: Fox confirmed Friday that Antonio Reid would be one of the judges of The X Factor, a singing competition that starts on the network in September.

title: Scenes from SXSW
description: More Photographs

title: Classmates Will Now Stroll Along Memory Lane
description: Nostalgia isnt what it used to be, the saying goes. But the jape certainly applies to a revamped Web site devoted to nostalgia that is being reintroduced in a campaign that is to begin on Monday.

title: Experience Counts for Butler
description: WASHINGTON  While Butler has had success on par with the teams from the major conferences, the Bulldogs are not necessarily considered a high-major. But they are not really a mid-major either. So what exactly is Butler?

title: Senate Ally Defends Obama on Gas Prices
description: In recent weeks, President Obamas foes in Congress and industry have sought to pin the blame for rising gasoline prices  now averaging above $3.50 a gallon  on his administrations energy policies.

title: Radiation Plume Reaches U.S., but Is Said to Pose No Risk
description: Faint traces of very low levels of radiation from the stricken nuclear complex in Japan have been detected in Sacramento, European officials reported Friday, bringing the distant atomic crisis to American shores for the first time.

title: A Few Wacky Victorians in Love
description: The most scrumptious English tea, with precisely cut cucumber sandwiches, warm scones, fresh clotted cream and a cake tray piled high, could hardly be more satisfying than the sweet, silly, thoroughly enchanting revival of the 1948 musical Wheres Charley?, at City Center through Sunday. The British director John Doyles staging of this rarely seen Frank Loesser show for Encores! is impeccable on every level, one of the most fully realized productions that this concert musicals series has presented in recent seasons.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 18
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Qaddafi and His Forces Warned on War Crimes
description: PARIS  The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court warned Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Friday that if he attacked civilians in the eastern city that is the rebels base or in any other towns, he would be committing war crimes.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 18
description: More Photographs

title: Judge Backs Arbitration in Case Against Securities America
description: In a potentially costly blow to the brokerage firm Securities America, a federal judge in Dallas ruled on Friday that hundreds of arbitration claims against the company should move forward rather than being stuffed into a catch-all class-action lawsuit.

title: On Libya, Suspicious Minds
description: Until Friday, most of us could have been forgiven for thinking nothing significant could possibly be happening beyond the catastrophic shores of Japan. But after weeks of mounting crisis over Libya, and accusations of dithering on the part of the Obama administration as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces continued to take control of key cities along the Libyan coast, the weeks end brought a flurry of the highest level diplomatic maneuvers, resolutions and demands.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com, or by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Chef-Inspired Sandwiches
description: The three-month-old Roast Sandwich House in Melville is more ambitious than its nondescript strip-mall setting suggests; most of the ingredients for its 26 specialty sandwiches are made on the premises. They include roast turkey, brisket, chicken, beef and pork; fresh mozzarella; and creative condiments like mellow ale-infused mustard, tomato jam and roasted poblano aioli.

title: Quickly Becoming One of the Neighbors
description: PARK PLACE, a snappy new restaurant that opened in Floral Park in late January, pays homage to its hometown on its walls. Artistically striped in shades of taupe, they are dotted with black-and-white blown-up pictures of Floral Park landmarks: not just buildings but features like weather vanes, clocks and bell towers.

title: Atomic Anne Keeps France Spinning
description: PARIS

title: This Texan Always Wants the First Word
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Ted Poe is enthusiastic about many things, largely those that come from his home state, Texas. Beef barbecue. Oil refineries. His custom-made ostrich-skin cowboy boots, featuring the Texas state seal and the image of an American Indian tepee that symbolize his initials. (As in Ted Poe. I know thats a little quirky.)

title: For Red Bulls, High Hopes and a Little Mystery
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  On the eve of their season opener, the Red Bulls have found themselves in a strange place, twice over.

title: Former Goldman Programmer Gets 8-year Jail Term for Code Theft
description: A former Goldman Sachs computer programmer convicted of stealing source code from the firm was sentenced on Friday to more than eight years in prison, capping a case that had shone a rare spotlight on the world of lightning-fast computer-driven trading.

title: American Official Warns That Qaddafi May Lash Out With New Terrorist Attacks
description: The United States is bracing for possible Libyan-backed terrorist attacks, President Obamas top counterterrorism official said on Friday.

title: Farm Too Formal? Try the Barn
description: As a more casual alternative to the Farmhouse, the Barn at Bedford Post serves dinner on Mondays and Tuesdays, in addition to breakfast and lunch seven days a week. In daylight, the Barns low-ceilinged dining room, wrapped with French doors framing a manicured patio, has the look and feel of a garden cafe. On a recent Tuesday night, flickering votives and a crackling fire transformed the space into something more like a tavern. The mood was relaxed, the service delightful (we had easily secured a reservation that morning).

title: A Rural Setting for Urbane Nights Out
description: MY introduction to the Farmhouse at Bedford Post did not go well. Having arrived on time, we were made to idle in the dimly lighted bar for 15 minutes before being led to what was perhaps the worst table in the place, just beyond the entry, in a wide, acoustically challenged hallway that stopped exasperatingly short of the restaurants inner sanctum.

title: Traditional Tacos, and More
description: Little English is spoken at Tacos Cancun, a Mexican grocery and taqueria in Lambertville. Even The Bourne Identity, playing on a television set perched above a case of Goya sodas, was a dubbed version titled El Caso Bourne. And you wont find much printed English, since the shelves are stocked mostly with imported products: bottled horchata (a rice-based drink), Zote laundry soap and cans of pickled jalapeos.

title: A New Spot In an Old Town
description: RUNNING in rows up and down the beige walls of David Todds City Tavern, a classy-looking spot that opened in December in Morristown, are bits of local lore: George Washington first came to Morristown in 1773; By 1900 it was said that more millionaires lived in a one-mile radius of Morristown than anywhere else in the world. They do well to anchor the restaurant in time and place.

title: The Timess Pay Plan: Readers React
description: To the Editor:

title: How Best to Prepare Students for Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Raises Danger Level at Power Plant
description: By raising the level of the crisis at the Fukushima nuclear power station to 5 on a scale of 1 to 7, Japans nuclear safety agency on Friday gave it a ranking equal to that of the Three Mile Island accident of 1979. Only two events rank higher, including the 1986 Chernobyl disaster, the only accident to be rated a 7.

title: Mapping Religious Life in the Five Boroughs, With Shoe Leather and a Web Site
description: Tony Carnes and I met for breakfast at Penelope, a homey little cafe across Lexington Avenue from First Moravian Church. Penelope sits one block north and three avenues east of Marble Collegiate Church, where Norman Vincent Peale preached for 52 years, and it is a 2.8-mile drive from Sons of Moses, the tiny Lower East Side synagogue where you can still hear Lithuanian Yiddish.

title: China: Pigs Fed Illegal Additive
description: A new food safety scandal erupted in China this week, this time over pigs in central Henan Province that were fed an illegal additive believed to speed up muscle growth and burn fat, resulting in leaner pork. The banned additive, clenbuterol, is considered hazardous to people and can cause nausea, headaches, limb tremors and cancer, the Chinese media reported. Authorities said they were investigating more than 1,300 pig farms. The police have detained more than 14 people and at least 6 government officials or employees have been fired or suspended, according to media reports on Friday.

title: Details Emerge on Battle Over Projected Revenue
description: N.F.L. players raised a new issue of contention Friday, when one of their leaders said the main reason players ended negotiations a week ago was that the owners latest offer would have prevented players from getting more money if revenue was above projections.

title: After Japan: Preparing for Disasters in the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Drop Castillo, a Symbol of Their Recent Struggles
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

title: Dissent in Saudi Arabia
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkeys Justice System: The Ambassadors View
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Opulent,And a Little Atlantic City
description: DINNER at Cafe Goodfellas in New Haven is a bit like eating in a gangster theme park. You can dine with your back to a wall that Robert De Niro autographed, while you watch soundless, subtitled gangster movies on one of the restaurants 10 plasma television screens. Its a little opulent, and a little Atlantic City. The service  men, in black  is brisk and entertaining. The food is hearty, traditional Italian-American: pasta with meatballs, rigatoni with vodka sauce, and pork chop Milanese.

title: A Growing Abundance
description: Natures Grocer packs so much into its five short aisles that it comes very close to being a one-stop health food shop. And with the three-year-old business set to expand into an adjacent storefront, its selection will soon grow even larger.

title: Elite Runner Back After Radical Cancer Surgery
description: Dr. Patrick J. Boland, an orthopedic oncologist at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York, had operated on many patients with sarcomas  cancers of soft tissues  but he had never had a patient like Serena Burla, a 27-year-old elite distance runner from St. Louis. She had a potentially deadly cancer, a synovial sarcoma, that arose in and replaced one of the muscles in her right hamstring.

title: For Hardy Californians, Another Frisson of Danger
description: LOS ANGELES  As plumes of slightly elevated radioactivity drifted over the West Coast on Friday, there were inevitable runs on potassium iodide, concerned e-mails rocketing around among friends, profiteering from people selling cure-alls and plenty of assurances from government officials that there really was nothing to worry about.

title: In Syria, Crackdown After Protests
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Protests broke out in four Syrian cities on Friday, the first large-scale demonstrations here since the pro-democracy uprisings began in the Arab world three months ago. Brutal police crackdowns followed, leaving six people dead and scores injured.

title: Looking Ahead to Saturdays Games
description: Southeast

title: In Big East Versus Big East, Success Is on Display
description: WASHINGTON

title: Trustee Contends Loan Was Signal Mets Missed
description: In 2004, the owners of the Mets were scrambling to put together the financing to start their regional sports cable network. Bernard L. Madoff, according to a new court filing, offered to help, ultimately loaning the owners $54 million.

title: Pearls Future Could Impact Freshman
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  One of the casualties of the Bruce Pearl situation could be one of Tennessees best players. After the Volunteers were pummeled by Michigan, 75-45, in their West Region game on Friday, the 6-foot-8 freshman forward Tobias Harris said he was uncertain about his future with the program.

title: Electric Kool-Aid Marketing Trip
description: Los Angeles

title: A Good Old Bad Day for 3 Southern Sisters
description: The exuberant Queen Anne-style architecture of the MaGrath family home in Crimes of the Heart, with its pink scalloped shingles and white trim, perches atop the action like a giant strawberry ice cream sundae.

title: For U.C.L.A., Nail-Biting Is Part of the Experience
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The sophomore forward Tyler Honeycutt knew the phone calls and text messages were coming from his friends. They had witnessed U.C.L.A.s meltdown against Michigan State on Thursday night in the N.C.A.A. tournament. In just a matter of minutes, the Bruins nearly blew a 23-point second-half lead.

title: I.B.M. to Settle Bribery Charges for $10 Million
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the computer services provider, agreed on Friday to pay $10 million to settle claims that it gave cash and gifts to Chinese and South Korean officials in connection with about $54 million in government contracts.

title: An Advocate Who Scares Republicans
description: The piata sat alone at the witness table, facing the members of the House subcommittee on financial institutions and consumer credit.

title: 150 Works Coming to Screens at Festival
description: DIANE RAVER, executive director of the Garden State Film Festival, likes to think of the event she founded nine years ago in Asbury Park as a populists film buff gathering.

title: The Wrong Type of Talk Therapy
description: San Francisco

title: In Japans Danger Zone, the Stranded Await the Merciful
description: YAMAGATA, Japan  Some are stuck in their homes, fearful of radiation, heeding government warnings to stay indoors, cut off without electricity or phone service. Others want to leave but have no gasoline. Still more, those whose homes were ruined, wait helplessly for evacuation at crowded shelters. All face dwindling supplies of heating fuel, food and water.

title: Radiation Fears Cloud Japans Recovery
description: Add fears of radiation to the long list of troubles threatening Japans export-led economy.

title: Arizona, Bowing to Business, Softens Stand on Immigration
description: Arizona established itself over the past year as the most aggressive state in cracking down on illegal immigrants, gaining so much momentum with its efforts that several other states vowed to follow suit. But now the harsh realities of economics appear to have intruded, and Arizona may be looking to shed the image of hard-line anti-immigration pioneer.

title: Forging a Connection in Songs of Women
description: SINCE her stunning debut as Aida at the Metropolitan Opera in 2004, Angela M. Brown has been portrayed as the latest in a line of powerful African-American sopranos, a reputation she enhanced last season with outsize performances in Richard Danielpours song cycle A Womans Life with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra and the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: A Price Too High?
description: Catastrophes happen.

title: Divorce, Antebellum Style
description: The end of a marriage: it seemed an almost perfect metaphor to the worldly Mary Boykin Chesnut. As she surveyed the Union (uppercase) splitting apart, with North and South hurling bitter recriminations at each other, they reminded her of nothing so much as a long-married, long-quarreling husband and wife whose union (lowercase) had finally gone asunder.

title: Japans Automakers Expect More Delays
description: DETROIT  A week after catastrophe struck Japan in the form of an earthquake, a tsunami and a nuclear crisis, manufacturers that rely on Japanese factories are concluding that their operations will be affected more severely  and for a longer time  than they had initially hoped.

title: Freshman Guard Returns From Injury as Duke Routs Hampton
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  A smile came across Kyrie Irvings face Friday afternoon as the final minutes ticked off in No. 1-seeded Dukes 87-45 blowout of No. 16 Hampton in its West region game at Time Warner Cable Arena.

title: A Priceless Feeling Comes With Tangible Rewards
description: DENVER  At Morehead State in Kentucky, the university bookstore struggled to keep up with demand for the T-shirts commemorating Thursdays surprise victory over Louisville. The admissions department was overwhelmed with three times as many application requests as usual. Five times as many people showed up on Friday saying they wanted to tour the tiny campus, officials said.

title: Settling Foreclosure Abuses
description: State attorneys general are the traditional defenders of consumers. So when all 50 of them announced an investigation last fall into foreclosure practices at the nations big banks, there was hope for an unsparing inquiry and a meaningful settlement. Most of all, we hoped that banks would be compelled, at long last, to aggressively modify millions of additional loans.

title: Security Firm Is Vague on Its Compromised Devices
description: SAN FRANCISCO  More than a day after RSA security posted an urgent alert warning that a sophisticated intruder might be able to initiate a broad attack on a password device used by millions of customers, the announcement and its meaning remain shrouded in mystery.

title: Undeterred by Fallout Fears, U.S. and Chile Sign Nuclear Accord
description: BRASLIA  With fears of radiation spreading in Japan after the devastating earthquake there, Chile and the United States signed an accord on Friday intended to help Chile develop a nuclear energy program.

title: 3-D Glasses Are Not Just for Movies Anymore
description: THOUGH the animated feature Mars Needs Moms  came up short at the box office last weekend, it is still fair to say that 3-D entertainment remains popular. But a movie theater is not the only place where a pair of 3-D glasses can help broaden a viewers experience.

title: Many Banks Are Clinging to Billions in Bailout Money
description: Minh Uong/The New York Times

title: Obama Takes Hard Line With Libya After Shift by Clinton
description: WASHINGTON  In a Paris hotel room on Monday night, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton found herself juggling the inconsistencies of American foreign policy in a turbulent Middle East. She criticized the foreign minister of the United Arab Emirates for sending troops to quash protests in Bahrain even as she pressed him to send planes to intervene in Libya.

title: The Deep End of the Lily Pond
description: Watch out. There are lots of people walking backward at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford these days. And who can blame them? The hypnotic paintings in Monets Water Lilies: An Artists Obsession draw viewers in, closer and closer, until the images dissolve into a chaos of paint. And then, naturally, an equal and opposite reaction occurs: visitors start to back up, farther and farther, until the pictures come into focus once again.

title: Red Storm and Coach Are Attempting To Change Perceptions
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Recognition has not necessarily followed success for Kim Barnes Arico, who last year guided St. Johns to a 25-7 record and has steered the Red Storm to berths in consecutive N.C.A.A. tournaments.

title: A Cuomo Who Is Catholic but Hardly Theological
description: He goes to Mass, though not every Sunday. He considers himself a practicing Roman Catholic, yet avoids calling himself devout. He opposes the death penalty, as church leaders do. But he is divorced. And he supports same-sex marriage and abortion rights, stances sharply at odds with church teaching.

title: Heres a Job for a Crusader of Yesteryear
description: Let us call from dark caves of memory a man with a terrible swift sword.

title: All About the Woman Behind Erica Kane
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.

title: A New Internet Privacy Law?
description: Considering how much information we entrust to the Internet every day, it is hard to believe there is no general law to protect peoples privacy online. Companies harvest data about people as they surf the Net, assemble it into detailed profiles and sell it to advertisers or others without ever asking permission.

title: With Gardner Leading Off, Questions Arise About Jeter
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Friday that his experimentation with the lineup this spring would not develop into an outright competition for the leadoff spot between Brett Gardner and Derek Jeter.

title: Obama and Brazilian President Will Not Hold Press Conference
description: Braslia, Brazil  President Obama had not left Washington for his first trip to South America and word came of a bit of a communication breakdown between the United States and Brazil: The two countries presidents will not be holding a press conference on Saturday, after all.

title: A Haunting Irish Dance to the Music of Time
description: The set could almost be a corner of a country antiques store: a pretty jumble of baskets, barrels, tables and stools. But the most important object in the room  the Mundy family kitchen in County Donegal, 1936  is the radio.

title: The Broken Machinery of Death
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration seized Georgias sodium thiopental supply this week, after a complaint that the sedative used in the three-drug protocol for execution by lethal injection was imported illegally. The American producer of sodium thiopental stopped making it and the complaint says the purchase of it from an unlicensed British supplier calls into question the legality and integrity of how Georgia administers injections.

title: Mission to Mercury
description: Late on St. Patricks Day, Eastern time, a spacecraft called Messenger, weighing a little more than a thousand pounds, slipped into an elliptical orbit around the planet Mercury, becoming the only manmade object to orbit the planet closest to the Sun.

title: L.I. Congressman Leads Uphill Charge Toward a Democratic House
description: WASHINGTON  Inside the crowded pink office building that is home to Democratic headquarters on Capitol Hill, Representative Steve Israel is getting frustrated.

title: The Transmigration of a Brooklyn Saloon
description: Freddys, an iconoclastic Brooklyn dive bar that once stood in the way of a bulldozer, has returned  at least in the physical sense.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 18, 2011

title: A.C.P.T.: And So It Begins
description: BROOKLYN, NEW YORK   The serene quiet that enveloped the Ballroom of the Brooklyn Bridge Marriott this afternoon was deceptive. A mere few hours ago the room was empty, and the only evidence that something was about to happen there were the rows of tables and chairs lined up and waiting for more than 600 puzzle lovers, all vying for a place in crossword puzzle history.

title: Pierre de Beaumont, Brookstone Founder, Dies at 95
description: Pierre de Beaumont, a nominal nobleman and inveterate tinkerer who founded Brookstone, the gadget-and-gift retailer that is a familiar presence in American shopping malls, died on Dec. 4 at his home in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass. He was 95.

title: Saturday: Spirit of the Caribbean
description: Victor Mather, Metro Desk Editor at The New York Times, is gearing up to give champion Dan Feyer a run for his money at the 34th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. Read all about Victors experience as a competitive speed solver here.

title: Playoffs in Peril as Devils Are Shut Out by the Capitals
description: NEWARK  For the second straight night, the Devils lost another game they had to win, tumbling Friday to the Washington Capitals, 3-0. The Devils margin for error, hardly fat to begin with, has pretty much vanished in 27 fruitless hours.

title: David Rumelhart Dies at 68; Created Computer Simulations of Perception
description: David E. Rumelhart, whose computer simulations of perception gave scientists some of the first testable models of neural processing and proved helpful in the development of machine learning and artificial intelligence, died Sunday in Chelsea, Mich. He was 68.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Pornography Sites Will Be Allowed to Use .XXX Addresses
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The agency governing Internet addresses on Friday approved the creation of a new red-light district on the Web, but the decision may not end years of fighting over the contentious plan.

title: Chairman to Step Down at H&R Block
description: H&R Block, the tax preparation company, said Richard C. Breeden would step down as chairman, more than three years after he took control of the company in a proxy fight. Mr. Breeden, 61, plans to leave on April 18, the company said Thursday in a statement. He intends to devote more time to his hedge fund, Breeden Capital Management, H&R Block said. The company did not name a successor. Mr. Breeden, a former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was elected chairman Sept. 6, 2007.

title: Brian Lanker, Pulitzer-Winning Photojournalist, Dies at 63
description: Brian Lanker, a photojournalist who showed that small-city newspapers could have large-scale impact through the empathetic and intimate visual portrayal of American lives, died Sunday at his home in Eugene, Ore. He was 63.

title: Charges of Neglect Bring Review by State Officials
description: The New York Attorney Generals Charities Bureau will review complaints about fiscal irresponsibility and improper care given to former racehorses that have been leveled against the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation.
