title: De Niro, in a Very Limited Engagement, Takes the Witness Stand
description: It was as though a Hollywood set were being prepped.

title: Trade Unions in City Confront a Rise in Nonunion Projects
description: A luxury apartment building is rising at 23rd Street and 10th Avenue, and, across town, one is being created inside an old Salvation Army building overlooking Gramercy Park. Other residential buildings and hotels are going up on 11th Avenue, West 18th Street and East 23rd Street.

title: Answers About Stickball and Snowfall in the Spring
A Nightmarish Time in the City Is Revisited
description: T.J. ENGLISH, who chronicled Irish mobsters in The Westies, Vietnamese gangs in Chinatown in Born to Kill and the Mafias pre-Castro Cuba, returns with a swashbuckling, racially charged nightmare about New York City in the 1960s. This is one nightmare worth reliving because Mr. English so vividly recreates an era when, he writes, the city was perched on the brink of self-immolation and reminds New Yorkers how lucky they are to be living here today.

title: Anthony Is Quiet During the Game, and After
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  It was 10:30 p.m. when Carmelo Anthony finally found an unfettered path, with the goal in his sights. His gaze steady, his hood pulled tight, Anthony emerged from the visitors locker room and strode straight to the team bus, a frustrated star gone silent.

title: School-Liaison Office Is Accused of Pushing a Political Cause
description: In 2007, the New York City Department of Education created an office to help families navigate the school system and to make sure their grievances got to the right ears.

title: Japan Crisis Could Rekindle U.S. Antinuclear Movement
description: In 1973, vexed by an Arab oil embargo and soaring fuel prices, President Richard M. Nixon championed a long-term solution: to have 1,000 nuclear reactors in place in America by the year 2000 as part of a national energy independence plan.

title: Lundqvist Hurts Neck Near End of a Big Win
description: The Rangers earned an important victory at Madison Square Garden Friday night, but it almost came at an enormous cost: their workhorse goalie, Henrik Lundqvist.

title: Another Role for Buses in Civil Rights History
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Get people talking about civil rights-era buses and its all Rosa Parks all the time.

title: Remembering a Birmingham Bus Line
description: A man is working to preserve the memory of his father, who owned a fleet of buses that helped African-Americans get to school, church events and civil rights marches.

title: Escape From New York
description: New York City holds a special place in the collective conscience of Black America.

title: Bloggingheads: Daniels and the Right
description: Conor Friedersdorf, left, of The Atlantic and Conn Carroll of the Heritage Foundation debate conservative criticism of G.O.P. presidential contender Mitch Daniels.

title: No Bribes for Nuclear Deal, India Premier Says
description: NEW DELHI  Indias prime minister hit back at allegations that members of his party paid hefty bribes in exchange for support in a crucial vote to salvage the landmark civilian nuclear deal between India and the United States in July 2008, declaring in Parliament on Friday that no member of the Congress Party or his government had broken the law.

title: Q&A With Cal Ripken Jr.
description: Cal Ripken has seamlessly handled the transition from playing (he retired in 2001 after 21 years as an infielder with the Baltimore Orioles) to life as chairman and chief executive of Ripken Baseball, a grass-roots organization that oversees leagues for players ages 5 to 12; operates a youth academy in Aberdeen, Md.; and owns several minor-league teams. Ripken has added a new title: childrens book author. Hothead, Ripkens new book, written with The Baltimore Suns Kevin Cowherd and published by Disney-Hyperion, chronicles the tribulations of 12-year-old Connor Sullivan, a talented player whose temper is as uncontrollable as his power, and threatens his all-star career. Ripken, 50, has said the tale is somewhat autobiographical.

title: Prust Ignites Rangers in Win over Montreal
description: Brandon Prusts name is not on the Rangers injured list. The N.H.L. is not like the N.F.L., which documents every bruise and strain in daily reports. If Prust were a member of the New York Giants, he would probably be listed as questionable with an assortment of injuries. But Prust,a 6-foot-2 left wing that Marc Staal calls one of the toughest teammates Ive ever had, played his 72nd consecutive game of the season Friday night when the Rangers defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 6-3, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Motives of Journalist Questioned in Exiles Trial
description: EL PASO  A journalist who is a key prosecution witness in the perjury trial of a Cuban exile suspected of coordinating bombings in Havana in 1997 came under sharp attack on Friday from a defense lawyer who accused her of exaggerating news articles she wrote about the man.

title: Buzz Makes It Home, as Usual
description: I FELT so virtuous handing over $1 for the Buzz Lightyear action figure my 3-year-old daughter found amid the wreckage at the charity bazaar. Little did I know shed stolen it from a younger kid.

title: Relief at Kansas State as a Fever Recedes
description: TUCSON  From the chatter that surrounded Kansas States Jacob Pullen in recent days, youd have thought it was 2002 all over again.

title: Going Big and Getting Bigger
description: Big is the point at Lavo, a boisterous restaurant and nightclub on East 58th Street with roots in Las Vegas: big portions of Southern Italian food, big goblets of wine, big tables littered with empty lobster-tail shells and the remnants of a behemoth meatball lingering in a cast-iron skillet. The place, from the same team behind Tao and Marquee, has itself become so big since opening in September that it is already planning to expand the bar area to help get the lines of nightclub supplicants off the street. And on Wednesday, as one big man, Charles Barkley, headed to the lounge downstairs, four friends celebrated two birthdays in the dining room.

title: Agent Pursues a Cut of the Yoga Boom
description: MAJOR-LEAGUE athletes have agents who negotiate multimillion-dollar contracts with provisions like private planes and Rolexes. Hollywood actors have agents who scout for their scripts. Now comes Ava Taylor, whom one blogger has called the Ari Gold of yoga, trying to make a business out of managing the careers of yoga teachers. Yes, yoga teachers have careers.

title: Bethenny Ever Relaxing
description: One of the original Real Housewives of New York City, Bethenny Frankel, 40, has starred in two solo spinoffs on Bravo: first Bethenny Getting Married? and now Bethenny Ever After, in its second season. She lives in TriBeCa with her reality show co-stars: her husband, Jason Hoppy, 39, who works in sales; their 10-month-old daughter, Bryn; and their dog, Cookie, a Lhasa apso mix. ROBIN FINN

title: On Twitter, What a Party! Brings an Envious Enough, Already!
description: @emilyolson: And ... Im eating a taco next to Danny DeVito. #sxsw

title: Preparing for the Day the Earth Moves
description: Its not the San Andreas, but its something: Running along 125th Street, through layers of schist, lies Manhattans own fault line. In 2001, it shook the Upper East Side with a magnitude-2.4 tremor.

title: Indiana State Is No Match for Syracuses Size
description: CLEVELAND  To simulate going against Syracuses tall, long-armed front line, Indiana State Coach Greg Lansing had his players practice shooting over an assistant coach holding up a hockey stick. Lansing borrowed the idea from his former boss at Iowa, Steve Alford. He also made them practice against six defenders to prepare for Syracuses 2-3 matchup zone.

title: A Senators Shadow Family
description: EVEN in a city that celebrates unbridled ostentation, the sprawling estate at 139 Bassett Avenue in the seaside enclave of Mill Basin, Brooklyn, seems to redefine conspicuous consumption.

title: Warren Christopher, Lawyer, Negotiator and Adviser to Presidents, Dies at 85
description: Warren M. Christopher, the courtly and reserved secretary of state in President Bill Clintons first term and the chief negotiator for the 1981 release of American hostages in Iran, died on Friday night in Los Angeles. He was 85 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Japan Finds Tainted Food Up to 90 Miles From Nuclear Sites
description: TOKYO  As Japan edged forward in its battle to contain the damage at its ravaged nuclear power plants on Saturday, the government said it had found higher than normal levels of radioactivity in spinach and milk at farms up to 90 miles away from the plants, the first confirmation that the unfolding nuclear crisis has affected the nations food supply.

title: The Weekend Word: Shifting
description: Todays Times

title: Allies Open Air Assault on Qaddafis Forces in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  American and European forces began a broad campaign of strikes against the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Saturday, unleashing warplanes and missiles in a military intervention on a scale not seen in the Arab world since the Iraq war.

title: Classic Ad: A Little Extra From Esso
description: This weeks classic ad, for Esso Extra fuel, goes all the way back to the 1930s  the days when the butcher, the baker and the gasoline maker all took pride in their work, and didnt mind throwing in a little something extra for their customers.

title: Calvin Johnson and the Competition Committee
description: Are you confused by what constitutes a catch when a receiver goes to the ground? Well, youre out of luck. The competition committee chairman Rich McKay said Wednesday that if you asked me the simple question of would Calvin Johnson be a catch in 2011, the answer in our minds would be no. That means the committee is satisfied with the status quo.

title: Egypts Appetite for Politics
description: The Timess Adam B. Ellick follows an activist campaigning against a referendum.

title: TARPs Watchdog: A Tough Act to Follow
description: THE American taxpayer will lose a rare straight shooter when Neil M. Barofsky, the special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, leaves his post on March 30. In his frequent testimony before Congress and in the nine quarterly reports and 13 audits his office has published, Mr. Barofsky has served taxpayers well by speaking truth to the powers at the Treasury.

title: Amid Crises, Obama Lands in South America
description: BRASLIA  Behind the scenes here, President Obama on Saturday performed the most profound act of a commander in chief: sending American forces into conflict. Publicly, however, he kept to the schedule of his first visit to South America, hailing the United States growing economic and political ties with Brazil and predicting a path toward even greater cooperation for decades to come.

title: Obamas N.C.A.A. Bracket Is One of the Best
description: Being president is an ego trip. So you would have thought President Obama wouldnt need to add to his bragging rights. But Mr. Obamas N.C.A.A. mens basketball bracket stands  for the moment, anyway  as one of the best out there.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Photos of business news and features over the last week.

title: Japan Earthquake
description: The government said Saturday that small but safe amounts of radioactive iodine turned up in tap water in Tokyo and five other areas, amid concerns about radiation leaking from a damaged nuclear power plant.

title: Variety: Crossword Sudoku
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Ready for a cool concept?

title: A.C.P.T.: Off to the Races
description: Tournament Update: After Puzzle #6, reigning champion Dan Feyer is in first place, followed by Anne Erdmann, Francis Heaney, Tyler Hinman, and Trip Payne. You can follow the scoring as the competition continues at the A.C.P.T. rankings page.

title: In Yemen, Opposition Encourages Protesters
description: SANA, Yemen  For the first time since demonstrators began camping out in front of Sana University calling for an end to the rule of President Ali Abdullah Saleh, the countrys opposition leaders attended the protest as a group on Saturday afternoon to voice their support.

title: Euphoric, Egyptians Vote on Future
description: MANSOURA, Egypt  Elated that for the first time in their lives every ballot mattered, Egyptians flocked to the polls in record numbers on Saturday to vote in a referendum on a package of constitutional amendments that will shape the countrys political future after Hosni Mubaraks overthrow.

title: Heroes As Villains: The Case of Elizabeth Warren
description: Joe Nocera has a good piece about the demonization of Elizabeth Warren; its something remarkable to watch. In a sane world, Warren  who warned about consumer debt before it was fashionable, and in particular warned about the abusive lending practices that played a significant role in the buildup of that debt  would be an icon of reform. But to listen to the GOP, shes a power-mad usurper of individual rights, a threat to the solvency of our financial system.

title: Symbolism Jumps the Years to Duke and Michigan
description: As if it needed a shot of electricity, Sundays Duke-Michigan game contains an undercurrent of racism and class.

title: Riesch Tops Vonn After Race Is Canceled
description: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland  Lindsey Vonn lost a chance to compete for a fourth straight World Cup overall title after the season-ending giant slalom was canceled Saturday because of poor course conditions.

title: Prime Number
description: 27: The estimated percentage of the $80 billion cigarette market in the United States accounted for by menthol cigarettes. An estimated 19 million smokers prefer menthol, including 80 percent of black smokers, about 22 percent of white smokers and nearly half of 12- to 17-year-old smokers. An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration said last week that removing menthol cigarettes from the market would benefit public health, noting that evidence showed that menthol, which provides a cooling sensation that masks the harsh taste of tobacco, leads to more smoking by young people and makes it harder to quit.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: A Self-Taught Chemist Turns On the Beatles
description: Owsley Stanley, the self-taught applied chemist who perfected a recipe for highly purified LSD in the early 1960s, died last Saturday at age 76 in a car accident in Australia. In his book The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test, the writer Tom Wolfe explored Mr. Stanleys impact on the generation that came of age in the 1960s:

title: A Debate Rages On in Words, Not Punches
description: Jon Jones, a former college wrestler from Endicott, N.Y., was scheduled to step into the cage Saturday night in Newark to fight for the Ultimate Fighting Championship light heavyweight title. Bob Reilly, a Democratic state assemblyman from Clifton Park, N.Y., is working to make sure Jones never competes in mixed martial arts in their home state. Reilly is the main opponent of the effort to legalize the sport in New York State.

title: The Grime and the Emptiness of N.F.L. Labor Disputes
description: The words lockout and antitrust are not found in any N.F.L. teams playbook, but until further notice, they define a pro football future shaped by its past.

title: All Are Welcome at His Meetings. (That Means Interns, Too.)
description: This interview with  Irwin D. Simon, chairman, president and C.E.O. of the Hain Celestial Group, the natural and organic food and personal care products company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Disagreement Among Economists
description: Henry Farrell has an interesting model  as he says, more of a sketch than a fully-worked-out thesis, but provocative all the same  of disagreement among economists. The core of it is that when there are powerful political interests that want certain economic conclusions, and which believe that voters will be influenced by what economists say, economists who are politically aligned with one faction or another get suborned into providing analysis that backs that position.

title: For Yankees, an Apprentice Has Become a Survivor
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The book on Brian Cashman was that he was a small but scrappy second baseman, excellent speed, active bat, good glove, average arm and stubborn as a Steinbrenner in his approach to the game.

title: Four New Twitter Poems
description: Calling all bards! Week in Review asked four poets each to write a poem within Twitters text limit of 140 characters  title and author name not included. Share your own verse on Twitter using the hash tag #poetweet.

title: How Do I Love Thee? Count 140 Characters
description: As literary coincidences go, it might not carry quite the same cosmic portent as Halleys Comet appearing in the month of Mark Twains birth. But Monday happens to be both World Poetry Day and the fifth anniversary of the moment when a young American software designer named Jack Dorsey sent out to the world the first message using the service that soon became known as Twitter.

title: Learning to See the Strike Zone With One Eye
description: CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo.  Three weeks after a line drive crashed into his face and destroyed his left eye, Jordan Underwood sat at Logans Roadhouse in Oklahoma City and decided his tea needed some sweetener. He opened a packet, extended his arm to the glass and proceeded to pour sugar all over the table.

title: Whisper Words of Business Wisdom
description: THE Beatles were stymied. During a 1968 recording session, they couldnt find a suitable introduction to Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da, a song written by Paul McCartney. John Lennon didnt much like the song, and, after several hours, he stormed out of the studio. When he returned, he strode to the piano and banged out several chords, then added petulantly, Heres your intro!

title: The Wristwatch Is Reimagined. Will Young Shoppers Care?
description: HOW many tiny keypad buttons can fit on one wristwatch? At least 28. Thats the number that Hewlett-Packard packed onto its first watch, the HP-01, in 1977. It was such a strange hybrid of watch and algebraic calculator that calling it a mere watch or a calculator would not do it full justice. So HP called it a wrist instrument.

title: Behind a Coup of Cybercrime
description: FOR sheer entertainment purposes, one of the best subgenres of business books has been the computer-hacker narrative, the kind of technological detective story found in books like Takedown, by Tsutomu Shimomura with John Markoff (1996), and my personal favorite, The Cuckoos Egg, by Clifford Stoll (1989). When done well, these books do what the best business stories do: take readers into strange new worlds to learn strange new things, and not have it taste like cough syrup.

title: Share the Risk and Share the Harvest
description: NOT so very long ago, most Americans lived on farms, with three generations under one roof: grandparents, parents and children.

title: The Critic Returns, as the Performer
description: THE offer for the job of music critic came with this catch: If I accepted, Id have to forgo any further work as a professional musician.

title: Fighting Words
description: House Republicans have ended a Democratic program that required the Houses three main cafeterias to provide compostable cups and utensils.

title: Mind-Changing Events
description: One question that comes up occasionally in comments is, what would make me change my mind about how the economy works? Associated with this is the question of whether I have ever changed my views drastically in the face of events.

title: Agudelo Gets Red Bulls Off to Winning Start
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Veteran savvy and youthful exuberance carried the Red Bulls to a season-opening 1-0 victory over the Seattle Sounders on Saturday night.

title: Carel Boshoff, Founder of White Redoubt in South Africa, Dies at 83
description: Carel Boshoff, who established Orania, the community in South Africa that remains the countrys last bastion of white separatism, died on Wednesday at his home there. He was 83.

title: Mortar Fire From Hamas, and Israeli Tanks Respond
description: JERUSALEM  Hamas militants fired dozens of mortar shells from Gaza into southern Israel during a 15-minute period on Saturday morning, slightly injuring two Israeli civilians and sharply escalating tensions along the Israel-Gaza border.

title: Tipping the Hat to Dad
description: IM the fourth generation of my family to run our 90-year-old company, which makes official caps and apparel for major sports leagues.

title: At a Nuclear Evacuation Center
description: The Times's Mac William Bishop visits an evacuation center near the crippled nuclear plant in Japan.

title: In a Deadly Bus Crash, an American Tale
description: When a bus crashed in the Bronx a week ago, killing 15 passengers in grisly fashion, a window was opened not only on an industry that few Americans knew about, the Chinese bus business, but also on an American immigrant tradition: the ethnic occupational niche.

title: Injuries Behind Her, Versatile Guard Leads St. Johns to Opening Win
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Injuries prevented Nadirah McKenith of St. Johns from playing her best basketball for most of the season. In the Red Storms 55-50 victory Saturday against Texas Tech in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, McKenith played as if she were trying to cram a seasons worth of highlights into 38 minutes.

title: Libyas Rebellion
description: Rebels said they repelled forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that had stormed Benghazi on Saturday and appealed to the West to launch military strikes to check the advance of the Libyan leaders troops.

title: Devils Use Social Media as a Promotional Tool
description: NEWARK  Jeff Vanderbeek, the Devils owner and a New Jersey native, says it makes good business sense to listen to his teams fans because they are customers, or can be. He had about a dozen meet-and-greet receptions with hundreds of fans on his first Jersey tour last off-season.

title: Food Contamination Fears Could Harm Japanese Brands
description: TOKYO  Japans list of casualties, already long, could soon include two of the countrys iconic brands: sushi and Kobe beef.

title: Lessons for Spider-Man From the Campaign Trail
description: It was November 2003 and Senator John Kerry was nervous. Howard Dean, an opponent for the Democratic presidential nomination, had a lead in fund-raising, new endorsements from two major unions, and apparent momentum in Iowa and New Hampshire, where voting was two months away. So Mr. Kerry took one of the few quick actions within his control: He fired his campaign manager, Jim Jordan. The day after, in a five-minute exchange with reporters, Mr. Kerry repeated 10 times that he wanted to change the dynamics of the race by overhauling his political strategy.

title: Health Care Prices, for Everyone to See
description: To the Editor:

title: A Crisis That Markets Cant Grasp
description: THE risks are clear enough in hindsight.

title: Where Steaming Fried Noodles Spell Relief
description: Ramen is usually just steps away from hungry diners in most parts of Japan. Often, its in the form of flash-fried, pre-seasoned noodles packed into cellophane bags and foam cups. Now instant ramen is being sent by the truckload to the survivors of the Japanese earthquake.

title: Stress Test for the Global Supply Chain
description: TONY PROPHET, a senior vice president for operations at Hewlett-Packard, was awakened at 3:30 a.m. in California and was told that an earthquake and tsunami had struck Japan. Soon after, Mr. Prophet had set up a virtual situation room, so managers in Japan, Taiwan and America could instantly share information.

title: Lives on Edge, Focused on the Quake Zone
description: With Japan reeling from serial disasters, worried relatives of Americans living there use love, prayer and, in some cases, money to deal from afar with the tragedy and stress.

title: With a Step Back, Chasing a Return to the N.H.L.
description: WORCESTER, Mass.  Cutting through the offensive zone, Jonathan Cheechoo, who once scored 56 goals in a season for the San Jose Sharks, appeared ready to score again. But this was not the N.H.L., and when Cheechoo deftly drew the goalie out only to slide the puck to a teammate, the teammate was not ready for it.

title: Kentuckys Knight Stands Out From the Start Against West Virginia
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Except for the final two seconds, the Kentucky freshman Brandon Knight would rather forget his N.C.A.A. tournament debut. Knight missed all seven shots he took until making the game-winning layup just before the buzzer in Kentuckys victory against Princeton on Thursday.

title: The Proxy Battle in Bahrain
description: CAIRO  King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia has demonstrated one lesson learned from the course of pro-democracy uprisings across the Middle East: The world may cheer when autocrats resign, but it picks carefully which autocrats to punish for opening fire on their citizens.

title: The UConn Jersey Is the Same; the Player Isnt
description: STORRS, Conn.  Stefanie Dolson was lazy, Coach Geno Auriemma said recently. Then he reconsidered. Lazy was the wrong word. But as a freshman, Dolson did not arrive at Connecticut last fall with a real understanding of the demand for hard work on a team that has won seven national basketball championships.

title: Lessons for Japans Survivors: The Psychology of Recovery
description: JAPAN is in the middle of a catastrophe that transcends any talk of trauma and resilience, the easy language of armchair psychology. There is no reintegrating with friends and social networks now scattered or lost in the sea; there is no easy rebuilding of communities washed away, swallowed by the earth or bathed in radiation from ruptured nuclear plants.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Syrian Police Attack Marchers at Funerals
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  More than 20,000 people marched Saturday in the southern Syrian town of Daraa in funerals for protesters killed in demonstrations the day before, and the police used truncheons and tear gas to disperse the mourners.

title: At Kansas State, Teachable Moments
description: TUCSON  Kansas State Coach Frank Martin clearly does not like the word panic.

title: Green Bay Is Left a Town With a Title but No Team
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The N.F.L. lockout and the threat of a canceled 2011 football season have disquieted fans in many American cities, but the unease in Green Bay (population 102,000) is profound and multilayered. In the leagues smallest market, the Green Bay Packers not only give the region a cherished identity and an annual economic boost of more than $280 million, they are also the N.F.L.s only community-owned franchise, with more than 112,000 shareholders.

title: Palin, in India, Still Mum About 2012
description: NEW DELHI  Sarah Palin said on Saturday that she wasnt ready to announce a presidential run. I dont think there needs to be a rush, she said during an appearance at a conference here in New Delhi. Running for political office is a life-changing decision that so affects a family, she said, and many questions still needed to be answered.

title: N.F.L. and Its Players Spar in Letters From Each Side
description: N.F.L. players, angered by a letter sent to them by Commissioner Roger Goodell last week that urged them to tell their leaders to return to the bargaining table, responded Saturday with a pointed four-page missive that rebutted the leagues characterization of the negotiations and its most recent offer to players.

title: Blues Draw Fans, but Now Need an Owner
description: Dave Checketts, the St. Louis Blues chairman, announced last week that the club was for sale, a somewhat unexpected development considering it is among the strongest home draws in the N.H.L. The Blues average a crowd of 19,150 per game, which is 100 percent capacity for hockey at the Scottrade Center, and the eighth highest average attendance in the league.

title: A Countrys Lasting Aftershocks
Scenes From the Tsunami
description: Original work from three graphic artists in Japan.

title: Lessons From Chernobyl for Japan
description: CHERNOBYL, Ukraine  Twelve times a month  the maximum number of shifts the doctors will allow  Sergei A. Krasikov takes a train across the no mans land and reports for work at a structure enclosing Reactor No. 4 known as the sarcophagus.

title: A Farewell to a Member of Sabres French Connection
description: The public memorial service for the former Buffalo Sabre Rick Martin will be held at HSBC Arena in Buffalo on Thursday. For the hundreds, perhaps thousands, expected to attend, it will be an emotional and significant event. For some, saying goodbye to Martin, who died March 12 of a heart attack at age 59, will be a little like saying farewell to their favorite Beatle.

title: Bitter Legacy, Injured Coast
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: A Day for Democracy
description: Egyptians flocked to the polls in record numbers on Saturday to vote on a referendum that will shape the countrys future.

title: Fantasy Fanfare for the Common Man
description: It is a crying shame the Knicks and the Nuggets are not scheduled to meet again this season, unless miracles of Red Sea proportion were to occur east and west and the N.B.A. found itself with a New York-Denver finals attraction in June.

title: A Range of Styles in Three Performances
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Bands, bands, bands. Yes, Ive heard a few. Among them:

title: Executives May Have Lost Valuable Time at Damaged Nuclear Plant
description: This article is by  Ken Belson,  Keith Bradsher and  Matthew L. Wald.

title: Waiting for Energy to Translate Into Victories
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

title: Czech Village in Cedar Rapids Struggles for a Comeback
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  When the Cedar River rose higher than ever three years ago, it swept across the neighborhood known as Czech Village with particular brutality.

title: The Good and the Bad of Coaching Against a Friend
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Kentuckys John Calipari finally ended his drought against Bob Huggins, but if it was up to Calipari he would prefer not to coach against Huggins in the future.

title: Past and Present Meet at L.P.G.A. Tour Event
description: PHOENIX  After her second shot on the first hole bounced on the fringe of the green and stopped rolling within a foot of the cup, Shirley Spork seemed pleased.

title: Help From the U.S. for Afflicted Sister Cities in Japan
description: In Napa, Calif., residents planned a fund-raiser for Iwanuma, Japan, after seeing photographs of the damage caused when the tsunami swept over it. In Galveston, Tex., a group stitched blankets for the residents of Niigata to protect them against radiation that could fall with the snow and rain there. In Tuscaloosa, Ala., residents gathered money for Narashino, a city in Tokyo Bay.

title: Washington vs. the Merciless
description: It is hard to read the news from Japan to the Persian Gulf and then reflect on American politics and not conclude, as scientists would say, that were running an uncontrolled experiment on the only country and planet we have. And what is that experiment? Were basically taunting  there is no other word for it  the two most merciless forces on earth: the market and Mother Nature.

title: Not on the Ballot, but on All Minds in Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  It may seem odd at first glance  the first democratically elected president here, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, returning from exile on Friday, days before Haitis elections, after a vow not to insert himself in its democracy.

title: Moscows Ex-Mayor Faces Legal Scrutiny
description: MOSCOW  For years, opposition politicians accused the longtime mayor of Moscow of ruling over a sprawling empire of crony capitalism.

title: Deconstructing a Controversial Design
description: A leading question about the Fukushima Daiichi plant is why the spent fuel pool was placed on a high platform.

title: The Japanese Could Teach Us a Thing or Two
description: When America is under stress, as is happening right now with debates about where to pare the budget, we sometimes trample the least powerful and most vulnerable among us.

title: No Kiss From Kate
description: WASHINGTON

title: Still in the Fight: Steps
description: This is the last of a three-part series.

title: Gov. Cuomos All-Cuts Budget
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has rightly argued that painful spending cuts will be needed to close New Yorks projected $10 billion deficit. The hard truth is that it is impossible to cut spending deeply without cutting the states huge outlays for education and health care. That means that New Yorks most vulnerable citizens  schoolchildren, the elderly, the poor, the sick  will feel a disproportionate amount of the pain.

title: Health Law Waivers Draw Kudos, and Criticism
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials say they were expecting praise from critics of the new health care law when they offered to exempt selected employers and labor unions from a requirement to provide at least $750,000 in coverage to each person in their health insurance plans this year.

title: Deconstructing the Japanese Nuclear Plant Design
description: Watching the helicopters try to drop desperately needed water through the wrecked tops of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactors to cool the spent fuel pools, a television viewer might wonder why the waste was up there in the first place.

title: Too Late for Some Tsunami Victims to Rebuild in Japan
description: KESENNUMA, Japan  A week after the tsunami obliterated most of this northern Japanese citys seafront and not a little of its inland, the first handful of shopkeepers and their employees were outdoors shoveling mud and hauling wreckage from their businesses, signs of rebirth after this regions worst catastrophe in memory.

title: D.I.Y. Immigration Reform
description: Political, business, labor and religious leaders in Utah were widely praised last year for signing the Utah Compact, agreeing to seek practical solutions to the problems of illegal immigration while avoiding the extremist oratory and harsh enforcement schemes that have given its neighbor Arizona such a toxic reputation.

title: The Passion of Dorothy Day
description: The Roman Catholic calendar is thick with feasts of saints, each one a story. Pick a day  say, Feb. 1. Thats St. Brigid of Ireland, a nun of the early church and the patroness of dairy maids. She was a great beauty, until she lost an eye and her face became disfigured. She rejoiced, for now she could repel suitors.

title: JaVale McGees Unusual Triple-Double
description: In an attempt to get his first career triple-double Tuesday against the Bulls, Wizards center JaVale McGee showed poor judgment by taking a few ill-advised shots, then looked even worse when he achieved the feat. With 18.7 seconds left in the game, a dunk gave him 11 points, but he drew a technical foul by hanging from the rim with his team down by 19 points.

title: Abuse of the Disabled in Group Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Lost Day for Oliver Perez
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets may have finally reached their breaking point with the embattled left-hander Oliver Perez. A day after releasing second baseman Luis Castillo, the Mets watched in resignation Saturday as Perez struggled again.

title: Resignations and Budget Battles: Hard Times for NPR
description: To the Editor:

title: Time for Malpractice Reform in New York State?
description: To the Editor:

title: With Each Victory, Virginia Commonwealth Silences Critics
description: CHICAGO  There werent many of them, but the Virginia Commonwealth fans were loud and proud as the seconds ticked down on the Rams 74-56 victory over Georgetown on Friday.

title: Radiation Safety for Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting Childhood Obesity
description: To the Editor:

title: Children of Farmworkers
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Far From Title, Florida Beats U.C.L.A. Anyway
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The last two times Florida defeated U.C.L.A., the Gators ended up winning a national title. The Gators may not win it all this season, but they moved a step closer with a 73-65 victory against the Bruins in the Round of 32 in the N.C.A.A. tournament Saturday.

title: Reeling From Crises, Japan Approaches Familiar Crossroads
description: TOKYO  Such was the power of the magnitude 9.0 earthquake on March 11 that it bent the tip of Tokyo Tower, the 1,093-foot Eiffel-like structure that has stood as the symbol of Japans postwar rebirth for half a century. For the first time since it was erected in 1958, the tower no longer points directly upward, the direction that Japan followed for much of its history after World War II.

title: Your Comments on My Japan Column
description: My sunday column looks at the way Japan has pulled together in the aftermath of its earthquake/tsunami/nuclear crisis and argues that we Americans could learn a thing or two from that reaction. The backdrop is the distress Ive felt in the last few months as it has become apparent that in budget battles the tendency is to throw the weakest and most vulnerable sectors (i.e. children) overboard. In contrast, Japan seems to me to offer an example where stress knits a country more tightly together and where there has been a certain tendency for people to look after each other. (If youve come to this blog to see how to weigh in on my Win-a-Trip finalists, check out this post.)

title: Miniature Shampoo Bottles and Acoustic Sets in an Austin Hotel Room
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  There were gigs in parking lots, the noise carried off on dusty winds. There were lakeside gigs lighted by fireworks. Gigs in big theaters, at an old power plant, in a death metal pizza joint. Gigs  parades, funky drummers, ukulele serenades  in the middle of Sixth Street, the always-mobbed party thoroughfare here. And, of course, there were gigs within, outside and above bars all over downtown.

title: Sunday: Down With Thee!
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Im going to preface this by saying that I am resisting with all of my might making the obvious joke about this puzzle being for the birds. Oops. Sorry, everyone. Sometimes it just slips out.

title: A Very Mad-Man
description: Students at the nerdier extremities of American history know that The Times was founded by Henry J. Raymond, a Republican stalwart of the 1850s, and they also know that the original Republican party  a fairly radical anti-slavery party  bears little in common with the modern GOP. But these early relationships are worth probing, for they show that The Times and Lincoln were helpful to each other on their way up, and that newspapers were anything but gray ladies as the conflict drew closer. It also shows that their symbiotic relationship was seriously strained in the weeks between the inaugural on March 4 and the outbreak of war on April 12. Like so many presidents since then, Lincoln found that The Times was getting on his nerves.

title: Ringing In the Year 1390
description: MARCH 1981. My mother, all curves and decorum in her uptight Chanel suit, and my father, all stutter, glasses and advanced degrees, walked into an Alhambra, Calif., apartment: two bedrooms, one bathroom, furnished, $450 a month. Its not nice  its not Paris of the last several months, no Tehran of the 70s  but they took it. Everything is going to be different, but just for now, they kept telling themselves, this is temporary, all the change.

title: Yanks Abroad: Dempsey Sets a Record; Holden Hurt
description: Perhaps it was the prospect of a statue of Michael Jackson that is soon to be erected outside Craven Cottage. Perhaps it was nothing of the sort.

title: Full Text and Audio of Obamas Statement on Military Action in Libya
description: As my colleagues Steven Erlanger and David Kirkpatrick report, American and European forces began a broad campaign of strikes against the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Saturday, unleashing warplanes and missiles in the first round of the largest international military intervention in the Arab world since the invasion of Iraq.

title: Quinoas Global Success Creates Quandary at Home
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  When NASA scientists were searching decades ago for an ideal food for long-term human space missions, they came across an Andean plant called quinoa. With an exceptional balance of amino acids, quinoa, they declared, is virtually unrivaled in the plant or animal kingdom for its life-sustaining nutrients.

title: Williams May Be Done, But Assists Streak Continues
description: If Deron Williamss ailing wrist leads to him being shut down for the season as some are speculating, his brief time with the Nets did at least help him preserve an impressive streak.

title: Too Little Information
description: Re A Cocktail Party With Readers (March 13):

title: Teaching to the Text Message
description: IVE been teaching college freshmen to write the five-paragraph essay and its bully of a cousin, the research paper, for years. But these forms invite font-size manipulation, plagiarism and clichs. We need to set our sights not lower, but shorter.

title: A Reunion of High School Rivals
description: WASHINGTON  When Butler forward Matt Howard and Pittsburgh center Gary McGhee face each other in Saturdays Round of 32 game here, it will be a kind of Hoosier reunion.

title: Spring
description: A video, featuring Umm Kulthum, is a tribute to the young Egyptian protesters who are ushering in change.

title: Veterinarian Fired After Finding Neglected Horses
description: The veterinarian who had been evaluating hundreds of former racehorses and found that many of them needed urgent care because they were malnourished and neglected, some fatally, was fired Saturday by the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation.

title: Unfinished Business at OHare
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley will be in China next week, home of the magnetically levitated train that whisks passengers from downtown Shanghai to Pudong International Airport  just like the one he had hoped to introduce in Chicago.His trip comes a week after he had to accept a compromise plan that formally delays the final phase of the OHare Airport expansion.

title: At Qaddafi Compound, a Human Shield
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Even as the allied intervention began, a group of foreign journalists were bused on a rare visit inside Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis compound  a labyrinth of concrete barracks, fortified walls and barbed wire designed to deter potential military coups.

title: In a Tragedy, a Mission to Remember
description: I GREW up with this story, and Ive always wanted to do something about it, Ruth Sergel said. Its like a black hole in your heart.

title: Playboy Alumni Give an Old Magazine a Slick New Look
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Perezs Time as a Met Seems Short
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets may have finally reached their breaking point with the embattled left-hander Oliver Perez. A day after releasing second baseman Luis Castillo, the Mets watched in resignation Saturday as Perez struggled again.

title: 30 Seconds With Hank Aaron
description: Hank Aaron was the major league career home run leader from 1974 until 2007. Now 77, he has served since 1998 as the senior vice president of the Atlanta Braves. He is helping Topps commemorate its 60th anniversary with a Diamond Dig promotion. Special code cards are inserted in packs of 2011 Topps Baseball Series 1. Fans who enter the codes online at DiamondTopps.com receive vintage cards and a chance to win other prizes.

title: In Post-Daley Era, the Status Quo of Ward Politics Is Challenged
description: Growing up in a predominantly Italian neighborhood on Chicagos Far Northwest Side, John Rice tagged along while his father, Charlie, visited voters on behalf of the 36th Ward Regular Democratic Organization.

title: Battle Rages Over a College Radio Stations Sale
description: In mid-January, the University of San Francisco abruptly took KUSF off the air.

title: Pigeon Spikes
description: Hanging on roof and window ledges throughout the Bay Area, pigeon spikes serve as one of the many deterrents that protect local buildings from the oft-maligned birds.

title: An Element of Risk, Sure, but Oh What Fun
description: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Documents From the Kruger Files
description: State Senator Carl Kruger, an Albany power broker and Democratic moneyman, is a key player in a complicated story of corruption. These documents help to trace the tale.

title: Unclear Oversight Yields Repeated Violations at Home for Troubled Youth
description: In Alameda County, there is just one emergency group-home shelter for emotionally disturbed teenagers. It is called Refuge, for Resource Environment for Underprivileged Groups Enterprise Inc., but according to state documents and former employees, it is anything but a safe haven.

title: Yankees Count on Burnett as Their No. 2
description: TAMPA, Fla.  After a miserable season last year, A. J. Burnett will be the Yankees No. 2 starter  at least in designation  to start the season. Phil Hughes will be the No. 3 starter.

title: Kentuckys Knight Stands Out From the Start
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Except for the final two seconds, the Kentucky freshman Brandon Knight would rather forget his N.C.A.A. tournament debut. Knight missed all seven shots he took until making the game-winning layup just before the buzzer in Kentuckys victory against Princeton on Thursday.

title: A Tough Task for Illinois
description: TULAS, Okla.  It looks like a mental mismatch, not to mention a talent mismatch. Kansas and its twin big men, Marcus and Markieff Morris, against Illinois, which has been portrayed as timid by some because of so many close losses this season.

title: Pats Pick
description: The best new restaurant in Texas right now.

title: U.T. Chairman Redefines Advisory Post
description: After running a gantlet of concerned, even angry legislators, Gene Powell, the chairman of the University of Texas System Board of Regents since February, took steps last week to assuage concerns that he was leading the system toward what one prominent University of Texas at Austin alumnus called in an open letter degradation.

title: In Redistricting, Some Democrats Play the Endangered Species Card
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Police Say Brooklyn Boy Was Probably Beaten
description: The authorities are investigating what they say appears to have been the beating of a 17-month-old boy who was found unconscious and struggling to breathe inside his foster mothers Brooklyn apartment.

title: Syracuses Jardine Says Wrist Is Fine
description: CLEVELAND  Syracuse guard Scoop Jardine, who finished Fridays 77-60 victory over Indiana State on the bench with ice on his left wrist after a second-half tumble, said it would not keep him from facing Marquette on Sunday.

title: In Search of Cuts, Health Officials Question NICU Overuse
description: An unlikely battlefield in Texas budget war is a hushed pink-and-blue hospital nursery, where 1- and 2-pound babies bleat like lambs under heating lamps and neonatal nurses use tiny rulers to measure limbs that are no bigger than fingers.

title: No Stranger to Pipelines, Texas Builds One to Canada
description: TULSA, Okla.  Cory Josephs mother did not have to persuade him to shovel snow. The basketball goal was part of the driveway in their Major Oaks neighborhood in Toronto. So Joseph, a freshman guard for Texas, and his brother, Devoe, shoveled and chipped ice without threat and then left their gloves on to play ball.

title: Ohio State Assistants Higher Cause
description: CLEVELAND  If Kevin Kuwik, the video coordinator for the Ohio State basketball team, spots a flaw in George Masons defense that the Buckeyes can exploit in their N.C.A.A. tournament game Sunday, it will not be anywhere close to the most significant thing he has done in his life.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 20
description: As international leaders carry out a military intervention in Libya, Admiral Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and members of the Senate foreign policy committees will dominate the Sunday talk shows.

title: Crackdown Feeds a Flourishing World of Graffiti
description: Every big city in America has graffiti, and each tries, with varying degrees of success, to eliminate it. It is illegal, and at its worst it helps perpetuate gang violence and can foment a sense of urban disorder. At its best, graffiti is a kind of graphic art, treating city surfaces as gallery walls where anyone with a spray can may give a show.

title: Methodical Richmond Tops Fellow Underdog
description: DENVER  Richmond, a private university of 2,750 students in Richmond, Va., is no stranger to surprise advances in the N.C.A.A. tournament. It is the only program to win games while seeded No. 12, 13, 14 and 15, and it now has eight victories when seeded 12th or lower.

title: Corrections
description: SPORTS

title: Temple Pushes San Diego State, but Aztecs Hold on in Double Overtime
description: TUCSON  The pulse of a college basketball team isnt hard to find this time of year.

title: Hazel Rowley, Who Wrote of Charismatic Lives, Dies at 59
description: Hazel Rowley, a biographer whose subjects ranged from a neglected Australian writer to a famous African-American one, and from a distinguished pair of French philosophers and their romantic entanglements to a distinguished American presidential couple and their (possible) romantic entanglements, died on March 1 in Manhattan. She was 59.

title: Toshiko Takaezu, Ceramic Artist, Dies at 88
description: Toshiko Takaezu, a Japanese-American ceramist whose closed pots and torpedolike cylinders, derived from natural forms, helped to elevate ceramics from the production of functional vessels to a fine art, died on March 9 in Honolulu. She was 88.

title: Timeline: Carl Kruger and the Turano Family
description: State Senator Carl Kruger, an Albany power broker, and the Turano family of Mill Basin, Brooklyn, are players in a story of corruption and lavish living.

title: In Europe, Four Elite Events Are Closing or in Trouble
description: Some of Europes greatest tournaments are disappearing, and others are in peril.

title: Over the Brooklyn Navy Yard, 7:32 P.M.
Davies Scores Twice in D.C. Uniteds Opener
description: 11:09 p.m. | Updated Striker Charlie Davies scored two goals for D.C. United in its 3-1 victory over Columbus on Saturday night  his first league game since a car accident in October 2009 nearly cost him his life.

title: Black and White and Married in the Deep South: A Shifting Image
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss.  For generations here in the deepest South, there had been a great taboo: publicly crossing the color line for love. Less than 45 years ago, marriage between blacks and whites was illegal, and it has been frowned upon for much of the time since.

title: A Big Matchup Highlights Texas-Arizona
description: TULSA, Okla.  It is the game footage that will be within close reach of N.B.A. scouts and general managers for the next several months. It will remain on their desks or in their DVD players so they can study it frequently before the draft. It will not be put away.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 19, 2011

title: Vows: Andrea & Jeremy
description: After meeting at a Purim party in 2008 at 92Y Tribeca, Andrea Kussack and Jeremy Berman are getting married on Purim at 92y Tribeca.

title: Additional Letters: Too Little Information
description: Following up on the reader letters that appeared in my print column for this week, here are some additional letters via e-mail to my two columns, An American in Pakistan and Business News You Didnt Read Here.

title: Fredette Leads B.Y.U. to the Round of 16
description: DENVER  At the end, Brigham Young fans chanted the rare refrain of Sweet 16 and the familiar chorus of You got Jimmered, sending the legend of Jimmer Fredette  his first name now a verb  on to New Orleans for the Round of 16.

title: Envoy Quits Over Cables on Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  After a series of leaked diplomatic cables led to bitter complaints from President Felipe Caldern of Mexico, the American ambassador to Mexico has resigned, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Saturday.

title: When the Whistles Stop, Butler Beats Pittsburgh
description: WASHINGTON  Butler guard Shelvin Mack has upset a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament, won a Final Four game and come within inches of winning the national title.

title: Officials Become the Story of Butler-Pittsburgh Game
description: WASHINGTON  In an interview the week before the N.C.A.A. tournament, the officiating coordinator John Adams said the goal of the referees in the tournament was simple: We dont want to become the story.

title: Scenes From the Final Seconds of Butler-Pitt
description: WASHINGTON  This was a game that you will always remember where you watched it. Luckily for me, I got to watch Butlers 71-70 win over Pittsburgh up close. And by all accounts, Matt Howard was fouled, regardless of whether you would like a game to end on a call nearly 90 feet from the basket.

title: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: March 19
description: Action from across the country in Saturdays N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: Wisconsins Block Leaves Kansas State Hanging Its Heads
description: TUCSON  By the time two seasons came to a head at the McKale Center on Saturday night, Wisconsin guard Jordan Taylor had long since lost the much-anticipated battle with Kansas State guard Jacob Pullen.

title: Looking Ahead to Sundays Games
description: East

title: 14 Tour Buses Fail Inspection in Manhattan
description: The police pulled over more than a dozen tour buses at a surprise checkpoint on Friday night in Manhattan, and not one of them passed an inspection, state officials said.

title: The Life of Warren Christopher
description: Credited with coining the term responsible liberalism, Warren Christopher is remembered for pursuing peace through dogged diplomacy in a long career of public and private service.

title: Connecticut Holds Off Cincinnati in Win-Win Game for the Big East
description: WASHINGTON  After receiving a record 11 bids to this N.C.A.A. tournament, it was inevitable that Big East Conference teams would be put in position to devour their own. Initially, some of the leagues coaches said this would be an unfortunate result of an otherwise sunny situation.

title: Japan Makes Progress at Nuclear Reactors, but Contamination Spreads
description: TOKYO  Japan appeared to make moderate progress in stabilizing some of the nuclear reactors at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi power plant on Sunday, but at the same time it disclosed new signs of radioactive contamination in agricultural produce and livestock.

title: Allies Target Qaddafis Ground Forces as Libyan Rebels Regroup
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  American and European militaries intensified their barrage of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces by air and sea on Sunday, as the mission moved beyond taking away his ability to use Libyan airspace, to obliterating his hold on the ground as well, allied officials said.

title: Japan Reels From the Crisis
description: Scenes from the aftermath of the tsunami and earthquake in Japan.

title: 2012 Mercedes-Benz C63 AMG Coupe Unveiled Before New York Auto Show
description: Mercedes-Benz announced on Sunday that its 2012 C63 AMG coupe would arrive in dealer showrooms in September, on the same timeline as the revised C63 AMG sedan. The coupe will be shown at the New York auto show next month.

title: Yemens President Said to Have Fired Cabinet
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemens president fired his cabinet on Sunday, while antigovernment demonstrations here in the capital grew in number and momentum two days after government-linked forces opened fire on protesters, killing at least 45 people and wounding more than 200.

title: At London Antiques Fair, Something for Everyone
description: Chelsea is home to the longest continually running antiques fair in London. Now in its seventh decade, the Chelsea Antique Fair, running from March 23 to 27, takes place amid the gilded opulence of Chelsea Old Town Hall. Organized by the veteran dealer Caroline Penman, who took over the fair in 1984, its the place to get a glimpse into a particularly British world of taste and decorum.

title: A Grappler Says Goodbye
description: While most of the sporting world was glued to the mens basketball tournament, a true champion of the spirit of collegiate sports slipped relatively quietly into retirement on Saturday after the N.C.A.A. wrestling championships in Philadelphia.

title: Chad Ochocinco Probably Isnt Good at Soccer
description: Darn you, Chad Ochocinco. The Fifth Down tries to resist your relentless promotions  your one-man permanent publicity campaign  but gave up on this one.

title: Haitians Go to the Polls to Choose a New President
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Many of the ballots arrived late and some voters were turned away, but the problems appeared minimal in a presidential runoff Sunday to decide whether a bawdy Carnival singer running as a populist or a former first lady rooted in the establishment will lead this country for the next five years.

title: With Confidence and Skittishness, Libyan Rebels Renew Charge
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  The streets of Benghazi lurched between ecstasy and paranoia on Sunday.

title: A.C.P.T.: The Shake Out
description: BROOKLYN, NEW YORK   Going into the Finals with Puzzle #8, the competitors going to the big boards in the A Division are Dan Feyer, Anne Erdmann, and Tyler Hinman. Congratulations to all who competed! Stay tuned for more updates on the Finals and my wrap-up, which will be posted on Monday.

title: Was Tokyo Electric Singing Hesitation Blues?
description: 12:46 p.m. | Updated

title: Detritus of War
description: Littered across the landscape, some 30 miles south of Benghazi, the detritus of the allied airstrikes offered a panorama of destruction on Sunday.

title: Rotation and Lineup News and Notes
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Derek Jeters beloved Michigan Wolverines are scheduled to play Duke in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament at 2:45 p.m. Sunday  or, right around the sixth inning of the Yankees game here against Philadelphia. Jeter, smiling, sounded disappointed when he was told that Joe Blanton was starting for the Phillies. If it was Halladay, Jeter said, we might be able to finish by then.

title: Taliban Condemn Attacks on Libya
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has at least one good friend in the outside world  the Taliban in Afghanistan.

title: In Britain, Curbing Lawsuits Over Libel
description: Some tourists head to London to visit Big Ben or the Tate museum. For wealthy individuals or celebrities who feel that they can sue the news media under Britains libel laws, the Royal Courts of Justice have long been a popular stop.

title: Reuters: West Strikes Libya
description: Qaddafi remains defiant as the West strikes Libya. (Video: Reuters)

title: A.C.P.T.: The Big Boards
description: BROOKLYN, NEW YORK   Sunday morning at A.C.P.T. has an unusual flavor. Most of the attendees are exhausted, either from competition or from socializing or a nice mixture of both. The mood is subdued, and those who are not in the top tier of solvers will go into Puzzle #7 just trying to maintain their pride and finish respectably. Conversation centers, as it should, around personal rankings and thoughts as to who will face the big boards later on today in the Finals.

title: Paying for The Times at SXSW
description: On Thursday, I had lunch with a pal at the South by Southwest Interactive Conference, that annual crush of media and technology people that descends on the lovely town of Austin, Tex. When he offered to pay, I said, You dont need to do that.

title: Strangers in a Strange Land
description: Haitians living in the United States but convicted of misdemeanors and drug offenses are now being deported to Haiti again after a one-year moratorium.

title: Scenes From a Japanese Restaurant
description: Six oclock on Thursday evening and Geido was filling up.

title: 'Songs of Wars I Have Seen'
description: An excerpt from Heiner Goebbels's "Songs of Wars I Have Seen," with Anu Tali conducting the London Sinfonietta and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment. (Video courtesy of Lincoln Center.)

title: All-Star Teams in Bonds Case: The Lawyers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Barry Bonds will walk into United States District Court here on Monday ready for a contest likely to be tougher than any baseball game or home run race he ever took part in.

title: Young and Mixed in America
description: College campuses across the United States are seeing more mixed-race students than ever before. They are leading a sea of change in how we think about race and ethnicity.

title: AT&T to Buy T-Mobile USA for $39 Billion
description: 12:16 a.m. | Updated AT&T announced on Sunday that it had agreed to buy T-Mobile USA from Deutsche Telekom for $39 billion, in a deal that would create the largest wireless carrier in the nation and promised to reshape the industry.

title: In Brazil, Racial Symbolism is Unmistakable
description: President Obamas trip to multiracial Brazil is providing a case study in how Americas first African-American president approaches the matter of his race: Let the symbolism speak for itself.

title: Normalcy Returns for Tar Heels After Another Wild Finish
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  North Carolina returned to national prominence this season after being banished to the National Invitation Tournament in 2010, a one-year hiatus that seemed like 10 for a program expected to challenge for titles ever year.

title: Egyptian Voters Approve Constitutional Changes
description: CAIRO  Egyptian voters overwhelmingly approved a referendum on constitutional changes on Sunday that will usher in rapid elections, with the results underscoring the strength of established political organizations, particularly the Muslim Brotherhood, and the weakness of emerging liberal groups.

title: Newcomer Wins New York City Half Marathon
description: On a cloudless 34-degree morning at the New York City Half Marathon on Sunday, two men who had never raced a half marathon outlasted all but one of the heavy favorites as the 12-man lead pack in Central Park narrowed to seven on 42nd Street and dissolved to four heading down the West Side Highway.

title: Rangers Beat Penguins to Extend Win Streak to 4
description: PITTSBURGHThe Rangers have gotten hot when they needed to. They won their fourth game in a row and sixth in their last seven, giving themselves a big boost in the tight Eastern Conference race, with a 5-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins on Sunday afternoon.

title: Focusing on the Prize
Three Queens of 'Priscilla'
description: Simon Phillips talks about directing the new Broadway musical "Priscilla, Queen of the Desert."

title: Regulator Says Fuel Pools at U.S. Reactors Are Ready for Emergencies
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Sunday morning that the spent fuel pools at American nuclear reactors are less vulnerable than the ones in Japan because of steps ordered by his agency after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, including having utilities prepare to use fire hoses to pump in extra water in the event ordinary cooling systems are knocked out.

title: Telecoms Active Deal Machine
description: With AT&T moving to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, telecom companies are now the second most active deal-makers in the world.

title: A Castles Locked Doors Bring Out a Wifes High C
description: Since he stepped down as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in 2009, Esa-Pekka Salonen has largely devoted himself to composing and, luckily for us, freelance conducting. Last season he led a burning new production of Janaceks From the House of the Dead at the Metropolitan Opera, and he has now organized the New York Philharmonics three-week Hungarian Echoes festival, juxtaposing works by Haydn, Bartok and Ligeti.

title: The Shape of Fun (Birds and Forests Included)
description: Since Theatre-Rites and Arthur Pitas Mischief is aimed at the 10-and-under demographic, it seemed only proper procedure to engage research assistants for a trip to the New Victory Theater, where the show opened on Friday. The assistants, aged 10 and 8, made copious notes during the performance. Afterward I asked for opinions. Good, said the 10-year-old. Very good, said the 8-year-old. Any complaints? Criticism? No, good, they chorused.

title: A.C.P.T.: The Winners
description: BROOKLYN, NEW YORK   Congratulations to Dan Feyer, who won the top prize at the A.C.P.T. for his second year in a row. Tyler Hinman came in second and Anne Erdmann third. Further congratulations to David Plotkin, Ken Stern, and Richard Kalustian in the B Division and Jeffrey Dubner, James Lehr, and Andrew Snyder in the C Division.

title: Rantings of an Ex-Maestro
description: Some people have asked me for reactions to this piece by Alan Greenspan (pdf) on how Obamas activism is preventing economic recovery. I could go through the weak reasoning, the shoddy econometrics that ignores a large literature on business investment and ignores simultaneity problems, etc., etc..

title: Baroque Music So Clean It Runs Itself
description: You rarely see a conductor remove himself from a performance, but that was what Christopher Hogwood did on Saturday evening when he presided over a program by Juilliard415, the Juilliard Schools period-instrument ensemble, at Alice Tully Hall. Just after leading the opening work, Haydns Symphony No. 6, Le Matin (Morning), Mr. Hogwood turned to the audience. He expounded on the music the group would be playing  the rest of Haydns times-of-day trilogy and music by Francesco Geminiani (whose complete works Mr. Hogwood is editing)  and on some of the ways a historically minded conductor prepares a young ensemble of this kind.

title: The Advisers Behind the AT&T Deal
description: More than a few banks and law firms will be ringing up handsome fees for putting together AT&Ts $39 billion bid for T-Mobile USA.

title: The Butler Does It for Marquette
description: CLEVELAND  Its one thing to be Jimmered. The other night, Tu Holloway of Xavier got Butlered.

title: A Young Muse in the Service of Male Writers
description: One of the semifamous men who populate Art and Madness, Anne Roiphes new memoir about her years as a hands-on worshiper of male writers, is a lyricist. He has written the words to a song that Elvis Presley has made as common as salt on the dinner table, she says. She sounds so unimpressed that it takes her three pages to indicate what the song was. (Hound Dog, of course.)

title: Assessing the Casualties in Libya
description: A day after Western nations struck Libyan air defenses, surveying the damage has been difficult.

title: First-Person Reflections on a Pop Career
description: At a certain point in the middle of their lives it is good for pop stars to go away for a while  not just for a year, but even for 5 or 10. They come to understand what theyve done in the world. They can frame it all better. The river of ones work is over here, and the task of mapping it over there; generally you have to abandon one to attend to the other.

title: Crackdown Was Only Option, Bahrain Sunnis Say
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  When Bahrains pro-democracy movement began its demonstrations in Pearl Square last month, Atif Abdulmalik was supportive. An American-educated investment banker and a member of the Sunni Muslim elite, he favored a constitutional monarchy and increasing opportunities and support for the poorer Shiite majority.

title: The Vanderbilt Field Narrows in Louisville
description: In Louisville, Ky., the 64-board final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams was scheduled to be played on Sunday between the teams led by Martin Fleisher and Joe Grue, both of New York.

title: Duke-Michigan Rivalry Renewed With Same Result
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Whatever controversy swirled around Duke and Michigan before their N.C.A.A. tournament game Sunday, the renewal of their rivalry had less to do with revisiting history than with repeating it.

title: With Color and Cream, a Tiny Dessert Stakes Its Claim
description: A delicate French pastry is trying to take over New York, one mouth at a time.

title: Limitless and Rango Lead the Way
description: The increasing star power of Bradley Cooper, right, helped lift Limitless to a stronger-than-expected $19 million in ticket sales over the weekend, easily making this supernatural thriller No. 1 at North American theaters. Produced for about $27 million, Limitless, about a writer who discovers a secret drug that gives him special powers, gives Relativity Medias fledgling distribution operation a much-needed win. Rango (Paramount Pictures) was second with about $15.3 million in sales for a three-week total of $92.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. Battle: Los Angeles (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was third with an estimated $14.6 million for a two-week total of $60.6 million. A much-publicized marketing partnership with Groupon.com appeared to be a failure for Lions Gate Entertainment, as its Lincoln Lawyer, produced for about $40 million, opened in fourth place with a tepid $13.4 million. Paul, a comedy from Universal Pictures that also cost about $40 million to make, was a disappointing fifth with $13.2 million.

title: Glaad Awards for Russell Simmons and Others
description: Russell Simmons and Ricky Martin were honored at the 22nd annual Glaad Media Awards presented by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation on Saturday in New York. Mr. Simmons, right, a co-founder of Def Jam Records, a fashion designer and the author of several self-help books, received the award for excellence in media. Mr. Simmons recently took part in advertisements for the Human Rights Campaign, along with other celebrities, to support the New Yorkers for Marriage Equality campaign. Mr. Martin, who announced on his Web site last March that he is gay, was given the Vito Russo Award for promoting equal rights. Mr. Martins appearance on The Oprah Winfrey Show to talk about his experience also won for outstanding talk show episode. Other honorees included Frank Rich, former columnist for The New York Times; The Star-Ledger in Newark, for its coverage of the suicide of the Rutgers student Tyler Clementi; and CNNs Anderson Cooper 360 for an episode about the suicides of gay teenagers. The band the Scissor Sisters won for its album Night Work (Downtown Records), and Marvel Comics was recognized for its X-Factor comic series by Peter David. More awards will be announced later this year at ceremonies in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

title: Stories of Isolation Receive Attention
description: Two Canadian authors tales of youths growing up in isolation have been added to the list of nominees for the British Orange Prize for fiction written by women, BBC News reported. Emma Donoghues Room, which was also on the short list for last years Man Booker prize, made the cut of 20 writers, along with Annabel, the first novel by Kathleen Winter, a former writer for Sesame Street, about a young hermaphrodite growing up on the northeast coast of Canada in 1968. Ms. Winter joins eight other debut novelists on the list, including Ta Obreht, whose Tigers Wife was released to critical acclaim this month; Tishani Doshi (The Pleasure Seekers); and Samantha Hunt (The Seas). The short list of nominees will be announced on April 12, and the winner, who will receive almost $50,000 and a bronze statue, will be announced on June 8 at a ceremony in London.

title: The Art of War, in Graphic Detail
description: Next month The Art of War, Sun Tzus dissection of military operations from more than 2,000 years ago, will join the recent string of novels, television shows and, now, advice, business and motivational books to be turned into graphic novels. According to a report on the blog galleycat.com, the publishing group Round Table Companies, in partnership with Smarter Comics, will release a series of comic book adaptations of best-selling nonfiction titles. The Art of War; The Long Tail, by Chris Anderson; From the Barrio to the Boardroom, by Robert Renteria; and How to Master the Art of Selling, by Tom Hopkins, will be among the titles released in print on April 16 and as a free download online from April 1through July 1. In an e-mail Corey Michael Blake, the chief executive of Round Table, said that he hoped to attract the interest of busy professionals, Twitter-generation readers who prefer to be entertained as they are educated, and traditional comic book readers. Ive been combining business and entertainment for years, Mr. Blake wrote. Seeing it working over and over, this was a gut play. My instinct told me that we had an opportunity to revolutionize the nonfiction reading experience.

title: Monday: Amount in a Whiskey Glass
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Who knew there were so many ways to indicate agreement?

title: Flamenco, Hip-Hop and Bare Midriffs
description: If visitors from another galaxy descended on Earth and happened to land at New World Stages Theater No. 1, where Between Worlds (Entre Mundos) is playing, they would find a useful shorthand guide to life here.

title: Beltran Confident He Will Be Ready Opening Day
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  After taking batting practice from both sides of the plate and doing some light sprinting in the outfield, Carlos Beltran said Sunday that he was more confident than he had been in days that he would be ready to play on opening day, April 1.

title: At the Maastricht Art Fair, a Rembrandt and a Red Shoe
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  There are crowd pleasers at this years European Fine Art Fair, like a Rembrandt portrait regally displayed behind a black rope. There are also paintings by Renoir and Picasso, Mir and Warhol. But the main allure of this annual, super-size event is its breadth. Besides the smorgasbord of brand-name paintings there are arcane objects here too, like a 12th-century carved ivory chess piece about the size of a thumbnail, or a two-headed Chinese wood sculpture dating from around the third century B.C. Theres even a 118-carat diamond with a $25 million price tag.

title: A Musical Discourse on War and Cities
description: The Tully Scope festival at Lincoln Center opened on Feb. 22 with a free performance of a contemplative new piece by Nathan Davis, presented in the beautifully renovated lobby of Alice Tully Hall, and a bracing concert by the International Contemporary Ensemble in the auditorium. But the theme of the festival was hard to discern.

title: Where the Music Still Roils in a Critical Mass
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The keynote speech at the 25th annual South by Southwest Music festival, which took over downtown Austin from Wednesday to Saturday, was a bit grumpy. Bob Geldof, the Irish rocker who led the Boomtown Rats in the 1970s and went on to assemble the global Live Aid benefit concert in 1985 and its Live 8 sequel in 2005, bemoaned musics loss of relevance. Although there was no shortage of cool bands, he said, music didnt have the kind of broader social impact that it did with the Beatles, Bob Dylan, punk and grunge. He argued that music was no longer channeling rebelliousness and discontent.

title: Agudelo Has the World at His Feet
description: It would be easy to get overheated and overexcited about the impressive play of Red Bulls striker Juan Agudelo after he scored the only goal in his clubs season-opening win over Seattle on Saturday night.

title: Regional Election Gives Merkels Party Some Hope
description: BERLIN  Gaining a respite after recent defeats in regional votes, Chancellor Angela Merkels Christian Democratic Union looked set to remain in power on Sunday in the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt, according to preliminary election results.

title: Hello Again
description: Photos from the Transport Groups revival of the Michael John LaChiusa musical.

title: Music and More
description: Photos of performances at the 25th annual South by Southwest music festival in Austin, Tex.

title: Matt Cooke Does It Again
description: Penguins agitator Matt Cooke will almost certainly be ordered to pay another visit to the office of N.H.L. judge Colin Campbell in the next few days. With his Penguins tied with the Rangers in the third period, 1-1, Cooke nailed Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonough with an elbow to the head. This is exactly the kind of hit that the league has implemented rules over the last year to eliminate  motivated, in part, by some hits by Cooke to heads of his opponents.

title: How Manhattans Grid Grew
description: Compare the proposed street grid for Manhattan, from 1811, with the current layout.

title: Slow at Start, Ohio State Finds Its Rhythm in Rout of George Mason
description: CLEVELAND  Coming out of a timeout with 2 minutes 35 seconds left in the first half, the players remaining on the George Mason bench slumped in their chairs with blank looks, as if they were watching a fistfight too gruesome to be believed.

title: Drew Hill, Receiver for Run-and-Shoot Oilers, Dies at 54
description: Drew Hill, who arrived in the National Football League as a 12th-round draft pick but became a Pro Bowl receiver in the Houston Oilers high-powered run-and-shoot offense of the late 1980s and early 90s, died Friday in Atlanta. He was 54.

title: Educated, Unemployed and Frustrated
description: WE all enjoy speculating about which Arab regime will be toppled next, but maybe we should be looking closer to home. High unemployment? Check. Out-of-touch elites? Check. Frustrated young people? As a 24-year-old American, I can testify that this rich democracy has plenty of those too.

title: A Rosenberg Co-Conspirator Reveals More About His Role
description: Morton Sobell, who was convicted with Julius and Ethel Rosenberg in 1951 in an espionage conspiracy case and finally admitted nearly six decades later that he had been a Soviet spy, now says he helped copy hundreds of pages of secret Air Force documents stolen from a Columbia University professors safe in 1948.

title: Fukushima, Indian Point and Fantasy
description: Theres no magic number, of course. Is it perilous at 10 miles away, but not 11? Is there an evacuation zone that would be a one-size-fits-all plan for any nuclear disaster? You dont need a physics degree to answer those questions.

title: Sarkozy Puts France at Vanguard of Wests War Effort
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy may be down in the opinion polls, but he has put France boldly in the forefront of an allied effort to prevent the decimation of the opposition to Libyas leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Rush of Events Gives Foreign News a Top Priority
