description: Propelled by revolution in the Middle East and radiation in Japan, television news coverage of foreign events this year is at the highest level since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks 10 years ago, news executives in the United States say.

title: Yankees Could Face Hard Choice on Garcia
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  The Yankees starting pitchers in games to come are listed by their initials on the dry-erase board in Manager Joe Girardis office, and on Sunday morning there was no sign of F.G. A day after Freddy Garcia faltered late in his six-inning start against Toronto, Girardi hinted that Garcia was likely to pitch next on Thursday, a scheduled day off, a development that casts further intrigue into the competition for a rotation job.

title: Bidders Near First Step in Mets Deal
description: Over the next week to 10 days, five to eight possible bidders for a minority stake in the Mets will take a first step to making an offer by examining the teams financial records.

title: Receiving a Jolt From Fresh Faces at Point Guard
description: STORRS, Conn.

title: He Can Hit Shots, but Must Wait for One
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees welcomed Jorge Vazquez into their spring training facility with the intention of sending him to Scranton, Pa., not the Bronx, when they break camp at the end of the month.

title: 200th Birthday for the Map That Made New York
description: Henry James condemned it a century ago as a primal topographic curse. Rem Koolhaas, the architect and urbanist, countered that its two-dimensional form created undreamed-of freedom for three-dimensional anarchy. More recently, two historians described its map, regardless of its flaws, as the single most important document in New York Citys development.

title: At Thrillist, Mingling Commerce and Content
description: The Web site Thrillist publishes daily e-mails aimed at a young, male audience, with tips about activities in various cities. But along with that content, it offers separate e-mails selling clothes and deals at local businesses, melding commerce and content in ways that have long made traditional publications bristle.

title: Users Help a Weather Site Hone Its Forecasts
description: Kevin Bleier, an amateur meteorologist, lugged a weather station up several precarious ladders to reach the peaked roof on his 40-foot-tall house in Alameda, Calif., then mounted it on a 15-foot pole to capture data for his personal weather site.

title: A Second Front to Open in the Labor Battle
description: Last week, Kevin Mawae, the president of the now-dissolved N.F.L. players union, sought to explain the status of the owners accusation now before the National Labor Relations Board that the union had not negotiated in good faith.

title: Delaying First Pitch Debated in Baseball-Loving Japan
description: TOKYO  As bodies are still being pulled from the rubble, as the effects of a nuclear crisis spread, as many companies and schools remain closed if they are standing at all, is it time to play baseball?

title: Unbreakable Bonds
description: Washington

title: Anthony Is Better in Loss, but Its Not Good Enough
description: MILWAUKEE  Carmelo Anthony made amends, reclaimed his smile and his swagger and reasserted his place in a Knicks offense that remains intermittently ragged but badly needs him in it.

title: The Evolving Mission of Google
description: Todays quiz: What company derives 96 percent of its revenue from advertising, has a video platform that is currently negotiating with the National Basketball Association, a movie studio and various celebrities, and is developing a subscription service that would be plug-and-play for publishers and consumers the world over.

title: Details Emerge on Sticking Points in N.F.L. Talks
description: With the N.F.L. expected to file its brief Monday on the players request for an injunction to lift the lockout just as owners and coaches begin their annual meeting, more details emerged about the offer that was on the table when talks collapsed March 11.

title: Officers Fire on Crowd as Syrian Protests Grow
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Protesters set fire to the ruling Baath Partys headquarters and other government buildings in the southern city of Daraa on Sunday, as protesters rallied and clashed with the police for a third straight day, witnesses said.

title: Telecom Union Backs T-Mobile Deal
description: 8:53 p.m. | Updated

title: No Hero in 1811, Street Grids Father Was Showered With Produce, Not Praise
description: John Randel Jr., the secretary, surveyor and chief engineer for New York Citys street commissioners, was hardly the most popular public servant of his day.

title: Tweety Was Right: Cats Are a Birds No. 1 Enemy
description: While public attention has focused on wind turbines as a menace to birds, a new study shows that a far greater threat may be posed by a more familiar antagonist: the pet house cat.

title: Food Stamps and Tax Aid Kept Poverty Rate in Check
description: Without a flood of food stamps and tax benefits for low-income families, about 250,000 more New Yorkers would have slipped into poverty at the height of the recession, according to calculations to be released Monday by city officials.

title: That Budget Battle? Only a Skirmish
description: Think of Washingtons initial 2011 budget fights as spring training  for a season about to open in a hailstorm.

title: 2 Decade-Old Arrest Warrants for Queens Councilman
description: Councilman Ruben W. Wills of Queens acknowledged on Sunday that he had failed to resolve an outstanding arrest warrant related to a business dispute from more than a decade ago.

title: As Mets Travel, Perez Stays Behind, Awaiting a Possible Last Chance
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The embattled reliever Oliver Perez walked into the clubhouse in Port St. Lucie at 8:04 a.m. Sunday for another workday with the Mets. Beyond that, however, his future with the team seemed as if it could be counted in hours and minutes.

title: Target in Libya Is Clear; Intent Is Not
description: WASHINGTON  All the deliberations over what military action to take against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya have failed to answer the most fundamental question: Is it merely to protect the Libyan population from the government, or is it intended to fulfill President Obamas objective declared two weeks ago that Colonel Qaddafi must leave?

title: Obama Urges Irans Youth to Shed Chains
description: Even as the United States has joined a coalition at war against Libyas government and monitors pro-democracy upheaval throughout the Middle East, President Obama on Sunday all but invited the young population of Iran to throw off the government there in a Web address transmitted to the region, adding, I am with you.

title: Timess Online Pay Model Was Years in the Making
description: The discussions played out over most of 2009 amid the hum of the third floor newsroom and in the executive suites high above Times Square, consuming what seemed like countless meetings and consultants recommendations.

title: Mets Owners Rebut Charges in Madoff Suit
description: The owners of the Mets, having been sued for $1 billion by the trustee representing victims of Bernard L. Madoffs vast Ponzi scheme, charged in court papers Sunday that the trustee had repeatedly ignored or misrepresented evidence that showed they had no good reason to have suspected Mr. Madoff was operating a fraud during their many years of investing with him.

title: Airstrikes in Libya; Questions Back Home
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas decision to authorize military strikes against Libya exposed him to another set of political crosscurrents from right and left and further complicated his plan to keep his agenda focused on the domestic economy.

title: Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz Response to Irving H. Picard
description: The court filings on behalf of Mets owners Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz charging that Irving H. Picard repeatedly ignored or misrepresented evidence.

title: 3 Youths Held in Killing of Woman Over Purse
description: The newlyweds were often spotted hand-in-hand, strolling in their Queens neighborhood.

title: Mullah in Debate of Tradition vs. Modern Schooling
description: AKKALKUWA, India  On opposite sides of a dusty road, thousands of Muslim students in this remote farming town are preparing for very different futures. On one side, inside a traditional Islamic seminary, teenage boys in skullcaps are studying ancient texts to become imams. On the other, students are hunched before computers in college classrooms, learning to become doctors, pharmacists and engineers.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: At End, Arizona Hits Shots That Count
description: TULSA, Okla.  Texas was a bust again in the N.C.A.A tournament, an upset victim not just at the hands of the opponents star player, but also at the hands of Arizonas band of outside shooters and perhaps another bewildering game by the officials.

title: Teacher Lesson: The Work and the Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Harlem Skaters Say Park Favors Hockey
description: A long-simmering dispute over the use of the ice rink at Riverbank State Park in Harlem burst into the open under the bright skies of Sunday afternoon, with protesters from a girls figure skating organization charging that hockey teams, made up mostly of boys, dominated the ice time.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: What to Make of Big East After the First Weekend
description: The Big East Conferences strut has officially been reduced to a stumble. When the dust settled and the N.C.A.A. tournaments Round of 32 drew to a close Sunday night, just 2 of the leagues 11 teams were left standing, and both reached that point by eliminating teams from their own conference.

title: Ending the Abuse of the Developmentally Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: A Very Liberal Intervention
description: In its month-long crab walk toward a military confrontation with Libyas Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Obama administration has delivered a clinic in the liberal way of war.

title: Trial to Open in Lawsuit Connected to Hospital Deaths After Katrina
description: A jury trial set to open on Monday will weigh whether one of Americas largest health care corporations should be held accountable for deaths and injuries at a New Orleans hospital marooned by floodwaters after Hurricane Katrina.

title: The War on Warren
description: Last week, at a House hearing on financial institutions and consumer credit, Republicans lined up to grill and attack Elizabeth Warren, the law professor and bankruptcy expert who is in charge of setting up the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. Ostensibly, they believed that Ms. Warren had overstepped her legal authority by helping state attorneys general put together a proposed settlement with mortgage servicers, which are charged with a number of abuses.

title: Castillo Close to Deal With Phillies
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Released by the Mets on Friday, Luis Castillo is on his way up in the National League East hierarchy.

title: President Underscores Similarities With Brazilians, but Sidesteps One
description: RIO de JANEIRO  From a visit to this citys most infamous slum to a national address amid the gilded elegance of a celebrated theater, President Obama on Sunday sought to underscore the shared histories and futures of the United States and Brazil, reaching out to the people of one of the most racially diverse countries in the Americas.

title: J. D. Salinger Slept Here (Just Dont Tell Anyone)
description: COLLEGEVILLE, Pa.  For years, officials at Ursinus College had been trying to figure out how to capitalize on the fact that J. D. Salinger had spent one semester there in the fall of 1938.

title: Web of Love, Explicitly Woven in Shades of Anguish
description: Do you know how to behave in public when people are having sex only a few feet away from you? You had better address this delicate point of etiquette before you see the Transport Groups exceedingly intimate revival of Hello Again, Michael John LaChiusas musical portrait of lust in the 20th century.

title: A Chance to Build Again
description: Many of the 85,000 dams in the United States are so old  an average of half a century  that every time one is repaired, two more become dangerously weak. Cities across the country discharge billions of gallons of untreated wastewater into rivers and lakes, and more than a quarter of all bridges are either deficient or obsolete.

title: With Song in Heart, Pompoms on Head
description: Every conceivable surface has been decked with sequins, spattered with colored lights, plastered in mirrored chips or trimmed in feathers and fringe in Priscilla Queen of the Desert, the new musical that shimmied open Sunday night at the Palace Theater. Probably a few inconceivable surfaces have been accessorized with equally exotic detail, but I hesitate to inquire.

title: Long-Delayed Rules for Cleaner Air
description: After 20 years of delays and interminable litigation, the Obama administration has proposed a new rule requiring power plants to reduce emissions of mercury and other airborne toxics by 91 percent within the next five years. Some environmental groups saw the rule as the most important step forward for healthier air since the Clean Air Act was last updated in 1990. It is unquestionably a victory for the public: when fully effective, the rule could save as many as 17,000 lives a year.

title: A New Way to Watch the Tournament
description: All hail the clicker.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 5, 2011

title: False Confessions
description: Douglas Warney, a person of limited mental capabilities who has been diagnosed with AIDS and AIDS dementia, served nine years in New York State prisons for a murder he did not commit. Now the state is seeking to compound the injustice by denying Mr. Warney compensation, even though there is a state law to provide redress for people who are wrongly convicted. New Yorks highest court, which is considering his case, should not permit it.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 20, 2011

title: T-Mobile Deal Leaves Sprints Future Unclear
description: With AT&T agreeing to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, the future of Sprint Nextel just got fuzzier.

title: Crises in Japan Ripple Across the Global Economy
description: In the wake of Japans cascading disasters, signs of economic loss can be found in many corners of the globe, from Sendai, on the battered Japanese coast, to Paris to Marion, Ark.

title: Reconsidering the Robin
description: Emily Dickinson may have dreaded that first robin so, but she speaks for herself alone. To the rest of us, robins bring a mixture of joy and relief, the sign of a natural cycle still intact. The snow withdraws, and returning robins follow it across newly open ground like shorebirds tracing a falling tide. Their movement is almost as distinctive as their call: hasten and pause, hasten and pause. Once the ground is thoroughly thawed, there they are, tugging on earthworms as though they were the hawsers of the S.S. Earth.

title: For Kansas States Martin, Emotion Is Never Far Away
description: TUCSON  The boiling point is never far away for Frank Martin, the fourth-year Kansas State coach who is notorious for his fiery, demonstrative ways.

title: Japan Factories Take Steps to Resume Production
description: Nissan Motor said on Sunday that it planned to restart production this week at five of its six Japanese plants that have been idled since an earthquake and tsunami pummeled the country on March 11. The announcement was among a handful of encouraging signs for Japans economy, the worlds third largest, which has been staggered by the natural disasters and the subsequent crisis the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station.

title: Corrections
description: OPINION

title: Coach Waxes Poetic After Upset of Syracuse
description: CLEVELAND  In a wide-ranging postgame news conference, Marquette Coach Buzz Williams quoted Albert Einstein and Robert Frost, teared up when asked about hugging his wife, and defended the five players he called Jukes, the junior-college products who helped the Golden Eagles advance to the N.C.A.A. tournaments Round of 16.

title: Google Accuses Chinese of Blocking Gmail Service
description: SHANGHAI  Google has accused the Chinese government of disrupting Gmail in the country, making it difficult in the last few weeks for users here to gain access to the companys popular e-mail service.

title: A Disaster Spares the Heart of Sony
description: LOS ANGELES  Howard Stringer, Sonys chief executive, left Tokyo a week ago Thursday in a wheelchair. A slipped disk in his back required emergency surgery, and he was flying home to New York for the procedure. But he was calm  the electronics and media giant would run just fine on autopilot for a day or two.

title: Is Old Firm Dominance Good for Scottish Soccer?
description: Hampden Park is hailed as the spiritual home of Scottish soccer, the place where some say modern soccer was truly born, the place where legends such as Pele and Diego Maradona admitted to being astonished by the famous Hampden Roar, but this historic stadium in Glasgows south side could now be just as conclusively defined as a soothing buffer zone in one of sports fiercest rivalries.

title: In Battle of the Bulbs, One Based on TV Tubes
description: As the nation shifts from standard incandescent light bulbs to higher-efficiency versions, one company believes it has a product for consumers dissatisfied with the alternatives: the harsh light of compact fluorescents and the high price of LED lamps.

title: Cellphone Reception Is Getting Worse
description: The quality of wireless phone calls, which improved steadily from 2003 to 2009, has hit a plateau, according to J.D. Power and Associates, the consumer ratings firm. One reason is the increasing number of cellphone calls placed or answered indoors, as people use their cellphones to replace or supplement landlines. Indoor calls tend to be fuzzier than outdoor calls, because the signal must penetrate walls and windows to reach the tower.

title: From First Four to the Final 16: Virginia Commonwealth Rolls
description: CHICAGO  So Virginia Commonwealth should have been in the N.I.T? Dont tell that to the Purdue Boilermakers, who for 40 minutes were put through a clinic by a Rams squad that won its third game in five days, 94-76, to advance to the Round of 16 for the first time in university history.

title: Arrest Made in Beating of a Child in Brooklyn
description: The boyfriend of a Brooklyn foster mother has been arrested in the beating of a 17-month-old boy in her care, law enforcement officials said Sunday night.

title: A Badge of Honor for a Regulator
description: Sheila C. Bair may unwittingly have discovered a simple litmus test for bank regulator effectiveness. As chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, she faced catcalls last week from a mob of community bankers. She was taken aback by the booing. But in fact, watchdogs should bask in such disdain if it means they are doing their jobs.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Another Day, Another Home Run for A-Rod
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Struggling players often say that results in spring training do not matter. But what about for someone like, say, Alex Rodriguez, who seems to reach base every time up?

title: From a Food Giant, a Broad Effort to Feed Hungry Children
description: CONAGRA FOODS, whose social cause is ending child hunger, is taking a new approach to raise the issues visibility. The company is starting its largest campaign ever, including a television special, to spur more grass-roots involvement to make sure no child goes hungry.

title: Looking Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include existing home sales for February (Monday); new home sales for February (Wednesday); durable goods orders for February and initial jobless claims (Thursday); and gross domestic product for the fourth quarter and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March (Friday).

title: WNET Local News, Via the Web
description: WNET, the parent company of New York City-area public broadcasters WNET Channel 13 and WLIW Channel 21, is going into the local news business, starting on the Web around Memorial Day.

title: At Mining Championship, Winning Might Mean a Job
description: RENO, Nev.  Burly, bearded and beer-loving, Kris Strickland is not your average student-athlete. He doesnt use a ball, a mitt, or a racket to show his skills.

title: A Glossy Take on Disney
description: LOS ANGELES  Ask executives at Disney Publishing to explain why they are trying to build a childrens subscription magazine business in the United States, and the answer will involve marketplace analysis this and business model that. It boils down to this explanation, offered by Aparna Pande, Disneys general manager for American magazines: Kids want them, and moms will pay for them.

title: Melvin Sparks, Guitarist, Is Dead at 64
description: Melvin Sparks, a guitarist whose brightly sinewy style made him an in-demand session player during the soul-jazz boom of the late 1960s and early 70s, a touchstone during the acid-jazz trend of the 90s and a wise elder on the jam-band scene of the last decade, died on March 15 at his home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 64.

title: W.J. Stuntz, Who Stimulated Legal Minds, Dies at 52
description: William J. Stuntz, an influential legal scholar known for his counterintuitive insights, who blamed liberal judges, conservative legislators and ambitious prosecutors for what he saw as a criminal justice system that imprisons far too many people, died on Tuesday at his home in Belmont, Mass. He was 52.

title: Kansas Dominates Inside to Beat Illinois
description: TULSA, Okla.  A year removed from an N.C.A.A. tournament upset loss to Northern Iowa, Kansas did not let the fear of being surprised again interfere with its performance Sunday. The Jayhawks played Illinois, not ghosts.

title: Gains, and Drawbacks, for Female Professors
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  When the Massachusetts Institute of Technology acknowledged 12 years ago that it had discriminated against female professors in subtle but pervasive ways, it became a national model for addressing gender inequity.

description: Accounts

title: SXSW, Brought to You by G.O.O.D.
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Kanye West likes having the last word, and he likes it big. That was clear on Saturday night when Mr. West and corporate sponsors staged a gargantuan late-night event, which for most was the final show of South by Southwest. (Emos and Emos Jr., two parts of the same club, scheduled SXSW shows Sunday.)

title: Unturned Cobblestones on the Citys Grid
description: In honor of the 200th anniversary of the Manhattan street grid, here are some facts that may have eluded even avid city history buffs:

description: David Clarkson scored twice and Martin Brodeur made 13 saves to earn his record 115th shutout as the Devils ended a two-game slide at Columbus.

description: Action from across the country in Sundays Round of 32.

description: Competition at the 33rd International Intercollegiate Mining Competition is not as easy as it looks.

title: Florida State Routs Notre Dame and Adds to Big East Misery
description: CHICAGO  This was supposed to be the best Notre Dame team in decades, a No. 2 seed that thought it should have been a No. 1. The United Center was a virtual home court, 90 or so miles from South Bend, Ind., and the green-and-gold-clad Notre Dame faithful were here in force.

title: Farewell to Bill and His Family, Family, Family Values
description: Big Love ended its five-season run on HBO on Sunday night, and if the show had achieved the resonance of the networks other heralded series, the national conversation would surely be dominated now  at least for a couple of hours  by the events that transpired during the final explosive seconds. (If you dont know what happened but intend to watch the finale, read no further.)

title: Big Love Watch: Q. and A. With the Creators
description: Sunday night brought the finale of Big Love after five seasons. And shockingly (spoiler alert), the shows protagonist, Bill Henrickson, of the hardware-store minichain and multiple marriages, died at the hands of an emasculated whack-job neighbor. You can read my thoughts on the conclusion in a critics notebook in The Times. Below are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mark V. Olsen and Will Scheffer, the creators and head writers of the series, about, among other things, how and why they chose to end the show the way they did. Wed like to keep the discussion going, so please post your comments.

title: News Quiz | March 21, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Riddled With Metal by Mistake in a Study
description: Women participating in a study of patients with breast cancer have been inadvertently left with hundreds of tiny particles of the heavy metal tungsten in their breast tissue and chest muscles. The particles came from a device used during surgery. The device has since been recalled.

description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article The Destructive Power of Water.

title: What Would You Plan If a Local Museum Paid You to Attract Teens?
description: Four times a year, the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston pays a teen council to plan and market events and programs to help expand its young audience. From hiring teenage bands to inviting teenagers to make their own art, this councils goal is to show kids their own age that museums dont have to be boring. If a local museum in your area hired you to create programs and events that would attract your friends, what would you plan? Why?

title: U.S.-Led Assault Nears Goal in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  An American-led military campaign to destroy Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis air defenses and establish a no-fly zone over Libya has nearly accomplished its initial objectives, and the United States is moving swiftly to hand command to allies in Europe, American officials said Monday.

title: Jan Stallers Roadside Attraction
description: These images portray an otherworldly place that somehow feels familiar. They do so elegantly. Yet the photographer, Jan Staller, would be the first to acknowledge the limited intrinsic appeal of his typical subjects: recycled scrap, twisted steel and roadways speckled with trash.

title: Buffett Sees Buying Opportunity in Stricken Japan
description: Major Japanese stock indexes plunged last week in days of frantic trading, with the Nikkei 225 stock average ending the week down more than 10 percent. But at least one prominent investor says the market has gotten it wrong.

title: Crackdown Was Only Option, Bahrain Sunnis Say
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  When Bahrains pro-democracy movement began its demonstrations in Pearl Square last month, Atif Abdulmalik was supportive. An American-educated investment banker and a member of the Sunni Muslim elite, he favored a constitutional monarchy and increasing opportunities and support for the poorer Shiite majority.

description: Todays word, in association with the magnificent Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Continuing the Conversation on Free Trade
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: In Mumbai, Flocking With the Flamingos
description: As Mumbais western seafront becomes increasingly gentrified, the citys east remains resolutely industrial. Against the backdrop of warehouses, oil terminals, toothpaste factories and refineries lies one of the citys most rewarding  and unexpected  sights: a vast swath of flamingos, many of them shocking pink.

title: Fantasy Focus: Understanding Injury Risks
description: Injuries are an intrinsic risk for fantasy owners, one that often decides who gets the trophy. While injuries remain unpredictable, you can take steps to better prepare yourself on draft day and throughout the season. The easiest way to start is to get familiar with basic medical terminology.

title: The Early Word: Whats the End Game?
description: Todays Times

title: The Art of Making Things
description: If you make things instead of finance them or talk about them, you can findyourself relegated to the bottom of the economic and intellectual heap. In TheFinancial Times not long ago, Edmund de Waal, a potter and a professorof ceramics at the University of Westminster, made an impassioned case for theintelligence of craft and for how deeply connectedthe hand and the head really are (found via Jessica Crispins Bookslut blog).

title: The Ins and Outs of U.S. Roster Selection
description: Why is there such intrigue surrounding United States Coach Bob Bradleys recent roster selection for his teams matches against Argentina and Paraguay?

title: Rio Tinto Extends Riversdale Bid, Again
description: Rio Tinto said on Monday that it would extend its $3.9 billion offer for Riversdale Mining of Australia for three days as it attempts to rally Riversdale shareholders to its bid.

title: Key Supporters Are Forsaking Yemen Leader
description: SANA, Yemen  The tenuous power of Yemens embattled president weakened Monday as a wave of high-level officials, including the countrys senior military commander, an important tribal leader and a half-dozen ambassadors, abandoned him and threw their support behind protesters calling for his ouster.

title: Looking Back at Drew Hill, Run-and-Shoot Receiver for Oilers
description: Remembering Drew Hill, whose career, in many ways, was a manifestation of his character. His refreshing humility stands in contrast with many of todays receivers. Hill died Friday at age 54. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down.

title: This Week in Small Business: Radiation, Inflation and Regulation
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review Arcadia
description: Readers offered mixed reviews of the Broadway revival of Arcadia, Tom Stoppards play about sex, science and poetry that opened on Friday at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. Some readers found it intriguing, others said it was dull, and almost everyone said they had difficulty hearing and understanding the actors. Following are excerpts from several readers reviews on the Theater section of NYTimes.com.

title: In Russia, Gates Stresses Cooperation With West
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  The United States defense secretary, Robert M. Gates, visited Russia on Monday, a trip he had delayed by a day to monitor the start of the international military effort against Libyan government forces.

title: Best Political Quotes of the Weekend
description: Miss some of the most important political commentary over the weekend? Heres a rundown of some of the best political quotes.

title: A New Arab Generation Finds Its Voice
description: Video interviews with more than two dozen people under 30, from Libya to the West Bank, talking about their generations moment in history and prospects for the future.

title: Triangle Fire: A Half-Hour of Horror
description: Saturday, March 25, 1911. The work week was ending at the Triangle Waist Company factory in Lower Manhattan, and the men and women who operated the sewing machines and cut the cloth were pushing away from their tables, with some anticipating a night on the town and all looking toward their one day of rest.

title: Facebook Agrees to Buy Mobile App Developer Snaptu
description: Facebook has agreed to buy mobile application developer Snaptu, a move that would expand the social networking giants reach in the cellular phone market.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Cauliflower Sformato
description: Adam Weisell, the former executive chef of Aurora in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, grew up in Rome, where his father worked for the United Nations. His cauliflower sformato  a savory flan studded with a few tiny florets  is a play on cauliflower and cheese, he said. It is to cauliflower and cheese what a beignet is to an ordinary doughnut.

title: Freed Times Journalists Give Account of Captivity
description: The Libyan government freed four New York Times journalists on Monday, six days after they were captured while covering the conflict between government and rebel forces in the eastern city of Ajdabiya. They were released into the custody of Turkish diplomats and crossed safely into Tunisia in the late afternoon, from where they provided a harrowing account of their captivity.

title: Morning Buzz | Reflections on Manhattan Grid
description: Early showers with a chance of rain into the evening and high temperatures in the low-50s.

title: T-Mobile Sale May Close Tough Chapter for Deutsche Telekom
description: In agreeing to sell its T-Mobile USA unit to AT&T for $39 billion, Deutsche Telekom will finally shed a subsidiary that has caused the German telecommunications giant considerable difficulty.

title: Citi Plans Dividend and Reverse Stock Split
description: 8:24 p.m. | Updated

title: Divvying Up the Water Down Under
description: Andrew Gregson, an official with the New South Wales Irrigators Council, is the kind of Australian completely at home in the agricultural sea that is Californias San Joaquin Valley. He knows all about the business and the social fabric of farming and about irrigated agriculture. He believes that modern regulators favor environmental uses of water over agricultural ones, and he is not pleased about that.

title: Nomura Hires a Prominent Former Goldman Analyst
description: Nomura has reeled in another top research analyst.

title: Libya Releases 4 Times Journalists
description: The Libyan government has released four detained New York Times journalists  Tyler Hicks, Lynsey Addario, Stephen Farrell and Anthony Shadid  six days after they were captured while covering the conflict between government and rebel forces in the eastern city of Ajdabiya. Further details in World.

title: 2010 Cowboys: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. Offense

title: Spring Shopping | Outfit Essentials
description: Nine to Five: Workplace-ready attire need not follow suit. For the sartorial worker with a scrambled schedule, masculine-inspired womens wear in sublime spring shades make for a coolly unruffled uniform.

title: Questions for the Author of Crazy U
description: Since its publication earlier this month, Crazy U: One Dads Crash Course in Getting His Kid Into College, has been the subject of much buzz within the admissions world  and outside it, too. Some parents have seized on the book, by Andrew Ferguson, a senior editor at The Weekly Standard, as a much-needed manifesto, one in which the author brings the perspective of a curious outsider to an oft-bewildering process.

title: Schwab Agrees to Buy OptionsXpress for $1 Billion
description: Charles Schwab on Monday said it had agreed to acquire online options trading firm OptionsXpress for $1 billion in stock.

title: Peacocks on Parade
description: I havent written much about the grandly styled Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget; but its become more and more clear that the committees real purpose isnt to balance the budget, its to provide additional plumage for deficit peacocks.

title: Monday Morning Skate: Geoffrion Hat Trick, Reaction to Cookes Hit, Rinne for Hart?
description: Goals of the Weekend: Geoffrion Goes Boom

title: Elizabeth Warren Is Not Jesus
description: Yves Smith, while rightly denouncing the right-wing attack on Elizabeth Warren, seems almost equally perturbed by the ardor of her defenders. But I think she misunderstands the nature of that defense.

title: Mets Release Oliver Perez
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets finally consummated the inevitable Monday morning when they released the ineffective but highly paid left-handed pitcher Oliver Perez.

title: Palin Meets With Netanyahu in Israel
description: 2:40 p.m. | Updated  Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, was scheduled to dine in Jerusalem with Israels prime minister on Monday evening after a whirlwind tour that was heavy on holy sites but devoid of public statements on foreign policy issues.

title: Greenspan Deconstructed
description: I wrote my quick reaction to Greenspan after a hard day of column-writing. If you want a bit more economic analysis, read Brad DeLong. As Brad says, to accept Greenspans thesis you have to believe, simultaneously, that businesses are terrified of future confiscatory government action, and that investors are so bullish on business prospects that theyve bid stock prices ofup hugely since Obama took office. Oh, and business surveys show that poor sales, not any imagined threat from government, are the reason for low investment.

title: Big Easts Performance Is Upsetting, But Its No Failure
description: At some point during the second half of Notre Dames loss to Florida State on Sunday night, I started to imagine a New York Post back cover featuring a dejected-looking Ben Hansbrough, alongside a 72-point headline reading BIG LEAST.

title: Why Buffett Thinks Japan Is a Buy
description: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor, thinks the disaster in Japan doesnt change the economic future of the country, with the market turmoil creating a buying opportunity for investors.

title: Fly Zone
description: The question Would you like iceberg ice in your water glass tonight? is the kind typically reserved for destinations of rarefied pomposity. A boutique Japanese cruise liner, say, or a nightclub in Moscow that only the oligarchs know about. But not in the interior of a Dodge Caliber doing the speed limit on Grenfell Drive, a highway lined by fir trees, the odd birch and an almost ridiculous number of moose.

title: March 21 Updates on War in Libya and Mideast Protests
description: On Monday, The Lede is following the war in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from journalists and bloggers in the region.

title: A Look Ahead to the Round of 16
description: The former North Carolina State coach Jim Valvanos famous mantra about the N.C.A.A. tournament was survive and advance.

title: Holden to Miss Rest of Season in England
description: If Stuart Holden did not have bad luck, he would have no luck at all.

title: One Caregiver vs. One Stuffed Condo
description: Im enjoying a blog called The Downsize Challenge, whose author posts weekly about her trials and triumphs as she culls through a lifetimes possessions crammed into her grandfathers two-bedroom Florida condo.

title: A Beginning for Middle-Earth: The Hobbit Starts Production
description: They say that even the longest journey begins with a single step, and Peter Jackson has finally reached that step on his movie adaptations of The Hobbit where cameras are (metaphorically) rolling, actors are performing their parts and footage is being gathered that will someday arrive in your local cinema. Warner Brothers announced on Monday that production had begun in Wellington, New Zealand, on Mr. Jacksons two-film version of J. R. R. Tolkiens Hobbit novel, a project that has previously been stalled by the loss of the director Guillermo del Toro; a battle between Mr. Jackson and labor unions in New Zealand and Australia over hiring practices for the films; and, just when things finally seemed to be getting on track, an emergency surgery for Mr. Jackson to repair a perforated ulcer.

title: Monday Reading: Insurance for People with Pre-Existing Conditions
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Knife-Wielding Man in Bronx, Authorities Say
description: Updated, 6:11 p.m. | The police shot and killed a 48-year-old man when he attacked them with a six-inch steak knife in an apartment in the Bronx on Sunday night, the authorities said. The man, Paul Goldreyer, first attacked his roommate with a knife, then lunged at officers who responded to a 911 call, the police said.

title: Heck of a Job Brown
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared paint colors fit for our times.

title: Q&A: How to Kick Some Apps Tires
description: Q.

title: Numberplay: Manhole Covers
description: This weeks puzzle is fun because its about everyday objects. And theres no right answer. At least, I dont think there is.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

title: Business Jazz
description: Last month Inc. magazine ran a fascinating article by Leigh Buchanan called How Entrepreneurs Think. Corporate leaders, Buchanan wrote, are often good at causal reasoning. They set a goal and diligently find the best way to achieve it. Entrepreneurs are often good at effectual reasoning. They start without concrete goals but constantly improvise and react creatively to contingencies.

title: U.S. Africa Command Seen Taking Key Role
description: WASHINGTON  When the United States Africa Command was created four years ago, it was the militarys first smart power command. It has no assigned troops and no headquarters in Africa itself, and one of its two top deputies is a seasoned American diplomat.

title: That De Niro Look, Captured in Charcoal and Pastels
description: The look could be one of befuddlement or disgust. Or maybe of resignation or amusement.

title: Pawlenty Announces Presidential Exploratory Committee
description: 3:33 p.m. | Updated  Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, announced on Monday afternoon that he is opening a presidential exploratory committee, a step that formalizes his race for the Republican nomination that he has been working toward for more than a year.

title: Blues Traveler
description: Dostoyevsky wrote about the magic of a change of place. And as Adan Jodorowsky can attest, it doesnt hurt to change your name and your language while youre at it. In 2004, in a cheap hotel in Mexico City, the 31-year-old singer (and the son of the cult filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky) was reborn as Adanowsky after taking part in a shamanic ritual. But it wasnt until he left his native Paris for Chile and translated his lyrics from French to Spanish that he and his career started to go places. Lately, he splits his time between Mexico City, Los Angeles, Paris and anywhere the tour for his melancholy new album, Amador, takes him. Catch him if you can.

title: Rear-Facing Car Seats Advised at Least to Age of 2
description: Toddlers are usually switched from rear-facing to forward-facing car seats right after their first birthday  an event many parents may celebrate as a kind of milestone.

title: State Senator Receives 3 Years Probation
description: Updated 9:00 p.m. | State Senator Kevin S. Parker, who faced as much as two years in prison for his role in attacking a staff photographer from The New York Post, was sentenced on Monday to three years probation.

title: Leading Off: Wild Tournament Gets Weird
description: Perhaps some of the theoretically surprising developments of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournaments early rounds are not really surprises at all. After all, when 11 teams from one conference make the field, isnt that pretty much setting up a historic swan dive? And honestly, a year after Butler nearly wins the whole thing, can Virginia Commonwealth be that much of a revelation? And the referees are a big part of the story. Sun rises in East.

title: Goldman, Conspicuous by Its Absence
description: Bankers up and down Wall Street have reason to pop open the Champagne corks in the wake of AT&Ts announcement of its $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile from Deutsche Telekom. Six investment banks will reap millions of dollars in fees if the deal is completed.

title: In a Fast-Forward World, a Pause to Breathe
description: .As spring unfolds with a brief snow squall in the Hudson Valley (above), as work to stabilize the damaged nuclear plant in Japan continues and a steady stream of developments related to climate and energy flows, Im trying to learn to pause and, as Richard Butler wrote and sang, just breathe.

title: For the Brain, a Race To Recall the Details
description: It is always a challenge to remember a new computer password after an old one has expired, or to memorize a new phone number.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: One year ago this week, President Obama signed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act into law. The anniversary will be marked by a series of events from proponents and opponents of the law who are still waging a pitched battle over provisions of the health care legislation.

title: Photos Stoke Tension Over Afghan Civilian Deaths
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The release of explicit photographs of American soldiers apparently engaged in atrocities against Afghan civilians threatens to ignite tensions between the Afghan and American governments and provide fodder for the Talibans efforts to persuade Afghans that the foreign troops fighting here are a malevolent force.

title: Puzzling Across and Down, but Foiled by a Ton
description: Dan Feyer won his second consecutive American Crossword Puzzle Tournament on Sunday in Brooklyn, beating the five-time champion Tyler Hinman (who came in second) and Anne Erdmann (third). The event, hosted by the New York Times puzzle editor, Will Shortz, (and sponsored by, among others, New York Times Digital) attracted 655 entrants.

title: Apollo Plans to Raise About $400 Million in I.P.O.
description: 5:26 p.m. | Updated

title: End in Sight for The Divine Sister
description: The Divine Sister, Charles Buschs Off Broadway love letter to Hollywood movies about nuns, will end its run on May 1 after nearly eight months of performances at the Soho Playhouse. The producers, Daryl Roth and Bob Boyett, said this weekend that the critically acclaimed comedy would close because of the previous commitments of several cast members. One of them, Alison Fraser, had already announced plans to leave next month to join the cast of the coming Off Broadway production of The School for Lies. Mr. Busch dons a nuns wimple to star as Mother Superior, his latest drag role in a celebrated career in New York theater, where he is best known for his works Vampire Lesbians of Sodom and Die Mommie Die! His foray onto Broadway as a playwright also yielded a hit in 2000, The Tale of the Allergists Wife. Directed by Carl Andress, The Divine Sister also stars Julie Halston, Amy Rutberg, Jennifer Van Dyck and Jonathan Walker. It began preview performances on Sept. 12 and opened on Sept. 22.

title: Dont Confuse the Urgent With the Important
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Lowering Sin Taxes to Attract Those Lucrative Sinners
description: Weve written before about how strapped states have increased or levied new sin taxes  taxes on things like cigarettes, alcohol and strip clubs  to bring in more revenue. While most tax increases are, as you might expect, quite unpopular, sin taxes can be a little easier to squeak through because they discourage behaviors deemed to be socially pernicious.

title: The Regulatory Risk in the AT&T Deal
description: DealBooks Coverage of AT&T-T-Mobile Deal

title: When Wind Farms Trump House Cats
description: In an article in Mondays Times, I focus on a study by ornithologists in the Washington suburbs that highlights the heavy toll that domestic cats take on birds. Researchers found that cats were responsible for nearly half of the predation on baby gray catbirds.

title: Asked & Answered | OHWOW
description: Downtown is a state of mind for the art impresarios Aaron Bondaroff and Al Moran, whether theyre selling Statue of Liberty figurines by Kembra Pfahler at a pop-up shop in Athens, Greece, or recreating the Ludlow Street watering hole Max Fish at a bar in Miami (bar staff included). After descending upon Los Angeles last year with a one-night-only Halloween Neckface show that drew 5,000 people, this weekend the two introduced the new L.A. home of their OHWOW gallery. Opening Saturday in a 4,000-square-foot, ivy-covered former Laundromat on La Cienega Boulevard in West Hollywood, OHWOW presented Noblesse Oblige, the first L.A. exhibition from Scott Campbell, who is as well known for the work hes inked into the flesh of Marc Jacobs, Terry Richardson and others as he is for the intricate 3-D pieces he cuts into sheets of United States currency. Noblesse Oblige  an ironic battle cry for Campbells backwoods Louisiana kin and a phrase he has tattooed on his neck  also finds the artist working with neon, etching onto 24-karat gold plates, and drawing on the insides of ostrich eggs. We caught up with Bondaroff and Moran in the Rafael de Cardenas-designed space to discuss the bigger picture.

title: A Better Way to Serve Eggs
description: I teach a class in knife skills for home cooks in Los Angeles. The students arent expected to wield their blades like Top Chefs, but my fellow instructor, Clifford A. Wright, and I do have them chop, slice, mince and dice often enough to become comfortable in front of a cutting board.

title: AT&T Deal Joins a History of Antitrust Fights
description: 6:38 p.m. | Updated

title: Two Teens, Two Videos
description: If, somehow, you have not heard of 13-year-old Rebecca Black, let me back up for a moment. The eighth grader wants to be a pop star, and her parents paid $2,000 to the Ark Music Factory to turn her simple song Friday, about looking forward to a weekend party, into an Internet-ready video. It went viral, but not entirely in the way Rebecca and her family had hoped. She received nearly 30 million YouTube hits, and that became license for countless strangers to pummel her online. They called her the worst singer in the world and  in the comment she says hurt the most  said, I hope youll get an eating disorder so youll be pretty.

title: Too Cool
description: As the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament rages on, the spectacle of competitive sports seems more surreal than usual. In a country barely wobbling out of the recession, how can so much energy, ambition and money be channeled into this? Should we Americans be proud, or a little ashamed? Its hardly just basketball and football. The freakiest detail to catch my attention over the weekend came from the unlikely realm of long-distance running, in a Wall Street Journal profile of the former marathon champ Alberto Salazar, who now works for Nike. Salazar is obsessed with restoring American runners, long displaced by Africans and others, to a position of greatness in the world. How obsessed? The poor man could be mistaken for one of those screaming college basketball coaches:

title: TimesCast | Egypt Votes
description: March 21, 2011 - Neil MacFarquhar reports on the results of Egypt's referendum.

title: New Charges Against 2 Officers in Village Rape Case
description: Updated 3:25 p.m. | The New York police officers accused in the rape of a drunken woman in the East Village sneaked out of their precinct station house to return to her apartment one more time than had been previously disclosed, prosecutors alleged on Monday.

title: No Urgent Changes Seen for U.S. Nuclear Plants
description: ROCKVILLE, Md.  A top official with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Monday that the nuclear crisis in Japan did not warrant any immediate changes at American nuclear plants.

title: Jury Selected for Barry Bonds Trial
description: 6:35 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO  After a grueling day of being questioned by the judge and by lawyers, 12 people  eight women and four men  were picked Monday to sit through Barry Bondss perjury trial, which is expected to last about three weeks. Two alternates, who are women, were also chosen for the case in which Bonds has been charged with lying to a federal grand jury and obstruction of justice. He has pleaded not guilty.

title: Muscovite Lives, Entangled in History
description: MOSCOW  The Meyersons of Moscow are not oligarchs or ex-K.G.B. agents, gangsters or alcoholics. They are a pair of public school teachers who have little in common with the stock characters often depicted in tales of this land. They disdain Communism, but warmly recall childhoods in the 1970s. They bristle at what they believe Vladimir V. Putin has done to Russia, but dont deny that things are far better now.

title: The Technology Behind Making Mobile Payments a Reality
description: Its only a matter of time before your mobile phone swallows up yet another piece of technology: your credit card.

title: More on Overexposing Photos
description: Last week, I posted some of the best and most entertaining tips I learned in a private photography session with a pro. One tip in particular  a suggestion to overexpose your shots, and fix things later in Photoshop if necessary  drew a particularly vocal response from the photographers online. (Then again, in my experience, just about anything draws a vocal response from photographers online.)

title: Avenue of the Americas, 8:42 A.M.
description: Spring, which officially began Sunday at 7:21 p.m., blew in on fluffy blobs of snow Monday morning. You can see some on the black umbrella in the center if you look really close.

title: Tyler Hansbroughs Makeshift Stardom
description: Tyler Hansbrough must have the alarm on his biological clock set for mid-March. The four-time Associated Press all-American is no stranger to the months basketball festivities  he won an N.C.A.A. tournament championship as a member of the 2009 North Carolina Tar Heels  but this years occasion provides contrast through caliber of competition; rather than roll over lower-seeded teams on a deep tournament run, Hansbrough has risen and dominated pro-level opposition.

title: Q. & A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Jeffrey Abramson, senior vice president for film at Gen Art, Los Angeles, part of Sandow Media, and Elizabeth Shaffer, senior vice president for events and creative director, were promoted to co-presidents.

title: A Temple of Automotive Design Reopens in Turin
description: It is only natural that Turin, the Detroit of Italy, should have an automobile museum. But for years, the place offered a rather haphazard and miscellaneous assemblage of vehicles. Following a four-year renovation  which was celebrated this past weekend at the museums official reopening  the collection of around 200 vehicles is now organized with a new sense of cohesion.

title: Horizon Organic's "Chess Mates" Ad
description: Advertisement for Horizon Organic milk. A girl and her grandfather play chess together. Horizon Organic is a sponsor of Disney Channel.

title: How the iPhone Led to the Sale of T-Mobile USA
description: BERLIN  Deutsche Telekoms announcement over the weekend to sell its American wireless unit, T-Mobile USA, to AT&T for $39 billion ended a decade-long foray into the American market that was undermined, in part, by one big event: the advent of the iPhone.

title: Will Mickey Mouse Wear a Milk Mustache?
description: The Disney Channel is answering yes to the question Got milk?

title: Battle for Libya
description: The latest images after Western intervention in Libya.

title: James Levine to Cut Back Met Spring Performances
description: Giving up the Boston Symphony Orchestra was not enough for James Levines health. The Metropolitan Opera said on Monday that Mr. Levine, who is music director of both the Met and the symphony, will cut back on opera performances in the spring.

title: Behind the Mask
description: Q. Does wearing surgical masks reduce the spread of illnesses?

title: 1/100 as Bad as Chernobyl
description: We know that the nuclear situation in Japan is critical. But how bad is it? Japans nuclear safety agency on Friday raised the rating of the crisis at Fukushima from 4 to 5 on the 7-step international scale. On one hand, this is scary: another Level 5 nuclear crisis was at Three Mile Island in 1979. (Chernobyl was a 7.) On the other hand, as a scientist friend pointed out to me this morning, the new rating means that the situation in Fukushima is 1/100 as bad as the Chernobyl accident.

title: Ask About Labor Laws and Unions in the Fires Wake
description: This week, Steven Greenhouse, the labor and workplace correspondent for The Times, responded to readers questions about the evolution of the nations labor laws and labor unions since the Triangle fire 100 years ago.

title: How a Building Dispute Can Sink a Sale
description: When Amber Brien, a 36-year-old researcher by day and bass guitar player by night, put her sun-filled sixth-floor condominium near Downtown Brooklyn up for sale last March, she thought it would not be long before she sold it and moved in full time with her boyfriend in Park Slope. Since then, her boyfriend has become her fianc and her music jobs have brought her to Eastern Europe.

title: The Claim: Eating Flaxseed Can Help Relieve Hot Flashes
description: THE FACTS

title: Hama Rules
description: The rule of the Middle East: that there are no rules  named after the Syrian city of Hama, in which a rebellion was brutally quashed in 1982.

title: TimesCast | Third Day of Allied Strikes
description: March 21, 2011 - David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim report on the third day of allied strikes in Libya and the release of the four New York Times journalists.

title: TimesCast | Yemen's New Divide
description: March 21, 2011 - Laura Kasinof reports on the growing numbers of anti-government protesters in Sana, Yemen.

title: Supreme Court Denies a Move to Bar the Details of a Fed Bailout
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve will publish new details about its emergency lending to banks during the 2008 financial crisis after the Supreme Court on Monday rejected an industry appeal for secrecy.

title: Shares of Sprint Down on AT&T Deal with T-Mobile
description: With AT&T moving to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, investors are fretting about the fate of Sprint-Nextel.

title: Local Hero
description: We all have an image of the politicians who started out in the log cabin or the farm and rose to greatness. It turns out this doesnt happen very often. James Gimpel, Francis Lee and Rebecca Thorpe published a study in Political Geography finding that candidates and nominees for statewide office rarely come from rural parts of their states. Instead, these candidates and nominees come from the most populous countiesin numbers significantly out of proportion to these counties share of their state population. Gimpel, Lee and Thorpe argue that dense population fosters political ambition and provides candidates with the resources they need to pursue their ambition. The upshot is that rural areas are under-represented in state governments.

title: Noted Self-Publisher May Be Close to a Book Deal
description: Amanda Hocking, the darling of the self-publishing world, has been shopping a four-book series to major publishers, attracting bids of well over $1 million for world English rights, two publishing executives said.

title: Is Subway Music a Contradiction in Terms?
description: Sometimes, passing underground through Union Square or Times Square, you hear snatches of good music: the well-scratched washboard of the Ebony Hillbillies or the sonic eruption of the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, who upset commuters boroughwide when they made the understandable if regrettable decision not long ago to move into the light. Riders are divided in their response to the single-minded intensity of Alice Tan Ridley, whose many renditions of I Will Survive are almost too authentic. Ridley, by the way, is Gabourey Sidibes mother (Sidibe played Precious in the movie of the same name a couple of years ago), and when the conversation turns to subway music, she is the first person many locals mention, rarely by name, almost always as the woman who sings I Will Survive for hours on end. Ridley taught special ed before she hit the platforms, and after reaching the semifinals of Americas Got Talent last year, she has become perhaps our best-known subway performer.

title: Liberty Global to Buy German Cable Operator for $4.5 Billion
description: 5:37 p.m. | Updated

title: Sutras Stones | DVF and H. Stern
description: Seven years after the debut of her Indian-inspired jewelry collaboration with H. Stern, Diane von Furstenberg has added eight new gem-inlaid yellow gold pieces to the Sutras collection. Rock crystals and diamonds are organically incorporated into the designs, using techniques employed by the Mughal Empire of Jaipur, India. Gold embraces a gemstone and assumes its form, says von Furstenberg of eye-catching pieces like the undulating teardrop crystal rings. The movement within the gold alludes to sensuality and natural feminine forms. Inspirational inscriptions, like love, laughter, harmony and freedom, are engraved on the back of each pendant, earring droplet and ring, a tribute to the power von Furstenberg sees in both words and gold. (Prices range from $3,200 to $8,200). The combination not only adds beauty, but strength and empowerment as well, she explains. Indeed, the collection displays a majestic embodiment of the literal translation of sutra from Sanskrit: a line that holds objects together.

title: Nobodies of Macroeconomics (Very Wonkish)
description: Brad DeLong, in writing about the dubious state of economics as a discipline (at least in some quarters), offers a useful set of quotes and links from freshwater economists who were shocked, shocked at the idea that anyone imagined that fiscal expansion might be expansionary. Brad stresses these economists ignorance of intellectual tradition. But they were and still are amazingly ignorant of what contemporary economists who dont happen to be part of their hermetic world have been doing.

title: Pelosi Is Briefly Hospitalized in Rome
description: Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, has resumed her activities in Rome after being briefly hospitalized on Monday.

title: Judge Rules Against Richard Prince in Copyright Case
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled against the artist Richard Prince in a closely watched copyright case, finding that Mr. Prince  who is well known for appropriating imagery created by others  violated the law by using photographs from a book about Rastafarians to create a series of collages and paintings.

title: Once the Condo Goes Up
description: It wasnt that long ago that dozens of developers started to construct glassy condominiums across the five boroughs. The thousands of apartments that were created in the past decade have given plenty of New Yorkers new homes (some of them, arguably, overpriced), along with, in some cases, construction-related headaches.

title: Its Opening Day, and Theyre Playing for Keeps at Last
description: San Francisco

title: On Twitter, Conservative (or Liberal) by Association
description: Active users of Twitter are revealing their political leanings even if they are careful not to post about politics, a group of researchers at Duke University says.

title: Harrowing Details Emerge in Beating of 18-Month-Old
description: 6:41 p.m. | Updated  Harrowing details in the beating of an 18-month-old Brooklyn foster child emerged in court on Monday, during the arraignment of the man charged in the case, Kysheen Oliver, 19, the boyfriend of the childs foster mother.

title: President Obama and Libya
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times and Mark Landler of The New York Times discuss the limited options that President Obama has as the air strikes in Libya continue.

title: Girls in the Spotlight: A Lesson from Rwanda
description: When I try to get people interested in the education cause in Rwanda, they often tell me that theyre up to their eyeballs in work on public or charter schools in their own neighborhoods  Upper West Side, Noe Valley, wherever. Some people, though, have a broad definition of neighborhood.

title: Photo Replay: March 21
description: A view of the day in sports included a high demand for cricket tickets and Rafael Nadals dance moves.

title: David Burke Takes His Cuisine to the Air
description: David Burke, an American chef with a mini-empire of restaurants and a notoriously outsize personality, is showcasing his talents at 35,000 feet. Beginning in March and continuing through April, Mr. Burke is designing dishes for first- and business-class passengers on intercontinental Lufthansa flights out of Germany, part of the airlines Star Chef program.

title: A New Ballet From Twyla Tharp
description: Twyla Tharp turns 70 this summer, but the choreographer isnt slowing down any time soon. Atlanta Ballet and the Royal Winnipeg Ballet have announced that Ms. Tharp will collaborate with the two companies on a new evening-length ballet for next season. The work, which will be based on the writings of the Scottish author George MacDonald, will feature music based on Schubert and arranged by Richard Burke. The ballet will be produced by the two companies and will have its premiere in Atlanta in February 2012, followed by a Canadian premiere in the fall of 2012.

title: V.C.U. Capitalizes on Chance It Wasnt Sure It Would Get
description: As I watched No. 11 Virginia Commonwealth defeat No. 3 Purdue on Sunday to clinch a berth in the Round of 16 for the first time in the universitys history, I thought back to March 7, when the Rams hopes of reaching the N.C.A.A. tournament appeared slim.

title: Go Online, Not Downtown, to Fight a Parking Ticket
description: For years, New Yorkers have hurled obscenities, or simply given up, at the sight of a dreaded orange slip on their windshield, knowing that anyone brave enough to challenge a parking ticket would face interminable lines, stuffy hearing rooms and subpar snacks.

title: Iroquois Hotel Is Joining the Times Square Cocktail Scene
description: The bit-by-bit upgrade of the liquid life in and around Times Square continues with plans, finalized late last week, for the head bartender at the Raines Law Room in Chelsea to oversee the creation of a new, 25-seat cocktail bar and lounge in the Iroquois New York hotel on West 44th Street, just a few paces from the Blue Bar at the Algonquin.

title: Behind Galleon Figures Court Challenge to S.E.C.
description: It is extraordinary that someone would sue the Securities and Exchange Commission, contending that he should have been accused of insider trading in federal court. But that is exactly what Rajat K. Gupta, a former board member at Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble, has done in seeking to stop an S.E.C. administrative case that alleges he tipped off Raj Rajaratnam about inside information at both companies.

title: Oil Sightings Are Not From BP Spill, Coast Guard Says
description: A rainbow-colored sheen spotted in the Gulf of Mexico over the weekend was not oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill, the Coast Guard says. Officials said the sheen was probably caused by large amounts of sediment driven out to sea by high water volumes on the Mississippi River.

title: Struggling to Stitch
description: A look inside New York's garment industry, where day laborers are hard pressed to find paying jobs.

title: Video: President Obama and Libya
description: John Harwood and Mark Landler discuss President Obama and the allied strikes in Libya.

title: JPMorgan, the Lender Behind the T-Mobile Deal
description: Behind the scenes of AT&Ts $39 billion bid for T-Mobile, a Wall Street giant left its mark on one of the biggest deals to emerge since the financial crisis.

title: Hostel Takeover
description: The Left Banks notorious Nazi lair has a new owner. Mazel tov?

title: A Decade of Boosting Breast Size
description: Breast implant operations have surged 40 percent in the past decade, with nearly 300,000 women last year opting to increase their breast size.

title: Do You Have Free Will? Yes, Its the Only Choice
description: Suppose that Mark and Bill live in a deterministic universe. Everything that happens this morning  like Marks decision to wear a blue shirt, or Bills latest attempt to comb over his bald spot  is completely caused by whatever happened before it.

title: Illuminating Voices of Vietnamese Women
description: Remember those grammar school field trips when your excitement at being at a real live arts event turned to dismay as you realized it was only a thinly veiled social studies lesson?

title: Galleon Trial Focuses on Clearwire Deal With Intel
description: 9:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Independence Day: Developing Self-Directed Learning Projects
description: Overview | What would schools look like if students developed their own curriculum? How would education and the experience of being in school differ for students if they had more power to direct their learning? In this lesson, students consider an experiment in public education in which a small group of high school students planned and executed a model for their own learning. They then develop and implement their own self-directed projects and reflect on the results.

title: Evercore Hires Senior UBS Tech Banker
description: Evercore Partners has hired Eric Mandl, a software banker at UBS, as a senior managing director.

title: Flaxseed for Hot Flashes?
description: Flaxseed contains estrogenlike compounds, making it a candidate for hot flash relief. But so far, the data are mixed, reports Anahad OConnor in todays Really? column.

title: Yemen Countdown
description: Its hard to see how President Ali Abdullah Saleh can hold on. Only 45 minutes or so after Al Jazeera published the list below, Yemens Embassy in London, including its ambassador, flew the coop. Saleh dismissed his own cabinet on Sunday; three of his ministers had already resigned. Now senior military figures are turning on him.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Japan and Afghanistan.

title: Jon Cryer and Christina Hendricks Join Philharmonics Company
description: After the month that Jon Cryer just lived through, youd think hed had his fill of toxic bachelors. Instead, Mr. Cryer will spend some time away from Two and a Half Men, the CBS comedy on which he stars (starred?) with Charlie Sheen, in a semistaged production of Company for the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Cryer will play the role of David, a pot-puffing chum of the perennially single protagonist, Robert, who will be portrayed by his CBS colleague Neil Patrick Harris, representatives for the Philharmonic said on Monday.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Night of the Hunter'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Charles Laughton's film about a murderous Southern minister played by Robert Mitchum.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Japan and Afghanistan.

title: N.H.L. Urges Uniformity on New Concussion Protocol
description: PITTSBURGH  After a weekend when inconsistencies arose in the application of the N.H.L.s newly revised concussion-evaluation protocol, the league is continuing with a series of conference calls to clubs to try to ensure that the evaluations are carried out uniformly.

title: Garment Work in New York 100 Years After the Triangle Fire
description: A century after 146 garment workers died in a fire at the Triangle shirtwaist factory, new immigrants still try to sew their way to the American dream. But these days, especially in New York, garment work is hard to come by. Safe working conditions and living wages in unionized factories are a legacy of the Triangle fire, but in other factories, day laborers from Latin America say they are treated poorly, paid less than minimum wage, or not paid at all. That is, if they can find work.

title: In ALMS Season Opener, Oreca Takes Podium at 12 Hours of Sebring
description: On Saturday night, Oreca, the French racing team, notched its first victory at Sebring International Raceway in more than a decade, winning the prototype class at the 12 Hours of Sebring.

title: Grass Fed | Ramen Relief in Tokyo
description: Just as the aftershocks in Tokyo appear to have finally subsided, so too has the hoarding that followed the initial disaster. There was not one bread product on the shelves, said Ivan Orkin, the chef and owner of two ramen shops in Rokkakoen, a residential neighborhood in Tokyo, when we spoke this morning.

title: Celebrating a Form of Twitterature
description: An article by Randy Kennedy in Sunday's Week in Review section called attention to two momentous events that converged on Monday: World Poetry Day and the fifth anniversary of the first message ever sent on Twitter. To celebrate, The Times asked its readers and followers to compose short poems on Twitter using the hashtag #poetweet. Hundreds of poems, many of them brevity-friendly haiku, flooded the Twittersphere. Below, a few of the submissions. More Twitter poems can be found by searching #poetweet at search.twitter.com.

title: After a Diagnosis, Wishing for a Magic Number
description: When my wife, Ruth, learned she had breast cancer, friends told us not to worry. After all, they said, a lot of progress has been made.

title: Libyan Rebels Retreat as Allies Continue Attacks
description: Rocket and tank fire from loyalists seemed to throw the rebels into disarray.

title: Greening the Team: Will Fans Follow Suit?
description: With the current political climate in Washington tending toward the anti-environmental (especially among Republicans in the House of Representatives), some campaigners are seeking new ways to rally public support.

title: YouTube Offers Free Image Stabilization
description: Starting today, Googles YouTube video Web site will make the road for video enthusiasts smoother.

title: Poll Finds Tentative Support, Potential Risks for Obama on Libya
description: CNN has released a poll, conducted Friday through Sunday, that asked people for their views on President Obamas handling of Libya. Initial reactions are more favorable for Mr. Obama than not, but the numbers are close enough that one can easily imagine some political downside for the president.

title: McCaskill Admits to Owing $287,000 in Taxes on Plane
description: Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, admitted Monday that she had failed to pay nearly $290,000 in property taxes on a private charter plane in which she has an ownership stake.

title: Renshaw Bay Hires Chief Operating Officer
description: William T. Winters, a former top executive at JPMorgan Chase, has hired Joseph C. Novarro as chief operating officer for his new advisory firm, Renshaw Bay, according to two people with direct knowledge of the appointment.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Night of the Hunter
description: Love and hate do battle in Charles Laughtons eerie 1955 film The Night of the Hunter, starring Robert Mitchum as a preacher harboring demons of his own. In his discussion of the film, A. O. Scott called it a hybrid of a folk tale and a film noir, but true to its own vivid and haunting reality. The film was the first and only one directed by Mr. Laughton, who found inspiration in German Expressionism. You can analyze it from a distance, which might bring some comfort, Mr. Scott says, but while youre watching this movie, youre like a child in the grip of a nightmare.

title: Court Reinstates Lawsuit Challenging Wiretapping Powers
description: Civil liberties advocates opposed to the governments expanded wiretapping powers can fight another day after an appellate court on Monday reinstated a lawsuit challenging an eavesdropping law passed by Congress three years ago.

title: Confusion Over Who Leads Libya Strikes, and for How Long
description: PARIS  As the military operation continued over Libya on Monday, there was some confusion about which country or organization is actually leading it, and for how long. France, Britain and the United States are in charge of their own operations, which each have different code names.

title: Trichet Persists in Expecting to Raise Europes Benchmark Rate
description: FRANKFURT  Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, stood by his prediction of higher interest rates for the euro zone on Monday despite the recent calamity in Japan.

title: Blindsided by Ferocity Unleashed by a Fault
description: On a map of Japan that shows seismic hazards, the area around the prefecture of Fukushima is colored in green, signifying a fairly low risk, and yellow, denoting a fairly high one.

title: Chase to End Debit Card Rewards
description: Is it time to hunt around for a new debit card that offers rewards?

title: Sizing Up the Silicon Problem After the Quake
description: Plant shutdowns in Japan have halted production in factories accounting for 25 percent of the worlds silicon wafers used to make computer chips, according to a report released Monday by the research firm IHS iSuppli.

title: Five Challenges for Pawlenty in 2012 Race
description: Can Tim Pawlenty win?

title: Twitter Turns Five
description: Just 1,825 days ago,Jack Dorsey sent a five-word message using a new service he had just finished building with a team of programmers: just setting up my twttr. If you saw this message back then, you might have thought Mr. Dorsey was starting a pet shop that specialized in exotic birds. In fact, he was sending the first-ever Twitter message.

title: The Music Industry, Post-Napster
description: A new study argues that Napster and its file-sharing descendants have not, in fact, reduced the entrance of new artists to the music market, even if piracy has made it harder to make a financial killing in the industry.

title: Philippine President Still High on Hope
description: MANILA  He has been chided for an easygoing work ethic and for his flashy new Porsche, but more than eight months into his presidency, Benigno S. Aquino III still carries with him a glow of hope, much of it inherited along with his family name.

title: City Makes a Calculated Case for Bicycle Lanes
description: The Bloomberg administration released an unusual two-page communiqu on Monday laying out its arguments for bicycle lanes, the subject of what one magazine has labeled the newest urban culture war.

title: Next on Bravo? Ad Executives and All-Star Chefs
description: As cable television channels make plans for elaborate presentations at which they woo prospective advertisers, one is deciding to turn the cameras on the attendees at its events.

title: Sex and the Souk
description: Joumana Haddad, the Oprah of Lebanon, is flirting with a fatwa.
