In the Arab world, suddenly shes everywhere, a dark-haired, golden-eyed looker sashaying onto talk shows in stiletto heels, provoking Hezbollah with her contempt for Shariah law, penning newspaper columns and books about Arab gender politics, publishing a racy magazine and flashing a winning smile as a judge on Lebanons Celebrity Duets.

title: Giving Literature Virtual Life
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa.  Prof. Katherine Rowes blue-haired avatar was flying across a grassy landscape to a virtual three-dimensional re-creation of the Globe Theater, where some students from her introductory Shakespeare class at Bryn Mawr College had already gathered online. Their assignment was to create characters on the Web site Theatron3 and use them to block scenes from the gory revenge tragedy Titus Andronicus, to see how setting can heighten the drama.

title: Asymmetrical Ignorance (Wonkish and Self-Indulgent)
description: Just a brief note on a couple of things that came up in comments on my Nobodies post.

title: Japans Nuclear Crisis Causes Run on Radiation Detectors
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Since Japans nuclear crisis started, Tim Flanegins phone has barely stopped ringing with orders for Geiger counters, the radiation detectors, to the point that he has no more in stock.

title: Retelling the Tale of a Terrorist Plot
description: There is an old quotation, possibly apocryphal, attributed to Stephen King regarding the film Stanley Kubrick made of his novel The Shining: I have my days when I think I gave Kubrick a live grenade on which he heroically threw his body. Similar thoughts arose during a performance of The Secret Agent, a new opera based on Joseph Conrads novel of the same title, at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College on Saturday evening.

title: Treasurys TARP Investment Chief to Step Down
description: 7:04 p.m. | Updated

title: For Composers, Bending the Notes for Cunningham
description: Movement and pulse are ingredients missing from some avant-garde music, whose arbitrary array of sounds can seem frustratingly static. But when combined with the brilliant works of Merce Cunningham, the revolutionary choreographer who died in 2009, sonic abstractions come to life.

title: Levine Cuts Back on Work for the Met
description: Giving up the Boston Symphony Orchestra was not enough for James Levines health. The Metropolitan Opera said on Monday that Mr. Levine, who is music director of both the Met and the symphony, will cut back on opera performances in the spring.

title: A Cheney Miniseries
description: George W. Bush had a movie, W, made about him. Now Dick Cheney may be getting one as well, though for smaller screens. HBO confirmed on Monday that it was developing a miniseries about the political life of Mr. Cheney, the former vice president, emphasizing his decades-long effort to give more power to the executive branch of government. The untitled project is based on two nonfiction sources, the Frontline documentary The Dark Side and the best-selling book Angler: The Cheney Vice Presidency, by Barton Gellman. Deadline.com reported that one executive producer was Paula Weinstein, who produced Recount, about the presidential vote counting in Florida in 2000.

title: A Gadfly in the Pinot Noir
description: ITS been called the Ol Switcheroo, and the Great Pinot Noir Kerfuffle. Depending on your point of view, it was either a surprise changeup that proved a point, or a dirty trick that proved nothing at all. Either way, the stunt that the winemaker Adam Lee pulled at a pinot noir seminar earlier this month has evoked both claims of vindication and cries of outrage throughout the wine-drinking world.

title: Crowd-Created Video Uses Poo to Explain Japans Nuclear Crisis
description: There have been a host of efforts to describe Japans earthquake and nuclear emergency, ranging from volumes of helpful graphics generated by The Times and other media to freelance efforts, including the sonification of a month of earthquake activity surrounding the great quake off Japan by Paul May and a chart by Randall Munroe comparing human radiation exposure from an array of sources  ranging from a banana to a mammogram to a leaking nuclear plant and A Laymans Intro to Radiation by Ellen McManis, who operates a research reactor at Reed College.

title: Putting Up Your Dukes, or at Least Your Thumbs
description: In all of reality and cyberspace, I know exactly one person who qualifies as even a moderate boxing fan. Among folks under 40, he seems pretty lonely that way.

title: Broadway Flexes Box Office Muscle
description: Spring has arrived on Broadway, with many musicals and a relatively large number of plays performing solidly at the box office last week. Several plays earned at least 50 percent of their maximum possible gross amounts, an indicator that each was in the black for the week. They were Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, with a healthy $637,756 in its first full week of previews; Driving Miss Daisy; Good People; Ghetto Klown; and War Horse, which also had a strong showing of $653,919 for its first seven performances. Also above 50 percent was the weeks top-grossing play, That Championship Season, at $698,853, as well as Arcadia and The Importance of Being Earnest. The musical Wicked was the top-grossing show, as usual, at $1.67 million; others that earned more than $1 million were The Lion King, Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, Jersey Boys and Mary Poppins. Broadway shows earned $22.2 million over all last week, according to the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

title: Inventing George Washington
description: Chapter 1

title: How George Washington, So Help Him God, Acquired His Many Myths
description: Like other iconic figures in history, whether Shakespeare or Leonardo, Napoleon or Lincoln, George Washington has been mythologized, psychoanalyzed and reimagined by successive generations, his reputation and image filtered through the prism of various eras and interest groups wildly disparate cultural and political ideals.

title: Tracking Your Wi-Fi Trail
description: GENEVA  The scene at Copenhagen International Airport one recent day was much like that at any airport around the world: passengers hurrying through the terminal, waiting in security lines or lingering at the duty-free shops.

title: Trailer: Fight Night Champion
description: The new boxing game by Electronic Arts is for the PlayStation 3 and the Xbox 360.

title: Textiles in Style | Carolina Irving
description: Enormous suitcases, a digital camera and fashion-pack friends like Hamish Bowles and Christian Louboutin are constant companions for the on-the-dash textile designer Carolina Irving, whose finds in souks and museums inspire her delicately patterned, vintage-looking pastels. Born in Miami to Venezuelan parents and raised in Paris, she developed a passion for antique textile design in college. My fabrics look old, hand printed, vegetable dyed, Irving says. A modern twist isnt me at all. Go to interactive >>

title: Breaking Up
description: It had a fairy tale beginning and it was supposed to have a fairy tale ending. Jennifer was everything I could have asked for in a woman. Our paths crossed for the first time this past fall. We immediately fell in love. In fact, she said the words first. Her confidence inspired me. I knew the dangers of taking a girlfriend into a deployment. I tried it during my last deployment to Iraq in 2005, and it was an epic failure. The problems with that relationship began before I even got on a plane, and continued throughout my time overseas. This time, as I prepared to return to Iraq, I felt a lot better about things, even though Jennifer and I had only been together a few months. She told me it would work, that the deployment wasnt that long of a time. I jumped in both feet first. I thought she jumped in with me.

title: Dangers of Leaving No Resident Behind
description: When the Three Mile Island nuclear generating station along the Susquehanna River seemed on the verge of a full meltdown in March 1979, Gov. Richard L. Thornburgh of Pennsylvania asked a trusted aide to make sure that the evacuation plans for the surrounding counties would work.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: CHRIS BROWN

title: The Lords of the Drum
description: When Kodo, the Japanese drumming troupe, appeared at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening, you expected some reference to the recent earthquake and its aftermath in Japan, but you had no idea what form it might take. A statement? An appeal? A performance dedicated to the victims? After all, such memorials have been inserted into programs of the New York Philharmonic, the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra and others, and whole concerts are being organized in the West to raise funds for relief efforts.

title: Bangladesh Bans Sale of Palm Sap After an Unusually Lethal Oubreak
description: Bangladesh is suffering an outbreak of deadly Nipah virus, causing the government to adopt an unusual prevention tactic: a ban on the sale of fresh palm sap.

title: Tortoise and Hare, in a Laboratory Flask
description: Ever since Darwin, biologists have recognized that life evolves. But in the past 25 years, some researchers have argued that certain organisms are better at evolving than others. Their genomes have a flexibility that lets them adapt effectively. The less evolvable species, by contrast, are too rigid to take advantage of new mutations or to find new solutions for survival.

title: Just Say Yes to Marriage of Music and Words
description: When you see a tuxedoed conductor helping to change the set during an operas intermission, you know youre watching a labor of love. Albert Bergeret has led the performances of the scrappy, energetic New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players since he helped found the group in 1974. This repertory is his lifes work; you get the sense that he would do a lot more than carry around some furniture to get the job done.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,430 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,493 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: A Restaurant Owner Bites Into Something Foul, Dark and Winged
description: IN my line of work, I have to go everywhere to get new ideas. When it comes to food, I will eat local delicacies to get inspiration, too.

title: Readers Photos: A Familys Best Friend?
description: Photos and stories of pets that were viewed differently by family members.

title: Music in Review
description: ALINA IBRAGIMOVA, CDRIC TIBERGHIEN

title: Egypt: Militant Is Rearrested Days After Release From Prison
description: Egypt rearrested the brother of Al Qaedas second in command, Ayman al-Zawahri, days after he was released from prison as part of a broader effort to free political prisoners jailed under the government of former President Hosni Mubarak. Muhammad al-Zawahri, a member of Islamic Jihad who is believed to help plan the groups terrorist attacks, will be retried in relation to a 1998 conviction for which he received the death penalty in absentia, security officials said. Mr. Zawahri had been jailed since 2000 on charges of conspiring to overthrow the government, but his supporters accused Egypt of holding him to obtain information about his brother. He was released from prison on Thursday, and then arrested again at his home early Sunday.

title: Natural Gas Now Viewed as Safer Bet
description: Natural gas may be having its day, as its rival energy sources come under a cloud.

title: Gaza: Israel Replies With Strikes
description: Israeli warplanes struck the Gaza Strip late Monday, in response to a barrage of mortar shells and missiles fired by Hamas militants at Israel two days earlier. Israeli F-16s carried out at least eight airstrikes, hitting a Hamas training camp, a brick factory, a metal workshop and a mechanics garage, according to residents. Local reports said that at least five people, including a woman and two children, sustained moderate injuries. With attacks over the weekend, Hamas ended a cease-fire that had lasted since an Israeli military operation in Gaza ended more than two years ago. Hamas said the attacks were in response to ongoing Israeli crimes. However, there were signs of internal differences within Hamas, particularly between the hard-line military wing and the government, which may have led to the escalation.

title: Court to Hear Case Stalled by Mistake in Mailroom
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear an appeal from a death row inmate who faces execution after a mailroom mix-up at one of the nations most prominent law firms.

title: Day Care Owner Is Returned; Fled Country After Fatal Fire
description: A woman who fled to Nigeria after a fire killed four children at her day care center in Houston was flown back to the United States on Monday, the authorities said.

title: Google Faces French Fine for Breach of Privacy
description: PARIS  Googles privacy problems mounted Monday as French regulators fined the company for violating data protection laws and accused it of continuing to flout the rules even though it acknowledged mistakes in collecting data for an online mapping service.

title: A Panel Decides Washington States Health Care Costs
description: SEATTLE  The health care board was in session, and Deryk Lamb was pleading for them to continue paying for the spinal injections he receives to dull the pain from a workplace injury.

title: A Friendship Endures, Even Under a Wars Heavy Toll
description: BAGHDAD  As long as they can remember, Sadiq Ali and Mohammed Ahmed have been inseparable. They grew up on the same block in western Baghdad. Walked each other to school. Dreamed about being soccer stars. And they were playing video games together at an outdoor arcade when a rocket whipped down from the sky and sprayed the boys with fire and shrapnel.

title: For Law Students With Everything, Dog Therapy for Stress
description: Blacks Law Dictionary? Check.

title: Emmett J. Rice, Former Fed Governor, Is Dead at 91
description: Emmett J. Rice, a former Federal Reserve governor, World Bank executive and adviser on economic development who helped Nigeria set up its banking system in the 1960s, died on March 10 at his home in Camas, Wash. He was 91.

title: Court Revives Lawsuit Over Government Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  Civil libertarians opposed to the governments expanded wiretapping powers were bolstered Monday after an appellate court reinstated a lawsuit challenging an eavesdropping law passed by Congress in 2008.

title: Pinetop Perkins, Delta Boogie-Woogie Master, Dies at 97
description: Pinetop Perkins, the boogie-woogie piano player who worked in Muddy Waterss last great band and was among the last surviving members of the first generation of Delta bluesmen, died on Monday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 97.

title: Robert Ross, Global Deal Maker, Dies at 92
description: Robert Ross, a gung-ho entrepreneur who juggled global deals in things like fertilizer, pantyhose, steel and antisnoring medicine, then made his big mark by starting for-profit medical, veterinary and nursing schools in the Caribbean, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: Treasury to Test Mortgage Market;
Natural Oil Seep
description: Diving in the Alvin submersible at the site of the Deepwater Horizon spill.

title: Revisiting the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill
description: Until a year ago, the marine scientist Samantha Joye studied a fairly obscure natural phenomenon: the seepage of oil from undersea deposits into deepwater environments. Then, in the wake of the BP Deepwater Horizon accident, she felt compelled to turn her attention to an unnatural phenomenon: oil spills.

title: Radiation Over U.S. Is Harmless, Officials Say
description: Harmless traces of radiation from the stricken nuclear complex in Japan have been detected wafting over the East Coast of the United States, European officials said Monday.

title: On Our Radar: Cycling Deaths Decline in New York
description: While a debate rages over the safety and utility of new bike lanes in Manhattan and Brooklyn, statistics show that cycling-related fatalities and overall pedestrian injuries have fallen in recent years, even as the number of cyclists on New York streets has grown. There will always be some who resist change, but in the case of bike lanes, the community boards have strongly supported them  and the safety numbers show theyre saving lives, says a City Hall spokesman, responding to bike lane critics. [New York magazine]

title: Once in the Publics Hands, Now Back in Picassos
description: WASHINGTON

title: Lessons of Japan: Travelers, Be Prepared
description: BIG trouble can happen anywhere on a business trip, but its reasonable to think it least likely in a place where daily routines run efficiently and where tranquillity is a civic virtue.

title: Japanese Town Holds On to Hope
description: RIKUZENTAKATA, Japan  On the afternoon of Friday, March 11, the Takata High School swim team walked a half-mile to practice at the citys nearly new natatorium, overlooking the broad sand beach of Hirota Bay.

title: Pearl Fired as Tennessees Coach
description: Bruce Pearl would wade into the stands at Thompson-Boling Arena to shake the hands of Tennessee basketball fans, thanking them for their support. They would stay to listen to his postgame radio show, and he would sign autograph after autograph.

title: A Guide to Smarter, Safer Antibiotic Use
description: Antibiotics are important drugs, perhaps the most important. In a world beset with an unprecedented wave of new and old infections, as one expert recently wrote, it is critically important that antibiotics work well when people need them.

title: In Vitro Fertilization, 1974
description: When The New York Times first mentioned in vitro fertilization, the paper might have been reporting on a casually uttered lie.

title: Goldman Partnership Memo Stirs Succession Talk
description: There is nothing like a change in the leadership of Goldman Sachss influential partnership committee to fan rumors of succession at the influential Wall Street bank.

title: Were All Badgers Now
description: A conversation about unionization and higher education between Stanley Fish and Walter Benn Michaels, professor of English at the University of Illinois at Chicago.

title: The Plants That Cried (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Unmarried Pastor, Seeking a Job, Sees Bias
description: Like all too many Americans, Mark Almlie was laid off in the spring of 2009 when his workplace downsized. He has been searching for an appropriate position ever since, replying to more than 500 job postings without success.

title: Not for Men Only (1 Letter)
Retrievers, Truly Golden (1 Letter)
As the Allies Wage War on Qaddafi
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Friend? Not Always (1 Letter)
description: The Plants That Cried

title: Internet Privacy Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: Dislike for Qaddafi Gives Arabs a Point of Unity
description: CAIRO  With his brutal military assault on civilians, and his rantings about spiked Nescaf, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi handed many leaders across the Arab world what had otherwise eluded them: A chance to side with the people while deflecting attention from their own citizens call for democracy, political analysts around the region said. And they really do not like him.

title: Domestic Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Back to the Future for AT&T
description: 8:42 p.m. | Updated

title: Sprint Adds Google Voice Tie-In
description: For Sprint customers, Google Voice just got a lot more useful. They will now be able to use Googles phone service with their Sprint phone numbers and for voicemail and text messages.

title: Ex-Governor of Minnesota Enters Race for President
description: WASHINGTON  Former Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota became the first major Republican to enter the 2012 presidential race, announcing an exploratory committee on Monday that formalizes an ambition that has been steadily building for more than a year.

title: How Many Does It Take to Change a Light Bulb?
description: To the Editor:

title: Attack Renews Debate Over Congressional Consent
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is facing criticism that crosses the political divide for not seeking Congressional authorization before ordering the American military to join in attacks of Libyan air defenses and government forces.

title: N.F.L. Asks Court to Wait for Labor Boards Ruling
description: The N.F.L. responded in court documents Monday to players attempt to gain an injunction to lift the lockout, claiming that courts are barred from issuing injunctions in labor disputes and that no decision on the injunction should be made before the National Labor Relations Board rules on the N.F.L.s charge that the unions decertification is a sham. One league official Monday called the decertification a fake suicide.

title: Setbacks for Farmworkers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bike Safety in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: A Proud Lobbyist and Southerner Weighs President
description: DES MOINES  He became wealthy as a lobbyist, representing tobacco companies and foreign governments. A former Republican Party chairman, he would seem the ultimate Washington insider. A white Southerner, he has faced questions about his remarks on race.

title: China Tightens Censorship of Electronic Communications
description: BEIJING  If anyone wonders whether the Chinese government has tightened its grip on electronic communications since protests began engulfing the Arab world, Shakespeare may prove instructive.

title: In Rare Split, Two Leaders in Russia Differ on Libya
description: MOSCOW  The conflict in Libya caused an unusual rift on Monday between Russias two leaders, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin and his protg, President Dmitri A. Medvedev, who typically choreograph their statements and refrain from criticizing each other.

title: The Ken Doll Turns 50, and Wins a New Face
description: THE toy maker Mattel is revamping its best-selling Barbie franchise by emphasizing her longtime beau, Ken.

title: AT&Ts Full Cost for Getting T-Mobile
description: We have never seen a deal with more regulatory risk be attempted in the U.S.

title: Putting Un-American in Perspective
description: Some history is in order.

title: An Example for Anthony on Putting Team First
description: There they were, on graphic and occasionally brutal display, the terms of playoff-type engagement, as set forth by the Boston Celtics. There was Rajon Rondo streaking from one side of the court to the other to save a key fourth-quarter possession. There was Kevin Garnett hitting the floor at midcourt, sacrificing his 34-year-old knees for a measly jump ball.

title: Obama Cites Latin Americans as Example for Others
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  With his first trip to South America eclipsed by war and upheaval in the Middle East and North Africa, President Obama sought to connect the two in a speech here on Monday, calling Latin America a model for those trying to throw off dictatorships in favor of democracy and broadly shared economic growth.

title: Wisconsins Radical Break
description: Madison, Wis.

title: Lawyer in Perjury Case Tries to Discredit Reporter
description: EL PASO  A defense lawyer tried to discredit a former contract writer for The New York Times in the perjury trial of a Cuban exile here on Monday, forcing her to defend a 1998 front-page article that said the defendant had taken credit for orchestrating a series of bombings in Havana.

title: Planning for a Post-Qaddafi Libya
description: FOR weeks, Ive argued that the United States and our allies should impose a no-fly zone over Libya and mount airstrikes to stop Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis advance against the embattled rebels. Last week, the United Nations Security Council authorized precisely those actions. Over the weekend, missile strikes began.

title: Japan Extended Reactors Life, Despite Warning
description: TOKYO  Just a month before a powerful earthquake and tsunami crippled the Fukushima Daiichi plant at the center of Japans nuclear crisis, government regulators approved a 10-year extension for the oldest of the six reactors at the power station despite warnings about its safety.

title: Separate and Unequal
description: One of the most powerful tools for improving the educational achievement of poor black and Hispanic public school students is, regrettably, seldom even considered. It has become a political no-no.

title: Sharp Scrutiny for Merger of AT&T and T-Mobile
description: WASHINGTON  Mega-mergers may be celebrated on Wall Street on the theory that bigger is better. But the proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile is likely to face intense scrutiny by regulators, lawmakers and consumer advocates.

title: For Consumers, Little to Cheer in AT&T Deal
description: The $39 billion proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile could save the companies a lot of money. For everyone else, it could cost a lot of money. No sooner did the two companies announce a $39 billion merger on Sunday than industry analysts began assessing the impact on the biggest potential losers in the deal: consumers.

title: After Day of Questions, Bonds Trial Has a Jury
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Some frowned when their names were announced, others sat stone-faced, but every person chosen on Monday as a juror for Barry Bondss perjury trial had one thing in common. Over the next few weeks, they will hold Bondss fate in their hands.

title: G. A. Marlatt, Advocate of Shift in Treating Addicts, Dies at 69
description: G. Alan Marlatt, a psychologist who challenged the longstanding belief that substance addiction is incurable and that it can be controlled only by abstinence, died March 14 at his vacation home in Stanwood, Wash. He was 69 and lived in Seattle.

title: The Problem With Partners
description: These days we are all co-religionists in the church of multilateralism. The Iraq war reminded everybody not to embark on an international effort without a broad coalition.

title: Hopes for a Qaddafi Exit, and Worries of What Comes Next
description: TRIPOLI  The question has hovered over the Libyan uprising from the moment the first tank commander defected to join his cousins protesting in the streets of Benghazi: Is the battle for Libya the clash of a brutal dictator against a democratic opposition, or is it fundamentally a tribal civil war?

title: Microfinance Under Fire
description: At Fixes, our focus is typically on implementing new or underutilized ideas to help those in need. But sometimes its just as important to protect institutions that are already working well. Which is why Im writing today about the Grameen Bank, the Bangladeshi organization that won the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize, along with its founder Muhammad Yunus, for its work extending microloans to some of the worlds poorest, and has been crucial in global efforts to lift millions of people out of poverty.

title: The Souths Capital Dilemma
description: The month of March, 1861, found the once sleepy riverside town of Montgomery, Ala., suddenly awake with the efforts to build the new Confederate government. Delegates from the seceding states had gathered there in February, and they had already written a constitution for the Confederate States of America and elected Jefferson Davis as president. Now the new Congress was busy with more routine matters like the postal service, liquor regulations and the salary of members. Cannons saluted arriving dignitaries and receptions, dinners and plays were regularly held. One delegate wrote his wife that cheers, enthusiasm, and waving handkerchiefs went along with the work of bringing a nation into existence.

title: At War in Libya
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has long been a thug and a murderer who has never paid for his many crimes, including the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. The United Nations Security Council resolution authorized member nations to take all necessary measures to protect civilians and was perhaps the only hope of stopping him from slaughtering thousands more.

title: A Dangerous Pursuit
description: In a world where most people consume their news safely, perhaps in a comfortable chair on some electronic device, it is worth remembering how dangerous news-gathering has become. Mondays release of four New York Times staff members in Libya was a powerful reminder of the hazards journalists face around the world.

title: Radiation, Once Free, Can Follow Tricky Path
description: Ten days after an earthquake and tsunami crippled a nuclear plant in Japan, officials are detecting abnormal levels of radiation in what may seem like a scattershot assortment of foods: milk from Fukushima Prefecture, where the reactors sit; spinach from Ibaraki Prefecture to the south; canola from Gunma Prefecture to the west; and chrysanthemum greens from Chiba to the south. Shipments of the milk and spinach have been banned.

title: Beckham Returns; Fans Turn
description: CARSON, Calif.  One of the worlds most recognizable athletes began his career in Major League Soccer by listening to a serenade based on the 1960s hit Guantanamera.

title: Arizona Flinches
description: Arizona, the nations leader in over-the-top immigration laws, has pulled back. Its Republican-controlled Senate rejected five anti-immigration bills in one day last week. It was a startling rebuke to the Senate president, the architect of the states go-it-alone approach to enforcement. Other states weighing similar crackdowns should take note.

title: New Yorks Prisons Fall Short, Again
description: Perhaps as many as three-quarters of New York States 57,000 prison inmates need drug counseling or treatment to have a chance at productive, crime-free lives once they are released. A three-year study of drug and alcohol abuse programs in the New York State Department of Corrections suggests that prisons are failing to provide adequate treatment programs for the tens of thousands of inmates who need them.

title: Judge Again Questions an S.E.C. Settlement
description: Woe be to the S.E.C. lawyer who next draws Judge Jed S. Rakoff.

title: After Years of Boos, Perez Goes Quietly
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The end came with little suspense.

title: City Is Planning Major Cuts in the Construction of Schools
description: New York City education officials are set to approve a school construction budget on Wednesday that would significantly cut the number of schools to be built in the next three years, as the city faces what it says is a new cap on state construction aid.

title: Bloggingheads: Don't Give to Japan?
description: Annie Lowrey, left, of Slate and Timothy Carney of The Washington Examiner discuss whether Americans should send aid money to Japan.

title: He Wrote the Book on a Bust
description: When Oliver Perez entered free agency after the 2008 season, his agent, Scott Boras, followed his standard procedure and produced a binder, 45 pages in length, that praised his client to the heavens.

title: A.C.P.T. Wrap-Up
Lottery Numbers
description: March 21, 2011

title: With Six Strong Innings, Colon Keeps Himself in Mix
description: 10:52 p.m. | Updated PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  Every start for Bartolo Colon has been a revelation. He arrived in Yankees camp as a curiosity. He may leave it next week as a member of their rotation. With the competition nearing its final stages, Colon flummoxed the Tampa Bay Rays over six innings Monday night, retiring 18 of 20 hitters in the Yankees 3-1 loss.

title: Tuesday: Tribal Emblems
description: Administrivial Digital Subscriptions/Puzzle Access Update:  There is now someone specific to write to regarding the transition to digital subscriptions and how or where that runs into your old Times Reader subscription for the puzzles. If you are having a problem, please send a courteous e-mail to cday@nytimes.com with all of your pertinent information. I reiterate the courteous part, because a good many of the e-mails sent to me have not been, and Ms. Day is doing her very best behind the scenes to work out a nearly impossible situation with a good deal of grace. Please be kind to her, and remember that the Premium Puzzle subscription is a different animal than the rest of the online paper, so please be patient as the New York Times works out all of the kinks. Back to our regularly scheduled puzzling.

title: No Connection Is Too Far, or Unlikely
description: The truism that families come in all shapes and sizes is illuminated with haunting beauty in the new play Kin, by Bathsheba Doran. The daisy chain of relationships depicted in this exquisitely wrought comedy-drama, which opened on Monday night at Playwrights Horizons, moves through a couple of generations and across several American states and two countries. It might even be said to include a live bear and a dead dog.

title: Louisiana: No-Contest Plea in 5 Killings
description: A New Orleans man pleaded no contest Monday to manslaughter charges in the killing of five teenagers in 2006. Michael Anderson, 24, was convicted of the murders in 2009 and was facing a death sentence. But a judge ordered a new trial after Mr. Andersons lawyers discovered that prosecutors had not turned over possibly exculpatory evidence. Before that new trial took place, Mr. Anderson was indicted on federal charges for his leadership role in a violent drug gang. He reached a deal with prosecutors, and pleaded guilty last Friday to helping plan a murder as well as to two other conspiracy charges. He also agreed to plead no contest to state charges of manslaughter in the 2006 killings, though, in his court filing, he maintains his innocence in that case. He faces a life sentence.

title: With Six Strong Innings, Colon Keeps Himself in Mix
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  Every start for Bartolo Colon has been a revelation. He arrived in Yankees camp as a curiosity. He may leave it next week as a member of their rotation. With the competition nearing its final stages, Colon flummoxed the Tampa Bay Rays over six innings Monday night, retiring 18 of 20 hitters in the Yankees 3-1 loss.

title: Bus Crash in the Bronx Ends a Mans Fight for His Family
description: The authorities were at Wang Jianhuas door in Fujian Province, China, intent on taking his wife away. Her crime: She already had a child and she was pregnant again, in violation of the countrys one-child policy.

title: Operators of Indian Point Say Changes Are Likely
description: WHITE PLAINS  The operators of the Indian Point nuclear power plant said Monday that they did not expect ever to face the combination of earthquake and flooding that devastated Japan this month. But in the aftermath of those disasters, they said, some regulatory changes were to be expected.

title: Pawlenty's Papers with the Federal Election Commission
description: Tim Pawlenty became the first major Republican candidate to file papers with the Federal Election Commission, allowing him to raise money and hire staff members as he further explores a presidential bid.

title: After Gaining for 3 Days, Shares Slip on Oil Worries
description: Stocks on Wall Street edged lower Tuesday, reversing three consecutive trading days of advances amid concerns over oil prices and Japans nuclear crisis.

title: In Los Angeles, a Broken Relationship
description: As David Beckham enters the final year of his contract with the Los Angeles Galaxy, the fans who once serenaded him with songs have changed their tune. The cause, Joseph DHippolito reports, is a string of off-season loans, critical comments and trophy-less seasons. Read the entire article here, and come back to this post to comment.

title: Richmond: Virginias Basketball Capital
description: The two universities sit five miles apart, one amid the manicured grass of the suburbs and the other rising from the concrete of the city.

title: Elbows Land but Shots Miss as the Knicks Lose Again
description: Carmelo Anthony lay on the Madison Square Garden floor as blood dripped from his left eyebrow. The blow was the final, lasting image of a night when the Knicks and Boston Celtics traded elbows, shoves and leads in what could be the precursor to a first-round playoff matchup.

title: Incentives Offered to Raise College Graduation Rates
description: In what amounts to a Race to the Top for higher education, the Obama administration is offering competitive grants and a new tool kit to help states increase their college completion rates.

title: Open Networking Foundation Pursues New Standards
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Acknowledging that so-called cloud computing will blur the distinctions between computers and networks, about two dozen big information technology companies plan to announce on Tuesday a new standards-setting group for computer networking.

title: Deal on Stalled Condo Project Is First Under a City Program
description: In the summer of 2009, city officials began a $20 million program that would allow developers to convert stalled condominium sites into moderate-income housing. The initial response was tepid, as many developers and investors clung to the hope that the New York housing market would rebound.

title: Stanford Women Oust St. Johns
description: STANFORD, Calif.  One minute the St. Johns basketball team was forcing turnovers, making baskets and grabbing rebounds as if its players had tapped into a supercharged energy source. And then Stanford pulled the plug.

title: Why Should We Care About Events in Other Parts of the World?
description: Propelled by revolution in the Middle East and radiation in Japan, television news coverage of foreign events this year is at the highest level since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks 10 years ago, a Business section article reports. Have you been following coverage of these events? Why or why not? In general, do you tend to pay attention to what happens in other parts of the world? Why, in your opinion, should we care in general about what happens in places far away from where we live?

title: Patrick Baz Is in His Element in Libya
description: Patrick Baz, 47, is the Middle East photo manager for Agence France-Presse, based in Cyprus. He has been covering the conflict in Libya since the end of February. His telephone conversation with Kerri MacDonald and David Furst on Monday night has been edited and condensed.

title: Obama Seeks to Unify Allies as More Airstrikes Rock Tripoli
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama worked on Tuesday to bridge differences among allies about how to manage the military campaign in Libya, as airstrikes continued to rock Tripoli. Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, however, showed no sign of ending their sieges of rebel-held cities.

title: Yemens Leader Defiant Amid Protests and Defections
description: SANA, Yemen  President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen, increasingly isolated amid defections and resignations, clung to power on Tuesday despite continuing protests and ominous signs of fragmentation among the nations main military units.

title: Afghans to Take Over Security in 7 Areas, Mostly Peaceful, by July
description: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan  The target could not have been more inviting: hundreds of thousands of Afghans, government officials and foreign dignitaries converging on the ancient blue-tiled shrine in the center of this relatively peaceful northern city for the celebration of Nowruz, the Persian New Year.

title: Fantasy Focus: A Socratic Approach
description: Most readers of this blog are familiar with Socrates declaration that the unexamined life is not worth living. What fewer people will know is that Socrates was speaking less in a general sense about life and more about fantasy baseball, specifically.

title: Exploring English at the British Library
description: Toe-MAY-toe? Toe-MAH-toe? The roots of this vexing dilemma, and many others, are on display at Londons British Library, along with ancient manuscripts and modern recording devices all documenting the evolution of the English language.

title: Who Made That T-Shirt?
description: Ten years ago, Experimental Jetset, an Amsterdam-based design firm comprising Marieke Stolk, Danny van den Dungen and Erwin Brinkers, sought to design an archetypal band shirt  for the Japanese label 2K/Gingham.

description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis.

title: Democrats Cant Afford Mistakes Like McCaskills Plane
description: Democrats in the Senate face steep odds in 2012. They are defending more than 20 seats against an energized Republican party, which only needs to pick up four seats to win the majority. Five Democratic incumbents are retiring from the Senate, making their seats instantly more vulnerable to Republicans.

title: Ex-President of Israel Sentenced to Prison in Rape Case
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli court sentenced Moshe Katsav, the countrys former president, to seven years in prison for rape on Tuesday.

title: How Much Technology Is Too Much?
description: Beck Ag is a small agricultural marketing firm that helps companies get good word of mouth among farmers. Clients often ask the Omaha-based firm to set the farmers up with video conferences, chat groups and Web-based meetings. But John Finegan, founder and owner, offers a surprising response: Nah.

title: Dirty Thoughts on Cleanliness, and Much More
description: In his book The Biographical Dictionary of Film, David Thomson explained what knocked him out about James Agees film criticism during the 1940s. Agee wrote, Mr. Thompson said, like someone who had not just viewed the movie but been in it  out with it, as if it were a girl; drinking with it; driving in the night with it.

description: On Tuesday, The Lede is following the war in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from journalists and bloggers in the region.

title: For Time Warner, a Rival to Watch
Ignoramitocracy
description: Harold Pollack points out that everything I said about Elizabeth Warren applies, with even more force, to Donald Berwick, a highly qualified technocrat who cant even get a confirmation hearing on his nomination to run Medicare and Medicaid. And then there is, of course, Peter Diamond, an economists economist with a sterling reputation, who is being blocked at the Fed.

description: The buyout firm Leonard Green & Partners is weighing a possible acquisition of BJs Wholesale Club, the company said in a securities filing on Tuesday.

title: Stephen Colbert Exposes Himself to Art (the Appropriate Way)
description: For some reason, Steve Martins visits to The Colbert Report always seem to bring out the erudite side of its host, Stephen Colbert. Back in December, when Mr. Martin came on to evaluate a portrait of Mr. Colbert, the segment turned into an art party crashed by Frank Stella, Shepard Fairey and Andres Serrano (not the sort of folks one expects to see just before midnight on Comedy Central). And when Mr. Martin returned to the show on Monday night, Mr. Colbert used the occasion to visit his portrait at the Phillips de Pury & Company gallery in Manhattan (where it was sold at a recent auction) and to subject the auction house chairman, Simon de Pury, to a typically tongue-in-cheek grilling. (Be prepared to find out who Mr. de Purys favorite rap artist is!)

title: Media Group Opposes News Corp. Deal for BSkyB
description: An group of major British media companies has filed a legal objection to the News Corporations plan to take over the pay-television company BSkyB, just weeks after the British government cleared the way for the deal.

title: Edanoru
description: A neologism, popularised on Twitter, extolling the virtues of the Japanese politician Yukio Edano, whose work following the March earthquake has been praised as exemplary.

title: The Family Pet Slide Show
description: Last week, we asked readers to share stories of how pets had changed their family relationships and to submit their own family pet photos.

title: Tuesday Reading: Rear-Facing Seats for Kids Under 2
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Actor Is Injured in Irish Production of Hamlet
description: An actor portraying Hamlet in an Irish production of that Shakespeare play sustained a palpable and frightening hit during a performance on Monday, resulting in his hospitalization, The Associated Press reported. Conor Madden, who is portraying the melancholy Danish prince in the Second Age Theater Companys production of Hamlet being presented at the Everyman Palace Theater in Cork, Ireland, was wounded during a sword fight. The A.P. said that Mr. Madden sustained a cut beneath his eye and collapsed on stage, requiring the theater companys artistic director, Alan Stanford, to go to the stage and explain to stunned audience members that this was not part of the play: the actor had been injured, and the play could not continue. Mr. Madden was treated and released. He will miss two performances scheduled for Tuesday but could return to the production as soon as Wednesday.

title: Gates Expects Decline in Fighting
description: MOSCOW  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Tuesday that fighting in Libya would soon decline significantly, and he attributed criticism of the American-led military campaign to the outright lies by the Qaddafi government about civilian casualties.

title: China Urges Quick End to Airstrikes in Libya
description: BEIJING  China escalated its opposition to American-led airstrikes on Libya on Tuesday, joining Russia and India in calls for an immediate cease-fire and suggesting that coalition forces were imperiling civilians by exceeding the United Nations-mandated no-fly zone.

title: French Official Calls Bank Bashing Futile
description: The French economy minister said it was futile to continue castigating bankers for their role in the financial crisis, arguing that attention should shift to making sure the banks returned to their core role of financing growth.

title: Canucks Lose Malhotra for Rest of the Season
description: The Vancouver Canucks veteran center Manny Malhotra will miss the remainder of the regular season and the Stanley Cup playoffs with an eye injury. Malhotra, a former first round pick of the Rangers, suffered the injury during a game against Colorado on March 16 when a shot by Erik Johnson hit him in the face.
