description: London: Theres a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

title: Off the Menu: Walle
description: Its a good thing that Wally Chin is a man of patience. He is an owner of Chin Chin, a highly respected Chinese restaurant in Midtown, with his brother, Jimmy Chin, and he had the notion of opening a place that ventured beyond a classic Chinese menu. But after he rented the space that had been Il Nido, he had some health problems that set back his timetable by almost a year. Im glad I had the restaurant to think of during this time, he said. It kept me going.

title: Fill-In | A New Ken Doll
Two New Buyers Take Over Donnell Library Site
description: The deal to create a hotel-slash-condominium-slash-library on the site of the former Donnell Library on West 53rd Street has been finalized, and clarified. Orient-Express Hotels, which originally agreed to buy the site from the New York Public Library in 2007 for $59 million, then saw its plan to build a hotel there derailed by the recession, has unloaded its contract to two other developers.

title: Containing the Damage at Tennessee
description: Today, the University of Tennessee really should send out a mass apology. Firing Bruce Pearl on Monday was, of course, inevitable, totally expected and showed some self-awareness because Tennessee officials first instinct was probably to can him on his way off the court Friday after losing to Michigan by 30. No, Tennessee should apologize for being a major buzz kill in an otherwise charming tournament. Nothing like reminding everyone of the sports shaky moral underpinnings by having your about-to-be-fired coach walking around in a glowing orange sport coat.

title: Hopeful Message About the Worlds Poorest
description: In the not too distant past  1980  one of every six babies born in the West African nation of Liberia died in infancy. Overall life expectancy was a mere 48 years. The great majority of Liberians couldnt read in 1980. Most girls had never attended school.

title: War Without Illusions
description: Judging from my inbox, many readers interpreted this weeks column, which examines the perils inherent in the liberal interventionist style of warfare, as an implicit defense of the Bush administrations rather different approach to the invasion of Iraq. (There were hints of a similar critique from Adam Serwer and Andrew Sullivan as well.) This was not my intention at all: As Ive suggested before, I think that the Iraq War was a mistake in its conception and a botch in its execution, and I wouldnt be supportive of our Libya intervention if it were being undertaken la Rumsfeld (or John Bolton) rather than la Samantha Power. My point, rather, was to push back against the conceit that the form of a war can vindicate its strategy  that what matters most in warfare is whether youre part of U.N. Security Council approved action and whether the Arab League gives you the go-ahead, and that merely invoking the Obama White Houses multilateralism is sufficient to prove that our Libyan venture is far more responsible than the invasion of Iraq. Too many liberal Libya hawks (the president included) seem bent on persuading themselves that a strategically dubious intervention is justified so long as its goals are sufficiently high-minded and the French and the United Nations are on board. But the history of such interventions doesnt bear their logic out.

title: Australian Playwright Wins Yale Drama Series Award
description: An Australian play about four people from a small town trying to build new lives after a violent crime has won the 2011 Yale Drama Series award for an emerging playwright. John Guare, the acclaimed stage writer (The House of Blue Leaves, Six Degrees of Separation) and judge for the series, announced on Tuesday that Shannon Murdoch had won for New Light Shine. Ms. Murdoch, who is a legal assistant and writer living near Melbourne, will receive $10,000 from the David Charles Horn Foundation, and there will be a staged reading of the play at the Yale Repertory Theater on Sept. 12. Yale University Press will also publish the play.

title: The Best Part of Parenting
description: Anna Quindlen was one of my first editors. I was a clerk on the Metro desk back then, and she was the Deputy Metropolitan Editor. When I was granted the precious four-week tryout that would eventually land me a spot as a reporter, Anna made sure to send me on assignments that would allow me to shine.

title: Buffett, Indias Insurance Salesman
description: NEW DEHLI  Warren E. Buffetts annual shareholder meeting is legendary, drawing thousands to an event that is considered the Woodstock for capitalists.

title: Nuclear Industry in Russia Sells Safety, Taught by Chernobyl
description: MOSCOW  It was truly a trial by fire  one that has now become part of Russias nuclear marketing message. Cynical as that might seem.

title: Four New Landmarks Include Citys Youngest
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission approved four new landmarks Tuesday morning: a former social club for engineers, an early experimental theater, a Bronx cottage attributed to the architect James Renwick Jr. and the Modernist headquarters of a Japanese cultural organization.

title: Muscle Strain Sidelines Granderson
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Curtis Granderson was scratched about an hour before the Yankees game Tuesday against the Orioles after straining his right oblique muscle. It is unclear how or when Granderson sustained the injury, but he took batting practice.

title: Rare Ruth and Gehrig Film
description: An excerpt of the film of Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig during their famous 1927 barnstorming tour. Film provided by R.C. Raycraft.

title: A Meaty Role Brings James Gandolfini Back to HBO
description: James Gandolfini may be a man of few words, but when he returns to the cable channel that made him, its worth devoting a few words to. HBO said on Tuesday that Mr. Gandolfini was planning to star in a new made-for-cable film that would return him to the network that gave us The Sopranos, as well as the state that gave us the Bada Bing! club. The film will be adapted from Eating With the Enemy: How I Waged Peace With North Korea From My BBQ Shack in Hackensack, a nonfiction book by Robert Egan and Kurt Pitzer, in which Mr. Egan recounts how he used his barbecue restaurant to build friendships with diplomats from Vietnam and North Korea, and became an unlikely liaison between North Korea and the United States. Mr. Gandolfini, who has also produced the HBO documentaries Alive Day: Home from Iraq and Wartorn: 1861-2010, is attached as a star and would also be an executive producer of the new film, which will be produced by his Attaboy Productions company and Tribeca Productions, though neither a start date for production nor a broadcast date on HBO have been announced.

title: Should I Dump My Servers and Embrace the Cloud?
description: Id like to thank all who took a moment to chime in on my three problems. The advice, as usual, was very helpful. I will be adding my reactions to the suggestions in the reverse order that I posted them, meaning Ill start with question No. 3 and work my way backwards. Without further ado:

title: Knicks Run Out of Tricks Against Boston
description: With 7 minutes 26 seconds remaining in Mondays Celtics-Knicks game, Chauncey Billups converted a 4-point play that gave the Knicks a 9-point lead over the Celtics. Everything seemed to be working for the Knicks; the ball was moving, shots were falling and the Celtics were struggling offensively. Unfortunately for the Knicks, they were outscored, 23-4, after Billupss 4-point play, and managed only one field goal in the final seven minutes of the game.

title: Q&A: An Excursion From Kiev?
description: We are traveling to Ukraine with our two children (14 and 12) for a week in April. We will be based out of Kiev but are having a hard time narrowing down what other city we should visit there as our time is rather limited. Is it better to fly between cities to save time, or travel by train or bus?

title: Notes from the Underground | Julia Haltigan
description: The youthfully exuberant Julia Haltigan performed a free set recently at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics upstairs cafe. Backed by a full band that included trumpet drums and a rarely seen steel guitar Haltigan, a modern descendant of a caste of strong female country singers conjured an air of sultry class. Haltigan and company performed a smattering of numbers, including a selection from her latest album.

title: Julian Schnabel Discusses His New Film, a Palestinian Story
description: At an exhibition opening in Rome in 2007, Julian Schnabel, the burly artist and filmmaker known for his enormous canvases and outsize personality, met a svelte, stylish journalist who was born in Haifa and lived in Italy. As they chatted, Mr. Schnabel tried to place her accent.

title: Film Shows Babe Ruth, at Leisure and Up Close
description: HENDERSON, Nev.  Tom Stevens sat at a Starbucks in this Las Vegas suburb and watched his grandfather, Babe Ruth, cavort across the computer screen.

title: Continental to Add In-Flight Wi-Fi to 200 Planes
description: The airline announced that it would be equipping more than 200 Boeing 737 and 757 aircraft with wireless Internet beginning in 2012.

title: Controlling Times Squares Screens With a Phone, for Real This Time
description: Adi Isakovic called MTV last fall to propose a deal: he would stream live video, text messages and other content directly from his phone onto the companys gargantuan video screen in Times Square. The demonstration would give Mr. Isakovic the chance show off a technology he had been developing for years, while MTV would place itself at the forefront of a movement, attracting a wave of innovators eager to develop the next generation of public art and advertising.

title: Porsche 918 Spyder: Hybrid Power at a Heart-Pounding Premium
description: Porsche is taking orders for the 918 Spyder. The automakers Stuttgart-Zuffenhausen plant will build no more than 918 examples of the split-personality plug-in hybrid, and production is scheduled to begin on Sept. 18, 2013 (9/18, get it?). The only thing that throws off the numerical symmetry is the price.

title: With Silence, Bondss Trainer Risks More Than Jail Time
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Greg Anderson, the childhood friend and former trainer of Barry Bonds, went to jail Tuesday for refusing to testify in Bondss perjury trial. For Anderson, it is nothing new.

title: Mad Men Fifth Season? Follow the Money
description: Fans accustomed to spending their summer Sundays with Don Draper may have to wait a while longer. It looks increasingly likely that the fifth season of Mad Men, the three-time Emmy Award-winning AMC series, will not have its debut until late 2011 or early 2012.

title: Important Administrivial Puzzle Access Update
description: The New York Times apologizes for the inconvenience to those who have been having problems getting their daily crossword fix.

title: An Authors View of a World Getting Better
description: My column this week discusses Getting Better, a new book in which the economist Charles Kenny argues that many people have overlooked the enormous improvements in human well-being over the last few decades. Mr. Kenny is a senior fellow at the Center for Global Development in Washington. Foreign Policy magazine, where Mr. Kenny is a contributing writer, recently organized a discussion of his book. He also wrote a recent article for Time on the worlds youth.

title: Man Group Sells Back Stake to BlueCrest
description: The Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded alternative asset manager, will sell its 25 percent stake in BlueCrest Capital back to the hedge fund for $633 million, ending an investment that lasted more than seven years.

title: The Risks ID Cards May Carry
description: Just about everyone who works in an office or retail outlet these days has some sort of identification tag dangling from a lanyard around their neck. But besides your name and photograph, what else is lurking on that laminated card?

title: Ad Spending Could Change With AT&T Deal
description: The advertising implications for the acquisition of T-Mobile by AT&T will take some time to unfold.

title: Never-Betters, Better-Nevers and Ever-Wasers
description: Adam Gopniks categorisation of peoples views on the impact of new technology.

title: Newport Jazz Festival Embraces Fresh Talent
description: There will be plenty of new blood and young performers on stage this summer at the Newport Jazz Festival, whose 2011 schedule was announced on Tuesday. The bassist and singer Esperanza Spalding, who last month won the Grammy for best new artist, will perform on two of the festivals three days of shows, which begin on Friday, Aug. 5, in Newport, R.I., where the festival was first held in 1954.

title: Capitals Playoff Quandary: Whos in Goal?
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  With an eye on the Stanley Cup playoffs, the Washington Capitals appear to have finalized many of their roster spots. One key position, however, has yet to be decided: goalie.

title: The Aftermath in Japan
description: A look at the devastation caused by a tsunami and earthquake that struck the country on March 11, 2011.

title: Women Seeking Abortions in South Dakota to Get Anti-Abortion Advice
description: The sign out front advertises free pregnancy tests, information about abortion and testing for sexually transmitted diseases. But it is not an abortion clinic  it is home to the Alpha Center, an organization in Sioux Falls, S.D., dedicated to encouraging women to bring their babies to term.

title: Democrats Defend Futures Regulators Budget
description: Dozens of Democratic senators are fighting Republican efforts to cut the budget of the nations regulator of commodities trading, arguing that reckless cuts could allow gasoline prices to skyrocket.

title: Artful Lodging
description: London: Theres a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

title: Ex-President of Ukraine Is Implicated in 2000 Killing
description: MOSCOW  The former president of Ukraine whose political skulduggery helped precipitate that countrys democratic Orange Revolution seven years ago was officially named on Tuesday as a suspect in the killing of a prominent investigative journalist.

title: VW Beetle Turns Up as Skins Bugs Out
description: The season  or series  finale of the controversial show Skins on MTV on Monday night had the usual assortment of sponsors: movies, movies coming out on DVD and video games. But there was a notable newcomer: Volkswagen, promoting the new version of the New Beetle that is due out in the fall.

title: Race Issues Rise for Miami Police
description: MIAMI  The video, shot with a hand-held camera, shows brawny Miami police officers breaking down doors and hauling handcuffed African-American suspects off some of the citys toughest streets. We hunt, one officer says in the five-and-a-half-minute clip. I like to hunt.

title: Reviewing La Petite Maison
Magnates and Beignets in Midtown
description: LATE night in Midtown, and the tables were pressed close at La Petite Maison, newly installed in the basement of those beautiful old Rockefeller town houses across from the Museum of Modern Art. It might have been the opening shot in a new Whit Stillman film.

title: Sex and the Long-Term Relationship
description: Are you happy with the frequency of sex in your relationship?

title: F.C.C. Chief Talks Up Spectrum, but Stays Mum on T-Mobile Deal
description: Julius Genachowski addressing the CTIA Wireless convention in Orlando, Fla., on Tuesday.

title: How to Not Catch a Sea Turtle
description: Lekelia D. Jenkins, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington, writes from Ecuador, where she is studying factors in the cross-cultural adoption of marine conservation technologies like turtle excluder devices and circle hooks. She co-leads this project with Patrick Christie, who is an environmental sociologist and associate professor at the University of Washington.

title: Q&A: Making a Picture Show
description: Q.

title: The Excitement Algorithm: Watch This Game Now
description: The N.C.A.A. tournament can be daunting: so many games, so many networks, so little time. Luckily, technology can tell us what to get excited about, and when.

title: Controlling Times Square by Cellphone
description: Adi Isakovic, a Toronto entrepreneur, will attempt to take over a 5,000-square-foot screen in Times Square with his cellphone on Tuesday at 8 p.m. Mr. Isakovics company, TubeMote, wants to allow people to use their phones as universal remotes, controlling not only their televisions and home security systems, but also public screens in elevators, stadium scoreboards  and screens in Times Square. He rented a few minutes of screen space to show what he can do. Read the full article on the Bits blog.

title: Vain Glorious | Fatboy Putty
description: Who: Tyson Kennedy, the lead singer of Steriogram and a hairstylist at Cutler Soho.

title: 4 Wall Street Banks Still Dominate Derivatives Trade
description: A few select titans of Wall Street continue to dominate the banking industrys role in derivatives trading, according to a report issued by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.

title: Virginia Thomas to Write for Daily Caller
description: Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court, is set to be a special correspondent for the Daily Caller, a news Web site run by the conservative commentator Tucker Carlson.

title: More Examples of SAT Pop Culture Essay Questions
description: The passionate discussion last week about the propriety of the now-infamous reality television essay question on the SAT  including more than 350 comments posted on The Choice  has had one noticeable reverberation: it has pulled back the curtain a bit on how the College Board and Educational Testing Service approach the essay portion of the exam.

title: Securities America Agrees to Mediation
description: The brokerage firm Securities America  in an attempt to resolve hundreds of potentially costly arbitration claims against it  has agreed to meet with a mediator.

title: TimesCast | A Tour Through Tripoli
description: March 22, 2011 - David D. Kirkpatrick reports on a Qaddafi-sponsored tour to show journalists the damage by allied strikes.

title: With High Demand, iPad 2 Goes on Sale in 25 Countries
description: The iPad 2 is about to go global.

title: An Uneasy Return for Chris Brown on Good Morning America
description: After several months out of the spotlight, Chris Brown has the nations attention again, though surely not for the reason he intended. On Tuesday, the first day of release for his new album, F.A.M.E., Mr. Brown reportedly left behind a dressing room strewn with broken glass at ABCs Good Morning America after giving an uncomfortable interview to the G.M.A. co-anchor Robin Roberts. In the interview, Ms. Roberts asked Mr. Brown about a 2009 incident involving his ex-companion, the pop singer Rihanna, after which Mr. Brown pleaded guilty to a charge of felonious assault and was sentenced to five years of probation and six months of community labor. After Mr. Brown said that a restraining order against him had recently been relaxed, Ms. Roberts asked if he and Rihanna still saw each other; Mr. Brown replied, I mean, not really, and he avoided follow-up questions. Mr. Brown then performed a song from his new album and returned to his dressing room, where the G.M.A. morning staff members said they heard loud noises that prompted a call to security, according to a report on the ABC News Web site. It was later found that a window in the dressing room had been broken, leaving glass in the room and on the street outside ABCs studio in Times Square, and that Mr. Brown and his representatives had left the building.

title: Naming a School Is Not a Task Taken Lightly
description: Theres a lot that goes into opening a new school in New York City. For the Department of Education, the process demands several layers of discussions and decisions that include finding a place for the school, fine-tuning its academic mission and, especially in the case of high schools, settling on a name that will make it stand out in a crowded, competitive field.

title: Some Worry That Success of Apple Is Tied to Japan
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last week, shares of Apple did something they rarely do: they fell nearly 7 percent, in two days.

title: A Plea for More Disclosure on Political Ads
description: Does the Federal Communications Commission have the power to require the disclosure of who pays for political ads?

title: Does It Matter Where Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Is Filed?
description: Congress is looking at Chapter 11 filing venue again. In particular, some senators want to restrict the ability of corporations to file for bankruptcy in their jurisdiction of incorporation, rather than their home jurisdiction where they have their headquarters.

title: VW Beetle Turns Up as Skins Bugs Out
description: From our colleagues at Media Decoder:

title: The Events in Libya: Using Reporting and Multimedia to Understand News
description: Overview | What is happening in Libya, and how is it significant in global affairs? Why did the United States and other nations initiate a military operation? In this lesson, students learn about the events unfolding in Libya and the international implications by exploring traditional reporting and multimedia, graphics, videos and photographs in The Times and explaining to one another what they learned from these materials.

title: Meatless Burgers, Masters of Disguise
description: The specs on six very different veggie burgers from New York and Los Angeles.

title: Amid Rubble in Tripoli From Attacks, Hints of a Changed Atmosphere
description: TRIPOLI  The Qaddafi government gave journalists a tour on Tuesday of the wreckage of two missile warehouses at the Tripoli port in the first public display of significant damage to the capital from the American and European airstrikes.

title: Masters of Disguise Among Meatless Burgers
description: THEY were the four syllables that had the power to make both carnivores and vegetarians cringe: veggie burger.

title: Rerunning the James OKeefe NPR Tape
description: Last Thursday, James OKeefe, the conservative provocateur who all but brought down ACORN and wounded NPR through tendentiously edited video, made a speech to members of the Bayshore Tea Party and objected to  wait for it  being videotaped, according to The Asbury Park Press.

title: Albany, 8:41 A.M.
description: The Senate majority leader, Dean G. Skelos, center, at the State Capitol.

title: Penguins Forward Regrets Dangerous Play
description: Penguins forward Matt Cooke expressed contrition Tuesday for the elbow he threw at Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonagh during a game in Pittsburgh on Sunday afternoon.

title: Aflac and Monster Team Up to Find a Ducks Voice
description: 10:37 a.m. | Updated Aflac is reworking plans it has been making on the fly to address the absence of Gilbert Gottfried, the comedian who had supplied the voice of the squawking Aflac duck in many commercials. The new plans include teaming up with Monster.com to help find his replacement.

title: Disruption in Japan Slows Rise in Oil Price
description: HOUSTON  The recent economic jolt to Japans economy, by lowering energy demand, has at least temporarily offset some of the Libyan uprisings impact on oil prices. But experts say there are limits to how long that buffering effect might last.

title: As Police Protest in Cairo, Fire Engulfs Interior Ministry Building
description: CAIRO  Flames engulfed the upper floors of a building in Egypts Interior Ministry compound on Tuesday, after a protest by thousands of police officers demanding higher wages and the resignation of the newly installed interior minister. It was the second time in a month that a police protest at the ministry ended with the building ablaze.

title: A Creative Strategy for Finding the Perfect Home
description: My husband and I have been in the market to buy a home for months.

title: Kitchen Crew
description: London: Theres a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

title: Bernie, Dorothy and That Interior Voice
description: Some might call the pesky inner voice that nags us to do the right thing a conscience, others a guardian angel. In the language of Dave Frishberg, the great jazz songwriter, who is playing a rare engagement at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel with the singer Jessica Molaskey, it is the singular sense of self invoked in Listen Here, his final number in the show.

title: Turning In Your Child for Bullying
description: Many of you have surely seen the painful-to-watch video of Australian 16-year-old Casey Heynes body-slamming his 12-year-old classmate Ritchard Gale.

title: Back at Midcentury, When Broadway Knew Romance
description: A he-man and an all-American gal, a baritone and a soprano: to watch Nathan Gunn and Kelli OHara interact vocally and dramatically in Broadways Classic Hits, the New York Philharmonic program at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, was to encounter the ultimate embodiment of the romantic myth that sustained the Broadway musical during its golden years.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Egypt, Japan, and England.

title: You Say You Want a Revolution  Well, You Know
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  As a revolutionary spirit blossoms through much of the Middle East, many in Pakistan are also dreaming of a revolution.

title: Panel Chief: F.D.A. Could Still Ban Menthol
description: Dr. Jonathan M. Samet, the chairman of a federal advisory panel on tobacco whose report last Friday sent menthol cigarette stock prices soaring, says the investor enthusiasm may be premature.

title: Judge Rejects Googles Deal to Digitize Books
description: Googles ambition to create the worlds largest digital library and bookstore has run into the reality of a 300-year-old legal concept: copyright.

title: Israeli Attack on Gaza Militants Kills 4 Civilians
description: GAZA  An Israeli attempt to hit Palestinian militants who had fired rockets at Israel went horribly wrong on Tuesday, with mortar shells killing three youths playing soccer and a 60-year-old grandfather leaving his house.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Egypt, Japan and England.

title: Veggie Burgers of Note Around Manhattan
description: Here are a few veggie burgers of note around Manhattan, in approximate descending order of preference.

title: Photo Replay: March 23
description: The day in sports included muscles in India and a bare-it-all tribute to Ivica Kostelic by his fellow Croats for his World Cup overall Alpine skiing title.

title: Triangle Fire: The Building Survives
description: The onetime Asch Building, whose top three floors were occupied by the Triangle Waist Company, is now the Brown Building of Science, where New York University students and scientists occupy laboratories devoted to biology and chemistry. The only hint of its role in one of Americas worst  and most indelible  industrial disasters can be found on two street-level bronze plaques on its facade, one put up by the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Going Backward
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics issued a new policy statement Monday, advising that toddlers remain in rear-facing car seats until they are at least 2 years old  and preferably longer. This is because, as Madonna Behen reports in The Times, children under 2 are 75 percent less likely to suffer severe or fatal injuries in a crash if they are facing the rear.

title: Cuomo Says Budget Wont Include Rent Laws or Property Tax Cap
description: ALBANY  Five days after he said he wanted to include the extension of rent regulation laws in the state budget, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Tuesday that the issue turned out to be too complicated and was not likely to be part of a budget deal after all.

title: Chicago Bulls: Championship Favorites
description: The Chicago Bulls are, without a doubt, championship contenders. Any claim to the contrary is ignorant of the information available, either willingly or otherwise.

title: Injured Spider-Man Actor Undergoes DNA Testing
description: Its not as transformative as something Norman Osborn might try, but add DNA testing to the measures being taken to speed the recovery of Christopher Tierney, the actor who was hurt when he fell during a December performance of Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.

title: The Aflac Duck Will Quack Again
description: Aflac is on the hunt for the new voice of its beloved duck, after the actor Gilbert Gottfried was fired from the job for making insensitive remarks about Japan on Twitter this month.

title: Amartya Sen on Growth and Well-Being
description: While reporting my column this week, I exchanged e-mails with the development economists Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee. They pointed out that one of the central arguments in Charles Kennys book  the relationship between economic growth and better living standards is complicated  was also at the heart of the work for which Amartya Sen won the Nobel Prize. (And Mr. Kennys cites Mr. Sen in the book.)

title: High on the Hog | Miru Kims The Pig That Therefore I Am
description: At first glance, the photographs in Miru Kims new show, The Pig That Therefore I Am, opening this Thursday at the Doosan Gallery in New York, seem like abstract studies of female skin. But as your eye moves to take in the big picture, you are surprised and perhaps a bit horrified to discover that most of the flesh in these intimate compositions is not human. A nude female (the 30-year-old artist herself) lies in filth with hundreds of caged hogs in industrial farms. The impulse is to recoil in disgust, but you are easily drawn back by the stillness, the almost transcendental quality of the images.

title: $12 Million Gift for Concert Hall in California
description: The financier Sanford I. Weill and his wife, Joan, have given a $12 million gift to Sonoma State University  the largest cash gift in the universitys history  for the completion of a concert hall at the Green Music Center, the university announced on Tuesday. The opening is scheduled for fall 2012.

title: Super-Frog
description: Theres this story in Haruki Murakamis after the quake (according to Jay Rubin, the books translator, Murakami insisted that the title be lowercase) called Super-Frog Saves Tokyo. The book is a collection of short stories about the psychic aftershocks of the 95 Kobe earthquake. (Heres a fascinating conversation between Murakami and Jonathan Lethem, plus audio of Murakami reading Super-Frog.) Five of the six stories are more or less straight-up realism, but Super-Frog is from the land of Kafka. A slightly overwhelmed and depressive banker named Katagiri comes home one day to find a huge Dostoyevsky-quoting frog in his house. The frog tells Katagiri that he needs his help defeating the monstrous Worm thats raging beneath the streets of Tokyo. (Worm, by the way, is a version of the catfish of Japanese mythology, which my colleague Harvey Dickson wrote about.)

title: Japan Festival Continues, Despite Sadness and Anxiety
description: With Japan still much in the news, the spring installment of Carnegie Halls citywide festival of Japanese culture, JapanNYC, took center stage on Monday evening, with a concert by the NHK Symphony Orchestra in the Stern Auditorium at Carnegie. In addition to the recent devastating earthquake in Japan and its aftermath, another melancholy note had sounded beforehand.

title: Brown Says Planned Parenthood Cuts Go Too Far
description: In a signal that Senate Republicans will not be automatically aligning with their brethren in the House over the course of a vast and raucous spending debate, Senator Scott Brown of Massachusetts said on Tuesday that he did not support eliminating federal financing of Planned Parenthood, a move approved by the House last month as part of a larger spending bill.

title: Excerpt: 'Ghetto Klown'
description: John Leguizamo in a scene from his new one-man Broadway show. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Come Back, Veggie Burger. All Is Forgiven.
description: I got a call yesterday morning from David Wilson, the general manager of Quorn in the United States. Quorn is a British enterprise that has been moving into the American market with a line of meatless products that approximate the taste of meat but are, in fact, developed from a mycoprotein that comes from Fusarium venenatum, which was originally discovered growing in a field in Buckinghamshire, England, as I learned from the Quorn Web site.

title: The Search for Ingredients to Replicate Silicon Valley
description: Harry Campbell

title: Libya Vs. Iraq
description: For the top 10 ways Libya is not like Iraq, see this post at InformedComment, the blog on Mideast affairs kept by a University of Michigan professor named Juan Cole. No. 6: No false allegations were made against the Qaddafi regime ofbeing in league with Al Qaeda or of having a nuclear-weapons program.

title: Craft Service
description: London: Theres a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

title: Snacking in Koreatown
description: THERES a wonder of things to eat in Koreatown: marinated bulgogi, milky beef-bone soup, sizzling bibimbap. But, with the banchan, the tableside grilling, and the communal grazing, dining here can be a commitment.

title: Koreatown: Where to Eat
description: In this weeks $25 and Under column, Betsy Andrews chose to graze along the main drag of Manhattans busiest Korean neighborhood, looking for places to snack. But for years, Times reviewers have found good places to sit down and enjoy a meal in Koreatown. There are plenty of others that arent listed here. Do you have a favorite? (Or are you not so crazy about some of these?)

title: Another Spider-Man Actress Injured
description: The actress who plays the villainess Arachne in Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark will be out of the show for the next two weeks after sustaining an injury during an onstage battle scene, the productions spokesman said on Tuesday.

title: A Militarily Tough iPhone Case  Sort Of
description: You have to be one serious klutz to need the Ballistic HC iPhone case. This chunky Humvee of a case encloses the iPhone in a hard shell that includes a clear screen cover, which is then wrapped in a silicon bumper, which is then inserted into a hard holster.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: California Judge Calls Time Out for Climate Change Law
description: Irony usually speaks for itself, so Ill tread lightly here. But what is one to make of a climate-change law that withstands a $35 million campaign supported by conservative oil interests only to be thrown off course by a legal challenge from the leftier edges of the environmental movement, particularly its environmental justice wing?

title: Dining Calendar
description: Young Chefs

title: Mozilla Releases New Version of Firefox Browser
description: Mozilla, the maker of Firefox, released the latest version of its free and open source Web browser to the public on Tuesday.

title: Celebrating Phagwah in Queens
description: A festival held by the Indian Caribbean community in Richmond Hill, Queens, greets spring with a parade, pageant, colored dyes and good food.

title: Staten Island Museum Breaks Ground on New Home
description: Wednesday, March 23, 2:09 p.m. | Updated The Staten Island Museum on Wednesday broke ground on its new $25 million home in Building A, a landmark on the campus of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center.

title: Hollywood Faces High Prices but No Tape Shortage Yet
description: First came the tips: Because of the earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan earlier this month, Hollywood movie and television studios are facing a dire shortage of master tape, a crucial piece of equipment for television and movie production. Hoarding, price-gouging, a crisis, one studio worker told us.

title: Diplomas and Uncertainty for Japanese Pupils
description: KESENNUMA, Japan  Schools here begin class in April and hold graduation ceremonies in March; like spring, they represent renewal and rebirth.

title: Rebuilding Lives and American Ties to Japan
description: ON BOARD THE RONALD REAGAN  When United States Navy helicopters swept down on the school in a ruined Japanese village, survivors first looked hesitantly from the windows. Then they rushed out, helping unload food, water and clothes. They clasped hands with the Americans. Some embraced them.

title: Animals DNA Helps Catch Their Abusers
description: Scruffys DNA was harvested in 2008 from a sample of burnt tissue found in the Brooklyn apartment where teenagers doused him with lighter fluid and set him aflame. Madeas was found on the plastic guard of the umbrella that her owners son-in-law used to fatally club her in 2009.

title: In Tokyo Shops, Grasping Local Links to Devastated Areas
description: TOKYO  In a metropolis as large as this one, it is easy to get lost, both literally and emotionally. This is true even more so these days for the countless residents who hail from prefectures northeast of here that were shattered by a massive earthquake and tsunami nearly two weeks ago.

title: Melting-Pot Musical With One Foot in Comedy, One in Tragedy
description: For those who love nothing better than unearthing lost musical gems, A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is a dangerous temptation. This classic story of a soulful, alcoholic husband who dreams of making it big as a singer is blessed with a lovely score by Arthur Schwartz and Dorothy Fields from the golden age of Broadway.

title: Eat, Pray, Smear
description: ON Sunday, Julie Ji got up early at her home in Richmond Hill, Queens, to make cook-up rice. The day began bright and quiet as she washed black-eyed peas and sliced mackerel for the dish, with no hint of the wild party to come.

title: At the Track, Before the Starting Gate and After the Finish
description: NEW ORLEANS  Martin Brown started writing a book in 1975 and has been looking for an ending ever since.

title: Yogurt to Start the Morning or End the Day
description: Hammond Dairy in Amenia, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley, specializes in yogurt that can go from breakfast to dessert. Its unhomogenized whole milk yogurt with a gentle flavor, even though its made with five kinds of active cultures. In addition to the delicious plain, which can enhance a bowl of granola in the morning, there is a richer vanilla, and three fruit flavors: strawberry, raspberry and peach, all made with local fruit (not Hammonds own). For that dessert there is chocolate, best enjoyed by inverting the contents into a dish so the chocolate sauce, which is on the bottom, becomes a sundaelike topping for what amounts to a panna cotta for health nuts. You can serve the fruit yogurts this way, too.

title: Chipotle Vodka, More From Mexico Than Moscow
description: Several years ago Lance Winters, the head distiller for Hangar One in California, concocted a limited batch of chipotle vodka by infusing fresh, dried and smoked chilies. The demand outpaced supply. Finally, he has been able to triple the production, and the vodka is now being sold across the country. In addition to japaleos and chipotles (smoked jalapeos), he also uses habaneros for heat, and bell peppers for vegetal richness. The result, 80 proof, has a pale straw color, peppery complexity, haunting smoke and an almost tequilalike greenness to the flavor, making it a spirit to savor on the rocks, to mix in a bloody mary or margarita or to season ceviche.

title: The Warm Glow of Copper Pots, Made in Brooklyn
description: Untilthe mid-70s, high-quality copper cookware was made in Brooklyn, by Bruno Waldrow. When he shut down no one in Brooklyn, and quite possibly the United States,was making classic copper pots.

title: Tsunami Alters Sushi Markets
description: SEAFOOD supplies in northern Japan were devastated by the tsunami that destroyed the regions fishing fleets and aquaculture farms as well as the ports themselves. The Japanese daily Asahi Shimbun reported on Tuesday that fishermen in the area are living in shelters, transportation to the famous Tsukiji market in Tokyo is not possible, and there is no ice to keep fish fresh.

title: Jonathan Waxman: Food Inspired by Italy, but All His Own
description: JONATHAN WAXMAN wasnt trying to channel Frank Sinatra with the title of his new cookbook, Italian, My Way (Simon & Schuster, $32).

title: Gnocchi With Spring Vegetables and Basil
description: Adapted from Italian, My Way, Jonathan Waxman (Simon & Schuster, 2011)

title: Revisiting Favorite Budget Destinations
description: Of all the jobs in the world, travel writer may the least conducive to telecommuting. At the very least, its in a four-way tie with coal miner, waiter and circus clown.

title: Polls Finds Bipartisan Support for Libya Campaign
description: Half of the public approves of President Obamas handling of the situation in Libya and two-thirds support the American-led strikes by air and sea against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces, according to the latest nationwide CBS News poll.

title: Despite Vacancies, Office Developers Bet on Miami
description: MIAMI  Bucking a trend that has curtailed development in other cities, the downtown Miami skyline has two shiny new office towers, its first since 2004, and will soon have a third. More office space was added in Miami last year  1.3 million square feet  than in any other American city except Washington, which grew by 2.5 million square feet.

title: BASF Joins Pipeline Project Led by Gazprom
description: BERLIN  Wintershall, the energy subsidiary of the chemicals giant BASF, has agreed to join Russia in building the South Stream natural gas pipeline. It will become the first German company to join a project that will compete directly with the European Unions planned pipeline, Nabucco.

title: Creating Plays, but Holding On to the Day Job
Mexican? American? Call Her Writer
description: IN reviewing the ebullient play Kita y Fernanda in 2008, a Chicago critic called its young author, Tanya Saracho, the Chicana Chekhov for her deft blend of comedy and drama. Its hardly surprising, then, that the vehicle that brings Ms. Saracho to the Goodman Theater in Chicago this week is her loose adaptation of Chekhovs Cherry Orchard, titled El Nogalar, which she sets against the bloody backdrop of Mexicos drug wars.

title: A Staged Accident, Caught on Video
description: Their first attempt at deliberately ramming their vehicles into one another on a Bronx street last summer did not sufficiently damage the cars. So the suspects  nine of them spread out in three vehicles  tried again, this time backing into each other in what the authorities say was a criminal version of demolition derby.

title: Exiles Lawyer Questions Tapes in Perjury Trial
description: EL PASO  A defense lawyer raised questions Tuesday about tape recordings that have become a key piece of evidence in the perjury trial of a militant Cuban exile here, asking a former contract journalist for The New York Times about why there is a four-minute gap on one tape, why better recordings were not made and why the original recordings were not better protected.

title: Modest Methods, Big Ambitions
description: New Directors/New Films, a cinematic rite of spring in Manhattan, stakes its claim and its name on a forthright promise of novelty. Here are a bunch of movies  28 features in this years edition, which starts on Wednesday and runs through April 4 at Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art  that we have not seen before, from filmmakers whose names are not yet household words.

title: Whats He Doing in Center Field?
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  For the first time since the World Baseball Classic in 2009, Jason Bay played center field on Tuesday. Bay was shifted there to replace Angel Pagan, who had minor stiffness in his back caused by the two-hour bus ride here from Port St. Lucie, he said.

title: 40 Years of New
description: A look back at some of the directors and films included in the 40-year history of the New Directors/New Films series.

title: Obama to Head Home a Bit Early
description: 8:50 p.m. | Updated  President Obama will return to Washington from his five-day Latin American trip a couple of hours earlier than originally planned on Wednesday, just as the coalition military campaign in Libya shifts to its next phase.

title: 4 Times Journalists Held Captive in Libya Faced Days of Brutality
description: As the four of us headed toward the eastern gate of Ajdabiya, the front line of a desperate rebel stand against the advancing forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a car pulled up alongside.

title: Nuclear Power Loses Support in New Poll
description: What had been growing acceptance of nuclear power in the United States has eroded sharply in the wake of the nuclear crisis in Japan, with support for building nuclear power plants dropping slightly lower than it was immediately after the accident at the Three Mile Island plant in 1979, according to a CBS News poll released on Tuesday evening.

title: Through the Looking Glass of History
description: I cant say I wanted to be like everybody else  I simply was like everybody else, completely satisfied with my beautiful Soviet reality, says Lyuba Meyerson, a public school teacher in her 40s, recalling her childhood in Robin Hessmans enthralling documentary My Perestroika.

title: Louis Dreyfus Highbridge in $1.95 Billion Energy Sale
description: Louis Dreyfus Highbridge Energy on Tuesday said that it had agreed to sell a pipeline and natural-gas liquids storage and processing plants for $1.95 billion in cash.

title: Audra McDonald Looking Likely for Porgy and Bess
description: Audra McDonald, the four-time Tony Award winner, has signaled that she is on board to play Bess in a newly conceived musical version of the opera Porgy and Bess that the American Repertory Theater plans to mount in September, according to a Playbill.com report on Tuesday evening.

title: You Might Die Tonight
description: The photographers Tyler Hicks and Lynsey Addario have collaborated with their colleagues Stephen Farrell and Anthony Shadid in a firsthand account of their days in captivity: Uncertainty and Cruelty Followed Times Journalists Held in Libya.

title: TimesCast | Allies Debate Leadership
description: March 22, 2011  Steven Erlanger reports on disputes between France and other nations over who should take charge of operations in Libya.

title: Libya Crisis Thrusts U.S. Africa Command Into Leadership Role
description: WASHINGTON  When the United States Africa Command was created four years ago, it was the militarys first smart power command. It has no assigned troops and no headquarters in Africa itself, and one of its two top deputies is a seasoned American diplomat.

title: David Nevin, Author of Historical Novels, Dies at 83
description: David Nevin, an author of historical novels, including the best-seller Dream West, the epic tale of John Charles Frmonts role in the opening of the American West, died on Friday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 83.

title: Appropriations Chief Spends Less and Cuts More
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Harold Rogers toiled on the House Appropriations Committee for 28 years, using the plum assignment to ship tens of millions of federal dollars back home for projects in his rural Kentucky district.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,494 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Thoroughbred Foundation Loses Financing for Care Evaluations
description: The Thoroughbred Retirement Foundations primary benefactor said if the group wants to continue evaluating its herd of more than 1,000 horses, it must do so with its own money. The foundations board fired the veterinarian Stacey Huntington on Saturday, claiming she had not been objective.

title: Congress Unhappy With Obama on Libya
description: They came in trickles but they came steadily and across party lines throughout Monday and Tuesday  complaints from members of Congress that President Obama had done too little consulting with them about United State military actions in Libya.

title: Oil Spill in South Atlantic Threatens Endangered Penguins
description: A major spill of heavy crude oil from a wrecked freighter has coated an estimated 20,000 endangered penguins on a remote South Atlantic island chain, the local authorities and environmental groups said Tuesday.

title: New York Rabbi Known as Innovator Is Picked to Lead Reform Jews
description: Reform Judaism, facing a recent decline in numbers and an uncertain future despite its stature as the largest movement in American Jewry, announced on Tuesday that its next president would be a rabbi known for rejuvenating his suburban New York congregation.

title: Nikolai Andrianov, Gymnastics Icon, Dies at 58
description: Nikolai Andrianov, the record-setting Russian gymnast who had won more Olympic medals than any other male athlete before the swimmer Michael Phelps passed him, died Monday in Vladimir, Russia. He was 58.

title: How to Prepare for the Next Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Returns Young Girl, a Citizen, to Guatemala
description: Leonel Ruiz, a landscaper in Brentwood, N.Y., was waiting at Kennedy International Airport on the early morning of March 11 for his 4-year-old daughter, Emily, to arrive home from a trip to Guatemala. The plane arrived hours late, but Emily was not on it, and neither was her grandfather, who was supposed to be escorting her back.

title: A War in Libya, and a Range of Voices Back Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Airstrikes on Tripoli Continue
description: Explosions rocked Tripoli on Tuesday in a fourth day of airstrikes, but forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi showed no signs of ending their sieges of rebel-held cities.

title: Justices Back Employee in Wage Complaint Case
description: WASHINGTON  Workers who complain to their employers about wage violations are protected from retaliation whether the complaints are oral or written, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday in a 6-to-2 decision.

title: Clash on Conservative Budget Could Spur Canadian Election
description: OTTAWA  Canadas Conservative government appeared destined for certain defeat after all three opposition parties said that they would not support its budget after its release Tuesday.

title: Soldier Is Expected to Plead Guilty in Afghan Killings Case
description: SEATTLE  One of five Army soldiers accused of killing three Afghan civilians for sport near Kandahar last year is expected to plead guilty and agree to testify against other defendants at a court-martial hearing set to begin Wednesday, according to one of his lawyers and documents in the case.

title: Food: Six Things to Feel Good About
description: The great American writer, thinker and farmer Wendell Berry recently said, You cant be a critic by simply being a griper . . . One has also to . . . search out the examples of good work.

title: More Pain for Airlines, but This Time Carriers Are Ready
description: The airlines cant catch a break this year.

title: Britain: Student Visas Restricted
description: Home Secretary Theresa May announced restrictions on student visas on Tuesday after the government expressed concern that they provided an easy route into Britain for those seeking to sidestep stringent immigration controls. Immigration by students has more than tripled in 10 years, and Ms. May blamed bogus schools for allowing in underqualified students.

title: France: Concert Hall Gutted in Fire
description: An early-morning fire gutted the historic lyse Montmartre concert hall in Paris on Tuesday, French officials said. The central stage was untouched, but the second floor partially collapsed, according to news reports. Police said they suspected that the fire was caused by faulty wiring. The hall opened in 1807. Toulouse-Lautrec is reported to have painted several works there, and it is said to have been the birthplace of the cancan. It is a part of Pariss identity that has been struck, said Mayor Bertrand Delano, who pledged that it would be rebuilt. No one was hurt in the fire, the authorities said.

title: After Bronx Bus Accident, a Call for Better Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Stanfords Coach VanDerveer Preaches the Joy of Victory
description: STANFORD, Calif.  She assigns her players extra homework, makes them perform endless repetitions and sees mirth and mastery as congenitally joined. So is Tara VanDerveer, the Stanford womens basketball coach, a Tiger mother?

title: China: Officials Deny Google Claim
description: The Chinese government on Tuesday denied Googles claim that it has interfered with the companys Gmail service. Google began receiving complaints from Gmail users and its employees in China about a month ago, about the time that anonymous Internet posts called for antigovernment protests, and on Sunday, the company blamed the Chinese government for disrupting the service.

title: Children and Social Media
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Rules Against Zicam Maker
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Tuesday that investors suing a drug company for securities fraud may rely on its failure to disclose scattered reports of adverse affects from an over-the-counter cold remedy that fell short of statistical significance.

title: N.F.L. Moves Kickoffs to the 35
description: Love the thrill of a long kickoff return by Devin Hester?

title: In Mixed-Race Marriages, a Challenge to Intolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Freight Railroads
description: To the Editor:

title: A Steep Discount for Apollo I.P.O.
description: Apollo Global Management is heading into life as a publicly traded firm at a steep discount to its larger rivals the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Too steep.

title: Glenn Beck Contemplates Starting Own Channel
description: The possibility that Glenn Beck will exit the Fox News Channel at the end of the year has prompted a big question in media circles: if he leaves, how will he bring his considerable audience with him?

title: What Will Blankfein Say at Galleon Trial?
description: 9:22 a.m. | Updated

title: Sara Ruddick Dies at 76; Pondered the Nature of Mothering
description: Sara Ruddick, whose 1989 book, Maternal Thinking: Toward a Politics of Peace, laid the groundwork for a feminist approach to understanding and analyzing the practices and intellectual disciplines involved in rearing children, died on March 20 at her home in Manhattan. She was 76.

title: Going Viral With Celebrity Pitchmen
description: IN an Audi commercial that had its premier during the Super Bowl, Kenny G, the saxophone player, made a self-deprecating appearance as a prison riot suppressor whose performing instantly put unruly inmates to sleep.

title: Knicks Keep Looking for Answers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks are on the wrong side of a list of worrisome numbers. They blew a 15-point lead and lost to the Boston Celtics on Monday, their sixth defeat in seven games, and fell to .500 for the first time in more than a month.

title: Marines Face Questions About Rescue of Officers in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  An American pilot and a weapons officer were safely rescued in Libya on Tuesday after their warplane crashed near Benghazi, but the United States Marine Corps dropped two 500-pound bombs during the recovery and faced questions about whether Marines had fired on villagers.

title: Head-Scratching Plays Dominate the N.C.A.A.
description: When Butlers Shelvin Mack made what he called the dumbest mistake of my life against Pittsburgh, it was merely the second-silliest thing a player did in the course of six-tenths of a second.

title: Judge Is Critical of Cuts in Aid for New Jersey Schools
description: New Jerseys cuts in school financing violate the State Constitutions mandate to provide a thorough and efficient education system and hit poor districts especially hard, a judge reported to the State Supreme Court on Tuesday.

title: Detroit Census Confirms a Desertion Like No Other
description: Laying bare the countrys most startling example of modern urban collapse, census data on Tuesday showed that Detroits population had plunged by 25 percent over the last decade. It was dramatic testimony to the crumbling industrial base of the Midwest, black flight to the suburbs and the tenuous future of what was once a thriving metropolis.

title: Frank Neuhauser, a Spellers Speller, Dies at 97
description: The word was gladiolus, and though he was only 11, the boy knew it cold. As luck would have it, he grew the flower in his garden back home in Louisville, Ky.

title: Obama Calls for an Economic Cure for Illegal Immigration
description: SAN SALVADOR  President Obama ended his three-nation Latin American tour on Tuesday with a visit to El Salvador, a source of one of the largest immigrant groups in the United States, and agreed with its president that the best strategy for curbing illegal immigration was to create economic growth in the region.

title: Government Lays Out Case Against Bonds
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal prosecutor opened the governments case against Barry Bonds on Tuesday by calling Bondss assertion that he did not know he was taking performance-enhancing drugs an utterly ridiculous and unbelievable story.

title: Bronx Man Charged in Strangulation of His Wife
description: A 38-year-old Bronx man was charged on Tuesday with killing his wife, whose body was discovered last week by two young brothers riding all-terrain vehicles in a wooded area of Westchester County, the authorities said.

title: Along 5th Ave. in Manhattan, a Dispute Over Where East and West Begin
description: Fifth Avenue, the glittering central spine of Manhattan, is the undisputed divider of the citys famous street grid: east of Fifth is East, and west of Fifth is West. Been that way since 1838.

title: The Right to Sue Over Wiretapping
description: Federal authorities have always made it difficult to bring a legal challenge against the governments warrantless wiretapping enterprise that was set up by the Bush administration in the years after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Because the wiretaps were secret, no one could know for certain if they were being tapped, so the government urged judges to throw out lawsuits for lack of proof of real harm.

title: Natural Gas and Clean Water
description: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar told a House subcommittee recently that a drilling technique known as hydraulic fracturing could be the Achilles heel that kills the natural gas industry. Like many others, Mr. Salazar sees natural gas, which America has in great abundance, as cleaner and more climate-friendly than coal or oil and a useful transition to alternative fuels. But he also fears, as we do, that public support for drilling will diminish unless the industry and its state and federal regulators do a better job of making sure the gas does no harm to drinking water.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 22, 2011

title: Fatal Confusion in a Nassau Town
description: So many police officers, retired or working patrol, live in and around Massapequa Park, N.Y., it is something of a Cop Land. They listen to scanners, swap crime stories and remember how it once was.

title: Legal Game of Keep-Away Counters the Mets Owners
description: Karen Wagner, a lawyer for the owners of the Mets, was insistent.

title: Libel Tourism, R.I.P.?
description: The British government is, at last, moving to reform the countrys notorious libel law, which has long made London a magnet for frivolous lawsuits. The reform proposal presented to Parliament last week by Kenneth Clarke, the justice secretary, is far from perfect but represents a reasonable first effort to change a law regarded as so unfair that it has been condemned by the United Nations. Last summer, President Obama signed a bill blocking enforcement of British libel judgments in American courts.

title: Arab Revolts Force Diplomats to Remake Lives and Careers
description: WASHINGTON  The maids who once swept the white marble floors at the Libyan ambassadors residence here have gone home to the Philippines, their visas expired now that their boss, Ali Suleiman Aujali, has quit his job. The driver is gone, too. Pretty soon, Mr. Aujali figures, the State Department will repossess the official license plates on the shiny black Mercedes and Audi parked in his garage.

title: Tucson Suspect to Transfer for a Competency Exam
description: The first federal prison dedicated to providing treatment for physically and mentally ill federal inmates  originally known as the United States Hospital for Defective Delinquents  has brought a number of infamous visitors to Springfield, Mo., over the years.

title: Suits Dispute Citys Rule on Recording Sex Changes
description: Two transgender New Yorkers say that their birth certificates incorrectly identify their sex, subjecting them to awkward and humiliating public moments. So they are suing the city to change a requirement that transgender people have genital surgery to get their sex changed  corrected, as they say  on their birth certificates.

title: A Nucleated Century
description: If you asked someone to draw an atom, he or she would probably draw something like a cockeyed solar system. The sun  the nucleus  is at the center, and the planets  the electrons  orbit in several different planes.

title: BlackBerry to Match Apple on the Price of Its Tablet
description: OTTAWA  Research In Motion challenged Apple on Tuesday by announcing that its BlackBerry PlayBook would be sold at the same price as the iPad 2.

title: At the Witness Stand, Two Parallel Paths Diverge
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: California: Scientist Accused of Bias
description: An Interior Department report released Tuesday found that a scientist at Point Reyes National Seashore committed misconduct by misusing photographic evidence that appeared to contradict her contention that an oyster farms operations disturbed harbor seals. This misconduct arose from incomplete and biased evaluation of the evidence, wrote Gavin Frost, an attorney-adviser in the solicitor generals office. The identities of the two, Sarah Allen, and her superiors  including Jon Jarvis, director of the National Park System, were obtained independently by The New York Times and other news organizations. Mr. Frost said that despite misconduct the two had not violated any law. The Drakes Bay Oyster Company has a lease to operate in the Point Reyes park until next year. The Park Service is reviewing what effects a lease extension might have on the environment.

title: CNN Leads in Cable News as MSNBC Loses Ground
description: CNN has been the big ratings gainer among the cable news networks during the extensive coverage of events in Japan and Libya in the last two weeks, and that success has come mostly at the expense of MSNBC, which has fallen into third place almost across the board because of CNNs surge.

title: One Play Is Enough for the Rangers
description: The Rangers had a hard time Tuesday night against a Florida Panthers team with a world-class goalie but little hope for the playoffs.

title: Howard Stern Sues Sirius XM Radio, Saying It Reneged on Stock Awards
description: Howard Stern and his agent have sued Sirius XM Radio, claiming the satellite radio company has failed to pay him stock awards tied to subscriber growth.

title: Parents of Rutgers Student in Suicide Say No Harsh Penalty Is Needed
description: The parents of Tyler Clementi, the Rutgers University student whose suicide last fall focused national attention on bullying, say in a statement that they are not interested in harsh punishment for Mr. Clementis former roommate, who was accused of secretly streaming video of a romantic encounter between Mr. Clementi and another man.

title: Monuments to Clan Life Are Losing Their Appeal
description: YONGDING, China  The gargantuan buildings are so iconic that they appear on a Chinese stamp. The most famous have distinctive round shapes, appearing from a distance like flying saucers that have plopped down in the middle of farm fields. Some were reportedly mistaken for missile silos by American officials poring over satellite images.

title: Triangle Fire: One Woman Who Changed the Rules
description: For much of her life, Rita Margules knew practically nothing about how her mother, Clara Lemlich Shavelson, had changed the world a century ago. It never came up, Ms. Margules said. My mother was not one to say, Oh, you know what I did as a young girl?

title: For Cuomo and Indian Point, New Round in a Long Fight
description: ALBANY  Two months after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Andrew M. Cuomo signed a petition urging that the Indian Point nuclear power complex in Westchester County be shut down for safety reasons.

title: Mets Thole to Put Catching Education to the Test
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Josh Thole has played baseball in front of 45,000 people and hit baseballs in some menacing places, including hostile stadiums in Philadelphia and in Caracas, Venezuela. But even more intimidating were the days when he stood nervously in front of more than a dozen of his peers in a side room in a minor league clubhouse and attempted to facilitate a meeting.

title: A Queens Guy Toughs It Out in Hollywood
description: At 46, an age when many men are tempted to flee the treadmill and hoist the white flag in the battle against middle-age spread, John Leguizamo still appears to have the energy of a 12-year-old who has just downed a Red Bull and a jumbo package of Twinkies.

title: Questions of Depth Haunt Knicks
description: As the Knicks crashed and burned last week, fans got a crash course in Carmelo Studies, each defeat a tutorial on one star players worst potential traits.

title: Idle Land Finds a Purpose as Farms for Solar Power
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Since the economic downturn, residents and businesses have been looking for ways to use real estate that may no longer appeal to mall developers or home builders. One option is to build solar energy farms, where thousands of solar panels convert the suns energy into electricity.

title: Fight of the Valkyries
description: WASHINGTON

title: Tribes With Flags
description: David Kirkpatrick, the Cairo bureau chief for The Times, wrote an article fromLibya on Monday that posed the key question, not only about Libya but about all the new revolutions brewing in the Arab world: The question has hovered over the Libyan uprising from the moment the first tank commander defected to join his cousins protesting in the streets of Benghazi: Is the battle for Libya the clash of a brutal dictator against a democratic opposition, or is it fundamentally a tribal civil war?

title: Strained Oblique Sidelines Granderson
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  The Yankees are bracing for the possibility that Curtis Granderson, their starting center fielder, will not be available for the March 31 opener after straining his right oblique muscle Tuesday during batting practice. Manager Joe Girardi said that no tests had been scheduled, but that he did not expect to know the extent of the injury until Wednesday.

title: In China, Remnants of a Way of Life
description: The tulou, largely earthen structures that often rise to four floors and sometimes include hundreds of rooms, are an iconic presence in parts of China, but few young people still live in them.

title: Mayor Counters Teachers Ads With His Own
description: After being pilloried for weeks in advertisements from the citys teachers union accusing him of threatening to fire teachers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg hit back on Tuesday by using a familiar tactic: paying for his own campaign-style advertisement.

title: Settling the Afghan War
description: DESPITE the American-led counterinsurgency in Afghanistan, the Taliban resistance endures. It is not realistic to think it can be eradicated. Efforts by the Afghan government, the United States and their allies to win over insurgents and co-opt Taliban leaders into joining the Kabul regime are unlikely to end the conflict.

title: Defense Puts UConn on Track to a Rout
description: Drey Mingo, a junior forward for the Purdue womens basketball team, took a pass and banked in a shot from short range just before halftime. Boilermakers fans behind the bench cheered. Purdue had lifted its field-goal percentage all the way up to 20 percent.

title: Six Protesters Killed in Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  At least six people were killed early Wednesday when Syrian security forces attacked protesters who had taken refuge in a mosque in the center of the southern city of Daraa, Reuters reported.

title: Putrid Past, and a Still-Distant Future as Fields of Play
description: The Department of Sanitations pipe and drum corps, dressed in green kilts and white boots, performed Tuesday in a parking lot that used to be the center of the worlds largest landfill.

title: High Jumper Vlasic to Compete in New York
description: The Croatian high jumper Blanka Vlasic, track and fields athlete of the year in 2010, will compete at the Adidas Grand Prix on June 11 at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island, organizers said. Also competing will be Tyson Gay, the American record-holder in the 100 meters; Jeremy Wariner, an Olympic gold medalist in the 400; and the Briton Jessica Ennis, the world heptathlon champion.

title: Wednesday: It May Have a Square in the Middle
description: Administrivial Puzzle Access Update:  If you continue to have trouble accessing the puzzle, I am told that the correct e-mail address for contacting customer support specific to puzzle issues is premium@nytimes.com.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Police Apologize in Person for Cyclists Ticket in Park
description: David Regen was sitting down to dinner Tuesday night when two police officers appeared at his home under circumstances that will instantly evoke envy from any New Yorker who has ever been issued a ticket.

title: In the Shadow of Disaster, Celebrating Students
description: In Kesennuma, Japan, graduation ceremonies were held for the sixth and ninth grade classes.

title: Word of the Day | penance
description: penance \pe-nn(t)s\ noun

title: How Sports May Focus the Brain
description: Who can cross a busy road better, a varsity wrestler or a psychology major? That question, which seems to beg for a punch line, actually provided the motivation for an unusual and rather beguiling new experiment in which student athletes were pitted against regular collegians in a test of traffic-dodging skill. The results were revelatory.

title: Think Like a Doctor (The Contest)
description: Mar. 24 Update |  Thanks for all your diagnosis submissions! To find the answer to the medical mystery, see Think Like a Doctor (The Winner).

title: Shares Gain as Metal Prices Lift Commodity Producers
description: Stock prices rose on Wednesday as shares of commodity producers pulled the broader market higher despite dismal housing sales and a failure by Bank of America to secure approval to raise its dividend.

title: News Quiz | March 23, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Death Toll Rises in Japan
description: On Tuesday, the Japanese government raised the official death toll from the tsunami and earthquake to 9,079, and said more than 12,600 were missing.

title: Anxiety Up as Tokyo Issues Warning on Its Tap Water
description: TOKYO  Radioactive iodine detected in Tokyos water supply prompted Japanese authorities on Wednesday to warn that infants in Tokyo and surrounding areas should not be given tap water to drink, adding to the anxiety about public safety posed by Japans unfolding nuclear crisis.

title: E-Textbooks Get a Lift From Publishers
description: Over the years, publishers have tried a variety of strategies to sell digital textbooks but with limited success. Most students continue to buy print books despite the inconvenience of having to lug them around in their backpacks.

description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article So Far Rivals Cant Beat iPads Price.

title: Rights Group Accuses Ugandan Police of Torture and Killings
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The Ugandan government has engaged in torture, illegal detention and extrajudicial killings of its citizens, according to a report released on Wednesday.

title: Do You Use Twitter?
description: Twitter celebrated its fifth birthday on Monday and said it now handles a billion messages every eight days, according to a Bits blog post. Do you use Twitter? If so, how? If not, why not?

title: Allies Pressure Qaddafi Forces Around Rebel Cities
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and its allies shifted on Wednesday to ferocious airstrikes on Libyan ground forces, tanks and artillery, marking the second phase of a military campaign that drew the Pentagon deeper into the fight.

title: Sanofi Raising $7 Billion in Debt to Fund Genzyme Deal
description: The French pharmaceutical giant Sanofi-Aventis said on Wednesday that it was issuing $7 billion worth of notes to help finance its acquisition of the American biotechnology firm Genzyme, which it agreed to last month.

title: What Price a Formula One Pedigree? Jenson Buttons Ferrari to Be Auctioned
description: Making room for a McLaren MP4-12C?

title: Vaclav Havels New Role: Film Director
description: Playwright. Dissident. President. Vaclav Havel has held many titles over the last five decades. He can now add one more to the list: film director. Leaving, his directorial debut, hits Prague movie theaters tomorrow. It may not be his swan song, but Mr. Havel, 74, has long hinted that this could very well be among the last of his public projects.

title: Fantasy Focus: Ranking the Closers
description: Last week we talked about the concept of properly pricing closers, particularly those that we suspect will post poorer earned run averages and ratio numbers compared with their competition. One suggestion I received from a reader was to have a separate set of rankings just for the projected closers of each team. While I think its important to realize that some of the top setup men will be worth more than the worst closers, I understand the desire to have one list of just those closers.

title: How Oil Wealth Undercuts Democracy in Libya
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Wrestle Mania
description: Its a feel-good story, and for one very obvious reason: Anthony Robles, a single-legged wrestler from Arizona State University, became the national champion in the 125-pound weight class. In numerous print and television interviews, Robles has proved to be an inspirational figure, someone who changes the perceptions of what it means to have a physical disability.

title: Boehner, McConnell Push Assault on Health Care Law
description: 8:58 a.m. | Updated A year after President Obama signed his health care law into effect, the two leading Republicans in Congress are making it clear that they do not intend to let up in their assault on the historic measure.

description: GAZA  Palestinian militants fired rockets far into southern Israel late Tuesday and early Wednesday and Israel responded with airstrikes in Gaza.

description: For all of President Obamas talk about the economy during the 2008 campaign, the issue that gave him a crucial early opening against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was the war in Iraq.

description: One year after President Obama signed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act into law, the public remains confused about the legislation, divided on its passage and unconvinced that it will improve health care.

title: Eight Fallacies of Entrepreneurship
description: People start businesses for all kinds of reasons. Other people dont start businesses for all kinds of reasons. Sometimes they are the very same reasons. I have compiled a list of frequently used phrases and comments that I often hear when people are discussing this decision and that I think reflect serious misunderstandings. At best, these misunderstandings can lead to a waste of time. At worst, they can lead to very bad decisions and very big losses. Here are my top eight:

title: Protesters Are Killed in Syrian Crackdown

title: Sun Ra: Mr. Honecker, Tear Down This Wall
description: I have some odd interests. Two are the Sun Ra Arkestra (the legendary jazz commune/band) and East Germany (the former country). I was reminded that these two interests once intersected by the Ra blog Adventure-Equation last weekend. In trying to sort out the bands (often label-less) records and tapes that were sold at its shows, the blog mentioned a 1986 performance that was also broadcast, unedited, on East German TV in 1988, as two 45-minute shows. That merry band of space pranksters? Broadcast to the East Germans before the Berlin Wall opened? Hilarious! (This clip may be from the same East German concert, to judge from the banner at the back of the stage.)

title: Off the Wall | Paul Smith for Maharam Digital Projects
description: Maharam Digital Projects  the mural-scaled wallpaper collection from the forward-thinking textile company Maharam  includes work by designers like Marian Bantjes, and artists like James Welling and Marilyn Minter. The fashion icon Paul Smith, who has designed fabrics for Maharam, has also contributed wallpapers. These have tended toward the abstract, but Smiths latest, Stamp World Map, is a richly detailed collage of letters and stamps from what he calls his amazing mailbag, adding that I love the emphasis and character you can put into handwriting. People around the world write to Smith, and he answers them all, although he has no idea how to reply to the anonymous American whose fan mail includes actual objects  like a surfboard or a bright pink plastic mannequin  that arrive at Smiths London studio unboxed and covered with stamps. With the correct postage, of course. Available at Moroso, 146 Greene Street.

title: Rangers Young Defensemen Valuable in Playoff March
description: The game was packed with as many thrills as this years Academy Awards, but the Rangers grind-it-out, 1-0 victory over Florida Tuesday was a showcase of the teams unheralded and young defense. As they have for most of this season, the defensemen stood outby not making any glaring errors in their own zone.
