title: Germany Steps Away From European Unity
description: PARIS  Driven by electoral pressures and Germanys postwar aversion to war and nuclear power, Chancellor Angela Merkel has deeply strained relations with allies in the European Union and the NATO alliance, raising new questions about Germanys ability to play a global role in foreign policy, even as its economic power and influence grow.

title: Plate of Shrimp (Synchronicity III)
description: Id hesitate to call it synchronicity  since I dont really know what synchronicity is. (Most of what I know of Carl Jungs theories, I must admit, came to me in the early 80s* when I was a huge Police fan.) But I had an eerie little moment on the train in to work that might qualify. I was reading David Mitchells strange and wonderful Cloud Atlas  a novel whose shifting ground may, in fact, have something to do with the expression of a deeper order. (Im only a hundred pages in, so dont tell me anything.) One character is a Nobel-winning scientist, Rufus Sixsmith, who is involved in a cover-up about an unsafe nuclear power plant about to go online outside Los Angeles. In this passage, he is hiding out at a motel, watching a fawning news report about the new $50 million HYDRA Zero reactor:

title: Jerusalem Blast Raises Fears of Growing Violence
description: JERUSALEM  A bomb exploded at a crowded bus stop near Jerusalems main bus station on Wednesday, killing one woman and wounding at least 24 other people. It was the worst attack in Jerusalem in four years, putting Israelis on alert, shattering years of relative calm here and prompting international condemnation.

title: The (Nature of) Shock Doctrine
description: Just a thought on market movements: you often see news stories confidently asserting that factor X was responsible for any given market movement. Serious observers rightly make fun of such stories; after all, how do they know? And it goes beyond funny to downright harmful when the stories assert supposed facts that actually serve some policy agenda. Lately weve seen that with regard to interest rates: again and again, upticks in US interest rates are asserted to be the result of debt fears, as evidence that the bond vigilantes have arrived.

title: A Liberal Plan for Social Security
description: Writing today on the op-ed page of The Washington Post, Robert Pozen makes the case that liberals should support changes to Social Security. Mr. Pozen is a Democrat, though not necessarily a liberal one; he is a financial executive who served on President George W. Bushs Social Security commission and in Mitt Romneys administration in Massachusetts. But his argument is worth considering, whether youre liberal or conservative.

title: R.I.P., Elizabeth Taylor (1932-2011)
description: Elizabeth Taylor, who died of congestive heart failure today at 79, was synonymous with jewelry and fragrance. (She famously owned the Cartier and Krupp diamonds, and made a fortune from her various lifestyle perfume concerns.) But Elizabeth Taylor Hilton Wilding Todd Fisher Burton Burton Warner Fortensky was also the embodiment of modern celebrity glamour. Whether being snapped by the ever-present paparazzi or lighting up the screen in her turban-wearing turn as the divinely decadent Sissy Goforth in Boom!, she more than looked the part. A lot has been written about the exotic allure she exuded as Cleopatra in 1963, but we have a soft spot for the carnal outfits she wore in her Oscar-winning performance as the call girl Gloria Wandrous in Butterfield 8, pictured. What was your favorite Liz Taylor look? Leave your suggestions in the comments below.

title: Plane Tickets: Buy Early or Wait?
description: BUYING an airline ticket is always something of a gamble  prices go up and down, and trying to figure out how far in advance to book to get the best fare can be tricky. Recent world events have been causing oil prices  a major factor in ticket prices  to fluctuate, making the calculation of when to buy even more challenging. Earlier this month, the price of a barrel of oil, which had skyrocketed to as high as $104 in response to events in Libya and the Middle East, dropped below $100 a barrel when disaster hit Japan.

title: Simple Rules for Better Sleep
description: This sounds way too good to be true: a quick, effective solution to the insomnia that plagues an estimated 15 to 30 percent of older adults  without drugs, without even needing to consult a physician.

title: Owned
description: Theres a pro football team in Washington whose name rhymes  sort of  with wineskins. Its probably best to refer to it this way for now, because the team recently cracked down and made The Washington Post drop the real name from the title of one of its blogs. The rationale seems to be that some other entity, in this case the paper, might be making some unauthorized money by appropriating a brand that belongs to someone else, in this case the teams owner, Daniel Snyder. No doubt he has the right to do so, but does that mean hes right to do so? Is it a smart business decision? Youd think that such vigorous policing of a brands use in a case like this would threaten to make the brand less appealing to the fans who make that brand valuable in the first place. Apparently not. Snyder has a history of antagonisms  start here, then check out his current lawsuit against The Washington City Paper  and still his is the fourth-most valuable sports team in the world.

title: Leading Off: The N.C.A.A. Antidote for Everything
description: Its reasonable to ask at this time of year why the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament is so loved. There are a lot of reasons not to love it: the preening coaches, many of whom make more than Exxon executives, the recruiting shenanigans, the N.C.A.A.s self-righteousness as it defends the honor of the student-athletes while making gobs of money off them.

title: Out With Winter
description: How to explain to a child the vexing, seemingly unending misery that is March? By this time of year, children have had enough books about snowmen and snowballs. Theyve passed through the brief red-hued respite of Valentines Day books  only to end up back in the throes of bitter cold weather.

title: Welfare Worker and Supervisor Charged in Death of Child
description: A former New York City child welfare worker and his supervisor were indicted on charges of criminally negligent homicide, the Brooklyn district attorney announced on Wednesday, saying that their failures had contributed to the death of a 4-year-old, Marchella Pierce, who had been repeatedly beaten and tied to a bed and weighed 18 pounds at the end of her life in September.

title: BlinkyTM
description: On slashfilm.com on Monday, I was intrigued by an article on the short BlinkyTM, which turns out to be a supercreepy little number by the Irish director Ruairi Robinson, who was nominated for an Oscar in 2002 for the short animated film Fifty Percent Grey. In this new film, young Alex Neville (played by Max Records of Where the Wild Things Are), neglected by his constantly arguing parents, sees an ad for Blinky, a home help robot, on TV and asks for it as a Christmas gift. This is officially the best Christmas ever, the boy declares. But the robot cannot be a substitute for his parents attention without dire consequences, and soon after there are.

title: Platini Could Be the Big Winner in FIFAs Election
description: FIFA will hold its presidential election in June, and there are two major candidates (and at least one very minor hopeful). The leading candidate, Sepp Blatter, had held the job since 1998. His rival, Mohammed bin Hammam of Qatar, helped him get it but now thinks he can do it better.

title: Elizabeth Taylor, Guinea Pig for Modern Celebrity
description: Much has been said/will be said/is currently being said about the death of Elizabeth Taylor, an icon who, at the relatively young age of 79, managed a seven-decade film career, yet may be best remembered by everyone under roughly 50 as a kind of guinea pig for the ravages of modern celebrity.

description: WACO, Tex.  When Baylors Melissa Jones dived for a loose basketball on Feb. 27, it did not seem risky for a hard-nosed guard who played football in junior high, had gone skydiving and once acted on a dare by drinking a cup of hot sauce.

description: LONDON  Britains chancellor of the Exchequer presented a budget Wednesday that veered little from the governments commitment to sharp and controversial cuts in public spending, despite new signs of slowing growth.

title: Taking Over a Jumbo Screen, but Little Reaction From Below
description: A 50-foot high image of Adi Isakovics dog, Cookie, appeared on a jumbo screen in Times Square several minutes after 8 p.m. last night. Cookie sniffed around for a bit, then Mr. Isakovic pressed a button on his phone and the screen switched to a video of his wife, Tania, on vacation in Maui.

title: Miranda Cosgrove, the American Tween Idol
description: A backstage concert pass for the star of the hugely popular iCarly.

title: The Good Girl, Miranda Cosgrove
description: On Veterans Day at Mary Fay Pendleton elementary school on the Camp Pendleton Marine Base, American flags lined the sidewalks. Bunting festooned the windows along with childrens crayoned drawings of tanks, fighter planes and soldiers shooting bullets or throwing grenades. Although the school was closed for the holiday, hundreds of kids and parents had gathered on a playing field to break ground for a new teaching garden. The program was sponsored by the American Heart Association and Kelly Meyer, the wife of the Universal Studios president, Ron Meyer. Which explained the improbable presence of Miranda Cosgrove, the 17-year-old star of the hit Nickelodeon show iCarly. A photographer stopped her as she walked toward a makeshift stage and asked her to plant a cabbage seedling, but a strand of her long, dark hair fell across her face, ruining his shot. Cosgroves smile never dimmed as she scooped up the plant and tried again. This time her hair stayed put. Perfect, said the photographer. And it was.

title: Robert De Niro to Get a Good Talking-To at Tribeca Festival
description: Jimmy Fallon recently demonstrated that it was possible to extricate a few unscripted words from Robert De Niro, at least within the context of a Late Night recreation of the game show Password. Next, Mr. Fallons NBC colleague Brian Williams will attempt to coax further spontaneous utterances out of Mr. De Niro, the soft-spoken screen actor and co-founder of the Tribeca Film Festival, at a one-on-one discussion that will be held as part of the festivals Tribeca Talks panel series, its organizers said on Wednesday. In addition to Mr. Williamss interview of Mr. De Niro, which will take place on April 23 at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, other announced events include a conversation between Doug Liman, the Bourne Identity director, and Alec Baldwin, the 30 Rock star; a discussion between the director Martin Scorsese and the Malian filmmaker Souleymane Ciss; and a 10th-anniversary screening of A Beautiful Mind that will be followed by a conversation with that films director, Ron Howard, producer Brian Grazer, and the screenwriter, Akiva Goldsman. The films math consultant, Dave Bayer, Sylvia Nasar, the author of the book A Beautiful Mind, and Brian Greene, the theoretical physicist and mathematician will also participate. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 20 to May 1, and more information about its screenings and events can be found at tribecafilm.com.

title: A Prairie Home Companion | A.P.C. Quilts
description: A.P.C. does not, as far as we know, stand for A Prairie (Home) Companion, but the 25-year-old brands latest edition of quilts has us wondering. The seven styles  made from 50 collections worth of unused tweed, wool, corduroy and printed cotton scrap fabric  are at once graphically modern and sentimentally nostalgic. My mother made me a log cabin quilt from leftover fabric that we were given while I was working at Kenzo, says the A.P.C. founder Jean Touitou. So, the idea came quite naturally. And while quilts are very of the moment  think Rodartes prairie-inspired collection for fall 2011  according to Touitou, these are pieces that are designed to last. Whats important is passing on culture, its like blues or cooking, he says. Perhaps it will fix some memories for people. Or simply theyll have a hell of a graceful piece of popular art where they live.

title: New Film Festival Has Focus on the Wild
description: A new movie event is aiming to bring the real jungle to the concrete one. Starting in April 2012, the New York Wild Film Festival will present a roster of movies and filmmaker panels in four categories: adventure, environmental, wildlife documentaries and shorts. Nancy Rosenthal, a former documentarian for National Geographic who is the festivals founder and director, said the goal was to inspire appreciation for the planet.

title: Severed From the World, Villagers Survive on Tight Bonds and To-Do Lists
description: HADENYA, Japan  The colossal wave that swept away this tiny fishing hamlet also washed out nearby bridges, phone lines and cellphone service, leaving survivors shivering and dazed and completely cut off at a hilltop community center.

title: Federal Lands in Wyoming Opened to Coal Mining
description: Federal land in Wyoming holding roughly 750 million tons of coal will be leased to mining companies, the Interior Department announced. The leases will generate $13.4 billion to $21.3 billion, with roughly half of the proceeds going to the State of Wyoming, according to federal estimates.

title: Mom Takes a Vacation
description: Does Mom deserve a vacation? Is it a dereliction of duties to head someplace sunny for a week and leave your husband and children behind? Assuming you could find the money, could you justify the time? Thats exactly what Lisa T. McElroy, an associate professor at the Drexel University Earle Mack School of Law, just did.

title: Trolling the Oceans to Combat Aging
description: FROM a marketing perspective, theres something alluring about being a beauty outsider. Just ask Allison Slater, the vice president for retail marketing at Sephora, about the new anti-aging skin care line Algenist  featuring a star ingredient, alguronic acid, that scientists in San Francisco say they stumbled upon while researching microalgae.

title: Panel on Anthrax Inquiry Finds Case Against Ivins Persuasive
description: WASHINGTON  A panel of psychiatrists who studied the medical records of Bruce E. Ivins said Wednesday that the F.B.I.s case that he mailed the anthrax letters in 2001 was persuasive, and that Dr. Ivinss history of mental problems should have disqualified him from working with dangerous pathogens.

title: The Game of Risk
description: Ian Frazier doesnt need me to help him sell his book Travels in Siberia. In fact, after reading an excerpt in The New Yorker, I thought: I get it; its long and cold. I dont need a whole book. But there it was at the Morningside Heights library. And I was hooked, especially when he reminded me of the importance of Kamchatka in the game Risk. Frazier, like me, apparently spent many high-school hours in someones basement in the 1970s, trying to dominate the world on the games map. Like me, he may have wondered why no girls ever wanted to play this fascinating board game with us.

title: A Decision to Hire a Sales Agent for Big Money
description: Prometheus Research was founded in 1999 when Leon Rozenblit, then a graduate student pursuing his Ph.D. in psychology at Yale University, began building customized data management tools for research scientists. The company, which is based in New Haven, now serves major research and academic institutions across the country. It has 40 employees and had revenue of about $4 million in 2010.

With less than 48 hours to prepare for Duke, Stevens flipped open his laptop.

title: Anadarko Buys BP Gas Plant as Sell-Off Continues
description: BP said Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its controlling stake in a Colorado natural gas plant to the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation for $575.5 million, as the energy giant continues on its path to divest assets worth $30 billion.

title: Swiping Is the Easy Part
description: The cellphone has been more than a cellphone for years, but soon it could take on an entirely new role  standing in for all of the credit and debit cards crammed into wallets.

title: Elizabeth Taylors Place in the Sun
description: Many moviegoers watched Elizabeth Taylor grow up on screen. She made her first film, Theres One Born Every Minute, at age 9 and became a child star after appearing in 1944s National Velvet. Ms. Taylor grew into a more mature artist in the 1950s and at age 19 starred with Montgomery Clift in George Stevenss 1951 drama A Place in the Sun, the second screen adaptation of Theodore Dreisers novel. The film features Mr. Clift as a factory worker who falls for a socialite (Ms. Taylor). This party scene shows the moment, as they dance together, that their romance blossoms.

title: Turning the Other Cheek. It Works.
description: When I do TV pundit shows, I am usually placed on the right facing the host so when I turn to speak with my more liberal partner, I end up exposing my right cheek to the camera. I never really thought about the significance of this. But in the journal Laterality: Assymetries of the Body, Brain & Cognition, Annukka Lindell and Nicola Savill point out that the face expresses emotion asymmetrically. The left cheek is more emotionally expressive whereas the right cheek is more passive.

title: Not a Bird or a Plane, but Home
description: Perched at the base of the Beskydy Mountains in the Czech Republic is a titanium-plated house in the fanciful shape of a bird with wings extended. The steel-and-glass structure in the picturesque northeastern region is the home of Pavel Horak, the chief executive of PPL, an express mail firm.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Algeria, Israel, Libya and Tunisia.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Soldier Gets 24 Years for Killing 3 Afghan Civilians
description: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash.  A soldier accused of killing Afghan civilians for sport was sentenced Wednesday to 24 years in prison after he pleaded guilty and agreed to testify against other defendants in the case.

title: An Unintended Sneak Peek at Albany Deal-Making
description: Policy Advice 2011 12 Executive Budget

title: Smile When You Call Her a Diva
description: KEISHER McLEOD-WELLS peered up at the empty patch of wall over the doorway of Gleasons Gym in Brooklyn, near the reception desk where she answers telephones five days a week when shes not training to be a super-flyweight champion.

title: House Hunting in ... Hong Kong
description: A TWO-BEDROOM TWO-BATH APARTMENT IN THE POKFULAM SECTION OF HONG KONG

title: Even More Brutally Candid Interviews About Breaking Up: The Book
description: If you enjoyed the magazines recent story, A Brutally Candid Oral History of Breaking Up (well, enjoyed might be the wrong word, given the articles dire take on romance; perhaps read with interest is more appropriate) youll be keen to know that the filmmaker Dana Adam Shapiro (Monogamy) just sold his book of interviews with divorced people to Scribner.

title: In Hong Kong, an Environmentally Friendly Apartment
description: A two-bedroom, two-bath apartment in this environmentally-friendly development is on the market for 18.6 million Hong Kong dollars, about $2.385 million. Its located in Pokfulam, a residential neighborhood near Hong Kongs central business district.

title: Homes for $1.1 million
description: A three-bedroom stone house in Haverford, Pa.; a midcentury building in Long Beach, Calif.; and a historic captains house on Cape Cod.

title: A Model Moment | Giovanna Battaglia
description: Giovanna Battaglia, a model turned stylist for LUomo Vogue and W, among others, has emerged as a street-style darling and blog favorite. Battaglia is in So Paulo this week to host the opening of the Carla Amorim boutique, and for the next three days she will walk us through her wardrobe choices.

title: S.I. Museum Breaks Ground for New Home
description: The Staten Island Museum broke ground on its new $25 million home on the campus of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Wednesday. Elizabeth Egbert, the president and chief executive of the 130-year-old museum, called the development the fulfillment of a dream 40 years in the making. Read the full article on ArtsBeat.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Kate Middletons see-through dress sells for $125,000 at auction. A proper thread count and we could have been looking at a cool half-million.

title: More Americans Dropping Out of the Labor Force
description: Ive written before about the very low share of Americans who are in the labor force right now. In February, for example, just 64.2 percent of adults were either in a job or actively looking for one, representing the lowest participation rate in 25 years.

title: What You Get for ... $1.1 Million
description: HAVERFORD, PA.

title: Teaching and Learning About Energy With The New York Times
description: Energy is a prominent topic in the news, both explicitly and implicitly, because of developments like a nuclear plant failing in Japan in the aftermath of the tsunami and a rise in United States gasoline prices  both with far-reaching implications.

title: As Tsunami Robbed Life, It Also Robs Rite of Death
description: HIGASHI-MATSUSHIMA, Japan  It was neither the place nor the time for a proper goodbye: not here, on a homely hilltop that used to house the city garbage incinerator. And not now, fully 12 days after a tsunami erased this towns seacoast and forever sundered hundreds of families and friendships.

title: Two Riffs on Street Wear Gone Fusion
description: THE Mishka store is a burst of bright underneath the J-M-Z tracks streaking off the Williamsburg Bridge. A life-size E.T. peers out over the unkempt block through a window trimmed with purple neon. Just inside is a Street Fighter II arcade game, rigged for free plays.

title: Maurizio Pollini Cancels United States Recital Tour
description: The pianist Maurizio Pollini has canceled a United States recital tour because of illness, Carnegie Hall said in a statement on Wednesday. Mr. Pollini was to have played at Carnegie on Sunday and on April 4. The pianist Jeremy Denk will perform in his place on Sunday; a substitute has yet to be named for the April 4 concert. Mr. Pollini also had stops in Princeton, N.J., and Chicago. He previously canceled appearances this month with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Boston and at Carnegie. A hall spokesman said he did not know the nature of Mr. Pollinis illness, and the pianists New York-based manager did not immediately return a phone call. Mr. Denk will play Charles Ivess Piano Sonata No. 2 ( Concord) and Bachs Goldberg Variations, which he performed just last month at Carnegies smaller Zankel Hall.

title: Democrats Defend Obama on Libya
description: Top Senate Democrats defended the administrations handling of the crisis in Libya on Wednesday and predicted that President Obama would win bipartisan backing for the military intervention there if it comes to a Congressional vote.

title: Whats a YouTube Pop Hit Worth?
description: In the age of YouTube, Pandora and Spotify, fans can watch millions of videos or listen to endless hours of music for free. But do those services make significant money for artists and record companies? Those questions became all the more interesting last week with Friday, a song by Rebecca Black, a 13-year-old amateur from California whose YouTube video became a viral sensation. With heavily Auto-Tuned vocals and lines like Tomorrow is Saturday/And Sunday comes afterwards, critics abhorred it. Yet it had racked up more than 38.5 million views by Wednesday afternoon, and the single was slowly climbing iTuness posted popularity charts.

title: German Chancellor Calls for Tests of Europes Nuclear Reactors
description: BRUSSELS  The German chancellor, Angela Merkel, is pushing for the European Union to conduct stress tests on all the nuclear reactors of its member countries in the wake of Japans calamity.

title: TimesCast | Jerusalem Explosion
description: March 23, 2011 - Ethan Bronner reports on the explosion near a bus stop in Jerusalem and the unrest between Palestinians and Israelis in the region.

title: U.S. Will Profit From A.I.G., Chief Says
description: Robert Benmosche, the chief executive of American International Group, tells CNBC that taxpayers will make $10 billion to $15 billion from the insurers bailout.

title: The Obama Press Pool in Brazil
description: Over at the Lens blog, the photography blog of The Times, Stephen Crowley, a Times staff photographer, has a personal video essay of his trip to Brazil with President Obama. Watch the video  filmed with a Flip camera  about press pool experience covering the president.

title: CBS Formula Works
description: CBSs Tuesday night block of procedurals lifted the network to No. 1 in the ratings, as NCIS delivered the largest audience in prime time with 19.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. NCIS: Los Angeles was close behind at 9 p.m. with 16.5 million viewers, while The Good Wife, at 10, delivered 11.6 million to win its time slot ahead of its network competitors. ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for second place over all, with ABC broadcasting a two-hour special, Best in Film: The Greatest Movies of Our Time (7.1 million). Fox ranked fourth with mostly repeats.

title: Tucson Girls Memorial Gets Piece of Trade Center
description: A memorial to the youngest victim of the shooting rampage in Tucson, a 9-year-old girl who was born on 9/11, will include a five-foot length of steel from the World Trade Center.A statue of an angel, which will incorporate the steel, will memorialize the girl, Christina-Taylor Green. It is to be erected in the outfield of her Little League softball field in a Tucson suburb.Workers at Kennedy Airports Hangar 17, where the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey stores debris from 9/11, removed a 272-pound beam on Wednesday; it is to be trucked to Arizona. Similar pieces have been sent to cities and towns and other countries for use in memorials.

title: The Timess Digital Subscription Plan
description: Paul Smurl, vice president for paid products at NYTimes.com, is answering readers questions this week about The Timess digital subscription plan, which is scheduled to begin globally on March 28. Under the plan, heavy users of NYTimes.com who do not receive home delivery of the printed paper will be able to read up to 20 articles a month free; further access to the sites content will come with purchase of a digital subscription.

title: Web Video and the Presidential Election
description: Megan Liberman and Brian Stelter discuss Tim Pawlenty's use of web video and what it means for the upcoming 2012 presidential campaign.

title: Gadgets You Should Get Rid Of (or Not)
description: The common rap against technology is that it leads to an accumulation of devices. But the nature of technology is changing. Fewer products are doing more tasks  all accomplished by countless lines of massless software code.

title: Culture Club
description: London: Theres a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

title: Council Votes to Rename Queensboro Bridge for Koch
description: Edward I. Koch is many things to many people: larger-than-life mayor, cantankerous commentator, amateur movie critic. Now he will be a bridge.

title: Voices of the High School Graduating Class of 2011
description: The Times Magazine has just published a fun, fascinating, interactive Web presentation featuring audio interviews with 18 high school seniors from a San Diego high school, who were asked what they imagine the next decade will have in store for them.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Algeria, Israel, Libya and Tunisia.

title: The Adams Family
description: When Charles Francis Adams reflected on history, people listened. He was, after all, more than just a representative from Massachusetts and the future ambassador to Britain. The son of John Quincy Adams and the grandson of John Adams, he brought to Washington a sense of historical perspective and gravitas often lacking in the rough-and-tumble world of national politics.

title: The Libyan Rabbit Hole
description: This administrations Libya policy has grown steadily more baffling with every day that weve spent at war. On the one hand, its clear that the Obama White House desires nothing more than to hand responsibility for this military operation over to France and Britain posthaste, and that the president has absolutely no intention of committing American ground forces to the shores of Tripoli. On the other hand, its also clear that it may well take more than an air bombardment to remove Qaddafis regime from power, which is the outcome that France is more or less explicitly pursuing, and that Britain and the United States are informally committed to as well. So where does this leave us? Adam Garfinkle minces no words:

title: Triangle Fire: A Frontier in Photojournalism
description: American Newspaper Repository Collection, Duke University (The World, New-York Tribune, The Chicago Sunday Tribune); The Forward Association; The New York TimesBy using the sliding control in the upper right corner or double-clicking on the newspaper image itself, readers can take a close look at how five newspapers covered the Triangle fire. Out-of-town newspapers, like The Chicago Tribune, did not have photographs in time for their Sunday issues.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic: On the Town With Teenagers
description: The mailbag brought questions about feeding high school students and an opera singer, a New Jersey bachelor party and an adventurous couple from Washington. I did my best to answer them. As always, keep sending me your dining out questions.

title: One Turbulent World Readied Her for Another
description: ON the evening of March 14 at the United Nations General Assembly, the Palestinian journalist Rula Jebreal welcomed a crowd of cultural luminaries that included Robert DeNiro, Dick Cavett and the designer Zac Posen to the United States premiere of Julian Schnabels film Miral  based on her autobiographical novel named for her teenage daughter and starring Freida Pinto.

title: What Gadgets Do You Want to Get Rid Of?
description: My article for Thursdays personal technology section is about gadgets that you can throw out because other devices have taken over their functions. An obvious example: You dont need an answering machine anymore because your phone company offers voice mail.

title: Three More Journalists Released in Libya
description: Joe Raedle of Getty Images and two colleagues from Agence France-Presse, the photographer Roberto Schmidt and the reporter Dave Clark, have been released in Tripoli, the agency announced on Wednesday. They were arrested on Saturday.

title: Shopping Picks for March 24
description: Steven Alan has a new line of striped tanks, T-shirts and dresses; for spring, Bottega Veneta offers a deconstructionist take on its leather Intrecciato hobo bag; and other items.

title: Ghetto Klown, Kin, Good People, Starcatcher  To Extend Their Runs
description: Several new shows on and off Broadway recently announced they are extending though the spring, and in one case, into the summer.

title: Austerity Debate Fells Portugals Premier
description: Another European government fell victim to the politics of austerity on Wednesday when the prime minister of Portugal resigned after opposition parties rejected his last-ditch attempt to push through a package of spending cuts and tax increases.

title: Rove Group Introduces Web Site Seeking Disclosures
description: Crossroads GPS, the group founded by Karl Rove to help finance conservative issues and election-year messages, on Wednesday introduced a Web site aimed at collecting the unfulfilled Freedom of Information requests made of President Obamas government.

title: PowerPoint With Few Bells, but Finally on the Go
description: As smartphones become the worlds go-to computing device, many business users are lagging, partly because of the phones limited ability to work with Microsoft Office documents.

title: Elizabeth Taylors New York
description: In the theatrical trailer for Butterfield 8, the deep-voiced announcer declared: Shes not like anyone. Thats for sure.

title: Asked and Answered | Jason Bell
description: Nothing makes New Yorkers melt quite like an English accent. On March 24, the New York outpost of the Jermyn Street mens-wear import Thomas Pink will celebrate the British photographer Jason Bells latest book, An Englishman in New York (Dewi Lewis Publishing), which captures his fellow Brits in their current New York digs. The Moment sipped some tea with Bell (and some of his subjects) to gain insight into the expat psyche.

title: Ishinomaki Journal: No Plans To Leave
description: Toshiyo Fujisaki, a restaurant owner, discusses life after the tsunami in Ishinomaki City, directly north of the Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant.

title: Police-Checkpoint Smartphone Apps Encourage D.U.I., Senators Argue
description: Driving under the influence? There are several apps for that  and several United States senators who are not pleased about it.

title: Merce Cunningham Dance at the Joyce
description: The company, which will cease of operations on December 31, performed at Joyce Theater on Tuesday.

title: When Properties Seem Priced to Spur a Bidding War
description: If youre in the market for a home, you may want to consider some advice from academics before sealing the deal. Research papers on the subject of negotiation offer numerous tips to help potential home buyers better navigate the home-buying process, as I recently learned when I wrote a paper for my business school negotiation class on the subject. This post is part of a series on some of the findings that I thought were worth sharing. These are my earlier posts: The True Value of a Home to a Seller, Keeping Your Top House Price to Yourself and Why to Know What a Home Seller Paid.

title: Lawyers for Sheen, Rebuffed, Still Look to Block Arbitration
description: The court fight between Charlie Sheen, Warner Brothers and the producer Chuck Lorre is on, for real.

title: Portable, but Not Puny, Speakers
description: You could argue about what makes a gadget delightful: Simplicity, sleek looks or cool materials. But one element doesnt get nearly enough press: magic.

title: Idiosyncratic Pairings on a Wide Playing Field
description: It says something about the increasingly boundary-free state of the music world that no one batted an eye when Tactus, a new-music student ensemble at the Manhattan School of Music, opened its Tuesday evening concert at the school with Cardiac Arrest, a song about the perils of overdrive by the 1980s British rock band Madness.

title: Too Much Information About Information?
description: Information seems to be everywhere these days, bombarding us via Twitter, Facebook and the Web, not to mention the creakier delivery systems of newspapers and other legacy media. It has even made it onto the best-seller list, thanks to the success of James Gleicks latest scientific door-stopper, The Information: A History, a Theory, a Flood.

title: In a Mass, a Cradle of Consolation for Japan
description: Hearing a good performance of Bachs Mass in B minor is always a privilege. But it was especially meaningful to hear the Bach Collegium Japans account of this astounding masterpiece on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: A Golden Age Continues Without Its Midas
description: When Merce Cunningham was alive, people walked out at most of his companys performances, sometimes in droves. Since his death in 2009, this still happens  on Saturday a very few left during an exceptionally exciting performance of Nearly Ninety2 at Purchase College  but the general mood has grown more reverential. Naturally so, since the company plans to cease operations altogether after Dec. 31. Did anyone depart during Tuesday evenings performance at the Joyce Theater? The theater still seemed full at the end. All three works were heartily cheered.

title: Here, Some Promising Young Dancers, There, Some Well-Seasoned Pros
description: The Youth America Grand Prix has completely revolutionized the world of dance, said Brian dArcy James, the host of the gala on Tuesday night celebrating this annual competition. That might be a slight exaggeration. What the competition  which drew more than 5,000 entries this year  has possibly done is emphasize and spread the idea that ballet is an American Idol kind of spectator sport. The dancer who jumps highest, turns fastest or splits legs into the most physically improbable position is the best.

title: Two Debuts at a Diner That Specializes in Donizettis Secret Sauce
description: It was hard to tell if David Lomel was laughing or crying at the warm, extended ovation that followed his big aria on Tuesday evening at the New York City Opera, but he certainly deserved all the applause and bravos. As the lovesick small-town bumpkin Nemorino in Donizettis classic, deliriously entertaining comedy The Elixir of Love, this 29-year-old tenor sang with sincerity and style and acted with energy in his New York stage debut.

title: Report on Oil Spill Pinpoints Failure of Blowout Preventer
description: HOUSTON  A buckled section of drill pipe caused the malfunction of supposedly fail-safe equipment when a BP well in the Gulf of Mexico blew out last April, killing 11 workers and spewing millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, according to a report released by the Interior Department on Wednesday.

title: The Man Whos Been Taking Trinidads Carnival on the Road
description: Machel Montano was a teenage calypso prodigy when he discovered something that would horrify any young person: He was so not cool.

title: Americas Superiority Complex
description: Aaron Carroll has a very good takedown of an op-ed article by Senator Ron Johnson, who basically exploits his infant daughters medical experience to make an incoherent attack on the Affordable Care Act. His daughter received excellent treatment, and he asserts that she wouldnt have received that kind of treatment under universal health insurance, because . well, he doesnt explain.

title: Star Power Meets Wars Firepower
description: How to turn the bloody truths of the Iraq war into mass entertainment is a problem that has repeatedly bedeviled Hollywood executives. Even The Hurt Locker, which won the Academy Award for best picture last year, earned only $17 million domestically. Now Broadway, where the price of a ticket can be 10 times as much as at the multiplex, is taking its first major look at Iraq eight years after the invasion, with a play that starts with a behanding, descends into brutality and murder, and features no less than Uday Hussein clutching the severed head of his brother, Qusay.

title: On Our Radar: Climate Questions Follow 2012 Presidential Contender
description: A video created by a Democratic state legislator in Minnesota captures Tim Pawlenty, the former Republican governor and a 2012 presidential candidate, repeatedly calling for a cap-and-trade program for carbon dioxide emissions to fight climate change. The video was aired during a hearing on a Republican bill to lift restrictions on coal-fired power plants. Mr. Pawlenty now describes his past support for cap-and-trade as stupid. [MinnPost]

title: 1911 Fire Proved Photojournalisms Power
description: Coverage of the Triangle Waist Company factory fire in 1911 by a corps of photojournalists  armed most likely with hand-held Press Graflex cameras  was one of the earliest such graphic, public, inescapable and almost instantaneous media assaults on genteel sensibility and certainly helped enshrine the tragedy. City Room takes a look at the newspapers that published the chilling pictures, in Triangle Fire: A Frontier in Photojournalism, part of its overall centennial presentation this week, The 1911 Triangle Fire.

title: War Plays
description: A look at recent plays about war that have been produced on and off Broadway.

title: Video: Tim Pawlentys Use of Web Video
Mommy Issues and 'Mildred Pierce'
description: Todd Haynes, the director and writer of the HBO miniseries Mildred Pierce, discussed the relationship at the heart of the drama.

title: Vivid Years on the Arm of a Kennedy
description: The tabloid press has already found its three hottest revelations from Come to the Edge, Christina Haags book about her five-year romance (1985-90) with John F. Kennedy Jr. They are as follows: On a tropical vacation they found Jamaican hospitality was impossible to refuse on that ganja-happy island. He showed her a book about tantric sex. And they shared a dangerous kayak adventure.

title: Lawrence Taylor Gives His Side After Sentencing
description: The former Giants star Lawrence Taylor was matter-of-fact Tuesday about his involvement with prostitutes. On Studio B with Shepard Smith on Fox News, he said that Im not saying its right but its the oldest profession in the world and that the only person he had to answer to was his wife.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Viral Marketing
description: That clever video of a Times Square billboard being hacked that you and thousands of other people passed around? It was an ad, designed to go viral. Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a Times media reporter who followed a small team as they created a video in Times Square. Edited to look authentically amateur, the video was actually a promotion for a movie and it got nearly a million views in just a few days. For advertisers, this kind of viral marketing is a new direction, Ms. Vega says.

title: Banking Reforms Without Leaders
description: The hour is upon American banking regulators. They have been handed 2,000-plus pages of new law in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act that must be transformed into workable rules and procedures and then put into effect to fulfill the legislations promise to make the financial system safer. But there is a problem: many of the watchdogs charged with the task face leadership vacuums. This could spell trouble.

title: Border Crossing
description: Most people keep their New Years resolutions simple: exercise, save money, volunteer. Mya Henry and Eric Werner took on something more challenging  they made a pact to leave New York and open a restaurant in Tulum, Mexico. Last December, after seven months of planning, building and traveling around the country in search of antiques, they opened Hartwood, which they describe as Mexican farmhouse rustic. Werner, who cooked at Peasant in Manhattan and Vinegar Hill House in Brooklyn, helms the kitchen, while Henry, who worked for the Soho Grand Hotel, runs the front of the house. Henry blames her navet for fueling their project. Ive never worked so hard in my life  despite being in this paradise. Go to interactive feature >>

title: Skins Ends Season on a Higher Ratings Note
description: The controversial series Skins on MTV, which ended its first season  and perhaps last  on Monday night, went out on a higher note.

title: Looking Back at Elizabeth Taylor
description: A. O. Scott reflects on the life and career of this star of the silver screen.

title: Bonds Trial Testimony Centers on Steroid Conversations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When the recording of a taped conversation began to play Wednesday at Barry Bondss perjury trial, the jurors could barely hear what was being said.

title: Gingrich Calls For No-Fly Zone, Then Attacks It
description: Newt Gingrich, the former Republican House speaker, was pretty clear on March 7: President Obama should establish a no-fly zone over Libya this evening, he said on Fox News. All we have to do is suppress his air force, which we could do in minutes, he said.

title: Balancing Debt Against College Choice
description: SHUTESBURY, Mass.

title: TimesCast | Qaddafi Arms Supporters
description: March 23, 2011 - David D. Kirkpatrick visited the town of Bani Walid, Libya, where Col. Qaddafi's supporters were armed with new Kalashnikov rifles.

title: Video: A. O. Scott Remembers Elizabeth Taylor
description: In this video, A. O. Scott looks back at the actress and the various roles she played both on and off screen.

title: At Mugler, Genius and Its Limits
description: ON the evening of March 2 in Paris, people were not quite ready to let go of their sentimental baggage regarding so-called genius talent. Too much self-questioning may have been involved, for one thing. Anyway, it was hard to get any perspective. That morning newspapers carried the story of John Gallianos dismissal from Dior. At 9:30 p.m., an audience of mostly journalists and fashion professionals gathered to see the Mugler show and its headliner, Lady Gaga.

title: Five Titles Are Settled as Nationals Wind Down
description: Five national titles were decided on Sunday, the last day of the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky. The Machlin Womens Swiss Teams resulted in a tie, which was very surprising given the fractions of victory points generated by the carryover formula into the final day. One teams was Geeske Joel of Palo Alto, Calif.; Tobi Sokolow of Austin, Tex.; Jill Levin of Henderson, Nev.; Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif.; Debbie Rosenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y. The other was Janice Seamon-Molson of Hollywood, Fla.; and Joyce Hampton of Blythewood, S.C.; Jenny Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla.; Sabine Auken from Denmark; Daniela von Arnim from Germany; and Bndicte Cronier and Sylvie Willard from France.

title: A Studied Cool: Street Style at SXSW
description: The rest of the year, fashion in Austin can be post-collegiate casual, but during SXSW, people turn it out.

title: Heirloom Seeds or Flinty Hybrids?
description: AS gardeners stock up on heirloom seeds for spring, Rob Johnston, the chairman of Johnnys Selected Seeds in Winslow, Me., would like to suggest an accessory. Why not buckle up in a 1936 Oldsmobile coupe?

title: Introducing a Special Section
description: We all have our issues. Sure, most of us spend a bit too much and save too little, no matter how old we are. We live for today without thinking enough about tomorrow. But many of the thorniest money issues are age-specific, whether its paying for a college education or figuring out what kind of allowance to give ourselves during the first years of retirement. If we could tackle these things when they first present themselves, they wouldnt become problems that last for decades.

title: Undecorate by Christiane Lemieux
description: The title of Christiane Lemieuxs book, which she wrote with Rumaan Alam, Undecorate ($40, Clarkson Potter), is a bit deceptive. While the 20 spaces shown may not be decorated in the traditional sense, they are very stylish.

title: Repairing a Long-Neglected Nest Egg
description: TUCSON

title: Returning Chestnut Trees to City Where Blight Was First Found
description: All Chestnut Trees Here Are Doomed read the headline in The New York Times.

title: Out of College, Not on Her Own
description: LOS ANGELES

title: New Problems at Japanese Plant Subdue Optimism
description: The Japanese electricians who bravely strung wires this week to all six reactor buildings at a stricken nuclear power plant succeeded despite waves of heat and blasts of radioactive steam.

title: A Homeowner With No Savings, but Some Options
description: GRASS VALLEY, Calif.

title: Mets Second-Base Race Has a Front-Runner
description: JUPITER, Fla.  With only seven games remaining in spring training, the Mets narrowed their search for a second baseman Wednesday when the long-shot candidate Justin Turner was demoted to the minor leagues and Brad Emaus was nudged ahead in the race.

title: TimesCast | Arab Leaders Unify on Libya
description: Michael Slackman talks with political analysts about the rare show of support from many Arab leaders for the Western-led military intervention in Libya.

title: Parting Glance: Michael L. Abramson, 62
description: The photographer Michael L. Abramson, whose pictures of nightlife on the South Side of Chicago bring to mind Brassas depiction of Paris, died Monday of kidney cancer. The announcement was made by the Numero Group, a Chicago music company that published his book Light: On the South Side.

title: Bus Driver in Bronx Crash Says He Was Sober and Awake
description: The tour-bus driver whose actions are being questioned in the crash that killed 15 passengers says he was sober, rested and fully awake at the time of the accident, his lawyers said Wednesday.

title: The Outback in Bloom
description: IT wasnt easy to tell which was campier, the show or the opening party.

title: Early 20th-Century Style
description: An aesthetic characterized by old, rustic, American objects, designed to be useful, but whose handsomeness is burnished by each passing year.

title: American Rustic
description: THE ballad of Kenyan Lewis and Grace Kelsey, were there a ballad of Kenyan and Grace, would be in part a song about stuff  old stuff, rustic stuff, American stuff, stuff that was designed, above all, to be useful, but whose handsomeness grows more burnished with each passing year. Prop designers and dealers by trade, the two are collectors of early 20th-century Americana, objects that date, roughly, from the end of the Victorian era through the machine age.

title: R&Y Augousti Opens American Showroom
description: Ria and Yiouri Augousti raised many eyebrows back in 1990 when they introduced a collection of home furnishings covered in exotic skins like shagreen and snakeskin. In the decades since, their company, the Paris-based R&Y Augousti, has gained quite a following, but it wasnt until two weeks ago that they opened their first American showroom, at the New York Design Center.

title: Shigeru Ban on Designing Shelters for the Quake Victims
description: The Japanese architect Shigeru Ban is known for his acts of modesty. For one thing, he likes to build with paper, a material that is surprisingly strong when rolled into logs. For another, while directing offices on three continents that turn out museums, factories and houses, he also routinely builds shelters for victims of natural and manmade disasters.

title: When Rockport Was My Own
The Letterpress Rug From Commune Design
description: Dont bother trying to find hidden messages in the Letterpress rug, one of three styles in a new collection from Commune Design. Theres no subliminal message, said Steven Johanknecht, one of the partners at this Los Angeles-based firm.

description: The 3:1 table ($2,200) challenges the idea that nesting tables need to be stackable. Instead, the three small, angular pieces that make up the 3:1 cluster together to form a cube.

description: SPRINGDALE, Ark.

description: THE official start of spring has some gardeners dreaming up grand plans for their outdoor spaces, while others  especially those who live in New York City  are limited to indoor or container gardening. Shane Powers belongs to the latter category.

title: California: Marriage Ban Stays in Place
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied a request on Wednesday to set aside a ban on same-sex marriage while the court considers its constitutionality. Plaintiffs challenging the ban  Proposition 8, approved by voters in 2008  had sought to vacate a stay in February, saying that denying gay couples the right to marry was causing grievous, humiliating and irreparable injury. In August, a federal district judge found that Proposition 8 discriminated against gay men and lesbians. That decision has been subject to a stay while the case works through its appeal in the Ninth Circuit.

description: The American and European coalition turned its firepower Wednesday on the military units loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that are besieging rebel-held cities in Libya.

title: Justices Grapple With Issue of Right to Lawyers in Child Support Cases
description: WASHINGTON  Members of the Supreme Court appeared frustrated Wednesday during an argument about whether poor people facing jail time for failing to pay child support are entitled to court-appointed lawyers. It seemed that there were procedural and practical problems with almost every potential ruling.

title: Yahoo Fine-Tunes Its Search Engine
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  Since Yahoo surrendered its search engine to Microsoft two years ago as part of a major overhaul of its business, it has been trying to innovate on top of Microsofts technology to keep people coming to its site.

title: Mural of Maines Workers Becomes Political Target
description: Clashes at state capitols over organized labor have become commonplace this year, with protesters throughout the country objecting to proposed limits on collective bargaining and cuts in benefits. Maines governor, Paul LePage, has opened a new  and unlikely  front in the battle between some lawmakers and unions: a 36-foot-wide mural in the states Department of Labor building in Augusta.

title: Proposal on Mortgages
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Feeling Free, but Still Without Work, Tunisians Look Toward Europe
description: ZARZIS, Tunisia  The revolution has changed much in this low-slung, whitewashed city on the Mediterranean coast. Residents no longer live in fear of the secret police, and speak openly of politics. Devout Muslims say they feel a new freedom to practice their faith. The red national flags that hang almost everywhere are no longer joined by the portrait of the ousted president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali.

title: Looking at the Whole Defendant
description: Even before she graduated from Stanford Law School in 2010, Michelle Parris knew she wanted to help people with psychiatric disabilities and take a holistic approach to defense law. She designed a project with that in mind and received a two-year Equal Justice Works fellowship and an assignment at the Bronx Defenders. Still in the early stages of her fellowship, which began in September, she already has a caseload of 40 clients facing issues like homelessness, lack of access to health care, addiction, deportation and the ultimate nemesis of her project, criminal recidivism. A native of Queens, Ms. Parris, 27, now lives in Midtown.

title: Once Rare in Rural America, Divorce Is Changing the Face of Its Families
description: SIOUX COUNTY, Iowa  In the 1970s, the divorce rate was so low in this rural northwest Iowa County that it resembled the rest of America in the 1910s. Most of its 28,000 residents were churchgoers, few of its women were in the work force, and divorce was simply not done.

title: Twitter Co-Founder Jack Dorsey Mulls a Return to Twitter
description: Jack Dorsey, Twitters co-founder, is talking with Twitter about returning to the company in a product leadership role, according to three sources briefed on the discussions.

title: Los Angeles County Moves to Fire 6 Sheriffs Deputies
description: LOS ANGELES  The Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department has moved to fire six deputies in connection with an assault on other deputies at a Christmas party last year.

title: UConns Calhoun Speaks His Mind
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  At the West regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament, the most entertaining interview did not come last. It came first. And it came from Jim Calhoun.Connecticuts coach since 1986, Calhoun remains as crusty and insightful as ever, particularly on a national stage. Here are some excerpts from his Wednesday news conference, which took place at the Honda Center:

title: For Coach Krzyzewski, Its 900 and Counting
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  After Duke secured career victory No. 900 for Coach Mike Krzyzewski last weekend, he took a moment to reflect. One. Then he boarded the team bus and watched the game that would decide his next N.C.A.A. tournament opponent.

title: Census Lessons for Detroit From Memphiss 1870s Loss
description: Detroits condition may look bleak. The news on Tuesday that the city had lost 25 percent of its population over the last decade  the highest percentage loss for any American city with more than 100,000 people  was grim indeed.

title: Ready or Not, Iraq Ascends to Take Helm of Arab Bloc
description: BAGHDAD  After Libya was suspended from the Arab League last month, de facto leadership ended up coincidentally in the hands of Iraq, the Arab nation with the most experience  much of it painful  with a foreign-led military campaign against an unpopular dictator.

title: An Alluring Beauty Exempt From Fashions Rules
description: She was short. She didnt have the greatest legs in the world for a sex symbol, which she wasnt anyway. She was overloaded with hair and bosom, a dreadnought of glamour rather than an elegant swan, and for that reason she did not fit as naturally on best-dressed lists as Audrey Hepburn or Grace Kelly did. But Elizabeth Taylors style told a great deal more.

title: Morgan Stanley Takes Backseat to Rival at Galleon Trial
description: It had to have stung Morgan Stanley, even in the courtroom, that it was second banana to archrival Goldman Sachs.

title: Bill Seeks to Expand Rights for New Yorks Immigrants
description: Three months after the defeat of the Dream Act, a Congressional bill that would have provided a path to legal residency for young illegal immigrants, a state senator from New York City has introduced his own version of the legislation in Albany.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,496 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Boehner Presses Obama on Libya Action
description: WASHINGTON  The House speaker, John A. Boehner, on Wednesday pressed President Obama to clarify what the administration hoped to achieve through military intervention in Libya, as top Senate Democrats defended the presidents handling of the crisis.

title: At Palmer Invitational, Woods Faces Golfs New Order
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  When Tiger Woods smashes one off the tee at Bay Hill on Thursday  gets every bit of the club face on the golf ball  chances are he will not be strutting out to the longest drive in the fairway. In fact, he may not be walking to the second longest.

title: Lust for Life: Movies, Men, Melodramas
description: The last movie star died Wednesday. By the time Elizabeth Taylor left this mortal coil at 79, she had cheated death with a long line of infirmities that had repeatedly put her in the hospital  and on front pages across the world  and in 1961 left her with a tracheotomy scar on a neck more accustomed to diamonds. The tracheotomy was the result of a bout with pneumonia that left her gasping for air and it returned her to the big, bountiful, hungry life that was one of her greatest roles. It was a minor incision (later, she had surgery to remove the scar), but its easy to think of it as some kind of war wound for a life lived so magnificently.

title: Central Americas Drug Problem
description: Aggressive crackdowns on criminal organizations in Mexico and Colombia has brought the drug scourge deeper into small Central American countries incapable of combating it.

title: Drug Wars Push Deeper Into Central America
description: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras  Josue Oviedo looked into his sisters fading eyes as she fought to speak her last words.

description: FOR American Idol, having more than five million followers on Facebook is encouraging, but there is something besides devotion the show wants from Facebook users: cash.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Now that a judge has curtailed Googles ambitions to create a giant digital bookstore and library, the company is left with few appealing options.

title: N.B.A. Scouting Report on Fredette: Good but Not Great
description: NEW ORLEANS  From conjuring up memories of Pete Maravich with his scoring binges to carrying Brigham Young to its first N.C.A.A. tournament Round of 16 since 1981, Jimmer Fredette has put together one of the most remarkable college basketball seasons of this generation.

title: It Could Happen Here

title: Discord Among Allies
description: Many people were taken aback when France emerged as one of the most pugnacious advocates of military action in Libya, especially Americans who were accustomed to French criticism over Iraq and French foot-dragging over Afghanistan. Without President Nicolas Sarkozys early and constant pressure for a United Nations-endorsed no-flight zone, military intervention might have come too late to save Benghazis people from the murderous threats of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: My Dog Days Are Over
description: I was in a rush that morning and so our walk was shorter than usual. As I brought Lee back inside our building and fed her and put water in her bowl and put her pills between two slices of salami, I told myself that her dog walker was coming in the afternoon and, in any case, the day before we had gone to Fort Greene Park and I had let her off her leash and she had scampered around.

title: We Were Kittens Once, and Young
description: All of our cats are dying.

title: Injured Granderson Doubtful for Opener
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Curtis Grandersons status for the March 31 opener remained in question Wednesday, the day after he injured his right internal oblique muscle taking batting practice. A magnetic resonance imaging exam confirmed a strain, and Granderson said he felt better but expected to learn Thursday or Friday when he can resume baseball-related activity.

title: States Pass Budget Pain to Cities
description: The state budget squeeze is fast becoming a city budget squeeze, as struggling states around the nation plan deep cuts in aid to cities and local governments that will almost certainly result in more service cuts, layoffs and local tax increases.

title: Feds Clash With Bank of America Raises Questions

title: Mets Value Declines, Forbes Says
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The true value of the Mets will be established once part of the team is sold, but in the meantime, one estimate suggests that their value decreased drastically over the past year, more than any other franchise in Major League Baseball.

title: U.S. Investors Place Record Wager on Japanese Funds
description: Some investors may be already shrugging off Japans crisis.

title: Japan Nuclear Crisis Revives Long U.S. Fight on Spent Fuel
description: WASHINGTON  The threat of the release of highly radioactive spent fuel at a Japanese nuclear plant has revived a debate in the United States about how to manage such waste and has led to new recriminations over a derailed plan for a national repository in Nevada.

description: The 36-foot-wide mural at the Maine Department of Labor building by Judy Taylor. Gov. Paul LePage is Gov. Paul LePage has demanded its removal.

description: Among common impressions of the current Supreme Court are that Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas are joined at the hip and that the majority tilts reflexively in favor of corporations and employers.

title: Less Than Needed on the Euro
description: By the end of this week, European Union leaders hope to endorse their most far-reaching proposals to address the 15-month-old euro-zone crisis that has already forced two countries into onerous bailouts and now threatens several more. Individually, many of the proposals have merit. But, as a whole, the package falls well short of a durable, long-term solution.

title: B.Y.U. and Big Easy: Just Basketball, Thanks
description: NEW ORLEANS  The awkward clash of cultures between Brigham Young and New Orleans is not lost on the B.Y.U. star guard Jimmer Fredette.

title: Real Family Values
description: President Obama came to the right conclusion last month when he decided that the Defense of Marriage Act, which denies federal spousal benefits to married same-sex couples, is unconstitutional, and ended the governments defense of the law in pending court cases. But that did not relieve Congress of its duty to renounce the bigotry behind the 1996 law and wipe it off the books.

title: Thursday: Wicked Women
description: Administrivial Chance To Be Heard Alert: There is now a place to submit questions about changes to the puzzle page and the digital subscriptions plan for The New York Times. Please click here to read Talk To The Times and use the link provided there to send an e-mail with your question to Paul Smurl, V.P. for paid products at NYTimes.com.

title: Duke Adjusts to Life With Irving
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski could not recall another recent season in which he employed quite so many lineup combinations. Most, if not all of the changes stemmed, Krzyzewski said Wednesday, from the prolonged absence of the freshman point guard Kyrie Irving.

title: Flying Above Emotions, Then Grounded by Trauma
description: Reed Birney is quickly becoming New Yorks foremost actor in a particular subspecialty, communicating the grief of average men facing extraordinary loss. Mr. Birneys performance in The Dream of the Burning Boy, an eloquent, affecting new play by the newcomer David West Read at the Roundabout Undergrounds Black Box Theater, is the third hes given this season Off Broadway, a feat in itself deserving of some sort of badge of honor, given the size of the paychecks.

title: William Stuntz
description: The Collapse of American Criminal Justice by William Stuntz, to be published this year, is the capstone to the career of one of the most influential legal scholars of the past generation. He died last week at 52.

description: Jane Rosenberg/ReutersLloyd C. Blankfein, rear, and Raj Rajaratnam, front, in a courtroom sketch.

title: A Digital Library Better Than Googles
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Rebel Insider Concedes Weaknesses in Libya
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  After the uprising, the rebels stumbled as they tried to organize. They did a poor job of defining themselves when Libyans and the outside world tried to figure out what they stood for. And now, as they try to defeat Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis armed forces and militias, they will have to rely on allied airstrikes and young men with guns because the army that rebel military leaders bragged about consists of only about 1,000 trained men.

title: Weakening Web of Tribal Support Softens Yemen Leaders Grip
description: SANA, Yemen  About 20 men were crammed into a corner of a large green tent at the protesters encampment here in the capital. Sitting on foam mattresses, they leaned on one another in a Yemeni sign of affinity, despite coming from two dueling tribes back in their home province.

title: Jerry West to Knicks Fans: Calm Down
description: The advice probably sounds strange coming from the N.B.A.s most famously stressed-out superstar. Jerry West  Lakers legend and Hall of Fame worrier  believes Knicks fans need to relax.

title: Control Tower Unresponsive to 2 Planes in Washington
description: Two passenger airliners landed at Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington without clearance or guidance from the airports control tower early Wednesday, and officials were looking into the possibility that the air traffic controller on duty had fallen asleep.

title: China: Court Upholds Death Penalty for 7 Convicted in Xinjiang Violence
description: The countrys highest court has upheld the death sentences of seven people in the far western region of Xinjiang who were convicted of murders and robberies aimed at raising money for a terrorist plot, state media reported Wednesday. Three others who had been sentenced to death were given a two-year reprieve, which often leads to life in prison. The attacks in Kashgar left nine people dead, the newspaper The Xinjiang Daily said. It did not cite the ethnicity of the defendants, but the names suggested that they were Uighurs, who make up a majority of Kashgars population. Calls to the Peoples Intermediate Court in Kashgar rang unanswered Wednesday; the Supreme Peoples Court typically does not release details of its rulings.

title: Imax to Open 75 New Theaters in China
description: LOS ANGELES  Imax has reached a deal valued at about $100 million to open 75 new theaters in China, a move that underscores the degree to which the movie exhibition business is surging there.

title: Ready for the Round of 16
description: On Thursday, the mad scramble that is the opening week of the N.C.A.A. tournament makes way for a more orderly Round of 16: eight games in two nights to whittle the field to eight teams. But dont be fooled. There is plenty of opportunity for the unexpected. While spunky underdogs often face up to the reality that they are out of their depth in this round, teams with bushels of talent can ill afford to be caught looking ahead.

title: Helen Stenborg, Actress From Theatrical Family, Dies at 86
description: Helen Stenborg, whose myriad roles on Broadway ranged from the comically loopy Sarita Myrtle, an aged pyromaniac, in Nol Cowards Waiting in the Wings to Rebecca Nurse, Arthur Millers personification of moral rectitude, in The Crucible, and who shared the acting life for more than half a century with her husband, Barnard Hughes, died at her home in Manhattan on Tuesday. She was 86.

title: Loleatta Holloway, Gospel and Disco Singer, Is Dead at 64
description: Loleatta Holloway, a gospel-charged disco singer whose 1980 hit Love Sensation had a long afterlife when fragments of it were used in later hits, died Monday in a suburban Chicago hospital. She was 64 and lived in Chicago.

title: Parks Dept. Disavows a Speed Limit for Bicycles
description: On Tuesday morning, police officers aimed a radar gun at West Drive in Central Park, hoping to catch bicyclists going too fast. Instead they exposed a city bureaucracy bungling the enforcement of one of the simplest of laws: the speed limit.

title: Hughes Shows Off His New Weapon
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Call it a slurve, a cutter, a slider  Phil Hughes does not care. The new pitch he unveiled Wednesday night generated several swings-and-misses and six of his seven strikeouts against Toronto. With additional refinement, Hughes said it could be an asset during the season.

title: In Japans Rubble, Fragments of Lives Past
description: The center of Minamisanriku, a fishing port on Japans northeastern coast, has disappeared. It was completely washed away by the tsunami that devastated the country on March 11. As I looked down from a hilltop while on assignment there last week, it was hard for me to imagine that a town had really existed, that people had had lives there.

title: Where Do You See Yourself in 10 Years?
description: The Times asked 18 high school seniors about their plans, and only one said he was undecided about his future. Others said they planned or aspired to pursue careers in psychology, medicine, photography and other fields. How about you? What are your goals? When you look into the future, where do you see yourself 10 years from now?

title: Where to Watch Oxford vs. Cambridge
description: For anyone looking to know more about rowing after watching the acclaimed Henley sequence from The Social Network, a good place to begin is the Xchanging Boat Race on the Thames River on Saturday. First held in 1829 and an annual event since 1856 (with the exception of the two World Wars), it pits the Oxford University Boat Club against the Cambridge University Boat Club. They compete on a four-and-a-quarter-mile course that follows the tidal stretch of the river that extends through central London to the open sea. Winners last year, Cambridge currently leads the series 80 to 75.

title: NATO Agrees to Take Command of No-Fly Zone in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  NATO will assume leadership from the United States of patrolling the skies over Libya but the military alliance remains divided over who will command aggressive coalition airstrikes on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis ground troops, NATO and American officials said Thursday.

title: Thousands March to Protest Syria Killings
description: Syrias repressive leadership came under unexpectedly heavy pressure on Thursday as thousands of angry demonstrators massed again in the southern city of Daraa, demanding democratic reform and protesting the deaths of more than a dozen people shot by security forces in the past week.

title: The Pinking of Preschool
description: The recent announcement that a mother and part-time family counselor in Santa Cruz, Calif., was starting an all-girls preschool called the Pink Academy (Its pink, its girly and its all about them!) has, as you may imagine, received quite a bit of opprobrium. I asked Peggy Orenstein, whose recent book, Cinderella Ate My Daughter, takes a hard look at the princess-industrial complex and the emphasis on the hyper-feminine, girlie-girl culture. Heres her response:

title: Ed Rendell Defends Philadelphia Fans
description: Ed Rendell, the former mayor of Philadelphia, defended the honor of Philadelphia fans on Wednesday after GQ magazine declared Eagles and Phillies supporters the worst fans in the United States.  In this case, worst means meanest, and Rendell, writing in The Philadelphia Daily News, accused GQ of laziness in leaning on stereotypes:

title: Triangle Fire: New Leaders Emerge
description: Most of the victims were unglorified, but the Triangle fire a century ago propelled other individuals to greater prominence. Among them were Frances Perkins, Alfred E. Smith, Robert F. Wagner, Rose Schneiderman, Anne Morgan and Max D. Steuer.

title: Lies During Wartime
description: As an infantry sergeant during World War II, I wrote about 100 letters to wives and parents of soldiers in my unit who died in action. No matter if they died by friendly fire or cowering in their holes, in my letters they were all killed while heroically charging the enemy. One was killed by a French farmer for raping his daughter. To his parents, he, too, died a hero. Today such lies would not be tolerated. Did I do wrong? NAME WITHHELD

title: Community College vs. Student Loan Debt
description: One of the articles in our special section on Money Through the Ages (produced in partnership with the public radio program Marketplace Money) is about an 18-year-old high school senior with a choice to make. Should he go into at least $6,500 in debt each year to attend a private college or university like Juniata or Clark, or is he better off working part time and attending community college for two years before transferring to one of those colleges?

title: A Park, an Oyster Farm and Science
description: The question at the core of the seven-year-old feud in Californias Marin County is whether an oyster farm at Point Reyes National Seashore should be allowed to continue operations after 2012. The controversy, centering on the management of an area designated as potential wilderness, remains unresolved. Both sides are putting forth their best arguments for a continuing environmental impact review.

title: So, You Buying It?
description: Have you bought your copy of Modernist Cuisine yet? Readers of Dining are well aware that its out there, of course: a six-volume self-published encyclopedia of kitchen history, tools, techniques, ingredients and recipes, a 40-pound love letter to the science and art of modern cooking from Nathan Myhrvold, the Microsoft gajillionaire. At $467.25, it is the No. 1 best-selling food-reference book on Amazon, where it is, perhaps not coincidentally, out of stock.

description: On Thursday, The Lede is following the war in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region.

title: HBO Votes for Ed Harris to Play John McCain
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, made a pretty convincing Senator John McCain when he appeared as himself in Wedding Crashers and on Saturday Night Live, but HBO Films has decided to go a different route in casting for its coming television-movie Game Change. On Wednesday evening HBO said that it had chosen Ed Harris, the Academy Award-nominated star of Apollo 13, Pollock, The Truman Show and The Hours, to play Mr. McCain in the film, which is adapted from the book of the same title by John Heilemann and Mark Halperin. The film will chronicle Mr. McCains 2008 presidential campaign starting with his selection of Sarah Palin as his running mate. HBO previously announced that Julianne Moore (of The Kids Are All Right) would play Ms. Palin in the film, which will be directed by Jay Roach (Dinner for Schmucks) and written by Danny Strong. Mr. Roach and Mr. Strong previously collaborated on the HBO movie Recount, about the backroom battles that followed the 2000 presidential election. A broadcast date for Game Change has not yet been announced.

title: The World Economy Shifts Eastward
description: William Easterly points us to a provocative new paper by Danny Quah on how the center of the world economy is shifting eastward.

title: A Different Kind of N.C.A.A. Moment
description: Playing off the age-old wisdom that boys dont cry, anytime a player does so, hes sure to find himself the focus of more media attention and camera lenses than when actually playing the game. (A player could step off the team bus wearing a tutu and not get the same amount of attention.)

title: Camelot Revisited: The Creators of The Kennedys Speak Out

title: Poetry Pairing | March 24, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Fashion Village on a Wet Night
description: Wednesday nights shindig (nice word  mmm ) for Vanessa Traina and her Maje collaboration was relaxed and fun. I didnt need to go to the hairdresser, after all. It started on the seventh floor of Barneys, with a D.J., and the arrivals of Ashley and Mary-Kate Olsen, in a great-looking fur jacket, though I liked the look of Ashleys broad-shoulder beige coat over a long black Row dress; then the designers Alexander Wang, Joseph Altuzarra and Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler. People were talking about Elizabeth Taylor, Carine Roitfelds appointment as a guest editor/stylist for Barneys and places they had recently been (other than fashion shows), and eyeing a Maje blazer with satin lapels, as if to say, Should I or shouldnt I? Ms. Traina, whose sisters Victoria and Samantha also attended, had on a blazer and skinny pants, with a cutaway Balenciaga top that draped in the front. Dinner was down the slushy street, at Caprice.

title: ReTweet | Window Dressing
description: Is there anything she cant do? A report today has the erstwhile Paris Vogue editor styling the fall campaign for Barneys (working photographer Mario Sorrenti and creative director Dennis Freedman), doing the windows in September and generally lending her air of fabulousness to the department store.
