title: New York Senators Push for Same-Sex Marriage Rights
description: New Yorks two senators, Charles E. Schumer and Kirsten E. Gillibrand, joined a growing list of celebrities and public officials on Thursday by appearing in a series of 30-second ads supporting same-sex marriage rights. The ad series is being coordinated by the Human Rights Campaign, and the appearance of the two senators, both Democrats, lends some Washington muscle at a time when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has said he will personally push for legislation in Albany to legalize same-sex marriage.

title: Advice on The Decision From the Today Show
description: The NBCs Today Show this morning turned its attention to college applicants and their families, and the challenge of narrowing their choices this decision season. Jean Chatzky, the programs financial editor, talked about the nuances of comparing financial aid offers, specifically merit- and need-based scholarships, as opposed to loans. I tried to reassure students that they will most likely have excellent choices  even if not necessarily the colleges that may have been their first or second choices.

The commentary is signed by economists from both Republican and Democratic administrations. Read Catherine Rampells post on Economix.

Von Hippel, a nuclear physicist and professor of public and international affairs at Princeton, is also co-chairman of the International Panel on Fissile Materials.

title: A Former Chiefs New Word on Why He Resigned
description: Former Chief of Detectives Albert A. Seedman worked some of the most notorious cases in New York City policing history. The 1964 murder of Kitty Genovese, a Queens woman who screamed as she was attacked repeatedly, ignored by scores of neighbors; the fatal shooting in 1972, at a Little Italy restaurant, of Joseph Gallo, leader of a violence-prone faction in the Colombo crime family.

title: Leading Off: We Now Return to Jimmermania
description: Our long days of waiting are now over. We can stop tapping our toes in impatience, checking the calendar for how much longer until the N.C.A.A. mens tournament resumes. Yes, we know the nation has a severe case of Jimmermania. It seems like forever since Jimmer Fredette dashed across our screen and scored another improbable basket for Brigham Young. But hes back, for a night anyway.

title: Hold Your Tongue: PG-13 Version of Kings Speech Coming
description: If your fear of a few naughty words enunciated by Colin Firth, some absolutely nonexistent sex scenes or Helena Bonham Carters hair was all that was keeping you from seeing The Kings Speech, you have only slightly less to be afraid of. The Weinstein Company said on Thursday that it would release a PG-13 version of The Kings Speech, its Academy Award-winning biographical film about King George VI (played by Mr. Firth) and the speech therapist (Geoffrey Rush) who helped him tame his stammer. The film, which won Oscars for best picture, director (Tom Hooper) and original screenplay (David Seidler) as well as for Mr. Firths performance, was originally released with an R rating. The Weinstein Company did not immediately explain what changes it was making to the PG-13 cut, but presumably some un-regal language will be toned down.

title: Toyota to Resume Production of Prius and Two Lexus Hybrids
description: On Thursday, nearly two weeks after an 8.9-magnitude earthquake devastated northeastern Japan, Toyota announced its intent to restart production of the Prius, its most popular hybrid model, on March 28. The automaker also plans to resume building the CT 200h and HS 250h, two Lexus hybrids based on the Prius platform, on the same timetable.

At the end of each one, she offers up a few sentences of what she calls her humble opinion, and she has always assumed that most readers glance over those and then move on. Lets just say the IMHO section is normally not a huge generator of mail at our magazine, she explained in an e-mail.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  A North Korean statement that Libyas dismantling of its nuclear weapons program had made it vulnerable to military intervention by the West is being seen by analysts as an ominous reinforcement of the Norths refusal to end its own nuclear program.

description: Of all the triple-doubles that have been recorded this season, Houston forward Chuck Hayess has to be considered one of the most unlikely. Hayes recorded 14 rebounds and a stunning 11 assists against the notoriously defense-adverse Golden State Warriors, and he sealed the triple-double with a jumper in the fourth quarter.

title: Spear Points Found in Texas Dial Back Arrival of Humans in America
description: For many years, scientists have thought that the first Americans came here from Asia 13,000 years ago, during the last ice age, probably by way of the Bering Strait. They were known as the Clovis people, after the town in New Mexico where their finely wrought spear points were first discovered in 1929.

title: Journalists at Risk: Considering the Perils and Value of War Reporting
description: Overview | Why have journalists throughout history risked death to bring us living history? What stories are worth risking ones life for? In this lesson, students perform monologues excerpted from first-person accounts by New York Times journalists who have experienced perilous situations in their pursuit of news. They then analyze photographs taken by photojournalists covering war and other dangers, and discuss why some journalists risk danger and whether the value of what they report is worth that risk.

title: Eyes Open, WaMu Still Failed
description: In the crazy days of 2005 and 2006, when home prices were soaring and mortgage underwriting standards were crumbling, it took foresight and judgment to see that it was all a bubble.

title: The Replacements Approach to the Replacements
description: Color Me Obsessed is just about the perfect title for a new documentary about the Replacements. The movies tag line is also promising: The potentially true story of the last best band. And yet I was a little surprised to learn that the Replacements themselves are not really in the film. Instead, the movie is a parade of 40-something (and older) ex-rockers and critics reminiscing ecstatically about the glory days. (Those would be the years 1981 to 1987.) A colleague (and huge Mats fan) objected, If I want to hear a bunch of guys talk about how great the Replacements were, Ill go hang out in a record store! He paused as the realization sunk in: there are no more record stores. Color Me Obsessed will have to do.

title: Finally, Mrs. Rose (and the Public) Can See All Her Quilts
With Drugstore.com Purchase, Walgreen Diverges From CVS Strategy
description: Updated: Walgreens announcement today that it plans to purchase the Web business drugstore.com for $409 million highlights the radically different business strategies of the nations two leading drugstore chains.

title: A Model Moment | Giovanna Battaglia, Part II
description: Surrounded by glittering names and fashions, Giovanna Battaglia still managed to shine last night at the Carla Amorim boutique opening party So Paulo, Brazil. In the second of her three dispatches about her outfit choices, Battaglia explains why it pays to Sparkle, Neely, sparkle!: The party was super glamorous and I wanted to be the jewel in the crown, which is why I wore a white, lace Dolce & Gabbana dress with lots of black and white diamond pieces from Amorim. To keep my feet glittering all night, I slipped into some Giuseppe Zanotti heels. No point being shy.

title: Everybodys Entitled to a Lift
description: The building I work in has 20 stories; and even though there are four (slow) elevators, its common for only one to be running at any time. I work on the 10th floor, so taking the stairs is not exactly a viable option. But I often find myself on the elevator with people getting off at the second or third floor. Taking the stairs would be faster for them, and they wouldnt delay the rest of us. May I say something to convey my irritation?

title: Now, Starter Homes Boast Solar Arrays
description: Among the standard features offered for new homes at Manzanita at Paseo del Sol, a KB Home development in a desert suburb southeast of Los Angeles, are nine-foot ceilings, six-panel doors and a 1.4-kilowatt solar array.

title: 36 Hours in Seattle
description: This is one of the rare American cities where you can be outdoors year-round without either shivering or sweating.

title: 36 Hours in Seattle
description: SPRING comes early to Seattle and lasts long. By the end of February, the rains relent and pastel shades of plum and narcissus initiate a progression of color and scent that lasts months. But new flora is not the only thing popping out of the ground in Seattle these days. Seemingly overnight, whole swatches of downtown and close-in neighborhoods  notably South Lake Union and the Pike-Pine Corridor  have transformed themselves into vibrant enclaves of restaurants, bars and galleries. With so many converted and repurposed buildings, Seattles cityscape is starting to look as layered as the wardrobes of its inhabitants. The tarry pitch of the timber port never disappeared; it just got plastered over with grunge flannel, tech money, yuppie coffee, Pacific Rim flavors, and more recently the backyard chickens and chard of urban pioneers. Dont let a passing shower keep you from entering the mix. This is one of the rare American cities where you can be outdoors year-round without either shivering or sweating.

title: In Israel, Gates Condemns Recent Attacks From Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  A rocket fired by militants from Gaza overshot the Israeli port city of Ashdod on Thursday afternoon, landing in an open area to the north, as Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates was meeting with Israels defense minister, Ehud Barak, less than 20 miles up the coast in Tel Aviv.

title: Revenge of the Friend
description: THEY kissed! Nobody kisses in spin class. A roomful of sweaty people panting atop steel bikes with 30-pound flywheels is no place for romance, and certainly no place for my friends ex-husband to show up with his girlfriend, the woman he left her for.

title: GHOSTS

title: Classic Editions of Childrens Folk Tales Reissued
description: Given the longevity of folk tales, youd think it would be hard to screw one up. But as any parent or teacher can attest, at least if theyve read aloud from myriad renditions of a single tale  whether its Little Red Riding Hood or Rumpelstiltskin  the quality of the prose and accompanying illustration varies widely. Even the The Three Bears, done wrong, can bore a preschooler.

title: Fed to Take a Step Out From Behind the Veil
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke will become the first Federal Reserve chairman to hold regular news conferences as he seeks to improve the central banks image.

title: A Glimpse Inside Bradleys Construction of the National Team
description: CARY, N.C.  Bob Bradley looked around the breakfast room, where the United States national team soccer players were reconnecting with big hugs and warm words. Some of the veterans were introducing themselves to new players, called in for the first time. The cycle was beginning anew.

title: Interns at the Operating Table
description: One afternoon in clinic, a patients wife stopped me in the hallway. I had just finished describing an operation to her and her husband, obtaining his consent and answering their questions, but I wasnt surprised that the woman was still worried. Despite her easy smile and infectious throaty laugh, she had appeared anxious throughout the visit, the corners of her mouth twitching and her hands flitting from her hair to her face to her pocketbook and back to her hair again.

title: Idol Tops Ratings (Again)
description: American Idol remained dominant in the ratings on Wednesday as 23.5 million viewers tuned in for two hours of performances from the remaining competitors on the Fox reality show, according to Nielsens estimates. CBS ranked a distant runner-up for the night, earning decent results opposite Idol with Survivor: Redemption Island at 8 (10.8 million) and a rerun of Criminal Minds at 9 (8.7 million). CBSs Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior led the 10 p.m. time slot with 8.9 million viewers, edging past NBCs Law & Order: SVU (8.7 million) and easily beating ABCs Off the Map (4.5 million) in the hour. ABC and its comedy line-up finished in third place over all, benefiting largely from solid ratings for Modern Family at 9 (10.8 million). NBC was fourth with Minute to Win It at 8 (4.2 million) and a repeat of Law & Order: SVU at 9 (4 million).

title: Bloomberg May Take On Spider-Man at Inner Circle Dinner
description: Even the mayor is not above taking a few free swings at the ever-more-battered cultural punching bag that is Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark. At Saturdays Inner Circle charity dinner, which features skits performed by the City Hall press corps and the mayor, Mr. Bloomberg plans to work some Spider-Man into his act  including, perhaps, a flying entrance from the balcony at the Hilton New York. Read all about it on Artsbeat.

title: A Woman With a Son, but Not a Country
description: Ripped from the headlines or a pool of similarly themed movies, the fiction film Illegal traces the ups and increasing downs of an immigrants struggles to stay in her adopted land. At once high-minded, sincere and frustrating, it opens with its central character, a Russian immigrant, Tania (Anne Coesens), reading a letter denying her residency in Belgium. Facing immediate deportation with her young son, Ivan (Alexandre Gontcharov), Tania reacts with the rash desperation that characterizes many of her subsequent actions: she takes an iron and begins burning her fingertips, obliterating one proof of her identity.

title: Things Fall Apart When a Family Gets Together
description: Every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way, according to Tolstoy, except in mainstream movie comedies where many unhappy families are exactly alike. The latest proof is Peep World, a family circus of dysfunction thats so familiar you may feel tempted to place bets on how everything will shake out, and painless enough that you might not resent doing so. Thats particularly the case whenever Michael C. Hall and Judy Greer, as a troubled married couple, show up and, by virtue of their professionalism, help to distract you from the flat jokes, ethnic clichs and formulaic relationships noisily vying for your attention.

title: Programming Your Elizabeth Taylor Mini-Film-Festival
description: Naturally, my recent admission that I have seen only one Elizabeth Taylor film prompted several of my more cultured colleagues to emphatically suggest to me the one film of hers that I absolutely, positively need to watch.

title: Kander and.Pierce? A New Collaborator for the Composer of Chicago and Cabaret
description: John Kander, who with Fred Ebb spent four decades creating some of musical theaters most beloved hits, including Cabaret and Chicago, is teaming up with a 32-year-old playwright and fiction writer, Gregory Pierce, on his first full, new theater collaboration with another writer since the passing of Mr. Ebb in 2004.

title: Taliban Cut Cellphone Service in Helmand
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai surprised some people this week when he announced that his forces would take over security responsibilities from international forces in the city of Lashkar Gah, capital of the volatile southern province of Helmand, this summer.

title: Strong Software Sales Drive Oracles Profit Up 78%
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Oracle, the business software maker, reported yet another quarter of strong gains on Thursday, as corporate spending on its software accelerated in a more robust economy.

title: A Tattoo Master, Off the Street, Into the Gallery
description: WHEN artists come to New York for a show, they often make a trip to Chelsea to check out the competition. But when the Mexican tattoo artist known as Dr. Lakra arrived last month to install his exhibition at the Drawing Center, he headed straight for the New York Public Library on 42nd Street, to sign up for a library card. Then he began researching some of the subjects that fascinate him, like 19th-century medical instruments, witchcraft and anthropology.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Libya, Italy and Tajikistan.

title: Labor Strife? Send in the Bosss Wife
description: The experience of watching Franois Ozons Potiche (Trophy Wife) is, in many ways, more like attending a theatrical matinee than like going out for a night at the movies. This is not only because Mr. Ozons source is a once popular, slightly musty play from the 1970s (by the writing team of Pierre Barillet and Jean-Pierre Grdy), which he has lovingly refurbished with impeccable attention to period dcor and present-day sensitivities. Mr. Ozon, a prolific filmmaker, has also, perhaps intentionally, approximated the stodgy good cheer that often distinguishes lavish, star-studded stage revivals of beloved old chestnuts. You suspect, before long, that there is no strong reason for this production to exist, but it is reasonably good fun all the same.

title: An Unintended Cameo for Splitter in Duncans Absence
description: The Spurs are without Tim Duncan, if only for a matter of weeks. As injuries go, San Antonio got off lightly; Duncan is hobbled, but his injured ankle reportedly suffered no structural damage as a result of a cringe-worthy buckle. His season - and San Antonios - is ongoing, though in a slight intermission.

title: A Newsmans Family, Missing in Action
description: As coping devices go, mythmaking is a bit more sophisticated than vodka or pills, if less conscious.Especially when a son is trying to make sense of a fathers fingerprints on his soul. In his memoir, Almost a Family, the former New York Times reporter and editor John Darnton describes the poignant process of examining and debunking the elaborately constructed defenses erected to cushion a boy growing up without a father.

title: Rules Faulted For Poor Data On Failures At Reactors
description: Nuclear power plants in the United States are not reporting some equipment failures to the government because of badly written rules, the inspector general of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has warned.

title: Rainbow Coalition
description: If the threat of April showers, or even snow, is prolonging your winter blues, spring forward in these cool-hued kicks. Eschewing the traditional red-brick crepe sole, these suede bucks and leather lace-ups look to the brighter side of the spectrum for extra zing. From top: Dunhill oxford, $520. Go to dunhill.com. Walk-Over suede buck, $225. Available at T.C. Supply Shop, 1079 Sixth Avenue. Call (212) 921-4430. Santoni oxford, $630. Go to santonishoesusa.com. Jil Sander oxford, $795. Available at Jil Sander, 30 Howard Street. Call (212) 925-2345. Mark McNairy New Amsterdam white buck, $350. Go to markmcnairy.com.

title: Traffic Pollution Doubles Lung Transplant Death Rate, Study Finds
description: Air pollution from car traffic may double the risk of organ rejection and death in lung transplant patients, Belgian researchers report in a new study.

title: Defending America, the Underdog
description: When it comes to our national self-image, humility gave way to hubris long ago.

title: House Tour: Chatham, N.Y.
description: A three-bedroom Greek Revival house in Columbia County, N.Y., provides a peaceful environment for a busy mind.

title: Spare Times for March 25-31
description: Around Town

title: Spare Times: For Children, for March 25-31
description: TO THE MOON

title: Sharing Her Secrets
description: EVERY family has its own inimitable way of communicating, and in my family you sometimes stumble across a secret or little piece of hidden family history in a bookstore. By my count my mother has written three memoirs, six autobiographical novels and four memoirish explorations, and so I think its safe to say that the shelves of Barnes & Noble know nearly as much about her life and times as I do.

title: An Entire Assignment, Lying in the Street
description: You might take another look at Tony Cenicolas photographs of a West Village apartment that appear in Thursdays Home section (American Rustic). Its actually a small miracle that you can.

title: Hand-Drawn Adventures
description: Images from the animated film Mia and the Migoo.

title: Movie Listings for March 25-31
description: Movies

title: Antiques Dealers on TV (Casting Calls Posted)
description: Cable networks are now showing practically nonstop footage of antiques dealers crawling around attics and warehouses and giving high appraisal values to stunned owners. During the last year at least 11 new reality series have documented the business.

title: House Tour: East Chatham, N.Y.
description: WHAT Three-bedroom house.

title: Locura del Marzo
description: As March Madness begins another four-day run tonight, I suspect that I will once again find Dan Shanoffs Quickish.com to be  well, not exactly an essential resource, but a delightfully inessential one. Quickish compiles the best insights  from ESPN.com, from SI.com, from Yahoo Sports, sometimes even from the Twitter feeds of certain denizens of The New York Times Magazine  into a real-time feed of instant tournament analysis. Odds are, whatever is being said there tonight will be at least as interesting as whatever is being said on the TV screen by the people calling the games.

title: TimesCast | March 24, 2011
description: A look at the potential military and political outcomes for Libya.

title: Prognosis: Study Finds Troubles With Gastric Band Surgery
description: More than a decade after having gastric band surgery for weight loss, patients at a university hospital in Belgium had lost just 43 percent of their excess weight on average, a new study reports. In nearly half of the patients, the bands had been removed because of medical complications.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Chaim Lazaros dresses in disguise to hand out toothbrushes to the homeless, not roundhouse kicks to evil villains. Nevertheless, Mr. Lazaros says that his work, and that of numerous others, is superheroic. Thats why he helped found Superheroes Anonymous, a collective dedicated to inspiring the superhero in all people through outreach, education and creative community service, as the groups Web site puts it. On Monday, as part of the Open City Dialogue lecture series, Mr. Lazaros will discuss his work and that of other X Alts (extreme altruists) around the country. (7:30 p.m.; Petes Candy Store, 709 Lorimer Street, at Richardson Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; 718-302-3770, petescandystore.com; free.)

title: Risks: Wealthier Women Get More Melanoma, Study Finds
description: Rates of melanoma among young white women have more than doubled in the past three decades, and wealthier, more educated women appear to be at greatest risk. Experts arent sure why, but a new study suggests that these women may be at increased risk because they are spending more leisure time outdoors.

title: Trailer: Homefront
description: The game, developed in New York by Kaos Studios, was released by THQ for Windows, Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3.

title: Old Rituals to Shape Young Dancers
description: Lawrence Rhodes, the artistic director of Juilliard Dance, knows that his talented pupils require shaping, and that for this purpose new choreography isnt always the answer. In Juilliard Dances Repertory, a program featuring classic works, students learn about dance history while onstage.

title: Bad News For Rent-Stabilized Tenants Paying Under $1,000
description: Perhaps, in the grand scheme of things, occupants of rent-stabilized apartments that go for under $1,000 a month can consider themselves lucky. Now they are slightly less so.

title: Reconstructing a Retreat House in Ronkonkoma
description: Ronkonkoma

title: Pop and Rock Listings for March 25-31
description: Pop

title: Jazz Listings for March 25-31
description: Jazz

title: The Magic of Wireless Speakers
description: The best gadgets should have a little bit of magic, and speakers that connect to your smartphone wirelessly meet that requirement.

title: Partnerships and Power Shifts Between Two Mighty Lands
description: Nubia: Ancient Kingdoms of Africa, an exhibition at New York Universitys Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, takes you deep into the history of a currently volatile part of the continent.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for March 25-31
description: Classical

title: Simple Truths in Matters of Life and Death
description: In 1970 the Japanese artist On Kawara began sending out a series of telegrams to friends around the world. Each one bore the message I am still alive, turning an urgent medium often associated with bad news into a steady, reassuring pulse.

title: Hopes and Struggles in a Difficult Land
description: Miral, Julian Schnabels fourth feature film, based on an autobiographical novel by Rula Jebreal (who wrote the screenplay), recounts the linked and partial life stories of four Palestinian women, beginning in the last days of the British mandate and ending in the 1990s, when it looked as if peace between Israelis and Palestinians might finally be on the horizon. That the film, an international co-production involving France, India, Israel and Italy, has been greeted with a flurry of controversy may show just how far that horizon has receded.

title: Musical Dialogue Beyond Embargoes
description: AFTER a decade-long drought imposed by the vestiges of cold-war hostilities, New York is about to be flooded with Cuban music. The appearance Saturday night of the Afro-Cuban All-Stars from Havana will be followed March 31 by the  Si Cuba! arts festival, which, over the next three months, will feature performances by or films about more than a dozen groups.

title: Bleak Visions From Early-20th-Century Rebels
description: If you sometimes feel that Germany has contributed more than its share of provocative, irreverent artists to 20th- and 21st-century art, you may be right. From Hannah Hch and John Heartfield to Martin Kippenberger and John Bock, the supply has been extraordinarily robust. During the postwar era, at least, we might credit an art-academy system that encourages independence, or maybe a society that remains somewhat more rigid than many of its Western counterparts.

title: Dance Listings for March 25-31
description: Dance

title: A Run at the Armory
description: The old, splintered wooden track has been replaced by a six-lane banked synthetic track at the Armory in Washington Heights.

title: Along a Fast Track, a Pause for Nostalgia
description: MY precise thoughts are lost to time, but when I last walked out of the Armory onto West 168th Street in Washington Heights on a winters night nearly 30 years ago, its a good bet that I felt it would be for the last time.

title: A Short Hop to Tax Savings
description: FOR almost 25 years Hugh Osborn and Claudia Wallis felt their six-bedroom home in Pelham suited them perfectly. Yes, the property taxes, which over time grew to exceed $30,000 a year, weighed heavily on their shoulders. But they agreed that was part of the price of living in a community with highly rated schools, gracious housing stock and proximity to Manhattan.

title: The Spiritual Network
description: BALTIMORE  Treasures of Heaven: Saints, Relics, and Devotion in Medieval Europe at the Walters Art Museum here is the most beautifully mysterious exhibition Ive seen this season. Its also a model of institutional sharing. The Walters, the Cleveland Museum of Art and the British Museum, all with deep medieval holdings, have combined their forces brilliantly.

title: Seeking a Missing Father and Mending the Earth
description: The evidence of the human hand, and all the labor implied by such work, is part of the low-wattage charm of the French animated childrens movie Mia and the Migoo, where visible brushstrokes fill blocks of bright color. The human touch is the most notable aspect of Mia, which won as best animated feature at the 2009 European Film Awards and involves a girl, her father, a tree of life, a bad dad, his unhappy son and the curious shapeshifter (or two) that is the movies most diverting creation.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for March 25-31
description: Art

title: Elevating a Nobody to Somebody
description: The portrait of a young man with penetrating brown eyes that had been languishing in storage at the Brooklyn Museum for decades was one of a list of artworks earmarked for possible sale. The painting had not been shown since 1945, and its attribution had been questioned.

title: BPs Move to Join Russian Company in Arctic Drilling Set Back
description: MOSCOW  BP suffered a setback in its efforts to remake itself in the wake of the gulf oil spill on Thursday when a Swedish arbitration tribunal blocked an $8 billion stock swap and Arctic exploration agreement with the Russian company Rosneft.

title: A Co-op in Fort Lee Considers Converting to Condo
description: FORT LEE

title: Calligraphy Made of Sound
description: As the worlds most prominent Japanese violinist and a frequent visitor to Carnegie Hall, Midori undoubtedly had a guaranteed berth in Carnegies JapanNYC festival. The question was what she would do with it. She could have assembled a program of Japanese music, something not in tremendous supply in this festivals high-profile classical music offerings, which are skewed mainly toward Japanese performers interpretations of the Western canon. Given that, she could also have played a standard recital and not seemed out of step.

title: A Long-Running Mismatch
description: FOR over a century, the Home Life and Postal Telegraph Buildings, next to each other at Broadway and Murray Street since 1894, have been locked in an irrevocable embrace, adjacent towers on the skyline around City Hall Park.

title: Playwrights Horizons Announces 2011-12 Season
description: Coming off another season of critically acclaimed work, the Off Broadway theater Playwrights Horizons on Thursday announced five of the six productions in its 2011-12 line-up, including a world premiere from Gina Gionfriddo (a Pulitzer Prize finalist for Becky Shaw) and directing gigs for Sam Gold (who staged the theaters current hit Kin) and Pam MacKinnon (director of its 2010 hit Clybourne Park).

title: Ensign Aide Indicted on Seven Counts
description: 6:43 p.m. | Updated Doug Hampton, the former senior aide to Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, was indicted on Thursday for violating a one-year lobbying ban, an unexpected development in a case that only became a subject of a federal criminal investigation after Mr. Hampton himself accused his former boss of instructing him to ignore the lobbying ban.

title: Well, Here They Are, Wherever This May Be
description: You could go to see Sucker Punch this weekend  a lot of people probably will, and a few may even admit as much back at the office on Monday  or you could try to make it yourself, which might be more fun, though not necessarily cheaper. Heres what you will need: a bunch of video-game platforms; DVDs of Shutter Island, Kill Bill, Burlesque and Shrek; some back issues of Maxim; a large bag of crystal meth; and around $100 million. Your imagination will take care of the rest.

title: Problems With New Good Faith Estimate Forms
description: THE revamped Good Faith Estimate form, which arrived just over a year ago, has helped give home buyers and homeowners looking to refinance their mortgages a better understanding of their borrowing costs

title: S.&P. Warns About Excessive Bank Dividends
description: Standard & Poors issued a warning on Thursday to big banks itching to increase their dividends: proceed with caution.

title: Advertisers in Europe May Face Limits in Use of Keywords
description: PARIS  An adviser to the highest European Union court recommended Thursday that some restrictions be placed on the rights of advertisers to use the names of rivals as keywords to generate sponsored links on Internet search engines.

title: Scrawling Style
description: A look at the work of the Mexican tattoo artist known as Dr. Lakra.

title: Q & A
description: Dealing With Asbestos in a Co-op Unit

title: A Successful Self-Publishing Author Decides to Try the Traditional Route
description: If any writer proved that modern self-publishing could be a pretty sweet deal, it was Amanda Hocking.

title: Japanese Town Mulls Future Without Whaling Industry
description: AYUKAWAHAMA, Japan  At first glance, it seemed like just one more flattened building in a seaside town where a tsunami had leveled hundreds of homes. But survivors gathered at this one to stand and brood.

title: Playwright Lanford Wilson, a Pulitzer Winner for Talleys Folly, Has Died
description: Lanford Wilson, a Pulitzer-Prize winning playwright best known for The Hot L Baltimore, Fifth of July and Talleys Folly, died Thursday morning of complications from pneumonia at the Kindred St. Joseph Hospital in Wayne, N.J., according to Marshall Mason, a friend and frequent collaborator. Mr. Wilson was 73 and lived in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Douglas C. Yearley Jr.
description: Mr. Yearley, 51, is the new chief executive of Toll Brothers Inc., one of the countrys largest builders of luxury homes, with developments in 19 states.

title: Keeping Score: Take Heart, Knicks Fans
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: The Graphic Impulse
description: Images from the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Norwegian Ensemble Flaunts Its Bows and Body English
description: In December, when Carnegie Hall set up an outpost of the Risor Chamber Music Festival, a summer event on the southeast coast of Norway featuring the pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, it supplied little local color. On Wednesday evening, when the Stavanger Symphony Orchestra appeared at Carnegie under the patronage of Crown Prince Haakon, the weather gods left nothing to chance, conjuring an atmosphere  literal and figurative  appropriate to early spring in a city on the southwest coast of Norway: a full-fledged sleet storm. (This sat oddly alongside the cherry-blossom motif in Carnegies lobby for its current festival, JapanNYC, but thats another story.)

title: Answers About the Nations Labor Laws and Unions, Part 1
description: Following is the first set of responses from Steven Greenhouse, the labor and workplace correspondent for The Times, who responded to your questions about the evolution of the nations labor laws and labor unions since the Triangle fire 100 years ago.

title: Bringing Out the Bad Girl for Some Tough Times
description: Fresh out of reform school  Barbara Graham, announced a booming voice to open Nellie McKays new show, I Want to Live!, on Tuesday evening at Feinsteins at Loews Regency. Wearing a copper-colored dress whose tarnished glitter suggested crushed Christmas ornaments and flashing a bright artificial smile, Ms. McKay, bounced onto the stage like an animated package of pretty poison.

title: U.N. Secretary General Expresses New Alarm Over Libya Strife
description: UNITED NATIONS  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon expressed deep concern Thursday about a possible humanitarian crisis in Libya despite Security Council steps to isolate and punish Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces, which have been ignoring warnings to stop a military campaign to crush a rebel movement seeking to end his long rule.

title: In Yorkville, Building With Families in Mind
description: IT seemed fitting for the developers of the Isis, a new high-rise condominium in Yorkville, to invite local first graders to watch the buildings construction. The neighborhood on the Upper East Side, once a German enclave of low- and midrise apartments, is becoming more popular with families because of its excellent schools and good real estate values.

title: Life and Loesser
description: Jo Sullivan Loesser, the widow of the composer Frank Loesser, narrates a look at the new Broadway revival of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying."

title: The Worlds of Lanford Wilson
description: A look at the works of the playwright Lanford Wilson, who died Wednesday.

title: The Most Influential People on Twitter
description: No one knows how to attract Twitter followers better than musicians. The three users with the most followers  Lady Gaga, Justin Bieber and Britney Spears  are all singers. In fact, 12 of the 20 most-followed people on Twitter are singers. So it would be natural to assume that musicians are also the most influential people on Twitter  the ones who can most quickly cause an idea to go viral. But it would also be incorrect.

title: Catering to Romance, by the Hour
description: Maybe youve seen it: the triangular three-story brick building at the west end of 14th Street. The peculiar location, on an isolated block beside the West Side Highway, allows for easy access by car, and maximum discretion.

title: Its Lights Out for Boxing Drama on FX
description: The FX network hit the cancellation button on its boxing drama Lights Out Thursday, a move that surprised few in the television business.

title: Art in Review
description: ARTS OF PACIFIC ASIA SHOW

title: 100,000 Libyan Casualties?
description: Laura Rozen reports on a White House briefing defending the Libyan intervention:

title: Under the Weather
description: No blogging today, probably none until tomorrow afternoon.

title: Already Short-Handed, Red Bulls Will Also Miss Henry  and Sutton, Too
description: 2:54 p.m. | Updated  On Friday, the Red Bulls took a skeleton crew to Columbus after the club signed goalkeeper Alex Horwath as an emergency replacement for Greg Sutton, who sustained a concussion in training on Tuesday.

title: Activist Investors Turn to Social Media to Enlist Support
description: Social media has proved to be a powerful tool for a wide range of constituencies, including revolutionaries in the Middle East and corporations in the Midwest. But hedge funds and other investors have yet to really embrace sites like Twitter and Facebook as they rally support for their causes.

title: As Student Absenteeism Rises, a Charter School Fights Back
description: The corridors were calm and the classrooms humming at the Chicago Talent Development Charter High School, but Kirby Callam, the schools chief executive, was focused on one missing honor student. On a sunny March morning, that 15-year-old was chalking up yet another unexcused absence and falling further behind in his accelerated coursework.

title: CarZen Puts Cross-Shopping Power on iPad
description: CarZen, a new car-shopping app, may not put you in a meditative state, but it could be a step toward automotive enlightenment.

title: Far From Duke and N.B.A., a Former Star Toils
description: A year removed from the one shining moment that is the dream of every collegiate hoopster, Jon Scheyers reality is not as glamorous: puddle-jumper airplane flights, lengthy bus rides, fast-food cuisine at odd hours and brief stopovers in half-star hotels.

title: John Grays White Irish Drinkers
description: Putting profane adjectives in front of every other noun in dialogue that wants desperately to sound streetwise doesnt make it feel authentic if the other words spoken by the characters are arranged into orderly little blocks of exposition. That tidiness is the fatal flaw of John Grays semi-autobiographical White Irish Drinkers, especially in scenes during which its nice young protagonist sits around shooting the breeze with his neighborhood pals.

title: State Board Freezes Wages on Most Nassau Workers
description: A state fiscal control board imposed a wage freeze on Thursday on Nassau Countys 8,100 employees, saying the countys latest effort to balance its $2.7 billion budget had fallen short.

title: Stories of War Through a Gypsy Lens
description: Tony Gatlifs Korkoro opens with an essential image of 20th-century horror: a camp of low barracks surrounded by barbed wire. It then cuts to a Gypsy caravan clanking through the French woods in 1943.

title: Todd Giglios Drawing With Chalk
description: Screaming vanity project from every hackneyed frame, Drawing With Chalk is yet another example of midlife American males doing all they can to avoid acting their age.

title: Moods and Messages From the Earth
description: As singular as its title, I Travel Because I Have To, I Come Back Because I Love You embraces road movie, personal journal and trancelike study of arcing grief.

title: Madonnas Charity Fails in Bid to Finance School
description: LOS ANGELES  A high-profile charitable foundation set up to build a school for impoverished girls in Malawi, founded by the singer Madonna and fellow devotees of a prominent Jewish mysticism movement, has collapsed after spending $3.8 million on a project that never came to fruition.

title: Looking Ahead to Fridays Matchups
description: East

title: Time, and Again, Glimpses of Youth
description: Ricardo Costa prefers realism of the rambling variety in Mists, a documentary-ish film that looks in on Peniche, the Portuguese fishing town where he spent his childhood. It starts out as if its going to be a simple story of reuniting with the now-graying housemaid who helped raise him, but it isnt really about her. Instead it sketches an impressionistic portrait of a town simultaneously removed from the world and touched by it.

title: A New Choreographer for Spider-Man
description: The producers of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark announced on Thursday evening that they had hired a choreographer, Chase Brock, to help stage new musical numbers and script revisions during the shows fifth and sixth months of preview performances before the scheduled opening on June 14.

title: The Personal Style of Elizabeth Taylor
description: From giant jewels to plunging necklines, the actress had a distinct personal style all her own.

title: Conor Horgans One Hundred Mornings
description: Playing like balm to the soul of anyone quivering from too many overworked, over-agitated multiplex experiences, Conor Horgans One Hundred Mornings uses an apocalyptic event as a springboard into the human psyche.

title: A Sons Quest, With Nature as a Guide
description: Its the rare director who can imbue the outdoors with a soul of its own. Sure, John Ford made Monument Valley, in Utah, an indispensable co-star for John Wayne. But Nicolas Roeg, in 1971, made the Australian outback almost sentient in Walkabout. With Bal (Honey), the Turkish director Semih Kaplanoglu enables the lush mountain forests of Rize Province, near the Black Sea, to express what its young protagonist cannot.

title: The Sequel to Diary of a Wimpy Kid
description: Diary of a Wimpy Kid, the first movie based on Jeff Kinneys illustrated childrens books, was made on a shoestring and grossed $75 million. Hence the arrival in theaters a year later of Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules, a sequel with straight to video written all over it. About the most you can say for it is that its inoffensive, which isnt necessarily what you want in a movie about the humiliations of being a seventh grader with a bullying older brother.

title: Cancer Survival
description: OK, one more post before taking to bed. What about those cancer survival rates that a lot of people, including Senator Johnson, cite when asserting US medical superiority?

title: In a Brazilian Town, a Rogue Gene and a Boom in Twins
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  For years, so many twins have been born in the small southern Brazilian town of Cndido Godi that residents wonder whether something mysterious lurks in the water, or even if Josef Mengele, the Nazi physician known as the Angel of Death, conducted experiments on the women there.

title: Bridges Need Work, but That Crucial Allure Is Missing
description: A news conference had petered out on a misty, chilly Tuesday when an officer stopped his squad car upon spotting me and a news media colleague. Whats up? he asked as he entered the lot at 19th District police headquarters at Belmont and Western Avenues.

title: Gun Range Near Birds Is Opposed
description: A bird-call ringtone emanated from Roger Shamleys smart phone after a slog last week through a marsh on the Southeast Side where birdwatchers say many migratory birds nest. The ringtone, one of his favorite apps, was a natural  Mr. Shamley is the president of the Chicago Audubon Society, having become a birdwatcher after retiring from the Chicago Police Department in 1997.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,498 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Two Coaches Share Last Name and Little Else
description: NEWARK  The two Williamses on the sideline Friday when No. 11 Marquette takes on No. 2 North Carolina will be a study of contrasts.

title: Transforming Streetscapes With Touches of Parks
description: Efforts are under way in San Francisco to transform pavement into parks and public spaces.

title: Hydraulic Fracturing Bill Could Force Disclosure
description: Hydraulic fracturing, an increasingly common method of extracting natural gas that involves shooting a concoction of water, sand and chemicals deep underground, has sparked controversy around the country  in part because drillers mostly keep their chemical formulas secret. But Texas, the leading gas-producing state, could help change industry practices by requiring public disclosure of the chemicals used.

title: Deep Rift in Beaumont on School Administration
description: BEAUMONT  Just off I-10, where the bayous between Houston and this once boomtown begin to transform into the landscape of suburbia, stands the imposing Carrol A. Butch Thomas Educational Support Center.

title: A Search in the Senate to Avert Houses Cuts
description: The Texas Senate isnt allowed to raise money. Its right there in the states Constitution, which says all revenue bills must originate in the House.

title: Gay Bar Mourns Elizabeth Taylor
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Last Halloween, David Cooley, the founder of the Abbey, a sprawling gay bar here, got a phone call. Elizabeth Taylor was on the line, and she wanted to know if it was a good night to swing by.

title: Swing Advice From Woods via Mobile App
description: Tiger Woods, who has been battling problems with his swing, unveiled a mobile application Wednesday called Tiger Woods: My Swing for iPhone and iPod users. The app gives hacks and crackerjacks alike a chance to evaluate their golf games by offering them instruction and an opportunity to compare their swings to Woodss through video analysis.

title: Buffett and Gates Prod Indias Wealthy to Be More Philanthropic
description: NEW DELHI  India is behind only the United States and China in its number of billionaires. But by global standards, its charitable giving is miserly.

title: Chinatowns Funeral Row, After a Crash
description: The Mulberry Street funeral homes have handled funerals for several passengers who were killed when a discount tour bus crashed on its way back to Manhattan from an overnight trip to the Mohegan Sun casino this month.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Throwing Together a Meal, One Swap at a Time
description: When Karen Solomon, author of Jam It, Pickle It, Cure It, began sending out invitations for a monthly baby-food swap, she was not sure how her recipients would respond.

title: Not Only the Bride Is Beaming
description: WHEN Angus and Michelle Mitchell think back to their  wedding last July, some of the memories sparkle with the light of a 500-pound crystal chandelier.

description: General Electric, the nations largest corporation, had a very good year in 2010.

title: U.S. Group Stirs Debate on Being Pro-Israel
description: JERUSALEM  On one side were members of the Israeli Parliament and advocates who argued that there was only one legitimate way to support Israel from abroad  unconditionally. On the other were those who insisted that love and devotion did not mean withholding criticism.

title: A Business Tax Charged When Employees Cash in Stock Options Is Scrutinized
description: A rare provision in San Franciscos business tax code that taxes companies when employees cash in their stock options has caused a stir in this hotbed of fledgling tech companies.

title: Leaders Spat Tests Skills of Survival in the Kremlin
description: MOSCOW  It was a strange week for Russias political elite.

title: Race, Poverty and the Public Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: What Could Have Been for Kentucky
description: NEWARK  In a season lacking dominance, Ohio State has had perhaps the most complete team in the country, with an array of perimeter shooters to complement the presence of Jared Sullinger inside.

title: How Gandhi Became Gandhi
description: Some years ago, the British writer Patrick French visited the Sabarmati ashram on the outskirts of Ahmedabad in the Indian state of Gujarat, the site from which Mahatma Gandhi led his salt march to the sea in 1930. French was so appalled by the noisome state of the latrines that he asked the ashram secretary whose job it was to clean them.

title: The Special Correspondent
description: On the night before William Howard Russell left London for New York, he dined at the Garrick Club with William Makepeace Thackeray. Charles Dickens, Anthony Trollope and many other leading lights of English culture and society also belonged to the private establishment. Although admitted to the Bar, it was as a correspondent for The Times of London that Russell established his reputation. His fame came from his dogged coverage of the Crimean War and, at its conclusion in 1856, he returned a hero. His dispatches brought the war home to readers. He wrote with clarity and vitality about the grandeur and the horror of battle. He followed that with an equally vivid account of the Sepoy Rebellion in India. People called him a war correspondent, perhaps the first, but he rejected the label and departed on March 3 for the brewing conflict in America as special correspondent for The Times.

title: In Defense of Dithering
description: Five years ago a young politician who seemed wise beyond his years was asked by Tim Russert what makes a great president. It was the kind of question that Russert, who could prompt more news in a single interview than entire cable operations do in a year, was so good at.

title: A Race Against Time to Save Oiled Penguins
description: Responders to a shipwreck and oil spill off a remote South Atlantic archipelago are in a race against time to save thousands of endangered penguins that have been coated in crude, local officials said Thursday.

title: Lawsuit Lays Out Activists Death by Elevator
description: Daniel Kliman stepped alone into a wood-paneled elevator in late 2008 and pressed the silver L button. The doors slid shut, and the carriage began gliding toward the lobby, but it lurched to a halt after descending just half a floor.

title: Sixth Day of Air Campaign in Libya
description: As the air campaign entered its sixth day on Thursday, NATO member nations approved a plan under which the alliance would assume command of the no-fly zone over Libya.

title: Court Condemns Uruguay for a Disappearance
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The Inter-American Court of Human Rights has condemned Uruguay for its actions related to the forced disappearance of a woman in the 1970s, in a case that human rights experts see as a watershed for ending impunity for crimes against humanity committed under Uruguays military dictatorship.

title: Marquettes Formula: Grit Trumps Star Power
description: NEWARK  Buzz Williams and the Jukes are an unlikely act to ascend the stage in the second week of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Inflated Worries
description: Washington

title: Caution: Wide Load (and Just Getting Wider)
description: Who is heavier: a) the average bus rider, b) the average boat passenger or c) the average flier?

title: General Electric: Where Taxes Are a Source of Profits
description: A graphic that describes how General Electric reduces its taxes.

title: V.C.U. Turned Barbs Into a Dream Trip to the Round of 16
description: SAN ANTONIO  A couple of Sundays ago, when the 68 teams for the N.C.A.A. tournament field were announced on national television, the Virginia Commonwealth basketball players did not gather to watch.

title: Delayed Miranda Warning Ordered for Terror Suspects
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has instructed agents to interrogate suspected operational terrorists about immediate threats to public safety without advising them of their Miranda rights to remain silent and to have an attorney present.

title: In Camp With the U.S. National Team
description: George Vecsey was given some rare access to Bob Bradley and the United States national team this week at their training camp in Cary, N.C. The result was an interesting look inside the preparations for and the man-management of the camp, and at some of the personalities  old and new. Read the entire article, and then come back here to comment.

title: Yemens Leader in Talks on Exit but Still Defiant
description: SANA, Yemen  As antigovernment demonstrators planned a new round of rallies on Friday, President Ali Abdullah Saleh was engaged in serious negotiations over the timing and conditions for the end of his 32-year rule, Yemeni and American officials said Thursday.

title: Excerpt from Radio Communication
description: Following is an excerpt from radio communication Wednesday between a third aircraft and a controller in Warrenton, Va., who warned that the tower at Reagan National was unstaffed.

title: The Austerity Delusion
description: Portugals government has just fallen in a dispute over austerity proposals. Irish bond yields have topped 10 percent for the first time. And the British government has just marked its economic forecast down and its deficit forecast up.

title: Lanford Wilson, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Playwright, Dies at 73
description: Lanford Wilson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright whose work  earthy, realist, greatly admired, widely performed  centered on the sheer ordinariness of marginality, died on Thursday in Wayne, N.J. He was 73 and lived in Sag Harbor, on Long Island.

title: Playwright Infusing His Losers With Love
description: Lanford Wilson liked losers. This is not to say that he gloried, masochistically, in defeat. But as a playwright, he knew that the most poignant drama often radiates from peoples failure to connect with one another, with their aspirations and with their own feelings. In this sense, you could say he was an heir to Tennessee Williams, another dramatist who saw the poetry in withered hopes and ideals tenuously sustained against a world of denial. If his characters lacked the complexity of Williamss greatest creations, they possessed some of the same vital glow, that of a self-consuming bonfire in a chilly twilight.

title: Richard Leacock, Innovative Documentary Maker, Dies at 89
description: Richard Leacock, a filmmaker who helped create the documentary style known as direct camera or cinma vrit, and who played a pivotal role in making some of the most innovative documentaries of the 1960s, died on Wednesday at his home in Paris. He was 89.

title: From Sandal-Wearing Weather to Chilly, in Less Than a Week
description: For a moment, it felt like spring. For a fleeting, flip-flop-flecked, sundress-decked, get-yourself-to-the-nearest-ice-cream-stand moment last Friday, 77 flirtatious degrees beguiled us out of our down jackets and downtrodden demeanors, to melt a winters worth of woe-is-mes. In a tree bed on the High Line Park in the meatpacking district, purple crocuses peered out over the pavement.

title: Prosecutors Focus on Small Trades in Galleon Trial
description: Louis Lanzano/Bloomberg NewsRaj Rajaratnam arriving at federal court in Manhattan on Thursday.

title: Four Years After a Death, a Gift Continues to Inspire
description: NEWARK  No one from this host city for the East Regional of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament will be rooting harder for North Carolina when it plays Marquette on Friday night at Prudential Center than Antwan Hunter. His love for the Tar Heels is practically a matter of life and death.

title: Some Weigh Restructuring Portugals Debt
description: LONDON  As Europe struggles to come to grips with its debt crisis, which has deepened with the collapse of Portugals government after it pushed for yet another round of budget cuts, three numbers stand out: 12.4, 9.8 and 7.8.

title: The Boss Falls. Then What?
description: Cairo

title: Even While Taking a Chance With Libya, Obama Is Playing It Low-Key
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas intervention in Libya is one of the riskiest gambles of his presidency, but he is doing his best not to make it seem like a major crisis.

title: Let Them Eat Cutbacks
description: Food stamps are part of the social safety net, but they work more as the ultimate ground-level crutch for Americans staggering against poverty. During the recession, food stamps were an important factor in helping an estimated 4.5 million Americans stave off the official poverty (no more than $21,756 annually for a family of four) that engulfed nearly 16 percent of the nation. The stamps are win-win: $9 in fast economic stimulus for every $5 spent on food for a hungry family.

title: A Reformed Ex-Felon in Trouble Once Again
description: MIAMI  Barry Minkow has made many names for himself: as a boy-wonder entrepreneur, as a Ponzi schemer who served seven years in prison and then reinvented himself as a fraud-detection specialist, government informant and pastor.

title: The Message of Labor, Proclaimed Through Song
description: The singers sounded good to Jana Ballard, but they needed a bit more  how to put it?  oomph. Youre just a little on the flat side, she said. No one argued. Though half the age of some in the room, she was the boss.

title: Mixed Marriages in the South
description: The 2010 census shows that the nation's mixed race population is growing faster than demographers expected.

title: Caseworkers Dispirited Over Charges in Girls Death
description: The faces looked commanding, soulful and, above all, streetwise, as they began staring out at New Yorkers three years ago from posters blanketing subway cars. The intent was to recruit top-flight talent to the citys beleaguered Administration of Childrens Services after the death of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown.

title: Beltran Reports No Pain in Knees
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Sometime in the next several days, Carlos Beltran hopes to come to the plate with teammates named Reyes and Wright on base.

title: Pressing Ahead Where Others Have Failed
description: SHIDAO, China  In pursuing pebble-bed nuclear reactors, China is pressing ahead with a nuclear technology that other countries have struggled to master. In some ways, its progress is a result of being less adventurous than foreign researchers.

title: A Radical Kind of Reactor
description: SHIDAO, China  While engineers at Japans stricken nuclear power plant struggle to keep its uranium fuel rods from melting down, engineers in China are building a radically different type of reactor that some experts say offers a safer nuclear alternative.

title: Allies Are Split on Goal and Exit Strategy in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  Having largely succeeded in stopping a rout of Libyas rebels, the inchoate coalition attacking Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces remains divided over the ultimate goal  and exit strategy  of what officials acknowledged Thursday would be a military campaign that could last for weeks.

title: Starz to Delay Release of Shows on Netflix
description: Starz, the pay cable channel, is about to be more restrictive about what it allows Netflix to stream to customers computers and television sets.

title: PG&E Offers Critics Option to Turn Off Smart Meters
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Pacific Gas and Electric proposed a solution on Thursday for Northern Californians who do not want so-called smart electricity meters installed in their homes: they must accept them but may have their wireless radio signals turned off, the company said.

title: Exelon, Largest U.S. Reactor Owner, Seeks to Reassure
description: WASHINGTON  Exelon, the largest operator of nuclear power plants in the United States, sought to reassure investors and the public about the safety of its 17 reactors on Thursday. The companys chief executive, John W. Rowe, declared that the company was well prepared to respond to emergencies not contemplated in the original design.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 24, 2011

title: Islamist Group Is Rising Force in a New Egypt
description: CAIRO  In post-revolutionary Egypt, where hope and confusion collide in the daily struggle to build a new nation, religion has emerged as a powerful political force, following an uprising that was based on secular ideals. The Muslim Brotherhood, an Islamist group once banned by the state, is at the forefront, transformed into a tacit partner with the military government that many fear will thwart fundamental changes.

title: Pentagon Orders a Stop to Engines Construction
description: The Pentagon ordered General Electric and Rolls-Royce on Thursday to stop building an alternate engine for the F-35 fighter plane, but the companies said they would spend millions of dollars of their own money to keep the project alive.

title: Mounting Minutes Do Not Add Up to Stoudemires Finest Hour
description: The N.B.A. regular season comprises 82 games for all 30 teams, but the games are not distributed evenly. At some point, back-to-back games stack up to resemble a baseball schedule more than an N.B.A. one.

title: Doing the Math on Japan Crisis
One Hundred Years Later, a Tragedy Remembered
description: The 100th anniversary of the fire at the Triangle Waist Company, which left 146 workers dead, is being marked by an outpouring of events.

title: Census Data Presents Rise in Multiracial Population of Youths
description: WASHINGTON  Among American children, the multiracial population has increased almost 50 percent, to 4.2 million, since 2000, making it the fastest growing youth group in the country. The number of people of all ages who identified themselves as both white and black soared by 134 percent since 2000 to 1.8 million people, according to census data released Thursday.

title: Many U.S. Blacks Moving to South, Reversing Trend
description: WASHINGTON  The percentage of the nations black population living in the South has hit its highest point in half a century, according to census data released Thursday, as younger and more educated black residents move out of declining cities in the Northeast and Midwest in search of better opportunities.

title: Mets Are Said to Be Suffering Sizable Losses
description: The Mets, long one of baseballs most highly valued franchises, have lost millions of dollars in recent years, including nearly $50 million in 2010, according to two people briefed on the teams finances.

title: Elements of Theater on View in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  More than 30 coffins were carried to Martyrs Cemetery here Thursday, escorted by hundreds of flag-waving supporters of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi chanting condemnation of what the state media said were civilian casualties of American and European airstrikes.

title: Bonds Jury Hears the Science of Steroids
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The jurors at the Barry Bonds perjury trial received a science lesson on Thursday, with Larry Bowers  a government witness and an antidoping expert  acting as their professor.

title: N.Y.C. vs. N.Y.S., the Pension Battle
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg wants New York City to take control of its own business back from Albany, especially pension costs.

title: Jordan Protesters Set Up Camp in Amman
description: AMMAN, Jordan  More than 1,000 pro-democracy demonstrators set up a tent camp in the center of Amman, the Jordanian capital, on Thursday in conscious imitation of Tahrir Square in Cairo, saying they would stay put until they saw real change.

title: Friday: Dramatic Confession
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  How can you not like a puzzle that has PAT BOONE, Neil PEART, and BECK all in the same grid? Some of you might not be into music, but that one has to be almost a virtual time line of tune makers.

title: Grameen Bank and the Public Good
description: In Tuesdays column I wrote about Grameen Bank, the pioneering microfinance organization, which has come under attack by the government of Bangladesh. The government has ruled that the banks founder, Muhammad Yunus, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2006, must step down from his post as managing director. Yunus has fought the order and taken his case to Bangladeshs Supreme Court.

title: Missionary Men With Confidence in Sunshine
description: This is to all the doubters and deniers out there, the ones who say that heaven on Broadway does not exist, that its only some myth our ancestors dreamed up. I am here to report that a newborn, old-fashioned, pleasure-giving musical has arrived at the Eugene ONeill Theater, the kind our grandparents told us left them walking on air if not on water. So hie thee hence, nonbelievers (and believers too), to The Book of Mormon, and feast upon its sweetness.

title: Egypts Unfinished Revolution
description: While everyone is focusing on the war in Libya, the revolution is still playing out in Egypt  a vital fact that its neighbors and other nations should not forget. The mostly peaceful protests that overthrew President Hosni Mubarak six weeks ago were just the first phase in a transition to what, we hope, will be a democratic future.

title: Entrapment Is Reasserted in Appeal in Synagogue Bombing Case
description: Lawyers for four men who were convicted in October of placing what they thought were explosives in front of two Bronx synagogues and plotting to fire missiles at military planes reprised parts of their entrapment defense on Thursday as they asked a federal district judge in Manhattan to set aside the guilty verdicts against the men and dismiss the indictment.

title: Lessons for Albany on Malpractice Limits
description: ALBANY  As New York lawmakers strive to complete the state budget by April 1, one of the most contentious battles involves whether to include a cap on medical malpractice payments that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has proposed with the support of the states hospital industry.

title: Man Facing Homicide Charge Is Shot Dead in Brooklyn
description: A 23-year-old man who was facing charges in a killing in SoHo was himself shot to death near Prospect Park in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, the police said.

title: To End Inquiry, Suffolk Leader Exits Race
description: Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive who switched parties to seek the Republican nomination for governor last year, abruptly ended his bid for a third term on Thursday in a deal to end a 16-month criminal investigation of his political fund-raising.

title: Now Batting Leadoff for the Yankees, Jeter or Gardner?
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Derek Jeter has hit second for the Yankees thousands of times, just as he has batting leadoff. He has moved seamlessly between the spots, accommodating the arrivals of players like Chuck Knoblauch and Johnny Damon, and has won championships hitting in both places. Over 16 years, Jeter has produced at almost the same rate in each spot, with no appreciable difference in his batting average, on-base percentage or slugging numbers.

title: Vexing Questions of East and West
description: To the surprise of many New Yorkers, evidence emerged this week that Central Park  by virtue of being west of Fifth Avenue  may be a wholly owned entity of the Upper West Side.

title: Lobbyists Long Effort to Revive Nuclear Industry Faces New Test
description: WASHINGTON  One flash point in the remarkable revival of interest in nuclear energy here  a revival now threatened by the calamity in Japan  came almost by accident at a late-night brainstorming session in a senators office in 1997.

title: The Ego Advantage
description: Theres something Ive always wondered about Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi: How does a guy who seems to be only marginally attached to reality manage to stay in power for 42 years?

title: A Different Kind of Nuclear Reactor in China
description: Experts say pebble-bed reactors offer a safer nuclear alternative.

title: Lundqvist Is Sharp, but Rangers Are Not
description: The Rangers appear to be in pretty good shape these days, but they have yet to lock up a playoff berth, let alone determine the identity of their first-round opponent next month. But they already seem to be leaning as hard on goaltender Henrik Lundqvist as they would in the postseason.

title: Leonard I. Weinglass, Lawyer, Dies at 77; Defended Renegades and the Notorious
description: Leonard I. Weinglass, perhaps the nations pre-eminent progressive defense lawyer, who represented political renegades, government opponents and notorious criminal defendants in a half century of controversial cases, including the Chicago Seven, the Pentagon Papers and the Hearst kidnapping, died on Wednesday. He was 77 and lived in Manhattan.

title: For Walker and UConn, March Goes On
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The Connecticut guard Kemba Walker continued his March mastery, proving to San Diego State on Thursday that he really could do everything. He played all 40 minutes, scored 36 points, procured steals, rebounds and assists. And yet perhaps his most important play came during a timeout.

title: Spider-Man Is Said to Drop Geek Chorus of Narrators
description: The geeks are gone. In the first major change confirmed for Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, the critically panned Geek Chorus of narrators  a strategic device in the musical  will be cut altogether during the shows hiatus this spring, three members of the production said on Thursday night.

title: Fredettes Shot Is Off, and Florida Advances
description: NEW ORLEANS  Brigham Young guard Jimmer Fredette wore a bandage on his chin after taking a second-half spill and spent part of the game hobbled with a calf injury. B.Y.U. fans threw quarters on the court to protest noncalls on Fredette, who had a heated exchange with an official in the second half. Even B.Y.U.s normally mild-mannered Jackson Emery drew a technical foul protesting a charging call on Fredette.

title: In Lockout, Twitter Can Be a Pulpit or a Distraction
description: We often think of social media as a powder keg, but in the N.F.L. labor dispute, it may be acting more like a boiling chip. Twitter may provide an instantaneous sounding board for discontented players weary of the party line, but its wide range and immediate feedback create sudden consequences for anyone who stands out from the crowd.

title: Air Traffic Controller Suspended in Unguided Landings
description: The Federal Aviation Administration on Thursday suspended the air traffic controller who was on duty when two passenger jets landed at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport without clearance or guidance from the tower. The controller, who officials said had 20 years of experience, is believed to have been asleep.

title: Extent of Damage to Japans Infrastructure Still Unclear
description: Nearly two weeks after the earthquake and tsunami struck Japan, engineers still do not know the full extent of damage to roads, bridges, rail lines and other infrastructure.

title: 'Book of Mormon': Naughty and Nice
description: Ben Brantley narrates a look at the new Broadway musical from the creators of "South Park."

title: Competing for Summer Internships, Using a Twitter Contest
description: A VENERABLE agency has turned to a new form of communication to find its annual batch of interns in a shift that underlines how Madison Avenue is seeking to change the way it reaches out to everyone, from consumers to potential employees.

title: Photo Replay: March 24
description: A view of the day in sports, with cricket fans in India and a tennis fan from the Miami Metro Zoo.

title: Dorothy Young, Houdinis Stage Assistant, Is Dead at 103
description: From one side of the stage would glide Bess Houdini, wife of the master magician and escape artist, draped in a billowing gown like Marie Antoinette. From the other side would prance Dorothy Young, dressed as a courtly boy page in ruffled silk.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Word of the Day | facile
description: facile \fa-sl\ adjective

title: Wisconsin: No Ruling on Union Law
description: The battle over a state law curbing the union rights of public workers is headed for the State Supreme Court after a lower court declined to weigh in on the issue. The lower court, the Wisconsin Court of Appeals, said the issues involved were so fundamental  involving a clash between the states open meetings law and the separation of legislative and judicial powers  that it made sense to send the case straight to states highest court. Last Friday, a judge in Dane County blocked the law while she considered a lawsuit that accuses Republican lawmakers of violating open meetings laws by failing to give adequate notice of the vote on the union law. The state had asked the appeals court to throw out that order. Also Thursday, an Indiana prosecutor said one of his deputies had resigned after admitting that he sent an e-mail to Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin suggesting that Mr. Walker fake an attack on himself to discredit the unions. The prosecutor, Brad Cooper of Johnson County, said the deputy, Carlos Lam, acknowledged that he sent an e-mail, which was obtained by The Associated Press. It said: If you could employ an associate who pretends to be sympathetic to the unions cause to physically attack you (or even use a firearm against you), you could discredit the public unions.

title: In Melbourne, Talk of Another U.S. Race and Great Aussie Fans
description: MELBOURNE  Its a sign of how seriously Australian fans take the Formula One race in Melbourne that even my shuttle driver there knew about Bernie Ecclestone visiting New York this weekend to talk about the possibility of a Grand Prix race on Staten Island.

title: In Melbourne, Talk of Another U.S. Race and Great Aussie Fans
description: MELBOURNE  Its a sign of how seriously Australian fans take the Formula One race in Melbourne that even my shuttle driver there knew about Bernie Ecclestone visiting New York this weekend to talk about the possibility of a Grand Prix race on Staten Island.

title: U.N. Council Establishes Monitor for Iran Abuses
description: The United Nations human rights body voted Thursday for the appointment of an investigator to monitor and report on Iran in response to its crackdown on political dissent. The Human Rights Council in Geneva voted 20 to 7, with 11 abstentions, in favor of the resolution co-sponsored by the United States and Sweden to appoint the investigator. Earlier, the council heard a report by the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, in which he said Irans leaders had intensified their crackdown on political opponents, activists and journalists and noted a dramatic surge in the number of executions since the start of 2011. The United States ambassador, Eileen Donahoe, hailed the vote as a seminal moment for the council. Iran condemned the resolution as an abuse of the council.

title: Ukraine: Ex-Leader Is Charged in Journalists Killing
description: Former President Leonid D. Kuchma was officially charged Thursday in connection with the murder of a prominent investigative journalist. Though the precise nature of the charges remains unclear, prosecutors announced this week that Mr. Kuchma was suspected of ordering the 2000 murder of the journalist, Georgy Gongadze. Mr. Kuchma, whose decade as president was known for widespread corruption and political violence, could be sentenced to up to 12 years in prison if convicted, the Ukrainian media reported. Earlier, he said he was prepared to go through all the tortures of hell to prove his innocence.

title: Russia: Ships Hijackers Are Convicted of Piracy
description: A Russian court sentenced six men involved in a rare case of European piracy to 7 to 12 years in prison on Thursday for their roles in the hijacking of a cargo ship off the coast of Sweden in July 2009, Russian news agencies reported. The men were among a team of eight hijackers, mostly residents of Estonia, charged with commandeering the ship and 15 Russian crew members and ferrying it through European waters out into the Atlantic Ocean. The Russian Navy eventually tracked down the ship, Arctic Sea. It was officially carrying cheap timber, though the heavy-handed rescue operation fueled rumors that it was smuggling illicit cargo. Russian investigators denied this. The two other hijackers were convicted earlier.

title: A Makeover Continues as Arizona Stuns Duke
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  When Arizona Coach Sean Miller was 14 years old, he dribbled his way onto the national stage.

title: Butler Relies on Defense to Stymie Wisconsin
description: NEW ORLEANS  The qualifiers that have been attached to Butlers N.C.A.A. tournament success should be removed. As Butler storms toward a potential second consecutive Final Four and continues to mow down major programs with higher seeds, words like surprise, upset and Cinderella should be deleted from stories about the Bulldogs.

title: Japan Encourages a Wider Evacuation From Reactor Area
description: This article is by  Hiroko Tabuchi,  Keith Bradsher and  David Jolly.

title: News Quiz | March 25, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Lundqvist Finds Benefits in Starting Every Game
description: Henrik Lundqvist would rather have Martin Biron healthy and serving as an experienced, highly capable backup in the Rangers goal for the rest of the regular season. Biron sustained a broken collarbone during practice on theafternoon of the Feb. 28 trade deadline, and the Rangers ran out of time to fill the hole. As a result, Lundqvists team is relying on him even more than usual.

title: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: March 24
description: Half of the Round of 8 is decided as some favorites go home and everyones sweetheart advances.

title: Reconstruction Continues in Japan
description: Reconstruction continued in the areas hit by the earthquake and tsunami in Japan.

title: Test Yourself | History, March 25, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about a famous disaster that happened 100 years ago today.

title: NATO Set to Take Full Command of Libyan Campaign
description: BRUSSELS  Resolving internal divisions, NATO prepared on Friday to assume leadership from the United States of the military campaign against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces as allied officials scrambled to work out the precise command arrangements, senior NATO and American officials said.

title: This Is Your Brain on Sports
description: WHO can cross a busy road better, a varsity wrestler or a psychology major?

title: What Places Do You Remember Fondly From Childhood?
