description: In an essay for the Home & Garden section, Kevin Baker remembers the small town in Massachusetts in which he grew up  a place, he says, that is dear to those who know it. What place do you remember especially well from your own childhood? Why are those memories important to you?

title: Thirty Days on the Ground in Libya
description: Goran Tomasevic of Reuters arrived in Libya on Feb. 23, having covered the upheaval in Egypt. (Even the Middle Ground Is Perilous in Cairo, Feb. 4.) These images, presented in chronological order, convey some sense of what a tumultuous month it has been. Kerri MacDonald interviewed Mr. Tomasevic by e-mail last week. Their correspondence has been edited.

title: Daily Lexeme: Noctivagous
description: Todays word, in association with the educational Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Yemeni Leader Would Yield Power Only to Safe Hands
description: SANA, Yemen  As hundreds of thousands of demonstrators for and against President Ali Abdullah Saleh poured into the streets here in the capital for competing rallies on Friday, the Yemeni leader said he was ready to yield power if he could hand it over to safe hands.

title: In Germany, a Growing Flirtation With Classic American Muscle
description: The modern passenger car may have its roots in Germany, but some young German enthusiasts are more inclined to pay homage to the automobiles American forebears.

title: Seeing Art in Paris as the Sun Sets
description: Over the first few days of April, the Art Paris fair draws crowds of collectors to the Grand Palais exhibition hall. This year the organizers are offering an additional attraction: Les Nuits Parisiennes, an evening art stroll on April 1 and 2 that links 15 art installations in nine locations across the city center.

title: The Early Word: Objective
description: From Todays Times:

title: Fantasy Focus: Closers in Waiting
description: Whereas my colleague Jeff Erickson recently ranked closers, Id like to take a step further and look over relievers who could end up factoring in your leagues save category this season. Closers-in-waiting have become increasingly overpriced in recent years, which is a mistake, given how volatile relief pitching is year-to-year. Nevertheless, 20 to 30 percent of a typical fantasy leagues saves during the season come off the waiver wire, so this aspect cant be ignored. Just let your own league dictate which middle relievers to grab. Im not ranking the following for a reason  all are similar, so you might as well take those who come cheapest.

title: Julian Assange: Also Not a Great Houseguest
description: We all need a laugh right about now. So, please, enjoy this hilarious send-up of Julian Assange (cat hater) as a houseguest. It comes from Allison Silverman, a former Colbert Report writer. According to the comedy blog Splitsider, Silvermans friends once let Assange stay with them for a few days, and, lets just say hes not invited back. She recorded them describing the incident, then set it to this re-enactment complete with crazy white wig.

title: Chinese Democracy Activist Is Given 10-Year Sentence
description: BEIJING  A Chinese court sentenced one of the countrys most seasoned pro-democracy activists to 10 years in prison on Friday on charges that his writings slandered the ruling Communist Party and were part of an effort to end its monopoly on power, his lawyer said.

title: A $23,000 Facebook App That Comes With a Car
description: You have no doubt seen the charming TV commercial for the Chevrolet Cruze in which the driver drops off his date, then uses the cars Facebook feature to check his news feed. We hear the cars voice read back his dates posting, Best first date ever. Awww, enchanting!

title: Syrian Troops Open Fire on Protesters in Several Cities
description: CAIRO  Military troops opened fire during protests in the southern part of Syria on Friday and killed peaceful demonstrators, according to witnesses and news reports, hurtling the strategically important nation along the same trajectory that has altered the landscape of power across the Arab world.

title: Questions Linger on 1099 Rules
description: As expected, many Agenda readers took us to task for a post last week that considered the burden small businesses would bear if the expanded 1099 reporting requirements embedded in the health care overhaul are not repealed. What was surprising was that the view was not unanimous, or even close to it: Of the commenters who expressed anopinion, about a third did not find the new requirements particularly onerous.

title: Atomic Ages
description: The imperiled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan dates from the 1960s. Forty-plus years may not be a long time when it comes to radioactive decay  300 years to go for the Switzerland-size contaminated area around Chernobyl  but it can feel like close to forever when you think about the engineering and technological advances since the pre-moon-landing days. Steven Chu, the secretary of energy, says that the 23 American reactors (more than 20 percent of our reactor fleet, by the way) built according to the same design as the Fukushima Daiichi station are continually upgraded to ensure their safety. But still. As one of our contributing writers, Jon Gertner, put it a few years ago, Nuclear power plants are arguably the most complicated machines in the history of civilization. Even as that partly hints at why their failures can be so catastrophic, it also prompts the question: Shouldnt we have more than upgrades by now? Shouldnt we have much more advanced nuclear machines already?

title: Who Wins and Who Loses if Bachmann Runs in 2012?
description: 8:27 a.m. | Updated Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota seized the media spotlight on Thursday by merely leaking out the possibility that she might  someday, maybe months from now  form an exploratory committee to consider running for president.

title: Triangle Fire: Clinging to Scraps of Memories
description: On the day after the Triangle fire, the scores of victims were laid out in a makeshift morgue set up at the so-called Charities Pier off East 26th Street. Many were burned so badly that they were almost impossible to identify.

title: David Stern vs. Roger Goodell
description: THERE IS A STRONG chance that by midsummer, the N.B.A. will have joined the N.F.L. in locking out its players, and for this we can credit two men above all others, the commissioners David Stern and Roger Goodell. Sterns N.B.A., which just had one of its least successful franchises (the Warriors) sell for a record $450 million, wants player salaries slashed by 38 percent. Goodells N.F.L., which has never been more profitable, wants 18 percent. Ponder for a moment that both commissioners are peddling what is essentially an upward redistribution of wealth into the hands of guys like Jerry Jones and Mark Cuban. Its going to take some real salesmanship to get the public to go for that. So whos better equipped to do it?

title: Online Pokers Big Winner
description: Daniel (jungleman12) Cates, a 21-year-old self-made multimillionaire, lapsed economics/computer-science major and one-day Bubble Trouble champion of the world, was mildly annoyed. A reputedly solid player under the gun had just bet, and Cates needed to figure out if he was bluffing. Cates consulted the stat readout and deduced that the kids erratic betting over the past 200 hands was a product of emotional fragility. With no pair, no draw and no hope of winning a showdown of hands, Cates again raised the pot. At a second table, Cates had just made his flush. He put out a value bet that was precisely calibrated to resemble a bluff. At a third table, he folded. At a fourth, he called for time. At a fifth, his mouse slipped, causing him to accidentally fold. He muttered a profanity before turning his attention back to the first two tables.

title: Next-Generation Scientists
description: One day in the fall of their sophomore year, Matthew Fernandez and Akash Krishnan were at Akashs house in Portland, Ore., trying to come up with an idea for their schools science fair. At Oregon Episcopal School, all students in 7th to 11th grade are required to enter a project in the Aardvark Science Expo (the aardvark is the schools mascot), and these two had teamed up for the last three years. Temporarily defeated, they popped in a DVD of I, Robot.

title: LCD Soundsystem  The Finale
description: James Murphy accepted his fate while sitting in a van outside a club, in a city he cant remember, on a tour taking him nowhere. He was 26 and traveling as the sound man with a couple of punk acts, Six Finger Satellite and Thee Hydrogen Terrors. But on this particular night in 1996, Murphy was talking with Six Fingers frontman when he came to a conclusion that most of us reach early and a sad few reach too late: I will never be a singer in a rock n roll band.

title: Soccer Sensation
description: Indi Cowie performs her trick freestyle moves.

title: The Dark Side of Choice in Higher Education
description: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: Keller vs. Huffington
description: Bill Kellers column (All the Aggregation Thats Fit to Aggregate) was exactly right, and Arianna Huffington should be ashamed of the way she runs her Web site. She essentially makes money off others hard work. Aggregating is one thing, but you cant write a 72-point headline that merely links to the Rolling Stone site and call it journalism. EKEIZER4Oregon, 5:06 p.m., March 13, The 6th Floor, nytimes.com

title: A Soccer Phenom Puts the I in Team
description: Last spring, Indi Cowie performed her freestyle soccer routine for 76,000 fans during halftime at a Chelsea-Manchester United match in Manchester. But standing backstage at the Green Hope High talent show in Cary, N.C., she was nervous. She may have won freestyle competitions in Rome and shot Sony Playstation commercials in Prague, but shes not exactly the popular girl in high school. They even spelled her name wrong in the event program. But this 16-year-old nobody does things that no other girl on the planet can do.

title: Complaint Box | Local Hypocrites
description: Marietta Ladies, Mens and Childrens Wear has been part of my neighborhood in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, for over half a century. Hand-lettered signs fill the display window (Heavy sox, $1.50 a pair). Inside, the walls are lined with honey-colored wooden drawers stuffed with bras and pajamas. Two elderly brothers run the shop, which they inherited from their mother. I often go in to buy T-shirts (rung up on a cash register that, like the brothers, is old but still working).

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Morning Buzz | Population Is Up, but Just a Bit
description: Last Friday it was 77 degrees. Yesterday, it snowed an inch. March has been switching lion and lamb masks like an Indy pit crew changes tires. Today and the weekend will be quite chilly, with highs in the 40s and lows in the 20s. But the sun will shine.

title: March 25 Updates on Mideast Protests and Libyan War
description: On Friday, The Lede is following the war in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region.

title: Does He Have Your Full Attention? Aaron Sorkin in the Most Meta 30 Rock Clip Ever
description: In the autumn of 2006, NBC found itself with a surfeit of shows (which is to say, two) with numerically themed titles that were set backstage at fictional television sketch programs. The first, 30 Rock, created by Tina Fey, was a rapid-fire sitcom containing zany shenanigans, wacky hijinks and roughly 100 jokes per minute. The second, Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip, created by Aaron Sorkin, was an hour-long drama about philosophical and aesthetic debates, the pioneering satire of Gilbert and Sullivan and, somehow, the delicacy of hostage negotiations during wartime. Guess which one survived its freshman season?

title: Brixton Gets Cooking
description: London: Theres a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

title: How Shakespeare Invented Teenagers
description: Shakespeare described the terrifying beauty of the adolescent so early in its development, and so definitively and so thoroughly, that it is only slightly an exaggeration to say that he invented teenagers as we know them today. Romeo and Juliet, his extended study of the humiliations and glories of adolescence, is the biggest hit of all time and, unlike most of Shakespeares works, it has never slipped out of fashion. It has been adapted across genres and eras, into operas and ballets and musicals. The most popular brand of Cuban cigars: Romeo y Julietta. State laws that allow judges to exempt minors from statutory-rape charges are called, naturally, Romeo and Juliet provisions.

title: A Teachable Moment for a Stepson and His Mom
description: No way! I dont like anyone else! My stepson has just admitted that he has a crush on the hottest girl in his ninth-grade class. I am trying to talk him out of it. Why not take a more pragmatic approach, I ask him, and focus his energies on the third- or fourth-hottest girl in his class instead? He thinks Im being absurd. I think hes being absurd. Were at an impasse.

title: Dick Clark, Still the Oldest Living Teenager
description: So hows retirement?  I dont enjoy retirement. I would much rather be working.

title: German Business Confidence, While Still High, Slides a Bit
description: FRANKFURT  A closely watched indicator of German business sentiment, while still indicating economic growth, declined on Friday, signaling that events in Japan and the Arab world could be making businesses more cautious.

title: Goldmans Slow Start in M.&A.
description: When it comes to merger advising, Goldman Sachs is like a venerable sports franchise that has stumbled early in the season.

title: U.S. Growth More Robust Than Earlier Estimated
description: The nations economy grew at a 3.1 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, led by an increase in consumer spending.

title: Roches Bloc of Heirs Lose Majority Vote After One Bolts
description: A shareholder pool made of up descendants of the founder of the Roche Holding, which controls the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, has slipped below the 50 percent threshold after one member of the family broke away, a representative for the group said Thursday.

title: Aftershocks Rattle Myanmar as Toll Rises
description: TACHILEK, Myanmar  Aftershocks continued in Myanmar on Friday, and residents camped out on streets and in parks, praying at makeshift shrines after a major earthquake the night before killed more than 70 people, injured hundreds and shattered hundreds of buildings.

title: AT&T Deal Shows How Different a Private Sale Can Be
description: AT&Ts 78-page agreement to acquire T-Mobile USA from Deutsche Telekom shows how creative deal makers can become when the agreement is a sale of a private company, rather than the purchase of a public company. Here are the highlights from the filing:

title: Al Hirschfeld Draws Elizabeth Taylor
description: Al Hirschfeld, the artist, did many illustrations of Elizabeth Taylor, who died Wednesday at 79.

title: Twist and Stout
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#107", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: With Rossinis Mix of This and That, the Met Finds an Excuse for a Romp
description: When you consider how it came into being, Le Comte Ory, Rossinis final comic opera, should have turned out a mess. It was a loose amalgamation of two completely different works: Il Viaggio a Reims, an operatic entertainment Rossini wrote to celebrate the coronation of Charles X in France, and a one-act vaudeville play, by Eugne Scribe and Charles-Gaspard Delestre-Poirson, about the exploits of a libidinous young nobleman, Count Ory, and his band of knights, who weasel their way into a French convent during the Crusades.

title: A Feast of Food Links
description: Or mostly food links, at least. Pick and choose; this is what Ive been reading this week.

title: Hes the Shade of Martha Graham
description: RICHARD MOVE will never get Martha Graham out of his system. Even though she died in 1991, she just wont leave him alone.

title: Mets Archive Yields Past Treasures
description: LIKE all other branches of the recording industry, classical music can see an online future coming. The die-hards who still enjoy collecting prerecorded CDs in plastic cases may not be so happy about this. Yet files of studio and live recordings that can be purchased and downloaded are increasingly popular.

title: Theatrical Nuance on a Grand Scale
description: RUNNING the Metropolitan Opera for the past five seasons has taught me to stay in a constant state of alert. The ups and downs of our recent revival of Gounods Romo et Juliette provide a good example. Our star soprano, thinking she might have been poisoned, withdrew from the cast  one day after marking her way through Juliettes poison aria during a rehearsal.

title: Mar. 27  April 2
description: Theater

title: A Clock Moves in Grand Central, and Memories Stir
description: It was never the famous meet-me-under-the-clock clock at the old Biltmore Hotel. Nor is it the gilded four-faced centerpiece in the concourse of Grand Central Terminal. It was just a plain workaday clock that spent most of its life in a lower-profile nook at Grand Central answering one of two questions: Can I make the train, for people sprinting to catch one, or how late was it, for people sprinting off a train that had finally arrived.

title: Relive Through This: A Hole Reunion of Sorts at New Directors/New Films
description: Reunited and it feels so good: four members of the vintage-1990s rock band Hole, which never got along as smoothly as any  Peaches & Herb song, are planning to reconvene on Monday at the New Directors/New Films series to see a documentary about the former Hole drummer Patty Schemel, the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center said. A screening at MoMA of Hit So Hard, directed by P. David Ebersole, is set to be visited by its subject, Ms. Schemel, as well as the guitarist Eric Erlandson and the bassist Melissa Auf der Maur, not to mention a certain idiosyncratic front woman and fashion plate named Courtney Love. If we sound a little surprised by the gathering (which the film series organizers say is the first time these four musicians have been together at a public event in 13 years), consider such past events in the history of Hole as: Ms. Schemels departure from the group in 1998 and the bands dissolution in 2002; Ms. Loves announcement of a Hole reunion in 2009 that seemed to surprise Ms. Auf der Mar; Mr. Erlandsons remarks that there is no Hole without me and Ms. Loves online reply that Hole is MY Band and MY name. A Q. and A. with Mr. Ebersole and the band members is set to follow the screening; there was no mention of whether it would be conducted from within a steel cage.

title: Rubble-Necking
description: Rubber-necking at the post-quake destruction in Christchurch, New Zealand.

title: Whats Your Screaming Eagle?
description: I have a column in the Times magazine this weekend extolling the virtues of the Screaming Eagle cheese steak sandwich, available at Boston College. Every college town has one of these sandwiches, I say, some nasty-fantastic combination of meat and cheese and salt and grease. Tell us about your college sandwich memories.

title: F.B.I. Memorandum
description: Below is the text of an unsigned, internal F.B.I. memorandum, obtained by The New York Times, that provides guidance to agents about when, in the course of interrogating a terrorism suspect, they should advise the suspect of his so-called Miranda rights to remain silent and have an attorney present during questioning.

title: On the Bucks Blog: Weighing the Financial Appeal of Community College
description: The Timess Bucks blog is hosting a timely discussion on the merits of taking on student loan debt for a four-year college versus paying the relatively inexpensive tuition of community college, perhaps with an eye on transferring later. As its jumping-off point, the blog post uses an article about an 18-year-old high school senior with a choice to make. Should he go into at least $6,500 in debt each year to attend a private college or university like Juniata or Clark, or is he better off working part time and attending community college for two years before transferring to one of those colleges?

title: Leading Off: This Year, Butler Outlasts Duke
description: It is no longer a surprise to see Butler win an N.C.A.A. tournament game, under any circumstances. If Gordon Haywards almost incredible last shot at a national championship last year did not convince you, this years march through the bracket certainly should. The Bulldogs have a roster of guys who might live next door to you and are coached by a man who doesnt look a day over 20. And they look calm even when they need a buzzer-beater to win a game.

title: Recruiting for the U.S. Marines, Imperial, Mo.
description: I was going to try to hang there as long as I could.

title: Burmese Nights
description: More than 2,000 young Burmese gathered for a Valentines Day hip-hop concert.

title: Friday Reading: Food Swaps Catch On
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Portugals Education Lesson
description: Another reason not to take to the education naysayers too seriously, via Charles Forelle in todays Wall Street Journal:

title: Hedge Fund Increases Stake in Avis
description: The Senator Investment Group, a hedge fund founded in 2008 by two former portfolio managers of York Capital Management, said on Friday that it had raised its stake in the Avis Budget Group to 7.24 percent from 5.7 percent in December.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

title: New York's Labor Patrol
description: In the field with the New York State Department of Labor's Apparel Industry Task Force.

title: No Place Like Home in Womens Tournament
description: A lot of factors need to come to together to win the womens N.C.A.A. basketball title. Luck, good play and decent officiating all help.

title: Prices Say Its Time to Think Studios
description: WHEN New Yorks real estate market was at its dizziest height, $1 million studios had become routine and buyers with less than $250,000 to spend were almost surely headed out of Manhattan, perhaps even to another state.

title: Faith Was on the Governors Shoulder
description: Early on the morning of Ash Wednesday, the beginning of Lents season of penitence, Gov. Pat Quinn of Illinois went through some final, solitary rumination. For much of his political career, he had supported capital punishment, albeit with reservations, even debating it at the dinner table with his mother. Now a legislative bill abolishing it was waiting for his signature, or his veto.

title: Elegy on the Adriatic
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#681", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Off the Menu: Almond Returns to Bridgehampton
description: Almond, the French bistro that Eric Lemonides and Jason Weiner opened in 2001 on the outskirts of Bridgehampton, and then recently closed, will reopen in the One Ocean space, at 1 Ocean Road in Bridgehampton, before Memorial Day weekend, Mr. Lemonides said. The partners closed the original Bridgehampton location in November after negotiations to renew their lease fell through. They opened a Manhattan branch in the Flatiron district three years ago,

title: Habitats | Upper West Side
description: Susan Buckley lives in an apartment that reflects her well-traveled life with her late husband, Peter.

title: Traditional News Outlets  Living Among the Guerrillas
description: Has anyone actually seen James OKeefe and Julian Assange together? Are we quite sure that the right-wing prankster who brought down the leadership of National Public Radio and the anarchic leaker arent split personalities of the same guy  sent by fate to mess with the heads of mainstream journalists?

title: Apartment 10E, as in Effervescent
description: IN Susan Buckleys apartment on East 83rd Street in Manhattan, amid the conch shells and coral from the Caribbean, the walking sticks capped by Alpine ferrules, the French sleigh bells and the Civil War-era flag, are five guest books testifying to a life well lived.

title: 30 Rock and Paulsons Big (Fictional) Party
description: Its been three and a half years since John A. Paulsons now-legendary party at the Metropolitan Club in the fall of 2008, a fete that unofficially crowned him as a prince of finance after he made billions from the housing collapse.

title: Whipping Up a Vegetable Frittata
description: For a fast, easy one-dish meal thats packed with vegetables, nothing beats a frittata, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: A Renter Trims His Sails
description: EVER since his arrival in New York from Chicago a dozen years ago, Dan Babic had lived in the same apartment  a two-bedroom rental on Front Street, near South Street Seaport.

title: President of College Board to Step Down in 2012
description: Gaston Caperton, the president of the College Board  and, in that capacity, the ultimate proctor of the SAT and Advanced Placement exams  announced Friday morning that he would step down in June 2012. Mr. Caperton, 71, a former Democratic governor of West Virginia, has led the College Board since 1999.

title: Answers About the Nations Labor Laws and Unions, Part 2
description: Following is the second and final set of responses from Steven Greenhouse, the labor and workplace correspondent for The Times, who responded to your questions about the evolution of the nations labor laws and labor unions since the Triangle fire 100 years ago.

title: Being Gay on the Left
description: This detailed and absorbing dual biography begins with an explanation of the title. The phrase a saving remnant,  Martin Duberman writes, has historically referred to that small number of people neither indoctrinated nor frightened into accepting oppressive social conditions. Unlike the general populace, they openly challenge the reigning powers that be and speak out early and passionately against injustice of various kinds.

title: 100 Years Later: Examining the Impact of the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire
description: Today is the 100th anniversary of the Triangle Waist Company factory fire, a tragedy in Lower Manhattan that claimed the lives of 146 people, all but 23 of whom were young women. One of the landmark disasters in American history, it eventually inspired important shifts in the nations laws, particularly those protecting the rights of workers and the safety of buildings.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 25
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Up Front: Kathryn Schulz
description: According to Kathryn Schulz, the author of Being Wrong: Adventures in the Margin of Error, the idea to study the human propensity for making mistakes came to her basically out of the ether.

title: Why Experts Get the Future Wrong
description: What does the future hold? To answer that question, human beings have looked to stars and to dreams; to cards, dice and the Delphic oracle; to animal entrails, Alan Greenspan, mathematical models, the palms of our hands. As the number and variety of these soothsaying techniques suggest, we have a deep, probably intrinsic desire to know the future. Unfortunately for us, the future is deeply, intrinsically unknowable.

title: Kansas: Easy Path to Final Four, or Trap?
description: SAN ANTONIO - Kansas has the easiest road to the Final Four of any top-seeded team in N.C.A.A. history, if the seeds are used to compare opponents.

title: What Newton Gave Us
description: London before the mid-1600s was a general calamity. The streets were full of thieves, murderers and human waste. Death was everywhere: doctors were hapless, adults lived to about age 30, children died like flies. In 1665, plague moved into the city, killing sometimes 6,000 people a week. In 1666, an unstoppable fire burned the city to the ground; the bells of St. Pauls melted. Londoners thought that the terrible voice of God was roaring in the City, one witness wrote, and they would do best to accept the horror, calculate their sins, pray for guidance and await retribution.

title: Yankees Trade Mitre and Sign Millwood
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Some of the intrigue surrounding the Yankees pitching plans cleared up Friday when their trade of Sergio Mitre to Milwaukee ensured that Ivan Nova, Freddy Garcia and Bartolo Colon will make the opening day roster.

title: Marvel Moments
description: A look at some of Marvels characters and their transitions from comic book to screen.

title: Propelling a Genre Beyond Hero Worship
description: IN the scheme of outr hotheads, Frank DArbo falls somewhere between George M. Steinbrenner and the Human Torch. As portrayed by Rainn Wilson in the new action-comedy film Super, DArbo is a tormented fry cook whose preferred style of relationship is the slow-burning feud.

title: Modern Marvel
description: AXEL ALONSO, the new editor in chief of Marvel Comics, was recalling how, about 10 years ago, when he was less experienced and recently hired by the company, he persuaded the British writer Peter Milligan to take over a struggling superhero comic called X-Force.

title: Excerpt: 'Le Comte Ory'
description: Diana Damrau, Joyce DiDonato and Juan Diego Flrez in an excerpt from Act 2 of the Met's production of the Rossini comic opera.

title: Lazards High-Priced Real Estate Bargain
description: Manhattans high-end rental market has remained remarkably resilient, rising even amid a nationwide real estate slump. But the investment bank Lazard is still getting a deal on a luxury apartment it rents for one of its directors, Vernon E. Jordan Jr.

title: A Man Remembers Meeting the Babe
description: The little boy on the pony is 92 now, but he does not need a black-and-white film to remember the October afternoon in 1927 when Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig came to his familys backyard in Sioux City, Iowa.

title: False Alarms and False Springs: Our Hiatus is Over
description: For me, the first signs of spring are pitchers and catchers. For Chef Isidori, its shad roe and wild leeks.

title: Lt. Andrew McCarthy
description: Lt. Andrew McCarthy is a platoon leader who deployed to Afghanistan with First Battalion, 87th Infantry.

title: Proenza Schouler Doesnt Care for Targets Messenger
description: FOR the last month a few blogs have noted the similarity between the Proenza Schouler PS1 bag and Targets Mossimo Messenger bag. But on Wednesday, the Proenza designers, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, became aware themselves when Mr. McColloughs sister in California e-mailed a photo of the Mossimo bag at her local Target and another blog mentioned the similarities. The designers say they are disappointed with Target.

title: Maj. Jake Larkowich
description: Major Larkowich is second in command for First Battalion, 87th Infantry.

title: Pfc. Bradley Pawlowski
description: About halfway through his deployment to Afghanistan, Pfc. Bradley Pawlowski discusses living conditions on the base.

title: Mercedes-Benz to Offer Drivers Education
description: On Wednesday, Mercedes-Benz USA announced plans to introduce the Mercedes-Benz Driving Academy at the end of this year. The program is intended to teach teenage drivers the basics and more advanced lessons that, in an era of curtailed financing for public drivers education, they might otherwise miss.

title: Pfc. Bradley Pawlowski
description: About halfway through his deployment to Afghanistan, Pfc. Bradley Pawlowski discusses the progress he has made on his goal to lose weight.

title: Pfc. Bradley Pawlowski
description: About halfway through his deployment to Afghanistan, Pfc. Bradley Pawlowski discusses the heat there.

title: Reviewer Spotlight: Kathryn Schulz and the Rightness of Wrongness
description: This weekend in the Book Review, Kathryn Schulz, the author of Being Wrong: Adventures in the Margin of Error, reviews Future Babble: Why Expert Predictions Are Next to Worthless, and You Can Do Better, by Dan Gardner. In a recent e-mail interview, she discussed her own interest in wrongness, as well as the roles that philosophy, science and literature have played her life.

title: African Tyrant
description: Peter Godwin has carved out a niche as a skillful chronicler of politics and war in his native Zimbabwe. His 1996 memoir, Mukiwa: A White Boy in Africa, was an affecting account of his coming-of-age in white-minority-ruled Rhodesia, where his father managed a factory and his mother, a physician, operated a rural health clinic. The story climaxed with the outbreak of the civil war that would bring the guerrilla leader Robert Mugabe to power  and with the accidental killing of Godwins elder sister by Rhodesian troops at a roadblock. When a Crocodile Eats the Sun: A Memoir of Africa, published in 2007, picked up the narrative with Mugabes evolution into a brutal dictator who stomped on the opposition, evicted thousands of white farmers in a violent land reform program and plunged his country into ruin. Now Godwin has written the third installment of what might be called his Zimbabwe trilogy. In The Fear: Robert Mugabe and the Martyrdom of Zimbabwe, he documents the 2008 presidential election and its aftermath, when Mugabe unleashed ruling-party militias in a savage campaign to keep his hold on power.

title: Petite Italian Model Seeks Love in America
description: THREE years ago in Italy, as I was preparing to drive the reborn Fiat 500, a company spokesman had a point he wished to emphasize. Let me be clear, said the spokesman, Richard Gadeselli. There are no plans to sell this car in the U.S.

title: A Love Triangle From Brazil to Brooklyn
description: Thomas Pletzingers first novel, Funeral for a Dog, is about sex, love, Brazil, a form of mnage--trois, childrens books, Finland, dogs, Ping-Pong, New York  in short, the good things. But more than anything else, it is about what happens when a thing is lost: a Brazilian police dog loses a leg, a German-Finnish love triangle loses a member, a boy loses his friend, a woman loses her baby, an ethnologist loses his calling, a journalist loses his way.

title: Mack Not Running for Senate in Florida
description: Representative Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, upended political expectations by announcing Friday that he would not challenge Senator Bill Nelson, a Democrat, in 2012.

title: Regimens: Drug Is Seen to Limit Progression to Diabetes
description: People at high risk of developing diabetes may be able to ward off the disease by taking the drug pioglitazone, a new study suggests, but critics say the potential side effects of the medication may outweigh the benefits for those who are still disease-free.

title: Look of the Moment | Rosie Huntington-Whiteley
description: The Look: Model Symphony  a pared-down pelt balances out this seasons must-have maxi dress.The Girl: Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, the star of the coming movie Transformers: Dark of the Moon and the Burberry It chick, checks out of Mr. Chow in Los Angeles.

title: Romney Backs Away From $50 Million Fund-Raising Goal
description: Let the expectation games begin.

title: Academic Intimidation
description: Regular readers may recall my praise for William Cronons Natures Metropolis: Chicago and the Great West, a great book that had a big influence on my work in economic geography. Cronon has inspired many other people; Josh Marshall was deeply influenced by his environmental history of New England. Cronon, who teaches at the University of Wisconsin, is, quite simply, a great historian.

title: Best Kept Secrets
description: There has been so much written about the death of Elizabeth Taylor over the past two days (even right here) and deservedly so.

title: Hospital Groups Assess Health Care Law
description: The year-old federal health care law offers a tempting promise for the countrys hospitals: a potential pool of 32 million newly insured customers. That could produce a huge reduction in the tens of billions of dollars worth of services for patients who cannot be refused, but who often cannot pay.

title: How the Indians Lost Washington Territory
description: Richard Kluger has written a half-dozen novels, but hes best known for telling true stories, hard stories, very well: Brown v. Board of Education (Simple Justice), the rise and fall of The New York Herald Tribune (The Paper), the cigarette wars (Ashes to Ashes) and, more recently, American expansionism (Seizing Destiny). Of late he appears to be drawn toward the deep, the dark and the lethal in our past. The Bitter Waters of Medicine Creek is a worthy spinoff of Seizing Destiny, which described the active and often ugly process of taking the continent.

title: Resignation Shows U.S.-Mexico Divide on Role
description: MEXICO CITY  Carlos Pascual, the American ambassador here who resigned last week, had hoped to withstand the fierce storm caused by the release of diplomatic cables revealing his private criticism of Mexicos fight against organized crime.

title: An Internet Stars Mom Responds
description: In response to my post earlier this week about 13-year-old Rebecca Blacks viral video, frequent commenter Kris wrote:

title: Interview with Capt. Tony Hampton
description: About halfway through his deployment to Afghanistan, Capt. Tony Hampton tells an anecdote about his daughter back home.

title: Sefina Adasi and Michael Lucki
description: Sefina Onozar Adasi and Michael Thaddeus Lucki were married Saturday afternoon at the Somerset, a resort on Providenciales, part of the Turks and Caicos Islands. The Rev. E. Conrad Howell, a minister affiliated with Sure Foundation Ministries, a Christian sect, officiated.

title: The Man Who Hired Jackie Robinson
description: In the summer of 1937, with the Dodgers holding down their familiar spot near the bottom of the National League, the cartoonist Willard Mullin drew the unforgettable image of the Brooklyn Bum  a potbellied, cigar-chomping hobo who combined the cheerful ineptitude of the players and the goofy optimism of their fans. Named for the singular dodging skills of pedestrians in a borough crammed with trolley lines, the Dodgers hadnt captured a pennant since 1920, and had never won a World Series. Brooklyn? roared Bill Terry, manager of the hated New York Giants. Is Brooklyn still in the league? Dodger fans were largely immune to this abuse. Their addiction had taught them patience and humility  like belonging to a religion whose one flaw was an unreachable promised land. From Bay Ridge to Brownsville, from Flatbush to Coney Island, it was always Wait till next year.

title: Ward Justs Portrait of an Artist
description: Many coming-of-age novels share a problem. Their callow protagonists, self-absorbed but not yet self-aware, tend to be less interesting than the supporting cast  those confidently eccentric mentors, charismatic coaches and first lovers, those parents and confessors, tempters and tricksters. An authors insistence on keeping an immature figure front and center, page after ruminative page, can seem a vexing self-indulgence.

title: Lt. Matthew Vinton
description: Lt. Matthew Vinton is a platoon leader who deployed to Afghanistan with First Battalion, 87th Infantry.

title: Appalachian Gothic
description: Its October 1940 and Tucker, a writer, and his photographer girlfriend are on an assignment for the W.P.A., chronicling the landmarks and local history of Virginia. Driving along a dusty mountain road, they accidentally knock down a child. Though he seems unhurt, they feel responsible and insist on taking him back to the dismal, isolated shack in the middle of the woods where the boy, Eddie, lives with his mother, Cora.

title: A Cheating Husbands World
description: Before Peter Stamm emerged as one of Europes most exciting writers, he worked, for nearly a decade, as an accountant. But although Stamm has left this career behind, the characters in his novels and short stories often act and think like bookkeepers, calculating their experiences in terms of ratios and costs, gains and losses.

title: Was the Civil War Necessary?
description: Writing about what might have been is something historians tend to avoid. You may find the occasional counterfactual sentence in a serious history book  What if Lee had accepted command of the Union army? What if Lincoln had lived?  but that sort of speculation is usually left to novelists, as when Philip Roth, in The Plot Against America, imagines a United States gone fascist under President Charles Lindbergh.

title: Stories of Small-Town Strife
description: Throughout Alan Heathcocks impressive first story collection, Volt, trouble appears in biblical proportions in the imaginary rural town of Krafton: floods, homicides, fires and fratricides are among the catastrophes to confront the blue-collar citizenry. For Heathcock, suffering is everyones fate, a point he drives home repeatedly. When a teenager in one story helps burn the body of a man his father has killed in a senseless fight, he thinks of all the fires the world has ever seen, fires from wars, fires from bombs, and concludes that the lingering remains of all that smoke is now just the air we breathe. In other words, sorrow and strife are permanent parts of the human condition.

title: The Rise of dith Piaf
description: Popular song gained an indelible image in 1935, when dith Piaf, Frances fabled Little Sparrow, first stood onstage in a plain black dress, a rats nest of dark hair topping her weary eyes. Singing in a piquant tone with a thick vibrato, she poured out tales of working-class lives and endurance pushed to the brink, usually by love. Face, hands and voice were all she needed to bring her playlets to life. One of her trademarks, LAccordoniste, was written for her in 1940. As she sang of a prostitute whose musician lover went off to war and never returned, Piaf rocked her arms through the air manically to the rhythm of his playing; she caressed her stomach as though remembering how he felt against her.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Danny Meyers latest, Untitled, a cafe-restaurant at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue (75th Street), (212) 570-3670, is now open 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. on weekends. On Sunday, Wally Chin, an owner of Chin Chin, and the chef Chris Cheung open Walle Restaurant & Lounge, with their personal spin on Chinese food, at 249-251 East 53rd Street, (212) 371-0888.

title: Will Rogers, Populist Cowboy
description: Will Rogers: Thats the guy who never met a man he didnt like, right? Today, few people know more than that.

title: How a Gift Card Can Cut Your Tuition Bill
description: Zac Bissonnette is a senior at the University of Massachusetts and the author of Debt-Free U. In an article in the special section this week on Money Through the Ages, he offered advice for a student grappling with a choice of taking on student debt or starting at a community college.

title: American Mischief in the Carribean
description: For a historian wishing to chronicle American foreign policy foolishness, there is no more promising territory than the Western Hemisphere. One could begin with the 1823 Monroe Doctrine, by which the United States reserved the right to intervene militarily in the region, and then look just about anywhere down through the years for examples of shameful behavior. In Red Heat, Alex von Tunzelmann concentrates on just one area, the Caribbean, and mainly on one decade, the 1960s. In those years, the United States promoted political assassinations, turned a blind eye to horrific brutality and repression by local tyrants, sponsored an invasion of Cuba and dispatched 23,000 soldiers and Marines to the Dominican Republic in order to prevent the establishment of a government there it feared would be unfriendly.

title: Oprah Magazines Adventures in Poetry
description: The signs of the coming apocalypse are many, but none are starker than this Web headline in the April issue of O: The Oprah Magazine: Spring Fashion Modeled by Rising Young Poets. Yes. Spring fashion. Modeled. By rising young poets. There follows a photomontage of attractive younger women  some of whom are rising poets mostly in the I get up in the morning sense, but all of whom certainly look poetic  in outfits costing $472 to $5,003. This is all part of Os special issue celebrating National Poetry Month, edited by the noted verse aficionado Maria Shriver and including interviews with all-star readers like Bono, Ashton Kutcher, the gossip columnist Liz Smith and someone named James Franco, who is apparently an actor.

title: Mankells Endgame
description: Henning Mankell has spoken: Detective Chief Inspector Kurt Wallander has solved his last case. Making this news more bitter, the alcoholic, diabetic, antisocial and perpetually dour Swedish detective is at his gloomy best in THE TROUBLED MAN (Knopf, $26.95). After his colleagues on the Ystad police force gave him a 50th-birthday party, Wallander started keeping a record of all the people he knew of who were now dead, a morbid task that he abandoned after the 10th suicide. Five years later, he bought a house near the sea and acquired a dog, indicating some improvement in his mental health. But having reached the age of 60, Wallander has become lonely and despondent. His life was now centered increasingly on recalling things from the past that he now realized he missed, Mankell observes, in the melancholy words of Laurie Thompsons translation.

title: Lt. Matthew Vinton
description: During his deployment to Afghanistan, Lt. Matthew Vinton reflects on conditions on the ground in his area of northern Afghanistan.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE INFORMATION: A History. A Theory. A Flood,  by James Gleick (Pantheon, $29.95.) Gleick argues that information is more than just the contents of our libraries and Web servers: human consciousness, life on earth, the cosmos  its bits all the way down.

title: Paperback Row
description: WHY TRANSLATION MATTERS,  by Edith Grossman (Yale University, $16.) Comparing the translators craft to that of the actor transforming a playwrights words in performance, Grossman, the celebrated translator of Don Quixote and works by Gabriel Garca Mrquez and Mario Vargas Llosa, addresses the inadequate treatment  by publishers, reviewers and academics  of translated literature in this country.

title: Researchers Republicans Like
description: Through some kind of synchronicity, at the same time that great scholar William Cronon finds himself under attack for being honest, an intellectual the right likes has added a new chapter to his illustrious career.

title: Roomy Lots and Recurrent Teardowns
description: ANYONE unfamiliar with northern Queens could be forgiven for imagining that living at the foot of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge might be more likely to involve sleeping on a flattened cardboard box than in a sprawling multimillion-dollar home with a swimming pool. But despite its traditionally low profile, the 100-year-old residential enclave of Malba, nestled just to the west of the bridge along the gently undulating waters of Powells Cove, is one of the most upscale and picturesque neighborhoods in the borough.

title: Frdric Chopin Letters Go On Display in Warsaw
description: They speak of his friends, the troubled composition of his Cello Sonata, his favorite hot chocolate. Six letters by Frdric Chopin went on display this week at the Chopin museum in Warsaw after having been lost from view since the early years of World War II. The missives date from 1845 to 1848, a year before Chopins death, and were written from Paris and Nohant in central France  the childhood home of George Sand, Chopins lover  to the composers family in Warsaw. It was a time of considerable turmoil in the Chopin-Sand domestic arrangement. The letters were in the hands of Laura Ciechomska, a grandniece of Chopin, until at least 1939, a museum curator, Alicja Knast, said, according to The Associated Press. They resurfaced in 2003, and the museum later acquired them, The Associated Press said.

title: Even the Optometrist Asks, Where Are You Going to College?
description: You hear it in the halls, at restaurants, and in aisle three. Your optometrist asks it as he dilates your eyes. Your new barber, struggling, among other things, to make casual conversation, lets it slip faster than you can say keep the sideburns, please.

title: Bank Robbery Suspects Luck Runs Out on the L.I.R.R.
description: Updated, 3:52 p.m. | Max Schneider of Dix Hills on Long Island was a wanted man.

title: Interview with Capt. Tony Hampton
description: About halfway through his deployment to Afghanistan, Capt. Tony Hampton talks about helping soldiers who are contemplating suicide.

title: Inside the List
description: CANT DRIVE 55: Sammy Hagar may have lost his job fronting Van Halen, but he zooms to the top of the hardcover nonfiction list this week with Red: My Uncensored Life in Rock. Hagar has spent the last 25 years locked in a Bush v. Gore-style battle with David Lee Roth over control of the Van Halen mic, and he gives some of the gory details here, though his true feelings can be a bit hard to untangle. I hated Dave. The guy rubbed me wrong, he writes at one point, before adding, Im sure I rub all kinds of people wrong, so its not like Im putting him down.

title: Kate Ryan, Derick Stowe
description: Kate Elizabeth Ryan and Daniel Derickson Stowe were married Saturday afternoon by the Rev. Peter Pichet Saengthien at the Roman Catholic Basilica of St. Louis, King, in St. Louis.

title: Interview with Capt. Tony Hampton
description: About halfway through his deployment to Afghanistan, Capt. Tony Hampton reflects on issues that he encounters as a chaplain.

title: Grooming at a Briefing
description: Grooming at a Briefing

title: Kiddie Pool
description: Kiddie Pool

title: Occupied Territory
description: Occupied Territory

title: Controlled Detonation
description: Controlled Detonation

title: The Future of Nuclear Energy
description: Eric Lichtblau takes reader questions, submitted online, on the future of nuclear power in the United States.

title: Lt. Matthew Vinton
description: During his deployment to Afghanistan, Lt. Matthew Vinton reflects on combat and how it affects his men.

title: Denim in Distress
description: Knowing my weakness for blue jeans, a friend sent a link to a story last month in The Telegraph about  a city in China that produces 260 million pairs of jeans a year. The gist of the article was that high cotton prices are driving local factories out of business and that cool, cheap clothes are becoming a thing of the past.

title: Lori McCoy and Edwin Rossman Jr.
description: ON that November day in 2006, when First Sgt. Edwin Rossman Jr., formerly of HellRaiser Platoon, stood up at the funeral of Staff Sgt. Greg McCoy, his role in the lives of the wife and two young boys left behind by his fallen Iraq War comrade was respectful and narrowly defined.

title: The High Life
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#494", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Obesity and the Mind
description: There are many different explanations for the global obesity epidemic, but heres one I hadnt come across. Petra Jansen and others studied obese children for a forthcoming issue of Appetite and found that these children performed poorly on what is called chronometric mental rotation test, which measures spatial ability. Maybe some people are less astute at judging portion sizes or even their own body mass.

title: Weekend Competition: Wii Knee
description: This weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting modern maladies.

title: Rebecca Kelly, Justin Slaughter
description: Rebecca Joy Kelly and Justin Booth Slaughter were married Saturday evening at the Hotel Monaco in Washington by Saralee Evans, an acting New York State Supreme Court justice, who was granted permission by the Superior Court of the District of Columbia to perform the marriage.

title: Video: Reader Questions on Nuclear Power
description: Read Eric Lichtblaus related story, Lobbyists Long Effort to Revive Nuclear Industry Faces New Test, published on Friday.

title: Fans Get Another Chance to Hear LCD Soundsystems Farewell Concert
description: Fans eager to see James Murphy, the LCD Soundsystem frontman and white T-shirt devotee, croon his paean to Drunk Girls will have another chance. The groups sold-out final concert, on April 2nd at Madison Square Garden, will be streamed live by Pitchfork, the music site announced on Friday.

title: Triangle Fire: In Search of Sweatshops
description: Several days a week, investigators for the Apparel Industry Task Force make surprise visits to garment factories. The 30 or so investigators under the New York State Department of Labor speak many languages and keep tabs on apparel makers throughout the city, looking for unsafe or unfair working conditions.

title: Alexandra Adler and Michael Toccin
description: Alexandra Rochelle Adler, a daughter of Rita N. Adler and Jeffrey A. Adler of Winter Park, Fla., was married in Orlando, Fla., Saturday evening to Michael David Toccin, the son of Ferne J. Toccin and Daniel H. Toccin of Miami. Rabbi Aaron D. Rubinger officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Orlando.

title: Lucy Ward, Matthew Stroup
description: Lucy Jane Ward and Matthew Joseph Stroup were married Saturday evening at the Haygood Memorial United Methodist Church in Atlanta. The Rev. Tavye Morgan, a United Methodist minister, performed a ceremony that incorporated both Methodist and Jewish traditions.

title: Patricia Bissett, James Higgins
description: Patricia Grace Bissett and James Henry Bertram Higgins were married Saturday evening at the Chatham Bars Inn, a hotel in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Where to Turn When the Appliance Warranty Expires
description: IM going to tell you the tale of my refrigerator breakdown and recovery. Now, Im not devoting a column to this because I believe you are all so fascinated by the life of my appliances. But rather, I learned some valuable lessons on the way, and I thought my mistakes and discoveries might help others.

title: Lee Kushnir and Michael Lewittes
description: Lee Kushnir, a daughter of Lynne Kushnir and Dr. Seymour Kushnir of Monsey, N.Y., is to be married Sunday at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in New York to Michael Edison Lewittes, a son of Ruth Lewittes and Joel Lewittes of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, the congregations leader, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Approval for Drug That Treats Melanoma
description: The first drug shown to prolong the lives of people with the skin cancer melanoma won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Friday.

title: Rebecca Silberberg, Eric Levine
description: Rebecca Cory Silberberg, a daughter of Nina P. Silberberg and Dr. Steve H. Silberberg of Manalapan, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Eric Marc Levine, a son of Diane J. Levine and Ross H. Levine of Kings Point, N.Y. Rabbi Dennis C. Tobin officiated at the Crystal Plaza, an event space in Livingston, N.J.

title: Lauren Gilbert , Nicholas Kaplan
description: Lauren Blake Gilbert, the daughter of Andrea L. Gilbert of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., and Michael H. Gilbert of Palm Desert, Calif., was married Friday night to Nicholas Harry Kaplan, a son of Jill P. Jackson of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Steven B. Kaplan of New York. Rabbi Brian Z. Mayer officiated at the Parker Palm Springs, in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Jennifer Alt, Thomas Facelle
description: Dr. Jennifer Narciso Alt and Dr. Thomas Michael Facelle were married Saturday at the Sacred Heart Parish in Suffern, N.Y. Msgr. Joseph Giandurco performed the ceremony.

title: Japan Earthquake and Tsunami Multimedia
description: Videos, photographs and interactive features documenting the destruction in Japan after a powerful earthquake and tsunami devastated the country on March 11.

title: Britten Heft and Gregory Wolfe
description: Britten Leigh Heft, a daughter of Lynn Harris Heft and Donald S. Heft of New York, and Gregory Eugene Wolfe, the son of Eileen Wolfe and Eugene E. Wolfe of Pelham Manor, N.Y., were married Friday evening at the Plaza in New York. Stephen F. Huff, a town justice in Pelham, N.Y., officiated.

title: A Housing Market Cycle Different From Others
description: TO judge by the overall level of home sales in the United States, the housing market has stabilized at a level well below the peak period of 2005 and 2006 but still higher than the sales rates that characterized prosperous periods in the 1980s and 1990s. Still, few of those sales are of new homes and a rising proportion are forced sales of homes no longer worth the amount that was borrowed.

title: Andrea Wissot, Benjamin Wolf
description: Andrea Lynne Wissot and Benjamin David Wolf were married Saturday evening in Palm Springs, Calif. Rabbi Hillel Cohn officiated at the Parker Palm Springs.

title: Seminoles Quietly Make Their Presence Felt
description: SAN ANTONIO - If there is such a thing as tiptoeing into the Round of 16, sneaking in virtually unnoticed, Florida State has done it.

title: Mexicans Fill Pews, Even as Church Is Slow to Adapt
description: Two years ago, St. Josephs Church in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, seemed to be headed for extinction. Attendance at Sunday Masses had fallen below 100. The 159-year-old parishs buildings were crumbling and its coffers were empty.

title: Chris Min and Vincent Huang
description: Sie Ne Chris Min and Dr. Vincent Huang were married Monday by Rose M. Solorio, a deputy commissioner of marriage, at the office of the Orange County Clerk-Recorder Department in Laguna Hills, Calif. On Friday, the couple had a religious ceremony at Pelican Hill, a resort in Newport Beach, Calif. It was led by Rev. Ken Lang, who is affiliated with Calvary Chapel, a nondenominational Christian church.

title: Kate Rose, Michael Gerard
description: Kate Weber Rose and Michael Gerard were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Lynnda Targan at the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Ramona Fastow and Chad Jones
description: Capt. Ramona Lisa Fastow and Capt. Chad Lee Jones are to be married Sunday at the Fox Hollow, an event space in Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Jill Hausman is to officiate.

title: A Closer Look at Spider-Mans New Choreographer
description: Who is Chase Brock? The producers of the troubled Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark are making so many changes  like this and this, not to mention this  that you may be forgiven for not realizing a new choreographer was brought in. That would be Mr. Brock. (More on the switch here.)

title: China Bans Some Foods From Japan
description: BEIJING  China on Friday joined several other nations that have sought to limit potential radioactive contamination from Japan, by banning fish, vegetables and other food products from regions closest to the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant.

title: Insurance Dictated by the Bank
description: Back in November, my bank sent my wife and me a letter asking that we provide proof of flood insurance for the condominium we own in Florida. We did. But three months later, we found ourselves in the midst of a Kafkaesque world, where we were being charged for bank-imposed insurance and couldnt figure out a way to get the bank to take back the insurance and remove the charges.

title: Cuomo and Lawmakers Flirt With Budget Agreement
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the leaders of the State Legislature flirted with an agreement on the state budget on Friday, but several sticking points appeared to stall negotiations by the end of the day.

title: Jugaad: Cheaper Than a Nano, but Watch for Splinters
description: On the wall at the Center for Architecture in Manhattan is a huge image of a rickety, trucklike conveyance cobbled together out of a miscellany of parts. It is a classic example of the vehicles called jugaad in India.

title: A Model Moment | Giovanna Battaglia, Part III
description: After a week of nonstop partying and posing for the paparazzi in So Paulo, Giovanna Battaglia manages to keep herself looking picture-perfect even when lunching with girlfriends. In our final installment of the stylists wardrobe diaries, Battaglia reveals that the key to her charm is actually her lucky talisman: I love this Erdem dress  its floral, laid-back and glamorous, which is the So Paulo way. In addition to my Carla Amorim baubles, I am wearing a pendant my mother designed, which I never take off. Its like my hidden armor!

title: Out of Character, in the Directors Chair
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Revisiting the Cassette Era and Tito Puente
description: Scott Weinrich

title: A Book for @MayorEmanuel
description: Add another entry to the growing publishing genre of Twitter lit. Scribner has acquired the rights to publish a book based on the profanity-laced Twitter feed written by a fake Rahm Emanuel, later revealed to be Dan Sinker. Mr. Sinker, the founding editor of the culture magazine Punk Planet and an assistant professor at Columbia College in Chicago, was anonymously behind the much-followed Twitter feed until he revealed his identity in The Atlantic last month. The book will compile the tweets, annotate them and include Sinkers first-person account of the phenomenon that has attracted legions of followers and media attention, his publisher said in a statement on Friday. Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, plans to release the book  with a foreword by Biz Stone, a founder of Twitter  later this year.

title: Restaurant Review: The Inn at Dos Brisas, Washington, Tex.
description: Food in rural Texas is often peppered, chicken-fried and smothered in gravy  so it might come as a surprise that there is a restaurant in Washington, Tex., about 50 miles west of Houston, which, at least according to two sources, rates on a par with some of the nations most acclaimed restaurants.

title: Letters: Travelers, Not Tourists
description: TRAVELERS, NOT TOURISTS

title: Hotel Review: Media One Hotel in Dubai, United Arab Emirates
description: THE BASICS

title: Astoria, Oregon, Discovers a Waterfront Chic
description: IT was a damp, wind-whipped Thursday night in Astoria, Ore., but inside the Fort George Brewery & Public House an eclectic, standing-room-only crowd kept warm and dry. Ol Danny Barnes, a Washington State-based singer and banjoist, twanged and crooned before a hooting audience of Astorians who had poured into the space on their way home from work. In the crowd were Coast Guard officers, marine biologists, nursing students  and the waitress who had served me lunch earlier that day.

title: In Israel, Treasures for Those Willing to Dig
description: YOU might have mistaken it for a typical summer barbecue: friends sprawled on a sandy ledge, shielded from the sun by a tarp flapping sporadically from an elusive sea breeze, listening to Kings of Leon blare from minispeakers connected to an iPod as they poked at the embers of a campfire.

title: In Dubai, a View From the Burj Khalifa
description: IN a city already stocked with modernist towers, the Burj Khalifa in Dubai is still a notable addition to the skyline. Rising precipitously more than 2,715 feet  just over a half-mile  this tapered stainless steel and glass structure became the worlds tallest building when it opened in January 2010.

title: A Paris Farewell
description: IVE always been one of those girls. A die-hard Francophile. An American helpless in the face of Parisian charms and pleasures. A New Yorker who could never seem to shake the City of Light. I went for a college semester, I went with boyfriends, I went to eat chocolate. And finally, for a two-year period beginning in 2009, I went to live my dream.

title: Guatemala, Trekking in the Highlands
description: WE walked into the village around dusk, but with the fog pouring down the dirt streets, it could have been anytime. It was cold, and I could hardly see across the concrete plaza. The Catholic church had been cleaved by an earthquake, the gap between its two halves now spanned with sheets of plywood, but that didnt stop people from praying in the dank cavern on a floor littered with boughs of long green pine needles.

title: Hidden Design In Stockholm
description: The best places for original wares in Swedens capital are located along the broad boulevards north of the city center in Vasastan.

title: A Waterfront Revival in Astoria, Ore.
description: The 10,000-person city, two hours from Portland, has become a cosmopolitan artists enclave.

title: Paris, Divided
description: Where the Left and Right Bank are divided by the Seine, east and west might make more sense.

title: Grassley Says Only 2 or 3 Republicans Are Qualified for White House
description: 5:11 p.m. | Updated Talk about a cliffhanger.

title: After Facing Many Kerrs, V.C.U. Meets the Real One
description: SAN ANTONIO  Virginia Commonwealth breaks down opposing shooters with one of three designations: Kerr, Rondo or Wade. On the scouting reports, V.C.U. coaches will put a photograph of the opposing guard and a call him a Kerr, a Wade or a Rondo, depending on his playing style.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Dead (Again) Robin?
description: The new book on our hardcover list this week, Gotham Central: Corrigan, at No. 1, is the fourth and final volume of the series. Gotham Central, written by Greg Rucka and Ed Brubaker, is an inside look at the police detectives in the major crime unit who must solve cases in a city populated by Batman, his allies and his gruesome collection of archfoes.

title: Chic Peek | David Beckham in Fantastic Man
description: David Beckham is no stranger to fashion magazines, having appeared in more naked pictorials than Paz de la Huerta. But his latest turn in Fantastic Man finds him fully clothed and in a modest setting. Beckhams first editorial in over a year was shot by Alasdair McLellan in a pie and mash shop in East London.

title: The Pistons Continue to Crumble
description: Once upon a time, Detroit Pistons president of basketball operations Joe Dumars spat in the face of reason. He invested quickly and significantly in two players - Ben Gordon and Charlie Villanueva - using almost the entirety of the teams 2009 cap space and foregoing salary flexibility in a futile attempt at a franchise reboot.

title: Bob Herbert to Leave The Times
description: Bob Herbert, a columnist for The New York Times Op-Ed page, is leaving the paper after nearly 20 years.

title: Plum Role: Historys Ultimate Godfather
description: ALTHOUGH they lived in the 15th and 16th centuries, the Borgias, the subject of a new nine-part Showtime mini-series that begins next Sunday, were a family made for TV. The Borgias were rich, ruthless, scheming and corrupt, and so sexually voracious that, if you believe the rumors, they slept with everyone, including one another. Mario Puzo, who worked on a novel about them, called the Borgias the Corleones of the Renaissance. They also resemble The Sopranos a little. Imagine if Tony, instead of running a garbage hauling business, had bought himself the papacy.

title: The Pitfalls of Wiretaps in White-Collar Crime Cases
description: The wiretaps of conversations between Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group hedge fund manager, and his sources of information appear to provide powerful evidence that he traded on illegal insider tips. The jury in Mr. Rajaratnams insider trading trial can hear what was actually said rather than relying on the sometimes-fuzzy recollections of various witnesses.

title: Aging Without Children
description: Ann Logan and her three sisters grew up in Delaware; none of them have children. Their stepbrother and seven first cousins on both sides are childless, as well. Each of us had different reasons, she told me.

title: If the Taxes Are Done, You Might Consider a Financial Tuneup
description: Its hard to find many people who derive much joy from income tax season. But consider for a moment what you end up with.

title: A Series With Little Action and No Sex, but Lots of Fans
description: LONDON  To explain the appeal of The Killing, a four-year-old, 20-part, subtitled Danish crime thriller that has become an unexpected hit on British television this winter, it helps to describe not so much what the series has, but what it does not.

title: Things to Do on Your Financial Tuneup Day
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I write about my third annual financial tuneup, where I try to cross off as many things as possible on my list of undone money tasks.

title: The Accidental Activist
description: Related: Adventures in Humanitarian Tourism

title: Adventures in Humanitarian Tourism
description: Related: The Accidental Activist, Sean Penn

title: Excerpt: 'The Borgias'
description: The new Showtime mini-series, created by Neil Jordan, is about the corrupt Borgias family of the Renaissance.

title: New York Proposes Delay for Waste Transfer Stations
description: Five years ago, the Bloomberg administration proposed the creation of new waste transfer stations in Manhattan to address a stark inequality among the five boroughs: the disproportionate number of garbage removal operations in poorer communities like areas of the South Bronx.

title: Book Review Podcast: Joseph Lelyveld on Gandhi
description: This week: Joseph Lelyveld revisits Gandhis years in South Africa; The Timess John Schwartz on a new biography of Will Rogers; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Deficits and the Printing Press (Somewhat Wonkish)
description: Right now, deficits dont matter  a point borne out by all the evidence. But theres a school of thought  the modern monetary theory people  who say that deficits never matter, as long as you have your own currency.

title: Carving Out a Bold Destiny for Fado
description: IN the beginning was Amlia Rodrigues. That singer so dominates the modern history of the fado, Portugals soulful, guitar-based national song style, that during a 60-year career brought to an end only with her death in 1999, her name became virtually synonymous with the genre, leaving precious little room for others to flourish.

title: Guess Where This Is: The Answer
description: Our quiz this week drew a lot of guesses. Some readers correctly guessed that the picture was near Durdle Door, in Dorset England. The arch is one of the highlights of the Jurassic Coast, a World Heritage site. But enough readers guessed Cabo San Lucas that we thought it may be helpful to put images of the two side by side  we can see why you guessed it!

title: TimesCast | March 25, 2011
description: Japanese officials recommend a wider evacuation area; in Tokyo, water contamination levels are lower, but residents remain skeptical; and answering readers' questions.

title: European Leaders Press Portugal on Austerity Path
description: BRUSSELS  Faced with the collapse of the government of debt-troubled Portugal, European leaders on Friday called on competing political parties in Lisbon to commit to tough financial targets, while Spain sought to protect itself from contagion by announcing new economic policies.

title: In Wake of Bronx Bus Accident, D.M.V. Response Combines High- and Low-Tech Tools
description: 9:54 a.m. | Updated

title: Pictures of the Day: Jordan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Jordan, Yemen, Libya and Japan.

title: Big Deal | More Changes for Rene Zellweger
description: In the days since the Hollywood couple Rene Zellweger and Bradley Cooper ended their two-year relationship, the tabloids have, of course, chronicled Ms. Zellwegers every move. Among the moves: She was comforted by Sandra Bullock; she was reading the best seller Social Animal: The Hidden Sources of Love, Character and Achievement; she attended opening night of Priscilla Queen of the Desert on Broadway; she went to a birthday party for Robert De Niros son Elliot; and she went to another birthday party, where she wore a skin-tight black dress and fabulous lace-up shoes.

title: First Food, Then Sneakers
description: Marcus Samuelsson, 40, is an award-winning chef, a cookbook author, a philanthropist, a founder of the new Web site FoodRepublic.com and the owner of the restaurant Red Rooster Harlem, where President Obama will hold his next Democratic National Committee fund-raiser, on March 29. CHLOE MALLE

title: The 2012 Fiat 500
description: The modern version of Italys Cinquecento comes to America.

title: Still Tiny After All These Years
description: From its birth in 1936, the diminutive 500 was a true peoples car.

title: Resilience
description: None of us is looking to sustain a serious head injury, but Janelle Jones and some colleagues conducted a survey of 630 people who had sustained serious injuries with the help of Headway UK. She found that survivors of serious head injuries are much more satisfied with their lives than others. They seem to regard themselves as survivors. They tell stories about their lives that emphasize resilience and bouncing back. Whats more, they relied on strong social support networks to get through their injuries. The write up of the study in Psychology and Health carries the apt title: That Which Doesnt Kill Us Can Make Us Stronger.

title: Ts Spring Travel Issue
description: The latest Spring Travel issue of T magazine heads to Haiti with the actor Sean Penn, who spent most of the last year in the country coordinating a remarkably effective relief effort. Zo Hellers profile helps us see the beauty beneath the devastation and the generosity behind the usually guarded star. The writer Wells Tower also takes a timely journey, this one through Humboldt County, the cannabis-growing hub of California (much in the news recently) with a lovably cantankerous local culture and an impossibly gorgeous landscape. Nature is also the lure in Newfoundland, Canada, which, as Mark Schatzker learns, is perhaps the best place to catch and eat a wild Atlantic salmon, a fish most of us have only eaten farmed. Elsewhere in the issue are more cerebral pleasures, as in Trieste, a legendary Italian redoubt for thinkers and flneurs, and Beirut, Lebanon, where Joumana Haddad is creating a stir with her erotic writing  as well as plenty of sybaritic pursuits: a luxurious new boot-camp spa in Laguna, Calif.; a revived, post-recession London filled with new restaurants, shops and bars; and a lively music scene revolves around the beer halls and nightclubs of Hamburg, Germany, a playground forever enshrined by the Beatles. See all stories from the issue >>

title: More Ask the Film Critics
description: Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer your questions in a monthly column that appears in print and online. (In this weeks Arts and Leisure section, they talk about the formative movies of their youth, revisiting previous reviews and letting the proverbial cat out of the bag.) For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: Groups Demand Data on Radiation Release
description: As the Japanese authorities order a wider evacuation area around the stricken Fukushima reactor complex to as far out as 19 miles, three health and environmental groups in the United States announced that they were seeking further information about why American officials recommended that its citizens keep at least 50 miles away.

description: Photographs from Jordan, Yemen, Libya and Japan.

description: Chapter One

description: Introduction
