description: To the Editor:

title: A Point Guard Develops for Tar Heels
description: NEWARK  After Georgia Tech trounced North Carolina, 78-58, on Jan. 16, Tar Heels Coach Roy Williams decided to change his starting point guard, demoting Larry Drew II and promoting Kendall Marshall, a freshman from Dumfries, Va., who had been seeing some playing time.

title: Designing for Earthquakes: Assessing the Risks
description: By determining the likelihood and severity of an earthquake, engineers can improve the safety of nuclear facilities.

title: Chicago Embraces Teams as Other Cities Are Jilted
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Every Revolution Is Revolutionary in Its Own Way
description: London

title: Misplaced Priorities at a Session on Schools
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Countering Radiation Fears With Just the Facts
description: As soon as David J. Brenner heard about the undersea earthquake and subsequent tsunami that devastated northern Japan on March 11, he checked a map of the regions nuclear power plants. One, because of its coastal location and reactor design, looked particularly vulnerable: Fukushima Daiichi. He hoped he was wrong.

title: Cabrini-Green to Exit With Poetry and Lights
description: The last high-rise at Cabrini-Green is coming down starting Wednesday, stirring strong emotions among former residents who remember the troubled housing project as their home and community, as well as a place of menace. Those feelings will emerge in an unusual light display that will accompany the demolition.

title: A Dream Still Deferred
description: AT first glance, the numbers released by the Census Bureau last week showing a precipitous drop in Detroits population  25 percent over the last decade  seem to bear a silver lining: most of those leaving the city are blacks headed to the suburbs, once the refuge of mid-century white flight.

title: Documents Reveal Pressure to Comply With Program to Deport Immigrants
description: Federal immigration officials, frustrated by the refusal of Chicago and Cook County to join a controversial program aimed at deporting immigrants with criminal records, pressed Mayor Richard M. Daley and Sheriff Tom Dart in an aggressive campaign to obtain participation from reluctant police authorities, according to internal documents.

title: Syria Detains Egyptian-American Blogger
description: In an apparent attempt to bolster the Syrian governments claim that this weeks protests were the result of a foreign plot, Syrian state television has broadcast what it called a confession by an Egyptian-American who was detained in Damascus on Friday.

title: Sonoma Plaza
description: Sonomas 8.5-acre plaza celebrates both the towns colorful history and its present prosperity. Selected as a prime location for settlement by a missionary 188 years ago, the little village with the biggest plaza in California has blossomed into a tourist magnet. HANK PELLISSIER

title: Unrest in Syria and Jordan Poses New Test for U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Even as the Obama administration defends the NATO-led air war in Libya, the latest violent clashes in Syria and Jordan are raising new alarm among senior officials who view those countries, in the heartland of the Arab world, as far more vital to American interests.

title: Honest Numbers and Their Maker
description: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Howards Other Side
description: Every player looks to improve during his career, but the Orlando Magic would probably be happier if Dwight Howard, above in a dispute with the referee John Goble, would stop his improvement at collecting technical fouls.

title: Pressures Continue to Mount for the Troubled Oakland Police
description: Last fall, after 21 years at the Oakland Police Department, Sgt. Robert Glock was fired for dishonesty.

title: President of Yemen Vows to Stay
description: SANA, Yemen  A day after he said he was ready to yield power to safe hands, President Ali Abdullah Saleh asserted Saturday that his departure was not imminent, leaving unclear when and under what terms he would agree to step down.

title: N.H.L. Puts Freeze on Games in Russia
description: The Rangers and the Washington Capitals will not open the 2011-12 N.H.L. season in Russia, nor will any N.H.L. clubs play Kontinental Hockey League clubs in exhibition games in Russia next fall.

title: Butler Claws Its Way Back to Final Four
description: NEW ORLEANS  After Butlers charmed run to the national title game last year came up inches short of victory, President Obama made the rare gesture of telephoning the losing team to offer his congratulations.

title: Uncanny Partnership of Morris and Morris
description: SAN ANTONIO  Their mother said Marcus and Markieff Morris were fraternal twins. Good luck finding any that are more identical.

title: North Carolina Rises From Last Seasons Ashes
description: NEWARK  A fire alarm squawked through Prudential Center midway through a news conference featuring North Carolina Coach Roy Williams and his five starters Saturday, and Williams joked over the din that his talented team could beat it out of the arena faster than most opponents.

title: Bus That Hit and Killed Cyclist Is Located
description: Investigators have found the city bus that struck and killed a delivery man on the Upper East Side on Friday afternoon.

title: Corrections
description: METROPOLITAN

title: A Rivalry of Elites and Sharp Elbows
description: NEWARK  Kentucky and North Carolina have their own circle-the-date rivals on the schedule each season: Louisville for the Wildcats, Duke for the Tar Heels. But the two programs are entwined in their own history.

title: Laird Stays in Control as Woods Stumbles
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Martin Laird of Scotland clung to his overnight lead at the Arnold Palmer Invitational on Saturday, overcoming back-to-back bogeys late in the third round with a strong finish on Bay Hills tough final three holes. Laird closed with a two-under-par 70 that widened his lead over Spencer Levin (71) to two strokes.

title: American Student Held By Syria, His Father Says
description: WASHINGTON  An American student missing in Syria for several days amid a swirl of protests has been detained by Syrian security officers, the mans father said Saturday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: John Cashin Jr. Dies at 82; Campaigned for Civil Rights
description: John L. Cashin Jr., a civil rights campaigner who was the first black candidate for governor of Alabama since Reconstruction, mounting an unsuccessful challenge in 1970 to the arch-segregationist George C. Wallace, died on Monday in Washington, where he lived in recent years. He was 82.

title: Ralph Mooney, Master of the Steel Guitar, Dies at 82
description: Ralph Mooney, who played pedal steel guitar on hit recordings by Merle Haggard and Waylon Jennings and who was a writer of Crazy Arms, one of the most enduring shuffles in country music, died at his home in Kennedale, Tex., on Sunday. He was 82.

title: Health Procedures Costs Vary Widely Across State
description: The cost of common medical procedures paid for by Medicaid  the joint state-federal health care program for indigent children, the disabled and the very poor  varies dramatically by hospital and region, according to a Texas Tribune analysis of claims by and payments to hundreds of hospitals statewide.

title: Looking Back on Life as a Death House Warden
description: HUNTSVILLE  Jim Willett has never hit anyone in his life, never even wanted to hurt anyone. But at the height of his career, this mild-mannered, white-haired man with reading glasses perched on the end of his nose was responsible for carrying out 89 executions.

title: Nordiques Nation Is Headed to Newark
description: Nordiques Nation is returning to the New York area.

title: Vows: Ramona and Chad
description: Capt. Ramona Fastow and Capt. Chad Jones met at the beginning of a deployment to Afghanistan. It was a tactical operation to keep their love under wraps until their tour was over.

title: Muni Chief Under Fire for Record and Absences
description: Last week, Nathaniel Ford, the chief executive of the San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency, was in a familiar place: not San Francisco.

title: Huskies Pull Together
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Coach Jim Calhoun ascended the ladder last, after all the freshmen he relied upon this season, after all the role players who took a star turn Saturday, after even Kemba Walker, the Connecticut star for whom Calhoun has run out of adjectives to describe.

title: No Margin for Error
description: In general, if a team wants to succeed, it helps to score more points than it allows. But over the course of a season, that does not always have to be true.

title: Anthonys High Point Cant Raise the Knicks
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Mike DAntonis offense deteriorated into the Carmelo Anthony show Saturday night, with Anthony driving into the lane, posting up, spotting up, usually shooting and often scoring.

title: States Struggle With Minors Sexting
description: In the last two years, legislators have been weighing graduated responses to sexting between minors. Some legal scholars refer to the images as self-produced child pornography.

title: What Theyre Saying About Sexting
description: The New York Times interviewed teenagers individually and in two focus groups. The first, in Manhattan, was organized by the Anti-Defamation League, which offers cyberbullying prevention programs. The second, with students from Lower Merion, a Philadelphia suburb, was coordinated by Stephanie Newberg, a therapist who works with adolescents, and Paula Singer, a community organizer.

title: A Girls Nude Photo, and Altered Lives
description: LACEY, Wash.  One day last winter Margarite posed naked before her bathroom mirror, held up her cellphone and took a picture. Then she sent the full-length frontal photo to Isaiah, her new boyfriend.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 27
description: As the United States works with its allies to define an endgame in Libya, Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will appear on several Sunday talk shows to try to help clarify the mission to the American people.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 26, 2011

title: Its Business to the Rescue at a Tournament in Texas
description: Tournament organizers struggle to find sponsors, particularly in the United States. Though chess has a reputation as a worthwhile game to learn and play, it is not as easy to market as, say, poker.

title: Theyre New, Theyre Conservative, and They Say Theyre Here to Make Cuts
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Four Hotels With Spice, Allure and the Liz Lambert Touch
description: If youre looking for Liz Lambert, the West Texas-born hotelier, she might be in San Antonio, perfecting hand-chipped-ice margaritas in her new restaurant at the historic Hotel Havana. She may be meeting guests at the Saint Cecilia, her quietly luxurious property in Austin, where bungalows have Swedish Hastens mattresses and guests sip throwback cocktails at a private bar shaded by live oaks. Or, if the South by Southwest festival is in full swing, youre likely to find her in Austin chatting with musicians outside the Hotel San Jos, converted from a seedy by-the-hour motel to a Zen-like retreat  the first property in her hotel empire.

title: Driver Is Shot Dead by Police After Bronx Car Chase
description: A fugitive facing charges that could have sent him to prison for 25 years led the police on a six-mile chase through the Bronx early Saturday, battering vehicles in his way, but was cornered in a traffic jam and killed in a hail of 19 police bullets when, the authorities said, he tried to run over several officers.

title: Yankees Feliciano Faces His First Trip to the Disabled List
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It sounds almost hard to believe, but Pedro Feliciano swears it is the truth. The last time he visited a training room  for anything more than an ice pack, a heat wrap or the occasional anti-inflammatory medicine  came in 1999, which he sat out with a shoulder injury.

title: In Pagans Eyes, a Gift Often Overlooked
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Early Saturday morning, with the sun low and the dew glistening on the grass, Angel Pagan leaned back against the batting cage at home plate, his arms folded, and started reading. The small print on an advertising sign was more than 400 feet away, in letters about three and a half inches high, and Pagan could see it vividly.

title: V.C.U.s Brightest Star May Be the Head Coach
description: SAN ANTONIO  Shaka Smart has lived his basketball life mostly in obscurity, as a player at Division III Kenyon College in Ohio and as an assistant coach at five other universities. But now in his second season as the coach at Virginia Commonwealth, Smart, a slight 33-year-old with a buzz cut and a faint goatee, is the N.C.A.A. tournaments breakout star.

title: Teenage Strikers Energy Propels U.S. to a Tie
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The United States national team adopted a new motto on Saturday: Indivisible, which was emblazoned on their new red jerseys. In stark contrast, Saturdays 1-1 tie against Argentina in an international friendly match was divided neatly into two tidy 45-minute halves  the first dominated by the visitors, the second belonging to the Americans.

title: High Praise From One Who Knows
description: NEW ORLEANS  In the most recent generation of college basketball, comparisons to Floridas back-to-back N.C.A.A. title teams may be the highest compliment in the sport. So when Florida Coach Billy Donovan brought up those teams when talking about Butler, it was an impressive comparison.

title: Just Short of Final Four, but Arizona Goes Home Proud
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  There was something mysteriously serene about the look on Derrick Williamss face.

title: Back to the Final Four
description: Butler, which last year made an electrifying run to the N.C.A.A. tournament title game, booked its return ticket to the national semifinals after a 74-71 victory over Florida on Saturday.

title: Watching Argentina Up Close, Hoping to Learn Something
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: A Barrier-Breaking Woman on a Major-Party Ticket
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, who died Saturday, removed the men only sign from the White House door with her vice-presidential candidacy in 1984.

title: Tainted Water at 2 Reactors Increases Alarm for Japanese
description: This article is by  David Jolly,  Hiroko Tabuchi and  Keith Bradsher.

title: At Istanbul Festival, Foreign and Homegrown Films
description: On April 2, the curtain rises on the 30th annual Istanbul Film Festival, offering two weeks of nearly nonstop screenings of Hollywood blockbusters, Oscar winners and international box office hits at seven theaters around town. But for visitors, the festival is also a rare chance to see Turkish films with English subtitles.

title: Vettel, and F1, Pick Up Where They Left Off Last Year
description: MELBOURNE  Not even a raft of new technical regulations could change the physiognomy of a Formula One race as the season debuted at the Australian Grand Prix at Melbourne on Sunday.

title: Vettel, and F1, Pick Up Where They Left Off Last Year
description: MELBOURNE  Not even a raft of new technical regulations could change the physiognomy of a Formula One race as the season debuted at the Australian Grand Prix at Melbourne on Sunday.

title: Social Ills Feed Rise of Far-Right Party in France
description: HNIN-BEAUMONT, France  The far-right National Front, under the new leadership of Marine Le Pen, is sending shivers through Frances political world in the maneuvering for the 2012 presidential elections. Ms. Le Pen, a more telegenic and less cheerfully divisive figure than her father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, is getting around 20 percent in early opinion polls, putting her about even with the main parties of the right and left.

title: Photoshop Express 2.0 Says Kill That Noise!
description: Photoshop, the photo-editing software that is so ubiquitous that it has become a verb (Photoshop that blemish) has upped the features and price of its iPhone picture editing software.

title: Rex Ryan and Wes Welker Had History of Trading Barbs
description: If the season is canceled, one thing that will be sorely missed is the Jets-Patriots rivalry. Heres a postscript to the wacky week leading into their playoff game in January:

title: A Place to Connect
description: The Times reports on Sunday on the plight of New Yorks 256 senior centers, many of which have been threatened by budget cuts over the last two years. The centers feed about 28,000 elderly people at a cost of about $86 million a year. John Leland takes a close look at Seaside, a center situated on a windswept strip of land separated from the rest of Queens by the waters of Jamaica Bay.

title: Napoleonic War Finance
description: I was doing a bit of random research related to the whole credibility/deficits issue, basically for fun  theres more important stuff to worry about now  and came across a fascinating [/Spock] paper by Bordo and White on Napoleonic War finance. They point out that there was a remarkable and surprising contrast between Britain and France. Britain relied heavily on deficit finance:

title: Libyan Rebels March Toward Qaddafi Stronghold
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  American and European bombs battered Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis most important bastion of support in his tribal homeland of Surt on Sunday night, as rebels seeking his ouster capitalized on the damage from the Western airstrikes to erase their recent losses and return to the citys doorstep.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Denis Villeneuve
description: Family, love, war and history are all explored in the French-Canadian drama Incendies, nominated this year for a foreign-language Oscar, opening in theaters April 22 and screening in the New Directors/New Films series. The film, adapted from Wajdi Mouawads play, was first performed in 2003. In this video, the director Denis Villeneuve, discusses the film adaptation and its look at one familys connections to the Middle East. Mr. Villeneuve spoke about the scope of the stories in the film, his connection to family and more.

title: Digital Subscription Plan Begins March 28
description: The Times on Monday will start a digital subscription plan for access to NYTimes.com and mobile applications. Under this plan, the home page, section fronts and blog fronts will continue to be free. Users will also be able to read 20 full-length articles per month free on NYTimes.com.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Argentina
description: For the first 45 minutes of Saturday nights 1-1 tie against Argentina, the United States national team seemed entirely focused on trying not to lose. Coach Bob Bradley opened the game with a defensive-minded 4-5-1 formation and placed 10  and sometimes all 11  players behind the ball as he tried to keep the dangerous Argentines off the scoreboard.

title: Searching, Waiting and Mourning in Japan
description: Efforts continued on Sunday to locate over 17,000 people still missing; families buried their loved ones; sharply elevated levels of radiation were detected at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex.

title: Remembering a Brooklyn Publisher Who Kept the News Local
description: Hong Kong Flu Hits Bay Ridge, screamed the headline. And just in case readers in December 1968 were not already alarmed, a smaller headline below warned: Its Upon Us!

title: Clinton and Gates Defend Mission in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  The United States military intervention in Libya has saved perhaps tens of thousands of lives, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said Sunday, as she and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates defended a mission they acknowledged is drawing increasing skepticism from both liberals and conservatives.

title: The Endless Game of a Lifetime, Recalled by a Baseball Lifer
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Our planning went no further than to meet at the ballpark. Simple in theory but madness in practice, given the thousands of others with similar plans. My only hope was to find a white-haired man exuding boyish wonder; who looked as if he was about to see a baseball game for the 10,000th time  and for the first.

title: Trylle Trilogy Film Rights Are Sold
description: Has Hollywood just found another big teenage film franchise? Media Rights Capital, a prominent film financier and production company, has snapped up the rights to the Trylle Trilogy book series by Amanda Hocking, the 26-year-old self-publishing wunderkind. The company plans to make three novels into two movies, and Terri Tatchell, a co-writer of the hit science-fiction film District 9, is already at work on the screenplays.

title: 40 Afghans Kidnapped by Insurgents
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents kidnapped 40 men in an ambush in the northeastern province of Kunar on Saturday, Afghan officials said. And a suicide bomber killed 13 people and wounded 56 others in the eastern province of Paktika on Sunday, according to initial NATO reports, although the toll was still being assessed.

title: Syria Tries to Ease Deep Political Crisis
description: CAIRO  The Syrian government tried to ease a grave political crisis on Sunday by blaming armed gangs for killing 12 people in the northwestern port city of Latakia in previous days and promising to soon lift a draconian emergency law that allows the government to detain people without charges.

title: Gingrich on Bill Clinton: Its Not About Personal Behavior
description: Is Newt Gingrich a hypocrite?

title: UConn Women Rally to Avoid Upset Against Georgetown
description: PHILADELPHIA  Connecticut avoided one of the biggest upsets in the history of the womens N.C.A.A. basketball tournament on Sunday, trailing much of the way before rallying to defeat Georgetown, 68-63, in the semifinals of the Philadelphia regional.

title: Merkel Loses Key German State on Nuclear Fears
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels conservative Christian Democrats on Sunday suffered a major defeat in a historic stronghold in southwestern Germany, where the Green Party appeared poised to head a state government for the first time, according to official preliminary results.

title: Investing Like Its 1999
description: Banks pouring money into technology funds, wealthy clients and institutions clamoring to get pieces of start-ups, expectations of stock market debuts building  as Wall Streets machinery kicks into second gear, some investors with memories of the Internet bust a decade earlier are wondering whether this sudden burst of activity spells danger for the industry once again.

title: Rebels Advance as Government Troops Withdraw
description: Rebel fighters, emboldened after retaking the crossroads city of Ajdabiya in eastern Libya, pushed westward along the main coastal road to Ras Lanuf, the site of a major refinery complex.

title: Wages and Employment, Yet Again
description: Oh, my. Even Matt Yglesias doesnt quite get it.

title: First Four to Final Four: V.C.U. Stuns Kansas
description: SAN ANTONIO  The team that so many thought should not be in the tournament rushed the floor at the final buzzer, then delved deep into the crowd for hugs and disbelieving smiles as another vanquished and surprised opponent shuffled silently off the court.

title: The Euro Straitjacket
description: I think Dean Baker and I are converging on deficits and independent currencies. He asserts that having your own currency makes a big difference  you can still end up like Zimbabwe, but not like Greece right now. Im fine with that.

title: Awkward Embraces, Assured Directors
description: One of the reliable pleasures of New Directors/New Films is that at one point in this annual festival  or, if its a good year, five or more points  a director will light up the screen with an unexpected burst of beauty, a swoop of the camera, a moment of grace. She may not revolutionize the art, but she will make you sit up, and focus your eyes and mind. The monologue running in your head that becomes louder in unmemorable movies (Im thirsty, whats for dinner?, thats a nice lamp) doesnt stand a chance against a film like Attenberg, a highlight of the second week of the festival, which ends Sunday.

title: American Dance Festival
description: Along with premieres by Paul Taylor and Pilobolus, among others, this years American Dance Festival will be notable as the final one led by Charles L. Reinhart. After 43 years as director of the annual event, now in Durham, N.C., Mr. Reinhart has announced he will retire at the end of 2011, to be succeeded by his co-director, Jodee Nimerichter. This years festival, Something New, Something Treasured, will run from June 9 through July 23, opening with a gala in Mr. Reinharts honor and including work by Twyla Tharp, Bill T. Jones, Eiko & Koma and Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker. Information: americandancefestival.org.

title: In Soviet-Style Belarus, Crackdown Extends to Those Outside Politics
description: MINSK, Belarus  Andrei Vilkin has long been celebrated in Belarus for his skills as a karate master and a coach. The patriarch of a family of decorated martial artists, he has filled his living room with the hallmarks of his success: trophies from world championships and national awards for service to the motherland.

title: Wimpy Kid Is Strongest
description: In an embarrassment for Warner Brothers, which spent over $100 million to make and market the fantasy thriller Sucker Punch, an inexpensive childrens movie from 20th Century Fox  Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules  was No. 1 at the weekend box office. Rodrick, with Zachary Gordon and Laine MacNeil, above, is the second in the Wimpy Kid series. It was produced for about $21 million and sold an estimated $24.4 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. Sucker Punch, directed by Zack Snyder and partly financed by Legendary Pictures, was second with about $19 million. A forceful marketing campaign could not overcome abysmal reviews and a lack of interest (aside from young men) for the story line, in which a group of scantily clad, gun-toting women try to escape from an insane asylum. Limitless (Relativity Media) was third in its second week with about $15.2 million for a new total of $41.3 million. The Lincoln Lawyer (Lionsgate) was fourth, selling $11 million for a two-week total of about $30 million. Rango (Paramount Pictures) was fifth, with $9.8 million to lift its four-week total to about $106.4 million.

title: A Musicians Musician Receives His Tribute
description: Before the songwriter Alex Chilton died in March 2010 the producer and guitarist Chris Stamey was already working on a quixotic project: live performances of Big Stars entire album Third (also known as Sister Lovers), made in 1974, when the band was essentially Mr. Chilton and the drummer Jody Stephens with studio musicians. The concert Big Stars Third, first presented last year in North Carolina, came to Mason Hall at Baruch College on Saturday night.

title: Monday: Lies in the Sun
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Making a debut as a crossword constructor in The New York Times is a pretty nifty thing. I personally hyperventilated when I got my first acceptance from Will Shortz, and even his rejections are so kind that Ive had to read them through more than once to make sure Id actually been rejected. Add to that the admiration and amazement of friends and family, as you regale them over and over with tales of construction woes and punny challenges, and its enough to keep your head swelled long after these same people have stopped taking your phone calls.

title: Who Killed This Womans Lover? And Other Elusive Operatic Issues
description: There was encouraging evidence on Friday night that the struggling New York City Opera is making smart moves and continuing to rebound. It was the premiere of Monodramas, a triple bill of one-act works that are not operas in any traditional sense. Before the performance so many ticket buyers, including noticeable numbers of young people, were lined up in the lobby of the David H. Koch Theater waiting to get inside that the curtain had to be delayed more than 20 minutes to accommodate them.

title: The Sacred Art and Ritual of Hawaiian Hula Warm Up a Cold Night
description: Many indigenous dance forms are reflections of the same human impulses: to tell stories, to explain human history, to express relationships to the natural world and to honor ancestors and the gods. Its fascinating to think about how variously those impulses have evolved in different cultures, and its tempting to extrapolate national characteristics from the way people move. (Thats true even for dance forms with different kinds of origins: ballet lovers like nothing better than to discuss the differences between, say, French and Danish ways of holding the arms or jumping.)

title: A Tour of Two Continents: Jaunty Mexican Musings to Somber Cosmic Questions
description: Alondra de la Parra, a dynamic young Mexican conductor and graduate of the Manhattan School of Music, founded the Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas in 2004 to promote performers and composers from the Americas.

title: Revisiting and Recharging an Album With a Fleshed-Out Crew
description: Sentiment is neither what you want nor expect from Queens of the Stone Age. So it stood to reason that Josh Homme, its callous, acerbic frontman, would be matter-of-fact about his mission at Terminal 5 on Friday night. The band was there to play through its self-titled 1998 debut album, which has just been reissued on Rekords Rekords/Domino. That gesture, though retrospective by design, felt bleached of any trace of nostalgia onstage.

title: Artistic Nostalgia (Cookies Served)
description: Sarah Maxfield doesnt have to try hard to create a cozy atmosphere around her new work, We deserve each other. As audience members filed into the Chocolate Factory on Thursday night, she cheerfully served black-and-white cookies, waited patiently for everyone to settle in and then began asking questions: Do you remember the first time you took the subway? Do you remember the first time you saw the city at night?

title: N.Y. Budget Deal Cuts Aid to Schools and Health Care
description: Capping weeks of secretive negotiations and intense political jockeying, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature on Sunday announced a $132.5 billion budgetagreement that would cut overall spending, impose no major new taxes and begin a long-term overhaul of New York States bloated Medicaid programs.

title: A Former Child Star Returns, With Wisdom
description: When Daisy Eagan won a Tony Award at the age of 11 for her performance in The Secret Garden, she was so dazed, and so unfamiliar with the protocol of the ceremony, that when she left the stage and a crew member reached out to take the award from her, she thought that she had done something wrong and the honor was being revoked.

title: Detective Meets His End, Sort Of
description: At the end of The Troubled Man, Henning Mankell needs only six short lines of narrative to pull the plug on his enormously popular series of Kurt Wallander detective novels. Mr. Mankell doesnt do this delicately. After that there is nothing more, the swan song reads in part. The story of Kurt Wallander is finished, once and for all. As an irritable kiss-off to his readers this couldnt be any more abrupt.

title: In the Confessional Booth With Plenty to Confess
description: Kiefer Sutherland may have left television behind for his latest project, but he brought along the sound effects of 24: the hollow pock-pock of the silenced handgun, the crunchy-cereal noise of kneecaps being pulverized.

title: Oprah Winfrey Sets Date for Finale
description: The last original episode of The Oprah Winfrey Show has been scheduled: the 25th and final season of the program will end on May 25, Harpo Productions, the shows producer, confirmed to The Associated Press. Ms. Winfrey posted to her Twitter account last week that she was hard at work planning the final shows, which are to begin on April 7. Details on which celebrity might be jumping up and down on her couch for the last time, or which decadent prizes will be hidden under the seats of those in the audience, have not been released.

title: Bret Michaels Files Suit
description: Bret Michaels, the lead singer of the band Poison, filed a lawsuit against Tony Award Productions, CBS and others, claiming that they were responsible for the accident that lead to his near-fatal brain hemorrhage last year, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Mr. Michaels was treated for a broken nose and received stitches for a split lip after he was struck by a descending backdrop while exiting the stage after a performance at the 2009 Tony Awards. In the suit, filed on Friday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Mr. Michaels alleged that he was not properly informed of how to leave the stage safely, which led to his injury and eventually to his brain hemorrhage last April. Representatives from Tony Award Productions and CBS have not responded.

title: The Choice Is Charybdis
Devoted to Echoes of a Composers Brief Career
description: Chopins cello sonata, Verdis string quartet and Hugo Wolfs String Quartet in D minor are neglected in part because the composers demonstrated greater and more prolific talent in other genres  in Wolfs case, lieder.

title: Hair Club Hitches Its Sidecar to a Biker Theme
description: IT is among the most memorable  and parodied  lines from a television commercial: Sy Sperling, who in 1976 founded Hair Club for Men, would end his pitches in the 1980s and 1990s by saying, Im not only the Hair Club president, but Im also a client. As he delivered the line, Mr. Sperling, who appeared to have a full head of hair, held up a photograph in which he was nearly completely bald.

title: What Did Wisconsinites Vote For?
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Rolls Out First Mobile Battery of Antirocket System
description: BEERSHEBA, Israel  The Israeli military deployed the first mobile battery of a new antirocket missile defense system on Sunday on a dusty rise at the outskirts of this southern Israeli city after a week of heightened tensions between Israel and Gaza.

title: False Confessions
description: To the Editor:

title: One Overtrick Looms Large
description: In addition to the Geeske Joel squad, featured in Saturdays column, the other team that tied for the Machlin Womens Swiss Teams at the recent Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., was Joyce Hampton of Blythewood, S.C.; Jenny Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla.; Sabine Auken from Denmark; Daniela von Arnim from Germany; and Bndicte Cronier and Sylvie Willard from France.

title: Drug Treatment for Prisoners in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Paying for Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: States Bills on Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: Program by the Book: Orchestral Colors? Check. Solo Showcase? Check.
description: Seven years into the tenure of its music director, Peter Oundjian, the Toronto Symphony Orchestra has emerged from a period of financial and administrative turmoil. The orchestra seems to be flourishing musically too, having instituted an annual contemporary-music festival and attracted major guest artists. On Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall the results of Mr. Oundjians careful work were clear. The orchestra sounded bright and confident, though the program was uneven.

title: Shakespearean Plot Twists, Maybe Even by Shakespeare
description: Praying to, denouncing or otherwise addressing the gods? Tilt your head back and cup your hands so that they can hear you. Feeling pangs of conscience? Buckle forward, clutch your stomach and groan. Referring to these eyes? Be sure to point at your eyes.

title: Caught Up in the Online Video Stream
description: Online video gained few viewers over the 12-month period ended Jan. 31. The number of people who watched videos online in January was only 3.1 percent higher than in January 2010, according to the Nielsen Company.

title: Getting Set to Head North, Mets Wonder What Isringhausen Has Left in the Tank
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The Mets have serious concerns about the health of Jason Isringhausens right elbow, which has been operated on six times, most recently in 2009. As they ponder one of their final roster decisions, they are judging the talent and the experience that the 38-year-old Isringhausen brings against the fear that keeping him on the 25-man roster could prove costly.

title: For Vodafone in India, a Swift but Bumpy Rise
Kentucky Returns to Where Its Expected
description: NEWARK  Kentucky measures success based on the banners hanging from Rupp Arena. Final Fours and national titles are the only forms of currency there.

title: Long-Form Journalism Finds a Home
description: In 2009, Evan Ratliff, a freelance writer for Wired, and Nicholas Thompson, a senior editor there, had just concluded a particularly satisfying article in which Mr. Ratliff tried to drop off the grid for a month and obscure his whereabouts in the digital age, while Wired magazine offered $5,000 to the person who could find him.

title: Eminem Lawsuit May Raise Pay for Older Artists
description: The most closely watched lawsuit in the music industry asks this question: how much should a song on iTunes or another digital music service be worth to the performer?

title: Semantics Complicate N.F.L. Labor Stalemate
description: N.F.L. players are expected to file their reply Monday to the leagues brief in an antitrust case, bringing the parties closer to a courtroom showdown that will probably determine when  or if  negotiations toward a new contract resume this spring.

title: Granderson Improves
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Curtis Grandersons recovery from a strained right internal oblique muscle is progressing rapidly, raising the possibility that he could play Thursday at Yankee Stadium against the Tigers.

title: Gates and Clinton Unite to Defend Libya Intervention, and Say It May Last Awhile
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates acknowledged Sunday that the unrest in Libya did not pose an immediate threat to the United States. Even so, he and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said the Obama administration was justified in taking military action to avert a massacre there that could have altered the course of the popular revolts roiling the Arab world.

title: Ethical Quandary for Social Sites
description: Two days after using Flickr to display photos of police officers from Egypts feared state security force, Hossam el-Hamalawy watched in disbelief as they vanished, one by one, from the popular social networking site, which he had been using since 2008.

title: Russian Site Smokes Out Corruption
description: MOSCOW  Before the Internet, a Russian dissident might have hoped to reach dozens of sympathetic readers with a mimeographed samizdat publication of forbidden material.

title: Helped by Stockton, Compared to Gretzky
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  In this quiet eastern Washington town rich in timber, metals and wheat, fun is another product to be manufactured from raw materials. This is not a problem for the members of the Gonzaga womens basketball team, who derive great amusement by extending invitations to their practices to friends or relatives or, better yet, encouraging vainglorious men to join them in a pickup game at the university gym.

title: Libyans Call Woman Who Claimed Gang Rape a Prostitute
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The Libyan authorities on Sunday attacked the character and credibility of a Libyan woman who burst into a hotel full of foreign journalists to say that she had been abducted and raped by militia members working for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, calling her a known prostitute and a thief.

title: Opportunities and Perils for Obama in Military Action in Libya
description: Politicians define themselves by choosing enemies, and exemplars. Suddenly, President Obamas choices on Libya are reshaping his profile in unpredictable ways as he heads into the 2012 election season.

title: The Future of Manufacturing Is Local
description: Think manufacturing, and most likely your brain defaults to abandoned factories, outsourcing and economically devastated regions like the Rust Belt. So strong is our tendency to focus on American manufacturing as something thats been lost that a chorus has risen up to decry the prevalence of ruin porn  those aestheticized versions of the decidedly un-pretty, with a particular focus on the once-triumphant automotive center of the universe, Detroit.

title: The New Grave Robbers
description: Newton, Mass.

title: For $1,000, Site Lets Celebrities Say It Aint So
description: LONDON  Imagine you are a well-known person aggrieved by how you are portrayed on the Internet: the slapdash Wikipedia entry; the unflattering gossip item; the endlessly repeated story about how you cheated on your spouse when in point of fact you were blamelessly resuscitating a platonic friend who was choking on an olive.

title: Senior Tour Tightens Its Focus on the Big Three
description: Last May, the Hall of Fame tennis player Jim Courier and his business partner Jon Venison left Boston after staging their latest senior event with the conviction that they needed to revitalize their five-year-old tour, the Champions Series, in a difficult economy.

title: Midmajors Rise Could Trickle Down
description: NEW ORLEANS  Butler Coach Brad Stevens has a librarians calm, his in-game demeanor doubling as the consummate poker face. Virginia Commonwealth Coach Shaka Smart bounces along the sideline as if it were a trampoline, hopping around and calling out plays as if he had hot coals in his loafers.

title: The Dissidents Wife
description: San Francisco

title: Harry Coover, Super Glues Inventor, Dies at 94
description: Harry Wesley Coover Jr., the man who invented Super Glue, died on Saturday night at his home in Kingsport, Tenn. He was 94.

title: At Calhouns Side, Exemplifying and Reinforcing His Message
description: Anaheim, Calif.

title: Paul Baran, Internet Pioneer, Dies at 84
description: Paul Baran, an engineer who helped create the technical underpinnings for the Arpanet, the government-sponsored precursor to todays Internet, died Saturday night at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 84.

title: In Deference to Crisis, a New Obsession Sweeps Japan: Self-Restraint
description: TOKYO  Even in a country whose people are known for walking in lockstep, a national consensus on the proper code of behavior has emerged with startling speed. Consider post-tsunami Japan as the age of voluntary self-restraint, or jishuku, the antipode of the Japan of the bubble era that celebrated excess.

title: Hardly Settled in House, but Already in Hot Seat
description: MOLINE, Ill.  In the 11 weeks since Representative Bobby Schilling left his family pizza business to join Congress, he has learned that sleeping on an office couch is extremely uncomfortable, that appearing on Meet the Press can be daunting, and that voting against federal money for a local rail project will cause some of your constituents to become very cranky.

title: Knicks Fumble for a Solution With Nine to Play
description: The Knicks will conduct a shootaround Monday morning ahead of their home game against the Orlando Magic, which in itself is not a drastic development for an N.B.A. team. Unless that team is the Knicks, mired in a swoon that threatens to wipe out the good vibrations from earlier in the season and provide a test case on the Carmelo Anthony trade.

title: Hip-Hop D.J. Is Killed on Staten Island
description: A hip-hop disc jockey who was a featured regular on a popular music-video show, 106 & Park, was shot to death early Sunday morning a block from his home on Staten Island, the police said.

title: Behind Troubled City Payroll Project, Lax Oversight and One Powerful Insider
description: This article is by  David W. Chen,  Serge F. Kovaleski and  John Eligon.

title: American Thought Police
description: Recently William Cronon, a historian who teaches at the University of Wisconsin, decided to weigh in on his states political turmoil. He started a blog, Scholar as Citizen, devoting his first post to the role of the shadowy American Legislative Exchange Council in pushing hard-line conservative legislation at the state level. Then he published an opinion piece in The Times, suggesting that Wisconsins Republican governor has turned his back on the states long tradition of neighborliness, decency and mutual respect.

title: A War by Any Name
description: Tonight, in a speech that probably should have been delivered before American planes began flying missions over North Africa, Barack Obama will try to explain to a puzzled nation why we are at war with Libya.

title: Supreme Court to Weigh Sociology Issue in Wal-Mart Discrimination Case
description: WASHINGTON  When the Supreme Court considers on Tuesday whether hundreds of thousands of women can band together in an employment discrimination suit against Wal-Mart, the argument may hinge on the validity of the hotly disputed conclusions of a Chicago sociologist.

title: Erasing Her Own Doubt, and a Deficit
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Quake Area Residents Turn to Old Means of Communication to Keep Informed
description: MIYAKO, Japan  To Ryo Orui, a high school junior, almost as frightening as the trembling of the earth or the wailing of tsunami sirens was the loss of his cellphone signal. When Japans big earthquake struck, Mr. Orui said, he felt a wave of panic at not being able to instantly contact loved ones, or get news on what was happening.

title: A Usual Suspect Slips Into a Party Owned by Outsiders
description: Newark

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 27, 2011

title: Reality TV, Shaking Off Recession, Takes Entrepreneurial Turn
description: If reality television could be considered an economic indicator, then perhaps the recovery is finally under way. Slowly.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: In Fight for Space, Educator Takes On Charter Chain
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Joel I. Klein, the former schools chancellor, are strong supporters of charter schools. Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Klein have repeatedly told principals at New York Citys traditional public schools that a new age of reform has dawned, that charter schools are the cutting edge and that if these principals want traditional public schools to survive, they must learn to compete in the educational marketplace.

title: Who Will Rescue Financial Reform?
description: In what passes for self-restraint these days, House Republicans have been insisting that they do not intend to repeal last years Dodd-Frank financial reform law.

title: After Suspicious Fire in Free Store, Some Lose a Home
description: Last summer, a group of people set up a large tent in an empty lot in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, and filled it with used books, secondhand clothes and many other items that had been discarded but seemed too useful to bury in a landfill.

title: New Jersey Students, Shortchanged
description: The New Jersey Legislature acted in the best interest of the states most vulnerable children in 2008 when it adopted a school financing formula that guaranteed districts enough money to give needy and disabled students a chance at a decent education. The state declared that it had found a way to quantify and subsidize the costs of the extra services  tutoring, counseling and after-school programs  that high-risk students needed to succeed at school. The plan won court approval.

title: Fear of Shortages Drives Panic Buying of Japanese Goods
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Tremors from the strong Japanese earthquake continue to rattle American businesses, even those companies that have experienced no disruptions in parts or supplies.

title: Tar Heels Gallant Defense Falls Just Short Against Wildcats
description: NEWARK  Even at the end of a lost cause Sunday, North Carolina guard Dexter Strickland was so close to Kentucky guard Brandon Knight that he could quickly offer Knight a hug, a pat on the head and his congratulations after the Wildcats 76-69 victory at Prudential Center.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include personal income and spending for February (Monday); the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price index (Tuesday); initial jobless claims (Thursday); and the Institute for Supply Managements manufacturing index (Friday).

title: He Dreamed He Saw Kim Jong-il
description: As Republican governors vie to become the most anti-union executive in the land, Gov. Paul LePage of Maine has stooped to behavior worthy of the pharaohs chiseling historic truth from Egyptian monuments. Mr. LePage has ordered that a 36-foot-wide mural depicting workers history in Maine be removed from the lobby of the states Labor Department.

description: Addiction is a big business  and not just for the treatment centers that rake in billions of dollars every year. Its also a huge media business that has spawned popular shows like A&Es Intervention and VH1s Celebrity Rehab, and best-selling memoirs by Mary Karr, Augusten Burroughs and a seemingly inexhaustible list of other recovering writers.

title: Egypt Needs a Rebuilding Fund
description: Egypt needs a reconstruction fund, too. Japan will be spending tens of billions of dollars on rebuilding after its tsunami. Egypt cant afford to finance an equivalent fund. But foreign powers could help by showing theyre not just interested in bombing neighboring Libya.

title: Of Ferraros Roles in Many Arenas, a Favorite: Gerry From Queens
description: One bitingly cold night in the early 1980s, Constance Mandina pulled her car up to a brick Tudor house in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, to pick up her friend Geraldine A. Ferraro. The two women had been close for years, forming a bond over various commonalities. Both had worked as teachers and then as assistant district attorneys. Both were Italian-American. Ms. Mandina, however, was a fervent environmentalist. And on that wintry night, Ms. Ferraro emerged from her home wrapped in a mink coat.

title: Philadelphia School Battles Students Bad Eating Habits, on Campus and Off
description: PHILADELPHIA  Tatyana Gray bolted from her house and headed toward her elementary school. But when she reached the corner store where she usually gets her morning snack of chips or a sweet drink, she encountered a protective phalanx of parents with bright-colored safety vests and walkie-talkies.

description: On March 28, The New York Times took a major step forward as we introduced digital subscriptions in the United States and the rest of the world. Since we first announced our plan 11 days ago, we have heard from so many of you, our readers. We are grateful for your feedback and, most of all, for your commitment to The Times.

description: BIN JAWWAD, Libya  Rebel forces westward charge was repulsed on Monday by a barrage of tank and artillery fire from forces guarding one of Col. title: How Should Educators and Legislators Deal With Minors Who Sext?
description: An article about sexting, or sending sexual photos, videos or texts from one cellphone to another, tells the story of several eighth graders whose lives were upended by a risqu photo. It also examines how schools and legal systems across the country are struggling to confront minors who sext. How common do you think the practice is among your peers? How dangerous? Why? How do you think parents, educators and legal systems should confront it? Do you agree with the expert quoted in the article that adults have to protect kids from themselves sometimes? Why or why not?

description: Porsche said on Sunday night that it had priced its issue of new shares at 38 euros, putting the value of the offering at 4.9 billion euros.

title: Fantasy Focus: Playing to the Rules
description: Looking over the draft order for the first couple of rounds of Major League Baseballs 2011 first-year player draft, set to take place in early June, the observant reader will notice something peculiar. No, its not that the Pirates have the first overall pick  for, really, what could be more predictable? Rather, its that, of the first 89 picks to be made, a full 12 of them (or 13.5%) belong to the Tampa Bay Rays.

title: Beyond the Bunny at Pragues Easter Markets
description: Come April, Prague wastes no time shedding its winter coats, joyfully ushering in spring with a swirl of pastel streamers, frisky, star-crossed lovers and dozens of hand-painted Easter eggs. The ancient tradition of men (playfully) whipping women with decorated willow sticks in exchange for plum brandy and colored eggs may be on the outs these days, but elements of the practice are still very much a part of the Eastertime fun and games. Willow sticks, painted eggs, as well as a wide assortment of beverages are all on tap at the citys festive outdoor markets, which run through May 1 (daily, from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m.).

title: Irish Banks Edge Closer to Stress Test Results
description: Irelands troubled banks may need up to 23 billion euros more to meet their capital requirements after the results of the stress tests are released by the Irish central bank on Thursday, Irish newspapers have reported.

title: Pick a Historical Analogy, Any Historical Analogy
description: Will intervention in Libya turn out to be Afghanistan redux? Or Vietnam? Or perhaps Bosnia? Faced with an open-ended war in a little-understood country, it is natural to grasp at historical precedents to explain what we are doing in Libya and why. Rory Stewart, the British member of Parliament and author of The Places in Between, makes the argument that this tendency speaks little about our views on Libya or Qaddafi and volumes about our personal philosophy. He writes in the London Review of Books:

title: Obama Campaign Picks Headquarters in Chicago
description: President Obamas aides have settled on the location of a campaign headquarters in downtown Chicago, with his re-election effort poised to open early next month by raising money and building a political organization for the 2012 presidential race.

description: Members of Congress return this week with plenty of questions about military involvement in Libya and a sticky budget impasse to resolve if lawmakers hope to avoid a shutdown of the federal government.

description: Walter Investment Management said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Green Tree Credit Solutions, a loan servicer, in a deal valued at more than $1 billion.

title: In Retirement, Sampras Looks for Balance
description: Pete Sampras, winner of 14 Grand Slam singles titles, retired officially in 2003 but has been showing plenty of interest in playing the game of late. He has taken part in exhibitions in the United States, including a match in Madison Square Garden last month against Andre Agassi; he played in a senior tournament in Zurich; and he signed on to take part in a 12-city tour of the United States in September and October with Agassi, Jim Courier, John McEnroe and others.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian:  Eggplant Caponata Crostini
description: David Seigal, the executive chef at the Tangled Vine Wine Bar & Kitchen in Manhattan, makes a caponata that works as a crostini, on top of toasted coarse bread, or as a sauce for pasta. What he remembers from his childhood, when his mother made it, was that at the end she always sprinkled it with a few drops of precious aged balsamic vinegar, at least 10 years old.

title: Who Made That Sound?
description: For the past week, I actually havent set foot on the sixth floor, as Ive been serving my civic duty as a juror in the State of New York. Between each case thats called, though, I cant help hearing that sound. If youve ever watched an episode of Law and Order, you know exactly what I mean. It has been called, among other variations, the doink doink, the dun dun and the chung chung.

title: U.N. Rights Group Calls on China to Release Lawyer
description: BEIJING  A United Nations human rights agency has demanded that the Chinese government immediately release a prominent Chinese human rights lawyer who has been detained for nearly a year, according to a statement released on Monday by an advocacy group. The lawyer, Gao Zhisheng, had said he was tortured during previous rounds of detention.

For a summary of the latest developments in Libya, read an updated report from our colleagues on the ground, David Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim.

title: He Wrote Like a Wounded Angel': Remembering Lanford Wilson
description: Jack Viertel met the playwright Lanford Wilson in 1978 when he was the theater critic for The Los Angeles Reader. As dramaturge for the Mark Taper Forum in 1986 and 1987, he worked with Wilson on Burn This and continued as the shows unofficial dramaturge for its Broadway run. Mr. Viertel, now senior vice president of Jujamcyn Theaters and artistic director of the New York City Center Encores! series, was discussing a revival of Wilsons Talleys Folly at the time of his death last week. Here he recalls what made Wilson a singular figure:

title: India Reports an Increase In Wild Tiger Population
description: NEW DELHI  India said Monday that it was making progress in saving endangered tigers, with a new nationwide survey estimating a 20 percent increase in their numbers in the wild over the last five years.

title: Amy Adams to Play Lois Lane in Superman Movie (That Zack Snyder Is Still Directing)
description: If youre a movie studio looking to change the subject from Zack Snyders current movie, one surefire way to do it is to slip out a little news about his next one. Over the weekend, when Mr. Snyders new fetishized fantasy-adventure, Sucker Punch, failed to get off the ground, selling just $19 million in tickets on a budget of at least $80 million, Warner Brothers Pictures countered with an announcement that Mr. Snyder had found the actress who will play Lois Lane in his coming Superman movie. Amy Adams, an Academy Award nominee for The Fighter, Doubt and Junebug, will play that fearless Daily Planet reporter and sometime paramour to the Man of Steel and his alter ego, Clark Kent. In a statement to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Snyder described Ms. Adams as one of the most versatile and respected actresses in films today with the talent to capture all of the qualities we love about Lois: smart, tough, funny, warm, ambitious and, of course, beautiful.

description: With warmer weather approaching, its tempting to take a break from politics over the weekend. Here are a few of the best political moments:

title: Afghan Elite Borrowed Freely From Kabul Bank
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When a brother and a nephew of an Afghan vice president wanted to build up their fuel transport business, they took out a $19 million loan from Kabul Bank. When a brother of the president wanted to invest in a cement factory, he took out a $2.9 million loan; he also took out $6 million for a town house in Dubai. When the banks chief executive wanted to invest in newly built apartments in Kabul, he took almost $18 million.

title: Broadway Star to Direct Film Version of Facing East
description: Will Swenson, a Tony Award nominee for his performance in Hair (2009) and a star of the new Broadway musical Priscilla Queen of the Desert, will direct an independent film adaptation of Carol Lynn Pearsons play Facing East. In the play, a Mormon couple grapple with their faith after the suicide of their gay son. Ms. Pearson, whose 1986 memoir, Good-bye, I Love You, told the story of her husbands struggle to come out as a gay man and his eventual death from AIDS, also wrote the screenplay. Mr. Swenson has personal reasons for working on this project: Getting through my own adolescence as a young Mormon was challenging as it was, but watching my best friend struggle with his identity as a gay teenager was heartbreaking, he said in a statement from the producers. Production is expected to begin in the fall. A percentage of the films profits will be donated to the Trevor Project, a nationwide crisis and suicide prevention help line for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning youth.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

title: Middleweight Cities as Growth Engines
description: A new study by the McKinsey Global Institute has put a spotlight on a trend shaping the world: urbanization, in particular the shift toward emerging nations in Asia and Latin America.

title: On Our Radar: Dont Tear Down E.P.A., Former Agency Chiefs Urge
description: The Republican assault on the Environmental Protection Agency, including a proposed bill to repeal the agencys recent finding that carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases pose a threat to human health and welfare, goes too far, write two former E.P.A. chiefs, both appointed by Republican presidents. Amid the virulent attacks on the E.P.A. driven by concern about overregulation, it is easy to forget how far we have come in the past 40 years, William D. Ruckelshaus and Christine Todd Whitman write. We should take heart from all this progress and not, as some in Congress have suggested, seek to tear down the agency that the president and Congress created to protect Americas health and environment. [The Washington Post]

title: Australia Paddock Notes
description: MELBOURNE  Down in an Italian quarter of the city on Sunday morning, a friend invited me into an ice cream shop run by an Italian immigrant with an accent thicker than the prickly pear ice cream my friend wanted me to try. When the owner learned I was a journalist here to cover the Australian Grand Prix, he flew into a diatribe over how the lord mayor of Melbourne, Robert Doyle, was spoiling the race atmosphere.

title: In the Market for an Ace? Its Best to Invest Early
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  A 4-year-old boy in Arizona seems destined to become the most valuable commodity in baseball when he grows up. His name is Ace.

title: Fast Company
description: Seventeen examples from Ralph Laurens holdings of classic cars  including the sexy, slightly menacing 1955 Jaguar XKD shown here  will be featured in the exhibition The Art of the Automobile: Masterpieces of the Ralph Lauren Collection, opening April 28 at Les Arts Dcoratifs in Paris. How do you say vroom in French?

title: Baryshnikov Arts Center to Auction Off Favorite Painting of its Founder
description: When he was in Finland in 1978, Mikhail Baryshnikov fell in love with a painting in a gallery  a panoramic cityscape of St. Petersburg by the 19th-century artist Petr Petrovich Vereshchagin  and bought it. I used to live right behind the Hermitage, so it was a personal icon for me, Mr. Baryshnikov said in a telephone interview. But now its time for someone else to take ownership of it.

title: Indias Tiger Count Rises Even as Human Numbers Climb
description: The tiger population in India has risen in the last four years, according to data released by the government on Monday. In a country with 1.15 billion humans and a population density now topping that of Japan, its great to see a growing focus on preserving some space for the last big cats.

title: Vettel Triumphs in Formula One Season Opener
description: After political unrest in Bahrain led to a controversial postponement of its opening race, the 2011 Formula One season finally got under way on Sunday in Melbourne, Australia. And much as the 2010 season ended  with the Red Bull driver Sebastian Vettel on top  so the 2011 campaign began.

description: HOUSTON  After seizing control of critical oil fields and terminals in eastern Libya over the weekend, Libyan rebels are now trying to sell oil in international markets, potentially raising hundreds of millions of dollars to buy weapons and supplies.

title: At U.S. Nuclear Sites, Preparing for the Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON  American nuclear safety regulators, using a complex mathematical technique, determined that the simultaneous failure of both emergency shutdown systems that are designed to prevent a core meltdown was so unlikely that it would happen once every 17,000 years.

title: Now Tippling | Windy City Speakeasy
description: Grant Achatzs new Chicago restaurant, Next  where the theme will change every three months (starting with Paris 1906)  might just be the most hotly anticipated opening in the country. But the bars the young chef is building next door in the citys Meatpacking District may be just as significant. Aviary, the 64-seat experimental drinks den scheduled to open April 1, is already well known to anxious cocktail geeks. But a second, much more secretive bar tucked underneath has so far gone largely unnoticed.

title: Among Independents, Poll Favors Obama Over Congress
description: Independent voters make up an influential voting bloc that frequently decides elections, but they are an unpredictable bunch. In 2008, just over half of independent voters threw their support behind Barack Obama and Congressional Democrats, yet by the election of 2010, they had swung back to supporting Republicans for Congress. Now, just a few months into the new Congresss term, more than twice as many independents approve of the job the president is doing than they do of the job Congress is doing, according to the latest CBS News poll.

title: Brazil, in London, Puts On Another Successful Show
description: Friendly matches tend to have trivial importance, especially when Scotland is involved. But even for Scots, a game like Sundays  against the five-time world champion Brazil  retains a mystical and romantic quality.

title: Making the College Choice
description: The Times's Jacques Steinberg on college acceptance letters and the decision facing high school seniors in the coming weeks.

title: Did You Say What I Thought You Said?
description: It shouldnt be this difficult for brokers to refrain from using discriminatory language when trying to sell or rent homes. But over the decades, enough brokerages and newspapers publishing real estate listings have been sued that they now assemble lists of forbidden words and phrases that, if used, could violate fair housing laws.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: The government is expected to introduce two significant new policies this week in emerging areas of health care, one on whether Medicare will pay for a $93,000 cancer drug treatment, and the other on rules that may affect hospitals, insurers, doctors and patients in accountable care organizations set up under the new health care law.
