description: Q: (Reader)

title: Numberplay: Seeding Marquee Matchups
description: Its no secret that sports is entertainment. Just as moviegoers flock to the films with the biggest stars, so do sports fans cram stadiums to watch the biggest names. No wonder then, that tournament organizers take extraordinary care to ensure marquee matchups at the biggest stages of an event. The common tool is to seed highly ranked players or teams, so that they do not play each other prematurely.

title: Profiles of World Leaders, at a Distance
description: Photographs and psychological assessments of nine world leaders.

title: A Versatile Vegetable for a Chilly Spring
description: Spring vegetables arent here quiet yet  and if the weather doesnt improve soon, they may not arrive for a while. Until then, theres a fine alternative: Swiss chard.

title: Teasing Out Policy Insight From a Character Profile
description: He is a delusional narcissist who will fight until his last breath. Or an impulsive showman who will hop the next flight out of town when cornered. Or maybe hes a psychopath, a coldly calculating strategist  crazy, like a desert fox.

title: Pretty as a (Census) Picture
description: It has been said that in America, a minority group has not truly arrived into the mainstream until it has been marketed to. That was true for African-Americans, gay men and lesbians and, most recently, consumers who speak Spanish.

title: UBS Reshuffles M.&A. Team
description: The Swiss bank UBS reshuffled the leadership of its mergers and acquisitions team on Monday to win market share.

title: Food Carts Make the Rounds at Hotels
description: Taking their cue from the food-truck trend, a number of upscale hotels have initiated food trolleys.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Andrew Altersohn joined Havas Digital, part of the Havas Media unit of Havas, as president for Havas Digital North America, New York. He succeeds Ed Montes, who left to join Adnetik, Boston, as chief executive. Mr. Altersohn had held numerous executive posts at Publicis Modem USA, New York, part of the Publicis Groupe.

title: New Edward Burns Movie Will Close Tribeca Film Festival
description: The story of a veteran director sharing the spotlight at a long-running film festival with his spouse and her directorial debut could have been the premise of an Edward Burns movie, if it werent also his reality at the 2010 Tribeca Film Festival, which saw the debut of his ninth film, Nice Guy Johnny, as well as No Woman No Cry, the first by his wife, Christy Turlington Burns. But this year Mr. Burns gets a platform all to himself: the festivals organizers said on Monday that the closing night film of its 2011 program would be Newlyweds, which Mr. Burns wrote, directed and stars in. It is the latest in a series of films (including Ash Wednesday, Looking for Kitty and Purple Violets) that have made their debuts at Tribeca.

title: Breaking Down the Nuggets Offense
description: When the Denver Nuggets traded Carmelo Anthony and Chauncey Billups to the Knicks for Raymond Felton, Wilson Chandler, Danilo Gallinari and Timofey Mozgov, it was almost guaranteed that the Nuggets were going to drop out of the tight playoff race in the Western Conference. But the exact opposite happened as the Nuggets went 12-4, solidifying their place in the playoff picture. Not only that, but the Nuggets now have the most efficient offense in the N.B.A., scoring 109.8 points per 100 possessions (the league average is 104.3 points per 100 possessions).

title: Gladverts
description: Advertisements tailored to an individuals mood.

title: Hevesi Hospitalized; Sentencing Delayed as Judge Steps Aside
description: Updated 4:25 p.m. | The sentencing of Alan G. Hevesi, the former New York State comptroller convicted in a pay-to-play pension scandal, was delayed for at least one week as the presiding judge stepped aside from the case on Monday.

title: Souto de Moura Wins 2011 Pritzker Architecture Prize
description: Eduardo Souto de Moura, a Portuguese architect who has worked mainly in his native country, designing a major soccer stadium and numerous private houses, has been awarded the 2011 Pritzker Prize, architectures highest honor.

title: Bloomberg Calls State Budget Deal an Outrage
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday dismissed the budget agreement reached in Albany over the weekend as an outrage, saying that it was likely to require the city to make another round of steep cuts.

title: Why You Cant Be Sure About Home Purchases
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Libya and the Domestic Sphere
description: Joe Klein has a theory about the commentary on Libya:

title: Libyans Seek News of Vanished Relatives
description: AJDABIYA, Libya  There were four doctors, a medical equipment salesman, a student studying economics, and dozens of others. Some went out to protest, some to fight, and others to tend to the wounded.

title: Living Color
description: Next month, the Indianapolis Museum of Art will open to the public the house that Eero Saarinen designed for the industrialist J. Irwin Miller and his wife, Xenia, giving design pilgrims one more reason to visit Columbus, Ind., the mecca of Modernist architecture that Miller sponsored. The stone- and glass-walled house, which Saarinen completed in 1957, includes about 14 acres of landscaping by Dan Kiley and meticulously preserved interiors by Alexander Girard, who sank the worlds first conversation pit into its living room. The Eames Aluminum Group chairs were designed for the Millers, whose dining table was a precursor to Saarinens Tulip pedestal series. The couple lived in the house until their deaths (his in 2004, hers in 2008) and left behind a portrait not just of enlightened 20th-century arts patronage but of family life as well. Its not like the Farnsworth House, which was a weekend getaway, or the Glass House, which is purely an architects personal expression of his ideas, says Bradley Brooks, the museums director of historic resources. It had to accommodate entertaining and employees and five kids, and yet it was still resolved so beautifully.

title: Unemployments Rising Toll on Families
description: Last year, nearly one in eight families included an unemployed person, the highest proportion since the Labor Department began keeping track in 1994.

title: In Houston, Faded Visions of Phi Slama Jama
description: As the host of the Final Four, the University of Houston will be at the center of college basketball this week. It has been 40 years since the Astrodome hosted the event, and nearly three decades since Houston has been relevant in the sport.

title: States Battling Meth Makers Look to Limit Ingredients
description: NASHVILLE  Faced with a surging methamphetamine problem, a number of states are weighing contentious bills this spring that would require a doctors prescription for popular decongestants like Sudafed.

title: States Weigh Fighting Meth With Drug Prescriptions
description: NASHVILLE  Faced with a surging methamphetamine problem, a number of states are weighing contentious bills this spring that would require a doctors prescription for popular decongestants like Sudafed.

title: David E. Davis Jr., Dean of Automotive Journalism, Dies at 80
description: David E. Davis Jr., the writer, editor and publisher who helped influence the form and tenor of feature-based automotive journalism, died on Sunday evening at the St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ypsilanti, Mich. He was 80.

title: Photos That Come From Not Giving Up
description: Paul Patrick Borhaug, known on his Web site simply as Paul Patrick, is 21 and lives in Oslo. His current project is The Violence of Silence. He spoke with Kerri MacDonald for the Turning Point series. Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

title: The Kennedys: After the Debate, the Debut
description: When the first episode of The Kennedys, the costly and controversial mini-series about that American political dynasty, makes its debut on Sunday, a chapter in television history will be closed, but a debate about the balance between accuracy and creative license in historical dramas will be renewed.

title: The Panic Virus
description: INTRODUCTION

title: Repertory Casting Returns for Shakespeare in the Park
description: New Yorks Public Theater on Monday announced its second consecutive summer of casting a repertory company of actors in its two Shakespeare in the Park productions, Measure for Measure and Alls Well That Ends Well, which will run June 6 to July 30 and, as usual, offer free tickets to most playgoers.

title: Defending Vaccination Once Again, With Feeling
description: Does the reading public really need yet one more rundown of the repeatedly debunked claims linking childhood vaccinations and autism? The positions of those who uphold vaccine safety and those who assail it have at this point thoroughly saturated the news media; what more is there to say?

title: Artifacts | The Cute and the Gross: David Altmejds Gorgeous Gothic
description: One reason the grotesque is so compelling is its ravaged beauty. Bound up in the distorting horror, at least in art, is an absurdity that also makes its appearance rather comic. All of those elements are in play in David Altmejds dazzling new show at the Andrea Rosen Gallery, where decapitated heads grow glittering crystals, fossilized angels are crucified within the walls, and agglomerations of human ears ornament plexiglass cages swarming with jewel-like, plastic bees.

title: Unfamiliar, but Worth Getting to Know
description: FEW things are simple in northeastern Italy, least of all lagrein, a red grape that can produce fresh, aromatic, highly seductive wines. Why, just last week, I asked a linguistically minded friend who is fluent in Italian for the proper pronunciation of lagrein. Here is his response, or part of it:

title: New Seasons Ordered for Amazing Race and Undercover Boss
description: CBS said Monday that it had ordered new seasons of The Amazing Race and Undercover Boss, two of its most reliable reality shows.

title: Prayers for Japan Reflect Citys Diversity
description: First came the Muslim imam, singing an Arabic prayer in an undulating melody. Next came the rabbi, chanting in Hebrew, followed by the Hindu leader praying in Sanskrit, the Christian in English, the Sikh in Punjabi and the Buddhist in Japanese.

title: J/P HRO in Haiti
description: A look inside Sean Penns aid group and its work in Haiti. To learn more about the organization or to donate, please visit jphro.org.

title: Crowds Come Over Roads and by Helicopters for Tanzanians Cure-All Potion
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Hes a sensation in two countries. Hes snarled traffic for miles. Hes so popular that people have literally died waiting in line to see him.

title: A Preview of President Obama's Address
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times and Helene Cooper of The New York Times discuss what President Obama may address in his remarks Monday evening on Libya.

title: Interview: Anne Sewitzky
description: Anne Sewitzky, the director of the Norwegian comedy "Happy, Happy," discusses her film.

title: Video: Previewing the Presidents Address on Libya
description: Read John Harwoods related story, Opportunities and Perils for Obama in Military Action in Libya, published in Mondays Times.

title: Carbon Date Stamps
description: Q. Is it true that because of radiation, people born after about 1950 cant be carbon-dated?

title: Bolao, Reading and Nazis
description: One of the great pleasures of reading Roberto Bolao is reading Roberto Bolao on reading. On the New York Review of Books blog is an excerpt (found via 3Quarksdaily) from Between Parentheses, a collection of his essays, articles and speeches, translated by Natasha Wimmer and due out next month from New Directions. In it, Bolao recounts a youthful adventure in book stealing  his favorite, Pierre Lous, with pages as thin as Bible paper, but also Champfleury, Samuel Pepys, the Goncourt brothers, Alphonse Daudet and Rulfo. A version of this unusual shoplifters library finds its way into the beginning of The Savage Detectives, giving readers of that novel the double pleasure of recognition.

title: Case of a 145-Day Tax Refund Delay
description: Tim Ryan has been sucked into a vortex of bad tax luck. Last week, we reported that some taxpayers were facing delays in getting refund checks, due to computer snafus in processing their repayment of the 2008 first-time home buyer tax credit. (The credit was really a no-interest loan and has to be repaid over 15 years, beginning this year). Many of those filers, the Internal Revenue Service says, should begin getting their refunds in April.

title: Rajaratnam Lawyer Spars With Witness Over Clearwire Deal
description: Raj Rajaratnam, right, and one of his lawyers, John Dowd, arrive at the federal courthouse in Manhattan on Monday.

title: Two Twitter Founders Trade Places
description: As Twitter tries to manage its explosive growth, two of the companys founders have traded roles.

title: Indiana House Democrats Returning to State Capitol
description: Indiana Democrats planned to return to the state Capitol on Monday afternoon, almost five weeks after they fled the state to protest several bills they said would weaken organized labor.

title: For Sale: Illiquid Assets, Hard to Value
description: Side pockets might as well be a curse word for hedge fund investors.

title: Egypts Military Confirms Travel Ban on Mubarak
description: CAIRO  Egypts military command said on Monday that the ousted president, Hosni Mubarak, was prohibited from leaving the country, and that it would soon lift a detested emergency law, among a number of announcements seemingly intended to shore up diminishing support for the armed forces council ruling the nation.

title: Smithsonian Wont  Buy Murals of Black Life in California
description: The Smithsonians National Museum of African American History and Culture has withdrawn its controversial offer to spend $750,000 on 1949 murals of early black Californians. The African-American painters Charles Alston and Hale Woodruff created the scenes for the lobby of a Los Angeles insurance companys headquarters, designed by the architect Paul Williams, who was also African American. Preservationists opposed the plan to remove the canvases, commissioned by the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, which is being liquidated. The Smithsonians statement withdrawing its offer, issued over the weekend, was announced at a court hearing on Monday. (The hearing settled the fate of Golden States archive, which will be going to UCLA.) Further proceedings in the next few months will decide if the paintings, which have been appraised at up to $5 million, stay onsite. The museum stated that it is pleased to learn that members of the arts and cultural community of Los Angeles are working to retain the paintings.

title: Finding a Balm for Frequent Nosebleeds
description: Nosebleeds, like noses, come in varied forms, and the number of sufferers is growing as the population ages. Millions of them rejoice at this time of year, when the most frequent cause  winters dry, heated indoor air  begins to yield to the warm, moist air of spring.

title: A Century Later, Jurys Still Out on Caffeine Limits
description: The latest skirmish in the caffeine wars  this one involving the high levels of caffeine in so-called energy drinks, especially those consumed by children  recalls one of the earliest.

title: Can Cavities Be Contagious?
description: Brace yourself for this daunting piece of dental health news. Cavities can be contagious.

title: The Aftermath in Japan | March 28, 2011
description: Photographs from Japan following the March 11 earthquake and tsunami.

title: Less Is More: Using Social Media to Inspire Concise Writing
description: Overview | How can online media like Twitter posts, Facebook status updates and text messages be harnessed to inspire and guide concise writing? In this lesson, students read, respond to and write brief fiction and nonfiction stories, and reflect on the benefits and drawbacks of writing short.

title: Just Right
description: When Jonathan Ive, Apples senior vice president of industrial design, was a boy, a Braun juicer designed by Dieter Rams (above) made a big impression: At a glance, you knew exactly what it was and exactly how to use it. So its fitting that Ive, whose own work reflects the German masters principles, wrote the introduction to As Little Design as Possible: The Work of Dieter Rams, to be published by Phaidon in June. Written by Sophie Lovell and Klaus Kemp, the book examines Ramss less but better philosophy, as illustrated by the hundreds of products (like the coffee grinder shown here) that he produced for Braun, as well as by the iconic 606 shelving system for Vitsoe, still in production after 50 years. On May 2, the Vitsoe shop at 33 Bond Street will open an exhibition of early 606 pieces, while Braun is producing watches  including the one shown here  inspired by models that Rams and Dietrich Lubs designed in the 1970s. Go to ameico.com.

title: An Herbal Alternative to Creams for Pale Skin
description: Mirror, mirror on the wall, whos the fairest of them all?

title: Deep Flavor, No Browning Required
description: LORD knows Ive written the words often enough myself: Brown meat over high heat, in batches if necessary, until well seared on all sides. But I have to admit that whenever I see this instruction at the beginning of a braise or stew, my first reaction is to turn the page.

title: More Fees, More Carry-Ons
description: The price of checking a suitcase on an airplane  $15 to $40 a bag  has added up to more than $6 billion in revenue for airlines in the United States in the last four years, according to Transportation Department statistics. The fees have also led to an increased number of bags being carried onto airplanes.

title: What a Gibbs Hire Might Mean for Facebook
description: DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin discusses on CNBC his exclusive report that Facebook is in talks to hire Robert Gibbs, President Obamas former White House press secretary, for a senior role in helping to manage the companys communications.

title: France Sees Surge in Foreign Investments
description: PARIS  The French economy is popularly viewed as sclerotic and sheltered, but government data released Monday  as well as the testimony of a number of global chief executives  suggest the opposite.

title: Metropolitan Museum Names Manager of Concerts and Lectures
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has named a new director of its Concert & Lecture series to succeed Hilde Limondjian, who retired from the post last year after programming 41 seasons and more than 9,000 events.

title: Doubts Raised on Gains in Indian Tiger Census
description: On Monday, Indian officials released the findings of a new survey showing the countrys population of endangered tigers had increased 20 percent in the last five years.

title: The Poker Writing of Jay Caspian Kang
description: If you enjoyed the magazines profile of Dan Cates, the 21-year-old online-poker millionaire, by Jay Caspian Kang (and if you havent read it, go now, read it and enjoy it), you will definitely want to follow it up by reading The High Is Always the Pain and the Pain Is Always the High, Kangs first-person look at gambling addiction published last year on the Web site The Morning News.

title: Will Obama Speech Address Region or Just Libya?
description: With a televised speech to the American public, President Obama on Monday evening will seek to answer what the White House calls legitimate questions about the American involvement in the war in Libya.

title: TimesCast | March 28, 2011
description: President Obama prepares an address to the nation on Libya; and why the United States does not plan to militarily intervene in other conflicts, like Syria's.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Anne Sewitzky
description: The Norwegian filmmaker Anne Sewitzky makes her directorial debut with Happy, Happy, a comedy about the mixed-up lives of two neighboring couples. Before screening at New Directors/New Films, the movie played at Sundance and won the grand jury prize for world cinema. In this video Ms. Sewitzky discusses the origins of the films narrative and how it reflects the complexity of modern relationships.

title: Brian OConnell, Advocate for Philanthropies, Dies at 81
description: Brian OConnell, who helped found Independent Sector, an organization that represents the interests of charities, foundations and nonprofit giving programs in the United States, often before Congress, died March 21 at his home in Chatham, Mass. He was 81. The cause was cancer, his wife, Ann, said.

title: Sprint Formally Denounces AT&Ts Deal for T-Mobile
description: Sprint Nextel formally announced its opposition to AT&Ts proposed $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA on Monday, saying that the deal would drastically cut down on cellphone service competition in the country.

title: Gerald Wallaces Renaissance in Portland
description: The traditional box score is a tool primarily designed to measure offense, and as a result, the work of some of the N.B.A.s top defenders can go unnoticed. Without a quantitative point of reference to indicate who is succeeding on defense, an accurate assessment often requires a deliberate viewing approach. Nick Collisons rotations and Toney Douglass blanketing of ball-handlers may not show up in an easily countable form, but those who know where to look can see the quiet defensive impact of either player.

title: Chelsea, 1:25 P.M.
A Bones Telltale Shape Eases Weight Estimates
description: When a human skeleton is found, forensic scientists create what is called a biological profile. By studying the bones, they can guess the persons height, sex and age.

title: To Shill a Mockingbird
description: Atticus Finch, the heroic lawyer at the heart of Harper Lees Pulitzer Prize-winning To Kill a Mockingbird, is best remembered for his colorblindness in the face of small-town racism. In his 1962 Oscar-winning portrayal of Atticus, Gregory Peck wore a pair of tortoiseshell-style spectacles that aptly symbolized the clarity and wisdom so central to his character.

title: An Older Generation Falls Prey to Eating Disorders
Radiation Fears in Tokyo
description: Tokyo residents worry about radiation following reports of further contamination escaping from the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power station.

title: Deciphering Old Texts, One Woozy, Curvy Word at a Time
description: In the old days, anybody interested in seeing a Mets game during a trip to New York would have to call the team, or write away, or wait to get to the city and visit the box office. No more. Now, all it takes is to find an online ticket distributor. Sign in, click Mets, pick the date and pay.

title: On the Red Carpet, and Waving Like a Natural
description: THE one thing Ive learned in my travels is that no matter how carefully my staff and I plan, something unexpected happens. A typical business trip for me involves visiting as many of our locations as I can in one trip. For example, I was recently in Asia and visited 38 hotels in about one week. I have the trips down to a science, but I cant plan for every contingency.

title: They Love the Nightlife: Audiences Flock to Priscilla Queen of the Desert
description: In its first full week of performances since opening on Broadway to generally good reviews, the new musical Priscilla Queen of the Desert notched a 30 percent increase in ticket sales last week and the revival of Arcadia was up 20 percent compared to its box-office grosses the prior week, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League.

title: For Iraq, a Surge in Petty Crime Is a Victory, of Sorts
description: BAGHDAD  On a day when the prime minister of Turkey arrived to promote business ties between his country and Iraq, a spate of attacks, including roadside bombings, jewelry heists and the slaughter of six women and a man in Mosul that may have been related to prostitution, rippled across the country.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Libya, the Gaza Strip and Yemen.

title: Excerpt: 'The Kennedys'
description: The controversial mini-series, rejected by the History Channel, begins Sunday on ReelzChannel.

title: Major Polaroid Collection to Be Kept Intact, in Vienna
description: A nonprofit photo gallery in Vienna and a group of analog photography entrepreneurs announced Monday that they had acquired a collection of several thousand Polaroid prints by well-known artists that were in danger of being auctioned off piecemeal as part of the bankruptcy proceedings of the Polaroid company.

title: Treatments: W.H.O. Lists Priority Medicines for Children and Pregnant Women
description: The World Health Organization recently released its first list of what it called the top 30 medicines to save mothers and children, a formulary of drugs that every hospital and clinic in every poor country should have.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Japan, Libya, the Gaza Strip and Yemen.

title: Her Sequins, Plumes and Foghorn Voice
description: The leading ladys costumes have had to be sized up, but there was never any question of their not fitting. After all, its Harvey Fierstein who has stepped into the role (and corset, plumes and pumps) of Zaza, the main attraction of the nightclub and the musical named La Cage aux Folles.

title: Dispute Over Time Warner Cables Streaming to iPad Bursts Into the Open
description: Companies like Time Warner Cable and Cablevision buy the rights to beam channels to customers television sets. But do those rights extend to iPads?

title: A Guide to Entice Heads Into the Clouds
description: Gavin Pretor-Pinney confronts his new books major problem right up front. You might well think, he writes, that cloud collecting sounds like a ridiculous idea.

title: Up in the Clouds
description: Some notable selections from The Cloud Collectors Handbook by Gavin Pretor-Pinney, with comments from the author.

title: How to Come Out of Labor Strife as a Super Bowl Champ
description: Shortly before N.F.L. players traded playbooks for picket signs in 1982, Joe Gibbs, coach of the Washington Redskins, called right tackle George Starke at home. According to Starke, Gibbs urged him to reconsider. If captains like Starke went on strike, Gibbs reasoned, so would teammates.

title: The Child Becomes the Parent
description: Greetings from my couch! Its been three weeks since my post about how I managed to break both ankles while walking across my driveway, so it is time for an update. Im trying hard not to make this the Blog About Lisas Ankles, and I certainly dont want to imply that there arent far more important problems in the world right now. But there is a parenting point here, so bear with me.

title: CBS Takes Sunday Night
description: The news magazine 60 Minutes and reality shows on Sunday topped the nights ratings in prime time for CBS. Although Nielsens estimates are imprecise because of a 17-minute overrun of the networks late-afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, the preliminary results show 60 Minutes leading the night over all with about 13.4 million viewers. The rest of the CBS lineup drew slightly smaller audiences: The Amazing Race (roughly 10.9 million), Undercover Boss (11.8 million) and CSI: Miami (10.6 million). ABC ranked second with solid results for Secret Millionaire at 8 p.m. (10.5 million) but low ratings at 9 and 10 for reruns of Desperate Housewives (4.7 million) and Brothers & Sisters (2.7 million). NBC was close behind in third, and Fox was fourth.

title: Midmajors Capitalize on Their Chance
description: In a January item about the expansion of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament from 65 to 68 teams, I cited the recent Final Four appearances by George Mason and Butler as evidence that midmajor teams might have a case for some of the extra at-large bids. I went on to write that underdogs make great stories and are very popular. It stands to reason, the more chances they get, the more theyll capitalize.

title: A Speech Lost in Digital Translation
description: It was Nov. 2, 1859. The jury in Charles Town, Va., deliberated only 45 minutes before sentencing John Brown to death by hanging for leading a raid on the federal arsenal at nearby Harpers Ferry. The court asked Brown, a gaunt, craggy-faced abolitionist, if he wished to speak. He did.

title: Styled to a T | Big-Game
description: The Guys

title: Readers Advice on Appliance Repairs
description: After my Shortcuts column about my refrigerator breakdown ran in The Times on Saturday, I received quite a few readers comments about their repair experiences. It goes to show that the joy of comparing appliance problems is second only to that of discussing medical misfortunes.

title: Despite Promise of Reforms, Syrian Forces Try to Disperse Protesters With Gunfire
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  The political crisis in Syria deepened on Monday as the armed forces in the restive southern city of Daraa fired live ammunition in the air to disperse hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators who had taken to the streets.

title: Explaining Sullingers Decision to Stay
description: Satch Sullinger, the father of the Ohio State star Jared Sullinger, is a human fortune cookie. A retired high school and college coach in Ohio, the elder Sullinger speaks in coaching nuggets.

title: Feisty Types? Try Looking in the Morgue
description: There are so few nice women on reality television  try finding a sweet, trustworthy friend at any of the locations where The Real Housewives lurk. And, conversely, its just as hard to find a truly unpleasant heroine of a network drama or sitcom.

title: TimesCast | U.S. Limits Intervention
description: March 28, 2011 - Michael Slackman reports that the United States maintains it has no plans to convene in other conflicts in the Middle East, like in Syria.

title: Playing Simon Says at Airport Security
description: IN general, I dont take orders from anyone except (as a matter of prudence) my wife. So the last time I was in an airport and security agents started bellowing, Freeze! I simply carried on with my business of buying a box of chocolates at a pushcart a few dozen feet away from the Transportation Security Administration checkpoint area.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Akira'
description: A. O. Scott discusses the anime classic and the obsession with disaster in Japanese pop culture.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,499 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: TimesCast | NATO to Take Command
description: March 28, 2011 - President Obama prepares to address the nation Monday night on America's role in the Libyan conflict.

title: Critics Picks Video: Akira
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Katsuhiro Otomos 1988 animated film Akira. The film takes place in a post-apocalyptic neo-Tokyo filled with teenage motorcycle gangs, protesters, violent revolutionaries and more. Akira defies genre, Mr. Scott says. Its a boys adventure wrapped in a detective story tucked inside a nuclear allegory surrounded by a dystopian fable. Although the film moves rapidly through these ideas, it does so in the service of creating a sublime and radical new art form, adds Mr. Scott. Have you seen Akira? Please share your thoughts.

title: A Snakes Game of Hide-and-Seek
description: The case of the missing venomous snake in the Bronx Zoo has yielded much interest, many press inquiries and even a fake Twitter feed. What it has not yielded is the missing snake.

title: Back From Vacation, Lil Wayne Returns to Reclaim His Perch
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Just before Lil Wayne, a k a Weezy, went to jail last March, he took on a new nickname, Lil Tunechi. It seemed ungainly at first, awkward sounding and unrevealing. Plus: what rhymes with Tunechi?

title: Fill-In Delivers a Muscular Pairing of Ives and Bachs Goldberg Variations
description: If the pianist Jeremy Denk has a fitness regimen, he should share it with musician colleagues. He has always been an accomplished and adventurous pianist with boundless enthusiasm and stamina. In recent weeks he has also been the go-to choice for institutions in need of a replacement artist.

title: When Youthful Ambition Was Restrained by Prudence
description: Youth can be a time of rebellion, but in the artistic sphere composers usually adhere to tradition before breaking the rules. Just as a chef cant experiment in the kitchen without familiarity with essential ingredients, a composer cant innovate without basic mastery of the craft.

title: Q&A: Making More Room for Search Terms
description: Q.

title: Before Libya, White House Must Negotiate With ABC
description: President Obama had a message for the American people Monday night, an explanation of the governments intentions in Libya, one that he believed was important enough to request air time from the broadcast networks as well as the cable news networks.

title: Thoughts of a Former Gardener
description: Writing about gardening in my Six Things to Feel Good About piece made me think about same, and I missed it. I grew up here, in N.Y.C. And though some people kept tomato plants on their fire escapes, for the most part theres more gardening going on here now than there was then, when if you wanted to see a head of lettuce in soil you had to go to New Jersey, Westchester or Long Island. And, truthfully, most suburbanites of those days  when the word sustainable had not yet been coined  didnt grow anything besides lawn and dandelions (the latter unintentionally).

title: Architect From Portugal Wins Pritzker
description: Eduardo Souto de Moura, a Portuguese architect whose work combines the abstract minimalism of Mies van der Rohe with a preference for local materials and building techniques, has been awarded the 2011 Pritzker Prize, architectures highest honor.

title: Allies in Improvisation and in a Cause
description: The earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis in Japan have inspired benefit concerts across New York City. One of the first to be announced was held on Sunday night at Miller Theater at Columbia University.

title: Crucifixes and Diversity: The Odd Couple
description: In these columns I have often remarked that religion-clause jurisprudence is characterized by contortions that would be the envy of Houdini. title: Italy: Berlusconi Tax Fraud Trial Opens
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi appeared in a Milan court on Monday where he is accused of tax fraud in the acquisition of film rights by his Mediaset company. Mr. Berlusconi did not speak during the hearing, Italian wire agencies reported, but in a telephone call to a program on one of his television channels, he called the accusations unfounded and ridiculous, as well as politically motivated. The court will decide whether to indict Mr. Berlusconi and three other defendants. Mr. Berlusconi also faces charges in three other cases, including one in which he is accused of having sex with an underage prostitute. That trial will open next week.

title: Afghanistan: Bombing Toll Rises to 20
description: The death toll in a suicide bombing in Paktika Province rose to 20 on Monday, Afghan officials said, and 50 people were wounded. Afghan officials said that three suicide bombers attacked a road construction base on Sunday, killing the security guard at the gate then driving a vehicle laden with explosives into the compound and setting them off. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the bombing.

title: Fantasy Focus: Expected Return vs. Ceiling
description: During a lengthy debate on the wisdom of my Mike Stanton pick in the fourth round of the 14-team Yahoo! Friends and Family League, a couple of the commenters panned the pick, citing the possibility that Stanton would struggle would because of his low contact rate and get sent down to the minors. They estimated the chance at 20 percent. Whether thats true (I think 20 is too high, and if so, that would mean he was playing badly enough to get sent down, which means getting sent down would hardly make things worse), the argument boils down to this: Stanton is a bad pick in the fourth round of a 14-team mixed league because his non-injury-related floor is too low. Setting aside the merits of the argument about Stanton in particular (which are laid out in detail in the debate linked above), I think the argument misses a key point generally.

Now, an exhibition of historical photographs  some in the photojournalist style, some more stylized  offers an unusual and disquieting vision of the city. Peurs Sur la Ville, (Fear Over the City), showing at the Monnaie (11, Quai Conti; www.monnaiedeparis.fr) through April 17, focuses on the violent history of Paris from three vantage points.

title: Spellbinding
description: In certain cultures, voodoo objects were commissioned to solve anything that vexed you  from failed crops to failed romance. Approximately 100 such tools of divine intervention are at hand this month when the Fondation Cartier in Paris presents Voodoo (April 5 to Sept. 25), an exhibition culled mostly from the collection of Jacques Kerchache, a legendary curator and champion of primitive art. The shows focus is on the Republic of Benin, where voodoo orginated, and the objects can be mind-boggling in their dense, everything-but-the-kitchen-sink assemblage. But according to the exhibitions co-curator, Leanne Sacramone, we can now only imagine the circumstances of their creation. The figure above, made of wood, rope, animal bones, terra cotta pots, plants, feathers, cotton threads, shells, cloth, hair, beads and chain, might have done wonders for a fashion designer in need of inspiration.

title: How Elite Colleges Still Arent Diverse
description: Theres an old joke that Harvards definition of diversity is having a rich kid from New York room with a rich kid from California. No doubt the joke has also been told about Yale or Duke and about kids from places other than New York and California.

title: Clean Energy Investment Is Up, but U.S. Lags
description: A study released Tuesday by the Pew Environment Group suggests that investment in clean energy among the worlds 20 leading economies, a k a the G-20, is generally on the rebound after a grinding global recession.

title: Tuesday Reading: Defending Vaccination, Again
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: U.S. Housing Prices Fell Again in January
description: The housing market remains mired in trouble, with plummeting prices and slumping sales. First-time buyers are fleeing, sellers are frustrated, builders are depressed and lenders are skittish about making new loans.

title: Road to Appomattox Blogging
description: Its the 150th anniversary of the start of the Civil War, and the Times has a special blog, Disunion, covering the events in real time  day by day, as they happened in 1861. Great stuff.

title: New Whit Stillman Movie Picked Up by Sony Pictures Classics
description: When the filmmaker Whit Stillman released his last movie, The Last Days of Disco, it was 1998, and he was on pace to produce a new film roughly every three years (while Chlo Sevigny was still an intriguing ingnue for whom the title The Brown Bunny had no meaning). Times have changed, and while it feels as if whole civilizations have come and gone, Mr. Stillman is at last about to put out a fourth film.

title: Shop Talk
description: London: Theres a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

title: Not All Choices Are False
description: One of President Obamas recurrent rhetorical tropes during the 2008 campaign was the false choice maneuver, in which he would distance himself from straw men of the left and right to better sell himself as a post-partisan figure. He made the same move last night, defending his administrations Libya policy by distancing himself from the some who question why America should intervene at all, and the others who have suggested that we broaden our military mission beyond the task of protecting the Libyan people, and do whatever it takes to bring down Qaddafi and usher in a new government. The proper course, the president argued, lay somewhere in between, with an intervention designed to save civilian lives, prevent a destabilizing refugee crisis, and stop Qaddafis forces in their tracks, without committing American power (and American troops, and American money ) to the task of changing Libyas regime outright. Here was his defense of of making war (a word he never used, of course) on Qaddafis regime while stopping short of toppling the dictator directly:

title: Contraction is Contractionary
description: Mike Konczal has been blogging about the continuing conservative insistence that slashing government spending is actually expansionary, as embodied in the recent JEC report (pdf). As he says, its a remarkable thing: the empirical case for expansionary austerity has collapsed on examination, but the doctrine lives on regardless.

title: After Stellar Year, Bertelsmann Thinks Deals
description: Bertelsmanns chief financial officer, Thomas Rabe, left, and its chief executive, Hartmut Ostrowski.

title: A Mothers Life Is Taken, as She Feared
description: About a year ago, Patricia Garcia, 5 feet tall and 261 pounds, had allowed herself to become the lead character in an article in The New York Times about the rise in maternal obesity, and how it was putting the health of mothers and babies in jeopardy and forcing hospitals to adapt.

title: Iraqi Hostages Die in Attack on Leadership of Province
description: BAGHDAD  Gunmen wearing police uniforms and suicide vests stormed the provincial council office in the northern Iraqi city of Tikrit on Tuesday and seized hostages in a brazen attack that left dozens of people dead, officials in Tikrit said.

title: Lusi
description: Nickname for a mud volcano in Sidoarjo, Indonesia.(Lumpur [mud] + Sidoarjo.)

title: Live-Blogging a Senate Briefing on Nuclear Safety
description: On Tuesday, the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee heard from four experts on Japans nuclear crisis and efforts to limit risks at nuclear plants in the United States.

title: On Sampling Methods and Santa Rosa
description: Lekelia D. Jenkins, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington, writes from Ecuador, where she is studying factors in the cross-cultural adoption of marine conservation technologies like turtle excluder devices and circle hooks. She leads this project along with Patrick Christie, who is an environmental sociologist and associate professor at the University of Washington.

title: Radioactive Headlines
description: Officials findtoxic plutonium pools around stricken reactor

title: Echoes of Bush in Obamas Libya Speech
description: The mission of President Obamas 28-minute address to the nation was, first and foremost, a narrow one: to explain  and defend  his decision to engage in military action in Libya.

title: Farley Granger, Screen Star of the 1950s, Dies at 85
description: Farley Granger, who found quick stardom in films like Alfred Hitchcocks Strangers on a Train in the 1940s and 50s but who then turned aside from Hollywood to pursue stage and television roles, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Floor Show
description: Late last year, the artists and rug designers Brad Davis and Janis Provisor of Fort Street Studio traveled to Morocco to shop for the tribal rugs known as boucherouites, which are made of everything from wool to synthetic fabrics to scraps of plastic. The rugs abstract, wildly colorful, intensely personal designs make them catnip to creative types like Davis and Provisor. They came home with 33 rugs, which they are exhibiting at their SoHo showroom for two weeks beginning April 28. Along with the boucherouites, the show will include the spoils of one of the couples frequent trips to China, where Fort Streets factory is located: seven Chinese art rugs from the 1980s, including one by LeRoy Neiman that depicts the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Go to fortstreetstudio.com.

title: Willie Nelson May Be Able to Sing His Way Out of Pot Bust
description: When Willie Nelson found himself in trouble with the Internal Revenue Service in the 1990s, it nearly cost him everything he had. But now that country-music outlaw may be able to escape more recent legal troubles for little more than a song.

title: David E. Daviss Mission: To Banish the Boring From Auto Writing
description: Was David E. Davis Jr. the most interesting man in the world? Probably not, though his writing, at its best, could argue the case. Certainly he had more claim to the title than a Mexican beers fictional pitchman whose beard alone has experienced more than a lesser mans entire body. In the case of Mr. Daviss meticulously groomed facial hair, that could well be true.

title: Fill-In | Battling Obesity in Schools
The New York Times and Twitter
description: The Timess new digital-subscription system went global at 2 p.m. E.S.T. yesterday, and I am in a state of high-revenue readiness. Coincidentally, Nicholas Carlson (@nichcarlson) of Silicon Alley Insider had an item on Monday morning about a very interesting report, Who Says What to Whom on Twitter, from Shaomei Wu, of Cornell University, and three researchers at Yahoo. They found that a fairly small number of people who use Twitter generate an awful lot of the posts. As with many things Webby (e.g. Wikipedia), Twitter empowers a small set of superusers. It also extends the reach of existing elites  specifically celebrities and us old-media peeps (joined by new-media bloggers).

title: On the Rise
description: If Joachim de Callatays shoes have the height of a small building and the heft of a piece of furniture, perhaps its because the 31-year-old Belgian studied industrial design rather than fashion. His first collection, which is available at Jeffrey in New York and Patron of the New, includes a wedge (above) that was inspired by the construction of a traditional Japanese house.

title: AMC Confirms Mad Men Delay Over Contract Dispute
description: 1:12 p.m. | Updated

title: S.&P. Downgrades Portugal and Greece Again
description: Standard & Poors said Tuesday that it had cut its sovereign credit ratings for Portugal and Greece, piling further pressure on the two countries with heavy debt loads, weak economies and moribund banks.

title: Twitter Patter | @BronxZoosCobra
description: Tweeting Since MondayFollowers 75,650Twitter Bio Im an Egyptian cobra out on the town.

title: Food Fight!
description: On Monday, in a widely read post for his No Reservations blog, Anthony Bourdain called out the annual James Beard Awards as a goat rodeo and chef shakedown. On Tuesday morning, Kat Kinsman, the managing editor of Eatocracy, a food blog maintained by CNN, issued a cry of protest, asking that all those involved with the Beards not be tarred with the same brush. (Ms. Kinsman is the vice chairwoman of the nominating committee for the Beard journalism awards.)

title: Cricket Offers Chance for India-Pakistan Diplomacy
description: NEW DELHI  With careful diplomatic scripting, India and Pakistan began talking again this week. Officials from the two countries convened in New Delhi to discuss security issues and pave the way for future meetings between more powerful officials. The talks were billed as baby steps, a modest restarting of an important diplomatic dialogue that had stalled.

title: Once Upon a Time in Harvard Square
description: Thank you, Boston, for not dumping beer on my wife during the Rangers-Bruins game on Saturday at the Boston Garden, even though she wore her blue No. 68 Jagr jersey and was cheering for New York. (A former colleague in Boston points out, It may have been an oversight rather than a courtesy.) On Sunday, we stopped in Algiers, a cafe in Harvard Square. I remember Algiers from my years in Boston in the late 80s, early 90s. It was one of the two great cafes in the square. The other, Cafe Pamplona, with a problematic bathroom situation, was better for quick trysts. Back then, Algiers was a smoky, subterranean lair; the kind of place Kropotkin might have appreciated.

title: Schools Under Pressure to Spare the Rod Forever
description: When Tyler Anastopoulos got in trouble for skipping detention at his high school recently, he received the same punishment that students in parts of rural Texas have been getting for generations.

title: Leading Off: Womens Version of Madness
description: We finally have something to talk about in the N.C.A.A. womens tournament, a development so stunning it is reverberating around the sport. One of the superpowers, Tennessee, failed to make it to the Final Four, and falls short for the third straight year no less. It represents a No. 1 seed not making it to the big party. Of course, it lost to a No. 2 seed (Notre Dame), but this represents crazy stuff in the womens game. But yes, its sort of like the classical music getting a little loud during high tea, while the mens Final Four is a toga party.

title: Checking In on Four Marketing Makeovers
description: Last September, Branded featured four small-business owners across the United States who had won a berth in Project REV, a yearlong marketing makeover sponsored by the Deluxe Corporation. Six months later, I was curious about the progress Felicia, Trevor, Tashaand Scot had made with the support of Project REV, Score and their $5,000 in services from Deluxe.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

title: F.B.I. Says It Has Arrested the Holiday Bandit
description: Updated 10:16 p.m. | A Ukrainian man who federal authorities said robbed a string of banks, earning him a place among the F.B.I.s most wanted and the nickname the Holiday Bandit, was arrested early Tuesday in Queens.

title: Japan Weighs Nationalizing a Stricken Utility
description: TOKYO  Japanese lawmakers publicly debated nationalizing the Tokyo Electric Power Company on Tuesday, as there seemed no end in sight to the problems at the companys crippled nuclear power plant.

title: Baselworld 2011 | About Faces
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#718", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: On a Senate Call, a Glimpse of Marching Orders
description: 4:58 p.m. | Updated Um, senators, ever heard of the mute button?

title: Victoria and Albert Museum Names Architect for Expansion
description: Although it may soon be without a director  Mark Jones is leaving to become master of St. Cross College at Oxford this fall, and his replacement has not been named  the Victoria and Albert Museum in London is moving ahead with an expansion that is far more modest than the controversial and expensive Daniel Libeskind plan abandoned seven years ago.

title: On Our Radar: Brazil May Import Ethanol From U.S.
description: Brazil may import ethanol from the United States in April, Brazils oil regulator says. The move comes as a growing number of Brazilian cane farmers choose to produce sugar, which has surged in price over the last year, rather than ethanol, leading to a spike in fuel costs. Earlier this month, Brazil also said that it would import 1.5 million barrels of gasoline in April, while reducing the mixture of ethanol required in gasoline at the pump. [Bloomberg]

title: Hit by the Reality of Cancer Treatment
description: Months into Ruths treatment for breast cancer, after she had completed her chemotherapy, she needed a break. So did I. We cobbled together our airline miles and made plans for a short break in the Caribbean.

title: Allies Renew Demand for Qaddafi to Give Up Power
description: LONDON  Leaders of the four dozen countries and international organizations meeting here on Tuesday made it clear that they agreed that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi would have to relinquish power, even though regime change is not the stated aim of the United Nations resolution authorizing military action against his forces.

title: Custody of Your Child if You Die
description: Who to choose as the guardian of your child?

title: Credit Score Recovery Time After a Foreclosure
description: Wondering how long it will take your credit score to recover from a home foreclosure or short sale? That depends on how good your credit was in the first place, says John Ulzheimer, a credit reporting guru who blogs on the subject for mint.com.

title: Two-faced Sweden
description: I have, in the past, used Swedens experience in the 1990s to illustrate the difficulties we face in recovering from a global financial crisis: Sweden recovered from crisis, but it did so only by devaluing its currency and moving from trade deficit to trade surplus, a route thats not available to the world as a whole (unless we can find another planet to trade with).

title: Spin Takes a Different Approach to an iPad Magazine
description: When print magazines finally begin offering their wares for tablets, there are inevitably some pretty big hurdles.

title: Nationals Werth Is Following Through
description: VIERA, Fla.  The drive from Rochester, Minn., to Springfield, Ill., should take about seven hours by car. But it goes a lot faster when you fly, as Jayson Werth discovered in December 2006.

title: Divining Clues From Spring Training Success
description: Spring training is almost over and your team has been red hot. Or maybe your team has had a tough spring. But who cares? Its just spring training, right? Do wins and losses during spring training mean anything? To answer that, we analyzed whether spring training is connected to performance during the regular season.

title: Wheelies: The Phantom-Espresso Edition
description: In which we bring you automotive news from around the Web:

title: Behind Books for Urban Students, an Unlikely Author
description: Justin Pagan, a seventh grader at the Lower Manhattan Community Middle School, barely liked reading, he said  until he discovered the Bluford series. With the Bluford books, Justins classmate Wilson Velez explained, The thing is, you want to keep reading it because the drama never gets old.

title: Notre Dames Intensity Stuns Tennessee
description: Its happened before, but still stunning to see: Tennessees womens basketball team is out of the N.C.A.A. tournament, thanks to a thorough domination by Notre Dame in the regional final Monday.

title: Bay Hurts Ribcage; Roster Almost Set
description: VIERA, Fla.  Shortly after settling on a 25-man roster Tuesday morning, Mets officials drove here for the Mets game against the Nationals, and by the time they arrived an hour later, the list was in jeopardy.

title: Justices Take Up Crucial Issue in Wal-Mart Suit
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court appeared closely divided on Tuesday during arguments over the theory put forth by the plaintiffs in an enormous sex discrimination class-action case against Wal-Mart.

title: Q&A: Normandys D-Day Sites and Beyond
description: Q.

title: Styled to a T | Todd Bracher
description: The Guy

title: Sleep Machismo
description: Viewing lack of sleep as a virtue.

title: F.D.I.C. Proposes Rule to Tie Banks to Mortgage Risk
description: 8:17 p.m. | Updated

title: Spoiler Alert: Downforce Accessories May Concentrate Pollution
description: Like the tail fins of yore, rear spoilers on the majority of todays passenger cars are primarily appearance enhancers, not downforce tools, because the benefits of downforce are only apparent at high speeds. A new study suggests that rear spoilers do serve a dynamic purpose  one that might induce coughing fits in transportation-design classrooms.

title: More Tools For Thinking
description: In Tuesdays column I describe a symposium over at Edge.org on what scientific concepts everyones cognitive toolbox should hold. There were many superb entries in that symposium, and I only had space to highlight a few, so Id like to mention a few more here.

title: Court to Hear More Arguments in Barnes Foundation Dispute
description: Opponents of a plan to move the Barnes Foundation and its world-renowned art collection from a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown museum quarter asked a Pennsylvania judge on Tuesday to reconsider his 2004 ruling to allow the relocation, arguing that a 2009 documentary about the court case, called The Art of the Steal, revealed new evidence that the judge did not have when he made his decision.

title: Dancing With the Stars Delivers Again for ABC
description: Dancing With the Stars dominated the ratings on Monday as 22.3 million viewers tuned in to a two-hour installment of the ABC reality show, according to Nielsens estimates. ABC led the night by a wide margin, including the 10 p.m. hour after the dancing competition: Castle (12.8 million) outperformed Harrys Law on NBC (8.2 million) and a rerun of Hawaii Five-0 on CBS (5.8 million). CBS ranked second for the night with mostly sitcom repeats from 8 to 10, while NBC was third, averaging 4.2 million for its 8 p.m. special All Together Now: A Celebration of Service, followed by 4.4 million for The Event at 9. Fox was fourth with reruns of House (4.8 million) and The Chicago Code (4 million).

title: Bills, Baby, Bills
description: Frustrated by the Obama administrations slow pace in restarting offshore drilling in the Gulf of Mexico after the Deepwater Horizon accident last year, Republicans in Congress are proposing a range of bills to force the administration to accelerate the granting of drilling permits and open new offshore areas to oil and gas exploration.

title: Citigroup Hires 2 Senior Bankers in London
description: Citigroup announced two senior hires in London on Tuesday as the Wall Street bank expands its British business.

title: Smartphone Market Expected to Soar in 2011
description: Smartphones, smartphones, smarthphones! Thats what we have to look forward to over the next several months.

title: Big Prices Come in Small Packages
Jayson Werth and What Might Have Been
description: VIERA, Fla.  When Ryan Howard struck out looking to end the 2010 National League Championship Series, my pal Gar Ryness, better known as Batting Stance Guy, had a genius text message on Twitter. I cant find it now, but it was something like this: Scott Boras just prepared a simulated version of Jayson Werths game-winning grand slam.

title: A New Era in Melanoma Treatment
description: Dr. Derek Raghavan joins the Consults blog to answer readers questions about melanoma.Last week, the Food and Drug Administration approved Yervoy, or ipilimumab, a new treatment for use in patients with advanced malignant melanoma. The decision is a landmark in view of the relative lack of effective, available treatments for this skin cancer once it has spread through the body.

title: Indictment in $100,000 Theft From PTA
description: When the former PTA treasurer at a public school in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, was arrested in January on charges of embezzling about $5,500 and The Daily News reported her total haul as up to $100,000, the police dismissed the report at a public meeting as completely made up.

title: Fiesta Bowl Spending and Donations Questioned
description: Top executives at the Fiesta Bowl funneled campaign contributions to local politicians, flew other Arizona elected officials around the country at the bowls expense, racked up a $1,200 bill at a strip club and even spent $30,000 on a birthday party for the chief executive, according to an investigative report commissioned by the bowls board of directors.

title: Confident and Calm, Moore Leads the Huskies
description: PHILADELPHIA  With a 75-40 victory over Duke, Connecticut again turned the N.C.A.A. womens tournament into a personal game of Monopoly, earning another title deed to the Final Four in pursuit of a third consecutive national championship. It is an achievement that Geno Auriemma calls 99 percent Maya Moore and one percent coaching.

title: A Snake Escapes the Bronx Zoo and Appears on Twitter
description: Screenshot via Twitter @BronxZoosCobras Twitter stream.Last Friday, as New Yorkers droned through their morning commute, employees of the Bronx Zoo discovered something rather disturbing: An adolescent Egyptian cobra had gone missing from an exhibit enclosure at the zoo.

title: Bravo Milano
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#585", 592, 430, true, chameleonData);

title: Look Busy for the Boss: Bruce Springsteen Visits Little Stevens Underground Garage
description: In the nine years that Little Stevens Underground Garage has been on the air, Steven Van Zandt, this E Street Band guitarist and host of that radio program, has been visited by his share of rock n roll luminaries, including Ringo Starr, Brian Wilson and Keith Richards. But one particularly impressive  and seemingly obvious  guest has eluded Mr. Van Zandt, until now.

title: Comedy of Errors in Kabul as Karzai Aide Is Arrested, Then Released
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai on Tuesday ordered the release of a prominent presidential aide two hours after his arrest on corruption charges, according to two officials in the office of Afghanistans attorney general.

title: Grand Central, 12:35 P.M.
description: Sandra Lee (hands upraised), Food Network star and girlfriend of the governor, hosted the Worlds Largest Bake Sale in Vanderbilt Hall on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Friedrich Hayek, Zombie
description: Brad DeLong directs us to a 1932 letter by Friedrich Hayek and others arguing that (a) deficits somehow caused the Great Depression (b) deficit spending would drive up interest rates and make the Depression worse.

title: Shaka Smart Continues Despite Personal Loss
description: March has been a whirlwind month for Virginia Commonwealth Coach Shaka Smart, from his teams run to the Final Four to his rising stock for more high-profile jobs.

title: You Saw the Movie; Now Heres the Book
description: Sooner than we had imagined, the Deepwater Horizon oil spill has produced an excellent book. Joel Achenbachs A Hole at the Bottom of the Sea: The Race to Kill the BP Oil Gusher, to be published next week by Simon & Schuster, is a gripping reconstruction of the events of last summer, when the nation was transfixed by that seemingly endless disaster.

title: New Gallery Inspired by J. M. W. Turner to Open in England
description: Margate, a town in the far southeast corner of England, may soon become a cultural destination thanks to a new, ambitious gallery inspired by and named after a native artist. For years, the seaside town was a summertime getaway for the English, including the 19th-century artist J. M. W. Turner, who attended school there and, throughout his life, used it as the backdrop for some of his most memorable landscapes.

title: The Pinch of Food and Gas
description: 5:38 p.m. | Updated with 20-year chart

title: Paris, la Nuit
description: Madame Sarkozy, the former-model-turned-actress-singer Carla Bruni, has a starring role in Woody Allens next film, Midnight in Paris, which opens Cannes this year. Does Owen Wilson fall for her or Marion Cotillard? And what chance does the wholesome Rachel McAdams have to keep Wilson, her fianc, from the clutches of these French seductresses? You wont get much of a clue from the trailer, as New York Magazine points out, in which Allen seems to have peopled the streets of Paris with Americans. In his defense, that may be because all of Paris now lives in Manhattan  or Fort Greene.

title: Medvedev Follows Lethal Attack on Islamic Separatists With Warning
description: MOSCOW  A day after an unusual air attack on what officials here said was a militant base in Russias North Caucasus region, President Dmitri A. Medvedev warned separatist fighters in the mostly Muslim region to surrender or be destroyed.

title: Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain
Facebook Removes Palestinian Intifada Page
description: 5:43 p.m. | Updated After complaints by Israeli government officials and Jewish organizations in the United States, Facebook took down a page today by Palestinian supporters that called for violence against Jews and an uprising against Israel.

title: Ex-Galleon Worker Tells of Gathering Tips on Intersil
description: I shared it with Raj.

title: Food Banks? Sandra Lee Enthuses. Budget? No Comment.
description: Sandra Lee, the Food Network personality and best-selling author, was surrounded by butter-cream-frosted cupcakes and mini-pecan pies, poised to kick off what she had billed as the worlds largest bake sale to raise $50,000 for the Food Bank for New York City.

title: New York Attorney General Weighs In on AT&Ts Deal
description: With a deal as big as AT&Ts $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA, a little regulatory review is to be expected.

title: Christopher Dodd Accentuates the Positive in First Speech as Head of Film Group
description: Christopher J. Dodd excoriated movie pirates, complained about the exclusion of many American movies from China, and generally did whats expected of a brand-new chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America in his inaugural speech about the state of the movie industry: Played the cheerleader. I passionately believe there remains no better way to see a movie than in a theater, and no more important relationship for our studios to maintain than the one we have with you, Mr. Dodd told theater executives and others at the CinemaCon convention in Las Vegas on Tuesday. Earlier this month, Mr. Dodd took charge of the motion picture association, an industry trade group, after a long career in politics.

title: Paper Cuts
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#261", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Confronted Challenges and Broken Barriers: Profiling Extraordinary Women
description: Overview | How has life for women changed over the course of the last century? What role have notable women played in changing the roles that women play in our society? In this lesson, students will examine the obituaries of notable women who have recently died to learn more about how life has changed for women over the last century.

title: An Old-Fashioned Promo for Radioheads New Album
description: When Radiohead announced its new album, The King of Limbs, last month, it did so in the high-tech, media-smart way its fans have come to expect: a brief note online, followed by a rush when the songs were made available for download a day earlier than expected.

title: Appreciating Gandhi Through His Human Side
description: Few figures seem more remote from contemporary India than Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, the Mahatma, or Great Soul, who spearheaded the struggle for independence. Gandhis beloved rural poor figure only intermittently in the consciousness of a country now focused on call centers, software entrepreneurs and movie stars. In the cities the Gandhian ideals of service, self-denial and universal uplift have been drowned out by the aggressive nationalism and shiny consumer culture of Indias urban boom.

title: The Overstated Significance of Points in the Paint
description: Points in the paint are among the most basic and straightforward measures of basketball efficiency. Logically, the best shots a player can take are those with a high probability of success (or a higher potential reward, like a 3-pointer), and no shot is more likely to be made than those closest to the basket.

title: Opposition Forces in Ivory Coast Take Towns on 2 Fronts
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Ivory Coast tipped further toward civil war on Tuesday as forces opposed to the nations strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, captured strategic towns on two fronts, diplomats in the countrys main city, Abidjan, said.

title: TimesCast | March 29, 2011
description: American, NATO and Arab officials met in London and agreed that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi must go, but will the international pressure inspire a military coup?

title: Crosstown Tour of India
description: TWO new Indian restaurants have joined the Manhattan fray, competitors for a place in the upper castes of the citys Indian fine-dining scene. Junoon rises lush and enormous off a dark stretch of West 24th Street, an Indian restaurant remade as a luxe Western palace, with a marvelous wine list and perfect rye manhattans. Tulsi glitters bright and almost romantic on East 46th Street across the street from Sparks, a Midtown bet on a great chefs talent.

title: Reviewing Tulsi, Reviewing Junoon
College Plaintiff Takes One for the Team
description: After his junior season in 2009, when he was college footballs sack leader, Von Miller struggled to make what seemed likely to be his career-defining decision. The N.F.L. was beckoning, but Miller, a pass-rushing linebacker, had not redshirted and was just 20. When he and his father sat in the office of Texas A&M Coach Mike Sherman seeking his advice on Millers future, Sherman spoke candidly: Miller did not yet have the maturity to ease the fraught transition to the N.F.L.

title: Photo Replay: March 29
description: The day in sports included the Cricket World Cup semifinal between Sri Lanka and New Zealand, and anticipation for Wednesdays other semifinal, between Pakistan and India.

title: Red Devils, Red Bull Arena: Perfect Together
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Manchester United Manager Alex Ferguson was sitting only a few feet from the Red Bulls striker Thierry Henry, who usually gave Ferguson fits when he played in the English Premier League for Arsenal.

title: A Piece of Gone With the Wind Isnt Gone After All
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn.  Long thought to have been burned the way the North set fire to the cotton at Tara, the final typescript of the last four chapters of Margaret Mitchells Gone With the Wind has turned up in the Pequot Library in this Yankee seaport town. If not quite a spoil of war, the manuscript is a relic of some publishing skirmishes, and it will go on exhibit starting on Saturday, before traveling to Atlanta, Mitchells hometown, in time for the 75th anniversary of the novels publication in June.

title: Japan Nuclear Crisis Erodes Farmers Livelihoods
description: TOWA, Japan  If Japans leaders regard the collapse of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex as this nations greatest crisis in decades, Saichi Sato has a different perspective. From where he sits in this leafy village of 8,000 about 25 miles from Daiichi, he says, this is the greatest crisis in 400 years.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Yemen, Syria and Japan.

title: In Coverage of 2012 Candidates, the Blogs and the Beltway Divide
description: Which Republican presidential candidates are getting the most attention, favorable or otherwise, from the media these days?

title: Dara Foster, Stylist for Clients With Four Legs
description: What does a doggie stylist do? Wendy Williams asked Dara Foster on a recent episode of her syndicated daytime talk show.

title: Go for Broke | Bally Rosella Bag, $750
description: What: Bally black calf Rosella bag

title: Reader Response: Economic Diversity at Colleges
description: I wanted to reply to a few reader comments about the post on the lack of economic diversity at elite colleges.

title: Inside Morgan Stanley Smith Barney
description: The new head of Morgan Stanleys brokerage unit, Greg Fleming, talks to CNBC about how his group fits into the broader company  and what the market environment means for business.

title: George Tooker, Painter Capturing Modern Anxieties, Dies at 90
description: George Tooker, a painter whose haunting images of trapped clerical workers and forbidding government offices expressed a peculiarly 20th-century brand of anxiety and alienation, died on Sunday at his home in Hartland, Vt. He was 90.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Yemen, Syria and Japan.

title: A Safe Walk in the Dark
description: I STUMBLED into a United Nude store for the first time a couple of weeks ago in Miami. I was curious, because I was told that the creative director of the store was the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas. This turned out to be completely specious.

title: Reuters Freelancer Killed in Iraq
description: Sabah al-Bazee, a 30-year-old freelance journalist for Reuters whose photographs captured the often bloody struggles around the northern Iraq city of Tikrit, was among those killed Tuesday when gunmen dressed in police uniforms and suicide vests stormed the provincial council office there. The announcement of his death was made by Reuters. Sabah, who was killed by shrapnel, was outside the building, trying as always to get the news and to tell it, Peter Graff wrote in a tribute on the Reuters Photographers blog.

title: Tax Season Gets Trickier for Some Gay Couples
description: Tax season often delivers more than the usual set of headaches for same-sex couples. But its about to get incredibly more complicated for couples living in California, Nevada and Washington. There is an upside, though. Many of them will save thousands of dollars in federal income taxes.

title: Dance Along With Twyla and Other Online Nuggets
description: The Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival has long been known for eclectic lineups: ballet one week, flamenco the next. Alongside plenty of modern and contemporary performances, tap, street, Broadway, African and Indian (American and South Asian) styles have also made appearances. That breadth becomes apparent perusing the Pillows new online archive of video clips, which made its debut on Monday.

title: After Science Meets Art, Everyone Gets Some Cake
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Its by now well established that science and art have a lot in common, as well as much to teach each other. For evidence you need look no further than the choreographer Wayne McGregors scientific ventures, which include a research fellowship at Cambridge Universitys neuroscience department.

title: Soundtrack for Bird and Turtle, and Other New Music
description: The composer and conductor Victoria Bond has always devoted her Cutting Edge Concerts series to recent works, but she has tinkered with the format over the years. For several seasons, she tried to prod listeners, and perhaps performers, to think differently about music by bringing in artists from other disciplines to discuss what they do. More recently, Ms. Bond has reconfigured the series as a new-music festival. Chat remains a component, but now it is entirely musical: each performance is introduced by an interview with the composer, and Ms. Bond is adept at getting composers to speak concisely about their goals and processes.

title: Sounds of a New World, a Few Years On
description: You know you are entering relatively uncharted territory when the old guard on a concert program is represented by Gyorgy Ligeti. And for the JACK Quartet, the Ligeti work it played at Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday evening, the String Quartet No. 2 (1968), must have seemed an antique. It is older than any of the ensembles players by more than a decade. For that matter, the oldest of the JACK players were teenagers when Horatiu Radulescu completed his String Quartet No. 5 (Before the Universe Was Born, 1995), the long, otherworldly soundscape that closed the program.

title: Where the Grid Will Not Go
description: When an Italian priest and his cadre of nuns founded the Munyaga Health Center in 1986, it was a barebones operation. Tucked among the rolling green hills and small mud homes of eastern Rwanda, the health center had limited services; the nearest source of potable water was five miles away, and kerosene lamps were often the only source of light. The centers most expensive technology was an array of solar cells to provide power for part of the day.

title: Becks Back, With Roots Rock the Les Paul Way
description: Jeff Beck has demoted himself to sideman for his Rock n Roll Party tour, which came to the Beacon Theater on Monday night.

title: Zyngas Wall Street Debut
description: While Zynga may not be going public for awhile, the Internet gaming company has made its Wall Street debut.

title: Led Zeppelins Stairway to Tully Hall
description: Twisted is a term with which the composer Mark-Anthony Turnage presumably has some acquaintance, given his abrasive subjects and vernacular borrowings in major pieces like the opera Greek and the chamber orchestra work Blood on the Floor  not to mention Anna Nicole, his recent opera based on the life and death of the troubled celebrity Anna Nicole Smith.

title: U.S. Chemist Is Charged With Insider Stock Trades
description: A 15-year veteran of the federal Food and Drug Administration and his 25-year-old son were arrested on Tuesday and charged with systematically using confidential information about pending drug applications to reap millions in illegal trading profits since 2007.

title: A Day in the Garden, Riding Mood Swings
description: Of all the reviews Ive read, the single line that most often floats through my head is probably this one, written in 2004 in The New York Times by Kelefa Sanneh, about the English pop singer Dido: She has figured out a way to make music that is no better, but also no worse, than silence.

title: Qaddafi Forces Counterattack
description: Having halted a westward push by rebel fighters, pro-Qaddafi forces on Tuesday marched eastward to Ras Lanuf.

title: U.A.W. Open to More Jobs At a Second-Tier Pay Level
description: ORION TOWNSHIP, Mich.  The United Automobile Workers union might allow carmakers to put more new workers on a lower wage scale to create more jobs and reopen idled plants, a U.A.W. official said Tuesday.

title: A Classic Comedy Upended: Changing Female to Male, and Old to Young
description: Thanks to the new proliferation of live broadcasts, we now can watch dance productions from Europe at the moment of their performance. This is not always a boon, however.

title: On the Edge | Paul Johnson
description: At his dynamic downtown Manhattan space, Paul Johnson caters to collectors with visions as daring as his own. Go to interactive feature >>

title: At Forum for Deal Makers, M.&A. Meets the Law
description: Harry Campbell

title: A Visit to London, With Students as My Guide
description: Back in January, I was handed a daunting task: spend a week in London on a budget. The city consistently ranks far ahead of any city in the United States in cost-of-living indexes; so the cost of traveling couldnt be far behind.   To make matters worse, my first step was to lose $600 on a Craigslist rental scam.

title: George Tooker: 1920-2011
description: The painter, whose haunting images expressed a peculiarly 20th-century brand of anxiety and alienation, died on Sunday at 90.

title: Another Tylenol Recall
description: 4/4/11 | Updated to fix link to list of recalled products.

title: The Varied Costs of Catastrophe
