description: Ive written repeatedly about how there are two utterly divergent human worlds at this remarkable juncture in our history  one in which lives and economies are enabled by technology and ample energy, and a much larger one without those assets (I use that word in a nonjudgmental way).

title: Global Crises Cause Turbulent Times for Airlines
description: Political upheaval and the nuclear crisis in Japan have taken their toll on air travel this year.

title: For a Hot-and-Cold March, 1921 Has 2011 Beat
description: If you think this Marchs weather has been zig-zagging zanily, you should have been here 90 years ago.

title: DealBook: Zyngas Wall Street Debut
description: While Zynga may not be going public for a while, the Internet gaming company has made its Wall Street debut.

title: Season 5 of Mad Men Is Delayed Until 2012
description: Mad Men, the three-time Emmy Award-winning drama, will not return to television until sometime early next year, AMC confirmed on Tuesday, because of a deepening dispute with the shows creator, Matthew Weiner.

title: Raging Domesticity Erupts From a Dominatrix Encounter
description: When you title your play Sex on Sunday (Or How to Make a Man Stay, Beg and Roll Over), youd better be prepared to deliver the goods. But Chisa Hutchinson, the writer of this Be Company production at Urban Stages, cant decide whether she wants to titillate, educate or entertain sitcom-style.

title: A First Look at Mercurys Surface
description: It is the first photo from the first spacecraft to orbit the first rock from the Sun.

title: Apollo Prices I.P.O. at $19 a Share
description: 12:08 p.m. | Updated Shares of Apollo Global Management slumped on their debut on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday.

title: Q&A: Avoiding Glare on the Go
description: Q.

title: Eternal Complexities of the Very Simple Life
description: Le Quattro Volte, an idiosyncratic and amazing new film by Michelangelo Frammartino, is so full of surprises  nearly every shot contains a revelation, sneaky or overt, cosmic or mundane  that even to describe it is to risk giving something away. At the same time, the nervous reviewers convention of posting spoiler alerts has rarely seemed so irrelevant. Would I ruin tomorrow by telling you the sun is going to rise? Will your life be spoiled if I divulge that it will end in your death?

title: 3 of 14 Pit Bulls Hurt in Bronx Fire Were Euthanized
description: Three of the 14 pit bulls who were badly injured in an apartment fire in the Bronx three weeks ago were euthanized at a veterinary hospital shortly after their rescue, Richard Gentles, a spokesman for Animal Care and Control of New York City, said this week.

title: Excerpt: 'Capriccio'
description: Rene Fleming sings the lead in the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Strauss's "Capriccio."

title: Words or Music: Why Choose?
description: Throughout her career Rene Fleming has made very personal choices of opera roles. Some have confounded even her fans. A live Sony recording documents how brilliantly she sang the title role of Rossinis Armida in 1993 at the Rossini Festival in Pesaro, Italy. But when she reprised that role for Mary Zimmermans 2010 production of the work at the Metropolitan Opera, which returned last month, she had to compromise technically on the coloratura passagework in this demanding music. It seemed a curious choice.

title: Valeant Makes $5.7 Billion Hostile Bid for Cephalon
description: 8:12 p.m. | Updated

title: MacNeil Returns to NewsHour for Autism Series
description: Veteran journalist Robert MacNeil will return to the PBS NewsHour in April for a six-part series of reports on autism, the program said Tuesday.

title: F.D.A. Panel to Consider Warnings for Artificial Food Colorings
description: WASHINGTON  After staunchly defending the safety of artificial food colorings, the federal government is for the first time publicly reassessing whether foods like Jell-O, Lucky Charms cereal and Minute Maid Lemonade should carry warnings that the bright artificial colorings in them worsen behavior problems like hyperactivity in some children.

title: Where Wal-Mart Failed, Aldi Succeeds
description: While Wal-Mart revives its plans to get into New York City, a giant German retailer has slipped in relatively unnoticed.

title: Still Crusading, but Now on the Inside
description: WASHINGTON  Samantha Power took the podium at Columbia University on Monday night sounding hoarse and looking uncomfortable. In two hours, President Obama would address the nation on Libya and Ms. Power, the fiery human rights crusader who now advises Mr. Obama on foreign policy, did not want to get out in front of the boss.

title: Justice Lawyers Cleared in Voting Case
description: The Justice Departments internal ethics watchdog on Tuesday told Congress that it had cleared all department lawyers of wrongdoing in relation to a much-disputed voter-intimidation case involving the New Black Panther Party, a black-nationalist fringe group.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: An Exhibit Focuses on Food Loved by the Camera
description: An exhibition of food photography from the last 80 years or so, including names like Irving Penn and Ansel Adams, shows the artistry and range of the genre. It includes a panorama of food signs by Berenice Abbott, silvery fish in a 1930s French market, and arresting still-life arrangements by Paulette Tavormina and Julie Blackmon inspired by Flemish and Dutch masters.

title: A Tour of Bon Yagis Japantown
description: If youre a New Yorker whos fond of Japanese food, youve probably patronized one of Bon Yagis 11 restaurants in the East Village.

title: Calamansi Juice Hard to Find? Not So at Shi Eurasia
description: On the off chance that you need Vegemite from Australia, calamansi juice from the Philippines, chili-spiked canned tuna from Malaysia and Polish chocolate-covered dried plums all at once, Shi Eurasia, on the Lower East Side, is for you. Erry Ong, from Malaysia, and her two partners, from England and from Iceland, thought it was time New York had a shop where hard-to-find Asian and European products were sold. They plan to add France, Italy and Spain to the inventory, but those countries are not their focus.

title: David Burke Kitchen
description: The James New York, 23 Grand Street (between Avenue of the Americas and Thompson Street), SoHo; (212) 201-9119.

title: Ember Room
description: 647 Ninth Avenue (West 45th Street), Clinton; (212) 245-8880.

title: An East Village Ambassador for Japanese Cuisine
description: SOON after the earthquake and the tsunami pulverized the northeastern coast of Japan earlier this month, the men and women who work at Japanese restaurants in the East Village began setting out little cardboard boxes so customers could leave a few dollars to help the ravaged country.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Aid for Japan and Italy

title: An Easter Treat From the Cake Boss
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: Charlie Trotter, a Leader Left Behind
description: CHICAGO

title: Joining Virginia Ham: Salami and Speck
description: Think Virginia and think ham. But now there is salami and speck from heritage pork to consider. Late last year, Olli Salumeria in Manakin, Va., near Richmond, began selling cured meats inspired by Italian recipes. Co-founded by Oliviero Colmignoli, known as Olli, whose great-great-grandfather started the Fiorucci meat company in Italy, it buys Mangalitsa pork from producers in several states.

title: A New iPad Speaker Dock from JBL
description: Audio-component maker JBL announced this week its OnBeat iPad speaker dock. Costing $150, the OnBeat can increase the iPads audio output while also charging the tablet. A USB port can connect the dock to a computer, so it can charge, amplify and sync an iPad at the same time.

title: Doctrine for Libya: Not Carved in Stone
description: WASHINGTON  So, is there an Obama doctrine?

title: $14 Million Jury Award to Ex-Inmate Is Dismissed
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday threw out a $14 million jury award in favor of a former death row inmate who was freed after prosecutorial misconduct came to light.

title: Obama, at U.N., Hails Allies in Libya Action
description: President Obama on Tuesday used the dedication of the United States mission at the United Nations to again hail the international coalition fighting to protect civilians in Libya, contrasting it with times in the past when allies inaction led to wars and atrocities.

title: U.S. Changes Lineup and Formation for Paraguay
description: United States Coach Bob Bradley made five changes to his starting lineup for Tuesdays exhibition match against Paraguay in Nashville. The more noteworthy change is how those players will line up: Bradley has the U.S. in a 4-4-2 for the game, rather than the much more defensive  and largely ineffective, offensively at least  4-5-1 that the Americans used in the first half Saturdays 1-1 tie against Argentina.

title: Rhode Island: Receivership Is Upheld
description: The State Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld a law allowing Rhode Island to take control of financially troubled cities. The law, passed last year, allowed the state to appoint a receiver to act in place of local officials in Central Falls, which declared fiscal insolvency in May. Mayor Charles D. Moreau sued, asserting that the law violated his right to due process and the citys right to self-governance. But the court ruled that the law was constitutional because the receivership was temporary and Mr. Moreau had not been removed from office.

title: Acers Iconia Is the Craziest Laptop of All Time
description: Sometimes engineers get excited about things without stopping to ask the question: Why? Why is this better? Why would anyone want this?

title: State Agency Puts Off Vote on Importing Electricity
description: Would they or wouldnt they? Not even the trustees of the New York Power Authority themselves knew for sure.

title: Manchester United Plans a U.S. Sweep
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Manchester United Manager Alex Ferguson was sitting only a few feet from the Red Bulls striker Thierry Henry, who usually gave Ferguson fits when he played in the English Premier League for Arsenal.

title: Under a Cooking Magazine and Medical Journal, a Clear Congratulations
description: Saturday morning, and my window is wide open. Is that the garbage truck? No, too quiet. I stumble out of bed and make it to the front door without running into anything. This is a good day so far. Greg gets back into his truck and pulls away, stopping twice more before turning out of the cul-de-sac and vanishing around the corner.

title: Lessons From Fukushima Taught on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON  Almost all American nuclear power plants have backup batteries that would last only half as long as those at Japans troubled Fukushima Daiichi plant did after a tsunami knocked out power there, an expert testified Tuesday at a Senate committee briefing on nuclear safety.

title: Alaska Clash Over Resources and Rights Heats Up
description: JUNEAU, Alaska  Anyone interested in learning more about the distinctive flora and fauna here in the Last Frontier will want to pick up a copy of an unconventional new field guide: the 2010 Annual Report of the Alaska Department of Law.

title: Same .270 Average, Varied Weight
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Of the 151 players who qualified for batting titles last year, five hit exactly .270 and two of them patrolled the left side of the Yankees infield.

title: 7-Day D.L. Established to Aid in Recovery From Concussions
description: In a decision expected to improve the treatment of baseball players with concussions, Major League Baseball will allow teams this season to place those players on a disabled list for seven days rather than the customary 15, the league and players union announced on Tuesday.

title: Budget Fight Faces Hurdle Beyond Price Tag
description: WASHINGTON  The most visible element of the budget fight in Congress is the one over the scale of spending cuts this year. But increasingly, other deeply contentious policy issues that House Republicans insist must be addressed in any budget deal are as much of a stumbling block as the final dollar figure.

title: Syrias Cabinet Resigns; Concessions Expected
description: CAIRO  The Syrian government resigned Tuesday in what might have been a prelude to other concessions in a speech President Bashar al-Assad is expected to give to the nation on Wednesday, part of an expanding effort to address protests against his authoritarian rule.

title: Irving Shulman, Retailer of Discount Apparel, Dies at 96
description: Irving J. Shulman, who founded the Daffys clothing store chain and brought discount fashion to Fifth Avenue through quirky marketing and a promise of clothing bargains for millionaires, died on Friday in Houston. He was 96 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Rangers See Room to Move Up
description: BUFFALO  The Rangers are on the verge of qualifying for the Stanley Cup playoffs, a journey that began here six months ago on opening night with a 6-3 victory over the Sabres.

title: As Regulators Weigh AT&T Bid, a Look at Wireless Markets Abroad
description: For Americans, complaining about big cellphone bills that seem to only get bigger is standard practice. But they may actually be getting a pretty good deal  globally speaking.

title: Interpublic, 5 Years and 180 Degrees Later
description: FOR the Interpublic Group of Companies, what a difference five years and two days make.

title: Group Seeks Labor E-Mails by Michigan Professors
description: A conservative research group in Michigan has issued a far-reaching public records request to the labor studies departments at three public universities in the state, seeking any e-mails involving the Wisconsin labor turmoil.

title: House Votes to Scrap Foreclosure Program
description: Republicans, ignoring a veto threat from the White House, pushed a bill through the House on Tuesday that would eliminate a foreclosure prevention program that provides financial incentives to mortgage servicers who modify loans for homeowners who are behind on their payments.

title: Parsing Obamas Address on Libya
description: To the Editor:

title: Players Detail Dealings With Bondss Trainer
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With only his ruddy face betraying any nervousness, Jason Giambi, the former Yankees slugger who plays for the Colorado Rockies, calmly testified Tuesday at Barry Bondss perjury trial, describing the items he received from Bondss trainer, Greg Anderson, as if reciting items on his grocery list.

title: Confusion Over Policy on Married Gay Immigrants
description: An announcement by immigration officials in Washington on Monday that they were delaying decisions on some immigration cases involving gay couples led to a surge of expectations among gay advocates that the Obama administration had taken a small but significant step toward recognizing same-sex marriage.

title: They Know All About You
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring Frances Perkins
description: To the Editor:

title: Take the Koch Bridge ...
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Migration
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Galleon Employee Tells of Firms Insider Trades
description: Despite his impeccable pedigree, Adam Smith still thought he needed an edge on Wall Street.

title: Foreclosure Aid Fell Short, and Is Fading
description: Last summer, as President Obamas premier plan to save millions of Americans from foreclosure foundered, the administration tossed a new life preserver to homeowners.

title: Ohio Lawmakers Pass Anti-Union Bill
description: CHICAGO  Ohio lawmakers approved legislation Wednesday to limit collective bargaining rights for public sector workers, while legislation in Wisconsin continued to be tied up in the courts.

title: Audit of Pentagon Spending Finds $70 Billion in Waste
description: Despite improvements, more than half of the Pentagons big weapons systems still cost more than they should, with management failures adding at least $70 billion to the projected costs over the last two years, government auditors said Tuesday.

title: In City Schools, Tech Spending to Rise Despite Cuts
description: Despite sharp drops in state aid, New York Citys Department of Education plans to increase its technology spending, including $542 million next year alone that will primarily pay for wiring and other behind-the-wall upgrades to city schools.

title: A Victim, Her Picture and Facebook
description: The truth, said Chrissy Criscitiello, is that she never gave a moments thought to the deal she was making when she posted pictures on Facebook. Theyre of me and my friends when we go out, Ms. Criscitiello said. My sons graduation. My husbands family reunion. A vacation we went on to Lake Wallenpaupack.

title: Finally, California Finds a Surplus: 50 Feet of Snow
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sure, fine, California may have its problems right now. There is the budget, yes, what with that pesky $26.5 billion deficit, and the legislative stalemate with its, you know, stalemate-ness. Unemployment is still high, and so is anxiety, about everything from housing prices to radioactive clouds drifting over from Japan.

title: Washington in Fierce Debate on Arming Libyan Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is engaged in a fierce debate over whether to supply weapons to the rebels in Libya, senior officials said on Tuesday, with some fearful that providing arms would deepen American involvement in a civil war and that some fighters may have links to Al Qaeda.

title: As Economy Sputters, a Timid Fed
description: WASHINGTON

title: Chinatown Mobilizes to Enhance Its Outside Appeal
description: The 9/11 attacks took a particularly large toll on small businesses in Chinatown. Dependent on tourists and clients who work downtown, shopkeepers saw sales fall precipitously  and have struggled to return activity to the levels of a decade ago.

title: In Congress, Bills to Speed Unwinding of 2 Giants
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans announced a package of eight bills on Tuesday that would wind down the mortgage finance giants, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, more quickly than the Obama administration proposed.

title: Glimmer of Better Days for Manhattan Offices
description: In late 2008, with the economy in free fall and the collapse of negotiations with an anchor tenant, Boston Properties halted construction on an office tower at 250 West 55th Street in Manhattan.

title: Lincoln and the Little Giant
description: It was shortly after noon on Inauguration Day, and Abraham Lincoln was standing on a wooden portico teeming with dignitaries on the western side of the Capitol. In his hands were his inaugural address and his trademark stovepipe hat. He fumbled awkwardly with the hat, first placing it beside him on the floor, then picking it up as the growing throng forced him closer to the front. As his friend Edward Baker introduced him to the massive audience, he shifted the hat from hand to hand, uncertain what to do with it. Finally Senator Stephen A. Douglas, his old Illinois rival and closest challenger in the recent election, who had been looking on quietly, and apparently with some apprehensions of a catastrophe to the hat, said, Permit me, Sir, and gallantly took the vexatious article and held it during the entire reading of the Inaugural!

title: A Bad Record on Buybacks
description: Home Depot investors cheered the companys new stock repurchase plan, adding about $1.5 billion to its market value on Tuesday. History suggests they should curb some of their enthusiasm. American companies have a terrible track record of buying their own shares high and selling them low. Home Depots $1 billion program adds to the $136 billion of buybacks announced this year. Only the market peak of 2007 had more such activity. Thats not a good sign.

title: Zimbabwe Lawmakers Pick Mugabe Rival for Post
description: JOHANNESBURG  In a rare upset for President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, the countrys Parliament on Tuesday decisively re-elected one of his political opponents to serve as its speaker.

title: Where the Bailout Went Wrong
description: Washington

title: Oprah Tweets in a Bid for Viewers
description: Oprah Winfrey and her colleagues took to Twitter on Sunday night to promote a new episode of a show on OWN, her new cable channel. Did the posting help her ratings?

title: China: Government Tells U.N. Agency Not to Interfere
description: A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said Tuesday that human rights monitors at the United Nations should respect Chinas sovereignty, in effect rebuffing a demand that a prominent dissident lawyer, Gao Zhisheng, be released immediately from secret detention. The demand, which was made in a letter to the government in July, was made public on Monday. The spokeswoman, Jiang Yu, said at a regularly scheduled news conference in Beijing that she did not know the specifics of Mr. Gaos case. We attach importance to cooperation with the U.N. human rights monitoring mechanism and urge the mechanism to respect Chinas judicial sovereignty, she said. China is a country under the rule of law. Mr. Gao, missing for almost one year, had said earlier that he had been tortured in the past.

title: Pakistan: Six Held in Attack on Sri Lanka Cricket Team
description: Pakistan has arrested six men wanted in the March 2009 attack on Sri Lankas national cricket team, a police official in Lahore said Tuesday. Six police officers and a driver were killed, and six team members hurt, in the commando-style attack. The aim of this operation was to kidnap Sri Lankan players and exchange them for Taliban prisoners, said the police official, Aslam Tarin.

title: The Syrian President I Know
description: San Antonio, Tex.

title: Planners of Mosque Considering New Project
description: Two co-founders of the plan to build a Muslim community center and mosque in downtown Manhattan have begun exploring a new, and possibly competing, project: an interfaith cultural center that they said might be located at the currently proposed site, two blocks from ground zero, or elsewhere in the neighborhood.

title: High School Graduation Rate in the City Is Lower Than Reported
description: New York Citys high school graduation rate may be slightly lower than advertised because some dropouts have been improperly left out of the calculations, the state comptrollers office said Tuesday.

title: Looking for Luck in Libya
description: There is an old saying in the Middle East that a camel is a horse that was designed by a committee. That thought came to my mind as I listened to President Obama trying to explain the intervention of America and its allies in Libya  and I dont say that as criticism. I say it with empathy. This is really hard stuff, and its just the beginning.

title: After 9 Bank Holdups and Much Publicity, a Suspect Is Caught
description: A Ukrainian man who federal authorities said robbed a string of banks, earning him a place among the F.B.I.s most wanted and the nickname the Holiday Bandit, was arrested early Tuesday in Queens.

title: After Fire Kills 3, Returning to Salvage Urn With Another Daughters Ashes
description: The woman stared up in shock at the scorched remains of her Brooklyn apartment on Tuesday morning, a day after a fire there killed two of her daughters and her husband. She was hoping for a small piece of salvation.

title: Wednesday: Not So Off the Wall
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  True Confessions time: It took me a while to figure out what was going on here, thematically speaking.

title: Retooled Mets at Fraction of the Cost
description: VIERA, Fla.  For the first time since March 6, and for only the second time in spring training, Carlos Beltran played in a Grapefruit League game Tuesday, signaling he is ready to rejoin the Mets and open the season in right field.

title: Budget Talks in California Break Down
description: LOS ANGELES  Negotiations between California Republican leaders and Gov. Jerry Brown on a package to close the states huge budget deficit  including a proposal to ask residents to vote on an extension of about $12.5 billion in taxes this June  collapsed on Tuesday with each side accusing the other of intransigence.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 29, 2011

title: Anthony and Knicks Can See What Might Have Been
description: Carmelo Anthony was finally able to bask in another win as a Knick on Tuesday, as well as in the unveiling of a 128-foot advertising billboard of himself.

title: Obama Returns to Harlem for a Lucrative Fund-Raiser
description: Add this to all the evidence that Harlem has been gentrified since Barack Obamas days as a Columbia University student: He returned there on Tuesday evening as the nations first African-American president, and for a $30,800-a-person fund-raiser.

title: Does Core Inflation Predict Overall Inflation?
description: In his recent op-ed in The Times, Laurence Meyer, a former Federal Reserve governor, argued that core inflation  excluding oil and food prices  was a better predictor of future inflation than overall inflation was. In other words, if overall inflation is rising rapidly but core inflation is not, as is happening now, we should assume that overall inflation will soon drop.

title: Mexican Immigrants Face Darkest Housing Picture
description: Among New Yorkers, it is a sentiment universally shared: the housing situation is tough. But a new study suggests that no one has it as tough as the citys Mexican immigrants.

title: Former PTA Treasurer at Brooklyn School Is Indicted in Theft of $100,000
description: A former PTA treasurer at a public school in Brooklyn has been indicted on charges that she embezzled about $100,000 from the organization over a two-year period.

title: Promoting Bicycle Lanes as if They Were on the Ballot
description: Struggling to control the controversy over one of its signature transportation policies, the Bloomberg administration is embarking on an unusual kind of political campaign: convincing New Yorkers that bicycle lanes are good for them.

title: Virginia Tech Faces a Fine for Its Delays After Shooting
description: The Department of Education fined Virginia Tech $55,000 on Tuesday for waiting too long to notify students after the 2007 campus shooting that left 33 people dead.

title: Why Were Fasting
description: I stopped eating on Monday and joined around 4,000 other people in a fast to call attention to Congressional budget proposals that would make huge cuts in programs for the poor and hungry.

title: Given a Shot, Alabama Takes Hold
description: Before Alabama fought off Colorado, 62-61, in a National Invitation Tournament semifinal Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, both coaches  Alabamas Anthony Grant and Colorados Tad Boyle  had seen their previous teams register more March decibels.

title: Ellen McCormack, Anti-Abortion Presidential Candidate, Dies at 84
description: Ellen McCormack, a self-described housewife and grandmother who ran for president as an anti-abortion candidate in 1976 and 1980, doing well enough to become the first woman to qualify as a candidate for federal financing and Secret Service protection, died on Sunday in Avon, Conn. She was 84.

title: Cuomo to Tighten Requirements for Workers in Homes for Disabled
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos administration is planning to announce initial steps aimed at addressing problems of abuse in homes for the developmentally disabled that are overseen by the state.

title: Agency Lawyers Cleared in Voting Case
description: The Justice Departments internal ethics watchdog told Congress on Tuesday that it had cleared all department lawyers of wrongdoing in relation to a voter-intimidation case involving the New Black Panther Party, a black-nationalist fringe group. In a letter to the House Judiciary Committee, the departments Office of Professional Responsibility said it had found no evidence that officials involved in decisions about the case acted inappropriately out of political or racial motivations. The office said its conclusion applied both to officials who brought a sweeping civil lawsuit against the party in the closing days of the Bush administration and to those who decided to reduce the scope of the case early in the Obama administration. The case involved accusations that two party members had intimidated voters at a Philadelphia polling place in November 2008.

title: The High Price of Rigidity
description: House Republicans have already won so much in this years federal budget standoff that they could easily declare victory and put an end to the maddening and dysfunctional cycle. Previous Congresses would have noticed that millions of people are still struggling in an economic downturn and tried to help, but Republicans have succeeded in shutting off that conversation.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Preserving the Coalition
description: The United States, its allies and Libyan rebels all want to see Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi out of power and support United Nations-mandated military action to keep him from slaughtering innocent civilians. But as an international conference of those allies proved on Tuesday, they are going to have to work hard to maintain that unity of purpose, and they have a long way to go to flesh out a long-term strategy for Libya.

title: Time Runs Out for St. Bernard Parish
description: It has taken far too long, but the Department of Housing and Urban Development has finally intervened in an outrageous case of housing discrimination by the government of St. Bernard Parish, an overwhelmingly white district adjacent to New Orleans.

title: Police Say Woman Picked Many Pockets in Chinatown
description: A 67-year-old woman from Florida, the authorities say, found an unusual way to experience the town on her frequent trips to Manhattan: strolling through Chinatown, picking the pockets of unsuspecting pedestrians.

title: Adventures in Reptilian Vocabulary
description: Today we learn the word elapidae  a family of snakes that includes the Egyptian cobra (species Naja haje) that has been missing at the Bronx Zoo since Friday. What makes an elapid elapidated? Fangs that are proteroglyphous, which means they appear at the front of the mouth. They are also hollow and short. A cobra cant merely bite to deliver its venom, like a rattlesnake (which is solenoglyphous, with long, folding fangs). It must bite and hang on. It compensates for this inefficiency by having more powerful venom.

title: Mets to Try to Convince Isringhausen to Stay
description: VIERA, Fla.  Mets Manager Terry Collins said he would meet with Jason Isringhausen on Wednesday morning to try to convince him to remain in Florida for extended spring training. The Mets chose to keep the right-handed reliever Blaine Boyer on the team instead of Isringhausen, and designated the right-handed reliever Manny Acosta for assignment.

title: When It Counts Most, Texas A&M Beats Baylor
description: DALLAS  At the end of the N.C.A.A. womens tournament regional final here Tuesday, the happiest player on the court was Texas A&Ms star senior Danielle Adams, whose moony smile belied the fact that she had just endured, in terms of pure numbers, a terrible night.

title: Israel: Facebook Removes a Page Calling for Violence
description: After complaints by Israeli officials and American Jewish groups, Facebook took down a page Tuesday by Palestinian supporters that called for violence against Jews and an uprising against Israel. The page, titled Third Palestinian Intifada, began this month as a call for peaceful protests in the occupied Palestinian territories, one of more than a dozen Facebook pages used recently to mobilize uprisings across the Middle East and North Africa. The unidentified advocates who managed the page initially removed comments that promoted violence, according to Facebook officials. But as the page grew to 340,000 members as of Monday, Facebook officials said the comments had deteriorated into direct calls for violence against Israel and Jews.

title: What the Circus Can Teach Us About Sports Injuries
description: Can the tears of a clown contribute to the twisted ankle of a clown? According to an offbeat new study of the psychological underpinnings of sports injuries, the answer is a guarded yes, depending on just what occasioned those tears.

title: Word of the Day | pry
description: pry \pri\ verb

title: TimesCast | Push to Topple Qaddafi
description: Steven Lee Meyers reports from London, where leaders of more than 40 countries met and agreed on the need to remove Qaddafi.

title: TimesCast | Potential for Military Coup
description: David D. Kirkpatrick reports on how military force and international pressure could inspire a coup that topples Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: More Remains Found on L.I. Beach
description: Investigators found more remains Tuesday on a Long Island beach where the bodies of four women were found in December, the Suffolk County police said.

title: News Quiz | March 30, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 30, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article Itinerant Life Weighs on Farmworkers Children.

title: Dangerous Levels of Radioactive Isotope Found 25 Miles From Nuclear Plant
description: WASHINGTON  A long-lasting radioactive element has been measured at levels that pose a long-term danger at one spot 25 miles from the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, raising questions about whether Japans evacuation zone should be expanded and whether the land might need to be abandoned.

title: Tullow Sells Stakes in Ugandan Project to Total and Cnooc
description: Tullow Oil, the British energy company, said on Wednesday that it was selling stakes in its Ugandan oil exploration project to China National Offshore Oil Corporation and Total of France for $2.9 billion.

title: Daily Lexeme: Ombrellino
description: Todays word, in association with the renowned Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Philippines Says China Executes Three Filipinos
description: MANILA  Three Filipinos convicted of drug trafficking in China were executed on Wednesday, Filipino officials said, prompting grief and outrage in the Philippines.

title: The Kennedys, in History and on Film
description: WHO produced and wrote the television movie The Kennedys?

title: Daily Life in the Business of Death
description: When Scott Palmer was growing up in Gowrie, Iowa, it wasnt unusual for him to be picked up by a hearse with a body in it. Death was part of day-to-day life.

title: India Wins Cricket Game Tinged by Politics
description: NEW DELHI  India rejoiced on Wednesday after defeating Pakistan in the World Cup of cricket, a sporting event charged with geopolitics. The prime ministers of the nuclear-armed neighbors had sought to improve relations by sitting together in the grandstands.

title: Should Schools Be Allowed to Use Corporal Punishment?
description: Corporal  physical  punishment of students has a long history, and 20 states still permit its use. What are the arguments for and against corporal punishment? Should administrators and teachers be allowed to discipline students physically? Why or why not?

title: Indonesia Headed to Pakistan to Identify Possible Bali Bombing Suspect
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia Indonesia will send a team of counterterrorism officers to Pakistan to identify and possibly bring home an alleged Islamist militant accused of playing a key role in the deadly 2002 nightclub bombings on Bali, officials said Wednesday.

title: Measuring Jobless Families
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Nokia Wants a Standard for In-Car Telematics
description: While Terminal Mode may sound like a death-ray setting in a bad science-fiction novel, its aims are far less dastardly. It is the name of a unified standard that would connect drivers and their smartphones to the swirling proliferation of in-car infotainment systems.

title: Fantasy Focus: Old and Boring Bargain Hitters
description: While we rightfully are looking for players on their upward arc, often in that quest we leave behind veteran players that can prove valuable in the short term. The old and boring veterans that slide in drafts arent going to have career years more often than not, but they will provide a pretty stable floor of production that their younger counterparts will more often miss.

title: The Early Word: Combat
description: Todays Times

title: Accessing Difficult Art at Londons Spill Festival
description: London may be famed for its West End theater scene, but theres a whole other world of entertainment available during the Spill Festival, where an array of exceptional artists from around the world will present bold experimental theater, live art and nontraditional performances, from April 18 to 24.

title: Obama Sets Goal of One-Third Cut in Oil Imports
description: WASHINGTON  As a candidate in the fall of 2008, when Republicans held the White House, Barack Obama benefited politically from voters anger about gasoline costs hitting $4 a gallon on average. But as the incumbent facing re-election next year, he knows that will not be the case if prices are so high again.

title: 2010 Bengals: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the A.F.C. North:

title: Your Envelope: Fat or Thin?
description: For those of you applying to college this year, these last few days  and in some cases, weeks  may feel a bit like those early scenes in the Willie Wonka books and movies, when young Charlie furiously tears open candy wrappers to see if he has scored a golden ticket.

title: Fun With the Public Domain
description: Is one issue of The New York Times Magazine each week not enough to sate you? Check out SundayMagazine.org, which posts the most interesting articles from The New York Times Sunday Magazine from exactly 100 years ago, with a little bit of commentary or context. (The site is not affiliated with this magazine in any way.) Recent stories include Can Science Hereafter Grow Giants at Will?; Circus Acrobat Woos Death Daily, but Rarely Weds Her; and Big Highway Planned From New York to Washington.

title: Retreat for Rebels; Libyan Foreign Minister Quits
description: BREGA, Libya  Libyas foreign minister defected to Britain on Wednesday, dealing a blow to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis government even as his forces pushed rebels into a panicked retreat and seized valuable towns they ceded just days ago under allied airstrikes.

title: Meg Whitman Finds a Job
description: Meg Whitman, the former chief executive of eBay who lost her bid to become Californias governor, has a new job.

title: More Good Times Ahead for M.&A., Survey Finds
description: Deal-makers are by their very nature an optimistic lot. And as many of the top legal specialists in the field head down to the annual Tulane Corporate Law Institute in New Orleans on Wednesday, it appears that their confidence is rising.

title: Penders: College Coaching Is a Minefield
description: Tom Penders retired last year after coaching 36 years at seven college programs, finishing with a career record of 638-438. His final exit was from Houston, where he coached six seasons and brought the Cougars to their first N.C.A.A. tournament in 18 years. Dead Coach Walking, a book about his careers ups and downs, was recently published, and below he shares his thoughts on his former profession and the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Fat Stigma Spreads Around the Globe
description: In Mexico, the latest anti-obesity public health campaign shows people with bulging stomachs eating greasy food.

title: Wounded in Crossfire of a Capital Culture War
description: WASHINGTON

title: Why the Decision to Hire a High-Paid Sales Rep Failed
description: Last week, we published a case study reviewing Leon Rozenblits recent decision to hire a senior sales representative at Prometheus Research, a data-management company he founded in New Haven. Unfortunately for Prometheus, a strategy that seemed promising proved too pricey to sustain.

title: Obama to Call for Slashing Oil Imports
description: President Obama will deliver a speech on Wednesday in which he sets a goal of reducing oil imports by a third over the next decade, John M. Broder reports, citing White House aides.

title: In Crackdown by Chinese, a New Arrest
description: BEIJING  A human rights advocate in Sichuan has been formally arrested and charged with inciting subversion against the state, according to a statement on Wednesday by China Human Rights Defenders, an advocacy group that tracks violations by the Chinese government. The advocate, Chen Wei, was charged on Monday, and his family was notified on Tuesday.

title: The Case for Obama Campaigning as a Foreign Policy President
description: The clear expectation in Washington is that President Obama will campaign for re-election by focusing, laser-like, on the economy, jobs, government spending and the nations debt.

title: Syrian Leader Blames Conspiracy for Turmoil
description: CAIRO  The much-anticipated speech by the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, on Wednesday was a well-choreographed effort to showcase his firm grip on power, as he refused to offer concessions and labeled pro-democracy demonstrators as either duped or as conspirators in a plot to destroy the nation.

title: Japans Nuclear Crisis Revives Debate Over Iodide Tablets
description: The nuclear calamity at the Fukushima nuclear plant in Japan has reopened a 30-year debate about how to stockpile potassium iodide, a drug that protects the human thyroid gland from radioactive iodine emitted in reactor accidents.

title: The Caregivers Bookshelf: How She Carries On
description: So often, novels and movies with elderly protagonists take pains to depict them in a state of rebellion. Theyre breaking out of an assisted living facility. Theyre skydiving and climbing the pyramids, pursuing their bucket lists. Theyre heading into space for one last, crucial mission.

title: Former Merrill Executive Awarded $1.2 Million
description: 9:20 a.m. | Updated A former Merrill Lynch executive, Ahmass Fakahany, was awarded $1.2 million in compensatory damages in an employment-related claim against the Wall Street investment bank, now owned by Bank of America.

title: Player Ratings for U.S.-Paraguay
description: Coming off a dramatic, tension-filled tie against fourth-ranked Argentina on Saturday, expectations were soaring as the U.S. national team prepared to face a solid-yet-beatable Paraguay squad Tuesday night in Nashville.

title: Morning Buzz | More Technology in the Classroom
description: Partly cloudy with a high of 51 Wednesday. Thats as good as its going to get for a little while; showers start at night and wont stop for a couple of days.

title: Opposition Forces in Ivory Coast Make Major Gains
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The rule of Ivory Coasts strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, took another blow on Wednesday as the countrys administrative capital fell to forces loyal to his rival, Alassane Ouattara, with little resistance.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Shares Rise on Job Gains, Extending S.&P. Rally
description: Stocks rose Wednesday, extending the biggest first-quarter rally in 13 years for the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, as a report showing companies added more workers in March bolstered optimism about the economy.

title: Since Alan Failed, the Job Must Be Impossible
description: Alan Greenspan is back, lecturing the regulators that they cant possibly hope to do the jobs the Dodd-Frank law assigned to them.

title: Icahn Offers a Loan to Mentor Graphics
description: Carl C. Icahn offered a $220 million loan to Mentor Graphics, the latest salvo in his continuing takeover battle with the software maker.

title: Homeowner Help Gone Awry: A Readers Guide
description: Begun with the greatest of hopes, the Obama administrations foreclosure prevention program has fallen far short of expectations. In todays paper we examine why this program stumbled so badly.

title: Homegirl
description: Courtney Applebaum, 24, studied social theory at the New School  which is, in crucial ways, ideal training for an interior decorator. Her relationships with clients can be intensely personal, and it shows in the spaces she creates. I dont want people to walk into a space and say, Courtney did this,  she says. I just want it to be beautiful, and for the people who live there to be comfortable. The Los Angeles native already has half a dozen projects under her belt and at least that many in the works, some very high profile. But while her taste can be daring, she is the picture of discretion. The only names youll hear her drop are those of Prouv and Nakashima.

title: DuPont Extends $6 Billion Danisco Bid
description: DuPont said Wednesday that it had extended its $6 billion offer for the Danish food ingredients company Danisco for a second time, giving shareholders an additional four weeks to act on the bid.

title: March 30 Updates on Libyan War and Mideast Protests
description: On Wednesday, The Lede is following the war in Libya, unrest in Syria and protest movements across the Middle East and North Africa. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region. For a summary of the latest developments in Libya, read the frequently updated main news article on our home page.

title: 4-Year-Old Citizen Who Was Deported Comes Back
description: Updated | 4:20 p.m. It has been a confusing three weeks for Emily Ruiz, the 4-year-old United States citizen and Long Island native who was deported earlier this month to her parents native country, Guatemala.

title: Qaddafi Forces Said to Lay Land Mines at City
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Militia loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi laid land mines on the edge of the city of Ajdabiya in eastern Libya, Human Rights Watch said in a statement Wednesday.

title: Ore-Ore Fraud
description: Pretending to be a relative in distress (its me, its me)in an attempt to defraud.

title: Poll Shows More Americans Have Unfavorable Views of Tea Party
description: CNN has a new poll out showing their highest-ever level of unfavorable views for the Tea Party movement. According to the poll, 47 percent of Americans now have an unfavorable view of the Tea Party, as compared to 32 percent with a favorable one.

title: Less than 50 Years of Oil Left, HSBC Warns
description: The world may have no more than half a century of oil left at current rates of consumption, while surging demand from the developing world threatens to create very significant price rises before substitutes like biofuels can serve as viable alternatives, the British bank HSBC warns in a new report.

title: Judge Says Willie Nelson Wont Have to Sing as Punishment for Pot Bust
description: A Texas prosecutors proposal that Willie Nelson sing his way out of a recent arrest for marijuana possession has all but gone up in smoke after a judge there rejected the idea. Kit Bramblett, the county attorney for Hudspeth County in West Texas, had suggested that Mr. Nelson pay a small fine and sing Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain at the courthouse as punishment after his arrest at a border stop in Sierra Blanca, Tex., on Nov. 26, when a Border Patrol agent smelled pot on his tour bus. Mr. Bramblett acknowledged that his suggested sentencing would still need to be approved by a judge.

title: Bound for Glory
description: Im pretty sure you dont know what head and tail bands are. I didnt, anyway: I had never heard the term before, and if Id ever seen one, I hadnt noticed it. Theyre the tiny strips of cloth that lie at the top and bottom of a book, between the back of the paper and the spine. They were originally meant to cover up imperfectly hand-cut pages, but now that commercial bookbinding is done by machine, theyve become mostly decorative, and most books dont have them anymore.

title: Deutsche Bank Fire Case May Hinge on Citys Role
description: More than two years ago, when prosecutors announced that they would be seeking charges in the deaths of two firefighters in a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building the City of New York escaped indictment, but it did not escape scrutiny or blame.

title: Is More Bond-Buying the Answer?
description: Pedro da Costa of Reuters asks, Is more bond-buying really the solution to the U.S. jobless crisis?

title: Austerity Games, Here And There
description: Early last year, many people on both sides of the Atlantic seized on the idea that less is more  that cutting spending would actually help, not hinder, recovery. There was a paper by Alesina and Ardagna that seemed to provide evidence to that effect, and nothing succeeds like telling people what they want to hear.

title: Achatzs Restaurant May Open in a Week
description: Per Grant Achatz (@gachatz) on Twitter: We R excited & nervous about openings. Everything thus far points 2 4/6 opening 4 Next. Aviary will delay slightly. We want 2 make it great. Thats a week from today for the debut of Mr. Achatzs new restaurant where not just the menu but the style and period of the cuisine will change every three months. Tickets  yes, tickets  are not on sale yet, although the most avid fans have doubtless signed up on the Next Web site to be notified the minute they are available.

title: The Eruption of Benghazi
description: Protesters and rebel soldiers drove Qaddafis forces from the second largest city in Libya.

title: On Libyas Revolutionary Road
description: On the evening of Feb. 8, Khalid Saih found himself in the back of a speeding car on the outskirts of Tripoli. It was not by choice. Saih, a lanky 36-year-old lawyer, was part of a small group of Libyan activists who were openly calling for a new constitution and more civil rights. After months of harassment by the police, he and three fellow lawyers were ordered to report to the Interior Ministry in Tripoli. From there, with no warning, they were bundled into a car and told they would be meeting the Leader.

title: Summer Rental Deals
description: LAST year, Katie and J. B. Heaton of Chicago waited until March to book a summer rental on the shores of Lake Michigan for their family vacation, choosing a prime, $9,800-a-week, lake-view, five-bedroom house with private beach access and a swimming pool. It was easy for us, said Mrs. Heaton, noting the wide array of rentals to choose from. We could pick our weeks.

title: Strut Your Stuff
description: In this sequence, the first bird runs across a rough surface. The second bird runs across a slick surface successfully, but the third bird runs across the same slick surface and slips and falls.

title: James Murdoch Is Moving Up at News Corp.
description: 8:35 p.m. | Updated

title: Ethical Engineering- No Oxymoron
description: Theres something afoot in the bolts and circuits world of engineering  a focus on designing and building devices and systems that can improve the lot of struggling societies.

title: Creator of Maine Labor Mural Addresses Controversy
description: Judy Taylor, the artist who painted the mural that was removed from Maines Department of Labor, said on Wednesday that she was sad to learn that the governors decision to move the mural might have started with an anonymous letter comparing it to North Korean brainwashing.

title: Timely | Cults
description: Last May, Madeline Follin and Brian Oblivion of the much-hyped indie rock band Cults took to the stage for one of their first performances ever  opening for the Internet sensations Sleigh Bells at the Ridgewood Masonic Temple in Brooklyn. Follin wore a mini A-line dress that she has since turned into her signature. Oblivions steady strum of the guitar set against her sweet and seductive singing took the crowd to a happy place; their identical long and stringy hairdos swayed together.

title: The Exceptional Mr. Greenspan
description: Alan Greenspan continues his efforts to cement his reputation as the worst ex-Fed chairman in history; in todays FT, he comes out for a repeal of financial regulations designed to prevent a repeat of the crisis for which he, more than any other individual, bears personal responsibility.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: The President's Trip to New York
description: On Tuesday afternoon, President Obama traveled to New York City. Some scenes from New York Times photographer Doug Mills.

title: Deaths of 9 Alabama Patients Tied to Intravenous Supplement
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  State and federal health officials are investigating the deaths of nine patients at Alabama hospitals who were all given an intravenous nutritional supplement that investigators have found was contaminated by bacteria.

title: Formula One Champ Kimi Raikkonen to Race in Nascar in May
description: Kimi Raikkonen, the 2007 Formula One world champion, has requested and received approval to run in a Nascar Camping World Truck Series race at Charlotte Motor Speedway on May 20, said Amanda Jones Ellis, a spokeswoman for the series.

title: Wednesday Reading: Yet Another Tylenol Recall
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Let Them Eat Pita
description: The attackers and defenders of Marie Antoinette have been going at it for more than 200 years. She may be the most written-about woman in the history of the world. But the real historical figure has lost out to our picture of her as Madame Dficit, the queen who wouldnt wear the same dress twice. It is the extravagance of her reign  90 dresses in a year from one dressmaker alone  that makes her the metaphor of choice for critics of tyrants everywhere. As Noreen Malone recently put it in Slate, a handful of rulers wives in Syria, Jordan and elsewhere in the region became fashion magazine darlings here and symbols of inequality back home, cast as the Middle Easts Marie Antoinettes. The strangest evocation of this image, an indication of just how detached it has gotten from its source, was a comment in Haaretz concerning the protests in Egypt: Mubarak and his thugs are the Marie Antoinettes of the Middle East. Picture that, if you dare.

title: Griner and Baylor Stymied by Texas A&M
description: In most ways, its hard to make 6-foot-8 Baylor sophomore star Brittney Griner disappear. But Texas A&M found the magic wand Tuesday, reducing Griners normally game-changing play at center into a non-factor.

title: Google Introduces New Social Tool and Settles Privacy Charge
description: Google is trying social networking again, even as it pays a price for earlier privacy blunders.

title: Britain Releases Guidance on New Anti-Bribery Law
description: LONDON  Britain on Wednesday published guidelines for a new bribery law that would exempt foreign companies whose shares were traded on the London stock exchange if they did not have operations in Britain.

title: Obamas New Plan for Old Goal, Cutting Oil Imports
description: March 31, 10:30 a.m. | Updated

title: Warren Courts Her Top Critics
description: Elizabeth Warrens charm campaign made a stop in enemy territory on Wednesday.

title: The Other Jersey Shore
description: Just as some books that children find appealing make librarians want to yank their hair out, so other books guaranteed to please school librarians turn childrens gazes toward the recess yard. Then there are the books that satisfy both, like Meadowlands, by Hobokens Thomas F. Yezerski. Parents in Summit and Montclair will probably like it too.

title: Wiz Khalifa Raps Beyond His Years
description: Wiz Khalifa shares the remix to his huge hit single Black and Yellow with his spiritual elder Snoop Dogg, and also Juicy J, of the foundational Memphis rap group Three 6 Mafia. On another of Wiz Khalifas singles, On My Level, the straight-talking Oakland foulmouth Too Short is his guest.

title: Cephalons Shares Surge Above Offer Price
description: Shares of Cephalon surged more than 28 percent on Wednesday, above the hostile offer price of $73 a share from Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

title: No. 2 Official at State Department Is Leaving
description: The State Departments No. 2 official, James B. Steinberg, is leaving to become dean of the Maxwell School at Syracuse University, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said in a letter to her staff Wednesday. President Obama plans to nominate William J. Burns, the undersecretary of state for political affairs, to succeed Mr. Steinberg as deputy secretary.

title: Countries Begin Radiation Checks on Ships That Have Visited Japan
description: HONG KONG  Shipping companies and airlines around the world, already nervous about rising fuel prices and the potential effect of an economic slowdown in Japan, now have another worry: intensified monitoring of ships and aircraft that have made recent stops in Japan.

title: Court Affirms Californias Marine Emissions Rules
description: To hear T.L. Garrett, the vice president of the Pacific Merchant Shipping Association tell it, the point of challenging California rules requiring ships to use cleaner-burning fuel near the states shores was not to defend the burning of some of the dirtiest, most unhealthy motor fuel around today.

title: John le Carr, the Unwilling Prize Nominee
description: The spy novelist John le Carr was chosen as one of 13 finalists for the Man Booker International Prize, the prize committee announced in Sydney on Wednesday. His response? No, thanks.

title: Edible Selby | Stevie Parle
description: An ambitious young chef whips up world-class cuisine in an unlikely setting in West London. Go to interactive feature >>

title: As Sweeping Layoffs Loom, Schools Gird for Turmoil
description: School authorities across the nation are warning thousands of teachers that they could lose their jobs in June, raising the possibility that Americas public schools may see the most extensive layoffs of their teaching staffs in decades.

title: Solving the Microbial Whodunit
description: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

title: Video: The Presidents Trip to New York City
The Race(!) to the Budget Deadline
description: ALBANY  After countless hours of number-crunching, dozens of hearings and one triumphant news conference in Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos ceremonial office, the State Legislature has finally begun approving the state budget.

title: Khmer Rouge Officials Sentence Opposed
description: BANGKOK  Prosecutors and defense lawyers asked for drastic changes this week in the sentence given to the former commandant of the Khmer Rouges main prison.

title: President Replaces Junta in Myanmar Shadow Play
description: BANGKOK  A nominally civilian government took office in Myanmar on Wednesday but the change was mostly one of political structure as the military, which has ruled for a half-century, maintained its grip on power.

title: Does This Green Flatter Me?
description: I AM feeling more in the mood for green lately, said the designer Rebecca Moses, who was wearing a long silk jacket about the color of a fairway. Then she smiled wryly and added, especially emeralds.

title: How Small Companies Get in Trouble
description: Most of us have an image of the turnaround guy. For some, the term can conjure up images of an unfeeling taskmaster, exemplified by Albert Dunlap, known as Chainsaw Al, who applied his famously ruthless methods to companies like Scott Paper and Sunbeam in the 1990s. Recently, however, I had the good fortune to meet not one but two men who put to rest my stereotype of the turnaround guy as Rambo in pinstripes.

title: The Imaginary Budget
description: Gail Collins: David, I just got back from a vacation in Argentina. I read your new book on the very long plane ride.

title: The Fasting Experience
description: My first few notes from the beginning of the fast I wrote about in Opinion this morning  I stopped eating after an early dinner Sunday and began taking notes when I woke up Monday  are mildly amusing, in retrospect:

title: Slip-Sliding Birds Show How to Avoid Human Falls
description: The video shows several guinea fowl running confidently across a track. Then one takes a step and  whoops!  the bird slips and lands on its feathered backside, beak agape and wings flailing as it skids out of the picture.

title: Where the Excitement Never Began
description: It would have been a treat to be reveling in the womens N.C.A.A. basketball tournament today, celebrating the completion of the Final Four field, the contestants coming of age and so on and so on. Problem is, Tuesday nights regional finals put everyone to sleep a few minutes after the national anthem ended.

title: The Presidents Credibility Gap
description: Addressing the nation Monday evening, President Obama suggested that the United States was in the process of reducing its military footprint in Libya, even as he explicitly rejected the idea of pursuing regime change in Tripoli by force of arms. Both statements seemed calculated to make our intervention seem tightly limited rather than open-ended. (I want to be clear, Obama said. The United States of America has done what we said we would do.) But two days later, both look dubious in the extreme.

title: Egyptian Antiquities Minister Returns Less Than a Month After Quitting
description: Zahi Hawass, who resigned as Egypts minister of antiquities less than a month ago under criticism for his close ties to former President Hosni Mubarak, was reappointed to the post on Wednesday, Agence France-Presse reported, citing an Egyptian news report; Mr. Hawass, reached by phone, confirmed his reappointment.

title: Metropolitan Opera Evaluating Planned Japan Trip
description: With the Metropolitan Operas Japan tour approaching this June, Peter Gelb, the Mets general manager, told the company on Wednesday that the safety of the trip was being evaluated and that a decision on whether to proceed would be made before the advance team is scheduled to depart in the middle of May.

title: Dun Certain ge | Potiche and 70s Style
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#815", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: In Paris, a Restored Apartment
description: A one-bedroom 17th-century apartment on the storied Left Bank is on the market for $1,696,000 (1,203,690 euros).

title: House Hunting in ... Paris
description: A RESTORED 17TH-CENTURY APARTMENT IN SAINT GERMAIN DES PRS, PARIS

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Going to War: Part 1
description: HELMAND, Afghanistan  The two worst parts of a deployment are the flights to and from theater. On the way there youre asking, What the hell am I getting myself into? And on the way back, youre hoping to God the plane doesnt crash after all youve made it through.

title: U.S. U-20 Team Wins Opener  and More
description: The United States enjoyed a bounty of variety Tuesday night when the mens under-20 national team opened regional qualifying for the world championships with a 4-0 win against Suriname in Estadio Nacional Mateo Flores in Guatemala City in which the goals were scored by four different players. The United States was led by Kelyn Rowe and Conor Doyle with a goal and an assist each, while Bobby Wood and Joe Gyau each added a goal.

title: Homes for $700,000
description: A row house in Washington, D.C.; a Victorian in Salt Lake City; and a converted barn in Indianapolis.

title: What You Get for ... $700,000
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: Inequality Is Most Extreme in Wealth, Not Income
description: Typically, comments about rising inequality refer to the stark disparities in incomes of the very highest-paid Americans and everyone. We have observed in several posts, for example, that most of the income gains over the last few decades have gone to the very richest Americans. That means the highest-paid Americans have been claiming a larger and larger share of earnings.

title: The Cloud That Rains Music
description: For years now, the most popular music system  Apples  has worked like this. You buy song files from the iTunes store. They download to your computer. If you want to listen to them on the road, you connect your iPod or iPhone to that computer and copy the files to it.

title: Isringhausen Agrees to Stay Behind
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jason Isringhausen had his bags packed and ready to load in his car for the drive back home to St. Louis. But the Mets convinced him Wednesday that he should stay in Port St. Lucie for extended spring training, and Isringhausen agreed  for now.

title: The Great Wave
description: Jimmy Chen, the very clever contributor to the handsomely designed HTMLGIANT (the literature blog that is not always about literature), compares David Lynchs hair styles to famous works of art.

title: Ex-Players Tell of Receiving Illicit Payments at Auburn and Elsewhere
description: Four former Auburn football players said in an HBO Real Sports report on Wednesday night that they were paid thousands of dollars during their college careers, including one who said he received money from an assistant coach.

title: Whats Behind Low Investment?
description: This post by John Taylor is getting a lot of attention, because it does show a striking correlation between investment and unemployment:

title: Riff Raffs Tiki Bar
description: TIKI bars are enjoying a resurgence in New York, perhaps as a coconut-scented escape for the citys frostbitten citizenry. Among the latest to join the mai tai-slingers is Riff Raffs, which opened in January beneath the Hurricane Club, a restaurant near Madison Square Park. The twist? Giving the bottle-service nightclub model some Polynesian pageantry by submerging it in a communal punch bowl.

title: Porsche Panamera Turbo S Breaks Cover Ahead of New York Show
description: In what is becoming common practice, especially among German automakers, Porsche introduced its Panamera Turbo S four-door luxury sedan on the Web on Wednesday, three weeks ahead of its formal debut scheduled for April 20 at the New York auto show.

title: In Salesforce.coms Deal for Radian6, a Nod to Facebooks Rise
description: As the social Web becomes increasingly important to consumer brands, Salesforce.com is responding by loosening its purse strings.

title: S.E.C. Supports Rule on Mortgage Securities
description: A federal effort to force banks to retain some stake in risky mortgages gained traction on Wednesday, as securities regulators blessed a plan to restrict one of the chief causes of the financial crisis.

title: An Hour to Pamper, Remote in Hand
description: WHEN I was a child, my Haitian father, an anesthesiologist, made a big show of using his spare time to accomplish goals like getting a pilots license or a black belt in karate. So is it any wonder Id feel unproductive using my free hours merely to watch TV?

title: An Evening With the Eco-Glitterati
description: On Tuesday night I attended one of those New York charity functions that make your head spin.

title: A Closer Look at the Citys Online Learning Contracts
description: As we reported on Wednesday, the New York City Department of Education has ramped up technology spending as it creates a digital platform for online learning called iLearn NYC, which is due to make its debut in 120 schools in September. The city hopes 300,000 students in 750 schools will be using iLearn within five years.

title: Panda Dads and Parenting Goals
description: Alan Paul, an American father who spent several years raising three children in Beijing, is the author of Big in China: My Unlikely Adventures Raising a Family, Playing the Blues, and Becoming a Star in Beijing. He has been watching the Tiger Mom debate from the country where it began, and in a rebuttal essay yesterday on wsj.com, he asked the question that so many of you have asked: Where are the Dads?

title: Obama Lays Out Plan to Cut Reliance on Fuel Imports
description: WASHINGTON

title: The First Close-Ups of Mercury
description: NASAs Messenger spacecraft sent back the first of what is expected to be 75,000 photographs during a yearlong investigation of Mercury.

title: British Lawmakers Say Auditors Contributed to Crisis
description: A British parliamentary report published on Wednesday said that mistakes by the worlds four largest accounting firms helped cause the financial crisis.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Pakistan, Japan and Afghanistan.

title: Pinnacle's Opposed Piston Engine
description: In this design, two pistons face each other, the space between them forming a combustion chamber. Eliminating the traditional cylinder head results in a lighter, cheaper and more efficient engine.

title: In NASAs Lens, Mercury Comes Into Focus
description: Its really hot, really cold and maybe even a bit icy.

title: Paul Allen Writes of Plots and Slights at Microsoft
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Paul G. Allen, the Microsoft co-founder, may be one of the worlds richest men, with a fortune pegged at $13 billion. But he still resents his former partner, Bill Gates, for not sharing enough credit or giving him his due financially.

title: The High Low | J. Brand Ela Mae Pants, $235
description: What: J. Brand Ela Mae pants

title: Making the Case to Cephalon Shareholders
description: J. Michael Pearson, chief executive of Valeant Pharmaceuticals, tells CNBC why his company made a hostile bid for the rival drug maker.

title: Militants Put Gazans in Danger, Group Says
description: GAZA  A Palestinian human rights group in Gaza took the unusual step this week of condemning the building and storage of anti-Israel rockets in densely populated areas, a practice that has led to injuries and deaths of civilians.

title: Survey Finds B, C and D Trains Most in Need of Diction Lessons
description: St**d C***r of *he Clos**g Doo**!

title: Obama: On Peace, Physics and Prizes
description: President Obama departed from the draft of his speech far more than usual on Wednesday during an address on energy policy at Georgetown University. But the ad lib that got the biggest rise from students came when he gave a nod to his energy secretary, the Nobel laureate Steven Chu.

title: App Offers Guide to Sustainable Seafood
description: Environmentally conscious travelers often have one question when faced with, say, a sushi menu: Is any of this seafood the product of overfishing?

title: A New Anchor at Good Morning America
description: The producers of Good Morning America are replacing Juju Chang, the news anchor on the morning show, with Josh Elliott, a co-anchor of ESPNs SportsCenter.

title: Chris Brown Tops the Pop Chart
description: Did Chris Browns outburst on Good Morning America last week cost him album sales?

title: Jackson Heights Awakens to a Cricket Bats Crack
description: If there seemed to be a shortage of taxis at 5 a.m. on Wednesday, one possible reason was apparent on the streets of Jackson Heights in Queens.

title: Asked and Answered | Harel Skaat
description: The Israeli pop star Harel Skaat first grabbed the spotlight as a fixture on reality television in his home country. In the seven years since, the 29-year-old singer has released a monster-hit album (2006), represented Israel in last years Eurovision contest, made the rounds of Paris Fashion Week and came out of the closet in a TV documentary about his life. Now at work on his first English-language studio album, Skaat agreed to sit down for a few questions.

title: Galleon Jurors Hear Tape Discussing Call of Goldman Director
description: 8:04 p.m. | Updated

title: Greenspan and Unemployment
description: Alan Greenspans reputation obviously isnt what it used to be, and for good reason. His re-entry into partisan politics  arguing that Wall Street is over-regulated  probably wont help. But it would be a mistake to turn him into a caricature of an unsuccessful central banker, just as it was a mistake to lionize him in the past.

title: Loyalist Forces Push Rebels Into Retreat
description: The Libyan rebels continued their eastward retreat on Wednesday, fleeing before the loyalists shelling and missile attacks.

title: Freestyle Fellowship
description: In The Soloist, Tim Crothers introduced readers of the magazine to Indi Cowie, an irrepressible freestyle soccer phenom from Cary, N.C. If youve already seen our video, youre familiar with what she can do with the ball. Still, you should tune into Good Morning America on Thursday, when Cowie is scheduled to display her arsenal of tricks live on national television.

title: Dimon Brings On the Drama at the Chamber
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, despises some of the new federal regulations that his bank faces  and he is not reluctant to tell you so.

title: Will Other Retailers Adopt L.L. Beans Free Shipping?
description: 4:12 p.m. | Updated  to add links to the L.L. Bean announcement and the Amazon Prime site. Also updated the Lands End reference to reflect its promotions.

title: Scooped!
description: Here I am thinking that Im sitting on an-unscoopable story  an essay about what its like to read the Times magazine from 100 years ago  and you go and blog it, John Swansburg, Slates culture editor, fretted in an e-mail to me not long after this mornings post on SundayMagazine.org was published. Id been planning to run this on Monday, but since you got the ball rolling I figured Id push the button now.

title: The Buzz About the Buzz: Learning How Caffeine Affects the Body
description: Overview | What is caffeine, and how does it affect the body? What are some everyday sources of caffeine in the diet? In this lesson, students survey their own caffeine consumption. They rank various beverage and food products for their caffeine content, learn about how caffeine affects the body and create and perform educational skits about caffeine and health.

title: When a Girl Is Executed  for Being Raped
description: Were all focused right now on Libya and budget battles at home, but this story from Bangladesh just broke my heart and outraged me  and offers a reminder of the daily human rights struggles of so many women and girls in villages around the world. A 14-year-old Bangladeshi girl, Hena,allegedly was ambushed when she went to an outdoor toilet, gagged, beaten and raped by an older man in her village (who was actually her cousin). They were caught by wife of the alleged rapist, and the wife then beat Hena up. An imam at a local mosque issued a fatwa saying that Hena was guilty of adultery and must be punished, and a village makeshift court sentenced Hena to 100 lashes in a public whipping.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Pakistan, Japan and Afghanistan.

title: S.E.I.U. Accuses Workers United Chief of Misconduct
description: The Service Employees International Union has filed internal charges against Bruce S. Raynor, one of New Yorks most prominent union leaders and the head of that unions apparel workers affiliate, accusing him of financial misconduct.

title: Beauty Spots
description: Argan oil, derived from the nuts of argan trees in Morocco and naturally high in vitamin E, essential fatty acids and antioxidants, has become a star ingredient in products meant to moisturize and control curly hair. Now its appearing in luxury skin-care products, too.

title: A Ferrari Book to Rival the Real Thing, if Only in Price
description: The publishers of the new book The Official Ferrari Opus, diamond-studded copies of which may sell for $275,000 or more each, are calling it the most exclusive book in the world. Book collectors may quibble with that claim; one of 21 known complete copies of the Gutenberg Bible, the first book printed on a movable-type press, sold at auction last year for $5.4 million.

title: Behind the Train Scenes of 'Source Code'
description: Duncan Jones, the director of the action thriller "Source Code," narrates a look at the film's train sequences.

title: Strangers on a Train, With Explosives
description: AT first glance it might seem odd that Duncan Jones, David Bowies son and a British film director, would follow up his minimalist and haunting first feature, Moon, with a significantly larger-budgeted action thriller. But his new film, Source Code, which opened Friday, deals with similar questions of identity and existence. To a degree its science fiction wrapped in an explosive package.

title: Nets Open Sale on Season Tickets  for 2012
description: The Nets new home in Brooklyn is still an unfinished collection of steel beams, but the seats that are still quite a bit away from being actual seats have started to be offered for sale.

title: TimesCast | March 30, 2011
description: President Bashar al-Assad blames a broad conspiracy for Syria's turmoil; and how Israel views the unrest.

title: Getty Museum Will Return Painting From Collection Looted by Nazis
description: A 370-year-old painting that belonged to a Jewish art dealer who fled the Netherlands around the time of the Nazi invasion in 1940 will be returned to his family by the J. Paul Getty Museum, The Associated Press reported.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Fruitcakes that are ripening: Kate and Willss wedding cake; Dionne Warwick on Celebrity Apprentice.

title: Shutdown Watch: Nine Days Out
description: With nine days left until the federal governments spending authority runs out, tensions are high on Capitol Hill and the rhetoric is growing increasingly sharp. Lawmakers from both parties are taking to television and the Internet in the hopes of framing the debate in advance of a possible shutdown.

title: Nation Building
description: The silent star of the 1948 hit film Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House is a handsome Colonial with bright clapboard walls and dark shutters. Cary Grant and Myrna Loy co-starred as the New York City adman Jim Blandings and his wife, Muriel  up-to-date apartment dwellers whose relationship with early-American style personified the hopes and struggles of moviegoers from coast to coast. The Blandings country home became so popular that Kelloggs cereal boxes offered a cardboard cutout model, and Manhattan charity fund-raisers oversaw the construction of a full-scale Dream House knockoff on a vacant lot in Midtown. As the backdrop for a 1949 fashion photo in Cosmopolitan magazine, the suburban colonial parked at the corner of 48th and Fifth now seems quaintly surreal, but at the time it was shot, this back to the New Look tableau would have made perfect sense to passers-by.

title: Growlers for Grapes
description: If you live and drink in a major city, you have probably encountered wine on tap, and the proliferation of growlers, those glass hillbilly jugs that enable you to take draft beer from a bar or liquor store to your home.
