But unless you live in Greenville, S.C., you may not have met the lovechild of those two trends: the wine growler.

title: Castillo Is Cut by Phillies, Too
description: First, Luis Castillo was released by the Mets, who will start a Rule 5 draftee, Brad Emaus, at second base instead.

title: Body of Proof Has Strong Start for ABC
description: Body of Proof, a new drama with Dana Delany playing a medical examiner, delivered promising ratings for ABC in its 10 p.m. debut on Tuesday, helping the network draw the most viewers on average for the night. According to Nielsens estimates, 13.9 million viewers watched the premiere  a smaller audience than the one for ABCs Dancing With the Stars at 9 (18.8 million) but large enough to top The Good Wife on CBS (10 million) and Parenthood on NBC (4.8 million). CBS ranked a solid second place on the night, with 18.3 million for NCIS at 8 and 15.2 million for NCIS: Los Angeles at 9, while NBC finished third with The Biggest Loser from 8 to 10 (7.1 million). Fox was a distant fourth with mostly repeats.

title: Readers Letters on Styles Articles
description: Potpies Top Billing

title: In Debate Over Bank Capital Regulation, a Trans-Atlantic Gulf
description: Anat Admati, a professor at the Stanford Graduate School of Business.

title: Could Barclays Move to New York?
description: LONDON  An analyst report has renewed speculation among some investors that the British bank Barclays might leave London for New York.

title: Textiles Reveal Women's Unheralded Role in Armenian Church
description: Sacred treasures tell a story of the role of women and colorfully record the skills of women artisans.

title: Taxpayer Suggestions for Improving the I.R.S.
description: This is the time of year when many Americans are dealing with the usual frustrations of filing their annual tax returns with the Internal Revenue Service. But there is a group whose job is to make the I.R.S. better: The Taxpayer Advocacy Panel.

title: Roberta Mancino's Sky Dive
description: A clip of Ms. Mancino's jump from an airplane that was shot from a helmet mounted camera.

title: Cellphone Radiation May Alter Your Brain. Lets Talk.
description: In a culture where people cradle their cellphones next to their heads with the same constancy and affection that toddlers hold their security blankets, it was unsettling last month when a study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association indicated that doing so could alter brain activity.

title: Medicare Says It Will Pay for Expensive Prostate Drug
description: Updated: Medicare announced on Wednesday that it would pay for Dendreons prostate cancer drug Provenge, whose $93,000 price tag had ignited debate about the cost and effectiveness of cancer drugs.

title: Design Must Haves | Home Springs Eternal
description: In order to view this feature, you must download the latest version of flash player here.

title: V.C.U. Coach Hears From LeBron James
description: At Virginia Commonwealth, the students have lined up at the bookstore looking to purchase the schools Final Four apparel. Players have been stopped for photographs on their way to class.

title: Talks Resume in Spending Stalemate
description: Congressional officials on Wednesday reported some progress in resolving their budget stalemate as senior representatives of the House and Senate resumed negotiations on how to fund the government through Sept. 30.

title: Can We Do Without the Mideast?
description: IMAGINE a foreign policy version of the movie Groundhog Day, with Bill Murray playing the president of the United States. The alarm clock rings. Political mayhem is again shaking the Middle East, crude oil and gasoline prices are climbing, and an economic recovery is under threat.

title: Senators Press U.S. Officials on Storage of Spent Nuclear Fuel
description: A Senate subcommittee pressed federal officials on Wednesday on the safety of long-term storage of spent nuclear fuel in pools, a common practice at nuclear reactors in the United States and at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi plant in Japan.

title: Loose Snake in the Bronx, and Other Tales of Horror
description: Surely by now youve heard about the runaway asp at the Bronx Zoo, the 20-inch Egyptian cobra that has eluded capture since Friday. Though just a youngster, the snake is considered fanged and dangerous.

title: Q&A: Zooming Out of the Mac Desktop
description: Q.

title: Vintage Typewriters
description: A digital generation has fallen in love with the sound and the feel of old manual typewriters.

title: C.I.A. Agents in Libya Aid Airstrikes and Meet Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency has inserted clandestine operatives into Libya to gather intelligence for military airstrikes and to contact and vet the beleaguered rebels battling Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces, according to American officials.

title: Click, Clack, Ding! Sigh ...
description: EVEN by Brooklyn standards, it was a curious spectacle: a dozen mechanical contraptions sat on a white tablecloth, emitting occasional clacks and dings. Shoppers peered at the display, excited but hesitant, as if theyd stumbled upon a trove of strange inventions from a Jules Verne fantasy. Some snapped pictures with their iPhones.

title: Stanford and Duke Accepted How Many? Colleges Report 2011 Admission Figures
description: By now, many of you who are applicants (or parents of applicants) for the Class of 2015 have received your admissions decisions.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Googles Library
description: Googles plans for a digital library are in limbo following a federal judges ruling last week. On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein talks to Miguel Helft, a Times technology reporter, about the collapse of the Internet giants efforts to digitize millions of books and make them widely available. He explains what is at stake.

title: A Jazzman Encounters His Life and Death
description: The lore of jazz is filled with operatic episodes, none larger or more dramatic than the last days of Charlie Parker. His sad death, 56 years ago this month, in a Fifth Avenue apartment, is well known among music fans for its tabloid stew of tragedy, scandal, rumor and innuendo.

title: Shopping Picks for March 31
description: Band of Outsiders introduces its girl line, spring espadrilles, a sample sale to benefit Japans recovery effort, fresh Australian shoes land in Williamsburg and more.

title: Velarde Says He Received Drugs and Injections From Bondss Trainer
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The former Yankee Randy Velarde testified Wednesday that he bought performance-enhancing drugs from Barry Bondss personal trainer and met him in parking lots to receive injections of steroids or human growth hormone.

title: Foreclosure Prevention: The Treasurys View
description: An article today, and a follow-up blog post here on Economix, looked at a Treasury effort at the heart of the administrations foreclosure-prevention effort, the Home Affordable Modification Program. The program is widely considered to have fallen short of expectations, and the Republican-led House voted Tuesday evening to eliminate it. The Treasury makes the case that any judgment of the program must take into account the circumstances in which it has operated. In response to the Times article, Timothy Massad, the acting assistant secretary for financial stability, laid out the Treasurys view:

title: Abrupt Exit for a Top Deputy to Warren Buffett
description: 10:15 p.m. | Updated

title: New York Fed Rejects A.I.G. Bid to Buy Mortgage Assets
description: 7:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Trading Pumps for Plugs: We Arent There Yet
description: KEVIN WALSH and his wife, Jeri Countryman, are young professionals in San Francisco with jobs requiring a fair amount of commuting. By himself, Mr. Walsh, a process engineer for a large international pharmaceutical company in San Carlos, Calif., logs a total of 43 miles each day.

title: Warren Defends Agency at Chamber of Commerce
description: WASHINGTON  She never actually uttered I come in peace, but Elizabeth Warren, the Obama administration aide charged with setting up the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, might have felt like an alien visiting an anxious planet Wednesday when she went to the United States Chamber of Commerce.

title: Dueling Mentors Bedevil a Dithering Young Dane
description: In case Arcadia hasnt sated your appetite for smarty-pants mash-ups, the Pearl Theater has a crackling good bit of entertainment for you. David Davaloss Wittenberg, which is at City Center Stage II, bursts with a Stoppardian eagerness to tickle as it tangles with weightier issues.

title: Nuclear Industry Thrives in the U.S., but for Export
description: CRANBERRY TOWNSHIP, Pa.

title: HTCs Thunderbolt Is as Fast as Lightning
description: Finally, a credible 4G phone. The term 4G has been conveniently applied to half-step measures that speed up phone networks, but the HTC Thunderbolt in tandem with Verizons LTE network finally provides the ripping speeds we have been promised.

title: Tucking Carbon Into the Ground
description: IF carbon is going to be kept out of the atmosphere, a lot of it is probably going to have to be injected back into the ground from which it was mined as coal or extracted as oil or gas.

title: Philadanco Gets Funky in a Night of the New
description: The Philadelphia Dance Company, otherwise known as Philadanco, returned to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with a program of mostly new choreography. If only it had been mostly laudable too. A few sparks flew, notably created by the choreographer Jawole Willa Jo Zollar in her homage to funk, but for the most part the company offered a boilerplate show that took few chances and offered scant rewards.

title: An Energy Plan Derailed by Events Is Being Retooled
description: WASHINGTON

title: Poetry of Stillness, in a Moment Stretched to Infinity
description: A naked man and woman moving with glacial slowness on a mound of earth, feathers, sticks and vegetation doesnt sound at all like an enthralling theatrical experience. But such is the almost inexplicable magic of Naked: A Living Installation, by the Japanese-American duo Eiko and Koma, that watching two bodies inch toward and away from each other in infinitely tiny increments is an utterly absorbing, potent drama of time and space  endless in the moment, over before you know it.

title: London Underground | Now Viewing
description: I have always had a soft spot for the Aram Gallery. While the Aram shop in Covent Garden is an established retail destination for anyone interested in modern and contemporary design, its no-fuss, top-floor design gallery has always felt like a secret. From 2002 to 2010, the gallery was curated by Daniel Charny and is currently under the guidance of Ellie Parke.

title: Can You Wear Silly Hats With Your Cloak and Dagger?
description: Chaos, a new series beginning Friday on CBS is at once a deadpan sendup of the spy genre, in the manner of Get Smart, and something considerably less ambitious. The opening montage, a series of black-and-white cold war images making reference to intelligence foibles and occasions of malfeasance, offers a wry instant history of misguided American foreign policy.

title: Excerpt: 'Chaos'
description: The new CBS spy comedy stars Freddie Rodriguez.

title: More on Budget Cuts, Hunger and Poverty
description: A little more about the fast, the budget cuts and the protests. (Heres my Opinion piece if you havent seen it.)

title: Start-Ups Work to Reinvent the Combustion Engine
description: BERKELEY, Calif.

title: A Game for Opening Day, With Stat Lovers in Mind
description: Pro football may be the nations top spectator sport, but serious baseball nerds are the most frightening fans in the country.

title: Trailer: MLB11: The Show
description: MLB11: The Show, Sonys latest version of the baseball title, favors the obsessive fan.

title: Kindergarten Waiting Lists Get Longer
description: The Department of Education on Wednesday released citywide information about kindergarten waiting lists for the upcoming school year, and, over all, the news isnt good.

title: In San Salvador, an Apartment Doubles as a Design Lab
description: A couples two-bedroom doubles as a home and informal showroom for their designs.

title: Like, O.K., to Pull the Sword From the Stone, Young Arthur Needs a Life Coach
description: First things first: Camelot is no Spartacus, for better and for worse. The latest glossy repackaging of ancient legend on Starz has neither the gleeful hamminess nor the bounteous exposed flesh and soft-core sex of its channel mate. Thats not to say there isnt wholly gratuitous nudity  this is pay cable, after all  but its more discreetly photographed and limited to one or two scenes per episode.

title: In Mexico City, Kissing Tells of More Than Romance
description: MEXICO CITY  Armando Ruiz and Vernica Villafuerte held each other tight, cuddling, caressing, stretched out on a bench in the middle of a busy promenade here. Nearby, just past a couple deep kissing in the grass, a man toyed with the buttons of his paramours blouse.

title: Possible Safety Risks Put Met Opera Tour to Japan in Jeopardy
description: The Metropolitan Opera is debating whether to proceed with its scheduled Japanese tour in June, an ambitious trip that was several years in the planning and would be the Mets first to that country since 2006.

title: Houses Passes School Voucher Bill
description: House Republicans voted overwhelmingly Wednesday for the only bill that the Speaker is expected to offer this year, a voucher measure that would provide $20 million annually for five years for scholarships for public school children attending poorly performing schools in the District of Columbia, and $20 million each for charter and traditional public schools in the district.

title: A Store for Android Apps, Under Amazons Oversight
description: Android phones and tablets are in many ways as good as Apple devices, but Apple owners have always had a big advantage  namely, the iTunes App Store, which makes it easy to find good software, read reviews from others and even get suggestions on apps that other users bought.

title: A Mothers Devotion, a Familys Tearful Regrets
description: Please Look After Mom is the work of a popular South Korean novelist, Kyung-sook Shin, who is being published in English for the first time. It sold more than a million copies in South Korea, where there may not be a dry hankie left in the land.

title: A Composer Left Out in the Cold
description: Even at a time when adventure is on the rise at our major orchestras we are confronted season after season with a ceaseless tide of the well-worn and the safe: another trawl through Tchaikovsky, the familiar comforts of Dvorak, the latest attempt to show that Schumann had it right all along.

title: Roberta Mancino at Work
description: Ms. Mancino is fearless in the air, but her looks count for more.

title: Building Better Batteries for Electric Cars
description: TO reduce our vast appetite for oil, the government and auto industry are working together to encourage car buyers to think electric when they go car shopping.

title: Ethanol Industry Hoping for Surge
description: CELLULOSIC ethanol could be poised for a surge  finally.

title: Former PTA Treasurer Pleads Not Guilty
description: Wearing baggy, brown wool pants and a rumpled, purple sweater over a T-shirt, a Brooklyn woman accused of embezzling about $100,000 from a Cobble Hill elementary schools PTA while serving as its treasurer pleaded not guilty on Wednesday at Brooklyn Supreme Court.

title: Raising Her Profile by Showing Some Skin
description: TEN THOUSAND FEET above Southern California, Roberta Mancino stood before the open door of an airplane. She smiled, said Ciao! as if she were stepping out for an espresso, and leaped into the sky.

title: In El Salvador, Design Thrives
description: SAN SALVADOR

title: A.I.G.s Chief Calls Fed Rejection a Huge Problem
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New Yorks rejection of the American International Groups offer to buy back $15.7 billion worth of mortgage securities poses a big problem for the insurer, the companys chief executive said on Wednesday.

title: An Outsider Blossom Upends the Flowerpot
description: FORTY-EIGHT hours before the March 15 party at La Grenouille celebrating a collaboration between Yoox, the e-tailer, and Kenneth Jay Lane, the irrefutable king of high-end costume jewelry, professional foragers were still combing woods outside New York City for the perfect 28-inch-high, two-pronged tree stump (not birch!).

title: The Promise and Risks of Natural Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping for Coffee Tables With Deborah Berke
description: An architect went shopping for good-looking coffee tables that would also work well for family nights.

title: A New Chair From Philippe Starck Salutes Midcentury Masters
description: Philippe Starck, the French designer, created the new Masters chair (at left) for the furniture manufacturer Kartell with the help of the designer Eugeni Quitllet. In doing so, he wove together three silhouettes by midcentury masters: Eero Saarinens Tulip chair, Charles and Ray Eamess Eiffel chair and Arne Jacobsens Series 7 chair.

title: The Wood Menagerie
description: This is not a momentary toy, its something that lingers, said Linnea Gits, describing the pieces that she and her husband, Peter Dunham, recently designed. A lot of people who buy these say theyre putting them on their desk at work. Its an adult sensibility, but theyre playful.

title: The First Manhattan Store for Flor
description: The modular carpet tile manufacturer Flor, founded as a Web- and catalog-based company in 2003, is establishing brick-and-mortar stores. The companys Manhattan boutique (at left) opens on Thursday in SoHo, offering help to those tired of deciphering carpet texture from photos.

title: Sales at A&G Merch, Kartell and Others
description: Metropolitan Window Fashions will discount all fabrics 20 percent from April 1 to 15 (silk drapery material, regularly starting at $40 a yard, will start at $32; upholstery fabrics, regularly starting at $50 a yard, will start at $40); 189 East 79th Street and at 469 Amsterdam Avenue (82nd Street), (212) 501-8282, windowfashions.com.

title: Revisiting a House of Nooks and Crannies
description: ITS been more than 40 years since I lived in the house, but every so often I wake up knowing Ive been there in my sleep. Architectural elements  a window, a porch, a staircase  have made cameo appearances in several of my novels. I even started a novel in which a disturbed Raskolnikov type dreams of walking through the house, his long-lost childhood home. I wrote one chapter and put it aside. Something about it scared me.

title: Apps for Taking Inventory at Home
description: HONESTLY, I didnt set out to be a hoarder. Its just that Im a tech reviewer, and sometimes that amounts to the same thing. Technology companies are always sending me gadgets to evaluate; its my job to catalog everything that arrives, keep notes on how I use the products, maintain the packing materials and manuals, and then send it all back. (Ethics!)

title: Stationary Mobile Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Coffee Tables
description: DEBORAH BERKE needs a coffee table. Not just any old table, but one for her library that will support some very specific functions.

title: A Blown Glass Teardrop
description: Caleb Siemon likes to say that most glassblowers are not born artists, theyre born pyromaniacs. Mr. Siemon, a Southern California native, made a name for himself with vases and bowls that combine the techniques he learned as an apprentice to Pino Signoretto, a glass sculptor in Murano, with the Scandinavian style he personally prefers. Three years ago he teamed up with his wife, Carmen Salazar.

title: Imagine, Measure, Cut, Hammer
description: Construction classes for children in San Francisco, Brooklyn and Boston.

title: To Lure Foreign Investment, Russian President Calls for Reforms
Michael Graves on Objects He Designs for Target, and Himself
description: Michael Graves may be one of the most prolific designers of our time. The Indianapolis native founded Michael Graves & Associates in Princeton, N.J., in 1964, and has designed more than 350 buildings around the world since. Through Michael Graves Design Group, he has also created more than 2,000 products for companies like Alessi, Steuben, Dansk and Disney. But when it comes to product design, he is probably best known for the work he has done for Target. Mr. Graves was the first well-known designer to create a line for the mass market chain, a relationship that began 15 years ago.

title: Academy: U.S. Lulled on Need for Earthquake Resilience
description: The United States, lulled by a century of relatively modest earthquakes in populous places, is poorly prepared for the kind of jolt that devastated northern Japan and is inevitable in several parts of this country, according to a new report from the National Academies, the nations preeminent independent advisory body on science. A summary of 18 recommendations that the report said would substantially boost resilience over the next 20 years is at the end of this post.

title: Kindergarten Shop Class
description: IN honor of Presidents Day last month, Deb Winsor, a carpenter with a workshop in Brooklyn, led a crew in the construction of an 8-foot-wide model of the White House, complete with north and south porticos and two dozen hand-painted windows.

title: Richard Holbrookes Papers Entrusted to George Packer
description: When Richard C. Holbrooke died in December, he left behind the notes for a project he never had time to finish.

title: G.E.s Response on Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Scene City: Jeffrey Fashion Cares Benefit
description: The Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum was the site of a beefcake fashion show courtesy of Jeffrey Fashion Cares.

title: A Fashion Event Is Cleared for Takeoff
description: BARE-CHESTED bronzed men are one way to heat up an unseasonably frigid night. On Monday, the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum was the site of a beefcake fashion show courtesy of Jeffrey Fashion Cares, which left the predominantly male crowd a little hot under their starched collars.

title: Between the Devil and the Deep Red Idiocy
description: So, on one side, you have David Leonhardt pointing out, completely correctly, that the Fed is being far too timid. And on the other hand (via Yglesias), we have Tim Pawlenty  whos supposed to be the non-crazy non-Romney  saying things like this:

title: A Woodworking Class for Kids
description: A video from the Trackers Earth program in Portland, Ore., where children learn how to work with tools.

title: More on Unemployment and Investment
description: To follow up on John Taylor: suppose we look only at nonresidential investment, and suppose that we think (as we should) that the causation runs mainly from unemployment  a proxy for excess capacity  to business investment, rather than the other way around. Then the data since 1990 look like this:

title: Rain, Snow and the Forests Primeval Power, Channeled Through Beats
description: Percussion has always held an honored place in Japanese music, in both its traditional and Western-influenced manifestations. Carnegie Halls JapanNYC festival has offered samples of each style. The Juilliard Percussion Ensembles contribution was a richly varied evening of contemporary Japanese works at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday. The program included five scores calling for three to nine players, with Daniel Druckman, the associate principal percussionist of the New York Philharmonic, on the podium for the larger works.

title: Workers Give Glimpse of Japans Nuclear Crisis
description: TOKYO  With the power out, trucks were parked in a circle with their lights on, creating a shadowy stage. A manager from the Tokyo Electric Power Company explained how the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant had been slammed by a mammoth tsunami and rocked by hydrogen explosions and had become highly radioactive. Some workers wept.

title: Vintage Signs Head Home (for Sale) After Year in Police Custody
description: William LeRoy and his lawyer trudged up a short flight of dusty stairs in a former factory on a dead-end street in Queens. Behind a steel mesh barrier, a man in a pork-pie hat waited at a counter with his ledger. He had heard something about Mr. LeRoy.

title: Culture, Rolling Into Towns on Big Rigs
description: Trucks transport 70 percent of the freight in the United States, according to the Department of Transportation. And if a prominent New York artist and his friends have their way, a tiny fraction of that total  six 18-wheelers full, to be exact  will soon be a variety of cargo not usually found barreling down the interstate: art, fresh from painters studios; poets, playwrights and songwriters pens; and filmmakers cameras.

title: Captive in a Zoo
description: To the Editor:

title: Fleeing North Africa and Landing in an Italian Limbo
description: MANDURIA, Italy  Under dark rain clouds on Tuesday afternoon, a group of about 10 immigrants hopped the thin wire fence surrounding the makeshift tent camp here and made a run for it into a silvery olive grove and the freedom of Italy beyond.

title: Photo Replay: March 30
description: The day in sports included baseballs final exhibition games before the start of the season and the highly anticipated Cricket World Cup match between India and Pakistan.

title: Low Levels of Radiation Found in American Milk
description: Tests of milk samples taken last week in Spokane, Wash., indicate the presence of radioactive iodine from the troubled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan, but at levels far below those at which action would have to be taken, the Environmental Protection Agency said on Wednesday.

title: Libya Taps Nicaraguan as Its Envoy at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  A former Nicaraguan foreign minister who once called President Ronald Reagan the butcher of my people has been appointed to represent Libya at the United Nations after its delegate was denied a visa, the Nicaraguan government said on Wednesday.

title: Egypt's Bumpy Road to Democracy
description: Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof reports on the messy state of Egypt after street protests inspired a democratic revolution.

title: From an Opponents Mistake, an Opportunity
description: The winners of the Leventritt Silver Ribbon Pairs at the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., this month were Richard DeMartino of Riverside, Conn., the president of the American Contract Bridge League in 2010, and John Stiefel of Wethersfield, Conn.

title: Democracy Is Messy
description: CAIRO

title: House Passes School Voucher Bill
description: The House voted Wednesday to provide $20 million annually for five years for scholarships to pay for private school for children who now attend poorly performing schools in the District of Columbia, and $20 million each for charter and traditional public schools there. The bill would reprise a 2004 program, devised by Speaker John A. Boehner and later undone by Democrats, through which more than 1,000 low-income students in the District of Columbia were given $7,500 annually in federal money, the only program in the country that provides federal money for vouchers. The bill, which passed by a vote of 225 to 195 almost directly along partisan lines, will have an uphill battle in the Senate; the White House, while stopping short of a veto threat, has made clear its lack of support.

title: Activists Urge a Vegan Makeover
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It may never make it on the political menu, but the animal rights group People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals is urging city leaders in San Francisco to change the name of its legendarily gritty Tenderloin to something with decidedly less gristle.

title: Knicks and Nets: Two Teams That Need an Introduction
description: Dig We Must. That was the ominous sign Consolidated Edison used to place in the middle of New York streets  for years at a time  back in the 70s. (They still do the digging; they just lost the sign.)

title: Disclosure Rules Need Revision
description: Activist investors generally prefer to be on the attack. So its odd to see them on the back foot, fighting to preserve an important arrow in their quiver. The Securities and Exchange Commission is weighing whether to curb the ability of shareholders from quietly building stakes in companies. The battle should intensify Thursday when the merger worlds top lawyers and bankers hold their annual conference in New Orleans.

title: Criticism of Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Politicians and the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: The Reform That Wasnt
description: From the outset of the recent financial crisis, the governments often-haphazard response was motivated by an overarching desire to re-establish the status quo on Wall Street as quickly as possible.

title: Abuse in Group Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiki Confidential
description: Cocktail connoisseur "Tiki Adam" Kolesar passes on some Tiki history at the bar Death & Co. Mixologist Brian Miller prepares the fabled Zombie 34.

title: Manhattan Streets, the Dutch Way
description: To the Editor:

title: A Book for Sale on Tax Day, but Online Now
description: To publicize the release of The Pale King, a posthumously published novel by David Foster Wallace that is set in an Internal Revenue Service processing center, Hachette Book Group created a marketing campaign centered on the traditional tax day: April 15.

title: No Belfry, Just a House With 20,000 or So Bats
description: TIFTON, Ga.  The civic leaders of this south Georgia town want it to be known for more than just bats.

title: Lynsey Addario: Its What I Do
description: Lynsey Addario was freed from captivity in Libya on March 21, along with Tyler Hicks, Stephen Farrell and Anthony Shadid. Nine days later, in New York, she sat down with James Estrin, Kerri MacDonald and David Furst to share her thoughts on the experience. David W. Dunlap edited Ms. Addarios answers to her colleagues questions into a narrative.

title: In Bid for Young Viewers, Baseball Ads Swap Action for Funny Videos
description: DUDE, take me out to the ball game

title: In Foreclosure Settlement Talks With Banks, Predictions of a Long Process
description: Little was settled in the first round of foreclosure settlement talks.

title: Let There Be Light Bulbs
description: Of all the controversies now raging in Washington, the one I find most endearing is the fight over federal regulation of light bulb efficiency.

title: At Texas A&M, a Long Journey to the Final Four
description: When Penny King began working in the ticket office at Texas A&M in 1972, she could not imagine that the womens basketball team would ever reach the Final Four.

title: Relentless Leader of Underdogs Run Is Underdog Himself
description: Tommy Tonelli knows how Bill Self feels. And so do Leonard Hamilton, Matt Painter, John Thompson III and Kevin ONeill.

title: Officers Death Shows Struggle to Define Link Between 9/11 Dust and Disease
description: When George Wong, a retired police officer, died last week after a battle with gastric cancer, his family assumed, as Mr. Wong had, that the cause of his disease was the many hours he had put in directing traffic around ground zero in 2001.

title: Bats, Balls and Bullets
description: In late March and early April 1861, ballplayers in dozens of American towns looked forward to another season of play. But they were not highly paid professionals whose teams traveled to Florida or Arizona for spring training. Rather, they were amateur members of private organizations founded by men whose social standing ranged from the working class through the upper-middle ranks of society. There were no formal leagues or fixed schedules of games, although there were regional associations of clubs that drew up and enforced rules for each type of bat and ball game. Contests between the best teams attracted large crowds (including many gamblers), and reporters from daily newspapers and weekly sporting magazines wrote detailed accounts of the games.

title: Yankees Bracing for Cold in Opener and in April
description: We just left 85, man, Nick Swisher was saying in the home clubhouse at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, referring to the temperature in Tampa, Fla., where the Yankees beat the Detroit Tigers on Tuesday before flying north to start the season.

title: Tests Show Irish Banks Still Ailing
description: LONDON  Once again, Irelands banking mess seems to be sending a message that Europe does not want to hear: only by dealing with stricken banks can the Continent expect to end its debt crisis soon.

title: In Yemen, Sit-In Against the Government Yields Business Opportunities
description: SANA, Yemen  The antigovernment sit-in here in the capital has endured everything from violent attacks to driving rain over the last two months. It has transformed from a small student demonstration at the university to a vast mass of determination stretching for two miles down an adjacent boulevard. It is shaking the government.

title: Just Look at This Place. Whats Not to Love?
description: Flabbergasting was the word in Brooklyn. Impossible, newspapers in Queens claimed. Inconceivable, said the mayor.

title: Saving Mouths and Restoring Smiles
description: Snaggle teeth, gapped teeth, smashed teeth, no teeth; there are few dental maladies that Dr. Abraham Biegeleisen, a periodontist, has not seen and fixed. Over his 30-year career, Dr. Biegeleisen, 58, the son of Holocaust survivors, has implanted teeth, reconstructed jaws and restored the gums of thousands of patients on Staten Island, all the while retaining his own picture-perfect grin. He lives in Holmdel, N.J., with his wife and four children.

title: Some Rabbinical Students to Get State Tuition Aid
description: The state budget plan that moved toward enactment on Wednesday calls for 10 percent cuts in aid to public colleges and universities, but it would add about $18 million a year in tuition assistance for students attending some private religious schools.

title: A Trial in Brazil, With Testimony on Long Island
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y.  Its a small room in the federal courthouse here. Four men sit around a table, all business, looking up at two television screens. On one of the screens, another man in a business suit speaks in Portuguese. His words are then translated into English. He is asking questions about altitude, about transponders, about air-traffic control.

title: Does Mutts Infringe on Rutts? Hot Dog Status Is at Stake
description: CLIFTON, N.J.

title: Meet 30-Down: Wilson Is Answer for the Giants
description: The following article will give away some additional answers to Thursdays crossword puzzle in The New York Times. Proceed at your own curiosity.

title: Elections in Egypt by the Fall, Leaders Say
description: CAIRO  Egypts military rulers announced an interim constitution Wednesday and said presidential elections would be held by November, both important steps in their plan for getting out of the daily business of governing the country.

title: Islamists Are Elated by Revolts, Cleric Says
description: WASHINGTON  Anwar al-Awlaki, the Yemeni-American cleric who is a top propagandist for Al Qaeda, broke his silence on the uprisings in the Arab world on Wednesday, claiming that Islamist extremists had gleefully watched the success of protest movements against governments they had long despised.

title: Trying to Relish the Big Time, Even When It Brings a Cringe
description: The house lights came up and it was intermission at The Book of Mormon, the new Broadway musical about a pair of innocent young Mormon missionaries sent to Uganda to spread the faith. John Dehlin, a graduate student who flew in from Utah to see the show with a group of Mormons from around the country, was still riveted to his theater seat, having flashbacks.

title: Bloggingheads | Libya: U.N. Unnecessary?
description: Adam Serwer, left, of The American Prospect and Daniel Foster of National Review debate whether United Nations approval was necessary in Libya.

title: Strained Muscle May Send Mets Bay to Disabled List
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jason Bay has not played in a major league game since July 25, missing the final 63 games of last season because of the lingering effects of a concussion. It was not until the off-season that the symptoms subsided completely.

title: Treasury Now Sees Profit From Bailouts
description: Take your pick: A $100 billion loss. A nearly $24 billion profit. A $100 billion profit.

title: Take Dip Out of the Ballgame
description: Stamford, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Ex-Wifes Suit Against Steven Cohen Is Dismissed
description: A federal court judge on Wednesday dismissed a suit brought against the billionaire Steven A. Cohen by his former wife, ending a highly public chapter for the secretive hedge fund manager.

title: Justices Hear Arguments in Generic-Drug Lawsuit
description: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, the Supreme Court ruled that makers of brand-name drugs may be sued under state law for failing to warn consumers about the risks associated with their products. That decision, Wyeth v. Levine, was based in large part on the fact that such drug companies can sometimes change the labels on their products without permission from the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Mets Seek $200 Million For Portion of the Team
description: The Mets are seeking $200 million for a minority portion of the team  a badly needed cash infusion that the teams owners would pour directly into the clubs operations and use to pay off some of their debt, according to a person briefed on the sale process.

title: Captured by Qaddafi's Forces
description: On March 15, four New York Times journalists covering the Libyan conflict were captured. They were freed six days later. Back in New York, they reflected on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Libya.

title: Because of Japans Problems, Auto Dealers See Trouble Ahead in Meeting Demand
description: DETROIT  As automakers prepare to report strong sales for March, dealers and analysts say that some brands could begin having difficulty meeting demand in the months ahead because of production disruptions in Japan.

title: Libyans Offer Credible Case of Death by Airstrike
description: GHARYAN, Libya  Standing at the grave of an 18-month-old baby on Wednesday, officials of the Qaddafi government presented the first specific and credible case of a civilian death caused by Western airstrikes.

title: A Hidden Lobby for Indonesian Paper?
description: The Institute for Liberty, a Tea Party group, has attacked Greenpeace, U.S. labor unions and paper companies in the name of populist values. But an examination by the New York Times found ties between the Institute for Liberty and Asia Pulp & Paper Ltd., a large corporation that has often been targeted by those same groups.

title: Despite Hecklers, Lawmakers Close In on Rare Early Budget
description: ALBANY  With a backdrop of chanting from protesters who draped banners from staircases and banged on the doors of the legislative chambers, lawmakers on Wednesday sped toward the passage of a state budget, seeking the first on-time passage in five years.

title: What I Learned at School
description: Providence, R.I.

title: Odd Alliance: Business Lobby and Tea Party
description: The Tea Party does not have a presence in Indonesia, where the term evokes cups of orange pekoe and sweet cakes rather than angry citizens in Dont Tread on Me T-shirts.

title: China Hedges Over Whether South China Sea Is a Core Interest Worth War
description: BEIJING  When President Hu Jintao of China dropped in on Washington this winter, one hot-button topic was notably absent from the agenda: the South China Sea. Nor will Chinese officials be keen to discuss it during a summit meeting between the countries planned for May in Washington.

title: Thursday: Totally Out
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Theres an interesting story behind todays puzzle. Im not going to go into detail, because there is a feature article in todays New York Times by Jason Turbow, and he really deserves to tell the full story of how he, Will Shortz, Jeremy Horwitz and Tyler Hinman pulled this off. I will, however, give you a small piece of the story leading up to the puzzles publication. When youre finished here, please go and read Mr. Turbows excellent article.

title: China: Crackdown on Foreigners
description: Guangdong Province in southern China is tightening rules on foreigners living and working in the province as part of what it calls a clampdown on illegal immigration, according to the official China Daily. A new regulation that takes effect on May 1 asks people to report malpractice involving foreigners, including overstaying visas, illegal entry and working without permits. Guangdong has been one of the most open provinces to foreigners; many foreign-run factories are in the Pearl River Delta area.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 30, 2011

title: Theyve Got to Fix Their Priorities
description: The banks may have weathered the financial crisis, but the rest of the country hasnt. Taxpayers are still on the hook for federally guaranteed bank debt. Homeowners equity continues to erode. Small businesses still have trouble getting loans, and savers are still getting hammered by near zero interest rates. Joblessness remains high. State budgets are ravaged.

title: Black Caucus Celebrates 40 Years
description: Founding and current members of the Congressional Black Caucus blew out the candles and toasted the caucuss 40th anniversary Wednesday night in Statuary Hall in the Capitol.

title: Bishops Criticize Nuns Book
description: A committee of American Roman Catholic bishops announced Wednesday that a popular book about God by Sister Elizabeth A. Johnson, a theologian at Fordham University in New York, should not be used in Catholic schools and universities because it does not uphold church doctrine.

title: Rookie Goalie Foils Rangers, and Race Tightens
description: BUFFALO  The Rangers scoring troubles have become so pronounced that even when they catch a fortunate break, they struggle to produce goals.

title: Ohio Lawmakers Pass Anti-Union Bill
description: The two houses of the Ohio Legislature approved a far-reaching bill on Wednesday that would hobble the ability of public-employee unions to bargain collectively and undercut their political clout.

title: Googles Book Deal
description: Googles ambitious proposal to scan, index and make available every book ever written promised a cultural revolution. Yet for all its promise, Judge Denny Chin of the United States District Court in Manhattan was right to strike down the plan last week, ruling that a settlement with the Authors Guild and publishers that would allow Google to put millions of books online without the explicit consent of their authors would simply go too far.

title: An Extraordinary Intrusion on Womens Rights
description: Far too many states are putting new obstacles in the way of women seeking legal abortions. But South Dakotas new law stands out for its intrusiveness and its abuse of womens rights.

title: An Arizona Senate Race Waits to See if Giffords Emerges to Run
description: TUCSON  Representative Gabrielle Giffords is still in the hospital, but some of her most ardent backers are so enamored of the idea of her running for the Senate that they describe the inevitable campaign commercials: the deep-voiced narrator recounting what happened to her, the images of her wounded, then recovering and speaking into the camera alongside her astronaut husband to call on Arizonans to unite.

title: Without the Campaign Donors, This Wouldnt Be Possible
description: Even by Washingtons low standards, the Houses Republican freshmen are turning pandering into a high art. At a recent transportation hearing in his home district, Representative James Lankford of Oklahoma heaped praise on a panel of private sector witnesses. Three of the four executives so publicly favored were later discovered to be donors to Mr. Lankfords campaign.

title: Union Accuses a Leader Of Financial Misconduct
description: The Service Employees International Union has filed internal charges against Bruce S. Raynor, one of New Yorks most prominent union leaders and the head of that unions apparel workers affiliate, accusing him of financial misconduct.

title: Belgium: Call for Sex-Abuse Panel
description: Almost a year after a scandal engulfed Belgium following the resignation of a Roman Catholic bishop who admitted he had sexually abused boys, a parliamentary commission called for a new panel to adjudicate compensation claims for the hundreds of people who say they were the victims of predatory priests. Among the commissions other recommendations was to extend the statute of limitations on crimes of sexual abuse to 15 years, up from 10.

title: Israel: Doubling Tax on Energy
description: The Israeli Parliament overwhelmingly approved a near doubling of the profit tax on gas and oil extracted from Israeli territory, a move expected to be worth tens of billions of dollars over the coming decades. In recent years, Israel has discovered huge fields of natural gas off its coast, aided in part by a much lower than average tax structure that provided incentives for energy companies to take on the risks and costs of such searches.

title: TimesCast | The View in Israel
description: Ethan Bronner, The Times's Jerusalem bureau chief, discusses Israel's reaction to the protests in Syria.

title: Negotiations on Budget Inch Ahead in House
description: WASHINGTON  As budget negotiations resumed on Capitol Hill and appeared to make headway, House Republican leaders on Wednesday began the delicate task of assessing what level of compromise they can sell to a conservative rank-and-file spoiling for a fiscal fight.

title: TimesCast | Reviewing Bashar's Speech
description: Michael Slackman, The Times's Berlin bureau chief, discusses the characterization of unrest in Syria by the country's president, Bashar al-Assad.

title: 3 Tons of Marijuana Seized in Sullivan County Raid
description: Federal drug officials have helped break up an upstate drug ring and seized more than 6,000 pounds of marijuana worth nearly $20 million, they announced on Wednesday.

title: Official Says Bus in Crash That Killed 15 Was Speeding
description: The casino bus that crashed in the Bronx this month, killing 15 of its passengers, was exceeding the speed limit by more than 20 miles an hour before it drifted off the highway, rolled over and skidded into a sturdy signpost, a federal official told a United States Senate panel on Wednesday.

title: Thomas Eisner, Who Cracked Chemistry of Bugs, Dies at 81
description: Thomas Eisner, a groundbreaking authority on insects whose research revealed the complex chemistry that they use to repel predators, attract mates and protect their young, died on Friday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 81.

title: H. R. F. Keating, Author of Crime Series, Is Dead at 84
description: H. R. F. Keating, the prolific British crime novelist who created Ganesh Ghote, the humble Indian police inspector in Bombay, died on Sunday in London. He was 84.

title: Pennsylvania: 2 More Priests Are Suspended
description: The Archdiocese of Philadelphia said Wednesday that it had suspended two retired priests, bringing the total placed on administrative leave since Feb. 10 to 26. The archdiocese did not name the priests, both of whom live in private residences, nor did it describe the incidents that led to their suspension, pending fuller investigations. One retired in 2005 and is not serving in any public ministry; the other retired in 2006 and has assisted at parishes. The suspensions began after a grand jury revealed that up to 37 priests suspected of behavior ranging from sexual abuse to boundary issues remained in active ministry.

title: Revamped Knicks Rally and Outlast the Retooled Nets
description: Barring what would amount to a meteoric fall, the Knicks will make the Eastern Conference playoffs. The Nets, mathematically, cannot.

title: Nets Begin Selling Tickets for New Arena
description: The Nets new home in Brooklyn is still an unfinished collection of steel beams, but the seats that are still quite a bit away from being actual seats are on sale  for some.

title: Word of the Day | corporeal
description: corporeal \kr-pr-e-l\ adjective

title: Artists to Transform Bowerys Roll-Down Gates
description: There probably wont be many New Yorkers mourning the death of the security roll-down gate, that unlovely after-hours face of the citys storefronts. In 2009 the City Council, citing high rates of graffiti, voted to begin slowly phasing out the gates in favor of rolling grilles. But for at least a couple of months this summer, roll gates and paint will have a last hurrah together, courtesy of the New Museum and the Art Production Fund. As part of the Festival of Ideas for the New City  a series of arts and civic events that the New Museum and other downtown cultural institutions will conduct from May 4 through 8  17 artists have been recruited to create paintings that will soon start appearing on roll-down gates along the Bowery, from Houston Street to Canal Street. The artists  among them Mary Heilmann, Glenn Ligon and Ingrid Calame  have created the images but will hand off the actual painting chores to Colossal Media, a Brooklyn-based company. It removes itself from the practice of real graffiti, but it plays with the idea, said Yvonne Force Villareal, a co-founder of the Art Production Fund. She said that she and others involved with the project, to be called After Hours: Murals on the Bowery, first combed the Bowery at night, then spent months talking to property owners. Next comes power washing and, within the next several weeks, she said, the murals will start to appear for anyone interested in nocturnal Bowery art appreciation. They will remain for two months.

title: Antitrust Cry From Microsoft
description: The wheel of technology history turns remarkably fast. Microsoft, whose domination of the technology industry provoked a landmark federal antitrust case, is crying foul against Google and urging European Union antitrust officials to go after the search giant.

title: In England on a Business Trip, With the Boys, the Boots, the Kits and on the Pitch!
Study Says Charter Network Has Financial Advantages Over Public Schools
description: Most charter schools receive less government money for each student, on average, than traditional public schools.

title: New York City: Whats Not to Love?
description: The news that New York Citys population grew by a mere 2.1 percent over the last decade has baffled some of the citys denizens, but not left them speechless (really, what could do that to a true New Yorker?). For some residents of the city of Ellis Island, the Yankees, Radio City Music Hall and more, the idea that the world is not rushing to their shores is inconceivable, even just plain wrong, as Senator Charles E. Schumer said.

title: News Quiz | March 31, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Albany Finishes Rare On-Time Budget
description: ALBANY  To the soundtrack of chanting protesters who draped banners from staircases and banged on the doors of the legislative chambers, lawmakers finished approving Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos budget early Thursday morning, making for the states first on-time spending plan in five years.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 31, 2011
description: Test your vocabulary skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article Japans Strict Building Codes Saved Lives.

title: Daily Lexeme: Attercop
description: Todays word, in association with the formidable Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Really Hot, Really Cold and Maybe Even a Bit Icy
description: WHAT is this a picture of?

title: What Memorable Poetry Have You Ever Read or Heard?
description: April is National Poetry Month, and to celebrate it were asking you to write about your own experiences with verse. What poems do you remember hearing or reading, whether in early childhood or in English class last week? Do you like poetry in general? Do you have a favorite poet? Have you ever written a poem?

title: The Myth of Resolution Authority
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: In India, Vodafone to Buy Out a Partner
description: 7:59 p.m. | Updated

title: Rare 1967 Toyota 2000 GT Hits eBay for $650,000
description: Finding a Toyota 2000GT while combing the assembled coterie of Camrys and Corollas that inhabit the Toyota section of eBay Motors is equivalent to finding King Tuts sarcophagus at the Container Store. Sure, the sarcophagus is technically a container, and the Toyota 2000GT a used car, but both stand out slightly when placed among their more pedestrian brethren.

title: 2010 Browns: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we complete our look at the A.F.C. North:

title: Fantasy Focus: Power and Park Effects
description: Tracking off-season player movement is crucial for fantasy owners looking to gain a competitive edge when a power hitter moves into a more offense-friendly environment or when a pitcher gets an opportunity to move to a more spacious park such as Petco Park in San Diego or McAfee Coliseum in Oakland.

title: The Early Word: Undercover
description: In Todays Times:Covert operatives from the Central Intelligence Agency are in Libya gathering military intelligence that the United States and its allies hope to use to bleed dry Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces, Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt report.The American spies are also meeting with rebels to try to fill in gaps in understanding who their leaders are and the allegiances of the groups opposed to Colonel Qaddafi, said United States government officials, speaking on condition of anonymity because of the classified nature of the activities. American officials cautioned, though, that the Western operatives were not directing the actions of rebel forces.

title: Transforming a Berlin Gas Station Into Art
description: Freie Internationale Tankstelle, or FIT, is back in Berlin, offering passersby a fueling station for the creative spirit in the most unlikely of art venues: a gas station. Founded in 2002 by the artist Dida Zende, FIT sits just off the beaten path on a leafy street in Prenzlauer Berg. The station itself dates back to the 1920s, a quirky historical monument that Mr. Zende has transformed into what he describes as an inverse white cube for contemporary artists.

title: Anxiety Roils Libyan Capital Amid Top-Level Defections
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Anxiety seized the Qaddafi government on Thursday over the second defection in two days of a senior official close to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, stirring talk of others to follow and a crackdown to stop them.

title: Five Tips for Helping Parents With Technology
description: Digital technology and the Internet arent for early adopters and tweens anymore. Thats great, but its led to a new problem for a lot of grown-ups: Theyve become the first line of tech support for their parents. For most people, debugging someone elses problem  usually done remotely  is an exercise in exasperation. Especially when that someone changed your diapers, put up with your teenage years and now expects payback.

title: Who Made That Radiation Symbol?
description: For hundreds of years, the image of a skull and crossbones was all we needed to communicate the concept of poison. That is, until we started experimenting with radioactive compounds.

title: Radioactive Iodine Detected in Ocean, Despite Gains at Japanese Plant
description: TOKYO  Workers made incremental progress at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant on Thursday, but disturbingly high radiation readings there as well as miles away continued to reinforce fears that Japans crisis was far from over.

title: Q&A: Keeping Direct Messages Private on Twitter
description: Q.

title: Letter Bomb Injures 2 at Swiss Nuclear Office
description: GENEVA  A letter bomb exploded at the office of a Swiss nuclear industry lobbying group on Thursday, slightly injuring two employees, a police spokesman said.

title: Broiled, Sauted, Roasted, Poached
description: If youre serious about eating sustainable fish, you may have given up on the most fundamental of all: the white fillet. After nearly exhausting cod stocks 20 years ago, we have gone through a dozen or more alternatives, from red snapper to orange roughy to so-called Chilean sea bass, and fished them all practically out of existence.

title: Sweet on Tiki, Flower of Cocktails
description: There have been many changes in Adam Kolesar over the years, starting with his facial hair, to which he devotes an agitated, overzealous attention described less aptly as grooming than as absurdist art project. He has made geometric patterns with it. He has dyed it blue. In its current, uncolored form it crawls in five bands, separated by shaved skin, from his cheeks to a point just a few inches below his jaw line. Its a stylized but scraggly marvel.

title: In Shadow of Yankee Stadium, 3 Unfinished Ball Fields
description: On Thursday, the New York Yankees began their regular season at Yankee Stadium, a gleaming $1.5 billion behemoth that opened in the Bronx in 2009 as the new home of one of the richest franchises in sports.

title: A Tech Tool That Puts Employees and Customers to the Test
description: Everyone does online presentations of one sort or another today. But do you always question the people who are sitting through them to make sure theyre getting the message?

title: Making Photos Good Enough to Eat
description: Every wonder why photos of the delicacies at your cookout dont look like the shots in food magazines? The reason, says food-photo pro Bill Brady is because when it comes to those magazine shots, Most of it is fake.

title: Volcanic Rocks Just North of the Border
description: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from New Mexico, where he is measuring sand particle sizes, layer thicknesses and angles to address questions about volcanoes and rock patterns on Mars.

title: Sequins in Your Step
description: Kooky attire has dug its heels in against the widespread appeal of minimalism, so why not just go for it? These shoes are magical, says LeAnn Nealz, the president and chief creative officer of Juicy Couture, referring to the Duchess, the brands new sequined sandal, available April 15 in both silver and gold. Add a pair of neon socks or Julian Louie cropped patterned pants and youll be fast following in the steps of such maximalists as Anna Piaggi and Catherine Baba, whose more is more approach keeps the fashion pack on its toes.

title: Doe, Xylophone, Cellphone
description: This commercial was posted by a friend on Facebook. Stunning, he wrote by way of introduction. A wooden ball is set atop a long, wooden structure that might be a xylophone or a marimba, constructed in the middle of the woods. As the ball rolls downward, dropping onto each wooden key, it plays a note, and suddenly we are hearing Bachs Cantata 147, Jesu, Joy of Mans Desiring.

title: The Case for Obama Campaigning on the Economy
description: For the last several weeks, it has been hard to miss the shift in political and media attention toward foreign policy. The democratic upheavals in the Middle East, the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster in Japan and even President Obamas trip to Latin America have stolen the headlines.

title: China Lays Out Vision for Military
description: BEIJING  The Chinese military said Thursday that while the security situation in Asia and the Pacific was generally stable, it was becoming more intricate and volatile, with no clear solutions for tension points like the divided Korean Peninsula and with the United States increasing its involvement in regional issues.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Solar, Wind, and Nuclear: South Africas New Electricity Plan
description: You might think that this would be the sort of month to hold off on investing in a new nuclear reactor. But even as some countries are taking a step back  Germany has taken seven of its oldest plants offline, Italy has declared a one-year moratorium on a plan to re-establish its nuclear industry, and China has temporarily suspended approvals of new plants  South Africa is moving confidently ahead.

title: Morning Buzz | A Budget With Time to Spare
description: Thursday will reach a high of around 45, and rain is likely. The rain may turn to snow during the night. Bundle up if youre heading to the ballpark for opening day.

title: France to Assess Nuclear Risk and Safety Measures
description: PARIS  Although France has avoided most of the global anti-nuclear backlash prompted by the Fukushima reactor crisis, there is a serious, if quiet, reassessing of the risks here in a country that obtains nearly 80 percent of its electricity from nuclear power.

title: Counting Her Blessings
description: We are driving in silence along the road near my house when I hear my mother counting. I am hunched over the wheel, gnawing the inside of my lip, plotting how I am going to pay this winters heating bill while Mom strains against her seat belt, craning her neck, whispering: Three! Four! Five!

title: Google Plays Down Microsoft's Antitrust Complaint in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  Google played down the significance of an antitrust complaint filed by one of its main rivals, Microsoft, on Thursday and said its discussions were continuing with European Union regulators.

title: March 31 Updates on Libyan War and Mideast Protests
description: On Thursday, The Lede is following the war in Libya, unrest in Syria and protest movements across the Middle East and North Africa. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region. For a summary of the latest developments in Libya, read the frequently updated main news article on our home page.

title: A Decline in American Entrepreneurship
description: American workers werent the only ones sacrificed by the Great Recession. Start-ups suffered, too.

title: Ristretto | Modernist Coffee
description: Nathan Myhrvold keeps busy. The former chief technology officer of Microsoft is an executive at DreamWorks Animation, once studied with Stephen Hawking and donated Tyrannosaurus rex fossils he uncovered in Montana to the Smithsonian. He was profiled by Malcolm Gladwell, is a pal of Bill Gates and spent the last several years working on Modernist Cuisine, an encyclopedic six-volume compendium of cutting-edge cooking that is not only one of the most expensive cookbooks ever published (the list price is $625, though its available on Amazon.com for a mere $461.62) but also one of the heaviest, a fire-door-stopper that tips the scales at more than 40 pounds. An initial print run of 6,000 editions has already sold out.

title: Private Equity to Buy Taylor Wimpey Unit for $955 Million
description: Taylor Wimpey, the British homebuilder, announced on Thursday that it would sell its North American business for $955 million to a group of private equity investors that includes TPG Capital and Oaktree Capital Management.

title: The Perception of the Sokol Situation
description: Perception is more important than reality.

title: Ivory Coast Battle Nears Decisive Stage in Key City
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The end of the Ivory Coast strongman Laurent Gbagbos rule appeared to be nearing Thursday as his rivals troops approached the countrys main city of Abidjan, his own army chief of staff abandoned his post and his opponents claimed substantial defections of his troops and police officers.

title: The Phillies Four Aces
description: When I pitched in the minor leagues, we called it stuff. A pitchers currency. Hard stuff, breaking stuff, slow stuff, trick stuff. Trick stuff was Phil Niekros knuckleball. He won 318 major league games by digging his fingernails into the seams of a ball and throwing it toward the plate as if he were pushing open a door. Trying to hit his knuckleball was like swatting at a fly with a straw.

title: Future of HBOs In Treatment Is Couched in Mystery
description: Almost everything about the psychiatric process is apparently open to interpretation, even the status of a television series about it. On Wednesday night, reports surfaced that HBO had canceled its drama In Treatment, which has starred Gabriel Byrne as the psychotherapist Dr. Paul Weston, and featured a rotating roster of actors including Hope Davis, Debra Winger and Mia Wasikowska as his patients. Dianne Wiest and Amy Ryan also starred, as Dr. Westons own therapists. And while a cigar is sometimes just a cigar, HBO seemed to suggest that this cancellation was not necessarily a cancellation. In a statement, the network said: Its true that we have no plans to continue with In Treatment as previously formatted. However, we are in continued conversations with the executive producers to find another way to continue telling these rich stories.

title: Sight Lines
description: Precocious and self-possessed, Charlotte Perriand was a girl among men, admitted to the ranks of the architects whose names would become synonymous with the new century, at an age when her outlook on design and the world was still in formation. In what would prove to be one of Modernisms signal images, she reclines in the chaise longue she designed in collaboration with Le Corbusier and his cousin Pierre Jeanneret. It was, in Le Corbusiers utopian terms, a machine for resting in, and as if to remind us that its the chair, not the woman, being presented for our consideration, her face is turned away; she is at once familiar and unrecognizable. That the design of their now-famous furniture was for many years attributed to Le Corbusier alone, that most of her architectural projects never made it past the drawing board, that her far-ranging commissions defied easy classification, that her most significant projects are either gone or off the beaten path: all this only contributed to the enigma. Now, 12 years after her death, at 96, Charlotte Perriand: Photography: A Wide-Angle Eye, by Jacques Barsac (5 Continents Editions), offers an intimate glimpse of the woman and the workings of her mind.

title: Poetry Pairing | March 31, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Artists to Transform the Bowerys Roll-Down Gates
description: There probably wont be many New Yorkers mourning the death of the security roll-down gate, that unlovely after-hours face of the citys storefronts. In 2009, the City Council, citing high rates of graffiti, voted to begin slowly phasing out the gates in favor of rolling grilles, which allow passers-by to look into store windows and do not provide the same kind of metal canvas for spray-can artists.

title: Awaiting Springs Arrival With an Onion Tart
description: By the calendar it has been spring for more than a week, but the Manhattan farmers markets remain in winter mode, and our home vegetable bin contains onions (and their kin), carrots, parsnips, celery root and not much else. These, of course, are the foundations of many a dish, so theres no ground for complaint. Yet with company coming, I needed to come up with a delicious and, preferably, unexpected first course. A slice of onion tart is always a nice way to start a meal - who could ever get tired of onions? Plus, I had already cooked a couple of pounds of onions in butter, and these were waiting in the refrigerator (keeping cooked onions at the ready is a great time saver, as they can kick-start innumerable preparations).

title: 2 Cabinet Officials Say U.S. Isnt Likely to Arm Libyans
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas top two national security officials signaled on Thursday that the United States was unlikely to arm the Libyan rebels, raising the possibility that the French alone among the Western allies would provide weapons and training for the poorly organized forces fighting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis government.

title: Thursday Reading: Low Levels of Radiation Found in Milk
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

title: Winters Last Stand (for Now)
description: Cherry Hill, Central Park, Wednesday, 9:15 a.m. Could this finally be the end? Well know Friday.

title: Peabody Awards Go to Justified, The Good Wife and Sherlock
description: The gun-toting federal marshal Raylan Givens, the litigator Alicia Florrick and the consulting detective Sherlock Holmes may not share much when it comes to righting wrong-doings, but television series featuring those characters were all named winners of the 70th annual George Foster Peabody Awards on Thursday. Peabody Awards, bestowed by the University of Georgia Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication and recognizing excellence in electronic media, were given to the FX series Justified and the CBS drama The Good Wife, as well as Sherlock: A Study in Pink, a 21st-century spin on Sherlock Holmes seen on the PBS series Masterpiece/Mystery! Other winners included the HBO movie Temple Grandin, about that autism advocate, as well as the World War II mini-series The Pacific and the Spike Lee documentary If God Is Willing and Da Creek Dont Rise, about life in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, both shown on that cable network. C-Span was named the winner of an award for its searchable video library and CNN for its coverage of the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico; Peabodys also went to the arts series American Masters for LennonNYC, about John Lennon, and Elia Kazan: A Letter to Elia, directed by Kent Jones and Martin Scorsese.

title: Sokol Speaks About His Surprise Exit
description: David L. Sokol, the former Berkshire Hathaway executive, tells CNBC why he left the company and how he plans to start his own mini Berkshire Hathaway.

title: Heat Over Light
description: It looks like the power of the edge might be weakening a bit. The National Journal is reporting that the Tea Party movement is being gently shunned by leading Republican lawmakers (perhaps influenced by a CNN poll showing it is now viewed as unfavorably as the two established political parties; quite an achievement).

title: Groupon Co-Founders Invest in Qwiki
description: Two founders of Groupon, Brad Keywell and Eric Lefkofsky, have invested $1 million in the Silicon Valley start-up Qwiki through their investment fund, Lightbank, extending Qwikis latest fund-raising round to about $9 million.

title: What Were Reading
description: Heres a quick roundup of what were reading right now. What books are on your bedside table?

title: Stating the Obvious: Hunger Is a Disease
description: Hunger is a disease; starvation is its extreme form. Hunger can lead to starvation; starvation to death. Obvious, no?

title: Suicide Attack on Politician in Pakistan Fails Again
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A prominent Islamist politician escaped an assassination attempt on Thursday in northwestern Pakistan, the second in two days, as a suicide bomb ripped through his convoy, killing at least 12 people and injuring more than 30, police officials said.

title: The Skateboarder and His Girlfriend, Los Angeles
description: This was the day I came back from the hospital, with third-degree burns on my chest and my back.

title: The Rise of Desktop Medicine
description: Recently, a colleague lamented a change she had noticed among the young doctors at her hospital. They are always in front of the hospital computers, she said. I never see them with patients, but I can always find them sitting at a terminal.

title: Final Four Trip Pays Off for Coaches
description: Its typical to hear the coaches involved in the Final Four to talk about being happy and thankful for the opportunity to play for the N.C.A.A. title.

title: Vain Glorious | Edgy Makeup From Illamasqua
description: What: The Toxic Nature Collection from the British beauty brand Illamasqua.

title: Ferdinand the Bull Turns 75
description: With new war fronts popping up on a seemingly daily basis, it may be an opportune moment to revisit the story of Ferdinand, the peaceable bull. Today marks the 75th anniversary of The Story of Ferdinand, written by Munro Leaf, a prolific writer for children, and illustrated by Robert Lawson, the only person ever to win both the Caldecott and Newbery medals.

title: Leading Off: First Pitch, 30 Degrees
description: We feel the need to inform you that it is opening day in baseball. We feel the need to inform you of this because, A) its a Thursday, which departs from the usual opening on a Monday (with one Sunday game; Major League Baseball always likes messing with you a bit); and B) the weather in many cities is more suited to the opening of icy mud-wrestling season.

title: Wheelies: The Mixed-Blessings Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Vietnam Persecutes Christian Minority, Report Says
description: BANGKOK  Vietnam has increased repression of indigenous minority Christians in the countrys Central Highlands, closing small informal churches, compelling public renunciations of faith and arresting worshipers, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Thursday.

title: Are You Your Childs A.T.M.?
description: Times are tough. Kids should be learning harsh financial truths right about now, no? Lessons learned: Money doesnt grow on trees, nor is there an endless supply in Mom or Dads wallet, right?

title: Alone Together
description: The Dutch photographer Reinier Gerritsen went into the New York City subway system to try to capture the mood of commuters.

title: Expedia Launches Sweepstakes on Facebook
description: Many travel companies offer discounts and deals through their Facebook pages, but starting today, Expedia is upping the ante: It has created a sweepstakes that offers more than $1 million in prizes, including five trips that cost more than $100,000.

title: U.S. Dropped Nuclear Rule Meant to Avert Hydrogen Explosions
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has allowed reactors to phase out some equipment that eliminates explosive hydrogen, the gas that blew up the outer containments of three reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi in Japan. The commission says it judged that at the American plants, the containments were strong enough that the equipment was not needed or other methods would do.

title: Prison Cell or Pitchers Mound?
description: The baseball season opens today, but the Mets home opener isnt until next Friday, which leaves me, as someone who in 1973 at the age of 6 threw my plastic fan-appreciation-day helmet right into our black-and-white television set when Wayne Garrett popped out to short for the final out of the seventh game of the World Series, with a question: is there still time for the owners of the Mets to return the loyalty Bernie Madoff showed them by requesting a furlough for Madoff on opening day so that he can travel up to the city from prison in North Carolina to throw out the ceremonial first pitch?

title: Coal, Jobs and Americas Energy Future
description: No one should be surprised to learn that in trying to woo a reluctant community, developers in just about every industry tend to exaggerate  or perhaps optimistically overestimate  the number of jobs they expect to create by building that new shopping mall, industrial park, widget factory or other project.

title: Mets Place Bay on Disabled List
description: Miami Gardens, Fla.  The Mets placed Jason Bay on the 15-day disabled list with a strained intercostal muscle in his left rib cage.

title: Boehner: No Agreement on Budget Cuts
description: The speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, said Thursday that there was not yet any budget deal for the rest of the year, tamping down speculation that the two parties had all but worked out their differences.

title: Italys Refuge of Last Resort
description: Thousands of immigrants are living in limbo in the Puglia region, transplants from a tiny island south of Sicily that has been overwhelmed by a flood of new arrivals from North Africa.

title: Sokol, Buffett and the Lubrizol Trades
description: David L. Sokols abrupt resignation from Berkshire Hathaway has raised questions about his decision to purchase shares in Lubrizol shortly before Berkshire agreed to buy the specialty chemicals company.

title: Thailand Mounts Rescue Effort After Powerful Storms
description: BANGKOK  The Thai government sent its only aircraft carrier to rescue stranded residents and tourists on Thursday after unseasonable storms inundated six southern provinces and offshore islands, killing at least 17 people and stranding thousands more.

title: Berthing Pains
description: Anyone lucky enough to be invited to Camp Topridge, the cereal heiress Marjorie Merriweather Posts 207-acre Adirondack camp, was greeted  upon arrival by water on her private launch  by an elaborate two-story, five-bay boathouse. Built in the 1920s with natural cedar logs with bark cut directly from local woods, it was decorated with a profusion of intricate twigs and branches. Later, a second boathouse was added.

title: Republicans Get Inconvenient Replies at Climate Hearing
description: 6:06 p.m. | Updated Richard Muller, a Berkeley physicist who at times has been embraced by foes of action to limit greenhouse gases because of his criticism of depictions of catastrophic global warming, was a star witness at a hearing today organized by Republican lawmakers. Ill be adding some observations from the hearing below as time allows. Add yours, of course!

title: The Bullish Case for Deal Growth
description: NEW ORLEANS  Deal makers have descended upon New Orleans for the 23rd Tulane Corporate Law Institute, an annual conference for mergers and acquisitions practitioners.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: For our guessing game this week, we shift to an urban location.

title: Behind Twittering Cobra, a Downtown Brooklynite?
description: Updated, 1:48 p.m. | We think we may have located the Bronx Zoos missing cobra.

title: Hotelier Offers New Options to Rewards Program
description: Anyone who is a member of a loyalty rewards program has been in this frustrating situation: You have a small number of points left over after a big redemption, but the rewards available for low balances arent very enticing. (How many cheap steak knives do you really need?)
