title: Our Allies, the Libyan Rebels
description: In the last 24 hours, weve learned three important things about the Libyan rebellion. First, judging by events on the battlefield, its fighters probably wont be able to topple Qaddafis government unless we find a way to significantly step our support. Second, weve already offered them more support than anyone realized, since it turns out that the C.I.A. has been assisting the rebel leadership since well before the United Nations resolution that officially justifies our involvement in this conflict. And third, the jihadist presence within the rebellion, while not dominant by any means, may nonetheless be real and meaningful  and growing apace, perhaps, as the civil war drags on.

title: Gingrich Urges Lawmakers Not to Give on Core Principles
description: Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, was on Capitol Hill on Thursday, admonishing his Republican colleagues that their goal should be to avoid a shutdown, while not giving in on their core principles.

title: Setbacks in Portugal and Ireland Renew Worry on Debt Crisis
description: LONDON  A higher-than-expected budget deficit in Portugal and the need for more money to rescue Irelands failing banks have renewed fears that Europes debt crisis is worsening despite its sizable bailout fund.

title: New Regulations Proposed for Accountable Care Organizations
description: Theyre finally out. The much-awaited, much-speculated-about proposed rules that would govern accountable care organizations, the new and somewhat nebulous entities that are a key part of the federal governments health care legislation, were announced on Thursday morning.

title: Fox Tops the TV Ratings Again
description: With the American Idol judges having saved Casey Abrams from elimination a week ago, the same slate of 11 competitors faced off again on Wednesday with two hours of musical trials, this time performing the songs of Elton John and Bernie Taupin. The performances attracted an average audience of 23.6 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. for Fox, according to Nielsens estimates, producing far higher ratings than any other program on that night. Fox easily won the night over all with CBS in second place, NBC in third, followed by ABC in fourth. CBS earned its best ratings at 9 p.m. with Criminal Minds (12.9 million), but drew a solid 10.6 million at 8 for Survivor: Redemption Island. CBSs spinoff Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior (9.3 million) led the 10 p.m. hour ahead of Law & Order: SVU on NBC (8.3 million) and Off the Map on ABC (4.2 million). NBC garnered 4.2 million at 8 for Minute to Win It followed by a rerun of SVU at 9 (3.6 million), while ABC broadcast sitcom repeats from 8 to 9:30 prior to Mr. Sunshine at 9:30 (4.1 million).

title: W.T.O. Rules U.S. Subsidies for Boeing Unfair
description: PARIS  Boeing received at least $5.3 billion in improper subsidies from the United States government to develop its 787 Dreamliner and other jet models, giving it an unfair advantage against its European rival, Airbus, the World Trade Organization confirmed in a report published Thursday.

title: Wisconsin Halts Union Law After Judges Ruling
description: CHICAGO  Officials in Wisconsin halted implementation of a law limiting collective bargaining rights for public workers on Thursday after a judge there ruled the law was not in effect because it had not been officially published.

title: NATO Warns Rebels Against Attacking Civilians
description: WASHINGTON  Members of the NATO alliance have sternly warned the rebels in Libya not to attack civilians as they push against the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, according to senior military and government officials.

title: Fairy Tale Endings?
description: The other day my daughter came home from school excited about having read the book Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes. She grabbed the book out of her backpack, opened it to the end, and told me to read the last line. I did, and then had to read the whole thing (it doesnt take long, though you have to get an actual bound copy; the Google book is partial). The true story of Sadako Sasaki is well known in Japan, and the book by Eleanor Coerr is a staple of elementary-school curricula and class projects in the United States, so chances are you know the basic outline: A Japanese girl gets leukemia as a result of radiation from the bombing of Hiroshima. A friend tells her that if she folds 1,000 paper cranes, her wish to be made well will come true. I couldnt find much about Eleanor Coerr online beyond that she was a Canadian who had spent time in Japan, and died last year at age 88. She wrote in spare, descriptive prose, and I understand why my daughter was stunned by the last line. Here it is, in context:

title: A Happily-Retired Mussina Throws the First Pitch
description: One of the first questions Mike Mussina was asked Thursday morning, about an hour and a half before he was to throw out the ceremonial first pitch at Yankee Stadium, was whether he had spoken to Andy Pettitte, another superb pitcher who retired on his terms. Mussina said that he hadnt and that he was only mildly surprised.

title: The Curious Case of Sokols Departure
description: 3:00 p.m. | Updated Reading Warren E. Buffetts letter announcing the resignation of David Sokol from Berkshire Hathaway brings to mind a movie scene in which a police officer yells amid a wild crowd, There is nothing to see here! Move along.

title: And the Actual Shows Are...
description: Extreme Couponing starts Wednesday on TLC. Gigolos arrives Thursday on Showtime. Pregnant in Heels has its premiere on Bravo on Tuesday. Glamour Belles makes its debut Wednesday on Lifetime. Mounted in Alaska begins Thursday on History. Moonshiners is being developed by Discovery. The Never Nude entry is based on a casting call circulated on the Internet recently for the TLC series My Strange Addiction. Whisker Wars is scheduled for August on IFC. The other entries dont exist on anyones TV grid  at least not yet.

title: For Twins, a Double Shot at a Slot in Kindergarten
description: Nine sets of twins will be entering kindergarten at Public School 107 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, in the fall, more than its longtime principal, Cynthia Holton, could recall ever admitting at once.

title: Have I Got a Show for You...
description: JUST how absurd and/or desperate have makers of reality television become?

title: CBS Declares Next Week Is Tweet Week
description: If only theyd thought of this while Charlie Sheen was still on one of their shows: taking a page from rival networks like ABC, CNN and Comedy Central that have used Twitter to draw in and keep viewers watching shows like Piers Morgan Tonight and events like the Academy Awards or The Comedy Central Roast of Donald Trump, CBS announced on Thursday that it would have eight nights of programming emphasizing that platform, during which some of its performers and personalities will post on Twitter in real time. #CBSTweetWeek, as the network is calling it (with a friendly Twitter hashtag), will run from Sunday through April 11 and spotlight events like Sundays Academy of Country Music Awards (for which the musicians Dierks Bentley and Julianne Hough will post comments and answer questions on Twitter) and Mondays N.C.A.A. Division I mens basketball national championship game (during which the CBS Sports analysts Greg Anthony and Seth Davis will both be on call). On Tuesday, Pauley Perrette will entertain your inquiries about the various stains and improvised killing implements seen on N.C.I.S., and on Wednesday the Survivor host Jeff Probst will surely fend off thousands of questions about how contestants relieve themselves.

title: Patient Voices: Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease
description: A genetic disease that causes weakness in the hands, arms, feet and legs, C.M.T. can cause difficulty walking and performing tasks.

title: The Voices of Charcot-Marie-Tooth
description: People with the neurological disorder called Charcot-Marie-Tooth must contend not only with pain and muscle weakness but also the frustration of having a disease with a funny-sounding name that most people have never heard of.

title: Ally Files for I.P.O. of Treasurys Stake
description: 5:21 p.m. | Updated DETROIT  Ally Financial, the former finance arm of General Motors, filed Thursday for an initial public offering that would allow the federal government to begin selling off its 73.8 percent stake.

title: Sokols Other Big Investment
description: The Warren Buffett Effect is well known. Now, it seems David Sokol can have the same impact on a stock.

title: Do You Still Use Print Ads?
description: In the 25 years Ive been in business, I have tried a variety of ways of reaching customers: print advertising, a retail store, a Web site in the days prior to Google and search-engine optimization, a Web site with extremely poor S.E.O. and the early versions of AdWords, and now a Web site with good S.E.O. and the current AdWords.

title: Seeing Things | Disco Silencio!
description: On April 1, the gallery space at the Southern California Institute of Architecture in downtown Los Angeles will become a disco. This isnt an April Fools joke  its Disco Silencio! (Silent Disco), an exhibition that runs through May 5. The architect Barbara Bestor, an alumna of the institute, and her firm have designed what they call a plywood polyhedron of hedonism. Incorporating technologies of surface deception inspired by World War I Razzle Dazzle camouflage, which used bold graphic and anamorphic surfaces to mislead enemy bombers about the size, speed and direction of warships, the crew at Bestor Architecture built an overscaled plywood polyhedron structure in the gallery space. They covered it with a lively graphic surface embedded with fragments of mirrored disco ball, that emblem of 1980s night life, which also distort the space by refracting light. Bestor, whose firm operates under the contemporary manifesto that everyone should experience strange beauty every day, combines deception and illusion of both the serious and the frivolous kind in Disco Silencio!

title: 2 Former Officers Sentenced in a Killing After Katrina
description: NEW ORLEANS  Two former police officers were sentenced to prison on Thursday in the killing of an unarmed civilian and the burning of his body in the days after Hurricane Katrina in a case that exposed the citys troubled police department.

title: Three Mail Bombs Explode in Europe, Injuring Three
description: ROME  A letter bomb seriously wounded a senior Italian Army official in Livorno on Thursday, the army said in a statement.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Japan, Pakistan and Ivory Coast.

title: Interview: Mohamed Diab
description: The director Mohamed Diab discusses his feminist drama "Cairo 678," about sexual harassment in Egypt.

title: Take the Reality Challenge
description: With a batch of new, ridiculous-sounding reality shows about to hit the air, Sundays Arts & Leisure section will offer readers a little test: in a list of 17 descriptions of reality shows, can you tell the real ones from the ones we just made up? And with the article comes an opportunity to make up your own show idea and post it in the comments section. Just dont blame us if some producer steals it.

title: The iPad 2 Has Been a Boon to eBay
description: The Apple iPad 2, which is still very difficult to acquire at Apple retail stores, is creating a robust and healthy resale market online.

title: Toddler Twins: Secret Language or Babble?
description: A video of two diaper-clad twins chatting up a storm in the family kitchen has gone viral, prompting millions of viewers to wonder what the heck the toddlers might be talking about.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: BRIDESMAID QUESTION

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: NUDE WALKER  By Bathsheba Monk.  306 pp. Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: Betty White to Host a Hidden-Camera Prank Show on NBC
description: Nearly a year after hosting Saturday Night Live to great acclaim  and nearly 20 years after starring in The Golden Girls  Betty White is heading back to NBC.

title: The Power Brokers: Fathers, Sons, Dynasties
description: A ruthless, tyrannical striver grasps for power, promoting his sons to establish his rule and cement his legacy.

title: On Our Radar: Senator Expects Vote on Delaying E.P.A. Rules
description: Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, has pledged to bring to a vote an amendment blocking the Environmental Protection Agencys authority to regulate climate-warming gases for two years, Senator Jim Webb, a Virginia Democrat, says in a statement. I hope we will have the opportunity to vote on this measure within the next day or so, said Mr. Webb, an opponent of E.P.A. emissions rules for stationary sources like power plants. [Blue Virginia]

title: Assessing Americas Energy Choices
description: The Business Section of The Times has run a valuable special section on Americas energy options that kicks off with a piece by Clifford Krauss noting the Groundhog Day feel of President Obamas latest oil speech. (If that sounds familiar, it should). Heres a guide to the other coverage:

title: House Tour: New Hope, Penn.
description: A stone house in Bucks County, Pa., where the front door opens onto a stone fireplace, exposed ceiling beams, wide plank floors and a winding staircase.

title: Andy Warhol Commemorated in Chrome on Union Square
description: Chrome is the new bronze. Thats one of the main lessons of The Andy Monument, a glistening semi-accurate sculpture of the Pop artist Andy Warhol. It was unveiled yesterday on the northwest corner of Union Square, amid a small throng that included two surviving Warhol superstars (Taylor Meade and Ultra Violet), friends and colleagues of the artist, art world press and curious passers-by.

title: Yankees Opening Day
description: The temperature made it feel like winter, but the Yankees and Tigers opened the baseball season at Yankee Stadium. The Yankees won, 6-3.

title: G-8 du Web
description: Term for a conference on digital piracy, privacy and security issues planned to coincide with the May G-8 summit.

title: Billy Joel Cancels Memoir
description: Billy Joel has canceled a memoir that was scheduled for release in June, his publisher, HarperCollins said on Thursday. The Book of Joel had been written and edited when Mr. Joel backed out of his contract this week. HarperCollins acquired the book in 2008 for $3 million. Mr. Joel is expected to return the portion of the advance that he has already received. Mr. Joel told The Associated Press in a statement that writing the book made him realize that he was not all that interested in talking about the past.

title: One-Way Ticket? Exploring the Great Migration in Literature and the Arts
description: Overview| What was the Great Migration, and what cultural movements are associated with it? How can we put current United States demographic patterns into historical context? In this lesson, students learn about the contemporary trend of reverse migration and then create research-based presentations on the Great Migration in association with their learning in literature, art, history or geography.

title: Season Opener: Yankees 6, Tigers 3, Final
description: Curtis Granderson hit a go-ahead home run in the seventh inning and made two terrific catches in center field to lead the Yankees to a 6-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers on Thursday afternoon in the season opener at Yankee Stadium.

title: After Japan Crisis, New Urgency for Radiation Drugs
description: A flash of blue light signaled the end for Hisashi Ouchi and Masato Shinohara. It meant that a nuclear chain reaction had started unexpectedly, bathing the two men in lethal doses of radiation. After they ran out of the room, Mr. Ouchi, who received the higher dose, briefly lost consciousness, then began vomiting.

title: Geithner Says Strict Policy on Currency Hurts China
description: NANJING, China  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner urged China again on Thursday to adopt a more flexible exchange rate policy, saying failing to do so could worsen inflation in China and impede growth in other parts of the world.

title: The Feds Crisis Lending: A Billion Here, a Thousand There
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserves huge lending programs, which saved Wall Street in the fall of 2008, also benefited a wide range of other financial companies, including community banks, credit unions and foreign banks, according to documents released by the central bank on Thursday.

title: Theater Talkback: Too Much Information?
description: The topic of our discussion today is  spoiler alert!  the careful use of spoiler alerts. For readers unfamiliar with the term, it is occasionally inserted in prose or conversation, and not infrequently in reviews of movies or plays, to indicate that a key plot point is about to be divulged that some may prefer to remain in ignorance of. It gives the reader a chance to shut down all systems rather that discover that Mary is really the long-lost sister of Rose, that a freak accident will claim the life of John just when it looks as if things might turn out all right, that in fact the whole traumatic episode was really just a dream!

title: For a Galleon Ex-Manager, Questions of Motivation
description: Twice last year, Adam Smith, a former portfolio manager at the Galleon Group hedge fund, met with lawyers for its co-founder, Raj Rajaratnam, who had been charged with netting tens of millions through insider trading.

title: Brooke Shields Will Be the New Morticia in Addams Family
description: Brooke Shields will continue her run as high-profile replacement actress on Broadway this summer when she takes over the role of Morticia in The Addams Family musical from Bebe Neuwirth, who will depart the show after 15 months.

title: TimesCast | March 31, 2011
description: Two of Colonel Qaddafi's top advisers defect to Britain; and Defense Secretary Robert Gates reaffirms the limited scope of America's role in the Libyan conflict.

title: Free Software to Protect Your Bank Account
description: Hackers and crooks are scheming to crack Internet banking links and steal your money and personal data. So some banks are urging you to add an extra layer of protection, by using software with the somewhat tongue-twisting name Trusteer Rapport.

title: Bronx Zoo Cobra Found Alive
description: Updated | 4:51 p.m.

title: Live Nation Said to Bid for Warner Music Group
description: 8:27 p.m. | Updated Live Nation Entertainment, the concert and ticketing giant created by the merger of Ticketmaster and the promoter Live Nation, has emerged as a bidder for the Warner Music Group, according to a person apprised of the bidding who spoke only on the condition of anonymity because the process was intended to be confidential.

title: Keeping Score: Why Rose Should Not Win M.V.P.
description: Neil Paine is an analyst at Basketball-Reference.com, an online encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores.

title: E.P.A. Eases Way for Alternative-Fuel Engine Conversions
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has revised its alternative-fuel conversion regulations for light and heavy-duty vehicles, making it easier for manufacturers to sell conversions that are compliant with clean-air laws. The 186-page ruling provides an exemption from a Clean Air Act prohibition against tampering when converting an engine to run on alternative fuel.

title: Curious About Georges
description: Georges Dambier, whose work is the subject of a delightful exhibition at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery on East 57th Street (through May 14), liked to use Paris as the backdrop for his fashion photographs. Or Cannes or Marrakesh. This was the postwar world of jazz clubs, existentialists, cheap travel, uncrowded streets, beautiful cars, artists and, of course, Paris couture. With his Rolleiflex, Mr. Dambier, who will be 86 on Tuesday, captured all of this with honest joie de vivre, publishing his fashion images in French Elle. And he worked with some of the eras great beauties: Suzy Parker, Dorian Leigh, Bettina, Marie-Hlne Arnaud, Capucine, Ivy Nicholson and a young Brigitte Bardot.

title: Time Warner Pulls Channels From iPad App
description: Time Warner Cable on Thursday abruptly removed several channels from its app that replicates the TV viewing experience on an iPad.

title: Sweet Dreams
description: A stylish nights rest  and a place to stack that bedtime reading. Go to interactive feature >>

title: Neighborhood Joint | Mimulo
description: A flower shop in the Crown Heights area of Brooklyn does a brisk business on Friday, just prior to the Sabbath.

title: Teixeira and Revamped Bullpen Start Strong for Yankees in Chilly Opener
description: On the final day of March, it felt like just another afternoon of an endless winter Thursday at Yankee Stadium, raw and wet and frigid, with a wind that howled and swirled.

title: The Sokol Drama Takes Hold of Tulane
description: NEW ORLEANS  For a conference brimming with lawyers, theres probably no more suitable topic for discussion right now than the surprise resignation of David L. Sokol from Berkshire Hathaway.

title: Americana Shows That Keep It Local
description: For something fresh to say about Americana, scholars are carving the subject into ever smaller regional slices. In the last year books and exhibitions have focused on topics as narrow as western Virginia chairs and central North Carolina furniture.

title: Mir in Motion
description: Images of the removal of the artists triptych.

title: Where Every Bouquet Tells a Story
description: ON Friday afternoons, the headquarters of the Chabad sect of Orthodox Judaism comes alive as men in black jackets and hats stream like worker bees in and out of the subterranean entrance on Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn. Those exiting scatter across Crown Heights to prepare for the Sabbath  Shabbos in Yiddish  many drawn a block east by the overpowering smell of lilies and the ebullient welcome of Chani Frankel to Mimulo, a flower shop on Albany Avenue.

description: Theater

description: A number of breastfeeding stories have been in the news the past week or so.

title: The Greatest Pitching Rotation of All Time and Its Not Close
description: This is catnip just in time for Major League Baseballs Opening Day: A great story by Pat Jordan on the Phillies four pitching aces. (The Phearsome Phoursome? Has this been copyrighted yet? If not, I call dibs. Oh, wait.) As an added bonus: Nate Silver uses the magic of statistics to definitively answer the question: What is the greatest four-man rotation of all time?

title: American Idol': The Top 11. Again.
description: Lauren Alaina > Haley Reinhart > Jacob Lusk > James Durbin > Scotty McCreery > Casey Abrams > Naima Adedapo > Pia Toscano > Stefano Langone > Thia Megia > Paul McDonald

title: Weekend Miser
description: Poetry and beer. Maira Kalman and Gypsy rhythms. Theres nothing the Miser likes better than mixing it up.

title: Bill Moyers Eyes a Possible Return to PBS
description: 5:04 p.m. | Updated Bill Moyers retirement from weekly television last year may not last long. He has received preliminary approval for a major grant to return to PBS with a half-hour show with the working title Something Different With Bill Moyers.

title: Two Slumps in Business Investment
description: Oh, my. I think John Taylor is being deliberately dense here: he professes himself baffled by my two posts criticizing his assertion that the investment-unemployment correlation says that anti-business rhetoric and policies are the problem.

title: Auburn Coach Criticizes HBO Report
description: Auburn Coach Gene Chizik criticized HBO Real Sports for its report in which four former Auburn players said they were paid thousands of dollars during their college careers, calling it pathetic and pure garbage.

title: Shutdown Watch: Eight Days Out
description: With eight days left until the federal governments spending authority runs out, lawmakers on Thursday expressed some optimism about reaching a budget compromise even as Tea Party members rallied outside the Capitol and the House speaker, John Boehner, said no deal had been reached yet.

title: 36 Hours in Louisville
description: In the Derby City, a glass of fine bourbon and good conversation arent hard to find.

title: Piston Engine Holds Promise for Fuel Economy
description: As I wrote in Thursdays Times, several start-ups backed by Silicon Valley venture capital firms are developing a new type of internal combustion engine that promises a striking boost in fuel economy while reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

title: 36 Hours in Louisville, Ky.
description: LOUISVILLE bolts into the public eye for 120 seconds each May, but there is more to this courtly city on the Ohio River than the Kentucky Derby. The last decade has seen a cultural and civic blooming, with new galleries, restaurants and performance spaces taking their place alongside the citys already robust roster of seductions. Entire neighborhoods  Butchertown, for instance, and East Market  have been reimagined as engines of cultural and culinary expression. Regardless of the changes, Derby City retains its easy charm  a glass of fine bourbon and good conversation arent hard to find. And for the record, its pronounced LOU-uh-vull.

title: Safety Agency Widens Inquiry Into Repairs of Rental Cars
description: In an expansion of its investigation into whether millions of rental cars are repaired quickly enough, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is demanding that major rental car companies quickly provide detailed information about their safety operations.

title: Where Every Bouquet Tells a Story
description: On Friday afternoons, the headquarters of the Chabad sect of Orthodox Judaism comes alive as men in black jackets and hats stream like worker bees in and out of the subterranean entrance on Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn. Those exiting scatter across Crown Heights to prepare for the coming Sabbath  Shabbos in Yiddish  many drawn a block east by the overpowering smell of lilies and the ebullient welcome of Chani Frankel to Mimulo, a flower shop on Albany Avenue.

description: Robin Williams performs an excerpt from Rajiv Josephs Broadway play, Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo.

description: FALLS VILLAGE, Conn.

description: The coalition has told the rebels that they are no less subject to bombardment by NATO planes than pro-Qaddafi forces if they endanger civilians.

description: Around Town

title: Paragallo Loses Appeal of Animal Cruelty Conviction
description: Ernie Paragallo, a thoroughbred breeder and owner, lost his appeal of his conviction for animal cruelty charges on Thursday. He was convicted on 33 counts of misdemeanor animal cruelty and sentenced to two years in prison last year for starving his horses at his Center Brook Farm in Greene County, N.Y.

title: Opposition Newspaper in Kazakhstan Says Its Publisher Is Missing
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  On the eve of an election in which Kazakhstans strongman leader hopes to improve his democratic credentials, a prominent opposition newspaper announced on Thursday that its publisher had suffered a severe beating and that his whereabouts were unknown.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for April 1-7
description: Pop

title: Maximized Revenue, Minimized Existence
description: David Foster Wallaces magnum opus Infinite Jest depicted an America so distracted and obsessed with entertainment that a mesmerizing movie becomes a potential terrorist weapon  capable of making viewers die of pleasure.

title: John Mellencamp-Stephen King Stage Collaboration Gets an Opening Date
description: Ghost Brothers of Darkland County, a long-in-the-works musical by the horror writer Stephen King and the rock musician John Mellencamp, will have its world premiere in April 2012 at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta, according to the theaters Web site.

title: Movie Listings for April 1-7
description: Movies

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for April 1-7
description: Classical

title: After Convalescence, Muti Leads the Chicago Symphony With Fresh Physicality
description: CHICAGO  There was nothing tentative about Riccardo Mutis return to the podium of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on Wednesday afternoon. Starting rehearsals of Verdis opera Otello for three concert performances here at the Symphony Center beginning on Thursday, and a fourth at Carnegie Hall on April 15, Mr. Muti was a dynamo, throwing himself bodily into the two-hour session and clearly making a statement about his physical condition.

title: Jazz Listings for April 1-7
description: Jazz

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Japan, Pakistan and Ivory Coast.

title: Tesla Sues Top Gear Over Show About the Roadster
description: Tesla Motors, the electric vehicle manufacturer based in Silicon Valley, filed a lawsuit this week in Britain against the BBCs popular Top Gear television program.

title: The Tread Life on This Tire Is Something Else
description: It took an entire car to power Stephen Kings Christine, a horror novel about a possessed 1958 Plymouth Fury that runs murderously amok. The considerably lower-budgeted Rubber wittily makes do with a single  and ferociously single-minded  car tire. It doesnt just hit the road, it also wobbles and weaves and executes a diabolically jaunty victory lap, leaving a long bloody smear in its increasingly brutal wake. This being a conceptual horror flick, the tire also runs wild while some onlookers play the Greek chorus and in-house audience both, commenting on the movie as it happens. Its already boring, says one. Nope  it isnt.

title: Book on Gandhi Stirs Passion in India
description: KOCHI, India

title: For Championship Season Cast, It Wont Be One-for-All Come Tony Time
description: The producers of the Broadway revival of That Championship Season have decided to give Brian Cox a clear shot at his first Tony Award nomination for lead actor in a play (and first Tony nod, period) for his performance as the plays anti-Semitic basketball coach whose reunion with four former players turns fractious.

title: Dance Listings for April 1-7
description: Dance

title: Martha Graham Lives, and Is Interviewed
description: Its a pity that Richard Moves new Martha@...The 1963 Interview is running at Dance Theater Workshop just after the recent Martha Graham Dance Company season in New York. This 70-minute re-enactment of a 1963 conversation between Graham and the dance critic Walter Terry  a recording was discovered in the archives of the 92nd Street Y last year  is both a primer for her work and an enticement to see it.

title: Sour Economy and Multiple New Crises Test Japans Young
description: TOKYO  As hundreds of thousands of young people begin their working lives on Friday, they face a transformed Japan that will test a generation reared in affluence yet dismissed by its elders as selfish materialists.

title: What Befits a Legendary Queen
description: THE first time Karen Mason saw the elaborate, multilayered black-and-white dress that Susan Hilferty designed for her character, the Queen of Hearts, in the musical Wonderland, she burst into tears.

title: Consumer Shoe Index
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#533", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Phish Announces a Festival for July 4 Weekend
description: Phish, the popular improvisational rock band, announced Thursday that it plans to play a three-day festival over the July 4 weekend at the Watkins Glen International racetrack in Watkins Glen, N.Y.

title: The Enduring Power of an Icon
description: The only thing wrong with Passion in Venice: Crivelli to Tintoretto and Veronese, a fascinating exhibition at the Museum of Biblical Art, is the title. It sounds like a mixed-quality hodgepodge representing the standard canon of late medieval and Renaissance Venetian painters.

title: Dont Know Who You Are, but Dont Know Who I Am
description: It doesnt take long for Source Code, a science-fiction thriller with a contemporary twist, to hook you. A smooth diversion directed by Duncan Jones that bats around a few big ideas, the movie opens with a succession of overhead images of Chicago and its environs gleaming in the bright day. Again and again the camera swoops and soars above the doll-like houses, rushing past ribbons of freeway and nearly skimming the tops of silver skyscrapers. And again and again, and closer and closer, it returns to a speeding commuter train, a recurrence that artfully foreshadows the storys nifty repetition compulsion.

title: For Red Bulls, 3 Games, 3 Keepers and a New TV Deal
description: The Red Bulls own an odd distinction as they prepare for Saturdays match against visiting Houston: Bouna Coundoul, who is expected to start his first game of the season, will be the third goalkeeper Coach Hans Backe has used in the clubs first three games.

title: Once Lost, Snake Now Is Found
description: Its Opening Day at Yankee Stadium, so naturally the big buzz up in the Bronx today is all about the snake that escaped from the zoo last weekend. I kid, of course. In fact, the buzz is dying down, because the latest reports indicate that the wayward Egyptian cobra has been found, which will certainly dampen the burgeoning snake fever that was gripping the globe, what with the lack of any real, hard news out there these days. If the snake could have held out a few more days, Im sure we would have reached novelty-song-dance-craze stage.

title: JPMorgan Syndicates $20 Billion AT&T Loan
description: JPMorgan Chase has fully syndicated its $20 billion loan to AT&T for the cellphone carriers bid to buy T-Mobile USA, spreading it out across 11 other banks, according to a regulatory filing.

title: App Smart Extra: Pimping Your Screen
description: Sometimes the best apps are the simplest ones.

title: Pimco Chief Takes Bearish Stance in Turbulent World
description: Mohamed A. El-Erian is not easily unnerved. But Mr. El-Erian, the chief executive and co-chief investment officer of Pimco, the worlds largest bond fund manager, has been taking some extra precautions lately in the face of a topsy-turvy geopolitical climate.

title: New Directors/New Films Video: Mohamed Diab
description: In the feminist drama Cairo 678, three women in modern Cairo who have suffered sexual harassment decide to take matters into their own hands. The film is the directorial debut of the Egyptian screenwriter Mohamed Diab. In this video, the director speaks about how he sees his film as a reflection of some of the injustices prevalent in Egypt before the revolution that overthrew Hosni Mubaraks government. He also discusses why he felt this film about the struggles of Egyptian women needed to be directed by a man.

title: A Do-Gooder Vision Clouded by Blind Spots
description: In a Better World, directed by the Danish filmmaker Susanne Bier and written by Anders Thomas Jensen, is an elegant, somber scourge for the guilty conscience of the affluent, liberal West. Or, to put it another way, In a Better World is the winner of the 2011 Academy Award for best foreign language film. Im not trying to be glib  well, maybe a little  but rather to put my finger on the merits and limitations of this ethically serious, aesthetically graceful and curiously bloodless movie.

title: Versatile Collagist, Dangerous Times
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Timing is everything, and it can be ruinous. The German artist Kurt Schwitters built his magnum opus, the sculptural environment he called the Merzbau, in the early 1930s. He produced his most innovative collages in the decade before. In 1933 Hitler came to power. The collages were instant fodder for Nazi Degenerate Art shows. The Merzbau was bombed to dust in 1943.

title: Ferraro Remembered as Inspiration to a Nations Daughters
description: In vivid testimonials from some of the most visible politicians in the country, Geraldine A. Ferraro was recalled on Thursday as a pioneer with true grit and a sense of humor who blazed a trail for future generations of women.

title: Visions of Life, Built From Bits and Pieces
description: Romare Bearden (1911-88) spent more than 30 years striving to be a great artist, and in the early 1960s, when he took up collage in earnest, he became one. A small exhibition at the Michael Rosenfeld Gallery, organized to celebrate the centennial of Beardens birth, delivers this message with unusual clarity. It contains only 21 collages, all superb, in an intimate context that facilitates savoring their every formal twist and narrative turn, not to mention the ingenious mixing of mediums that takes them far beyond collage.

title: This Is the (Wagner) House That Levine Built
description: It was disappointing to James Levines countless admirers that his health problems, especially chronic back pain lingering from surgery, forced him to curtail his work at the Metropolitan Opera this spring. That included Wednesday nights return of Wagners Rheingold, Robert Lepages new production that opened the season in September.

title: A Little Lint and Suddenly Youre Bridezilla
description: AS the daughter of divorced parents, I wasnt sentimental about weddings or marriage. I had no visions of myself wearing a white dress. My thoughts on the subject instead tended toward pre-nups, counseling and custody.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 1-7
description: Art

title: The Interplay of JPMorgan and AT&T
description: JPMorgan Chases record $20 billion financing for AT&T is turning bankers green the world over. With this as the new benchmark for credit-hungry corporate executives, the worry is that banks wind up competing in a game of one-upmanship that leads some to fly solo on riskier deals.

title: Remembering When College Was a Buyers Bazaar
A Perverse Mind Populated by Devils, Snakes and Buxom Nudes
description: Was Friedrich Schrder-Sonnenstern crazy? Or was he crazy like a fox? Either way, he was certainly some kind of crackpot genius, and his cartoonish, sexually charged, mystically suggestive colored-pencil drawings from the 1950s, on view in From Barefoot Prophet to Avant-Garde Artist at Michael Werner Gallery, are as compelling for their beautiful draftsmanship as they are for their bizarre metaphysics and gleefully fierce satire.

title: Youth Finds Comfort Alongside Experience
description: Dont worry  just go out there and play. Onstage at the Rose Theater on Tuesday evening, the violinist Pinchas Zukerman recalled that advice from Susan Wadsworth when she presented his first United States recitals, in 1966, under the auspices of Young Concert Artists, her management and mentoring firm.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for April 1-7
description: THE SUNNY SIDE OF THE STREET

title: Brattons Law-and-Order Appeal for Same-Sex Marriage
description: The headlines come with depressing regularity: two men attacked in the bathroom of the Stonewall Inn; a group of men set upon by those hurling homosexual slurs in Chelsea; a wicked antigay attack in an abandoned apartment in the Bronx. And just days ago, the beating of a young gay man outside a McDonalds in the West Village.

title: GoDaddy Chief Draws Criticism for Elephant Hunting Video
description: What did Bob Parsons, chief executive and founder of the Web services company GoDaddy, do on his vacation?

title: A Flaw in New Rules for Mortgages
description: If you want to get the government out of financing normal home mortgages, you have to find a way to bring in private capital  and on terms that do not make government-guaranteed mortgages a clearly superior product.

title: Snipping Off Appendages and Other Comic Ploys
description: In the slick, puerile comedy thriller Cat Run, the only saving grace (though an insult to the concept of grace) is Janet McTeers deadpan portrayal of a lethal freelance interrogator. Ms. McTeers character, Helen Bingham, a prim torturer-for-hire, proudly wields a gadget that snips off noses, fingers and male genitalia. The final image in the movies grisliest scene is a brief shot of a room drenched in blood and strewn with body parts after one of her question-and-answer sessions. Icy doesnt begin to describe the chill that sets in when this caricature of a cold English aristocrat appears in any scene, her eyes glinting with cruelty.

title: U.A.W. Reverses Losses as Detroits Big Three Add Jobs
description: DETROIT  The United Automobile Workers union, whose ranks have been decimated by decades of job cuts at the Detroit carmakers, gained members last year for the first time since 2005.

title: Otto von Bismarck, Master Statesman
description: In the summer of 1862, Otto von Bismarck was appointed minister-president of Prussia. His highest previous rank had been ambassador to Russia. He had never held an administrative position. Yet with a few brusque strokes, the novice minister solved the riddle that had stymied European diplomacy for two generations: how to unify Germany and reorganize Central Europe. He had to overcome the obstacle that Germany comprised 39 sovereign states grouped in the so-called German Confederation. All the while, Central European trends were warily observed by the two flanking powers, France and Russia, ever uneasy about  and tempted to prevent  the emergence of a state capable of altering the existing European balance of power.

title: Seattles Intiman Theater Raises Enough to Stay Open
description: The Intiman Theater in Seattle, which is fighting for its survival, announced on Thursday that it had raised just over $450,000 so far in a seven-week emergency fundraising campaign and would stay open. The Intiman had previously said that it needed to raise $500,000 by the end of March and another $500,000 by September in order to keep operating, but apparently this was close enough. A press release said that the remaining $50,000 would be added to the next benchmark.

title: No Matches for Some Students on High School Decision Day
description: Thousands of city eighth graders celebrated getting into their first-choice public high school on Thursday, but there was somber news for more than 8,200 students: they learned that they had gotten into none of the high schools to which they had applied.

title: Where Was That Wraparound View?
description: The Transparent Room

title: Bunny Doesnt Want to Work, Just Wants to Bang the Drum All Day
description: It was better than Alvin and the Chipmunks. I dont think I can improve on that assessment  delivered by my son in the wake of a Saturday morning sneak-preview screening of Hop  and I certainly cant contradict it. Connoisseurs of the school of cinema in which fuzzy animated creatures interact with hard-working, slightly desperate-looking human actors may find themselves, if not exactly delighted, then at least pleasantly tickled. The rest of us, who endure such movies in the name of family harmony, masochism or lack of leisure-time imagination, may be happily surprised to emerge from the theater in something other than a state of murderous rage.

title: Inside the Bag, Less Food for the Price
Professor Is Named to Public Housing Board
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has appointed a former New York City housing official to the citys public housing board, three weeks after her predecessor resigned after improperly using agency letterhead to vouch for a defendant in a child pornography case.

title: Jitters About Nuclear Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Color and Collage
description: The work of the artist Kurt Schwitters is on view at the Princeton University Art Museum.

title: Arizona Transplants Survive Sticker Shock
description: WHEN Stephen Caesar and Ryan Lathrum planned their move to New York from Arizona, they figured they could bank on doubling their rent and (at the very least) halving their space. In Mesa, a suburb of Phoenix, they were paying $1,500 a month for a three-bedroom, three-bathroom house.

title: Sothebys Strategy: One Offer for Two Sales
description: In the auction world memories are short and relationships fickle. From season to season there is no way to predict which auction house will win the prized property, and it often comes down to the most lucrative deal a firm can offer the seller, although occasionally a clever marketing strategy can make the difference.

title: Preserving Tenure
Next Step Is Hazy in Battle Over the Poison Pill
description: NEW ORLEANS  A mergers and acquisitions panel at the Tulane Corporate Law Institute focused on the future of the poison pill takeover defense on Thursday after Airgas won its battle against its hostile bidder, Air Products and Chemicals. That future is hazy.

title: Chess as a Slow Dance of Seduction
description: Caroline Bottaros tangy comic bonbon, Queen to Play, plucks the game of chess out of the metaphorical realm of spy thrillers and reimagines it as a fable about relationships and upward mobility. Adapted from Bertina Henrichss novel The Chess Player, this slight but captivating movie (Ms. Bottaros directorial debut) compares the strategies of chess to the erotic maneuvers in a flirtatious pas de deux that may be more satisfying than actual sex. At the same time, a womans winning the game symbolizes female empowerment in a mans world and ascent from working-class drudgery to the bourgeoisie.

title: Players Ask Judge to Punish N.F.L. Over TV Deal
description: The former N.F.L. players union asked a federal judge in Minneapolis on Thursday to impose damages against the league for the way it negotiated to be paid $4 billion in TV revenue during a lockout. The dissolved union wants the court to deny the league access to that money.

title: Romare Bearden Collage
description: Images from the exhibition at Michael Rosenfeld Gallery.

title: To V.C.U., Butler Is No Lovable Underdog
description: HOUSTON  This time last year, Virginia Commonwealth guard Joey Rodriguez watched the N.C.A.A. tournament title game in his dorm room. He cheered mostly for Butler, the small, lovable underdog from Indiana, the peoples favorite. (Butler lost that game to Duke.)

title: New Online Tool Helps Buyers Keep Track of Properties
description: TECHNOLOGY has made buying a home easier by making an unprecedented amount of information available to buyers. But managing that data and keeping track of multiple properties can be a challenge for house-hunting clients and their brokers

title: Development Begins at Old Aircraft Engine Plant
description: WOOD-RIDGE

title: You Dont Need Superpowers if You Have a Pipe Wrench (and Anger Issues)
description: Bam! Ka-pow! The exclamatory cartoon balloons that pop up during a scene of gruesome vigilante justice late in James Gunns Super are supposed to remind us that at heart the movie is a harmless live-action satire of comic-book revenge fantasies. But is it?

title: New Push for a Condo Ombudsman
description: JOHN Avignone and David Kelman both live at Colonial Village, a condominium complex in West Hartford, but their views on the management of the 84-unit community suggest they dwell in different worlds.

title: Glenn J. Rufrano
description: Mr. Rufrano, 61, is the new chief executive and president of Cushman and Wakefield, a global real estate services firm whose majority owner is Exor S.p.A. of Italy.

title: G.M. Sells Delphi Stake for $3.8 Billion
description: DETROIT  General Motors said Thursday it had raised $3.8 billion by selling its stake in the auto parts maker Delphi Automotive as it works to bolster its balance sheet and increase its appeal to investors.

title: Q & A
description: Security Locks and Aesthetics

title: A Punishing Drive
description: As soon as we hear the first few bars of Tiny Tims Tiptoe Through the Tulips dribble from the radio of a trashed car, we suspect that Wrecked might be a horror movie. The suspicion grows when one of the cars three occupants  the other two are goners  regains consciousness, and we get a good look at his rearranged face. Adrien Brody is somewhere underneath all that blood and swelling, but it will be a while before we can tell.

title: Nonbank Lenders Staging a Comeback
description: MORTGAGE lenders that are not banks acquired a bad reputation during the housing crisis, when now-defunct players like Countrywide Financial and Ameriquest Mortgage came to light as purveyors of risky, high-priced loans, often to subprime borrowers with less-than-stellar credit.

title: Portraits
description: Images of photographs by Catherine Opie and Ryan McGinley.

title: A Career Woven From Life
description: PARIS

title: Looking Ahead to the Jobs Report
description: Maybe, just maybe, this is the month the job number pops.

title: Somethings Going On in That House
description: In Insidious, their latest attempt to go straight, the Saw team of James Wan (director) and Leigh Whannell (writer) avoid almost completely the gore and mechanized instruments of torture on which they built their careers. The results are mixed.

title: The Rich and the Poor
Priests Abuse Victims
A Road-Trip Diet
description: Shaped like Michael Moore and thinking like Morgan Spurlock, Joe Cross, a cheery Australian futures trader, came to the conclusion that his 310 pounds and 53-inch girth were the cause of his chronic autoimmune disorder. An adulthood spent focusing on my wealth rather than my health had left him with a body mass that, according to one waggish friend, went up and down like a brides nightie.

title: The Financial Reform Law
Artificial Dye Safe to Eat, Panel Says
description: WASHINGTON  There is no proof that foods with artificial colorings cause hyperactivity in most children and there is no need for these foods to carry special warning labels, a government advisory panel voted Thursday.

title: The Kennedy TV Series
Need a Broad? Call Turner
description: IN Matthew Lombardos play High, Kathleen Turner plays a nun, of all people. This is the same actress whose character in Body Heat had a thermostat set so high she melted the brains and willpower of any man who got too close; who was a contract killer in Prizzis Honor and a prostitute in Crimes of Passion; and who in her previous Broadway appearance, in 2005, played a notably blowsy and vicious Martha in an acclaimed revival of Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf? Before that, in 2002, she was the main reason for seeing the ill-conceived Broadway version of The Graduate, because in one scene she wore only a pair of high heels.

title: Being Kathleen Turner
description: Photos of the actresss performances on stage and screen.

title: Traveling in Suriname With Marley and Bush on the Bus
description: PARAMARIBO, Suriname  Stroll through this city, perched between jungle and sea, and Surinames past as a Dutch colony comes into view: stately wooden white mansions, Lutheran churches, street names with vast streams of consonants and vowels (try Zwartenhovenbrugstraat on for size.)

title: Ol Bob and Weave
description: The textile artist Sheila Hicks works at the confluence of art, craft, design and architecture.

title: For Hedge Fund Investors, Brazil Is the Country of Now
description: Ten years ago, Goldman Sachs proclaimed that Brazil was among the new economic powerhouses. Now it is the next frontier for hedge funds.

title: At Publicis, a Big Bet on Digital Seems to Be Paying Off
description: WHEN Microsoft last month awarded a big portion of its North American advertising account to the Publicis Groupe, the marketing company based in Paris, the news felt like vindication for its chief executive, Maurice Lvy.

title: Star Architects Civic Center Design Divides California City
description: ELK GROVE, Calif.  The firm owned by the internationally renowned architect Zaha Hadid is in high demand these days, designing projects in Hong Kong, Milan and Seoul, not to mention the London Aquatics Center, the swimming arena for the 2012 Olympics.

title: Yankees Granderson Shows That Hes Feeling Fine
description: If Curtis Granderson had not put the Yankees ahead for good with a home run in the seventh inning, his performance Thursday still would have been notable for the three great catches he made in center field in a 6-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers in a dank Yankee Stadium.

title: Traveling With Autism
description: Those who work with or are related to people with disabilities can get considerable encouragement from Wretches & Jabberers, a documentary about two autistic men who learned only in adulthood how to use a keyboard to convey their thoughts and needs. But the film also has a message for a different group: the technical wizards who develop communication devices. Gerardine Wurzburg, the director, is not shy about showing that even though her subjects now have a way to communicate, it is a painstaking process; perhaps this film will encourage engineers and software developers to keep the innovations coming.
